title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes income of $59,575, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $119,150, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months, due to early compliance with Financial Accounting Standard No. 87, the ''Employers Accounting for Pensions.'' c-Net income and includes extraordinary tax credits of $58,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 6 months. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ZAKHAROV, FREED BY U.S., LEAVES; SOVIET TO LET 2 GO
description: The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, will meet in Iceland next week.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOLLYWOOD ON THE HUDSON
description: THERE is no popcorn. Admission is still only $6, but a scalped ticket to a hot film can cost as much as $20 at the door.

title: NEW TRANQUILIZER WINS APPROVAL
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new tranquilizer that treats anxiety without causing drowsiness or interfering with a patient's ability to work and drive, it was announced yesterday.

title: LONGSHOREMEN WALK OFF JOBS AFTER TALKS FAIL
description: A longshoremen's strike threatened to halt container-ship operations at major East Coast ports today.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,377,000. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Support Group
description: Tonight three wives of Democrats in Congress - Judy Fazio of California, wife of Vic; Rhoda Glickman of Kansas, wife of Dan, and Susan Torricelli of New Jersey, wife of Robert G. - are holding a $50-a-ticket fund-raising reception for a fourth, Linda Daschle, whose husband, Thomas A., is running for the Senate in South Dakota. Men will be admitted to perform party services, such as tending the bar, serving snacks and collecting contribution checks. Representative Mike Synar of Oklahoma, whose house is being lent, will be permitted to clean up.

title: U.S. Tops Cuba In Volleyball
description: The United States defeated Cuba, 15-7, 16-18, 15-5, 15-7, today to advance to the final round of four in the men's world volleyball championship.

title: NEWARK SETS OCT. 15 DEADLINE FOR HOMELESS FROM NEW YORK
description: Mayor Sharpe James today warned that he would not allow homeless families from New York City to remain at a hotel here after Oct. 15.

title: Panel Backs Savers' Bill
description: The House Banking Committee today approved a ''truth in savings'' bill to protect small investors, along with a provision requiring credit card companies to fully disclose interest and other finance charges.

title: U.S. Warships to Visit China for First Time
description: United States warships are to visit China for the first time after an agreement between Peking and Washington on port calls by ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons.

title: Egypt Jails Cook for Holding Consul and 3 Others Hostage
description: A court sentenced an Egyptian with a history of mental illness to two months' hard labor today for holding the Italian consul and three co-workers hostage.

title: 3 Thwarted in Attempt To Rob the Vatican
description: Three gunmen burst into the Vatican's payroll office today in what the police said was the first armed robbery ever attempted at the Vatican, but they fled empty-handed when security agents rushed to the scene.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.2%
description: In a sign that the economy faces at least several more months of weak growth, the Government said today that its index of leading economic indicators fell two-tenths of 1 percent in August.

title: 139 ARESTED IN PROTEST AT NEVADA NUCLEAR TEST SITE
description: One hundred thirty-nine people, including Carl Sagan, the Cornell astronomer, were arrested today at the nuclear test site in a protest against the nation's continued underground testing of nuclear weapons in the face of a Soviet moratorium.

title: RIGHETTI GETS 43D SAVE
description: He exaggerated his stance in the batting cage, leaning back, back, back, and he stretched as always in his crouch, to have his chin positioned directly over the plate. And he hit off of a batting tee, drilling baseballs into a net. Don Mattingly, challenging for the American League batting championship, worked as diligently as any Little Leaguer would for his first day of practice.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Digital Equipment Corp., Maynard, Mass., and Valid Logic Systems Inc. said they had entered into a marketing agreement to promote Valid's computer-aided engineering products.

title: DAYTON PLANS SALE OF B. DALTON CHAIN
description: In a move reflecting soft demand for books and the sharp inroads made by discounters, the Dayton-Hudson Corporation said yesterday that it would sell B. Dalton, the nation's second-largest chain of bookstores.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,800,000.

title: TEST GROUP FOR AIDS DRUG IS BROADENED TO INCLUDE 7,000
description: The group eligible to receive azidothymidine, the first drug to show promise against AIDS, has been broadened to include most of the 7,000 AIDS victims who have suffered a specific form of pneumonia, the Burroughs Wellcome Company announced yesterday.

title: SAFETY BOARD, ACTING IN 3 CRASHES, URGES TRAINING OF COMMUTER PILOTS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, citing concerns raised by three fatal commuter airline crashes, including one in Maine that killed the schoolgirl Samantha Smith and seven other people, called today for increased pilot training, better Government surveillance and new training and safety equipment for commuter airlines.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes after-tax charges of $9 million related to the restructuring of stores.

title: Group Buys 8.37% Of Computer Unit
description: A group of California investors led by Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company of Los Angeles has acquired 8.37 percent of Computer Memories Inc. of Chatsworth, Calif., and would consider acquiring a majority stake, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Japan Trading at High
description: Japanese trading of foreign securities set record highs in August, while foreign trading of Japanese bonds also set records, according to figures released today by the Ministry of Finance. Japanese investors bought a record $2.38 billion and sold a record $1.78 billion worth of foreign stocks in August, the ministry said. Officials attributed the upsurge to the yen's sharp appreciation against the dollar.

title: BADILLO ASSERTS REGAN'S AUDITS 'TOTALLY USELESS'
description: Challenging an assertion by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan that his audits have saved the state $160 million in the last eight years, Herman Badillo, the Democratic candidate for comptroller, charged yesterday that the audits were ''totally useless'' because they were late.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD HOME reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FINAL CUTS REMAIN ON HOCKEY ROSTERS
description: With the opening of the 1986-87 National Hockey League season only a week away, the three area franchises are unsettled as they try to compose their final rosters.

title: DONOVAN JURORS HEAR AN OUTLINE OF STATE'S CASE
description: ''This case is about greed - plain and simple,'' a Bronx prosecutor asserted yesterday in his opening arguments in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and eight other men.

title: METS' FORECAST: A DELUGE
description: And now for the long-range weather forecast for New York City and vicinity. Mostly fair over the tri-state region except for heavy rains from sundown Oct. 12 to sundown Oct. 13, followed by immediate clearing. One of the things you could always count on in New York was good weather for the Jewish holidays. As the rye bread advertisement used to say, you didn't have to be Jewish to enjoy it. The crisp, cool weather for Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur was a gift, a mitzvah, to the rest of us.

title: RAISING STAKES FOR DANILOFF: HOW U.S. KEPT UP PRESSURE
description: On the afternoon of Sept. 19, President Reagan held an unscheduled White House meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister to express, in blunt, sometimes angry, words, his displeasure that the Soviet Union was refusing to let an American journalist return to the United States, according to an Administration official.

title: NEW ARTS CENTER OPENS SOUTH OF LOS ANGELES
description: Having sprouted like Jack's magical beanstalk from five acres of lima bean fields, the $70 million Orange County Performing Arts Center opened here Monday night with Zubin Mehta conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

title: DOW CLIMBS 12.38 IN SLOW TRADING
description: A decline in the nation's trade deficit, along with a sign of weakness in the economy, helped Wall Street yesterday regain most of the loss it incurred in the previous session.

title: ASPIN'S BROTHER LOSES HIS PENTAGON CONTRACT
description: The brother of the chairman of the House Armed Services committee today lost his bid to renew a Pentagon contract. He was underbid by the New York State Department of Transportation, Defense Department officials said today.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WHO are these people who can take a pair of black pants and a black sweater and an important jewel and turn it into a fashion statement anyway? I want to meet one. I don't know these people. I know people like me who buy outfits - the kind of people who have a party to go to and panic, and in that panic run out and make a kamikaze attack on a dressing room and buy themselves an outfit. Three months later, they run into that outfit in the closet and say, like the caterpillar in Wonderland, ''Whoooo are Yooooou?''

title: SUNLITE INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $1,132,000 on the value of the company's U.S. oil and gas assets and charges of $548,000 associated with the recent sale of its U.K. assets. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $561,459.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Greg Adams, the Washington Capitals' forward has been suspended for three regular-season National Hockey League games and faces a $1,000 fine for leaving the bench and participating in the altercation that broke out last Friday in an exhibition game against the Whalers in Hartford. . . . John Stallworth will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow or Friday, and the Pittsburgh Steelers' wide receiver will be sidelined indefinitely. . . . Kevin Allen, the Philadelphia Eagles' top draft pick in 1985, was waived yesterday. The 6-5, 280-pound lineman from Indiana had been placed on the team's non-football injury reserve list Aug. 26 after saying he suffered from cramps and exhaustion. The Eagles said medical tests had uncovered no major medical disorder.

title: Questions Raised by the New Reproductive Biology
description: To the Editor:

title: Flutie in Tryout
description: Doug Flutie, the 1984 Heisman Trophy winner who played for the Generals, is in Green Bay, Wis., for a tryout with the 0-4 Packers, who have been struggling under Randy Wright and Vince Ferragamo at quarterback.

title: Nike Profit Off; Revenues Fall
description: Nike Inc., a leading athletic shoe and apparel maker based in Beaverton, Ore., today reported a profit of $14.9 million, or 39 cents a share, for its fiscal first quarter, ended Aug. 31.

title: Intense Search Resumes For Fugitive in Missouri
description: The police today resumed searching on foot for Michael Wayne Jackson, starting from a trailer where the authorities believe the fugitive ate, changed clothes and shaved off his beard.

title: Accord Reported on Nigerian Loan
description: Arrangements that could make $1.5 billion available to Nigeria are in the final stages as a result of an accord between Africa's most populous country and the International Monetary Fund, officials said today.

title: FRIEDMAN TRIAL IS TOLD OF 'ENTERPRISE FOR PLUNDER'
description: New York City's Parking Violations Bureau was turned into ''an enterprise for plunder'' by a small group of public officials and business executives, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, told jurors today.

title: Uranium Mine Is Backed Near Grand Canyon
description: The United States Forest Service has approved a proposed uranium mine 13 miles south of the Grand Canyon despite opposition from an Indian tribe whose reservation is downstream.

title: Spinks Vs. Cooney Is Possible
description: Amid rumors that Michael Spinks, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, and Butch Lewis, his promoter, intend to announce at a news conference today that they are withdrawing from the Home Box Office heavyweight-unification series, Rock Newman, a spokesman for Lewis, would say only that, ''Butch is going to make a statement to clear up rumors and misconceptions.''

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Free-Room Vouchers By Holiday Adventures
description: Holiday Adventures is a new joint venture between Bob Guccione's Omni Publications and Flexibreaks, a London-based creator of incentive programs.

title: EXERTING HIMSELF TO GET AHEAD OF DEMOCRATIC PARK
description: Is Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona running for President or training for the Olympic Games?

title: PRESIDENT WANTS U.S. RATE DROP
description: President Reagan said today he wants American interest rates to decline ''even further'' than they have already this year.

title: No Headline
description: The man chosen by Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, to head fund-raising for his 1983 campaign for Westchester County Executive was at the time being accused by investors of ''aiding and abetting'' a scheme to defraud them of millions of dollars.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL TO COMBAT DRUGS
description: The Senate today passed its version of an anti-drug bill after declaring that ''the exceptional nature of the drug abuse problem'' warranted exceeding existing budget limits to combat it.

title: Dome Misses A Repayment
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said yesterday that it had failed to pay a bank debt of about $400,000 due to Bayerische Landesbank. The energy company said it had attempted to get a waiver from the West German bank but had been unable to do so.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: TRIAL STARTS IN AIRPORT EXTORTION CASE
description: Four figures from organized-crime families conspired with officials of two local unions and transport companies to extort more than $1 million from trucking concerns at Kennedy International Airport, Federal prosecutors contended yesterday.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
U.S. Tests Its Prototype Of Antisatellite Device
description: As Congressional negotiators argued over whether to limit tests of antisatellite weapons in the new fiscal year that begins Wednesay, the Air Force today ended the 1986 fiscal year with a test of its prototype of the weapon.

title: School Volunteers Turns 30
description: A concern about educating disadvantaged children led Mary A. Fisk to become a teacher's helper three decades ago and then join 19 other women in creating School Volunteers.

title: Some Great Leaps Forward
description: Cleveland and San Francisco are on the verge of becoming only the ninth and 10th clubs in modern major league history to finish with a winning record after losing 100 games the year before. The eight others:

title: The View From Beacon Hill
description: When President Reagan says his Administration has turned the nation's economy around, you have to ask, which part of it?

title: Daiwa Widens Bond Market
description: Daiwa Securities America, already well established in the Treasury bond market, yesterday made its debut as the lead underwriter in the domestic corporate market with a $125 million offering for the General Telephone Company of California.

title: LOBBYISTS REGROUP FOR TAX BILLS ON FAR HORIZONS
description: When Charls Walker, one of Washington's best known tax lobbyists, addresses business seminars and conventions these days, he begins his speech talking not about the major battles lost in the tax bill of 1986 but about the promising opportunities ahead. ''Let me talk to you about the tax reform act of 1987,'' he begins in his smooth Texas drawl.

title: India Engine Deal
description: The United States Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, is expected to sign a contract to supply 10 F-404 engines for India's prototype light combat aircraft during a visit to New Delhi from Oct. 11 to 14, the United News of India News Agency said.

title: NEW STUDIES FOCUS ON AIDS TRANSMISSION CHANCES
description: The chances are small that a single heterosexual encounter will spread the AIDS infection, new research suggests.

title: FRICTION OVER KRISHNAS IN WEST VIRGINIA'S HILLS
description: Before leaving his house for work each morning, Alfred Clark slips a silver-plated .38-caliber revolver into his jacket pocket.

title: FUEL ECONOMY STANDARD FOR CARS SAID TO BE EASED FOR '87 AND '88
description: The Department of Transportation, granting a request by the General Motors Corporation, has decided to ease the fuel economy standard for passenger cars for the next two model years, sources close to the department said today.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,069,000 for the quarter and $12,447,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,796,000.

title:
FOOD AND FITNESS;
On Vegetable Gum
description: IF only we had substances that would do for our lives what vegetable gums do for food -smooth, emulsify and cohere. Theirs is a tradition of service. When a plant is injured by trauma, bacterial or fungal attack, gum is produced and flows to the distressed site. There it forms a protective seal, drying when the air hits it.

title: STATEMENT BY MOSCOW
description: Following is the text of the Soviet announcement today of the meeting next month between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: WORLD BANK CHIEF OUTLINES STRATEGY
description: In his first major address as president of the World Bank, Barber B. Conable Jr. today outlined a strategy against global poverty, stressing more help for subsistence farmers and attention to the role of women, who he said ''do two-thirds of the world's work.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CLAMS are among the foods I like best, so I am fortunate that they are in season all year. One of my favorite preparations is clam fritters, and to make this dish, I generally use cherrystone clams, which are larger than littlenecks and therefore more efficient to chop.

title: TWO SKILLFUL AND TIRELESS FOES BATTLE IN MISSOURI SENATE RACE
description: With one month to go and with one of the highlights of his campaign for the Senate just past, former Gov. Christopher S. Bond was displaying mixed feelings.

title: BEHIND DIM SUM, AN INFERNAL MACHINE
description: AT 5 o'clock every weekday morning, Man Cheung Ho, dim sum chef for the five H.S.F. restaurants in Manhattan and on Long Island, climbs the stairs to a third-floor loft at 413 West 14th Street. There, in a cavernous 8,000-square-foot commercial kitchen, Mr. Ho and Joe Tam, the manager, supervise eight assistants in producing thousands of the restaurants' popular dim sum.

title: DAY OF SURPRISES: HOW NEWS UNFOLDED
description: Soviet-American developments unfolded quickly yesterday in Washington, Moscow, Frankfurt and New York. Here are the key events; times are given in New York time. 8:19 A.M. Nicholas S. Daniloff, a correspondent for U.S. News & World Report freed by the Soviet Union, leaves Frankfurt for Washington. 9:50 A.M. Tass, the Soviet press agency, announces a meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in Iceland on Oct. 11 and 12. 9:54 A.M. Gennadi F. Zakharov, a Soviet employee to the United Nations, enters a plea of no contest to spying charges in Federal court in Brooklyn. 10:15 A.M. President Reagan announces in Washington that he will meet with Mr. Gorbachev in Icelan. 3:15 P.M. Mr. Zakharov's plane leaves Dulles International Airport for Moscow. 4:40 P.M. Mr. Daniloff's flight lands at Dulles.

title: DANILOFF HAS AN EMOTIONAL HOMECOMING
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff was reunited with his children and colleagues from U.S. News & World Report today in an emotional homecoming at Dulles Airport outside Washington.

title: Dingman Quits Allied-Signal
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that Michael D. Dingman had resigned as a director.

title: SOLIDARITY'S LEADERS CHALLENGE WARSAW
description: The leadership of the outlawed Solidarity movement seriously challenged the Polish Government today by announcing the formation of a council composed of seven former fugitive leaders who are to work openly for the restoration of the union.

title: MISSING CHILD LIVING IN JERSEY SPOTTED ON TV BY BABYSITTER
description: Pictures of missing children flashed on the television screen Monday night after a program about a family whose son was kidnapped, changing the lives of two women here, Ellen Conner and her babysitter.

title: PHILIPPINE ARMY SEIZES A TOP REBEL
description: The military reported the arrest today of a top Communist leader, and a rebel spokesman demanded his release if cease-fire talks were to continue.

title: Ending Khomeini's Blood Bath
description: As the carnage known as the Iran-Iraq war enters its seventh year, some observers contend that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's anticipated fall offensive may penetrate the Iraqi defenses, leading to the ouster of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the establishment of a pro-Khomeini regime in that country. Such a scenario would, it is feared, put the Ayatollah on the doorstep of other Arab nations supporting Iraq.

title: Jets, Giants Add a Player
description: The Jets and Giants will each have a new player on the roster when they resume practice today.

title: More Municipalities Try Taxable Bonds
description: Sales of taxable bonds by local governments and authorities are leaving the realm of the imagination and becoming reality, according to a nine-month compilation of issuing activity in the municipal bond market.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
U.S. MARRIAGE PATTERN FOUND TO CHANGE
description: Men and women of the baby-boom generation are marrying later and less frequently, which partly accounts for the marriage rate in the United States being at its lowest level in nine years, authorities in the Federal Government say.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SOUTH KOREA DROPS CONTRACT WITH DEAVER AGENCY
description: The South Korean Government has notified Michael K. Deaver's lobbying company that it will not renew a $475,000 contract that expired today, according to a South Korean official.

title: A Leap to the Summit
description: A bleak logjam suddenly broken, Soviet-American relations now flow with promise. That the two superpowers could loosen this tangle shows how much benefit each foresees from negotiations and how hopeful each has grown that the other shares the ambition. In the untangling itself, President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev have gained momentum for their meeting in Iceland next week.

title: SOME ARMS GROUNDWORK DONE FOR ICELAND SESSION
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will approach their meeting in Iceland having narrowed their differences on medium-range missiles, but not on ''Star Wars'' research and a nuclear test ban.

title: Sears and Kraft Alter Lineups
description: THE big advertising news yesterday came out of Chicago, with both Kraft and Sears, Roebuck consolidating their advertising agencies.

title: Farewell, Tip
description: The House of Representatives will bid a fond, sentimental and bipartisan farewell tonight to Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who is retiring when Congress adjourns, probably in the next few days.

title: CAREFUL PLAY GIVES KASPAROV DRAW
description: Gary Kasparov pulled himself together and played carefully to make a draw Monday with Anatoly Karpov in the 20th game of their world championship chess match in Leningrad. The 23-year-old titleholder thus ended his string of three consecutive losses and steadied himself for the struggle in the four remaining games.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: New-Home Sales Down For 5th Straight Month
description: Sales of new homes fell for the fifth consecutive month in August, a 13.4 percent decline that was the largest in more than four years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PENGUIN AGREES TO BUY NEW AMERICAN LIBRARY
description: Less than a week after a German publisher agreed to buy Doubleday, the Penguin Publishing Company of London has agreed to buy New American Library and its hard-cover affiliate, E. P. Dutton. The agreement, announced yesterday, will give Penguin a vastly expanded presence in the United States, and should provide the two American companies much broader access to international markets.

title: Fighting on Green Line Traps Beirut Lawmakers
description: Moslem and Christian soldiers battled across Beirut's Green Line for three hours today, trapping several legislators in the Parliament building.

title: U.S. TO SELL HIGH-TECH EQUIPMENT TO INDIA FOR ARMS-UPGRADING PLAN
description: Two decades after ending military sales to India, the United States is now poised to sell jet engines, radars and other high-technology equipment to the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi for the country's military modernization program.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1986
description: The Economy

title: CONSUL RESTAURANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE STAGE: 'BLUE NIGHT,' AN EVENING OF PUPPETRY
description: JANIE GEISER, director of Atlanta's Jottay Theater, is a puppeteer as conjurer. In ''Blue Night,'' an evening of short plays at Dance Theater Workshop, she creates a miniature world so tangible that a curious reversal takes place. The puppets begin to seem life-size; we, as theatergoers, feel larger than life.

title: Dressy Chains That Lend Chic
description: 1.A Calculating Book This credit-card lookalike is actually a Calling Card, which can store up to 150 names and telephone numbers.

title: BOYFRIEND HELD IN COED'S DEATH ON LONG ISLAND
description: An 18-year-old C. W. Post student who had been missing since Sunday was found strangled early today, and her boyfriend was charged with killing her in an argument over breaking up their relationship, the police said.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 1, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE PASS STOPGAP MEASURE TO AVERT FEDERAL SHUTDOWN
description: A shutdown of Federal Government operations was averted today as the House and Senate approved a stopgap appropriation bill that extends financing of activities for eight days.

title: 'QUEENIE PIE' FEELS PULL AND PUSH OF NEW YORK
description: The only thing missing from the money reviews was the money.

title: Concert for Refugee Agency Draws 1,000 in Switzerland
description: About 1,000 people today attended ''Classic Aid,'' a four-hour classical music concert sponsored by the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to raise money for refugee programs.

title: REPORT SAYS AMERICANS MAY BE IN INDOCHINA
description: The Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency said today that there was a ''strong possibility'' that some Americans remain alive in Indochina 14 years after the end of American participation in the Vietnam war.

title: Underwriting Activity Falls
description: Underwriting activity during the quarter ended yesterday remained intense but fell sharply from the torrid pace of the previous two quarters.

title: Kroger Plans Sale Of Its Drugstores
description: The Kroger Company said today that it would sell its drugstore operations, as part of a previously announced restructuring. Analysts have estimated that the stores, which generated about $1.15 billion in revenues last year, would fetch between $300 million and $400 million.

title: Vestron Video In Movie Venture
description: Vestron Video, an independent videocassette company, and Integrated Resources Inc., a financial services company, have formed a joint venture to finance and distribute motion pictures.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. EXPOS, at Montreal, 7:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:00 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:00 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: On Not Killing People to Win Them Over
description: To the Editor:

title: SURROGATE MOTHERS GROW IN NUMBER DESPITE QUESTIONS
description: IN a final, desperate effort to have a family, hundreds of infertile couples across the country have turned to surrogate motherhood in recent years. The half-dozen major centers in the United States that match infertile couples with surrogates report that business is flourishing.

title: FINALLY, PITT CAN PLAY NIGHT GAMES
description: Night football games may become a regular thing in September and October at Pittsburgh, now that a way has been found to provide lights without having to cope with some abandoned mine shafts under Pitt Stadium.

title: Newmont Official Plans for Spinoff
description: David C. Ridinger, a mining executive, will soon be leaving his New York office for good for the copper-mining regions of Arizona, if a spinoff plan goes through as scheduled.

title: SOVIET WARNING ON EXPULSION ORDER
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that Moscow planned a major retaliation against the United States if agreement was not reached on the American order to expel 25 staff members of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: RUBICON CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $409,000 for the latest year and $2,444,000 for the year-earlier period from the forgiveness of outstanding debt.

title: Container Corp.
description: The Jefferson Smurfit Corporation and the Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund said they had completed the previously announced acquisition of Container Corporation of America from Mobil Corporation for about $1.2 billion. Container makes paperboard and packaging products, and had sales of $1.6 billion in 1985.

title: JAPAN TRANSPORT PLAN
description: Japan Air Lines said today that it planned to have the world's first commercial linear motor transport system in operation in northern Japan by 1990. The $98 million project would run on a 3.7-mile line in Asahikawa, a city of 360,000 people, a spokesman said.

title: MUSIC: YO-YO MA IN RECITAL
description: THE cellist Yo-Yo Ma began his Sunday afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall with an exquisite reading of the ''Adagio'' from Bach's ''Toccata, Adagio and Fugue'' (BWV 564) in a transcription by Pablo Casals. Mr. Ma's playing was characterized by a lustrous tone, long, legato phrasing and an unembarrassed emotionalism that never devolved into vulgarity.

title: In 'Tutu,' Miles Davis Goes Fully Electronic
description: ''TUTU,'' Miles Davis's new album and his first for Warner Brothers after nearly 30 years at Columbia, is his first full-scale foray into electronic pop. His later Columbia albums increasingly used synthesizer textures and began to experiment with synthesized percussion, but they were still built around the trumpeter's performing band. ''Tutu'' dispenses with the band almost entirely. It has been built up layer by layer, like any pop recording, over drum-machine rhythms and heavy bass. The bass, along with most of the synthesizers and other instrumentation, was provided by Marcus Miller, who co-produced the album with the chief architect of Warner Brothers' successful jazz-fusion activities, Tommy LiPuma.

title: DENIZENS OF THE NIGHT: THEIR FAVORITE HAUNTS
description: THE early evening starts at the Odeon with elegant, spare, three- and four-course dinners served to a basically Brooks Brothers and Eurostyle crowd with, perhaps, a smattering of movie celebrities.

title: Frankfurt Book Fair Opens
description: The 38th Frankfurt Book Fair opened today with 320,000 titles from 7,000 publishers in 84 countries on display. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany officially opened the fair, which is scheduled to run through Oct. 6.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Murdoch Unit Moving
description: Murdoch Magazines, which publishes more than a dozen business journals, will relocate from New York City to Secaucus, N.J., the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Development Commissioner, Borden Putnam, announced today.

title: FATHER OF 6-YEAR-OLD TESTIFIES IN FILM DEATHS TRIAL
description: The father of a 6-year-old girl who was killed while filming a scene for ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' testified today that he had not been told his daughter would be filmed amid explosions and beneath a hovering helicopter.

title: Lehrer/McGovern Partner in Europe
description: Bovis International Ltd., a unit of the Peninsula and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, one of Britain's largest conglomerates, has acquired a 50 percent stake in Lehrer/McGovern Inc., the closely held construction management company that oversaw the renovation of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Diego J. Lopez Is Dead at 41; Ex-Director of AIDS Program
description: Diego J. Lopez, a social worker and psychotherapist, and a former clinical director of Gay Men's Health Crisis, an AIDS service and educational organization, died Monday at the New York University Medical Center of complications related to acquired immune deficiency syndrome. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Women's Success
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

description: b-Net loss

title: Discrimination Counted In Bob Jones Case
description: To the Editor:

FOOD NOTES
description: Safe Jams Recently, a Queens reader wrote that he had seen some bargain-priced imported jams from Rumania, Yugoslavia and Hungary. ''I've hesitated to buy them recently, fearing they might be from fruit collected after Chernobyl,'' he wrote, referring to the nuclear accident in the Soviet Union. ''Do you know if these shipments are inspected for radioactivity?''

title: Popular Restaurant Seized
description: A 1977 review posted in the window of the Pantheon, a Greek restaurant on Eighth Avenue, said finding an establishment offering good food in pleasant surroundings at moderate prices on that avenue was difficult and praised the Pantheon as ''something of a minor miracle'' for fitting just that bill.

title: Jewish Newsletter
description: The American Jewish Committee tomorrow will begin publishing a Washington newsletter with the dual goal of keeping Government leaders informed of ''the Jewish agenda'' and telling the Jewish community how the White House, Congress and the courts are handling issues of concern to its members.

title: FOR CARTER, CONTROVERSY AMID GLORY
description: Even the nickname is perfect: The Kid. As in the All-American Kid, the Oklahoma Kid, Oh, You Kid. It comes with curly hair, handsome looks, football shoulders and a catcher's mitt, and it belongs to the man who leads the Mets in runs batted in, game-winning runs batted in, salary, commercials, autographs and curtain-calls. Some kid.

title: U.S. ENVOY DISPLAYS THE GIFT, ENCHANTING THE IRISH
description: Last January, Margaret M. Heckler set down on these shores in political steerage, unceremoniously dislodged from her post as Secretary of Health and Human Services in the Reagan Administration and packed off to be Ambassador to Ireland, a job she did not covet.

title: KEEPING SCORE: 3 MAJOR QUESIONS FOR PRESIDENT
description: Administration officials and outside foreign-policy experts are asking themselves three questions about the events leading to today's announcement that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev would meet next week.

title: FARM PRICES PLUMMET
description: Prices that farmers receive for raw farm products fell 2.4 percent in September, the largest decline since January, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: UNITED AND AMERICAN TO LIFT MANY FARES 5%
description: At least two airlines are raising fares in their hubs by up to 5 percent on Thursday. The move could cause other carriers to increase fares in their hubs.

title: READICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tax Increase in Texas Approved by Legislature
description: The Legislature today approved a temporary $872 million tax increase and companion spending cuts to offset a budget shortfall of $2.8 billion caused by slumping oil prices.

title: Buffalo TV Station Sale
description: The General Cinema Corporation, owner of the nation's largest movie theater chain, said it had completed the sale of a subsidiary that owns WGRZ-TV in Buffalo. The $56 million sale of the NBC affiliate to the WGRZ Acquisition Corporation will add about $35 million to General Cinema's income in the fiscal year 1986, the company said.

title: FILIPINOS DISAPPOINTED BY SENATE VOTE AGAINST AID
description: The Government reacted with disappointment and some bitterness today over the defeat in the United States Senate on Monday of a proposal for $200 million in increased economic aid for the Philippines.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: EVERY year at about this time - the start of the peak season for colds - researchers announce yet another promising way of treating this common ailment. Recent possibilities include drugs that block the proliferation of cold viruses and substances that help the body resist them. The latest is a nasal spray with antibodies that prevent the largest group of cold viruses from entering cells in the nasal passages, where most colds begin.

title: The Perfect Egg Cream
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Give Kids a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TELEVISION'S VIETNAM,' A DOCUMENTARY ON 31
description: TO begin with the critical point, there is no very good reason why ''Television's Vietnam: The Impact of Media'' should not be shown. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 31 at 8 o'clock tonight, became controversial when the Public Broadcasting Service turned it down. Subsequently, a number of public-television stations, acting independently of PBS, have chosen to show it anyway. They should. It is a provocative documentary.

title: Real Estate; Relocating State Units Inside City
description: WHEN New York State decided to give up the 50 floors it occupied in the World Trade Center more than three years ago, a major goal was to strengthen commercial areas in the outer boroughs by moving state offices into those areas.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a provision for loss on real estate of $1,536,000 and a gain related to investments in affiliate of $7,456,000, both for the quarter and year.

Daugherty Agrees
description: Brad Daugherty, the No. 1 selection in the National Basketball Association draft, has agreed to a six-year, $5.8 million contract with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: INFORMANT UNABLE TO CITE ANY CRIMES BY PERSICO
description: An informant conceded yesterday that he had no first-hand knowledge of any illegal activities by Carmine Persico, whom he had identified as the boss of an organized-crime family.

title: Gates Corp. to Sell Learjet Holdings
description: The Gates Corporation, in a move that had been expected, agreed to sell its 64.8 percent stake in the Gates Learjet Corporation to M. J. Rosenthal & Associates Inc., a New York investment firm, for $62.7 million. Under the agreement, each share of Gates Learjet will be exchanged for $6 in cash and $2 in preferred stock of the new company formed to consummate the transaction.

title: U.S. ESTABLISHES NATIONAL ORGAN DONOR NETWORK IN VIRGINIA
description: The Health and Human Services Secretary, Otis R. Bowen, announced today that a single national network to match donated human organs for transplanting to recipients had been established.

title: BELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from debt restructuring of $7,786 and $434,986 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

description: Following are excerpts from a news conference in Washington yesterday by President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, as recorded by The New York Times:

PRESIDIO OIL CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
NVHOMES LEADER SEES RYAN AS A STRATEGIC FIT
description: Dwight C. Schar, chairman and chief executive of NVHomes L.P., is a residential builder by trade. Now, he is trying to make a large addition to his home construction company.

title: PARKWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN CHEF'S LONG ROAD TO SUCCESS
description: LONG before Americans clamored to get into the best professional cooking schools and long before being a chef was considered an appropriate alternative to the legal profession or medicine, Bruce LeFavour, who was born in Amsterdam, N.Y., owned his own restaurant, raised his own chickens, rabbits, ducks, pigs, sheep, vegetables and cooked his own version of French food. It's been 20 years, but today, at 51 years of age, Mr. LeFavour is still on the front line of the American culinary scene. Until a few years ago hardly anyone had recognized his talents.

title: ICELAND: PROUD, ISOLATED
description: Iceland, which is being thrust into the global spotlight as the venue for the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting next month, is among the world's most isolated nations, and proudly so.

title: The Editorial Notebook; When Congress Gave Money Back
description: This first day of fiscal 1987, staring at a run of $200 billion Federal budget deficits, is an apt time to ponder the unimaginable: a Federal budget surplus and no national debt. It happened once, 150 fiscal years ago. The surplus loomed large enough to arouse much commotion in the 24th Congress. The temporary solution, then as now, was to juggle the books.

title: O. J. Simpson Returns
description: The voice of O. J. Simpson will be heard again on ''Monday Night Football'' when the San Diego Chargers play the Seattle Seahawks next week.

title: 12,000 VOTES SEPARATE DEMOCRATS IN FLORIDA RACE
description: Bob Martinez, the grandson of Spanish immigrants, today won the Republican nomination for Governor by a 2-to-1 margin over Lou Frey, his opponent in the party's runoff contest.

title: A SEASON OF CHANGE IN N.B.A.
description: ''Hello, my name is Moses Malone.''

title: Texaco Case Judge Dies
description: State District Judge J. P. Farris, who presided over the major portion of the Pennzoil-Texaco trial that led to a $10.53 billion judgment against Texaco, died at the age of 65 at his home here on Monday.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Plea To the Allies
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN, in his address to the annual conference of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank here yesterday, gave strong backing to the position of his Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, that other industrial countries need to accelerate the growth of their economies or see the United States dollar sink further.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHERE YOU'LL FIND ME and Other Stories. By Ann Beattie. 191 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: PENNANT FEVER STRIKES THE PHONE LINES
description: ''I called my brother-in-law and was nice,'' Morton Garrett Jr., a Mets fan from Brooklyn, conceded ashamedly. In mitigation, he said that this was a first, that he only did it because his brother-in-law has Mets playoff tickets and promised it would not happen again.

title: KEEPING SCORE: A LIMITED SUCCESS FOR GORBACHEV
description: In terms of political barter, Mikhail S. Gorbachev got what he wanted out of the test of wills that came to be known as the Daniloff affair.

title: Terry W. McAdam, 44, Dies; Hilton Foundation Executive
description: Terry W. McAdam, executive vice president and program director of the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation in Los Angeles, died Friday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 44 years old.

title: More Paralysis on Single-Room Units?
description: Mayor Koch of New York and the City Council are preparing to renew the five-year moratorium on demolishing Single Room Occupancy housing, which expires Dec. 31. To do so, however, is to confess a failure of housing policy. A moratorium ought to last only long enough to develop and enact a rational program for replacing S.R.O.'s while providing adequately for their residents.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
DANCE: JAZZ TAP AND GREGORY HINES
description: GREGORY HINES is performing as guest artist with the Jazz Tap Ensemble this week at the Joyce Theater, where last night's opening by the Los Angeles troupe offered a study in contrasts and in audience frenzy.

title: 'SILVER GUN' TRIAL BEGINS
description: A Bronx man identified by prosecutors as the ''silver gun bandit'' went on trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday. The defendant, Michael Dirton, 24 years old, of 840 Grand Concourse, is charged with breaking into 23 apartments in Manhattan last year and early this year, robbing 38 persons and sexually assaulting four.

title: ON ROSH-HA-SHANAH, HONEY FINDS ONE OF ITS MANY RITUAL USES
description: WHEN Aristotle wrote that honey was dew distilled from the stars and so delicious that it was fit for the gods, he was speaking of the rich, herbal Greek Hymettian variety. Honey, a supersaturated sugar solution created by bees from nectar, was once the only sweetener known to man.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In the largest competitive tax-exempt sale of the week, the Florida State Board of Education is offering $300 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 7.31 percent for a 7 1/8 percent issue due 2017 at a price of 97 3/4 through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: WINE TALK
description: AFTER a brief detour, we are on the road again to worthwhile wine purchases for $10 and under - this time among the red wines of Italy and Spain.

title: Women's Success
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Norfolk Purchase Challenged
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission erred when it approved the acquisition of North American Van Lines, a large trucking company, by the Norfolk Southern Corporation, a leader in the railroad industry, a Federal appeals court ruled today. It returned the case to the I.C.C. for reconsideration.

title: ZAKHAROV, FREED BY U.S., LEAVES; 'NOT SPY,' HE SAYS
description: The United States today freed Gennadi F. Zakharov, a convicted Soviet spy, one day after Nicholas S. Daniloff, an American journalist charged with espionage, was released from confinement in Moscow.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $743,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Offer for Nets Rejected
description: An offer from Russ Berrie, a New Jersey toymaker, to buy the Nets was rejected yesterday, according to Alan Aufzien, chairman of the seven-man partnership that owns the team.

title: SAHLEN & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: WITH IRAQIS AT THE FRONT: ESPRIT LOOKS STRONG
description: Presumably they complain, or else they would be among the few soldiers in history not to exercise that right. But even after six years of war, the morale of Iraq's soldiers appears to be reasonably good.

title: Celeron Vice President Will Become Chairman
description: In 1977, when the Mid Louisiana Gas Company was sold to the Celeron Corporation, Carl S. Quinn told Celeron's chairman he did not want to run a company that had been acquired.

title: LATE-NIGHT TALK-SHOW EXPLOSION
description: THE talk-show explosion is upon us, if for no other reason than the formats are relatively cheap. And just about everybody, it seems, will do anything to grab an audience these days. Some of the golden moments from recent shows:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1986
description: International

title: What the Tax Law Means for New York
description: When President Reagan signs the new tax bill into law, New York State will face its greatest economic challenge since the city and state fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.

title: INCUMBENCY BUOYS G.O.P. IN GEORGIA
description: In a way, Mack Mattingly is a prototype of the class of 1980, the group of little-known Republicans elected in the Reagan sweep of that year who are the prime targets this year as the Democrats seek to regain control of the Senate.

title: Lear Petroleum
description: Lear Petroleum Partners L. P.'s Operating Company said it agreed to sell its exploration and production-related assets to the Minatome Corporation, a unit of Total-Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, for $115 million. Lear said the price is subject to adjustment to reflect oil and natural gas operations since Jan. 1 and requires the approval of the shareholders of the Lear Petroleum Corporation, general partner for the limited partnership.

title: MANY LAWMAKERS HAIL AGREEMENT WITH SOVIET
description: Although some Republicans in Congress were critical, lawmakers from both parties today praised the agreement that led to the release of an American journalist from the Soviet Union and a Soviet spy suspect from the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the plans of Federal Express to end its electronic mail service misstated the company's stock performance on Monday. It rose $8.25, to $63.75, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading.

title: SPACECRAFT TRANSCRIPT RELEASED
description: The crew members of the space shuttle Challenger bantered frequently about cold weather before their craft was launched on its disastrous mission Jan. 28, but they seemed to show no concern about their safety, according to a transcript of crew conversations released today.

title: Empathy From Roberts
description: ''I don't think it's fair to Bert Blyleven, especially considering the phenomenal record he's had, for you guys to bring that up,'' said Robin Roberts, whose record for single-season home run pitches was erased Monday night by the Minnesota Twins' right-hander, of the news media coverage of the dubious feat. Blyleven surpassed Roberts's record of 46 home runs allowed when he gave up three homers to the Cleveland Indians for his 47th, 48th and 49th of the season.

title: GREEN STUDY SAYS SPECIAL INTERESTS DONATED $1.3 MILLION TO D'AMATO
description: Mark Green, the Democrat seeking to unseat Republican Alfonse M. D'Amato from the United States Senate, yesterday called the incumbent a ''Senator for sale or rent.''

title: Gaelic Football, Of a Sort
description: Here are the clues for today's problem in creative logic: 1. Boston has strong ties to Ireland, so strong, in fact, that during the tourist season Aer Lingus needs three flights a week from Boston to Dublin just to accommodate the area's Irish-American residents clamoring to return to the old sod. 2. West Point, given the nation's NATO commitments, probably has more alumni living in Western Europe than does any other American college. 3. One of the hardships inflicted on American Army officers by such overseas duty is the absence of American football. 4. Boston College and Army play each other in football just about every year. 5. One of Dublin's main stadiums, Lansdowne Road, doesn't have an insurmountable commitment to rugby or Gaelic football for Nov. 19, 1988, when Army and B.C. are scheduled to meet. 6. What Lansdowne Road does have is room for 55,000 football fans, whether they be visiting Bostonians, American Army officers or locals curious to see what the American game is all about. 7. Several major American corporations with big advertising budgets and a yen for sponsoring sports events (Ford, McDonald's, Coca-Cola and Budweiser come to mind) have operations in Ireland. 8. Jim O'Brien, a former Boston College tackle who's now a marketing representative and a frequent visitor to Ireland, considered all the above and had an idea. 9. Boston College's athletic director, Bill Flynn, thought it was a terrific idea, and so did Army's athletic director, Carl Ullrich. 10.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 'MENAGE,' A COMEDY FROM BERTRAND BLIER
description: BERTRAND BLIER never seemed much of a fabulist in the past, but his ''Menage'' puts its characters through the kinds of buoyantly kaleidoscopic changes one might associate with a fairy tale. It's an extraordinarily spry and witty film from a director who, on the evidence of ''Going Places'' and ''Get Out Your Handkerchiefs,'' has never regarded charming his audiences as much of a priority. Indeed, Mr. Blier has said in interviews that it disappoints him when his films fail to provoke indignation. So in terms of sheer shock value, ''Menage'' may seem some slight comedown (though this director, whose great love of sexually explicit dialogue has not left him, will never be accused of gentility). In all other respects, it is Mr. Blier's most satisfying work.

title: Deboning a Duck
description: DUCK meat has come into its own in recent years. Once a specialty item sold primarily by butchers who featured game, it is now widely available in supermarkets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is speculation as to who blinked first, and who outsmarted the other side.

title: Stubborn
description: Joseph B. Kennedy, who has managed to antagonize both the Federal agency for which he worked for 13 years and the industry that the agency oversees, has resigned under fire. But he is by no means fleeing the field.

title: ZACCARO SEEKS TO DISQUALIFY A GRAND JURY
description: A lawyer for John A. Zaccaro, trying to avert the possibility of an indictment against his client, pleaded with a judge yesterday to hear a motion to disqualify a grand jury looking into allegations of bribery in the awarding of cable television franchises in Queens.

title: POLYMERIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Indoor League
description: One day late in 1982, Chet Simmons met with a number of the biggest and most recognizable names in American football to discuss a matter of some consequence to all of them. Simmons was the newly appointed commissioner of the United States Football League, which would begin its first season in just a few months, and the others in attendance were members of the league's competition committee, who had been summoned to select an official U.S.F.L. game ball.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Mitsui Manufacturers Bank, Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Mitsui Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, said its president and chief executive, Leonard Weil, will retire on Dec. 31 and would become president emeritus.

title: AULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GIULIANI VS. PUCCIO: CLASH OF MANNERS
description: It has been billed as a battle of the Titans, a heavyweight championship fight, a fall classic: Rudolph W. Giuliani for the prosecution vs. Thomas P. Puccio for the defense, starring in the New York City corruption trial. Andrew Horowitz, a recent law school graduate, left New York City before dawn and was standing in line outside the courtroom here, hoping for a seat for the opening arguments.

title: VIETNAM AND TERRORISM ASSAILED BY SPEAKERS AT THE UNITED NATIONS
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk head of an exiled coalition fighting to oust the Vietnamese from Cambodia, denounced Vietnam today for its ''illegal occupation'' of his country.

title: FRENCH LINK SYRIA TO TERROR GROUP
description: A senior French official cited evidence today linking Syria with the group that the police believe carried out a series of bomb attacks here this month.

title: HORACE MANN SCHOOL BEGINS CELEBRATION OF 100TH BIRTHDAY
description: Joseph Chase, a mathematics teacher at the Horace Mann-Barnard School in the Bronx, has witnessed almost half the history of the institution, which began its 100th anniversary celebration yesterday.

title: To Sever the Link Between Failure in School and a Life of Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Malfunction Delays Midwest Flights
description: Up to 600 flights in five states in the Middle West were delayed Monday, in part, because of a breakdown in an old computer at the country's busiest air traffic control center near Chicago, the Federal Aviation Administration acknowledged today.

title: A FINAL DAY: 4 MINUTES FOR ZAKHAROV
description: Gennadi F. Zakharov's final appearance yesterday in an American courtroom barely lasted four minutes but, despite its seemingly pro forma nature, it was no ordinary proceeding.

title: JULIA R. KENT
description: Julia R. Kent, a retired New York City public schoolteacher, died Friday at a nursing home in Albany.

title: Penalty Declined
description: Coach Mack Brown, whose Tulane football team has given up 100 points in three games, when asked about the execution of the defense: ''I don't think we ought to execute them yet.''

title: Bridge; Young Pair Draws Attention At an Event in White Plains
description: Almost all the great players in the game began at an early age, and some when they were very young indeed. It was natural, therefore, that observers should wonder whether they were seeing the start of two such careers in White Plains last weekend.

title: EXPOS' 2-HITTER BEATS DARLING
description: The Mets played tonight as if they were somewhere else. ''It seemed that we had the blues or something,'' Wally Backman said after the 1-0 loss to the Expos. ''It's been so long since we clinched, our mind is on other things.''

title: Give RICO a New Life and a New Name
description: One provision of RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, gives victims private redress, permitting them to sue gangsters for triple their actual losses. But there have been few private suits against the mob; more commonly, lawyers are using the law effectively in conventional contract, business fraud and consumer disputes. Business groups, resentful of being lumped with mobsters, want Congress to gut the law. Less-drastic change makes more sense.

title: MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The year-ago quarter's share earnings restated to reflect changes in employer's accounting for pension plan.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS BY DANILOFF AT DULLES
description: Following are excerpts from Nicholas S. Daniloff's news conference yesterday at Dulles Airport outside Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Women's Success
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Trafalgar Stake In Conglomerate
description: Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. said it had acquired a significant stake in Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate that rejected a $900 million bid by Trafalgar for its hotel interests last June.

title: THE GRIEVANCE BELL THAT NEVER RINGS
description: For the more than 20 years that a ''grievance bell'' has stood in front of the District of Columbia's municipal building, no one has rung it. This is not to say that district residents have nothing to complain about, but that steps have been taken to protect the bell from the public, although some might suggest that its effect has been to protect officials from complaining citizens.

title: B.J.K.&E. Unit Names Head
description: Myron Slosberg, 51 years old, is about to put his many years of direct marketing experience to work as president of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/ Direct, which bills about $40 million a year.

title: AT SCHOOLS, A TEACH-IN ON CRACK
description: At Public School 126 in the South Bronx, the story of Pinocchio being enticed into a coach driven by a man who transformed little boys into donkeys was used to illustrate the foolishness of succumbing to peer pressure and turning to crack.

title: IRT IS MOST IMPROVED, SUBWAY GROUP REPORTS
description: The IRT, which for years was considered the sorriest of the city's subway lines, now leads the others in such amenities as working doors and lights, readable maps and accurate signs, according to a survey released yesterday by a transit advocacy group.

title: TWO FINALISTS REPORTED IN BIDDING WAR FOR 7-UP
description: Two soft drink companies that are trying to build viable competitors to Coke and Pepsi are the finalists in the bidding for the Seven-Up Company, according to industry sources.

title: Jeannette Levison, 93; Humanitarian Activist
description: Jeannette Van Raalte Levison, who was active in humanitarian and philanthropic causes for several decades in New York City, died Monday at a nursing home in Stamford, Conn. She was 93 years old and formerly lived in Manhattan.

title: G.M. Saturn Plant Financing Begun
description: A $65 million issue of 7 1/4 percent pollution control bonds due in 2005 to finance facilities at the General Motors Corporation's new Saturn Corporation plant in Tennessee was offered yesterday at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Hopeless and Hopelesser
description: The second most depressing Monday morning news story was The Washington Post's ''Scientists See Signs of Mass Extinction,'' subtitled ''Species Vanishing as Forests Are Cleared,'' and beginning, ''Life on Earth is being ravaged by a mass extinction that is killing off 17,500 species. . . .''

title: SUSPICIOUS FIRE BADLY DAMAGES WEST SIDE HOTEL
description: A boarded-up hotel on West 44th Street, owned by a developer whose company illegally demolished four adjacent buildings last year, was heavily damaged by a blaze yesterday morning. Fire officials termed the fire suspicious.

title: AGREEMENT ON LOAN TO MEXICO
description: Mexico and its creditor banks announced tonight that they had finally reached agreement on a $6 billion loan package.

title: Emergency for Test Plane
description: An experimental airplane that was to be taken on a nonstop, round-the-world flight this month made an emergency landing in a test flight today when one of its propellers broke. The plane, the Voyager, and its two pilots landed safely at Edwards Air Force Base in the Mojave Desert, said Lee Herron, a spokesman for the private group that developed the plane.

title: Korea Electric
description: South Korea's state-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation has provisionally selected three American companies to supply equipment and services for its 10th and 11th nuclear power plants, at a total cost of $3 billion. Combustion Engineering Inc. will supply pressurized light-water reactors, the General Electric Company will provide turbines, and Sargent & Lundy Engineers will consult on engineering and design. Formal contracts are expected to be signed in February.

title: TEXT OF MAIN ADDRESSES AT BANK-I.M.F. MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared texts of the addresses by President Reagan, Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, and Jacques de Larosiere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, to the joint meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund yesterday: PRESIDENT REAGAN All in all, we have made great progress towards a stronger world economy since I last addressed you, and yet problems remain.

title: People
description: * Eric Anderson, Charles M. Kinsolving, Alfred Eisenpreis, James H. Hollis and Mac Morris have been named senior vice presidents at the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 1.

title: Market Place; Generic Drugs: Views Split
description: WITH an estimated $3 billion worth of prescription drugs losing patent protection between 1986 and the early 1990's, investors are looking more closely at the prospects for such generic drug stocks as Bolar Pharmaceutical, Par Pharmaceutical, Lyphomed Inc., Biocraft Laboratories and Mylan Laboratories.

title: REAGAN NAMES A BLACK DIPLOMAT U.S. AMBASSADOR TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: President Reagan, trying to win Senate support for his veto of South African sanctions legislation, today appointed Edward J. Perkins, a veteran black diplomat, as the new Ambassador to Pretoria.

title: STATE TO STIFFEN SEDATIVE RULES
description: The New York State Health Commissioner plans to tighten the procedures doctors use for prescribing sedatives, including Valium, one of the most prescribed and abused drugs in the nation.

title: SOON, A MILK SPRITZER
description: Researchers are working on a carbonated version of milk that will not leave a mustache on your upper lip or a film on your tongue, and might help dairy farmers.

title: A Move to Lift Viacom Stake
description: Sumner M. Redstone, president of National Amusements Inc., asked the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department yesterday for approval to increase his company's stake in Viacom International Inc., the diversified media company, to as much as 24.99 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Passes Drug Bill The Senate voted, 97 to 2, to increase penalties for drug dealers and step up law enforcement, but the source of funds remains at issue.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The loss for fiscal 1986 is after net non-recurring charges of $10.3 million. The net income in 1985 includes non- recurring gains of $19.6 million.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $8,600,000 and $18,300,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $8,500,000 and $18,500,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Rally for the B51
description: A group of 50 fervent but frustrated citizens gathered yesterday on Smith Street in downtown Brooklyn to say ''yes'' to the B51.

title: CHINESE 'STREET FOOD' AS A QUICK SNACK AND LEISURELY MEAL
description: IT is food that can be ordered off a curbside cart and eaten quickly. It is also food that can be dawdled over and admired bite by bite. Whether eaten quickly or leisurely, it is the essence of many of New York City's Chinese restaurants.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT REDUCED IN AUGUST BY RECORD AMOUNT
description: The nation's trade deficit shrank by $4.7 billion in August, the biggest one-month reduction on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: EFFORTS TO EASE PAIN OF LAYOFFS AT KODAK
description: When torn home movies needed splicing, or octagonal prints needed shaping, when pale graduation portraits had to be brought back to life or odd-size posters enlarged, Eastman Kodak sent the jobs here, to its flagship photo-finishing laboratory.

title: A PRAGMATIC CRUSADER: YURI FYODOROVICH ORLOV
description: In a remote village in Yakutia, one of Siberia's bleakest and coldest regions, Yuri F. Orlov has lived in often solitary exile.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
DROP IN GERMAN EXPORTS REPORTED
description: The West German machine-building industry, which makes everything from sewing machines to manufacturing plants, said today that the value of export orders booked in August fell 28 percent from the level a year before.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SHARP INCREASE IN BOND PRICES
description: Fresh economic data pointing to continued slow growth in the economy prompted a sharp rise of more than 1 point in Treasury bond prices and a flurry of new issues in the corporate bond market yesterday.

title: Consortium to Buy 52.6% of Cominco
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., a large diversified company in Montreal, said it would sell its 52.6 percent stake in Cominco Ltd., one of the world's largest producers of zinc and lead, to a consortium of mining companies and a group of investment firms for $472 million. A spokesman for Canadian Pacific said the company was selling the stake to reduce its dependence on world commodity cycles.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE OF COMPTROLLER CANDIDATES
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between two of the candidates for State Comptroller, the incumbent, Edward V. Regan, and the challenger, Herman Badillo:

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Beer-Distribution Bill Hurts Small Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TAPPING TALENT In recent times, the art of jazz tap-dance, which once routinely delighted vaudeville and other audiences, has made a comeback. Its firm footing with audiences that were not yet born during its heyday is exemplified by the arrival in town of the Jazz Tap Ensemble from Los Angeles. The troupe is appearing through Sunday at that Chelsea shrine of Terpsichore, the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street (242-0800).

title: GOVERNMENT SECRETLY TAPED FRIEDMAN'S ATTORNEY
description: The Government secretly recorded a conversation between Stanley M. Friedman's defense lawyer and a potential witness in the Federal corruption trial here, according to court papers released today.

title: MONTGOMERY SELLS STAKE TO PRITZKERS
description: Montgomery Securities, a leading West Coast investment banking firm, said today that it had sold a minority interest to a new investment partnership controlled by the Pritzker family, the wealthy Chicago family that controls the Hyatt Corporation, Braniff Inc. and other companies.

title: DONOVAN DEFENSE CALLS FRAUD CHARGES 'INSANE'
description: A defense lawyer yesterday assailed the motives of Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola for obtaining fraud indictments against former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and eight other men.

title: Red and Green Tamper Signals for Packages
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1986
description: International

title: FANTASIES IN WOOD
description: Tommy Simpson, the woodworker and sculptor, has always been a fantasist. He was going his own way more than 20 years ago while most contemporary woodworkers were still in the smooth, lean grip of Scandinavian modern design.

title: SPEAKERS IN THE U.N. DISTINGUISH TERRORISM AND 'LIBERATION' DRIVE
description: The Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, said today that his Government was ''against terrorism in every part of the world.''

title: Company Sold For 49 Cents
description: West German labor unions today sold a union-owned, debt-burdened real estate concern for one mark, or the equivalent of 49 cents, to a Berlin bakery owner.

title: Schlumberger Chairman Replaced
description: Schlumberger Ltd., in a surprise move, announced last night the election of Euan Baird to the posts of chairman, president and chief executive officer. Mr. Baird, who is 49 years old, will replace Michel Vaillaud in those posts.

title: JAZZ: WORKS FROM DOLPHY-LITTLE
description: HARD-BOP and free-bop from the turn of the 1960's are having a new heyday, but the music of the winds player Eric Dolphy (who died in 1964) and his frequent collaborator, the trumpeter Booker Little (who died in 1961), remains underdiscovered. Even now, their repertory sounds wayward and unsettling, with its sudden shifts of tempo and its wandering, dissonant tonalities. Yet a Dolphy revival may now be in the making, with new albums of vintage Dolphy material on GM Records and forthcoming on Blue Note. And this week at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, at Grove Street), three musicians from the Dolphy-Little quintet that recorded at the Five Spot in 1961 - the pianist Mal Waldron, the bassist Richard Davis and the drummer Ed Blackwell - are playing the group's repertory with two young horn players, the alto saxophonist Donald Harrison and the trumpeter Terence Blanchard.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: The share earnings reflect a 5-for-1 stock split June 20. The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Agnes Rogers Allen, 92, Dies; An Editor at Reader's Digest
description: Agnes Rogers Allen, an author and a founding editor of the Reader's Digest Condensed Books, died Sept. 5 at her home in Bergenfield, N.J. She was 92 years old.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The results reflect writedowns of $4,861,000 for the latest quarter and $19.3 million for 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1986
description: Companies

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $470,000.

title: CLEMEN'S PITCHING ARM INJURED
description: A meaningless game on the way to the American League playoffs may turn out to have substantial significance for the Boston Red Sox. In the second inning of tonight's game with the Baltimore Orioles, Roger Clemens, the team's leading pitcher and an almost certain Cy Young Award winner, was struck on the elbow of his pitching arm by a line drive off the bat of John Stefano, a reserve catcher for the Orioles.

title: 'LIKE COMING HOME AGAIN'
description: Monday afternoon's message to Phil McConkey was unusual.

title: NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE reports earnings for 12mo to Aug 31
description: b-After a writeoff of $94,843,000 related to the Bailly Nuclear Plant. c-Net income

title: Why Reagan Blinked
description: ''Let there be no talk of a trade for Daniloff,'' Secretary of State Shultz said at Harvard on Sept. 5. Well, there has been a trade. And the Reagan Administration, for all its tough talk, accepted terms significantly worse than Jimmy Carter got from the Russians in similar circumstances in 1978.

title: A LEGAL CURB RAISES HACKLES
description: Three years ago, amid growing concern that the litigation process was being abused, the judiciary toughened Rule 11, providing sanctions against frivolous litigation and overzealous lawyering.

title: Air Fare Increases
description: Delta Air Lines and Trans World Airlines confirmed that they would match fare increases planned by their major rivals, United Air Lines and American Airlines, on routes where they compete. The increases of about 5 percent take effect Thursday and are aimed largely at business travelers. They do not affect discount fares, which comprise the majority of airline business.

title: Koch Offers Regrets To a Whistleblower
description: Mayor Koch wrote yesterday to a taxicab company executive, saying he shared her distress that her 1982 complaints of corruption in the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission had not been pursued by the Department of Investigation.

title: Retired Veterans Urged To Become Educators
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger urged retired military personnel Monday to build on their experience in working with young people and enter second careers in education.

title: 2 HOUSES AGREE ON ASBESTOS CLEANUP FOR SCHOOLS
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a bill to require the cleanup of asbestos in the nation's schools.

title: PRETORIA OFFICIAL WARNS SENATORS OVER SANCTIONS
description: The South African Foreign Minister called Farm Belt Senators tonight and said Pretoria would cut off grain purchases from the United States if the Senate voted Thursday to override President Reagan's veto of a bill imposing economic sanctions on South Africa.

title: Hartman Will Leave ABC's Morning Show
description: David Hartman, who has been host or co-host of ABC's ''Good Morning America'' for 11 years, will leave the program by February, he said yesterday.

title: Little Shift In Yields
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed little change for the week ended yesterday.

title: Not Tax Tinkering, but Cuts in Military Budget; Pareto's Law
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Sept. 23, with a report in New York Day by Day about Nathan Hale Day, omitted the identity of a man beneath the Hale statue in City Hall Park. He was Robert N. McKay, president of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York, whose organization commissioned the statue.

title: BECK NOT PLANNING TO REJOIN RANGERS
description: The message from Barry Beck's former teammates is clear: If he doesn't want to be here, then it is just as well that he's not here. General Manager Phil Esposito feels the same way, but yesterday Esposito said that if Beck decided to return to the Rangers any time soon, he could.

title: SOME DESIGNS AND DESIGNERS REMATCHED AT BENTWOOD SHOW
description: EVER since Michael Thonet first bent wooden rods into furniture in the 1830's many designers have created masterpieces using this material or metal tubing. This is the message of the stunning exhibition ''Bent Wood and Metal Furniture: 1850-1946'' on view through Nov. 15 at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art.

title: METS VIEW VICTORY AS PLAYOFF PRACTICE
description: The Mets viewed tonight's 6-4 victory over the Expos in 10 innings as an excellent tune-up for the playoff series against Houston, which starts a week from tonight.

title: Capital Group Fills Post
description: Michael J. Johnston, who resigned in May as president of Paine Webber Capital Markets, the investment banking subsidiary of Paine Webber Group Inc., has joined Capital Group Inc., Capital Group said yesterday. He will be executive vice president in charge of fixed-income securities.

title: Scripps Deal Completed
description: The E. W. Scripps Company and the John P. Scripps Newspaper Group have announced the completion of their merger.

title: ANOTHER 'DENKINGER' CALL?
description: It's not perfect. And the National Football League's instant-replay system will never be perfect. For all the technology in his booth, a human ''replay official'' is reviewing the live network feed. But approaching the N.F.L.'s fifth week, nine calls have been reversed by instant-replay officials who ruled those on-the-field decisions to be indisputably incorrect. And that's progress.

title: Technology; Automation That's Flexible
description: MORGAN WHITNEY calls it his ''technological sandbox,'' a place for engineers to play. It is the Ford Motor Company's robotics and automation applications consulting center in Dearborn, Mich., where Mr. Whitney is director.

title: STOCKS WEAKENED IN QUARTER
description: Takeover and gold mining stocks, as well as a paint company that changed its stripes, a fishmeal producer and a Philippine sugar miller, emerged as the big winners on Wall Street during the third quarter.

title: KOCH DENOUNCES JUDGE FOR CURB ON HOTEL SHELTERS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday denounced a Manhattan judge who issued an order temporarily preventing the city from housing any more homeless people in midtown Manhattan.

title: 21ST GAME FOR CHESS TITLE IS ADJOURNED ON 41ST MOVE
description: Anatoly Karpov, challenging the world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, held a small advantage today at the adjournment of the 21st game of the match. The match is tied at 10 points.
