title: YALE CLEARS HOMOSEXUALS' FOE
description: A Yale University student who was disciplined earlier this year for violating university regulations by distributing a poster satirizing the university's annual Gay and Lesbian Awareness Days was cleared in a rehearing of the case yesterday.

title: Required Reading; Religion in Politics
description: In a speech at the University of Missouri, on Sept. 17, Education Secretary William J. Bennett criticized those who contend ''religious faith gives them a monopoly on political truth'' as engaging in ''invidious sectarianism.'' He cited the case of ''a public figure'' who ''recently said that Christians feel more strongly about love of country, love of God and support for the traditional family than do non-Christians.'' Such sectarianism should be ''renounced in the strongest terms,'' Mr. Bennett said.

title: New World Offers Sinking-Fund Issue
description: New World Pictures Ltd. is offering $215 million of speculative-grade sinking-fund debentures through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: POLITICIANS FIND A FLAW IN CUOMO ELECTION PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo's resistance to debating his Republican opponent reflects the classic strategy of a well-financed, popular incumbent, both Democratic and Republican politicians said yesterday.

title: A Top Savin Executive Moved Up to Chairman
description: The Savin Corporation, the manufacturer of office copiers, announced yesterday that David G. Sadler has been elected chairman of the troubled company. Mr. Sadler, who joined Savin in March, was already chief executive office and vice chairman.

title: BRITISH PRO-LABOR ECONOMIST
description: Nicholas Kaldor, an economist and longtime adviser to the British Labor Party, died yesterday at his home in Cambridge, England, his family said. He was 78 years old. An iconoclast whom John Kenneth Galbraith once described as ''the last of the economic innovators,'' Dr. Kaldor challenged much of the conventional wisdom of postwar economics. In recent years, he was a critic of the monetarist policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a Conservative.

title: JETS LOOK FOR IMPROVEMENT IN THEIR RUNNING GAME
description: Although they have been crawling inch by inch on the ground, the Jets have produced a 3-1 record with an often spectacular passing show.

title: Bond Rating Reductions By Moody's Exceed '85
description: Reductions in corporate bond ratings during the first nine months of this year exceeded the record level for all of 1985, and prospects are for a continuing trend toward lower ratings, Moody's Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday.

title:
Market Place;
New Offering Of Waste Unit
description: CHEMICAL and nuclear waste disposal is the fastest-growing segment of the waste-handling industry. Seeking to capitalize on this, Waste Management Inc., the giant disposal company, plans to spin off its hazardous-waste subsidiary this month.

title: Brewers' New Boss
description: The word ''interim'' was removed from the title of Manager Tom Trebelhorn yesterday as the Milwaukee Brewers named the former minor league manager to guide the team in 1987. The Brewers won three of their first four games after the 38-year-old Trebelhorn took over on an interim basis following the resignation of George Bamberger last Friday.

title: BUILDING SPENDING RISES 1.1%
description: Construction spending, powered by healthy increases in single-family homes and nonresidential building, jumped 1.1 percent in August for the fastest rise since April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR SIGNS BILL TO KEEP THE STATE SOLVENT
description: After nearly eight tumultuous weeks, two back-to-back special sessions of the Texas Legislature have finally come up with a compromise plan to keep the state treasury solvent.

title: FRONTIER LABOR ACCORD
description: Continental Air Lines and People Express Inc.'s Frontier Airlines unit said they had reached an employment agreement. The agreement provides for the pilots, flight attendants and air line employees associations to waive certain bankruptch claims against Frontier and People Express. If the pact is approved, Continental would hire up to 4,000 of the affected employees of Frontier, which ceased operations Aug. 24.

title: Veto the Veto
description: Grudgingly, President Reagan now endorses some of the very sanctions against South Africa that he vetoed last week, calling them ''incontestably necessary in today's circumstances.'' Since the main circumstance is the Senate's likely override of the veto, his compromise offers too little too late. The most powerful argument for the Senate to join the House in overriding is Mr. Reagan's failure to develop a sound strategy for registering America's abhorrence of a tyrannical racism.

title: MICHAEL BENNETT TO SELL STAGE AND DANCE SPACE
description: The director and choreographer Michael Bennett is selling the building he owns on lower Broadway, a move that could eliminate one of the city's most attractive rehearsal spaces, according to a close adviser to Mr. Bennett. The sale also would almost certainly force the relocation of two major dance companies and several theater-related businesses, all of which have enjoyed rents in the building that are far below market value.

title: Le Clip Watch Selects Biederman in the U.S.
description: Biederman & Company has become the United States ad agency for Le Clip, a Swiss-made watch that may be clipped to a place of your choice. According to Barry Biederman, the watch has already caught on in Switzerland, Britain, France and Spain, where 500,000 of them are expected to be sold this year.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. EXPOS, at Montreal, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Resorts Bid Ends
description: The Pratt Hotel Corporation withdrew its bid for control of Resorts International Inc. after trustees for the estate of Resorts' late chairman, James M. Crosby, did not respond to the offer by Tuesday's deadline. Pratt, the operator of the Sands Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, said it would drop the matter and not pursue a hostile tender offer for Resorts. A hostile offer was considered unlikely to succeed because the estate and the Crosby family own a huge block of Resorts stock.

title: FINDING THE PARTS FOR OLD FIXTURES
description: MANY New Yorkers live in prewar co-ops and apartments that still have the original bathroom fixtures. Proud as they may be of their oversize tubs, pedestal sinks and oval toilets, it can be a challenge to find fittings for repairs.

title: WOMEN OVER 40 CHOOSING LAW
description: AFTER 20 years of raising a family and serving as a volunteer in a variety of community organizations, 40-year-old Muriel G. Hubsher of Brooklyn was looking for a new challenge.

title: SPINKS REMAINS IN THE HBO SERIES
description: The rumors about Butch Lewis and Michael Spinks turned out to be within hailing distance of the truth.

title: A Contract Worth Millions
description: Borrowing a fixture of professional sports, high schools have devised a new tactic to combat the old problem of students' alcohol and drug use. A sprinkling of school districts across the nation have begun requiring that youths sign contracts, in which they agree to refrain from alcohol, drugs and tobacco as a condition of participating in athletics and other extracurricular activities.

title: SHABBY GRASS AND THE JOYS OF SPRINKLING
description: NO one has ever written more tellingly about it than James Agee in ''Knoxville:

title: Anti-crack Mural Will Rise Again
description: The artist Keith Haring did not mind so much going to court for his East Harlem mural ''Crack Is Wack'' or even the $25 fine for disorderly conduct, because he had made his statement.

title: Japan Toy Maker, Coleco in Pact
description: Coleco Industries said that it had signed a $62 million marketing, manufacturing and development agreement with the Tomy Kogyo Company of Tokyo, a privately owned toy company.

title: Allied-Lyons Unit Chairman
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C. said yesterday that it had named Charles E. Arnett chairman of Allied-Lyons North America, the parent company of Baskin-Robbins Ice Cream, Tetley Inc. and DCA Food Industries.

title: 2 AGENCIES FAULTED ON REACTOR SAFETY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the Tennessee Valley Authority both came under sharp criticism from House investigators today.

title: ROBERTSON'S TV NETWORK MARKS 25TH ANNIVERSARY
description: With fireworks and choirs and evangelical fervor, the Rev. Pat Robertson and his supporters celebrated the 25th anniversary of his Christian Broadcasting Network here today.

title: SOVIET LOOKING TO PROGRESS ON ARMS IN ICELAND SESSION
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that the Kremlin hoped the Iceland meeting with President Reagan would give a ''strong impulse'' to arms-control negotiations.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes a charge of $400,000 from the discontinuance of jobbing operations. The company said the year-ago quarter included 14 weeks and the previous year had 53 weeks.

title: PRESIDENT PRAISES CARTER AT LIBRARY
description: President Reagan came to Atlanta today to help dedicate Jimmy Carter's new Presidential library and museum, and he celebrated the man he defeated in 1980 as a President whose life and career ''is distinctively and gloriously American.''

title: FOR FLOORS, DESIGNER RUGS
description: LAST fall, Lau Aabling, president of EGE, a Danish rug company, invited 12 Danish artists to design rugs. Called Art Line, the collection is in three sizes.

title: Burlington Rail Upheld On Drug Testing
description: A Federal appeals court panel ruled today that the Burlington Northern Railroad Company could require employees involved in accidents or returning from seasonal furloughs to take a drug test.

title: UNDUE RISK IS SEEN IN NECK OPERATION
description: Most people with clogged arteries in the neck are in little danger of stroke, so a common operation to prevent stroke by relieving these blockages is unnecessary, a new study has concluded.

title: 'THERESE,' AN ACCOUNT OF LITTLE FLOWER OF JESUS
description: THERESE,'' Alain Cavalier's cool, unsentimental, astonishingly handsome consideration of the life of St. Therese of Lisieux (1873-1897), is a far cry from ''The Song of Bernadette.'' Here are no heavenly choirs, no visions bathed in celestial light, no skeptics suddenly transformed into believers by miraculous, not otherwise explicable phenomena.

title: 2 Die in Boating Mishap
description: Two participants in the New York Bassmaster Invitational were killed and a third was seriously injured when two boats collided on the Hudson River today, authorities said.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 14
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in March.

title: AIRBUS GETS BIG ORDER BY NWA
description: NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, said yesterday that it might buy as many as 100 planes from Airbus Industrie, for up to $3.2 billion.

title: Huntington Art Gallery Opens Again After Fire
description: After a yearlong, $1 million refurbishing project following a fire, the Huntington Art Gallery reopened today with its artworks meticulously cleaned of soot and stains.

title: Pakistan Says Hijackers Planned to Blow Up Jet
description: A Pakistani official said today that four gunmen who seized a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet last month may have been on a suicide mission, planning to blow up the plane in midair with 400 people aboard.

title: COURT UPHOLDS DEMOCRATIC PARTY ON CHOICE FOR ALABAMA GOVERNOR
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a judge's order for a second Democratic primary runoff in Alabama, leaving Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley as the party's nominee for Governor.

title: FOR RUTGERS, THE ULTIMATE TEST
description: For Harry Swayne and the rest of the Rutgers team, Saturday will mean three hours of opportunity against Penn State in Beaver Stadium.

title: An 'Official Language' For California?
description: Strange as it may seem, the people of California -the creators of Marinspeak and Valley Girl Talk - will vote this fall on a measure intended to protect the English language from baneful foreign influences. Proposition 63 would amend the state constitution to make English California's ''official language'' and to prevent state business from being transacted in other tongues.

title: A Scholar's Fresh Look At the Constitution
description: Although the bicentennial celebration of the United States Constitution is 11 months off, preparations for the event are in full swing at the New-York Historical Society.

title: CME-SAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW F.B.I. TEAM TRACING SOME UNAUTHORIZED DISCLOSURES TO PRESS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has formed a special team of agents to investigate disclosures of sensitive Government information to news organizations, and officials said the squad was at work on about a dozen cases.

title: BAKER SURE ON GLOBAL REVIVAL
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, the person most identified with American-led attempts to revive the world economy, noted some ''frustrations'' today in putting the programs to work, but said he was confident they would eventually succeed.

title: 'CUBA: IN THE SHADOW OF DOUBT,' ON 13
description: LET'S hear it now for the Cuban revolution, a fine adventure gone slightly astray, although not through any fault of Fidel Castro. ''Cuba: In the Shadow of Doubt'' pretends to be balanced - on the one hand this, on the other hand that, with friends and foes of Mr. Castro clashing. This is window dressing. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., sells a myth.

title: 15% of Elected City Officials Are Women, New Study Says
description: More than 15 percent of the mayors and city council members in cities over 10,000 people are women, the National League of Cities said Monday. That triples the figure of little more than a decade ago.

title: Snooping in Wisconsin
description: Comes now an intriguing tale of political snooping from the United States Senate campaign in Wisconsin.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company's share of Sea-Land Corp.'s loss totaled $3 million for the latest third quarter and $5 million for the latest 9 months.

title: Australia Given Names Of 40 Linked to Nazis
description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center for Holocaust Studies presented Foreign Minister William Hayden of Australia today with the names and addresses of 40 suspected Nazi war criminals believed to be living in Australia, as well as evidence against them, the center's director said.

title: LA GEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $2,295,000 related to litigation.

title: Franz Burda, Publisher, Dies; Built European Print Empire
description: Franz Burda, who took over a small family printing business in 1928 and built it into one of Europe's biggest publishing empires, died in Offenburg on Tuesday.

title: SHULTZ SAYS SOVIET FAILS TO STEM GULF ARMS FLOW
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that in his recent talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister the two men had agreed to seek an end to the Iran-Iraq war.

title: CHAMBERS FREED ON A BAIL BOND ON SLAYING CASE
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., the 20-year-old man charged with strangling Jennifer Dawn Levin on a knoll in Central Park, was released from jail on $150,000 bail yesterday.

title: U.S. PLAN AGAINST QADDAFI IS SAID TO INTENSIFY
description: The United States has intensified an extensive covert campaign to exploit what it believes are psychological weaknesses of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, according to Government officials familiar with the plans.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Net loss

title: C.B.O.E. Request on Futures
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the world's largest options exchange, will take steps by the end of the year to become a stock and futures exchange, its vice chairman, Gary Lahey, said today.

title: JOURNALISTS DIFFER ON THE LONG-TERM EFFECTS OF THE DANILOFF CASE
description: Although journalists welcomed the release of Nicholas S. Daniloff from Soviet custody, they have expressed widely differing views on the long-term effect of the incident and how it was handled.

title: NEW, STRICTER RULE ISSUED FOR TONY AWARDS
description: The Tony Awards administration committee has issued a new, stricter guideline concerning plays eligible for a Tony Award in the categories of best play and best musical.

title: Astronomical
description: If you were one of the legion of disappointed Met fans who got a busy signal when the last 9,000 playoff tickets were sold by telephone last Sunday, don't despair. There is still hope of seeing your team tangle with the Astros.

title: A GUIDE TO THE RESEEDING OF A LAWN
description: ALTHOUGH I got an early start in renewing my shabby lawn, which now looks so good from an upstairs window that it seems to have blown in from Oz, it's not too late for other gardeners in the Northeast to follow suit. Here are a few do's and and don'ts to consider.

title: 3 DIE IN SRI LANKA FIGHTING
description: Two Tamil separatist guerrillas and a soldier were killed today in fighting in Sri Lanka's eastern district of Trincomalee, a military spokesman said. He said the fighting erupted when the guerrillas, who are fighting for a separate Tamil state, fired at a military patrol at Nilaveli.

title: NEW PERSPECTIVE ON MIES IN CHICAGO
description: THE conventional way to mount a retrospective exhibition about the work of a great artistic figure is to approach him or her head-on - to try to look at a career in totality, often tracing it chronologically, moving in encyclopedic sweep from period to period, from work to work, in the hope that from all of this a great pattern will emerge. The ultimate example of such an exhibition in our time was surely the extraordinary Picasso show that the Museum of Modern Art mounted in 1979; similar in intention, if less overwhelming in scope, was the exhibition the Modern mounted last winter to commemorate the centennial of the birth of the architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe.

title: EXTRA AID TO THE PHILIPPINES LOSES TO ONE-TWO PUNCH
description: Last month, President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines made a speech before a joint meeting of Congress that was greeted with enthusiasm. Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said Mrs. Aquino had ''hit a home run.''

title: G.O.P. CONFIDENT
description: With just 35 days to the general election, Democrats in Florida today were worried about picking up the pieces after a bitter primary campaign that finally ended Tuesday when Steve Pajcic, a former legislator, edged State Attorney General Jim Smith to win the party's Smith to win the party's nomination for Governor.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alliance Capital Management Corp. said it would combine with another investment management firm, Calvin Bullock Ltd. Both companies are subsidiaries of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: SUSPENSION OF 13 OFFICERS PUTS 80 CRIMINAL CASES IN JEOPARDY
description: The suspension of 13 police officers accused of stealing from drug dealers in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn jeopardizes 80 criminal cases they were involved in, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Waldorf-Astoria
description: The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel has brought its advertising account back to New York from Washington and has asked its new agency, Kaufman & Maraffi, to promote its lodgings to corporate upper and middle management, who had previously been awed by the establishment. Soghigian & Macuga of Washington previously had the account. The ad budget is $1.2 million.

title: INTELLIGENT BUSINESS COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company reported no revenue in the year-ago third quarter because of a lack of shipments.

title: Earthquake Jolts San Diego
description: A light earthquake rumbled beneath the Pacific Ocean off southern California today, the second temblor there in two days, the United States Geological Survey said. The quake, which registered 3.9 on the richter scale, was centered about 40 miles northwest of San Diego and was felt in San Diego, Oceanside and parts of Orange County, according to a spokesman for the geological agency's offices in Reston, Va.There were no immediate reports of injury or damages.

title: First B-1 Bomber in Operation
description: The first B-1 bomber of the new fleet went on full-alert status today, marking the beginning of regular operation for the once-canceled plane since its resurrection five years ago.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WISE MEN: Six Friends and the World They Made. By Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas. Illustrated. 853 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Advanced Micro To Take Write-Off
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a leading semiconductor maker, said that it would take an extraordinary charge of $15 million to $20 million in the just-ended second fiscal quarter for costs associated with the consolidation of manufacturing operations.

title: Token Exchange Runs Its Course
description: The New York City Transit Authority announced yesterday that more than one million old Y-cutout and solid brass subway tokens had been exchanged last month and that there were no plans to extend the period.

title: U.S. 'INTERFERENCE' SHAPING UP AS BRITISH ISSUE
description: When Glenys Kinnock, the wife of the leader of the Labor Party, bumped into the American Ambassador at the party's annual conference here, she didn't try to hide her displeasure.

title: Temple-Inland
description: Temple-Inland Inc. is offering $70 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 8.412 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes, which are not callable before maturity, are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P. and yield about 1.02 percentage points more than 10-year Treasury notes.

title: Chinese Britannica
description: Culminating a project initiated six years ago by China and Encyclopedia Britannica, a new 10-volume version of the Britannica in Chinese will be unveiled here Oct. 7.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAPANESE ART A distinctly new look has taken over the galleries and the lobby of the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 71st Street (288-6400), where a big new exhibition, ''Art of Japan: Selections From the Burke Collection,'' opens today.

title: F.D.A. REPORT SPLITS ON EFFECTS OF SUGAR
description: Upholding a warning that dentists have sounded for years, the Food and Drug Administration says in a report by three staff scientists that sugar contributes to tooth decay.

title: LEOPOLD J. OBIEREK, LONGTIME ADVOCATE OF POLISH FREEDOM
description: Leopold J. Obierek, a Polish patriot and writer who devoted his life to freeing his country from foreign domination, died of a heart attack Monday at New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CABLE'S MAX HEADROOM, A TRUE MEDIA CREATION
description: MAX HEADROOM is selling out and enjoying every minute of it -while it lasts. Made in Britain, the computer-generated video host was first seen here 18 months ago. ''The Max Headroom Show'' made its debut on pay cable's Cinemax service. Today Max can be seen on Coca-Cola commercials and on the covers of splashily promoted publications: a picture book (Random House) and a ''Guide to Life'' (Bantam). In short, Max has become precisely the kind of media creation he set out to satirize. The contemporary hustle comes full circle.

title: Anxiety Drug Approved
description: A new drug that treats anxiety without causing drowsiness or impairing a person's ability to drive or work has won Food and Drug Administration approval.

title: FOR ZACCARO, TWO YEARS OF LIFE UNDER A MICROSCOPE
description: In the two years since his wife's historic Vice-Presidential campaign thrust him into the public spotlight, John Anthony Zaccaro has figured in an extraordinary array of investigations, charges and pleadings.

title: Sharpen Set-Asides, Don't Destroy Them
description: Set-asides are the provisions in Government contracts that reserve a portion of the business for minority members and women. Though well intentioned, abuses are now so rampant that some members of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights would suspend set-asides altogether. The problem is real, but that remedy is too drastic.

title: USX Stock Up; Rumors Cited
description: Shares of the USX Corporation rose yesterday in heavy trading as rumors circulated that Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, had resumed buying shares in the steel and oil company and may soon disclose his holdings.

title: OPTO MECHANIK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Not Tax Tinkering, but Cuts in Military Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Suns Sign Davis
description: Walter Davis, the Phoenix Suns' leading career scorer, signed a new two-year contract with an option for a third year yesterday and said it may be his last one. ''Three more years in the league, that'll give me 12 years and that's been my goal, to play 12 years,'' said Davis, who is 32 years old.

title: HERS
description: MY best friend sometimes dresses funny. And when she does I tell her so. For this she loves me, because she knows that when I turn up my nose at her $3.99 lace-up espadrilles, I am paying her the highest compliment: honesty. She knows that underlying my insult is the message that I love her enough to speak the truth.

title: ECLIPSE OF THE SUN TOMORROW TO BE VISIBLE ACROSS NATION
description: On Friday afternoon a partial eclipse of the Sun will be visible in most of the United States as the Moon passes between the Earth and the Sun and briefly turns the Sun into a thin crescent.

title: Assault by Nurse Brings 17-Year Term in Georgia
description: A nurse acquitted by a jury of killing six patients was sentenced to 17 years in prison today on her conviction for aggravated assault on another patient in her intensive care ward.

title: Pentagon Buzz
description: The word in Pentagon corridors is that Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman is the leading candidate to be the new Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the second-ranking military officer in the armed forces. The new position was established as part of the recently adopted Defense Reorganization Act.

title: MEXICO DEBT LINK SEEN AS PRECEDENT
description: Bankers said today that the Mexican lending agreement would set a precedent for debt talks with other nations.

title: REPORTER IN LIMELIGHT: DANILOFF IS ADJUSTING
description: The journey that brought Nicholas S. Daniloff from a Moscow prison to a meeting in the White House with President Reagan today has changed his life in ways that he says he is only beginning to fathom.

title: BASS TOURNAMENT DRAWS TOP ANGLERS
description: The Bass Angler's Sportsman Society has launched its 1986-1987 black bass tournament trail on the Hudson River. The three-day event - called the New York Bass-master Invitational - ends tomorrow afternoon. It is being held in Catskill, N.Y., and some 250 fishermen are competing for $127,500 in prizes and cash awards.

title: UNITED SERVICES ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $374,998 for the quarter and $407,040 for the year. c-Net income

title: DRUG WAR VS. DEFICIT: THE SENATE BLINKS
description: Only a playwright with a devilish sense of humor could have invented the scene that took place Tuesday on the floor of the Senate, when two of the senators' most urgent political priorities crashed headlong into one another.

title: Help for Vaccine Victims and Makers
description: Of the three million American infants vaccinated for whooping cough each year, some 40 suffer brain damage. That is because the vaccine that immunizes the millions inevitably harms a handful.

title: SECURITY AT PARIS SHOWS A CENCERN
description: THE part of the American fashion industry that is leaving for Europe this week is worrying about more than which designers will have the best collections this season. The wave of terrorist bombings last month in Paris, which left 10 people dead and 160 injured, has cast a shadow over the scheduled showings of the French spring and summer fashion collections.

title: JURY SEES FOOTAGE OF DEATHS FROM 'TWILIGHT ZONE'
description: The jury in the manslaughter trial arising from the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' went to a theater today to view film of the helicopter crash that killed the actor Vic Morrow and two children.

title: ENVIROMENTAL'S SECURITIES ISSUES
description: The Environmental Treatment and Technologies Corporation is offering debt and equity securities through underwriters led by Allen & Company.

title: IN BRONX, A PRIMER ON DAYS OF AWE
description: Gone are the children who once sat around their tables. Gone are the days spent in the market selecting the freshest carp and the plumpest chickens.

title: Packers Sign Fusina
description: Although the struggling Green Bay Packers announced the signing of Chuck Fusina, the former Baltimore and Philadelphia Stars quarterback, yesterday, the club said it had not abandoned the pursuit of another United States Football League quarterback, Doug Flutie, the former Generals player who won the 1984 Heisman Trophy. ''We saw in Doug Flutie the same thing we saw in college,'' said Coach Forrest Gregg.

title: Toast and Relish
description: Earnest Jackson, whom Buddy Ryan dropped from the Philadelphia roster last month, holding aloft a soft-drink can after averaging 4 yards a rush and throwing the block that sprang the Steelers' winning touchdown against the Oilers: ''This, Bud, is for you.''

title: EXECUTIVE TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss Figures for latest quarter and 9 months include results for Potomac Financial Equities Inc., acquired May 17.

title: U.S.F.L. Case Ruling Is Set
description: The Federal judge who presided in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League this summer told attorneys for both sides yesterday that he would rule today on motions to set aside various elements of the verdict.

title: Tommy Reynolds, Clarinetist And Band Leader, Dies at 69
description: Tommy Reynolds, a clarinetist and band leader, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: REMARKS BY THE PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan at the dedication of the Carter Presidential Center here today:

title: BID TO RECONSIDER ALIEN BILL BLOCKED
description: Republicans made a surprise move today to bring a comprehensive immigration bill to the floor of the House of Representatives, but Democrats blocked the effort after an impassioned debate.

title: FINE YEAR IN METS' BROADCAST BOOTH, TOO
description: The 1986 Mets have treated their followers to a memorable year, and not only on the playing field. For as good as the team has been, the television broadcast crew has been its equal.

title: STRIKE SHUTS OVER A DOZEN PORTS IN EAST
description: A strike by 30,000 longshoremen yesterday idled more than a dozen ports from Maine to Virginia in the first industrywide walkout against East Coast shipping companies since 1971.

title: New York Could Gain A Beautiful Skyscraper
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK LOANS IN '87 PREDICTED BY BRAZIL
description: Brazil, the third world's biggest debtor - yet one of its fastest-growing economies - predicts that commercial banks will resume lending to it voluntarily next year, Finance Minister Dilson Domingos Funaro said today.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes net gain of $1,172,000, or 20 cents a share, from the sale and leaseback of a manufacturing facility, and a related extraordinary tax credit of $622,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: A.T.&T. Computer Price
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company said it is cutting the price of its PC 6300 Plus personal computer by 24 to 30 percent to better position it in the market. That will bring the price closer to personal computers sold by such competitors as I.B.M. and Compaq. The new prices will range from $3,025 to $3,775, depending on the model. A.T.&T. has also lowered its price of the color monitor for the PC 6300 and the PC 6300 Plus by 16 percent, bringing that price down to $795 from $945, effective through December.

title: DOUBLEDAY'S DECLINE: WHAT WENT AWRY
description: Almost a week after a West German publisher agreed to buy Doubleday & Company, thereby ending three generations of family ownership, authors and editors are still asking what happened to a publishing house that until recently was one of the premier publishers in the world.

title: INDIAN PRIME MINISTER UNHURT
description: A man fired three shots this morning near Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and other leading Indian dignitaries at a public ceremony, but Mr. Gandhi was not hurt.

title: Bridge; Study of Suit Combinations Is Still Making Discoveries
description: One might think that in a century or so of bridge playing the experts would know all there is to be known about suit combinations. Twenty-three years ago, 656 of them were analyzed in detail for ''The Encyclopedia of Bridge'' by the British authority Eric Crowhurst.

title: Losing Battle
description: When the National Conference of Editorial Writers convened in Charleston, S.C., last week, it planned to present an array of important speakers. One of those invited was former President Richard M. Nixon. Mr. Nixon accepted, but imposed a condition: no ''working press.''

title: British to Buy Pension Firm
description: The Guinness Peat Group, a British financial services concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Forstmann-Leff Associates, a New York money management company, for a package of cash, notes and shares valued at almost $100 million.

title: A DISSIDENT IS ANXIOUS ABOUT EXIT
description: ''He never wanted to emigrate,'' Irina L. Valitova said today of her husband, Yuri F. Orlov, trying to explain the crosscurrents of joy, anticipation and wistfulness that have buffeted her since she learned that they were the two dissidents chosen to leave by Oct. 7 under a Soviet-American accord.

title: FIAT VOWS COUNTEROFFER
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had offered to link up with Alfa-Romeo, Italy's state-owned car maker, presumably by acquiring a substantial interest. Fiat S.p.A. immediately stated that it was preparing a counteroffer.

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $526,387 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: DOTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTONS
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Margaret M. Heckler, the United States Ambassador to Ireland, misidentified two officials with whom she was talking. They were Barry Desmond, the Irish Minister of Health, and Peter Barry, the Foreign Minister.

title: EX-DEPUTY IN CITY AGENCY RECALLS HIS FIRST BRIBE
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the former deputy director of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau, told a Federal jury today how he took his first bribe - a plain white envelope containing $500 in cash placed in his hands by a former city commissioner wearing a bathrobe.

title: Allons, Enfants, to the Linguistic Barricades
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt Opposition Parties Boycott an Election
description: Egypt's five legal opposition parties boycotted an election for a Government advisory body today, as President Hosni Mubarak urged citizens to vote ''for the sake of democracy.''

title: Reagan's Other Cheek
description: ''There was no connection between these two releases,'' insisted President Reagan to the belief of nobody.

title: BIRTHDAY GIFT FOR REYKJAVIK
description: The first Icelander to get the news was Prime Minister Steingrimur Hermannsson. The Soviet and American Ambassadors visited him separately Monday morning to ask if his country would serve as host to the talks this month between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: 2 BARFIELD HOMERS TOP GUIDRY
description: In the game that might have been Ron Guidry's last as a Yankee pitcher, Don Mattingly stroked two hits last night in his pursuit of Wade Boggs for the American League batting title. Mattingly thought one of the hits would be a double that would aid him in his pursuit of Lou Gehrig for the Yankee season record, but Jesse Barfield thwarted that thought.

title: CANDELA LASER reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CONFEREES REACH AGREEMENT ON BILL FOR INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES
description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a bill that sets spending limits for United States intelligence agencies, leaving intact a Senate amendment that the Central Intelligence Agency asserts is an unwarranted interference.

title: August Factory Orders Show Large 1.4% Drop
description: Orders to United States factories in August took their biggest plunge in five months as demand for military equipment plummeted and American manufacturers continued to be battered by foreign competition, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ZACCARO INDICTED IN CABLE TV CASE BY JURY IN QUEENS
description: John A. Zaccaro was indicted yesterday on criminal charges by a grand jury investigating allegations of bribery in the awarding of cable television franchises in Queens.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: OCT. 2, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. And 3 P.M.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 17
Maureen Reagan Visits Africa
description: President Reagan's daughter Maureen arrived in Marxist-ruled Mozambique today for a brief visit at the invitation of President Samora Machel, the Portuguese radio reported. The radio said Miss Reagan was traveling around Africa for a United Nations mission studying the problems of women worldwide. She was met at Maputo airport by the Deputy Foreign Minister, Carlos Lobo, and the head of the Organization of Mozambican Women, Salome Moiane.

title: IN SCOTLAND, A COMPOSER'S 85-ROOM RETREAT
description: WHEN the composer Gian Carlo Menotti was in the market for a second house, the kind of place where he could write music, spend Christmas and eventually retire, he had one big requirement - ''perfect silence.''

title: COMPUTERS FALTER BUT PAN AM SHUTTLE MAKES DEBUT
description: The ticketing machines were down but the planes were up as nearly 3,000 passengers braved computer glitches yesterday to inaugurate the Pan Am Shuttle's new hourly service between New York, Boston and Washington.

title: DEBATE ON ARMS TURNING SHARPER IN THE CONGRESS
description: The announcement of the meeting in Iceland between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev has polarized the arms control battle in Congress, House and Senate leaders said today.

title: Carolina Controversy
description: Strong words are flying in South Carolina politics between Lee Atwater, a strategist for Vice President Bush, and Samuel Tenenbaum, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser and civic leader.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I have a plaster statue that had the arm broken off cleanly at the shoulder. Any ideas on how I can repair it? A.A two-part clear epoxy adhesive will work, but most of these are amber in color so the glue line or crack may still show. If so, touch it up with a flat white paint so it will be hardly noticeable. The new two-part ''instant'' adhesives, such as Depend (there are other brands), may be better. With those, brush part A on one piece and part B onto the second. The adhesive is not activated until the two come together. The glue line is then hardly visible.

title: MORE THAN GRIEF FOR TRANSKEI KIN OF DEAD MINER
description: For the last five years or so, Nowebile Ntoba has been used to seeing her son Nkosinam just once a year. That was when he returned from his job in the mines to visit for a month at the end of a contract.

title: Mary Mercy Hirschboeck, 83, Maryknoll Sister and Doctor
description: Sister Mary Mercy Hirschboeck, of the Maryknoll Sisters, who as a physician administered Maryknoll clinics in Korea and Bolivia, died Sept. 20 at the Maryknoll Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. She was 83 years old.

title: Washington Post Faces Suit Charging Abuse of Overtime
description: Five employees of The Washington Post sued the newspaper today in United States District Court, charging it violated Federal labor law by refusing to pay cash or premium wages for overtime work and, in some instances, gave no compensation for overtime.

title: DESIGN ON A BUDGET: ONE STUDIO, TWO POINTS OF VIEW
description: THAT all good things in New York are expensive all the time is a commonly shared apprehension - especially among those setting out to furnish an apartment. Two young design firms, however, recently dispelled the notion when they both furnished the same studio, as an experiment, at a reasonable price, buying at shops and department stores accessible to any New Yorker.

title: THEATER: COMIC RUSES IN 'ATLANTIC CITY LOST'
description: IN writing ''Atlantic City Lost,'' playing at the Quaigh Theater, Sidney Eden seems to have assumed that the secret of comedy is the systematic perversion of poetic justice. Here the harmless are victimized and the predatory are rescued from vengeance. There are a few laughs in it, but on the whole this comedy has no sting and produces no honey.

title: New Publisher Named At Esquire Magazine
description: W. Randall Jones, 30 years old, has been promoted from vice president and ad director at Esquire to publisher, replacing Orlin (Chick) Davis, 48, who had had the job since March. Mr. Davis will be moving to a corporate job at the Esquire Magazine Group, where he will be involved in developing special projects.

title: Judicial Pow
description: Now that he has been confirmed after a long and bitter battle, Federal Appeals Judge Daniel A. Manion says the job itself was not worth the trouble, but the prospect of going after liberals is.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Borden's President Promoted to Chief
description: Borden Inc., a diversified company in consumer products and specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it had named R. J. Ventres chief executive, effective Nov. 1, and chairman, effective Feb. 1.

title: Emergency Food Airlift Is Postponed in Sudan
description: An emergency airlift that was to begin delivering food and medicine to starving civilians in the southern Sudan was postponed today for at least one day, according to sponsors of the airlift.

title: CBS TELLS F.C.C. THAT CONTROL HAS NOT CHANGED
description: CBS Inc. attempted to assure the Government yesterday that control of the company had not transferred with the recent departure of Thomas H. Wyman as chairman.

title: BLACK MINERS IN SOUTH AFRICA PROTEST
description: More than a quarter of a million black mineworkers stayed away from their jobs today to mourn the 177 men killed last month in South Africa's worst gold-mining disaster.

title: Kentucky Chicken
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it and Pepsico Inc. closed the previously announced sale of Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation to Pepsico for about $840 million.

title: Museum Director Retiring
description: Jan Fontein, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, has announced that he will retire from the directorship, effective in the summer of 1987.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Tom Trebelhorn, manager, to one-year contract.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PLYWOOD is still one of the most popular materials for all kinds of projects around the home, from a new doghouse to a large built-in wall unit. The panels are strong and relatively stable, although they will warp under certain conditions if not supported or fastened down around the edges.

title: PHILIPPINE ARREST IMPERILS PEACE TALKS
description: The arrest by the military of a top Communist leader appeared today to have jeopardized the cease-fire talks on which President Corazon C. Aquino has based her counterinsurgency policy.

title: JAPAN CAR MAKERS ASK END OF CURB ON U.S. SALES
description: Japan's auto makers have called on the Government to end the country's voluntary restraints on automobile exports to the United States when the fiscal year ends next March, a Government official said today.

title: GNI INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $76,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $344,000.

title: Record Fine For Trader
description: Conticommodity Services Inc., a former futures trading unit of the Continental Grain Company, agreed yesterday to settle two lawsuits against it by paying $1.5 million, the largest civil penalty ever assessed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Settlement Is Imposed In 7-Month Rail Dispute
description: President Reagan on Tuesday signed into law a measure imposing a contract settlement in the seven-month dispute between the Maine Central Railroad and a union representing track maintenance workers.

title: EXPERTS AT SHAKING THE MEDIA TREE
description: When the Federal Communications Commission recently disavowed its policies favoring women and racial minorities in the awarding of broadcast licenses, one of the first to protest was Pluria W. Marshall.

title: Citicorp Unit Chairman Quits
description: Citicorp, which has seen a number of its top investment banking officials resign to take more lucrative positions elsewhere, has lost another.

title: STRIKE DISRUPTS DOCKS IN NEW YORK
description: A shipping terminal vice president ran a crane to lower a gangway, many passengers on the Queen Elizabeth 2 carried their own baggage and a banana boat bobbed in New York Harbor - not sure where to drop its cargo - as 7,600 longshoremen in New York and New Jersey joined their union brothers yesterday on picket lines at 11 East Coast ports.

title: SIZE OF SOVIET MISSION AT U.N. AN ISSUE FOR ICELAND
description: When President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Iceland, they are expected to deal with the issue of whether the United States can dictate the size and makeup of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: Dow Rises 15.32; Trading Is Heavier
description: Trading volume increased dramatically on Wall Street yesterday, as stock prices, despite some last-hour selling pressure, rose for the second consecutive day.

title: CALENDAR: ANTIQUES, CARPETS AND CRAFTS
description: Cabinetmakers and Collectors. The Rhode Island School of Design Museum of Art, 224 Benefit Street (near Waterman Street), Providence, R.I., 401-331-3511.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: RIDING HILLS AT HOME
description: THE trouble with riding a bicycle indoors is walls. Just when winter cycling enthusiasts begin to pick up speed, they hit them. A stationary bicycle solves this problem well enough, but there is little excitement left in the ride.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY EWAZEN
description: LIKE many composers of his generation, Eric Ewazen is an eclectic. However, as a Monday evening program of Mr. Ewazen's music at Merkin Concert Hall made clear, he has managed to synthesize a distinct, and often appealing, voice from his influences.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income Results for the latest 9 months include a pre-tax gain of $1,236,396 from the sale of assets, and a loss of $2,551,469 from Chapter 11 damages. The year-ago 9-month results include a pre-tax gain of $223,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Tax Issue in Alabama
description: Back in June, Charles Graddick, the Alabama Attorney General, accused Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley, his rival for the state's Democratic nomination for Governor, of failing to pay some of his state income taxes. It was a curious allegation by the state's chief law-enforcement officer, given that state income tax returns are by law confidential.

title: A Seasonable Reason To Recall Jake Pitler
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Striking Winery Workers Vote Anew on Contract
description: Striking California wine workers, facing the loss of their jobs if they are not back at work by Monday, were voting again today on a contract offer they overwhelmingly rejected earlier.

title: Rates Steady in a Quiet Day
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, as the lack of conviction about future changes in the economy continued to deter many investors and speculators.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Go, Bo
description: Bo Schembechler, whose Michigan team meets Wisconsin this Saturday, needs only one more victory to become the 14th head college football coach ever to post 200.

title: Not Tax Tinkering, but Cuts in Military Budget; France Tried It
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman Lear Acquires A Second Magazine
description: Norman Lear's Act III Communications has acquired a majority interest in Marketing and Media Decisions magazine.

title: To Honor Aquino's Investment Needs
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines won the hearts of the American people during her visit to the United States, but she failed to achieve her chief objective - enlisting American investors to put their capital to work in rebuilding her nation's ravaged economy. United States Government assistance and trade agreements cannot make up for the lack of private capital. Yet such aid could help her develop a political climate that would attract foreign investors in the future. Against this background, the Senate's rejection Monday of a $200 million aid package seems shortsighted in the extreme.

title: 294 PROTECTED BIRDS ARE SEIZED IN L.I. RAID
description: Federal wildlife agents, in a raid on a Long Island taxidermist's home, have made what they called the largest seizure of endangered and protected migratory birds in the United States in recent history - 294 birds in all, the agents said yesterday.

title: NBC OFFICIAL FORESEES REASSESSMENT
description: Robert C. Wright, NBC's new president, said yesterday that while its current ratings success gives the network some latitude, the same issues of stalled income growth and viewership decline that have forced severe cutbacks at ABC and CBS will prompt a reassessment of the way NBC does business, as well.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''For myself, I can pay no higher honor than to say simply this: You gave of yourself to your country, gracing the White House with your passion and intellect and commitment.''

title: Siemens-GTE Deal
description: Siemens Communication Systems Inc., a unit of Siemens A. G. of West Germany, said that it had purchased the foreign and domestic transmission systems of the GTE Corporation for $420 million. The sale, which also includes GTE's international switching and business systems, consummates a previously announced joint venture between the two companies to make telecommunications equipment. A new company called Siemens Transmission Inc. will result from the sale and will be owned 80 percent by Siemens, the remainder by GTE.

title: A JAPANESE SHRINE TO HENRY MOORE
description: A Japanese art patron who has purchased 18 sculptures by Henry Moore will create a sculpture garden devoted to the artist's work in an open-air museum outside of Tokyo.

title: TEXAS AIR CLEARS 2 TAKEOVER HURDLES
description: The Texas Air Corporation's takeover of Eastern Airlines won final Government approval today, and Texas Air's plan to buy People Express Inc. moved a step forward when the Justice Department said it would not object to the purchase on antitrust grounds.

title: Citicorp Bonds
description: Citicorp is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1993 at a price of 101 1/8 through Morgan Stanley International. The seven-year bonds are callable beginning in 1990 at a price of 100.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After some round-the-clock negotiations and an ultimatum from Mayor Vincent C. Schoemehl Jr., Harry Ornest agreed early yesterday to the sale of the St. Louis Blues for $19 million to a group of investors led by Michael Shananan, a local businessman. Ornest also agreed to the sale of The Arena to the city's Land Clearance for Redevelopment Authority for an additional $15 million. . . . Wes Hopkins, the Philadelphia Eagles' All-Pro safety, will miss the rest of the season.

title: SAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $300,000 from arbitration of a royalty dispute.

title: Bicyclists Discouraged on Washington Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Newsweek Quarterly Is Healthy
description: NEXT to getting promoted, there is nothing that tickles a magazine publisher quite as much as making money out of recycled material. Unless it's high readers per copy. Or, perhaps, the elimination of costly subscription solicitation.

title: A Corruption Informer Is Accused of a Murder
description: The police in Florida have filed first-degree murder charges against Michael Burnett, the convicted swindler and Federal informer who played a role in setting off the investigation of corruption in New York City's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Nets Close on Woolridge
description: Talks aimed at bringing Orlando Woolridge, the high-scoring free-agent forward, to the Nets in time for the opening of training camp tomorrow at Princeton University continued yesterday.

title: Chairman Of Blair Named
description: Henry R. Silverman, a senior vice president of Reliance Group Holdings Inc. and chief executive of its Reliance Capital Group unit, was named chairman yesterday of John Blair & Company, which Reliance acquired in August after a long takeover battle.

title: RESCUE PLAN FOR MEXICO VIEWED AS NO CURE-ALL
description: Mexico's financial rescue package is unlikely to end its economic troubles, according to economists, bankers and financial analysts.

title: A Drug Bill Dialogue, Overheard
description: This war on drugs will turn out to be expensive. Helicopters, radar balloons, more Federal agents and police, treatment programs, education . . . It could cost a billion or two every year. Where's the money going to come from?

title: Q-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $177,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
A MUSEUM ILLUSTRATES PERILS OF ALCOHOLISM
description: Maxine's singing career is in the hands of children at a Boston Museum of Science exhibit: Push one button and a sober Maxine belts out a song that delights a talent agent; push another and a drunken Maxine slurs the words.

title: Sheriff in Tennessee Indicted on Drug Charge
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a sheriff and his top investigator today on charges of protecting drug dealers and conspiring to sell drugs.

title: Not Tax Tinkering, but Cuts in Military Budget; Share the Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. HOPES TO USE MEETING IN ICELAND TO SPUR ARMS PACT
description: Administration officials said today that they hoped to use the talks in Iceland next week between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to spur arms control agreements at a full-scale summit meeting in the United States.

title: 3 U.S. BIDS CHOSEN BY KOREANS
description: South Korea's state-owned electric power company has provisionally chosen plans submitted by three American companies to equip and service the two nuclear power plants it intends to build by the mid-1990's.

title: INSIDE
description: Asbestos Cleanup Bill House and Senate negotiators agreed on a bill to require the cleanup of asbestos in schools and to set up exposure standards.

title: FRANCE CANCELS ALL POLICE LEAVES AMID FEAR OVER NEW TERROR RAIDS
description: For the first time in 18 years, the French Government has canceled all police leaves amid warnings by senior Government officials that a new wave of terrorist attacks could begin here soon.

title: Jackson Loses His No-Hit Bid
description: Danny Jackson of Kansas City pitched a no-hitter for eight innings against the California Angels tonight, but had to settle for a two-hit, 2-0 shutout victory. Jackson struck out five and walked three.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: FOR the last year, Nam June Paik has regularly sent a team of studio assistants to junkyards across the United States. The assignment: to find old televisions and buy them in bulk. It was an updated version of quarrying, for Mr. Paik then used the sets as material for sculpture.

title: Only Bolivians Starve in Bolivia's Recovery
description: To the Editor:

title: KLM Names President
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said today that its vice president, Jan de Soet, 61 years old, would succeed Sergio Orlandini as president.

title: 'Variety of Sects'
description: To the Editor:

title: RATES MIXED IN CAUTIOUS DAY
description: Interest rates were mixed in quiet trading yesterday, declining for short-term issues and rising a bit for long-term bonds.

title: Help for Help I and the Homeless
description: For the sake of politics and the obstructionism of New York City's building-trades unions, 200 homeless families will have to spend this winter in wretched welfare hotels or crowded shelters instead of a clean, safe hostel in Brooklyn.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Products Corp., Chicago, has promoted its president, Richard Drexler, to chief executive, succeeding Lloyd A. Drexler, who will remain chairman of the executive committee. It also named Charles W. Lunger executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Economic Scene; New Problems Loom at I.M.F.
description: THE man who has guided the global monetary system through eight of its most turbulent years told this week's conference of the world's top financial officials: ''This is the last time that I will be attending the annual meetings as managing director of the International Monetary Fund.'' Jacques de Larosiere said he had decided to leave his position by the end of 1986 ''to keep the period of transition as short as possible.''

title: CARMEN DERUE
description: Carmen DeRue, a child star of the early silent screen, died of a heart attack Sunday.

title: MICRO BIO-MEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Lies Wound America, Not Libya
description: On Aug. 14, the White House endorsed a secret plan to spread lies that might rattle Colonel Qaddafi of Libya and finally provoke his long-desired overthrow. According to a memorandum first disclosed by The Washington Post, the idea was to ''combine real and illusionary events - through a disinformation program - with the basic goal of making Qaddafi think that there is a high degree of internal opposition to him within Libya, that his key trusted aides are disloyal, that the U.S. is about to move against him militarily.''

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
AUCTIONS
description: THE largest auction in New York of Viennese decorative arts dating from 1900 to 1930 will be held Oct. 11 at 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. The 135 works up for bidding include furniture, silver, glass, jewelry and posters by most of the major architects, designers and artists of the period - Josef Hoffmann, Koloman Moser, Oskar Kokoschka, Otto Wagner and Dagobert Peche.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IN ''Menage,'' the new film by Bertrand Blier, Michel Blanc plays a down-on-his-luck Frenchman - in love with a wife who despises him - who is slowly seduced by a burly energetic thief who sets out to teach him how to enjoy life. Mr. Blanc won the best actor prize at Cannes for his portrayal of Antoine, the downtrodden little man who fights to hold on to his heterosexuality with the nervous tenacity of a fox terrier and is finally overwhelmed by a homosexual passion that transforms his idea of who he is. By the end, when Antoine dresses as a woman to go dancing, the audience sees something more than the usual scene in which a man dons a woman's clothing. Nor is Mr. Blanc playing a transvestite. He actually took it upon himself to attempt to play a woman.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: N.C.A.A. to Lift Ban at Florida
description: The University of Florida was officially notified by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today that the school's football program would be taken off probation after this season.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Subway Series!
description: What, you didn't know about the Subway Series this fall? Sure, it's at the Museum of Broadcasting on East 53d Street, which is screening the sixth and seventh games of the 1952 Series, between the Yanks and the Dodgers.

title: OIL CONCERN REPLACES CHAIRMAN
description: Michel Vaillaud was ousted as chairman and chief executive of Schlumberger Ltd. because some members of the Schlumberger family were anxious to wield greater power over the huge oilfield services concern, sources close to the company said yesterday.

title: IDAHOANS CALM IN FACE OF BOMBINGS
description: While the authorities say they have no suspects and are still looking for clues, residents of Coeur d'Alene seem to have resolved not to be frightened by four bomb explosions in two weeks, three in one day.

title: Global Celebration Of Music on Channel 13
description: The Spanish Steps in Rome, Cardiff Castle in Wales, Peter the Great's summer palace in Leningrad, a music barge in Brooklyn, the Greek Theater in Tindari, Sicily, - all serve as scenic co-stars behind the performers in ''The Night of Music: A Global Celebration.'' The two-hour music and dance program, tonight at 9 on Channel 13, opens this season's ''Great Performances'' series on a high note - a very high note, in fact, since the whole show was achieved by satellite.

title: LATE GOLD CUP ENTRANT MAY SET THE PACE
description: By 10 o'clock yesterday morning, only five horses had been entered for the $850,500 Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park tomorrow. By noon there was a sixth, and the complexion of the race had changed drastically.

title: Unesco Official Resigns And Assails Leadership
description: In a public letter of resignation circulated here, Unesco's former legal director has accused the organization's Director General, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, of waging ''a private war'' against the United States and Britain.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND ITS NEWS
description: In considering ''disinformation'' as a means to undermine the Libyan leader, the Reagan Administration has not only risked damage to its credibility but also cast doubt over its news policy.

title: General Pinochet's War on the Poor
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean dictator, responded to the failed attempt on his life last month by unleashing new spasms of official violence. The victims include human rights advocates, moderate opposition parties and the people of Santiago's slums.

title: Bridge: Zedtwitz Double Knockout Has Postponed Conclusion
description: The postponed conclusion of the 1985-86 Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship came Tuesday night, barely avoiding an overlap with the 1986-87 event. Entries for the 1986-87 event are to close Oct. 15 and information can be obtained by calling Ira Herman at (212) 679-6105.

title: HARM TO PEACE TALKS SEEN
description: The Government charged a captured Communist leader with rebellion today and shrugged off protests by his comrades that his continued detention could harm peace talks.

title: EX-HOME STATE OFFICIALS FACE FEDERAL CHARGES
description: Marvin L. Warner, former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, and Burton M. Bongard, former president of Home State, were indicted today on Federal charges of conspiracy and fraud relating to the Cincinnati thrift institution's investments with a collapsed Florida securities dealer.

title: China's Sidelines Policy
description: The impending Soviet-American mini-summit puts China on the sidelines for the time being, and officials here indicate that it is just fine with them. All foreign policy now derives from the central focus on economic development, which means China is looking for enough stability and peace in the world not to complicate its efforts.

title: Fall Harvest
description: So the major leagues go two years without a no-hitter, and then they get a pair of them, by Joe Cowley and Mike Scott, within a week. And both come in September. Hmm.

title: DECISION REACHED ON SHUTTLE TESTS
description: The space agency said today that it would test the new booster rockets for the space shuttle by firing them horizontally rather than in the vertical position suggested as a possibility by the Presidential commission that investigated the Challenger disaster.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS ACCUSED OF DECEIVING PRESS ON LIBYA
description: The Reagan Administration faced a growing controversy today over reports that it had made selective disclosures of news and ''disinformation'' about Libya and its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Scott Misses 2d No-Hitter
description: Bill Doran led off the 10th inning with a home run to give Houston a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today in a game that saw Mike Scott of the Astros make a bid for his second consecutive no-hitter.

title: THE ADMINISTRATION DENIES PLANTING REPORTS IN THE U.S.
description: The White House denied today that it had planted false reports with American news organizations as a means of bringing pressure on the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. At the same time, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said President Reagan had approved in mid-August a policy of unspecified steps to discourage the Libyan leader from conducting terrorist attacks against the United States.

title: 'Action: Terminated': False Alarm at City Hall
description: The entire City Council, the Council staff, the City Clerk's office and the Office of Economic Development lost their jobs yesterday.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the sales figures for 1985 are restated to reflect the sales net of sales discounts to conform to the 1986 presentation.

title: FOR FORMER METS, DREAMS OF WHAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN
description: Their time in New York was defined by the presence of a mule. Even after the Mets were sold and the new management gave the old mascot its unconditional release and began the building process, the fact remained that the Met bandwagon had fallen into such disrepair that its entire membership could have been powered by sad little Mettle the Mule, the symbol of a not-so-amazing era.

title: WEISS HOSPITALIZED IN CAPITAL
description: Representative Theodore S. Weiss was flown by helicopter to a hospital tonight after suffering chest pains at a Capitol Hill reception, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Pulaski Day Parade
description: For 49 years, Polish-Americans have marched in bands and ridden atop floats along Fifth Avenue in the annual Pulaski Day Parade. The tradition continues on Sunday with the 50th edition of the parade, which begins at 1 P.M. at Fifth Avenue and 26th Street. It will move up the avenue to 52d Street, where it will turn east to Third Avenue and disband.

title: JOB DESCRIPTION
description: Despite all rumors to the contrary, there are some things in the White House that are not known to the chief of staff, Donald T. Regan. Anthony Dolan, the President's chief speech writer, was chatting with a new employee in the corridor when Mr. Regan walked by. ''I'm telling Nancy what it is I do here,'' Mr. Dolan explained. ''Nancy,'' the chief of staff said the the recurit, ''if you find out, will you let me know?''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Kenny Barron Quintet, Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street (675-7100). New York jazz would be far poorer without the pianist Kenny Barron, who works constantly as a sideman, as a member of the quartet Sphere, in duos and, in this week's engagement, as the leader of a full quintet. Mr. Barron brings a suave touch, a command of be-bop filigree and a gift for bluesy phrasing to all sorts of material, and in recent years he has been turning typical melodic figures sideways and inside-out, with sly aplomb. He's leading an aggressive quintet, with John Stubblefield on saxophone, Eddie Henderson on trumpet, Cecil McBee on bass and Victor Lewis on drums, which ought to be a showcase for Mr. Barron's compositions, which are too rarely heard. Sets today through Sunday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12.50 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FACING PRECONCEPTIONS OF WOMEN AS CANDIDATES
description: They are honest and sensitive politicians who care about the concerns of average people. They are good listeners. They would do a good job on issues like the environment and education.

title: FIREFIGHTER FINED IN SEX HARASSMENT CASE
description: The city's Fire Commissioner, rejecting a judge's recommendation to dismiss a firefighter for harassing a female colleague, fined the firefighter $15,000 yesterday and suspended him for six months without pay.

title: CITING A DEFICIT, NURSING AGENCY REDUCES ITS STAFF
description: The Visiting Nurse Service of New York dismissed 288 staff members yesterday because of a projected year-end budget deficit, the service's chief executive officer said last night.

title: STAGE: TALE OF APARTHEID, 'BORN IN THE R.S.A.'
description: WHEN an outsider thinks of South Africa, chances are that he does not think of VCR's, marijuana, discos, fast food, telephone answering machines, bowling clubs and ''hot'' male bodies. It's one of the many achievements of ''Born in the R.S.A.,'' the riveting final attraction in Lincoln Center's festival of South African theater, that the audience learns just as much about such diurnal trivia as it does about detention, police brutality and the rest of apartheid's arsenal of repression. In this work, politics is inseparable from the everyday life of a society, and the white middle-class manners of that society are not always as alien as an American might wish. Being born in the U.S.A., a nation whose contributions to South Africa include a policy of ''constructive engagement'' with the Pretoria Government, is no guarantee of immunity from the devastating implications of ''Born in the R.S.A.''

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON VETO
description: Here is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today overrode President Reagan's veto of a bill imposing economic sanctions on the South African Government. The margin was 11 votes more than the two-thirds needed to override the veto.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adelphia Communications Corp., Coudersport, Pa., said it had acquired cable television systems serving 125,000 subscribers in the Buffalo area from affiliates of Prime Cable Corp. for $172.5 million.

title: ROBINSON'S GAINS ENCOURAGE GIANTS
description: The Giants' starting flanker against the Cardinals Sunday in St. Louis will be Bobby Johnson. Or Solomon Miller.

title: FOR HYUNDAI EXCEL, A SPECTACULAR START
description: When officials of Hyundai Motor America were preparing to introduce the automobile into the American market earlier this year, one question they grappled with was the pronounciation of the name. To make things easy for customers, they adopted an English sound that rhymed with the days of the week, as in ''Sunday, Monday, Hyundai,'' a pronunciation rather different from the way Koreans say it.

title: Lloyds to Acquire A Canadian Bank
description: The Continental Bank of Canada, which has lost half of its deposits in the last 12 months, said today that it was being acquired by Lloyds Bank International, the fourth-largest bank in Britain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a friend of that Government we are saying, wake up!'' - Senator Richard G. Lugar, addressing South Africa. [ A1:6. ]

title: '21' AND ARCADIA SHARE TALENT
description: Principals of the ''21'' Club, Manhattan's celebrated roost for corporate movers and shakers, announced major changes in management yesterday, including the appointment of Ken Aretsky and Anne Rosenzweig, co-owners of the popular American-style restaurant Arcadia, to high-level positions.

title: SORG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The company was formerly the Sorg Printing Co.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THIS is a real New York story, a tale of power and intrigue and lox and bagels. The plot concerns a party celebrating a new novel set in New York's glamorous fashion industry.

title: Race for House Whip
description: The race for House Democratic whip in the next Congress may be tightening, with the current session drawing to a close. Supporters of Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, who had been an underdog, now contend he is only a few votes behind Representative Tony Coelho of California, whose backers insist he still holds a commanding lead.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net income c-After losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $18,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $48,000 and $78,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Tulsa Wins, 20-10
description: Steve Gage, the Tulsa quarterback, rushed for two touchdowns, including one for 63 yards, in a 20-10 victory tonight over Fullerton State. Fullerton (1-5) got its only touchdown in the fourth quarter, on a 23-yard pass from Ronnie Barber to Bill Brennan, a freshman tight end. Tulsa is 4-2.

title: KNICKS TRADE DARRELL WALKER
description: Darrell Walker, the player foremost in Knick trade plans during the off-season, was finally traded last night, a day before the opening of training camp. The 6-foot-4-inch guard, a defensive specialist, went to the Denver Nuggets for a 1987 first-round draft choice.

title: MILITARY TO CUT 6,200 OFFICERS UNDER BUDGET-BALANCING LAW
description: The Defense Department plans to cut 6,200 officers from the military services each year over the next three to four fiscal years when legislation now before Congress takes effect, the Pentagon's senior personnel officer said today.

title: Marshals in the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL STATES' EDGY LEGISLATORS FACE SIMILAR ATTACKS
description: Politics in Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana resonates with gloom these days, out of line with the upbeat mood that has characterized the nation over the last few years.

title: BENDEL SETS MOVE TO 5TH AVE.
description: Henri Bendel plans to leave 57th Street in 1988 for a site four times as large on Fifth Avenue, its owner said yesterday.

title: 2 Big Construction Companies Merge
description: Two major southern California heavy construction concerns, C.L. Peck Contractor and the Jones Brothers Construction Corporation, have agreed to merge into a single company to be called Peck/Jones. The new company, which will have annual revenues of about $400 million, will be formed Jan. 1.

title: STUDY CLARIFIES CAUSE OF ILLNESS IN UNCLASSIFIED AIDS VICTIMS
description: Most of the AIDS victims who could not initially be placed in a high-risk group for the fatal disease can now be placed in such a group, new research shows.

title: 24 TASK FORCES SOUGHT BY MEESE TO FIGHT CRACK
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reported today that the use of crack, a highly addictive form of cocaine, appeared to be a ''crisis of epidemic proportions in some areas'' and urged creation of 24 special crack task forces around the country.

title: MATTINGLY SETS RECORD FOR HITS
description: The batting race was the attraction, but only Don Mattingly played his part. While Wade Boggs was bothered by an injury to his right hamstring tonight and sat out the first game of a season-ending four-game series, Mattingly broke one 59-year-old Yankee club record and tied another but gained no ground in his pursuit of Boggs for the league batting title.

title: LOWER INTEREST? WHAT'S HE MEAN?
description: In most countries of the world, a call by president or prime minister for lower interest rates usually inspires a prompt effort by the monetary authorities to lower the rates. But not in the United States.

title: SHORTAGE OF CANTORS IS FORCING CHANGES IN RITUALS OF JUDAISM
description: The days before Rosh ha-Shanah are an anxious time for many Jews, but for cantors, such as Joseph Malovany, they seem especially so.

title: Senate, 78 to 21, Overrides Reagans Veto and Imposes Sanctions on South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The Senate voted today to override President Reagan's veto of legislation imposing stiff economic sanctions on South Africa. In doing so it rejected his pleas for support as he prepares to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in Iceland.

title: CONCERT: ZUKERMAN AND MEHTA
description: BUILDING an effective orchestral program is an art, but there are standard ideas that all conductors find useful when inspiration flags. One is to place a light-textured work flush against a relatively heavy one, trusting that the contrast will work to the advantage of both composers. Zubin Mehta put two such pieces cheek-to-cheek last night for a New York Philharmonic concert: Mozart's Violin Concerto No. 5, which is a deliciously feathery work, and Strauss's ''Alpine'' Symphony, which is anything but.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY BEGINS 5-YEAR CAMPAIGN TO RAISE $307 MILLION
description: A five-year campaign to raise $307 million for the New York Public Library began yesterday, with Mayor Koch promising the city's help, a group of benefactors pledging millions and grateful writers and actors telling how the library had influenced their careers.

title: RICE, AN ALLY OF VOLCKER ON FED, IS RESIGNING
description: Emmett J. Rice, a close ally of the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, today announced his resignation as a member of the central bank's board of governors, effective Dec. 31.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AMERICANS IN LONDON: A GROWING CROWD
description: George Gershwin rhapsodized about being an American in Paris, but never about being an American in London. Perhaps he should have: the American resident community here is more vigorous than ever and growing by the minute.

title: Egypt Says 98% of Voters Backed Ruling Party
description: The Egyptian Government announced today that almost 98 percent of voters chose the ruling party in unopposed nationwide by-elections for a legislative advisory body.

title: New Chief Elected At Kaneb Services
description: Kaneb Services Inc., announced yesterday that John R. Barnes had been elected president and chief executive of the Houston-based energy services company.
