Mr. Barnes, formerly president of the Stanton Oil Company in Dallas, replaces James R. Whatley, who as chairman of Kaneb had assumed the additional posts on an interim basis.

title: KENNETH MEEKS
description: Kenneth Meeks, a member of the board of directors of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, a social-service and educational organization assisting victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, died of an AIDS-related illness last Friday while visiting San Francisco.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Topics; Filling Gaps; Small Triumphs
description: The Reagan Administration may lack interest in using government creatively but states and localities do not. To encourage such creativity, the Ford Foundation identified 10 noteworthy state and local initiatives and awarded them grants up to $100,000.

title: IN ENGLAND, A RESURRECTON FOR JOE CLAY AND THE 50'S
description: During the summer of 1957, 18-year-old Claiborne Joseph Cheramie of New Orleans was a minor star in the young world of rock and roll. Using the name Joe Clay, he backed up Elvis Presley on guitar and drums, appeared on the Ed Sullivan television show and recorded nine songs at the RCA studios in New York. Then his career foundered, and for most of the past three decades Mr. Cheramie - C. J. to friends -has been driving a New Orleans school bus on weekdays and playing drums for combos doing Top 40 or country-and-western music at weddings, proms and hotel lounges around New Orleans.

title: HARVARD CUTS SOUTH AFRICA-LINKED HOLDINGS
description: Harvard University announced today that it had sold off over $150 million of its investments in eight major companies that do business in South Africa. It said it had taken the action because the companies either sell products to the South African military or refused to provide the school with sufficient information about their activities.

title: I.B.M. Package
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer company, will announce an expert-systems software package next week, a company official said. The official, Victor Goldberg, assistant group executive for market development in I.B.M.'s Information Systems Group, said the product would combine into one package all the artificial intelligence tools and software that I.B.M. now sells separately.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $12,217 for the quarter and $26,717 for the 6 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $1,275 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $272,750 for the 6 months, both from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: ART: BROOKLYN SHOW, 'MONUMENTAL DRAWING'
description: DRAWING isn't what it was, and it hasn't been for some time. Yet because there is something sinister about a change that deprives a term as simple as drawing of its meaning, it still seems necessary to remark on it. The latest authority to do so is Charlotta Kotik - in the show of monumental drawings that she has organized for the Brooklyn Museum, at 200 Eastern Parkway.

title: Bowling in '88 Games
description: Neither Mark Roth nor Johnny Petraglia nor any other member of the Professional Bowlers Association will be there, but the Federation Internationale des Quilleurs has managed to get bowling back into the Olympic Games after a 50 year absence, if only as a one-day exhibition during the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Ferragamo Released
description: The Green Bay Packers have released Vince Ferragamo, a nine-year veteran quarterback in the National Football League, to make room for Chuck Fusina, a former quarterback in the United States Football League.

title: New Solidarity Council Is Warned by Poland
description: An official newspaper warned Poland's outlawed Solidarity labor union today that its formation of a council of former underground leaders was ''political blindness'' headed for conflict with the law.

title: USX Continues To Trade Heavily
description: Shares of the USX Corporation continued to trade heavily yesterday, even though Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, was still not commenting on whether he had increased his holdings.

title: Hotel Chain to Promote Rooms for Nonsmokers
description: Quality International, a 934-hotel franchise operation, will begin promoting its rooms for nonsmokers in a network TV campaign beginning Monday and running through mid-November.

title: CITISOURCE ROLE GIVEN IN DETAIL BY LINDENAUER
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer painted a detailed picture today of how a company with no assets, engineering staff or working prototype took over a New York City selection process and obtained a $22.7 million contract for a hand-held computer to write parking tickets.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Treasury Secretary James A. Baker's speech at a meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank misidentified an official. Moeen Qureshi is a Pakistani (not an Egyptian) and is a senior vice president at the World Bank (not the Monetary Fund).

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split effective May 5.

title: SPACE AIDE WHO LEAD SHUTTLE PROGRAM AT TIME OF BLAST IS REASSIGNED
description: The man in charge of the space shuttle program when the Challenger exploded will step down from his current post, the space agency announced yesterday.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Change Law to Make Possession of 10 Vials of Crack a Felony
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $3.2 billion, to $235.9 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: HARLYN PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been restated to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend distributed in February 1986.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE idea is ingenious, even if the early execution is a bit wobbly. At the spiffy new Shun Lee Cafe on West 65th Street, which is adjacent to its parent restaurant, Shun Lee, diners can nibble on dim sum dishes from a rolling cart or order what is described as Chinese street food from the menu. This kind of informal ''grazing'' restaurant is most welcome in the Lincoln Center neighborhood, where it is hard to find good quick meals before or after performances.

title: Korean Parade
description: The costumes and customs of Korea will be displayed during the annual Korean-American parade tomorrow along Broadway. It begins at noon at 41st Street and moves down the avenue to 23d Street, where it disperses. More than 20 floats and thousands of marchers will be featured at the parade, sponsored by the Korean-American Association and The Korea News.

title: OPENING DEFENSE OF DONOVAN, LAWYER LABELS FRAUD TRIAL 'A PHANTOM CASE'
description: The chief lawyer for Raymond J. Donovan opened his defense of the former Labor Secretary yesterday by denouncing the charges in the fraud trial as ''a phantom case.''

title: PRETORIA SAYS SENATE ACTED ON 'EMOTIONAL BASIS'
description: The South African Government said tonight that the United States Senate's 78-to-21 override of President Reagan's sanctions veto was taken on an ''emotional basis'' and added that 'it is clear that misconceptions on South Africa exist.''

title: Striking Longshoremen Reject Ship Lines' Offer
description: Negotiations to settle a walkout by 30,000 longshoremen collapsed today, leaving ports along the East Coast idle for a second day.

title: Canada II in Trial With America II
description: Canada II will meet America II Sunday in the toughest draw of the first day of the preliminary series in the eliminations to select a challenger to meet Australia for the America's Cup.

title: Dining Out Guide; French Bistros
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AU TROQUET, #328 West 12th Street (924-3413) - **(April 5, 1985) Everything about this little West Village bistro evokes France, from the lettered awning and white-framed windows to the small bar and simple dining room highlighted with paintings by the owner. Appetizers include marinated salmon with basil, endive with Roquefort and vinaigrette, and wild mushrooms in cream sauce crowned with puff pastry. Main dish options are medallions of veal in a stock sauce with tarragon; sauteed shrimp and scallops; rabbit sauteed with white wine sauce; grilled salmon with Bordelaise sauce.

title: BROADWAY
description: KATHLEEN TURNER, currently considered one of the sizzlers of filmdom, will be returning to the stage, probably in two plays, one hot on the heels of the other. She'll be at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven in late November, starring in ''Camille,'' and from there is likely to go into rehearsals in New York for ''The Widow's Blind Date.''

title: SENATE BARS AID INCREASE TO MANILA A SECOND TIME
description: The Republican-controlled Senate rejected a $200 million increase in economic aid to the Philippines on Thursday, the second time this week it has turned down the request.

title: Soviet-British Space Pact
description: Soviet and British scientists have agreed on joint space research, leading to the possible launching of an unmanned satellite in the 1990's, a British Embassy spokesman said today. The accord was signed here Wednesday by the Institute for Space Studies of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and the British National Space Center.

title: Report of AIDS Jokes Roils San Franciscans
description: Officials from San Francisco said today that they were offended by jokes attributed by The Washington Post to President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in which they reportedly discussed sending the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to San Francisco and giving him AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: WINERY UNION, IN REVERSAL, VOTES TO ACCEPT PACT
description: Reversing their vote of two weeks ago, workers striking 11 of California's largest wineries today approved the employers association's contract offer.

title: The Wrong Way to Pick Judges
description: It is sometimes said that a Federal judge is a lawyer who knew a senator. The cynical adage contains more than a grain of truth, since it describes the traditional mechanism for selecting candidates for the Federal bench: sponsorship by a senator of the incumbent President's political party.

title: Making Good Schools Worse
description: New York City's Board of Education recently voted to lower the admissions standards of eight special high schools because, it said, theschools are ''elitist.'' The schools involved were not the truly elite ''examination'' schools, like the Bronx High School of Science or Stuyvesant. Instead, the Board picked on the ''educational option'' schools -highly popular and successful magnet schools developed during the past 15 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1986
description: The Economy

title: BUNDESBANK INTERVENES, BUT DOLLAR STILL DECLINES
description: The dollar fell against the mark and most other major currencies yesterday, despite efforts by West Germany's central bank to shore up the American currency.

title: FOR BANKERS, A RELAXED PARLEY
description: For commercial bankers, this year's meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank proved refreshingly unpressured and free of the intense competitiveness and financial crises that frayed bankers' nerves in prior gatherings.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 13
Dearie and O'Connor To Discuss Church Ban
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie is to meet with John Cardinal O'Connor today in an effort to reverse a ban on the Assemblyman's speaking at events sponsored by his local Roman Catholic parish.

title: EXTENSION OF OIL CURB EXPECTED
description: OPEC appears ready to extend its pledge to restrain oil production through the end of the year, oil specialists in the United States said yesterday.

title: CSX Net Off 27%
description: The CSX Corporation, citing weakness in its transportation business, said its third-quarter profit fell 27 percent from a year earlier on a 15 percent revenue decline. CSX is a major railroad holding company that also has interests in energy and real estate.

title: DE LAURENTIIS ENTERTAINENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Latest quarter figures reflect results from the first DEG film releases since the company's intitial public offering in May. Comparable results for the year- earlier periods are not presented since the company released its first theatrical film in June.

title: IRAN REPORTS TALKS WITH FRANCE AIMED AT IMPROVING TIES
description: The Iranian Foreign Minister said today that his Government had engaged in ''extensive talks'' with the French Government aimed at improving relations between the two countries.

title: Bulls Sign Sellers
description: Brad Sellers, a 7-foot forward and Chicago's first-round draft pick, has decided not to sit out training camp, which begins today, and has signed a four-year contract with the Bulls.

title: Topics; Filling Gaps; Auto Intelligence
description: Which is more crashworthy: a Ford LTD or a Volkswagen Jetta? Which would cost more to fix after a collision: a Chrysler Laser or a Mazda 626?

title: AFGHANISTAN MAY BE TOPIC IN ICELAND
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that he expected other issues besides arms control, including the Soviet presence in Afghanistan, to come up in the Iceland meeting.

title: Option Deal Is Largest Ever
description: The largest option trade in history was transacted yesterday, when Salomon Brothers Inc. bought 30,000 December put options on the British pound at the Philadelphia Board of Trade.

title: 'THERE MUST BE A PONY,' WITH ELIZABETH TAYLOR
description: RIGHT at the beginning of ''There Must Be a Pony,'' ABC's television movie

title: CALTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in the form of a dividend.

title: Not Government's Place
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN CHOCOLATE FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CORPORATE MANAGEMENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
F.C.C. ACTION CRITICIZED
description: Democratic members of the House telecommunications subcommittee today harshly criticized the Federal Communications Commission for asking a Federal court to declare unconstitutional the agency's policy of granting women and racial minorities special consideration in awarding broadcast licenses.

title: No Cachet
description: In the week each year that Washington plays host to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund meeting, some of the rules change.

title: REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Witness Was Affiliate Of Lindenauer Center
description: Dr. Jerome Driesen, identified last week as a ''secret witness'' in the corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and four other defendants, was once affiliated with the Manhattan psychotherapy institute run by the Government's chief witness, Geoffrey G. Lindenauer.

title: Delta-Western Air
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division said it would not oppose Delta Air Lines' proposed $860 million acquisition of Western Air Lines since the merger was unlikely to affect competition. Charles Rule, Deputy Assistant Attorney General, announced the decision in a letter to the Transportation Department, which has final say on the deal. Analysts said that Atlanta-based Delta and Los-Angeles Western operations are concentrated in different parts of the country, lessening antitrust concerns.

title: AARON SPELLING PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Finland to Ban War Toys
description: Finland will ban the manufacture and sale of war toys from the beginning of next year under an agreement with the Association of Toy Producers, the National Board of Social Welfare said today. A board official said there would also be an import ban on war toys. A similar step was taken in Sweden 10 years ago.

title: No Retrial for U.S.F.L.
description: A Federal judge has denied the United States Football League's request for a new trial to reconsider its $1 award in its multimillion-dollar antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses of $1,939,000 and $2,965,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses of $127,000 and $202,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively.

title: Partial Eclipse of Sun To Cover Up to 70%
description: A rare eclipse of the sun will dim the light over much of the United States Friday.

title: Proposal by GCA
description: The GCA Corporation said it might have to seek protection under Federal bankruptcy laws if it was not able to successfully complete new talks with its lenders. The company, an integrated circuits concern based in Bedford, Mass., said its management had made a refinancing proposal to institutional lenders that included an infusion of $54 million in cash by the sale of equity securities; the raising of $26 million through previously announced asset sales, and the payment of about $50 million to the institutional lenders, with most of the balance of GCA debt being eliminated.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for 16wks to Sept 21
description: b-After a credit of $51.2 million in connection with an accounting change. The year-ago figures are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: PERSICO OPPOSED 1979 SLAYING OF MAFIA BOSS, AN INFORMER TESTIFIES
description: An informer testified yesterday that Carmine Persico told him that he had voted against killing Carmine Galante, a Mafia boss who was shot to death in 1979.

title: JAZZ AND TAP, A MARRIAGE SURVIVES THE SKEPTICS
description: When Lynn Dally founded the Jazz Tap Ensemble in 1979, skeptics told her that, yes, there was such a thing as jazz and, yes, there was such a thing as tap, but they weren't so sure there was - or could be - such a thing as jazz tap. Ms. Dally disagreed, and went ahead to organize a company of dancers and musicians who attempt to blend two indigenous and rhythmically intricate American art forms.

title: SHULTZ CALLS USE OF PRESS TO SCARE LIBYAN JUSTIFIED
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Washington was free to take whatever actions might cause trouble for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi because the United States was ''pretty darn close'' to a state of war with Libya.

title: 2 LUXURY RENTALS EXTEND COLUMBUS AVE. RENEWAL
description: The forces that turned Columbus Avenue into the main stem of the Upper West Side are pushing north again. Soon, strollers searching for that hybrid of glitz and chic will discover a Benetton's clothing store on the southwest corner of 96th Street. And gelato shops and aerobic centers probably will not be far behind.

title: U.S. PLANS JAPANESE TEXTILE CUT
description: The United States moved today to cut imports of textiles from Japan by 10 percent, charging that some of the goods sent from there have been illegal transshipments of fabrics made in South Korea.

title: OFFICERS SEIZE GUNMAN
description: A lone gunman made an apparent attempt to kill Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today, leaving Mr. Gandhi's entourage shaken and leading to the suspension of several top officials in charge of his security.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 17
description: b-Includes pretax charges of $371,000 and $49,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, for professional and other expenses relating to the pending acquisition of the company by Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc. and to other acquisition-related activities. c-Includes a tax credit of $450,000.

title: CUOMO REAFFIRMS HIS ADHERENCE TO TEACHINGS OF CHURCH
description: Governor Cuomo sought last night to separate himself from theological dissidents in the Roman Catholic Church and reaffirmed his own adherence to church teachings.

title: Betty Kean, 69, a TV Actress And Part of 50's Comedy Act
description: Betty Kean, part of the Kean Sisters comedy team in the 1950's and an actress in many television comedies, died of cancer Monday at her Hollywood home, according to Gene Walsh, an NBC spokesman. She was 69 years old.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday DOWN MEMORY LANE Does the refrain, ''Well they often call me Speedo but my real name is Mr. Earl'' mean anything to you? If you know the song -''Speedo,'' a golden oldie from the Cadillacs - you may be the right audience for the Royal New York Doo-Wop Show, an annual celebration of vintage rock-and-roll at Radio City Music Hall. This year's lineup includes such 50's favorites as the Cadillacs (also known for ''Gloria''), the Penguins (''Earth Angel''), Randy and the Rainbows (''Denise''), the Marcels (''Blue Moon''), Johnnie and Joe (''Over the Mountain, Across the Sea''), Richard Blandon and the Dubs (''Could This Be Magic?''), and the Happy Daze Band. Tonight's concert begins at 8, with tickets priced at $16.50 and $18.50. Information: 757-3100.

title: DEAN OF THE ARTS SCHOOL AT COLUMBIA IS LEAVING
description: Schuyler G. Chapin is leaving after 10 years as dean of the Columbia University School of the Arts, effective at the end of this academic year.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 3, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on the Iran-Iraq war. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RUSSIAN EMIGRE INDICTED IN FIRE SET IN BUILDING
description: A concert violinist was indicted yesterday after law-enforcement authorities said they had linked him to a bungling band of arsonists who burned themselves more severely than the apartment building they had been paid to destroy.

title: Market Place; Closed Funds Snapped Up
description: NOT since the go-go stock market of the late 1960's have closed-end mutual funds been so popular with investors as they are today. The Zweig Fund, for instance, last week sold $300 million of shares in an initial offering - after it had originally planned to raise only $65 million. That followed similar receptions given two other closed-end funds recently: Mario Gabelli's $400 million fund, which sold out in August, and Charles Allmon's $143 million fund, which was snapped up last March.

title: INSIDE
description: Volcker Ally Resigns Emmett J. Rice, an ally of the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, announced his resignation as a central bank governor.

title: SMALLEST CROP OF WHITE HOUSE FELLOWS
description: When the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, greeted the 11 new White House Fellows today, the new class was the smallest in the program's 21 years.

title: Motorists Cautioned On Lincoln Tunnel
description: Motorists are being warned again to avoid using the Lincoln Tunnel this weekend while repairs are made to an access road in New Jersey.

title: SCREEN: 'TOUGH GUYS,' LANCASTER AND DOUGLAS
description: WHEN Burt Lancaster and Kirk Douglas star together in a movie, certain expectations are aroused, and, for much of the way, ''Tough Guys'' satisfies them. The two pros settle comfortably into the roles of a couple of train robbers, whose last exploit, holding up the Gold Coast Flyer, sent them to jail for 30 years. When we meet them, they are on their way out into the strange world of Los Angeles, circa 1986, abounding in homosexuals, health fanatics and young folks in more peculiar get-ups than even our heroes' dusted-off wide-lapeled jackets, jazzy ties and snappy fedoras.

title: Hostages' Families Make Appeal on Lebanon TV
description: Lebanon's state television station broadcast a videotaped appeal today for the release of American hostages that was made by their families and former United States captives.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
New Envoy to Ghana Named
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Stephen R. Lyne, a Foreign Service officer, as Ambassador to Ghana. Mr. Lyne, 51 years old, has held posts in Cambodia, Vietnam, New Zealand, Gabon, Algeria, Australia and Lebanon and since last year has been diplomat-in-residence and an adjunct professor at Boston University's Center for International Relations.

title: PENDERS TO COACH AT RHODE ISLAND
description: Tom Penders, who turned Columbia from an Ivy League also-ran into a contender, then revitalized the basketball program at Fordham, is leaving one group of Rams to become head coach of another, at the University of Rhode Island.

title: Decoy Show on L.I.
description: Decoy collectors from along the Eastern seaboard will gather to buy, swap and talk about their collections on Sunday at the annual show run by the Long Island Decoy Collectors Association.

title: Humana Cites Earnings Drop
description: Humana Inc., a major operator of hospitals and health-care plans, said today that it would post its first annual earnings decline in more than a decade because of after-tax charges totaling $131 million.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept. 6
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,512,000 and $1,824,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: TOUGH SCHEDULE FOR IVY TEAMS
description: Three Ivy League teams, Dartmouth, Harvard and Yale, appear to be in line for more pummeling tomorrow, which raises a question about the effects of decisive defeats.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SESSION WITH THE PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's interview at the White House today with invited columnists and television commentators:

title: AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF SAKHAROV SMUGGLED OUT FOR PUBLICATION
description: Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished Soviet physicist and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has written his autobiography and managed to smuggle it to the West, where it will be published by Alfred A. Knopf after further editing work is completed, Dr. Sakharov's son-in-law announced today.

title: NEWS EXECUTIVES EXPRESS OUTRAGE
description: News executives yesterday deplored the Reagan Administration's reported use of a disinformation campaign against the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. They suggested that, if true, it raised serious credibility problems for the White House.

title: ART: THE FOLK WORK OF THE 'YOUNG AMERICA'
description: FOLK art is a funny business. A day or two ago this critic went to see ''Young America: A Folk-Art History,'' an exhibition organized by the American Museum of Folk Art that can be seen through Nov. 15 at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art on Madison Avenue at 56th Street. It was crowded. Women wore hats and gloves. Men treated them with Old World courtesy. Children were squeaky clean. Everybody was having a very good time.

title: Jersey Broker Appears Shut
description: Yves Hentic & Company, a small Jersey City broker-dealer and underwriter in over-the-counter issues, has apparently gone out of business after a speculative run on one of its holdings forced it to liquidate its stock to meet capital requirements.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stock Prices Mixed; Dow Off 1.69, to 1,781.21
description: Ending a two-day rally on Wall Street, stock prices closed mixed yesterday as trading volume contracted.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT is amazing what surprises pop up in this city if you snoop around long enough. Take, for example, the Ambassador Grill, a coolly urbane restaurant in the United Nations Plaza Hotel. Never terribly distinguished in matters gustatory, the Ambassador Grill has been pegged as a convenient spot for diplomatic types to take a breather from solving the world's woes by having a tall drink and grilled slab of all-American steak.

title: INITIAL REPORT ON LIBYAN PLOTS STIRRED SKEPTICISM
description: A front-page article in The Wall Street Journal on Aug. 25 saying Libya was plotting new terrorist attacks prompted almost immediate skepticism and conflicting information from other major news organizations as they sought to confirm The Journal's report.

title: A Dissenter On Pop-Ups
description: At least one advertising agency is not overjoyed about those spectacular pop-up ads that have run recently - and at great expense - in Time and Sports Illustrated. And MacNamara, Clapp & Klein is not too crazy about those ''advertorial inserts'' either.

title: WATCHING WALKER, DENVER ASSISTANT FEELS LIKE CRYING
description: Alex Gibbs, the Denver Broncos' offensive line coach, watched the Dallas Cowboys win for the third time this season, beating the St. Louis Cardinals Monday night, and he almost felt depressed.

title: 76er-Cheeks Accord
description: The Philadelphia 76ers say they have reached a contract agreement with Maurice Cheeks, a point guard, and expect him to attend the second day of camp today.

title: SOVIET CALLED UNSURE ON U.S. ARMS AIM
description: A senior Administration official said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems to be uncertain about present United States positions on arms control. The official said the Soviet leader had sought the Iceland meeting with President Reagan to hear his thinking about arms issues first-hand.

title: YELENA BONNER'S WORDS
description: From ''Alone Together'' (1986):

title: FUGITIVE DEAD AFTER STANDOFF
description: Michael Wayne Jackson, who eluded the authorities for 11 days after a three-state spree of murder and abductions, killed himself Thursday night in a barn less than a quarter mile from where he was last seen on foot.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jerome Cooper, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). If the idea of an evening of drum solos sounds about as rewarding as a migraine, it's probably because you haven't heard Jerome Cooper. With a fastidiously tuned drum set spread out before him, an African xylophone or two within easy reach, a flute or reed instrument in his mouth, and an ear for melodic and rhythmic organization second to none, Mr. Cooper is truly a one-man orchestra. There are no headaches here. He plays tonight at 9; admission is $5.

title: ART: 'A DISTANCED VIEW,' BY GROUP FROM EUROPE
description: ''A DISTANCED VIEW: One Aspect of Recent Art From Belgium, France, Germany and Holland'' introduces the United States to a different kind of European art. It is not Expressionist but Conceptual, not hot but cool. The interest is not painting or sculpture, but installation, design, architecture, music, photography and video. The result is one of the best arguments for Conceptual Art that any curator has made.

title: New President At Ashton-Tate
description: The Ashton-Tate Company said today that Luther J. Nussbaum had been named president and chief operating officer of the microcomputer software company based in Culver City, Calif.

title: QUERY SEEN ON TRADING IN CBS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission turned to the First Boston Corporation yesterday for help in uncovering possible illegal trading in CBS stock or stock options, Wall Street sources said.

title: GOODEN REACHES 200-STRIKEOUT MARK
description: Dwight Gooden made more history tonight by becoming the first pitcher to earn 200 or more strikeouts in each of his first three major league seasons.

title: KASPAROV MAKES DRAW IN 21ST GAME FOR TITLE
description: Gary Kasparov drew closer to retaining his world chess championship by making a draw in the 21st game of the match yesterday in Leningrad. The 23-year-old titleholder is tied with his 35-year-old challenger, Anatoly Karpov, at 10 1/2, and there are just three more games to be played.

title: Micron Drops Chip Suit
description: Micron Technology Inc., a semiconductor maker based in Boise, Idaho, has dropped its antitrust complaint against six major Japanese chip makers and their subsidiaries in the United States. The suit, originally filed Sept. 6, 1985, charged the Japanese companies with monopolisitic and predatory pricing policies.

title: SANDSTROM, RANGERS FAR APART
description: Following this season, Tomas Sandstrom may become another Ranger to defect from the team and return to Europe. At least that is the indication offered by Sandstrom's decision not to sign a new contract and play out his option.

title: JETS PERPLEXED BY INJURY PLAGUE
description: The Jets keep tumbling down.

title: Rights of Palestinians Must Be Addressed
description: To the Editor:

title: Who D'ya Like?
description: Right about now, Coach Jerry Pettibone has to be having second thoughts over Northern Illinois's decision to bolt the Mid-American Conference this year in favor of independence and an increasingly strong football schedule. To be sure, the Huskies still play a few games at the proper level, such as against Ball State and Western Illinois.

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said there were 14 weeks in the latest quarter and 13 weeks in the year-ago period. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: Farm in Wyeth Work, 'Christina's World,' Sold
description: The farm immortalized in Andrew Wyeth's painting ''Christina's World'' has been sold, and the film producer Joseph E. Levine says he's glad to be rid of it.

title: CHICAGO'S NEWBERRY LIBRARY BROADENS ITS ALLURE
description: For decades it sat there on Chicago's Near North Side, a grim edifice where a steady flow of scholars entered seeking knowledge and left each evening somewhat wiser though unnoticed by most.

title: Lumber Offer Is Rejected
description: American lumber executives today rejected a Canadian proposal that would have ended an increasingly bitter dispute between the United States and Canada over softwood.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. PITTSBURGH PIRATES, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Alabama Governor Race To Be a 3-Man Contest
description: Alabama's Attorney General said today that he would definitely run a write-in campaign for Governor even if the United States Supreme Court ruled that Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley was the legal nominee of the Democratic Party.

title: JOY OVER CARTER LIBRARY FAILS TO STOP FIGHT OVER PARKWAY TO IT
description: Behind Jimmy Carter's new Presidential Center here, out of the view of President Reagan and others at Wednesday's dedication ceremonies, the abutments of an unfinished highway bridge rise among the weeds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1986
description: International Tight U.S. sanctions against Pretoria will be imposed. The Senate voted, 78 to 21, to override President Reagan's veto of legislation to impose the economic penalties against South Africa. Since the House has also voted to rebuff Mr. Reagan, the sanctions bill now becomes law. [ Page A1, Col. 6 ]

title: The Comp Case, Continued
description: People who can do without the coming of the college football season got a raw deal a few weeks back when the National Collegiate Athletic Association retreated from its determination that 60 Nebraska players ought to be suspended for violating the complimentary-ticket rule.

title: The Trouble With Mixing Religion and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: GOSSIP WITH ICING: AT TEA WITH BRAZIL'S LITERATI
description: The Immortals met for tea, as usual, on Thursday at 4 P.M. and, passing courtesies and witticisms as deftly as the platters of coconut cake, they swapped gossip about politics and literature.

title: A New Proprietor For Umberto's Clam House
description: A Federal district judge has given the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan permission to take over the operation of Umberto's Clam House in Little Italy.

title: Carbide Plans Sale Of Electronics Unit
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it wants to sell its electronic components busines, part of the company's specilaties and services business group.

title: S.R.O. AT SCOOTER'S
description: In Houston, it's all over for Cooter's. As Yogi Berra may or may not have said about a restaurant in Minneapolis many years ago, nobody goes there any more because it's too crowded.

title: O'ROURKE SEEKS TO TIE CUOMO TO CITY SCANDAL
description: Seizing on governmental-corruption trials and disclosures dominating the news, Andrew P. O'Rourke sought yesterday to link Governor Cuomo with allegations of corruption among Mr. Cuomo's fellow Queens Democrats.

title: Ford Raises Prices on '87's
description: The Ford Motor Company followed the lead of the General Motors Corporation and raised 1987 sticker prices an average of 2.3 percent today. Foreign auto makers have also increased sticker prices on their new model cars.

title: E.P.A. OFFERS LIMITED CURBS ON TOP HERBICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed limited restrictions on how alachlor, the nation's most widely used agricultural herbicide, may be used.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
SENATE, 78 TO 21, OVERRIDES REAGAN'S VETO AND IMPOSES SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Senate voted today to override President Reagan's veto of legislation imposing stiff economic sanctions on South Africa. In doing so it rejected his pleas for support as he prepares to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in Iceland.

title: Transworld 2-Part Sale
description: The Transworld Corporation is selling $250 million of notes and debentures, in two parts. Underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: A Merger Born of Competition
description: JOSEPH K. FISHER, Bruce N. Jackson, Richard Levy and Richard Flaxman have had one thing in common - years of experience on major package goods brands at some of the country's largest ad agencies.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Business People col-umn yesterday misidentified the nation that once employed R. J. Ventres, newly named chief executive of Borden Inc., to help train nationals to run oil refineries. It was Iraq.

title: 'SID AND NANCY' RE-CREATES TALE OF PUNK ROMANCE
description: FEW would have suspected, when Sid Vicious died of a heroin overdose in 1979 after having been charged with the stabbing death of his girlfriend Nancy Spungen several months earlier, that this story had the makings of a big-screen romance. Even now, there are those who wouldn't quite understand. But Alex Cox, who directed ''Repo Man,'' saw the Sid and Nancy story as the occasion for a sordid, intentionally ugly and sometimes unexpectedly beautiful film, a pitch-black comedy about wasted love. At the very least, you have to admire his nerve.

title: CONSERVATIVES URGE QUICK U.S. ACTION ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: Conservative legislators and scientists who favor early steps to defend against a missile attack are urging the Reagan Administration to move quickly to deploy defensive missiles, even though they might be only partly effective.

title: John Drew Arrested
description: John Drew, who was expelled from the National Basketball Associaiton for violating the league's drug policy, was arrested and charged with selling cocaine to an undercover Georgia Bureau of Investigation agent, the police said.

title: RE-CREATING DOLPHY-LITTLE MUSIC OF 1961
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, five exceptional musicians pooled their talents in a band that lasted all of two weeks, the length of its engagement at a Bowery jazz club of the period called the Five Spot. This week, at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, three of the original five - the pianist Mal Waldron, the bassist Richard Davis and the drummer Ed Blackwell - are revisiting the music they played at the Five Spot in 1961. The original group's two leaders, Eric Dolphy and Booker Little, died in the 60's, still young, vigorously creative to the end. Their stand-ins at Sweet Basil are the saxophonist Donald Harrison and the trumpeter Terence Blanchard, gifted newcomers who are still in their mid-20's.

title: JOSEPH H. NICHOLSON
description: Joseph H. Nicholson, the New York City editor for The Associated Press from 1942 to 1965, died Sunday at his home in Lake Worth, Fla.

title: Mahatma's Likeness In Union Square
description: With a garland of marigolds, warm applause, many eloquent words and chants of ''Gandhiji! Gandhiji!,'' the larger-than-life statue of Mohandas K. Gandhi was welcomed yesterday to New York City.

title: 14 REASONS WHY NEW YORK IS NEW
description: IN this vast work-in-progress that we call New York, change is a constant, giving the city's face a quicksilver quality: Vistas are transformed and the landscape is recast. At no time of year, probably, is this so evident as the early fall, when New Yorkers return to their neighborhoods to discover the panoply of new restaurants, museums, clubs, shops, theaters, amusements and a mind-boggling miscellany of other things that have made their debuts during the seemingly lazy days of summer. This year, of course, is no exception. Outdoor artworks have appeared in the most unexpected places. A talking robot has come to midtown and the Bronx Zoo's Himalayan snow leopards finally have a new home. In addition to the six newcomers shown here, eight other recent arrivals are featured on page C28.

title: SENATE PANEL DERAILS NOMINATION FOR ARCHIVES
description: The nomination of John T. Agresto to the lifetime post of Archivist of the United States was derailed today when a Senate committee decided not to act before the end of the current session of Congress.

title: Cocaine 'Factory' Is Raided By U.S. Agents in Brooklyn
description: Federal drug agents raided a Brooklyn apartment yesterday that they said was a ''factory'' capable of processing 50 pounds of cocaine a week with a street value of $4 million.

title: Grumman Unit
description: The Grumman Corporation plans to move a unit that works on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space station and other projects to Houston. The company's initial transfer from its Bethpage, L.I., headquarters will involve about 100 employees, principally engineers and technicians, according to Gerry Griffin, president of the Houston Chamber of Commerce and former director of the Johnson Space Center. If Grumman's plans for new business development succeed, the company estimates its Civil Space Programs Unit 1 in Houston will expand tenfold.

title: SCREEN: AN ADAPTION, 'CHILDREN OF LESSER GOD'
description: WATCHING ''Children of a Lesser God,'' the screen adaptation of Mark Medoff's 1980 Broadway play, is like being on a cruise to nowhere aboard a ship with decent service and above-par fast-food. Everything has been carefully programmed so that there are no surprises, no discoveries, nothing to do except to sit -with eyes propped open - and applaud the crew's efficiency.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: LINDENAUER, AT CORRUPTION TRIAL, DESCRIBES LAST DAYS WITH MANES
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer described today how he tearfully pledged not to turn against his friend Donald R. Manes and how, at Mr. Manes's suggestion, he considered suicide as their corruption scheme began to unravel.

title: LOS ANGELES PACT ON SEWAGE MADE
description: Under pressure from the Environmental Protection Agency, the City of Los Angeles agreed today to spend an estimated $2.3 billion over the next 12 years to reduce the flow of city sewage into the Pacific Ocean.

title: FEWER POOR SEEN IF AID IS COUNTED
description: The Census Bureau said today that 2.7 million to 11.5 million Americans would no longer be classified as poor if the Government counted the value of food stamps, housing subsidies and medical assistance as income.

title: A Different Approach By Voter Campaign
description: As a public service effort Grey Advertising has created and taped a bunch of 10-second or 15-second commercials to help Vote America Youth Initiative, a Washington-based nonprofit organization, stimulate the nation's young voters to show up at the polls.

title: WALTER D. BADEN
description: Walter Douglas Baden, a theatrical producer and director who founded the Airport Playhouse in Bohemia, L.I., died Tuesday in Patchogue after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Bohemia.

title: Shift at Brown-Forman Tied to Business Dispute
description: When Martin S. Brown resigned as vice chairman of the Brown-Forman Corporation on Wednesday, rumors spread that there had been ''a falling out'' between Mr. Brown and his two brothers, William Lee Lyons Brown Jr. and Owsley Brown 2d, who serve as chairman and president, respectively.

title: LAWMAKERS AGREE ON TAX MEASURES FOR TOXIC WASTES
description: After arduous negotiations, House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a tax package to pay for a $9 billion, five-year program to clean up toxic waste sites.

title: 55-M.P.H. Speed Limit Is Favored by 62% in Poll
description: Americans continue to support the national 55-mile-per-hour speed limit, but they are less enthusiastic about it than at any time since it went into effect 12 years ago, according to a new Gallup Poll.

title: CONGRESSMAN MADE THREAT, EX-OFFICIAL SAYS
description: James L. Larocca, former New York State Commissioner of Transportation, said today that the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee had threatened a Congressional investigation in a discussion of his brother's contract to manage an airport in upstate New York.

title: NEW JUDGE ASSIGNED TO SUPERVISE INQUIRY ON QUEENS CABLE TV
description: Court officials yesterday assigned a judge from Staten Island to replace the Queens judge who had been supervising the grand jury investigating allegations of bribery involving Queens cable television contracts.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PECKHAM'S MARBLES. By Peter De Vries. 253 pages. Putnam. $17.95.

title: BROOKLYN JUDGE IS INDICTED IN LOANS FROM CREDIT UNION
description: A State Supreme Court justice was indicted yesterday on charges that he accepted bribes in exchange for funneling thousands of dollars from children's trust funds that he controlled into a Brooklyn credit union.

title: Council Votes to Shut City Offices on Fridays
description: The City Council voted today to close city government on Fridays and tax the income of everyone who works in the city. The measures were adopted to help ease the city's financial plight, which has grown worse with the decline of the state's oil economy.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. IS UNITED IN OPPOSING APARTHEID
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told African leaders today that despite the Reagan Administration's opposition to severe economic sanctions against South Africa, Washington was united with them in seeking ''an urgent end to apartheid.''

title: Diplomacy
description: A key financial adviser to Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan said the other night that most Japanese disagreed with Mr. Nakasone's recent suggestion that racial minorities had impaired educational progress in the United States.

title: ROONEY, PACE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Net loss

title: MOST APPROVE ZAKHAROV RELEASE
description: A solid majority of the American public approves of the release of Gennadi F. Zakharov, the convicted Soviet spy, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. In addition, an overwhelming majority said there was a connection between his release and the release of Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American journalist who was arrested in Moscow.

title: First Nationwide Offers Debentures
description: The First Nationwide Bank, formerly known as First Nationwide Savings, is offering $100 million of 10 percent noncallable subordinated debentures due in 2006 at par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: MUGABE SAYS 'WELL DONE' ON SANCTIONS BILL PASSAGE
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe congratulated the United States today for the passage by Congress of sanctions on South Africa.

title: Letter: On Drug Testing; Employers Should Not Be Law Enforcers
description: To the Editor:

title: Silver Screen In Financing Bid
description: Silver Screen Partners is seeking to raise $300 million from investors to finance up to 18 new Walt Disney Company movies in one of the largest film-underwriting ventures ever undertaken.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Tuesday misstated the third-quarter outlook for Apollo Computer Inc. The company expects sales to exceed $100 million.

title: Trio at Jupiter
description: The pianist James Williams, the bassist Mike Richmond and the French hornist Tom Varner are playing tonight at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $5 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: SENATE, IN SWITCH, BACKS RISE IN AID TO THE PHILIPPINES
description: The Senate reversed itself today and approved $200 million in increased economic aid to the Philippine Government. The vote was 82 to 14.

title: PIONEER SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $606,000 for the quarter and 9 months from income tax effect from prior years operating losses. c-After an extraordinary gain of $483,000 for the quarter and $488,000 for the 9 months from income tax effect from prior years operating losses. The 9 months also includes an extraordinary gain of $654,000 from a F.H.L.B. dividend. d-Net income The share earnings have been presented for periods subsequent to conversion on Feb. 4, 1985 during which the common stock was outstanding for the full period.

title: Hallmark Bid Advances
description: Federal broadcasting rules have been waived to allow Hallmark Cards Inc. to proceed with its $301.5 million purchase of five Spanish-language TV stations, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

title: NEW YORK AND JERSEY JOBLESSNESS NEARLY UNCHANGED IN SEPTEMBER
description: The unemployment rates for New York City, New York State and New Jersey changed little, if any, last month, reflecting sustained economic growth in the region, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Thomson Homer Still Going
description: Thirty-five years ago yesterday, Oct. 3, 1951, was a day in which, for most baseball fans, the Earth stood still.

title: WORLD BANK SEES RISE IN LOANS TO POOR LANDS
description: The World Bank expects to increase its lending commitments to poor countries by more than $2 billion over the past fiscal year, Barber B. Conable Jr., the bank's president, said today.

title: 7-YEAR SCHEDULE IS SET IN SPACE SHUTTLE TASKS
description: The space shuttle faces a heavy schedule of military missions when it resumes flying in early 1988 but will soon cut back to the normal rate of military flights, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: FREE SPEECH DEBATE
description: Yale University's decision Wednesday to lift disciplinary measures against a student who had put up a poster satirizing homosexual activists is part of a growing debate over the limits of free speech on college campuses. At Dartmouth, Johns

title: MARIJUANA DRIVE REDUCES SUPPLIES AND RAISES PRICES
description: Police officials say the nation's increased efforts to curtail marijuana smuggling and cultivation and a shift by many drug traffickers into the more profitable cocaine trade are causing a deepening shortage of marijuana around the country.

title: 15 Arrested in Poland In a Demonstration
description: Fifteen young men were arrested at a downtown shopping center today as they demonstrated openly for the right of all Polish draftees to refuse military service on grounds of conscience.

title: DAVID BYRNE IN 'TRUE STORIES'
description: Luckily, a lot of the small-town American artifacts David Byrne uses in ''True Stories'' already existed, so Mr. Byrne didn't have to invent them. But he easily could have, so perfectly do they follow from the sensibility he has displayed as the singer, songwriter and visionary behind Talking Heads. Mr. Byrne's music has always been uncommonly visual, and when he began directing rock videos he seemed to be making an effortless transition. The leap to feature film making comes even more freely: ''True Stories'' is a pure and jubilant extension of Mr. Byrne's distinctive world view.

title: Allied-Campeau
description: The Allied Stores Corporation's board reportedly met to review the $66-a-share bid by the Campeau Corporation and to map strategy.

title: Uncommitted Women
description: To the Editor:

title: PITCHING A TENT FOR A GALA BENEFIT
description: Glenn Bernbaum pitched a tent next to Mortimer's, his restaurant, and charged his friends and neighbors ''20,000 cents'' to attend a lavish block party to raise money for the new laboratory for AIDS research at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Bobby Short, Felix Rohatyn, Henry Kissinger and Gloria Vanderbilt were all at the party Thursday night on Lexington Avenue at 75th Street.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. The eyebrows in this ''Portrait of a Man'' are ''coquettish,'' according to experts. Why is that noteworthy? 2. ''There is speculation as to who blinked first.'' Who made this remark, to what was he referring, and what were the circumstances? 3. Promises of bags of bagels and bran muffins, and free beer and wine loomed as ammunition in a battle for some travelers' dollars. Explain. 4. ''A miracle of some kind,'' said a family member about the eventual publication of twinned memoirs by a husband and wife. Identify the authors and explain. 5. In a game against the Boston Red Sox, Don Mattingly broke one 59-year-old Yankee club record and tied another club record. What records were they? 6. ''I've been sitting on this stoop on Sundays for over 50 years and this is the first time I've ever seen it happen,'' said a resident of Manhattan's Upper West Side. To what unusual activity was he referring? 7. For the first time in 18 years, the French Government issued an order, amid warnings that a new wave of terrorists attacks could begin soon in Paris. What was the order? 8. A major American corporation closed a facility it called ''Mother-lab.'' Identify the company and the facility. 9. President Reagan delivered a gracious address this week at the dedication of the building that has prompted this sign.

title: Quaker Sells Gerber Stake
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that it had sold its 4.8 percent stake in the Gerber Products Company back to Gerber.

title:
PATENTS;
Aircraft Laser Advance
description: A wide-angle laser window for aircraft, patented this week by the Boeing Company of Seattle, is described as directing a laser beam at a distant point or controlling an incoming beam. The inventors named in Patent No. 4,614,405 are Werner M. Brandenberg, a retired engineering supervisor, and Denis J. Pistoresi, an engineer. Mr. Pistoresi said the beams can be used for tracking targets or for optical communications. The wide-angle windows have been tested in the laboratory but not yet installed in aircraft.

title: John A. Scott, Ex-Chairman Of <u4the <u4Gannett <u4Foundation
description: John A. Scott, a former publisher and retired chairman of the Gannett Foundation, died Wednesday. He was 70 years old, and no cause of death was disclosed.

title: AN ESCAPE PLOT, WITH CROSSBOW, IS THWARTED AT PRISON IN TRENTON
description: A plot by at least six inmates to use a crossbow to kill a tower guard - or incinerate the tower and then escape from Trenton State Prison over a homemade bridge - has been thwarted, state correction officials said today.

title: Edmee Slocum Is Married To John Neilson, a Banker
description: Edmee de Montmollin Slocum of New York and John Neilson of London were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in Manhattan.

title: Memories and Anecdotes About a Formidable Editor
description: He was remembered as a tough editor, a throwback to the 20's and the Front Page, who believed in scoops and drove his reporters hard to get them.

title: ELECTION OF U.N. LEADER TO 2D TERM IS EXPECTED
description: The re-election of Javier Perez de Cuellar as Secretary General is virtually assured, diplomats said today.

title: No Headline
description: ''It's too vast,'' confessed R. K. Narayan, the Indian novelist. ''I can't go around.''

title: V for O'Neill
description: If it's seemed that Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill has become a major news figure on television in a way that his predecessors never were, you're right.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net loss

title: When Celluloid Renders Unto Mammon
description: The hottest thing in show biz?

title: VINCE DiMAGGIO IS DEAD AT 74
description: Vince DiMaggio, the oldest of the baseball-playing DiMaggio brothers, died today at his home in nearby North Hollywood. He was 74 years old.

title: Patrice Le Melle Wed to S.J. Di Cioccio
description: Patrice Marie Le Melle, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Wilbert John Le Melle of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen John Di Cioccio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carmelo Bernard Di Cioccio of West Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. William F. Guido performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: SARDI'S OWNERS PLAN TO BUILD ATLANTIC CITY CASINO-HOTEL
description: One year after purchasing Vincent Sardi's famed restaurant in the Broadway theater district (not to mention the right to merchandise the name), the producers Ivan Bloch and Harvey Klaris have announced plans to build Sardi's Broadway Hotel/Casino in Atlantic City, N.J.

title: WISE TIMES SPARKS TRAINER'S CAREER
description: Nine months ago in Florida, Phil Gleaves had just eight horses in his care, including a little-known 3-year-old named Wise Times whom the trainer half-seriously referred to as ''my Derby colt.''

title: HOW TO HELP CABBIES AND RIDERS
description: Most well-informed people of good will agree that New York City cabdrivers are due for a fare increase. Most well-informed people of good will also agree that New Yorkers need more taxi service during rush hours, in the rain, before and after the theater, and when trains, buses and planes arrive at terminals.

title:
PATENTS;
A Bilingual Computer System
description: ADATA processing system that permits concurrent operation by a number of users in different languages was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation. John G. Innes, an I.B.M. employee in Irving, Tex., was granted Patent No. 4,615,002.

title: WATERWAYS PLAN NEARS AGREEMENT
description: The House and Senate are close to an agreement on legislation that would provide for dams, ports, inland waterways and other major water projects costing as much as $16 billion, a key Senator said today.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $21,680,000, or 46 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Virginia service territory to Virginia Power.

title: Judge Backs Knudsen Deal
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved the sale of about half of the operations of Knudsen Foods Inc. to Kraft Inc. and Hughes Markets, a Southern California grocery operator.

title: Phil Niekro Honored
description: Phil Niekro of the Cleveland Indians was honored just outside the home of the Braves Thursday night at Atlanta Fulton County Stadium when a statue of the knuckleball pitcher who won 268 games in 18 seasons for Atlanta was unveiled. But as the fans on the way to the Braves final home game listened to tributes from Braves players and officials, they also heard an invitation extended to the 47-year-old hurler to return next season to Cleveland.

title: 7 BIRDIES HELP NICKLAUS
description: Rodger Davis of Australia and Jack Nicklaus reached the semifinals of the $270,000 Suntory World Match Play Championships today, Davis by defeating the four-time champion, Seve Ballesteros of Spain, and Nicklaus by defeating a rookie.

title: BOURNE AND GILLIES AVAILABLE IN DRAFT
description: The Islanders produced surprises yesterday with their list of unprotected players available for selection in the waiver draft Monday by leaving two veteran forwards, Bob Bourne and Clark Gillies, unprotected.

title: Blues at Abilene
description: The blues singer-saxophonist A. C. Reed will lead his band tonight at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Shows are around 9 P.M. and midnight, with the the Bobby Radcliff band opening; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ALEXANDER'S PLANS SHIFT TO PARTNERSHIP
description: Alexander's Inc. announced yesterday it would transform itself from a corporation into a limited partnership.

title: SENATE APPROVES $557.6 BILLION IN SPENDING, EXCEEDING '87 TARGET
description: A weary Senate today approved a $557.6 billion bill to finance Government programs for 1987, including $1.54 billion to fight drugs, a measure that pushed spending above a limit approved earlier in the budget resolution for the year.

title: SUNBELT NURSERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bond Prices Climb Sharply
description: Bond prices posted strong gains yesterday, propelled by a Government report showing an unexpected drop in employment last month.

title: U.S. OPEN TO TALKS TO FREE HOSTAGES SEIZED IN LEBANON
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was willing to have discussions with those holding the American hostages in Lebanon but that it would not yield to their demands.

title: Ladies' Mile Landmark Net Would Catch Many Nondescript Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW, UP 18 EARLY, ENDS WITH A 7.03-POINT LOSS
description: After whittling away a big first-hour gain, Wall Street saw stock prices close modestly lower yesterday, when investors again became nervous about the economy.

title: LINDENAUER, PRESSED BY DEFENSE, CANNOT RECALL TWO KEY MEETINGS
description: The Government's chief witness in a Federal corruption trial today did not recall two key meetings with a Bronx political leader, became confused when discussing a third and said that ''so much was happening, the dates were a jumble'' in his mind.

title: High Before Chernobyl
description: To the Editor:

title: MINING THE YOUNG SET FOR CAMPAIGNS
description: It was not a typical black-tie, $500-a-plate political fund-raising event.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Metropolitan Report yesterday about a speech by Governor Cuomo, on dissent in the Roman CatholIc Church, appeared with a paragraph missing.

title: FILM: 'PLAYING FOR KEEPS,' A ROCK-AND-ROLL RESORT
description: In the genre of ''Fame,'' ''Playing for Keeps'' is a movie about teen-agers with a dream, backed by a soundtrack that aspires to the Top 40. In this case, three street kids from New York, wondering if there's life after high school, try to turn a broken-down country hotel into a rock-and-roll resort, a kind of hip Hilton where there are no parents to tell them to turn down the music.

title: USX STOCK UP ON TAKEOVER
description: Indications that Carl C. Icahn, the New York takeover specialist, might soon make a move against the USX Corporation sent that company's shares sharply higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SIKHS FIRE AT TOP POLICEMAN IN PUNJAB By STEVEN R. WEISMAN
description: In the second major Indian security breach in two days, Sikh extremists slipped into a heavily guarded police compound in Punjab today and fired shots at the top police official in the state.

title: JETS GAME A HOMECOMING FRO BILLS' HULL
description: It will be an away game for the Buffalo Bills when they play the Jets at Giants Stadium on Sunday. But not for Kent Hull, the Bills' center.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Marcos Not Covered By Neutrality Act
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: Figures reflect the 5-for-4 stock split which was effective on July 31, 1986.

title: INSURING NURSING-HOME COSTS
description: Some insurance companies that offer long-term health care insurance, which helps cover nursing-home expenses, sell their policies in a limited number of states. Many companies say they hesitate to sell certain policies in New York because of strict insurance laws there.

title:
PATENTS;
A New Interferon
description: A new form of interferon was patented this week for Damon Biotech Inc. of Needham Heights, Mass.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ART SCENE Nowhere is there a more inspirational, man-made scenic backdrop than New York City, a fact that has not escaped painters, movie makers and other artists. It is a fact that emerges in the twin exhibitions now on view at Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street (535-8810).

title:
PATENTS;
Method to Remove Substances in Blood
description: For the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, a method of removing immunoreactive substances from a patient's blood was patented this week.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $269,555 from discontinued operations.

title: BIRDSONG ABSENT AS NETS START TRAINING
description: While the Nets were going through a light workout yesterday, mainly for what was billed as Media Day at the opening of their training camp at Princeton University, Otis Birdsong was more than 50 miles away at Ramapo College working on his jump shot.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lucky Stores Inc.
description: Lucky Stores Inc., a supermarket chain based in Dublin, Calif., said that its board met Thursday to discuss the proposal from New York investor Asher B. Edelman to acquire all shares of the company for $35 a share, or about $1.79 billion. The board asked for additional information from management and from Lucky's investment bankers, Goldman, Sachs & Company, and adjourned its meeting until next week. Mr. Edelman was reportedly in Europe and unavailable for comment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1986
description: International

title: How Mother Really Cooked
description: Ask any number of young Americans in the food business if their mothers were good cooks, and there is a pause and then a small nervous laugh at the other end of the telephone conversation. The notion that every good cook must have learned at his or her mother's knee is a myth. But being loving sons and daughters these food professionals are not anxious to burst the bubble.

title: Disabled Boy Awarded $6.5 Million by a Jury
description: A Federal jury today found two obstetricians and three nurses liable for an 8-year-old Florida boy's severe handicaps and awarded him $6.5 million for damages and lifetime medical costs.

title: Cardinal and Dearie Meet on Ban
description: John Cardinal O'Connor and Assemblyman John C. Dearie met for an hour and 15 minutes yesterday to discuss a ban on the Assemblyman's speaking at events sponsored by his local Roman Catholic parish.

title: Greyhound Studies Sale of Its Bus Line
description: The Greyhound Corporation, which operates the nation's largest intercity bus system, may sell nearly all of its bus operations if it does not win concessions from union workers in the next several weeks.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. After art historians who studied such details of the work concluded its style was not Rembrandt's, to whom it had been credited, the painting was attributed to ''the workshop of Rembrandt.'' 2. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made the remark after Moscow's release of an American journalist, Nicholas S. Daniloff, and the release of Gennadi F. Zakharov, a Soviet citizen who pleaded no contest to spying charges in New York. In the negotiations, President Reagan said the Soviet Union had ''blinked,'' a remark Mr. Shevardnadze deplored as ''confrontational rhetoric.'' 3. Challenging the Eastern Air Lines Air Shuttle, Pan Am prepared to inaugurate shuttle service between New York City, Washington and Boston by promises passengers such amenities as free beer, wine, bagels and muffins. 4. An autobiography by Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished Soviet physicist who won the Nobel Peace Prize, was smuggled to the West, where it is to be published after further editing. A memoir by his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, of the couple's life in Gorky, which was written on a medical visit to the United States this year, is also to be published in the West. 5. He collected two hits, a double and a single, giving him 232 hits this season and breaking the team mark of 231 set by Earle Combs in 1927. His double matched Lou Gehrig's club record of 52. 6. To catch up on a heavy backlog of mail, the Postal Service delivered mail on Sunday. 7.

title: Yet Another Loan for Mexico
description: Heave a sigh that Mexico and its creditors have agreed on another big loan, but there's no end in sight for our neighbor's troubles. Mexico needs a further $12 billion to stay afloat, and the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks have prudently set easier terms than before. But no one can be confident that Mexico's Government is prepared, or strong enough, to revitalize its economy.

title: Gelco Rejects Merger Offer
description: The Gelco Corporation, a leasing and management services concern, today rejected a merger valued at more than $250 million offered by an affiliate of Coniston Partners.

title: FIVE YALE STUDENTS SUSPENDED IN WAKE OF APARTHEID PROTEST
description: Five Yale undergraduates were suspended for the semester today for participating in an anti-apartheid sit-in at the school's investment office last month.

title: Yugoslavia Arrests An American Citizen
description: The State Department said today that Yugoslavia had arrested an American citizen for political activities conducted while the man was in the United States.

title: Carbide-GAF Accord Is Set
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, one of the nation's leading chemical companies, today signed an agreement with the GAF Corporation, which had tried to take over the company last year.

title: POPE TO BEGIN A 4-DY TRIP TO FRANCE TODAY
description: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to begin a four-day visit to France on Saturday, and the local authorities and the national Government have mounted what is said to be one of the most extensive security operations ever seen in this country.

title: 3 IN RACIST GROUP HELD ON COUNTERFEITING CHARGES
description: The Police Chief here said today that three members of the radical racist Church of Jesus Christ Christian (Aryan Nations) had been arrested on charges involving counterfeiting after the search of a house near here.

title: RED SOX UNCERTAIN ON SEAVER'S RETURN
description: Inside, where it was warm and dry, John McNamara was asked one more time about Tom Seaver's condition. He shrugged. He shook his head. He said he wasn't sure.

title: GOVERNOR HOLDS A DECIDED EDGE IN FUND-RAISING
description: Governor Cuomo spent twice as much on his radio and television advertising in the last 10 weeks as the total of funds raised by his Republican opponent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, according to financial reports filed yesterday with the State Board of Elections.

title: The What?
description: With so many buildings, monuments and even traffic circles named for people, some of whose achievements can be but dimly recalled, how can it be that one of Washington's more magnificent structures has a nondistinctive, even ambigious, name?

title: Comings and Goings
description: Frank Bush, a starting linebacker with the Houston Oilers who suffered a neck injury in a game two weeks ago, said that he was 90 percent certain he would retire after being warned by three specialists to give up football. . . . John Cangelosi, an outfielder for the Chicago White Sox, tied a 76-year-old American League record on Thursday when he stole his 49th base of the season, tying the mark for rookies set in 1910 by Rollie Zeiden of the White Sox.

title: Arab League Asks U.N. Unit To Seek End to Iran-Iraq War
description: The Arab League called on the Secutiry Council today to seek an end to the Iran-Iraq war.

title: COURT BARS SCHOOL PARTITION FOR BROOKLYN HASIDIC GIRLS
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday blocked a plan by the city's Board of Education to give remedial lessons to Hasidic girls in a partitioned-off section of a public school in Brooklyn.

title: WEISS UNDERGOES QUADRUPLE BYPASS
description: Representative Ted Weiss, a veteran Democrat from the West Side of Manhattan, underwent quadruple coronary bypass surgery here today at the Washington Hospital Center.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. The year-ago periods have been restated.

title: German Crash Kills 3 G.I.'s
description: Three United States soldiers were killed today when their helicopter crashed in West Germany, the police said. The craft had been flying close to the ground on a trip between Grafenwohr and Wiesbaden and crashed after trying to turn sharply 25 miles south of Bamberg. The three soldiers, who were not identified, were based at Wiesbaden, west of Frankfurt.

title: STOPPING HIGHWAY HYPOCRISY
description: A great many American drivers have had it up to their windshield wipers with the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit.

title: Iowa Governor Files Suit To Block Foreclosure
description: Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican, went to court today to block an Ida County farm foreclosure, saying it was the first step in halting what he called criminal foreclosures by Federal lenders throughout Iowa.

title: SETLING AN OLD WAR DEBT
description: After 122 years, a belatedly grateful nation appears ready to repay a $200,000 war debt to the city of Frederick, Md.

title: FOR ROOKIE KICKER, PRESSURE MOUNTS
description: You know the names by now. Ali Haji-Sheikh. Jess Atkinson. Eric Schubert. Bob Thomas. Joe Cooper. Raul Allegre. The grand parade of Giants kickers since the start of last season.

title: New Yorkers, by the Book
description: What is a New Yorker? A New Yorker is a person who steals a seat on the bus and a place on the movie line, crosses on the red and, if male, believes he can win at three-card monte. (The female New Yorker knows better.) That's the simple definition.

title: Likely Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: The following are among the most severe traffic trouble spots likely this weekend in the New York metropolitan region, according to the City Transportation Department.

title: CIVICS: A LINDENAUER GUIDE
description: In his testimony at Federal Court here, Geoffrey G. Lindenauer was asked to explain the workings of New York City government, as well as some of the lessons he had learned during the years he collected bribes from city contractors. Here are some of his explanations:

title: Sigma Chi Sweetheart Marks 75th Birthday
description: She was the coolest coed, the frat's meow, a mythic queen of the campus. And she supposedly inspired two Sigma Chi brothers to write what may be the nation's most famous fraternity song, tapping out the tune on an Albion College organ 75 years ago today.

title: ROTHMANS TALKS
description: Rothmans Inc. said discussions are taking place that could lead to a merger of its tobacco unit, Rothmans of Pall Mall Ltd., with Philip Morris Inc.'s unit, Benson & Hedges Canada Inc. Any agreement would be subject to Government approvals, said Rothmans, which is 71 percent-owned by Rothmans International.

title: CBS Inquiry Widens
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday broadened its inquiry into possible illegal trading in CBS stock and options.

title: Investment Bid by Peking
description: China today outlined concessions that it will make to attract desperately needed foreign investment, but said traditional-minded bureaucrats needed to revolutionize their thinking.

title: Is Sweden Too Cautious on Reindeer Radiation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooper Lasersonics
description: The Cooper Development Company said it had raised its offer for Cooper Lasersonics Inc. from a straight stock-for-stock merger to a transaction in which each ouststanding Cooper Lasersonics share would be exchanged for 1.25 shares of Cooper Development common and one-tenth of a share of Series A convertible preferred stock. The combined value of the securities is about $5, the company said. Based in Palo Alto, Calif., Cooper Development and Cooper Lasersonics were both spun off from Cooper Laboratories along with Coopervision Inc.

title: KEY RATES
CABLE TV INQUIRY IN QUEENS IS ATTACKED BY TWO LAWYERS
description: Lawyers for John A. Zaccaro and for the top judge in Queens argued in court yesterday that a grand jury that indicted Mr. Zaccaro on criminal charges and received testimony from the judge should be disqualified and its work annulled.

title: GENERAL EQUITY FUNDS AGAIN TRAIL THE MARKET
description: Despite the fact that individual investors are continuing to pour money into mutual funds, general equity funds again failed to beat the market in the third quarter of 1986.

title: Spoon Concerts
description: Joseph Jones is probably only among a few people in the city whose work involves clacking 10 serving spoons against his head.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Boeing Co., Seattle, said the Australian carrier Quantas Airways had ordered one 767-200 ER jet for $66 million, and a Dutch carrier, Transavia-Holland, ordered a 737-300 jet for $26 million. Continental Airlines said its board has approved revisions to its agreement to merge into the Texas Air Corporation, raising the amount paid for Continental common to $15.30 a share from $15.20.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page last Saturday about health insurance for nursing-home expenses incompletely specified the states where such policies are sold. Additional information about the policies appears today on page 48.

title: 2 HOSTAGES TAPE A PLEA FOR MORE EFFORT BY U.S.
description: Two American hostages pleaded for greater efforts by the United States to obtain their release in a videotape made available today by Islamic Holy War, the militant Shiite Moslem organization that says it is holding them.

title: DEMOCRAT TURNING UP THE HEAT IN NORTH CAROLINA SENATE RACE
description: Terry Sanford is a courtly man, given to understatement, not hyperbole.

title: CRESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: GRAND JURY HEARS EVIDENCE ON SUSPENDED OFFICERS
description: A special grand jury, meeting at an undisclosed location in Brooklyn, began hearing evidence yesterday against 13 suspended police officers who have been accused of stealing cash and drugs from drug dealers.

title: Associated-May
description: Shareholders of both the May Department Stores Company and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation approved the $2.47 billion acquisition of Associated by May.
