Associated holders will receive 1.72 shares of May common for each Associated common. May shareholders also approved an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 350 million, from 200 million.

title: Hawks 153, Doves 133
description: The American Security Council, a conservative, military-oriented information and lobbying group, has rated members of Congress on what it considers 10 key national security issues, such as support for the MX missile appropriation and the space-based missile defense system, and the results showed interesting patterns.

title: Belgian Reporter Freed After Customs Review
description: Immigration officials said today that they have decided not to send home a Belgian reporter they had ordered held after finding leftist literature in his luggage as he entered the United States.

title: Syrian Aide Is Seized In Iran but Later Freed
description: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped the Syrian charge d'affaires near his embassy in Teheran on Thursday, the Iranian radio reported today.

title: METS ARE RAINED OUT
description: The opening game of the Mets-Pirates season-ending series was postponed by rain last night and the teams will play a doubleheader today at Shea Stadium beginning at 1 P.M.

title: TV: 4 MORE FOR THE SITCOM CLUTTER
description: Just a couple of years ago, informed sources were assuring viewers everywhere that the situation comedy was dead. Then along came ''The Cosby Show'' and that particular insight was put to rest. Sitcoms are now tumbling out of the studio closets faster than ever before. The schedules of the three networks are no longer big enough to contain the first-run flow. New sitcoms are being featured on independent stations, on cable and even on network flagship stations outside the hallowed prime-time precincts of 8 to 11 P.M.

title: Official Language
description: U.S. English, a group lobbying for recognition of English as the official language of the United States, concedes that a constitutional amendment to do the job has virtually no chance of adoption, but the organization says it will continue to push indefinitely for its introduction in Congress.

title: Control Data Registers Offering
description: The Control Data Corporation has registered for the previously announced initial public offering of 38 million common shares of its financial services unit, the Commercial Credit Company. In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Control Data said it plans to sell 32.3 million shares of the Baltimore-based concern in the United States and 5.7 milllion shares overseas for estimated prices ranging from $21 to $24 a share.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT PACKING COMPANY reports earnings for 13wks to July 26
description: b-Net loss Both 1985 periods showed the results of Swift Independent Corp., the predecessor company. The 1985 results include a provision for realignment of operations of $3.7 million relating principally to the closing of the Hereford, Tex., plant. Swift Independent Packing became wholly owned by interests on Feb. 27, 1986.

title: ELECTRONIC TAX REPORTS BOOM
description: One of the first things that Susan K. Smith, a tax partner in the Phoenix law firm of Olsen-Smith Ltd., does when she sits down at her personal computer every morning is to call up a tax information service that keeps her apprised of the latest developments.

title: Continental Air
description: Pilots unemployed by the shutdown of Frontier Airlines have approved a plan that would guarantee jobs at Continental Airlines to those who drop claims against Frontier. Continental's parent, the Texas Air Corporation, is seeking to buy People Express and the remaining assets of Frontier. People Express, which owned Frontier, shut it down Aug. 24 and four days later filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for Frontier.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
Rabbi's Duet and Pre-Rosh ha-Shanah Shopping
description: Strange sounds - something on the order of a first group trumpet lesson - wafted out of the small shop onto Essex Street, where some of the passers-by gave smiles of recognition and others stopped to see what all the racket was.

title: GERMAN JOBLESSNESS OFF
description: Unemployment in West Germany fell sharply last month to 8.2 percent from 8.5 percent in August, and it seems likely to decline further this month, the Government said today.

title: 3 Plead in Mueller Abduction; Charges Against One Dropped
description: Three men pleaded not guilty Thursday in the kidnapping of the 9-year-old great-great-granddaughter of the founder of the Mueller Egg Noodle Company, and prosecutors dropped charges against a fourth man in the case.

title: NO PROSECUTION IN POSTAL CASE
description: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute John R. McKean, chairman of the United States Postal Service's board of governors, for his role in the awarding of $550,00 postal contract to a law firm with which he had business ties.

title: Inventory System Criticized
description: The Navy lost track of almost $320 million in aviation spare parts aboard its aircraft carriers last year, according to an internal audit released today.

title: Prudential Sales
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America is seeking partners for four commercial properties it already owns.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (NL) - Manager Jim Leyland signed a multiyear contract. BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Signed Spud Webb, guard.

title:
PATENTS;
Hood Safeguards Breathing in a Fire
description: A clear plastic hood to safeguard breathing in a fire or chemical spill has been invented for the Molecular Technology Corporation of Canton, Ohio.

title: Eight Family Members Charged in Sexual Abuse
description: A grand jury has indicted eight people in connection with the sexual abuse of 17 children who investigators say were burned, beaten, sodomized and raped by relatives.

title: Two Charged in Death of Boy Entrusted to Woman's Care
description: A Manhattan woman and the man she lives with were charged yesterday in the death of a 3-year-old boy in the woman's care.

title: THE APOLOGY IN JAPAN: MEA CULPA SPOKEN HERE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone apologized once more today for his recent offending remarks about ethnic minorities in the United States.

title: Palestinians and Shiites Fight For 3d Day in South Lebanon
description: Fighting continued for a third day today between Shiite militiamen and defenders of three Palestinian districts in southern Lebanon.

title: Philippines Sets Privatizations
description: The Philippine Government wants to sell 163 state-owned companies to raise $7 billion and save the economy $1.4 billion a year, a top minister said this week. Government Reorganization

title: MARS GRAPHIC SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Maintenance to Alter Some Subway Service
description: Track maintenance will cause a number of changes in subway service this weekend, the Transit Authority said.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS DIVIDED IN REACTION TO SENATE VOTE
description: South Africans offered varying responses today to the imposition of United States trade sanctions, in a way that suggested the cleavages of a divided nation.

title: NEW BARNEYS STORE: SPIRITED ROW HOUSES
description: The seven beige-colored row houses on West 17th Street off Seventh Avenue look unassuming enough, with regulation New York fire escapes along the facades, potted plants on windowsills and an occasional resident leaning out a window for a smoke. It seems to be New York as usual. Only the store windows along the sidewalk, with their angular red awnings, reveal that the buildings house the new Women's Store of Barneys New York.

title: ARMY DISMISSED EIGHT ACCUSED OF LESBIANISM
description: Eight military policewomen stationed at West Point have been discharged from the Army for what officials said were homosexual activities, the United States Military Academy said today.

title: CONTRACTS EXTENDED 45 DAYS
description: A strike by longshore workers that idled ports from Maine to Virginia this week was called off yesterday when the union agreed to return to work under extensions of the old contracts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There has never been a day that we have not been trying every channel to get our hostages back from Lebanon.''--President Reagan

title: TRAPPED IN BARN, MAN IN CRIME SPREE KILLS HIMSELF
description: Michael Wayne Jackson, the suspect in a three-state crime spree that set off a widespread manhunt, killed himself late Thursday night after he was cornered by the police in an abandoned barn.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $13,000 and $89,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses of $441,000 and $600,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: PROFITS ARE CORRUPTING OUR COLLEGES
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, the governing body of big-time college sports, has, as an adjunct to the professional sports business, done a good job filling stadiums. But, judged by any traditional educational criteria, the N.C.A.A. has been a dramatic failure. Unless it changes its ways, we are unlikely to make headway in returning our universities to their true function, which is teaching. This would be a tragedy not only for our schools but also for the athletes themselves.

title: SENATE PASSES ASBESTOS MEASURE
description: The Senate today passed legislation mandating a stepped-up campaign to rid the nation's schools of asbestos and sent the bill to an uncertain future at the White House.

title: AUSTRALIA LEADS U.S. DAVIS CUP
description: at Cash swept past Tim Mayotte, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, 6-2, in the completion of rain-delayed match today to give Australia a 2-0 lead over the United States in their Davis Cup tennis semifinal meeting.

title: CONCERT: SLOVAK ORCHESTRA
description: The Slovak Chamber Orchestra came to the Metropolitan Museum of Art Wednesday night bringing with it a particularly high level of enthusiasm, warmth and technical precision. One wishes there had been a little more adventure to go along with these admirable qualities - some music from today's Czechoslovakia or at least a celebration of its recent glories.

title: Eastern Air Unions Fight Takeover Bid
description: The leaders of three major unions at Eastern Air Lines have begun a last ditch effort to prevent Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, from gaining control of the carrier, union sources said yesterday.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SWINDLING VICTIM AND SUSPECT FIND JUSTICE IS ALL IN TIMING
description: For Jesus Felix Sanchez, this was a week of sweet justice.

title: CHANGES IN CAR RACING
description: The International Auto Sport Federation (FISA) today announced changes in the rules of the Formula One and world rally championships aimed at improving safety and reducing rapidly rising costs.

title: SEVEN-UP SALE SET AT $240 MILLION
description: A small Dallas investment firm yesterday established itself as a solid No. 3 in the soft-drink industry by agreeing to acquire the Seven-Up Company's domestic business from Philip Morris Inc. for $240 million.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL: METS VS. PITTSBURGH PIRATES, at Shea Stadium, 2, 1:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, first game, 1 P.M. and 8:15 P.M.; Channel 9, second game, 4 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) YANKEES VS. RED SOX, at Boston, 2, 1:05 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:05 P.M.) ATLANTA BRAVES VS. ASTROS, at Houston, 2:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.)

title: Harris Trio
description: The pianist Barry Harris will lead his trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.

title: Japan Suspends Tobacco Tariffs
description: Japan has agreed to suspend tariffs on imports of tobacco products from the United States, following a complaint by the Reagan Administration a year ago that Japan's import restrictions were unfair.

title: U.S. SANCTIONS MAY NOT HURT SOUTH AFRICA ECONOMY MUCH
description: While laden with symbolism, the new United States sanctions against South Africa will not have much direct impact on South Africa's economy, or on American corporations operating there.

title: AILMENT KEEPS KARAJAN FROM ORCHESTRA TOUR
description: Herbert von Karajan, the Austrian conductor, has contracted Lyme disease and has withdrawn from this month's tour of the United States and Tokyo by the Berlin Philharmonic. The announcement was made yesterday by Peter Gelb of Columbia Artists Management in New York.

title: U.S. AIDES UPBEAT ON ICELAND TALKS
description: President Reagan hopes to achieve an informal agreement with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on medium-range missiles when the two leaders meet next weekend in Iceland, a ranking White House official said today.

title: BOEING WORKERS REJECT CONTRACT BUT UNION AGREES TO RESUME TALKS
description: The union representing 40,000 machinists for the Boeing Company voted today to reject a new contract, but union leaders asked workers to ignore a midnight strike deadline and both sides agreed to resume negotiations Saturday.

title: FEEDING FIDO IS BIG BUSINESS
description: Last year, an estimated $5.4 billion in pet food was sold in America, almost four times more than was spent on baby food. Grocery stores took in more money selling pet food than they did selling cereal, candy, soup or coffee.

title: THE DANCE: SACHIYO ITO, WITH A BOW TO THE PAST
description: Sachiyo Ito and Company performed Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church as if dance were an art of taking care.

title: BETSY B. KAUFMAN
description: Betsy B. Kaufman, the dean of students at Queens College, died of cancer Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: ARTS TNNANTS ENLIST FOUNDATION AID
description: A foundation created by Frederick W. Richmond, a former member of Congress from Brooklyn, has offered to pay $750,000 to Michael Bennett for the option to buy a lower Broadway building that is owned by Mr. Bennett and that houses several dance companies, theater crafts workshops and rehearsal studios.

title: Buying a Policy For Disability
description: INDIVIDUAL disability insurance is one of the few categories of insurance that is more often bought than sold. Since commissions to agents and brokers are generally smaller, both in percentage and dollar terms, than they are for life insurance, salesmen may not push disability policies as hard as other types of insurance. As a result, buyers must do a lot of their own homework.

title: Soviet Seamen in Raft Rescued by U.S. Copter
description: An Air Force helicopter rescued a Russian seaman floating in a life raft in the Atlantic Ocean today after he was seen by chance from an Air Force cargo plane, the Defense Department said.

title: 22D GAME IN CHESS MATCH IS ADJOURNED ON 41ST MOVE
description: Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the 22d game of their title series today.

title: Arthur C. Kaufmann, Ex-Business Executive
description: Arthur C. Kaufmann, former chief executive of Gimbels in Philadelphia, died Wednesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: RULES FOR ATHLETES ARE ELITIST
description: Rules and the general antipathy against ''compromising'' academic standards for college athletes deserve only scorn. They are premised on an elitist notion that a university's mission excludes all but purely cerebral endeavors. They are a vestige of bygone days when universities were seen as ivory towers isolated and protected from the ugly influences and values of the working classes. It's time to discard these notions.

title: A Judge Is Moved To Help the Homeless
description: From the windows of his chambers in the First Department of the State Supreme Court Appellate Division at 25th Street and Madison Avenue, the presiding justice, Francis T. Murphy, has seen increasing numbers of apparently homeless people wandering by.

title: Books of The Times; A Cast of Storytellers
description: CELEBRATION. By Mary Lee Settle. 356 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95. In her last novel, ''The Killing Ground'' - the fifth and concluding volume of a cycle of historical novels called ''The Beulah Quintet'' - Mary Lee Settle examined the reasons her heroine, one Hannah McKarkle, had decided to become a novelist, and she traced the impulse back to Hannah's need to understand her brother's death, her need to make sense of her own losses and her family's past through the redemptive art of storytelling. Though the backdrop to her latest novel could hardly be more different - swinging London of the 1960's, instead of the American South - this same theme reverberates through its pages. The characters in ''Celebration'' not only count themselves as survivors of emotional trauma (deaths, betrayals and other defections of the heart), but they also emerge as inveterate storytellers, jabbering away to one another - and to us - about their fears, grievances and dreams.

title: Ex-Coach Wins Case
description: If Sam Goldwyn, the oft-quoted Hollywood producer, really did say that ''a verbal contract is not worth the paper it's written on,'' he was proven wrong on Thursday in Tucson, Ariz. Ben Lindsey, the former basketball coach at the University of Arizona, was awarded $695,000 by a Pima County jury, which apparently believed his contention that the university violated an oral contract by dismissing him after only one season.

title: MIAMI UNIT TO REVIEW PLAYERS' INCIDENTS
description: University of Miami officials today formed a six-member committee to investigate off-field incidents that have given the nation's top-ranked college football team an image that the officials said could hurt the university.

title: Marine Said to Admit He Caused Derailment
description: One of three Marines arrested for burglarizing Southern Pacific trains has also admitted causing a $3.5 million derailment near Palm Springs in August, the railroad police said today.

title: JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 6.9%, U.S. REPORTS
description: Reversing three months of improvement, the nation's unemployment rate climbed two-tenths of a percentage point in September, to 6.9 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: KING NOT READY AS CAMP OPENS
description: Bernard King emerged from more than 18 months of self-imposed exile this morning. He donned his Knick uniform for the first time since he suffered a serious knee injury near the end of the 1984-85 season and, after refusing to speak publicly throughout his arduous rehabilitation, he spoke candidly about the prospects of his return. His answers were not promising.

title: Bridge; A Vintage Television Series Returns to the Screen Today
description: A series of bridge programs for television made more than a decade ago will be broadcast again starting today, for viewers of cable television in Manhattan.

title: REALTY SOUTH INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Figures are not available since the company began operations on May 1, 1985.

title: Lawyer Is Indicted in Levine Case
description: Ilan K. Reich, a 32-year-old former partner of one of the nation's top law firms, was indicted yesterday on Federal charges that he helped Dennis B. Levine make nearly three quarters of a million dollars with insider information.

title: The President Has Grain on His Face
description: Should American taxpayers subsidize Soviet grain purchases? A year ago the idea would have been unthinkable, outrageous. Not in this election year. With control of the Senate in doubt, President Reagan bowed to farm-state pressure and agreed to subsidies.

title: U.S. HALTS ALL GOODS COMING FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Reagan Administration today ordered a halt of all South African goods coming to the United States pending clarification by the Administration of how to enforce the economic sanctions enacted by Congress on Thursday.

title: Albanians Provided a Haven for Jews When Others Did Not
description: To the Editor:

title: More Field Shredding May Await the Mets
description: To the Editor:

title: For Coach, Time Runs Out
description: Joe Yukica, Dartmouth's football coach, was musing the other day in his comfortable office on the second floor of the Davis Field House, an office that will no longer be his after Nov. 22.

title: Hawks Re-sign Webb
description: The Atlanta Hawks yesterday signed Spud Webb, a free agent, to a four-year contract.

title: Industrial Equity
description: The Hong Kong-based investment firm, Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., has purchased 5.8 percent of Consolidated Capital Income Trust and said it ''does not intend to be a passive investor'' in the real estate trust, which is based in Emeryville, Calif. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Industrial Equity said it has met with the management of Consolidated concerning possible representation on the board.

title: What to Do If Haircuts Go Wrong
description: A GOOD haircut is as much a part of fashion as an alligator belt or a cashmere jacket. Seems simple enough. But what is a good haircut? And, more important, what should a man or woman do about a bad one?

title: J. D. Salinger Sues to Bar a Biography
description: The author J. D. Salinger filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to bar the distribution of a biography about him.

title: Memo From Utility Draws Ire
description: The disclosure of a memorandum alleging kickbacks and favoritism within the Tennessee Valley Authority's retirement system is an example of the deception practiced by the utility's management, the agency's former general counsel said Thursday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article on big gainers and losers on the stock market included one company erroneously. The company stock of Fertility and Genetics Research Inc. fell only modestly during the time it traded in the third quarter.

title: '86 VEHICLES SET RECORD FOR SALES
description: Helped along by financing incentives and the popularity of light trucks, vehicle sales edged up to a fresh record for the 1986 model year.

title: F.B.I. WILL SEEK AIDE WHO CITED NEWS DECEPTION
description: The White House has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to find the source of a news report that the Administration organized an elaborate ''disinformation'' campaign that misled American reporters, Administration officials said today.

title: Dickinson Falls To North Bergen
description: North Bergen (2-0) struck for two quick touchdowns in the second quarter and defeated Dickinson (1-2), 13-6, yesterday at North Hudson Park, North Bergen.

title: HOW THE REBELS SEIZED THE PALACE
description: THE RISE OF THE COUNTER-ESTABLISHMENT From Conservative Ideology to Political Power. By Sidney Blumenthal. 369 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95

title: JUILLARD: A RENEWED QUARTET
description: AS THE JUILLIARD STRING Quartet begins rehearsing in a bare little room, the foursome - casually opened shirts and sneakers notwithstanding - becomes a study in different kinds of intensity. Robert Mann, the quartet's first violinist and one of its founders, simultaneously attacks the music at full tilt and breathes it in with rapt receptivity. Joel Krosnick practically dances around his cello with a fierce impishness. Samuel Rhodes, the violist, seems to wrap himself around his instrument as if to make it one with his innermost self. And, as he concentrates, there is a contraction of near pain on the face of Joel Smirnoff, the second violinist and the quartet's newest member. EVEN IN THIS WORKADAY MO-ment, the four pack enough power to fuel a Concorde. As usual, however, it isn't long before somebody interrupts with a concrete technical question: Smirnoff wonders whether Mann needs to give so marked an entry cue for the others.

title: BEHIND THE WARRING FACTIONS IN A BLOODY EAST BEIRUT
description: A POWERrrxh struggle involving President Amin Gemayel and three rival Christian factions erupted in several battles last week in and around predominantly Christian East Beirut. The violence began when about 300 Syrian-backed militiamen stormed predominantly Christian East Beirut from the Moslem, or western, side of the Green Line, which divides the city.

title: AT HIS BEST IN WAR
description: IRON EAGLE The Turbulent Life of General Curtis LeMay. By Thomas M. Coffey. Illustrated. 474 pp. New York. Crown. $18.95.

title: For Quick Relief, Take Barbecue
description: I arrived in Dallas ravenous and so I didn't go directly to the hotel, but to a barbecue restaurant instead. At the restaurant I was something of a spectacle, all formal-looking in the most casual of places.

title: PETER BRADFORD HAS UTILITIES ON EDGE
description: PETER A. Bradford has not yet taken over as chairman of New York State's Public Service Commission - the State Senate has not even set the date for hearings on his confirmation. But already he has the utilities on edge.

title: NEW UNIT TO SERVE HIGH-RISK INFANTS
description: WHEN Ellen McNees of Westport gave birth to her first child, Matthew, two months ago, she thought of her brother who had died unexpectedly in his crib 35 years ago. Ms. McNees's mother also thought of her deceased son.

title: PRAIRIE PANTHEISM AND OTHER AMERICANA
description: FROM HOMICIDE TO SLAVERY Studies in American Culture. By David Brion Davis. 305 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: DISCIPLINED TEMS THAT DARE
description: THE man with the magical touch was sitting behind his desk the other day sorting mail and choosing 8-by-10 color photographs of himself to be autographed. This was business as usual for him; at least, it seemed so because Dave Johnson was not smiling. Not on a game day. Johnson will not allow himself such irrational pleasures with his team 20 games in front and the race already over. If he is standing behind the batting cage, pacing the dugout, offering a grudging postgame analysis to the media, Johnson reveals only his hardened side. Little more.

title: DRUGS DOMINATING FLORIDA CAMPAIGN
description: ''It's gotten a little ridiculous,'' a Florida Republican committeeman says of this state's heated Senate race, which matches the Republican incumbent, Paula Hawkins, against Gov. Bob Graham, a Democrat. ''You turn on the television set and you'd think that the two of them were running for sheriff.''

title: Michel Aoun, Career Officer
description: Gen. Michel Aoun is a 51-year-old career officer of the Lebanese regular army, which has about 37,000 troops, half of them stationed in Christian areas of the country. During 11 years of civil war, the army, divided between its own Christian and Moslem units, has sometimes come into conflict with militias, though it has more often avoided combat.

title: PLAN FOR BETTING PARLOR HALTED
description: PLANS for a 1,000-capacity offtrack betting theater in Windsor Locks have been put on hold by State Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, who has ruled that the operation would violate Connecticut's 1979 moratorium on the construction of new betting theaters.

title: 'Peggy Sue Got Married,' Time Travel by Francis Coppola
description: ''PEGGY SUE GOT MARRIED'' is Francis Coppola's ''Back to the Future,'' with the estimably comic Kathleen Turner in the Michael J. Fox role, that of a time-traveler hurtled back to the something less than tumultuous 1959-60 high-school year.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A TALE OF FIVE BROTHERS AND OF 'TOMATOES IN WINTER'
description: OF THE several pictures of my father around the house, my favorite is the one in which he is holding my niece, at the time a bubbling, laughing 6-month-old.

title: HANNAH, WITH HER IMPLACABLE NEEDS
description: ENCHANTMENT By Daphne Merkin. 288 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: Long Island; Five Interceptions Stop Oyster Bay
description: The Carle Place Frogs chalked up a major victory this week, upsetting Oyster Bay, 22-8, in Nassau County's Conference 4.

title: TOXIC SITE TALLY GROWING?
description: TOXIC waste contamination on Long Island may be far more widespread than has been estimated by the state, several recent developments indicate.

title: Verbatim; Religious Dissent
description: 'I think that we should be neither surprised nor feel seriously threatened by disagreement among bishops and theologians or bishops and politicians in areas that don't touch the vital, central core of our belief.' Governor Cuomo a Roman Catholic who has publicly disagreed with leaders of the New York archdiocese, during a forum at St. James Cathedral in Brooklyn.

title: ART IN BROOKLYN REFLECTS IMMIGRATION
description: THERE is a central question that bedevils both the curator of an art exhibition and the administrator of an immigration law: Who should be admitted and who should be left out? The title of the new exhibition that opens opens Tuesday at the Museum of the Borough of Brooklyn, ''Tides of Immigration: Romantic Visions and Urban Realities,'' betokens a relationship in this instance between the policies of art and government.

title: TRIAL OPENS FOR EGYPTIAN POLICE WHO RIOTED
description: The first of 1,324 young security police draftees charged with going on a rampage last February went on trial today, but the proceedings were immediately put off for a month because the court had been unable to photocopy documents in time.

title: With a New Baby Boom, a Buying Boom
description: ''Definitely,'' said Marcia Handler. ''I've been noticing more babies. Tons of babies.''

title: CHURCH'S PARISHONERS CHANGE WITH THE TIDE
description: ''MY WIFE is the ocean,'' said the Rev. Charles H. McTague, ''and my children are its seamen.''

title: CABARET: MAXINE LAPIDUSS
description: THE rising young singer-comedienne Maxine Lapiduss is a shrewd strategist of urban survival techniques. In her one-woman show at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street), Miss Lapiduss demonstrates how a blueberry-filled jelly doughnut can be used defensively to ward off approaching muggers on the subway.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THE best possible financial arrangement to have with another person is defined by the old saw that goes ''What's mine is mine and what's yours is mine.'' The problem is that the person at the short end of the stick very often adopts a selfish and uncooperative attitude.

title: 'HOT LIPS' AT THE CRAFTMARKET
description: SO WHAT'S new about the Morristown CraftMarket, which will be in town this coming weekend?

title: THEATER: PSYCHOANALYSIS IN 'SCENT OF ALMONDS'
description: THERE are moments of gnawing pain in ''A Scent of Almonds'' by Marjorie Osterman, and guilt surges up around five of the six characters like the waters of an engulfing flood. The emotions aroused by this strange play come almost entirely from the material, not from the maddening contrivances of Ms. Osterman's plot. But there is enough power in it to make one wonder whether it might not have become a real tragedy if the playwright had infused it with a deeper dramatic imagination.

title: 'Adam's Task'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEBRASKA RALLY TOPS S. CAROLINE, 27-24
description: A safety, Bryan Siebler, recovered a fumble and made an interception in the last two minutes today to enable third-ranked Nebraska to rally for a a 27-24 victory over South Carolina, a four-touchdown underdog.

title: THE SUMMER I WAS DRAWN INTO THE SPIDER'S WEB
description: I FIRST saw the spider in late August, a big, black, pear-shaped creature with the bright yellow markings of a bumblebee. Its long reddish legs shot out from its body like skinny spokes and tapered to thin, lethal-looking points.

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE: THE OTHER FACTORS
description: Re: Michael Borsuk's recent article ''The Liability Insurance Crisis: A Threat to Jobs,'' on the Opinion Page:

title: 2 ASSAULT RATHER ON PARK AVE.
description: Dan Rather, the CBS News anchorman, was assaulted on Park Avenue by two unknown men last night, the police said.

title: WITH OLIVE BRANCH AND SWORD, AQUINO HAS HER HANDS FULL
description: PRESIDENT Corazon C. Aquino, who came to power with a dream of reconciliaton, is being pushed to take sides in an increasingly polarized nation.

title: AT THE I.M.F., WINKS AND NODS MAY BE THE NEWS
description: MOST of the world's finance ministers were in Washington last week trying to master the riddles of a weak world economy. They went home with little more than token achievements and high-minded declarations that obscured the usual discord. But there were hints, in their winks and nods and in the restlessness of the financial markets, that the gathering's epitaph has yet to be written - that the ground may have been laid for a lower dollar or a reduction in foreign interest rates, both of which President Reagan wants.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: HARD TIMES: An Oral History of the Great Depression, by Studs Terkel. (Pantheon, $6.95.) Studs Terkel's chronicle of the Depression era, told in the words of more than 160 Americans who lived through it, presents the reader with constant surprise, Richard Rhodes said in The Book Review in 1970. ''Surprise not only at the extent of the experience that most people called 'hard times,' '' he said, ''but the extraordinary depths of the memories that Mr. Terkel evokes. . . . Mr. Terkel draws them out, guilt, irony, humor and pain intact.'' LIFETIME, by Scott Sommer. (Washington Square/ Pocket Books, $5.95.) ''Crisscross,'' the longest piece in Scott Sommer's collection of three stories and two novellas, is about a 10-year-old boy who lives with his alco-holic mother in a dingy hotel in Key West, Fla., and it is a virtuoso performance, Jonathan Baumbach said here in 1981.

title: OLD KENTUCKY TOWNS
description: Augusta, Maysville and Washington are three small pioneer towns in northeast Kentucky - a gentle and pastoral land with a savage history, where old buildings are left to tell some of the story. And the Ohio River keeps rolling on.

title: 'CASINO' RAIL LINE 50% DONE
description: A MONSTER machine that looks as if it might have served as a giant caterpillar in a cheap science-fiction movie pulled into town here last month.

title: Reeking of Savoir-Faire
description: THE OBSERVANCE this summer of the 100th anniversary of the tuxedo evoked painful memories for me of a long ago when I yearned to pass for a man of the world. My dream then was to be suave and sophisticated and to reek of savoir-faire.

title: PASSPORT TO MEMORIES
description: It is a hot Sunday afternoon in Washington, and I am engaged in one of my favorite pastimes - wishful thinking. I am thinking wishfully that I would rather be on another continent; Europe would do nicely.

title: EYES ON THE FLYWAY
description: CONNIE HAGAR The Life History of a Texas Birdwatcher. By Karen Harden McCracken. 296 pp. College Station: Texas A & M University Press. $18.95.

title: SUFFOLK EYEING DRUG TESTING
description: DRUG testing and counseling programs for all Suffolk County employees may begin as early as next year, county officials say.

title: A LIFE ON THE COURT
description: SHORTLY BEFORE 10 tomorrow morning, as the United States Supreme Court begins its 1986 October term, Justice William J. Brennan Jr. will leave his chambers, turn right, then left, toward the small locker-lined robing room. There, he will slip his black judicial robe over his suit before crossing the corridor to await, along with his colleagues, for 10 o'clock precisely to arrive. At that time, a short electronic beep will sound, followed immediately by the sound of the marshal's gavel. Brennan will pass through the red velvet curtain that divides the anteroom from the courtroom to take his place on the mahogany bench just to the right of the Chief Justice, the seat traditionally occupied by the Associate Justice with the greatest seniority. Tomorrow will mark the beginning of Justice Brennan's 30th year on the Court. He is 80 years old and very fit, in part as a result of daily sessions on his exercise bicycle. Only two Justices appointed in this century, William O. Douglas and Hugo L. Black, have sat on the High Court longer than Brennan. During his tenure, he has written not only leading, but landmark, cases. And yet, despite his colorful personality, his long tenure and the enormous impact he has made on American life, Brennan remains, like all of the Justices, relatively unknown to most people.

title: Making the Home a Hall
description: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, whose opinions on almost everything are often and eagerly cited by German literati, defined architecture as ''frozen'' music. One may argue about the parallels between musical and architectural forms, but there is no question that music has always been strongly influenced by the architectural space available for its performance - so strongly, in fact, that it is no exaggeration to say that the space in which music is heard is part of the music.

title: IN HOMAGE TO BEN-GURION
description: I FIRST MET DAVID Ben-Gurion when I was yet a youth, and he already a legend. I spoke with him for the first time when he took me in his car from Tel Aviv to Haifa, a two-hour trip at that time. He was not a man of small talk, and most of the drive passed in disappointment for me, as he sat in silence. Toward the end of the trip, he suddenly turned to me and said: ''You know, Trotsky wasn't a true leader. Lenin was.'' I was dumbfounded. I did not understand why he had suddenly chosen to raise this subject, but I was curious, and I wanted to start a conversation, so I asked: ''Why?'' And he, as though waiting for the question, immediately replied: ''What is this 'no-peace-and-no-war'? This is a Jewish invention. A leader must know how to decide - either war, with all the risks this involves, or peace, and pay the price. Even though intellectually Lenin was inferior to Trotsky, Lenin became the leader of the Russian people because he knew how to decide.''

title: 10 TINY TREATS
description: 1. Tucked away on Montmartre, behind the museum and the Lapin Agile tavern and bordered by the Rue des Saules and the Rue St. Vincent, is a pocket-sized vineyard that yields 800 bottles a year. Never mind that connoisseurs have been turning up their noses at the product, called Clos Montmartre, since the 16th century.

title: A PRIDE OF POETS AT WATERLOO
description: POETRY, says Dr. James Haba, an associate professor of English at Glassboro State College, means - according to its Greek derivation - ''to make,'' and thus ''a poet is a maker and a poem is a made thing.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THE TORRID TANGO Two authentic Spanish dance troupes will elevate the temperature in theaters in the county next weekend. The ''Tango Fever'' group will perform at 8:30 P.M. Saturday in The Music Hall, at 13 Main Street in Tarrytown, demonstrating the dance that was shunned by respectable people when it was introduced in the waterfront dives of Buenos Aires at the turn of the century. By the 1920's it had become the rage of Paris and New York City, and is now enjoying a revival here - largely attributable to ''Tango Argentino,'' the South American dance production that took Broadway by storm last season.

title: CLARIFICATION OFFERED ON WHITESBOG SITE
description: The Sept. 14 article ''Historic Sites in Pinelands Endangered'' was timely. Whitesbog, a prime example of an endangered site, is indeed close to disappearing.

title: Changes Favoring Insiders
description: DURING the conversion of a rental building to co-op ownership, the tenants' committee is naturally eager to strike the best possible deal with the sponsor. Each tenant is also individually trying to make the best arrangements for himself.

title: STATE HONORS TEACHER IN RYE
description: THE notion was first articulated almost 2,400 years ago in Plato's masterwork on political philosophy, ''The Republic.'' In a winding and intricate dialogue, the ingenius interlocutor Socrates argues that the livelihood of the polis ultimately depends on the ethical and intellectual education of the citizenry. Without a commitment to education, Socrates warned, the state would unravel and experience inexorable decline.

title: Martha Wachtel To Become Bride Of Judd Burstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Wachtel of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Jean Wachtel to Judd Burstein, a son of Justice Beatrice S. Burstein of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Herbert Burstein. The wedding is planned for Dec. 7.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This will end the mythology of the dumb little Dutch boy with his stupid finger in the dike to save his country.

title: 'Next Time You See a Farm Sale on TV, It Will Probably Be Us'
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE 4-MILE LUNCH THEY descend on busy Marcus Avenue in Lake Success every weekday, starting at 11:45 A.M. In various abbreviated outfits and assorted shapes and sizes, the jogging men and women of the Sperry Corporation are on the move.

title: Deborah Kruter Plans to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Kruter of Huntington, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Kruter, to Todd James Langille, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Langille of Henniker, N.H.

title: Lahr and Perelman
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE ALBUMS SHED LIGHT ON POP SINGERS' CAREERS
description: The three albums under consideration here might seem oddly matched, and other than the fact that they're all by women singers, perhaps they are. Cyndi Lauper is a big if recent star; Bonnie Raitt has been around for years with a loyal cult but no mass success, and Rosie Vela is an unknown, with her debut album. But the three offer interesting, complementary insights into the relationship between music and image in the pop music of the 1970's and 80's.

title: COPYRIGHTS ARE AS VITAL AS MERCHANCISE
description: I TAEWON, a sprawling commercial district in South Korea's capital of Seoul, is a bargain-hunter's paradise. In shops and on the streets, vendors hawk audiotape cassettes for $2.50 - before any bargaining starts. Authentic-looking Louis Vuitton handbags are $12, and Gore-Tex running suits, which sell for $150 in the States, go for $45. The standard price for all types of Reebok athletic shoes is $10. The major constraint facing shoppers is not paying for, but physically carrying, all the products they would like to buy.

title: Jean Gonick Defended
description: To the Editor:

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
London's Resolute Wit
description: THE ENGLISH clothes for spring are serious, but not too serious. As always, there is something unexpected about them, a small surprise. One sees it in the wit of Betty Jackson's severe little pin-stripe coats, white embroidered batiste shirts and frivolous mini-culottes. And in Alistair Blair's strictly tailored fingertip jacket worn over a saucy black-and-white bustier and cropped pants. It exists in Joseph Tricot's classic cardigan, which is casually slung over a modern, oversize striped pullover and tubular knit skirt. It surfaces in Jean Muir's ladylike button-front dress, paired with a Turkish embroidered cap.

title: 10 KILLED IN LATVIA WHEN BRIDGE FAILS A TEST OF STRENGTH
description: The Soviet Union has announced that 10 people were killed and 14 were injured last month when a 40-year-old bridge over Latvia's main river collapsed during a test for strength.

title: A Few More Pieces of The AIDS Puzzle
description: AIDS researchers, after five years of trying to puzzle out patterns of infection, continue to report pieces of answers. At a conference in New Orleans last week, they described studies suggesting that, at least among heterosexuals, the virus is not easily transmitted.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Vanishing Act By Cape Whales WHEN most of the humpback whales disappeared this spring from the Stellwagen Bank off Provincetown, Mass., it was like old friends leaving suddenly without saying where they were going or why or even goodbye.

title: WHAT HAVE THEY DONE WITH THEIR PEACE?
description: BITTER VICTORY By Robert Shaplen. 309 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: FRANCES THE DOORMAT
description: GROUP SEX By Ann Arensberg. 175 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: THEIR SPECIALTY WAS MURDER
description: THE NAZI DOCTORS Medical Killing and the Psychology of Genocide. By Robert Jay Lifton. 561 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: DAYS BEFORE OPENING, JOBS STILL VACANT AT DANBURY MALL
description: WIELDING sanders or saws, driving forklifts or floor cleaners and stacking shelves or creating window displays, scores of workers are scrambling to complete the Danbury Fair Mall for its scheduled opening Thursday.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL '86: FRESNO STATE;
A FATHER-SON YARD GAME
description: A STRANGE sight indeed, but there it was in black and white.

title: F. L. AMES WED TO MISS GARDNER
description: Rebecca Burnett Gardner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lowell Gardner of South Hamilton, Mass., and Dark Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Frederick Lothrop Ames, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ames of Boston, North Easton, Mass., and Boca Grande, Fla. The Rev. Barry R. Howe performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Hamilton, Mass.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHILDREN, PARENTS
description: ''Caring is an essential aspect of education in a free society, but often we do not know how to care, to understand our children, to communicate with them and to facilitate their adjustment to adult life,'' said Olga Brom, director of the Institute for Single Parent Family. The insitute is one of the sponsors of a conference on ''Parenting in the 80's'' that will be held Oct. 18 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville.

title: Recent Sales
description: Allendale $330,000 73 Forest Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split-level; fireplace, modern eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $5,002. Bridgewater $163,000 416 Route 28 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; dining room, patio, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,416.

title: OUR BOYS
description: ERNIE'S WAR The Best of Ernie Pyle's World War II Dispatches. Edited with a biographical essay by David Nichols. Foreword by Studs Terkel. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: ADJUNCT TEACHERS: NEED FOR FAIR WAGES
description: THIS past spring I found myself spending a full seven- or eight-hour day each week reading nearly 50 student essays, marking them for errors and writing comments that I hoped would help my students think and write more clearly. Clear thinking is desperately needed in this world, as we all know, and I am convinced that good writing is the way to clear thinking (and vice versa). I could not help wondering, rather grimly, after each session of classes and paper-marking, why society seems so unwilling to provide smaller, more teachable classes - and decent pay - for those of us who are trying so hard to produce that most valuable of society's assets: clear-thinking youth.

title: TOUGHING IT OUT AT DEAN WITTER
description: PHILIP J. PURCELL, Dean Witter's 43-year-old chief, is no hands-on manager. ''I can hire the people I need for that,'' he says. Nor is he a Wall Street whiz. In fact, prior to five years ago, he had no experience in the financial community. Mr. Purcell is a business consultant turned corporate strategist. And since 1978, when Sears Roebuck hired him away from McKinsey & Company, he has been the driving force behind the huge retailer's decision to leap into financial services. He suggested Dean Witter as the principal vehicle for that diversification.

title: A Coming Broadway Attraction
description: LAST April, the Broadway Theater, a Shubert Organization house on the southwest corner of Broadway at 53d Street, reopened after a lavish $8 million interior renovation with a production of the musical ''Big Deal.'' The musical received mixed reviews, but the theater itself was a hit.

title: Invisible Monument
description: When completed in 1990, the first phase of New York City's third water tunnel will be all but invisible to most city residents. Its heart, a 600-foot-long distribution chamber in which water under pressure will be routed from 24-foot tunnels to 8-foot pipes and back into tunnels again, is taking shape 280 feet under Van Cortlandt Park.

title: A Wall Tumbles in A Brooklyn School
description: The United States Supreme Court, reaffirming its traditional insistence on the separation of church and state, ruled last year that public school systems may not send teachers into parochial schools to provide remedial instruction. What to do, then, about the Federal law requiring that such lessons be given - by public school teachers - to all parochial students who need them?

title: VOTER REGISTRATION INCREASES 11% IN NASSAU, 20% IN SUFFOLK
description: WHILE the population of Long Island has stabilized in the last five years at about 2.6 million, there has been a steady increase in voter registration in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, with both major parties sharing in the gains, county elections officials report.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IF A piano in Richard Smith's Piano Exchange at Smith Street and Dosoris Lane, Glen Cove, started playing by itself some night, his neighbors might not be at all surprised, although they would be hearing a dead composer playing a very live piano.

title: BROCCOLI GETS STAR TREATMENT
description: ACROSS the state this fall, a number of farmers are harvesting a new crop. In Glastonbury and Goshen, Woodstock and East Windsor and on a small number of farms in between, some 335,000 pounds of broccoli are being cut and crated, then shipped to major Connecticut supermarkets, where only imported broccoli - primarily from California and Maine -used to be available.

title: Is the Middle Class Doomed?
description: Barbara Ehrenreich's article ''Is the Middle Class Doomed?'' (Sept. 7), framed thoughts I have been pondering for some time.

title: SEMINARIES IN U.S. GET A HIGH GRADE
description: The majority of Roman Catholic seminaries in the United States are ''serving the church well in preparing candidates for the priesthood,'' according to a long-anticipated report by a Vatican official that was released today.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THREE FORMS OF SUDDEN DEATH: And Other Reflections on the Grandeur and Misery of the Body. By F. Gonzalez-Crussi. (Harper & Row, $15.95.)

title: SENATE PREPARING FOR TRIAL OF JUDGE
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, the first sitting Federal judge ever to be convicted of a felony, will have what is likely to be his final day in court this week. The court is the Senate of the United States, which will try the 69-year-old judge on four articles of impeachment voted unanimously by the House of Representatives in July.

title: A Jewish Dancing Master's Ideas Speak to Us Today
description: Dancing in a theater - especially ballet and modern-dance - is so familiar that we take its premises for granted. Yet choreography was once a new theoretical concept. Moreover, the style and manner of performance, even the idea that steps should be memorized and a vocabulary learned and perfected, were anything but givens during a great deal of human history.

title: SOME BOUNTY FOR THOSE WHO SIT
description: IT is the season to reap (literally) the bounty of an entire spring and summer spent on one's knees tending one's suburban vegetable patch. And I am duly impressed with those who can claim such an honor since I, with my gray thumb, am not among them. Not for me the digging, mulching, pruning, weeding, spraying and dancing for rain that some call therapeutic and I call downright boring.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
A Big Boost for Meadowlands Housing
description: SINCE the first brick warehouses went up in the Hackensack Meadowlands in the early 1970's, development has increased markedly, turning marshland into a thriving commercial and industrial precinct. By contrast, residential growth has been sluggish: Only one large-scale housing project - the 1,222-unit Harmon Cove - has taken root there in the last decade.

title: FIVE SPECIAL JUDGES IN CITY STILL WAITING FOR COURTROOM
description: An emergency program to increase the number of judges to deal with a sharp increase in drug arrests has left five of the 20 new judges ready to serve, but with literally no place to sit.

title: The Met's New 'Walkure' Favors Romantic Naturalism
description: When the Metropolitan Opera decided to turn over responsibility for its new ''Ring'' to Otto Schenk and Gunther Schneider-Siemssen, the team that had directed and designed its celebrated ''Tannhauser,'' a corner seemed to have been turned. In recent years, the ''Ring'' has been treated, even at Bayreuth, as a springboard off which trendy stage directors and designers could perform their nip-ups and full gainers, creating splashes of spectacular irrelevancy. The Metropolitan's ''Tannhauser'' bucked that trend, looking back into Wagnerian history for pictorial inspirations and paying honor to the work's spirit without seeming in any way old-fashioned. Thanks to skillful use of modern stage technology, direction fit into the pictures naturally, suggesting a 19th-century staging even while eliminating its worst cliches or softening them almost beyond recognition. Everything seemed to flow from the music, not from a producer's bag of tricks. In other words, Mr. Schenk and Mr. Schneider-Siemssen achieved stylistic consistency, that chimerical fusion of elements that in Wagnerian dogma is called the Gesamtkunstwerke, or complete art work.

title: TRUE TO HIMSELF AND HIS HOMELAND
description: LETTERS FROM PRISON And Other Essays. By Adam Michnik. Translated by Maya Latynski. Foreword by Czeslaw Milosz. Introduction by Jonathan Schell. 354 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: MUSIC: NEW COMPOSERS
description: WORKS by several young composers provided most of the interest Thursday night in a program at the New York University Theater that was part of the Washington Square Contemporary Music Series.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BRATS By X. J. Kennedy. Illustrated by James Watts. 42 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry/ Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 9) STREET TALK By Ann Turner. Illustrated by Catherine Stock. 47 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 9) BEST FRIENDS Poems selected by Lee Bennett Hopkins. Illustrated by James Watts. 48 pp. New York: Charlotte Zolotow/ Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Be Glad Your Mother Is Not an Emu
description: FEMALES OF THE SPECIES Sex and Survival in the Animal Kingdom. By Bettyann Kevles. Illustrated. 270 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: ABZUG AND DIOGUARDI ON ROAD TO NOVEMBER
description: REPRESENTATIVE Joseph J. DioGuardi was walking the streets of Bronxville last Sunday, accompanied by campaign workers carrying yellow balloons and a portable sound system that would be recognized as a ''ghetto blaster'' anywhere else. Here it was playing a political jingle about the ''common sense Congressman,'' who was seeking election support.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THE SICKLED CELL: From Myths to Molecules. By Stuart J. Edelstein. (Harvard University, $25.) Africa is a sickle-shaped continent and there, perhaps 2,400 years ago, a mutation of the hemoglobin molecule led to the evolution of sickle-cell anemia.

title: HOME MOVIES
description: DRUNK WITH LOVE By Ellen Gilchrist. 239 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95.

title: Pictures of Children
description: In January 1985, a new kind of message - featuring photographs of missing children - started appearing on a product found in virtually every household: milk cartons. The National Child Safety Council, which initiated the campaign, hoped that somewhere, someone would recognize a picture, and a kidnapped or runaway child would be found.

title: The South Rises Again
description: WHEN I WAS GROWING up, summer's end was marked by Beulah Presbyterian's annual homecoming feast. The sermon always seemed especially long on that particular Sunday, with the breathless Carolina heat interrupted only by the rhythmic fanning of a few of the local matriarchs. After singing the final refrains of ''Blessed Assurance'' or ''Bringing in the Sheaves,'' my brother and I would try our best not to giggle as one of the venerable elders whistled the closing prayer through his false teeth. At last we were released. We'd bolt through the door and watch the women lovingly fill the long tables with the dishes we looked forward to all year long: a special home-cured country ham, the best black walnut cake, an array of slaws and potato salads, mounds of sliced tomatoes and bowls of corn - picked, cooked and cut off the cob just hours before. There were homemade biscuits, peach pickles and chowchow, and always just as many desserts (including at least a dozen different pecan pies) as savory dishes. It was all washed down with the sweetest iced tea imaginable and accompanied by lots of laughter and story-telling.

title: U.N. DEMOTION BRINGS CHARGES OF FAVORITISM
description: The demotion of a top United Nations officer who defrauded the world body, in a case in which seven other employees lost their jobs, has raised a furor among employees here and led to charges of favoritism on the part of the Secretary General.

title: A Small Trove of Modernism Thrives in Holland
description: When I tell people that I think tenderly of Eindhoven, they hoot. They think of Eindhoven, if they think of it at all, as a company town in the Netherlands that has grown quickly and at random. Though blessed by the huge hurrying skies that are part of the Dutch inheritance, Eindhoven is nothing to look at. Philips, the international industrial conglomerate, is said to employ around 10 percent of its population of more than 200,000, and it has heavy commitments in cigars, paper, trucks and dairy products. It has a strong musical life. It has good theater. It has, in the Karpendonkse Hoeve, one of the best restaurants in the country. It has corporate patrons - the present show is sponsored both by Philips and by Hofnar, the cigar manufacturers, with supplementary contributions from Daf Trucks and Philip Morris. Even so, we can imagine that the people who live in Eindhoven - near the Belgian border about 70 miles southeast of Amsterdam - might dream of going to Amsterdam the way the three sisters in Chekhov's play dream of going to Moscow.

title: TEMPLE UPSETS PITT WITH PALMER SCORE
description: Paul Palmer, sixth in Division I-AA rushing yardage entering the game, ran for 105 yards and the deciding touchdown in a downpour tonight as Temple upset Pitt, 19-13.

title: Sarah Carter Cecil Becomes Fiancee Of C. S. Williams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell Cumming Cecil of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Carter Cecil, to Christopher Sewall Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sewall Williams of Waitsfield, Vt. and Small Point, Me. A late November wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
CULLING TIPS ON PLANTINGS FROM ENGLAND
description: THERE can be little disappointment in what one sees in the grand old gardens of England such as Sissinghurst or Hibcote. They are everything that one has been led to expect: works of art when it comes to design, use of plants and maintenance.

title: A JEW VISITS FRENCH SERVICE
description: ''LOOK,'' my friend exclaimed. ''Look at that!'' She was pointing at the map of

title: SHOREHAM PLAN CONTESTED
description: WHEN an atomic safety and licensing board of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission opens hearings this fall on the emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, the three members of the panel will be considering a large quantity of new evidence.

title: RECITAL: JUDITH NORELL, HARPSICHORD
description: JUDITH NORELL'S evening of harpsichord music at the Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday was a model of how recitals ought to be conceived and carried out. It was solidified by Bach at his most powerful, but it also instructed us in how a basically 18th-century instrument can be transformed by such contemporaries as Henze and Ligeti.

title: HOFSTRA BLANKS CATHOLIC
description: Hofstra, which has limited its four opponents to a total of 3 points, registered its second straight shutout and third of the season with a 17-0 decision over Catholic University yesterday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: WARNINGS AND INVITATIONS
description: IN the past several months we have witnessed the rise of a new phenomenon in motor vehicle adornment, a trend so popular that one is hard-pressed to spot a car of the road that does not have this new but familiar symbol of caution to other drivers: CHILD ON BOARD!

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Maywood
description: DESPITE the highways cluttered with storefronts and warehouses that frame its edges, Maywood is an attractive little borough with streets lined with trees so thick and tall they form a canopy of green.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM? WHAT'S THAT?
description: TIMES have changed, I thought, as I noted the Jewish holidays on the school calendar. When I went to school in the 1930's and 40's, there was no mention of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur on any public school calendar. Today, they are not only on the calendar but also many schools are closed. As someone who is Jewish, I appreciate the difference. And I begin to wonder, how different is it now for Jews from when I was growing up?

title: MOSCOW'S NEW POLICY REFLECTED IN SUB REPORT
description: The promptness with which the Government press agency reported the fire on board a Soviet nuclear submarine, which happened Friday, was the latest indication that the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev had shifted from its policy of either ignoring or delaying the announcement of major accidents.

title: THE QUEEN OF CRIME: P.D. JAMES
description: THE BODIES were discovered at eight forty-five on the morning of Wednesday 18 September by Miss Emily Wharton, a sixty-five-year-old spinster of the parish of St Matthew's in Paddington, London, and Darren Wilkes, aged ten.''

title: Susan Eckhardt Is Wed in Darien
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Susan Gardiner Eckhardt, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Eckhardt Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Quechee, Vt., was married to James David Simpson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simpson of New York and Fairfax, Va. The Rev. Edward Howley and the Rev. Alice Farquhar-Mayes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND FINE ISSUED
description: The operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant has been fined $40,000 for violating Government rules for cleaning up debris from the accident that occurred there in 1979. The error, involving equipment on a crane, was put in the third most serious of five categories, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Tuesday. James Taylor, director of the commission's Office of Inspection and Enforcement, said the violation was another, more serious example of previous failures to follow Government specifications.

title: Callas Compact Disks Recall The Magic
description: Of all the beloved standard operas, each with its two dozen or more complete recordings, is there any for which all observers concur on a Best Recorded Version?

title: OFFSTAGE PERFORMANCES ENLIVEN NIGHTS AT MET
description: Passion, envy, honor, combat, and death before a curtain fall; Fred Plotkin and his colleagues at the Metropolitan Opera House have seen them all - offstage. Once, there was even an umbrella duel. While classic themes unfold where they ought to - onstage - the sublime, the ridiculous and, sometimes, the tragic often find unscripted expression in the audience at the Met.

title: ASSASSINATION ATTEMPTS STIR UP FUROR IN INDIA
description: Two bold assassination attempts, apparently by Sikh extremists, have shaken the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi this week and exposed major flaws in India's security apparatus, Government officials said today.

title: Amin Gemayel, President
description: Amin Gemayel was elected President by the Parliament in 1982 for a six-year term to replace his brother, Bashir, a Christian militia leader who had been elected President but was assassinated before assuming office. Their father, Pierre, founded the Phalange Party 50 years ago, and its militia became a major part of the Lebanese Forces six years ago.

title: Elaine M. Coppola Is Wed To Todd Denison Heyda
description: Elaine Marie Coppola, the daughter of Justice and Mrs. Matthew F. Coppola of Crestwood, N.Y., was married yesterday to Todd Denison Heyda, the son of Beth Heyda of White Plains and the late Robert C. Heyda.

title: Grazing Meals
description: Grazing, shmazing (Food, ''Grazing Meals,'' by Bruce Cost, Sept. 7). The latest thing? Big deal. We've been doing it for years. We call it noshing! ARNOLD L. MARKOWITZ North River, N.Y.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DEWHURST AT THE 'Y' Colleen Dewhurst, the stage and screen star, will appear at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Wayne Saturday evening.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a headline was misplaced in a Pro & Con article about Federal bailouts in The Week in Review last Sunday. The effect of the error was to attribute to Senator John Melcher, a Montana Democrat, comments made by Senator William Proxmire.

title: OFFICE PARK FOR NORTH CASTLE ESTATE
description: ONE of North Castle's large old estates, owned for half a century by the Heyman family, has been sold for development as a corporate office park.

title: KOREAN BUDDHISTS STIRRING TO ACTION
description: Nearly 3,000 South Koreans held an anti-Government rally a few weeks ago in the southern town of Hapchon, after which came a two-mile march through the streets.

title: DANBURY PIANIST TAKES LIMELIGHT IN STRIDE
description: MICHAEL BORISKIN, a 35-year-old pianist who recently settled in Danbury, likens his career to a bull market in the business world.

title: Late Rally Pulls Choate Ahead
description: After giving up over 100 yards on the ground in the first half, the Choate defense limited Andover to 10 yards rushing in the second half. And after trailing for almost three quarters, the Choate offense roared back with two touchdowns in the last four minutes for a 28-20 victory.

title: Q AND A
description: 'Show Folks Shoe Shop' Question: What can you tell me about the I. Miller Building and the statues at the northeast corner of 46th Street and Seventh Avenue? . . . B. M., Manhattan Answer: Christopher Gray, an architectural historian and director of the Office of Metropolitan History, does not have a firm date on this building's construction, but believes it went up between 1870 and 1890. The two-story building, at 167 West 46th Street, originally may have been a private residence. The current facade was added in 1926 when the building was renovated by Louis Friedland for the I. Miller shoe company.

title: 'REAL MAN' LIMNS SINGLES LIFE
description: ANYONE who is single these days knows that dating can be more stressful than hurricanes, muggings or hijackings. Consider the following: You don't have to make small talk during a hurricane, you don't have to be punctual for a mugging and you can wear last year's jeans to a hijacking.

title: KASPAROV MAKES A KEY MOVE, AND HE FANS SENSE A VICTORY
description: As 800 people watched in tense silence in the Leningrad hall, the referee in the world chess championship today opened a move sealed by Gary Kasparov in a game adjourned the night before.

title: Helene J. Miller To Wed Banker
description: Helene Jodi Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Miller of Great Neck, L.I., and Miami, and James Howard Kase, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Kase of New York, plan to be married next month.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE PLESURE AND PASSION OF GLASS
description: MERGING the pleasures of an absorbing pastime into a profitable commercial venture is precisely what Karl and Martine Peterson have accomplished in a business called Glory Hole Antiques.

title: DEMOCRATS SEE ECONOMY EMERGING AS BIG ISSUE
description: After months of underscoring the uneven state of the economy, Democrats say the difficulties faced by the nation's troubled regions are finally emerging as powerful themes in this year's midterm elections.

title: Next Week; How Should Hockey Deal With Fighting?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: EXPORTING JAPAN'S WAY OF TEA
description: Sen Rikyu, the great tea master of the late 16th century, is said to have grown gorgeous morning glories, at the time a rare flower in Japan, in the garden by his teahouse. Toyotomi Hideyoshi, the ruthless ruler who had made Kyoto his capital, sought an invitation to tea so that he could see the flowers.

title: THE POWER OF WEAKNESS
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR By Richard Yates. 182 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95.

title: Message From A Land As Old As Time
description: The eyes stare out at you through space and time. They seem to stare right through you, penetrating your soul.

title: CROWDING IN NASSAU JAIL RENEWS AN OLD BATTLE
description: A Federal judge's order that Nassau County must end the overcrowding in its jail is rooted in a longstanding dispute involving the county, the prosecutor's office and the Legal Aid Society.

title: Robyn Greer Becomes the Bride of Kevin Hallock
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Roberta Lewis Greer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kirk Greer of Cos Cob, Conn., and East Dennis, Mass., to Kevin Patrick Hallock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Hallock of Greenwich. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John Bishop of Christ Church and the Rev. Robert McDermott, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TEXAS SAYS CENTER USES DECEPTION TO STOP ABORTION
description: The realization usually sets in when the film's narrator says that abortion is the equivalent of murder.

title: A Manuscript Liberated
description: It is remarkable that Andrei D. Sakharov even finished his autobiography, let alone managed to get it smuggled out of the Soviet Union. His wife, Yelena G. Bonner, said the K.G.B. stole his manuscript several times, once from his car after the Nobel Peace Prize laureate was knocked out by a drug.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN July 1982, a motorcycle accident left Robert White, then 24 years old, a quadraplegic, his plans as crushed as his spine.

title: Fresh Start
description: SAYING he had overcome the nervous disorder that forced him to give up major league baseball for more than two seasons, Jim Eisenreich has agreed to accept a waiver claim on him made by the Kansas City Royals and will report next spring to their training camp in Fort Myers, Fla. The 27-year-old outfielder hit .303 for the Minnesota Twins in 34 games during the 1982 season, but found that playing before large crowds caused him to become nervous and hyperventilate.

title: B.C. RALLY THWARTED BY S.M.U.
description: Jeff Atkins ran for 3 touchdowns and Bobby Watters threw 20 yards for another as Southern Methodist thwarted Boston College, 31-29, tonight.

title: The Most Beautiful Theories Are The Truest
description: THE ADVANCEMENT OF SCIENCE, AND ITS BURDENS The Jefferson Lecture and Other Essays. By Gerald Holton. Illustrated. 368 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $39.50. Paper, $12.95.

title: RULING WILL SPEED TOXIC CLEANUPS
description: A FEDERAL appeals court ruling in a Long Island case may help speed the cleanup of toxic wastes across the country.

title: Recent Releases of Video Cassettes
description: Joan Armatrading: Track Record A&M Video 90 minutes. $29.95

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption accompanying a review of David K. Shipler's ''Arab and Jew'' on Sept. 28 incorrectly located the town of Hebron. It is in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: Beer and Sympathy
description: ''There is nothing which has yet been contrived by man,'' said Dr. Johnson, ''by which so much happiness is produced as by a good tavern or inn.'' In The Crooked Billet, at Stoke Row, near Henley-on-Thames, I have been as happy as anywhere in my life.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: RCA AND THE VIDEODISC: The Business of Research. By Margaret B. W. Graham. (Cambridge University, $19.95.) In high-technology companies there is often little correlation between a good idea and a good product.

title: THE GHETTO OF UNHEARING
description: A LOSS FOR WORDS The Story of Deafness in a Family. By Lou Ann Walker. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THUNDERSTONES AND SHOOTING STARS. By Robert T. Dodd. (Harvard University, $24.95.) Anyone who has seen the delicate tracery of a falling star in the night sky can appreciate the fascination meteorites have always held for humans.

title: Amy Goodhart Is Wed To Gregory F. Rayburn
description: Amy Williams Goodhart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Malcolm Goodhart of New York and Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Gregory Franklin Rayburn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Franklin R. Rayburn of Tuscaloosa, Ala. The Rev. Harold Barrett performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: SEARCH FOR A BETTER CLAM TRAP
description: IT is the American dream: picture an object in your head, then go about making and selling it. Build a better mousetrap. Invent. Recently, a Yonkers man built a better clam and bait trap. Mikie's Bait Catcher is the product; Mikie B. Catcher, the inventor. (He swears it is the name he was born with.) Mr. Catcher is a plumber by trade. His device, made from materials of that trade, extracts clams and creatures used for bait from coastal sand and mud. He makes the trap in a workshop in the basement of the Colonial Village Shopping Center in Scarsdale.

title: DRAMA: 'NARNIA' A CHILDREN'S MUSICAL
description: FROM its opening moment, when a dancer in white antlers glides down the center aisle of Christ and St. Stephen's Church and into an eerie storybook forest, one is irresistibly drawn into the world of ''Narnia -the Musical.''

title: Energy Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: STATES SCRAMBLE TO GAUGE EFFECT OF TAX CHANGES
description: The new Federal tax bill has prompted concern over its impact on state taxes and how they would have to be changed to protect taxpayers and state and local public services.

title: Data Bank October 5, 1986
Diane B. Sperandio Weds
description: At St. Rose's Roman Catholic Church in Topsfield, Mass., yesterday Diane Beatrice Sperandio, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Sperandio of Belmont, N.H., was married to Francis Cooper Lawrance Jr., the son of Mr. Lawrance of Southport, Conn., and the late Priscilla Howe Lawrence. The bride's father is president of the Grounds Equipment Company, a sales concern in Newton, Mass. Mr. Lawrance's father retired as president of the former J. S. Frelinghuysen Corporation, a New York insurance brokerage.

title: STATE BOARD'S ADVERTISING RULES
description: In March 1984, the State's Board of Medical Examiners eased the restrictions on doctors' advertising, paving the way for radio and television promotions. The State Board of Dentistry had made similar changes in 1981.

title: Cosmic Cornerstone
description: WAS EINSTEIN RIGHT? Putting General Relativity to the Test. By Clifford M. Will. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

title: STATE TO ACT TO EASE MORTGAGE DELAYS
description: Reacting to the heavy volume of complaints about long delays in processing mortgage applications, the state's Department of Banking will soon propose regulations to alleviate the problem.

title: Buttered Shrimps, With A Beer Chaser
description: There is a Danish saying that a fish has to swim three times: once in water, once in butter, once in spirits. And in Denmark, it's a very easy dictum to follow, for fresh fish, hearty caraway rye bread smothered with salty Danish butter and a thimbleful of icy aquavit with a beer chaser make for a filling, satisfying snack.

title: FOR VACATIONERS, VERMONT'S MOST VIVID FOLIAGE IS JUST A PHONE CALL AWAY
description: Eighty-one Vermont autumns have taught Maude Shattuck a thing or two about foliage. She knows where the best views are: at Buels Gore, overlooking Hinesburg Hollow, or by the sugar shack a few miles up the road.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: MACHINERY OF THE MIND: Inside the New Science of Artificial Intelligence. By George Johnson. (Times Books, $19.95.) If a computer can be made to execute any precisely described process, and if human thought is a process that can be precisely described, a computer can be made to think.

title: CONSTITUTION GETS LIBERAL THUMBS UP
description: The message on fliers distributed for this ''Unconventional Constitutional Convention'' recalled words written more than 200 years ago.

title: De Rigueur Dogs
description: For some time the Agriculture Department has been conducting a pilot project at airports using beagles to sniff out prohibited fruit and meat in luggage.

title: Miss Doner Wed To A. G. Kennedy
description: The marriage of Linda Leigh Doner, a daughter of Mrs. Leonard H. Steibel of Sands Point, L.I., and the late Calvin Hershey Doner, to Andrew Gilbert Kennedy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David O'D. Kennedy of Oyster Bay, L.I., and New York, took place yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Umpires Get the Call
description: DOUG HARVEY, a 25-year National League veteran with five years of playoff experience, and Larry Barnett, a 17-year American League veteran who has worked four playoffs, will head their six-man umpiring crews in the League Championship Series.

title: The President, Imagined
description: No, says a spokesman, the President won't have a news conference before he leaves to meet Mikhail Gorbachev in Reykjavik. It's a special shame, and not just because Mr. Reagan has averaged only seven a year. Rarely has the public so needed to hear from the President.

title: SEAVER CAREER OVER?
description: HE'LL be 42 next month. Not even Tom Seaver can pitch forever. And maybe he's pitched for the last time.

title: Susan Sisto Is Married
description: Susan Marie Sisto, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sisto of Watchung, N.J., and Hillsboro Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to George Robert Cusick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Cusick of Willow Grove, Pa. The Rev. Terence Lawler performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in North Plainfield, N.J. Mrs. Cusick and her husband graduated from Bucknell University.

title: FEES PAID BY MEDICARE BENEFICIARIES WILL BE RAISED BY 15.5%
description: Government officials say the monthly premium that 30 million Medicare patients pay for physicians' services will climb 15.5 percent, to $17.90 from $15.50, on Jan. 1.

title: More Uncertainty About P.O.W.'s
