description: For the first time in years, a Defense Department investigation has found that Vietnam may indeed still hold American prisoners of war. At least that is the assessment of Lieut. Gen. Eugene F. Tighe Jr., a former Director of Defense Intelligence who headed a five-month review of intelligence files on the issue.

title: We Are Closer To the Ideal
description: WHILE the deregulation of routes and fares in 1978 spawned more than a score of new carriers, only big airlines with deep pockets survived the ensuing price wars. Last week, the contraction in the number of competitors proceeded apace. The Justice Department said it would not oppose either Delta Air Lines' proposed $860 million acquisition of Western Air Lines or Texas Air Corporation's proposed $301 million purchase of People Express Inc. and People's bankrupt subsidiary, Frontier Airlines. Both mergers must still pass muster with the Department of Transportation, which, as expected, approved Texas Air's $600 million purchase of Eastern Air Lines.

title: Ms. Steptoe Weds Dr. Peter E. Carson
description: Mary Lou Steptoe, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip P. Steptoe of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter E. Carson, a son of Col. Vincent A. Carson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Carson of Livingston, N.J. The Very Rev. Frances B. Sayre Jr. performed the ceremony at the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul), of which he is a former dean.

title: CONCRETE WALL DISPUTED
description: SIX North Lawrence homeowners are seeking to force a developer to take down an eight-foot-high concrete wall that borders their backyards and that is to be topped with a six-foot-high fence.

title: MUSIC: 'CARMILLA: A VAMPIRE TALE' AT LA MAMA
description: LA MAMA E.T.C., that extraordinary East Village home for theatrical innovation, is celebrating its 25th year - the kind of news that makes aging avant-gardists feel downright creaky. To open this silver anniversary season, Ellen Stewart, La Mama's founder, has revived one of her greatest hits, the 70-minute chamber opera ''Carmilla: A Vampire Tale,'' by the director-writer Wilford Leach and the composer Ben Johnston.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: BUZZING IN MARYLAND Winnie the Pooh would be so happy! Free samples of honey and honey-spiked food and drink will be available at the Fifth Annual Maryland Honey Festival, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today at the Oregon Ridge Nature Center, Cockeysville, Md.

title: Reviewer's Averages
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Foran Wed To Ray Sipherd
description: Anne Marie Foran, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Foran of Brooklyn, was married in New York yesterday to Ray Sipherd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin R. Sipherd of Green Valley, Ariz. The Rev. Robert Verrigni performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: 7 Food Establishments Cited in New York City
description: The New York City Health Department last week released a list of seven food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: A Jar And A Song
description: For the most part pubs are babels, with a preponderance of men and such incessant yapping that one's hearing is impaired on the doorstep. I avoid them for this reason and also for the fact that they serve neither Champagne nor decent white wine by the glass. However, I have found one exception, in the tiny village called Castletownshend, near Skibbereen in Ireland's County Cork. It is called Mary Ann's, though the good lady herself has moved away. Quiet, almost somnolent in the day, it is a hub of mirth, activity and surprise by evening. Wednesday and Sunday evenings are best because there is a sing-song. The pub is small, cramped, softly lighted and the effect is a bit like being in someone's cave.

title: DISCIPLINED TAMILS POISED FOR THE NEXT BATTLE
description: They stockpile weapons, train armies and issue cyanide tablets to young volunteers not afraid to kill themselves rather than be captured fighting for a cause. They spin political theories, publish daily news bulletins and turn out posters and booklets giving their reason for being.

title: HOSTAGE WIVES IN PLEA TO REAGAN
description: The wives of two kidnapped Americans appealed to President Reagan today to negotiate with the abductors and asked Americans to press Washington to work harder for the hostages' release.

title: Neighbors
description: New York's 15th Congressional District on Manhattan's East Side has the highest per capita income in the country while, a couple of miles up the estuary, the 18th Congressional District in the South Bronx has the lowest. While New York's Fourth District in Nassau County leads the nation in the share of homes and apartments that are owner-occupied, 85.8 percent, the 16th Congressional district in Harlem, 20 miles west, has the fewest homeowners, 4 percent.

title: AMID RISING CONCERN, THE DRINKING AGE IS INCREASED
description: IN Illinois, drivers' licenses are red for those younger than 21. Everyone else gets a white license. In West Virginia, license clerks photograph young drivers from the side, older ones from the front.

title: FROM THE DESK OF A DIRTY OLD MAN
description: POISON PEN Or, Live Now and Pay Later. By George Garrett. Illustrated. 258 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: Stuart Wright/Small Press Distribution. $20.

title: PROSTITUTES MAKE APPEAL FOR AIDS PREVENTION
description: The second International Whores Convention ended a three-day meeting here with an appeal for universal use of condoms to prevent the spread of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about a lawsuit against W.R. Grace & Company in The Week in Review last Sunday described incompletely the disposition of the case. In July, a jury found that Grace had contributed to the pollution of two wells in Woburn, Mass., but last month the court ordered a retrial of that issue. The families of eight leukemia victims later agreed to an out-of-court settlement of their suit against the company.

title: UNION COLLEGE (4-0) ROUTS WORCESTER
description: Tim Valachovic passed for two touchdowns and Todd Walker rushed for two more today as unbeaten Union College (4-0) defeated Worcester Polytechnic Institute, 32-16.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
In Southwest, Grave Looters Are Robbing History Blind
description: In the hundred-degree heat of an Arizona afternoon, a Bureau of Land Management archeologist, Don Simonis, picks his way through a rocky, cactus-studded canyon near this small town.

title: Ugandan Cabinet Official And 5 Others Seized
description: Energy Minister Andrew Kayiira and five senior officers from his Uganda Freedom Army have been detained in what appears to be a crackdown on groups sharing power with the governing National Resistance Movement.

title: Esplanade Art
description: Last January, Marisol, the artist known for her witty, carved figures and human tableaux, won a nationwide competition sponsored by the Brooklyn Heights Association for a monument to the Roebling family, creators of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Weiss's Condition Improves
description: Representative Ted Weiss was in critical but stable condition today at Washington Hospital Center, where he is recuperating from quadruple coronary bypass surgery. Mr. Weiss, 59 years old, was ''somewhat improved'' from the day before, according to a hospital administrator, who said his condition was normal for someone recovering from such an operation. Mr. Weiss, who is running for his sixth term in the House from the 17th Congressional District that mainly encompasses the Upper West Side of Manhattan, was taken to the hospital by helicopter from a banquet Thursday evening.

title: Gentle Lunacy Rules 'Pee-Wee's Playhouse'
description: In what is undoubtedly this season's most imaginative and disarming new series, the weekly scene opens on a sweet, gentle forest, the kind of bird-twittering paradise that Bambi would feel right at home in. Before anyone has time to think about some of the passing oddities - a snowman basking in the sun, for instance -the cameras move indoors to a kind of cluttered rumpus room filled with games and toys and, somewhere in the jumble, a bust of Beethoven looking terribly unamused. Then as the show's theme song merrily promises viewers something wacky, sunny and cuckoo, a strange little creature bursts through the door, skipping and squealing, his gray suit several sizes too small for his skinny frame, his red bow-tie setting off a squeaky-clean white shirt. He is, of course, Pee-wee Herman, also known in what may or may not be his real life as Paul Reubens, a comic whose professional beginnings go back at least as far as the 1980 ''Cheech and Chong's Next Movie.'' Mr. Reubens doesn't just play Pee-wee; he has become Pee-wee, maintaining the character even when giving press interviews.

title: THREAT OF CLOSURE GONE, CAMPUS SEES A SECURE FUTURE
description: FROM their hillside campus in Torrington, students and faculty members at the Litchfield County Center for Higher Education can see fields of corn bordered by thick stone walls. For the first time in more than a decade, they can also see a future for their school.

title: Chinese in Pyongyang Talks
description: President Li Xiannian of China and President Kim Il Sung held talks in Pyongyang today, the North Korean press agency reported. Without giving details of the meeting, the agency said, ''The talks took place in a comradely, sincere and friendly atmosphere.''

title: Queens Boy, 14, Seized In Death of a Cousin, 2
description: A 14-year-old Queens youth was arrested yesterday in the death by scalding of his two-year-old cousin.

title: A DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE JEMAA EL FNA
description: GEOGRAPHICALLY, THE Jemaa el Fna is nothing, a space in the middle of the city of Marrakesh, not even a square, a circle, an oval or any other recognizable shape. It is a negation of buildings that for 700 years has acted like a magnet for the various races of southern Morocco. They come from the deserts of the Sahara, crossing the High Atlas mountains, which remain snowcapped even while the desert burns. They come from the mountains themselves, from rocky fortresses where until recently rulers defied even the fiercest sultans. They come from the towns of northern Morocco, like Casablanca and Rabat. Arabs, blacks, Berbers and Bedouins, they all mix in this square that is not a square, which is not beautiful and which boasts only one historic sight - the Koutoubia mosque - and that is half a mile away.

title: Demure Women and Cross-Eyed Warriors
description: One of Tokyo's December joys is the Hagoita Ichi, a large and lively fair held in front of the equally large and lively Sensoji Temple in the Asakusa district. Stalls upon stalls - cheek-to-jowl, the way everything is in Tokyo -are set up for three days in the middle of the month, all selling hagoita, elaborate battledores that have been a New Year's tradition for centuries.

title: POPE URGES A DAY OF WORLD TRUCE
description: Pope John Paul II called today for all guerrilla groups, terrorists and nations at war to lay down their weapons for one day this month.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT TO ARRIVE TODAY
description: The authorities have told the wife of Yuri F. Orlov, the dissident, that he has been brought back from Siberian exile and will be put on an Aeroflot flight for New York on Sunday.

title: Russia In the Pacific
description: Congratulations to Clyde Haberman on his provocative article ''Challenge in the Pacific: Moscow's Growing Naval Strength'' (Sept. 7). In particular, I share the concerns of Malcolm Fraser, Australia's former Prime Minister.

title: U.S. AID DOESN'T EASE FILIPINO DOUBTS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino voiced restrained gratitude today that the United States Senate had reversed itself and voted to increase aid to the Philippines by $200 million.

title: Two Cities in Peru Shaken by Bombings
description: Antiterrorist policemen today interrogated suspects in bombings that rocked two Andean cities and the military said soldiers killed nine Shining Path rebels.

title: WORSHIPING SIS
description: EUSTACE AND HILDA A Trilogy. By L. P. Hartley. With an introduction by Lord David Cecil. 736 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $24.95.

title: CONTRAS APPEAR TO FORGE AN UNEASY ALLIANCE
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders remain divided by serious political differences, but appear to be forging an uneasy tactical alliance after three days of meetings here, according to rebel sources.

title: A Remembered Play of Light and Shadow
description: I should have bought the shadow-play puppets the first time I saw them, in a small shop in Siemreap, the town next to the magnificent ruins of Angkor in Cambodia. But the puppets were made of rawhide and seemed rustically naive compared with the sophisticated, strikingly painted puppets of Java and Bali. The pinholes that outlined their shapes - the puppeteer stands behind a screen to manipulate the puppets and cast their shadows by candlelight - seemed coarse compared with the delicate workmanship of the Indonesian artisans.

title: Old Russia Preserved In A Lacquered Box
description: It is a sad fact that folk crafts have fallen on hard times in the Soviet Union. Those lovely products of the long winter nights in northern log cabins - brightly decorated kitchen utensils, carved dolls or painted Easter eggs - are now mass-produced, barred from export or just very hard to find.

title: Michael Waring Burke Wed to Barbara Purcell
description: At the Chapel by the Sea at the United States Naval Hospital in Newport, R.I., yesterday, Barbara Lee Purcell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Purcell of Stamford, Conn., was married to Michael Waring Burke, a son of Mrs. Robert Phelps of Camden, S.C., and the late Stanley W. Burke Jr. The Rev. Eugene J. McKenna performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: DAVID BYRNE TURNS HIS HEAD TO MOVIES
description: In the opening scenes of David Byrne's new movie, ''True Stories,'' shots of a flat Texas landscape give way to images of a town named Virgil; the images of small-town shops, industrial plants, and prefab houses, to cameos of some of Virgil's leading citizens: a genial plant worker named Louis Fyne, who's taken out television advertisements in his search for the perfect wife; Kay and Earl Culver, a happily married couple who haven't spoken to one another in decades; Miss Rollings, the Laziest Woman in the World, who hasn't left her bed in years, as well as neighbors introduced simply as the Cute Woman, the Computer Guy and the Preacher.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THE BODY QUANTUM: The New Physics of Body, Mind and Health. By Fred Alan Wolf. (Macmillan, $19.95.) The theme of this interesting but sometimes exasperating book is that the rules and ambiguities of quantum physics are crucial to understanding health and disease, the control the mind exerts over the body, the nature of life and its evolution.

title: CITY WITH A GOLDEN PAST
description: Incas believed that Cuzco, the ''navel of the earth'' two miles high, was where the children of the sun and the moon had founded civilization. In its full glory five centuries ago, it was the richest and most important city in the Americas. Then, in 1533, came Francisco Pizarro, whose conquistadors slaughtered hundreds of thousands of Indians, looted the countryside and obliterated all they could of the rich Indian culture and religion.

title: Polish Official Questions Walesa on New Council
description: The authorities questioned Lech Walesa and other prominent Solidarity figures today over the banned union's newly created council of former underground leaders, which the Government has called illegal.

title: HARTFORD'S LAST SYNAGOGUE CLOSING
description: FOR more than 50 years, Herman L. Holtz has safeguarded the Torahs that belong to Congregation Ados Israel.

title: Condos Are Making Inroads In Litchfield
description: LITCHFIELD COUNTY - a picture-postcard region of winding country lanes, clear lakes and meadows - has long been recognized as a fashionable mecca for New Yorkers seeking a Connecticut country retreat.

title: CRIME
description: One of the more successful series of recent years has featured Brady Coyne, the Boston lawyer. It started in 1984 with ''Death at Charity's Point,'' and now comes THE MARINE CORPSE (Scribners, $13.95), the fourth in William G. Tapply's series. Coyne is a lawyer to the very rich and very aristocratic. The police find a derelict frozen to death on the streets and put the death down to natural causes. But it turns out that the man was a Coyne client and the nephew of a United States senator. He was researching a book, this time a serious one. His previous novel had been so deliriously bad it had become a best seller.

title: A Tang Of Salt
description: Where else would my favorite pub be but within sight of the sea? And what better name for it than Ferryboat Inn?

title: RADIUM SOIL: WHO DID WHAT?
description: IN THE middle of selecting a site last spring for processing radium-contaminated soil, the state's Department of Environmental Protection changed the criteria and later ordered its consultant to ignore one criterion that the eventual site, a quarry in Vernon Township, Sussex County, failed to meet.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Let us remember that growth is the key to repaying debt while fulfilling the dreams of the people.''

title: BOSTON HOSPITAL REACHES UNUSUAL AGREEMENT
description: The Hospital Corporation of America, the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, and Brigham and Women's Hospital, a prestigious nonprofit center for teaching, research and treatment, have announced an unusual agreement to share the hospital's expertise and the company's purchasing power.

title: 'MY ONE AND ONLY' IS WINNING
description: ''MY ONE AND ONLY'' is a happy hybrid of a musical with a cornucopia of sublime George and Ira Gershwin songs, culled from one or another show or film, and a rambling, ambling book that plays tricky games with rationality - and wins.

title: Priscilla Elizabeth Haack Is Married To Kenneth H. Klipstein 2d in Jersey
description: Priscilla Elizabeth Haack and Kenneth Hampton Klipstein 2d were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Leon B. Gladish, assisted by the Rev. George E. Chorba 3d, performed the ceremony Lauren Talley Ensslin was the matron of honor. Screven Peter Lorillard was best man.

title: JAPAN'S TRUE NORTH
description: EAST OF THE TOWN of Abashiri, the long, shallow curve of the Japanese coast turns abruptly northeast to form the high, uninhabited coast of the Shiretoko Peninsula, one of the northernmost reaches of Japan. I stand here on a fall afternoon looking out over waters most Western eyes are innocent of - the Sea of Okhotsk. Soviet waters. The surf breaks heavily on light gray sand at my feet.

title: Senate Aide Pleads Guilty
description: Katherine Bidden, 41 years old, former chief clerk of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, pleaded guilty today to a charge that she embezzled more than $5,000 in travel funds from the panel over four and a half years.

title: Chinese Artifacts in Ontario, Folk Art in Connecticut
description: Looking Back And Skyward In Toronto

title: Happy Return
description: MANAGER Jimy Williams of Toronto turned 43 years old yesterday, and the best present he received involved his future. Williams was rehired with a one-year contract for 1987, even though the Blue Jay team he took over this season, his first as a major league manager, failed to repeat as American League East champion.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Medal Proposal
description: Why doesn't the United States Mint issue a series of medals to honor its sculptor-engravers? This question is raised following a luncheon held recently in Cherry Hill, N.J. to honor the current chief engraver, Elizabeth Jones and her two predecessors, Frank Gasparro and Gilroy Roberts. Several dozen national and regional hobby leaders gathered for the occasion which represented a rare and historic moment in the annals of U.S. numismatics.

title: FORCING BANKS TO MARK DOWN LOANS
description: MANY Latin American countries became debt junkies during the decade of the 1970's. Now these countries claim that they cannot maintain their habits. In an attempt to keep the debtors addicted and to give the illusion that creditors are in perfect health, our financial alchemists have devised a virtual international Ponzi scheme. Here's how it works: If, after 90 days, interest due is not paid, loans must be placed in ''non-accrual status.'' At the same time, these loans are often declared ''non-performing'' and written down. But, to avoid these unpleasantries, banks have taken to rescheduling loans. In addition to reducing the servicing costs and extending the life of old loans, this procedure typically requires creditors to lend new money, which gives debtors the money to pay interest owed on old loans. As a result of these maneuvers, debts grow; loans continue to ''perform'' and are carried on the books at face value; and bank profits are realized.

title: MISS STOIANOVICH WEDS AN INVESTOR
description: The marriage of Diana Stoianovich, the daughter of Dr. Traian Stoianovich of Metuchen, N.J., and Paris and Marcelle Stoianovich of Paris, to Charles Haskell Revson Jr. took place yesterday in Eastsound, Wash. The bridegroom is a son of Johanna Johnson of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Revson, who was the president and a co-founder of Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company.

title: COURSE TO EXPLORE CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ''I believe in the power of books,'' said Judy Greenfield, children's librarian of the Rye Free Reading Room. She is one of six county librarians who will be teaching chldren's literature to adults in a new county program. Five of these librarians are from Rye, White Plains and Westchester libraries, and the sixth is a children's services consultant in the Westchester Library System.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CHICAGO;
What's Ahead For Navy Pier?
description: IN its 70-year existence, Navy Pier has been used to dock ships and as a naval training center, an amusement park, a university campus and now, occasionally, an exhibition center. Although several plans have been rejected in recent years, local politicians say they now are on the right track to decide what to do with the 588,200-square-foot property, which juts a mile into Lake Michigan.

title: NEW OPULENCE, OLD OPTIMISM MINGLE IN 'SOUTH PACIFIC'
description: ''South Pacific,'' the most red-blooded of American musicals, exerts a powerful nostalgic appeal. More than an alluring beacon toward a halcyon past, this patriotic show equates Americanism with brotherhood and social responsibility. That is one good reason to celebrate the release by Columbia Masterworks of an opulent new all-star recording of the Rodgers & Hammerstein score, featuring Kiri Te Kanawa, Jose Carreras, Sarah Vaughan and Mandy Patinkin.

title:
THE DRINKING WRITER'S GUIDE;
Shades Of Chaucer
description: I live in Oxford, and while there are many Oxford pubs I like, my favorite is The Waterman's Arms, Osney Town.

title: Dina A. Sheridan, Law Journal Editor, Is Bride of Stephen B. Grant, a Lawyer
description: Miss Dina Anne Sheridan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Sheridan Jr. of New York and Windham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Barrett Grant, a son of Col. Thomas J. Grant, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Grant of Alexandria, Va. The bride's uncle, the Rev. D. Bradley Murray, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Testing New Cosmetic Products
description: HOW DEEP IS A WRINKLE? HOW smooth is smooth skin? Technology can tell. Using sophisticated machines and computers, skilled technicians at cosmetics companies and research laboratories are studying skin-care products to see what they really do. Consumers read the results in advertising copy, often with a bit of skepticism. But while there is always the possibility of creative representation of facts and figures, as technology becomes more sophisticated researchers are increasingly able to quantify objectively the true capabilities of a product, so that what you expect is what you should get. And the Skin Study Center in Philadelphia, an independent research facility, is one of the pioneers of such claim-substantiation testing. Its clients include most of the major cosmetics companies: Elizabeth Arden, Christian Dior, Charles of the Ritz, Avon and Mary Kay Cosmetics, among others.

title: SHATTERING THE PC'S RAM BARRIER
description: THE personal computer user who had settled comfortably into a routine using a hard-disk-equipped machine replete with such extras as a modem, clock board, mouse and other customizing features probably thought the add-on race was over. But in the course of the last year or so, a new perplexity has arisen to beleaguer users, namely, whether or not to break the 640 K barrier.

title: RIGHETTI BREAKS RECORD
description: The Yankees were taken out of the race a week ago, but somehow they have found worth in their failed season. While the Boston Red Sox merely went through the obligatory motions of ending the season and preparing for the playoff, Dave Righetti and Don Mattingly put some drama into a long afternoon today.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Just About Everything In One-of-a-Kind Small Joys in Bedford Village has many one-of-a-kind gifts for all ages and in an unusual range - hand-embroidered pillows, bedcovers or canopies and aprons; baby clothes and toys; hand-painted baskets and cotton scatter rugs; woven mohair throws to keep grandmothers and others snug, and lingerie; wood inlay and other photo frames; rigid and cork-backed Pimpernel placemats and pillow-backed lap trays; dinner sets and French linens; and several types of pottery - Portuguese, Dedham cracked glaze and Barbara Eigen's designs.

title: 'CURTAIN' OF WAR SLOWING CAMBODIA REFUGEES
description: Nearly two years after Vietnamese forces began sealing the border between Cambodia and Thailand, Cambodian refugees fleeing their homeland say escape overland has become increasingly dangerous and expensive, forcing more to try to leave by sea. They join Vietnamese ''boat people'' heading for eastern Thailand or drift into the open South China Sea.

title: En Route ro Reykjavik, Reagan May Have One Eye on History
description: A FEW days after the 1980 election, Richard M. Nixon went to the Soviet Embassy to assure the Russians that notwithstanding his virulent anti-Communist views, Ronald Reagan would turn out to be a President just as dedicated to better Soviet-American relations as Mr. Nixon had been.

title: GOLD CUP TO CREME FRAICHE
description: Creme Fraiche, the little gelding who won the Belmont Stakes last year but had not won in his previous eight races this year, dug in through the final strides to hold off heavily favored Turkoman by a head and win the $850,500 Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: BREAKING BUTTERFLIES
description: THE PROSE WORKS OF ALEXANDER POPE Volume II: The Major Works, 1725-1744. Edited by Rosemary Cowler. 529 pp. Hamden, Conn.: Archon Books. $49.50.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: TUCSON, ARIZ.;
Tribal Land Gets New Value
description: IN 1890, when the Bureau of Indian Affairs gave the San Xavier Reservation to the Tohono O'odham Nation, the land was mostly uninhabitable desert and flood plain in the middle of nowhere.

title: Teen-Ager With Crack Slain
description: A teen-ager carrying more than 50 vials of the drug crack was shot to death last night in the Bronx, the police said.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THE NATURE OF REALITY. By Richard Morris. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) Modern people are supposed to laugh at Ptolemy and the epicycles he postulated to prop up the idea that the sun revolves around the earth.

title: Close Monitoring
description: Security was tight at the headquarters of the Christian Broadcasting Network last week as the Rev. Pat Robertson, a Republican Presidential hopeful, and his followers celebrated the network's 25th anniversary. It was particularly tight for journalists.

title: Automakers Win a Point on Mileage
description: It was 1975, and the price of oil was soaring; American buyers could choose among 20 imported cars that got more than 30 miles a gallon, but only one Detroit-made model did so. A quarter of a million auto production workers were unemployed.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THE QUANTUM UNIVERSE. By Tony Hey and Patrick Walters. (Cambridge University, Cloth, $44.50. Paper, $16.95.) There really are two cultures - that of the few who fathom quantum mechanics, and that of everyone else.

title: Dance
description: ''Make it new.'' That's what Ezra Pound once told poets. It's also advice that choreographers may be heeding, for this week there are several productions that attempt to view old themes in new ways.

title: Iris Murdoch Makes It Fun to Be Smart
description: SOMETIMES, in reading American fiction, I feel I'm associating with what my mother used to call ''a bad lot.'' Depressed, suspicious, cynical and self-indulgent, the characters you meet in the typical contemporary novel are rarely what the English call ''clubbable'' men. I didn't realize just how lacking in social graces they were until I read Peter J. Conradi's brilliant new book, ''Iris Murdoch: The Saint and the Artist'' (St. Martin's).

title: 'Sugarcane' Wins Futurity
description: Sugarcane Hanover overtook three horses in the stretch Friday to score a one-length victory in the $160,530 Kentucky Futurity, the final leg of trotting's Triple Crown, at The Red Mile.

title: How To Fool the People
description: Like most members of the human race, government officials make mistakes occasionally, but President Reagan has mastered the art of no-fault politics. He just pretends mistakes never happen.

title: EAST-WEST EXPRESS
description: THERE HAS LONG BEEN an amused conceit among commuters from the East Anglian suburbs that the London train station upon which they all converge - the cavernous iron cathedral of Liverpool Street - is the place from which you can travel by rail all the way to Hong Kong. So, when my wife and I did have to go to Hong Kong from London, had some days to spare, felt disinclined to squeeze ourselves and our many bags into a mere and unromantic eastbound jet, we opted for the comfortable and undemanding microcosm of a railway carriage.

title: Landmark In Brooklyn
description: LOEWS KINGS THEATER on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn - a huge and magnificent hodgepodge of Art Deco, Renaissance and ornate Baroque decoration - had been closed for almost a decade, the victim of low attendance and high maintenance.

title: CRACKDOWN ON ILLEGAL RENTALS
description: THE Village of Westbury will begin enforcing a new registration law for rental apartments and tenants this month in an effort to combat the spread of illegal apartments.

title: Miss Morash to Wed Thomas Evarts
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell F. Morash of Lexington and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Victoria Lee Morash to Thomas Morgan Evarts, a son of Josephine Evarts of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Maxwell Evarts.

title: The Competition Glut Killed People Express
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Cheshire, Conn.$125,000 412 Cedar Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, raised-hearth fireplace in living room; taxes $1,364. Farmington, Conn.

title:
OPINION;
RAIL FENCES NEEDED TO PREVENT TRAGEDY
description: IN THE last three years, NJ Transit trains have killed 75 people; 25 more New Jersey residents probably will be killed on the tracks in the next 12 months.

title: J. R. Barclay Wed To Dianne Richoz
description: Dianne Elizabeth Richoz, a daughter of Mary Kuntz Richoz and Charles F. Richoz Jr. of West Bloomfield, Mich., and John Randell Barclay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Barclay Jr. of London and Bovey Tracey, England, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Quebec
description: Quebec takes its name from an Algonquin Indian word meaning where the river narrows, but the city, perched on a cliff overlooking the St. Lawrence River, is historically and culturally French down to its early 17th-century roots. Its European ambiance has made Quebec, 500 miles north of New York, a destination for more than three million visitors a year, including a million Americans. By fall most of them have disappeared from the cobblestone streets, and as the trees turn red in the frosty nights, Quebecers - and visitors, too - enjoy an autumnal respite before winter snows set in.

title: PRIZES FOR HEALTHY HABITS
description: MANY companies segregate smokers in the workplace.

title: NEW DORP TOPS MARTIN IN 4TH QUARTER P.S.A.L.
description: New Dorp, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, relied on Tim Ryan and two key plays in the fourth quarter to defeat Martin, 20-8, yesterday. It was the Centrals' seventh consecutive victory in the P.S.A.L.

title: Arab Nations Seek U.N. Peace Effort
description: Arab countries, worried that Iran may be about to launch a large-scale military offensive in its six-year-old war with Iraq, appealed last week for renewed United Nations peace efforts. And Secretary of State George P. Shultz offered assurances to the foreign ministers of Persian Gulf countries, reaffirming the United States commitment to insure the flow of oil through the Strait of Hormuz, at the entrance to the Gulf.

title:
ART;
THEMES VARY IN MOTHER-SON SHOW
description: THE American art world has its share of talented families, from Charles Wilson Peale and his children to the Soyer brothers and the Wyeth clan. Indeed, one can think of several noted painters and sculptors whose fathers were artists before them; what does not come readily to mind is the name of a male artist whose professional predecessor is his mother.

title: BRITAIN HEADS FOR NUCLEAR WAR AT POLLS
description: POLITICAL commentators and supposed insiders - sometimes referred to in Britain as ''the chattering classes'' -scoffed for the most part a year ago when Neil Kinnock, the leader of Her Majesty's opposition, spoke of moving into 10 Downing Street as Prime Minister in a Labor Party Government. Now, though it is far from a sure thing, they are forced to suspend disbelief.

title: CAPTURING THE LUSTINESS OF NAPLES
description: SEATS at La Parma, in Williston Park, are as hard to come by as tickets to a Mets game. The simple, bright, noisy, crowded dining room with its greenhouse extension takes no reservations and there is frequently a long wait for tables.

title: Maine May Postpone Moving of Caribous
description: Charles E. Hewett, director of the Maine Audubon Society, says the plan to reintroduce caribous to Maine may have to be postponed for a year.

title: PHYSICIANS PLACING MORE EMPHASIS ON ADS
description: USING techniques ranging from promotional T-shirts to press releases, New Jersey doctors are marketing their services in ever more aggressive ways.

title: Belfast Police Uncover Arms
description: The police said they found 2,000 pounds of explosives, six rifles, two machine guns and several thousand rounds of ammunition on Friday in a raid on a house in West Belfast. A spokesman said the weapons belonged to Irish nationalists seeking to oust the British from Northern Ireland.

title: The Met Reviews Two Rembrandts
description: In the 1920's, there were more than 700 paintings attributed to Rembrandt van Rijn. But by the year 2000, art historians estimate, the number will be half that.

title: TRAFFIC SNARLED LEAVING CITY
description: Serious traffic tie-ups developed in Manhattan last evening as motorists leaving New York City for New Jersey ran into heavy delays at the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels.

title: First Monday in October
description: The summer's debate about William Rehnquist's fitness to be Chief Justice battered the Supreme Court as much as its new leader. It aroused fear among legal scholars and politicians that a chief with a 15-year record of hostility to civil rights and civil liberties, joined by a conservative new Justice, Antonin Scalia, would produce fundamental changes in law.

title: Is The Middle-Class Doomed?
description: It is my opinion that, for those who make less than $80,000 (jointly) or $40,000 (individually), the middle class no longer exists.

title: NEW YORK MEDICAL SCHOOLS RECRUIT PRECOLLEGE STUDENTS
description: New York State's 14 public and private medical schools, saying they have failed to attract a sufficient black and Hispanic enrollment, are beginning to recruit students even before they reach college.

title: MEMPHIS'S GRAND HOTEL
description: By 5 P.M. on most days, the lobby of the Peabody Hotel in Memphis is crowded. There are businessmen in silk ties and downtown office workers, families with small children in tow and visitors with cameras. The bar is crowded and the tables beneath the hand-painted glass ceiling are filling up. Like the ducks that splash in the lobby's marble fountain, everyone is waiting for Edward D. Pembroke.

title: Rest In Peace
description: Just outside Abergavenny, in the long-fought-over Welsh Marches, where unforgiving Celts defended their borders against us English parvenus, Skirrid Mountain raises a broken silhouette against the skyline. The mountain split into its present shape, legend says, at the moment of the Crucifixion, when the earth quaked and the rocks were rent. Near its base, The Skirrid Mountain Inn, in the village of Llanvihangel Crucorney, has stood for more than 800 years. From the mounting block outside, Owen Glendower rallied his troops to fight the English.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
A Game Show for 8- to 12-Year Olds
description: The rewards for knowing how many noses a bumblebee has are indeed increasing dramatically these days.

title: Kuhlau Honored The Flute
description: This year marks the centennial anniversary of the death of Franz Liszt, and the bicentennial anniversary of the birth of Carl Maria von Weber. Both composers have been feted throughout the year with a plethora of anniversary concerts. But little attention has been paid to Friedrich Kuhlau, who lived from 1786 to 1832, and who wrote operas, singspiels, concertos, piano sonatas and a great deal of music for flute.

title: When Legal Action Is the Route to Take
description: Going to court in travel disputes can be a gamble for the consumer. In many situations, there is no clear body of law to determine where liability lies.

title: FOX'S BARRY DILLER GAMBLES ON A FOURTH TV NETWORK
description: It is late on a Monday afternoon at the 20th Century Fox movie studio, and Barry Diller, Fox Inc.'s 44-year-old, $3-million-a-year chairman, is overseeing his third staff meeting of the day. Although his current obsession is creating a television network to compete each evening with NBC, CBS and ABC - a high-stakes gamble of more than $150 million that may well fail -Mr. Diller does not share power easily.All the strings from Fox movies, television and real estate are curled under his fingers.

title: 'Adam's Task'
description: To the Editor:

title: SELLING IN A BUYERS' MARKET
description: SEVERAL years ago, Smoke Enders charged $450 to help a smoker kick the habit. Now, because of competition from Smoke Stoppers, Smoking and Health Consultants, and hundreds of other anti-smoking groups, it charges between $200 and $300.

title: CZECHOSLOVAK RECALLS SPECIAL PLACE IN HISTORY
description: As Dr. Jan Papanek nears his 90th birthday, he looks back on a career in public life that included a history-making performance as a Czechoslovak diplomat, followed by decades of quiet service to the world's homeless refugees.

title: French Officials Mobilize Against New Terrorism
description: France took extraordinary precautions last week against terrorist incidents that might follow the five bombings that killed 10 people and injured 162 in September. Senior officials appealed for public vigilance, repeating warnings issued before the bombings.

title: Palpatating For Meaning
description: TAKING THE WORLD IN FOR REPAIRS By Richard Selzer. 239 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: WHEN A DOCTOR HATES A PATIENT: And Other Chapters in a Young Physician's Life. By Richard E. Peschel and Enid Rhodes Peschel.

title: IOWA HOLDS OFF MICHIGAN STATE, 24-21
description: Ken Sims intercepted a Dave Yarema pass in the end zone with 1 minute 25 seconds left to protect a 24-21 Iowa victory over Michigan State in a Big Ten game today.

title: In Nice, Snacking In The Flower Market
description: Socca is a thin, flat bread, served hot by street vendors at the flower market and other open-air markets in Nice. It's also available in the caves, those below-ground restaurants where working people eat. It's mostly a specialty of Nice, but I've also eaten it in Marseilles. It seems to be made only in the morning - at least I've never seen any sold past lunchtime. It's made of chickpea flour, water, olive oil and salt. You don't need butter. It has that good taste of the olive oil.

title: WHITNEY MUSEUM THE TARGET OF TAKEOVER STUDY
description: SINCE the Eli Whitney Museum Association was incorporated 10 years ago, it has restored much of the Hamden site where Whitney helped start the Industrial Revolution.

title: E.P.A. to Regulate Emissions From Wood Burning Stoves
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, saying smoke from wood stoves is a significant source of air pollution, has announced that it will propose rules to limit emissions from new wood burning stoves.

title: ENVOY, LEAVING PRETORIA, BACKS REAGAN'S POLICY
description: The United States Ambassador left South Africa tonight after four and a half years here, a tenure that has seen little but setbacks for the Reagan Administration's policy of ''constructive enggagement.''

title: A Governor Who Won Reforms In The Schools
description: THE nation's governors, at their recent convention in Hilton Head, S. C., called for radical changes in the public schools and sought to assume the lead in effecting reform. They acknowledged that many of their proposals - such as more pay and higher standards for teachers, new taxes for education and state authority to take over school districts that do not meet minimum standards - would be difficult to achieve. One Governor who could report success, however, was Richard W. Riley of South Carolina, who initiated sweeping changes for elementary and secondary schools three years ago. These included state authority to take over inferior districts and a one-cent sales tax increase to pay for new programs. In a recent exchange with faculty members at the Governors Center of Duke University, Mr. Riley, a Democrat, discussed his experience in South Carolina, where the constitution gives the Legislature rather than the governor prime authority. Excerpts follow. Question. You have outlined how you approached different policy problems. I see three things in your examples: First was creating a large, active, representative group to forge new policy directions. The second part seemed to be to take this public. The third was to be persistent - to keep putting it on the agenda until it passes. Does that describe your approach to governing?

title: Broker Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A Travel Advisory item Sept. 28 about the free Fall Events booklet offered by the Division of Tourism of the New York State Commerce Department gave an incorrect telephone number for ordering the booklet. The correct number is 800-225-5697.

title: ENCORE GETS A BREAK
description: There may be a debate over which industry group will lead any future market advance, but there is no question that computer and other high-technology stocks have been the market's big losers recently. Last quarter, the Nasdaq industrial index, loaded with small, over-the-counter technology issues, dropped 16 percent.

title: Karen R. Boutelle Wed in Nantucket
description: Karen Renee Boutelle, the daughter of Joan Boutelle of Branford, Conn., and William Boutelle of Tampa, Fla., was married in Nantucket, Mass., yesterday to John Dodd Lethbridge Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lethbridge of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Richard performed the ceremony in the Old North Vestry of the First Congregational Church.

title: Ann H. Carlston Is Married to William J. Kramer
description: Ann Hunter Carlston, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Anthony Carlston of Virginia Beach, Va., was married yesterday to William Jeffrey Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kramer of Princeton, N.J., and Greensboro, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Daniel Howard Hanchey performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Eastern Shore Chapel in Virginia Beach.

title: PRIMARY SEASON HEARTENS DEMOCRATS
description: THE last primary and the last runoff have taken place, and just a little more than four weeks remains until Election Day, 1986.

title: The Making Of a Dissident
description: Yuri Orlov, Soviet physicist and human rights activist, is being released as part of the deal that paved the way for the summit meeting. What follows are his own words, from letters, courtroom testimony and an autobiographical note written in 1974.

title: Data Update
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED(Housing units)

title: THEY HEAR DIFFERENT VOICES
description: WOMEN'S WAYS OF KNOWING The Development of Self, Voice, and Mind. By Mary Field Belenky, Blythe McVicker Clinchy, Nancy Rule Goldberger and Jill Mattuck Tarule. 256 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: A Great British Treat: Scotch Eggs
description: It is conceivable that my ultimate favorite nosh is that simple creation so typical of the pubs of the British Isles, Scotch eggs.

title: Junk Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE UNIT FAULTED ON AUDIT IN CREDIT UNION FRAUD
description: The State Banking Department failed to find large-scale fraud at the Hyfin Credit Union in Brooklyn because of slow auditing procedures and inadequate training of its examiners, a report by the state's Inspector General says.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO TIME TRAVEL, THERE'S NO TIME LIKE THE PRESENT
description: Modern writers who have attempted science fiction or fantasy have, on numerous occasions, ventured on plots in which the hero or heroine has gone back into the past. Mark Twain's ''Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court,'' published in 1889, was the first. Works by such writers as Jack Finney, Ray Bradbury and L. Sprague de Camp followed. Lately, there have been motion pictures on the theme, including ''Back to the Future,'' released in 1985, and ''Peggy Sue Got Married,'' which closes the New York Film Festival tonight and begins its commercial run Wednesday.

title: CABARET: PHOEBE LEGERE
description: WHEN toward the end of her cabaret act, the classically trained singer-pianist Phoebe Legere hikes up her skirt and sings Jerry Lee Lewis's ''Great Balls of Fire'' in a trilling operatic soprano, the moment comes as the climactic joke in an evening of subversive musical humor. The gesture reminds us that Jerry Lee Lewis, one of the pioneers of rock-and-roll, was himself a musical clown who dealt in outrageous affectation.

title: NEW ORLEANS GOES TO 4-DAY WEEK IN BUDGET CRISIS
description: Beginning next week, New Orleans residents will have one weekday fewer to call on City Hall, to appear in court and to go to the public library.

title: Amy L. Olmstead Marries Engineer
description: Amy Louise Olmstead, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Jay Olmstead of Westport, Conn., was married at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church there yesterday to David Gilbert Vanacek, a son of Robert Russell Vanacek of St. Louis and the late Arline Vanacek. The Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy performed the ceremony.

title: Kenya Safari For Birders
description: Kenya is better known for its larger inhabitants, including lions, elephants and giraffes, but ornithologists recognize it as one of the richest spots on earth for birdwatching. More than 1,000 species have been sighted there, 450 at Lake Naivasha alone.

title: Homeowner's Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: KEEPING THE SUMMER ALIVE IN THE FALL
description: THERE is a small ever-increasing number of malcontents who begin to go into a real emotional decline around Labor Day weekend. I am one of those, outspoken in my dislike of the oncoming winter with its gray cast and interminable darkness. If properly organized, with myself as leader, we would probably be able to win over to our thinking most of those sycophants who relish autumnal splendor and pristine snow. After all, most of those superlatives used to describe changes of seasons are merely used to mask one's obvious confusion with yet another change in an already peripatetic life style.

title: THE YOGI FACTOR
description: BACK in the early 60's, the Mets and the Yankees used to book their charter flights on DC-6B propeller-driven planes, not the sleek jet aircraft that now swoop and soar around lightning storms and other hazards.

title: DESHAIES WINS 12TH FOR ASTROS
description: Jim Deshaies became the first rookie in the Astros' 25-year history to win 12 games in a season, leading Houston to a 3-2 victory today over the Atlanta Braves.

title: A GRAIN GLUT HAS GROWERS SKIRMISHING FOR MARKETS
description: The Soviet Union, the best grain customer the United States has, ignored President Reagan's offer of American wheat at a bargain price last week. The rejection, which kindled an immediate political furor, showed just how sharply the world food market has changed.

title: Donovan Trial Opens in Bronx
description: Spectators in State Supreme Court in the Bronx last week heard a prosecutor at center stage describe Raymond J. Donovan, the former Secretary of Labor, as a participant in a larcenous scheme based on ''greed - plain and simple.'' Stage right, they heard defense counsel describe the case as a ''phantom'' and the 56-year-old defendant as a man who was orphaned in his teens, gave up studying for the priesthood to support five younger brothers and sisters, made good in the construction business and went on to do good by anonymously financing 60 minority students in a private high school.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THE WISDOM OF SCIENCE: Its Relevance to Culture and Religion. By Hanbury Brown. (Cambridge University, Cloth, $32.50. Paper, $13.95.) Hanbury Brown, an Australian physicist, looks on the world with a heavy heart.

title: A DELICATE BALANCE ON MENTAL ILLNESS
description: MENTAL illness strikes one of every five Americans. For some, it is a temporary condition that requires professional care, medication and perhaps a brief hospital stay. For others - about 2.4 million Americans - fighting the terror of mental illness is a constant battle.

title: Folk Art That Holds A Mirror to the American Past
description: Masterworks abound among the folk-art portraits, weathervanes, shop signs, quilts, furniture and objects on view in ''Young America: A Folk-Art History,'' an exhibition that tells the story of everyday life in this country between the Revolution and World War I. Organized for a national tour by the Museum of American Folk Art, the show is on view through Nov. 15 at the IBM Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street, while the Folk Art Museum is temporarily closed.

title: CARDINALS HOPE TO END THEIR NIGHTMARE
description: For the St. Louis Cardinals, this has been a season of nightmares.

title: THE RIGHT FLOWERS MAKE A TRADITIONAL LOT A SHOWPLACE
description: Tom Lavery bought his house on Long Island in the Syosset development community in 1950, four years after he was discharged from the Navy. ''I liked the simplicity and adaptability of the house plan, the 100 by 90 foot tract of land and the $10,500 price tag,'' he recalled.

title: Paul Doucette Married To Elizabeth L. Glassie
description: Elizabeth Leith Glassie, the daughter of Phyllis W. Fragola of Barrington, R.I., and Donelson Caffery Glassie Jr. of Newport, R.I., was married in Newport yesterday to Paul Francis Doucette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis S. Doucette of Braintree, Mass. The Rev. H. August Kuehl performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: JETS' QUIET BINGHAM IS AT CENTER STAGE FOR GAME WITH BILLS
description: Guy Bingham, one of the quietest Jets, will be filling one of their noisiest roles today.

title: EX-PARIS AIDE GAVE WARNING TO SYRIA
description: A former head of the French secret service says French theats of retaliation in 1982 led Syria to stop, at least for a time, what he called its support of terrorism in France.

title: Miracle on Fifth Avenue
description: Hail the return of the New York Public Library. Today it offers computer bibliographies and ready access to whatever is written to any who ask. Its reach stretches beyond 84 branches to most of the world's leading libraries, whose riches can be tapped without charge. Also free are millions of archival pictures, specialized collections, gallery exhibitions and the company of the complacent lions on its front steps.

title: Controls That Go Beyond Remote
description: In fairy tales, aside from living happily ever after, it is also possible to issue commands to inanimate objects. Mountains open, brooms sweep and tables promptly serve you dinner, if you speak the right word.

title: HEADS OF 2 AWARD-WINNING GROUPS JOIN HANDS AT PIANO
description: THE New Jersey Chamber Music Society will open its 12th season Friday with performances by society members and their guest artist, Hugh Wolff, music director and conductor of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title: RACING TO BRING HOME THE COME
description: EVEN THE LONG-est winning streak in history finally got boring.

title: Comings and Goings
description: BEN OGLIVIE, the 37-year-old outfielder-designated hitter who this season batted .286 with five home runs in 101 games, does not fit into the plans of the Milwaukee Brewers for the 1987 season and thus the final year of his contract has been bought out by the club. . . . Vice President Bush, who threw out the first ball at the All-Star Game in Houston July 15, will provide the same service for the Astros at their opening game of the National League championship series against the Mets at the Astrodome Wednesday night. John Lehman, the Secretary of the Navy, will do the honors at the second game on Thursday night.

title: Setup, Trumped-Up, But Not Framed-Up
description: A STATE DEPART-ment spokesman said that the Soviet case against Nicholas S. Daniloff, an American newsman in Moscow, was based on charges that were ''contrived,'' and many news stories promptly jettisoned that weak word for an informal but more widely understood usage: the newsman, it was reported, had been framed.

title: A HIGH COST TO DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
description: LAST July 21, the Republic of Korea agreed with the United States to increase its protection of patents, copyrights and trademarks. The negotiations were difficult, in part because the changes were widely viewed in Korea as having been won by the economic power of a large country from a smaller one. The United States claimed that Korea must change its intellectual property rules in order to insure international norms of fairness.

title: Foreign Policy and '88
description: President Reagan's handling of the Daniloff affair has dismayed the Republican right, but because conservatives cannot bring themselves to criticize Mr. Reagan personally, some political experts are wondering if they will take out their frustration on Vice President Bush in 1988.

title: Humor in Arizona
description: Some residents of Leisure World, a private retirement community in Arizona, were not amused by Representative John McCain's attempt at humor. In a speech to a group of college students, Mr. McCain, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, made a number of references to ''Seizure World,'' with pauses for laughter, in commenting on the state's reputation as a haven for retirees. He also joked that in the last state election 97 percent of the voters living at Leisure World cast ballots, adding, ''The other 3 percent were in intensive care.'' Mr. McCain has since campaigned at Leisure World and has said that the only person who seemed disturbed by the remarks was his Democratic challenger, Richard Kimball.

title:
IS OLIGOPOLY A LEGACY OF AIRLINE DEREGULATION?;
The Industry Is More Competitive
description: WHILE the deregulation of routes and fares in 1978 spawned more than a score of new carriers, only big airlines with deep pockets survived the ensuing price wars. Last week, the contraction in the number of competitors proceeded apace. The Justice Department said it would not oppose either Delta Air Lines' proposed $860 million acquisition of Western Air Lines or Texas Air Corporation's proposed $301 million purchase of People Express Inc. and People's bankrupt subsidiary, Frontier Airlines. Both mergers must still pass muster with the Department of Transportation, which, as expected, approved Texas Air's $600 million purchase of Eastern Air Lines.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE New Jersey Pinelands Commission has published its plan for scientific research in that million-acre reserve.

title: Mines of World War II Found At New Chernobyl Town Site
description: Workers building a temporary settlement for operators of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant found the site littered with World War II mines and had to call in army experts to explode them.

title: REAGAN SEES HOUSE UNDERCUTTING HIM AT SOVIET PARLEY
description: President Reagan warned today that some arms-control measures voted by the House of Representatives were undercutting American negotiating strength as he prepares for his meeting next weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: A-SUB ACCIDENTS: A LOG
description: A fire aboard a Soviet nuclear submarine on Friday is reported to have killed three people. Here are some notable accidents involving Soviet or American nuclear submarines over the last quarter-century.

title: TIMBERING CALLED THREAT TO VAST FOREST IN ALASKA
description: This quiet little village on the edge of Prince of Wales Island is one of a number of logging towns that are at the center of a furious debate over the fate of the nation's largest national forest.

title: SENATE OPPOSES CAPITAL'S BAN ON AIDS TEST
description: The Senate passed two amendments Friday to its $558 billion spending plan, including one that would overturn a District of Columbia law that bars insurance companies from testing people applying for policies for exposure to the AIDS virus.

title: A SHAW DRAMA STAYS MODERN AFTER 90 YEARS
description: Gloria's mother is a pioneering feminist, a best-selling author who has renounced marriage and men to dedicate her life to improving the human condition.

title: Oct. 25 Wedding For Miss Barton
description: Priscilla Taylor Barton of New York and Charles Frick Jenkins Jr. of Westport, Conn., graduates of the University of Vermont, plan to be married Oct. 25. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Walker Barton Jr. of Baltimore, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mrs. Jenkins of Glyndon, Md., and the late Mr. Jenkins.

title:
GARDENING;
CULLING TIPS ON PLANTINGS FROM ENGLAND
description: THERE can be little disappointment in what one sees in the grand old gardens of England such as Sissinghurst or Hibcote. They are everything that one has been led to expect: works of art when it comes to design, use of plants and maintenance.

title: M. M. Witherbee Wed To Laura Ann Parker
description: At the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday Laura Ann Parker, a daughter of Etta Schumann Parker of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Lawrence Sherman Parker of Southport, Conn., and New York, was married to Matthew Macrae Witherbee, a son of John Hemenway Witherbee of Nantucket, Mass., and Roxbury, Conn., and the late Jill Macrae Witherbee. The Rev. Dr. David L. Uhl performed the ceremony.

title: GOING FOR NON-CASH BENEFITS
description: WORKSITE wellness programs do more than lower medical costs. Here are just a few of the claims that wellness consultants make:

title: Burger's Title
description: Warren E. Burger, judicial protocol experts advise, is not former Chief Justice of the United States but retired Chief Justice of the United States. A member of the High Court who resigns from the bench to take another job, as Arthur Goldberg did in 1965, is properly referred to as a former Justice, officials say, but one who retired, as Mr. Burger just did at 79, should be called a retired Justice.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: SPECIAL CARE: Medical Decisions at the Beginning of Life. By Fred M. Frohock. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) Few environments harbor as many complex situations as neonatal intensive care nurseries.

title: HOMER, CATULLUS AND THE OX IN THE STAIRWELL
description: THE OXFORD HISTORY OF THE CLASSICAL WORLD Edited by John Boardman, Jasper Griffin and Oswyn Murray. Illustrated. 882 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $39.95.

title: Consumer Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: LANIER REVERSES ASTROS' COURSE
description: WHAT one has here is a clear example of how contrasting means can result in a similar end. Actually, there are many similarities between the managing styles of Hal Lanier of the Houston Astros and Dave Johnson of the Mets. Both men are relatively new to the profession - this is Lanier's first season as a major league manager, Johnson's third - and both are aggressive strategists who force opponents onto the defensive with daring base-running and hitting maneuvers.

title: 'New School'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: APPRENTICE TO GENIUS: The Making of a Scientific Dynasty. By Robert Kanigel. (Macmillan, $19.95.) Robert Kanigel's narrow subject is ''mentoring networks . . . in the highest ranks of science''; his broad one, how ''important'' science is done.

title: PIPELINE 'BENEFITS' UNWANTED
description: I'VE been searching Litchfield County trying to uncover the people who the Iroquois Gas Transmission System claims will benefit from the natural gas pipeline it proposes to lay through our towns. They are hard to find.

title: Seattle Brews
description: To the Editor: On reading the article on microbrews in Seattle and the Northwest (Travel, May 11), I was filled with thirsty anticipation for an upcoming trip that would take my wife and me through this beer drinkers' paradise.

title: Recitals by 2 Tenors, 2 Pianists and an Oboist
description: Daejin Kim Daejin Kim, a pianist from South Korea who gave his first New York recital at Merkin Concert Hall last Sunday, demonstrated all the accouterments necessary for a successful solo career. Mr. Kim has what seems to be a foolproof technique, and his careful choice of music showed a musician interested in subtleties, not just the usual frontal assaults of bravura repertory.

title: FIRMNESS IN THE 'SOFT' CO-OP MARKET
description: APARTMENT buyers in Manhattan often hear that the resale market for co-ops and condos is soft.

title: Coffee To Wine
description: Some remarkable destinies awaited the coffeehouses that flourished in the second half of the 17th century in the square mile east of Ludgate Circus called the City of London. Jonathan's developed into the Stock Exchange; Lloyd's became Lloyd's of London; The Jamaica . . . remained The Jamaica.

title: Stick to the Basics, End Losing Streak
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WHEN Joan Schulhafer of Bloomfield, a public-relations writer, wrote to this column recently to praise a new author, she omitted a vital fact.

title: Innocent Pleas
description: THREE days after his release from the Philadelphia Eagles, Kevin Allen was arrested Friday and charged with sexually assaulting a woman and beating her male companion on a beach in Margate, N.J., at 5:30 A.M. Sept. 1. Scott Cartwright, Allen's roomate and a former employee in the Eagles' marketing department, was charged with the same crimes and, like Allen, pleaded not guilty yesterday at an arraignment in New Jersey State Superior Court in Mays Landing.

title: A Suspect Released
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., the principal living figure in a case whose titillation sometimes seems to have obscured its tragedy, was released from jail on $150,000 bail last week. The 20-year-old Mr. Chambers, who is charged with strangling Jennifer Dawn Levin, 18, in the course of a predawn tryst in Central Park, was called ''a thug and a murderer'' by prosecutors, who opposed his release.

title: ALABAMA EASILY BEATS NOTRE DAME
description: Alabama had little trouble remaining undefeated today as it whipped Notre Dame, 28-10, for its first victory in five meetings between the schools. The victory was the Crimson Tide's fifth of the season.

title: Misplaced 'Regrets'
description: To the Editor:

title: FINE FARE AMONG THE ART
description: FOOD is often considered an art form, and at Au Musee you can enjoy the blending of food and art in a single place. This French-accented restaurant can be found in the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, one of Connecticut's premiere art museums.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
THE RADIO RED SOXM, A PART OF NEW ENGLAND
description: IN northern New England's September, as we drive past swamp maples flaring their Chinese reds, we keep our radios tuned to the calm urgencies of Ken Coleman broadcasting from Fenway Park. This year the month was splendid not only for leaves.

title:
THE DRINKING WRITER'S GUIDE;
LONDON VICTORIAN
description: My local, so local that even I can reach it on foot, is called The Queen's, commemorating not the present sovereign but Victoria. It stands on a street corner in a nice middle-class bit of north London, just up the hill from the zoo in Regent's Park. A pleasant stretch of grassland adjoins it, but you can't see much from the pub for the red, bottle-green and turquoise stained-glass windows. Except for a couple of panes, these are as old as the building (from about 1820), their age revealed by the distorted, as well as colored, image they give of outside. They are pretty in themselves, and they dim the daylight, as required in a pub.

title: SCOUT GETS A RAIL BILL IN TRENTON
description: WHAT started out as an Eagle Scout project for John M. Shue has become a campaign that could improve safety along the state's 380 miles of commuter railroad tracks.

title: MUBARAK FIGHTS A FUNDAMENTALIST TIDE ON CAMPUS
description: When the medical school of Asyut University held examinations recently, the bearded student recalled, the building was ringed with policemen.

title: CABLE TV: MAJOR CHANGES LOOM
description: FLANKED by videotape monitors, large charts and two associates, Rusty McCormack, vice president of the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, stepped to the microphone at a recent Babylon Town Board public hearing.

title: In Mexico, The Many Masks of Gods and Men
description: It was 1967, and masked men of a Mexican Indian village were performing a pre-Lenten dance. Suddenly encircling their visitors, two tiger-men and a devil shrieked and cracked their whips. A lizard-man with a bat mask swung a machete just inches away from me. Were these the gestures of friend or foe? The loud laughter of the villagers broke the tension, yet, clearly, behind the disguise there was a different perception of reality. The mask was only the visible part.

title: EMPTY HOUSES THAT CRY IN THE NIGHT
description: NT has been two years since the cornfield opposite my house was raped, bermed and filled with wooden mansions. Like certain unmentionable diseases, however, this symptom of progress spreads alarmingly, and its victims double in number each year.

title: The Elements Of a Deal
description: Even as Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev make their way to Reykjavik, the likely subject matter of their meeting is clear. Events of the past year - the longer-term developments that convinced both leaders to go to Iceland -bode well for progress in a number of substantive areas, particularly on intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe. The Administration may be prepared to take advantage of this opportunity, but it also ought to be encouraged to go an extra mile - to reach for a still broader deal and prepare the way for even more significant agreements in the future. In the past year, in spite of the tensions in the relationship, there has been slow but steady progress in arms control talks in Geneva. A new mood of seriousness has produced a stream of new proposals. Both sides have shifted from millenarian efforts to rid the world of every last nuclear weapon to a more pragmatic goal of perhaps a 30 percent cut. And both sides have made concessions to keep the negotiations alive.

title: SCHOLAR'S TENURE DENIAL STIRS HARVARD DISPUTE
description: A decision by Harvard University to deny tenure to a popular and widely respected junior professor of American history has touched off a dispute among faculty members and students over the university's promotion system.

title: SCHOOL FINANCING CHALLENGED AT TRIAL
description: AFTER years of procedural wrangling, a suit expected to have widespread implications for New Jersey's system of financing public education finally made it to trial here last week.

title: Byronic, Despite Everything
description: THE CALCULATING PASSION OF ADA BYRON By Joan Baum. Illustrated. 133 pp. Hamden, Conn. Archon Books/The Shoe String Press. $21.50.

title: AS THE TEMPERATURE DIPS, SOME DISHES OFFER UP WARMTH
description: ON fall evenings, when there is a chill in the air, I find myself longing for simple food.

title: Eternal Question
description: Pan American World Airways took full-page ads recently to tout its new shuttle services between New York and Washington and Boston - and to raise a classically puzzling question.

title: PORNOGRAPHY'S PLIGHT HITS TIMES SQUARE
description: Among its other distinctions, midtown Manhattan has always been the nation's capital for retail sex. There are not many other cities that, in the late 60's, boasted a topless shoeshine parlor, or a police force willing to set up barricades separating phalanxes of working prostitutes from people attempting to get to the theater.

title: CHEKHOVIAN LIVES IN SWAMP AND LAB
description: THE PEAK OF SUCCESS AND OTHER STORIES By Yury Nagibin. Edited by Helena Goscilo. 409 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis Publishers. $29.50.

title: The Happy Couple: Korean Wedding Ducks
description: We found the ducks in a cluttered shop on a back street in Seoul one Sunday afternoon. Perched on a dusty shelf, necks arched so they stared at each other, the wooden ducks were unmistakably a pair. We were actually cheating, buying them ourselves, for in South Korea everyone knows that such matched ducks are to be given as wedding presents, not purchased after the wedding by the couple themselves. But the ducks, tokens of the fidelity and constancy that should grace married life, seemed an apt and pleasant souvenir.

title:
GARDENING;
CULLING TIPS ON PLANTINGS FROM ENGLAND
description: THERE can be little disappointment in what one sees in the grand old gardens of England such as Sissinghurst or Hibcote. They are everything that one has been led to expect: works of art when it comes to design, use of plants and maintenance.

title: At Photokina, Still-Video Cameras
description: THE latest installment of the biennial Photokina trade show in Cologne, West Germany, is history. Since Photokina is where the major photographic manufacturers often introduce their new products and reveal their pie-in-in-sky prototypes, a look back at last month's show is instructive, if only to decipher where the industry thinks photography is headed.

title: UNDEFEATED BROWN DOWNS PRINCETON
description: Mark Donovan found Dave Fielding on a 55-yard scoring play early in the first quarter as Brown scored on its first three possessions to defeat Princeton, 24-10, in an Ivy League game and remain undefeated.

title: BEGUILED BY IRELAND
description: WHEN GOD DROP-ped that little bit of green in the northeast Atlantic Ocean between longitudes wet and latitudes chill, and there was in a trice this pleasantly peasant little island nation resting on the waves, the Almighty had no idea that such a bereft place would become an emerald-hued mecca for tourists.

title: Art
description: Arthur Weyhe has a way with wood. He spends his summers in Nova Scotia or in upstate New York, cutting, carving and assembling the cedar that he will then use for large-scale sculptures.

title: WHEN TO LEAVE A POLITICAL PARTY
description: The front-page piece ''Judgeship Primary Is Challenge to Ban on Endorsing'' [ Sept. 7 ] cries out for needed insight.

title: NORMAN DEFEATS NICKLAUS TO GAIN FINAL
description: Greg Norman of Australia sank a 60-foot putt for an eagle 3 at the 35th hole and went on to beat Jack Nicklaus on the last hole of their semifinal in the $270,000 Suntory world match play golf championships today.

title: Boon Companions
description: The Prince of Wales in London's Notting Hill is one of those fine old pubs with huge glass windows and a bar in the middle like a stockade. It is built astride two streets, Princedale Road and Pottery Lane, and there is a right-of-way through the public bar. If you see someone you do not like come in from one side you can quickly skip out on the other. Perhaps this is why some of the customers look like drug dealers or petty thieves.

title: ON BAVARIAN BYWAYS
description: SEVERAL YEARS AGO I was the house guest of a professor of American literature at the University of Wurzburg, and it was my first time in Bavaria. Coming from a winter in Moscow, I was wholly alive to the sights and sounds of early summer in Western Europe. The Main River and the Franconian vineyards were scintillant in the sun, and the sky was blue. My host was a proper and hospitable man, and there was a free afternoon ahead of us. Would I care to see something of the countryside? Yes, indeed. Thereupon he produced a kind of concentrated library, an assortment of maps and guides and legends and photographs that closely defined the geography of the neighborhood.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: Plant bulbs. . . . Finish lawn seeding and sodding. . . . Gather nuts. . . . Cut grasses and seed pods to dry for winter bouquets. A National Flower? Marigolds, dogwoods, corn tassels, columbines and mountain laurels have lost. The rose has won. On Sept. 23 the House of Representatives voted to agree with the Senate and make the rose the national flower.

title: SMALL THINGS COUNT
description: TRUE FREEDOM IS THE freedom to enjoy a private life. A private life is made up of atomic particles hard to make public. One of the troubles with travel these days is that it is all too public - great tourist buses, a huge collection of luggage piled in a hotel lobby, an abstract schedule of visits, the plastic of the tourist menu. We go home somehow diminished, having surrendered our idiosyncracies to the generalized public image of the 20th-Century Traveler. We ought to seek out and cherish the minutiae of the world. It is the only way to bring that world to life. Otherwise it is as dead as an atlas. T. S. Eliot could never forget the sight of an old white horse galloping away in a meadow: it seemed to hold some mysterious meaning beyond itself, hard to fathom but undoubtedly significant. James Joyce talked of epiphanies - meaning the sudden flashes of truth that come in the lighting of a cigarette or the scratching of a pimple. Small things count, but we don't know why. Not knowing why, we find it easier to ignore them. When we travel we photograph the Parthenon or the Vittorio Emanuele monument. We put them into our albums or project them on a screen for our bored neighbors. The small stuff is unrecorded and forgotten.

title: Miss Stanton Has Wedding
description: St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Helen Stanton, the daughter of Judge Louis L. Stanton and Phoebe R. Stanton, both of New York, to Rodman Wesley Benedict, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Benedict of Cranbury, N.J. The Rev. Hays Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: THAT ELUSIVE IDEAL, THE PERFECT PUB
description: TALK ABOUT AN ENGLISH pub and what do you think of? Perhaps it's a place of rural jollity with log fires crackling and grinning farm lads slurping pints and squaring up to the dart board; or a Cockney gin palace with gleaming brass and ornate mirrors carved and frosted with miraculous foliage, a place for strummed pianos and ''Knees Up, Mother Brown.'' Or is it a North Country haven where commercial travelers drink bottled Bass, exchange dirty jokes and chat up the bosomy barmaid? The ideal picture of the English pub, consistent in our fiction from Fielding to J. B. Priestley, has, of late, suffered a few rude shocks. The wayside inn may now be a brutalized drinking hole with mock pine wallpaper, pinging Space Invaders, graffiti in the loo and a smeared glass case containing one partially mummified cheese roll. Perhaps worse, it may have piped Barry Manilow in the ''Old Snug,'' pina coladas and greasy chicken and chips nestling in a checked paper napkin. The English pub is not exactly what it was, it has to be confessed, since the members of the Pickwick Club took the coach down to Dingley Dell.

title: Catherine Morton Richards Is Married To Robert H. P. Olney Jr. in New Jersey
description: Catherine Morton Richards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Richards of Far Hills, N.J., and Robert Hare Powel Olney Jr., a son of Mrs. Robert W. Tilney Jr. of Far Hills and the late Mr. Olney of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Giles Hayes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Brigid in Peapack, N.J. He was assisted by the bridegroom's sister, the Rev. Linda Peyton, an Episcopal priest.

title: A ROWDY 'GEMINI' IN FAIRFIELD
description: THE terrain of the playwright Albert Innaurato is bounded by the absurd and the ridiculous. Call it theater of the bizarre - a handy appellation since an anthology of six of Mr. Innaurato's published plays happens to be called ''Bizarre Behavior.''

title: 3d and Last In Fort Lee
description: The success of One Executive Drive and Two Executive Drive has led the Fort Lee Executive Park partners to go ahead with Three Executive Drive, a 28-story office tower.

title: 108 DAYS OF MARRIAGE, AND COUNTING
description: RAVEN'S WINGS By Joyce Carol Oates. 305 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: AMERICANS LOOK TO ISRAEL FOR EXPANSION
description: A HIGHLY skilled labor force, a favorable business climate and the elimination of customs duties make Israel a good place for American companies to conduct business. That was the message from American and Israeli officials at the first in a series of major conferences on United States-Israeli trade, held recently at the Crowne Plaza in White Plains.

title: ARBITRATION SEEMS APPEALING, BUT HAS MYRIAD OF PITFALLS
