description: EVERY day, contracts are signed stipulating that any dispute arising under that contract shall be resolved by arbitration. And every day, when that arbitration takes place, people learn first hand of the unexpected and even disastrous consequences that can result.

title: Question of the Week; Who Are Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: The National League most valuable player should be the Phillies' Mike Schmidt. Clearly, he has been the league's player of the year, leading the league or ranking among the leaders in home runs, runs batted in, slugging percentage, on-base percentage, walks and runs scored. He is even in the top 10 in hitting. Nevertheless, some fans may argue that because Schmidt's team did not win the division, he should not be selected. I think, however, that a more equitable measure of whether a candidate should be considered ''most valuable'' would be to assess how his team would have fared without him. Instead of finishing in second place, the Phillies would have battled the Cubs and the Pirates for the division cellar. However, if the National League division champions did not have Gary Carter or Glenn Davis, I think each would still have won the title. DAVIS W. STARFIELD

title: SPARRING SETS STAGE FOR TRIALS IN AMERICA'S CUP COMPETITION
description: For the last week, pairs of 12-Meters could be seen in the distance, sizing each other up in preparation for the America's Cup trial races for challengers, which are scheduled to begin Sunday. They are the fruition of multimillion-dollar campaigns and years of training for the 13 teams involved.

title: A TIME FOR MENDING FENCES: REPAIRS AND REINFORCEMENT
description: FALL is an ideal time for mending fences. The weather is still pleasant, the ground is not yet frozen - in case digging for new posts is required -and most gardening and yard work is done.

title: Blending 'Village' and Italy
description: A partnership of four Italian and American developers, headed by Carlo Fegiz, an architect based in Rome, is putting up a 12-unit condominium at 3 Bedford Street in Greenwich Village that is designed to combine the influence of Italy and the historic-district neighborhood.

title: Recent Releases of Video Cassettes
description: Nicolai Ghiaurov: Tribute to a Great Basso Featuring Nicolai Ghiaurov, Herbert von Karajan, Jose Carreras, Mirella Freni V.I.E.W. Video 82 minutes. $59.95

title: Angela Christmas Wed To Geoffrey Fitzgerald
description: Angela Christmas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Christmas of Middle Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Geoffrey David Fitzgerald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Fitzgerald Jr. of Dix Hills, L.I., and New York. The Rev. Robert Ross Johnson performed the ceremony at the St. Albans Congregational Church in Queens.

title: Spain's Universal Morning Munch
description: What makes many a delicious deep-fried street snack unacceptable at a proper meal is that wonderful greasiness. Take churros, for example, the universal golden-brown morning munch in Spain.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SCULPTURE COMPETITION
description: Westchester sculptors will have the opportunity to vie for a new award in the coming weeks. The Volunteer Service Bureau of United Way is sponsoring a sculpture competition for the design and production of a work that best exemplifies the Spirit of Volunteerism.

title: DARKEST CALIFORNIA
description: I AM IN A COMMERCIAL AIR-liner, 25,000 feet above California. The pilot makes an announcement: ''Coming up on the left-hand side of the aircraft is the city of Santa Barbara.'' But I am on the right-hand side of the aircraft. When I look down, I wonder, as so often in the past, if the pilot is trying to reassure us, inventing cities and landmarks to dispel our fear of this vast unknown.

title:
DINING OUT;
WHOLESOME FARE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: HOMEY food and lots of it is a familiar story at Michelangelo, now in its 13th year. At the helm since last March, new management has wisely chosen to intensify rather than to change the robust style of this lively restaurant. The place hums with cheery bustle from swift-footed dining room staff and from dating couples, sedate business people and entire families, all there to enjoy wholesome preparations in quantities that guarantee getting one's money's worth.

title: A French Accent Helps Earn The Festival Success
description: Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall, the principal site of the annual New York Film Festival, seems an especially neutral space at 10:30 in the morning when the day's first press screenings begin. Machines have recycled and chilled the air from the night before. The lobby could be that of a giant funeral parlor, or of a movie theater in some efficiently regimented Orwellian society - there's no popcorn on the floor.

title: IN THE SACRED VALLEY OF THE INCAS
description: Most tourists go to Cuzco to get to Machu Picchu, the great Incan ruin in the Peruvian Andes.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE LIASON
description: THERE goes the neighborhood. Property values will plunge. No one will move nearby. The new arrivals will look weird and act worse.

title: A SMALL-SCALE 'EVITA' AS LARGE AS LIFE
description: SMALL theater companies often excuse mediocre productions by saying that they do not have the budgets that allow them to do Broadway-quality musicals.

title: How Chance Leads of Change
description: SEWALL WRIGHT AND EVOLUTIONARY BIOLOGY By William B. Provine. Illustrated. 545 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $30.

title: DUTCH CHALLENGE THE SEA WITH $2.4 BILLION DIKE
description: Queen Beatrix pushed a button here today dropping a row of steel gates on the costliest and technologically most advanced sea barrier the Dutch have erected in the nine centuries they have been battling the sea.

title: AIDS LOOMS AS AN ISSUE IN VISITS BY FATHERS
description: A few years ago few homosexual fathers dared to fight for visiting rights in divorce cases. But today, even as the specter of AIDS is being raised in more cases, this has begun to change.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Cambridge, Mass., dispatch in some editions on Sept. 6 about Harvard University's 350th-anniversary celebration described Walter Cronkite's relationship to the university incorrectly. As later editions reported, he holds an honorary doctorate from Harvard. He also serves on the visiting committee of the Kennedy School of Government there.

title: 'WOZA AFRIKA!' AND THE STAGE AS A POLITICAL FORUM
description: The first four plays in the festival of South African drama at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater have raised two important questions: First, to what degree is this political statement and to what degree theater art? And second, in presuming to ask the first question, are we being politically naive, putting ourselves in the position of, let us say, asking a hungry lion to charm us with elegant table manners?

title: Texas Applies a Fiscal 'Band-Aid'
description: No one found it very satisfactory - the lieutenant governor called it a ''small Band-Aid'' - but a package of measures designed to keep Texas temporarily solvent is in place.

title: Kathryn J. Roseberry Weds Bruce Petersen
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday Kathryn Joan Roseberry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Roseberry Jr. of St. Louis, was married to Bruce Brownell Petersen, a son of Jean Snyder Petersen and Elton Reed Petersen, both of Mount Lebanon, Pa. The Rev. David Earnest performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: BIOTECHNOLOGY: Strategies for Life. By Elizabeth Antebi and David Fishlock. (MIT, $39.95.) What to buy the venture capitalist who has everything? Anyone facing that problem will be glad to know Elizabeth Antebi and David Fishlock have written a coffeetable book about biotechnology - a large, lavishly illustrated, handsomely produced guide to the scientific and commercial sides of genetic engineering and less exotic technologies.

title: Nicaraguan Views
description: Supporters of a strong anti-Communist action in Central America are pressing the Administration to withdraw recognition of the Government of Nicaragua and recognize the anti-Government guerrillas. At the same time critics of current American policy toward the region believe the Administration has a plan to do just that.

title: Susan Harley Weds
description: Susan Helene Harley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Harley of John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., and Muskoka, Ontario, was married last evening to Boris Gregory Kinberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kinberg of New York.

title: The Mediterranean In A Pie Shell
description: I usually spend a week each summer outside Beziers, France, a Romanesque city of about 60,000 on the Mediterranean coast between Marseilles and the Spanish border. One of my favorite pastimes is going each morning to the city's sprawling central market, especially the seafood section, where the array of fresh fish from the Atlantic and Mediterranean - all arranged neatly on glaciers of crushed ice and tended by women in white smocks - is overwhelming.

title: COLUMBIA IS DEALT 24TH LOSS IN A ROW
description: Pennsylvania set an Ivy League record for penalties in a game today, and for that followers of Columbia's football fortunes can be grateful.

title: INJURED LIST KEEPS PLAYERS ON HAND, IF NOT ON FIELD
description: More players than ever are on the National Football League's injured reserve list. Could that mean teams are stashing again?

title: DARWIN AND THE EVOLUTION OF FICTION
description: IT is arguable that the most influential English writer of the last 150 years is Charles Darwin and the most influential book ''The Origin of Species.'' Darwin gave to the West its most powerful myth of origins since the Old Testament; at the same time, he wrested biology, the study of life, from theological tradition and set it entirely within the explanatory range of a materialist science. The world, which had been understood as the material expression of a divine intention, became, in his argument, an accumulation of chance variations, subject only to the regularity of what he and his contemporaries thought of as natural law. Obviously, the moral and religious implications were enormous.

title: Is the Middle Class Doomed?
description: The title of Barbara Ehrenreich's article ''Is the Middle Class Doomed?'' is an overstatement of the data; the data, while disturbing, are limited and contradictory. Referring to proportions of wealth held by percentile groups doesn't tell you if absolute wealth has changed, nor if the individuals are the same in the percentile groups.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of Stephen King's ''It'' on Aug. 24 misstated the publishing history of Mr. King's novels. Doubleday & Company was the original publisher of his first four novels; the rest were published by Viking. New American Library and NAL Books originally published the five novels he wrote as Richard Bachman.

title: DIRECTOR OF CLINIC IS HONORED FOR WORK
description: THE executive director of a neighborhood health clinic in New Haven is one of five former Peace Corps volunteers honored recently by the corps for their humanitarian service.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY
description: THE EVOLUTION OF LIFE. Edited by Gail Vines and Linda Gamlin. (Oxford University, $35.) This brisk tour of the plant and animal kingdom begins with homage to Charles Darwin, for whom the mechanism behind the upward mobility of species was the progressive adaptation of all life-forms to their changing habitats.

title: SURVIVING POL POT
description: THE STONES CRY OUT A Cambodian Childhood, 1975-1980. By Molyda Szymusiak. Translated by Linda Coverdale. Maps. 245 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $17.95.

title: MIXING AND MATCHING IS ENLIVENING THE ARTS
description: The 80's are becoming, in ways almost unthinkable just a few years ago, the decade of collaboration - of established artists working in different media getting together to create upon a stage. Life in the arts today, in fact, is beginning to resemble the heady days of Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes when it was not uncommon for the likes of Satie, Picasso, Massine and Cocteau to collaborate with one another (as they did on ''Parade'' in 1917).

title: Figures for Reformers
description: THE RISE OF STATISTICAL THINKING #1820-1900. By Theodore M. Porter. 333 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $35. THE HISTORY OF STATISTICS The Measurement of Uncertainty Before 1900. By Stephen M. Stigler. Illustrated. 410 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25.

title: LOOKING AT AFRICA THROUGH AN AFRICAN'S EYES
description: ''I myself am an example of Africa's triple heritage,'' said Ali A. Mazrui, the central personality both as writer and as narrator on camera of the controversial new documentary series ''The Africans,'' which begins this week on the Public Broadcasting Service. The initial hourlong chapter in the nine-part series - a co-production of WETA, the Washington member station, and the British Broadcasting Corporation - will be broadcast Thursday evening at 9 on WNET/ Channel 13 in New York and at the same hour, two days earlier, on most of the other 300 PBS stations around the country.

title: Headliners; A Violinist Indicted
description: In economic systems, too, the zeal of converts bears watching. Or it could be that Gregory Gelman, a Soviet emigre, simply observed the real estate business as practiced in New York City and made the unfortunate assumption that it exemplified Western capitalism.

title: WHEN A WOMAN TAKES THE HELM
description: AFTER the bottom fell out of the clamming industry, my husband, a clam digger, had to find another job.

title: Taos
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a refreshing late summer visit to Taos, we were pleased to find Jeanie Puleston Fleming's ''What's Doing in Taos'' in the Sept. 7 Travel section. This guide provides a solid basis for enjoyable Taos exploration.

title: LEAK OF RADIATION IS CALLED UNLIKELY
description: A large-scale release of radioactivity from the fire-damaged Soviet submarine in the North Atlantic is highly unlikely, private and Government experts on nuclear technology said yesterday.

title: PEQUOT INDIANS PLAN MUSEUM ON HISTORY OF ANCESTRAL LAND
description: ON their reservation in Ledyard, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians now operate a high-stakes bingo hall. But on that land, their ancestors once hunted game, built wigwams and tried to deal with European settlers and the changes they brought to the Indian way of life.

title: A Very Good Year
description: Party labels may not matter much to voters in the 1986 elections, but wine labels have become an issue in the United States Senate campaign in Idaho.

title: IN THE SHADOW OF VESUVIUS
description: THE DELICIOUS SHORES of the Bay of Naples were crowded with villas.'' So Gibbon describes the Neapolitan scene of 2,000 years ago. And the story of this bay is, dramatically, a tale of habitation - of the houses of esthetes, philosophers and poets; of the villas of emperors and aristocrats, plutocrats and warriors, and the countless dwellings of their unknown contemporaries: a story formidably evident today, but visibly deriving from the ancient world. For no human settlements on earth have exercised a greater fascination than the lost cities of Vesuvius.

title: THE MISSING MEN OF SUBURBIA
description: THERE are no men in suburbia for happily married wives. In my eight years of changing diapers, car-pooling to nursery school and drinking coffee with women in towns all over Nassau and Suffolk Counties, I never realized until recently how few men I actually spoke to.

title: Eileen Gildea a Bride
description: Eileen C. Gildea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gildea of Brooklyn and Breezy Point, Queens, was married yesterday to Salvatore J. Amodeo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Amodeo of Breezy Point. The Rev. Michael Greene performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Brooklyn. Mrs. Amodeo is an advertising assistant for Self magazine in New York. Her husband is a pharmacist.

title: A MOTHER-DAUGHTER ARTISTIC EXCHANGE
description: IN preparing their first exhibition together, the photographer Inge Morath of Roxbury and her daughter, the painter Rebecca Miller, found themselves formally acknowledging an artistic exchange that had become second nature to them.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 5, 1986
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 4 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking,$22.95) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 2 10 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 3 12 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 4 7 3 ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A fiftyish professor wrestles with God, sex, science, technology, mathematics and computers. 5 4 5 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's coming of age in 18th-century England and France. 6 5 14 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 7 6 17 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 8 8 7 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Two women, two men, passion and power brokering in Washington. 9 15 2 THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $16.95.) Forty years of life in a small North Dakota town near an Indian reservation. 10 1 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) The complex relationships of a family in New York City and South Carolina's low country. 11 9 8 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $17.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 12 11 21 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 13 10 31 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 14 13 46 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla's adventures in the prehistoric world; the sequel to ''The Valley of Horses.'' 15* 14 16 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. Nonfiction 1 1 22 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 30 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden $ Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 3 6 3 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A member of one of America's oldest families tells of the world's oldest profession. 4 10 2 SNAKE, by Ken Stabler and Berry Stainback. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The experiences of the retired Oakland Raiders quarterback. 5 3 21 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 6 4 2 MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears. 7 5 24 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 8 1 I, TINA, by Tina Turner with Kurt Loder. (Morrow, $16.95.) The autobiography of a Tennessee sharecropper's daughter who became a rock-and- roll star. 9* 15 2 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) Observations on football by the television commentator and former Oakland Raiders coach. 10 8 17 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 11* 1 EISENHOWER: AT WAR, by David Eisenhower. (Random House, $29.95.) How fighting a coalition war from 1943 to 1945 developed the general's political acumen. 12 7 25 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 13 6 THE PASSION OF AYN RAND, by Barbara Branden. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of the author of ''The Fountainhead.'' 14 11 12 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation by the film director King Vidor of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 15 12 16 FORD: The Men and the Machine, by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 20 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 1 3 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) Coping with overbearing men. 3 3 59 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 4 4 67 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 2 UNLIMITED POWER, by Anthony Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Directions for achieving ''super success in personal and professional affairs.'' The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'GULLIVER' IN CONCERT For a long time, Larry Gelbart thought about converting ''Gulliver's Travels'' into a play. But writing scripts for the ''MASH'' television series, the film ''Tootsie'' and numerous other commitments kept him from it. But on the set of ''After MASH,'' he met Patrick Williams, composer of the show's theme song, as well as themes for ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' ''Lou Grant'' and the film ''Breaking Away.'' They decided to collaborate on Mr. Gelbart's idea.

title: U.S. Holds On at Davis
description: Ken Flach and Paul Annacone defeated Pat Cash and John Fitzgerald of Australia in a thrilling five-set match today to keep alive United States hopes of winning the Davis Cup semifinal.

title: MEADMORE AND ANUSKIEWICZ IN SEPARATE SHOWS IN COUNTY
description: The well-known artist who would show only in New York City or at selected out-of-town museums is dying out. Today, the same kind of artist is willing to exhibit in his or her own backyard, which as often as not is outside the city. Two notable examples are Robert Motherwell and Paul Cadmus, both of whom live in Connecticut and have had major solos there, albeit on university campuses. Then there is Knox Martin, who put in a surprise appearance at Irvington's River Galley some years ago.

title: MEMO MENTIONED KILLING OF QADDAFI
description: Administration officials acknowledged today that a memorandum prepared by the State Department for a meeting to consider how to deal with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi proposed a strategy which could lead to ''a coup or assassination attempt'' against the Libyan leader.

title: Miss Stevenson, A TV Producer, Becomes a Bride
description: Patience F. Stevenson, a daughter of John R. Stevenson of New York and the late Patience Fullerton Stevenson, was married in New York yesterday to Douglas Bruce Scott Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of Baltimore. The Rev. Dr. David H. C Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Susan Eva Fox Becomes Fiancee Of D. G. Rosellini
description: Mrs. William Fox Jr. of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter Susan Eva Fox to Donald G. Rosellini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Rosellini of Chicago. A March wedding is planned.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ATLANTA;
Peachtree City Progressing
description: TO most residents of this city's monied North Side, the South Side has for years signified poverty, rednecks, crime and Hartsfield International Airport before it was international. Now, however, all that is changing.

title: TWO FOOTBALL COACHES SHUN RETIREMENT
description: Stalking the sidelines and constantly talking to their players, George Butcher and Henry Giardi were totally immersed in the Glastonbury High School freshman football team's opening game against Wethersfield a week ago.

title: BUSINESS BRINGS BACK THE LOCKOUT
description: ONE of labor's model corporate citizens completely spoiled this year's Labor Day celebration for the United Automobile Workers. The week before the holiday, Deere & Company, long a practitioner of harmonious labor relations, jolted the powerful union by padlocking its plants' gates - locking out thousands of union members.

title: PLACID CORNELL CAMPUS UPSET BY SERIES OF CRIMES
description: Cornell University, normally a relaxed campus where it is not unusual for students to leave dormitory room doors unlocked, has been shaken by a series of crimes in the last two weeks, including an incident where four women were held captive and one of them was raped.

title: James Sottile 4th Wed To Noell Nantes Harris
description: At St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday Noell Nantes Harris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Harris Jr. of Bethesda, Md., was married to James Sottile 4th, a son of Judith H. Sottile of Indialantic, Fla., and the late Mr. Sottile 3d. The Rev. Dr. Francis H. Wade performed the ceremony.

title: Countryside Fragrance On A Roll
description: Roast chestnuts and gelato apart, Italians do not as a rule take comfortably to street noshing. Even gelato is usually consumed in a coolly tiled and mirrored ice cream parlor; and as for the rest of the food spectrum, it is a serious business, to be dealt with, Italians believe, sitting down, around a table, gathered together with friends and family for the high points of the day.

title: SHARON FESTIVAL TO PROMOTE CULTURES OF ASIA AND INDONESIA
description: INSTEAD of the traditional harvest festival so customary in New England in autumn, a procession of dancers garbed as ferocious Chinese lions will converge upon the Sharon Town Green on Saturday. Their huge papier-mache heads bobbing up and down, they will dance to the clamor of bells, gongs and whistles that marks the beginning of a daylong festival promoting the cultures of Asia and Indonesia.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
5 CONDUCTORS VIE FOR ONE BATON
description: THIS is the Nassau Symphony Orchestra's 30th anniversary season. But when the musicians take the stage of the John Cranford Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University on Saturday for the season's first concert, they will also usher in what has been informally tagged ''the year of the maestros.''

title: Elie Hobeika, Former Banker
description: Elie Hobeika, a 30-year-old former banker, was ousted as commander of the Lebanese Forces, the Christian militia comprising soldiers of several formerly independent factions, after bloody fighting last January.

title:
THE RACE FOR CONGRESS;
GEJDENSON AND MULLEN DEBATE THE MOOD OF THE 2D DISTRICT
description: ''THE voters and I are in sync,'' said a confident Representative Sam Gejdenson, a three-term Democrat. But his Republican challenger in the Second District, Francis M. (Bud) Mullen, contends that the Congressman's voting record is ''way out of tune'' with the citizens.

title: STUDY PORTRAYS CHICAGO AS A CITY THAT'S DIVIDED
description: Chicago, long regarded as ''the city that works,'' doesn't, according to a major new study of the city's civic, political and economic institutions.

title: IN CONGRESS, STATE DELEGATION TRIES TO DELAY GAS PIPELINE
description: THE Connecticut Congressional delegation, responding to an outcry over a proposal to build a $357 million natural gas pipeline through the western part of the state, is moving to delay the project.

title: A MYSTERY IN SPAIN: THOUSANDS OF BIRDS DIE NEAR SANCTUARY
description: Thousands of birds have died in the Guadalquivir River delta near here, and officials said today that they feared thousands more might die on their fall migration to Africa.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incomplete information supplied by the French Government, a Travel Advisory item Sept. 28 omitted a step of the procedure applicants must follow to obtain a visa to visit France and its territories. Travelers applying in person to the French consulates in this country must fill out an application form, available from travel agents or at the consulates, and bring a current passport, a color photograph of passport size, 2 inches by 2 inches, and cash or a money order for the visa. A three-month visa is $9, a one-year visa is $15, and a 72-hour transit visa is $3.

title: High School Youth Wins Championship
description: Danny Edelman of New Rochelle won the Arnold Denker National Tournament of High School Champions in Somerset, N.J., with a 5-1 score. Besides the trophy, he was awarded a $1,000 college scholarship.

title: Sanctions Veto Takes a Trouncing In Both Houses
description: Congress superseded the will of President Reagan last week, overriding his veto of economic sanctions against South Africa. The President's defeat was achieved by margins considerably greater than the necessary two-thirds: 313 to 83 in the House, and 78 to 21 in the Senate.

title: CENTER TREATS LUPUS SUFFERERS
description: SHIRLEY McCRAY of Hemptead says she will never forget all the years she spent going from one doctor to the next to find out why she was losing hair by the fistful, why her toes were often numb, and why her joints often ached.

title: OTHERS HAD TRIALS IN STAGING MALCOLM X
description: ''Do you realize,'' Malcolm X asked in his autobiography, ''that some of history's greatest leaders weren't recognized until they were safely in the ground?'' Malcolm X was not sure that he would receive such regard even posthumously, and there is hardly an American consensus that he deserves it. Toward the end of his autobiography, he said that he expected after his death to be memorialized as ''a convenient symbol of 'hatred,' '' or at best an '' 'irresponsible' leader.''

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: Connecticut; Muddy Struggle Ends in 6-6 Tie
description: Brian Smith scored on a 2-yard run on the next-to-last play of the third quarter to give St. Joseph of Trumbull a 6-6 tie with Fairfield Prep in an all-Connecticut Conference game yesterday in Trumbull.

title: Gold Buttons Spark White Cuffs
description: WHITE collar and white cuffs: it's a prim, tasteful, time-honored combination. The question is, how to give it a fresh approach?

title: POSTINGS: SEAWAY HIDEAWAY?;
description: It is in the Thousand Islands section of the St. Lawrence River, and in its heyday it boasted a 24-room mansion. But by 1956, with the coming of the St. Lawrence Seaway, 1.04-acre Stony Crest Island - 600 feet from shore and a mile from the village of Alexandria Bay - was in the way of a new channel.

title: IN BROADWAY PARADE, KOREANS MARK HERITAGE
description: White-clad Korean athletes shadowboxed down Broadway. Courtly Korean bankers waved fans at the Garment District. Deft Korean gong-players brought the music of Seoul to Herald Square.

title: A Leak on Leaks Stirs an Uproar
description: Dissembling has always had a role in diplomacy, as witness the job description offered three centuries ago by the British diplomat Sir Henry Wotton: ''An ambassador is an honest man sent to lie abroad for the good of his country.'' But the misinformation at issue in Washington last week had been fed to unwitting reporters.

title: The Woodcarvers
description: The sixth annual celebration of National Stamp Collecting Month begins this month. The theme is ''Celebrate a Century of Organized Stamp Collecting in the United States.''

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: ROGER MARIS: A MAN FOR ALL SEASONS. By Maury Allen. Donald I. Fine Inc. 272 pages. $16.95. Twenty-five years after Roger Maris hit his ''61 in '61'' to break Babe Ruth's season record of 60 homeruns, Maury Allen has written this biography, scheduled for publication on the Oct. 1 anniversary of the record homer, that follows Roger Maris from childhood to his death from cancer last year.

title: >Laborites End Parley With Victory Prediction
description: The Labor Party, buoyed by a lead in opinion polls and newfound unity, concluded its annual conference Friday with a prediction of victory over Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives in the next election.

title: HONG KONG'S OTHER ISLANDS
description: HONG KONG IN-habits several worlds. It is part of the immense and incalculable Chinese world. It is a glittering outstation in the world of high finance. It is a prodigy of the Orient and a late anachronism of Empire. But it is also the center of a world that is all its own, consisting of 235 tightly grouped and variously fascinating offshore islands.

title: PENN ST. ROUTS RUTGERS
description: In a matchup of unbeaten teams, Rutgers appeared so far out of its league from the start today against Penn State that it called for a timeout only 73 seconds into the game.

title: EX-GOVERNOR BALDWIN OF CONNECTICUT IS DEAD
description: Raymond Earl Baldwin, the only person to serve Connecticut as Governor, United States Senator and Chief Justice of the state, died yesterday in Fairfield, Conn. He was 93 years old.

title: Focus: Land Trusts; Preserving Wilderness Property
description: FOR more than 40 years, Carla Swan Coleman has been able to leave her Lookout Mountain cabin and strike off through the woods towards the jagged cliffs of Clear Creek Canyon, taking in unobstructed views of Colorado's snow-capped Front Range along the way.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ALL THAT JAZZ This is a good week on Long Island for jazz aficionados, as the International Art of Jazz gets in tune for its 22d season. It all begins today at 4 P.M. in Garden City at the Ethical Humanist Society, 38 Old Country Road, where the veteran percussionist Roy Haynes appears with his quartet. The action moves to Stony Brook on Saturday, when at 8 P.M. the Roger Kellaway Trio, featuring Grady Tate on drums and Michael Moore on bass, along with the acclaimed pianist, takes to the stage of Recital Hall at the State University's Fine Arts Center. For ticket and subscription information about both these winter jazz series call 632-6590.FROM THE CHAMBER

title: Recent Releases of Video Cassettes
description: The Magician Starring Max von Sydow, Ingrid Thulin, Erland Josephson, Gunnar Bjornstrand, Bibi Andersson; directed by Ingmar Bergman, 1959 Embassy Home Entertainment 101 minutes. $29.95

title:
ART;
WORKS BY HUBBARD ON EXHIBIT AT YALE
description: THE exhibition of 22 years of paintings by John Hubbard at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven might be subtitled, ''The Adventures of a Connecticut Yankee at King Arthur's Court.'' Mr. Hubbard was born in Ridgefield in 1931, attended Harvard University, studied art with Hans Hoffman and others and served in the United States Army. But since 1960, he has lived and worked near Dorset, England.

title: Britten's Suffolk
description: To the Editor: Much of the article ''The Britain That Britten Called Home '' by Lailan Young (Travel, Aug. 17) concerned the attractions of the town of Southwold and the village of Walberswick, lying respectively north and south of Southwold Harbor.

title:
SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY;
Keeping Track of All We Know
description: THE CONTROL REVOLUTION Technological and Economic Origins of the Information Society. By James R. Beniger. 493 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: NASSAU JAIL DISPUTE HEATS UP AGAIN
description: THE legal battle over overcrowding at the Nassau County jail has heated up again, with the county denying that there are too many inmates and a Federal court setting tomorrow as the new deadline for reducing the jail population.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS FIRE ON ATOMIC SUB IN NORTH ATLANTIC
description: The Soviet Union told the United States today that a fire broke out Friday aboard a Soviet nuclear submarine in the Atlantic Ocean 1,200 miles east of New York, the White House said.

title: TIME TO PLANT AND HARVEST IN NEW YORK
description: It is fall planting time in lower Manhattan, and the Green Guerrillas are preparing to put in a last crop of leaf lettuce and peas on an acre plot at the corner of Houston Street and the Bowery.

title: FACE TO FACE: Moscow and Washington at the summit
description: July 1955, Geneva Eisenhower, Bulganin and Khrushchev Main topics: Aerial surveillance, East-West relations, the reunification of Germany September 1959, Camp David Eisenhower and Khrushchev Main topics: Disarmament, scientific and cultural exchanges May 1960, Paris Eisenhower and Khrushchev Main topics: Berlin, disarmament, East-West relations; meeting breaks up after downing of U.S. U-2 spy plane over Soviet Union June 1961, Vienna Kennedy and Khrushchev Main topics: Nuclear test ban treaty, war in Laos, Berlin June 1967, Glassboro, N.J. Johnson and Kosygin Main topics: Middle East, Vietnam war, nuclear arms May 1972, Moscow Nixon and Brezhnev Main topics: Strategic arms agreement, antiballistic missile treaty June 1973, Washington Nixon and Brezhnev Main topics: Arms treaty, trade, agricultural research, cultural exchanges, transportation, oceanography, nuclear energy research June and July 1974, Moscow and Yalta Nixon and Brezhnev Main topics: Treaty banning underground nuclear weapons tests, 10-year economic pact November 1974, Vladivostok Ford and Brezhnev Main topic: New strategic arms treaty August 1975, Helsinki Ford and Brezhnev Main topics: European security, strategic arms treaty June 1979, Vienna Carter and Brezhnev Main topic: Strategic arms treaty November 1985, Geneva Reagan and Gorbachev Main topics: Nuclear arms reduction, cultural and educational exchanges

title: BROOKLYN'S BRIGHT ALTERNATIVE FOR CITY'S HOMELESS
description: The house in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn is one of the prettiest on its street, with freshly painted gray shingles, a blooming flower garden out front and ruffled curtains on the windows.

title: Samir Geagea, Physician
description: Maj. Samir Geagea was trained as a doctor at the American University in Beirut, and at 37 is commander of the Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia, which has about 6,000 soldiers.

title: Russia in the Pacific
description: I do not wish to speculate on whether the buildup of Soviet naval power in the Pacific is meant for defense or offense, or mainly to satisfy Soviet nationalistic feelings. However, it appears to me that, in some respects, United States' policies have contributed to the problems - real or imagined - that Washington now envisions.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: General Pershing's Passion During his long romance with a young Frenchwoman named Micheline Resco, Gen. John J. Pershing felt that because he was so much in the public eye their relationship had to be kept secret. The strategy he worked out evokes interesting comparisons between love and war. This is from ''Pershing: General of the Armies'' (Indiana University), by Donald Smythe. Separated by the Atlantic Ocean six to eight months a year, the couple kept in touch by letter and cablegram. A discreet man, Pershing usually wrote his letters on plain paper or hotel or shipboard stationery, and sent his cables in code. A sample went like this: CHELINER. AURORA VELOURS. BEATRICE.

title: RELYING ON THE UNSAVORY TO CATCH A BIGGER FISH
description: WHEN the Federal Government opened its case against five defendants last week on charges stemming from the New York City corruption scandal, it quickly brought an expert to the stand: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the former deputy director of the city's Parking Violations Bureau, who earlier this year admitted stealing some $250,000 and pleaded guilty to racketeering and mail fraud.

title: AT LAST, AN EASING OF THE TRADE DEFICIT
description: The trade deficit narrrowed by a record $4.7 billion in August as imports became more expensive because of the falling dollar. Administration officials said the reduction -the first in several months - may mark the turning point in the battle to make American products more competitive in the world marketplace. But skeptics noted that exports did not improve, as they would have to do if the momentum is to be maintained, and that much of the drop in imports was in foreign cars, whose sales have been hurt by the cut-rate financing offered for American models.

title: 3 Killed in Crash of Transport At San Antonio Air Force Base
description: A civilian cargo plane carrying military supplies crashed into a maintenance hangar today and burned seconds after taking off from Kelly Air Force Base, killing its three-man crew.

title: CALL ME ENTREPRENEUR
description: MAYFLOWER MADAM The Secret Life of Sydney Biddle Barrows. By Sydney Barrows with William Novak. 291 pp. New York: Arbor House. $17.95.

title: TALENTED EAST ISLIP KICKER THRIVES AT MANY POSITIONS
description: When John Biskup says that his favorite thing about playing high school football is ''everything,'' he speaks from experience.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ST, PAUL'S WALL
description: IN the more than 200 years since Saint Paul's Church in Mount Vernon was built of timber and native fieldstone, significant changes have overtaken the surrounding landscapes. The forests around the church, now a National Historic Site, and cemetery have given way to industry, and the only reminders of the village green -the setting of events that helped establish a foundation for the First Amendment freedoms of speech, religion, press and assembly - are a small parcel of land and the remnants of an old stone wall.

title: The Best-Played Hand
description: A 26-year jinx was finally broken two weeks ago in Miami Beach when the United States won the world knockout team championship. This was the first American success in a large international field, as distinct from the Bermuda Bowl championships in which continental zones are represented.

title: THE DRINKING WRITER'S GUIDE
description: NINE POETS, NOVEL-ists and critics name their favorite pubs in Britain and Ireland. Some are urban retreats, others village snugs; some raffish, others genteel.

title: Social Events; Benefits for Many Tastes
description: iplomatic Gathering Oct. 9 - Diplomats from East and West are expected at a black-tie dinner at the Pierre to benefit the Appeal of Conscience Foundation. Founded in 1965, the Foundation is a coalition of Catholic, Protestant, Jewish and Greek Orthodox religious and business leaders concerned with worldwide religious freedom. The chief United States representative at the United Nations, Vernon A. Walters, heads the list of dignitaries, who included diplomats from Egypt, Israel, the Soviet Union, Poland and France. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M., followed by dinner. Tickets, $500, from 212-535-5800. Legal Get-Together Oct. 9 - The fund-raising arm of the Legal Aid Society, the Civil Support Division, is holding its annual black-tie dinner-dance at Tavern on the Green starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets, $275, from 212-577-3346. Day at the Track Oct. 10 - From Pennsylvania Station, a special bar car will transport guests to the Belmont Park Race Track, where a Champagne brunch will be held at noon in the Turf and Field Club. The afternoon of racing will aid the New York chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. The television sports commentator Frank Gifford and the jockeys Angel Cordero and Jorge Velasquez are expected to provide tips. Tickets, $125, from 212-921-9199. L.I. Garden Party Oct. 11 - The formal gardens of a strikingly eclectic mansion in Muttontown, L.I., a 32-room combination of French Renaissance and Chinese and English country home styles, will be the setting of a 1:30 P.M. Champagne party.

title: CRUISING'S CLAMOR IS BACK ON MAIN STREET U.S.A.
description: As dusk slips over this bucolic college town on weekends, thousands of chrome-etched cars filled with gawking teen-agers and students snake down Main Street in a carnival of screaming colors.

title: Condos in Croton
description: Ground was broken last week for a 356-unit waterfront condominium in Croton-on-Hudson on one of the few remaining parcels between the railroad tracks and the east shore of the Hudson River.

title: Mental Illness Is No Bar to Buying a Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: DANILOFF DETAILS HIS PRISON DESPAIR
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff, describing for the first time in detail his confinement in a Moscow prison says he was ''manipulated into moments of hopeless despair, physical nausea - and even good feelings about some of my captors.''

title: A Courtyard In Katmandu
description: I was delighted to see a photograph of the windows of the same lovely room I occupied a few months ago at Dwarika's Katmandu Village Hotel in Nepal in Carol Vogel's article ''Travels With Tiffany'' (Home Design, Aug. 31).

title: Jennifer White Becomes Bride Of Peter Walsh
description: Jennifer White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden White Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Feely Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rall Walsh of Troy, N.Y. The Venerable Robert A. Bryan, archdeacon of the Anglican Diocese of the Quebec North Shore, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass. He was assisted by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger, rector of the church.

title: NO-FRILLS, NO SALES
description: BLACK lettering, usually on a white background, identifies the contents. ''Corn.'' Or ''Peas.'' Or ''Paper Towels.'' Next to the color-splashed packages and well-known brand names lined up on supermarket shelves, generic products stand out in their stark simplicity.

title: Shall We Take Arms Against a Sea of Digits?
description: DESCARTES' DREAM The World According to Mathematics. By Philip J. Davis and Reuben Hersh. Illustrated. 321 pp. Boston: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Q AND A
description: Tucson Trips Question:During a visit of several weeks in Tucson, Ariz., this winter, we would like to take bus tours of from two to five days. Are there any available? - A. S. F., Kingston, N.Y. Answer:One of several operators that run trips regularly throughout the winter is Off the Beaten Path Tours (840 North Stoner Avenue, Tucson, Ariz. 85748; 602-296-0909). Among destinations on its two- , three- and four-day tours are the Grand Canyon, the Petrified Forest National Park and Las Vegas, Nev. Lodging, some meals and admissions to sites are included in the prices, which range from $95 a person, double occupancy, for two days to about $200 for four. A guide travels with each group and conducts tours at the stops.

title: Grace Sharples to Wed Dr. Merritt T. Cooke Jr.
description: Grace E. Sharples, a fashion editor of Glamour magazine, and Dr. Merritt Todd Cooke Jr., a research associate in cultural anthropology at the University of California at Berkeley, plan to be married Nov. 22. The future bride is a daughter of Mrs. Alexander B. Wheeler of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Philip P. Sharples of Tubac, Ariz., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. Cooke of Media, Pa., and the late Mary Marshall Toland Cooke.

title: NASA Announces A Critical Transfer
description: The man who made the final decision to launch the Challenger is stepping down from his post, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said last week, and he is expected to take a leave of absence.

title: THE ISRAELIS TREASURE THEIR NATIONAL UNITY GOVERNMENT
description: FOR the last 25 months, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir has been something of a politician under siege. When the Labor Party was not looking for ways to break up Israel's national unity Government before Mr. Shamir could get his chance to rotate into the Prime Minister's job, the anti-Shamir maneuvering was conducted by rivals in his Likud Party.

title: Cable TV
description: What's new on cable this week is something rather old as movies go - ''The River,'' a film by the eminent French director Jean Renoir that first opened in New York 35 years ago last month.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A CHOIR WITH A FIVE-CENTURY HISTORY
description: After Sant'Andrea della Valle, the great Roman church where the first act of ''Tosca'' is set, the narrow, winding Via Monte della Farina runs behind the Teatro Argentina (where ''The Barber of Seville'' was first performed). In this musical context, at No. 68, an old, large, somewhat anonymous palazzo, a rehearsal of the Sistine Choir or -to give it its proper title - the Cappella Musicale Pontificia was recently held. It was to be the last rehearsal before the choir's departure for New York and its first-ever official American tour. It will appear in Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow night.

title: Penshurst
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from England, and a visit to Penshurst Place, I read with pleasure the fine article by Paula Deitz (Travel, July 27).

title: ARIZONA STATE BEATS U.C.L.A. FOR FIRST TIME, 16-9
description: After defeating U.C.L.A. for the first time ever, 16-9, Arizona State had a celebration in the Rose Bowl today and hoped for another one here on New Year's Day.

title:
THE DRINKING WRITER'S GUIDE;
Highland Pride
description: ''There's naething here,'' wrote the poet Robert Burns with a diamond on the window of The Argyll Arms Hotel in Inveraray, Scotland, But Highland pride, And Highland scab and hunger; If providence has sent me here, 'Twas surely in an anger. The Argyll Arms, an elegant, white 18th-century building looking out across Loch Fyne, still stands where it did in Burns's time. Of course, as an Ayrshire man, Burns may simply have been suffering from blind, unreasoning prejudice against the Highlands and their inhabitants, though it is also possible that in those days the hospitality at The Argyll Arms left a good deal to be desired. But I am quite sure that if he were to return there today, the poet would feel obliged to eat his words. Under the auspices of Niall Iain Maclean, his wife, Inez, and his son, Neil John, there is certainly no question of anyone going hungry. In the hotel dining room plenty of appetizing local delicacies are cheerfully served by the family and their assistants.

title: Labor Board Dismisses Charge Against Hormel
description: The National Labor Relations Board has dismissed a charge of unfair labor practices against Geo. A. Hormel & Company.

title: THE FELD BALLET CELEBRATES
description: What has Eliot Feld learned in 20 years?

title: SUFFERING FARMERS FACE NEW FOE AS FLOODS BATTER THE GRAIN BELT
description: Along a broad swath through the Middle West's most productive farm states, heavy rain and flooding is exacting a painful financial toll from farmers already troubled by declines in exports and depressed prices.

title: THE LAST INNING FOR CAPITAL GAINS PLAYS
description: NOW that the tax overhaul bill has finally cleared Congress, it is time to scrutinize your investment portfolio to make maximum use of the liberal capital gains provisions that will remain in effect only until the end of this year.

title: Jennifer Johnson Becomes a Bride
description: At the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Jennifer Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, and Christopher York Clark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Clark of Hilton Head, S.C., were married by the Rev. Avery C. Manchester.

title:
DINING OUT;
FROM NEW ENGLAND TO THE CONTINENT
description: WHEN The Fox and Hounds, a restaurant in the Monmouth County community of Colts Neck, was first reviewed here three years ago, it had made a genuine attempt to match the food with the decor. This was particularly interesting because the restaurant is a fairly good reproduction of an English club. As a result, the menu included several dishes that would not be out of place in London's better restaurants.

title: The Family Business
description: MY FATHER OWNS A textile business. It was his father's once. And because I am a first son, it could have been mine. But I've chosen to do something else for a living. This is something I think about more and more as my father nears retirement. I think about it because I fear he's thinking about it, too, that he's thinking how much easier it would be to wind things up, how much nicer, if he had someone to carry on for him, if it were clear the business could survive without him.

title: Miss O'Mara To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Mowbray O'Mara of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Margot Courtney O'Mara to Timothy Phillips Connors, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Phillips Connors of Englewood, Colo.

title: SCIENTISTS DISPUTE PLANET DISCOVERY
description: Two teams of astronomers, failing to see what other astronomers said they saw two years ago, are now questioning the existence of an object that was believed to be the first planet detected outside the Solar System.

title: Rhine Valley
description: To the Editor: While a boat trip on the Rhine (Travel, Aug. 24) is the best way to see the Rhine River and its spectacular scenery, the best way to enjoy the full flavor is to drive along it. Both Route 9 on the east bank and Route 42 on the west offer excellent views as well as charming towns and restaurants with terraces that overlook the Rhine and the boat traffic.

title: WITH A DEARTH OF DATA, TRACKING MARKET TRENDS TAKES AN EFFORT
description: BUYERS and sellers have a hard time following movements in the co-op market because sales are not recorded in public documents as they are for condominiums and houses. When a co-op is sold, the buyer does not get a registered deed to a piece of property but rather a proprietary lease and shares of stock in the cooperative corporation that owns the building. The sale, therefore, is a transfer of personal property, like that of a car or television set.

title: A VALLEY VIBRANT WITH CRAFTS
description: The Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts is a stretch of rich farmland, urban areas, rolling hills, upland pastures, deep woods, lively college towns and sleepy villages that runs from just south of Springfield, at the Connecticut border, to the edges of Vermont and New Hampshire. The area, which can be driven in just over an hour, is bisected by the broad silver ribbon of the Connecticut River rolling majestically down from its source at the Canadian border.

title: A SOBER SILICON VALLEY IS 'CHANGED FOREVER'
description: AT a business dinner here in Silicon Valley two weeks ago, a speaker began his talk on the outlook for computer chips by showing slides of himself skydiving.

title: BRINGING PEACE TO TED BATES
description: ''I JUST want to forget about it and go and do the job that has to be done,'' Donald Zuckert said. ''I'd rather wipe the slate clean and never think about it again.''

title: Reagan, Carter And No Acrimony
description: With no hint of the venom that often marked his comments during the heat of political battle six years ago, President Reagan went to Atlanta last week to praise Jimmy Carter as ''distinctively and gloriously American'' and help dedicate his Presidential library.

title: COURSE TO EXPLORE CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ''I BELIEVE in the power of books,'' said Judy Greenfield, children's librarian of the Rye Free Reading Room. She is one of six county librarians who will be teaching children's literature to adults in a new county program. Five of these librarians are from Rye, White Plains and Eastchester libraries, and the sixth is a children's services consultant in the Westchester Library System.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
Milan's New Shape
description: IN THE SUMMER READY-to-wear collections that get under way this weekend, the Milanese designers say basta, or enough, to their crisp signature tailoring, replacing it with unstructured construction.

title: Carey Collins Mayer Marries in Princeton
description: At the Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Carey Collins Mayer, a daughter of Mrs. Edward J. Edenfield 3d of Princeton and Eldon Cunningham Mayer Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Chebeague Island, Me., was married to George Cameron Ferrante di Ruffano, a son of Georgette D. Ferrante di Ruffano of Kingston, N.J., and Giovanni Ferrante di Ruffano of Bridgewater, N.J. The Rev. Jean Smith performed the ceremony.

title: F.B.I. TAPES WILL BE PLAYED AT DONOVAN TRIAL
description: Bronx prosecutors in the fraud trial of Raymond J. Donovan are ready to present what they consider their most damaging evidence - secretly recorded conversations.

title: SEXUAL POLITICS, FAMILY SECRETS
description: THE LOST LANGUAGE OF CRANES By David Leavitt. 319 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title:
SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY;
Are We All Downwinders?
description: UNDER THE CLOUD The Decades of Nuclear Testing. By Richard L. Miller. Illustrated. 547 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: Arms Control: If Not Now, When? If Not Us, Who?
description: TO the Editor:

title: Everything You Need For A Good Chew
description: Remember Bloody Mary and her betel nut? The chewing of betel - in reality a good deal more than a nut -has been a tradition in Southeast Asia and the South Pacific since ancient times.

title: Toward the Summit in Iceland
description: President Reagan's forthcoming meeting with Soviet Premier Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Iceland deserves full bipartisan support. No President since Dwight D. Eisenhower has possessed such credibility in dealing with the Sovet Union. Mr. Reagan could never be accused of being soft on any Communist. Whatever package he negotiates is therefore virtually assured of approval in Congress and in the nation at large. We have a rare opportunity over the next year to reach agreements with the Soviet Union on a significant reduction of medium range missiles in Europe; a framework for a 30 percent cut in warheads on strategic missiles; a definition of terms to preserve the ABM treaty; a limitation on chemical weapons; and a schedule for phasing down nuclear testing.

title: Visiting the Great Potoo
description: LIFE ABOVE THE JUNGLE FLOOR By Donald Perry. Illustrated. 170 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Barbara Healey Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Barbara Cahill Healey of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., and William Francis Healey of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Felix Healey, to Gary Thomas Gibson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gibson of New York and Bogota Colombia, The wedding is planned for December.

title: A Show That Gets Inside The Work Of Frank Gehry
description: Most architecture exhibitions deal, by their very nature, in vicarious experience. We learn about architecture from representations - models, photographs, plans, drawings - but we don't actually experience it.

title: Dinners and Dark Horses
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, is making what his campaign advisers regard as a critical appearance on Oct. 18 in Des Moines, where he is to be the keynote speaker at the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner. Gephardt strategists say it is essential that a dark horse like Mr. Gephardt finish at least third in the Iowa caucuses, the first delegate-selecting event of the primary season, if he is to have a chance of winning the 1988 nomination.

title: Miyako Hontani Marries
description: Miyako Hontani and Edmondo Schwartz were married yesterday at Windows on the World in New York by Acting Justice Ira F. Beal of the State Supreme Court. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Mitsuharu Hontani of Osaka, Japan, and Glendale, Calif., and Mr. and Mrs. Albert Schwartz of Englewood, N.J. The bride attended Skidmore and Emerson Colleges. Mr. Schwartz, a graduate of Boston University, is a salesman at Helmsley-Spear Inc.

title: Today's Sports
description: BASEBALL Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates At Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Television Channel 9, 1:30 Radio WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M. Yankees vs.

title: INCREASED BUS FLEET SET BY NJ TRANSIT
description: A CONTRACT to start NJ Transit's $114 million bus- purchase program will be signed by mid-October, according to agency officials.

title: METS WIN 2 FOR 107 SEASON VICTORIES
description: In their next-to-last performance of the regular season, the Mets swept a doubleheader from the Pittsburgh Pirates with great flair yesterday and headed for their final game this afternoon with 107 victories, the most in the big leagues in 11 years.

title: Some Big Names Are Dropped At a Mafia Trial
description: The names of reputed organized crime bosses, past and present, seemed to thud to the floor of a Manhattan courtroom last week as the racketeering trial of eight men accused of participating in a Mafia commission continued in Federal District Court.

title: Carol Jane Hoban Becomes Bride of Fellow Economist
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Simsbury, Conn., yesterday Carol Jane Hoban and Matthew Fisher, economists with the International Monetary Fund in Washington, were married by the Rev. William E. Dudack.

title: Age Minimums
description: To the Editor:

title: IF INDICATORS ARE RIGHT, MAUCH WILL FINALLY REACH THE SERIES
description: IF the prime playoff indicators work this year, Gene Mauch will end his careerlong pennant drought and take his California Angels into the World Series against the Mets. Mauch, however, should exercise caution. The prime indicators failed miserably last season, projecting the World Series opponents to be the teams that actually lost in the pennant playoffs.

title: UCONN SOCCER DRAWING BIG CROWDS
description: SOCCER being a contact sport, there is bound to be some colliding of bodies - and perhaps even some flaring of tempers - when the University of Connecticut plays host to Dartmouth College this afternoon at the UConn soccer stadium.

title: Zaccaro Indicted In Bribery Case
description: In pleading guilty to charges of fraud last year, John A. Zaccaro told the court, ''I have learned my lesson the hard way.'' But it was surely no harder than what prosecutors in Queens now have in mind.

title: Congress Misses Another Target For Adjournment
description: According to the Senate Historian, Congress keeps records only of the dates it adjourns, not of the dates it sets for adjournment. But in recent times, the target dates have been in early October, and in this decade none have been met. This year, the date was Oct. 3, Friday. Long before then and with ritual expressions of despair - ''We can't legislate,'' declared Representative Silvio Conte, a Massachusetts Republican - the lawmakers, quarreling with each other and the White House about foreign affairs and military and domestic spending, had resigned themselves to at least another week of deliberations before they can turn to campaigning. Matters finished and unfinished as Congress broke for the week included these:

title: JOURNALISTS FLOCK TO BIRTHDAY PARTY AT DISNEY WORLD
description: When the Mike Royko column arrived from Chicago, the editorial page editor of an old Southern daily paper said the other day, he published it.

title:
GARDENING;
CULLING TIPS ON PLANTINGS FROM ENGLAND
description: THERE can be little disappointment in what one sees in the grand old gardens of England such as Sissinghurst or Hibcote. They are everything that one has been led to expect: works of art when it comes to design, use of plants and maintenance.

title: SAFEGUARDING THE GERSHWIN HERITAGE
description: NEXT year ''marks the 50th anniversary of George Gershwin's death, and there are several major undertakings under way,'' said Marc G. (for George) Gershwin, of Manhattan and East Hampton.

title: Bronxville Surge Edges Rye Neck
description: Rye Neck scored 20 points in the first 12 minutes against visiting Bronxville Friday night, but failed to score again and lost, 23-20.

title: Pop Music
description: Marti Jones, the Akron-born former lead singer of the group, Color Me Gone, has a built-in vocal throb that lends everything she sings an intense, emotional electricity. On ''Unsophisticated Time,'' her 1985 debut solo album, Miss Jones established herself as one of the most powerful interpreters of post-new wave songs by little-known writers like Peter Holsapple and her producer-guitarist Don Dixon, stamping each with a signature style that strongly recalls the gospel-flavored torch singing of Dusty Springfield in the 1960's.

title: ON THE BEAT IN TRINIDAD
description: URBS, URBS, UR-bem.'' Rest. ''Urbis, urbi, urbe.'' ''A city,'' we conjugated, chanting the Latin from our scarred desks in the huge wooden college of colonial Castries, in St. Lucia. Long after our soprano voices had broken we would revise these conjugations in chorus as fourth formers, the tonic range of our chant combining fake falsettos, altos and the rumbling basses of the ones who shaved, at the back of the class. The caesura, dividing the six cases exactly - nominative, vocative, accusative - break - genitive, dative, ablative -once more - not only provided a calypso rhythm, but also gave the braver ones a chance to mutter, like calypsonians, such asides as ''Urbs, urbs, urbem, let me tell you,'' or ''what you talking?'' while the rest of us, looking above and beyond our Latin master's head to the woolly green hills and hill shacks over the town knew, sure as daylight, that we weren't living in an ''urbs.'' None of us would ever see one, unless we won the island scholarship and became doctors, lawyers or, occasionally, engineers, in London or Montreal. And there are still no cities in the islands. Our capitals are sprawling seaports, market towns.

title: Suzanne Neville Is Wed To Quentin H. Warren
description: Suzanne Fay Neville, who is with H. C. Wainwright & Company, an investment concern in Boston, and Quentin Haig Warren, a draughtsman with the architectural firm of Philip Minervino Associates in Cambridge, Mass., were married yesterday in Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Lorne Coyle and the Rev. Gordon J. Stenning performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: ASH DIEBACK TERMED A MAJOR PROBLEM HERE
description: ASH trees lack the delicate beauty of the flowering dogwood or the elegance of the American elm. But like dogwood and elm trees, ash trees are the victims of a fatal disease that has been dramatically reducing their numbers. And because ash trees are among the dominant trees in the Hudson Valley region, the effects of the disease are being felt in home gardens and forests alike.

title: GENETIC DISEASE RESEARCHERS FOCUS ON MAINE
description: Family trees in rural Maine sink deep roots, and that makes the state a good place for experts to uncover information about genetic diseases.

title: MERCHANT IS HELD IN BURGLAR'S DEATH
description: After his small general merchandise store was robbed eight times since it opened a year ago, four times in two recent weeks, Prentice F. Rasheed decided to catch the thief himself.

title: AIDS CASES ARE SAID TO RISE SHARPLY WORLDWIDE
description: The World Health Organization has reported a sharp increase in the number of cases of AIDS recorded worldwide in the first nine months of this year.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN 'WELLNESS' PROGRAMS
description: CORPORATIONS increasingly are focusing on keeping employees healthy, rather than helping them get well. They are investing in wellness programs at record rates.

title: Aline Rizk Weds Michael McCabe
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Aline Rizk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rizk of New York, Cannes, France, and Beirut, Lebanon, was married to Michael J. McCabe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael McCabe of Yonkers. The Rev. Thomas Phelan performed the ceremony.

title: BRUSSELS' UNDERGROUND GALLERY
description: A tunnel can also be a gallery. The stations in the Brussels metro are lined with the paintings of Jean-Michel Folon, Paul Delvaux, Roger Somville, Pierre Aleschinsky and the works of approximately 40 other artists. Sculptures hang, project or stand. Long designs of colored ceramic tiles that are meant to be viewed either in part or in motion fill the lengths of two stations.

title: Papal Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 SERIES TO HOLD OPENINGS
description: GLAD tidings: there will be three musical openings on Oct. 18 - the Taghkanic Chorale begins its four-concert season at the Peekskill Paramount; the Sleepy Hollow Concert Association offers its 39th year of presentations at Tarrytown's Washington Irving School; and the State University of New York at Purchase gives the first of two dozen concerts inaugurating the Performing Arts Series.

title: STATE TO SET H.M.O. AD RULES
description: THE director of the state Treasury Department's Division of Pensions is drafting advertising guidelines for the 15 health maintenance organizations that serve 50,000 state, county and municipal employees under the division's Health Benefits Program.

title: X-RATED INDUSTRY IN A SLUMP
description: WALK into an ''adult'' bookstore almost anywhere in the country, and you see piles of magazines: ''Orgy,'' ''Consenting Adults,'' ''Insatiables,'' to name a few of the more demure titles. There are shelves of sexual paraphernalia. And there is the pornography industry's fastest-growing offering: racks of video cassettes, with breathless headlines and glossy packaging, that show overdeveloped young people in positions never found in Grey's Anatomy.

title: Getting Fancy Food Up to the Competitive Level
description: People who have moved to this city from such outposts as New York may still insist that they cannot buy a good pastrami sandwich here, but things have got much better when it comes to haute cuisine to go.

title: A STATELY HOME IN REVOLUTIONARY IRELAND
description: SUPPLY OF HEROES By James Carroll. 403 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title:
INVESTING;
SORTING OUT THE NEXT MARKET LEADERS
description: MANY portfolio managers are sharply divided over which stock groups will lead the next stage of the bull market - should there be a next stage. One group still favors the past year's winners - those companies that benefit from disinflation. Another group, however, is betting on the so-called cyclicals, the heavy industry companies that do well in a surging economy. ''I walk into rooms and the first thing they say is, 'Which camp are you in?' '' said Byron R. Wien, investment strategist at Morgan, Stanley & Company in New York.

title: The Declining Safety Factor
description: WHILE the deregulation of routes and fares in 1978 spawned more than a score of new carriers, only big airlines with deep pockets survived the ensuing price wars. Last week, the contraction in the number of competitors proceeded apace. The Justice Department said it would not oppose either Delta Air Lines' proposed $860 million acquisition of Western Air Lines or Texas Air Corporation's proposed $301 million purchase of People Express Inc. and People's bankrupt subsidiary, Frontier Airlines. Both mergers must still pass muster with the Department of Transportation, which, as expected, approved Texas Air's $600 million purchase of Eastern Air Lines.

title: TOMATO ON WAY TO A TITLE
description: CONGRESS recently moved to make the rose the nation's official floral emblem, and New Jersey is moving to give its famous tomato official status.

title: Currency Tonic Can't Cure Trade Ailments
description: To the Editor:

title: Union and Boeing Talk After Pact Is Rejected
description: Negotiators for the Boeing Company and the union representing 40,000 machinists met for an hour today and agreed to a ''day to day'' delay of a strike threatened by the workers after they rejected a contract that did not provide for a wage increase.

title: ARMY OVERCOMES YALE QUATERBACK
description: The theme of the game was the pass against the run today at the Yale Bowl and as happens most times, the running team won. It was Army, a 41-24 victor over Yale before a crowd of 25,075.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Tricks of Trade Will a strong yen and weak dollar eventually reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States? Yes and no. ''There are signs that the monthly trade deficits are easing,'' said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. Even though Mr. Resler expects this year's trade deficit with Japan to be $60 billion - up from $46 billion last year - he says, the deficit may drop to $45 billion next year.

title: Lloyd Walser Is Dead at 49; A Chorus Leader at the Met
description: Lloyd Walser, the assistant chorus master of the Metropolitan Opera, died Friday at Doctors Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL SAN DIEGO CHARGERS VS. SEAHAWKS, at Seattle. 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660, 9 P.M.)

title: People Express Half-Price Sale
description: People Express Airlines begins another half-price sale today. For three days, through Wednesday, most of its domestic fares will be 50 percent off.

title: Report on U.S. Juvenile Crime
description: Nearly one of every five youths sent to a public juvenile detention facility for committing a crime last year was in custody for murder, rape, robbery or aggravated assault, the Justice Department said today in a new report.

title: OEPC TALKS OPEN TODAY
description: Oil ministers from the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries begin an emergency meeting here Monday to seek a credible oil-price-support agreement.

title: LUCERNE IS HIT HARD BY DROP IN U.S. TOURISTS
description: The lakeside city of Lucerne, the most popular destination in Switzerland for American tourists, has fallen victim to the threat of terrorism, officials here say.

title: STILL A DISTINCTIVE VOICE, BUT SOON AN ECHO
description: These were to have been quiet months for Mac Mathias, a time for reflection and for winding down a public career after four terms in the House of Representatives and three in the Senate.

title: Loan to Uruguay Signed
description: The World Bank announced Friday the signing of a $45 million loan, which it called the first ''voluntary'' commercial bank lending to Uruguay since 1983. The World Bank said it would guarantee 50 percent of the loan.

title: New York Tax Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Odds for Lame Ducks
description: Congress is laboring mightily these autumn days to wind up its business for the year so that the lawmakers will not have to come back to Washington after the election. Such lame-duck sessions are unpopular because they run into the holidays and because they inescapably involve participation by some members who have just been rejected by the voters.

title: The 32d Item
description: The C.I.A., feeling mischievous this summer, provided the State Department with conversations it overheard when Senator Jesse Helms visited Chilean President Pinochet.

title: An Ex-Technician Says Israelis Built A-Bombs
description: A British newspaper reported today that a former Israeli arms technician said that Israel had been building atomic weapons at a secret underground factory for 20 years.

title: N.J. DEVILS: LEADERS EMERGE
description: The coach and management claim that the time has come for the young Devils to show what they can do for New Jersey.

title: Volcker and the I.M.F.
description: In meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington last week, European finance ministers were unable to agree on a candidate to become managing director of the I.M.F., and a somewhat surprising new possibility has since arisen: Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: Law Bars Benefits For Illegal Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEN BRADLEY'S STARK VISION
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt was still President when the Allen-Bradley Company began making resistors for radios here. Thirty years later, after chips had rendered electrical components largely obsolete, Allen-Bradley moved the remnants of its resistor line to El Paso and nearby Juarez, Mexico, to take advantage of cheap, nonunion labor.

title: Post Offers Apology to Blacks
description: The executive editor of The Washington Post apologized today to anyone offended by the first issue of the newspaper's new Sunday magazine, which contained two articles that some black leaders called racist.

title: Iraq Reports 8 Civilians Killed by Iranians
description: Iranian planes bombed residential areas in the city of Kut today and artillery fire pounded neighborhoods in the port city of Basra, killing eight civilians and wounding 33, the Iraqi military command said.

title: The Governor Wins Apology
description: The national chairman of Blacks In Government has apologized to Governor Cuomo for a survey that asked black employees of the state government if they would vote for Mr. Cuomo.

title: 9 NEW YORK HIGH SCHOOLS DISPENSE CONTRACEPTIVES TO THEIR STUDENTS
description: Nine New York City high schools have state-paid programs that are dispensing contraceptives at the schools or at affiliated clinics as part of their general health-care services, according to a new report by the Board of Education staff.

title: Ad Is Misleading on Situation in Ethiopia
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS WIN ON PASS IN FINAL MINUTE; BILLS FALL BY 14-13
description: The Bills had 12 players on the field, one too many, but not one of them covered Mickey Shuler, the Jets' tight end, as he ran alone toward the Buffalo goal line.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If one of the division races in baseball had finished with three teams tied for first place, what kind of playoff arrangement would have been made?

title: IF SOUTH AFRICA GOES IT ALONE
description: Economic sanctions imposed against South Africa by its foreign trading partners, most recently the United States, seem likely to spur Pretoria to step up an old strategy: substituting domestically produced products for imports. But many economists here feel a move toward greater self-reliance could damage South African industry over the long term.

title: PURCHASERS SAY ECONOMY EXPANDED LAST MONTH
description: The economy expanded slightly in September and should continue to grow in the next two months, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its latest survey, released today.

title: Bill Sales to Dominate a Slow Week
description: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the regular weekly sale today of new bills due in three and six months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sept. 15 about a gathering of Aaron Burr's descendants misidentified the Burr relative for whom a building at Princeton University is named. The building is named for Aaron Burr Sr., who was Burr's father and Princeton's second president.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY PROCLAIMS A SUCCESS: 50% OF CARS CLEAN
