description: The president of the Transit Authority, David L. Gunn, will announce today that his agency is halfway to a goal many thought unattainable: 3,026 of the authority's approximately 6,000 subway cars are clean.

title: TROUT AND FISHERMEN RETURN TO A RIVER
description: FOR years when I lived and worked in Claremont, N.H., I ignored the nearby Sugar River except at the point where it joins the Connecticut at the city's western edge, a spot that would on occasion yield smallmouth bass or walleyed pike.

title: Addendum
description: * Carl Bakal, former senior vice president at Jack Raymond & Company, has formed his own public relations firm, Carl Bakal Associates, at 171 Madison Avenue.

title: Amazing Aches
description: Before you know it, it'll be time for the annual flood of baseball awards presented by sportswriters, magazines, manufacturers of mitts and hair tonics, and even antacid-makers. There's simply no room left for a Vince Coleman Award, which would otherwise go to the player who had been sidelined by the most curious kind of injury. Nonetheless, some worthy nominees from the season just past:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I left behind my homeland, my beloved culture, my language, my friends and dear ones.

title: Danielle Woerner In Debut as Soprano
description: As a founder and co-director of Woerner/Bobrick Associates, a New York public-relations and concert management agency, Danielle Woerner has long been well known in the musical field, and she has seen many young artists through the anxiety and excitement of a debut recital. Last Tuesday night, it was Ms. Woerner's turn to experience these emotions firsthand when she made her formal recital debut as a soprano at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Books; A Writer's Craft
description: IT SEEMS LIKE ONLY YESTERDAY:

title: When We Practice to Deceive
description: The news that the Reagan Administration planned a campaign of disinformation against Muammar el-Qaddafi tells us two things about the institution of the Presidency. More than ever, Americans need to know what it is doing. More than ever, the President and his people try to keep us from knowing.

title: CONGRESSIONAL BLACK CAUCUS REJOICES IN GROWING STRENGTH
description: For the Congressional Black Caucus, its five-day legislative conference that lasted through today was a time to reflect upon and to celebrate legislative and personal achievements.

title: GOTTI SAID TO FACE LOSS OF MOB POST
description: John Gotti, now on trial in Brooklyn and facing mounting legal problems, is on his way out as boss of the Gambino organized-crime family, and potential successors are maneuvering to succeed him, according to law-enforcement experts on the Mafia.

title: Ex-Employees Sue T.W.A.
description: Former Trans World Airlines flight attendants have filed an $80 million class-action lawsuit against the airline, contending that mass firings during a strike earlier this year hurt their careers.

title: No Rate Cut by Japan
description: Japan has no intention at present of cutting its official discount rate from 3.5 percent, Satoshi Sumita, the Governor of the Bank of Japan, said Saturday after returning from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in Washington. ''Frankly speaking, there has been no change at all in my thinking and attitude'' toward monetary policy, he added. The discount rate is the rate charged by the central bank for funds to commerical banks, and in turn affects interest rates paid by corporate and individual borrowers.

title: INDIANA PROVIDES SURPRISES
description: Preseason predictions were that Miami, Alabama, Nebraska, Michigan and Penn State were strong enough to have a good chance to get this far into the season undefeated, and they have. But few thought that Indiana would be 4-0, or that Stanford would get off to its best start since 1952 by winning its first four games, or that Iowa, without Chuck Long at quarterback anymore, would also be 4-0, a record that includes Saturday's 24-21 upset of Michigan State.

title: FLOODS RECEDING IN TULSA AREA: MANY STILL HOMELESS
description: Flooding on tributaries is pushing the Mississippi River to record and near-record crests, but the threat will diminish this week, experts said.

title: PARK AVE. ASSAULT ON RATHER LEAVES MYSTERY AS TO MOTIVE
description: Dan Rather, the CBS News anchorman, and the police said yesterday that they were mystified over a bizarre incident in which Mr. Rather was chased, punched and kicked by two well-dressed men near his home on the Upper East Side late Saturday night.

title: ICELAND IS SET TO DO ITS PART TO END THE EAST-WEST CHILL
description: Iceland is bracing, white-knuckled but thrilled, for the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting next weekend here in Reykjavik, a seaside capital in the shadow of snow-capped mountains.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MONKEY'S WRENCH. By Primo Levi. Translated by William Weaver. 171 pages. Summit. $15.95. PRIMO Levi's new novel, ''The Monkey's Wrench,'' is in a lighter spirit than the memoirs of his experiences as a Jewish Italian partisan captured by the Germans in World War II, but the glow is there. It is the glow of the humane intelligence that so warmly illuminates ''The Periodic Table'' and his other works.

title: Jakarta Seeks Asia Gas Pact
description: Indonesia, desperate to make up for declining oil revenues, hopes to end a price wrangle with Japan next month that will clear the way for large new gas sales to Asia.

title: ORIOLE JOB EXPECTED FOR CAL RIPKEN SR.
description: A 6-3 loss to the Detroit Tigers ended the Baltimore Orioles last-place season, and the club announced a news conference for this morning at which Cal Ripken Sr. is expected to be named as Earl Weaver's successor as manager.

title: Required Reading
description: Domestic Diplomacy Edward Derwinski, a State Department counselor and former Illinois Representative, in excerpts from ''The Capitol Connection,'' an article in the September issue of Foreign Service Journal, a monthly magazine for Foreign Service professionals:

title: A DISPUTE ON BABY M
description: The case of Baby M., a six-month-old girl who was born to a surrogate mother and is currently the subject of a court battle in New Jersey, has prompted intense debate on the legal and moral implications of modern reproductive technologies.

title: NBC'S 'FIGHT FOR JENNY'
description: NBC has had some difficulty deciding how to ''play'' the television movie it is broadcasting tonight at 9. The Robert Greenwald production, written by Duffy Bart and directed by Gilbert Moses, was first called ''Society's Child.'' Then, for a passing moment, it became ''Colors.'' Now, barring any last-minute change, the title is ''A Fight for Jenny,'' a reference to the child caught in a bitter custody battle. Throughout the film, for the record, she is referred to as Jennifer, not Jenny.

title: Icahn Is Silent On USX Plans
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York takeover specialist, said yesterday that he had no response to rumors last week that he would soon begin a takeover attempt for the USX Corporation, the nation's largest steel manufacturer. Reached yesterday at his home, Mr. Icahn said that he had ''no comment at this time'' and asked to be left alone.

title: RANGERS' McPHEE IS HURT
description: Last night's game between the Rangers and Islanders was supposed not only to wrap up each team's exhibition schedule, but also to illustrate the ''look'' the clubs intended to have at the start of the regular season later this week. The major league lineups, coaches Ted Sator of the Rangers and Terry Simpson of the Islanders had said, would be on the ice at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Milnes Recital to Open Colden Center Season
description: A recital by the baritone Sherrill Milnes on Oct. 18 at 8:30 P.M. will open the 26th season at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing, Queens. Mr. Milnes will sing works by Mozart, Strauss, Verdi, Copland and others; the pianist will be Jon Spong.

title: Rutgers May Lose Gagliardi for '86
description: Joe Gagliardi, the senior quarterback who led Rutgers to a 3-0-1 start this season, suffered a separated shoulder in Saturday's 31-6 loss to Penn State and will probably be lost for the season.

title: Show and Tell in Credit Cards
description: Banks are lending money to large corporations for 7.5 percent and home buyers for as little as 9 percent. But average rates on credit card balances hang at a stratospheric 18 percent. Some consumer advocates think the disparity calls for laws that limit credit card interest rates. But requiring their disclosure in ads should suffice to let the market work. A move in the House to add the requirement to an equally reasonable ''truth in savings'' bill deserves support.

title: METS INSTALLING SINGLE-WING OFFENSE?
description: FALL training ended on a successful note yesterday as Dave Johnson rolled regulars, irregulars and Tidewater recruits in and out of the lineup, and the Mets survived the first major-league start of Hippolito Pena with only one bruise and a few gray hairs.

title: O' Rourke, not Cuomo, Makes TV Appearance
description: Standing beside an empty lectern with Governor Cuomo's name on it, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, appeared alone on a live, 30-minute television program last night.

title: X-RATED 'COUPLES FILMS' FINDING A NEW MARKET
description: One cassette titled ''Femme'' promotes itself as ''created by women for people who love.'' Another, ''Naked Scents,'' comes with a vial of cologne. Pink ostrich feathers adorn the cover of ''Tickled Pink.''

title: A Flight of Fancy
description: Fans of 1950's television can meet and greet the original Captain Midnight at the National Air and Space Museum tomorrow when Richard Webb inaugurates the museum's fall series of aviation movies by donating his Secret Squad jacket and his Ovaltine decoder ring to the Smithsonian. ''Deadly Diamonds,'' one of the Captain Midnight half-hour episodes, will be screened, along with ''Thirteen Hours by Air'' starring Fred MacMurray. The free Tuesday night film series continues through early December.

title: Head of Memory Metals Removed by Directors
description: The board of Memory Metals Inc., a small company in Stamford, Conn., has removed its founder, Neil E. Rogen, as chairman, chief executive and as an employee.

title: D'Amato Bars Cuomo Attacks
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday refused to join the Republican gubernatorial candidate in criticizing Governor Cuomo, saying that he would probably have to work with Mr. Cuomo after the election.

title: CONNER GAINS AN EASY VICTORY
description: Tom Blackaller, the skipper for San Francisco's America's Cup team, got right to the heart of the matter.

title: YALE QUARTERBACK SUITS ROLE
description: Kelly Ryan, the Yale quarterback who passed for 426 yards against Army on Saturday, finally realized the considerable expectations others had for him.

title: Accounts
description: * AGS, a national computer service company, and Car Phone Connection, a cellular mobile telephone franchiser, to David H. Block Advertising.

title: Catching Up
description: * Dave Dixon, the New Orleans art dealer who dreamed up low-budget spring football and then saw his brainstorm, the United States Football League, fall prey to big-spending owners, says his effort to revive the idea next year is on track. ''We'll have a major announcement in a few weeks,'' says Dixon, whose plans for 10 fan-owned franchises playing as America's Football Teams have undergone a few revisions since he first disclosed them last winter: For one thing, fans won't be able to buy stock until after the first season.

title: Alexandra Christy Is a Bride in Wilton
description: Alexandra Christy and David Bayard Coggeshall were married yesterday at a private home in Wilton, Conn. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. of the Riverside Church in New York officiated.

title: JUSTICES TO OPEN 1986 TERM TODAY FACING KEY ISSUES
description: With a new Chief Justice and a new member, the Supreme Court will begin its 1986-87 term Monday facing issues that include racial disparities in death sentencing and the constitutionality of teaching creationism in public schools.

title: A TIME OF UPHEAVAL FOR CONFERENCE BOARD
description: Two ancient top hats in a glass case at the Conference Board's headquarters in Manhattan stand as a symbol of an illustrious past, when ''the Board'' served as a place where captains of industry rubbed shoulders and exchanged ideas.

title: Lucy B. Bolch Is Married To Jean-Charles Sprunger
description: Lucy Bishopric Bolch, a needlework designer, and Jean-Charles Sprunger, a lamp designer, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Robert B. Stuart, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: ALONG ONE RIVER, THE BATTLE IS JOINED
description: Frank Faruggia had all the basic gear this weekend - waist-high boots with optional suspenders, sandbags up to his porch and a pump draining his basement almost as fast as flood waters encased his washer-dryer.

title: REACTOR ON SOVIET SUBS: THIN PROTECTIVE COVER
description: Nuclear-powered Soviet submarines like the one that caught fire on Friday have reactors with less protective shielding than their Western counterparts, and Soviet operators have less training, according to American submarine experts with access to intelligence information.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on Saturday about legislation for dams, ports and other water projects misidentified Senator Robert T. Stafford, the chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee. He is a Republican from Vermont.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1986
description: THE WORLD A Soviet nuclear submarine, apparently crippled by a fire and explosion on Friday, is being towed toward the Soviet Union by a Soviet merchant ship, the Pentagon said. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said photos from reconnaissance planes showed that the explosion did a great deal of damage. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: AGENDA: OCT. 6, 1986
description: Response in Drug Inquiry Dismissed in connection with office drug parties, the former budget director for city's Buildings Department will tell his side of story. Lawyer says Michael Futterman to talk of ''drug involvement'' at the agency and ask for ''exoneration.'' Mr. Futterman was one of eight department employees to quit or be forced out after inquiry by Department of Investigation. 10 A.M. news conference, 999 Brush Hollow Road, Westbury, L.I. Persico for the Defense

title: 20,000 Swedes on Strike
description: Health services, transportation and other operations were disrupted today by a strike by nearly 20,000 Swedish workers, organizers said. Stockholm's subway system was halted over the weekend as public employees' unions increased their pressure in a long wage dispute. A strike by nurses has affected many hospitals, and officials said nonurgent surgery had been postponed.

title: Make Manhattan Available for Families Again
description: To the Editor:

title: AUDIT CHARGES SCHOOL CONTRACTORS WITH CUTTING CORNERS ON REPAIRS
description: Contractors generally cut corners on major school repairs and are rarely required to fulfill the terms of their agreements with New York City's Board of Education, according to an audit to be released today by the city's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Ad Is Misleading on Situation in Ethiopia; Long-Term Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Victim of Good Will
description: Crutches are uncomfortable but they are also educational. The need to use them for several weeks to ease a minor foot injury teaches that many more strangers than one might suspect are compassionate and helpful. Brimming with good will, they jump to help a hobbling unfortunate. Life on crutches also reveals, however, that these blessed qualities are sometimes a dangerous nuisance. At times it takes more patience and good will to receive help than to give it.

title: Sri Lanka Tells Of Killing 10 Tamils
description: The Government said today that 10 militants were killed in its weeklong offensive against Tamil guerrillas in eastern Sri Lanka, that 18 were captured and that a large cache of ammunition was recovered.

title: 5 PRIVATE HOSPITALS ARE LIKELY TO BE CLOSED
description: Health officials are negotiating to eliminate nearly 20 percent of the acute-care hospital beds in New York City over the next four years, largely through the closing of at least five private hospitals and the merger of others.

title: 3 SOVIET SUBMARINES SAID TO PATROL ATLANTIC 'BOX'
description: The Soviet submarine that caught fire Friday and is now apparently crippled east of Bermuda was probably one of three Yankee-class vessels the Russians keep in a well-defined patrol region in the Atlantic, according to military experts.

title: WOULD-BE SOVIET EMIGRES REDOUBLE THEIR EFFORTS
description: Less than a day before her departure for New York, the wife of the human rights activist Yuri F. Orlov paid a visit to the Moscow apartment of Naum and Inna Meiman.

title: Bride Killed In Car Crash
description: Thirteen hours after their wedding, a 41-year-old Long Island woman was killed and her husband was critically injured early yesterday when their car was struck from behind by an automobile that sped away from the accident in Hicksville, the Nassau County police reported.

title: Brighter Outlook for Rate Cut
description: Prospects for lower interest rates, which had dimmed considerably just two weeks ago, seem to have brightened, as fresh data show that the economy remains weak and may require more stimulus in the form of an easier monetary policy and lower short-term interest rates.

title: TV Union Rejected
description: To the Editor:

title: A MIDSIZE I.B.M. UNIT EXPECTED
description: After months of anticipation by the computer industry, the International Business Machines Corporation is expected to introduce tomorrow a series of small, relatively inexpensive mainframe computers, marking a radically new tactic in I.B.M.'s struggle to regain footing in the midsize computer market.

title: Seoul Lets Currency Inch Up
description: The changes so far have been small, but after years of steady devaluation South Korea is allowing its currency, the won, to rise against the dollar.

title: EGYPT'S SONS BACK HOME, BUT NOT TO FATTED CALVES
description: When Mohammed Ibrahim Mustapha came back to this Nile Delta village after a year in Iraq driving a truck on construction jobs he had saved enough money to build a little house.

title: Henry N. Wright Dies at 76; Ex-Professor of Architecture
description: Henry N. Wright, a former managing editor of the magazine Architectural Forum and a retired professor of architecture at City College of New York, died of a heart attack Friday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. A resident of Wellfleet, Mass., he was 76 years old.

title: Name That Button
description: Three months ago Privacy Journal, a Washington newsletter often concerned with computers, invited readers to submit names for the N symbol at the lower righthand corner of the telephone button panel. Among two dozen responses, the editor, Robert Ellis Smith, has determined Octothorpe to be the ''most authentic'' and Gridlet to be the ''most intriguing.''

title: DOLPHINS ROUTED BY PATRIOTS, 34-7
description: Tony Eason threw two touchdown passes as the New England Patriots scored on five of their six first-half possessions today and routed the Miami Dolphins, 34-7.

title: Market Place; Petro-Lewis Deal Is Clouded
description: BARRING any last-minute developments, the fate of the Petro-Lewis Corporation, the Denver oil and gas company that is one of the nation's largest oil and gas drillers, will be decided at midnight tonight. That is when a cash tender offer for Petro-Lewis debt securites expires. The offer is being made by Freeport-McMoran Inc., a natural resources company.

title: ASTROS COUNTING ON PITCHING TO BLOCK METS' PATH TO PENNANT
description: ''YOU can take these games and keep them for your library.''

title: American Textiles Lead a High-Tech World Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBURBIA PRICING OUT THE YOUNG
description: The economic forces that have brought prosperity and change to the suburbs around New York are also pushing out of the region a precious resource: its young people.

title: Japanese Securities Markets
description: E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, seems pleased enough with how much Japan has opened its securities markets to Americans to let Japanese firms here become primary dealers in Government securities. In a letter to Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat from Brooklyn, Mr. Corrigan said that the Fed has been ''encouraged that the Japanese authorities have been making steady progress toward opening their market to foreign firms.''

title: EUROPEANS SET GOAL FOR SPACE STATION
description: Despite uncertainty about when the United States space shuttles will fly again to launch a projected space station, the director general of the European Space Agency is considering an ambitious program of four space missions as part of the project.

title: RIDING THE NEXT WAVE OF PERFORMING ARTS
description: For something that began as a happy accident, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival has turned into a major cultural event in an amazingly short time.

title: FRANCIS KERNAN
description: Francis Kernan, an investment banker and philanthropist, died of a heart ailment Saturday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Diana L. Jones Is Married To Mark S. Boekenheide
description: Diana Lee Jones, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Jones of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Stephen Boekenheide, the son of Russell W. Boekenheide of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Jeanne Lampe of Belen, N.M. The Rev. Barbara Miller, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Community Church of Mountain Lakes.

title: W.P.C. Tops Kean
description: Eamon Doran scored a touchdown on 2-yard run and gained 103 yards over all today, a single-game school record, to lead William Paterson College to a 27-7 victory over Kean in a New Jersey State Athletic Conference contest.

title: Savings Plan By French
description: France plans new fiscal measures to encourage savings and investment as a central plank of government policy, Alain Juppe, the budget minister, said today.

title: AMONG SWEET ADELINES, CINDERELLA IS CENTER STAGE
description: If their game were baseball, football or basketball instead of singing, the quartet Ambiance would have been the Cinderella team of the year: Young, new, sharp and at its peak just as the playoffs began, but a surprise and an underdog.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1986
description: International

title: MOSCOW, LONG UNFRIENDLY, MOVES TO MEND ITS RELATIONS WITH BONN
description: After three years of trying to isolate and punish Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right Government, the Soviet Union has recently moved decisively to improve relations with West Germany.

title: Norman Captures Match Play Title
description: Greg Norman of Australia defeated Sandy Lyle of Britain, 2 and 1, today to win the $270,000 Suntory world match play championship.

title: Knicks' Walker Treated
description: Kenny (Sky) Walker, the Knicks' first-round draft choice and the player expected to replace the still-injured Bernard King, was admitted to Lenox Hill hospital in Manhattan late Saturday suffering severe muscle cramps. The condition was said to be the result of dehydration after his first complete day of workouts with the team.

title: Elizabeth Mead Wed To John K. Tabor Jr.
description: Elizabeth Mead and John K. Tabor Jr. were married yesterday at the home on Drakes Island, Me., of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Woodward Mead of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. James Birney, an Episcopal priest, officiated. Mr. Tabor is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tabor of Washington The bride, a computer softwear consultant with Selkirk Associates in Boston, graduated from Kirkland College and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MAYOR JAMES BRINGS OPTIMISM
description: In his first 100 days as Mayor of New Jersey's most populous city, Sharpe James has spent much of his time meeting with many of the city's business and community leaders, talking with potential developers and traveling to Trenton to discuss the city's fiscal woes.

title: PERILS OF A 2D TIME AROUND
description: ROBERT LOHR of Montrose, Colo., was only 20 years old when he married Penelope Merritt, his high school sweetheart. The marriage lasted 18 months. They both married for a second time, again without success.

title: Contract Talks Resume In Boeing Dispute
description: Negotiators for the Boeing Company and 40,000 machinists returned to the bargaining table with a Federal mediator today under the terms of an agreement Saturday that delayed a strike.

title: U.S. MIGHT HASTEN BREACH OF TREATY
description: The Reagan Administration has been considering whether to move up the date when the United States will exceed a limit in the 1979 strategic arms treaty, according to Administration officials and Congressional experts.

title: WALES
description: This conference preview was prepared and written by Craig Wolff. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish, with the Rangers picked for second, the Islanders fourth and the Devils sixth in the Patrick Divison. Patrick Division

title: Navratilova Wins
description: Martina Navratilova took a 6-1, 4-6, 6-2 victory over Pam Shriver to win the $150,000 Virginia Slims of New Orleans women's tennis tournament today.

title: A NOTED EXPLORER
description: David M. Newell, an author, an editor and a noted explorer, died of emphysema Sept. 26 at his home in Leesburg, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LE CINEMA The Cinema du Reel, an annual documentary festival in Paris, makes its New York debut today through Friday in the newly refurbished auditorium of the French Institute/Alliance Francaise, 22 East 60th Sreet (355-6100), and at several other locations around town.

title: AN ARTICLE BY KOCH FUELS A POLITICAL FIRE IN GREECE
description: An article by Mayor Koch accusing the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of being anti-American and anti-Semitic has caused widespread anger here. It has also been condemned as an intervention against the governing Socialist Party in local elections across Greece next Sunday.

title: Advertising; Layoffs Afflicting Agencies
description: THE New York office of Ogilvy & Mather dismissed 60 people last week. Graham Phillips, chairman of the domestic company, said these employees were the last of 200 to be dismissed nationwide this year because of the sluggish economy.

title: CHRONICLES OF POLITICS THEN AND NOW
description: ''They didn't seem to be paying attention much tonight. Not while I was trying to explain about my tax program.''

title: BRONCOS TROUNCE COWBOYS BY 29-14
description: John Elway threw three touchdown passes, Gerald Willhite scored three times and Karl Mecklenburg and Rulon Jones led a dominating defense today as the unbeaten Denver Broncos erupted for 22 second-quarter points and defeated the Dallas Cowboys, 29-14.

title: Bigger Job for Hertz
description: The Hertz Corporation, like other car leasers, sells its vehicles whenever it figures it has gotten enough use out of them.

title: Allied Stores Studies Offer
description: Top executives of the Allied Stores Corporation met in New York over the weekend to study a $66-a-share bid by the Campeau Corporation and to discuss other alternatives, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Barbados Sets Loan Accord
description: Barbados is completing plans for a $40 million syndicated loan from a bank consortium headed by United States-based County Natwest Capital Markets Ltd., a government statement said today.

title: Six Die in Apartment With Window Bars
description: A woman and five children died in an apartment fire today after flames blocked the doorway and bars on the windows prevented escape, officials said.

title: SOVIET SUBMARINE, CRIPPLED BY FIRE, ON HER WAY HOME
description: A Soviet nuclear submarine, apparently crippled by a fire and explosion on Friday, was being towed by a Soviet merchant ship tonight toward the Soviet Union, the Defense Department said.

title: AVOIDING A SPENDTHRIFT IMAGE IS A KEY GOAL IN HOUSE RACES
description: As Republican Congressional candidates around the country this year attack their opponents as free-spending ''Tip O'Neill liberals,'' Democrats are resorting to a variety of tactics to shed that label.

title: National Literacy Figures Getting Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 6, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Australians Oust U.S. in Davis Cup
description: Pat Cash defeated Brad Gilbert, 3-6, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4, today in the first reverse singles match to give Australia a 3-1 victory over the United States in the semifinals of the Davis Cup.

title: Deals for Bankers at Meetings
description: The thousands of private bankers at the annual meetings last week of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund obviously were not there to listen to speech after speech by finance ministers.

title: Gimbel Unit Purchased
description: The former Gimbel department store in Valley Stream, N.Y., has been acquired by Abraham & Straus and will be reopened as the newest A.&S. store on Long Island on Friday. A.&S., a division of Federated Department Stores Inc, said over the weekend that it had acquired the 275,000-square-foot store in August and that the site will be the division's seventh store on Long Island. A.&S. also has nine other stores in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: CEASE-FIRE EASES A SIX-DAY BATTLE IN LEBANON
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen from the Amal movement battled with Palestinians entrenched in a refugee district in southern Lebanon today, the sixth straight day of an effort to disarm the guerrillas. Late in the day a cease-fire was announced, and the fighting reportedly eased up.

title: Record Airline Traffic
description: The leading United States airlines carried 402 million passengers on six million flights during the 12 months that ended Sept. 30, a record number attributed to increased competition and lower fares, an industry group said Friday. The Air Transport Association said that during the 12-month period, 90 percent of the passengers traveled on discount fares, which averaged 60 percent of full fare. It was the first time that the number of passengers carried by the airlines exceeded 400 million during any 12-month period.

title: Just Rewards
description: At a time of intense concern about the academic neglect of college athletes, a few coaches are finding themselves under financial pressure to make sure their teams succeed in the classroom as well as on the playing field.

title: Ghost Mystery
description: The most puzzling question posed by ''Murder at the Super Bowl,'' a whodunit being published this month by William Morrow and Company, may not be who did in Magic Madjeski, the coach of the Brooklyn Wizards, but who did the whodunit?

title: 'CATCH-22': CADETS HAIL A CHRONICLER OF THE ABSURD
description: It was love at first sight.

title: STILL 'HUMMING' AFTER ALL THESE YEARS
description: THE answer to the age-old question ''Will wonders never cease?'' must be:

title: Whistleblower Loses In Labor Board Ruling
description: A company can legally dismiss an employee for reporting violations of Federal safety statutes to the Government, the National Labor Relations Board said in a ruling released today.

title: Washington Watch; Volcker 'Aura' And Fed Seat
description: THE announcement last week that Emmett J. Rice will relinquish his seat on the board of the Federal Reserve has not produced the intensive, supply-side lobbying that other openings on the seven-member board have stirred.

title: TORTOISES, PEDRO PAN, AND MASS
description: Instinct plays a cruel trick on newly hatched sea turtles.

title: AS THAI SEX TRADE INCREASES, SO DO ABUSES
description: A distinguished Thai lawyer paged through her stack of clippings and photographs as if it were a family album.

title: NEW YORK RANGERS: FOCUS ON SCORING
description: Phil says he gets along fine with Ted. Ted says he appreciates Phil. The players say they trust Ted and that they love Phil's openness. Ted says he feels more comfortable with his players. Everything is wonderful around the Rangers, but no one is quite sure what that means or how long this climate will last. Anyway, no one has quit the team in the last two months.

title: Why Won't the Doctors Let Her Die?
description: Her chief complaint is that she wants to die and that the doctors will not let her.

title: A Supermarket for Peking
description: A supermarket has been opened in the Lido Hotel in Peking, offering such previously unavailable or scarce items as breakfast cereals and disposable diapers. The store, managed by a Hong Kong supermarket chain, will accept only foreign exchange certificates, a special currency used by foreign visitors.

title: Meeting, or Beating, the Russians
description: Boy, what a switch Ronald Reagan has pulled on us with the Russians. After all this tough-guy stuff, he lies down like a pussycat. 'Just give us our guy, here's your guy, everything's fine, see you in Iceland.'

title: Parrish Dobson Wed To a Fellow Teacher
description: Parrish Dobson and Eugene H. Pool, English teachers at the Buckingham Browne & Nichols School in Cambridge, Mass., were married yesterday at St. Bede's Chapel in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. David Norris, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT AND WIFE ARRIVE, GRATEFUL, HE SAYS, BUT SAD, TOO
description: Yuri F. Orlov, the Soviet dissident freed from Siberia as part of an arrangement that led to the release of an American journalist in Moscow, arrived in New York with his wife yesterday. He said he was grateful for his freedom but sad for the land and the friends he left behind.

title: JETS WIN ON PASS IN FINAL MINUTE; CARDINALS LOSE, 13-6
description: If you like punts, it was a great game. Between them, the Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals punted 17 times. Throw in four field goals, two by each side, and it's a wonder anybody won.

title: SOME SOLACE FOR MATTINGLY
description: On the sixth pitch of the game, Don Mattingly swung his bat and then watched the ball soar over the outfield grass and the warning track and the bullpen in right-center field. And then it landed several rows back in the bleachers at Fenway Park, settling in a crowd of fans some 400 feet from where it was launched.

title: Waitress Slain At Restaurant
description: A 33-year-old waitress was fatally stabbed early yesterday morning at a midtown restaurant by the man she lived with, who is a chef at the restaurant, , the police said.

title: First TV Spot For Samsung
description: Samsung Electronics America has been promoting its Korean-made entertainment products with radio, out-of-home and print advertising since the turn of the decade. With the help of David

title: Homeless Man Is Assaulted
description: A homeless man, attacked by seven teen-agers, was thrown over a wall and dropped about 50 feet into Riverside Park early yesterday, leaving him with a fractured leg and back injuries, the police said.

title: Bridge: New England Grande Dame Reports a Deal to Remember
description: Take some aggressive bidders; make one partnership vulnerable with most of the high-card strength; make the other partnership nonvulnerable with a long suit.

title: DeLOREAN FRAUD TRIAL READY
description: John Z. DeLorean, the flamboyant auto maker who was acquitted in Los Angeles two years ago on charges of cocaine trafficking, is scheduled to go on trial here Monday on charges that he schemed to bilk investors in his failed car company.

title: DANCE: BALLET WEST OFFERS 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' is not only one of the most festive of 19th-century ballets, it is also one of the most difficult to produce. Above all, it requires splendor. There must be splendor in the scenery and costumes. More important, there must be splendor in the dancing. Therefore, it is not surprising that some companies are reluctant to stage it.

title: N.Y. ISLANDERS: WORKING HARDER
description: As the Islanders opened their training camp, General Manager Bill Torrey provided a dictum that became a warning to some players and an inspiration to others.

title: Uganda Detains Five On Subversion Charges
description: The Government has detained a former Vice President, two Cabinet ministers, a newspaper editor and a politician on subversion charges, the state-owned radio reported today.

title: COLUMN ONE: POLITICS
description: A Vacation Vetoed...Mayor Koch has canceled what would have been his first vacation in a year.

title: SOOTHSAYERS FIND A NEW MARKET
description: Brian Bricker was dining with friends at the Akbar restaurant on Park Avenue at 58th Street not long ago when one of the resident psychics there predicted that a man in green shoes was about to walk into his life. ''Green shoes?'' Mr. Bricker said, looking dubious. ''What else?'' Plenty, said the psychic, Carolyn Clark. Turning down tarot cards, she foresaw a future business deal and suggested a sales strategy. The tipoff would be the green shoes. After paying $10 for the reading, Mr. Bricker returned to his lamb vindaloo.

title: IN THE EAST ROOM, HOROWITZ AND 2 SURPRISES
description: Leading figures in music and politics went to the White House this afternoon for the first United States piano recital of Vladimir Horowitz since his triumphant tour of the Soviet Union, Europe and Japan this year.

title: 'BYE BYE KIPLING' ON 13, A VIDEO ADVENTURE
description: NAM JUNE PAIK, perhaps the least threatening of avant-garde artists, is fond of salutations. On the first day of 1984, he presided over a Paris-New York satellite transmission entitled ''Good Morning, Mr. Orwell.'' On Saturday evening, from 9 o'clock to nearly 10:30 on Channel 13, he conceived and coordinated a kind of space-opera variety show that was called ''Bye Bye Kipling.'' This time, with financing from American, Japanese and Korean sources - the title alludes to Kipling's famed conclusion that ''never the twain shall meet'' -he offered still another splashy and witty demonstration of his favorite subject: two-way, interactive television communications.

title: BEARS BATTER VIKINGS, 23-30, AND REMAIN UNDEFEATED
description: Jim McMahon's 58-yard touchdown pass to Keith Ortego early in the fourth quarter helped the undefeated Chicago Bears gain a 23-0 victory over the Minnesota Vikings today.

title: ON MAKING CRIME PAY: OFFENDERS AS AUTHORS
description: Crime may not pay for the average citizen, but several authors have discovered that running afoul of the law can be a springboard to literary, and perhaps even financial, success.

title: Companies Built Up By Buyout Partners
description: When Triangle Industries announced on Wednesday that it was calling in its $113.6 million of convertible debt, Nelson Peltz and Peter W. May had taken another step in their blueprint to build a sound industrial empire.

title: Marijuana Seized in Raid
description: The state police said they seized about 250 pounds of marijuana worth about $250,000 during a weekend raid of a farmhouse that was protected by electronic security and guard dogs.

title: METS END SEASON AS CITY'S TOP DRAW
description: The Mets ended their season of success with a titanic final performance yesterday, a five-game winning streak, an attendance record for sports in New York, numerous individual achievements and 108 victories against 54 losses - matching the best record in the National League in 77 years.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 6, 1986:

title: REHIRE PINIELLA
description: FOR one Yankee, finishing second reflected his gallantry. For another, finishing second reflected his vulnerability.

title: RITUAL LINKS AMERICANS TO AFRICAN HERITAGE
description: Even Bamidele Bomani, a 14-year-old with a serious face, clear eyes and an element of Brooklyn cool, seemed a little jittery.

title: Robertson Depicts Abortions As Racial Suicide in the West
description: Working toward a potential Presidential campaign here Saturday night, the evangelist Pat Robertson asserted that an increase in abortions was leading to ''racial suicide'' in the West.

title: Hong Kong Trading Comes of Age
description: When Hong Kong's new stock exchange moves from the experimental stage to its official opening on Monday, it will give the territory a chance to prove its financial maturity to foreign investors. After 13 years of effort, Hong Kong's four exchanges - the Far East, Kam Ngan, Hong Kong and Kowloon - will operate as one, as the Stock Exchange of Hongkong.

title: CAMPBELL
description: This conference preview was prepared and written by Robin Finn. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. Norris Division

title: The Mayor and the Whistleblower
description: ''Unhelpful, to say the least.'' That's how Patrick McGinley, New York City's Commissioner of Investigation four years ago, dismissed the charge of corruption at the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: EUROPEANS SEE EASING OF U.S.-SOVIET TENSION
description: European political figures and commentators, assessing the latest twists in Soviet-American relations, have emphasized hopes for easing tensions.

title: STAKES HIGH FOR BRITAIN'S FINANCIAL FIRMS IN FREER MARKETS
description: Ever since the Government of Margaret Thatcher reached an agreement three years ago with the London Stock Exchange for opening up the domestic securities business, Barclays Bank has been planning for the ''Big Bang.''

title: Americans Win Volleyball Title
description: The United States, led by Steve Timmons and Karch Kiraly, won the 1986 world men's volleyball championship today, defeating the Soviet Union, 12-15, 15-11, 15-8, 15-12.

title: Earnhardt Tops $1 Million Mark
description: Dale Earnhardt came from two laps down today to win the Oakwood Homes 500 and become only the fourth race car driver in history to earn more than $1 million in one season.

title: METROPOLITAN NEWS
description: Metropolitan News, an expanded section with new daily columns and features, begins in this issue of The Times.

title: ROCK: LOU REED IN CONCERT
description: LOU REED, punk-rock's godfather, couldn't resist the irony of his headlining Radio City Music Hall. For two decades, from his mid-1960's work with the Velvet Underground through his solo career, he has been known for songs such as ''Walk on the Wild Side'' and ''Street Hassle,'' about the mean, unglamorous side of his native New York. But on Wednesday, he had sold out the city's show-business palace. Just before he finished his two-hour set, a sign was lowered into place, the word ''Lou'' writ large, in eight-foot letters and flowing script worthy of Liberace.

title: DANILOFF'S UNWITTING ROLE IN INTRIGUE
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff said today that he had been unwittingly caught up in a complex intelligence confrontation in Moscow between the Central Intelligence Agency and the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and secret police agency.

title: Peking Urges Coexisting With Capitalist Nations
description: The Communist Party leader, Hu Yaobang, said today that Communist countries should seek peaceful coexistence with capitalist countries, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: EX-OFFICER CALLS CORRUPTION ON POLICE FORCE WIDESPREAD
description: David Durk, a retired police lieutenant who played a key role in the Knapp Commission investigation of New York City police corruption in 1970, said yesterday that corruption is widespread in the police department, particularly in precincts in the poorest areas of the city..

title: CONTINENT SEES THREAT IN LONDON
description: Tremors are already being felt throughout the rest of Europe as Britain gears up for the ''Big Bang'' on Oct. 27, when the most significant parts of the three-year-old financial deregulation pact between the London Stock Exchange and the Government take effect.

title: Sanctions as a Means to an End
description: Congress has prevailed. The Senate and the House have both overriden President Reagan's veto, imposing stringent sanctions against South Africa, and the United States will soon register its abhorrence for apartheid in no uncertain terms. Having won the battle for sanctions, Congress now should consider how to make the most of their impact.

title: I.R.S. Writing New Tax Rules
description: For the politicians, it might all be over but the signing, probably right after the President returns from Iceland. But the Internal Revenue Service now faces the task of writing regulations to guide taxpayers through the hundreds of provisions in the new tax legislation.

title: FRIEDMAN JURY TO HEAR MORE FROM WITNESS
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer will be questioned about his sexual relations with patients who saw him for psychotherapy and about a lucrative towing contract as he retakes the witness stand for cross-examination tomorrow in the Federal corruption trial in New Haven, defense lawyers said yesterday.

title: HABITUES OF THE HOUSE OF FAME, PAST AND PRESENT
description: IN his new biography of Langston Hughes, Arnold Rampersad recounts a droll incident in the 1920's when Hughes and a friend, driving through the South, heard a rural preacher inadvertently offering up an inspired variation on the Lord's Prayer: ''Our Father, who art in Heaven, Hollywood be thy name!''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Co. has named Jerry Cole senior vice president, strategic planning.

title: 'HUMANIST' SCHOOLBOOKS GO TO COURT IN ALABAMA
description: For the first time, come Monday morning, one of the basic intellectual arguments of the religious right will get a full-dress hearing in a Federal court.

title: Kenny Barron, Pianist, And His New Quintet
description: Leading a jazz band is a complex and demanding occupation, related to - but not at all the same thing as -playing the music. Some of the idiom's most inspirational players have been among its most abysmal band leaders. The pianist Kenny Barron, who led a new quintet at Whippoorwill through last night, seems to bring the same quiet authority and fierce concentration to both jobs.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
No Drastic Change Seen By Forstmann and Leff
description: Although J. Anthony Forstmann and Joel Leff agreed last week to sell their money-management firm for close to $100 million, they do not expect life to change drastically for them. Both will continue as co-chairmen under seven-year contracts after the sale of Forstmann-Leff Associates to the Guinness Peat Group of Britain is completed. ''I'll have to get a T-shirt that says Divisional Head,'' Mr. Leff said.

title: ZACCARO SAID TO HAVE SHUNNED CABLE INQUIRY
description: John A. Zaccaro refused a request to cooperate with the cable-television investigation in which he was indicted last week on criminal charges, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

title: Writers and Artists To Speak at Library
description: Discussions with the writers Raymond Carver and Nicolas Freeling, a lecture by the artist Romare Bearden and an interview with the actress Sylvia Sidney are among upcoming events sponsored by the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: People
description: * John Voulgaris and Ralph Pucci have been appointed senior vice presidents and creative directors at Solin Associates.

title: MOGAMBO BEATEN BY WAQUOIT
description: Waquoit, the fastest 3-year-old in New England, rallied again after being headed by the heavily favored Mogambo at the quarter pole and drew off by three lengths to win the Jamaica Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Grey's New Position
description: Grey Direct/West in San Francisco, which is part of Grey Advertising, is billing about $15 million and is getting its first president, David Jedele, 44 years old, who reports for duty today. He is coming in from Ogilvy & Mather Direct, where he ran its data base development. Previously he managed the London office, and before that worked 10 years for the firm in New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Mattingly .352, Boggs .357 The Yankee first baseman had a home run and double against Boston to finish at .352, compared to Wade Boggs's .357. SportsMonday, page C3. Oil Output Talks Start The 13 OPEC members meet today in Geneva to try to extend a two-month accord to restrain production to help stabilize oil prices. Page D1.

title: Irish Jockey Sets Paris Race Record
description: Dancing Brave of Britain, ridden by Pat Eddery of Ireland, staged a late rally today to win the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe at Longchamp in record-setting time.

title: U.S. CHARGES AIDES TO LaROUCHE WITH CREDIT-CARD FRAUD SCHEME
description: Ten key associates of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. were indicted today on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges as hundreds of law-enforcement agents raided the political extremist's headquarters in Virginia.

title: FEELING OF CONTROL VIEWED AS CENTRAL IN MENTAL HEALTH
description: THE feeling of being in control, of having a say over what happens in one's life, has far-reaching consequences for physical and mental health, for achievement at school and work, and even for sex, researchers are finding.

title: Lucky Stores Rejects Offer From Edelman
description: The board of Lucky Stores Inc. rejected a $35-a-share offer yesterday from Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, and said it would investigate various restructuring options.

title: Power Shortage
description: If this was the season of the lively ball, sombody forgot to tell these guys.

title: INDIA'S BELEAGUERED PHONE SYSTEM
description: Late one steamy night this summer, a well-known Indian politician picked up his pistol and stormed into a neighborhood telephone office, demanding to know why his call to Bombay had not gone through.

title: POPE, IN ADDRESS TO CLERGY IN FRANCE, SAYS LAITY SHOULD NOT PERFORM PRIESTLY TASKS
description: Pope John Paul II said today that some of the most serious problems of Roman Catholicism were a result of the vigorous internal debate in the church in the last two decades.

title: 2 TV Stations Acquired
description: Home Shopping Network Inc. said it had completed the acquisitions of the broadcasting assets of two UHF television stations, WWHT, Channel 68, in Newark, and WSNL, Channel 67, in Smithtown, L.I. The company said it had started full-time broadcasting of its programming on the stations.

title: NEW DEMANDS STRAINING CITY'S HOSPITALS
description: The general level of care in New York City hospitals is still regarded as among the best in the world. But the stress caused by the rapidly changing needs and demands in the hospitals is resulting in treatment that in some cases does more harm than good.

title: STATE DEPT. OPPOSED U.S. EFFORTS TO CUT SOVIET PRESENCE, AIDES SAY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz initially opposed the expulsion of 25 members of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations whom the United States identified as intelligence operatives, according to Administration officials.

title: Strangled Man Was a Judge
description: A strangling victim found in Central Park last week has been identified as a former state prosecutor who, for the past year, served as an administrative law judge in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: Senate Passes Measure On Intelligence Work
description: The Senate today passed and sent to President Reagan an intelligence bill that includes provisions the Central Intelligence Agency has called an unwarranted interference in its work.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS OFFER A WELCOME TO BATS
description: SO far, the effort to safeguard bats has been a lonely one.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago Previous Year In Percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 7.50 7.50 9.50 DISCOUNT RATE 5.50 5.50 7.50 FEDERAL FUNDS 5.75 5.79 7.80 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 5.05 5.03 7.07 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 5.15 5.13 7.30 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 7.05 7.10 10.26 30-

title: DIFFICULT CHOICE ON DRUGS AND DEATH PENALTY
description: The anti-drug bill that passed the Senate last week has created a dilemma for the Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives, which must decide within the next day or two how to deal with the politically charged issue of the death penalty.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS IT DOWNED PLANE WITH 4 U.S. CREWMEN, KILLING 3
description: The Defense Ministry said tonight that a rebel supply plane had been shot down in southern Nicaragua and that the sole survivor had identified himself as an American military adviser in El Salvador.

title: COSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes $280,000, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of the company's ribbon printer cartridge assets for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE HARVEST OF SORROW. Soviet Collectivization and the Terror-Famine.

title: 'WITNESS TO APARTHEID,' FILM ON 13
description: ''Witness to Apartheid,'' which will be telecast today on Channel 13 at 11 P.M., was shown as part of the New Directors/New Films series last April. Following are excerpts from a review by Walter Goodman.

title: IN FIGHTING DRUG TRAFFIC, ATTITUDE WINS THE AID
description: Holding meetings in a luxury-hotel suite here last week, surrounded by aides, armed guards at the doors, the Prime Minister of the Bahamas worked a pointer over a map of his archipelago that rested on a Louis XVI-style armchair.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings and shares outstanding are fuly diluted.

title: PINIELLA'S FUTURE LOOKING BRIGHTER
description: About a month ago, Lou Piniella had one foot planted firmly on the George Steinbrenner scrapheap of managers. Now, however, Piniella is on the verge of receiving another contract as manager of the Yankees.

title: Official Fights Ouster by City
description: The former budget director of the City Buildings Department denied yesterday that he had attended late-night parties at which staff members used marijuana and cocaine. The official, Michael Futterman, was dismissed from his $37,080-a-year job Sept. 25, along with other employees.

title: Teaching New York the Facts of Life
description: New York City's children take early sex for granted. More than 14,000 adolescent girls have babies each year and nearly twice as many abort or miscarry.

title: HISTORIC CASE ON RIGHTS IS REOPENED IN TOPEKA
description: Lawyers opened court maneuvers today in a new phase of Brown v. Board of Education, the historic case that 32 years ago ended legally sanctioned segregation of schools in the United States.

title: 3 HELD IN LEBANON ACCUSE PARIS ON TAPE
description: A video recording of three French hostages kidnapped in Lebanon more than a year ago was received by an international news agency in Moslem West Beirut today.

title: A Niche for Creationism
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. ROADS: TIE-UPS DEFY SOLUTION
description: Long Island's highways, already the most crowded in the New York suburban area, are becoming dramatically more congested each year, and neither a short-term nor a long-term solution is in sight.

title: FETUS RETURNED TO WOMB FOLLOWING SURGERY
description: In a pioneering operation, a team of California surgeons has removed a 23-week-old fetus from his mother's womb, successfully operated to correct a blocked urinary tract and then returned the unborn baby to the uterus and sewed the womb back up.

title: India Seeks Carbide Order
description: The Indian Government today asked an Indian court to bar the Union Carbide Corporation from destroying evidence relating to the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: Oxford First
description: The Oxford First Corporation, a financial services company, said unresolved issues threatened its proposed acquisition by the Banc One Corporation of Ohio. The deal, to be accomplished through an exchange of stock, had been valued at about $77 million. Oxford said negotiations to resolve the issues were continuing and that its board had called a special meeting for Tuesday.

title: SEEBURG PHONOGRAPH reports earnings for Year to June 30
CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to include poolings of interests of acquired banks and a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 1.

title: NETWORK CONTROL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ROZELLE IS CRITICIZED OVER INSTANT REPLAY
description: Tex Schramm, the president of the Dallas Cowboys and the driving force behind the National Football League's replay system, blamed Commissioner Pete Rozelle yesterday for the problems in the replay system, including the ''communications breakdown'' that led to a touchdown awarded in error to the Los Angeles Raiders Sunday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates Inc., Boston, said it had suspended coal-mining operations at its Powderhorn Mine in Grand Junction, Colo., laying off about 80 percent of the its 205 employees there.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MORTGAGE RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Mortgage rates fell sharply in September, to the levels of last spring, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. It was the third consecutive decline and the first time since May that both fixed- and adjustable-rate mortgages declined.

title: Pactel Unit Gets Chief
description: The Pacific Telesis Group said today that S. Ross Brown has been named president and chief executive of Pacific Telesis International, the telephone operating company's international business arm, which markets telecommunications and information systems and services through subsidiary companies in Korea, Japan, Thailand, Spain and Britain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1986
description: Companies

title: Revlon Deal Set For Frigitronics
description: The Revlon Group agreed to buy Frigitronics Inc. after increasing its bid for the eye-wear products company to $34.50 a share, from $33.50, or a total of about $111.8 million.

title: PARLEY SET TODAY ON DESIGN CHANGE IN JET ENGINE
description: Concerned by the fourth in a series of similar engine failures on Airbus A-310 jetliners, Pratt & Whitney, the engine maker, has invited the airlines to an urgent conference today to discuss a proposed design change to help deal with the hazard.

title: Children's Height Linked to Test Scores
description: Tall children score slightly higher on intelligence tests and perform somewhat better academically than their shorter classmates, perhaps because more is expected of them, researchers have found.

title: Marc Wilson Hurt
description: Marc Wilson, the Los Angeles Raider quarterback, has a swollen right thumb and may miss Sunday's game against the Seattle Seahawks. . . . Two Pittsburgh Steeler running backs, Frank Pollard and David Hughes, underwent arthroscopic knee surgery yesterday. Both will be sidelined indefinitely.

title: METS ARE SIZING UP THEIR STRENGTHS
description: The Mets flew to Houston yesterday in high spirits and said they were absolutely ready to open the playoff for the National League pennant Wednesday night against the Astros. But Manager Dave Johnson predicted, ''It'll be a dogfight.''

title: Collateralized Issue From West Coast
description: Santa Barbara Funding 1 Inc. is offering $375 million of collateralized mortgage obligations in four parts through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: INQUIRY A NEW TEST FOR QUEENS JUDGE
description: Francis X. Smith, the Queens administrative judge, learned long ago that a cardinal rule of Queens politics is to stand by your friends in times of trouble. Justice Smith stood by Matthew Troy. He stood by William J. Brennan. And he stood by Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: A VOTE FOR METS AND RED SOX
description: When the Houston Astros were in a brief slump several weeks ago, day by day their lead in the National League West was shrinking. But their eminent baseball philosopher, Yogi Berra, was not disturbed.

title: ATTACKS ON JAPAN'S EMBASSIES UP
description: Bombings and other attacks against Japanese embassies and overseas missions have increased dramatically in the last two years, the Government said today.

title: SUDBURY HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-After tax credits of $963,000 for the latest quarter and $885,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Topics: Vital Signs, Road Signs; Watch This Space
description: Highway Beautification, the well-intentioned 1965 law championed by Lady Bird Johnson, has flopped, and the House and Senate disagree about how to improve it. The Senate's approach promises to accomplish more.

title: MILAN PREDICTS A SOFT AND BREEZY SUMMER
description: Six months from now fashion's most avid followers will turn in their skin-tight black leather skirts for flaring, buoyant skirts propped by petticoats. They will also be wearing belts just under the bosom instead of at the waist. Almost all the Italian designers showing their spring and summer collections have gaily adopted the full skirt, often flounced and ruffled, as well as the high-waisted Empire line.

title: Boxing Problems
description: Many young boxers have serious eye injuries that should keep them out of the ring, says a study, released yesterday, which calls for the sport to require mandatory annual eye examinations. Dr. David J. Smith of the Wills Eye Hospital in Philadelphia said a study of 166 professional boxers examined before they fought in Atlantic City showed that 34 had significant eye problems.

title: SENATE VOTES TO STRENGTHEN LAW ON ASSURING SAFETY OF PESTICIDES
description: The Senate voted tonight to extend and strengthen the law protecting the public and the environment from chemical pesticides.

title: KOCH SUPPORTS SCHOOLS' ROLE IN BIRTH CONTROL
description: Mayor Koch, the New York City teachers' union and a leading Protestant church group expressed support yesterday for the distribution of contraceptives at nine high-school health clinics.

title: Icahn Takes Exception To Lack of Recognition
description: When Carl C. Icahn was omitted from a list of the big financial newsmakers of 1985, he asked reporters why.

title: Oil-Tax Fears in Venezuela
description: President Jaime Lusinchi has criticized a proposed United States tax on imported oil, saying that it represents a protectionist act that could seriously damage the economy of Venezuala and other oil-exporting nations.

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $515,000, or 5 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $199,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Hasidic Schoolboy Case Is Only Slightly About Sex Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Rubber Talks Resume
description: Negotiators from 50 nations resumed talks today on a new agreement to stabilize rubber prices, and the conference president said he was optimistic an agreement would be reached in the two-week meeting.

title: Bad Rap
description: Have you heard about the rap-music number being popularized on Milwaukee radio stations? It's called ''The Pack Rap Attack,'' and the opening lyrics go this way: We're the Green Bay Packers, We're green and gold.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: People will tell you Milan is the Pittsburgh of Italy, but then, they will also tell you the check is in the mail. Although the brightest lights of fashion here tend to work in the subdued dark tones of this industrial city, there is a new mood encouraged by Italy's economic recovery. A wall bears the graffito ''Basta grigio!'' ''Enough gray!'' And Milan's new ebullience is reflected in this week's incredible outpouring of new style ideas.

title: Miami Detectives Held; Corruption Trial Opens
description: Two police detectives were arrested today as part of the Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry into the Miami Police Department. They are charged with shooting into the home of a drug dealer cooperating with the Federal authorities.

title: Story of an Unclaimed Bank Deposit, Continued
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSISTENCY BREEDS HITS
description: To some, Wade Boggs is the mechanical man. Batters are forever changing their styles and techniques. Not Boggs. Not at all. Boggs, who hit .357 this season to win his third American League batting title in the four seasons he has been eligible, doesn't just step into the batter's box, he inserts himself into it.

title: Protesters Urge Gov. Dukakis To Free 4 Convicted of Rape
description: Thousands of Portuguese-Americans attended a rally Sunday to urge Gov. Michael S. Dukakis to free four men convicted of raping a woman on a pool table at Big Dan's tavern in 1983.

title: AGENDA: OCT. 7, 1986
description: Chief Judge Prods Albany Sol Wachtler to make urgent plea to Governor and Legislature for a special session to create new judgeships. Backlog of drug cases in Criminal Court is being temporarily handled by 20 Civil Court judges. Legislation to add permanent seats has been caught in political cross fire. 11 A.M. news conference, 100 Centre Street, Manhattan Dissident Speaks After a day out of the spotlight, Yuri F. Orlov and his wife, Irina L. Valitova, will talk of plans for life in the United States and of friends who remain in the Soviet Union. Physicist, who spent years in labor camps, gained freedom as part of deal to release American correspondent. Noon news conference, Grand Hyatt Hotel, Manhattan Politics Republicans on the TownLast month, when Andrew P. O'Rourke took his gubernatorial campaign to midtown Manhattan, he bused in Westchester supporters, concerned that the sluggish local organization would not deliver. Back at same site today, at rally organized by county committee, he hopes for a better turnout. 6:30 P.M., Roosevelt Hotel, Manhattan Proceedings Friedman TrialGeoffrey G. Lindenauer, Government's key witness in city corruption trial, will be questioned about his admitted sexual relations with psychotherapy patients. During second day of cross-examination, he will also be asked about a lucrative towing contract. 9:30 A.M., Federal Court House, Church Street, New Haven Landmark for a 'Palace'?A. T. Stewart's ''Marble Palace'' emporium at 280 Broadway, near Canal Street, later home to The Sun newspaper, is under consideration for landmark status. 9:30 A.M., Landmarks Preservation Commission, 20 Vesey Street, Manhattan Donovan TapesBronx prosecutors to present what they consider their most damaging evidence against Raymond J. Donovan, former Labor Secretary.

title: A HOUSE PROPOSAL WOULD DELAY RIFT OVER ARMS ISSUES
description: The majority leader of the House of Representatives said today that House Democrats were ready to delay a resolution of arms-control issues to avoid tying President Reagan's hands before he meets with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: CONSTANCE H. GETZ
description: Constance Hinman Getz, a horticulturist who was director of the Greenwich (Conn.) Garden Center and the Greenwich Garden Club, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday at Princeton (N.J.) Hospital.

title: NANCY HANKS CENTER DEDICATED IN THE CAPITAL
description: Nancy Hanks was remembered today by the actress Helen Hayes as a woman who ''could perform miracles'' in her role as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts from 1969 to 1977.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE GILLIES, BOURNE
description: The Islanders lost two of the symbols of their best years yesterday when Clark Gillies and Bob Bourne were both picked up during the annual waiver draft of the National Hockey League.

title: 'Playing It For History'
description: As Presidents approach the end of their terms in office, they tend to become preoccupied with the last campaign available to them: the one to insure their election by the historians of the future into the ranks of All-Time Great Leaders. This now seems to be happening to Ronald Reagan.

title: SOVIET TO CODIFY GORBACHEV OVERHAUL
description: The Soviet Government has announced a plan of legislation for the next five years to codify Mikhail S. Gorbachev's blueprint for the reconstruction of Soviet society.

title: Judith Hancock Plays Organ at St. Thomas
description: The most vivid moments of Judith Hancock's brief organ recital at St. Thomas Church on Sunday afternoon belonged to Charles Tournemire's ''Fantasie-Improvisation sur l'Ave maris stella.'' Tournemire, who died at the outset of World War II, was a French organist and Catholic mystic, and in this piece the organ is made to shimmer and undulate in the manner of a French Impressionist orchestra.

title: Killer Bees and Other Urgencies
description: When senators call their appropriations bill an omnibus bill, they mean it. It includes a last-minute addition of $1 million to save America from killer bees. The House bill, a slightly bigger omnibus, also includes measures that have nothing to do with orderly appropriations or cutting deficits - like a measure to protect America's shorelines from foreign-made oil rigs.

title: Peres Attacks Report On Israeli A-Arms
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that a report describing his country as the sixth-ranked nuclear power was ''sensationalist.''

title: 2 MINI-SERIES TO LOOK AT SAME KILLING
description: In a mini-series tug-of-war, two networks have pounced on the same racy murder, and both have refused to let go.

title: Microsoft Sees Earnings Rise
description: The Microsoft Corporation, a leading producer of personal computer software, based in Redmond, Wash., said today that it expects to report earnings in excess of $15 million, or about 55 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, more than double the $6.2 million, or 26 cents a share, earned in the comparable period a year ago.

title: BRIBERY IS CHARGED OVER PARKING FINES IN CITY AND CHICAGO
description: Federal officials here today charged Bernard Sandow, a New York business executive, with conspiracy and mail fraud, alleging that bribes were paid in Chicago and New York City to get business for his company.

title: 'ALTERNATIVE' PAPER, 2 DECADES OLD, DONS BLACK TIE
description: The Boston Phoenix, in its origins a prototype of the ''alternative'' weekly and enfant terrible of a rather proper city, does not want to be an adolescent any more.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PACIFIC NATIONS, AT U.S., CRITICIZE FRENCH POLICIES
description: Pacific island nations, speaking in the General Assembly, continued to criticize France today for its failure to grant independence to New Caledonia and for its nuclear testing in the region.

title: UNESCO'S CHIEF, UNDER ATTACK, BARS A 3D TERM
description: Unesco's Director General, who has been at the center of a dispute over how the organization has been run, said today that he would not seek a third term of office.

title: ORBITING AND GROUND TELESCOPES TEAMED
description: SIGNALS from a radio telescope orbiting in space have been combined for the first time with simultaneous observations in Australia and Japan to produce radio images of unsurpassed sharpness.

title: Advertising; New Face at Margeotes
description: Joanne Ambrose, who has 14 years of sales promotion experience, has joined Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss to run its new subsidiary, Strategic Marketing Alternatives. It will be available to handle the sales promotion needs of agency clients and other promotion-conscious companies.

title: CITY STUDIES PLAN TO USE TWO FERRIES FOR INMATES
description: The Koch administration, faced with severe overcrowding in city jails, is considering housing prisoners in two retired Staten Island ferryboats.

title: KASPAROV, WITH A DRAW, KEEPS HIS TITLE
description: Gary Kasparov remained alone atop the chess world tonight when Anatoly Karpov, the rival from whom he wrested the championship 11 months ago, agreed to a draw that ended his hopes to regain the title.

title: Why U.S. National Guardsmen Train in Honduras
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA ANGELS VS. RED SOX, at Boston, first game of American League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.; Radio - WCBS, 880, 8:00 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 1 P.M and 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: Rates Steady in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, as Treasury securities dealers said demand for short-term issues was good, while investor interest in long-term bonds was weak.

title: MAN TIED TO WHITE SUPREMACISTS FACES CHARGES IN IDAHO BOMBINGS
description: A man linked to the Aryan Nations white supremacist group was arrested and charged today in recent bombings that the Federal Bureau of Investigation said were set as a diversion for planned bank robberies.

title: RHNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 'UNOFFICIAL' ARTIST'S LIFE IN RUSSIA
description: They were all there in the current show at the new exhibition center of the Tretyakov Gallery: abstract works of the Constructivist Lyubov Popova and the Expressionist Vasily Kandinsky and early paintings of the Russian-born giant Marc Chagall. Once heretical deviations from the cult of Socialist Realism, the canvases are now an accepted part of the Soviet cultural heritage.

title: COURT SELECTS 22 CASES FOR NEW TERM
description: Opening its new term today, the Supreme Court agreed to decide whether Jews, Arabs and members of other minority groups who do not belong to distinct nonwhite races may bring racial discrimination suits under an 1866 civil rights law.

title: HOSTILE TONES FOR A FRIENDSHIP ARCH
description: When the scaffolding is cleared in November, the Chinese arch with the greatest span in the world will straddle a street that is not in Peking or Shanghai, but in Washington.

title: LARGENT, JOINER SET RECEPTION RECORDS
description: Steve Largent of the Seattle Seahawks and Charlie Joiner of the San Diego Chargers set National Football League receiving records tonight, as the Seahawks routed the Chargers, 33-7.

title: EVALUATING THE CROP OF STATISTICAL SOFTWARE
description: AFTER the appearance of last week's column on statistical software, I received a number of calls from people who had been looking for statistical programs but who had been unable to find what they needed. Typical was a call from the mother of a student in Australia who had asked her to send him a copy of Systat. One of the three programs selected by the General Accounting Office as the best of the current crop, Systat is also one of the better known.

title: Massachusetts Agency Arranges Bond Backing
description: The Massachusetts Industrial Finance Authority has arranged for the Rabobank Nederland to provide a $50 million letter of credit for new industrial development bonds issued by the authority on behalf of small businesses in the state.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 7, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Negotiations
description: In the Middle East war in 1973, over 1,800 Israeli soldiers were killed and several times that number wounded. Its blood banks depleted, Israel turned to the the League of Red Cross Societies, and with the assistance of the Shah of Iran, got the blood it needed.

title: SPECIALTY RETAIL CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect the dilution resulting from the issuance of 647,000 common shares in conjunction with initial public offering and the exercise of stock warrants.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about union opposition to the proposed takeover of Eastern Air Lines by the Texas Air Corporation misstated the rights of Texas Air to vote its stock on the matter. The airline can vote its 51 percent holding.

title: IF NOTHING EVER HAPPENS, IT'S ICELAND
description: When President Reagan arrives here later this week for talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he will glimpse a country that, to many Americans, would seem a latter-day Arcadia - a land of pristine air and lakes, general prosperity and carefree security.

title: ICAHN BIDS $8 BILLION FOR USX
description: Carl C. Icahn offered to acquire the USX Corporation yesterday for about $8 billion in cash.

title: ACQUITTED FEDERAL JUDGE EXPECTS IMPEACHMENT
description: When Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings was acquitted of bribery in 1983, he said he somehow knew it would not be the end of the matter.

title: Acid Rain in the West
description: Sulfur dioxide emissions in the American West, most from copper smelters in Arizona and other southwestern states, peaked in 1981 and then fell drastically along with the fortunes of the lagging world copper market. As emissions fell, so too did the acidity of rain hundreds of miles downwind in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Derrough Quits as Head Of a TV Division at CBS
description: Neil E. Derrough, president of the CBS stations division, which is responsible for the management of the network's four owned and operated television stations, resigned yesterday, CBS officials said.

title: NEW MARCHING ORDERS FOR AN 'INDECENT' BAND
description: When Tom Duffy was hired as a music professor five years ago, one of his assignments was to bring the Yale marching band's football halftime shows under control. ''The band used to have an unwritten code,'' said Professor Duffy. ''They'd do one phallic symbol per show.''

title: Walker Plea Bargain
description: At loggerheads for nearly a year, the Navy and the Justice Department have agreed to meet soon to try to iron out differences over the plea bargain reached with John A. Walker Jr. in his espionage case.

title: TODD RETURNS TO JETS
description: The Jets did some extraordinary quarterback juggling today when they learned that Ken O'Brien's injured knee probably would keep him out of the Patriots game next Sunday.

title: Armstrong Rubber Has Talks on Plant
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company said a management group represented by Marigold Enterprises Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., had expressed interest in buying Armstrong's truck tire manufacturing plant in Natchez, Miss.

title: RESEARCHERS FIND IMPORTANT FACTOR IN BLOOD GROWTH
description: AFTER a three-year search, researchers in Massachusetts have discovered an important human blood growth factor that some scientists thought did not exist.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for 13wks to July 31
description: All amounts are in Canadian dollars.

title: One Heck Of an Engineer
