description: Today marks the 70th anniversary of the most lopsided game in American football history, Georgia Tech's 222-0 demolition of a rag-tag squad from Cumberland College of Lebanon, Tenn., and only one of the victors is alive to tell about it. He's George Griffin, who played quarterback for the 1916 Rambling Wrecks before extending his Tech career in the posts of assistant football coach, mathematics instructor, assistant dean of students, dean of students (1946-64) and now dean emeritus.

title: Market Place; Energy Stocks: Analysts Split
description: ENERGY stocks, bolstered by the prospect of continued crude oil price stability, appear ready for a further move up, according to several analysts who follow the industry. Other experts, however, contend that oil issues are overvalued and that any improvement in the price of crude oil has already been discounted.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the 1986 results include a fourth quarter $9.4 million after-tax gain related to the July initial public offering by its consumer electronics subsidiary, Commtron Corp. The shares outstanding and share earnings give effect to the 5 percent stock dividend declared Dec. 18, 1985.

title: TAKEOVERS ONE OF ISSUES HIGH COURT WILL DECIDE
description: The Supreme Court agreed to consider the validity of an Indiana law restricting hostile takeovers of Indiana corporations and several other important business cases today, the beginning of its 1986-87 term.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
EUROPE SHRUGS AT REPORTS OF NEWS DECEPTION
description: The Reagan Administration's reported resort to a policy of deception to throw Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya off balance has aroused little hostile press commentary and no perceptible protest among West European allies of the United States.

title: EXTREMIST FINDS CABLE TV IS FORUM FOR RIGHT-WING VIEWS
description: Rules that require cable television systems to offer access to local residents are enabling a former Ku Klux Klan leader here to promulgate his racist and radical views in a number of towns and cities around the country.

title: SOVIET SCIENTISTS OFTEN THWARTED
description: Soviet scientists have matched or surpassed their Western counterparts in a few areas, particularly those affecting the military, but they are hampered in applying new technologies and discoveries by professional rivalry, lack of equipment, inadequate computer systemsand scientific conservatism, according to new assessments.

title: Prufrock Owners Chose 'Sellout' Over Offering
description: After meeting in a bar in Dallas in 1971, Philip E. Cobb and E. Gene Street discovered that they had two interests in common: restaurants and poetry. Within weeks they raised $13,500, and started Prufrock Restaurants Inc. with a bar called J. Alfred's.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY DEAL AT EASTMAN KODAK
description: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company, said today that it had entered into an agreement with the Eastman Kodak Company to gain increased production capability for Snomax, a bacteria that induces the formation of snow and ice.

title: Stephen P. Barry Dies at 37; Was Valet to Prince Charles
description: Stephen P. Barry, who served as personal valet of Prince Charles for 12 years until 1981 and reputedly earned $1 million from writing about those years, died at a London hospital, the hospital reported today. He was 37.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Hong Kong Stocks Fall
description: Hong Kong stock prices tumbled today as the British colony's unified stock exchange was formally opened. The Hang Seng index fell 50 points, to 2,084.93, the biggest one-day drop since July 1984. Brokers attributed the decline to profit taking and a technical correction after the market rose for 11 consecutive days.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on the Music page of the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday gave an incorrect time for the Juilliard String Quartet's concert at Alice Tully Hall. The time on Saturday is 3 P.M.

title: BANCO DE PONCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUTISM: A THEORY FROM TOKYO
description: A DOCTOR at the New England Medical Center, working with educators and other physicians, is adopting for a school near here an unorthodox approach developed in Japan for the treatment of autism.

title: NOT BECOMING SOFT ON SOVIET, PRESIDENT SAYS.
description: President Reagan, responding defensively to conservative criticism, said today that he was opening negotiations with Michael S. Gorbachev ''without illusions'' about the Soviet Union.

title: 2 COMEDY PROGRAMS, ON HBO AND SHOWTIME
description: PAY cable has had some of its more notable programming successes with comedy and comics, establishing a kind of ''borscht belt'' of its own. The rush to humor continues with two new shows: Elayne Boosler in ''Party of One,'' on Showtime tonight at 10, and ''Really Weird Tales,'' a Home Box Office spoof of television anthologies not unlike ''The Twilight Zone'' and ''Amazing Stories.'' The first half-hour episode can be seen this evening at 10:30.

title: Camacho Arrested
description: Hector Camacho, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, was arrested in New York City yesterday on a series of vehicular charges, including reckless driving and driving without a license, police said.

title: I.B.M. and Intel Trade Rights
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Intel Corporation today announced a technology exchange agreement that will catapult Intel into the business of making semi-customized computer chips.

title: U.S. Embassy Aide Is Barred At the Johannesburg Airport
description: A white policeman barred a black United States Government employee from an airport lounge and then pushed the American Consul General when he protested, a newspaper reported today.

title: Topics: Vital Signs, Road Signs; Fair Chance at Life
description: Few of the thousands of Americans waiting for organ transplants are as fortunate as the daughter of Senator Jake Garn. She needed a kidney; her father gave one.

title: ORGANISMS PROLIFERATE IN REACTOR VESSEL
description: Algae, yeast, bacteria and fungi are reproducing so fast in the contaminated vessel at the Three Mile Island Nuclear Power Plant that they are impairing efforts to clean up the stricken plant, officials report.

title: Reagans to Sponsor Series of Radio Concerts
description: President and Mrs. Reagan will sponsor a new concert series this season, to be presented on the Public Broadcasting System and performed by American artists, the White House announced today.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 2.

title: American's Trial Ends In Yugoslav Court
description: The trial of an ethnic Albanian with dual United States-Yugoslav citizenship on charges of anti-Yugoslav activity and propaganda ended today and the verdict will be announced Wednesday, court sources said.

title: Dow Up 10.27 in Very Light Trading
description: Prices rose yesterday on Wall Street, but the big news was the low volume of stock that changed hands as investors, not knowing whether the nation's economy is improving or slowing, turned from participants into spectators.

title: Do as I Say, Not as I Do
description: The reason the National Health Council serves meals of dubious nutritional quality at its breakfast briefings, officials maintain, is that the large group of health professionals attending the sessions prefer such food. Last week, for example, when Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, spoke, the menu offered its customary broad array of calories, cholesterol and nitrites: eggs, sausage, fried potatoes and pastries.

title: JETS TAKE GOOD LOOK IN MIRROR
description: The Buffalo Bills weren't the only team scouting the Jets last week. The Jets were scouting themselves. They always do. The idea is to find out if they are telegraphing what they are doing. If so, how do they trick the other team?

title: CITY OPERA: JOHN CHEEK AS MEFISTOFELE
description: BOITO'S ''Mefistofele'' is one of the New York City Opera's older productions, but judging from its enthusiastic reception Sunday night, it remains high among the company's successes.

title: Jury Selection on DeLorean
description: The task of selecting a jury to try John DeLorean on Federal racketeering, fraud and tax charges began here today.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Event in Florida Was the Longest Ever Held
description: The longest Swiss Team event ever played anywhere occurred during the world championships in Miami Beach last month. It ran concurrently with the Rosenblum Knockout event, and served several purposes: accommodating teams ineligible for the main event; giving them, and losers in the knockout, a chance, albeit a slim one, to rejoin the main event, and determining the bronze medal winners.

title: INSIDE
description: Americans Reported Killed Nicaragua said that it had downed a rebel supply plane and that three American crew members were killed.

title: Shuttle Tests Set At Launch Pad
description: The space agency will move the shuttle Atlantis to a launch pad Tuesday for seven weeks of tests, the first since the Challenger accident in January.

title: El Paso Utility Offering Bonds
description: The El Paso Electric Company is offering $311 million of 10 3/4 percent lease obligation bonds due in 2013 at par through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HISPANIC PERSPECTIVE ''A Decade of En Foco'' is an exhibition of photographs at the Bronx Museum of the Arts by members of En Foco, an organization of photographers, most of whom are Hispanic. En Foco promotes the work of Hispanic photographers and provides a setting for the exchange of information and ideas. Twelve years ago it organized its first exhibition, ''En Foco Documentation Portfolio N1, The New York Puerto Rican Experience.''

title: Wives at Reykjavik? Only One, It Seems
description: The White House expressed surprise today that Raisa M. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader's wife, was planning to attend the meeting this weekend in Iceland. Nancy Reagan is not scheduled to accompany her husband.

title: Advertising; Apple Returns To Screen
description: TO make sure that it is noticed when it returns to television after a year's absence, Apple Computer has had its new agency produce 11 commercials using the talents of three top directors and about $6 million for production.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How do spiders build webs between objects that are far apart? A. Spiders use the wind and convection currents to carry their silk lines to far-away objects, according to Dr. Hubert W. Levi, a professor of zoology at Harvard University. For example, Dr. Levi said a spider sits on a leaf, raises its abdominals, and releases a line of silk from its spinneretes.

title: Soviet Still Seeks Total Nuclear-Test Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: MENDING FINANCIAL SAFETY NET
description: Recognizing that the nation's banks and securities firms are exposed to far more risk than ever before, Federal regulators are beginning the complex and lengthy process of overhauling their control system.

title: HASIDIC SCHOOLBOY CASE IS ONLY SLIGHTLY ABOUT SEX DESCRIMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 6 Workers Suspended After Making Threats
description: At least six Dallas area postal workers have been suspended and ordered to undergo psychiatric examinations after threatening to emulate an Oklahoma mail carrier who killed 14 people before killing himself, officials said.

title: Pizzolato Back
description: It was a windy day here yesterday and Orlando Pizzolato of Italy was in town hoping that it would not be that way for the Nov. 2 New York City Marathon, which he will be trying to win for the third straight year.

title: Intellectual Property
description: America is a nation apparently possessed with the pursuit of a better mousetrap. Today a group named Intellectual Property Owners will gather to pay homage to the quest.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday about tenants' efforts to buy a performing arts building at 890 Broadway misstated expenditures by two tenants on improvements there.

title: STAGE: 'NIGHT OF IGUANA,' AT HARTMAN IN STAMFORD
description: THE Hartman Theater is doing more than justice to ''The Night of the Iguana,''

title: ANGELS
description: To some, even the suggestion that Reggie Jackson could make a difference in the American League playoffs is patently absurd. But remember, this is Mr. October - a man in the ninth inning of a magnificant career. Is there a better stage for him than this?

title: Salomon Unit Sells A 4-Part Offering
description: A $138.5 million four-part offering of collateralized mortgage obligations issued by the Home Mac Mortgage Securities Corporation is under way through a synicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The obligations, rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P., are backed mostly by Government National Mortgage Association pass-through securities.

title: VW's New U.S. Model
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. began production of its Jetta sedan at its Westmoreland County assembly plant today. It is the second Volkwagen model to be built in the United States, after the Golf, in production since 1984. Jettas have been imported into the United States since 1980.

title: Shell Oil Sets Yield Of Notes at 7.67%
description: The Shell Oil Company is offering $250 million of 7 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.75, to yield 7.67 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: BANKAMERICA GETS A TAKEOVER OFFER
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the California banking company that has staggered from loan loss to loan loss, said today that it had received a formal offer to be acquired by a bank less than half its size.

title: Yale Urged to Aid Developers
description: Mayor Biagio DiLieto has renewed a plea to Yale University for the school to set aside ''a small part'' of its $1.76 billion endowment to establish a fund for low-interest loans to city developers. The Mayor made the suggestion in an address today to about 115 members of the Yale Club.

title: ROBERT F. SIX, FOUNDER OF AIRLINE AND AVIATION PIONEER, DIES AT 79
description: Robert F. Six, the founder of Continental Airlines and a pioneer in commercial aviation who came of age in an era of open cockpits, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article yesterday about speakers at the New York Public Library gave an incorrect date for a lecture by Romare Bearden. He will appear on Nov. 5, not Oct. 15.

title: It's Doctors vs. Patients In Malpractice-Suit Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Montreal Canadiens have lost their captain, Bob Gainey, for eight to 12 weeks as a result of a torn knee ligament the left wing suffered in a preseason game. . . . George Scherger ended a 20-year association with the Cincinnati Reds by retiring as a coach at the age of 65.

title: Iraq Plea on Loan Seen
description: Iraq, whose economy has been severely affected by its war with Iran and the slump in oil prices, has asked banks to reschedule a $500 million loan, banking sources said today. Baghdad made the request after advising banks that it was unable to make a principal payment of $71.25 million on the loan, due at the end of last month. Iraq's total debt is estimated at about $50 billion.

title: REAGAN-LED PARTY SHIFT AIDING HOUSE HOPEFULS
description: President Reagan's continuing popularity is not transferring directly to Republican Congressional candidates, but the political sea change toward the Republican Party that Mr. Reagan set in motion in 1980 is clearly helping them in this fall's elections, The New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax benefit of $88,000.

title: JACKSON PRESENTS TEST FOR CLEMENS
description: Roger Clemens, who has been Mr. Momentum for the Boston Red Sox the past six months, may face his most critical task of the season here Tuesday night when he encounters Mr. October, Reggie Jackson.

title: METS REQUESTING EXTRA SECURITY FOR POSTSEASON
description: The New York Mets and the city are negotiating to keep history - at least selected parts of it - from repeating itself.

title: CODDLING THE IRATE WRITER
description: ALL you want to do is write a nasty letter to the editor.

title: TRIPLE CROWN SETS $3.5 MILLION BONUS
description: The next horse who wins throughbred racing's Triple Crown will earn a guaranteed $5 million through a package of bonuses announced yesterday by track officials.

title: DANCE: BALLET WEST IN A MIXED BILL
description: Ballet West demonstrated its versatility on Friday night at the Kennedy Center by offering a mixed bill that included two choreographically distinguished and stylistically challenging ballets: ''The Dream,'' Sir Frederick Ashton's airy adaptation of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' and Eugene Loring's earthy ''Billy the Kid.''

title: Lurie's Lounge Lizards Perform at Bottom Line
description: John Lurie should be feeling pretty pleased with himself these days. Most folks would be perfectly content with the widespread critical acclaim that has greeted his starring roles in the films ''Stranger Than Paradise'' and ''Down by Law.'' But Mr. Lurie seems equally determined to make the Lounge Lizards, the engagingly loopy band he founded with his brother Evan, a musical force to be reckoned with.

title: Business and Health; Mental Health Costs Soaring
description: IN the push to cope with drug and alcohol abuse, many employers have drifted into a twilight zone of uncontrolled costs. Large companies are spending 7 to 15 percent of health-care dollars on psychiatric care, with drug and alcohol cases absorbing more than a third of this. These costs are rising steeply, even as health-care cost containment in general takes hold. ''Psychiatric care is obviously out of control,'' says Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health-care analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.

title: DARTMOUTH'S EMBATTLED PRESIDENT SAYS HE WILL STEP DOWN
description: David T. McLaughlin, the president of Dartmouth College, announced today that he would step down from his post at the end of the academic year.

title: DR. RUDOLF FLESCH, 75, AUTHORITY ON LITERACY
description: Dr. Rudolf Flesch, the authority on literacy and clear writing who wrote ''Why Johnny Can't Read,'' died at Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital Sunday night of congestive heart failure. . He was 75 years old.

title: Careers; Mining Beckons Engineers
description: DESPITE the economic difficulties of the mining industry in the United States, the Colorado School of Mines, in Golden, Colo., sees good job potential for the many kinds of engineers it produces.

title: WHEN PARENTS CHOOSE THE SCHOOL
description: PUBLIC education is under pressure to let parents choose the school to which they send their children. Since bureaucracies do not like to give their clients a choice, the issue has aroused controversy. But advocates of choice hold one trump card: the Reagan Administration's idea of Federal vouchers that parents could use to pay their children's tuition in private schools or a public school outside the local district.

title: JACKSON REFLECTS ON PLAYOFFS
description: Reggie Jackson poked his head through a tunnel in the stands, saw the horde of television cameras, reporters and photographers waiting for him near the visiting dugout and ducked back inside. He was not ready for them yet. Instead, on the eve of perhaps his final appearance as a player in October, Jackson walked beneath the grandstand and emerged at the opposite side of the field. Then, completely unnoticed, he jogged slowly into right field and limbered up.

title: YAMANI URGES $17 TO $19 OIL PRICING
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani said today at the start of OPEC's fifth meeting this year that the group should restore a production and pricing arrangement based on a marker price of $17 to $19 for a barrel of crude oil.

title: THEATER: EQUITY LIBRARY OFFERS 'RELATIVE VALUES'
description: BY Noel Coward standards, ''Relative Values'' could be considered a play of social significance. The subject of this 1951 comedy, now having its New York premiere at Equity Library Theater, is the immutability of the English class system. In this waspish comedy, the playwright speculates on both the differences between classes and the different levels within a class.

title: PHONE-A-GRAM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After writeoffs of $235,000 on obsolete fixed assets, obsolete inventory and unrepairable or lost field equipment. c-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Celanese Corp., producer of chemicals, fibers and specialty materials, has named John N. Lauer president of its specialties operation.

title: Linear Technology
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it had reached an out-of-court settlement in its trade-secret litigation with Linear Technology Inc., a company founded by four former National employees in 1981 to produce integrated circuits for analog applications.

title: King Misses Practice
description: Bernard King, who missed virtually all the games and practices during his rehabilitation last season, was not at the Knicks' practice session this morning at Upsala College. Scotty Stirling, the Knicks' vice president, said, however, that King would not be making his absence a habit.

title: Advertising; Equicor Insurance Picks Bergin Group
description: Equicor - Equitable HCA Corporation, a recently formed joint-venture health insurance company - has selected the John Bergin Group as its first agency.

title: NASSAU COUNTY COMPTROLLER IN A TOUGH STATE RACE
description: In the Republican stronghold of Nassau County, Comptroller Peter T. King has had everything going for him as a politician: incumbency, fund raising and party organization.

title: SYRIAN ROLE CITED
description: A Jordanian accused of trying to blow up an El Al jumbo jet told British investigators that Syrian military intelligence officers had supplied him with an official Syrian passport, $12,000, a bag with deadly explosives hidden in a false bottom and training on how to detonate the bomb, a prosecutor said here today.

title: Hutton Buyout Unit Hires G.E. Official
description: E.F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that it had hired Warren B. Idsal from the General Electric Credit Corporation to take charge of its leveraged buyout unit.

title: Learning From Chernobyl
description: The Soviet Union lost a missile submarine yesterday off Bermuda, and gained a measure of respect. Had Mikhail Gorbachev maintained standard Soviet secrecy and denial in the face of disaster, he might have cast a pall of mistrust over this week's summit meeting in Iceland. But he broke with enduring practice, informing President Reagan on Saturday about the accident and informing him that there was no danger of a nuclear explosion, accidental launch of missiles or radioactive contamination. The Soviet Union's new spirit of candor is as welcome as it is necessary.

title: POLICE AND LAW
description: Overbooked at 911Nearly 7 million calls will pour in to 911 this year, and the Police Department thinks that's too many. So for the third time in 15 years it's planning a ''demarketing'' campaign to ask people to save the number for real emergencies like heart attacks and crimes in progress.

title: Gandhi Says India Needs To Emphasize Security
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was quoted today as having said that his country was not as concerned with security as it should be and that this lapse was partly responsible for the attempt on his life last week.

title: FIVE YEARS LATER, MUBARAK RULES A LAND ADRIFT
description: Five years ago today, Hosni Mubarak, a stocky, phlegmatic former fighter pilot, was thrust into the leadership of the Arab world's largest nation in a hail of gunfire.

title: Realignment at Turner
description: Ted Turner, the chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System, has reorganized the management of the company, giving greater authority to a five-member executive committee, according to one board member.

title: What's Possible in Reykjavik
description: We are about to learn whether President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, are statesmen or merely politicians grasping for advantage. Reykjavik and the summit meetings that may follow will test their capacity to frame a shared vision for future relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Allied Stores Stock
description: The common stock of the Allied Stores Corporation remained unchanged, at $64.50, as management and directors continued to deliberate strategy on the hostile $66-a-share offer by the Campeau Corporation, a real estate developer in Canada. Allied had no comment on its discussions. The stock had been halted early yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange on a possible news announcement but later resumed trading, with no statement from the company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is necessary, whatever the cost, to get Unesco out of the hurricane zone, while remaining faithful to its democratic principles.'' - Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. [ A8:1. ]

title: RATHER RETURNS TO NEWSCAST DESPITE BRUISES FROM ASSAULT
description: Despite painful bruises from a mysterious beating Saturday night by two well-dressed men on the Upper East Side, Dan Rather returned to the air last night as anchorman of the ''CBS Evening News.''

title: FINAL MATCH IN CHAMPIONSHIP AMOUNTS TO MATTER OF HONOR
description: Gary Kasparov retained his world chess championship by taking a draw with Anatoly Karpov in the 23d match game in Leningrad yesterday. The 23-year-old titleholder has amassed an unsurpassable 12 points to the 35-year-old Karpov's 11.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1986
description: The World

title: UNDER BOARDWALK, HOMELESS EKE OUT A SURVIVAL
description: The city is full of nomads - drifters, derelicts and the disposessed. They sprawl in doorways, they bathe in restrooms, and they prowl the streets. On a peninsula of land at the bottom of Brooklyn, some of them have gathered into a colony, a family of sorts that sleeps by the sea.

title: Hybrid Aircraft
description: A new research aircraft called X-Wing looks like the result of an unresolved argument among design engineers. The vehicle has four helicopter-like blades that rotate for takeoffs, landings and low-speed flight.

title: SOVIET ATOMIC SUB SINKS IN ATLANTIC 3 DAYS AFTER FIRE
description: A crippled Soviet nuclear submarine, after struggling to keep afloat for three days, sank early today in the Atlantic, about 1,200 miles east of New York, Defense Department officials announced.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Ruins Found in Scotland
description: Archeologists say they may have uncovered the ruins of an 800-year-old Norse settlement in southern Scotland. The Presbyterian Church of Scotland said Sunday that the remains of two houses in ''pristine'' condition had been found under a medieval cemetery near a ruined Christian priory at Whithorn, 40 miles southwest of Dumfries.

title: RED SOX
description: The Boston Red Sox were hurt last week by the announcement that Tom Seaver would be unable to pitch in the American League playoff because of a strained right knee. But it would have been disastrous if Roger Clemens had been knocked out after he was hit on the right elbow by a line drive just six days ago.

title: Judge Expands Visits to Baby
description: A judge yesterday expanded the visitation rights of a woman who wants to spend more time with the infant she was hired to bear for a Tenafly couple, but refused to let her have the child overnight.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains on the sale of marketable securities of $522,000, or 20 cents a share, and $3,747,000, or $1.43 a share, for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $1,569,000, or 60 cents a share, for the year-ago quarter and $2,229,000, or 85 cents a share, for the year-earlier 6 months. c-Includes income of $700,000, or 27 cents a share, and $1,025,000, or 39 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the spin- off of the discontinued operation, Brand Insulations Inc., to standard stockholders last October.

title: Ripken Gets Job
description: ''There should be no doubt in your minds that I'm very, very happy,'' said Cal Ripken Sr., who was named manager of the Baltimore Orioles yesterday. After being passed over twice, the last time for Earl Weaver, Ripken was widely rumored to have a lock on the job this time.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL ON DEALERS IN U.S. DEBT
description: The House passed an amended Senate bill today that will require that all dealers in Government debt securities register with the Federal Government.

title: Lawyer Is Said To Be on Tape
description: A Queens criminal lawyer was the third person in a secretly tape-recorded conversation that also included Stanley M. Friedman's lawyer and a prospective witness in the Federal corruption trial of Mr. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, people familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: A SURPRISE TICKS IN THE TAX BILL
description: One reason President Reagan has not signed the tax revision bill is a Congressional dispute over some provisions in a package of ''technical corrections'' for the legislation. One would give House Democrats valuable leverage when state legislators start drawing up new Congressional district boundaries in 1991.

title: GIANTS ARE PUZZLED BY SAGGING OFFENSE
description: The Giants' statistics on offense were disappointing, even embarrassing - only 8 first downs, 61 yards rushing, 83 net yards passing, 2 completions to wide receivers, 2 of 15 third-down conversions, 23 minutes 15 seconds of possession.

title: Alabama Textbook Case Seen as Hinging on Term
description: A Federal district judge said today that the key to a case by fundamentalist parents challenging Alabama textbooks was to define secular humanism and to prove that it was taught in public schools.

title: The Modern Ache
description: A brief stop in India to break the long trip back from China is a reminder of the agonizing contrast in the way the two societies are trying to drag themselves into modern times.

title: SFN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $43,065,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of Silver Burdett to a subsidiary of Gulf & Western Inc. and an after-tax charge of $13,413,000 for both periods. c-Net loss d-Includes an after-tax charge of $5,544,000.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Donna Roll, Soprano, At Alice Tully Hall
description: Boston is full of singers who earn a local reputation without always being able to export it effectively, but Donna Roll, who sang Liszt, Sibelius and Wagner in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night, made a persuasive showing that promises well for her future in the much-needed category of dramatic soprano.

title: BankAmerica: Recent Twists
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's announcement last night that its board had received a merger proposal from the First Interstate Bancorp is the latest twist for the company that was once the nation's biggest banking concern. What follows are recent milestones:

title: THE SPEECH BY ON ICELAND
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio:

title: 1 Man, 1 Vote
description: David Smith, after rushing for 166 yards and two touchdowns in Wichita State's victory over Tulane: ''Not being conceited, I am the best.''

title: CELICO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax benefit of $16,000. c-Net loss The company is listed on the Vancouver Stock Exchange. All results are in U.S. dollars.

title: 3 Principals Change In 'Don Quichotte' Cast
description: Massenet's ''Don Quichotte'' is not the panoramic epic one might expect from a setting of Cervantes but rather a tender, graceful and often very beautiful meditation on pride, power, humility and love. The present New York City Opera production is one of the troupe's most touching and imaginative.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
NATURE'S BOUNTIFUL BEAN
description: THE legume family is so talented, that if its members were humans, they would be the Leakeys, the Buckleys or perhaps the Osmonds. Legumes are the dried seeds of their plants of origin. They have significant amounts of iron and B vitamins and are low in fat and high in carbohydrates.

title: Dokes Arrested
description: Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, was arrested Monday at his home and is being held on drug trafficking and other charges, according to the police in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a biotechnology agreement between the Eastman Kodak Company and Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc. misreported the current status of Advanced Genetic's permit to test a frost-reducing bacteria. The Environmental Protection Agency reinstated the permit in August.

title: U.S. Justice Refuses to Order Alabama Democratic Runoff
description: A Supreme Court Justice today refused to order a second Democratic runoff in the Alabama gubernatorial election.

title: A FINE AMERICAN HAND WITH TRADITIONAL FOOD
description: ''WHENEVER I swallow, it spurs thoughts for new dishes,'' Jasper White said half jokingly, ''and eating is one of the most rewarding aspects of travel.'' Mr. White, the 34-year-old owner of Restaurant Jasper in Boston and considered one of the foremost young chefs on the East Coast, was in the midst of preparing a dish of Portuguese inspiration, made with pork and littleneck clams. He had brought all his provisions from Boston and set up in my kitchen.

title: STAGE: 'SEX TIPS FOR MODERN GIRLS'
description: DOT, Helen and Alyss, the three young women who swap confessions and advice in the musical revue ''Sex Tips for Modern Girls,'' have very different attitudes toward courtship and love. Dot (Kim Seary) is a self-recriminating prude with a streak of repressed sensuality. In microscopic detail she gleefully enumerates her supposed physical flaws. Alyss (Hilary Strang), a latter-day hippie who dresses in bright clownish outfits, likes to dance, take drugs and pick up sailors who speak in foreign languages. Helen (Christine Willes) is a sexual sophisticate who loathes domesticity as much as she loves romance.

title: Conviction on Abortion Ads
description: A pregnancy center and its founder were convicted of deceptive trade practices today and fined $39,000 for falsely advertising as an abortion clinic, then trying to persuade pregnant women to have their babies.

title: Cutting A Chicken
description: THIS country consumes more chicken per capita than any other kind of meat. Not only is chicken still among the most economical of foods, it is also extremely versatile.

title: STOCK PLUNGES
description: Bracing Wall Street for another depressed quarterly report, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its strong sales in foreign markets ''are beginning to moderate.'' The company added that total worldwide orders and shipments for the first nine months of the year would probably be below last year's levels.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Classified Financial Corporation, Waukesha, Wis., has named F.K. Neal Stanley as president and chief executive, and Thomas A. Cockrell as executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Replay Suggestion
description: Action, camera, lights: This is the sequence suggested by Tex Schramm for the National Football League's controversial instant-replay rule. Schramm, president of the Dallas Cowboys and chairman of the league's competition committee, wants to eliminate the kind of confusion in communication that occurred during the game Sunday between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: AIDE TO U.N. CHIEF CALLED SOVIET SPY IN SENATE REPORT
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence charged today that a Soviet intelligence officer holds the post of assistant to the Secretary General at the United Nations.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN my wife and I arrived in New York about 50 years ago, we were entertained on occasional weekends by American friends who had a penchant for curry. Most meals found me musing on the frequency with which the flavor of curry could be detected in the dishes served.

title: THOSE METS FROM QUEENS
description: THERE is a little secret about the New York Mets, which much of America has probably not caught on to. Perhaps it is time to expose this secret before the National League championship series begins in Houston tonight.

title: Neil Young Savors His Rough Edges
description: AT 40, Neil Young remains one of rock music's most intransigent renegades. In an era when veteran rock stars are falling all over themselves to make polished pop records that flaunt the latest wonders in keyboard technology, Mr. Young continues to make scrappy sounding, spur-of-the-moment albums that cut defiantly against the grain.

title: Officials Weigh Murder Case Over 3 Deaths in Illegal Lab
description: Three people were killed by vapors Sunday in an illegal makeshift drug laboratory, and the authorities said Monday that they hoped to bring a murder case against the company that sold chemicals used there.

title: ICAHN LIFTS USX STAKE TO 11.4%
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who announced an $8 billion bid for the USX Corporation on Monday, disclosed yesterday that he had bought an additional four million shares, raising his stake to 11.4 percent.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHULTZ SAYS SOVIET WILL 'PUBLICIZE' TAKING TROOPS OUT OF AFGHANISTAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that there were signs that Moscow was planning a ''publicized'' partial troop pullout from Afghanistan during the Iceland talks this weekend.

title: Economic Scene; Dangers of U.S. Trade Deficit
description: THE need to shrink the huge United States trade deficit, now running at about $200 billion a year, is the main reason the Administration has put so much pressure on West Germany and Japan to accelerate their economic growth. But during last week's annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, the Germans and Japanese pointed to a report by I.M.F. economists to support their contention that faster growth by their countries would have little effect on the American trade deficit.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The results for both periods in 1985 were restated. All results are reported in Canadian dollars.

title: Treasures of America
description: The National Gallery of Art, generally more inclined to painting and sculpture, had never held a major exhibition of a single collection of American furniture. But the gallery's director, J. Carter Brown, said that the popularity of furniture in the British show that the Prince and Princess of Wales visited last fall roused a keen competitive interest in the National Gallery.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MAYA ON CAMERA The Mayan civilization, which peaked in Mexico and Guatemala more than a thousand years ago, was an advanced society that might have found special ritual significance in the play of light and dark that is modern photography. Two photography exhibitions on the Maya are now on view in New York.

title: LAROUCHE WARNS U.S. ON ANY MOVE TO ARREST HIM
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. warned today that ''any attempt to arrest me would be an attempt to kill me,'' and one of his spokesmen would not preclude the use of violence against law-enforcement officials who tried to take the conspiracy theorist into custody.

title: A Weapons Test for Congress
description: Of the many defense issues the House and Senate are struggling to reconcile, only one would make a critical difference to American troops in battle. That's a proposal by the House side to insure that all weapons receive realistic combat testing by a genuinely independent Pentagon test office.

title: Bench Talk
description: When the Supreme Court convened this week, some seniority realignment took place on the bench. William H. Rehnquist, the new Chief Justice, moved to the traditonal center seat, so he is no longer sitting next to Justice Harry A. Blackmun, and this may impede their personal communication in session.

title: People
description: * Carole Cohan, Charles Abrams and David Herzbrun all named executive vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: Bridge; Anonymity Gave Advantage In a Club Game in New York
description: Every expert has had the experience of finishing a round of duplicate play and then having an opponent say: ''If I'd known who you were, Mr. Professional, I would have been so nervous I would not have been able to follow suit.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TENDER LOVING CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $130,000 and $330,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: JOHN PAUL, ENDING TRIP TO FRANCE, APPEALS FOR AN END TO TERRORISM
description: Pope John Paul II returned here today from a trip to France that he ended by calling on ''all of mankind'' to reject terrorism.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1986
description: Companies

title: Face Facts About Civil Rights
description: Fed up with all the static at the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights, the Senate wants to cut its funds in half - and the House wants to put it out of business altogether. Anticipating the Congressional assault, the commission itself has voted to cut 75 percent of its 182-member staff and 7 of its 10 regional offices. It's all hasty, heedless cutting. This once-proud agency may have fallen on hard times, but it can keep on holding up sordid social facts to reluctant American eyes; it deserves to live.

title: Inevitable
description: Let the record show that the first high Government official reported to speak publicly the inevitable phrase about this weekend's Reagan-Gorbachev meeting was Secretary of State George P. Shultz. At a party the other night for a program that places art in American embassies, Mr. Shultz did it, unabashed. ''The tagline of the week is 'the Iceland cometh','' he said.

title: Dutch Insurer Offering Bonds
description: Aegon N.V., one of the Netherlands' largest insurance groups, is offering $125 million of bonds and a separate issue of debt warrants in the Euromarkets.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: The caption of a picture from Reuters in Business Day on Friday with an article about the meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund misidentified two Egyptian delegates. They were Ali Negm, standing on the left, and Dr. Salah Hamed, standing on the right.

title: CATHOLIC COLLEGES IN U.S. DEBATE ACADEMIC FREEDOM AMID DISPUTES
description: The nation's Roman Catholic colleges and universities, a key part of the American educational network for more than a century, have recently had to examine a question that goes right to the heart of their identity: Can there be true academic freedom in an institution that retains strong religious ties?

title: City Fire Dept. Gets New Chief
description: Robert J. Butler, a 28-year veteran of the city's Fire Department, will be the new Chief of Department, Mayor Koch and Fire Commissioner Joseph E. Spinnato announced yesterday.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE hours between dinner and bedtime seemed very long two summers ago, when my second son was an infant and my stomach and daily routine had not yet flattened out. In the early evenings I would fold out the double stroller and walk to the end of town, and as I did so the people returning from work were walking too, carrying their briefcases, stopping for flowers and take-out food.

title: Pitching a Rumor
description: The Yankees, who sometimes change pitching coaches more often than managers, may be interested in making Ray Miller their pitching coach next season.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Central Banks Step In, But Dollar Later Softens
description: The dollar was little changed yesterday in spite of a concerted attempt by European central banks to force the currency higher.

title: WEINBERGER IS OFF ON A WORLD TRIP
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger arrived in the Chinese capital today on the first leg of a round-the-world-trip that will also include consultations with military leaders of India, Pakistan, Egypt and the European allies.

title: Mullen Released
description: Davlin Mullen, a reserve cornerback for most of his four seasons with the Jets, was released to make room for Richard Todd, the quarterback who was signed Monday. An eighth-round draft choice in 1983, Mullen was criticized by some coaches for his performance earlier this season. Recently, he played only as a sixth back in pass situations and on special teams.

title: COLONIAL AMERICAN BANKHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Original Line
description: Vin Scully, the veteran baseball broadcaster, staring at the zipper-like seam that runs from foul line to foul line at the Astrodome: ''This place is the origin of the infield fly.''

title: Gelco Plans Tender Offer
description: In yet another move designed to prevent a hostile takeover attempt, the Gelco Corporation announced a tender offer today for up to six million common shares, or 46 percent of its outstanding stock, for $26 to $30 a share in cash and notes. For each share tendered, Gelco will pay $10 in cash and offer one-tenth of a newly issued class A preferred stock, which it said would have a value of $16 to $20 a share.

title: MEAT IS GETTING TRIMMER FOR A COMEBACK FIGHT
description: BEEF has gone on a diet, its battle with fat a well-publicized fact.

title: DEMOCRATS SUE REPUBLICANS ON PLAN TO CHALLENGE VOTERS
description: The Democratic Party filed a $10 million lawsuit against the Republican National Committee today, charging that the Republicans' program to purge ineligible voters from the rolls was really an attempt to ''harass, intimidate and improperly challenge'' blacks.

title: 60% OF TRUCKS INSPECTED IN NEW YORK AREA FAIL
description: About 60 percent of the trucks inspected in recent months in New York and Connecticut under a new Federal program were ordered off the highways as unsafe. This reflects in part, the authorities say, economic strains and cutbacks in repairs since the deregulation of the industry.

title: New Jewish Book Fair To Focus on Authors
description: The first annual Jewish Heritage Book Fair is scheduled to take place on Nov. 9 and 10 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street. Participants include publishers, booksellers, academic presses and cultural institutions, who will display and sell their works in English, Hebrew and Yiddish.

title: NEED FOR TRUST STRESSED
description: At a news conference in New York before meeting with President Reagan, Mr. Orlov said yesterday that no real results could come from the Iceland meeting unless the President stressed the question of human rights.

title: Helping Families
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SEALRIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $2.8 million charge for a writeoff of debt of Knudsen Corp.

title: REPUBLIC SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alternative to a New York State Cap on Credit-Card Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: HUBCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 1.

title: Panel Favors Extending Term for Aquino
description: The committee drafting a new Philippine constitution voted today to propose that President Corazon C. Aquino's six-year term of office be extended slightly despite calls for an early presidential election.

title: POLISH DISSIDENTS GET KENNEDY PRIZE
description: The phone rang today just when the telegram had said it would, and Zbigniew Bujak, a former Solidarity official, and Adam Michnik, a former Solidarity adviser, took turns on the line.

title: MAMET, FOOTE AND WORDS ON FILM
description: On paper, the lineup Monday night at the 92d Street Y held the promise of an early Sam Shepard play, with its suggestion of a showdown between the soft-spoken patrician and the emperor of expletives. Horton Foote and David Mamet had been invited to the Poetry Center to talk about writing for the stage and the screen, and certainly no two sensibilities ever were more dissimilar than these: How would the author of the gently elegiac ''Trip to Bountiful'' get along with the author of the aggressively foul-mouthed ''Glengarry Glen Ross''? Famously, as it happened. Lindsay Crouse, who has performed in works by both men, set the tone by noting, in her introduction, that the ''irascible, eccentric'' Mr. Foote ''is prone to violence,'' while Mr. Mamet ''is really quite shy.'' Her irony was not lost on an audience that doubtless didn't even need to be told that Miss Crouse is married to Mr. Mamet. Similarly, the actress's comment that ''we should be grateful we can hear their voices for 5 bucks instead of 60'' brought nods from listeners who knew their theater as well as their movies. Movies by Committee

title: Real Estate; Showroom Area Rises In Queens
description: MORE than four years ago it was proposed that a string of industrial buildings at the foot of the Queensboro Bridge in Long Island City be converted into high-quality showroom space for the furniture and fixtures industry.

title: The Place to Restart Immigration Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN AND AIDES HOLD FIRM ON ARMS
description: Senior Administration officials met at the White House today with President Reagan in preparation for the Iceland meetings this weekend. After the session, one official said the Administration decided to hold firm on key arms-control issues.

title: STUDENTS DEBATE VALUE OF COLLEGE AT NEW YORK FAIRS
description: HENRY HENRIQUEZ, a 17-year-old senior at A. Philip Randolph Campus High School in Harlem, wants to be the first in his family to graduate from college. ''I want to get a degree, get a good job and raise a family,'' he said. ''That's my future.''

title: G.M. Rate Cuts End With Backlog Low
description: The General Motors Corporation's record-breaking sales-incentive campaign will end Wednesday, having largely accomplished its aim of clearing out unsold 1986 models.

title: The Summit's Promise
description: President Reagan must make certain that his forthcoming meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland, with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, does not become a one-issue trap. There are growing expectations that the meeting will accelerate momentum for an arms control agreement, perhaps as early as next spring. Let's hope we can get a good agreement that soon. But let's also keep in mind that this is an exploratory session and that there are other concerns - not least human rights -that deserve equal weight.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: JERSEY DRUG CHECKS YIELD 95 ARRESTS
description: The drug checks started at the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge last month have resulted in 95 arrests, including 19 motorists who were charged with driving under the influence of narcotics, according to the Bergen County Prosecutor.

title: RIVER FOREST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accord Near on Conrail Sale
description: House and Senate conferees today neared agreement on Conrail sale legislation after the railway labor lobby agreed to drop a key demand, legislative and industry sources said today.

title: U.S. URGED TO EMULATE OTHERS IN ARMS PURCHASING
description: An analyst at the Central Intelligence Agency has compared the way the United States develops and buys weapons with the methods of foreign nations, including the Soviet Union, and found that the Pentagon could benefit from emulating other countries.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1986
description: The World The President linked human rights in the Soviet Union to a full-fledged meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the United States. Mr. Reagan stressed the need for improvements in Soviet rights policies after meeting with Yuri F. Orlov, the freed Soviet dissident. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: VIDEO DISPLAY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective April 30, 1986.

title: Willie Never Did It, Nor Mickey, Nor Duke
18 Ugandans Charged With Plotting a Coup
description: Three Cabinet ministers, a former Vice President and 14 other men were charged with treason today, accused of plotting to overthrow the eight-month-old Government of President Yoweri Museveni.

title: McLouth Steel
description: Creditors of the McLouth Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest steelmaker, have threatened to cut off credit unless output at one of the company's two plants is increased by Friday, union officials said.

title: Bozell Acquires Grey Medical
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has acquired Grey Medical, a subsidiary of Grey Advertising, and will merge it into its own BJK&E Healthcare unit. The result will be a health-care specialty shop with about $40 million in billings and 50 professional employees.

title: NICARAGUA SHOWS REPORTERS MAN IT SAYS IS FLIER
description: Nicaraguan Government officials tonight showed reporters a man they described as an American captured from a downed Nicaraguan rebel supply plane that they say took off from El Salvador.

title: LEGISLATOR SUGGESTS U.S. SEEKS VETERANS FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of San Antonio has suggested that the Federal Government is recruiting Spanish-speaking Texas veterans for service in Central America.

title: Impressive Backers At Wellsford Group
description: Edward Lowenthal and Jeffrey H. Lynford have formed the Wellsford Group, a private real estate investment firm with some impressive financial backers.

title: Sansivieri Is Winner In 2d Queens Primary
description: Queens voters - a few, anyway -went to the polls yesterday in a replay of the Democratic primary in the 15th State Senatorial District.

title: 'Edge of Darkness,' Award-Winning Series
description: BRITISH producers are finally catching up with American television in the special art of producing slick, taut, action-adventure thrillers. And as the BBC and its commercial colleagues are traditionally not shy about injecting substance into their entertainments, this development is very welcome indeed. An outstanding example of the possibilities is ''Edge of Darkness,'' a six-hour series that last year walked off with several of Britain's top television awards. Now in syndication in this country, ''Edge of Darkness'' has been picked up by WNYC and begins a five-week run on Channel 31 with a two-hour premiere tonight at 9.

title: ANGELS SMOTHER CLEMENS AND RED SOX IN OPENER
description: Roger Clemens, baseball's dominant pitcher this season, punctured Boston's first postseason effort since 1975 tonight by pitching his worst game of the year.

title: SIDELINED TORY MATINEE IDOL WINS RAVES OFFSTAGE
description: For 10 straight years, the show stopper at the annual conference of the Conservative Party was a highly emotional and equally partisan harangue by a rising Tory frontbencher in the House of Commons with a mane of golden hair, a look of sleek prosperity and a self-imposed sense of destiny.

title: THEATER: 'CONCEPT' REVIVED
description: ''T HE CONCEPT'' is a play that should not have had to be revived. In its time, the late 1960's, it was a powerful social document, both as psychodrama and as a commentary on drug addiction. Now, in 1986, the drug problem is, if anything, even more acute and widespread. The sad truth is that the play retains its timeliness. In fact, one would add that ''The Concept,'' which opened last night at Circle in the Square (Downtown), is the first necessary event of the theatrical season.

title: DANCE: 'ROARATORIO' AT NEXT WAVE
description: ''ROARATORIO: AN IRISH CIRCUS ON FINNEGANS WAKE,'' with choreography by Merce Cunningham and music devised by John Cage, banks as much on the invented word as it does the invented step - its inspiration was James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake.''

title: FILM: A DOCUMENTARY ON GLASS'S 'AKHNATEN'
description: WOULD you like to have seen a feature-length film documentary about Mozart and the first production of ''Le Nozze di Figaro''? How about one on Wagner and the composition and first performance of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen''? Well, you can't have those, but you can have one on Philip Glass and the composition and first, nearly simultaneous two productions of his opera ''Akhnaten.'' Entitled ''A Composer's Notes: Philip Glass and the Making of an Opera,'' Michael Blackwood's film opens today at the Film Forum 1, 57 Watts Street, for a two-week run.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of a brief article yesterday about concerts to be sponsored by President and Mrs. Reagan characterized the broadcast arrangements incorrectly. The programs will be televised.

title: FROM A SOVIET CIRCUS TO A BRAND NEW LIFE
description: THE taxicab bounced along the Long Island Expressway, and when the Manhattan skyline suddenly sprang into full view, Lubov Pisarenkova burst into tears.

title: WOMAN'S IRE ERUPTS AT EL AL TRIAL: 'I HATE YOU!' SHE SHOUTS AT LOVER
description: The young Irishwoman's resentment against the lover she thought had tried to turn her into an instrument of destruction finally burst out today at the end of her cross-examination.

title: PANEL WARNS NASA MAY LACK SHUTTLE EXPERTISE
description: A Congressional committee warned today that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration might lack the technical expertise to operate the space shuttle program properly.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will make it amply clear to Mr. Gorbachev that unless there is real Soviet movement on human rights, we will not have the kind of political atmosphere necessary to make lasting progress on other issues.'' - President Reagan. [ A6:5. ]

title: GOODEN-SCOTT DUEL: POWER VS. POWER
description: Mike Scott, the master of the split-fingered fastball, and Dwight Gooden, the master of the old-fashioned fastball, shook hands in the Astrodome today and said they would come out firing Wednesday night in the first round of the National League Championship Series.

title: SUMMIT MEETINGS AS LOCAL POLITICS
description: Representative Tony Coelho has a recurring nightmare: President Reagan meets Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Iceland this weekend and then announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to buy vast quantities of American grain.

title: Stricter Penalties on Fighting Approved
description: As expected, the experimental National Hockey League rule calling for two extra minutes in the penalty box to any player who instigates a fight was formally adopted yesterday.

title: CLEMENS IS BATTERED BY UNLIKELY HITTERS
description: If you wanted a mismatch, this was it: Gary Pettis had come to bat nine times against Roger Clemens this season without once getting a hit. He had struck out three times.

title: Dow Is Unchanged; Volume Heavier
description: Stock prices ended virtually unchanged yesterday as investors continued to display a lack of conviction over the outlook for interest rates, earnings, crude oil prices and the course of the economy.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: INHIBITED sexual desire has emerged in the 1980's as the leading sexual disorder and a major underlying factor, if not a direct cause, of many marital breakups. The problem affects single people as well as married couples and those committed to long-term relationships.

title: JERSEY LAWMAKERS ARE TAKING TO TV
description: Bill Bradley, frankly, has had better time slots than this.

title: Fourth-Grade Reading Is Less Than Literacy
description: To the Editor:

title: On Nuremberg and the United Nations
description: Forty years ago this month, the trial of the major Nazi war criminals ended in Nuremberg. Inevitably, then, this is an occasion to reflect on those proceedings and on the historical era they brought to a close. Yet our remembrance will be pointless if it remains a routine recollection of past events.

title: Israeli Cab Driver Is Slain in Gaza
description: An Israeli civilian was fatally stabbed today in the Israeli-occupied town of Gaza, the second such incident in Gaza in less than two weeks, army spokesmen said.

title: Clout
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $31,358,000 from the sale of 2 million common shares of Continental Cablevision Inc. Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend in the form of Class B stock paid June 30.

title: CLEMENS LOSES CONTROL EARLY
description: In winning three starts against the California Angels during the season, Roger Clemens allowed a total of 8 runs, including 7 earned runs, over a total of 26 innings. But in tonight's opener of the American League Championship Series, the Red Sox right-hander allowed 8 runs - 7 earned - in his seven and one-third innings of an 8-1 loss.

title: NEW OFFER ACCEPTED BY ALLIED
description: In an effort to stave off a $66-a-share bid by the Campeau Corporation, the board of the Allied Stores Corporation yesterday approved a $67-a-share merger offer from Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. and Paul A. Bilzerian.

title: Tax-Exempt Dealers See a Test in Illinois
description: Securities dealers in the tax-exempt market are watching closely a $111.05 million bond financing by the Illinois Scholarship Commission because interest on the bonds is subject to the alternative minimum tax on personal incomes.

title: AID FOR SHAKESPEARE PROJECT
description: A program that will bring free performances of Shakespeare's plays to New York City high-school students won official sanction and a $525,000 grant from the city, Mayor Koch announced yesterday at City Hall. The city's commitment follows a successful test run of the program last spring.

title: Sex Discrimination Suit Settled for $37 Million
description: A sex discrimination case against United Airlines was settled today for $37 million, ending a 20-year battle over a rule that forced female flight attendants to resign if they got married.

title: A VITTADINI SCARF, DRAMATIC PEN
description: 1. Through a Glass Brightly In his studio in Stevens, Pa., Ivan Barnett fashions decorative handmade mirrors. They are painted wood, covered with metal cutouts shaped like stars and birds.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect 2-for-1 split of common stock effective July 23, 1986.

title: SUDAN'S LEADER SAYS NATION WON'T PAY ALL FOREIGN DEBT
description: The Prime Minister of the Sudan announced today that his country would not pay back all of its $10 billion foreign debt.

title: Astros
description: Catchers (Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 14Alan Ashby(.257, 7, 38) Switch-hitter who handles prize pitching staff with strength. But, like Gary Carter, he throws out about one in every four baserunners. Came back from injuries that limited him to 66 games last year and 65 the year before, and doubled those totals this year. Contact hitter, only occasional power. 4John Mizerock (.185, 1, 6) Went to bat only 81 times this year. Like Ashby, got his chance after Mark Bailey, the catcher of the future, was sent back to minors. Infielders (position, average, home runs, r.b.i.) 27Glenn Davis (First base, .265, 31, 101) Made waves last year as rookie with power, the missing ingredient in the Astrodome: Hit 20 home runs in 100 games and knocked in 62 runs. Kept up the power hitting this year, and only Mike Schmidt hit more home runs in National League. He is Houston's only bona fide slugger. 19Bill Doran (Second base, .276, 6, 37) Fine all-round performer who may be best player on team. Switch-hitter, and a good one, and he led the club in runs (92) and stolen bases (42). In field, superb second baseman who has great range and exceptional ability at turning the double play. The only thing he lacks is power. 29Denny Walling (Third base, .312, 13, 58) Left-handed clutch hitter from Neptune, N.J., who has been a jack of all trades for last nine years. Led team in hitting, one point above Kevin Bass, and third on team in home runs.

title: KEY RATES
Advertising; Esquire, Sail Join On Insert
description: ESQUIRE magazine's February issue will carry a special insert on the America's Cup race.

title: JUDGE ON TRIAL IN THE SENATE ASKS FOR 'SPIRIT OF FAIR PLAY'
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, arguing his innocence in the first Senate impeachment trial in 50 years, made an emotional appeal today to the Senate's ''spirit of fair play.''

title: OUTSPOKEN GENERAL: A FAST FRIEND TO CONTRAS
description: John K. Singlaub, who heads a private group that reportedly operated the American-built cargo plane shot down over southern Nicaragua on Sunday, was an outspoken figure even before he retired as an Army major general.

title: HISTORY WITH A BITE
description: By now, the mosquitoes in the old Colt Stadium have reached epic proportions - as big as hawks, as big as pterodactyls, as big as the Concorde itself.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 8, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Plenary sessions - 10 A.M. and 3 p.m.

title: WILL SOHO BE THE LITTLE SODA THAT COULD?
description: TO hear Sophia Collier talk about soda pop, you'd think anyone could bottle a batch.

title: Consumer Debt Rise Slackens
description: Americans took out $3.74 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in August, the smallest increase since March, the Government said today.

title: HERNANDEZ BLENDS INSTINCTS AND SAVVY
description: The Mets had won another ball game, so it was time for another celebration, with big smiles, hugs, and a reception line of coaches and reserves stretching from the first-base line to the pitcher's mound. A commotion like this happened 108 times this season, revealing almost daily the bright, showy, extroverted side of this talented team.

title: LIEBERMAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PRESIDENT LINKS RIGHTS IN SOVIET TO SUMMIT SUCCESS
description: President Reagan met today with Yuri F. Orlov, the freed Soviet dissident, and said later that a substantive improvement in Soviet human rights was crucial for a summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the United States.

title: Agency Seeks Racing Shift
description: The New Jersey State Commission of Investigation yesterday called for changes in the state's racing industry, including improved techniques for detecting drugs in horses, tighter security at the Meadowlands and Garden State racetracks, and an ''intensive annual audit'' of each racetrack in the state.

title: Banking Bill Advances
description: A bill to raise $15 billion for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation and expand the powers of Federal bank regulators to merge weak institutions with stronger ones was approved today by the House. The bill, passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate, would direct the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to lend $3 billion to a financing corporation owned by member savings and loan insitutions to float $15 billion in bonds for the insurance fund.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about two television mini-series based on books about the same murder reversed the identities of the paperback publishers. ''At Mother's Request'' was published by Pocket Books. ''Nutcracker: Money, Madness, Murder'' was published by Dell.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend Sept. 30 to shareholders of record Sept. 9.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split, April 11, 1986. Earnings for the latest 9 months include an after-tax gain of $1.5 million, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of stock in Merabank, a savings bank in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: PANEL SEEKS NEW LAW ON FINANCE OF OFFICIALS
description: Calling New York State's current conflict-of-interest and financial disclosure law ''archaic, inadequate'' and ''unenforceable,'' a city-state panel has called for a new law with stronger provisions and stiffer penalties.

title: Design Center to Open
description: Interior view of the side of Design Center One, with a view of the continuous stairway at left, which is part of the old Adams Gum Tower Building. The International Design Center will open tomorrow in Long Island City. (NYT/Edward Hausner)

title: Flying Tiger Line
description: Tiger International Inc.'s main operating subsidiary, Flying Tiger Line Inc., said it had told employees that it needs substantial cost reductions as an initial step to restore its viability as an air cargo shipper. The company said that if it did not resolve problems, it would have to evaluate whether it could continue operating.

title: MANAGERS' VIACOM BID IS REJECTED
description: Viacom International Inc. said yesterday that its outside directors had rejected a sweetened buyout bid of $44 a share from a group led by Viacom's senior management. A major Viacom shareholder, meanwhile, disclosed that he had greatly increased his stake in the company.

title: SENATE, AFTER SLOW START, SITS AS JURY
description: When the Senate's first impeachment trial in half a century began shortly after 10 o'clock this morning, it was a play in search of characters.

title: ELECTRO FUNDS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The results reflect the company's acquisition of Complete Management Systems in April.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted retroactively for the 3-for-2 stock split in March 1986.

title: LAW ON FOREIGN CONFLICTS
description: Federal law does not prohibit American citizens from fighting in a war in a foreign country, nor does such activity endanger American citizenship.

title: BANKAMERICA DEAL PRODUCES DOUBTS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation is likely to reject First Interstate Bancorp's takeover proposal as inadequate, analysts and banking industry sources said today.

title: ABRAMS SAYS HIS CONFIDENCE IS BASED ON RECORD
description: Robert Abrams describes himself as ''confident but not overconfident'' as he seeks his third term as State Attorney General.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NATIONAL ENTERPRISES BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRIEDMAN TRIAL HEARS TESTIMONY ON SEX AT CLINIC
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer testified today that before engaging in municipal corruption schemes in New York City, he headed a private psychotherapy clinic where he permitted patients to have sex with each other and with therapists.

title: Pennsylvania Plan
description: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Facilities Authority is offering $82.2 million of revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.49 percent for bonds due in 2010 through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Trust.

title: E-Z-EM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Reagan Backs His Hunch
description: President Reagan is getting plenty of advice in preparation for his meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev in Iceland, most of it negative.

title: Finding a Nanny
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Bond Offering By Seattle Utility
description: A $249.7 million issue of Seattle Municipal Light and Power refunding revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: SURVEY OF SERVICES FOR ELDERLY
description: One in five elderly people visit centers or use other facilities or services designed for them, and women are more likely than men to avail themselves of the programs, a Government study by the National Center for Health Statistics says.

title: Work and Stress
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ASTROS, at Houston, first game of National League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:45 P.M., WCBS 880, 8 P.M.) CALIFORNIA ANGELS VS. RED SOX, at Boston, second game of American League Championship Series, 3:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.; Radio - WCBS, 880, 3 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. SOCCER: Hofstra vs. Fordham, 3:30 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 3:30 P.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M., tape) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: KOSHER DINING OUT: THE OPTIONS GROW
description: UNTIL recently, dining options for Jews in New York City who keep kosher were largely limited to delicatessens and dairy restaurants that featured a predictable roster of foods and a clamorous eat-it's-good-for-you atmosphere. This left many observant Jews wistful observers of the restaurant explosion in the city over the past few years, especially younger people and singles who read about the buoyant social scenes and enticing foods at these places, yet were proscribed from frequenting them.

title: Heady Drug Issue
description: The issue of illegal drugs has got so out of hand in the United States Senate race in Florida that the Coast Guard has answered a political distress signal.

title: Nassau Police Gain Officers
description: The Nassau County Police Department, which has faced what it has called a serious manpower shortage in recent years, has received a new batch of officers - 150 recruits who graduated from the police academy yesterday.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $191,000.

title: TRANSPORT
description: Getting LaterAre suburbanites working longer? Schedule makers at the commuter railroads think so.

title: G.E. PROFITS RISE BY 5%; RCA A KEY CONTRIBUTOR
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter rose 5 percent on a 42.3 percent increase in sales.

title: THE ELUSIVE ELEMENT: COMPASSION
description: At a time when medical experts increasingly recognize the element of compassion as an essential aid in the healing process, several circumstances in New York City's hospitals continue to make them among the worst when it comes to treating patients like people, not just bed numbers or diseases.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Will Clark and Robby Thompson, two rookie infielders for the San Francisco Giants, underwent arthroscopic surgery.

title: Nominee to Bank Board
description: The White House today nominated Lee H. Henkel Jr., an Atlanta attorney, as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which oversees the thrift industry. Mr. Henkel, 58 years old, is a former chief counsel at the Internal Revenue Service.

title: JUDGE EXCLUDES KEY TESTIMONY IN TRIAL OF GOTTI
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a key Government witness - a career criminal - could not give testimony that prosecutors were counting on to help establish a motive for a 1973 murder that the authorities say John Gotti committed to gain favor with leaders of the Gambino crime family.

title: REAGAN SEES STATEHOUSE GAINS
description: President Reagan told the nation's Republican Governors today that the party had a chance to win a majority of the governorships this year for the first time since 1968.

title: Mets
description: Catchers(Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 8Gary Carter (.255, 24, 105) Cleanup hitter, money player and chief cheerleader. Reports right knee, minus cartilage, probably stronger than at start of season. Throwing better, but still nails only one in four base-stealers. 49Ed Hearn (.265, 5, 10) Long shot to make team in spring training as nonroster player, but got the job as Carter's backup and held it. Infielders (Position, average, home runs, r.b.i.) 17Keith Hernandez (First base, .310, 13, 83) Set standards for playing first base, best in business on choking bunt and knocking off lead runner at second or third, best on 3-6-3 double play. Probably least replaceable Met. 6Wally Backman (Second base, .320, 1, 27) Gritty, hard-nosed, self-made major leaguer, protege of Dave Johnson from minor leagues who fought way to job and won it by leading team in hitting this year. 22Ray Knight (Third base, .298, 11, 76) Retread with surgical history. Thought last spring he would be released, but hit home run off Steve Carlton first time at bat and went on spree that triggered Mets' rush to first place. 3Rafael Santana (Shortstop, .218, 1, 28) Professional shortstop who glues infield together. Sat for time this season when Johnson experimented with Kevin Mitchell and Howard Johnson, but now he's No. 1 again, with a rookie, Kevin Elster, as backup. Softest hitter in lineup. 20Howard Johnson (Third base, .245, 10, 39) Looked like the regular at third before Knight got hot, then sat and fretted much of the time.

title: PANEL SAYS OREGON DEMOCRAT VIOLATED HOUSE ETHICS RULES
description: The House ethics committee, seeking to avert what it called a ''potentially wide range of abuse,'' ruled today that Representative James Weaver had used campaign money for personal investments in violation of House rules.

title: HAL B. WALLIS, FILM PRODUCER, IS DEAD
description: Hal B. Wallis, who produced, co-produced or supervised the production of more than 400 films during a career that spanned half a century, has died at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: REAGAN ASKS HOUSE TO YIELD ON ARMS-CONTROL DISPUTES
description: President Reagan urged the House of Representatives today to drop completely the arms-control provisions he opposes, and one Administration official said he was ''pessimistic'' about agreeing to a proposal to put off consideration of the issues until next spring.

title: WAGNER TO SEEK SCHOOL CONTRACEPTIVES LIMIT
description: The president of New York City's Board of Education said yesterday that he would ask the board to prohibit the dispensing of contraceptives on school grounds to students under 18.

title: DULL QUITS AT MARYLAND
