description: Dick Dull, the University of Maryland athletic director, who has faced criticism because of academic problems suffered by athletes that were revealed after the death of Len Bias, resigned his post today.

title: 'World Without Walls,' About Beryl Markham
description: TONIGHT'S beautifully crafted documentary film about the still somewhat mysterious life of Beryl Markham is rooted in the rediscovery of her personal memoir, ''West With the Night,'' which was reissued in 1983 by North Point Press, the publishing house in Berkeley, Calif., after being out of print for many years. Here is a good television illustration of something that movie studio producers learned long ago but many documentarians continue to overlook: book and script must come first because they provide the spine for a show.

title: ALTAI INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Top Executives Picked For Contel-Comsat Link
description: The proposed merger of the Contel Corporation and Comsat was so natural that John N. Lemasters says he cannot remember who brought up the subject.

title: AGENDA: Oct. 8, 1986
description: Integrity in Government Joint state-city panel fields questions about its call for sweeping new law involving conflicts of interest, financial disclosures and protection for whistleblowers. At news conference, panelists - appointed in wake of city corruption scandal - will also discuss proposed commission to monitor law. 1 P.M., City Bar Association, 42 West 44th Street, Manhattan Alternatives to Westway Some want to rebuild the West Side Highway. Others want trees, wider medians and safer pedestrian crossings. Still others prefer a partly submerged roadway. Such proposals to be analyzed by experts at meeting of joint state-city task force. Recommendations due by year's end. 7:30 A.M., Vista International Hotel, 3 World Trade Center, Manhattan Closed Primaries Connecticut Republicans go to the United States Supreme Court to argue that voters not registered by party should be allowed in some primary elections. Case could affect electoral process nationwide as 35 states, including New York and New Jersey, have similar laws. 1 P.M., Supreme Court, Washington Proceedings Bumper to BumperAdding a fourth lane to the Long Island Expressway from North Hempstead to Brookhaven is up for discussion at hearing of Assembly Transportation Committee. State and Federal governments have already appropriated $2 million to study project, which could cost between $50 and $70 million. 2 P.M., Suffolk County Legislative Building, Veterans Memorial Highway, Hauppauge, L.I. Subway ShootingDefense lawyers want prosecutor removed in Goetz case because they may call him to testify. They say Gregory L. Waples has information from his interviews of the victims that will help defense in attempted murder and assault trial.

title: LUCK OF BERRA COMFORTS ASTROS
description: The Astros' Davey Lopes, on the eve of the National League Championship Series, called him ''our secret weapon.''

title: A New Choice For S.B.A. Post
description: The White House, in a shift, has come up with a new candidate for a permanent appointment as administrator of the Small Business Administration, according to informed Congressional sources.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Images, Old and New
description: The first televised debate between the two Senate candidates in Maryland was a rather tame affair Monday night when measured against the expectations raised by the candidates's early clashes on personal and political questions.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CITIES ON A HILL. A Journey Through Contemporary American Cultures. By Frances FitzGerald. 414 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: LEBANESE SUNNI MOSLEM LEADER IS SLAIN
description: A prominent Sunni clergymen admired by Moslems and Christians alike was assassinated here today, and the killing evoked nationwide condemnation.

title: Times Sq. Gets New Partner
description: The developer of four huge office towers in the Times Square redevelopment project has arranged new financing with the Prudential Insurance Company, which will become a half partner in the buildings, The arrangement will allow work on the first two buildings to proceed by the middle of next year, with completion scheduled for 1989, George Klein, president of the development company, Park Tower Realty, said yesterday.

title: OCE-VAN DER GRINTEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results are in U.S. currency.

title: Safety First
description: Pernell Whitaker hasn't tried to dunk a basketball lately, and his boxing career may be better off for it.

title: Suspension Of Judge Voted
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday suspended a Supreme Court justice from Brooklyn who was charged last week with taking bribes.

title: WALL ST. ATTACHES A LOW VALUE TO BID
description: Some Wall Street analysts said yesterday that, lacking details about Monday's takeover bid for the BankAmerica Corporation, they were valuing the offer at barely $15 a share, or $2.3 billion.

title: Gerber Debentures
description: The Gerber Products Company is offering $100 million of noncallable 9 percent debentures due in 2006 at 99.625, to yield 9.041 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Company. Rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., the debentures yield 1.12 percentage points more than Treasury bonds with a similar maturity.

title: G.O.P. Eyes 1991
description: While most Washington politicians are concentrating on the races for the Senate and House, a small group of futurists over at the Republican National Committee is equally concerned about the 6,248 seats in state legislatures that are on the ballot nationally in November. They are determined to improve the present figures: 736 Democrats to 450 Republicans in upper houses, 2,834 Democrats to 2,218 Republicans in lower houses.

title: SUMMCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $950,000. c-Includes extraordinary tax credit of $1 million for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $3.1 million for the 9 months.

title: 2 Ring Figures Guilty
description: Luis Resto, a junior-middleweight fighter, and Carlos (Panama) Lewis, his manager and trainer, were found guilty yesterday on two counts of assault in the second degree and one count each of criminal possession of a weapon and conspiracy stemming from a 1983 match between Resto and Billy Collins Jr. In addition, Lewis was found guilty of tampering with the outcome of a sporting event.

title: Young & Rubicam Gets Pillsbury Assignments
description: Young & Rubicam is joining the Pillsbury Company agency list, and will be working for its U.S. Foods division on dessert mixes and frostings, microwave products and toaster products, which the client considers three assignments.

title: EMERGENCY ORDER BANS MUCH-USED PESTICIDE
description: Asserting that the widely used pesticide dinoseb posed a ''very serious risk'' of birth defects, the Environmental Protection Agency issued an emergency order today barring sale or use of the chemical.

title: VICTIM OF FIREHOUSE SEX BIAS CHARGED IN A VIRGINIA ARSON
description: A firefighter at the center of a sexual harassment controversy in New York City's Fire Department has been charged with arson in Portsmouth, Va., officials said yesterday.

title: Early Regulatory Reaction Seems Favorable
description: Federal banking regulators indicated today that they had few initial objections to the offer by First Interstate Bancorp to buy the BankAmerica Corporation, and several of them said they saw significant benefits to the proposed merger.

title: DARTMOUTH: A MICROCOSM
description: David T. McLaughlin's resignation as the 14th president of Dartmouth College was impelled by personal reasons and by events peculiar to this Ivy League campus. However, his decision, which was announced Monday, can be seen as a product of broader forces that affect all major American colleges and universities.

title: A Tax Bill Favor That Hurts the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: SELECT GROUP COMPETES AT CELTICS' CAMP
description: There have always been players ready and willing to go from one National Basketball Association training camp to another for room and board and $50 a week in expenses, hoping one day to wind up on some roster. Because most coaches like to have at least 16 bodies around for their two-a-day workouts, these ''gym rats'' are usually welcomed when camps are being set up.

title: Voting and Television
description: Excerpt from ''The Transformation in American Politics: Implications for Federalism,'' a report by the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, an orgnization created by Congress to monitor the working of the Federal Government and recommend improvements:

title: False Air Controller Calls Investigated in Miami
description: Two recent incidents here in which someone posing as an air traffic controller radioed false instructions to pilots have raised concern among industry experts, who say such incidents have the potential for disaster.

title: Calm Trading for Second Day
description: In the second consecutive day of desultory trading, interest rates were little changed for short or long maturities.

title: ROLE OF SOVIET AIDE
description: With the General Assembly deep into its 41st session, Vladimir Kolesnikov is most often seen at a large table at the right of the speaker's podium, grappling with a master list of who will speak next during the general debate.

title: WINE TALK
description: LET'S take a look at white wines that sell for $10 or less. We Americans prefer white wines to red by a wide margin, but then white wines are far less interesting to drink - or write about - than reds, which were surveyed earlier. Aside from white Burgundy, including Chablis, some Loire Valley wines, a couple of white Graves and American chardonnays, most white wines are boring.

title: Chiron, Ciba-Geigy
description: The Chiron Corporation, a biotechnology company in Emeryville, Calif., said that it intended to form an equally owned joint venture with Ciba-Geigy Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceuticals giant, to develop and commercialize a new generation of genetically engineered vaccines. Edward E. Penhoet, Chiron's president and chief executive, said that Ciba-Geigy had agreed to provide five years' financing to develop genetically engineered vaccines for AIDS, oral and genital herpes, hepatitis A, hepatitis non-A and non-B, malaria and cytomegalovirus, which can cause mental retardation or death in infants.

title: Libya and Italy Complete A Prisoner Exchange
description: Italy has freed three Libyan prisoners in exchange for four Italians held in Libya, including two accused of involvement in a coup attempt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, officials said today.

title: BUGGING OF G.O.P. AIDE STIRS CONTROVERSY IN TEXAS
description: An electronic listening device has been found in the office of the chief campaign strategist of Bill Clements, the Texas Republican candidate for Governor, and the incident has set off a political outcry.

title: 'Women's Work'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: THE COURTSHIP OF MICHIGAN'S MACOMB COUNTY HAS BECOME A 2-PARTY AFFAIR
description: Macomb County has a no-nonsense air, a stubborn certainty about its likes and dislikes.

title: Market Place; Retail Merger Bids Puzzling
description: EMPLOYEES at one of the 145 department stores owned by the May Department Stores Company recently prepared for a visit by David Farrell, the dynamic chairman of May, by rolling out a lush carpet on the main floor. But Mr. Farrell was delayed by other business, so they rolled up the rug to keep it fresh, only to have to roll it out again when he finally arrived.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DR. STEPHEN ROSENBERG was working long hours - probably too long - in his office at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center one weekend when the telephone rang. ''Acme Watch Repair?'' the caller asked. ''Why not?'' Dr. Rosenberg said.

title: VECTOR AUTOMATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a $268,000 charge resulting from income timing differences for its Gull Resources Management Systems subsidiary. The year-ago figures are restated and reflect receipt of $250,000 insurance claim payment.

title: PERSIAN GULF RAID STIRS UNCERTAINTY FOR OPEC
description: The Iran-Iraq war spilled into the meeting of OPEC oil ministers today, after Iraqi planes virtually wiped out Iran's capacity to export oil from Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf.

title: CONCERT: THE SISTINE CHAPEL CHOIR
description: THE Sistine Chapel Choir, which appeared Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall, dates back to well before the discovery of America (assuming you count Columbus the discoverer), but this is its very first United States tour. While the official founding year of the choir was 1480, the Popes cultivated plainchant and other religious music long before that. The Sistine Chapel Choir thus represents, with variable success, a nearly 2,000-year-old musical tradition.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Cookbooks for Causes Firefighters cook their own dinners (although 60 percent of the time they are interrupted before they can eat them), and so do writers (and they frequently use cooking to avoid their work). These morsels, along with recipes and personal insights, are contained in two recent cookbooks with charitable beneficiaries.

title: AMERICAN IS CAPTURED AFTER PLANE IS DOWNED IN NICARAGUA TERRITORY
description: An American-built cargo plane that was shot down over southern Nicaragua on Sunday was operated by a private group led by a retired United States Army major general, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Florida Ruling For U.S. Trust
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a Federal Reserve Board ruling allowing the U.S. Trust Company of New York, to operate a limited service bank in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: BANK SUITOR BOLD, SUCCESSFUL
description: After spending 25 years working his way up the ladder at the Bank of America, Joseph J. Pinola resigned 10 years ago partly because he felt the top spot would never be his. Now the 61-year-old son of a machinist from Pennsylvania's coal country is engineering an audacious bid for his First Interstate Bancorp to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation, a move that would place him atop a powerful, world-class banking institution.

title: The News From Disney World
description: Walt Disney World did not purchase all the journalists who swarmed over the Florida amusement park last weekend. Some of the reporters covering the park's four-day 15th anniversary celebration were from news organizations that paid their own way. The public, however, could not have distinguished between the serious reporters and those who showed up only because Disney had offered free transportation, lodging, meals and entertainment. It appeared instead that the entire Fourth Estate was on the take.

title: Ex-Senator Leaves Hospital After Bone Marrow Surgery
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas has returned home after a bone marrow operation to treat his cancer.

title: DAVID RUBINOFF, 89, VIOLINIST
description: The violinist David Rubinoff, a Russian immigrant whose concert music lifted the nation's spirits during the Depression, has died at the age of 89.

title: AMBULATORY MEDICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it recorded a gain on the sale of an office of nearly $700,000 in June, which resulted in a profit for the latest quarter.

title: Sun Building Is Recognized
description: The Sun Building, the site of New York City's first department store and later the home for 33 years of the daily newspaper The Sun, was designated a landmark yesterday by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: T.W.A. GAINS TIED TO CHANGE IN ICAHN
description: The dramatic turnaround of Trans World Airlines under Carl C. Icahn can be explained by a combination of factors: steps taken by prior management, overall trends that were favorable to the industry and innovative actions by a new owner from outside the industry.

title: INSIDE
description: Lindenauer as Therapist A key witness in the New York corruption trial, a former psychotherapist, said his clinic had allowed sex involving patients.

title: 2 Pupils, 9, Eat Cocaine Brought by Classmate
description: Drug education officers held special sessions today with children at an elementary school where two fourth- grade pupils ate rock cocaine brought by a classmate, the authorities said.

title: Ziff-Davis Acquisition
description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company has acquired Government Computer News, an every-other-week newspaper with a circulation of 85,000 that is based in Silver Spring, Md. Israel Feldman, who sold it for an undisclosed price, will continue as its publisher. The acquisition brings to seven the number of Ziff-Davis computer publications.

title: 3 IN MEXICO POLICE ARRESTED IN TEXAS
description: The state and Federal law-enforcement authorities in Texas said today that they had arrested three men who identified themselves as members of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police and had charged them with kidnapping seven American citizens.

title: CHERYL CRAWFORD, THEATRICAL PRODUCER
description: Cheryl Crawford, a prominent theatrical producer and co-founder of the Group Theater and the Actors Studio, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan, and had been hospitalized since June following complications from a fall.

title: DESPITE U.S. OBJECTIONS, MORE SCHOOLS OFFER FAMILY PLANNING
description: Despite objections from some Reagan Administration officials, there has been a rapid increase in the number of clinics that provide family planning and other health care services to students at public schools around the country.

title: An Initiation On the Coast . . .and Abroad
description: The way George Rush sees it, the main thing wrong with the English brand of American football is not the players but the coaches. ''You have Englishmen coaching other Englishmen,'' he says, ''and the instructors don't know any more than the students.''

title: Danish Austerity Plan
description: Prime Minister Poul Schluter of Denmark introduced an economic austerity package today that is intended to curb Denmark's domestic demand and ease its balance of payments deficit.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Job Cuts by ITT May Start Today
description: About half of the 900 employees at the ITT Corporation's Manhattan headquarters are likely to be laid off within 30 days, with the first job cuts possible as soon as today, industry sources said.

title: GREASE MONKEY HOLDING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SUPPORTING EXPERTS FOR ICELAND
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz wears two hats. One is as the head of the State Department, overseeing the more than 150 embassies abroad, flying around the world on diplomatic missions on his own Air Force jet, with a staff to cater to his every need. The other is as a senior adviser to President Reagan. It is in this second role that Mr. Shultz will be accompanying Mr. Reagan to this weekend's summit meeting in Iceland.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Tony Perez coach.

title: FALLEN WAR CORRESPONDENTS JOIN TROOPS
description: An oak tree was dedicated and a plaque was unveiled in Arlington National Cemetery today to honor the more than 200 war correspondents who have been killed while reporting to the American public on the far-flung battles of the last 100 years.

title: SUNKEN SUB: A WINDFALL?
description: If the United States Navy could ever gain access to the Soviet submarine that has sunk in the mid-Atlantic, it could provide important intelligence for submarine warfare planners. But maritime lawyers say that unless the Soviet Union declares the submarine abandoned -which is considered unlikely - the submarine remains Soviet property even in a sunken state.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the partial settlement of an insurance claim amounting to $1.2 million, or 7 cents a share. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 28, 1986. The results of flow control operations have been included since its acquisition from ITT Corp. on Jan. 31, 1986.

title: In the Campaigns
description: The Democratic Party sued the Republican National Committee in Federal Court in Newark, charging that a Republican program to eliminate ineligible voters was an effort to intimidate black voters.

title: RABBI ABRAHAM L. FEINBERG
description: Rabbi Abraham L. Feinberg, who led demonstrations against the Vietnam war and the arms race in the United States and Canada, died of cancer Sunday in Reno, Nev., where he lived for the last 10 years. He was 87 years old.

title: Rose Is the National Flower
description: President Reagan signed legislation today making the rose the national flower. Guests in the Oval Office included Aimee Lynn Richelieu, queen of the Tournament of Roses in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Cash Shortage at People Express
description: People Express Inc. said yesterday that it was facing severe cash shortages and warned that if holders of its debt do not agree soon to proposed cuts in interest rates, its merger agreement with the Texas Air Corporation could be ended.

title: THE BRIGHT PALETTES OF ITALIAN DESIGNERS
description: Today's fashion shows demonstrated the many facets of Italian style. At a time when froufrou is making a comeback, the Complice clothes were stark and severe, a strong statement of hard chic. Salvatore Ferragamo made a case for contemporary classics, in clothes as well as shoes, and Franco Moschino told jokes.

title: Decision Time for Biden
description: Thanksgiving could be a momentous political event at the house of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware. Mr. Biden has said he will not seek the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination without the approval of his wife and three children. The family is reportedly is set to settle the matter over the Thanksgiving holidays, and if the Senator gets the nod, as his advisers expect, he will aim for a spring announcement.

title: CALIFORNIA VINTNERS REACH OUT TO AN EAGER MARKET IN JAPAN
description: REMEMBER when California wine makers couldn't wait to get their wines into the best New York restaurants and retail stores? New York was the prestige market. No more - or at least not as much. Tokyo is the new Emerald City, and California wine makers are doing everything short of taking Japanese lessons to get in on the action.

title: Senator Lugar as Leader
description: The Senate distinguished itself with last week's votes overriding President Reagan's veto of sanctions against South Africa and finally approving $200 million in additional aid to newborn democracy in the Philippines. Both votes were a credit to the leadership of Richard Lugar, the Indiana Republican who has invigorated the Foreign Relations Committee since becoming chairman in 1984. His remaining feat is to find the money for Manila without injuring other programs.

title: SOVIET EXPECTS ARMS CONTROL GAINS IN ICELAND
description: A Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister said here today that Moscow wanted the Iceland meeting this weekend to produce preliminary accords on two or three arms control issues.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter net earnings included $99 million from RCA operations before estimated acquisition costs, and G.E.'s sales included $2.31 billion from RCA.

title: WALL TO WALL SOUND & VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Biological Weapons: Outlawed but Not Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: This Y>ou Call Morning?
description: News headline: Projecting Cheapskate Image Is Goal in Congress Races In the beginning politicians ran against Red Russia. Soon all candidates who were on Russia's side were eliminated. We faced political disaster: with nothing to run against, could anybody ever get elected again?

title: Slight Drop In Yields
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds declined slightly for the week ended yesterday amid speculation of another discount rate cut.

title: CECILE MACMILLAN
description: Cecile MacMillan, who wrote romantic fiction in the 1940's and early 1950's under the name Cecile Gilmore, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at her Manhattan home. She was 88 years old.

title: CRIME RATE IS PUT AT A 13-YEAR LOW
description: The number of crimes committed against individuals and households last year fell to the lowest level since the Government began collecting the information 13 years ago, the Justice Department said today.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON TOXIC WASTES
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today to strengthen the toxic waste law, moving Congress and the White House toward a confrontation over the toxic waste cleanup program.

title: Europeans Protest on Chips
description: The European Community said today that it would ask the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to investigate the legality of a United States-Japan accord on semiconductor prices.

title: NEW RIVALS ASIDE, WALL ST. STILL CALLS THE TUNE
description: Wall Street, the bastion of capitalism, has suddenly found itself sharing the spotlight with a revitalized London and an emerging Tokyo as financial market centers. But for all the promise that these and other foreign marketplaces offer as they open their doors to new competition, one fact remains: The American capital markets, with headquarters in New York, continue to be the largest by far, and the envy of the rest of the world.

title: ITT Planning New York Layoffs
description: The ITT Corporation, as expected, said it planned to cut by more than half the 850 jobs at its New York headquarters, including clerical employees and executives. The staff cutbacks, which were expected, are intended to save the company about $50 million a year.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In South Africa, Black Leninism
description: Congress battled President Reagan and won legislation to impose sanctions against South Africa in hopes of ending apartheid. But if we are genuinely concerned about helping South Africans to achieve racial justice without creating large-scale bloodshed, economic deprivation and political oppression, we must now face squarely the nature of an organization widely regarded as the legitimate voice of black South African protest: the African National Congress.

title: DEBARTOLO'S CLIMB: BUILDER BEGAN AT 13
description: Edward J. DeBartolo has never moved from the house he built in Youngstown, Ohio, in 1959 for himself and his family of four. But it is one of the few moves he has not made.

title: ALLIANCE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ryan Opposes Bid by NVHomes
description: Ryan Homes Inc., a Pittsburgh-based home builder, said that a $45-a-share tender offer from NVHomes L. P. was financially inadequate, and it recommended that shareholders not tender their shares. Ryan also filed suit in Federal District Court in Pennsylvania, seeking to enjoin NVHomes, a home builder based in McLean, Va., from proceeding with the tender offer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LONE-STAR FILMS The Collective for Living Cinema has a grander than usual opening tonight for its 14th season. It is, in a sense, a Texas-scale opening for the collective, which devotes itself to the work of independent and experimental film makers, with frequent reference to great movie makers of the past. The program at 8 P.M. today marks the formal working start of the group's new quarters at 41 White Street, between Broadway and Church Street (925-3926).

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter results benefited from a $2 million LIFO credit, compared with a $10,000 credit in the latest quarter.

title: KEMP ASSAILS U.S. ACTIONS TO GAIN DANILOFF'S RELEASE
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, a leader of conservative Republicans, today delivered a sharp attack on what he called the Reagan Administration's decision to release ''a high-level Soviet spy'' in exchange for ''an innocent American journalist.''

title: CAPTIVE AMERICAN RECALLED AS SEEKER OF ADVENTURE
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American captured by the Nicaraguan Government while aiding rebels there, was described today as a tall, red-haired adventurer who loved the outdoors and had a strong sense of competition.

title: Siltec Buyout Set
description: The Siltec Corporation, a leading producer of silicon wafers based in Menlo Park, Calif., said that it had agreed to be acquired by the Mitsubishi Metal Corporation for $7.95 a share in cash. The agreement no longer includes the requirement that 75 cents a share be placed in escrow for five years to indemnify Mitsubishi from potential claims, as had been previously announced.

title: OTHERS WHO QUIT IN PROTEST
description: In resigning from the State Department today, Bernard Kalb joined what Dean Acheson once called ''the most exclusive club in the America - men in public life who have resigned in the cause of conscience.'' Here are some of the other officials who have taken similar steps in recent years:

title: Metro Datelines; Firefighter Is in Custody
description: A female firefighter at the center of a sexual harassment controversy in the city's Fire Department surrendered at a Brooklyn precinct yesterday to face charges of setting fire to a vacant house in Portsmouth, Va., the police said.

title: INDOOR SHOPPING MALLS 30 YEARS OLD
description: Indoor shopping malls were introduced 30 years ago this week and retailing has not been the same since.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Playoff Notebook; Jackson Explains His Role
description: When the California Angels clinched the American League championship, Reggie Jackson remained apart from the champagne-throwing celebration in the clubhouse. Some Jackson watchers suspected his behavior stemmed from his unhappiness with what he had said was the club's decision not to sign him for next season.

title: 'AFRICANS,' A SERIES ON 13
description: ''THE AFRICANS'' is an exercise in moralism, a nine-hour series obsessed by its own higher truth: Western values are pernicious; Western society is, and always has been, corrupt. ''The Africans,'' which begins on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is not burdened by complexity.

title: SCOTT CAN PITCH, BUT HE SURE CAN'T HIT
description: In the interview room after the game, Mike Scott, an ice pack bulging from under the right shoulder of his blue jacket, sat and was ready to answer questions.

title: CITY OPERA: NEW SINGERS IN 'WERTHER'
description: THE New York City Opera is to be congratulated for its attention to French repertory this season, and its new production of ''Werther'' is surely a boon to those who wish to partake of the Massenet mini-revival that seems to be happening worldwide. Likewise, the Lotfi Mansouri-Thierry Bosquet production is sound enough, although clearly Mr. Bosquet could have provided more beautiful, luxurious stage pictures given an even slightly more generous budget.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
NEW MILFORD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: New Milford went public in February.

title: NEW LOS ANGELES OPERA DEBUTS WITH 'OTELLO
description: A new Los Angeles opera company opened its first season Tuesday night with a new production of Verdi's ''Otello'' with Placido Domingo singing the title role. It was the latest bid by Los Angeles to shed a reputation as the only major city in the Western world to lack an opera company of its own.

title: GMF to Shut Plant
description: The GMF Robotics Corporation, jointly owned by the General Motors Corporation and Fanuc Ltd. of Japan, said it would close a recently opened plant in Utah because of G. M.'s cancellation of a major equipment order. GMF, which earlier this year ordered layoffs for 200 of 700 employees in Detroit, said 37 workers at its new plant at Salt Lake City would be affected.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: BULBS AND CRAFTS
description: Annual Bulb Sale, Wave Hill, 675 West 252d Street, Bronx; 212-549-3200.

title: THE BALLET: FELD 'ECHO' PREMIERES
description: THE Feld Ballet, which opened its season last night at the Joyce Theater, has acquired several new dancers and the difference is already felt in the best sense.

title: Daniloff's Reservations
description: n a letter to Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., hand-written while he was in the United States Embassy after being released from prison in the Soviet Union, Nicholas S. Daniloff thanked the Speaker for the support of Congress. But he expressed deep concern over the arrangements for his release after the Soviet Union accused him of spying.

title: 'Puppetronics' Display At the Citicorp Center
description: Visitors to the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street, can try their hand at being puppeteers at ''Puppetronics,'' an exhibition that begins Oct. 20 and runs through Oct. 31 at the atrium. The puppets, which range in size from several feet to 15 feet tall, are hooked up to a control panel that visitors can operate; the puppets were created by Ronnie Asbell.

title: A Big Wink for a Gray War
description: Whatever else is true about Gene Hasenfus of Marinette, Wis., he isn't Nicaraguan. His capture after an American-built supply plane was shot down Sunday in Nicaragua undercuts President Reagan's repeated claims that the ''contra'' rebels are indigenous freedom fighters, not mercenaries. The Administration may be encouraging such operations ''with a wink and a shrug,'' says Senator Patrick Leahy, a Democrat and the vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: ARCHBISHOP WARNS VATICAN MAY ALIENATE MANY IN U.S.
description: Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee has warned that disciplinary actions by the Vatican against Roman Catholic leaders in the United States are alienating ordinary Catholics from the institutional church and could cause many to drift away.

title: EDUCATIONAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $40,000 extraordinary gain.

title: People
description: * Timothy Lynch is going to T. McBrian Communications, publisher of Side Streets of the World magazine, as vice president, director of marketing.

title: PIANO: VASARY PLAYS LISZT
description: AS everyone must know by now, this year marks the 100th anniversary of the death of Franz Liszt, a composer whose contribution to music has been underestimated by most people during much of that time. Fortunately, this anniversary has brought some thoughtful explorations of his works that seem likely to alter our perceptions of Liszt's achievement.

title: 2 Chinese Counseling On China
description: SAMUEL WHITE and Donald G. Heller, veteran packaged goods marketers who served, respectively, at the Liggett Group and Chesebrough-Pond's, are playing modern Marco Polos these days with the help of a very special couple, the P'ans of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: MAN HIRES AIRPLANE AND FALLS TO DEATH IN A NEVADA MYSTERY
description: A man wearing a white dinner jacket hired a notary and two video camera operators to accompany him on a chartered airplane flight Monday night. At 10,000 feet he opened the door and toppled out, a witness said.

title: PETER F. YACAVONE
description: Peter F. Yacavone, vice chairman of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, a paper-manufacturing concern, died of an apparent heart attack Sept. 28 at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 58 years old.

title: DR. ALLAN BUTLER, PIONEER IN HEATLH
description: Dr. Allan Macy Butler, a pioneer in health maintenance services and an early advocate of government-paid medical care for the elderly and for indigent people, died Tuesday at his home in Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. He was 92 years old.

title: U.S. Plane Crashes in Spain
description: An American pilot escaped unhurt when his F-16 fighter plane crashed today near a United States air base here in eastern Spain, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. He said the pilot had parachuted out of the plane, which crashed against a mountain side.

title: ISRAELI FUNERAL IS AN ANTI-ARAB PROTEST
description: Yisrael Kitaro, the Ashkelon taxi driver whose throat was cut Tuesday while he was having his car repaired in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, was buried today in a funeral that erupted into a demonstration of anti-Arab emotions.

title: MARS GRAPHIC SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The net income and share earnings figures are pro forma.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-After a gain of $1,408,000 from an accounting change. The latest year includes a loss of $679,000 resulting at the end of the second quarter of the company's store located at Mohegan Lake, N.Y., and an increase of $1,180,000, net of income taxes, or 26 cents a share, in the fourth quarter resulting from the settlement of certain legal proceedings for fiscal years 1972 through 1975.

title: PROMISED CHANGES CAME SUDDENLY
description: The Islander roster was trimmed to 23 players today, and after practice, those players who survived the final cut quietly taped their sticks and packed their duffel bags in preparation for the season opener Thursday night in Chicago. Although the players were not, for the most part, strangers, an aura of strangeness and absence did hang over the locker room.

title: Dow Climbs 19.40 to Close at 1,803.85
description: Stock prices rose smartly yesterday on a strong showing by both transportation and oil issues and the continuing positive influence of takeover news. Trading was fairly heavy.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been adjusted retroactively for the 3-for-2 stock split distributed on May 16, 1986.

title: Broncos' Carter To Have Surgery
description: Rubin Carter, who has played more games at nose tackle (152) than any other player, will undergo arthroscopic knee surgery Friday and will be put on injured reserve by the Denver Broncos, clearing the way for Mark Haynes, a cornerback, to be activated.

title: Jersey Bonds Up to 6.5% Offered on Short Notice
description: A $195 million competitive sale of New Jersey bonds, rated triple-A, began yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Capital Markets. The issue was added to the competitive calendar earlier this week as New Jersey followed the lead of a few local governments that are trying to take advantage of market conditions and sell their bonds on 48 hours' notice.

title: DR. H. HERMAN SHUMAN
description: Dr. H. Herman Shuman, a pediatrician, who founded the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at the Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., in the late 1960's, died of heart failure Saturday at New England Deaconness Hospital in Boston. He was 74 years old and maintained homes in Longmeadow and Dennis, Mass.

title: THE EX-SPOKESMAN: BERNARD KALB
description: From the moment last Thursday morning when he read about the Reagan Administration's reported effort to deceive news organizations, Bernard Kalb's days and nights have been marked by personal anguish.

title: SOUTHEAST STILL DRY AS MIDWEST FLOODS
description: As the evening news brought fresh reports over the last week of yet more rain and worse flooding from Oklahoma to Michigan, David Word stared out at the cloudless Georgia sky and shook his head in disbelief.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF A PATCH OF SKY
description: THERE is one line that is crucial to the scale, the proportions, the mood, and the success or failure of every garden. It is the skyline. The size and shape of the sky, that great pale bowl inverted over all our strivings, is the determining factor in whether we feel exposed or enclosed.

title: SLAYING OF GALANTE IN '79 IS DETAILED AT MOB TRIAL
description: A jury heard dramatic testimony yesterday from the son and daughter of the owner of the Brooklyn restaurant where Carmine Galante, the boss of the Bonanno crime family, was shot to death in 1979.

title: HERS
description: THIRTEEN months ago Leon was not interested in babies. They didn't speak the language, and he was sure that if he touched one it would cry.

title: IN SUBURBS, SHOPPERS COME BACK TO MAIN ST.
description: Shopkeepers and other business owners in many of the downtown areas of the suburbs around New York are beginning to make a significant comeback against their longtime rivals - malls and strip shopping centers.

title: WESTAMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EDUCATOR IS CRITICAL OF SEX PLAN IN SCHOOLS
description: A member of the Board of Education, Dr. Gwendolyn C. Baker, said yesterday that, in her view, dispensing contraceptives at school health clinics encouraged promiscuity.

title: AMERICAN MIDLAND reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $1,230,000 and $1,441,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $86,000 and $312,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: TEXAN EMIGRATES TO SOVIET AFTER 'PERSECUTION'
description: An American cancer researcher said on television today that he had emigrated to the Soviet Union because of what he called ''persecution'' in the United States.

title: Accord Is Set On Conrail Sale
description: House and Senate conferees agreed on legislation tonight for the sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail.

title: CITY PLANS TO ADD 2,300 JAIL SPACES
description: The Koch administration, confronted with severely overcrowded jails, made public yesterday an emergency plan to add 2,300 jail beds in just over a year. Some would be in two new jails near the Canadian border and some on a refurbished Staten Island ferryboat.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $13,200,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months.

title: HORROR FOR A LOGISTICIAN: EXTRA BEDS IN REYKJAVIK
description: Shortly before 9 A.M. on Sept. 30, William Henkel, a Reagan assistant who oversees White House advance work, was summoned into the office of Donald T. Regan, the chief of staff.

title: SATOR IS EAGER BUT UNEASY FOR OPENER
description: The mood was upbeat, the predictions of the coach were heady, and then the Rangers went out West for a series of exhibition games and lost two players to injuries. Then they returned to New York and lost another player. The season, it should be noted, begins tonight.

title: Philippines Reports Purge by Communists
description: A senior military officer said today that Communist guerrillas put to death 600 of their own men this year in an effort to purge their ranks of informers.

title: CONCERT: JOSHUA RIFKIN AND MUSIC BEFORE 1800
description: BUSINESS as usual is a good thing to report when the business is the usually excellent Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church on 121st Street. Sunday afternoon the guests were Joshua Rifkin, with his six-member Bach Ensemble, and the well-known ''early music'' violinist Stanley Ritchie. On the bill was a Vivaldi concerto (RV 208) that Bach later arranged, along with three Bach concertos either derived from or later recycled into other of his own works.

title: New Chairman At Jack Daniel
description: David J. Mahanes, president of Jack Daniel Distillery for more than a year, has been named chairman of the board, Brown-Forman Inc., the company's parent, announced today. Mr. Mahanes, who joined the

title: Topics; Pitchers/Oils: Fats in Disguise
description: ''Baked with 100 percent vegetable shortening,'' boasts the package of a leading brand of cookies sold in supermarkets in an appeal to health-conscious consumers who want to avoid artery-clogging animal fat. Yet the fine print on the label reveals that the unspecified vegetable oil may be palm, palm kernel or coconut oil, which are far more damaging than any fat from an animal.

title: Integrated Stake
description: Paul Milstein, a New York real estate investor, has bought a 6.4 percent stake in Integrated Resources Inc., a New York-based financial services company that owns property in the city.

title: CALIFORNIA AMPLIFIER reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Talking Politics column yesterday misstated the political affiliation of Senator Paula Hawkins of Florida. She is a Republican.

title: House Passes Bill on Rackets
description: A bill to limit private lawsuits under the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act passed the House Tuesday and was sent to the Senate.

title: NEW COMPROMISE REACHED ON MOVE TO REVIVE IMMIGRATION MEASURE
description: Members of Congress today reported progress in efforts to revive a comprehensive immigration bill, which many lawmakers considered dead last month.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank has named Kenneth L. Dowd Jr. managing director in charge of its institutional asset management division.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $200 million financing by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company is under way through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The tile in our bathroom has lost its original glaze and is veined with many tiny grooves, but we don't want to replace the tile. Can it be painted? A. Yes. You can use any good grade of alkyd enamel, but a two-part epoxy enamel will last longest. Sold in most hardware stores, these create a tough finish that is highly resistant to abrasion and to attack by chemicals. It is important to clean the tiles first with a scouring powder, to rinse off the cleaner completely and then to follow the instructions on the can precisely. Q. The oil burner in our basement sends hot air into the house through galvanized metal ducts. Many of these ducts are in the basement, where I feel that a lot of heat is being lost. Our serviceman says insulating those ducts won't help much to increase the heat level to the rooms and is not worth the expense. What is your opinion? A. Uninsulated ducts do lose a lot of heat into the basement, but some of this heat finds its way upstairs through the walls, floors, etc. However, since the basement cold takes some of the heat out of the air inside the ducts, they are not delivering as much heat upstairs - in other words, the air coming in upstairs is not as hot as it should be.

title: West German Embassy Is Stormed by Iranians
description: More than 100 Iranians stormed the West German Embassy compound in Teheran today to protest the closing of Iran's exhibit at the Frankfurt book fair, but the demonstrators were driven away with tear gas, the Bonn Government said.

title: Metro Datelines; Black Jurors Are Court Issue
description: A Federal judge yesterday delayed three civil-rights lawsuits against the Police Department after an assistant city attorney admitted that he deliberately used his challenges to exclude blacks from the juries.

title: Hikers Advised on Apparel
description: The October-November issue of ''Trail-Walker,'' a publication of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, offers some exemplary advice to those who wish to hike while hunting seasons are in progress.

title: Metro Datelines; Stein Endorses Plan for Tolls
description: Joining the growing battle over tolls on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday that he favored continuing an experiment under which tolls have been charged only for vehicles traveling west from Brooklyn to Staten Island.

title: ZACCARO CHARGE SEEN FOR TODAY IN CABLE INQUIRY
description: A sealed indictment charging John A. Zaccaro with crimes related to the awarding of cable television franchises in Queens will be made public today, a spokesman for Mr. Zaccaro's wife, former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, indicated last night.

title: A New Publisher For Sport Magazine
description: Donald E. Hanrahan, 56-year-old president and publisher of Sport Magazine, telephoned yesterday to report that the publisher's title at the magazine is going to Charles M. Stentiford, 49, who will be coming aboard from Bill Communications' Successful Meetings magazine, where he is currently publisher.

title: AFGHAN TROOP CUT IS SET FOR OCT. 15
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would begin the previously pledged pullout of six regiments from Afghanistan next Wednesday and complete it this month.

title: BNH BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two Justices, Two Debates
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDERSON IS TRADED TO GIANTS
description: In a stunning move, the Giants beefed up their ailing offense today by obtaining Ottis (O. J.) Anderson, one of pro football's leading running backs, from the St. Louis Cardinals. In return, the Giants gave the Cardinals two undisclosed 1987 draft choices.

title: Two More in a Racist Group Arrested in Idaho Bombings
description: Two more men tied to a white supremacist group were charged today in a series of recent bombings in the northern Idaho resort of Coeur d'Alene.

title: Salomon Brothers Names a President
description: Thomas W. Strauss, the architect of Salomon Brothers Inc.'s international expansion, was named yesterday to the new position of president. The move was part of a management realignment intended to cope with the investment bank's rapid growth.

title: VISA FOR FRANCE: WHERE'S BEST PLACE TO GET IT?
description: When Air France Flight 34 from Chicago arrived at Charles de Gaulle Airport from Chicago today, there were only about 30 American passengers. All but a handful - no one gives exact figures -showed their new visas to the police and were officially admitted to France.

title: 'BABY ON BOARD' SIGNS BECOME CONTROVERSIAL
description: THOSE bright yellow ''Mother-in-Law in Trunk'' signs may soon go the way of the pet rock.At least that is the opinion - and fervent desire -of Michael Lerner, the unwitting father of this country's latest fad.

title: THE 'OTHER' PITCHER GETS RED SOX EVEN
description: Bruce Hurst? Nobody knew him. Not this year. Not here. The town belonged to Roger Clemens. Hurst could stroll along the Charles River on a summer afternoon and be ignored. Not Clemens.

title: ORION PICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: City Reaches Accord in a Suit Over Foster-Care Placements
description: New York City settled a 13-year-old lawsuit yesterday, agreeing to place children in foster-care agencies without regard to race or religion.

title: The Surer Way to Avoid Collisions in Midair
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Perron Re-signs
description: Coach Jean Perron, who led the Montreal Canadiens to a Stanley Cup in his rookie season, signed a new two-year contract. ''What more can you ask from a coach than a Stanley Cup championship,'' General Manager Serge Savard said.

title: Petro-Lewis Bid Extended
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc., the natural resources company that is trying to acquire the Petro-Lewis Corporation, announced yesterday that it has extended its cash tender offer until next Tuesday. Freeport has been unable to gain enough senior secured bonds and units of the American Royalty Trust, a Petro-Lewis affiliate, to complete its tender offer.

title: Keith Lee to Testify
description: Keith Lee, the career leader in points and rebounds at Memphis State, has been called to testify tomorrow before a Federal grand jury investigating the finances of Dana Kirk, the former Tiger coach, according to a report yesterday in The Commercial Appeal of Memphis. The newspaper did not name its sources.

title: Lucky May Be Selling Gemco
description: Lucky Stores Inc., in a move to deflect an unfriendly bid from Asher B. Edelman, is negotiating to sell its troubled Gemco unit to the Dayton Hudson Corporation, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Gold Warrants From Standard Oil
description: The Standard Oil Company said it would issue 120 million Swiss francs, or almost $75 million, of 3 1/8 percent bonds in the Euromarket at par, with detachable gold warrants, through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Ltd. of Switzerland.

title: Nobody's Perfect
description: Speaking of the Mets, that overbearing manner they're so frequently accused of carrying around must be contagious. An article in the October issue of The Washingtonian magazine concludes that, when it comes to the team Redskin fans most love to hate, Dallas has been supplanted by ''the cheap-shot, big-mouth New York Giants.''

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan on Aid to Contras The President suggested that he approved of efforts by private American citizens to help rebels fight the Nicaraguan Government.

title: P.L.O. MOVING FROM TUNIS TO YEMEN
description: In a move that appears to underscore the Palestine Liberation Organization's increasing isolation in the Arab world, the P.L.O. is moving its military headquarters from Tunis.

title: Alarming Words
description: Just how many Americans are functionally illiterate? And what does that mean exactly? Jonathan Kozol, author of the much-debated study ''Illiterate America,'' has just completed a new analysis for the newspaper industry and the findings, to be presented to the American Society of Newspapers Editors in Washington today, are disconcerting.

title: Marine Animals Freed As Ice Dam Ruptures
description: Hubbard Glacier's ice dam finally ruptured today, allowing pent-up water to rush out of Russell Lake and release marine mammals trapped by advancing ice four months ago.

title: Weinberger Sees Ruse
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger told Chinese officials here today that the Soviet pullout would be an elaborate ''ruse'' to make it appear that the force in Afghanistan was being reduced..

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Group Sues Schwab, Fed
description: The Securities Industry Association filed a suit today in Washington challenging the participation of Charles Schwab & Company in the offering of a new mutual fund.

title: Technology; A Better Pump For Injections
description: FOR diabetics who need insulin daily, and for patients who need frequent morphine to ease pain, bioengineers have made major improvements in a pumping device for injecting medications.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ASTROS, at Houston, second game of National League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:45 P.M.; WCBS 880, 8:07 P.M.) BOXING RENALDO SNIPES VS.

title: The Universal Suffering
description: Twenty-seven years in Houston have not altered Micheal Griffin's ack-ack Boston accent, but they have altered the source of his baseball anxiety.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A TOUCH OF THE PAST
description: BRASS fittings for roll-top desks and antique oak file cabinets are not things of the past. They can still be found in catalogues and specialty shops that carry reproduction 19th century hardware.

title: 24TH GAME IN CHESS ADJOURNED
description: The final game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov, who has retained his title, and Anatoly Karpov was adjourned today, when Karpov sealed his 41st move. The 24th game resumes Thursday.

title: Market Place; Creating Funds For a New Era
description: IF investors now have trouble selecting the right stocks and bonds and are uncertain about the timing of purchases and sales, they are bound to be even more confused after the Tax Reform Act of 1986 takes effect next year.

title: Auction Will Benefit Artists' Housing Group
description: A benefit auction of works by 150 artists, including James Rosenquist, Roy Lichtenstein and Claes Oldenburg, will be held on Tuesday to raise money for Artists for Artists, a coalition of groups devoted to protecting affordable housing for artists in New York City.

title: ICAHN'S USX PURCHASES ARE SAID TO CONTINUE
description: The stock of the USX Corporation traded heavily again yesterday, and Wall Street sources said part of the reason was that Carl C. Icahn was continuing to purchase the shares.

title: BOEING MACHINISTS VOTE TO ACCEPT REVISED CONTRACT
description: The union representing 40,000 machinists at the Boeing Company voted overwhelmingly today to accept a three-year contract that offers year-end bonus payments worth thousands of dollars, union officials said.

title: Will Democrats Self-Destruct?
description: The strategy of the Democratic Party's Policy Commission as spelled out in a recent statement, ''New Choices for a Changing America'' is a game plan for electoral defeat. It ignores social issues, like pay equity and reproductive rights; does not mention the goal of full employment, much less discuss how to reach it; and, on defense, it mixes hawkish generalizations with some dovish specifics in a way that will not satisfy or guide anyone.

title: TO METS, IT WAS A CLOSE CALL
description: Their clubhouse demeanor suggested a sense of reassurance. After the Mets fell behind the Houston Astros with the 1-0 loss to Mike Scott in the first game of their four-of-seven-game National League Championship Series, they could point to all the factors the Astros needed to win.

title: ADAMS'S INJURY CREATES GAP AT CENTER
description: It is not the best of circumstances for the Devils as they open their National Hockey League season.

title: CITY WITHHOLDS PAY FOR 13 WHO FAILED TO REPORT FINANCES
description: Thirteen city officials have failed to file required financial disclosure forms, according to City Department of Investigation records.

title: HAL WALLIS, PRODUCER OF FILM CLASSICS, DEAD AT 88
description: Hal B. Wallis, who produced, co-produced or supervised the production of more than 400 films during a career that spanned half a century, has died at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline on Sept. 16 about the financial plight of the Muslim Mosque in Manhattan characterized its members incorrectly.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $12 million and an extraordinary loss of $11.7 million. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $31.2 million for the quarter and $56.5 million for the 9 months and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $112 million and $120.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 9 months also includes a gain of $2.1 million from joint venture sale of stock.

title: STUDENTS FROM QUEENS SEE JUSTICE IN ACTION
description: To some students from Jamaica High School in Queens, Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the key Government witness, did not seem to remember too much about his years of crime, ''appeared to be covering up'' at times, but on occasion told a believable tale.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN MORGAN CASE SEEN
description: A former top officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company will plead guilty in Federal court today, according to his lawyer, on charges of having made $4.3 million in unauthorized withdrawals from Brazilian depositors' accounts.

title: FESTIVITIES OF AN ARTISTIC KIND
description: IN John Cage's score for ''Roaratorio,'' an interpretation of James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake'' that had its American premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Tuesday, background sounds include barking dogs, revving motorcycles, sloshing water and babies' wails.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS ENVOY TO PRETORIA
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Edward J. Perkins to be ambassador to South Africa. The full Senate is expected to vote on the nomination before the end of the week.

title: The Flying Bus Is No Bust
description: People Express, lushest fruit of airline deregulation, is about to be swallowed by giant Texas Air. That's bad news. Anyone with a heart had to root for the unorthodox airline that cut air travel costs. Anyone with a brain has to worry about increasing concentration in the airline industry.

title: FLOURISHES AND RUFFLES IN MILAN'S COLLECTIONS
description: As the Italian fashion openings for spring and summer continued, retailers from the United States were increasingly impressed by the quality of the clothes shown and the new direction fashion is taking toward softer, suppler and more feminine looks -reinforced by today's appealing collection at Genny.

title: Antioch Law School Gains
description: The District of Columbia Council approved legislation Tuesday to save the Antioch School of Law by creating a public law school that would eventually be merged with the University of the District of Columbia. The bill, approved by voice vote, needs approval by Mayor Marion Barry Jr. and Congress.

title: Centers Plan Partnership
description: Community Psychiatric Centers, which operates a chain of 27 acute psychiatric hospitals and 62 dialysis centers, said it would ask its shareholders to approve a plan to change the company into a limited partnership.

title: Make Way for More Workers
description: There's good news for the New York City job market: The city gained 50,000 jobs in 1985, reducing the unemployment rate to 8.1 percent and bringing the job increase since 1977 to an impressive 300,000. Yet the figures deserve only two cheers. For they also show that factory employment continues to plummet, with powerful implications.

title: Boxing Notebook; TYSON FOLLOWING D'AMATO'S KEEP-BUSY PLAN ON ROAD TO TITLE
description: Although Cus D'Amato died last November, before his protege, Mike Tyson, emerged as a world-ranked heavyweight, D'Amato's influence is still felt in the fighter's career.

title: ROCK: THE MOODY BLUES
description: ''THANK you for keeping the flame burning for such a long time,'' announced Justin Hayward, the singer-guitarist of the Moody Blues from the stage of Radio City Music Hall on Monday evening. Mr. Hayward composed ''Nights in White Satin,'' the wailingly romantic 1968 ballad that still remains a fixture on late-night rock radio. And the group's performance of the song - the ''Moonlight Serenade'' of the psychedelic era - drew a sustained standing ovation.

title: WRIGHT'S DESIGNS TO BE OFFERED AGAIN
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT, the architect of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo and nearly 600 residences, believed in licensing his designs for furniture and textiles. In 1955, he designed wall coverings and fabrics for Schumacher and a furniture line for Heritage-Henredon.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO SEND MOZAMBICAN WORKERS HOME
description: South Africa annnounced plans tonight to repatriate tens of thousands of Mozambican workers in retaliation for purported guerrilla attacks across the border by the African National Congress.

title: ALL SUITED UP, NOWHERE TO PLAY
description: The silliness started before the games did. An advertisement in a Houston newspaper yesterday, in the shape of a tombstone, proclaimed the death of the New York Mets due to ''Acute Reactions From Pitching, Hitting And Running That Was Inflicted by the 'Houston Proud - Houston Astros.' '' The announcement was made by local funeral directors.

title: SCOTT FANS RECORD-TYING 14 AND OUTDUELS GOODEN
description: Mike Scott, who was a struggling and losing pitcher on the Mets four years ago, came back with his split-fingered fastball tonight and conquered them.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 29
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $853,198, or 2 cents a share. The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in May.

title: Townsend Suspended
description: Commisoner Pete Rozelle announced yesterday that Greg Townsend, a defensive end for the Los Angeles Raiders, had been suspended without pay for this Sunday's game because of three ''flagrant'' fouls committed against three members of the Kansas City Chiefs last Sunday.

title: World Bank Issues 8 5/8% Debentures
description: The World Bank yesterday began offering $300 million of 8 5/8 percent debentures due in 2016 at par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: COLUMBUS LANDED SOMEWHERE ELSE, MAYBE
description: Attacking a centuries-old mystery, a team of researchers used computers and a new analysis of key documents to conclude that Columbus did not make his first landing in the New World where most historians had thought he did.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted retroactively to reflect the effect of the 3-for-1 stock split paid on June 9, 1986.

title: Accounts
description: * Rehab Hospital Services Corp., Camp Hill, Pa., to Wood/Cohen of Tampa, Fla., for advertising and public relations.

title: REAGAN AIMS FIRE AT LIBERAL JUDGES
description: President Reagan today railed against ''liberal judges,'' asserting that they were a factor in a crime epidemic that included the proliferation of illegal drugs.

title: PILOTING E.P.A. IN BIG SEAS
description: Lee M. Thomas, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is torn by divided loyalties.

title: Belzbergs Plan Sale Of Hamilton Beach
description: Scovill Inc., the diversified manufacturer acquired by the Belzberg family last year, announced today that it had agreed to sell its Hamilton Beach appliance subsidiary to the HB Holdings Corporation for about $103.5 million in cash.

title: UPHEAVAL IN U.S. FOOD INDUSTRY FORCES A HARD LOOK AT ITS FUTURE
description: The American food production industry, hurt by shrinking overseas markets, huge debts, falling prices and declining farm incomes, is in the midst of a substantial contraction and restructuring.

title: CBS EARNS $28.6 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it earned $28.6 million in the third quarter, results that several analysts said were better than expected.

title: Bridge: World Championship Book Will Have a New Publisher
description: A remarkable record of modern bridge history seems to be coming to an end in its present form. The American Contract Bridge League, which has done a great service to the game by publishing the annual world championship book since 1953, has decided to bow out.

title: MOSCHINO: MILAN'S IMPERTINENT DESIGNER
description: If the three fashion kings of Milan are the established giants - Gianni Versace, Gianfranco Ferre and Giorgio Armani - and if Romeo Gigli, the favorite of the black-clad avant-garde, is this town's crown prince, then Franco Moschino is its court jester.

title: DEAD BABY'S MOTHER FACES CRIMINAL CHARGE ON ACTS IN PREGNANCY
description: A 27-year-old woman is facing criminal charges in the death of her infant son because, the authorities say, she failed to summon medical help promptly when she began hemorrhaging the day he was born.

title: Bond and Note Prices Erratic
description: Anticipation of an imminent cut in the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate dictated trading patterns in the credit markets yesterday despite a conviction among many market players that logic, politics and economic fundamentals argue against such a move by the Fed.

title: FESTIVAL OF GARDENING ON LONG ISLAND
description: Now that the season brings respite to the busy gardener, there is time for events that may help in the planning of next year's garden.

title: SENATE VOTES TO BAR WITNESSES IN THE TRIAL OF JUDGE
description: The Senate, in a key preliminary vote in the impeachment trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, voted today not to call any witnesses or to hear further from the judge himself.

title: RED SOX DEFEAT BUMBLING ANGELS
description: Perhaps Doug DeCinces, California's veteran third baseman, summed up the remarkably sloppy game best. ''How often,'' DeCinces said, ''do you see a pitcher lose a ground ball in the sun?''

title: COLUMN ONE: CHANGES
description: Look AgainImpatient New York, restless and unmade, forever plots its next installment, even as newly cut ribbons flutter to the ground.

title: Appeals Court Delays U.S. Sale of Oil Lands
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered a temporary halt to a plan by the Interior Department to sell for $2.50 an acre Colorado oil-shale land that experts estimate is worth at least $300 an acre.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $156,000 for the quarter and $359,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,000 and $17,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: AMERICAN IS JAILED IN YUGOSLAV TRIAL
description: An American citizen of Yugoslav origin was sentenced to seven years in prison today by a district court in the republic of Montenegro for activities against the state.

title: Metro Datelines; Guilty Verdict In Sex Holdups
description: A 25-year-old Bronx man, accused of breaking into a number of apartments in affluent Manhattan neighborhoods, was convicted in State Supreme Court yesterday on seven counts of robbery and burglary and one count of sodomy.

title: U.N. CHIEF REBUTS SENATE CHARGE RUSSIAN IS A SPY
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today sharply criticized a report by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence that charged that one of his assistants is a Soviet intelligence officer.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AGENDA: OCT. 9, 1986
description: Big Plans for Brooklyn A dusty, largely vacant parcel of land, once home to Atlantic railroad terminal, at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, may be turned into a complex of offices, stores and condominiums. Board of Estimate expected to approve $530 million project after hearing. 1:30 P.M., Board of Estimate Chambers, City Hall Investigating Investigations Could there be better coordination between the city's Department of Investigation and its District Attorneys? Councilman Stanley E. Michels plans to ask John S. Martin Jr. during question-and-answer session with Mr. Martin, author of recent report describing flaws in department procedures. First meeting of Mr. Michels's new Subcommittee on Government Accountability. 1 P.M., 23d Floor hearing room, 250 Broadway, Manhattan Mistreated Children A coalition of community groups to issue 214-page report on the city's abused and neglected children. The group will note that problems and recommendations ''have been around since the time of Eleanor Roosevelt.'' No more blue ribbon panels, the report will ask of the Governor and Mayor. Instead, ''establish time lines and set dollar figures.''

title: FILM'S MAKER IS ANNOYED
description: The Israeli creator of the documentary ''The Russians Are Here'' has criticized the Soviet presentation of her film as an exercise in ''crass propaganda'' that distorted the documentary's intentions.

title: A GARDEN INSPIRED BY SHAKESPEARE
description: IN ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Oberon, King of the Fairies, tells Puck: ''I know a bank where the wild thyme blows, where oxlips and the nodding violet grows, quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine, with sweet musk-roses and with eglantine.''

title: HOUSE MODIFIES DRUG BILL, BUT SENATORS BALK
description: Pressured by election-year politics on the one hand and an urgent desire to adjourn on the other, the House and Senate remained deadlocked tonight on legislation to combat drug trafficking and narcotics abuse.

title: FOR TODD AND RYAN, A REVERSAL OF ROLES
description: That was no time warp on the Jets' practice field today. Richard Todd and Pat Ryan were indeed throwing footballs. But the order was reversed.

title: SHOCKER ON SOVIET TV: BROOKLYN EMIGRE CANDOR
description: Soviet television viewers have been given an unusual offering: an uncensored, uncut American television documentary on Soviet emigres in Brooklyn, openly discussing their problems not only with the society they joined but also with the one they left.

title: AMERICAN LIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JAZZ: RED RODNEY QUARTET
description: THE effervescent enthusiasm of Red Rodney, the short, stocky trumpeter and fluegelhornist, is still vitalizing his playing after 40 rigorous and adventurous years in and out of the music world.

title: NICARAGUA FORMALLY ACCUSES U.S. OF ROLE IN SUPPLY FLIGHT TO REBELS
description: The Nicaraguan Government formally accused the Reagan Administration today of sponsoring a rebel supply plane downed here and demanded an end to all American support for attacks in Nicaragua.

title: MCCALL'S-SEATRAIN TIE OFFERED
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago is offering to sell McCall's, the 110-year-old magazine, and related operations to Seatrain Lines Inc. in a complex deal intended to make the shipping line a more viable company once it comes out of bankruptcy.

title: ABRAMS AND KING TRADE PROBITY CHARGES
description: Peter T. King, the Republican candidate for State Attorney General, repeatedly questioned the integrity of the incumbent, Robert Abrams, yesterday.

title: SUCCESS OF SMELL IS SWEET FOR NEW GERMAN NOVELIST
description: A slender man with tiny metal-rim glasses, Patrick Suskind poked his head from the door of his sixth-floor apartment, smiled to a visitor and then wrinkled his nostrils suspiciously. ''Smells like rotten eggs out here, don't you think?'' he asked.

title: Homelessness Needs Two Solutions: Today's and Tomorrow's
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM ATTORNEY GENERAL DEBATE
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday between the two candidates in the Nov. 4 election for New York State Attorney General, the incumbent, Robert Abrams, and Peter T. King:

title: SPOKESMAN QUITS STATE DEPT. POST ON DECEPTION ISSUE
description: Citing the importance of personal and governmental credibility, Bernard Kalb resigned today as the State Department spokesman to protest what he called ''the reported disinformation program'' conducted by the Reagan Administration against the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: BEARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN TO STICK TO ARMS POLICY, OFFICIAL REPORTS
description: President Reagan plans to hold firm to his positions in the Geneva arms talks and does not plan to introduce new proposals at his meeting this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to an Administration official.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUSTICES HEAR DEBATE OVER PREGNANCY LEAVE
description: Confronting issues at the heart of a growing national debate about policies on pregnancy and parental leave, the Supreme Court heard spirited arguments today on whether states may require special job protections for pregnant employees.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1986
description: Companies

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said results include revenue of $3,427,000 in the latest quarter and $7,006,000 in the latest 6-month period from Howard H. Sweet & Son Inc., which was recently acquired by Designcraft.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LETTERS FROM PRISON AND OTHER ESSAYS. By Adam Michnik. Translated by Maya Latynski. 354 pages. University of California. $25. IF the struggle for a ''democratic alternative'' in Poland stands as one of the nobler political expressions of our time, it is owing to men such as Adam Michnik. Now 40 years old, Mr. Michnik has devoted most of his adult life to trying to find a way out of the Communist rule imposed on his country by the Soviet Union. In his part of the world, such a commitment often means jail, and so we have the gloomy title of this important collection of essays.

title: PUBLIC APATHY ON CORRUPTION CITED BY COMMISSION
description: A special New York commission on government ethics said yesterday that the public has not expressed sufficient outrage against corruption to force public officials to enact changes.

title: SINGLAUB DENIES LINK TO PLANE
description: A retired major general, John K. Singlaub, denied today that a group he heads had any connection with the cargo plane that was downed over Nicaragua.

title: STEP-SAVER DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $144,470 from a settlement from Exxon Corp. and $26,000 from a tax credit. c-Net loss

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 14.

title: PATTERN PROCESSING TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Denver Dilettante
description: Given the scope of his published work, it might have made more sense if he had been asked to write about a Reagan-Gorbachev summit. But, for all his interest in international affairs, Leon Uris, who lives in Aspen, Colo., doesn't keep up with Middle Eastern intrigue by maintaining an apartment in Cairo.

title: Helen Hayes to Receive Town Hall Arts Award
description: A special award ceremony on Oct. 26 at Town Hall will honor Helen Hayes and will mark the 65th anniversary of the hall, at 123 West 43d Street.

title: One Blow for Truth
description: At a birthday party for a former national security aide the other night, the State Department spokesman Bernard Kalb was not his usual convivial self. The ''disinformation'' problem was bothering him.

title: Plant Releases Toxic Fumes
description: Toxic fumes from a leaking valve at a chemical plant owned by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company drifted into Ohio today, forcing the evacuation of 1,500 workers and 150 residents.

title: Metro Datelines; 23 Arrested At Cornell
description: The Cornell University campus police last night arrested 23 demonstrators and demolished two shanties built on Cornell University's main quad to protest the university's financial investments in South Africa.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday about hospital care in New York City carried an erroneous figure from the New York State Health Department for the number of private hospitals. There are 75.

title: Burroughs to Slash Payroll by 8 Percent
description: The Burroughs Corporation, moving quickly to find economies in its merger with the Sperry Corporation, said yesterday that it would reduce its payroll by 9,000 to 10,000 workers by the end of the year.

title: A Rembrandt Is Found In German Train 8Station
description: A Rembrandt masterpiece estimated to be worth about $5 million was found undamaged today at the left-luggage office of a West German train station three years after it was stolen from a London gallery, officials said.

title: Topics; Pitchers/Oils: Baseball Parity
description: A novel measure of U.S.-Soviet relations: a Tass report that ''baseball, a sport that is quite popular in the world and is played by at least 300 million people, is to be cultivated in the U.S.S.R. along with softball and the old Russian game of lapta.''
