This week, just as American baseball headed into the playoffs, the cultivation started with a game in Moscow between two university teams.

title: Moss Wins Poetry Prize
description: Howard Moss is the winner of the Lenore Marshall-Nation Prize for Poetry for his book ''New Selected Poems'' (Atheneum). The $7,500 award is given annually for an outstanding book of poems published in the United States in the previous year. Mr. Moss, the poetry editor of The New Yorker, is the author of 12 books of poems, 4 books of criticism and 2 plays. Judges for the award were the poets Rachel Hadas, Richard Howard and J. D. McClatchy.

title: New Zealand Ship Wins
description: The New Zealand entry, Plastic Fantastic, the first fiberglass 12-Meter yacht, rallied on the last leg today and finished 40 seconds ahead of French Kiss of France for its fourth consecutive America's Cup victory in the challenger series.

title: GENETIC CODE FOUND FOR A VIRUS CAUSING A PERILOUS HEPATITIS
description: Scientists have cracked the genetic code for a virus that causes a rare but deadly form of hepatitis and discovered that it resembles a virus responsible for disease in plants.

title: Hottest Seat In Town
description: If you're a Met fan with an aptitude for subtraction, you may be wondering how it is that a team with a stadium that seats 55,000 and a commitment of 35,000 seats to holders of season tickets had only 3,000 or so seats left over to sell to the public for each of the National League playoff games.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: EVERY wise homeowner knows that getting the house ready for winter means more than merely changing from screens to storm sash and then turning up the thermostat on the heating system. It also means preparing the entire house to withstand the elements, plus doing everything possible to conserve heat and keep the interior comfortable in all kinds of weather.

title: NOT EVEN MAUCH UNDERSTOOD IT
description: He's finishing his 25th year as a major-league manager, as many as Casey Stengel had. Only Connie Mack, John McGraw and Bucky Harris have managed longer, but nobody has managed that long without winning a pennant.

title: THE CASE OF THE PURLOINED GODDESS
description: Last spring, Jonathan Rosen bought an ancient Roman sculpture of the goddess Roma from an art dealer in Switzerland. The dealer shipped the work to his office in midtown Manhattan, where Mr. Rosen planned to have it mounted and put on display.

title: Turning In Medals
description: A group of veterans and a 73-year-old woman who was the first civilian to receive the Bronze Star, will return their medals in a ceremony at the Lincoln Memorial today to protest the United States role in the conflict in Nicaragua.

title: INTERSTATE DEFENDS MERGER BID
description: The First Interstate Bancorp, breaking its silence on its bid to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation, began an effort today to persuade shareholders and Wall Street analysts that its offer would be beneficial to both banks.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary item of $109,000, which represents tax effect of net loss carryforward.

title: OFF-AGAIN, ON-AGAIN INSURANCE
description: Fifteen years ago, after riots rocked many American cities, Congress created a program to provide property insurance to homeowners and small businesses in high-crime areas where coverage was unavailable or too expensive.

title: LIGHT OPERA COMPANY, IN DEBT, TO CLOSE SUNDAY
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan, a troupe that offered sturdy, spirited performances of operettas by Gilbert and Sullivan, Victor Herbert, Sigmund Romberg and other composers, will cease operations Sunday afternoon, immediately after a matinee performance of Rudolf Friml's ''Vagabond King'' at the Cherry Lane Theater, it was announced yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1986
description: The World The State Dept. spokesman resigned in protest over what he called ''the reported disinformation program'' of the Reagan Administration against the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The spokesman, Bernard Kalb, told reporters, ''Anything that hurts America's credibility hurts America.'' [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Moscow Protest Staged Over Plea to Emigrate
description: A woman trying to emigrate so she can donate bone marrow to a brother in Israel who is stricken with leukemia tried to protest with her husband near Communist Party headquarters today. The police detained them for two hours.

title: GEODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Kaiser Holding
description: A group led by Joseph A. Frates, an Oklahoma investor, said it had raised its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to 27.6 percent, from 26.4 percent. The Frates group did not give any reason for the additional purchases in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CONCERT: BERIO CONDUCTS BERIO
description: LUCIANO BERIO, who conducted a program of his compositions during the New York Philharmonic's Horizons '86 series last summer, returned to the orchestra Wednesday night in the same dual role. This time he led a Haydn symphony as well as his own ''Voci'' (Folk Songs II), a 1984 work receiving its first New York performance, and the Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra, which dates from 1973. Either out of bravery or foolhardiness, Mr. Berio chose to position the Haydn symphony between the two newer pieces, which proved to be a temptation that much of the Philharmonic audience could not resist: fully a third of the hall emptied with an unseemly rush before the concerto and a few dozen more stragglers took flight while the piano soloists, Katia and Marielle Labeque, were laboring over the 13-year-old piece.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Metro Datelines; 5 Plead Guilty In Airport Trial
description: The month-old Federal trial of six people accused of extorting $1 million from trucking concerns at Kennedy International Airport was interrupted yesterday when five defendants entered guilty pleas.

title: WATERFORD SEEKS WEDGWOOD
description: Seeking to combine two of the leading names in tableware, the Waterford Glass Group of Ireland today offered more than $360 million for Wedgwood P.L.C., Britain's 227-year-old maker of fine china.

title: 'Humane and Positive'
description: Elizabeth Condon teaches Russian and French to high school students in Woburn, Mass. ''Before all of this,'' she says, ''I used to take student groups to the Soviet Union. I worked hard to try to promote some understanding of the society and culture. I still have so much affection for them.''

title: MOVING IS WHAT MARRIAGE IS ABOUT
description: THREE boxes of books, stacked in the corner, lean like a soft-sculpture man toward the dogeared lampshade. Nearby stands the green wing chair, the stain of my back from nearly 4,000 evenings across it like a ghost. In a paper bag is the pancake-size skillet that once performed admirably for ironing a wrinkled shirt. The plastic garbage bag, half-filled, yawns wide, waits.

title: 'CHANNEL 3, MOSCOW,' THE SOVIET VIEW
description: A COMEDIAN is standing before an audience clearly eager to be entertained. The first thing to be noted about the performance is that the comic is reading his material from a sheet of paper. The second is that the joke is dreadful, enough to make Henny Youngman look like Noel Coward. But this is not just another pay-cable comedy special. It's a scene from ''Channel 3, Moscow,'' an hourlong program that contains footage filched from Soviet state-controlled television. This unusual and laudable attempt to give American viewers a chance to see the world as it is seen by many Soviet citizens is being broadcast on Channel 13 tonight at midnight.

title: STAGE: TROUBLED MARRIAGE IN 'BEAUTIFUL DREAMER'
description: ''BEAUTIFUL DREAMER,'' a first play by Greg Zittel, would like to illuminate the psychological stresses on an interracial marriage. But almost from its opening scene, the drama fails to establish the basic plausibility of its main characters. When we first meet Betty Rollins (Carolyn Finney), an attractive, young black entertainment lawyer, and her white husband, Ed (David Newer), a would-be writer whom she is supporting, they are unpacking in the new condominium she has bought. Cuddling up to one another, they coo racial epithets as a prelude to pillow talk.

title: WOODWARD SAID TO REPLACE KING
description: Woody Woodward will replace Clyde King as general manager of the Yankees, a club source said today. King, in a mutually agreeable shift, will become a special assistant to the owner, George Steinbrenner, handling special assignments.

title: After Mr. Rehnquist's Elevation
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodhead Suspended
description: Bob Brodhead, the Louisiana State University athletic director, was suspended with pay yesterday after the State Commission on Ethics accused him and a Baton Rouge businessman of violating the state's ethics code.

title: CANADA PLANS RESPONSE TO A U.S. LUMBER DUTY
description: As the authorities in the United States prepare to announce a decision on whether to impose a duty on imports of softwood lumber from Canada, the Canadian Government is threatening retaliation. It is also studying ways to impose taxes that would exactly equal an American tariff.

title: Arco Sells Interest In Field to Amoco
description: The Amoco Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Atlantic-Richfield Company's stake in the Headlee Donovan oil and gas field in west Texas for more than $100 million. Amoco said it was buying Arco's 36.5 percent working interest in 113 producing wells, 37 gas injection wells and the Headlee cryogenic gas plant near Odessa, Tex., as part of its program to acquire quality oil and gas reserves.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Faith in the word of America is the pulsebeat of our democracy.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations.

title: 3d False Air Traffic Message
description: An unidentified male broadcaster broke into the air traffic control frequency at Palm Beach International Airport today and uttered obscenities, a Federal Aviation Administration official said.

title: DR. GARDNER, MIDDLEBROOK, 70
description: Dr. Gardner Middlebrook, a retired physician and authority on tuberculosis, died Sept. 27 at Woodland Memorial Hospital in Woodland, Calif. He was 70 years old.

title: Eastern Names Vice Presidents
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it had named two vice presidents, one for finance and one for personnel. Both executives come from

title: STAGE: 'GROUCHO: A LIFE IN REVUE' AT THE LORTEL
description: GROUCHO MARX is irreplaceable, but he is imitable, as Frank Ferrante demonstrates in ''Groucho: A Life in Revue,'' a new show that opened last night at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Less a musical than a stand-up impersonation with fringe benefits, this is a droll, affectionate portrait of one of our greatest clowns - and two clownish brothers.

title: BACTERIOLOGIST AND EDUCATOR
description: Dr. George Packer Berry, a bacteriologist and former dean of Harvard Medical School, died Sunday in Princeton, N.J., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: FIRST NH BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEAN, THE JERSEY POWER, TESTS THE NATIONAL SCENE
description: If Tom Kean is not putting his toe in the water, his aides like to say, he is at least standing on the shore throwing in pebbles.

title: GREAT LAKES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIVELY LESSONS FOR URBAN APARTMENTS
description: TRUSTING their budgets to less experienced designers, three New Yorkers got livable solutions to their housing problems. One new co-op owner worked with an interior design student to transform a mazelike row-house apartment into a folk art-filled miniature loft. A young design team adapted an unwieldy and drab fifth-floor walk-up duplex into a flexible home and design studio. And an architectural designer with a strong high-tech bent coped with a houseful of scrubbed Maine pine furniture and what could have been an overwhelming view.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Cheverly, Md., said it had retained Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. to consider the possibility of recapitalization or sale of its largest subsidiary, Service America Corp.

title: HAZARDOUS WASTE DISPOSAL
description: Every day in American homes, household products - paint thinners, furniture polishes, insecticides and glues - are dropped into trash containers or poured down the drain. But many of these products are toxic and can have harmful effects on the environment.

title: CHIRAC'S ANTI-TERROR POLICIES COME UNDER ATTACK
description: A major speech by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac on terrorism set off a raucous debate in the National Assembly today about the effectiveness of the Government's policies and the veracity of his assertions.

title: The Gate? Great!
description: During the first season in which each team attracted at least a million fans at home, the major leagues broke the attendance record they had set last year, jointly drawing 47.5 million. The standings of all the clubs in terms of attendance gains (+) or losses (-) from 1985 to 1986:

title: MEXICO DENIES 3 ARRESTED ARE FEDERAL POLICEMEN
description: Mexican Government officials denied today that three men arrested last month in the United States and accused of kidnapping seven United States citizens were members of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police.

title: Vietnam Calls Off Talks On Missing Americans
description: Vietnam, without any explanation, has called off talks scheduled for this week on accounting for the nearly 1,800 Americans missing in the Vietnam War, an American official said today.

title: New Poetry Award
description: A new award for poetry, in memory of Robert Winner, will be sponsored by the Poetry Society of America for ''a poem or sequence of poems characterized by a delight in language and the possibilities of ordinary life.'' The award carries an $800 cash prize. Entries should be sent by Dec. 31 to the society, 15 Gramercy Park, New York, N.Y. 10003.

title: Gulfstream Insider Case
description: An executive of Gulfstream Aerospace settled insider-trading charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. The allegations stemmed from profits he purportedly made in Gulfstream stock before its merger with the Chrysler Corporation last year.

title: LINDENAUER SAYS BRIBES FELL SHORT
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, who has admitted taking more than $250,000 in graft while deputy director of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, testified today that he was constantly being cheated by the businessmen from whom he demanded bribes.

title: Beirut Hostage's Wife Offers to Be Mediator
description: The wife of an American hostage being held in Lebanon, saying she understands both sides, offered today to mediate between the Reagan Administration and Islamic Holy War for the release of her husband and two other kidnapped Americans.

title: ROCK: NEIL YOUNG PLAYS AT MADISON SQ. GARDEN
description: NEIL YOUNG may be rock's scruffiest superstar - and he's proud of it. He likes loud, distorted guitar chords and basic, boom-chunk drumming; he rarely uses more than four chords per song; he prefers raw, out-of-tune music to slick but dispassionate performances.

title: U.S., CHARGING LAXITY, ORDERS PLUTONIUM PLANTS SHUT DOWN
description: The Energy Department, citing safety violations, today ordered the shutdown of two plants that make a significant part of the nation's weapons-grade plutonium.

title: JAZZ: GIOVANNI TOMMASO
description: THE Giovanni Tommaso Quintet, also known as the Umbria Jazz Festival All Stars, brought modern Italian jazz to the Blue Note on Monday. Mr. Tommaso, a bassist, leads a group that is fluent in post-bop jazz, from blues-inflected hard-bop to the complex structures of late-1960's jazz. But in Monday's early set, Mr. Tommaso's compositions had more substance than the quintet's lengthy solos in them.

title: Woolworth Announces Promotions
description: Harold E. Sells, the president and chief operating officer of the F. W. Woolworth Company since 1983, has been named chairman and chief executive. Frederick E. Hennig, 54, the senior vice president of worldwide merchandise operations, has been named to succeed him.

title: U.S. to the Rescue Of Haiti's Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Re's Reserves
description: The General Re Corporation will post a $40 million after-tax charge for the third quarter, it said today, because of a decision by its life reinsurance subsidiary to strengthen its net benefit reserves by $60 million.

title: REAGAN RULES OUT HOUSE COMPROMISE ON ARMS CONTROL
description: President Reagan today rejected overtures from the House of Representatives to resolve a deadlock on arms control issues on the eve of his weekend meeting in Iceland with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: PSYCHIATRIC CARE: THE SYSTEM IS OVERWHELMED
description: On a recent morning at the men's shelter on East Third Street near the Bowery, the scene in the waiting room is pandemonium. More than 100 disheveled men crowd the room, some crowded around a television, many sprawled, napping, on newspapers spread on the floor.

title: REAGAN CALLS PLANE'S CREW A NEW LINCOLN BRIGADE
description: President Reagan strongly suggested today that he approved of efforts by private American citizens to help Nicaraguan insurgents fighting the Sandinista Government, including those Americans who sent in a cargo plane that was shot down on Sunday.

title: ICAHN OFFER COMPLICATES LABOR DISPUTE AT USX
description: The effort by Carl C. Icahn to acquire the USX Corpororation adds more complexity to the work shutdown at USX, a bitter confrontation now in its third month.

title: Hunts Save Some Land
description: A tract of foreclosed land owned by the Hunt brothers was kept in the family on Tuesday when a company owned by two of their siblings bought the 48 acres from the banks. The Hunt Petroleum Corporation, owned by the trust estates of Margaret Hunt Hill and Haroldson L. Hunt Jr., paid $3.8 million for a two-thirds interest in the land.

title: STOPGAP BILL IS PASSED, AVERTING FEDERAL SHUTDOWN
description: The House and Senate tonight approved a two-day stopgap spending bill to keep the Federal Government operating through Friday.

title: Carbide Plans Bhopal Defense
description: Executives of the Union Carbide Corporation said today that the company was ''vigorously'' preparing to defend itself in Indian courts regarding the gas disaster in Bhopal, India.

title: PINOCHET SHIFTS ARMY LEADERS
description: The Government announced a series of retirements and promotions in the army leadership today that appeared to strengthen President Augusto Pinochet's already tight control over the most important of Chile's military branches.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Why 'We First' Must Take Second Place
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEECHES AT U.N. DEAL WITH APARTHEID AND THE AFRICAN DEBT
description: Representatives of six African nations addressed the United Nations General Assembly today on apartheid and the continent's external debt crisis. The Foreign Ministers of Honduras and the Solomon Islands also spoke.

title: JOURNALISTS LAUD KALB FOR QUITTING
description: Many journalists said today that they regarded the resignation of the top State Department press spokesman as a demonstration of his integrity and further evidence of the existence of a disinformation program within the Reagan Administration.

title: PUTTING VERNACULAR OPERA IN ITS PROPER PLACE, FINALLY
description: THERE has been an outpouring of vernacular operas in recent weeks, not all of them alike but alike enough to suggest a few insights into the future of opera itself. The most prominent example has been ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X),'' which will receive its fourth and final performance of the season Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. Then there was Duke Ellington's lovingly reconstructed ''Queenie Pie'' at the American Music Theater Festival in Philadelphia - also the progenitor of ''X'' - and now at the Kennedy Center in Washington. Finally, we have the new CBS recording of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical ''South Pacific'' with, among others, Kiri Te Kanawa and Jose Carreras.

title: Wickes Cos. Sells Simmons
description: The Simmons Company, an Atlanta-based manufacturer of bedding and furniture, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with a group of senior executives and the Wesray Capital Corporation to buy the company for about $120 million. Simmons, a subsidiary of the Wickes Companies, said the group of management investors was led by Robert A. Magnusson, Simmons's president and chief operating officer.

title: College Football Notebook; TENACIOUS PASSER GIVES RIVALS FITS
description: Mike Perez is a scrappy 6-foot-2-inch, 215-pound quarterback for San Jose State who is appreciated by his bigger teammates on the line. ''He's not one of those pretty-boy quarterbacks,'' said David Diaz-Infante, the left guard. ''He's a tough one.''

title: Ashe's Mission
description: Arthur Ashe showed up in the South Bronx yesterday to help the New York Junior Tennis League dedicate nine tennis courts in the hope that the city might get back into the business of developing world-class tennis players.

title: GIBSON, C R CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALLIED'S STOCK HITS OFFER PRICE
description: The common stock of Allied Stores rose $2 yesterday to close at $67, the offering price made on Tuesday by Edward J. DeBartolo and Paul A. Bilzerian, and which the big retailer accepted.

title: Railroad Merger Case
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission left open the possibility today that it might reconsider its controversial rejection of a proposed merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railroads. The I.C.C., which rejected the merger because of concern about competition, said it would decide whether to reopen the case in 60 days.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEADING NORTH TO VIEW THE COLORS OF FALL
description: FOR the last 25 years, Dan Smiley, director of research for the Mohonk Preserve just outside New Paltz, N.Y., has observed trees and shrubs in the Shawangunk Range to determine the average date for the peak of fall foliage color changes. His conclusion: Oct. 10.

title: DYSON AND GREEN BEGIN ADVERTISING IN RACE WITH D'AMATO
description: In an attempt to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's extensive media campaign, his two main rivals for the United States Senate began advertising campaigns of their own yesterday despite treasuries considerably smaller than the Republican Senator's.

title: Advertising; Military's Magazine On Careers
description: IN January the high school seniors of America, some 3.1 million of them, will receive at home in the mail and absolutely free a handsome 48-page career guide.

title: Settlement for Dooley
description: The Virginia Tech football coach, Bill Dooley, will be leaving the school at the end of the season, taking with him a sum of money to settle his $3.5 million lawsuit against Virginia Tech, said William Lavery, the university's president. Dooley, Virginia Tech's athletic director and football coach for nine years, agreed to an out-of-court settlement of his Sept. 15 lawsuit.

title: Why Illegal Drugs Are Getting Stronger
description: To the Editor:

title: Moratorium on S.R.O.'s Deserves No Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: INVENTOR OF WHIRPOOL BATH
description: Candido Jacuzzi, who in 1949 invented the whirlpool bath that made his name a household word, died Tuesday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 83 years old and had been paralyzed since he suffered a stroke in 1975.

title: THE FIVE MAIN ISSUES
description: Medium-Range Missiles American and Soviet officials have said that one of the most promising areas for negotiation at the Iceland talks is an agreement on a reduction of medium-range missiles in Europe. There is a lesser chance of major progress on nuclear testing though some headway could be made. President Reagan has said, according to advisers, that he will not let arms issues monopolize the Iceland talks. When the two men meet for their planned six or seven hours of discussions in Reykjavik, other topics are expected to include human rights, regional conflicts, and issues that involve Soviet-American agreements on subjects not directly related to arms.

title: AQUINO TO APPEAL ON THE ECONOMY
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that her Government had completed the groundwork for an economic recovery and that it was now up to the private sector to become more active.

title: SCREEN: WHOOPI GOLDBERG IN 'JUMPIN' JACK FLASH'
description: AS she demonstrated in Steven Spielberg's ''Color Purple,'' in which she gave a good, disciplined performance in a production that could otherwise have used some of her restraint, Whoopi Goldberg is a legitimate actress -one capable of submerging her own personality in the interests of a particular characterization.

title: RACE RAISED AS ISSUE IN VARIETY OF DISPUTES AT DETROIT'S BORDERS
description: In the well-tended parks of this Detroit suburb, the rallies, boycotts and symbolic softball games on the restricted diamonds have ended. And, in practical terms, it is getting too cold to matter much who gets to swim in the pool.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jimmy Esposito Dies at 69; Supervised Stadium Upkeep
description: Vincent James (Jimmy) Esposito, maintenance superintendent at Yankee Stadium, died of cancer Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Staten Island.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: FOR star watching at its best, it would have been hard to beat the assemblage at the Palladium the other evening. Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward, Tom Cruise, Emilio Estevez, Mariel Hemingway, Michael Douglas, Madeline Kahn and Jennifer Beals, as well as Calvin Klein and his new bride, Kelly, were among the 1,500 people who piled into the club after a screening of ''The Color of Money.'' The coffers of the beneficiary, the Actors Studio, were enriched by $213,000.

title: CHEMICAL'S NET INCOME RISES 3.7%
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, holding company for Chemical Bank, said yesterday that net income rose 3.7 percent in the third quarter. Earnings totaled $99.1 million, or $1.87 a share, up from $95.6 million, or $1.80 a share, in the third quarter last year.

title: Birdsong Negotiations
description: Bob Woolf, the attorney who represents the free-agent guard Otis Birdsong, met for two hours yesterday with Alan Aufzien, the Nets' chief executive officer, in a session Woolf called the ''most productive'' of their talks. He added that the 30-year-old guard could sign a contract within the next few days and join the team at training camp ''if things continue as well as they did today.''

title: Festivals And Fairs
description: Today Bryant Park Craft Show, 42d Street, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas. Clothing, leather goods, porcelain, ceramics, sculpture. Today, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tomorrow Book and Record Fair, Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South.

title: FRIEDMAN WITMESS PLEAS ARE SEEN
description: Dr. Jerome Driesen, a psychiatrist who was identified last week as a secret witness in the Government's corruption case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, is expected to enter guilty pleas today in Federal and state cases in which he is accused of committing crimes.

title: 'Big, Bold and Black'
description: The Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center, celebrating its 10th season, will present ''Big, Bold and Black'' today, tomorrow and Sunday at 4 P.M. at Klitgord Auditorium, New York Technical College, Jay and Tillary Streets, in Brooklyn.

title: Motorists Warned on Tunnel
description: Motorists are being warned by the New Jersey Department of Transportation not to use the Lincoln Tunnel tomorrow. The three eastbound lanes of the North Bergen Viaduct, the main route to the tunnel from New Jersey, will be closed from midnight tonight until noon tomorrow for repairs.

title: drawing; Why Hurry Into a Weapons Accord?
description: Washington and Moscow seem to be well on the way toward reaching some sort of an accord on nuclear arms. Conservatives worry that the President is about to make one-sided concessions and settle for a disadvantageous deal. This may or may not be likely, but this is not the real issue. Even a good deal would be a mistake, for the root of the problem is not nuclear weapons.

title: Credit Poland, Credit Sanctions
description: Poland's political scene has sprung to life again. Through an amnesty intended mostly to impress foreign critics, the Jaruzelski regime has permitted Solidarity's main leaders to join forces for the first time in five years. That makes possible a constructive new relationship between the regime and its Solidarity petitioners, and the United States is in a good position to encourage it.

title: The Home Front
description: Conscious that Raisa Gorbachev will be a subject of world press attention at Reykjavik, Nancy Reagan's press office at the White House has been emphasizing that Mrs. Reagan will be active while President Reagan is off conferring with the Soviet leader. Events for which aides have urged coverage include a luncheon speech to the National Federation of Parents for Drug-Free Youth yesterday and ceremonies at Catholic University tomorrow, where Mrs. Reagan will receive the institution's Cardinal Gibbons Medal for her efforts against drug abuse.

title: Weekend At Belmont
description: The local action at Belmont this weekend features three potential champion fillies on successive days.

title: Federal Revenue-Sharing: Born 1972. Died 1986. R.I.P.
description: In the first week of October, 39,000 cities, counties, towns, villages and other communities across the county received checks from the Treasury, some as small as $201. The biggest -$41,957,530 - went to New York City. With these checks, the program of Federal revenue-sharing came to an end, 14 years and $85 billion after it began.

title: 9 Are Executed in Indonesia
description: Indonesia executed nine men convicted of helping to lead an attempted coup in 1965, a military spokesman said today.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Ex-U.S. Housing Aide Linked to Lecture Pay
description: A top Federal housing official who resigned last February under allegations of wrongdoing was paid for private lectures he gave while traveling on Government business, an internal investigation showed Wednesday.

title: PRESIDENT ARRIVES FOR ICELAND TALKS
description: President Reagan, saying ''serious problems'' in arms control, human rights and other areas mark the relationship with the Soviet Union, arrived here today for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: INSIDE
description: Most Drug Use Stable A new survey says use of almost all illicit drugs except cocaine either remained stable or fell, though drug abuse was still common. Page A14. Met Win, Tie Playoff Bob Ojeda pitched the Mets to a 5-1 victory over the Astros that evened their series at 1-1, with Game 3 at Shea Stadium tomorrow, Page D19.

title: Leif Ericsson Day Observed
description: President Reagan today proclaimed the day Leif Ericsson Day in honor of the Viking explorer widely believed to have been the first European to reach North America. In a proclamation required by a Congressional resolution, Mr. Reagan said that Ericsson ''kindled the enthusiasm that brought other European explorers, missionaries, settlers and adventurers to North America in the years to follow.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1986
description: Markets

title: HIGH PROFILE FOR SOUTH KOREAN 'EMBASSY IN EXILE'
description: ''We would like to use this opportunity to express our deep appreciation to Ambassador Richard Walker for his dedicated effort to bring about stability and democracy to the troubled land of our heritage, Korea,'' said the statement issued at Senate confirmation hearings on the appointment of James R. Lilley as his successor as envoy to South Korea.

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9,609,000 and a gain on disposals of $129,700,000.

title: NICHOLS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Associate Publisher Leaving U.S. News
description: The ambition to lead lies deep in the core of many a man.

title: Vice Chairman to Quit At Saatchi Compton
description: A memo has been circulated at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton notifying the staff that Philip Voss Jr., vice chairman since August 1984, will be leaving the company next Wednesday in search of other things.

title: Talks Are Continuing In Bid for BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation continued its evaluation of a takeover proposal from the First Interstate Bancorp today without giving any indication of when it might have an answer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anadarko Petroleum Corp., Houston, has elected to its board Conrad P. Albert, executive vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Larry G. Barcus, president of L.G. Barcus & Sons Inc., Kansas City, Kan.

title: FIRST CAME FIERCE GUNNLAUG; NOW SUPERPOWERS
description: There was the time the Viking hero Gunnlaug the Serpent Tongue fought for the love of Hilda the Fair. And there was the time Bobby Fisher toppled Boris Spassky with a king rook pawn. And Bob Hope and Bing Crosby came salmon fishing - separately.

title: ORION PICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: MILAN: ARMANI SOFTENS THE MANNISH LOOK
description: Giorgio Armani's wonderful spring and summer collection, introduced last night, moves tailoring in a new direction. It transforms hard-tailored clothes into a fresher, gentler realm. They become feminine rather than mannish without resort to ruffles and frills.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $36.2 million from the sale of a property, a $34 million after-tax reserve from the company's decision to further implement its asset redeployment strategy and an extraordinary charge of $3.5 million. c-After an extraordinary charge of $700,000. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: THE STRATEGISTS: THE UNITED STATES
description: Mr. Reagan's delegation is headed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Other key players are Richard N. Perle, an Assistant Defense Secretary; Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency; Max W. Kampelman, chief negotiator in the Geneva arms talks; Donald T. Regan, White House chief of staff; Patrick J. Buchanan, White House director of communications; Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, and these four officials: Paul H. Nitze - Senior adviser on arms control to the President and the Secretary of State . . . Has Ambassador rank . . . 79 years old . . . Arms control negotiator and member of United States team at talks that led to the signing of Antiballistic Missile Treaty in 1972 . . . Was a member of U.S. delegation at strategic arms talks from 1969 to 1974 . . . Opposed ratification of 1979 arms treaty. Rozanne L. Ridgway - Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs . . . 51 years old . . . One of the first women to hold such a position . . . Career Foreign Service . . . Headed American team that negotiated final communique at 1985 Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting . . . Not a Soviet expert but did serve as Ambassador to East Germany.

title: CORRUPTION TRIAL HEARS TAPE OF A BRIBE REFUSAL
description: The former director of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau refused to accept a $5,000-a-month payment from a debt-collection agency that wanted him to stay in his job so that a bribery scheme could continue, according to a tape-recorded conversation played to a Federal jury here today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Iceland is not just mukluks and Ice Station Zebra, by any means.'' - Charles Pucie, of Gray & Company, Iceland's newly hired public relations consultant. [ A12:3. ]

title: HOUSES OF WORSHIP OPEN THEIR DOORS TO THE ARTS
description: ONLY a few years ago, church concerts were in many cases synonymous with choral music and organ recitals. But this has been changing. Today, numerous New York houses of worship have opened their doors to a wide variety of alternative programming, and everybody, no matter his religious beliefs, should be able to find a compelling reason to go to church - and not just on the Sabbath, either.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday GIVING LISZT A LISTEN The pianist Robert Goldsand will perform an all-Liszt program at Alice Tully Hall tonight to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the composer's death. The program will include the B-minor Sonata, ''Au Lac de Wallenstadt,'' ''Au Bord d'une Source,'' ''Dance of the Gnomes,'' ''Tarantella,'' ''Spring'' and the Polonaise in E. The recital begins at 8 P.M. Tickets are $12.50 and $15. Information: 362-1911. A YOUNG DANCER IN DEBUT

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from accounting changes of $76,000 and $207,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest-quarter results reflect the operations of the former Mastercraft Industries Corp.; St. Charles Manufacturing Co.; Aspera, S.R.L.; and Kitchenaid Inc.; all acquired since late December 1985. The combined sales of these companies included in Whirlpool's latest quarter and 9 months operating results totaled $88,340,000 and $244,581,000, respectively. The latest quarter and 9-month results were also favorably impacted by approximately ll cents a share and 32 cents a share, respectively, as a result of adopting FASB 87 pension accounting guidelines.

title: Topics; Exploring/Deploring: Enduring Voyage
description: Five centuries after his great voyage of discovery and long since it made any difference, Christopher Columbus still can command the front page. He did it again yesterday, as the National Geographic Society announced a new theory about his first landing in the New World.

title: THE PRESS
description: What Next for Kalb?For Bernard Kalb, whose resignation as the State Department's chief spokesman took effect yesterday, there's been a ''marvelous banquet of offerings.''

title: Senate Passes Dealer Rules
description: The Senate tonight passed by unanimous consent a bill that will require dealers in government debt securities to register with the Federal Government.

title: CANDELARIA SET FOR GAME 3
description: John Candelaria, who is scheduled to start the third game of the American League championship series for the California Angels Friday night, is eager to reach the World Series so he can resume a dormant part of his career.

title: PRETORIA CURBING OPPOSITION GROUP
description: The South African authorities today banned foreign financing for the United Democratic Front, the country's largest anti-apartheid movement. The move tightened a crackdown on dissent that has led to the detention of an estimated total of 20,000 people.

title: Starring Role Is New to Barrett
description: There was a voice in the distance, and it belonged to Marty Barrett. But he was submerged in the crowd, amid the microphones and cameras that had been wedged into the Boston Red Sox locker room late Wednesday afternoon. They wanted Barrett; Barrett wanted his freedom.

title: A Nuclear Test Ban Is Good for Us and the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsico Profits Increase 12.1%
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its earnings for the three months ended Sept. 6 rose 12.1 percent over last year as a strong performance in its soft-drink unit more than offset a decline in its restaurant business.

title: DROUGHT, DEBT AND APARTHEID ARE MAIN TOPICS AT THE U.N.
description: The Ethiopian Foreign Minister, Goshu Wolde, told the General Assembly today that his country was encouraged by ''measures taken by some Western governments to isolate'' South Africa.

title: Ogilvy Wins Account Of Concord Watch
description: In a nine-way competition Ogilvy & Mather, the largest component in the Ogilvy Group, has won the worldwide advertising account of the Concord Watch Corporation.

title: AGENDA: Oct. 10, 1986
description: U.N. Vote on Secretary General Re-election of Javier Perez de Cuellar as Secretary General expected. Vote is earlier than usual so Peruvian diplomat, closing out his first five-year term, can preside over meetings involving financial problems of world body. The 41st General Assembly debate will end with speeches by ministers from Grenada, Papua New Guinea, Samoa and Nicaragua. 10 A.M and 3 P.M. sessions, United Nations Lower Milk Prices?

title: ART: MORRIS LOUIS SHOW
description: THE good news about the Morris Louis exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is that it presents the best work of one of the most lyrical, elusive and uneven postwar American artists. It includes only 45 of Louis's 650 surviving paintings, carefully chosen by John Elderfield, the director of the museum's department of print and drawings and a curator in its department of painting and sculpture. All were done between 1954, when Louis began his first series of ''Veils,'' and 1962, when he died of lung cancer shortly before his 50th birthday.

title: Here's How the Mighty Have Fallen
CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN ONE-ON-ONE, CHILDREN QUIT STREET FOR THE STAGE
description: When 11-year-old Arlen Collier shows up for the One-on-One Project at the Duncan Center Police Athletic League on West 52d Street, he isn't there to play basketball. He is there to rehearse. While scores of other children play ping-pong and video games throughout the two-floor center, he is trying to pick up cues, remember blocking and project his voice.

title: Fermenta Plant
description: A Swedish biotechnology company, Fermenta A.B., said it had signed a letter of intent for the Monsanto Company to buy its Ohio-based agrochemical subsidiary, the Fermenta Plant Protection Company. In a statement, Fermenta said both companies had agreed in principle to the deal, but terms were not disclosed. Dealers said the sale was not likely to have a significant effect on talks between Fermenta's chief executive and major shareholder, Refaat el-Sayed, to obtain his controlling interest in Fermenta, and for Montedison S.p.a., the Italian company, to buy his controlling interest in Fermenta.

title: INJURIES DAMPEN OLD RIVALRY
description: For such a storied rivalry, Washington versus Dallas doesn't have the usual feel this time. The Redskins and the Cowboys meet for the first time this season Sunday in Texas Stadium, and so many regulars may be missing because of injuries that it's hard to drum up the usual mudslinging intensity.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax writedowns and additions to reserves of $127 million and $316 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses from discontinued operations of $27 million for the quarter and $36 million for the year. c-Net income

title: MESSAGE IN A BAG
description: Second only to wooing the voters, a Congressional candidate these days concentrates on wooing political action committees, each of which can give him up to $10,000 in campaign contributions in a two-year election cycle. But there are 4,000 of these special interest groups and sometimes, just as with the voters, it is hard to catch their attention.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE; HAWKS 3 ISLANDERS 2
description: They started smartly enough and betrayed none of the signs of a nervous visitor to Chicago Stadium. But as the evening wore on, the Islanders were worn down by the Blackhawks and were ultimately beaten by them, 3-2, in a disappointing season opener tonight.

title: Ferraro Is Dismissed
description: Mike Ferraro, the third-base coach who became the Kansas City Royals' interim manager July 17 after Dick Howser learned he had a brain tumor, was released yesterday by the Royals.

title: GORBACHEV IS DESCRIBED AS SET FOR COMPROMISE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared ''to do all in his power to bring about reasonable compromises'' in his meeting with President Reagan this weekend, a Soviet spokesman said today.

title: Fannie Mae Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, sold $100 million of 9 percent fixed-rate, mortgage-backed securities yesterday at an average price of 100 1/64, for a bond equivalent yield of 9.05 percent. These securities are backed by residential mortgages guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration. The underlying mortgages carry a weighted average coupon of 9.50 percent and an average maturity of just over 22 years.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Julie Wilson, Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800). ''Hooray for Love!,'' the latest tribute in Julie Wilson's series of salutes to great songwriters, celebrates the bluesy songs of Harold Arlen. Accompanied by the pianist William Roy, who sings with her on some of the lighter numbers, Miss Wilson offers brilliantly conceived medleys that take on the shape and emotional complexity of short stories. ''One for My Baby'' segues into ''The Man That Got Away.'' A sequence of blues laments, including ''Stormy Weather,'' rings more with resilience than self-pity. A third medley from ''House of Flowers'' glows with tenderness and insight. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9:15 and 11:15 P.M. with dinner seatings at 8:15 and 10:30 P.M. There is a $15 music charge and a $15 food and beverage minimum.

title: Chilean Leader Seeks Talks With Opposition
description: President Augusto Pinochet has directed the Minister of the Interior to open discussions with some Chilean political groups about the proposed law legalizing and regulating political parties, Government officials say.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL BOSTON RED SOX VS. ANGELS, at Anaheim, Calif., third game of American League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8:07 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS BOXING: Bert Cooper vs.

title: Market Place; Texas Banks' Grim Realities
description: INVESTORS willing to bet that enactment of a sweeping interstate banking bill in Texas would be rapidly followed by a wave of takeovers at rich prices may be in for a costly surprise.

title: Festival at Fairfield U.
description: Crafts, music and dance from the Appalachian Mountain region will be featured at a festival this weekend at Fairfield University, North Benson Road, Fairfield, Conn.

title: 2 Americans Die Off Senegal
description: A DC-7 plane crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off Senegal today, killing two Americans and injuring a third, a spokesman at the United States Embassy said.

title: KEY RATES
RESTAURANTS
description: THE Quilted Giraffe, Manhattan's celebrated monument to self-indulgence, has undergone several changes since it garnered four stars in 1984. The young chef, Noel Comess, has left to pursue private goals. The owners, Barry and Susan Wine, have taken on the burden of a second, more casual, restaurant in midtown. Fortunately, though, what has not changed at the Quilted Giraffe is the entire staff's dedication, energy and passion for quality that placed this restaurant at the top of a crowded and competitive class.

title: 6 Fur Coats Seized at Shop
description: Six illegal fur coats - including a three-quarter length leopard stole and others made from ocelot, jaguar and snow-leopard skins - were seized from a shop on the 17th floor of the Plaza Hotel yesterday, state environmental officials said.

title: New Sperry Model
description: The Sperry Corporation, which has merged into the Burroughs Corporation, yesterday introduced a new mainframe computer that runs high-level software at a lower price and performance level. Sperry said the new computer, dubbed 2200/200, is compatible with all existing Sperry 1100 systems, but is much smaller, uses less power and allows users to run a large number of applications in a mixed processing environment.

title: ART: PAINTINGS BY WILLIAM WILEY
description: IT is to William T. Wiley's credit that for all his success, he is still the troublemaker he was 20 years ago. His work remains a mixture of image and writing, and his subject, more or less the relationship between art and life. On the other hand, and notwithstanding sculptures such as the giant steel harp that recently appeared on Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, the artist's funky neo-Dadaism has long since given way to something more dignified.

title: Champion Spark Plugs Switches to Scali
description: After 33 years on the job the Detroit office of J. Walter Thompson was shocked to learn that it is no longer the agency for Champion Spark Plugs. The business has been switched to Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which is also a component of the Ogilvy Group.

title: Demand for Elf Oil
description: The sale of part of the French Government's ownership in the state-controlled Elf Oil Company, the first in a planned sale of 65 state-owned businesses, has attracted overwhelming demand, stock exchange sources said.

title: PANEL FINDS SHUTTLE LAUNCHING GOAL UNATTAINABLE
description: A fleet of four space shuttles could handle only three-fourths the number of annual flights that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is now planning, a panel of experts reported today.

title: Topics; Exploring/Deploring: Soap Talk
description: Daytime and nighttime soaps have a lot in common, reports a friend who just spent weeks watching both. Each employs characters with English accents - some authentic, some clearly bogus - and living rooms in which the ice bucket is always full.

title: DRUG USE HELD MOSTLY STABLE OR LOWER
description: In the first comprehensive national survey of drug abuse in three years, a new Government study today showed that the use of virtually all illicit drugs except cocaine had either remained stable or declined.

title: Bad Interception
description: It was a big football game against Madison High School last week, and his team was behind in the second half, 14-7. So when one of his assistants started picking up Madison's radio signals on his own headset, Mike Weaver, the coach of Langley High in McLean, Va., didn't think twice.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1986
description: The World The C.I.A. supervised supply flights for Nicaraguan rebels, Eugene Hasenfus, an American captured from a downed plane, said. Speaking at a Government-sponsored news conference in Managua, he gave the most detailed account so far of rebel supply operations out of El Salvador and Honduras. [ Page A1, Columns 1-2. ]

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months results include a non-recurring pretax gain of $3,800,000, or $2.2 million after taxes, from the sale of a Canadian auto products business in May 1985. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock splits effected in August 1986 and September 1985. Results have also been adjusted to reflect the acquisition of Seco Industries in June 1986 and Gott Corp. in 1985; these acquisitions were accounted for by the pooling-of-interest method.

title: Diner's Journal
description: HOME cooking, mom food, cuisine de femme - call it what you like, this fall and winter, restaurants around town are expected to be stirring up ingenuous belt-stretching dishes usually associated with home cooking.

title: LOSS OF MEMBERS FORCES SUBURBAN VOLUNTEER GROUPS TO CHANGE STRATEGIES
description: Volunteer organizations in the New York suburbs, faced with a dwindling membership, are being forced to reduce services or to rely more on paid staff and adopt more businesslike practices.

title: U.S. PRISONER IN NICARAGUA SAYS C.I.A. RAN CONTRA SUPPLY FLIGHTS
description: An American captured when a plane delivering supplies to rebels was shot down here said today that the supply flights were directly supervised by members of the Central Intelligence Agency in El Salvador.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Biathlon in Brooklyn
description: Several hundred athletes will run, bicycle, and then run some more on Sunday during the Goldome Brooklyn Biathlon.

title: TEXAN IN MOSCOW: JOB PROBLEM CITED
description: A Houston cancer researcer who has emigrated to the Soviet Union had become increasingly withdrawn and uncommunicative over the past year to the point where he could no longer function at work, his colleagues said today.

title: 2 SENATORS IN FARM BELT AHEAD AMID DISCONTENT
description: These ought to be tough times for Senators Bob Dole and Charles E. Grassley, a pair of Farm Belt Republicans up for re-election in a year of agricultural discontent.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend distributed June 16.

title: U.N. Delegate Denies Disinformation Role
description: Vernon A. Walters, the American delegate, sought to distance himself today from reports of a disinformation campaign against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

title: Mexican Chief in Talks On Fighting Drug Trade
description: President Miguel de la Madrid opened high-level talks today between the United States and Latin American and Caribbean countries on ways to combat drug trafficking.

title: Ethics, and Anger, in New York
description: New York City has a fairly far-reaching ethics law requiring public employees to file reports of their assets and debts for public inspection. Yet no city agency reviews the disclosures. Forms are filed with the City Clerk, who is not required even to scan them for minimal compliance.

title: THE STRATEGISTS: THE SOVIET UNION
description: Mr. Gorbachev's delegation is headed by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Other key players are Viktor P. Karpov, chief Soviet negotiator at the Geneva arms talks; Gennadi I. Gerasimov, chief of the Foreign Ministry Information Department; Yuri V. Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington; Anatoly S. Chernyayev, Mr. Gorbachev's personal foreign policy adviser; Yevgeny P. Velikhov, vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences; Georgi A. Arbatov, director of the U.S.A. and Canada Institute, and these four officials: Aleksandr N. Yakovlev - Secretary of the Central Committee . . . Head of the Central Committee Propaganda Department . . . Considered to be architect of more sophisticated Soviet public relations activities under Mr. Gorbachev . . . Former head of the institute of world economy and international relations . . . Former Ambassador to Canada.

title: A U.S. AGENCY USED PLANE LOST IN NICARAGUA
description: The cargo plane that was shot down Sunday while taking ammunition to insurgents in Nicaragua was earlier involved in a United States ''sting'' operation against the Sandinista Government in Managua, the Drug Enforcement Administration said today.

title: A Merger Vote By Peat, KMG
description: The American partners of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. and KMG Main Hurdman yesterday voted to approve a proposed merger, the first step in a process that would create the world's largest accounting and consulting firm.

title: FILM SERIES SALUTES THE SOVIET REPUBLICS
description: IN Russian they call it ''zakuska.'' That means a spread of mixed appetizers, and if ever there was a zakuska of a film exhibition, it is the one opening today at the Museum of Modern Art. The series is called ''A Salute to the Soviet Republics'' and will run through Nov. 4.

title: A Nuclear Test Ban Is Good for Us and the World; Perilous Pipe Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: DERAILMENT OF TRAIN IN WISCONSIN KILLS CREW MEMBER AND INJURES 33
description: Twelve cars of an Amtrak passenger train derailed today in rural south-central Wisconsin, killing a crewman and injuring at least 33 other people, officials said.

title: War Medals Returned To Protest U.S. Policy
description: Three Vietnam veterans and a World War II Red Cross worker gave up their medals today to protest United States aid to insurgents fighting the Nicaraguan Government.

title: PLEADS NOT GUILTY AT ARRAIGNMENT
description: John A. Zaccaro was charged with attempted extortion and with bribe-seeking in an indictment unsealed yesterday in Queens.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in the Scouting column of Sports Pages on Wednesday, on ballplayers who achieved at least 200 hits, a .350 average, 30 home runs and 100 runs batted in, omitted three players. They were Al Simmons (who had two such seasons, in 1929 and 1930), Babe Herman (1930) and Joe Medwick (1937).

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After special gains of $2,010,000 for the quarter and $13,101,000 for the year.

title: Juilliard Quartet
description: The Juilliard Quartet will mark its 40th anniversary tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock, exactly 40 years and one day after its public debut.

title: LIU BOCHENG, MILITARY LEADER IN TWO CHINESE REVOLUTIONS
description: Gen. Liu Bocheng, who fought in both of China's 20th century revolutions and emerged as one of the country's best-known military strategists, died in Peking on Tuesday, the official New China News Agency said yesterday. He was 94 years old.

title: Alec Chien, Pianist
description: The pianist Alec Chien, who recently won the grand prize in the 1986 Utah Symphony Gina Bachauer International Piano Competition, will play his New York debut recital Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Prices Flat; Money Supply Off
description: With hopes for an immediate cut in the discount rate having dimmed and with no new economic news of consequence, trading in the credit markets yesterday was lackluster.

title: PHYSICIAN LINKED TO FAKE RESEARCH
description: A former cardiologist at the University of California at San Diego produced 13 fraudulent research papers and 55 whose authenticity cannot be proved, a committee has determined.

title: THEATER: BERNARD SHAW'S 'YOU NEVER CAN TELL,' AT CIRCLE IN THE SQUARE
description: AUDIENCES and critics have never really arrived at a final judgment about ''You Never Can Tell,'' the early Shaw comedy now receiving a new Broadway staging at the Circle in the Square. Then again, its author was of two minds about the last of his so-called ''pleasant plays,'' too. ''Did you really read 'You Never Can Tell'?'' Shaw asked Ellen Terry in a letter of 1897. ''Could anyone read it? It maddens me. I'll have my revenge in the preface by offering it as a frightful example of the result of trying to write for the theater de nos jours.'' Yet the piece eventually proved a popular commercial venture of its day, rather than a frightful replica of one, and soon Shaw was declaring it an ''absolutely actor proof'' entertainment.

title: HEAD-ON CRASH OF BUSSES KILLS 1 AND INJURES 26
description: A Manhattan-bound commuter bus and a charter bus carrying vacationing Austrian police officers collided head-on a mile west of the Lincoln Tunnel this morning. One person was killed, 26 were injured and the rush-hour tie-ups that resulted delayed tens of thousands of travelers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Conseco Inc., Medford, Wis., said it had bought all the shares of Bankers National Life Insurance Co. from H.F. Ahmanson & Co. for $117.6 million.

title: Kranepool at Bat: Crowd Roars
description: Ed Kranepool is the sort of guy who'll go to bat for a friend. So when an old buddy called him a while back and asked for a favor, he didn't hestitate to say yes. Which is how it came about the other day that Kranepool put on one of his old uniforms with ''Mets'' emblazoned across the chest and traveled to a Long Island baseball field to make a television commercial endorsing his friend, Senator Alfonse D'Amato, for re-election.

title: Columbia Pictures Head Joins Allen & Company
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that Richard C. Gallop, president and chief operating officer of its Columbia Pictures Industries division and executive vice president of Coca-Cola's entertainment business sector, had resigned to join Allen & Company, the investment banking firm.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted retroactively for the 3-for-2 stock split in August 1986.

title: Brief Candle
description: The only House member not pushing to adjourn early next week and go home is probably Representative Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii, who might like to tell his grandchildren he served in Congress longer than three weeks. Mr. Abercrombie was elected Sept. 20 to fill a term that expires when Congress adjourns; on the same day he lost the Democratic primary for the same seat in the next Congress. So he finds himself, sadly, just passing through the Capitol.

title: Officials Seek More Jail Cells
description: Westchester officials yesterday called for $1 million in special financing to construct emergency jail cells, citing a sudden rise in the county jail population.

title: Board of Trade Is Criticized
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has criticized the Chicago Board of Trade for not doing enough investigating of its most actively traded contracts to uncover abuses.

title: 'Mark Morris,' a Sampler Of Choreographer's Work
description: Not only does Mark Morris seem to choreograph dances as easily as a tree grows apples, but he also choreographs in an almost bewildering variety of styles. His dances aren't just apples, they're peaches and pears, as well.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about two Polish dissidents who received the Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award reversed their identities. Zbigniew Bujak was on the left, Adam Michnik on the right.

title: Dining Out: Haute French
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. LA COTE BASQUE, #5 East 55th Street (688-6525) - ***(Aug. 22, 1986) For those who yearn for uncompromising classic fare, La Cote Basque may be the place to go. The wraparound dining room exudes a timeless glamour with its murals of coastal France, red leather banquettes, splendid flower clusters and a well-turned-out crowd.

title: METS BEAT THE HEAT INDOORS
description: In the great indoors of the Astrodome, where the temperature can be 72 degrees day or night and summer or fall, the second game of the National League Championship Series seemed to be all about heat.

title: GEBAUER OFFERS GUILTY PLEA
description: A former top officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company pleaded guilty, as expected, in Federal court yesterday to charges of defrauding the bank by making $4.3 million in unauthorized withdrawals from the accounts of Brazilian depositors.

title: DOW FALLS 7.03 POINTS, TO 1,796.82
description: With the International Business Machines Corporation's stock acting as its millstone, Wall Street's rally sunk yesterday just one day after it began.

title: 2 FILMS, 'BOUGH BREAKS' AND 'CIRCLE OF VIOLENCE'
description: AS two of this weekend's new television movies are scheduled against each other, on Sunday at 9 P.M., and as both of them fall apart about halfway through, any decision to watch either will depend on what story genre you might fancy. NBC's ''When the Bough Breaks'' is a kind of mystery, its Phil Penningroth script based on a novel by Jonathan Kellerman. CBS's ''Circle of Violence'' is a family drama tackling still another social issue. William Wood's script deals with an elderly woman who is being physically abused by her daughter, who is herself a mother.

title: Navratilova Wins Suit
description: A jury in Riverhead, L.I., yesterday found Martina Navratilova not guilty of hurting a photographer when she grabbed his camera in a scuffle after Ms. Navratilova's defeat at the 1982 United States Open. The photographer, Arthur Seitz of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., sued Ms. Navratilova for $2 million after she took his camera and exposed his film in the incident.

title: ON TERRORIST FRONT AT CONNECTICUT MOTEL
description: After they had finished their stuffed chicken and green beans, business executives meeting at the Ramada Inn moved into the Regency Room to listen to Stanley Klein's tips for travelers.

title: AUDIT FINDS 93 V.A. DOCTORS DISCIPLINED BY STATES
description: The Veterans Administration said today that an audit of its 47,000 doctors had found that, unknown to the agency, 93 of them were disciplined by state medical boards before or after they started working for the agency. The agency said the licenses of 24 were revoked or suspended, chiefly for drug-related misconduct.

title: People
description: * Richard L. McCullough has been appointed president and E.H. Brown Jr. has been named chairman of E.H. Brown Advertising, Chicago.

title: U.S. ARMS DEMAND CALLED EXCESSIVE
description: Some arms control experts said today that the American proposal on medium-range arms was unrealistic because it went too far in seeking reductions in the Soviet missile force in Asia.

title: ARMS TALKS: THE CONTEXT
description: American and Soviet officals have enouraged hopes that important progress can be made on the issue of medium-range arms when President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Iceland. There are lesser expectations that headway can be made on the issue of nuclear testing.

title: RESIDENTIAL PROJECTS SPUR WEST VILLAGE'S EXPANSION
description: For many years, residential development in the West Village has mostly been a matter of rehabilitation and conversion. Older buildings of all sorts have found their way into use as housing.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $2.9 billion, to $238.76 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: OCT. 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BBDO Health To Add Baxter
description: BBDO Health and Medical Communications, billing $125 million, has added to its depth and breadth with the acquisition of Baxter, Gurian & Mazzei, another health-care specialty agency, based in Los Angeles.

title: Palestinian-Shiite Battle Continues in Lebanon
description: Fighting continued for a seventh day today between Shiites and Palestinian guerrillas in Tyre in southern Lebanon, despite efforts by a coordination committee to establish a cease-fire.

title: Coniston Partners Cuts Viacom Stake
description: Coniston Partners said it had reduced its stake in Viacom International Inc., the communications and entertainment concern, to just above 1 percent from 3.9 percent.

title: Asset-Backed Offering
description: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that it plans to offer about $3.2 billion of asset-backed obligations next week, the largest corporate offering of its kind in the American capital markets.

title: Blood Platelet Transfusions Are Overused, Panel Reports
description: Transfusions of clot-enhancing blood cells are being overused in heart surgery, and doctors should consider factors other than low cell counts before using the therapy, a panel of experts says.

title: ANDERSON HAPPY TO BE A GIANT
description: Ottis Anderson joined the Giants today and said he expected to be ready for a limited role Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles. The 28-year-old running back was obviously delighted about Wednesday's trade from the 0-5 St. Louis Cardinals to the 4-1 Giants, and he said he had no objections to becoming a fullback.

title: O'ROURKE URGES AN INQUIRY ON SCRUTINY OF HIS RECORDS
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, called on Governor Cuomo yesterday to investigate whether a state official used state workers to scrutinize Mr. O'Rourke, his law practice and his income-tax returns.

title: Drug Charges For 5 Officers
description: Five city correction officers assigned to the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men were indicted yesterday on drug charges after an eight-month undercover investigation.

title: More Than Theater in Iceland
description: When President Reagan comes back from Iceland next week, he will not have stopped the arms race, gotten the Russians out of Afghanistan or freed Andrei Sakharov. He probably will not even have sold them more American grain. So what will come out of Reykjavik?

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE SCREEN: 'CLOCKWISE'
description: ''THE first step to knowing who we are is knowing where we are and when we are,'' proclaims Brian Stimpson, a headmaster who is the stuffily punctilious hero of ''Clockwise,'' a delightful little British comedy written by the playwright Michael Frayn. The film is about what happens to Brian when the trains, figuratively speaking, cease to run on time. Mr. Frayn's screenplay has something of the fine-tuned comic machinery of his ''Noises Off,'' and its craftsmanship is at least as enjoyable as its humor.

title: A.M.C. Incentive
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would continue its zero percent two-year financing for most 1986 cars and Jeep vehicles through October. The incentive program originally was to have ended Oct. 8. A.M.C. is offering 2.9 percent financing for 36-month contracts and a 5.9 percent rate for 48-month contracts.

title: BROADWAY
description: RAY GREENWALD saw what he described as ''an awful musical'' last season, and when it was all over he said to a friend, ''I could do better than that.'' He now has a lot of money riding on just that assumption, more than $400,000, in fact, for Mr. Greenwald is the sole producer of ''Oh, Coward!,'' which is scheduled to open Nov. 17 at the Helen Hayes Theater.

title: PATRIOTS UPDATE EASON STATUS
description: Raymond Berry is a religious man - he was one of the more prominent Sunday morning motivational speakers before he became the Patriots' head coach - so he wouldn't deceive the Jets, would he?

title: RYAN FINDS NO CONSOLATION
description: It was, as expected, quiet in the loser's clubhouse. In a corner of the room Nolan Ryan, the strikeout king, at 39 still one of baseball's most effective pitchers, and tonight's losing pitcher, was in front of his open locker. He was slipping a brown tie around the collar of his tan shirt.

title: AFRICA ISSUE: NOT GONE BY ANY MEANS
description: When Congress voted last week to override President Reagan's veto of a bill to impose sanctions on South Africa, most legislators thought they had finally finished with the issue for the year. They were wrong.

title: Semiconductor Orders Rise
description: The beleaguered semiconductor industry recorded a slight increase in business in September, after several months of decline, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today. But much of the increase merely reflects the traditional seasonal pickup in business after the summer lull, the trade group said.

title: GROWING BIRMINGHAM IRKS NEIGHBORS
description: When the City of Birmingham recently annexed a large block of land six miles beyond its borders, city officials built a metal Quonset hut on the site, parked a pumper truck inside and called it City Fire Station No. 32.

title: Soviet Orders Swedish Gear For Aiding Chernobyl Victims
description: The Soviet Union has placed large orders for radiation-measuring gear with a Swedish medical equipment company to help treat victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, company officials said today.

title: Brooklyn Plan Is Approved
description: In a unaminous vote, the Board of Estimate late last night approved the Atlantic Terminal plan for central Brooklyn, the largest urban-renewal project to date outside of Manhattan.

title: VIRUS TECHNIQUE MAY AID LIVER DISEASE FIGHT
description: For the first time scientists have successfully grown in the laboratory the human hepatitis B virus, a cause of serious and widespread liver disease.

title: VOLCKER RETREATS ON LOOPHOLE
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, has dropped his longstanding insistence that any banking legislation passed this year include a provision to ban limited-service banks. In letters sent to Congress this week and released by the Fed today, he said that various emergency provisions dealing with banking should take a higher legislative priority.

title: LaRouche Setbacks
description: The organization of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political conspiracy theorist, has not had much political success since two of its members won the Democratic nominations for Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of State in the Illinois primary last March.

title: U.S. STRESSING HUMAN RIGHTS AND REGIONAL ISSUES
description: American officials say there has to be significant progress in issues other than arms control for the expected visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the United States to be successful.

title: Homemade Parachute Used a in Fatal Plunge
description: A man who jumped to his death Monday from an airplane at 10,000 feet was wearing a homemade parachute that required him to open his shirt and pants for it to deploy, the authorities said today.

title: Eppler, Guerin Considers Merger
description: Eppler, Guerin & Turner Inc., the largest independent investment banking and brokerage firm based in the Southwest, said it was considering merging into the Principal Financial Group of Des Moines.

title: SPEAKES DEFINES HIS ROLE IN SHAPING EVENTS
description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, though not implicated in a reported disinformation campaign, acknowledges that he has used his press briefings to ''shape'' events in foreign countries, as well as to influence the content of domestic news reports.

title: Flying Boat
description: The Wright Brothers Flyer, the Spirit of St. Louis and the historic space capsules are making room for a new aviation pioneer in the National Air and Space Museum: the Ecker Flying Boat. For those who may have missed this chapter in the history of flight, the boat was designed and built by Herman A. Ecker from parts he bought in Syracuse, N.Y., hardware stores just after the turn of the century.

title: Ryan Seeks To Thwart Bid
description: Ryan Homes Inc. said its board was considering several options, including a leveraged buyout, to ward off a hostile bid by NVHomes Inc. Yesterday, the Ryan board rejected a $45-a-share, or $292 million, offer from NVHomes as inadequate and recommended that shareholders not tender their shares.

title: HOUSE APPROVES IMMIGRATION BILL CONSIDERED DEAD TWO WEEKS AGO
description: In a dramatic reversal, the House of Representatives tonight approved a comprehensive bill to overhaul the nation's immigration law and curtail the influx of illegal aliens.

title: JOHN HIATT, SONGWRITER AND SINGER
description: ''I'VE found that I have to bang up against things before I learn anything,'' John Hiatt reflected the other day. ''I push as hard as I can, until something falls apart. Only then do I learn my lesson. Had I become a big star, you probably wouldn't be talking to me. I was so nuts and out of it for so many years that any huge success would have done me in.''

title: SOME IN 99TH CONGRESS FINDING FRINGE BENEFITS IN 'OVERTIME'
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, one of 28 Senators running for re-election, took the floor this week to tell Senate leaders that he was frustrated by ''the uncertainty, not knowing to the last second'' whether Congress would be in session or not.

title: Down With the New York State Sales Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Inmate in Louisiana Gets Stay of Execution
description: A man facing electrocution for the murder of a cab driver won a reprieve in Federal District Court today less than seven hours before he was scheduled to die.

title: MUSIC: METROPOLITAN OPERA STAGES SEASON'S FIRST 'FIGARO'
description: IT happens often enough to be an opera cliche: a new production, fresh as paint at first, slides off into routine in subsequent years as cast change follows cast change and stage direction loses whatever shine it may have had. The Metropolitan Opera's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' however, reversed that scenario last evening in the first performance of its second season. What had been lusterless Mozart in 1985 leaped to life under James Levine's affectionate conducting, thanks largely to a radically revised lineup of principal singers, but also to welcome touching up of the Jean-Pierre Ponnelle staging. Perhaps the Metropolitan lives after all.

title: 'New Sounds' No. 2
description: The guitarist Dan Ar Bras, the pianist Richard Pierce Milner, and the cellist Tom McVeety are among the artists who will participate in the second live ''New Sounds'' broadcast from Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday at 2 P.M. John Schaefer will be the host of the program, which will be carried live on WNYC-FM. Admission is $10; $5 for WNYC and Hebrew Arts School members. Information: 362-8719.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $365,000 for shutdown and disposition of the company's Huntsville facility and consolidation of its operations in Cullman, Ala. The company said that during the latest quarter it made a cash payment of $9,000,000 to reduce a portion of its outstanding 13 l/8 percent long-term debt; prepayment penalties and charges associated with this debt retirement amounted to $819,000, or 10 cents a share, after tax.

title: Delays Seen for Apple Model
description: Apple Computer Inc. appears to be experiencing delays in shipping its new II GS personal computer. Dealers say they got demonstration units for the model's Sept. 27 introduction but do not expect to receive any inventory before next month.

title: MCA Inc. Restructures Television Components
description: MCA Inc. has restructured its various television components, promoting Al Rush to chairman and Robert A. Harris to president of the MCA Television Group.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eric (Sleepy) Floyd, the Golden State Warriors guard, has agreed to sign a new four-year contract, and Gary Plummer, a free agent 6-9 forward, has also agreed to a one-year contract with the Warriors. . . . Doug Moe, in the second year of a three-year contract with Denver, has been offered an extension on his contract that could keep him at the head of the club for the next two years. Moe's contract paid him $275,000 last year. . . .
