The Pittsburgh Steelers offensive guard, John Rienstra, will undergo surgery today to repair a broken bone in his left foot and will be out indefinitely. Rienstra, the club's No. 1 draft choice this year from Temple, had started the last four games at left guard before he injured the foot in Sunday's 27-24 loss to the Cleveland Browns.

title: Hart's Senate Farewell
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado said his farewell to the Senate yesterday, devoting his speech to nuclear arms control as President Reagan prepared to leave for Iceland for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Economic Scene; Capital Inflow And Trade Gap
description: THE flow of foreign capital into the United States, financing its trade deficit, has thus far helped sustain the American standard of living by enabling Americans to consume more than they produce. But the cost of amortizing and servicing the growing foreign debt, which could reach $1 trillion by the end of this decade, is rising.

title: Henley Officials In Stock Program
description: Henley Group Inc. said 20 of its officers and other directors had agreed to buy 5,075,000 Henley common shares at $21.25 a share under the first phase of a new stock purchase program. The program will be voted on by shareholders on Nov. 21.

title: Addenda
description: Launney, Hachmann & Harris has started a public relations unit headed by Mary Lois Timbes.

title: 3-State House Vote On Immigration Bill
description: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today approved the immigration bill. A ''yes'' vote is to pass the bill; ''xxx'' denotes those not voting.

title: Barbie's Documents Reported Missing at Jail
description: Documents belonging to Klaus Barbie, accused of Nazi war crimes, have been lost for 10 months at the prison where he is being held, the prison director said today.

title: DANILOFF BOOK RIGHTS SOLD
description: The Houghton Mifflin Company said yesterday that it had acquired the rights to a book by Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American journalist who was arrested in Moscow in August and accused of spying.

title: AMID CHANGE, SPIRIT OF BELLEVUE REMAINS
description: The dilapidated brick buildings have been replaced by a gleaming 25-story tower. The huge, open 40-bed wards have become rooms for one, two or four with sweeping views of the East River.

title: METS EVEN PLAYOFF AT 1-1 AS OJEDA OUPITCHES RYAN
description: Bamboozled and beaten in the opening round of the playoff for the National League pennant, the Mets turned on their tormentors tonight with all the sting that won 108 games this season and beat the Houston Astros, 5-1.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary losses of $3,520,000 and $17,352,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from penalties on pre-payment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: REYKJAVIK TALKS: A PRELUDE TO SUMMIT STRATEGY
description: The meeting in Reykjavik is not what, where or when the superpowers had expected only a year ago. But almost from the moment the Geneva summit meeting ended last November with the promise of a second meeting in Washington sometime in 1986, many summit-watchers doubted that any face-to-face discussions between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev would take place this year.

title: Shared Pain Over the Massacre in Istanbul
description: To the Editor:

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A New Haven dispatch in some editions yesterday described the reactions of 20 Queens high school students who attended the the Federal corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and four co-defendants.

title: Upside-Down Priorities In Fighting Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 U.S. Navy Ships To Visit a Chinese Port
description: Three United States Navy ships will visit a Chinese port city in November, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today as he concluded a visit here.

title: CITY SCHOOL BUILDINGS TO GET $16 MILLION IN BADLY NEEDED REPAIRS
description: Funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation's surplus - originally intended to help build a specialized high school - will now be used to repair and paint existing school buildings, many of which have not been painted in more than 20 years.

title: DEATH OF FATHER OF LINDENAUER TIED TO '72 TRIAL
description: An insight into the behavior of Geoffrey G. Lindenauer and his friendship with Donald R. Manes has emerged with the disclosure of the events surrounding the death of Mr. Lindenauer's father.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Columbus Day Parade
description: The official holiday is Monday, but the annual Columbus Day parade will travel up Fifth Avenue tomorrow, beginning at 9:30 A.M. Thousands of marchers from the United States and Italy will take part in the procession, which starts at 44th Street and continues up the avenue to 86th Street, where it turns right and disperses at Third Avenue. Governor Cuomo and Senator Alphonse D'Amato are the grand marshals.

title: BENNETT ASSAILS THE QUALITY OF EDUCATION AT UNIVERSITIES
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett sharply criticizes the quality of education at Harvard University and other institutions in the text of a speech he plans to deliver at Harvard Friday.

title: Bridge: Standing on One's Head Can Give a Valuable Perspective
description: While introducing his song about ''The New Math,'' Tom Lehrer once invited his listeners to stand on their heads to get the right effect.

title: No 'Disinformation' In This Playoff
description: The Mets stopped worrying about the umpire's calls or whether the baseball was scuffed and concentrated on Nolan Ryan's assortment of pitches last night, with results that were gratifying to them.

title: U.S. Rests Case In 'Pizza' Trial
description: Federal prosecutors finally rested their case yesterday in the one-year-old ''pizza connection'' drug trial in Federal District Court.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. WILL OPPOSE CURB ON LAWSUITS
description: The Justice Department said today that it would oppose a bill now before the Senate that was designed to limit private lawsuits under a Federal antiracketeering law.

title: ART: 3 GALLERIES SHOWING WORK BY ARNULF RAINER
description: OVERDOING it is Arnulf Rainer's stock in trade, whether he is achieving scabrous surfaces on canvas, painting over photographs of his contorted face and body with imagery that underscores the contortions, or reviving old etching plates with masses of incised lines.

title: REAGAN URGED TO ADMIT CONTRA-AID ROLE
description: The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence challenged the White House today to acknowledge what he said is its role in the flight of a cargo plane shot down over Nicaragua.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes foreign exchange losses of $1,979,000 for the quarter and $7,244,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains of $531,000 and $4,976,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1986. The company said effective Jan. 1, it implemented FASB 87, employers accounting for pensions, and this change increased net income for the latest quarter by about $4.5 milliion, or 2 cents a share and the 9 months by about $11.9 million, or 5 cents a share.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: NEW YORKERS get used to everything - even film trucks. ''Five Corners,'' starring Jodie Foster, was filming on 116th Street and First Avenue the other day and most of the local residents seemed distinctly unimpressed. They calmly stepped over cables and edged their way around cameras and lights, never breaking their conversations, occasionally raising an eyebrow in acknowledgement that something unusual was going on. ''They are very cool,'' said Miss Foster. ''People aren't even as relaxed about movie crews in California.''

title: Heck's to Be Sold In $145 Million Deal
description: Heck's Inc., a discount department store chain with 160 outlets in nine Southeastern and Middle Atlantic states, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by an investment group led by Robert I. Toussie and Edward A. Viner & Company, a New York brokerage.

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 14. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: 2,000 Dock Workers Strike in New Orleans
description: More than 2,000 dock workers walked off their jobs tonight in a dispute with the New Orleans Steamship Association over wage reductions and cuts in overtime pay.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE; DEVILS 5 RANGERS 3
description: A timeout was called and the crowd cheered. The puck was cleared to center ice and the crowd cheered. At 16 minutes 16 seconds of the second period, the fans really went wild. That's when Keith Hernandez tripled in two runs. Opening night of the hockey season at Madison Square Garden was a bit confusing.

title: LUCKY SET TO CLOSE GEMCO UNIT
description: Lucky Stores Inc., a retailer that has been under attack from the investor Asher B. Edelman, said yesterday that it would put itself through an extensive restructuring intended to focus the company once again on its core food business.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE HIT A SNAG IN EFFORTS TO CUT 1987 DEFICIT
description: House and Senate negotiators ran into a snag today in their effort to reach a compromise on a $12 billion package of savings to reduce the 1987 budget deficit.

title: Agony of Defeat
description: Coach Mack Brown, whose Tulane football team is now 1-3 after a 1-point loss to Wichita State last weekend: ''I feel like the guy in the javelin competition who won the toss and elected to receive.''

title: WEST GERMANS REPEL RABIES INVASION FROM EAST
description: Since 1950, slinking westward at a rate of 30 miles a year, foxes have been spreading a rabies epidemic from Poland and East Germany into Western Europe.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article on Sept. 12 about the court-ordered force feeding of Msgr. Thomas O'Brien, a stroke victim in a Bronx nursing home, misstated a Roman Catholic Church position on prolonging life. The church teaches that each person has a duty to foster his own life, but not an absolute obligation, and that a person is not obliged to use extraordinary means to sustain life.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ROBERT MOORE'S collection of Korean ceramics -pottery and porcelains of robust forms and bold decoration - will be auctioned at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, next Thursday at 10 A.M. The sale, described as the first major collection of Korean ceramics auctioned in New York in a decade, includes 182 offerings ranging in age from prehistoric and medieval Silla stoneware vessels to 12th- and 13th-century Koryo Dynasty celadons and stonewares, as well as 15th- through 19th-century Yi Dynasty bowls, bottles, jars and flasks.

title: A Quarterly From Dell
description: The Dell Magazine Group, which publishes several crossword puzzle magazines, is bringing out the first issue of Today's Marriage, a quarterly magazine for women aged 18 to 34. At first it will be sold only on newsstands, with 500,000 copies distributed. The full-page ad rates are $1,800 for black-and-white and $2,600 for four-color.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HIS WAY: The Unauthorized Biography of Frank Sinatra. By Kitty Kelley. Illustrated. 575 pages. Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: Apology by Atwater
description: In an effort to keep peace with an important political constituency, Lee Atwater, a strategist for Vice President Bush, has apologized to Samuel Tenenbaum, a Democratic fund-raiser who is a Jewish leader from Columbia, S.C., with whom he exchanged sharp words recently.

title: Overcrowded
description: Some days the Capitol is not big enough to accommodate all the people who use it. On Tuesday the paneled Mansfield Room just off the Senate floor was set up as a holding room for Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, who is serving a two-year Federal term for tax evasion.

title: CAMPEAU SUES ALLIED ON DeBARTOLO FEE DEAL
description: The Campeau Corporation turned to the courts yesterday to offset an opposing bid for the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Topeka, Kan., dispatch on Tuesday, about the reopening of a school desegregation case in Federal court, mislocated Central Surveys, which conducted a poll for plaintiffs in the case. Its headquarters are in Iowa, not Ohio.

title: Using the U.N. Crisis
description: While it isn't the kind of crisis that has senior leaders locked in situation rooms and the public glued to the screen, the state of the United Nations is now a grave worry for people concerned with long-term international developments.

title: Bill on Columbia Gorge
description: The Senate approved a compromise bill Wednesday to establish the Columbia Gorge National Scenic Area in Oregon and Washington. The measure sets a spending limit of $40 million for land acquisition in the gorge, where 40,000 people live. Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, said the bill prohibited ''the use of condemnation by the Forest Service for residential homes, farm land and grazing land, or lands used for religious, educational or charitable purposes.''

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RECEPTION AT SOVIET MISSION CELEBRATES FESTIVAL
description: Hundreds of New York film devotees got a rare glimpse of life inside the closely guarded white brick Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street last night, a building known to them only as a backdrop for televised news reports of political demonstrations.

title: EX-CHICAGO OFFICIAL MENTIONED IN NEW YORK CASE
description: Evidence at a Federal trial in Connecticut today implicated a former corporation counsel for the City of Chicago in payoffs made by private companies to obtain and keep business contracts with the city.

title: FINAL TITLE CHESS GAME IS DRAWN IN LENNIGRAD
description: Gary Kasparov drew the 24th game yesterday and, thus, won his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in Leningrad, 12 1/2-11 1/2.

title: U.S. JUDGE OUSTED BY IMPEACHMENT, FIRST IN 50 YEARS
description: The Senate today found Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne guilty of bringing the judiciary into disrepute by filing false tax returns and removed him from office in the first such impeachment conviction in 50 years.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: ; A CHANGING L.I. VILLAGE RECONSIDERS ITS IDENTITY
description: Some of the people of Shirley would like to change the village's name to Floyd. Floyd Harbor, actually. But many others think Shirley is just fine. And as Shirley's supporters point out, while the community is on the south shore of Suffolk County, the name Floyd Harbor would be a bit strange, because the village has no harbor.

title: ART: AT THE WHITNEY, JOHN SINGER SARGENT
description: IN the matter of John Singer Sargent, whose paintings and watercolors can be seen through Jan. 4 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, it is important to keep a delicate balance. Sargent painted some wonderful things. The fact that he also painted terrible things does not invalidate the quality of his portraits of Carolus-Duran, Robert Louis Stevenson, Vernon Lee and Henry James. Nor can it change the fact that Sargent's ''Interior in Venice'' of 1899 is our memorable image of the privileged life as it was lived in Venice by turn-of-the-century Americans who could have stepped straight out of a novel by Edith Wharton.

title: IRANIAN OIL MINISTER IN KEY OPEC ROLE
description: The seven-year-old war between Iran and Iraq is becoming an increasingly intrusive issue for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. As a result, the Iranian oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, has been cast in the role of a major power broker within the organization.

title: INCREASE IN CAB FARES DELAYED PENDING ACTION ON MEDALLIONS
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, at the request of Mayor Koch, will delay action on raising taxicab fares until the City Council decides whether to allow 1,800 more cabs on the streets.

title: 2 WILL PAY $630,790 IN INSIDER SUIT
description: Two young Wall Street executives agreed yesterday to pay civil penalties to the Government totaling $630,790 for their part in the Dennis B. Levine insider trading scandal.

title: CLEMENS WILL START GAME 4
description: If there was any lingering suspense about Boston's pitcher for the fourth game against California tomorrow night, it was eliminated quickly by Manager John McNamara, who said yesterday in Anaheim, Calif., that he would start Roger Clemens, the losing pitcher in Tuesday's opener.

title: Chemical Bank Fills 2 Investment Posts
description: Chemical Bank announced two senior investment banking appointments yesterday.

title: Space Shuttle Atlantis Is Put On Launching Pad in Florida
description: The space shuttle Atlantis was mounted atop the launching pad here today for a series of tests, including astronaut escape drills.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING LOSS OF COMPUTERS
description: Tracking an elusive trail of missing computer equipment, investigators in the United States and Western Europe are unraveling the complex details of what they say is one of the largest and most damaging diversions of high-technology equipment to the Eastern bloc.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Expressions '86, Aaron Davis Hall, City College, 134th Street and Convent Avenue (307-7420, 690-4100). The Caribbean Cultural Center's Expressions concerts, now in their eighth season, celebrate Africa's living presence in the pulse of Caribbean and Latin American traditional music and dance. The first of two concerts this weekend begins tomorrow at 8 P.M. and features the Haitian ritual drumming and dance of La Troupe Makandal, along with groups from the Dominican Republic and New Orleans. Sunday at 6 P.M., the formidable drummer and singer Orlando (Puntilla) Rios and his group present the liturgical music of Africa's Yoruba culture as it has survived, and flourished, in Cuba; dancers and drummers from West Africa, Brazil and the United States are also on the bill. Tickets are $10 in advance, $12 at the door, and are available at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street, or from the Aaron Davis Hall box office.

title: Zorinsky's Choice
description: Senator Edward Zorinsky of Nebraska, a former Republican who switched parties to run for the Senate in 1976, hinted recently that he might be agreeable to rejoining the Republican fold.

title: WHITAKER CRUISES TO VICTORY
description: In the third round of his lightweight fight last night at the Felt Forum, Pernell Whitaker hit Rafael Gandarilla with a right hook, missed with a left, and shook his head.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Warsaw on Monday about the selection of two Polish dissidents for the $40,000 Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award gave an incorrect date and place for the ceremony. The awards, to Zbigniew Bujak and Adam Michnik, will be presented in Washington on Nov. 20.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm delighted that now we can go forward united.'' - President Reagan, after agreement with Congressional leaders on arms policy.

title: 48 AFRICANS ARRESTED IN HEROIN RING
description: Federal agents and police officers raided about 30 sites in the New York metropolitan area yesterday and arrested 48 African nationals in connection with a multimillion-dollar heroin trafficking network in the Northeast Corridor.

title: COLLISION OF CULTURES
description: Around 10 o'clock on a recent morning in Houston in the midst of the National League playoffs, a pair of sports reporters from the East, ordinarily in search of truth, and generally hot in pursuit of knowledge, were taking a break from their labors and sought some breakfast.

title: RESIDENTS AID HUNT FOR KILLER
description: The tips have come by the hundreds. Sometimes they are anonymous. More often, they are not. In the wake of the crime, the angry and frustrated residents of this Fairfield County community have become something of an auxiliary detective bureau.

title: CCB FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Quest for the Hottest of the Hot
description: ''Food with a bite is big,'' said one food magazine more than a year ago. ''Hot, hotter, hottest,'' said another. Couple that kind of information with the publication in the last year of at least two books dealing with chilies, and one might get the impresssion that Americans have fallen in love with hot food, especially on the West Coast.

title: Longshoremen Protest As Labor Talks Stall
description: Pickets marched along the New Orleans and Mobile, Ala., waterfronts today after contract talks with a group representing stevedores and steamship companies broke down and about 2,700 longshoremen walked off the job.

title: UNION WARREN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $224,000.

title: Container Corp.
description: The Container Corporation of America said it would eliminate 1,000 jobs, or 6.6 percent of its total work force, as a result of the depressed conditions in the paperboard and packaging industry.

title:
PATENTS;
Patent Office Security
description: The Patent and Trademark Office is modifying its practice in security controls to follow those of the Department of Defense.

title: How to Divvy Up the Airwaves
description: Energy companies pay for oil and coal from Federal land. Restaurants pay for the right to serve the crowds in the national parks. Why shouldn't private users pay for the communications spectrum, a Government resource that's every bit as scarce and valuable?

title: David Holmes McKillop, 70; Ex-State Department Officer
description: David Holmes McKillop, a former deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassies in Tunis and Brussels and a former director of the State Department's Office of Western European Affairs, died Wednesday of a stroke in Washington. He was 70 years old and lived in Washington and in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Four Burned In Lab Mishap
description: Four employees at the Brookhaven National Research Laboratory were burned yesterday while working on newly installed steam lines, officials said.

title: U.N. Famine Fighters' Job Isn't Finished
description: To the Editor:

title: GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of 94 cents a share from the sale of contract servicing rights.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCORES DIE AS BUILDINGS COLLAPSE
description: A strong earthquake and a series of aftershocks hit the Salvadoran capital this morning, causing extensive damage in the center of the city and killing at least 100 people.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER DEBT
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had lowered its rating on $10 billion of securities offered by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and its banking subsidiaries, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: AMERICAN IN SOVIET UNION SAYS HE'S UNSURE IF HE WILL SETTLE THERE
description: The American cancer researcher who arrived in the Soviet Union under a grant of asylum Wednesday said at a news conference today that he was impressed by the Soviet Union but that it was to soon to decide if he and his family wanted to remain permanently.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THATCHER IN ATTACK ON LABOR
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, seizing on defense as a major campaign issue, said the Labor Party's unilateral nuclear disarmament policy would be ''the greatest gain for the Soviet Union in the last 40 years.''

title: Admiration and Resignation
description: Just as it begins full-time duties, the Bicentennial Commission has lost one of its key staff members because of ''fundamental differences'' with its chairman, the retired Chief Justice, Warren E. Burger.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY, TRYING TO ADD JAIL BEDS, VOWS TO MAKE IMPROVEMENTS
description: City officials, faced with a shortage of jail space, told a Federal District Court judge yesterday that they would increase services and security in three jails on Rikers Island, if he allows them to put more inmates in each dormitory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1986
description: Companies

title: SHAWMUT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures reflect July 1 acquisition of Home Bank & Trust Co. in Meriden, Conn.

title: Israeli Suffers Minor Wounds In Stabbing Attack in Hebron
description: An unidentified assailant stabbed an Israeli civilian in the occupied West Bank town of Hebron today and then fled, army spokesmen said.

title: Books of The Times; Haunted Characters
description: TO SKIN A CAT. By Thomas McGuane. 212 pages. E. P. Dutton/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95. Thomas McGuane's men would like to be Hemingway heroes - if they could. They cultivate the manly arts of hunting and fishing, drinking and swearing, and they're constantly getting involved with women who mess up their lives. But while the America they inhabit still boasts patches of pristine wilderness, it's hardly the testing ground for manhood that it was in simpler times - the frontier ethic is dead or dying in Mr. McGuane's America, and it's been replaced by a nasty new code of survivalism and cant. Cut off from their own nobler instincts and surrounded by despicable Snopesian rednecks -it's no wonder that McGuane characters suffer from a ''sadness-for-no-reason,'' a feeling of being ''superfluous'' and outdated.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $4,115,000 for the quarter and $11,194,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $3,445,000 for the quarter and $7,979,000 for the 9 months.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOLIDAYS ON MONDAY
description: Monday is Columbus Day and also Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement. Holiday schedules follow: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.

title: Oppenheimer Unit Has Viacom Stake
description: A unit of the New York-based financial services firm Oppenheimer Group Inc. has purchased the equivalent of a 5.2 percent stake in Viacom International Inc. Earlier this week, the outside directors of the New York-based communications and entertainment concern rejected a $44-a-share leveraged buyout proposal from a group led by its senior management.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sara Lee May Sell Its Popsicle Unit
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said it was considering the sale of its Popsicle Industries subsidiary, which markets the popular Popsicle, Fudgsicle and Creamsicle bars, because the unit does not fit into its long-range plans. The Englewood, N.J., company contributed about $60 million of Sara Lee's $7.94 billion in 1985 sales.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: 1. This infant, Baby Mitchell, made history before he was born last year. Explain. 2. With his resignation, a Reagan Administration official joined what Dean Acheson once called ''the most exclusive club in America.'' Identify him and explain. 3. ''We believe we have solved, after five centuries, one of the grandest of all geographic mysteries,'' an editor of National Geographic Magazine said about an investigation he directed. What did the investigation conclude? 4. The Koch administration unveiled plans for an unusual municipal jail. Explain. 5. Because it is physically impossible for a nuclear reactor to explode, in the sense that a nuclear bomb blows up, there is no danger of a nuclear explosion in either the reactor or in the missiles aboard the Soviet nuclear submarine that sank in the Atlantic Ocean. True or false? 6. In a case filled with historic echoes, lawyers opened court maneuvers in a new phase of a landmark Supreme Court decision. What decision was it? What is at issue? 7. A proposed merger may unite two companies that are among the leading names in tableware. Identify them. 8. ''Honey, I told you to do it only if I didn't get any applause,'' said President Reagan. To whom was he speaking and what were the circumstances? 9. In the 23d game, a dispirited contender went out like a lamb. Identify him and explain. 10. A weeklong celebration at the Air Force Academy marked the 25th anniversary of a novel that captured the insanity of war while adding a phrase to the English language.

title: F.A.A. Suspends License Of Pilot for Trespassing
description: A pilot whose plane entered restricted airspace just before a jetliner collision that killed 82 people will lose his license for six months, the Federal Aviation Administration has decided.

title: PCB Violation Prompts Fine
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed an $88,000 fine against the United Technologies Corporation for violating rules governing the use, storage and disposal of pylochlorinated biphenyls.

title: Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said in the latest quarter it posted a gain of 6 cents a share from a gain on the sale of real estate.

title: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1985 share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid June 2.

title: Bridge; Husband-Wife Partnerships Scoring Success in Tourneys
description: It used to be accepted wisdom that husband-and-wife partnerships were not in general effective at the bridge table. Emotional factors, it was thought, made cool judgment difficult to achieve.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Required Reading selection on the Washington Talk page Sept. 23 misidentified the site of the Alf Landon lecture. It was delivered at Kansas State University in Manhattan, Kan., not at the University of Kansas.

title: FOR DEMOCRATS, A HEAD START ON '88
description: About 40 wealthy Democrats assemble at one of this city's finest hotels every other month to consider the ultimate political decision: their party's Presidential nominee for 1988.

title: LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.4%
description: A key measure of inflation, the Producer Price Index, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September as gasoline prices increased sharply, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Keith Lee Testifies
description: Keith Lee, the career leader in points and rebounds at Memphis State University who is in his second professional season with the Cleveland Cavaliers, yesterday testified in Memphis before a Federal grand jury investigating the finances of Dana Kirk, the basketball coach who was dismissed without any public explanation Sept. 17. Lee appeared before the panel for 75 minutes but did not speak to reporters.

title: Marsh Settles With Manville
description: The Manville Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to a $29.75 million settlement to end its claims against Marsh & McLennan Inc. and Marsh & McLennan Ltd., which insured Manville starting in 1944.

title: WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 CHIP MAKERS' LOSSES WIDEN
description: The Intel Corporation today reported its largest quarterly loss ever, citing plant closings, manufacturing problems and the withdrawal from one business sector. Intel, a leading semiconductor maker, said it would phase out the production of bubble memory, a type of magnetic memory used primarily in military applications.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANKAMERICA HEAD IS STEPPING DOWN
description: Samuel H. Armacost, whose tenure at the helm of the BankAmerica Corporation has been marked by turmoil and huge losses, will resign this weekend, the banking company announced today.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $19,934,000 related to the consolidation of operations.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax net gain of $38.4 million on the sale of Alliance Mortgage Co. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 30.

title: CONFEREES ON BILL IMMIGRATION PRESSING TO RECONCILE DIFFERENCES
description: Moving with unusual speed, House and Senate negotiators met today to start working out their differences over a comprehensive immigration bill designed to stem the flow of illegal aliens into this country.

title: A STRUGGLE IN TREATING BRONX POOR
description: State health officials say that any measure of the success or failure of Medicaid in providing health care to New York's poor should begin amid the burned-out buildings and rubble-strewn lots that surround Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center in the South Bronx.

title: WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE ICELAND SUMMIT: SURPRISES FROM THE RUSSIANS
description: Irina Ratushinskaya, a poet who was sentenced in 1983 to 12 years in labor camp and internal exile for poetry deemed critical of the Soviet Union, was unexpectedly freed Thursday and returned home to her husband.

title: G.O.P. Seeks Hispanic Votes
description: The Republican National Committee has agreed to provide the Republican candidate for governor, Andrew P. O'Rourke, with $15,000 for a campaign commercial geared to the state's Hispanic voters.

title: Hicks Tells of Drug Use
description: Dwight Hicks, a four-time Pro Bowl selection at free safety who was released by the San Francisco 49ers in June, said yesterday that he had used cocaine from 1981 until early last summer and that the 49ers were aware of his habit. In interviews with The San Jose Mercury News and The San Francisco Chronicle, Hicks said he had used cocaine ''recreationally'' during the 1981 season with other 49ers he declined to identify.

title: NOW, THE CALIFORNIA TASK FORCE TO PROMOTE SELF-ESTEEM
description: California is a temperate and fertile place, and over the years a number of improbable ideas that might have been rejected elsewhere have easily taken root here.

title: General Assembly Talk Won't Stop Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
A Reactor Is Termed Less Costly
description: ANUCLEAR reactor that reportedly can be manufactured at reduced cost was patented this week for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: Letter: On the U.S. Money Bill; A Senator's Spending Amendments
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Ready For Tax Audit
description: ANYONE'S Federal income tax return can be audited by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: BENNETT AND BOK CLASH AT HARVARD
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett strongly criticized Harvard University's core curriculum today, charging that the widely discussed new curriculum was only an ''agglomeration'' of old courses.

title: An Ex-Country Doctor Recalls the Old, Non-HMO Days
description: Those doctors who came of age in the not too distant past may find it difficult to imagine what it was like to practice medicine in the bygone era when doctors were entrepreneurs and freedom was the order of the day.

title: Brooklyn Concert Canceled
description: A concert tonight at 8 o'clock by the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College has been canceled because of a strike by members of the musicians' union.

title: Count the Reasons for an All-American Rose
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 COUNTRIES PLAN TO FIGHT DRUGS
description: After three days of meetings to discuss mutual issues involving illegal drugs, a group of 13 nations in the Western Hemisphere agreed today to study the possibility of adopting a regionwide program to fight drug trafficking.

title:
PATENTS;
An Improved Bomb For the Air Force
description: A general purpose aerial bomb, patented this week for the Air Force, is described as having an improved thermoplastic liner.

title: Beep Beep: Stopwatch Gets Hot
description: Only fruit flies live harder and die sooner than New York street fashions.

title: Filing by Lindner
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, the financier, who together hold a 9.9 percent stake in National Convenience Stores Inc., said they were seeking clearance to purchase up to 25 percent of the company's shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Lindner said the group had no ''present plans to acquire control'' of the Houston-based food store concern but added that they ''may change their plans depending on future developments.'' National Convenience's stock closed today at $10.125, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Gettin' to Be Mighty Eerie Out Here
description: A man who had worked on guidance systems for the newest and deadliest American ballistic missiles was on television the other night saying the steering is so flawed that rockets aimed at Moscow might just as readily land on New York.

title: Cosmetics Go on Gold Standard
description: IN the just-when-you-thought-you-had-everything department: The latest ingredient in cosmetics is 24-carat gold.

title: ABRAM HILL, 76, THE FOUNDER OF A BLACK THEATER IN HARLEM
description: Abram Hill, a major figure in the development of black theater who provided the springboard for the careers of black actors such as Harry Belafonte, Alice Childress, Ruby Dee and Sidney Poitier, died at his home on Monday. He was 76 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: HE MIRRORS METS' PROGRESS
description: A Met fan's summer seemed so much longer when Wally Backman first arrived in Flushing six years ago, in the days when the idea of spending an afternoon at Shea Stadium held about as much appeal as your basic monster traffic jam on the nearby Long Island Expressway - fun-filled hours of watching exasperated people going nowhere.

title: Envoy Says Austrians Botched Computer Case
description: The United States Ambassador to Austria said yesterday that Austrian customs authorities ''blew it'' two months ago when they allowed the last part of a shipment of computer equipment to disappear mysteriously from a Vienna warehouse.

title: OPEC MINISTERS PLOD TOWARD EXTENDING PACT
description: OPEC ministers struggled through a fifth day of weary talks today on the issue of production quotas for individual members. The inaction heightens the likelihood that they might settle for extending their temporary program.

title: On Camera: Mrs. Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan has agreed to do a public service television spot for the National Institute on Drug Abuse, according to Gregg Stern, public relations representative for John Bonanno, the director and cameraman.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $3,414,000 on the sale of assets.

title: TV: 'NIGHTINGALE,' ON 13, A P.D. JAMES MYSTERY
description: Disappointing continues to be the word for British television's adapatations of P. D. James's novels. Like ''Death of an Expert Witness,'' seen here last year, ''Shroud for a Nightingale'' fails to realize fully the peculiar tensions lurking in the investigative explorations of Phyllis Dorothy James.

title: LATE NIGHTS, BRIGHT LIGHTS AND COCAINE ARE STILL ENTWINED
description: At Tory's, a rock club at 119 East 27th Street, a young man in jeans stamps out a marijuana cigarette on the bathroom floor, plucks a leather packet from his pocket and displays plastic envelopes filled with white powder.

title: CONNER WINS NO. 6
description: Dennis Conner sailed unbeaten Stars & Stripes, one of the United States challengers, to a sixth victory today, beating the Challenge France by 4 minutes 42 seconds at the America's Cup preliminaries. The French boat has yet to win.

title: U.S. DELAYS WITHHOLDING OF FUNDS FROM STATES OVER EXCESSIVE SPEED
description: The Department of Transportation is delaying action against states that have not enforced the 55-mile-per-hour limit on Federal highways. Officials cite the Reagan Administration's desire to do away with the limit and the move in Congress toward such a step.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN IN A SHIFT ON NUCLEAR TESTS ON EVE OF TALKS
description: President Reagan will offer a two-stage proposal on nuclear test curbs when he meets with Mikhail S. Gorbachev this weekend, the White House announced today.

title: CHICAGO CORRUPTION INQUIRY YIELDS LONG, SECRET REPORT
description: A special investigator, appointed by Mayor Harold Washington to examine the possibility of corruption in Chicago's City Hall, submitted his 147-page report today, but the contents were kept secret.

title: UNDER CLAUSEN'S REIGN, BANK'S ASSETS SURGED
description: A. W. Clausen will be on familiar ground if, as expected, he is named this weekend to succeed Samuel H. Armacost as president and chief executive officer of the troubled BankAmerica.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $365,000 for shutdown and disposition of the company's Huntsville facility and consolidation of its operations in Cullman, Ala. The company said that during the latest quarter it made a cash payment of $9,000,000 to reduce a portion of its outstanding 13 l/8 percent long-term debt; prepayment penalties and charges associated with this debt retirement amounted to $819,000, or 10 cents a share, after tax.

title: BANK OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Annals of Investigation: I. West, Pet Detective
description: The parakeet flew out the window, its whereabouts unknown.

title: Temple University Staff Awaits New Pact Talks
description: Negotiators waited for word from a state mediator today about the resumption of contract talks in the first faculty strike in Temple University's 102-year history.

title: DOWNFALL OF A 'BOY WONDER'
description: Samuel H. Armacost was BankAmerica's nice guy, a likable fellow who posed a sharp contrast to A. W. Clausen, his aloof, austere and autocratic predecessor. By most accounts, however, Mr. Armacost's niceness might have been a major reason behind his downfall and the persistent decline in the company's fortunes during his five-and-a-half-year reign.

title: WILLIAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cigarette Units Agree to Merge
description: In a move that may end Canada's yearlong cigarette price war, Rothmans of Pall Mall Ltd. today agreed to merge with Benson & Hedges (Canada) Inc., which is wholly owned by Philip Morris Inc., the American consumer-products conglomerate. The new company will be controlled by Rothmans, which is a subsidiary of the British company Rothmans International P.L.C., and will be named Rothmans, Benson & Hedges Inc.

title: Chief Retires At Associated
description: Joseph H. Johnson, chairman and chief executive of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, yesterday announced plans to retire effective Oct. 31.

title: The House of Presidents
description: A new two-volume history of the White House, ''The President's House: A History'' will be presented to President and Mrs. Reagan at a reception next Thursday in the East Room.

title: CONFEREES ACCEPT CLEAN-WATER BILL
description: After a two-year delay, House and Senate conferees agreed today to renew the Clean Water Act and called for $18 billion for sewage treatment over the next eight years.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary items from reduction of income taxes due to tax credits of $105,000 and $195,000 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, and $148,000 and $412,000 for the year-ago comparable periods, respectively.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes charges of $1.3 million and $3.1 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: CONSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $2,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $110,000 and $242,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: HOLMES COMING TO RYAN'S DEFENSE
description: They won't even be on the field at the same time when the Jets face the Patriots Sunday, but Jerry Holmes expects to protect Pat Ryan.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: A report in the Press column yesterday about the resignation of Bernard Kalb as State Department spokesman omitted a key part of his comment about his reason. Mr. Kalb said he was resigning to protest ''the reported disinformation program'' conducted by the Reagan Administration against the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi; he stopped short of confirming that such a program existed.

title: ANGELS TAKE 2-1 LEAD IN PLAYOFF WITH 2 HOME RUNS
description: The game was over, but the controversy kept swirling like so much dust around home plate. Yet even while the events of the fourth inning tonight were scrutinized over and over again, the primary characters could not be forgotten.

title: Getting Well at Home
description: The Reagan Administration deserves credit for intelligently limiting hospital costs reimbursed by Medicare, the Federal health insurance for the elderly. Now, though, the Administration is turning out to be less than intelligent concerning the part of Medicare that pays for health care in the home.

title: Steeplechase to Census
description: Census, the 3-to-5 favorite, carried top weight of 162 pounds to victory by a neck over Tostadero in the $54,400 Temple Gwathmey steepleechase yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: OPERA: THE MET STAGES SEASON'S FIRST 'FIGARO'
description: It happens often enough to be an opera cliche: a new production, fresh as paint at first, slides off into routine in subsequent years as cast change follows cast change and stage direction loses whatever shine it may have had. The Metropolitan Opera's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' however, reversed that scenario Thursday evening in the first performance of its second season. What had been lusterless Mozart in 1985 leaped to life under James Levine's affectionate conducting, thanks largely to a radically revised lineup of principal singers, but also to welcome touching up of the Jean-Pierre Ponnelle staging.

title: Howser Return Seen
description: The optimistic word from the Kansas City Royals after their manager underwent surgery in July for a malignant brain tumor was that Dick Howser would return as manager next season. Yesterday, the Royals made it official as John Schuerholz, the team's executive vice president and general manager, said, ''Dick Howser is the manager of our club next year.'' Schuerholz also confirmed that Mike Ferraro, the interim manager during Howser's absence, had been let go and would be replaced as third-base coach by Billy Gardner, former manager of the Minnesota Twins.

title: MUSIC: THE ST. JOHN PASSION
description: Of Bach's extant passions, the St. John is the darker, more turbulent -even the rougher of the two. Musica Sacra brought this rich choral work back to Central Presbyterian Church Wednesday night in a performance that not only honored, but emphatically underlined, its combative, almost warlike tone.

title: Moscow Plans to Add 2 Units to Chernobyl
description: Plans to build a fifth and a sixth reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power station will be fulfilled, and the No. 3 reactor at the complex is to resume operations next year, the Communist Party daily Pravda said today.

title:
How to Restore Public Confidence in New York State Officials;
A MATTER OF ETHICS
description: Much was accomplished in this year's regular session of the New York State Legislature. But a great and continuing disappointment was the Legislature's failure to enact a new ethics and campaign financing reform agenda. Powerful forces in the Legislature continue to resist reform. This inaction should now become a focus of public concern.

title: YANKEES REWARD PINIELLA WITH TWO-YEAR CONTRACT
description: In his quickest managerial decision in years, George Steinbrenner retained Lou Piniella as the Yankees' manager yesterday, giving him a two-year contract and a raise. Piniella, a rookie manager this year, now has a chance to become the first Yankee manager since Billy Martin in 1976-77 to last two consecutive complete seasons.

title: THE ALL-AMERICAN GUY BEHIND 'BLUE VELVET'
description: David Lynch loves the description of his new film, ''Blue Velvet,'' by one of his sound mixers: ''It's like Norman Rockwell meets Hieronymus Bosch.''

title: DEVILS ARE SPURRED BY THEIR DEFENSE
description: Defense and goaltending were the weaknesses for the Rangers and the strengths for the Devils in their National Hockey League opener.

title: KEYCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LINDENAUER SAYS MANES WANTED MAYORALTY AND BIG MONEY FROM IT
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer testified today that Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President, had told him he was planning to run for mayor and that if elected ''he would really show me how to make money.''

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bonds Ease in Light Trading
description: Bond prices eased in thin trading yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1986
description: The World The President will offer a two-stage plan to curb nuclear testing, the Administration announced. The plan does not seem to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev's insistence on a total ban on testing, however. The Soviet Union has refrained from testing for more than a year. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Two strong earthquakes rocked several buildings in downtown San Salvador. At least 30 people were killed, according to radio reports, and several structures were reduced to twisted steel. The intensity of the two tremors was reported to have varied from 4.5 on the Richter scale to 7.0. [ 1:1-2. ] Soviet emigration has emerged as a central topic at the Reagan-Gorbachev talks. President Reagan said Soviet human rights would receive as much priority as arms control when he meets Mr. Gorbachev this weekend. The Russians have seemed to encourage expectations of liberalization on the emigration issue. [ 1:4-6. ] Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Iceland and expressed optimism that his talks with the President would lead to steps that resolve differences between the two superpowers on arms control. ''We are prepared to look for solutions of the burning problems which concern peoples all over the world,'' he said. [ 5:5-6. ] Soviet officials held an unusual news conference on domestic issues. The session was a reflection of a spirit of self-assurance and pride about a program of domestic changes begun by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. [ 6:1-2. ] A Soviet poet was freed from jail unexpectedly and returned home.

title: 'CRAZY HORSE' LIBEL CASE A LITERARY CAUSE CELEBRE
description: Peter Matthiessen, the author and the naturalist, and his publisher, Viking Penguin, are being sued for libel in two states over his book ''In the Spirit of Crazy Horse.'' In a broad sense, the 1983 book, critically acclaimed but withdrawn after publication because of the legal actions, is on trial, too.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes securities gains of $502,000 and $17,638,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes securities gains of $3,935,000 and $5,850,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Why Do Clients Hire Andrew Cuomo?
description: Governor Mario Cuomo of New York boldly champions strict ethics rules for legislators and state officials. Yet he blinks past an obvious question of seemliness raised by his son's law practice: Why do big clients hire him?

title: STORM JAMESON, ENGLISH WRITER OF 50 BOOKS
description: Storm Jameson, who wrote more than 50 books and was a leading supporter of refugee writers, died in Cambridge, England, on Sept. 30 at the age of 95.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $22.5 million resulting from an Interstate Commerce Commision decision relating to coal rate refunds to Omaha Public Power district. c-Net income The year-ago results are stated on a pro-forma basis to include restatements for a change in accounting methods and the impact of the railroad' 7/8 depreciation charge. The company said the latest 9-month period is after previously reported accounting changes and asset writedowns.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL BANKING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AS STOCK FELL, CLAUSEN'S STAR ROSE
description: Over the last few months, Samuel H. Armacost, chief executive officer of the beleagurered BankAmerica Corporation, told directors repeatedly that he would step down any time they asked him, insiders said yesterday. Early this week, the directors did ask him.

title: JUDGE IMPEACHMENT PROCESS ASSAILED
description: Senator Howell Heflin, a former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, said today that the impeachment trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne proved so cumbersome and unworkable that the entire process of judicial impeachment should be taken out of the hands of Congress.

title: Hicks Leaves Key Post At Defense Department
description: Dr. Donald A. Hicks has resigned as Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, effective today. He was the senior civilian official in charge of new weapons development.

title: DECINCES' LITTLE HIT CREATES BIG DISPUTE
description: Until something better comes along -something really weird - it will be known as ''The Play'' of the 1986 American League Championship Series.

title: TMK/UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes securities gains of $587,000 for the quarter and $11,506,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes securities gains of $340,000 for the quarter and $1,121,000 for the 9 months. The 1985 results include a $4.5 million after-tax charge for a nonrecurring writeoff of certain deferred acquisition costs.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IT IS AGREED, THE 2 BATHROOMS ARE NEUTRAL GROUND
description: In the world of summit diplomacy, points are scored not only on intermediate missiles and human rights issues.

title: BACK HOME, METS SEEK EDGE
description: For the first time in 13 years, the playoff for the National League pennant will be staged in New York when the Mets shoot for the tiebreaker today against the Houston Astros in Shea Stadium.

title: CENTRAL BANCORPORATION (OHIO) INC (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January and an 8 percent stock dividend paid July 8.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. HOUSTON ASTROS, at Shea Stadium, third game of National League Championship Series, 12:10 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, noon; Radio - WCBS 880 and WHN 1050, 11:55 A.M.). BOSTON RED SOX VS. ANGELS, at Anaheim, Calif., third game of American League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8:07 P.M.) COLLEGE FOOTBALL Pittsburgh at Notre Dame (Television -USA, 12:30 P.M., & Channel 11, 12:30 P.M.); Auburn at Vanderbilt (Television - WTBS, 12:30 P.M.); Cornell at Harvard (Television - Channel 13, 1 P.M.); Princeton at Columbia, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Cablevision of Long Island, 4 P.M., tape); Fordham at Villanova (Radio -WFUV AM 90.7, 1:15 P.M.); Navy at Air Force (Television - MSG, 2 P.M., TEMPO, midnight, tape); Michigan St. at Michigan (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.); Miami at West Virginia (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.); Washington at Stanford (Television - WTBS, 7 P.M.); Oklahoma St. at Nebraska; (Television -ESPN, 7:30 P.M.).

title: Push Comes to Shove
description: Although members of the House do not normally go in for the elaborate displays of comity and courtesy that mark proceedings in the Senate, neither, by and large, do they often criticize one another personally, particularly when they are allies in the same party.

title: Alcohol as an Automotive Fuel Just Doesn't Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: INFORMER IN FRIEDMAN CASE ADMITS FRAUD
description: A Manhattan psychiatrist identified as one of the secret prosecution witnesses in the Government's corruption case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal fraud charge stemming from a related case. The plea resulted from a plea bargain, prosecutors said.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST BANK SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest results include the effects of several major transactions in the third quarter. First Bank System recognized loan chargeoffs, asset writedowns, discounts and a loss on disposition of a subsidiary, totaling $336.2 million during the quarter. The company also realized gains of $297.8 million from the sale of securities.

title: DOMESTIC ISSUES A TOPIC OF SOVIET NEWS BRIEFING
description: Soviet officials took the unusual step today of holding a news conference on domestic issues, saying Moscow's foreign policy was inextricably linked to its internal affairs.

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL N V reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: AFTER 8 MONTHS, U.A.W. SEES SHIFT IN COLT STRIKE
description: Samuel Colt's gun factory, which opened here in 1855, was viewed by some historians as the prototype for America's industrial revolution, with the first mass production of parts by belt-driven machinery and innovative working conditions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SURREALIST There is a new exhibition of 20th-century Surrealism that opens today in the ebulliently classical New York Public Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue, but this merely enhances the idea of a building that can handle with grace any aspect of art, literature or general knowledge.

title: SENIOR BONN OFFICIAL IS SLAIN BY MASKED GUNMAN
description: A senior official of the West German Foreign Ministry was shot and killed Friday night outside his home near Bonn.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT IS FOCUS OF NEW HAMPSHIRE RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: For voters who do not favor Gov. John H. Sununu, the race for Governor in New Hampshire has reduced itself to a single word, on bumper stickers that are plastered around the state. The word combines his name with the most emotional issue facing New Hampshire, the Seabrook nuclear plant. It is ''Sununuke.'' Mr. Sununu, who stresses that the plant is finished and that licensing is a Federal decision, has been the most prominent supporter of the project in Seabrook, the seacoast town that for more than a decade has attracted debate, demonstrations and predictions of doom. In recent weeks the nuclear issue has irritated Mr. Sununu's relationships with the Governors of neighboring Vermont and Massachusetts. Plant Ready to Load Fuel

title: Might as Well Call It the Iacoccamobile
description: The Lido, which does not yet exist, may already be a sign of the times. In case you missed the news, Lido (as in Lido A. ''Lee'' Iacocca), will probably be the name of the 1988 luxury sports coupe that Chrysler is producing in a joint venture with Maserati. If Chrysler can find a better name, it should buy it. Soon.

title: Outside Experts Back NASA On Decision on Shuttle Tests
description: An independent panel of scientific and engineering experts has endorsed the space agency's decision to continue testing its redesigned shuttle booster rockets in the same horizontal position as before the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a space agency source said today.

title: CHILD'S-EYE VIEWS OF MODERN WAR
description: The colored-pencil drawing, its ground and sky stacked in a manner typical of children's art, shows two cows grazing in a grassy field with a blue sky and a yellow sun overhead. Also in the sky are two biplanes loaded with bombs.

title: Lucky Stores Sets Stock Repurchase
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said yesterday that its directors had authorized the repurchase of up to 11.3 million of its approximately 52 million shares at $40 apiece, or about $450 million.

title: DEVELOPER WAS 92
description: Leon R. Spear, a senior vice president of Helmsley-Spear Inc., the real estate development company, and a leading Manhattan real-estate broker for almost 70 years, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: AS EXPO 86 EXPIRES, A CITY MOURNS
description: Nearly a decade ago, Grace McCarthy, then and now a Cabinet minister in British Columbia, had her heart set on bringing the Mona Lisa here for a visit to celebrate the centennial of this stunningly beautiful city. When others suggested that the French might not be amenable, she hit upon the idea of a world's fair instead.

title: Kay Jewelers
description: Kay Jewelers Inc. said it was negotiating to acquire the J.B. Robinson retail jewelry store subsidiary of W.R. Grace & Company.

title: Allied Blocks Campeau Bid
description: The Allied Stores Corporation yesterday obtained a temporary restraining order halting for 10 days the $66-a-share tender offer for its stock made by the Campeau Corporation.

title: Stories Of the City
description: Q. and A.Workers cleaning out the old Police Headquarters on Centre Street before turning it into condominiums recently entered a small room under the rafters in the clock tower. There, to their astonishment, was a huge bird's nest - about 10 feet in diameter.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAID TO HAVE AIDED PRIVATE SUPPLIERS OF CONTRA UNITS
description: Government officials said today that White House and Pentagon officials had continued to assist private efforts to supply the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: KEY RATES
BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Nine weeks before the infant's birth, a team of California surgeons removed him as a 23-week-old fetus from his mother's womb, successfullly operated to correct a blocked urinary tract, and then returned the unborn baby to the uterus and sewed the womb back up. 2. Bernard Kalb resigned as the State Department spokesman to protest what he called ''the reported disinformation program'' conducted by the Reagan Administration against the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. In doing so, he joined what Mr. Acheson called the ''exclusive club'' of public officials who ''resigned in the cause of conscience.'' 3. That Columbus made his first landing in the New World not at the Bahamian island of San Salvador but at Samana Cay, a Bahamian island 65 miles away. 4. If approved, a refurbished Staten Island ferry will become a floating jail. 5. True. 6. In a new phase of Brown v. Board of Education, the case that 32 years ago ended legally sanctioned segregation of schools in the United States, lawyers in Topeka, Kan., will argue that black students in that city still have not gained full redress for segregation. 7. The Waterford Glass Group of Ireland and Wedgwood P.L.C., of Britain. 8. President Reagan made the quip to his wife, Nancy, after she fell off a platform after a performance at the White House by the pianist Vladimir Horowitz. 9. Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw, ending his hopes of regaining the world chess championship, wrested from him 11 months ago by Gary Kasparov. 10.

title:
HOW TO RESTORE PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN NEW YORK STATE OFFICIALS;
CAMPAIGN FINANCING
description: Among the earliest recommendations of the State-City Commission on Integrity in Government, which last week delivered a report on government ethics, were those dealing with New York's system of campaign financing - a system that continues to offer vast opportunities for corruption and creates a climate for other abuses.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
description: b-Includes expenses of $27 million relating to the acquisition of the company and associated matters being charged to income in the quarter. c-Includes a $50 million pre-tax gain on the sale of certain foreign operations. The company said that as previously reported, adoption of new accounting methods resulted in the recognition of income in the latest quarter that amounted to $12.9 million, before tax.

title: HAMMER ATTACK ON HISTORIC DOCUMENTS
description: A man wielding a hammer and calling the United States ''an imperialistic country'' smashed the glass-encased display of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights at the National Archives today. Officials said the documents were not damaged.

title: GERMAN VIEW CITED
description: Dealers in foreign currency resumed selling dollars yesterday and buying West German marks after an official of the Bundesbank said that the recent European interventions were aimed at softening the dollar's decline, not reversing it.

title: Stake Held In Montedison
description: Gruppo Ferruzzi, Italy's biggest agricultural concern, has acquired a key stake in Montedison S.p.A., the Milan-based chemicals giant, Raul Gardini, the chairman of Ferruzzi, said Thursday night that his group had acquired a 14.5 percent stake, valued at around 700 billion lire, or about $500 million, in Montedison, which is Italy's second-biggest private industrial concern after Fiat S.p.A.

title:
PATENTS;
Computer Keyboard
description: A college faculty member has invented a keyboard that he hopes will make computerized services more widely available to business executives and other people who are not expert typists. Daniel J. Power, assistant professor in the College of Business Management at the University of Maryland at College Park, was granted patent No. 4,615,629 this week.

title: WEEKEND PARADES
description: The Columbus Day Parade begins today at 11 A.M., moving up Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Street and ending at 5 P.M.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND CONGRESS CHIEFS REACH AN ACCORD ON ARMS CONTROL
description: On the eve of the American-Soviet meeting in Iceland, the House and Senate leadership and the White House reached an accord on arms control issues today after House leaders backed off from major provisions the President objected to.

title: Anderson Studying Giants' Playbook Special to The New York Times
description: Now that the Giants have acquired Ottis Anderson from the St. Louis Cardinals, they are trying to teach him enough to play here Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been restated for the 33 l/3 percent common stock distribution made in December 1985.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Golden State Warriors requested waviers on Phil Ford, a veteran guard, and Mike Williams, a forward and third-round draft pick. . . . The Seattle Seahawks released Bob Cryder, a two-year starter at guard who was the club's final contract holdout before the first game. Lyle Blackwood, the veteran Miami safety who suffered a sprained ankle in the game against New England last week, was placed on injured reserve by the Dolphins. He will be out at least four weeks. . . . Mark Haynes, a former Giant cornerback, and Vance Johnson, a wide receiver, were activated by Denver to make them available for the Bronco-San Diego Charger game Sunday. . . . Chris Evert Lloyd has withdrawn from the United States team that will play Wightman Cup matches against Britain in London, Oct. 30 to Nov. 1, because of a knee injury. . . . Frank Shorter, who won a gold medal in the marathon at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, has entered the New York Marathon Nov. 2. Shorter, 37, finished 56th in last year's marathon, his fifth in New York. . . . Bail was denied Luis Resto, a former junior middleweight boxer, and Carlos (Panama) Lewis, his manager and trainer. Resto and Lewis were convicted earlier this week for their roles in a glove-tampering scheme surrounding Resto's June 1983 fight against Billy Collins Jr. Sentencing is scheduled for Oct. 27. . . . Terry Cummings concluded weeks of negotiation by signing a new contract with the Milwaukee Bucks. Terms of the two-year contract were not disclosed. . . . After Warren Young accumulated 40 goals and 32 assists as a rookie with the Pittsburgh Penguins during the 1984-85 season, he became a free agent and signed a four-year contract worth an estimated $1 million with the Detroit Red Wings. Thursday he was reacquired by Pittsburgh for cash considerations, which means that Detroit will pay part of his salary.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Maryland Standards
description: University of Maryland task force yesterday urged tighter admissions requirements and higher standards for athletes, conceding that the school ''has not been vigilant'' in insuring the academic integrity of its sports program.

title: Bolivians Chase Agents To Protest a Drug Raid
description: Bolivian and United States drug agents raided this town today in search of cocaine traffickers, but then fled during a protest by hundreds of angry residents, some shouting, ''Kill the Yankees!''

title: BENNINGTON SELECTS NEW YORK PROFESSOR AS ITS NEW PRESIDENT
description: The trustees of Bennington College today elected Elizabeth Coleman, a professor and former dean at the New School for Social Research, as president of the small liberal arts school.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter results include a non-recurring charge of $60 million to operations.

title: KOCH DENIES CURBING INQUIRIES
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had criticized Patrick W. McGinley, the former City Investigation Commissioner, for using ''inflammatory'' language in reports and for using a subpoena to obtain financial disclosure forms filed by City Council members.

title: FIRST PEOPLES BANK OF NEW JERSEY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $900,000 and $2,350,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Man Charged With 2 Deaths
description: A 30-year-old Manhattan man was arrested yesterday on charges of murdering his 5-year-old daughter and the 10-month-old son of his girlfriend to collect on life insurance policies he had taken out on them.

title: GORBACHEV, IN ICELAND, CITES HOPE OF ENDING WAR THREAT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today expressing optimism that his weekend talks with President Reagan would lead to steps that ''remove the threat of nuclear war.''

title: INSTANT REPLAY RULE TROUBLES NETWORKS
description: They usually spend their days in fierce competition for the almighty rating point, but sports executives at the three major networks are united these days against a common foe: The way the National Football League uses television replays to help officials.

title: 2 Americans Freed From Yugoslav Jails
description: Two Americans held in Yugoslav jails were released today, and a third American will soon be released, a Congressman announced today.

title: AGING CHURCH UNITES BLACKS AND JEWS
description: One day last October, Vernon Barker started thinking that the South Side church where he was head deacon needed repainting.

title: U.S. ENVOY IN NICARAGUA SEES AMERICAN SURVIVOR FROM LOST PLANE
description: Nicaraguan officials today permitted a United States diplomat to see for the first time the American who was captured five days ago when a rebel supply plane was shot down over Nicaragua.

title: THE DANCE: 'STRAW HEARTS'
description: Guest stars danced on the program performed by the Feld Ballet on Thursday at the Joyce Theater. The evening also featured a new work by Mr. Feld, and many new company dancers to get to know. But the show was stolen by a familiar young Feld dancer named James Sewell.

title: SUMMIT BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOR THE ST. LAWRENCE VALLEY, PRISONS REPRESENT A NEW GROWTH INDUSTRY
description: In New York City, nobody ever wants a jail built in their neighborhood. But here in the North Country, still trying to recover from the departure of the lumber and paper mills more than 30 years ago, people can hardly wait for construction to begin.

title: LANDLORDS GET HEAT WARNING
description: The current cool snap (10 degrees below normal for this time of year) has sent people scurrying to their furnaces - or to their landlords.

title:
PATENTS;
A Treatment for Wood To Improve Qualities
description: A team of Russian inventors obtained a patent this week for a composition to impregnate wood and improve its qualities, including making it weather-resistant.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOUISIANA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FED STAFF QUERIES DEAL BY SUMITOMO, GOLDMAN
description: The legal staff of the Federal Reserve Board voiced strong skepticism today about plans by Sumitomo Bank Ltd., the world's third-largest bank, to inject $500 million of capital into the investment banking firm Goldman, Sachs & Company in return for a 12.5 percent passive, nonvoting equity ownership.

title: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Beyond Daniloff
description: To the Editor:

title: BID PLANNED TO END JAMS AT JAMAICA STATION
description: Officials of the Long Island Rail Road have proposed a $240 million plan they say will finally break the infamous bottleneck at the antiquated Jamaica Station in Queens.

title: DOW DRIFTS 3.65 LOWER AS TURNOVER SHRINKS
description: With trading volume shrinking considerably, stock prices drifted lower on Wall Street yesterday as investors remained indifferent.

title: IN MILAN SHOPS, THE BEAUTIFUL AND THE EXOTIC
description: An army of plunderers descended on Milan this week. There are the fashion professionals who supposedly come to evaluate new clothes, but seem to spend almost as much time in Milan's stores buying things for themselves. There is the pop star Patti Labelle, who appeared at Franco Moschino's fashion show Tuesday, but by Wednesday could be found in the Prada shop on Milan's Madison Avenue, Via della Spiga, singing the praises of its fine leather shoes. And there are two stars of television's ''Dallas,'' Linda Grey and Larry Hagman, who came from Paris where they were publicizing their show. But, at a luncheon hosted by Krizia's designer, Mariuccia Mandelli and her husband, Aldo Pinto, when Mr. Hagman was asked why he'd come to Milan, he pointed to his wife, Maj(cq) and said, ''so she can shop.'' Though the dollar buys fewer lire, about 1370, today than it has in recent years, Milan is heaven for those who love to shop 'til they drop.

title: Retrial Opens for Man Accused in Cult Slayings
description: The second trial of Larry Layton, once a devoted member of the People's Temple religious commune, opened today with the prosecutor accusing him of being one of 13 assassins at a jungle airstrip that killed a Congressman and four others eight years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Chicago dispatch in some editions yesterday, about testimony in a Federal corruption trial in New Haven that implicated Chicago figures, misidentified a convicted procurer who is a former aide to Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago. He is Clarence McClain.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCREEN: WES CRAVEN'S 'DEADLY FRIEND'
description: ''Deadly Friend'' is a witty ghoul story, a grandson of ''Frankenstein'' that plays off the conventions of recent teen-age horror movies while paying homage to the classic starring Boris Karloff. In previous films, the director, Wes Craven, has played it straight, creating a bloody cult movie in ''A Nightmare on Elm Street,'' and he has played horror for laughs, in a lesser-known sendup, ''Swamp Thing.'' Here he creates a film that deliberately teeters on the edge of spoof, slowly moving toward such unpredictable goofiness that a basketball becomes a gory murder weapon.

title: PERES RESIGNS, PAVING WAY FOR SHAMIR TO TAKE OVER
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres submitted his resignation today to President Chaim Herzog, paving the way for Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir to succeed him next week in accordance with their power-sharing rotation agreement.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Javier Perez de Cuellar; UNANIMOUSLY, THE U.N.'S MAN
description: If Javier Perez de Cuellar could live his life over again, he says he would become a concert pianist.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING COMPANY OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $1,193,000 for the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also includes a gain of $25,164,000 from the sale of the company's 57 percent interest in its data processing operations and income from discontinued operations of $623,000. c-After income of $602,000 for the quarter and $1,636,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. The 1985 results have been restated for acquisitions made during that year.

title: Manager Dies in S.I. Shooting
description: The manager of a private bus company was shot to death yesterday morning as he was changing a flat tire outside his home on Staten Island, the police said.

title: LINDENAUER HAS WORKED IN STORE WITH LINKS TO SANTUCCI SECRETARY
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer testified yesterday in the corruption trial in New Haven that he had worked for $3 an hour in a cleaning store believed to be owned by the former husband of a secretary in the Queens District Attorney's office.

title: Ladies' Mile Is Bound to Thrive as a Manhattan Historic District
description: To the Editor:

title: A.& P. in Bid To Buy Delchamps
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday offered to purchase Delchamps Inc., a Gulf Coast supermarket chain, for $23 a share in cash, or about $160 million.

title: SOVIET JEWISH EMIGRATION GAINS IN THE AGENDA
description: The status of Soviet Jews has emerged in advance as a central topic at the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting here this weekend.

title: FEDERAL FUNCTIONS BEGIN A SHUTDOWN
description: The Reagan Administration shut down most of the Federal Government early today, seeking to put pressure on House and Senate negotiators to reach agreement on the comprehensive appropriations bill for 1987.

title: ARBOR DRUGS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Reflects pro forma income tax provisions assuming the company's wholly owned Century Drug Stores subsidiary was not an S corporation prior to its acquisition.

title: ABC PUTS JACKSON IN WRONG ARENA
description: Keith Jackson is the finest college football broadcaster in America. His Southern smoothness, the folksy description ''hoss'' for a big, strong player, the excitable call of ''Fuuummmble,'' the hurried tempo to match speeded action -these are some of the trademarks and talents of a skilled craftsman.

title: Communists Kill 9 In Philippine Ambush
