description: Communist rebels have ambushed an army platoon in the central Philippines, killing eight soldiers and a civilian in the most violent attack since the military captured a top rebel commander last month, officials said today.

title: IN NEW YORK, STORM OVER CONTRACEPTIVES IN SCHOOLS
description: WHAT Robert F. Wagner Jr., the president of the New York City Board of Education, hoped would be a simple matter of persuading his board to make sex education courses compulsory in the schools turned into a full-blown storm last week when it was discovered - or at least disclosed - that nine high school health clinics were offering contraceptives to students.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No Fine Frenzy Poets in fiction are usually satirized for their Dionysian extravagance, their ''fine frenzy,'' but in ''Group Sex'' (Knopf), Ann Arensberg's poet is a comedy of economy. He was thin, as a poet should be, and had insomnia. He subsisted on nuts and fruit, like the creatures of the field. He was gentle and good and shy of other people. He built bookshelves for Frances's apartment and painted them himself. He enjoyed taking walks. He enjoyed staring out of the window. When he stayed overnight, he kept to his side of the bed. . . . Even when he was working, he took up so little space. He would bring her his poems and ask her permission to read them. He read standing up, while Frances stretched out on the couch. His poems were simple. They were set in a rough, northern landscape, at three seasons of the year - he never wrote about summer. There were birds in his poems, and plants, but very few people. If people were introduced, they were harming creation, setting fires, cutting trees, or diverting streams and rivers.

title: PARKED IN THE GARAGE: EVERYTHING BUT THE CAR
description: IN the spring a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love. In fall, however, if that young man is anything like me, his thoughts turn to more mundane matters. Like clearing out the garage.

title: WESTFIELD SCHOOLS' STAKE IN CERTIFICATION IS HIGH
description: AFTER the local school district was denied state certification last spring, Laurence F. Greene, the Superintendent of Schools, was inundated with shocked inquiries about what had happened.

title: 40 Parachutists Jump From W. Virginia Bridge
description: About 40 parachutists defied stiff winds today and jumped off the 876-foot New River Gorge Bridge to the delight of nearly 200,000 onlookers.

title: 'Star Trek' Returning To TV With a New Cast
description: ''Star Trek,'' which became a show business legend after its cancellation nearly 20 years ago, will return to television next September with a new cast in a first-run syndicated series.

title: Home-Run Ball Was 'Terrible Pitch,' Smith Says
description: The pitch that Alan Ashby called that Dave Smith threw that Len Dykstra hit into the right-field seats to conclude the third game of the National League championship series, was an offspeed forkball over the plate and just above the knees. ''It was,'' said Smith, ''a terrible pitch.''

title: MAKING A RUST BOWL OF SILICON VALLEY
description: THIS is another story of the loss of a manufacturing industry to Japan, of protectionism that backfired, and of options unexplored. But this time it is not about steel, textiles, autos or anything else produced by unionized workers and entrenched managers in grimy factories in the middle of America.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Long Beach
description: WITH a Long Island Rail Road link that can carry commuters from Manhattan nearly to its two-and-a-half-mile boardwalk in about 50 minutes and an island climate that cools summer and warms winter, the wonder is that Long Beach ever lost its attraction as a place to live.

title: Wagner Downs Hofstra, 28-21
description: Terry Underwood, the leading rusher in Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, gained 157 yards in 32 carries and scored two touchdowns on runs of 1 and 11 yards to lead Wagner to a 28-21 victory over previously undefeated Hofstra yesterday.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
'Hotel Du Lac' Reconstructed on A&E;
description: Turning a book into a movie is always a tricky business.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT IS UNDER THE SOIL COUNTS, TOO
description: IF you ever had a houseplant that died for no apparent reason, this discussion is for you.

title: ABOUT I.R.A.'S, THE NEWS IS MOSTLY BAD
description: Among the myriad changes the tax revolution under way in Washington will bring about is a reshaping of the ground rules for Individual Retirement Accounts. Below are answers to frequent questions about how the new provisions will work. Q. Is there any action I should take about my I.R.A. this year? A. Yes. Be sure to make the full $2,000 contribution ($2,250 for one-income couples) for tax year 1986, even if you have to borrow to come up with the money. This is the last year that upper-income people covered by company retirement plans can make a tax-deductible contribution. And even though the stiffer new rules take effect on Jan. 1, you have until April 15 to make the contribution. Q. Are there limits on how much you can earn and still deduct your I.R.A. contribution? A. Taxpayers who are not covered by an employer retirement plan may continue to deduct their full contributions. But income limits have been imposed on taxpayers who are covered by an employer-sponsored retirement plan, such as a company pension plan or a Keogh plan.

title: YOUNG MAN, OLD EMPIRE, BAD WAR
description: GOING SOLO By Roald Dahl. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: MALE VEGETABLES?
description: THE LIFE OF HELEN ALONE By Karen Lawrence. 260 pp. New York: Villard Books. $15.95.

title: Miss Thomas Becomes Bride of E. Robert Lupone
description: Victoria Catherine Thomas, an associate in municipal finance at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, and E. Robert Lupone, an associate at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. The Rev. Stanley Moseley performed the ceremony.

title: Reagan Incorporated?
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX BILL SEEN AS BOTH GOOD AND BAD FOR L.I.
description: THE tax overhaul bill that President Reagan is expected to sign into law this week contains both good news and bad news for Long Islanders, according to local public officials and business leaders.

title: INSIDE THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
description: EACH NIGHT, WHEN the black workers of Soweto return home to their barren, segregated township, and the haze left by their coal-burning stoves glows overhead in the African sunset, thousands listen on shortwave radios to the fierce, clandestine voice of revolution.

title: Mountain Sites
description: A new development for weekenders, vacationers and permanent residents is taking shape on 78 acres in Dutchess County, N.Y., about a two-hour drive from New York City. The project had been initiated in the mid-1970's when a New York developer bought the wooded, mountaintop tract to set up a homeowners' association.

title: Anne Carroll Stires, a Securities Trader, To Marry John H. Carter Jr., a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer Stires have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Carroll Stires to John Henry Carter Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Carter of Loudonville, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May. The future bride is a foreign securities trader for the Soros Fund Management Company in New York.

title: GUILT AND A DAUGHTER'S DIABETES
description: WE had just finished a family outing that included a jaunt into the scenic fall foliage and all the obligatory stops for fresh apple cider and homemade ice cream. My daughter, Allison, went to have dinner that evening at a friend's house. She came home tired and very thirsty. After downing still another pint of apple juice and observing the bedtime rituals that are so typical of 4-year-old girls, she said her last goodnight and fell quickly off to sleep.

title: BEYOND SUPER BOWLS
description: ALABAMA SHOWDOWN The Football Rivalry Between Auburn and Alabama. By Geoffrey Norman. Illustrated. 238 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company.$18.95.

title: Captive to Be Tried, Sandinista Chief Says
description: President Daniel Ortega confirmed today that the American captured after Nicaraguan troops shot down an airplane flying supplies to the rebels will be put on trial.

title: Jazz Pays a Call In London
description: Soho, London's bohemian center, is home this week to an international jazz festival. Through next Sunday, performers from Britain and the United States can be heard from noon until after midnight at a variety of Soho clubs, theaters and restaurants, including such well-known jazz venues as Ronnie Scott's and the 100 Club.

title: No Headline
description: ALL OF US HERE By Irving Feldman. 81 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. Cloth, $17.95. Elisabeth Sifton Books/Penguin Books. Paper, $8.95. DREAM WORK By Mary Oliver. 90 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. DOMINION By Brooks Haxton. 107 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: EDUCATORS ISSUE WARNING
description: THE growing number of poor minority students in the county's public schools soon will pose added problems for Westchester's economy, members of a newly formed coalition of education groups warned last week. But the educators' calls for help in solving such problems as teen-age pregnancy, illiteracy and a lack of job skills did not receive an enthusiastic response from at least one spokesman for the Westchester business community.

title: FLAMBOYANT FINANCIER GUILTY OF SWINDLING WIDOW
description: Thomas A. Termotto once boasted that his art gallery atop one of Rochester's oldest landmark buildings would bring a touch of class to the city.

title: Jailhouse Rock Could Become Anchors Aweigh
description: Rather than cut down on the drug-related arrests that have been packing New York City jails to overflowing since April, the Koch administration last week announced a package of expansion proposals including a plan to house 150 convicts in a retired Staten Island ferryboat off Rikers Island. Officials said they would also seek approval to add space for 750 more prisoners on Rikers Island and send 1,400 convicts to two upstate communities where new jails will be built.

title: Assessing Mario Cuomo
description: In his article ''The Question of Mario Cuomo'' (Sept. 14), R. W. Apple Jr. suggests - as have other observers - that a 60-40 victory by Governor Cuomo in November would enhance his chances in a possible run for the Presidency in 1988. This suggestion may appear reasonable, but, in one key respect, it is unrealistic.

title:
THE JOB MARKET;
Regional Job Roundup: Far West
description: HEALTHY GROWTH in several industries in the West has lured thousands of job-seekers from more depressed areas of the nation. California, Nevada and Arizona all report marked increases in their work forces in the last year, which has skewed earlier forecasts but has not dampened the outlook for job growth in those states.

title: ALMOST 100 YEARS LATER, MICHIGAN TROUT RETURN
description: Headlights pierced the darkness as a small boat bobbed on wind-driven waves on Lewis Lake, in the southern part of the park. Two people, standing on a platform in the front of the boat, peered intently into the water. ''There we go,'' one yelled as he dipped a net into the water and swooped a glistening lake trout.

title: THE LIVING THEATER LOOKS BACK BEFORE RESUMING ITS AVANTE-GARDE WAYS
description: THE Living Theater, the avant-garde acting company that made its reputation in the 1950's and 60's with productions that were determinedly unconventional, and which styled itself as anarchist and revolutionary, has returned to center stage for what one of its co-founders, Judith Malina, called a ''retrospectacle.''

title: Lions Lose 25th In a Row
description: Not even the presence of the only Columbia football team ever to win an Ivy League title could help end the Lions' three-year losing streak on Homecoming Day yesterday at Lawrence A. Wien Stadium.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Icelanders that we met yesterday tried to persuade me very convincingly that we must agree on something with you, Mr. President.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF HENRY VIII. By Margaret George. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) In her first novel, Margaret George asks us to believe that Henry VIII wrote an extensive memoir, discovered posthumously and annotated by his erstwhile fool and companion, Will Somers.

title: SHOPPING CARTS THAT GO ASTRAY
description: I noted with interest ''The Wayward Carts'' [ Long Island Journal, Sept. 14 ] , since I formally complained to the Police Department that shopping carts were being deposited in a Town of Hempstead triangle adjacent to my home.

title: Daniel Franklin Mumford Weds Margaret C. Stribling
description: Margaret Coggeshall Stribling, a research assistant in oceanography, and Daniel Franklin Mumford, a graduate student in geology, both at Oregon State University, were married yesterday in Aiken, S.C. The Revs.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE state's Department of Higher Education is starting an $840,000 advertising campaign this month in an effort to stem the flight of students to out-of-state colleges.

title: Jack Clarke Is Married To Maureen A. Klinges
description: Maureen Ann Klinges, a daughter of Dr. Karl Guy Klinges of Paramus, N.J., and the late Maureen Dougherty Klinges, was married yesterday to James Archer Clarke Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke of Louisa, Va. The Rev. Robert Wolfe performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Tenafly, N.J.

title: ARTISTRY OF THE ICE AGE
description: IN A LABORATORY ACROSS THE narrow hall from his office, Dr. Randall White, an assistant professor of anthropology at New York University, picked carefully, almost reverently, through the assorted material remains of a prehistoric vision. In a tray lay some beads of stone and bone that ice age people had decorated with fine carved lines.

title: M. SARTRE GOES TO HOLLYWOOD
description: THE FREUD SCENARIO By Jean-Paul Sartre. Edited by J.-B. Pontalis. Translated by Quintin Hoare. 549 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WELCOME HOME, JENNY
description: JENNY came home today, to a small house with an apple tree outside and a patio to enjoy the summer evenings, in a comfortable neighborhood in a Connecticut town.

title: THE JOY OF ALFALFA
description: MAKING HAY By Verlyn Klinkenborg. Illustrated by Gordon Allen. 157 pp. New York: Nick Lyons Books. $14.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CONSUMING FEARS: The Politics of Product Risks. Edited by Harvey M. Sapolsky. (Basic Books, $18.95.) Books about risk are starting to form a genre with characteristics a little like books on the assassination of President Kennedy: nearly everybody finds the facts too incredible to take at face value; nearly everybody smells a conspiracy.

title: Tricky Politics: A Troubled Capital
description: There's an uneasy feeling in Washington these days. The Reagan Administration has been hurt by its misinformation campaign against Libya and its tricky handling of the Nicaraguan problem. It has denied everything but convinced nobody.

title: REPLYING TO ACKOFF
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN IN POLITICS: STATE LAGS
description: A RECENT study shows that New Jerseyans prefer men to women in local elected government, but female officials in the state say that may be changing.

title:
THE JOB MARKET;
Regional Job Roundup: Midwest
description: THE continued decline in heavy industry and agriculture, long the economic mainstay in the Middle West, is taking its toll on job opportunities. Even in high-growth fields, such as medicine and financial services, which have exploded in recent years, recruiting activity is being trimmed. There are a few bright spots, including Chicago's fast-growing financial district and retail sales.

title: THAT WILL BE 20 SHILLINGS, MR. CASANOVA
description: WITS, WENCHERS AND WANTONS London's Low Life: Covent Garden in the Eighteenth Century. By E. J. Burford. Illustrated. 260 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Salem House. $22.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
SUSHI IN MAMARONECK
description: IN the long, narrow space last occupied by a clothing store, Abis, in niftily redecorated quarters, seems to have found a niche in the immediate community. If you tried this restaurant last May or June, during its opening weeks, and were, as we were, disappointed, we recommend trying it again.

title: When the Work Is Too Easy
description: AN EMPLOYEE at a city sewage plant in Toledo, Ohio, spent $5,000 of his own money a month ago to tell the world in a series of newspaper ads that his job was too easy. He said he worked 30 minutes a day, loafed 7 1/2 hours and was paid $25,471 a year.

title: TRIAL STARTS IN PARIS FOR THE 'KING OF FENCES'
description: Maurice Joffo had it all - apartments in Paris, Cannes and Geneva, a country home, real estate in France and Brazil, and a certain notoriety in the slightly seedy world of nightclub habitues and people of suspicious wealth.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BRIDGETON'S 300TH Bridgeton, the seat of Cumberland County, will celebrate its tricentennial Saturday and next Sunday with a Civil War enactment in which battalions in authentic Union Army uniforms will march, sing and shoot.

title: Mozambique Accuses South Africa of Raid Plan
description: Mozambique's Government accused South Africa today of sending commandos into Maputo and planning an air raid on the capital, and it told its citizens to be on the alert.

title: Goodbye, America
description: Dr. Arnold Lockshin seems to have found something oppressive about life in Houston, Texas, but just what it was is unclear. Dr. Lockshin, who worked as a cancer researcher at the Stehlin Foundation until he was dismissed in August, turned up last week in the Soviet Union, where he said he and his family had emigrated to escape political ''persecution.'' Back in Houston, where Dr. Lockshin, his wife, Lauren, and their three children had left behind a house and two Chevrolets, Dr. John Stehlin, his former employer, dismissed the notion that Dr. Lockshin had been fired for political reasons. ''I don't know anything about his politics,'' he said, adding that Dr. Lockshin was dismissed after he became withdrawn and unable to do his work.

title: Bangladesh Towns Flooded By Heavy Rains of Monsoon
description: Monsoon floods in northeast Bangladesh have flooded at least 10 towns and cut roads and rail links with Dhaka, officials said today.

title: Article 237586 -- No Title
description: The Bic Corporation has agreed to pay $3.25 million to a woman who was burned over more than 25 percent of her body after a Bic lighter's fuel container exploded in her pocket.

title: Saving Bison At Yellowstone
description: ''F OR reasons unknown except to the buffalo'' - as the deputy United States attorney in Butte, Mont., puts it - a bison herd in Yellowstone National Park began to migrate northward out of the park into cattle rangeland. Montana officials, fearing the bison would infect the cattle with brucellosis, a disease that causes them to abort calves, sanctioned the hunting of the bison.

title: DANCE: A SHOWCASE FOR CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: ''CHOREO SHOWCASE II,'' presented on Wednesday at Theater of the Riverside Church, was a nicely balanced program of dances by relatively new or unknown choreographers.

title: Changes at the Top for Troubled BankAmerica
description: When Samuel H. Armacost took over at BankAmerica Corporation five and a half years ago, he was expected to streamline what was then the nation's largest bank and guide it through the rough era of deregulation. Today, Citicorp is No. 1 and BankAmerica is weighed down by heavy losses, which have badly depressed its stock.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COLLIECTIBLES EXPO AT LIBERTY PARK
description: TAKING advantage of a stunning locale facing the Statue of Liberty and the Lower Manhattan skyline, the Collectibles Expo at Liberty State Park here Saturday will bring together more than 100 dealers in the renovated Jersey Central terminal building.

title: Steven Lawrence Stone Weds Jennifer A. Swan
description: Jennifer Ann Swan and Steven Lawrence Stone were married yesterday at the First Church of Christ in Longmeadow, Mass., by the Rev. Gary A. DeLong. Penelope Swan was her sister's maid of honor.

title: BRAZIL GETS BACK ON THE FAST TRACK
description: ''NO one can hold back this country,'' Brazil's ruling generals used to boast back in the booming 1970's. And indeed, at that time, few people here seemed to doubt that Brazil's huge territory, population and natural resources would transform it into a major industrial power of the 21st century.

title: TO ILL AND DISABLED, PIANIST'S DREAM IS A GIFT
description: Michael John Spencer started out in 1969 with a piano and a hope of bringing the arts to people who were too ill or disabled to visit a theater or concert hall by themselves.

title: DATA BANK October 12, 1986
SEEING OFF A CHILD IN THE ERA OF TERRORISM...
description: ''I HATE hanging out at airports,'' said my daughter.

title: THE DARKER BROTHER
description: THE LIFE OF LANGSTON HUGHES Volume One: 1902-1941. I, Too, Sing America. By Arnold Rampersad. Illustrated. 468 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: POLITICAL NEWCOMER CHALLENGING BRODSKY
description: ROBIN BERGSTROM said her interest in politics was awakened as a reporter and news editor of radio station WVIP in Mount Kisco, and then intensified in Albany during the legislative year she worked as an assistant to State Senator Mary B. Goodhue.

title: Still In My Dinosaur Phase
description: MANY scholars can trace their personal roots to a lonely childhood spent reading. I was too busy on the local stickball court for such a life.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LAST OF THE MENU GIRLS. By Denise Chavez. (Arte Publico Press, University of Houston, University Park, Houston, Tex. 77004, Paper, $8.50.)

title: Of Power and Paralysis
description: Maurice B. Tobin should feel right at home when he begins a series of lectures tomorrow at the Strom Thurmond Institute of Government and Public Affairs at Clemson University. Mr. Tobin, a Washington lawyer and former counsel to Democratic Congressional committees, believes, not unlike Senator Thurmond, that the old ways may be the best ways when it comes to deciding how power should be distributed among the lawmakers.

title: 'Right Turn'
description: To the Editor:

title: Shield of David
description: To the Editor:

title: HISTORIC AMBIANCE IN THOMPSON
description: HOW refreshing to find a restaurant that actually takes the state's Clean Air Law seriously! A telephone call to make reservations at the Vernon Stiles Inn in Thompson elicited the question, ''Do you want the smoking or nonsmoking section?'' This is the effect the law should produce, but rarely does.

title: Opera and Politics Make Strange Bedfellows
description: Here's an esthetic exercise to perform the next time you find yourself at the end of a noontime line at the bank or waiting for an expressway to be cleared of fender-benders: Name the 10 most important political operas of all time. By political operas I mean those in which composers apparently set out to alter the public's attitude about some social injustice, cultural movement or patriotic dispute between nations. If the bank line seems to be moving a bit, try naming five. Or one. Don't give up, there really have been a few. Certainly there has been no lack of candidates over the years, including most recently the Anthony Davis work presented by the New York City Opera, ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X).''

title: Fast-Food Chains Going Upscale for Managers
description: ANTHONY J. PANDOLFI, like thousands of other college economics majors, is getting his master of business administration degree, but Mr. Pandolfi, a 23-year-old at the University of Illinois in Chicago, has spent the last six months flipping hamburgers and deep-frying french fries at a Wendy's fast-food restaurant nearby.

title: MR. POWER
description: IN HIS CORNER OFFICE AT THE JUS-tice Department, a private sanctum guarded by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, Edwin Meese 3d, the 75th Attorney General of the United States, has surrounded himself with symbols of the power he wields: a Border Patrol pistol; a United States marshal's badge; miniature police cars and helicopters. The office says much about the way Meese sees himself, for its motif reflects not so much the lawyer in Meese as it does the hard-nosed lawman: America's top cop.

title: BOSTONIANS DEBATING DRIVE TO CARVE OUT A BLACK CITY
description: A referendum on the Nov. 4 ballot that calls for the secession of black neighborhoods in Boston has touched off an emotional dispute and raised fears of renewed racism here.

title: 3 Named Co-Winners Of Jabotinsky Awards
description: A former President of Costa Rica, a former deputy prime minister of Sweden and a Soviet dissident have been named as co-winners of the 1986 Jabotinsky Prize-Defender of Jerusalem Award.

title: A RIP-OFF IN REVERSE
description: We'd heard about Americans being ripped off in Europe, so before we flew there my husband bought a khaki money belt and zipped in his passport, credit cards and traveler's checks. He fastened the belt around his naked waist and said he'd be damned if anyone would get his money. I practiced wearing my shoulder bag inside my coat between body and arm. I looked lopsided but thought the bag would be impossible to snatch.

title: Congress Jump-Starts a Corpse
description: Eight years and five days after a Presidential commission began studying the subject, the remarkable thing about the immigration reform bill is nothing about its contents but the fact that it is still alive at all. When the bill, having again been given up for dead, passed the House Thursday night, Alan Simpson, its calm Senate sponsor, said, ''I guess we just jump-started a corpse.''

title: Allie Ault and William J. Regan Marry
description: Allie Helene Ault, a daughter of J. Burchenal Ault and the late Joan Mitchell Ault of Sante Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to William Jeremiah Regan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Regan of Andover, Mass. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: PRIVATE ROLE INCREASING IN FOREIGN WAR ACTIONS
description: In the last four years, with the public blessing of the Reagan Administration and perhaps its covert support, a network of private citizens made up of former military men and anti-Communist political groups have taken an increasing role in foreign military operations.

title: BATTLING CORRUPTION: STATUS REPORT
description: Allegations of corruption in several city departments this year have led to proposals for government and political revisions at city and state levels.

title: Subaru Building On Success
description: HARVEY LAMM'S new office is straight out of a glossy magazine, all leather, chrome and glass. The office is bigger than most Manhattan apartments, and the view from his corner of the top floor is spectacular.

title: THE GROUPING OF AMERICA
description: CITIES ON A HILL A Journey Through Contemporary American Cultures. By Frances FitzGerald. 414 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: COCAINE USE UP AMONG METHADONE PATIENTS
description: A sharp rise in cocaine use among patients receiving methadone in the last year has led some drug experts to question whether the methadone programs, begun in the early 1970's to treat heroin addiction, are effective at keeping addicts drug-free.

title: Data Update
description: (Source: HSH Associates*Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: THE PUBLIC'S VIEW: CORPORATE ACCOUNTABILITY
description: If a major United States airline has a plane crash and 200 people die, should the president of that airline resign, or not? Should resign: Dec. 1985--7% May 1986--4% Should not:Dec. 1985--81% May 1986--87% If a major United States company pleads guilty to violating federal laws and cheating banks out of interest, thousands of times, should the president of that company resign, or not? Should resign:Dec. 1985--77% May 1986--74% Should not:Dec. 1985--13% May 1986--16% If an American chemical company's plant in a foreign country has a gas leak that kills 2,000 people, should the president of that company resign, or not? Should resign:Dec. 1985--36% May 1986--35% Should not:Dec. 1985--46% May 1986--48% Based on 1,354 telephone interviews conducted December 14 through 18 and 1,099 telphone interviews conducted April 29 through May 1.

title: Tracey Finn Is Married To Daniel Gerard Duffy
description: Tracey Maureen Finn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Michael Finn of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Gerard Duffy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell B. Duffy of Clinton, Iowa, and Bradenton, Fla. The Rev. Robert J. Sweeney performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FINDING DAVID DOLORES By Margaret Willey. 150 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 12 and up)

title: How New U.S. Code Will Affect New York Activity
description: LIKE an unseen hand, the Federal tax revision will work in New York City to suppress the level of new construction of rental apartments and the renovation of older loft buildings into modern office space.

title: Best Seller: October 12, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Spokesman Quits, Citing a Principle
description: Before he became the State Department spokesman nearly two years ago, Bernard Kalb had spent 38 years in the news business. He had a good reputation as a correspondent for The New York Times, CBS and NBC, working in in New York, Washington, Southeast Asia and many other places.

title: AMID RUBBLE, RESCUERS TRACK DOWN THE CRIES
description: In the hard-hit San Jacinto neighborhood near the center of San Salvador, rescue workers scrambled to pull young students from the Santa Catalina Elementary School.

title: Eastwood Keeps a Promise
description: Carmel is going to have ice cream again, fulfilling a promise Clint Eastwood made last April in his successful campaign for Mayor. The City Planning Commission, made up largely of Eastwood appointees, voted Wednesday to approve an application to open an ice cream parlor, replacing one that closed in May 1985. The pre-Eastwood city government had placed tight restrictions on shops' take-out food in an effort to cut down on litter. Mr. Eastwood campaigned on a pro-growth platform that included a promise to bring ice cream back.

title: 'RAINMENTS OF THE NIGHT' IN TRENTON
description: WHETHER by design or serendipitous coincidence, a Tibetan priest's vest is displayed in a case adjacent to the South Gallery in the State Museum here, where Christine Martens's ''Raiments of the Night'' also are on view.

title: Agony of Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Halfback Leads Bergen Catholic
description: Tom Kearney, a senior halfback, rushed for 281 yards on 27 carries, including an 83-yard scoring run in the first quarter, as Bergen Catholic defeated Hackensack, 22-12, yesterday in Oradell.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: First Interstate's bid for BankAmerica was the final blow for Samuel H. Armacost, the BankAmerica chief executive who has been on the outs with his board as loan losses have risen and performance has slipped. Mr. Armacost resigned, saying his presence was doing more harm than good. He is expected to be succeeded by A. W. Clausen, the former president of the World Bank, whom Mr. Armacost had succeeded at BankAmerica nearly six years ago. BankAmerica is likely to reject the bid from First Interstate, despite the attractiveness a merger of the two big banking companies holds in the eyes of many analysts.

title: NITROGLYCERIN IN THE HAND CREAM
description: ONE WOMAN LOST By Abigail McCarthy and Jane Gray Muskie. 321 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95.

title: Brown is Latest Victim of Penn, 34-0
description: It was Brown's turn today to go under the hammer of Pennsylvania, the defending Ivy League champion.

title: KREMLIN ADVISER CALLS OFFER ON NUCLEAR TESTS A 'TRICK'
description: A senior Soviet official today called President Reagan's proposal for a phased reduction in nuclear testing ''a trick and maneuver'' designed to draw attention away from the need for a total test ban.

title: E. 7TH ST. CHANGES; Synagogue To Co-ops
description: The City Planning Commission says the artistic, rapidly gentrifying piece of the Lower East Side known as the East Village runs from Houston Street north to 14th Street between Fourth Avenue and Avenue A. But the border may be stretching to the east.

title: THE ELUSIVE PROMISE OF ELECTRIC CARS
description: ELECTRICALLY powered cars are the ancient innovation that will neither grow up nor give up. These quiet, clean machines have been around since the auto industry's earliest days. By 1910, one out of every three cars or trucks on American roads rolled along under electric power provided by batteries. Most of the batteries were not rechargeable, but their owners seemed perfectly willing to replace them whenever need be.

title: G.O.P. LAWMAKERS SEEK NEW YORK TAX CUTS
description: Senate Republicans, predicting that the new Federal tax law would cost New Yorkers $2.4 billion in added state taxes next year, called this week for a cut in state income-tax rates to make up for the losses.

title: Cable TV
description: ''One minute you're the biggest gum surgeon on Long Island. The next thing you know it's 'goodbye, Charlie.' ''

title: ULTRAPHONE, ULTRASTOCK
description: It is not every day that the director of research of a respected regional brokerage house throws his weight behind a tiny company with negligible sales, no earnings and vanishing net worth.

title: For the Love Of Teaching
description: MANY friends thought Carol Wimer and Cheryl McLauchlan ''must be crazy.'' Unhappy with the performance of public education, they quit $26,000-a-year jobs as department chairmen at Hawthorne (N.J.) High School, opened their own school last year with six sixth-grade pupils and said they doubted they would make enough to get a salary.

title: ROMANCING THE SHRINK
description: THE PRINCE OF TIDES By Pat Conroy. 567 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: BEDFORD FARMER'S CLUB AT 134 FORECASTS A BRIGHT FUTURE
description: ONE hundred years ago, 34 years after the Bedford Farmer's Club was formed, John B. Day, the club's secretary, made the following entry for the September 1886 meeting: ''The club has now arrived at years of discretion, is in good health, with promise of long life, and in future years its posterity should be able to know the names of its ancestors.''

title: The Big Name Game
description: The nation seems to value the signatures of its Presidents on a mysterious scale, with prices sometimes reflecting their roles in history, sometimes not. Waverly Auctions in Bethesda, Md., has about 250 autographs and manuscripts coming up for auction Saturday, including Presidential items ranging from Thomas Jefferson to Ronald Reagan, but their estimated prices do not seem to follow any discernible pattern.

title: Korean Chests for Collectors
description: Simple, sturdy wooden chests are South Korea's contribution to the history of furniture and are as important in homes there as bookcases and breakfronts are in the United States. The shapes and decoration of these chests have remained largely unchanged for centuries.

title: THERE WAS A STORY ABOUT MY MOTHER AND FATHER
description: MY mother and father are the guests of my wife and me in an ornate restaurant in Briarcliff Manor. We want the experience to be special because they have been married for 50 years. They are agitated and distressed, however, by the prices on the menu. They tell the waiter who rolls the pastry cart over that for the cost of the slender pieces of cake he is offering, they expect to take the rest of the cake home.

title: SUFFOLK OTB REVENUE QUERIED
description: THE Suffolk County Comptroller's office is looking into the Suffolk Offtrack Betting Corporation to determine whether a full-scale audit should be conducted as a result of a steep decline in revenues paid to the county.

title: PILOT PROJECT TRIES TO MATCH THE RETARDED WITH JOBS
description: A TECHNIQUE being studied here may enable some mentally retarded people previously thought incapable of functioning outside a sheltered workshop or day program to hold nonsubsidized jobs.

title: Emily Cooperman Becomes a Bride
description: Emily Tyson Cooperman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harris Lee Cooperman of Baltimore and Easton, Md., was married yesterday to John Louis Jernigan 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Jernigan of Atlantic City. The Quaker ceremony was performed at the Third Haven Friends Meeting in Easton.

title: BETTER THAN PLEASURE
description: REDISCOVERING LOVE By Willard Gaylin. 288 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: NO. 5 IS NO. 1 FOR CHINESE CUISINE
description: HOMERS ORIENTAL, No. 5 in the series of restaurants owned by the peripatetic Homer Lee, recently made its debut in Syosset. Not only is it the best of the Homers, but also it is one of the most innovative Chinese restaurants to have opened on Long Island.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
The Marks Left, by Runners and on Runners
description: ON the North Shore of Long Island, overlooking Long Island Sound, there is a state park known for its panoramic beachfront, lush picnic areas and wooded hiking trails.

title: NORWALK TO LAUNCH ITS MARITIME CENTER
description: IT was an overcast, fall morning along the Norwalk River. The din from Interstate 95 mingled with the intermittent zing of a fishing line.

title: Waterfall in White Plains
description: The opulence of city condominiums is making its way into the suburbs. One example is Stewart Place, an 11-story condominium residence now rising in White Plains.

title: Nancy Havilande Bayard-Brown Wed To James H. Whitcomb Jr. in Houston
description: Nancy Havilande Bayard-Brown, a daughter of William Oliver Brown and Nancy Lois Bayard, both of Houston, was married there yesterday to James Howard Whitcomb Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitcomb of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Laurens Hall performed the ceremony at St. John the Divine Episcopal Church.

title: Q AND A
description: Scottish Isles Question:Where may I obtain information on cruises next year among the Scottish islands? -C. B. S., New York Answer:One or two of the large cruise liners include some of the islands of Scotland on their itineraries each summer, but for regular service the traveler must turn to the car and passenger ferries that also offer overnight accommodations. The only company, according to the British Tourist Authority, that runs regular cruises of this kind is Caledonian MacBrayne (Ferry Terminal, Gourock, Strathclyde PA19 1QP, Scotland; telephone, Gourock 33755). Caledonian MacBrayne is represented in this country by Tourpak (106 Calvert Street, Harrison, N.Y. 10528; 914-835-5454 or 800-468-0468).

title: SURPLUS FOOD PLAN'S ILLS SLOW DELIVERY TO NEEDY
description: Two summers ago in Idaho a van delivering Federal surplus butter for distribution to the needy was stalled by road construction. The butter soon melted and oozed out of the van.

title: Weinberger, in India, Sees Gandhi on Arms
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger arrived in India today, and after an initial meeting with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi held out the prospect of eventual production here of weapons designed in America.

title: AT SHOPPING MALL, A MARATHON OF MUSIC
description: ATTENTION bagpipers! Jug bands! Fifers and drummers! And people who love to hear their music, of course. Orchestra New England's second Music Marathon is tomorrow at Chapel Square in New Haven.

title: STATE'S HIKING TRAILS LOSING GROUND TO RAPID DEVELOPMENT
description: WITH the coming of crisp weather and bright foliage, Connecticut's hiking trails are especially popular. But those who maintain the state's 500-mile trail system - the second largest in New England after New Hampshire's - say development is encroaching on the trails, and motorcycles and other vehicles are tearing them up.

title: THE LEVEES FAIL
description: WHERE two great rivers join - rivers that, apart, had broken levees and birthed lakes last week - there is once again high water in streets and fields.

title: IN THE ARMY, IF IT'S A BAYONET, IT'S A KNIFE, A SAW AND SCISSORS
description: Army officials wanted a better bayonet for their combat forces, so they found one that resembled a hunting knife and could be used as a saw or converted to scissors to cut wire. It also had to be insulated against electric shock.

title: STUDYING MYSTERIES OF MYOCARDITIS
description: MYOCARDITIS, an inflammation of the heart, is a disease for which doctors have more questions than answers. It is difficult to diagnose and treat effectively, and they suspect it might be a cause of as much 90 percent of all heart muscle disease, including congestive heart failure, that is not readily explained by any other cause. But they simply do not have enough facts available to know much for certain about the illness.

title: THE LAVI FIGHTER: ANOTHER VIEW
description: The recent article [ Opinion Page, Sept. 14 ] by pro-Israel lobbyists extolling the value of the Lavi fighter program to the Long Island economy obscures several points.

title: TOWARD ERROR-FREE SPREADSHEETS
description: SPREADSHEETS have been with us long enough now so that some of their initial glamour, as well as our excitement over them, has worn off. This does not mean that their use has lessened. Quite to the contrary, for many they have become a staple of personal computing, an accepted component of the office routine. There are some, in truth, who could no longer conceive of doing their job without shuffling a cursor back and forth across one of these phosphorescent grids.

title: Soviet Nuclear Submarine Sinks In Atlantic
description: A Soviet nuclear submarine sank last week in the Atlantic Ocean, about 1,200 miles east of New York, three days after an explosion on board had killed three crewmen.

title: Servas
description: To the Editor: In the Aug. 17 Q & A column there was a question about how to arrange a home stay in West Germany. A more direct way, not involving being part of a group visit, is through the organization called Servas.

title: DATING SERVICE IS FORMED ON L.I. FOR HERPES SUFFERERS
description: LENNY SOBEL got herpes while dating. But in one way he has turned misfortune to advantage. Now he helps others with the disease find dates.

title: Zaccaro Charged, Ferraro Carries On
description: It was John Zaccaro's indictment, but Geraldine Ferraro did most of the talking. ''If I had not run,'' she told reporters last week after the indictment had just been unsealed, ''John Zaccaro would have been John Zaccaro, real estate broker. He would not have been John Zaccaro, center of national attention, husband of Geraldine Ferraro, who ran for Vice President.''

title: AFTER A VOTE TO CONVICT QUALMS IN THE SENATE
description: THE Senate put on judicial robes last week and found, to its surprise, that the fit was not completely comfortable.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Joe's got a soft spot in his heart for Bank of America. He'd like to be the guy on the white charger who saves it.'' G. Robert Truex, chairman, Rainier Bancorp, on bid by Joseph J. Pinola for BankAmerica.

title: DO SMALL CONDOS FIT NEW LIFE STYLES?
description: TODAY'S condominium apartments are notably smaller and more expensive than the apartments produced before World War II. They even have shrunk from the stingy dimensions of a decade ago, but developers insist that they are more efficient and better suited to today's life styles.

title: Marble Mountains
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed A. Alvarez's excellent coverage of the Marble Mountains of the Garfagnana (Travel, Sept. 7). For me, no trip to Italy is complete without visiting my favorite town in that region, Pietrasanta, just south of Seravezza. Pietrasanta, literally holy stone, takes its name and still derives its identity and livelihood from the marble in the mountains that surround it.

title: Nancy Ellen Love Becomes the Bride Of Kenneth Weith
description: Nancy Ellen Love, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Love of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Kenneth Brownlee Weith, a son of Marjorie Weith Capen of Deer Isle, Me., and the late Dr. Archie James Weith Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Howley at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: COSTUME DESIGNER THREADS HER WAY THROUGH HISTORY
description: WHEN Robert Burke in the title role of ''Tartuffe,'' the Moliere farce that is to open the Long Island Stage's 12th season Tuesday night, rips off his ''clerical'' collar just before a seduction scene, it will not be an idle theatrical gesture.

title: P. R. Haley Wed To Miss Holmes
description: Jacqueline Suzanne Holmes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Holmes of Tequesta, Fla., and Grantham, N.H., was married yesterday to Paul Richard Haley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Haley of Weymouth, Mass. The Rev. John MacInnis performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: BATTLE OF THE YELLOW PAGES DIRECTORIES
description: THE fingers stalking the yellow pages these days are looking for green in the $6.8 billion a year telephone directory industry. The latest chapter in the breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company deals with the war of the yellow pages that finds the regional Bell publishers invading each others' turf.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Consumer spending, which has played a major role in bolstering the economy, grew by more than 4.5 percent in 1983 and 1984 before dropping to about 3.5 percent in 1985. And this year, predicts Morris Cohen of Morris Cohen & Associates in Hackensack, N.J., real consumer spending growth should reach 4 percent.

title: Icahn Becoming a Force in Home-Building
description: A REAL-ESTATE company dominated by Carl Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines and a powerful figure in corporate takeovers, has bought 471 acres in northern Westchester and plans to build at least 180 high-priced single-family houses in the next five years.

title: SPLIT ON DOCKS WORSENS HARD TIMES
description: Bargaining has resumed after a 45-day extension ended the first widespread East Coast dock strike in 15 years. But behind the labor battle of the moment are profound problems that that have left a once-vigorous industry in its worst condition in decades, according to industry experts.

title: EARLY TWAIN SATIRE STAGED IN HARTFORD
description: WITH ''The Gilded Age,''

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SCHOOL PIONEER HONORED The little red one-room schoolhouse that Americans regard with such nostalgia was, according to the Connecticut Historical Society, ''a hovel characterized by poor lighting, heat and ventilation. As a place to get a good basic education it was a dismal failure.''

title: PIONEERING WINERIES WEST OF THE CASCADES
description: Seattle holds the promise of fresh breezes and mild, crisp weather, especially in autumn. Autumn also brings Washington's grape harvest, the best time of year to visit the state's wineries. Several are within the Seattle city limits or within an hour's drive.

title: The Twains Meet
description: AMERICA IS MORE A ratatouille than a melting pot. Like the ingredients in the classic French vegetable stew, the myriad ethnic and racial components of the United States have retained much of their individuality while blending into and imparting their special characteristics to the flavor of the nation.

title: Masters of Early American Furniture
description: The American master craftsmen who carved the trumpet-legged, bonnet-topped and scroll-armed furniture that George M. and Linda H. Kaufman collect produced chairs, tables, chests and sideboards memorable for their bold forms, aristocratic proportions and sheer variety of detailing.

title: To Foil a Thief
description: To the Editor: As a follow-up to the thoughtful article by Roberto Suro, ''Streetwise Abroad'' (Travel, Aug. 24), I have a couple of further suggestions.

title: CONCERT: A TRIBUTE TO LOUISE TALMA
description: IN intermission conversation at the Louise Talma tribute in Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday, one member of the audience regretted that a compositional career dating back five decades should be represented only by works composed since 1973. In a way he had a point; the concert was not a balanced retrospective. On the other hand, not many composers about to turn 80 years old (Miss Talma's birthday comes on Oct. 31) can offer a substantial program in which every work is recent and the best of all are the newest. It was a pleasure to encounter so much lucid music for the first time, and to realize that its author is still busy making more.

title: OUT OF THE MIDDLE EAST, COMES CONVENIENT BULGUR
description: BULGUR or cracked wheat is one of the most convenient of grains. It can be prepared without cooking. By soaking it in hot water or other liquid until it softens, you have the basis for the popular Middle Eastern salad called tabbouleh. The addition of cucumber, onion, tomato, lemon juice and abundant fresh mint are all it takes to make this nourishing as a salad, first course or side dish.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bedford Hills, N.Y. $208,000 458 Bedford Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; sun deck, library, family room, gazebo; taxes $3,246. Eastchester, N.Y. $239,500 10 Myrtle Place 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, walk to station and stores; taxes $2,805.

title: Kellyann Murphy Wed to J. Y. Jones
description: The wedding of Kellyann Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Murphy of Old Brookville, L.I., to Joseph Yaeger Jones, a son of Henry A. Jones of Chicago and Margaret Y. Jones of Milwaukee, took place yesterday. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at Old St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Milwaukee, assisted by the Rev. Dr. John P. Raynor, president of Marquette University.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: 'Mentally Ill' And Bound to Die

title: Palmer Runs For 349 Yards
description: Paul Palmer, Temple's senior tailback, rushed for a school-record 349 yards and 3 touchdowns today to help defeat East Carolina (0-6), 45-28, and extend the longest Division I-AA losing streak to 15 games.

title: The Right Age at the Right Time
description: YOUR PLANE'S NOT UNTIL 6,'' my friend said. ''I'm going to buy you lunch - anywhere you like.'' She said it with a fine smile. ''Le Cirque,'' I suggested, dueling with her generosity by naming the most expensive place I could think of near my last errands. She's hard to faze.

title: FAIRFIELD ARTIST GIVES SUPERMAN A MORE HUMAN SIDE
description: THE red cape and the bold ''S'' are still there, as are Lois Lane, The Daily Planet, Metropolis and ''the pursuit of truth, justice and the American way.'' But the new comic-book series of Superman has some surprises for fans of the superhero.

title: Assessing Mario Cuomo
description: Each time I read an article about Mario Cuomo, I'm struck by how intimate an examination of his personality the press is able to give.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bernardsville $389,000 118 Seney Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, oak floors, modern eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,123. Chatham $310,000 135 Watchung Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 68-year-old Tudor; deck, two fireplaces, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,896.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Aurora, Ill.; Farm Country's Growing Pains
description: THE forces of expansion in Du Page County along the Interstate 5 high-tech corridor west of Chicago not only have made it the fastest-growing county outside the Sun Belt, but also have strained relations between neighboring communities with opposing attitudes toward new development.

title: UNDERGROUND WITH MIRRORS AND MERMAIDS
description: FROM THE REALM OF MORPHEUS By Steven Millhauser. 370 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Cathleen A. Asch Wed To Jan Christian Goss
description: Cathleen Ann Asch, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Jacob Asch of Greenwich, Conn., became the bride yesterday of Jan Christian Goss, the son of Mrs. Joseph Robert Goss of Martinsville, Ind., and the late Mr. Goss. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at St. Bede's Chapel in Greenwich.

title: Replying to Ackoff
description: To the Editor:

title: Camper's Choices Down Under
description: Travelers who want to camp their way around Australia have two choices: they can take a guided tour or strike out on their own. Either way, visitors should be aware of the distances they expect to cover; the brochure published by AAT King's, one company that runs escorted camping tours by bus, points out, for example, that the distance by road from Perth to Sydney is about 2,500 miles -an average of some 280 miles a day on a nine-day tour.

title: BUILDING A CASE FOR THE HOUSING INDUSTRY
description: THE housing industry's outlook may not be as bleak as the sharp drop in new-home sales in August suggests, according to a leading analyst. Barbara Allen at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. recently raised her rating of five favorite issues, arguing that the summer numbers were misleading - reflecting not slack demand but short supplies after the booming sales builders rang up earlier in the year. ''My companies are working against backlogs that stretch out six or eight months and don't want to take new orders because of their cost exposure,'' Ms. Allen said.

title: CONGRESS IS NEAR ACCORD ON ALIENS
description: House and Senate negotiators made progress today on resolving their differences over a comprehensive immigration bill, but a Reagan Administration official expressed ''very serious objections'' to a key portion of the bill relating to foreign agricultural workers.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE MAKING OF A NOBEL PRIZE WINNER;
ON THE PROWL IN AN 'ENCHANTED FOREST'
description: Next week, when the Nobel Committee is scheduled to award the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, one of the world's great economists will be wrested from the ivory tower and vaulted into instant but not necessarily lasting fame. The economist will have a few hours of intense media attention. But months or even years later, when the true significance of the Nobel moment has finally sunken in, the spotlight will have moved on.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A WEATHERED gray barn against a backdrop of russet leaves. The white clapboard church next to the tombstones of a tiny cemetery. The sun rising on Croton Reservoir. These are some images of Somers that one of its residents, Steven Peltz, holds dear. Mr. Peltz, a financial consultant and photographer, loves the town's rural mood, the way it suggests a ''simpler time when people knew what was good.'' He loves Somers so much, in fact, he wants others to capture it on film, before the onslaught of development strips it of its small-town quality.

title: Charles Pevsner And Ms. Juneja Exchange Vows
description: Vinita M. Juneja, an analyst for National Economic Research Associates in White Plains, and Charles Dean Pevsner, a computer scientist with Trintex in White Plains, were married yesterday in a Sikh ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains. Giani Gurdip Singh, a Sikh priest, officiated.

title: Longshoremen's Strike Is Seen as Deadlocked
description: Union longshoremen and steamship companies here appeared to be drifting further apart today in a two-day-old strike that could cost the New Orleans economy $3 million a week.

title: Student With AIDS Allowed To Attend Connecticut School
description: A pupil at a public elementary school has become the first child with acquired immune deficiency syndrome to be allowed to continue attending regular classes in Connecticut, according to state education officials.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THIS weekend we honor the memory of Christopher Columbus and the spirit of exploration. But not all discoveries involve many men, many ships and much money. Not all discoveries make the history books.

title: DEMOCRATS' ODDS ON TAKING SENATE SEEM ABOUT EVEN
description: With about three weeks left in the 1986 political campaign, the Democrats seem sure to gain ground in the Senate, but they appear to have only slightly better than an even chance to regain control.

title: BELAGA AND THE GENDER FACTOR
description: IF you know that Julie D. Belaga is the first Republican woman to run for Governor, it is probably not because she told you. Mrs. Belaga does not talk much about being a woman. Governor O'Neill, the Democratic incumbent, challenges her politics, not her gender.

title: Washington State Upsets U.S.C., 34-14
description: Washington State took advantage of five turnovers today to upset Southern Cal, 34-14, as Ed Blount passed for two touchdowns and ran for two more.

title: Repairs on Rte. 495 Cause Traffic Delays
description: Continuing repairs on Route 495, the main New Jersey route to the Lincoln Tunnel, generated tie-ups and lengthy delays for motorists yesterday in the vicinity of the tunnel and at the George Washington Bridge and the Holland Tunnel, where traffic was diverted.

title: Expanding City's Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Test Challenge
description: Next to accepting a campaign contribution from Jane Fonda, it seems, about the most controversial thing a politician can do these days is to refuse his opponent's challenge to take a drug test.

title: THE READERS ASK: ANSWERS TO COMMON REPAIR PROBLEMS
description: IN an effort to catch up on the backlog of mail, this week's Home Clinic is devoted to questions from readers about common home repair and maintenance problems.

title: Jay Bailey Is the Bride Of Christopher Hynes
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Concord, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jean Bodell Bailey to Christopher Alden Hynes. The Rev. David M. Barney performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Early Weds W. H. von Oehsen 3d
description: Christ Church in Cambridge, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Nancy Davis Early and William Henry von Oehsen 3d, graduates of the Harvard Divinity School. The Rev. G. Stewart Barns, the Episcopal chaplain at Harvard and Radcliffe Colleges, performed the ceremony.

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: Westchester; Hastings Surge Beats Millbrook
description: Things were not looking good for Hastings this season. It scored only 14 points while losing the first three games of the season. But the Yellowjackets finally turned things around yesterday, scoring five touchdowns while overpowering Millbrook, 41-0.

title: Regional Job Roundup: New England
description: A CONTINUING high-technology boom, a flood of military contracts and a generally strong economy have combined to make employment in many areas of New England a problem only from the perspective of the employer.

title: A RUSTIC ALTERNATIVE FOR VISITORS TO TUSCANY
description: Perched high atop a Tuscan hillside covered with wavy, seemingly endless rows of Sangiovese grapevines lies possibly one of the most idyllic retreats in Italy. Called Fattoria La Loggia, it is a 15th-century working farm complete with an ivy-covered villa built in 1427 and a cluster of umber-colored guest cottages connected by narrow stone pathways that wend their way around the property.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Rain Forest's Ancient Library
description: In a patch of Borneo rain forest, botanists have identified 700 different species of tree, as many as exist in all of North America. A single tree by the Tambopata River in Peru is home to 43 species of ant, as many as in all the British Isles. But the riotous diversity of the world's tropical rain forests may not last much longer. At a conference in Washington last month, tropical biologists agreed that species are being lost faster than they can be catalogued.

title: Minors Must Be Free to Opt for Contraceptives
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah E. Beach Weds D. A. Porro
description: At the First Church of Christ in West Hartford, Conn., yesterday Miss Deborah Evelyn Beach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morrison H. Beach of West Hartford and Quechee, Vt., was married to David Alexander Porro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Porro of Longmeadow, Mass. The Revs.

title: RAISA GORBACHEV'S REYJKAVIK VISIT: A PUBLIC RELATIONS COUP FOR MOSCOW
description: Raisa M. Gorbachev shrugged in her silver fox coat when she was asked if she was sorry Nancy Reagan had not come north.

title: 3 SCHOOLS MOVE IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS
description: The three private high schools in the Riverdale section of the Bronx turn out Ivy League students faster than they do Division I athletes. Yet Horace Mann, Fieldston and Riverdale Country School have managed to field competitive - and sometimes powerful - football teams since the turn of the century. That is, until now. At Horace Mann, varsity football was dropped this year. And although the school retained the junior varsity program in hope that the varsity team may someday be revived, student interest in playing football has waned considerably. Only 17 candidates showed up for the preseason team meeting.

title: Maria E. Garlatti Wed To Robert C. Harrison
description: Maria Emilia Garlatti, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert S. Garlatti of Highland Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Charles Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Harrison of Iselin, N.J. The Rev. Immanuel W. Vernon performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Paul the Apostle Church in Highland Park.

title: Next Week; How Can Football Improve TV Replays?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Morris, Despite His Credentials, Likely To Stay With Tigers
description: Can anybody here use Jack Morris?

title: THE LOOK: IT COULD FREEZE YOUR BLOOD
description: ONE of my biggest mistakes in life was not teaching my children about The Look. It distresses me to think of what happened to The Look and the havoc it wreaked. When I was young, children used to be paralyzed by it. The Look could be seen from across the room. It penetrated noise, people, space, personal desire and happiness. The Look could have a variety of meanings. Sometimes it would mean stop and other times go ahead. It could mean yes, no, don't you dare, or don't touch. And, when ignored, it usually resulted in a martyred victim. Like the time The Look from my mother made me give up the last brownie to my worst cousin.

title: REAGAN SIGNS STOPGAP FUND BILL, AVERTING A GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN
description: President Reagan today signed a stopgap bill to finance Federal operations for five days, reversing the Administration's announced intention and averting a shutdown of the Government.

title: MAKING A SCIENCE OF GETTING LAUGHS
description: When the English comedy star Rowan Atkinson makes his American debut at the Brooks Atkinson Theater Tuesday, it will be the second Broadway production within 10 weeks overseen by the director Mike Ockrent. The two shows offer a dramatic contrast - this week's opening, ''Rowan Atkinson at the Atkinson,'' is essentially a one-man vehicle while Mr. Ockrent's other Broadway show, the hit British musical comedy ''Me and My Girl,'' boasts a company of 40 who turn English drawing-room elegance into a Busby Berkeley fantasy.

title: PAINTER OF WILDLIFE TO OPEN LECTURE SERIES
description: THE common ingredient in this fall's lecture and film series at the Washington Art Association is painting, but there any similarities end.

title: The Land Is Our Land
description: I was standing in a field of wildflowers on Beavertail Point at the entrance to Rhode Island's Narragansett Bay. The sun was sparkling on the water and, just offshore, terns were diving above a school of bluefish. A car with out-of-state plates pulled into the parking lot behind me. A couple got out, walked over and after only a few minutes of small talk the man said: ''You know, it's beautiful here. Is any of this land for sale?'' I replied, ''This is a state park.'' But I knew they wouldn't give up, because up the road, across the bay and all along the New England coast the land is for sale and somewhere they would find a piece of a farm, beach or bluff to buy, build on and make their own.

title: FIRST CREW HELPS REFIT A B-17 FOR HER LAST MISSION
description: As George Bogert looked into the cramped ball-turret gun compartment at the mannequin in the leather flight jacket and goggles, memories rushed back over more than 40 years.

title: Paging 'Kenneth'
description: It certainly didn't seem like the sort of thing that would have happened to Walter Cronkite. But last week, police in New York City were trying to figure out who beat up CBS News anchorman Dan Rather and why. Mr. Rather was walking home along Park Avenue after an evening at a friend's home last weekend when he was accosted by two men who punched and kicked him while repeatedly demanding, ''Kenneth, what is the frequency?'' Mr. Rather, who was treated for back and jaw injuries, praised a building superintendent who came to his aid, but did not discuss possible motives for the assault. A spokesman for CBS said it was presumed to be mistaken identity - Mr. Rather was casually dressed and wearing eyeglasses at the time.

title: A PRESIDENT'S RESIGNATION
description: DAVID T. McLAUGHLIN, who has led Dartmouth College for five bumpy years, announced Monday that he will resign at the end of the academic year. With a fund-raising drive looming that would require continuity of leadership, Mr. McLaughlin said he was not prepared ''to commit, irrevocably, 10 or more additional years to the presidency.''

title: 11 Die in Indian Bus Crash
description: A bus swerved off the road into a ditch in the northern Punjab today, killing 11 people and injuring more than 20, the United News of India reported. The accident occurred in the village of Dhar Kalan, near the border with Pakistan, the agency said.

title: COLUMBUS DAY PARADE: SMALLER BUT STILL LIVELY
description: Boy Scouts and Brownies, politicians and policemen, gymnasts and marching bands joined hundreds of other people yesterday in marching up Fifth Avenue under cool, cloudy skies to observe Columbus Day and to celebrate New York City's considerable Italian heritage.

title: Sooners, Behind Collins, Trounce Texas
description: Standing outside the locker room, talking above the sound of the Oklahoma band as it marched out of the Cotton Bowl and the mocking chants of several Sooner fans shouting, ''Keep Fred, keep Fred,'' Fred Akers made a concession speech he had avoided for nine previous years.

title: RUSSIAN SUSPECTS UNFAMILIAR AT U.N.
description: The Soviet diplomats ordered expelled by the United States who are still in New York are generally unknown to fellow diplomats and United Nations officials.

title: 'CORE' ADVISERS, 3 OR 4 ON EACH SIDE STAY CLOSE TO REAGAN AND GORBACHEV
description: When President Reagan arrived at Hofdi House this morning for his first meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he was accompanied in the back of his bullet-proof limousine by his Big Three advisers - Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Donald T. Regan.

title: STUDENTS VOLUNTEER IN HOMELESS FIGHT
description: ROSARIA CAPPA, a senior at Westlake High School in Thornwood, ran a clothing drive for the homeless at her school last year. Her interest started, she said, when she saw an item posted on her social-studies class bulletin board about County Legislator Paul J. Feiner's plans for a committee to work with the homeless.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WORDS ABOVE A DOORWAY: SYMBOL OF A COMMUNITY'S VALUES
description: I WAS a true stranger to northern New Jersey when I first drove to the township of Essex Fells to be interviewed for the position of Superintendent of Schools.

title: Raising The Flag
description: BANNERS DEPICTING A RED-striped map of the United States herald ''Furnish America'' and ''Accessorize America,'' the theme of this fall's Southern Furniture Market, which opens Thursday in High Point, N.C., and runs through Oct. 24. The reason for the patriotic celebration, according to Robert P. Gruenberg, the market's general manager, is that High Point is the largest marketplace for wholesale furniture in this country, attracting more manufacturers than any other show in the industry. ''If it's not here, you probably can't find it anywhere,'' Mr. Gruenberg says in referring to the wide range of exhibitors who come to this semiannual event.

title: THE GAME OF LIFE, PLAYED BY COMPUTER
description: The bully egged you on all week. You agree to fight after school. All the kids show up to watch. Shoves turn to punches. You can hit him in the stomach or the face. You choose the face. He recoils but rips out a knife. Everyone falls silent. Instead of running, you swing at him and miss, fall and feel a jolt in your chest as he knifes you. You are dead at 13. OR: You decide to hit him in the stomach. He starts crying and runs away. OR: You belt his face. He whips out a knife. The child falls silent. You swing again, miss, fall and look up to see a teacher grab his arm. You get suspended. He is sent to another school. OR: You don't show up after school. No fight.

title: Mother Teresa Unhurt In Tanzania Air Crash
description: Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize winner in 1979, escaped unhurt today from an air crash in which her small plane killed six people at a dusty airstrip in rural Tanzania.

title: THE WILD BLUE DRAWING BOARDS
description: Why would anyone but the most insatiable aeronautics buff want another photo-and-text history of human flight? Walter J. Boyne, in THE LEADING EDGE (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95), has anticipated that query and approached his task from an unusual perspective. The author focuses not on those famed for their piloting or on the captains of industry, but on the inventors whose ideas cut past apparent limits to extend the airplane's capabilities.

title: Assessing Mario Cuomo
description: On one hand, Mario Cuomo espouses the idea that partisanship and ideology should play no part in the selection of Supreme Court judges.

title: Evolution: The Hypothesis That Ranks as Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: Townsend to Play
description: THE NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE reversed its field yesterday and temporarily rescinded the one-game suspension of Greg Townsend, a defensive end for the Los Angeles Raiders, allowing Townsend to play against the Seattle Seahawks today. Townsend and the Raiders appealed the ruling Friday, after it was announced on Wednesday.

title: Dykstra 'Nails' Astros
description: LEN DYKSTRA hit eight home runs for the Mets during the regular season.

title: Carol Fisler Has Wedding
description: Carol Diane Fisler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Fisler of Palatine, Ill., and Lawrence M. Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Martin of Flushing, Queens, were married yesterday at the Picnic House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Acting Justice Anne G. Feldman of the Supreme Court of New York performed the ceremony.

title: The Common Speaker
description: To the Editor:

title: Vital Reading Material: 'Schools Without Drugs'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Cassettes: Big Stars and Big Bands
description: The Big Bands: Vol. 105 Featuring Jimmy Dorsey, Red Nichols, Bunny Berigan, Ina Ray Hutton Kartes Video Communications 50 minutes. $19.95

title: Regional Job Roundup: Mountain
description: DESPITE the resolutely bright skies and golden aspens that mark autumn in the Rocky Mountain West, the region's forecast for jobs remains gloomy. The continuing decline in employment opportunity is largely a result of low demand for energy-related resources, particularly oil and natural gas. Although lower oil prices have led to an increase in tourism, not even travel-related employment in the Rockies seems to be approaching expectations.

title: Diane Marie Kelly Is Wed To Christopher M. LaSalle
description: Diane Marie Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kelly of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Saltaire, Fire Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Michael LaSalle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry LaSalle of Jupiter, Fla. The Rev. Damian O'Connell performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: MISS ANDERSON A JERSEY BRIDE
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Anderson to Amory Fletcher Haight took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. Robert Bell performed the ceremony. Karen Anderson was maid of honor for her sister.

title:
THE NEW TAX BILL;
Legislative Mills Stir Up Lobbying
description: THIS has been a year of the lobbyists, whose work and influence in the nation's legislative corridors has been highlighted most notably in recent accounts of Congressional jousting over tax revision.

title: Rail Journeys in Europe, Contemporary Art in California
description: Taking a Train Around the City Of Luxembourg

title: 7 FORMER OFFICERS ON TRIAL IN MIAMI
description: Seven former members of the Miami Police Department have gone on trial here, accused of possession of cocaine and racketeering and of involvement in a case in which three suspects in a narcotics case drowned.

title: Bed & Breakfast
description: To the Editor: My wife and I, on a tour of England by the bed-and-breakfast route, discovered a brochure called Guestaccom that lists some of those pleasant conveniences throughout Britain. As it may not be generally known, we would like to recommend it to you.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MOHAWK. By Richard Russo. (Vintage Contemporaries, Paper, $6.95.) This first novel describes life in Mohawk, a small town in upstate New York, where the leather tanneries are failing, the local waters have been poisoned by years of chemical dumping, and the people endure lives of quiet desperation occasionally leavened by humor.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED IN SUBURBIA (ACT II)
description: When the People's Light and Theater Company opened a new $800,000 second stage and office complex on its manicured, 7.5-acre estate here last month, it presented a challenge to the common notion that the suburbs are a cultural wasteland, unable and unwilling to support serious art endeavors.

title: IRAN REPORTS DESTROYING IRAQI REFINERY
description: The official Iranian press agency said today that Iranian commandos, linking up with Kurdish rebels, had destroyed a major Iraqi oil installation in a raid deep into Iraqi territory.

title: Keeping the Defense on Track
description: In the 56 years since international competition began there have been a handful of moments of maximum drama savored by a large audience. It is the final crunch in a long match and the score is virtually tied. The spectators sit on the edge of their seats staring suspensefully at the Vugraph - in the old days the Bridgerama - knowing that a world title is about to be won and lost.

title: Black U.S. Envoy Going to Pretoria
description: For months, the Reagan Administration has wanted to send a black to South Africa as the new American ambassador. The Administration's original choice was Robert J. Brown, a businessman who withdrew after questions arose about his business dealings.

title: FLOYD RETURNS TO TV, BUT FANS ARE IRKED
description: UNCLE FLOYD fans across the state are delighted that the irreverent comic has been given a new lease on televised life, but many are indignant about what the head of a fan club called Trenton's ''political inability to laugh at themselves and the environment that they've created.''

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Housing at Monastery Raises Questions
description: NESTLED within the heart of Union City lies St. Michael's Passionist Monastery, which closed its doors in 1981 after serving the spiritual needs of local residents for more than a century. Since then, the fate of the old church, its adjacent seminary buildings and the 12.3 acres of open space surrounding them has been the subject of bitter discord in this densely populated community.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Orange County, Calif.; A Vast Ranch Yields Homes
description: RANCHO SANTA MARGARITA, which someday may be one of California's largest master-planned communities, is rising against the backdrop of the majestic Saddleback Mountains in Southern California on lands that once were used to raise citrus fruit.

title: BADILLO'S RUN HIGHLIGHTS LACK OF HISPANIC GAINS
description: HERMAN Badillo came to the United States from Puerto Rico at the age of 11. He worked his way through City College and Brooklyn Law School and got into politics by offering free legal services to the Caribe Democratic Club, Third Avenue and 114th Street. He was the first Puerto Rican to become a New York City commissioner - Mayor Robert F. Wagner named him to head the housing relocation office when he was 33 - and he made local political history again when he challenged the Bronx Democratic machine and became the city's first Puerto Rican borough president in 1965. By the mid-1970's Puerto Ricans held 10 city and state posts and Mr. Badillo was in his third term as a United States Congressman.

title: Christopher Hilbert Is Wed To Claudia Maria Abruzzo
description: Claudia Maria Abruzzo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Abruzzo of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Christopher Hilbert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hilbert of Haddonfield, N.J. Msgr. James M. Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine on Oct. 5, omitted credit for the cover illustration. The artist was Semyon Bilmes.

title: AN INNOVATOR GETS DOWN TO BUSINESS
description: IN one corner of the 3M Company's busy home products laboratory, an engineer is dunking hiking boots in water to measure the efficacy of 3M's new Scotchgard leather protector. Nearby a lab technician hunches over a machine that scrapes a new type of Scotchbrite pad back and forth over a frying pan encrusted with burnt food. And across the lab, Jen Jorgensen, a chemist, describes how he perfected an adhesive that will hold plastic film insulation onto the outside of windows through a blustery Minnesota winter.

title: Hempstead Tops Farmingdale
description: The Hempstead Tigers' last defeat in Nassau County action came on opening day two seasons ago, when Farmingdale defeated them, 3-0, on a last-minute field goal. By the end of yesterday's tense, bruising reunion of the two top teams in Conference I, the Tigers won, 8-7.

title: Grace Chapin Has Wedding
