description: Grace Selden Chapin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic L. Chapin of Washington, was married yesterday to Thomas Charles Ruska, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Ruska of Peachtree City, Ga. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: Knicks Lose to Rockets
description: If success is to be measured by their ability to leave the floor unscathed, then the Knicks succeeded tonight in their preseason debut. The only casualty in their 102-92 loss to the Houston Rockets was Pat Cummings, the forward-center, who suffered a cut under his chin in the first half that required six stitches.

title: Devils Rally to Defeat Bruins
description: Greg Adams, who led the Devils in scoring last season with 35 goals, scored two goals 54 seconds apart tonight in leading the Devils to a 5-4 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: GIFTED CHILDREN NEED BETTER SCHOOLING
description: IF New Jersey wants to become one of the leading high-tech states it will have to do better by its most able or gifted students. A ''thorough and efficient'' education, so clearly expressed in our State Constitution, does not challenge our best students. Indeed, a 1984 study by the Council for Exceptional Children placed New Jersey 47th in state expenditures for its gifted pupils.

title: WINDS OF CHANGE STIR SOVIET FILM
description: The scene: four men sit in an unheated room around a table covered with notes, planning ways to get official watchdogs off the back of Soviet film.

title: LINES ARE DRAWN IN OREGON BATTLE ON MARIJUANA REFERENDUM
description: While polling indicates that it will probably lose, a strong campaign is being waged here to liberalize Oregon's marijuana laws through a statewide vote in the election next month.

title: Jeanne M. O'Neil Marries Peter Garneau Henriques
description: Jeanne Marie O'Neil was married yesterday to Peter Garneau Henriques at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, Mass. The Rev. Frederick Radtke performed the ceremony.

title: FRANK E. O'NEAL
description: Frank E. O'Neal, former cartoonist for the comic strip ''Short Ribs,'' which appeared in more than 800 newspapers, died Friday at the age of 64.

title:
OCCUPATIONAL OUTLOOKS;
New Surge in Demand For Language Skills
description: GABE BOKOR, a chemical engineer born in Hungary and raised in Brazil, sits in his office on Main Street in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., electronically transmitting to West Germany a contract he has translated for a high-technology company. Twelve hundred miles away in a quiet suburb of Minneapolis, Charles Brown oversees the final production of a Spanish edition of an American textbook reading series. At a multinational corporation in Albuquerque, Patricia Newman is at work translating engineering documents.

title: Running to Daylight
description: THE MOST COVETED invitation on a Sunday in Washington is to the Lombardi Room, behind the owner's box at Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium, where pols, power brokers and media biggies munch hot dogs - nobody calls them ''tube steaks'' there - and speculate on the fortunes of Jack Kent Cooke's Redskins. (No thought is being given to changing the name to Native Americans.) The owner Cooke is a linguistic conservative; that is, he sticks to certain pronunciations, no matter how the accents of the rest of the world are changing.

title: KNIFE-WIELDING HOODS, UNSTABLE FEMME FATALE
description: STRAIGHT CUT By Madison Smartt Bell. 230 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95.

title: MORE FIXING AND LESS MOWING
description: IT'S easy to think sometimes that the people running this state have their priorities mixed up.

title: Elizabeth F. Taub Is Wed
description: Elizabeth France Taub, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Taub of Freeport, L.I., and Paris, was married yesterday to Richard Mark Breslow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Breslow of Framingham and East Falmouth, Mass. Rabbi Robert Summers performed the ceremony at The Ballroom at 24 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Breslow is administrative director of the New York law firm Dreyer & Traub. Mr. Breslow, a lawyer, is an associate at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: A SURGE IN LIBERAL ARTS AT STONY BROOK
description: INTEREST in the liberal arts is surging at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, reflecting a national trend toward more humanistic studies at the same time the materialistic ideology of the early 1980's seems to be waning, school officials say.

title: Regional Job Roundup: Southeast
description: THE ECONOMY of the Southeast continues to glow most brightly in its major cities -places like Tampa and Jacksonville, Fla., Charlotte, N.C., and Nashville. In Atlanta, a recent study by the Atlanta Regional Commission showed that the seven-county metropolitan area added 237,000 new jobs between 1980 and 1985, a rise of 27 percent.

title: Young Adult Suicides Linked to Drug Abuse
description: Most suicides by young adults, which have more than doubled in the United States since 1960, can be attributed primarily to drug and alcohol abuse, researchers say.

title: SEASON OPENERS OFFER WIDE CHOICES
description: THE season begins this week for several musical organizations across the state, with the offerings ranging from a dance treatment of a cantata to all-Beethoven concerts and homage to a pioneering composer.

title: Undefeated Bayside Shuts Out Clinton
description: Bayside (4-0) recorded its third consecutive shutout and did not allow a touchdown for the fourth consecutive game in its 13-0 shutout of Clinton (2-3) yesterday. The Commodores yielded a field goal in the first game of the Public Schools Athletic League season against Tottenville.

title: On A Stroll in Brooklyn, Long Skirts and Dresses
description: NEWS travels fast in Brooklyn, and today's late-breaking story on hemlines over there is that they are plunging, down to the ankle or at least the lower calf.

title: FUNDS EYED FOR FIRE UNIFORMS
description: LONG ISLAND'S volunteer firefighters are hoping that Governor Cuomo signs a bill that would provide funds for new, modern uniforms the fire departments must acquire by February.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
Paris: Self-Confident Clothes For Spring
description: PARIS IS OF TWO MINDS AS DE-signers prepare to premiere their ready-to-wear collections for spring. Given the recent incidents of random terrorist attacks, the mood is cautionary, resulting in new measures to reduce the usual congestion at the often chaotic presentations. But from a fashion point of view, the city seems totally self-confident.

title: Split in the Gun Lobby
description: The traditionally monolithic gun lobby, one of Washington's most powerful, is undergoing a siege of interservice rivalry.

title:
ART;
ITEMS FROM INDIAN RITUALS
description: THE current offering at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich is an ethnological show for people who usually stay away from such presentations. It is more concise: Everything is in one room-sized gallery and anteroom and every item has a short explanatory label intended to clearly define a context.

title: A New Wave of French Artists At The Guggenheim
description: The 1986 Exxon International Exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum starts with a serious handicap. To confirm this, just try inviting someone to ''an exhibition of new work by 10 younger French artists.'' You could hear them yawn through six feet of concrete.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO THE COURT SYSTEMS, U.S., FRANCE ARE BROTHERS, NOT TWINS
description: PRIME Minister Jacques Chirac has expressed concern that France may be heading toward ''government of the judges,'' with the Constitutional Council playing a dominant role similar to that of the Supreme Court in the United States.Of course, the American and

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Housing at Monastery Raises Questions
description: NESTLED within the heart of Union City lies St. Michael's Passionist Monastery, which closed its doors in 1981 after serving the spiritual needs of local residents for more than a century. Since then, the fate of the old church, its adjacent seminary buildings and the 12.3 acres of open space surrounding them has been the subject of bitter discord in this densely populated community.

title: Burned L.I. Lab Worker Dies
description: One of four employees at the Brookhaven National Research Laboratory who were burned while working on newly installed steam lines died today, officials said.

title: HOT SUMMERS AND THICK GRAVY
description: LOOKING FOR HOGEYE By Roy Reed. 132 pp. Fayetteville, Ark.: The University of Arkansas Press. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: Light Earthquake in West
description: A light earthquake that measured 3.8 on the Richter Scale occurred in the San Francisco Bay area, but no damage or injuries were reported, the United States Geological Survey said

title: Miss McGraw Married To Peter Kaiser Stark
description: Susan Hall McGraw, the daughter of Mrs. Thomas A. Grasso of Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Dr. Thomas A. McGraw of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Kaiser Stark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Stark Jr. of Stillwell, Kan. The Rev. Dr. Kirk Stevan Smith performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme.

title: Another American Freed By Belgrade Government
description: Yugoslavia has released a third Yugoslav-American citizen held on charges of hostile political activity, the State Department said today.

title: PARTY PARLEY DUE, ALBANIA CLUES ARE SOUGHT
description: In Bucharest, Belgrade and other Balkan capitals the question on the minds of the small groups of specialists who keep a close eye on Albania is when and if Ramiz Alia, the Communist leader in Tirana, can develop his own style of leadership, distinguishing himself from his predecessor, Enver Hoxha.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Variety of Balloons And Holiday Items Westchester Balloon and Carnival Supply in White Plains has a variety of balloons these days as well as discounted Halloween and other seasonal wares. It offers bulk discounts and will accommodate tax-exempt organizations producing certification on the prescribed forms.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Campbell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Colin G. Campbell of Middleton and Old Black Point, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Lee Campbell, to Robert Joseph Celata, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Celata of Milton, Mass.

title: Do Mergers Hurt?
description: THE buying and selling of American companies has created a volatile employment situation for thousands of American workers. And no slowdown is in sight for corporate mergers and acquisitions. In fact, these days it is not unusual for a company to change hands several times in a short period, in what one analyst has labeled ''the fast shuffle.''

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Las Vegas, N.M.; Timely Tapping Of Tax Credits
description: TWO years ago, a group of local property-owners banded together to renovate, lease out and manage 19 buildings in the historic Old Town district. Calling their joint effort La Plaza Vieja Partnership, they planned to renovate 14 buildings at one clip - the largest single such undertaking ever in New Mexico.

title: A FUNNY PLAY THAT FORGETS TO LAUGH
description: ONE of the structural problems in Neil Simon's autobiographical comedy, ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' is that the second act explores serious subjects ranging from the war in Europe to the Depression.

title: Texas Fishing Industry Threatened by Red Tide
description: Thousands of fish killed by spreading red tide piled up on Padre Island beaches today as a state ban on clam and oyster fishing was extended to more than 180 miles of Texas coast.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DAY THEY ALMOST BOMBED MOSCOW: The Allied War in Russia 1918-1920. By Christopher Dobson and John Miller. (Atheneum, $16.95.) Reaching for a cheerful note on relations between the United States and Russia, President Reagan has stated, ''Our sons and daughters have never fought each other in war.''

title: Regional Job Roundup: Southwest
description: BECAUSE the economies of Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana, along with most businesses, rise and fall with the oil industry, the dramatic slump in energy prices has caused cuts throughout all segments of the job market.

title: WITHDRAWAL OF PERSHING 2'S IS URGED
description: As President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev take up the subject of medium-range missiles, arms-control experts are urging the United States to stop insisting that Pershing 2 ballistic missiles be kept in West Germany.

title: CASHING IN ON AMERICA'S PHENOMENAL GRAIN GLUT
description: The corn is being brought in across the Middle West, a rich harvest that spills out of the granaries and into unprotected mountains on the ground. With prices and exports down, the bumper crop - the second in two years - is another harvest of despair for beleaguered farmers. But for the companies that manufacture or operate grain-storage facilities, the glut has been a bonanza.

title: RECOVERY PLANT BEING BUILT
description: Ground has been broken for a $2 million waste recovery plant that officials in industry say will be the world's first to convert wastes and pollutants into usable raw materials. Allied-Signal Inc. Of Morristown, N.J. announced Wednesday that the plant is being built for the Washington Steel Corporation.

title: DANCE: KINEMATIC'S 'SNOW QUEEN'
description: THINK of a music video with taste rather than vulgarity, with the performers live rather than on tape, and you have some idea of the work of Kinematic, an innovative dance group.

title: WOMAN WHO GOT 2 IMPLANTS DIES IN SURGERY AS A DONOR HEART FAILS
description: Bernadette Chayrez, the only person to receive artificial heart implants twice, died on the operating table today as doctors tried to replace her Jarvik-7 mechanical pump with a human heart. at the University Medical Center here.

title: Di Suvero's Dream of a Sculpture Park Grows in Queens
description: The recent opening of the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, has awakened dreams. There are a handful of outdoor sites in New York City where sculpture has been exhibited with some regularity during the summer months, but there has not been any place in which quality large-scale sculpture could be seen all year around. Now there is.

title: TOLL COULD BE 500
description: After shocks from an earthquake that killed at least 100 people rocked the Salvadoran capital all Friday night and this morning as poorly equipped rescue workers clawed through rubble in an effort to recover survivors and the bodies of the dead.

title: Nicaragua Downs Plane and Survivor Implicates C.I.A.
description: Government forces shot down a cargo plane carrying supplies to anti-Sandinista rebels last week, as it flew over southern Nicaragua. Three of the crew died in the crash, but the survivor - a 45-year-old former American marine who said he once worked as a civilian delivering supplies to Central Intelligence Agency operatives in Southeast Asia - was captured by the Sandinistas.

title: GETTING CLOSE TO THE ACTION IN PERTH
description: The races between the two 12-meter yachts that reach the finals of the first America's Cup in Australia are nearly four months away, but many Australians insist that there will be just as much excitement and activity for visitors to the Perth-Fremantle area before then.

title: Elizabeth Owens Becomes the Bride Of Steven D. Williams in Cambridge
description: The marriage of Elizabeth von Hartz Owens and Steven Douglas Williams, associate product managers of the Gillette Company in Boston, took place yesterday at the First Parish Church of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Edwin A. Lane performed the Unitarian ceremony.

title: Marie McCormick Married
description: Marie Louise McCormick, the daughter of Marie P. McCormick of Monroe, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Grossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert K. Grossman of the Bronx. Town Justice William Roy of Irvington, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Chart House restaurant in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Architects Sign In For A New Tool
description: BRIAN PILLING, an architect with Rothstein Architect, a small firm in Stockbridge, Mass., graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 1977 without ever taking a computer course. When he was studying architecture, computer courses were not required and he didn't see the need for taking any. Now, however, he routinely uses a computer to produce the ''working'' or production drawings that are the bread and butter of an architect's work.

title: J. A. Seidel Wed To Miss Suntken
description: Stephanie Jane Suntken, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Larry G. Suntken of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Arthur Seidel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Seidel of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Robert Dickson performed the ceremony at the Montclair Heights Reformed Church in Upper Montclair, where the bride's father is the minister.

title: Mark Kritzman And Sarah Clark Exchange Vows
description: Sarah Elizabeth Clark, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nesbitt Clark Jr. of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Paul Kritzman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Kritzman of Prospect, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: CHARLOTTE IN SEARCH OF ORDER
description: MERMAIDS By Patty Dann. 147 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $13.95.

title: OUTSIDER BACK INSIDE
description: RESIDENT ALIEN By Clark Blaise. 184 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: PIPELINE LETTER EVOKES A RESPONSE
description: Ralph Leviton of Southbury wrote to the editor on Sept. 28 about the natural gas pipeline that the Iroquois Gas Transmission System of Canada is trying to push through Connecticut in a straight line from Canada to Long Island.

title: China Reports Jailing 4 Spies From Taiwan for Up to 8 Years
description: China announced jail sentences of up to eight years today for a Taiwan spy who threatened to blow up the site of the Canton Trade Fair and four other convicted agents.

title: Dance
description: American dance is known for its rugged individualism. Nevertheless, some of this week's dance attractions are real choreographic get-togethers. In fact, Codanceco, the group directed by Nancy Duncan that will be at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, is a company that prizes eclecticism and seeks out choreographers with distinctive movement styles and sensibilities.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ALAMO HOUSE: Women Without Men, Men Without Brains. By Sarah Bird. (Norton, $15.95.) What's it like to go to graduate school in the 80's? For Mary Jo Steadman, first-year student at the University of Texas, it's a comic mixture of the worst of the early 60's, the sillier side of radical feminism and the glitz of MTV. Alamo House is a residence for graduate women, a down-at-the-heels dowager right across the street from the Sigma Upsilon Kappa fraternity. While the women attempt to pull their lives together, the SUK's are busy with beer blasts, classic rock-and-roll tunes and harassing the women across the street. After breaking up with her live-in lover, Mary Jo moves into this world and befriends a beautiful acting student, Collie, and an obese Baptist, Fayrene. Mary Jo has a job at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library, sorting Presidential papers and memorabilia, including three packing crates of Luci Johnson's wedding cake. Her co-worker is Tommy, who spends his time either sleeping or composing music for new rock bands he creates on impulse. Tommy is the only male character in this novel to achieve any humanity, and he's a bright relief. As the subtitle suggests, the SUK's and other men who inhabit Sarah Bird's first novel are portrayed with all the compassion we usually reserve for cockroaches. Even the men these three women date are entries in their Weirdo of the Week contest. Eventually the women at Alamo House, galvanized by Mary Jo and Collie, have had enough.

title: SPACE MOVE RAISES HOPES IN HOUSTON
description: After a summer of extraordinary concern about the city's role in future space ventures, three recent developments here have provided a dramatic lift to space-related industries and to Houston's overall economic prospects.

title: Colt Moving
description: THE syndicate that owns Affirmed, the 1978 winner of the Triple Crown, voted Friday to move the stallion from financially troubled Spendthrift Farm to Calumet Farm. C. Gibson Downing, a Lexington, Ky., attorney representing Affirmed's shareholders, cited Spendthrift's liquidation of most of its broodmares as one reason for the move.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HIGHER LEARNING. By Derek Bok. (Harvard University, $15.) The most important point Derek Bok makes in this book is that the undergraduate college ought to retain a central place within a major research university.

title: Lesley Simon a Bride
description: Lesley Ellen Simon, a business analyst for Young & Rubicam, and Salvatore A. Greco Jr., a credit analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, were married yesterday at the Oradell, N.J., home of the bride's mother, Nina Simon. Rabbi Phillip Berkowitz officiated. The bride is the daughter also of Dr. Gilbert Simon of Sacramento, Calif. Mr. Greco is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Greco of Kingston, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1986
description: THE WORLD Mikhail S. Gorbachev declined to set a date for a summit meeting in the United States unless prospects for signing a major arms control pact were good. Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan set up working groups on arms control and human rights and other issues to meet Mr. Gorbachev's concerns. [ Page 1, Cols. 4-6. ] Arms control experts have urged the United States to drop its insistence that Pershing 2 ballistic missiles be kept in West Germany. They say the deployment of cruise missiles would be sufficient as a symbol of American commitment to West Germany's defense. [ 8:4-6. ] Chancellor Helmut Kohl endorsed a radical reduction of American medium-range nuclear weapons stationed in West Germany and other NATO countries. The proposal does not link reduction of the missiles to similar cutbacks in Soviet short-range systems targeted on Europe. [ 8:1-4. ] Aftershocks rocked San Salvador yesterday as rescue workers tried to recover survivors and the bodies of the dead from the earthquake Friday night. Rescue officials estimated that the earthquake might have killed as many as 500 people and injured hundreds of others. [ 1:1-2. ] Iranian commandos destroyed an Iraqi oil refinery at a main northern oil center during a raid deep into Iraqi territory, the official Iranian press agency reported. The Iraqis, however, denied the report of an attack at the Kirkuk oil center. [ 3:4-6. ] Western military experts describe Iraq's defenses along its 733-mile war front with Iran as an impressive feat of military engineering.

title: WESTERN AUSTRALIA'S BIG COUNTRY
description: If Perth seems, as it is, a cozy place to play host to the America's Cup races, visitors should treat Western Australia with considerable respect. Americans should be prepared to be ambushed by the statistic that Western Australia, the state of which Perth is capital, is nearly three and a half times as big as Texas. It has a coastline longer than the West Coast, and the red-sand ridges and waterless scrub of the Great Victoria, Gibson and Great Sandy Deserts occupy an area twice the size of California.

title: REACTORS' PROCEDURES FAULTED
description: A Federal agency has concluded that it cannot provide ''reasonable assurance'' that schoolchildren in the vicinity of the Indian Point nuclear power plants in Westchester County would be protected in case of an accident.

title: NO CLEAN-UP YET FOR THE DIRTY DIESEL
description: THEY are smokier and smellier than their gasoline-powered counterparts, heavier and less peppy. So no one should be surprised that diesel-powered engines are less popular than they were in the 1970's.

title: DEVELOPER WAS 92
description: Leon R. Spear, a senior vice president of Helmsley-Spear Inc., the real estate development company, and a leading Manhattan real-estate broker for almost 70 years, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: NEW DISCOVERY ON NORTH POLE (EXPLORERS) HERALDS A REUNION
description: When Olive Henson, now 59 years old, was a young girl, she went on family trips to New York to visit her great uncle, Matthew A. Henson, who accompanied Comdr. Robert E. Peary on eight trips to reach the North Pole.

title: Finding a Berth For The Races
description: The following is a sampling of ships calling at or staying in Fremantle (the port for Perth) during the America's Cup competition or offering a land program that allows passengers to take in the races. Royal Viking SkyAs part of a 99-night world cruise, leaving Jan. 7 from San Francisco, this 710-passenger Royal Viking Line ship will spend the nights of Feb. 5 and 6 in Fremantle during the race finals. Cruise rates range from $20,952 to $88,270. Contact: Royal Viking Line, 750 Battery Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94111 (415-398-8000; 800-634-8000 outside California). Royal Viking StarPassengers on the Jan. 5, Jan. 17 and Jan. 29 Australia-New Zealand voyages of this 710-passenger Royal Viking Line ship can take an optional land package that will fly them from Sydney to Perth and give them three nights at a hotel in Perth, transportation to view the races and a day trip to the Darling Ranges as well as a local sightseeing tour, most meals (including full American breakfast daily), transfers, porterage and the services of a guide. The package also provides a hotel stay in Sydney (three nights for passengers on the Jan. 5 and Jan. 29 voyages, which originate in Sydney and terminate in Auckland; two nights for those on the Jan. 17 voyage, which goes from Auckland to Sydney).

title: IKE: THE GREATNESS WAS THE MAN, NOT HIS SUCCESSES
description: Are we in danger of losing the flavor and essence of Dwight D. Eisenhower?

title: Eleanor A. Hart Wed To Thomas R. Duffus
description: Eleanor Austin Hart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Hart Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Thomas Risley Duffus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Duffus of Rochester, were married yesterday. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the music business misidentifies a pianist managed by Harold Shaw. He is Sergei Edelmann, not Sergei Edelstein.

title:
ART;
SOCIAL MESSAGES, BOLDLY TOLD
description: SPAIN'S Civil War polarized forces of fascism and democracy everywhere. The arrival of the International Brigade, 50 years ago this month, became a turning point in social awareness for many on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: FOR AN URBAN FARM, A CHANCE TO GROW
description: ALMOST in the center of New Haven's impoverished Hill section, a vegetable garden grows. Hidden from the street by tall weeds, trees and construction crews - on one side, a four-lane highway is under construction, while Legion Avenue is being widened on the other side - the plants thrive nonetheless. And now a city grant will allow the garden to survive, also.

title: Space Jobs On Hold
description: FROM the moment the first space shuttle lifted off in 1981 until the moment the Challenger exploded last Jan. 28, everyone from aerospace-industry executives to space-agency administrators to Commerce Department officials exuded optimism that a new high-technology industry was under way. Space, they insisted, was the final frontier of corporate research and development.

title: ICELAND PROTESTS: FROM JEWS TO HARE KRISHNA
description: Jews held a Sabbath service here today and prayed for their brethren in the Soviet Union in one of several demonstrations on the first day of the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting.

title: Cuomo Disavows Letter Seeking to Raise Funds
description: Governor Cuomo has not authorized and does not support a fund-raising letter being circulated by a group that labels itself the National Draft Cuomo Committee, his campaign said Friday.

title: State Pinning Hopes on High Technology
description: AS PART of its campaign to make over a moribund ''smokestack industry'' economy into one based on high technology, New Jersey has committed itself strongly to the development of computer-integrated manufacturing, and is establishing two centers in the northern and southern parts of the state for training and development in this field.

title: No Headline
description: IN THE MID-1920'S, IN SEVERAL parts of the world, a number of brave, skilled young men and women began taking to the air at the controls of a variety of aircraft, most of which, by today's standards, were unenviably small, fragile and poorly equipped.

title: NOSTALGIA SHOW RECALLS THE BROOKLYN DODGERS
description: IN a city whose wizardly '86 Mets are battling for New York's 59th pennant of the century this week, baseball has long been a special passion. And for generations, nowhere were the fans more fanatic and the passion for baseball more passionate than in Brooklyn.

title: Wall Street Is on an Uptick
description: TIMES have rarely been better on Wall Street. Not only have profits been strong but securities firms have been growing at a terrific pace, which translates into an increasing number of opportunities for professionals, according to recruiting specialists.

title: Titus Brenninkmeyer Marries Wendy West
description: Wendy Phelps West, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps West of Harwichport, Mass., was married yesterday to Titus Brenninkmeyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Brenninkmeyer of Hilversum, the Netherlands. The Rev. Rene Caissey performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Cape Roman Catholic Church in Brewster, Mass.

title: Necip Alev Is Married To Joan E. Snedecor
description: Joan Elizabeth Snedecor, a daughter of Naomi Zuleger Snedecor of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and James Y. Snedecor of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Orleans, Mass., was married yesterday to Necip Alev, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ali Alev of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: A WRITER STRIVES TO SHED LIGHT ON THE HOLOCAUST'S DARKNESS
description: ''THE story of the White Rose has a significance beyond Nazi Germany,'' said Jud Newborn.

title: SHAMIR'S TASKS
description: Today, on the official day of ''rotation,'' Prime Minister Shimon Peres will voluntarily cede his seat to his former rival, Yitzhak Shamir, and the leadership of Israel's National Unity Government will pass from the Labor Party to the Likud bloc.

title: Senior U.N. Aide Accused as Spy
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said last week that the United States is afflicted with too many secrets and too many Soviet spies, notably ''a K.G.B. China expert'' who is one of two assistants to the Secretary General of the United Nations. It recommended, among other things, changing the system of classifying secrets, improving computer security and tightening surveillance of Federal employees.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ONE FOR THE BOOKS FOR almost 60 years, officials of the Village of New Hyde Park have gone about their business enforcing their zoning laws. Now, a lawyer has questioned whether New Hyde Park actually has any legal zoning ordinance.

title: JONATHAN MILLER'S 'MIKADO' OWES A LOT TO THE MARX BROTHERS
description: The first-night audience for the English National Opera's new production of Gilbert & Sullivan's ''Mikado'' two weeks ago suspected that it might see something bizarre, with Jonathan Miller as director. The former doctor famous for, among other things, a ''Rigoletto'' reset in 1950's New York's Little Italy in the 1950's (a version seen at the Metropolitan Opera during the ENO visit two years ago) had the curtain rise on a white English hotel lounge of the 1920's turned surreal by the designer Stefanos Lazaridis with floating spheres and superimposed musical instruments. And, oh dear, the Gentlemen of Japan were in black frock coats and lounge suits of various eras - not a kimono in sight. There were tap-dancing maids and bellhops, Monty Python's Eric Idle as a seedy Ko-Ko delivering his first speech as if doing a radio broadcast, and Katisha (a felicitous Felicity Palmer) singing ''The Hour of Sadness'' looking like Margaret Dumont singing an art song. Katisha then prepares to fly off somewhere (presumably from the Croydon Aerodrome) at the end of Act I. If you think this ''Mikado'' sounds more like a Marx Brothers movie than the D'Oyly Carte, Mr. Miller would applaud your perception, for that was precisely part of his inspiration for this production. In an interview before the premiere, he said that he wanted another operetta fantasyland to replace Gilbert's Titipu - an alternative artificial kingdom to which modern audiences could relate. He picked a country along the lines of Freedonia in the 1933 ''Duck Soup.''

title: REAGAN'S AGENDA - BEYOND ARMS
description: PRESIDENT Reagan flew to Iceland last week for two days of talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. Both sides said that advancing the discussion on controlling nuclear weapons was their main objective.

title: NETWORKS AND NEWS PERSONNEL AGREE ON PACT
description: Negotiators for the three television networks and the union representing news personnel reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract, the union said.

title: LEGISLATOR CALLED VICTIM OF UNPROVOKED ASSAULT
description: The Sept. 14 Opinion Page article by Todd A. Bryan was an unprovoked and unfounded assault on a legislator I respect and on many of my fellow colleagues in the Assembly. [ Mr. Bryan is executive director of the Stony Brook-Millstone Watershed Association. ] The article dealt with the much-debated issue of freshwater wetlands protection; however, rather than deal with the substantive issues, Mr. Bryan chose to make a personal attack on the sponsor of one bill.

title: WHY THE TRASH IS ALWAYS GREENER NEXT DOOR
description: ''DISCRIMINATING'' has always been a word I've considered in a certain category. There are shrewd shoppers, fussy eaters and fancy dressers who wear their fine feathers like exotic peacocks. Commercials on television relish the word; throwing it about to hawk everything from elite automobiles to dill pickles. In the dictionary, ''discriminating'' is listed as ''fastidiously selective.'' Somehow, discriminating is not a term one normally associates with trash.

title: NO WAVES MADE AT U.N.
description: AN IMPORTANT stop on the United Nations tour is a photo display that describes, a bit romantically perhaps, the role of the Secretary General: ''The most impossible, frustrating, daunting, challenging, rewarding, fascinating, clearly unique job on earth.''

title: THE WHITE HOUSE, THE MOB AND THE BOOK BIZ: FOOTNOTES TO 'THE VALACHI PAPERS'
description: TWENTY-ONE years ago this fall I started work on ''The Valachi Papers.''

title: FRANCE REJECTS ISRAELI COUNTERTERRORISM OFFER
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has agreed to increase exchanges of intelligence information with Israel to combat terrorism, according to Israeli officials.

title: REDISTRICTING OF YONKERS IN CONTENTION
description: UNDER the settlement of a Federal Voting Rights suit involving minority representation on the Yonkers City Council, city officials earlier this year adopted a redistricting proposal that goes before voters Nov. 4.

title: WOODLAND WONDERS TO PLANT NOW
description: Considering how much of New England is wooded, it is surprising that more Yankee gardeners have not tumbled to the season-long pleasures of a woodland garden. One reason may be an association in people's minds between wooded areas and the fleeting glory of spring blooming wildflowers. While, in fact, the great charm of a woodland garden is its long period of interest and smashing fall display that winds up the season in a blaze of glory.

title: LOBBY LOSING ITS CHIEF ADVOCATE
description: WHEN the Assembly Environmental Quality Committee approved a compromise package of bills last month to pay for cleaning up hazardous-waste sites, the New Jersey Chemical Industry Council issued a press release praising the compromise and urging legislators and voters to support it.

title: Q AND A
description: Capital-Gains Taxes Question: A few years ago, I bought an apartment for $21,000. When I married, I sold it for $60,000 and put the profit into a $310,000 apartment that my husband and I bought together. I have a one-third interest in the apartment and my husband has a two-thirds interest. We are now separating and he has agreed to sell it to me for $350,000. What will be the tax consequences if I buy the apartment and when I sell it? . . . B. S., Manhattan

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LONG DARKNESS: Psychological and Moral Perspectives on Nuclear Winter. Edited by Lester Grinspoon. (Yale University, Cloth, $25. Paper, $7.95.) The eight essays in this book are only tenuously related to one another and are, for the most part, even more tenuously related to the book's subtitle.

title: AUTUMN ON NORTH FORK: A BOUNTY OF BLESSINGS
description: IN Cutchogue, the sugar level of the Hargrave Vineyard's grapes has reached 20 percent. In Riverhead, Stella Baer of Oceanside clutched a bouquet of fresh produce the other day, while Rose Anne Berezny prepared to post a ''Pick Your Own Pumpkin'' sign.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING RULES TIGHTEN
description: THE rents of most of the 6,000 families living in moderate-income public housing in Connecticut are expected to rise under new guidelines imposed by the state.

title: Mark Smith Wed To Miss DeJager
description: Pamela Karan DeJager, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce D. DeJager of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday in Manhattan to Mark Christopher Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Emmett Smith of Dallas. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Mets Win, 6-5, on Dykstra Homer
description: The Mets staged their first playoff game in New York in 13 years yesterday and won it by 6-5 with two flashes of electrifying theater: a three-run home run by Darryl Strawberry in the sixth inning that tied the Houston Astros, and a two-run home run by Lenny Dykstra in the ninth that beat them.

title: AMERICA'S IMPERIAL CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: IT is amazing to many - even members of the business community - that Samuel H. Armacost, who resigned last Friday as chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation, held onto his job as long as he did. His long-floundering company recently suffered the second-largest quarterly loss ever sustained by a bank in the United States. And BankAmerica's stock price plummeted so precipitously during his five-year reign that the bank is now in danger of being swallowed by a competitor less than half its size.

title: San Antonio
description: There is no other city in Texas where the state's history, diverse cultures and contemporary aspirations mix so conspicuously as in San Antonio. With its Mexican and German heritage, walkable downtown, museums and historic sites, San Antonio is both the most historic city in Texas and the most accessible to visitors, especially in the fall when the summer heat has abated. (The average temperature is 71 degrees in October, 61 in November.) The state's 150th birthday celebration is still in progress, making this a a good year to see the Alamo and the Institute of Texan Cultures as well as museums and other attractions.

title: In New York City, A Maturing Recovery
description: AFTER seven years of famine and, at least relatively speaking, seven years of feast, 1986 seemed to many observers as likely a year as any for New York City's economy to undergo another biblical turn. Perhaps the most metaphorical indication that it might come occurred during the summer when Hebrew National Inc. announced that it was taking its rabbinically supervised kosher meat-processing operations to Indianapolis.

title: DANIEL J. FOX WED TO MISS ATHERTON
description: Kimberly J. Atherton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Atherton of New Canaan, Conn., and Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel J. Fox, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth T. Fox of Saegertown, Pa. The Rev. Gilford Green, assisted by the Rev. William J. Weber, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Aeolian Hall's Jazz Lives Again
description: Paul Whiteman's concert of ''jazz'' at Aeolian Hall in New York on Feb. 12, 1924, is remembered now almost entirely for one selection: the first performance of George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' with the composer as piano soloist. The story of how Gershwin came to write it, and its reception and its impact on the musical world have been told and retold. It is the stuff of musical history - and legend.

title:
RECORDINGS;
High Emotion From A Prize Symphony
description: Great as the distinction was when Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Symphony No. 1 won her the 1983 Pulitzer Prize in music, the first ever awarded to a woman, it overshadowed an even rarer quality in the symphony itself. The excellent premiere recording now provides an opportunity to discover what a treasure we have in this work and this composer. Unlike much American music being composed today - music represented, in all its healthy diversity, on other recent LP's - Mrs. Zwilich's symphony is unashamed in allowing heartfelt emotion to show through.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PENNSYLVANIA SPICE BOXES Spice boxes - small wooden cabinets fitted with interior drawers used in the 18th century to hold spices, jewelry and other sundries - will be displayed at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh through Nov. 30. The exhibit will include nearly 60 Pennsylvania examples of the form, many of which were made in Chester County, where the conservative Quaker population preserved the furniture form long after its popularity waned.

title: The Counterestablishment
description: To the Editor:

title: No Reason to Do Away With 55 M.P.H.
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 18 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 18 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Bomb Explodes at Office Of Athens City Council
description: A bomb went off outside the Athens City Council office early today, a day before nationwide local government elections. A left-wing Greek terrorist group said it was responsible.

title: TOPIC
description: FOR me there's nothing quite like a beach run at low tide on a sunny Sunday morning, summer or fall, on the South Shore. With the shoreline wide and fairly hard underfoot, I slip on socks, lace up the Tigers, add a hat, bid my bride a temporary goodbye and head east - destination Gilgo Beach and its farthest rock jetty.

title: GORBACHEV PUTS RUSSIA'S BEST FACE FORWARD
description: THE Mikhail S. Gorbachev sitting across from President Reagan in Reykjavik this weekend is hardly a novelty any more. In the 19 months since he took office, his televised travels, volumes of speeches and innumerable meetings with foreign dignitaries have made him the most familiar of Soviet leaders, at least since Nikita S. Khrushchev.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GAY PRIEST: An Inner Journey. By Malcolm Boyd. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Malcolm Boyd, a prolific writer with a long record of civil rights and peace activism, has been an Episcopal priest for 30 years and an open homosexual for the last 10.

title: DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT IS GATHERING SPOT FOR CUSTOM CARS
description: EVERY rain-free Wednesday evening, automobile enthusiasts of all sorts turn up at a drive-in restaurant on Route 31, just south of here, for a happening that has no name.

title:
ART;
AT THE NEUBERGER, WINDOWS ALLOW ARTISTS TO SHARE A THEME
description: ''THE Window in 20th-Century Art'' at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York in Purchase is a brilliant display case for some first-rate art, not to mention a few masterpices one is surprised to encounter.

title: MENDING THE WALL
description: THE ESTABLISHMENT CLAUSE Religion and the First Amendment. By Leonard W. Levy. 236 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: MAKING THE DEALS BEHIND THE MUSIC
description: When Omus Hirshbein agreed to organize this fall's ''Vienna 1900: A Festival of Music'' last May, he had only an idea - no programs, no performers. In a few months, he created eight concerts at the Museum of Modern Art peopled by distinguished artists playing strikingly original programs - and he sold out every event. His success, and how he achieved it, speaks not only about the acumen of a single man, but about the loyalties, the ambitions, the deals and compromises that make the music business work.

title: . . . and in Florida
description: Florida's gubernatorial primary has left Democrats in disarray and has brightened the prospects of Bob Martinez, who is seeking to become the state's second Republican Governor in this century. Steve Pajcic, a 40-year-old former state legislator, won the Democratic nomination after a runoff election against Jim Smith, the State Attorney General. Mr. Smith suggested that Mr. Pajcic was a liberal whose legislative record showed him to be soft on drugs and crime.

title: SHARPER THAN LOTS OF SERPENTS' TEETH
description: FUNNY SAUCE Us, the Ex, the Ex's New Mate, the New Mate's Ex, and the Kids. By Delia Ephron. 191 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95.

title: Cynthia Pendias Is Married To Kenneth Geoffrey Cox
description: Cynthia Pendias, a daughter of Cleopatra T. Pendias of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Orestes P. Pendias, was married yesterday to Kenneth Geoffrey Cox, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril H. Cox of Tonbridge, Kent, England. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: No Headline
description: Marion Bettle Huston, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Huston Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to John T. Lisko, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Lisko of Phoenix, Ariz. The Rev. John Crocker Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church in Princeton.

title: Verbatim; Pressure to Launch
description: 'The committee found that NASA's drive to achieve a launch schedule of 24 flights per year created pressure throughout the agency that directly contributed to unsafe launch operations.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: October 12, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Where Great Books Are the Teachers
description: I am an alumna of St. John's College, and Robert Kanigel's vivid description of tutorials and seminars brought back memories of many exciting and infuriating discussions (''Where Great Books Are the Teachers,'' Sept. 21).

title: Confessions of a Stepmother
description: I welcomed Delia Ephron's ''Confessions.'' She did not get stuck in the role of a beleaguered Cinderella but was able to look at her own motivations and even to understand her stepchildren's ambivalence.

title: Saralyn Bass Married
description: Saralyn Bass, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Bass of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan to James McCombe Shillinglaw, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Gordon Shillinglaw of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Justice Elliott Golden of the State Supreme Court officiated.

title: ISRAEL'S LEADERSHIP PROBLEM
description: THE TRANSITION IS expected to be mercifully swift. Sometime this week, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir's blue, armor-plated Chevrolet will cruise up the covered driveway of the Prime Minister's office building. The 70-year-old Mr. Shamir will stride up the familiar stairs to the second floor. There, a guard will hold open the bulletproof glass doors that lead into the Prime Minister's inner sanctum. Another right turn. A quick left. Two more doors and then he will have arrived.

title: CHILDREN CITING SELF-DEFENSE IN MURDER OF PARENTS
description: When he took the stand two weeks ago, Sociz Junatanov freely admitted that he was desperate to kill his father. The 19-year-old defendant, known as Johnny, told the jury that from childhood his father had beaten him, kept him in handcuffs and chained him. He said that about three years ago his father raped him.

title: How To Create Your Own Job
description: YOU hear stories about it all the time: a person applies to a company for a job, is told there are no openings, and ends up working there anyway, having created a job.

title: CANCER AND WORK ISSUE AT SYMPOSIUM
description: AT a recent symposium in Tarrytown, organized by the Westchester division of the American Cancer Society, representatives of labor and personnel directors of major corporations explored the legal and ethical issues involved when employees have a history of cancer.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
An Old Underdog Finds Himself On Top
description: YOU gotta understand - this Mets thing didn't just happen to me overnight; it began in 1946. Like many New Yorkers, my National League connection can be traced directly back to the Brooklyn Dodgers, the authentic spiritual ancestors of today's New York Mets. I was one of those long-suffering Dodger fans, back when they were an interesting team, and their fans actually had some color and texture. As a Mets fan, I may be celebrating my 25th anniversary, but, in truth, I've been trying to get a 20-game lead for 40 years.

title:
BASEBALL;
For Angels, an Inning to Remember; For Red Sox, One That's Hard to Forget
description: The California Angels came up with a ninth inning to remember tonight, and one that Calvin Schiraldi, the relief pitcher, and his Red Sox teammates probably would like to forget.

title: Martin Williams Marries Amy Scarlett in Baltimore
description: Amy Lawrence Scarlett, a daughter of Mrs. William Alexander Barr of Baltimore and Gibson Island, Md., and the late William George Scarlett Jr., was married yesterday to Martin Williams, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donlad Williams of Appleton, Wis. The Rev. Ernest Smart performed the ceremony at the Second Presbyterian Church in Baltimore.

title: How To Read The Code on DX Film Cartridges
description: In the last three years a mysterious group of checkerboard-style squares have found their way onto the cylindrical cartridges of 35-millimeter film. The silver and black patterns are not merely decorative; they are the most obvious manifestations of a new method of automatic film identification known as the DX coding system.

title: Leslie Gruis Wed To A. P. Cashman
description: Leslie Nottingham Gruis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Gruis of Lancaster, Va., and Washington, was married yesterday to Adam Parker Cashman, the son of Ruth Parker Cashman and Gideon Cashman, both of New York. The Rev. Thom Blair performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Lancaster.

title: A GLAZED BOWL OF ONE'S OWN
description: WHERE YOU'LL FIND ME And Other Stories. By Ann Beattie. 191 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: REMEMBER THOSE GAS-SAVING IDEAS?
description: WHEN gasoline was rocketing to $1 a gallon in the 1970's, developing new fuels and cars to use them had top priority on the national agenda. The Federal Government lavished millions of dollars on hurry-up experimental programs that promised a diesel-powered car in every driveway and two cars in every garage - one that ran on gasohol, one on electricity. Detroit, meanwhile, went into a research mania of its own.

title: New Cassettes: Big Stars and Big Bands
description: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner? Starring Spencer Tracy, Katharine Hepburn, Katharine Houghton, Sidney Poitier; directed by Stanley Kramer, 1967 RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 108 minutes. $59.95

title: ANGELS WIN IN 11TH TO TAKE 3-1 LEAD
description: The night had been a downer for Bobby Grich. He struck out in the first inning and in the third, and then again in the ninth. He had left seven base runners stranded. His error in the eighth inning helped the Boston Red Sox take a three-run lead. He was done, it seemed; so were the Angels. But the night was not over. Grich, who had failed to hit in 10 previous times at bat, came to the plate in the 11th inning tonight, lined a single to left field off Calvin Schiraldi and drove in the winning run in a 4-3 California Angels victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: A PLANE GOES DOWN, THE POLITICAL ANTE GOES UP
description: A SANDINISTA missile knocked out of the sky over southern Nicaragua a cargo plane bearing supplies for the anti-Government rebels. The only survivor, an American, traced the sweaty life of a hired hand in foreign wars and said he was supervised by the Central Intelligence Agency. The cremated remains of two other American crewmen were unceremoniously placed outside the American embassy here.

title: Priscilla Plummer Marries
description: Priscilla Jane Plummer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Plummer Jr. of Vancouver, Wash., was married there yesterday to Peter Phelps Macy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Macy Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., by the Rev. Robert W. Rhodes at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd. Mrs. Macy is the promotion director for the San Francisco-based City Sports Magazine. Her husband is a project engineer with Brown & Caldwell, Pleasantville, Calif., consulting engineers.

title: U.S. SENDING HELP TO QUAKE VICTIMS
description: The United States has sent four teams to assist the Government of El Salvador in its efforts to recover from the earthquake that struck San Salvador on Friday, the head of the Agency for International Development said today.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT IS UNDER THE SOIL COUNTS, TOO
description: IF you ever had a houseplant that died for no apparent reason, this discussion is for you.

title: VASSAR, IN 125TH YEAR, INSTALLS NINTH PRESIDENT
description: Frances Daley Fergusson was formally installed as Vassar College's ninth president today, culminating a week of ceremony celebrating the college.

title: Departmental Charges Filed Against Officers
description: The New York City Police Department served formal administrative charges Friday on 9 of the 13 police officers suspended in the 77th Precinct in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last month after an investigation into allegations of police corruption there.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Miss Livingston, An I.R.S. Lawyer, Is Bride in Capital
description: Catherine Schuyler Livingston and Louis John Fernandez, lawyers in the chief counsel's office of the Internal Revenue Service in Washington, were married there yesterday at St. Alban's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Charles Martin, assisted by the Rev. Peter J. Vaghi, performed the ceremony.

title: Mitford Against America
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRECTORY IS COMPILED TO AID THE NEEDY
description: A NEW directory of resources for the homeless and hungry in Westchester will be available by the end of the year through the Family Information and Referral Services Teams, the organization sometimes called First. The directory was researched by Ann Gillette, a college student and Citibank summer intern who worked for the nonprofit organization for eight weeks last summer.

title: Miss Wood Wed To M. F. Ahmed
description: Marion Geer Canfield Wood, an associate editor at Town & Country magazine, was married yesterday to Mohamed Farrag Ahmed, the senior vice president of W. J. Nolan & Company, a New York investment brokerage. The Rev. T. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros At Shea Stadium, fourth game of National League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. Television Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio WCBS 880, 8:07 P.M., and WHN 1050, 7:35 P.M. Boston Red Sox vs.

title: IT'S TOUCH-AND-GO FOR SMALL PLANES
description: ON sunny weekends, small planes still fill the skies over flight-training schools, landing fields and local airports. But these piston-engine craft - called ''putt-putts'' or ''little guys'' by commercial pilots - are facing a precipitous decline.

title: A LESSON FOR URUGUAY - NEW DEMOCRACY IS FRAIL
description: ALMOST to a man, Uruguayans shouted with glee when the country's armed forces relinquished power in March last year after more than a decade of harsh rule. Yet it took only a brief pronouncement by 19 retired generals earlier this month, cautioning Congress against approving a new human rights law, for worries about a military coup to arise. In reality, such fears seemed premature. Aware of the risks involved, President Julio Maria Sanguinetti stressed last week that he opposed prosecuting army and police officers for crimes such as murder, torture, rape and the ''disappearance'' of political prisoners during the dictatorship. He recommended granting an amnesty to bury the past.

title: HOSPITAL PATIENT 'BILL OF RIGHTS' GOES TO THE STATE SENATE
description: LEGISLATION that spells out the rights of New Jersey hospital patients to receive ''considerate and respectful care'' has cleared the State Senate Institutions, Health and Welfare Committee and is pending before the full Senate.

title: WHO GETS IN, AND WHY
description: CALCULATED KINDNESS Refugees and America's Half-Open Door, 1945 to the Present. By Gil Loescher and John A. Scanlan. 346 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: Confessions Of a Stepmother
description: Delia Ephron does a delightful job of capturing the mixed emotions of stepparenting in her article ''Confessions of a Stepmother'' (Sept. 14).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: HAITI LINGERS ON 'THE EDGE OF ANARCHY'
description: AFTER a relatively quiet summer, new tensions are tearing at Haiti. The provisional military Government that replaced President Jean Claude Duvalier in February, which many Haitians had looked to as the country's salvation, has failed to come to grips with the chaos that followed nearly 30 years of dictatorship.

title: Jahn's Yorkville Salute
description: It seems fitting that the German-born architect Helmut Jahn would design his first wholly residential building in New York City for a site in Yorkville, long a German-American enclave on the Upper East Side. But there is nothing German, or even foreign, about the slender tower by Mr. Jahn, who has dazzled the United States from his Chicago offices with romantic, sometimes showy, architecture.

title: A.M. ROSENTHAL LEAVING EXECUTIVE EDITOR'S POST AT THE TIMES, AND MAX FRANKEL IS HIS SUCCESSOR
description: A. M. Rosenthal is leaving his position as executive editor of The New York Times and will be succeeded by Max Frankel, who has been editor of the editorial page. The changes were announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the paper's publisher.

title: Chevy Chase Being Treated For Addiction to Painkillers
description: The comedian Chevy Chase, known for his slapstick humor and pratfalls, is addicted to painkillers and has checked into the Betty Ford drug rehabilitation center, his public relations agent says.

title: UNLIKELY STAR MAKES HIS MARK IN BASEBALL
description: A SCHOOL wouldn't pay tribute to a cheat, would it?

title: U.S. JOINS INVESTIGATIONS ON CABLE TV FRANCHISES
description: Federal prosecutors have joined investigations into the granting of cable television franchises for the boroughs outside Manhattan - awards that have yet to bring service to the vast majority of households.

title: Margaret Orr Married To Richard Wechsler
description: The marriage of Margaret Terry Orr, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Orr of Gallipolis, Ohio, to Richard Wechsler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Wechsler of McKeesport, Pa., took place yesterday at Moran's Chelsea Restaurant in New York. Acting Judge Ira R. Globerman of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: Helen Burton to Wed Rev. Charles Houghtlin
description: Helen Therese Burton, a family counselor at St. Vincent's and Foundling Hospitals in New York, and the Rev. Charles B. Houghtlin, the chaplain of the Collegiate School in New York, have announced their engagement. The wedding is planned for Nov. 7.

title: ADULT ENGLISH COURSES PRESSED BY IMMIGRANTS
description: The demand for adult English classes among non-English-speaking residents of New York is so strong that thousands of people are on waiting lists, and education officials say they could easily double their enrollment if the money and space were available.

title: THE AGED FIND YOU CAN GO HOME AGAIN
description: ALTHOUGH it is not easy for the elderly to make a major change in their way of life, some of them - usually those in their late 70's and early 80's - are doing just that as they leave Florida and return north to be near their families.

title: SUBPOENA QUASHED IN FILM DEATH CASE
description: The prosecutor in the manslaughter trial stemming from ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' has lost in an attempt to subpoena the actor Ralph Bellamy and has made allegations of ''blackballing'' in the entertainment industry.

title: 'INTIMATIONS' OF FIGURES AT NEWARK'S ROBESON CENTER GALLERY
description: THAT'S right: The picture is of a tree root, and it's not a trophy bagged on a nature hike, either. It's a sculpture, one of the 19 by 6 artists that make up the show now at Newark-Rutgers's Robeson Center Gallery, 350 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard.

title: When Young Passengers Fly Solo
description: Last April 5, Pauline Vaillancourt took her 14-year-old daughter, Veronique, to Los Angeles International Airport to put her on American Airlines Flight 194 to Chicago, where she was to transfer to American's Flight 448 to Montreal. Things promptly began to go wrong.

title: Maribeth Bersani Becomes a Bride
description: Maribeth Bersani, the daughter of Judge Mathilde C. Bersani and Henry A. Bersani of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Daniel F. McCormack, a son of Mary E. McCormack of Brooklyn and the late Eugene J. McCormack. The Rev. James Kane performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A JOCKEY'S LIFE: The Biography of Lester Piggott. By Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) There can be little argument that Lester Piggott, who won more than 5,000 races in a career that spanned almost four decades, was a successful jockey.

title: For Lady's Secret, A Busy Schedule Spurs Improvement
description: WHEN Lady's Secret steps onto the track for the Beldame Stakes today at Belmont Park, no one could complain if she dug in her heels, threw her head and whinnied, ''Enough already.''

title: BANKAMERICA'S EMPLOYEES EDGY OVER NEW CHIEF
description: Concern about the future gripped employees of the BankAmerica Corporation today as they awaited a board of directors meeting Sunday at which the banking company's president, Samuel H. Armacost, will resign and his replacement will be chosen.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE'S something chilling about getting on a scale that not only says out loud, ''Have a good day,'' a phrase that should be stricken from every tongue, but is also capable of delivering aloud the happy news that you've gained five pounds since last weighing in. The good thing about this scale - and it does exist - is that it is not thrust upon anyone. It is a voluntary acquisition for persons of sunny disposition, not easily irritated and willing to spend $100 to find out what they probably already know.

title: Truck Driver Shot in Robbery
description: A truck driver was shot in the head and robbed of $6 by two people early today as he lay sleeping in his tractor-trailer at an Interstate 95 rest stop here, the state police said. The driver, identified as Robert Campbell, 37 years old, of Stratford, was in critical condition at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport after being shot through the rig's window with a small-caliber handgun. Mr. Campbell pulled into the rest area around 4:20 A.M., the state police said.

title: SUDANESE FLEE STRIFE TO FIND NEW DESPAIR
description: People of the southern Sudan are fleeing the madness of war, clutching with desperate intensity the fragile promise of something better in the north. What they too often find is a squalid dead end, where life is just as precarious.

title: Assessing Mario Cuomo
description: On the subject of Roman Catholicism, Mario Cuomo is not to be paired with John F. Kennedy. John Kennedy, in his quest for the Presidency, never avowed or disavowed loyalty to his faith. It was at a Methodist, not a Baptist, convention that Mr. Kennedy sufficiently unshackled himself from the issue of religion to prompt Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, noted for his anti-Catholic bias, to say, ''Based on what we heard today, Kennedy is not a very good Catholic.'' ROBERT E. O'BRIEN Belmar, N.J.

title: Sneakers and Scunners
description: William Safire quotes Sally Quinn's goyishism ''to have a scunner on.''

title: State Is Faring Well
description: NEW JERSEY'S vast transformation from blue-collar manufacturing to the white-collar services, under way since the end of World War II, is now cemented in place. For the fifth straight year, unemployment is running below the national average. In August, the state's Labor Department reports, the rate was 4.7 percent, compared with the nation's 7 percent. For the year, the state's figure has averaged about 5.5 percent.

title: AFTER TWO LIVELY CAMPAIGNS, A MUTED RACE IN 3d DISTRICT
description: WHEN United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison read in the newspapers last summer that his likely Republican opponent had been a Democrat who voted for Walter F. Mondale in 1984, he dashed off a note to the Republican state chairman, Thomas J. D'Amore Jr. ''If the Republicans were interested in nominating someone with those characteristics, I thought there was a much more inexpensive solution, and I suggested that Tom D'Amore give me a call,'' Mr. Morrison said jokingly.

title: Army Stuns Tennessee, 25-21
description: Charles Williams blocked a punt with 35 seconds remaining and Reggie Fullwood picked the ball up for a 2-yard touchdown that gave Army (3-2) a 25-21 upset victory over Tennessee today.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should Hockey Deal With Fighting?
description: The people who advocate the abolition of fights by imposing stiffer penalties such as automatic ejections are missing the true problem in hockey violence. Dangerous stick penalties such as high-sticking and flagrant slashing that go unnoticed or ignored pose a much bigger threat to the game today. Fighting, in comparison, is a relatively harmless outlet of aggression only involving two players. Instead, the league should take steps to cut down on these incidents.

title: New Cassettes: Big Stars and Big Bands
description: The Best of Judy Garland RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 85 minutes. $29.95

title: SEEKING GAINS IN GOVERNORS' RACES
description: THERE are the elections that politicians here care about, and then there are the elections that the voters care about. In state after state, pulling levers and marking ''X'' 's for contests for House and Senate seats will be something many voters will do because they happen to be in the election booth. The reason they will be there, according to polltakers and politicians, is the governors' races.

title: BEIRUT CHRISTIANS PURGE OPPONENTS
description: A widespread purge of opponents of the main militia commander in Christian parts of Lebanon has been going on for the last two weeks, and 60 men have been killed so far, according to reports published in the press here.

title: ALSATIAN HAUTE CUISINE
description: What makes a great restaurant is hard work: so much work that no effort is visible at all.

title:
ART;
ABSTRACTION: 50 YEARS OF CHANGE
description: EARLY in 1936, a group of young abstract artists met at the Wooster Street studio of the sculptor Ibram Lassaw to discuss the prospects for promoting the dissemination and appreciation of their works.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE LIGHT IN THE PIAZZA, by Elizabeth Spencer. (Penguin, $6.95.) The three novellas in Elizabeth Spencer's collection are about Americans in Italy. ''This little book is a gem,'' The Times's reviewer, Orville Prescott, said of the title piece in 1960. Set in Florence, it is about a young American woman, mentally a child after an accident, who falls in love with an Italian. ''Its surface is so exquisitely polished that at first glance one might be tempted to dismiss it as slight and insubstantial,'' Mr. Prescott said, but ''the more one thinks about it the more subtle, suggestive and ironic it becomes.'' RECOLLECTIONS, by Colette. Translated by David Le Vay. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) Brought together here are two collections of sketches and memoirs, ''Journey for Myself'' and ''The Evening Star.'' The first cele-brates and sends up the fashions and fads of Parisian life; the second is Colette's musings on people, places and events. She approaches her subjects as mysteries in ''Journey for Myself,'' Nancy Hale wrote in these pages in 1972, ''and to tell the conclusions . . . she comes to . . . would be like giving away the secret of a mystery story.'' Reviewing ''The Evening Star'' for The Times in 1974, Anatole Broyard said that Colette ''writes like someone humming to herself, someone pleasantly insomniac, watching images and memories pass before her eyes.'' THE ASSAULT, by Harry Mulisch. Translated by Claire Nicolas White. (Pantheon, $6.95.) One winter night in 1945 on the outskirts of Haarlem, a Dutch policeman, a Nazi collaborator, is murdered in the street.

title: Plus For Accountants
description: RUBEN GOREWITZ, a Manhattan-based certified public accountant, wishes that the Internal Revenue Service would give lessons in forgetfulness. Changes in the tax bill are so sweeping, Mr. Gorewitz says, that even seasoned tax advisers such as he, with 30 years' experience, wish they could forget much of the tax law they have learned.

title: Soviet Bloc-Watcher Gives Americans a Scolding
description: George W. Hoffman's budget request for next year is due in the morning, and his entire staff of two people have called in with the flu.

title: Set Standards For Owners
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Cassettes: Big Stars and Big Bands
description: Blood Wedding Directed by Carlos Saura; choreographed by Antonio Gades, 1981 Cinematheque Collection 71 minutes. $59.95

title: Career Ends
description: TWO weeks after leading the University of New Mexico football team to victory and setting several school records in a game against San Diego State, Billy Rucker announced Friday that he was ending his career on the advice of his neurosurgeon. Rucker, a quarterback, was knocked unconscious and suffered a neck injury a week ago in a game against Hawaii, and briefly experienced paralysis of his right arm and leg.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Medal for Christopher Columbus
description: Although, the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's discovery of America is six years away, the tributes already have begun. The first major medal issued to date could well turn out to be one of the most significant. It is the latest in a series of annual issues by the Jewish-American Hall of Fame.

title: SAN SALVADOR QUAKE WRECKED 3 OUT OF 4 BIG HOSPITALS IN CITY
description: One of the worst problems created by the quake that hit El Salvador on Friday was the damage done to the city's major hospitals, officials here said.

title: Turmoil Ahead In Real Estate
description: IN MAY, when the Senate Finance Committee set forth its vision for the country's tax system, the real-estate industry appeared to panic.

title: CONCERT: MUTI AND WAGNER'S 'FLIEGENDE HOLLANDER'
description: Riccardo Muti likes to include concert performances of complete operas on his Philadelphia Orchestra subscription programs, a practice that seems to disconcert some members of the Academy of Music audience, those used to going home promptly at 10 P.M. They solve that problem by leaving at 10 anyway, but often as not, Mr. Muti's operatic efforts are good enough to stick around to the conclusion. That was the case tonight, when Mr. Muti's account of Wagner's ''Fliegende Hollander,'' heard in its three-act version with two intermissions, lasted until 11:10.

title: PARTIES WITH CAUSES
description: An Evening for P.A.L. Oct. 17 - The Police Athletic League operates 11 recreation centers in some of the city's poorer neighborhoods, providing services to about 50,000 children and young adults annually. The league is holding a benefit that starts with cocktails at 6 P.M. at the Tower Suite of the Time and Life Building follwed by the 8 P.M. performance of Liberace at Radio City Music Hall and ending with a dinner-dance at the Pierre. Tickets, $500, or $150 for cocktail party and concert, or $75 for concert alone, from 212-477-0830. Newport Party Oct. 17 - A ''Gatsby Returns'' party will be held at Rosecliff, the 85-year old mansion in Newport, R.I., designed by Stanford White, to benefit the Preservation Society of Newport County, which maintains eight of the gilded mansions in the resort. Guests are asked to wear period clothing from the 1920's to the mansion where ''The Great Gatsby'' was filmed in 1973. Tickets are $30 for society members, $40 for nonmembers, from 401-847-1000. New Center in Brooklyn Oct. 18 - The Park Slope section of Brooklyn represents one of the city's success stories in neighborhood revitalization, and the nearly completed Park Slope Neighborhood Center stands as an especially bright symbol of that transformation. Six community groups are soon to move into a renovated elementary school that had been vacant for years. From preschool children to the frail elderly, the center will offer a wide spectrum of services. To celebrate and to raise funds, the center will hold a benefit at the Montauk Club at 25 Eighth Avenue, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., followed by a dinner-dance.

title: LAWMAKERS GIVE OVERTIME A TRY
description: ''FOR 10 days,'' said House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., ''I've been trying to say goodbye.'' Mr. O'Neill, retiring from the House after 34 years, 10 of them as as Speaker, is not alone in hoping his chance will come this week, when the 99th Congress, trying now for Wednesday or Thursday, at long last and two weeks late, adjourns. Last week, disagreements with the White House over arms control and domestic programs kept the legislators off the campaign trail. The dispute over extending stopgap spending meant that yesterday, for the third time in the Reagan Administration, the Government ran out of operating money. But before Congress recessed for the weekend, the prevailing management principle was that work expands to fill the time available. Progress was made on a number of measures, including some thought abandoned. A partial scorecard follows.

title: IN ISRAEL, A CONFLUENCE OF STATE, TEMPLE AND GENDER ISSUES
description: EVERY so often in the history of a country issues of great moral or philosophical importance become focused on the simple action of a single person. For civil rights in America, Rosa Parks's refusal to give up her seat on the bus was one example. In Israel, such a case may be shaping up around an orthodox 35-year-old schoolteacher named Leah Shakdiel, who by getting elected to a local religious council that had never before admitted women is forcing the Israeli Government to define some delicate boundaries between synagogue and state, and between feminism and Jewish law.

title: New Conspiracy Charge - Aimed At LaRouche
description: After two of his adherents won nomination to state offices in the Illinois Democratic primary in March, Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. predicted a rising tide of support from voters who ''want me to stick it to Washington.'' Last week, Washington charged that Mr. LaRouche's extremist political movement had been doing the same to its donors.

title: WILLIAM M. TENDY, 71, DEPUTY IN FEDERAL PROSECUTOR'S OFFICE
description: William M. Tendy, deputy United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: New Cassettes: Big Stars and Big Bands
description: The Little Red Hen; Three Billy Goats Gruff Scholastic Blue Ribbon Vol. 1; Stuart Karl and Jan Startz,executive producers Karl/Lorimar 30 minutes. $14.95

title: 2 CENTS A WORD
description: IT SEEMS LIKE ONLY YESTERDAY Memoirs of Writing, Presidential Politics, and the Diplomatic Life. By John Bartlow Martin. 345 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Europe's Commemorative Issues
description: The Swiss postal service issued its latest definitive and special stamps on Sept. 9. The nation is introducing a new definitive series to replace the current folk customs set.The new stamps will be fed into the postal system as supplies of the folk customs stamps are exhausted.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FIVE years ago, New Jersey voters wrestled for the first time with the concept of ''riparian rights,'' an ancient principle of English common law declaring the state the owner of all lands that had ever been washed by tidal waters.

title: Regional Job Roundup: Northwest
description: RAND McNALLY'S rating of Seattle and its surrounding sea and mountain environment as the nation's number one tourist attraction bodes well for employment in tourism-related industries throughout the Pacific Northwest. Terrorism abroad has evidently been a catalyst for travel in the area.

title: NO-NEWS PACT APPEARS TO BE HOLDING
description: American and Soviet spokesmen accused each other today of minor violations of an agreement to withhold news of the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But neither side disclosed anything substantive.

title: Division in California . . .
description: The Senate campaign of Representative Ed Zschau, Republican of California, which has been running low on support from conservatives despite support from President Reagan, is getting a lift from Bruce Herschensohn, whom Mr. Zschau defeated in the primary, and some of his key supporters.

title: Lies Have Wings
description: Whose word can Americans still trust about what is happening in Nicaragua?

title: Michigan Defense Prevails
description: Jim Harbaugh, Michigan's versatile quarterback, lunged 1 yard for a touchdown and passed for two more to lead the undefeated Wolverines to a 27-6 victory over Michigan State today in a telling Big Ten match.

title: LOVE IS THE THEME ON MONTCLAIR STAGE
description: ROMULUS LINNEY'S ''Pops'' is six short plays all about love. The 90-minute evening at the Whole Theatre - the final performance is next Sunday - is an event.

title: Sneakers And Scunners
description: I've been subject to occasional ''sneakers,'' as defined by Sally Quinn, all my life (''That Secret Desire,'' by William Safire, On Language, Sept. 14).

title: Seeing Perelman Plain
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe Sounds Off
description: SOUNDING more like his old contentious self, John McEnroe expressed his displeasure with the United States Tennis Association president, J. Randolph Gregson, who has left McEnroe off the Davis Cup squad for the last two years.
