This year's Davis Cup team lost to Australia for the first time in 13 years, and McEnroe believes that flaws in Gregson's team selection philososphy had plenty to do with it.

title: Jets Rely On Second String
description: With a second-string quarterback taking the snap from the second-string center and handing off to the second-string running back, the Jets will try to hold onto first place today against the New England Patriots.

title: Art
description: Fifty years ago it was possible to buy a painting by John Martin for next to nothing. As for the books that he illustrated, they turned up on book-barrows all over England and often cost only pennies.

title: The Unfamous Mr. Braudy
description: To the Editor:

title: Flights to London
description: To the Editor: May I add to your advice concerning day or night flights to London (Q & A, Aug. 31)?

title: Nancy Kahn Wed To Gary Wilcox
description: The marriage of Nancy Virginia Kahn, the daughter of Virginia H. Kahn and Joseph Kahn Jr., both of White Plains, to Gary Robert Wilcox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Wilcox of Waterbury, Conn., took place yesterday at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Godley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Job Forecast: Sunny With Some Clouds
description: THE NUMBER of jobs in the nation continues to expand, and following this expansion has come widespread industrial growth. According to predictions by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, even moderate economic generation will increase the labor force 15 percent by 1995, to 129 million, from the current 111.6 million, including members of the armed forces serving in this country. Many observers say job growth will be substantial next year,though the manufacturing sector continues to lag and, the bureau says, slowdown in job growth is occurring in some service sectors. If present growth continues, the nation, with slightly less than 7 percent unemployed, will have 120 million jobs by the end of 1987. But the B.L.S. says that job growth will be slower in the remainder of this decade and the first half of the 1990's than in previous recent periods.

title: ANGLICANS KINDLE HOPE IN VAST ARCTIC DIOCESE
description: Not long ago, an imprisoned Eskimo who had killed a friend in a drunken rage resolved in his remorse to become an Anglican priest.

title: RENTAL-UNIT SHORTAGE EXPECTED TO WORSEN
description: IN Hartford, a company that is constructing an apartment building has received more than 1,000 inquiries for the 214 units, even though the building is not yet completed.

title:
NEW JERSEY REPORT;
The Japanese Way
description: SIMONE L. Kosuda says her seven years in accounting at the Nissan Foods U.S.A. Company in Fort Lee are evidence that she likes her employers. ''What is uniquely Japanese is that you feel part of a family much more than at American companies,'' said Ms. Kosuda, an American, who is the accounting manager.

title: Recent Sales
description: Freeport #190,000 66 West Second Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath 20-year-old colonial; two porches, eat-in kitchen, dining room, fireplace, waterfront; taxes $2,400. Nesconset $160,000 3 Atlas Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath 16-year-old colonial; den with fireplace, ceramic floors, new eat-in kitchen, stone fireplace; taxes $3,700.

title: Ithaca Reaches 4-0
description: George Mack returned the second-half kickoff 86 yards for a touchdown today to lead Ithaca past stubborn Springfield, 20-8.

title:
MUSIC;
HADDONFIELD AWAITS NEW MUSIC SEASON
description: THE 95-member Haddonfield Symphony, under its music director, Arthur Cohn, will open its 34th season Saturday with an all-Russian program.

title: Jessica Drury Becomes the Bride of I. Scott Bieler
description: Julia Jessica Boulton Drury, a daughter of the Rev. Eleanore Whitla Drury of New Haven and Felix Ralph Reinhold Drury of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to I. Scott Bieler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Bieler of Mahopac, N.Y. The Rev. Philip Zaeder, a United Church of Christ minister, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated at the ceremony at the New Haven Lawn Club.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL '86: OKLAHOMA-TEXAS;
Action, Cheering, and Then the Game
description: AT one time, it was described as a drunken brawl, when good ole boys drank whisky and rye through the night, hostilities often ensuing after some of them found courage in the bottom of a bottle.

title: SECURITY TO BE BOLSTERED IF METS WIN TODAY
description: If the Mets win the fourth game of the National League playoffs today, security for tomorrow's game - when the team could win the pennant and a World Series berth - will be strengthened, a city official said yesterday.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GHOST OF SANDBURG'S PHIZZOG. By Norbert Blei. (Ellis Press, $13.95.) Pritzker, the 63-year-old janitor of a Chicago building, sleeps in the boiler room with the wife of an elderly tenant.

title: YOUNG AMERICA TO CONQUISTAROSE
description: Conquistarose, a son of the recent stars Conquistador Cielo and De La Rose, made an exhilarating charge from last place to catch Damascus Drama in the final strides and win the $500,000 Young America Stakes for 2-year-olds tonight at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: C. Peyton Daniel 3d Weds Miss Bing in Pelham Manor
description: Lauren Jeanne Bing, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franz Josef Bing of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to C. Peyton Daniel 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Jr. of St. Louis. The Rev. Donald Morse performed the ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham Manor.

title: GOVERNMENT IS TOLD TO PAY $11 MILLION IN CRASH OF AIRLINER
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Government to pay half of $23.7 million in damages resulting from the crash of a World Airways jet in January 1982 in a landing in Boston.

title: An Imposed Ignorance
description: To the Editor:

title: BROTHERS' RIFT ON HOMOSEXUALITY REFLECTS A DIVISION IN ATLANTA
description: In childhood, they were two little boys who played and grew in the warmth of a large family of means on Long Island, boating on the Sound and picnicking with their sisters and parents in the woods. But little boys grow up.

title: BITTER BUT FUNNY, PERSICO QUESTIONS INFORMER
description: Carmine Persico, defending himself with derisive humor, has produced the highlight of a major Mafia trial by cross-examining the informer who betrayed him to the authorities.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAIL HELSINKI After an absence from American concert halls of more than three years, the Helsinki Philharmonic returns to these shores this season to make its presence felt - and on Long Island, at least, felt again and again. Under Okko Kamu's baton, the acclaimed orchestra begins its current United States tour in Brookville today at 3 P.M., opening the concert season at the C. W. Post Center's Tilles Center. It goes east to the Fine Arts Center at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on Saturday at 8 P.M. and then inaugurates the Bay Shore-Brightwaters Public Library Concert Series by playing at St. John the Baptist High School in West Islip next Sunday at 3 P.M. Although the programs vary, some elements are constant: Schubert's Symphony No. 8 (Unfinished) and works by Sibelius dominate. For ticket information about Tilles call 626-3100; Stony Brook, 246-5678, and West Islip, 665-4350.HOLIDAY FAIRS

title: IMPORTANCE OF VIENNA EXPLORED IN LECTURES AND THE CLASSROOM
description: THE current ''Vienna 1900'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art has sent strong reverberations through the county. Many residents with Viennese roots are rediscovering with others the role that turn-of-the-century Vienna played in the development of modern culture. Two lecture series have been planned to shed more light on the complex tapestry of art and thought that characterized this era.

title: IN LONDON, THE NATIONAL THEATER MARKS A STORMY DECADE
description: When Britain's National Theater was formally opened a decade ago, it was with plenty of razzmatazz: champagne, fireworks, trumpeters, everyone who was anyone in the audience, and a gigantic fiasco on stage. Indeed, the Queen herself was there, sitting unsmiling through a performance of Goldoni's ''Campiello,'' which the theater's director, Peter Hall, later confessed went very badly indeed. The actors were like men struggling through a nightmare. When he and his company celebrate the building's 10th anniversary later this month, it will be a very different occasion. Those who happen to be visiting one of the National's three constituent theaters will be offered a glass of wine and a slice of birthday cake in the foyer after the show - and that, more or less, will be that.

title: AT MERKIN HALL, 'FROM SHETL TO GOLDEN LAND'
description: ''SHOLOM ALEICHEM loved the poor Jews of Eastern Europe,'' Dr. Emanuel S. Goldsmith said the other day. ''In his stories, he portrayed them as poor, but cheerful, people who refused to let poverty degrade them. I think that all Jews look back fondly on some aspects of life in the small towns - or shtetls - of Eastern Europe. There was a sense of one's roots, of togetherness, of mutual aid among Jews. Of course, there was poverty as well, and a great deal of oppression. But there were many positive elements in that society, elements we long for today.''

title: Food Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Mixson Weds R. B. Lunt
description: Elizabeth Critchfield Mixson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Goodwin Mixson of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Browne Lunt, a son of Mrs. Robert Lunt and the late Mr. Lunt of Cape Elizabeth, Me. The Rev. Arthur Ross performed the ceremony at First Presbyterian Church in St. Petersburg.

title: STEPPING RIGHT INTO OLD CONTROVERSIES
description: WITH William H. Rehnquist newly installed as Chief Justice and Antonin Scalia popping tough questions at lawyers from his first day on the bench, the Supreme Court began its new term last week. And already the Justices are grappling with some old concepts that seem more elusive each time the Court confronts them.

title: WEST GERMAN LEADER ENDORSES BIG MISSILE CUT
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has spurned advice from the right wing of his own party and unequivocally endorsed a radical reduction of American medium-range nuclear weapons stationed in West Germany and other NATO countries.

title: SOME OLDER PESTICIDES YIELD A HARVEST OF UGLY SURPRISES
description: SINCE 1948, when it was approved for sale in the United States, dinoseb has been a mainstay of American agriculture.

title: IN NEW YORK EMBRACE: LEHIGH VALLEY
description: Metropolitan New York, in its farthest westward thrust so far, has crossed the Delaware, punched well into Pennsylvania and established a beachhead here in the Lehigh Valley.

title: GOUBEAUD SEEKS TO UNSEAT YOUNG IN ASSEMBLY CONTEST
description: WHEN Joseph G. Goubeaud Jr., a lawyer from Mount Vernon, won the Republican Party's nomination to run against the incumbent State Assemblyman Gregory P. Young, in the 88th Assembly District, he knew he faced ''a tough race.''

title: In the Israeli Government, a Changing of the Guard; PERES'S SUCCESSES
description: As Shimon Peres leaves office today, he looks back on two years of foreign and domestic triumphs marred by one disappointment.

title: Shrimp Shed Light On Digital Music
description: When German submarines haunted the seas in the early years of the last World War, the United States Navy had trouble locating their lairs. The search was hindered by a curious noise obscuring sonar signals, a kind of acoustic camouflage.

title: California Prospects
description: The City Hotel is a solidly built brick building that shows few signs that it is 130 years old and has survived two major fires. It has a balcony with a wrought-iron railing, and there is a wooden sidewalk in front of it. A stagecoach full of people is coming down the street, driven by a young woman in jeans. We park at the rear of the hotel and carry in our bags through the back door; cars are not allowed on Main Street or the streets intersecting it.

title: Notre Dame Beaten By Pitt's Late Kick
description: Jeff Van Horne, a freshman, made a 29-yard field goal with 1 minute 25 seconds to play today, and Notre Dame's John Carney missed a 44-yard attempt with 23 seconds left to allow Pitt to escape with a 10-9 upset.

title: SPANISH GALLEON'S TIMBERS MADE ACCESSIBLE
description: After 364 years under water, 40 timbers from the sunken 17th-century Spanish galleon Nuestra Senora de Atocha, each weighing 1,600 pounds, have been raised from a depth of 54 feet in the Gulf of Mexico.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
A Broker Goes the No-Commission Route
description: WHEN William Hayden decided to put his Lindenhurst home on the market recently, he wanted to price it competitively with other houses in his neighborhood that were not for sale through a broker.

title: RADIUM, VERNON AND MR. KEAN
description: AFTER narrowly squeaking into office for his first term as Governor, Tom Kean was returned to office last year in one of the greatest landslides in the state's history. But with both riveted on national office, he appears oblivious to a maelstrom back home that threatens to erase his popularity and credibility and destroy his dreams for bigger things in Washington.

title: THE BLUES OF EXPATRIATE PARIS: RECALLING AMERICA'S JAZZ EXILES
description: In the best sense of the term, Bertrand Tavernier's film '' 'Round Midnight'' is an exercise in ancestor worship. The character played by Dexter Gordon, himself a leading jazz saxophonist, is a composite of two of his stylistic forebears, the pianist Bud Powell and the saxophonist Lester Young. The film makes knowing references to such musicians as Herschel Evans and Coleman Hawkins, to such clubs as Birdland and the Blue Note, and even to the wife of the saxophonist Charlie Parker, whose name, Chan, is coyly given here to the character of Mr. Gordon's daughter.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday misidentified the baton twirler pictured on Page 1 of the Westcheester Weekly. She was Shelbi Rainey.

title: SERMONS FOR YOM KIPPUR: A RANGE OF THEMES
description: Rabbis in New York City have selected a variety of themes, from international brotherhood to man's relationship with God, for their sermons on Yom Kippur, which begins this evening at sundown.

title: God's Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics In Business
description: THIS YEAR'S highly publicized Wall Street scandal, centered on illegal trading activities by people privy to inside information, illustrated how human weakness can overcome ethical and legal strictures in a business setting. According to Dr. Paul Mok, a psychologist who has worked with large corporations directing employee seminars on values, expectations of ethical behavior are often overridden by pressure to cut costs, gain new business and increase profits. Dr. Mok, who as chairman of Training Associates of Dallas has such clients as Exxon, the International Business Machines Corporation, the General Electric Company, the Aluminum Company of America and SmithKline Beckman Corporation, recently responded to questions on the troubles employees and senior executives encounter in balancing the competitive demands of their jobs with ethical concerns.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ARCHITECTURE TALK/TOUR Marymount College has organized a comprehensive lecture-tour series on the architecture of Westchester, a program inspired by the state's Architectural Heritage Year. Each Saturday through Nov. 5, a talk will be given at the Tarrytown campus from 9:30 to 11:30 A.M., followed by a visit to relevant locations countywide from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M.

title: DESIGNER SHOWCASE IN GREEK REVIVAL HOUSE WILL BENEFIT HOSPITAL
description: ''EVERGREENS,'' a designer showcase on Colles Avenue, offers a visit to an early 19th-century summer dwelling.

title: Penn State Rallies Late, 23-17
description: David Clark, a senior tailback, ran 6 yards for a touchdown with 3 minutes 7 seconds left to rally fifth-ranked Penn State to a 23-17 victory today over Cincinnati, a 24-point underdog.

title: LYNNE BECKER TO WED
description: The engagement of Lynne Ellen Becker, a third-year medical student at the University of Pennsylvania, to Joseph Kossow of Washington, an artist, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Becker of Maplewood, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Kossow of Longboat Key, Fla., and Washington. Ms. Becker graduated magna cum laude from Bryn Mawr College. Mr. Kossow, a graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, recieved a Master of Fine Arts degree from American University.

title: PLAYWRIGHT'S ALLIANCE GROWS
description: SOMETIMES a regional theater forms a longterm alliance with a playwright, and the two become indelibly linked in a theatergoer's consciousness. Mention the Yale Repertory, for example, and Athol Fugard comes instantly to mind.

title:
DINING OUT;
STOREFRONT SURPRISE IN CHATHAM
description: THE simple hand-lettered sign with the name Fresh Fields Cafe surrounded by naively painted vegetables would lead one to think that the little storefront might be a health-food luncheonette.

title: PUTTING COSTLY GASOHOL OUT TO PASTURE
description: FOR motorists who disdained any radical change in their faithful internal combustion engines, gasohol seemed the perfect solution to the ''shortage'' of petroleum-based fuels a few years ago. Gasohol, a mixture of nine parts unleaded gasoline and one part alcohol, could power regular engines, usually without costly, complicated modifications. And the alcohol could be derived from corn, sugar beets, cane, wheat, potatoes, even weeds and other farmland debris.

title: Man of Few Words and Many Catches
description: IN professional wrestling, there is an event called the two-on-one ''handicap'' match.

title: CENTERS FOR DANCE IN COUNTY GROW
description: TWO dance-training centers opened in the county last month. One, in New Rochelle, is new. The other, in Ossining, is renewed. Both represent a cross of cultures, styles and influences.

title: One-Night Celtic
description: IT was a case of basketball court as movie set. Filming the movie ''Amazing Grace and Chuck'', in which he plays Amazing Grace Smith, Alex English, the all-star forward of the Denver Nuggets, put on a Celtics jersey and played for just over two minutes in the Celtics' 130-114 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in an exhibition game Friday night.

title: LIFE AND STEEL: A RIGGER'S TALE
description: THE MONKEY'S WRENCH By Primo Levi. Translated by William Weaver. 174 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.95.

title: APARTHEID ISSUE ROILS OSSINING
description: DURING the last few weeks officials of the town and village of Ossining have been confronting the issue of South Africa's apartheid policy instead of the zoning and budget questions that generally occupy their agendas.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED ON MARCOS'S SWISS MONEY
description: The head of a Philippine Government commission seeking to recover money once held by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos says the commission is about midway in its efforts to arrange the return to Manila of money believed held in a number of Swiss banks.

title: NEED FOR PIPELINE STILL UNPROVEN
description: As a lifetime resident of Litchfield County, I feel compelled to answer some unfortunate conclusions drawn in the letter published on Sept. 28, written by Ralph Leviton.

title: A Season That Fulfills the Aims Of Public Television
description: Television can do interesting things when it has to; public television can do some of the most interesting things of all. As it happens, public television is having a very interesting season, although, as is often the case in public television, our attention is deflected by other things. ''The Africans'' attracts attention because it is denounced by the National Endowment for the Humanities. A literacy campaign on public television attracts attention through its own self-promotion. At the same time, observers note, public television has no smashing new dramatic series. Where is this season's ''Jewel in the Crown''? Public television seems to be off to an abysmal year.

title: Selecting a Candidate
description: John Reilly and Tom Donilon two veterans of Walter F. Mondale's unsuccessful 1984 Presidential campaign, have already picked their horse for the 1988 race: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware. The two Washington lawyers have joined Mr. Biden's inner circle of advisers, which also includes David Doak, a Washington consultant who was a strategist for the successful gubernatorial campaigns of Charles S. Robb of Virginia in 1981 and Mark White of Texas in 1982; John Martilla, a Boston consultant who worked in Mr. Biden's first Senate campaign, and Patrick Caddell, the poll-taker.

title: SUSAN BEAUMONT LOWE
description: Susan Beaumont Lowe, the manager of corporate marketing at Harper & Row, the book publisher, died Friday at New York University Medical Center after a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE CHILDREN'S SUMMER WHEN MOTHERS WORK
description: Susan Bonnici's recent article [ ''Summer With the Children - Not as Planned,'' Opinion Page ] was a perfect illustration of what happens to families when mothers work full time out of the home.

title: Distinctive Plaids
description: JIMMY WALKER, a man with a zest for peaked lapels and homburgs, also seasoned his wardrobe with plaid suits. New York City's former mayor (1926-1932), walking the sartorial line between restraint and flamboyance, seemed to favor plaids for their individuality. He also knew how to tame them.

title: BERGEN VOTING FOR MORE THAN EXECUTIVE
description: VOTERS in Bergen County will do more than fill a new post when they vote for the county's first Executive on Nov. 4; they also will decide the shape and direction of the county government for years to come.

title: Regional Job Roundup: Mid-Atlantic
description: WHEN Robert J. Christian, director of economic research at PNC Financial Corporation in Philadelphia, is asked to give career advice to teen-agers, he tells them to work on improving their minds. ''If you can go to college, go,'' he says. ''If you can't go, get technical training.''

title: Riverdale Routs Poly Prep, 28-2
description: Robb Hirsch, a tailback, threw the first of Riverdale's two option passes resulting in touchdowns as the Indians (5-0) beat Poly Prep, 28-2, yesterday.

title: Confessions of a Stepmother
description: As a recent, full-time stepmother, I can relate to Delia Ephron's emotional roller coaster.

title: 2 STARS OFFERING STUDY OF GRAVITY
description: Astronomers in Europe and the United States have discovered what they believe is the spectacular aftermath of a collision of two stars, now locked in orbit far closer together than any pair of stars known.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music listing today in The Guide (section 2A) for the Light Opera of Manhattan is outdated. The company announced last Wednesday that it would cease operations after today's performance.

title: Headliners; Hello, Columbus
description: History does not fault Christopher Columbus for his profound confusion about where he was the morning of October 12, 1492. Historians may even be grateful for it, seeing as how so many of them have found gainful employment speculating on just what bit of beach Columbus first mistook for the Indies.

title: U.S.SAYS CONTRAS GET MORE SUPPLIES
description: Beginning about six months ago, the rebels fighting the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua began to receive significantly more arms and materiel, overcoming severe logistical problems that had frustrated delivery of supplies, according to Government officials.

title: Nancy Kauppi Is Wed To Peter Eliot Martin
description: Nancy Rae Kauppi and Peter Eliot Martin, 1982 graduates of Harvard College, were married yesterday at the Harvard/Epworth United Methodist Church in Cambridge, Mass., by the Rev. Edward L. Mark.

title: Those Killer Bills
description: SPEAKING OF MONEY, friend, when is the last time you paid your own hotel bill? With your own money, I mean. If, like me, you haven't done so for years, you are in for a shock when you go down to the cashier, say, ''My bill, please,'' and receive a document stating that you owe $128.58. And not for an entire week's stay, either.

title: JOFFREY STAGES ASHTON'S 'FILLE'
description: When the Joffrey Ballet opens its 30th anniversary season on Thursday at City Center, its proudest birthday present to itself and to the public will be unveiled - a production of Frederick Ashton's ''Fille Mal Gardee'' (''Unchaperoned Daughter''), one of the British choreographer's sunniest, funniest and most humane works.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT IS UNDER THE SOIL COUNTS, TOO
description: IF you ever had a houseplant that died for no apparent reason, this discussion is for you.

title: The Shifts In Service Contracts
description: UNTIL two or three years ago, most people who took out mortgage loans could be sure that the lenders that originated the loans would always handle the servicing.

title: BOXED SETS: POP MUSIC'S MELTING POT
description: Boxed sets of recordings, containing from three disks to more than 20, are high-status items for the record business, its equivalent of the glossy coffee-table art book. For years now, these sets have been reserved primarily for classical music in the European tradition, with a smaller number of sets devoted to big bands, jazz and show tunes. But recently, more American music has been finding its way into lavishly packaged boxed sets.

title: A Longtime Critic Prefers the Moderns Of the Past
description: Reading a new collection of essays by Walter Sorell, a veteran American dance critic, one risks being brought up short by a fervent and repeated assertion - namely that nothing less than the decline of Western civilization lies behind a decline in the quality of dance as an art form. What does one offer in retort? That the West has not declined? That dance has not declined either? Which reply is on firmer ground? Or can one stop and, after a minute's meditation, nod in quiet assent? A more immediate consideration might be more relevant. Critics - even more often than artists -have a tendency to identify with the period in which they discovered an art form and to favor the esthetics of those artists who took them deeper into the field as they first encountered it.

title: Souci Upton Wed To Alger Rollins
description: At the Bedford (N.H.) Presbyterian Church yesterday Sarah Bartlett Upton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Gordon Upton of Bedford and Darien, Conn., was married to Alger Rollins, a son of Mrs. Sherwood Rollins Jr. of Durham, N.H., and the late Mr. Rollins. The Rev. Ross Lilley performed the ceremony.

title: A MAN SAVED BY HIS SKILLS
description: ON the September Friday that I arrived in Turin - to renew a conversation with Primo Levi that we had begun one afternoon in London the spring before - I asked to be shown around the paint factory where he'd been employed as a research chemist and, afterwards, until retirement, as factory manager. Altogether the company employs 50 people, mainly chemists who work in the laboratories and skilled laborers on the floor of the plant. The production machinery, the row of storage tanks, the laboratory building, the finished product in man-sized containers ready to be shipped, the reprocessing facility that purifies the wastes - all of it is encompassed in four or five acres a seven-mile drive from Turin. The machines that are drying resin and blending varnish and pumping off pollutants are never really distressingly loud, the yard's acrid odor - the smell, Levi told me, that clung to his clothing for two years after his retirement - is by no means disgusting, and the skip loaded with the black sludgy residue of the antipolluting process isn't particularly unsightly. It is hardly the world's ugliest industrial environment, but a very long way, nonetheless, from those sentences suffused with mind that are the hallmark of Levi's autobiographical narratives. On the other hand, however far from the prose, it is clearly a place close to his heart; taking in what I could of the noise, the stench, the mosaic of pipes and vats and tanks and dials, I remembered Faussone, the skilled rigger in ''The Monkey's Wrench,'' saying to Levi - who calls Faussone ''my alter ego'' - ''I have to tell you, being around a work site is something I enjoy.''

title: DYLAN'S LIVES
description: NO DIRECTION HOME The Life and Music of Bob Dylan. By Robert Shelton. Illustrated. 573 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title:
FOCUS: Factory-Builts;
Sales Down In All Areas But the East
description: ALTHOUGH sales of manufactured houses, once known as mobile homes, have decreased in each of the last three years, they still account for almost a third of all sales of new single-family homes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AND THE VIOLINS STOPPED PLAYING: A STORY OF THE GYPSY HOLOCAUST. By Alexander Ramati. (Franklin Watts, $15.95.) This novel is based on the real-life experiences of a young Gypsy, Roman Mirga, who escaped from Auschwitz in 1944.

title: IRAQ DEFENSE SEEMS EQUAL TO THE TASK
description: Western military experts, who have seen only satellite photographs, say they believe Iraq's defenses along its 733-mile war front with Iran are an impressive feat of military engineering. At ground level, they are equally impressive.

title: ELM TREE A SYMBOL OF PRESERVATION FIGHT
description: As one of the early defenders of the elm, I was at first delighted to see the article on Sept. 21 [ ''Traffic Plan to Remove an Elm Tree Divides Ridgefield'' ] . Upon reading it, however, I was disappointed to discover that instead of being an interesting opinion piece, it was a rather tired rehash of previous interviews.

title: A QUEST FOR COMPROMISE
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded two of their three scheduled meetings here today, and the two sides seemed to be crystallizing areas of agreement on arms control, human rights and other issues. At the same time they seemed to be heading toward setting a date for a full summit meeting in the United States, some time next spring.

title: Individuality Rears Its Oh-So-Welcome Head
description: If you were a movie executive in today's high-concept Hollywood, where the one-sentence synopsis is everything, the story ideas that are currently afloat might be enough to make you think you were losing your mind. For example: ''A small-town boy finds a severed ear and embarks upon a search for its owner.'' ''An American girl and an English musician share some bad habits, and eventually he kills her.'' ''Three guys break out of jail and wander around.'' ''A thief seduces a married couple, finds he much prefers the husband and soon they're all wearing dresses.'' ''An American expatriate plays be-bop in Paris.'' ''A visitor studies the malls and lawnmowers in a tiny Texas town.'' Whatever happened to the kind of comedy-adventure-disco-flyboy-romance you could understand?

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE BIRD was crouched in a shallow depression just above the reach of the morning tide on the beach that linked the two towns.

title: Computers Tie for the Championship
description: The Fifth World Computer-Chess Championship, at the Cologne Trade Fair, was dominated by three American programs and one from Canada, all running on macroprocessors: Cray Blitz by Robert Hyatt, Al Gower and Harry Nelson of the University of Alabama, on a Cray XMP; Hitech by Hans Berliner of Carnegie Mellon University, on a VLSI-Sys; Bebe by Tony and Linda Scherzer of Hoffman Estates, Ill., on a Chess Engine, and Sun Phoenix by Jonathan Schaeffer of the University of Alberta, on a 20 Sun.

title: WORK UNITS SET UP
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev opened talks here today, and the Soviet leader told Mr. Reagan he would not set a date for a summit meeting in the United States unless prospects for signing a major arms control pact were high, a ranking Administration official said tonight.

title: Montclair State (5-0) Routs C.W. Post
description: Walter Briggs threw four touchdown passes, two to Tony Sweet, as undefeated Montclair State (5-0), ranked second in Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, crushed C. W. Post, 43-19, yesterday at Hickox Field in Brookville, L.I.

title: ...AND LEAVING BEHIND A LONELY GAP AT HOME
description: MY daughter just flew to Europe.

title: DRAG RACING: A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: BEHIND the stands at Raceway Park here each weekend, drag-racing enthusiasts watch their idols tune up their ''mean machines'' before roaring down the quarter-mile strip.

title: Tara FitzMaurice Is the Bride of David Doernberg
description: Tara Ann FitzMaurice, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. FitzMaurice of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to David Dudley Doernberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley D. Doernberg Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y. Judge Harold Tompkins, an acting State Supreme Court justice, officiated at the Explorers Club in Manhattan.

title: WOVEN IN ILLEGALLY, THEY'RE PART OF AMERICA'S FABRIC
description: WHEN school started last month in Brownsville, Tex., 900 new pupils enrolled. Just 35 of them said they had lived in the United States the year before; all the rest had been in Mexico.

title: California Board Rejects Mathematics Textbooks
description: The State Board of Education has rejected all math textbooks proposed for kindergarten through the eighth grade, a move that affects three million public school pupils in California and could have national repercussions.

title: INVESTORS LEAVING CONDO MARKET
description: AYEAR ago, Warren A. Estis had a half-dozen deals pending to buy blocks of condominiums under construction in Manhattan. Today, only two projects inspire the investor's confidence enough to draw him out.

title: CATHOLICS AT ODDS ON SCHOOL CLINICS
description: The Roman Catholic Church has begun a campaign to block a proposal for clinics in the Boston public schools that would dispense contraceptives as part of a general health care program for students. However, some Catholic community leaders and officeholders support the proposal and would like to see the church step aside.

title: WITH FUNDS STABILIZED, STATE IS EXPEDITING HIGHWAY WORK
description: THE highway reconstruction now under way across New Jersey may cause scattered delays for motorists, but officials say that the long-term payoff will be smooth riding on once-neglected thoroughfares.

title: KEY ADVISERS ON THE PRINCIPAL ISSUES
description: Arms Control Group Paul H. Nitze: Ambassador and special adviser to the President and the Secretary of State on arms control matters . . . 79 years old . . . Arms control negotiator and member of United States teams at talks that led to the first strategic arms pact in 1972 . . . Opposed ratification of 1979 arms treaty.

title: Syrians Accused Of El Al Bomb Role
description: Nezar Hindawi, the Jordanian accused of trying to blow up an El Al jumbo jet with 375 people aboard, was carrying an official Syrian passport and working with Syrian intelligence, a prosecutor told a London court last week. He said that Israeli security men found three and a half pounds of a Czechoslovakian plastic explosive in the false bottom of a bag being carried to the plane April 17 by an Irish woman who said Mr. Hindawi had packed it for her.

title: Pop Music
description: Chuck Berry is 60 this year, a sign one can only interpret as evidence that rock-and-roll has come of age. He is celebrating with a concert on Saturday at the Felt Forum, and the backing band that has been announced looks more than capable of fanning the flames on his birthday candles.

title: It Happened in Broad Daylight
description: HIGH above Shea Stadium, the legend still said: ''Baseball Like It Oughta Be,'' the same inscrutable message that has been on display all season.

title: IN CONGRESS, ARMS INPUT STOPS SHORT OF ICELAND
description: FRIDAY afternoon, Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. reached President Reagan in Iceland as he was preparing for his meeting with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. His message was that after weeks of wrangling, House and Senate negotiators had agreed on arms control provisions that were blocking Congressional adjournment.

title: READ A BOOK AND WRITE A LETTER
description: I HAVE lately begun to wonder about the extent to which writers would acknowledge what most readers have always been too polite or too timid to admit: namely, that the publication of a book is, as much as anything else, an act of prolonged rudeness. Human discourse is supposed to be two-way speech, but a book is a monologue, immune to interruption, cut off from the immediate response natural to conversation. Readers may sigh appreciatively, mutter discontentment, or even slam the cover shut, but the author hears none of it. His professional colleagues may respond in print, but what of the common reader whose curiosity, intelligence and pocketbook have always sustained authors? How does he make his editorial reply, turn the address into an exchange? He can write the author a letter. It ought to be a perfectly natural act. Holden Caulfield spoke some memorable good sense on the subject in ''The Catcher in the Rye'': ''What really knocks me out is a book that, when you're all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it.'' But most readers who feel the impulse let it subside, probably because they fear being intrusive or predict being rejected.

description: To the Editor:

title: SUFFOLK LAND PLAN DISPUTED
description: DESPITE the objections of Suffolk County's Comptroller, the Suffolk County Legislature is expected on Tuesday to pass a resolution authorizing a conservation group to negotiate for the county in purchasing several parcels of environmentally sensitive land.

title: Seeing Perelman Plain
description: To the Editor:

title: War? Peace? (No) Mets? (Yes!)
description: Some speeches in Congress concern war and peace. Some do not. Following are excerpts from a speech by Representative Alton R. Waldon Jr., Democrat of Queens, Oct. 9, 1986.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE is an art to making small talk with small fry, but I cannot claim to have mastered it. This is, I gather, an American problem because in Europe and Asia, where older civilizations long ago concluded that nothing was to be gained by such conversation with children, the kids were supposed to be introduced and then, with no dialogue, to be whisked offstage.

title: Rangers Lose to Penguins, 6-5
description: Doug Bodger scored 50 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 6-5 victory over the Rangers.

title: Susan Joan McGauley Weds Robert Murphy
description: Susan Joan McGauley, the daughter of Lawrence P. McGauley of Norwood, N.J., and the late Mrs. McGauley, and Robert Daniel Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Murphy of Highland Falls, N.Y., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Norwood by the Rev. Kenneth Moore and the Rev. Ignatius McPartland.

title: THE DANCE: 'CITADELLE' BY BRUNELLE
description: SINCE the 1950's Montreal has been a lively center for ballet. More recently, it has also developed its own modern-dance companies. One of the newest of them - Charles-Mathieu Dance, which was founded last year - made its New York debut Thursday night in ''Citadelle,'' a 50-minute work choreographed by its director, Charles-Mathieu Brunelle, with the artistic collaboration of Marie Brodeur.

title: DEBT COUNSELING MUSHROOMS
description: THE number of Connecticut residents looking for help in getting out of serious debt has almost tripled in the last three years, says Beverly E. Tuttle, executive director of the Consumer Credit Counseling office in the state.

title: U.S. WILL RESUME PACIFIC FISH TALKS
description: The United States and 16 Pacific nations are preparing for fishery talks whose outcome, negotiators say, will play an important role in determining American relations with this region.

title: 'MINIATURES', ONCE PETS OF ROYALTY, AGAIN GAIN POPULARITY
description: THOSE driving by a particularly pretty stretch of countryside in Bethlehem may do a double take when they get to a picturesque bend in Carmel Hill Road.

title: The Computers That Went Astray
description: The Soviet bloc may be behind in building its own computers, but it is highly skilled at diverting technology from abroad.

title: Wondering Where The Graffiti Went?
description: Anything else that was only half clean would still be considered pretty dirty, but last week's news from the New York City Transit Authority - that 3,026 of the T.A.'s 6,000 subway cars are being kept graffiti-free - brought cheers.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT IS UNDER THE SOIL COUNTS, TOO
description: IF you ever had a houseplant that died for no apparent reason, this discussion is for you.

title: Too Little, Too Late
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: McKinney, Silver
description: McKinney, Silver & Rockett of Raleigh, N.C., which is receiving the adulation of its peers for becoming the first ad agency in the Southeast to top $100 million in billings, has been named to handle an assignment for Del Monte, part of the vast RJR-Nabisco organization. The assignment is Del Monte Produce, in Miami, which nationally markets bananas, pineapples and papayas.

title: Fire Destroys A Warehouse
description: About 100 firefighters battled a three-alarm fire that destroyed an industrial building, fire officials said today.

title: Leo Burnett
description: Having realigned its domestic brand assignments on Sept. 30, Kraft Inc. last week did the same for its international operation.

title: BUSTING THE FUZZBUSTERS
description: Congress is abuzz, so to speak, over Representative James J. Howard's insistence that any legislation increasing the speed limit also outlaw motorists' use of devices to detect police radar.

title: JOAN RIVERS'S 'LATE SHOW' ENTERS TALK-SHOW FRAY
description: THERE she was, the star of ''The Late Show Starring Joan Rivers,'' applauding her studio audience eagerly with outstretched hands and, in turn, getting a standing ovation for the premiere of her very own talk show. ''So much has been said, so much has been written,'' she beamed, ''I am so happy to be here.'' Another standing, screaming ovation. This may have been the first hour in the history of television that begged for a stiff tranquilizer.

title: Claudia Lament Wed To Dennis L. Haseley
description: Claudia Eleanore Lament, the daughter of Dr. Marylee McMurray Lament of Cliffwood Beach, N.J., and the late Bernard J. Lament, was married yesterday to Dennis Lee Haseley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Haseley of Broadview Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Leonard Rust, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Bird and Bottle Inn in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Outdoors: Time to Call It Quits
description: THE BIBLE mentions neither the flyrod nor the shotgun, but the book of Ecclesiastes must have understood something about the sporting life when it says ''to everything there is a season.''

title: REPORT BACKS HUDSON AS WATER SOURCE
description: Supplementing New York City's water supply of 1.5 billion gallons a day with up to 300 million gallons from the Hudson River is feasible, an engineering study commissioned by the city has concluded.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a one-time charge of $834,000 to discontinue the Magnawave line of products. c-Net income and after a $702,000 one-time special charge to settle a suit.

title: AGENDA: OCT. 13, 1986
description: I.B.M. and Its Earnings I.B.M. will release its third-quarter earnings report, and Wall Street is braced for bad news. Last week the company warned that overseas business was not up to expectations, and the stock fell. The report is considered one barometer of the economy, and some analysts predict profits as low as $1.60 to $1,90 a share - compared with $2.40 a share in last year's third quarter.

title: Let's Address Our Taboos
description: A large chunk of the American political landscape is a no-man's land, filled with taboos and sacred cows where no elected leader dare tread. This no-man's land is one of the primary reasons that America's problems outpace its solutions. Our nation simply can't confront the issues because it can't seem to venture - or won't allow its leaders to venture - into this unchartedterritory.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an estimated loss on disposal of $1,735,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $871,000. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $111,000 and $707,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also includes an after- tax gain of $570,000 from the sale of land not used in operations.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AGGRESSIVE FUNDS GIVE JAPANESE MARKETS A LIFT
description: One of the driving forces behind Tokyo's growth as an international financial center has been the swelling of corporate profits and the increasing eagerness to invest those profits in the stock market.

title: TWIN CITIES MARATHON TO DONAKOWSKI
description: Bill Donakowski of Albany, Calif., won the Twin Cities Marathon today after surging at the 19-mile mark and finishing in 2 hours 10 minutes 40 seconds.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY SPOTLIGHT NOW SHINES ON CHIRON
description: In the rarefied world of biotechnology, the Chiron Corporation has always had the respect of its peers. Now, it is also starting to bask in the limelight long enjoyed by such older and larger competitors as Genentech Inc. and the Cetus Corporation.

title: China Reports Success In Orbiting a Satellite
description: China, which is preparing to enter the commercial space launching market, announced Saturday that it had successfully orbited its 19th satellite and retrieved it.

title: Gibson's Chief Finding Mixed Results for Cards
description: Greeting cards, Thomas M. Cooney insists, are the best business to be in. The product is used just once. There is no foreign competition. And every so often the Government enacts a new holiday that simply cries out for a new card.

title: Currie Cabot Is Wed to Thomas Barron
description: Currie Cabot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Cabot of Cold Spring, N.Y., and LaMalbaie, Quebec, was married yesterday to Thomas Archibald Barron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald G. Barron of Colorado Springs. The Rev. Charles W. Sheerin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel on Mount Murray Seigniory in LaMalbaie.

title: The Not-So-Novel Notions of a New Age; Fulfillers of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUE OR FALSE, AND WHO SAYS?
description: For many journalists who cover the White House, recent reports of a deception campaign by the Reagan Administration have prompted a mixture of anger at being intentionally misled and relief that the reports may give credence to their longstanding complaints of systematic manipulation by Government officials.

title: RECITAL: FORTUNATO SINGS LISZT
description: AT the outset of her appearance at the Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night, the mezzo-soprano D'Anna Fortunato announced that she was suffering from a cold but would sing anyway. More singers should catch her cold! Though she was surely uncomfortable and popped a lozenge into her mouth at every opportunity for a moment's rest, she performed beautifully. It may be that her voice would have had more lustre if she had been in the best of health, but it sounded just fine as it was and in nearly every instance seemed to do what she wanted it to.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL: HOW 'CORPSE' CAME BACK TO LIFE
description: Representative Dan Lungren recently described the immigration bill now pending in Congress as ''a corpse going to the morgue.'' But on the way, the California Republican said, ''a toe began to twitch,'' and lawmakers resuscitated the body.

title: Man Shoots 5 In Social Club
description: A man who was refused admittance to a Brooklyn social club early yesterday returned with a gun and began shooting, wounding five male patrons, one of them critically.

title: 11 Killed in Sri Lanka As Patrol Is Ambushed
description: Tamil rebels ambushed a security patrol today, killing three soldiers, and about eight guerrillas were killed by troops, a Government communique said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising Column of Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly described the type of business begun by Paul Chusid, former president of Grey Medical. He has established a consultancy firm on health care products.

title: PRIME MINISTER, ABOUT TO TURN OVER OFFICE, ACTED EFFECTIVELY ONLY ON CONSENSUS ISSUES
description: A close friend of Shimon Peres's was recently asked to sum up his performance as Prime Minister during the last 25 months.

title: VIEW FROM BULLPEN: MCDOWELL WAITS FOR A CHANCE
description: This is one man's day-to-day view of the National League Championship Series, seen primarily from the vantage point of the Mets' bullpen in the Astrodome and Shea Stadium.

title: IN PUBLISHING, THE NAME IS THE GAME
description: A GLANCE at yesterday's New York Times best-seller list shows that 7 of the top 15 nonfiction books were written by people best known for something other than writing. There are five autobiographies: ''Mayflower Madam,'' by Sydney Biddle Barrows, with William Novak; ''Snake'' by Ken Stabler, the retired Oakland Raiders quarterback, and Berry Stainback; ''I, Tina,'' by the singer Tina Turner, with Kurt Loder; ''McMahon!,'' by Jim McMahon, the quarterback for the Chicago Bears, with Bob Verdi; and ''And So It Goes,'' by Linda Ellerbee, the television commentator. The other two books are less memoirs than meditations: Bill Cosby on being a parent (''Fatherhood'') and the former Oakland Raiders coach John Madden (with Dave Anderson) on -what else? - football (''One Knee Equals Two Feet'').

title: Higher Fares? If There Are More Cabs.
description: Mayor Koch is asking the City Council to add 1,800 taxis to the 11,800 now permitted to cruise New York City streets. That's nothing new. Mr. Koch has floated plan after plan for expanding service, each of which has been brushed aside by a Council that marches only to the tune played by the taxi cartel. But this time the Mayor may prevail. He shrewdly insists that the Taxi and Limousine Commission postpone consideration of a fare increase until the Council acts.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

description: Iran appeared today to be starting a series of hit-and-run attacks against Iraq, possibly in preparation for a long-awaited major offensive.

title: THEATER: 'THE IMPOSTER,' AT PAN ASIAN REPERTORY
description: THE Pan Asian Repertory has opened its 10th season with a theatrical rarity from China, a contemporary comedy with political and social content. ''The Impostor (If I Were Real),'' written by a team of young Shanghai playwrights, Sha Yexin, Li Shoucheng and Yao Mingde, was considered controversial when it was produced in China - and one can readily understand why.

Those days are just memories now. Tokyo has become a vital international financial center, drawing on Japan's huge pools of capital and aided by easing of regulations.

description: Gale-force winds and rough seas interrupted close races at the America's Cup challenger trials today, and the long-awaited race between John Kolius of New York and Dennis Conner of San Diego was postponed until Monday.

Castle, the son of Joan Becker of Cos Cob, Conn., and Clifford D. Castle 3d of Fairfax, Va. title: I.R.A. Kills Policeman, Wounds 2, Police Say
description: Irish Republican Army guerrillas killed a policeman and wounded two civilians in a mortar attack on a police station in West Belfast, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday with an article about the Iceland summit incorrectly reported a question put to Nancy Reagan. She was asked if President Reagan referred to Mikhail S. Gorbachev in private as ''Gorby.'' She answered that he did not.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Radio's Rickles

description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL CLINICS ACROSS NATION DEFEND ROLE WITH TEEN-AGERS
description: An increasing number of schools around the country are looking beyond the school nurse's office in an effort to bring health care to low-income students and to combat teen-age pregnancy.

title: 3 Shop Employees Slain
description: Three workers were found shot Saturday at a cleaners' and formal wear rental shop.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ACROBATICS The Chinese have established themselves as masters of acrobatics, developing a talent for bounce and bound that has become one of their most prized and happily received exports. This evening at 7:30, a new group of athletic disrupters of gravitational theories arrives from Taiwan to perform at the Triplex I Theater, in the new complex of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, near the Hudson River (618-1980).

title: CUOMO AT HELM OF LUNDINE CAMPAIGN
description: Stan Lundine planted himself just outside the IRT stop at Broadway and 72d Street the other day, greeting the evening rush-hour crowd with a cheerful ''Hi, I'm Stan Lundine and I'm running for lieutenant governor.''

title: Lois, Pitts, Gershon
description: The National Enquirer, a weekly publication based in Lantana, Fla., that has a 4.5 million circulation, is switching its business to Lois, Pitts, Gershon, Pon/GGK. The ad budget, according to the agency, will exceed $20 million and will be to promote both circulation and advertising.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1986
description: The World The Iceland meeting failed after 11 hours of talks to reach an agreement on arms control or to set a date for full-fledged summit meeting in the United States. While officials said that tentative understandings were reached on most issues, a possible formal accord foundered over Soviet insistence that the United States restrain its program to develop a system of space-based missile defenses. Each leader blamed the other for the lack of results. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: SIGNS OF FALL IN MICHIGAN: FACES OF MAIZE OR GREEN
description: Fall unofficially began here this weekend with people painting themselves either green and white or maize and blue, finding new ways to heckle the enemy, and hurling rolls of toilet paper after each field goal and touchdown.

title: Bridge: Columnist and Cartoonist Collaborate on a 'Bestiary'
description: If you combine the talents of a major political columnist and a New Yorker cartoonist the result can be surprising.

title: Washington Watch; An Argument for I.R.S. Agents
description: Lawrence B. Gibbs, the new commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, adheres to the Reagan Administration position of no tax increases. But if the Congressional search for ways to reduce the deficit leads to a demand for new revenues, Mr. Gibbs said he figured that the I.R.S. could accommodate enough new enforcement and collection agents to raise a bundle in new revenues over a five-year period.

title: Greeks Vote in Local Races
description: Greeks voted today for mayors and city councils in what could be a major test of the Socialist Government's popularity. The police reported no incidents at polling places, which army units have guarded since Saturday, when a bomb exploded outside the Athens City Council office. Runoffs will be held next Sunday in those contests in which no one gets a majority today.

title: STICKING POINTS IN ICELAND
description: President Reagan and his aides came here with the expectation that Moscow was prepared to reach tentative agreements on medium-range missiles and other arms issues without first solving the problem of space-based defenses.

title: APARTMENT BUILDERS RETURN TO PREWAR DESIGN
description: A new generation of apartment buildings resembling the traditional, prewar structures of New York is being built in Manhattan, challenging the tall, thin apartment towers standing in plazas that have been typical of the last 25 years.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: HOW TO GET ACCEPTED AT YALE, IN 500 WORDS OR LESS
description: College admissions officers say the worst essays they read on college applications are self-absorbed recitals of high-school achievements: the what-I-learned-by-working-so-hard-a s-yearbook-editor essay, the I-went-to-Europe-and-learned-how-complex-the-world-is essay and the how-to-solve-world-hunger-and-all-the-other-world-problems essay.

title: Prospective Juror Excused
description: A dispute over public comments made by John Z. DeLorean, the former auto maker, about his Federal racketeering trial here widened Friday when a prospective juror was excused from the case after he said he was influenced by an interview Mr. DeLorean gave on a popular local radio show.

title: ON BEARS OLD SPANS AND SPEED
description: It is difficult for anyone to spend any time here these days without being exposed to an overwhelming amount of adulation and commercialization of the Chicago Bears, the champions of the National Football League.

title: EXECUTIVES SKEPTICAL ON TRADE
description: The heads of the nation's biggest corporations are not yet persuaded that the United States has finally succeeded in reversing its huge deficit in international trade.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Hal Mason, Animator, Dies; Created Famous Characters
description: Hal Mason, the creator of the Pillsbury Dough Boy, Mr. Clean and other animated commercial and entertainment characters, died of a heart ailment Friday. He was 69 years old.

title: Washington Watch; Supply-Side Socials
description: The corps of supply-side economists in Washington is still proliferating. An informal crowd of them has been meeting about once a month for about six months over beer and pizza at various locations, and it includes some relatively fresh faces that people are likely to see more of if their doctrine continues its fit-and-start progress toward general respectability.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LACK OF HELP ANGERS POOR IN EL SALVADOR
description: The people of this miserable warren of mud shacks have been promised by the Government that it will help them rebuild from the earthquake that swept away their homes and buried their loved ones on Friday morning.

title: Japan Chip Values Set
description: The Commerce Department assigned new fair market values over the weekend for chips made by Japanese semiconducter manufacturers that industry analysts and sources said are substantially lower than current minimum export prices for computer chips.

title: AUBURN HAS YET TO BE TESTED
description: There were enough upsets Saturday to cause a major shake-up in the lists of top 20 teams this week. Among the teams that lost unexpectedly and will drop several spots, or even completely out of the select group, were Arkansas, Southern California, Arizona, Baylor and North Carolina State.

title: TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the latest year includes a writedown of inventory, principally of equipment returned from rental and a recalculation resulting in an assessment for additional state corporate taxes and interest, all of which amounted to approximately $700,000. The company also said the latest year includes net depreciation of a large scale IBM computer amounting to about $350,000.

title: DANCE: FELD COMPANY IN 'SKARA BRAE' PREMIERE
description: THE premiere of Eliot Feld's ''Skara Brae'' at the Joyce Theater Saturday night was accompanied by a program note in which the choreographer explains why he originally called the ballet ''Nero's Fiddle'' and then changed his mind.

title: Levine, Huntley
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has become the agency for Maidenform Inc., the country's largest private manufacturer of intimate apparel for women ''who dare to dream.'' The account, which should bill about $6 million, was at Wyse Advertising for three years.

title: Cheryl Lilley, a Designer, Wed to Timothy Shea
description: Cheryl Anne Lilley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Lilley of Tenafly, N.J., and Timothy Edson Shea, a son of Dorothy Jayne Pedrini Shea of Santa Barbara and Lake Arrowhead, Calif., and Edward Stuart Shea of Palm Springs, Calif., were married yesterday at the Old South Church in Boston. The Rev. Ross Warren Lilley, the bride's brother and a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Pianist Idil Biret In Franz Liszt Program
description: At its least effective, Franz Liszt's music reminds this listener of an orator who finds many brilliant and virtuosic methods to clear his throat, but never quite gets to his speech. This thought came back to haunt Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, as the pianist Idil Biret played a program entitled ''The Legacy of Franz Liszt.''

title: Peter Corey on Guitar At Merkin Concert Hall
description: Peter Corey's guitar recital at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night looked at first to have a dual nature, being about both a performer and a composer. But listening to Mr. Corey's Preludes at the center of this program, one began to realize that the two components were really part of a single process.

title: Market Place; I.B.M. Rebound May Be Slow
description: CAPPING last Tuesday's introduction of a new series of small mainframe computers, the International Business Machines Corporation announced that its previously strong overseas sales were ''beginning to moderate,'' and analysts rushed to lower their already depressed earnings estimates for the company.

title: Town's Time Capsule May Be All-Time Loss
description: When Wilkinsburg's time capsule was buried in 1962, the precise location was such a closely held secret that today no one today seems to know where it is.

title: Lady's Secret, 1-20, Pressed in Victory
description: Lady's Secret won the Beldame Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday as expected, but with little of the style and authority that have stamped her as one of the greatest fillies in the history of the sport.

title: MUSIC: 'VAGABOND KING'
description: FOR what may prove to be the last time, the three tuxedoed men in the Light Opera of Manhattan's abbreviated orchestra walked onto the stage of the Cherry Lane Theater yesterday afternoon and struck up the overture to Rudolf Friml's ''Vagabond King.'' The performance that followed had the same qualities that had long typified the troupe's presentations: youth, energy and a certain giddy grace. Despite circumstances that were downright funereal, the show went on - the actors loved and clowned, the plot twisted and tangled, Friml's syncopated melodies filled the tiny house and, during the most popular selections, one could just make out the voices of the audience members, humming along in gentle descant.

title: Action Urged On People Deal
description: The Justice Department has urged quick approval of Texas Air Corporation's acquisition of People Express Inc., suggesting that Government delay might ''force People into bankruptcy and even scuttle'' the deal.

title: QUEEN FULFILLS A ROYAL GOAL: TO VISIT CHINA
description: As Elizabeth II touched her right foot to the ground here this evening, she became the first British sovereign to enter China.

title: B. Dalton's Top Officer Expects Happy Ending
description: When the Dayton Hudson Corporation sells its B. Dalton Bookseller chain, Sherman A. Swenson, the chain's chairman and chief executive with 28 years of experience at Dayton Hudson, would like to go with it.

title: 6 TEXAS REPUBLICANS HOPE TO SHOW THEY'RE NO FLUKE
description: When Texas sent six freshmen Republican Congressmen to Washington in 1984, it was an unprecedented political change for a state that has historically provided the House with powerful Democratic contingents.

title: CLAUSEN'S WORK CUT OUT FOR HIM
description: Everyone agrees that A. W. (Tom) Clausen has a big job ahead of him as leader of the BankAmerica Corporation - responsibilities he relinquished more than five years ago to become president of the World Bank.

title: Berger a Winner; Title Undecided
description: Gerhard Berger of Austria won today's Mexican Grand Prix, as Nigel Mansell of Great Britain failed to clinch the world driver's championship.

title: REAGAN-GORBACHEV TALKS END IN STALEMATE AS U.S. REJECTS DEMAND TO CURB 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended two days of talks here today with no agreement on arms control and no date for a full-fledged summit meeting in the United States.

title: Britain Is Deporting 6 Terrorism Suspects
description: Six terrorism suspects are being deported from Britain, Scotland Yard reported Saturday night.

title: STRAUSS PARTY IS WINNER IN ELECTIONS IN BAVARIA
description: Franz Josef Strauss's conservative Christian Social Union, which has governed Bavaria for 24 years, retained a solid majority today in state parliamentary elections that are seen as an important barometer to the January national vote.

title: Fumes Kill 2 and Sicken 5
description: Unidentified fumes in a manhole at a lumber mill killed two men and sickened five others Friday.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the results for 1985 are restated to reflect the acquisition of Santiago Corp.

title: EDITORS PROTEST TO WHITE HOUSE
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors has sent a telegram to President Reagan to protest the use of what it calls ''disinformation'' tactics to mislead the American public about United States policy.

title: Corporate Offering Would Set Record
description: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the weekly sale of $14 billion worth of new three- and six-month bills. However, the auction, normally held on a Monday, will be postponed a day this week, because of the Columbus Day holiday.

title: ADMINISTRATION TO DRAFT RULES FOR NURSING HOMES
description: After trying for five years to reduce Federal regulation of nursing homes, the Reagan Administration has reversed itself and plans to impose new rules to protect patients' rights.

title: DISCORD ERUPTS OVER VOW OF SILENCE
description: The agreement by Soviet and American officials to withhold disclosures about the summit conference produced an argument between the two delegations today, and between President Reagan's spokesman and reporters covering the meeting here.

title: Bowled Over
description: Football can be hazardous to your health, not only for those who block and tackle but also, it turns out, for those who lie and watch.

title: ARMS ISSUES OVERSHADOWED QUESTION OF RIGHTS IN SOVIET
description: The human rights issue played a secondary role in the meetings here, and officials indicated that the cause of Soviet Jewish emigration had received a setback because of the inability of the two sides to reach an arms control agreement.

title: Mother Teresa at Nuns' Vows After Plane Crash in Tanzania
description: Mother Teresa flew to western Tanzania today after emerging unscathed from a plane crash that killed five people.

title: QUAKE TOLL RISES TO 890, DUARTE SAYS
description: The death toll from a strong earthquake two days ago has risen to 890 and some stricken areas have still not been reached to search for victims, President Jose Napoleon Duarte said late tonight.

title: REMARKS BY REAGAN AND GORBACHEV AFTER REYKJAVIK TALKS: MR. GORBACHEV
description: Following are excerpts from the statement by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, at his news conference today, as translated by Mr. Gorbachev's interpreter:

title: RICO Is in Dire Need Of One Key Change
description: To the Editor:

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net income

title: INSIDE
description: The Pill: A New Kind A drug may soon be available in France that both blocks and terminates pregnancy, a World Health Organization official said.

title: HANDLING CRISES, BIG OR LITTLE
description: EVERYONE has faced them, life's emergencies both little and large: the new puppy chews a hole in the equally new rug; a long-awaited job transfer comes through, but you have a mere two weeks to pack up and move to a city 500 miles away; a child gets burned, proving the saucepan was just as hot as you said it was.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss from debt retirement costs of $1,361,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,466,000 and $4,594,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Norm Cash, 51, Is Found Dead
description: Norm Cash, a first baseman for the Detroit Tigers for 15 years and the American League batting champion in 1961, apparently drowned today while boating on northern Lake Michigan, authorities said.

title: Reagan-Gorbachev Talks End in Stalement as U.S. Rejects Demand to Curb Star Wars
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 12  President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended two days of talks here today with no agreement on arms control and no date for a full-fledged summit meeting in the United States.

title: The Reasons for Lying
description: There is a wonderful absurdity in the Reagan Administration's effort to distance itself from the C-123 cargo plane shot down in Nicaragua while carrying weapons to the contras. The performance brings back happy memories of Richard Nixon's flights of Watergate deniability.

title: Winning Friends, Pt. 2
description: ''They never go back to Pocatello'' is the way Washingtonians describe the life-after-Congress of most former Senators and Representatives. In the case of William M. Brodhead, the rule might be amended to read: ''They never go back for long.''

title: Dr. T. T. Higgins And Ms. Reichley Exchange Vows
description: Nancy Ellen Reichley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Reichley of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Timothy Taylor Higgins, the son of Dr. and Mrs. George F. Higgins of Presque Isle, Me. Bishop George N. Hunt 3d of the Episcopal Diocese of Providence performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church in Providence.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: EPSILON DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Onward and Upward
description: The Democratic Leadership Council, which generally favors a more centrist position for the party, will be traveling first-class when a team of its leaders takes off tomorrow for a three-day tour that will include forums in Tampa, St. Louis, Denver and Pittsburgh. The group, which includes at least three potential 1988 Democratic Presidential contenders, will be riding a 737 jetliner chartered from Presidential Airways, a mode of transportation to which the Democratic National Committee and individual party candidates have yet to ascend.

title: AL ULLMAN, FORMER CONGRESSMAN, DIES AT 72
description: Former Representative Al Ullman of Oregon, who served 24 years in Congress, including six years as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, died of cancer Saturday. He was 72 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: CONTRACEPTIVES' PRESENCE IN SCHOOLS CREATES A DISPUTE AMONG EDUCATORS
description: At nine New York City high schools over the past two years, state-financed health clinics have provided health care to low-income students, including birth-control counseling.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TEAMSTERS BOLSTER CAMPAIGN COFFERS
description: In a major strategic shift for the nation's largest labor union, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has made raising funds for political campaigns a top priority to bolster its influence.

title: BACK IN THE TOP JOB: ALEN WINSHIP CLAUSEN
description: A. W. (Tom) Clausen became president and chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation and its Bank of America subsidiary in 1970 at the age of 47. At the time he said he had no intention of staying in the job until he reached retirement age.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 15.

title: Relief Airlift Is Begun To Feed South Sudan
description: Two chartered aircraft left Khartoum today to start a delayed airlift of relief supplies for the southern Sudan, the official Sudan News Agency reported.

title: The '88 Campaign Begins
description: When Mr. Reagan too generously offered a 10-year delay in the deployment of our defense shield, in return for deep reductions in both sides' offensive missiles, Mr. Gorbachev demanded much more: the effective abandonment of our defensive strategy. The U.S. President was forced to refuse, and the summit collapsed.

title: RAISING SUNKEN SOVIET SUB: FOR U.S., THERE WOULD BE PRECEDENTS
description: Officially, Washington has expressed no interest in the intelligence value of the Soviet nuclear submarine that sank in the North Atlantic last week. But in the past the United States has gone to great lengths to examine Soviet vessels and equipment lost at sea.

title: GORBACHEV ANGRILY ACCUSES REAGAN OF SCUTTLING AN ACCORD AT REYKJAVIK
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that by insisting on development of ''Star Wars'' weapons, President Reagan ''scuttled'' a series of broad arms control agreements reached by the two men at their meetings here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1986
description: Companies

title: People
description: * Anthony R. Brescia, David Cantor, Alex Carlin and George Miller elected senior vice presidents at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

title: Truly a Sports Hero
description: It has been 50 years since a Korean marathoner named Sohn Kee Chung captured the gold medal at the Berlin Olympics. Even now, Sohn says, he can feel the ''jubilation and agony'' of that moment. His agony was that he had to climb onto the victory stand with the flag of Japan emblazoned on his jersey. His country was then under Japanese colonial rule. The anthem played in the Berlin stadium was Japan's. The name that went into the record books was the Japanese version that had been forced on him, Kitei Son.

title: KATE B. McKAY
description: Kate B. McKay, a copyright reference librarian at New York University Law School, died yesterday of a heart attack while visiting Cambridge, England. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Man Is Slain On L.I. Street
description: A man who shouted at a passing car to slow down was shot and killed on a street here tonight when the car stopped and backed up and one of its occupants fired at him, the Nassau County police reported.

title: Swallow the Toxic Smorgasbord
description: The President's advisers are at sixes and sevens on whether he should sign the $9 billion Superfund bill for cleaning up dumps of poisonous chemical waste. James Miller, the budget director, derides the bill as a ''smorgasbord of new taxes.'' But the Senate passed it, 88 to 8. Even the Chemical Manufacturers Association supports it, though the bill will add $1 billion to its members' taxes. However hard it may be for him to swallow, the bill also deserves the President's approval.

title: CONCERN ABOUT YOUTHS IN ADULT JAILS
description: More than two years ago, Kathy Robbins, a 15-year-old who had been charged with running away from home, committed suicide in a county jail in her hometown of Willows, 75 miles north of Sacramento.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Capital, a Washington venture capital company, has elected Clyde D. Garrett 2d and Jonathan J. Ledecky senior vice presidents.

title: G.M.-BACKED ISSUE IN DEMAND
description: The First Boston Corporation has increased a planned offering of debt securities backed by General Motors Corporation automobile loans, to $4 billion, from $3.2 billion. That would make it equal to the largest nongovernmental underwriting ever made.

title: LIMOS BECOME A COMMON LUXURY
description: LIMOUSINES, once the preserve of the ultra-rich, are everywhere these days, it seems, double-parked on crowded streets or inching forward in traffic. And they are carrying a varied breed.

title: TENACE THEORY OF HEROICS
description: KEITH HERNANDEZ remembers a talk he had with his teammate, Gene Tenace, as the St. Louis Cardinals prepared for the 1982 World Series.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 13, 1986: MONDAY Dana Corp United Technologies PSA Inc TUESDAY AAR Corp Procter & Gamble Bemis Co Inc Teco Energy Diversified Energies Weyerhaeuser Co Equitable Resources Inc Xerox Corp Learonal Inc WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Dow Jones & Co Artra Group Dun & Bradstreet Bally Mfg Corp Fleming Cos Calfed Inc Hillebrand Indus Chase Manhattan Intl Minerals & Chem Clorox (The) Co Mortgage & Rlty Tr Columbia Gas Sys Winsconsin Pwr & Lt Conrac Corp THURSDAY Archer-Daniels-Midland Kimberly-Clarke Black & Decker Corp Kollmorgen Corp Bundy Corp Owens-Corning Fiberglas Central&SouthWest Corp RJR Nabisco Inc Cincinnati Gas & Elec Sherwin-Williams Diamond Shamrock Springs Industries DiamondShamrock Offsh Sundstrand Corp Energen Corp Thomas Industries Gillette Co Twin Disc Grumman Corp FRIDAY Acme Elec Kaufman & Broad Inc Flowers Indus McNeil Corp Illinois Tool Works Univar Corp

title: City Opera Performs 1st 'Traviata' of Season
description: The main interest in the New York City Opera's first ''Traviata'' of the season Friday night was a new Violetta, Karen Huffstodt. In size, timbre and character of voice, Miss Huffstodt is well suited to the part, but she gave the impression Friday of being not yet ready to carry it off in demanding circumstances. Her tone carried a hectic-sounding quaver that may be attributable to nerves (though it did not go away as the evening went on), and she finished most of her phrases with a kind of gasp that did not bespeak ease. Perhaps in compensation, she threw herself recklessly at every opportunity for dramatic accentuation; Violetta seemed always in extremis, and it was hard to get to know her. The ringing high C's in Act I were the most enjoyable moments, and future performances may well find her in fuller command.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $145,000 and $356,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $20,000.

title: Pretoria Is Condemned By 7 African Nations
description: Political and military leaders of seven African nations held a special one-day security meeting today in Mozambique's capital, Maputo. They issued a statement condemning what they called South African aggression against Mozambique and accusing Pretoria of planning to invade that country.

title: WASHINGTON AREA SAID TO OFFER BEST JOB OPTIONS FOR WOMEN
