description: Women make up almost half the work force in the Washington area and have the greatest employment opportunities and the highest incomes of working women in any city in the United States, a regional research group concluded today.

title: REVLON TO PAY FOR POLLUTION STUDY IN PUERTO RICO
description: Revlon, the New York-based cosmetics company, will pay for the most comprehensive study yet of a mercury-polluted creek that runs alongside a housing development evacuated early last year, the United States Environmental Protection Agency has announced.

title: WALKER HELPS COWBOYS ROUT REDSKINS
description: A rush of anticipation spread around Texas Stadium every time Herschel Walker trotted onto the field today, a type of verbal wave. Tony Dorsett once stirred the masses like this, a threat to burst through the line for a touchdown on every play, like a cork popping on a bottle of champagne.

title: Washington Watch; New Approach At the F.E.R.C.
description: MARTHA O. HESSE seems determined to make her presence felt as the new chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. In her first day at work last Wednesday, Ms. Hesse filled three key positions, decided on an agenda for this week's meeting of the commission, had her four fellow commissioners in for lunch and conducted a news conference.

title: Schooling in Contraception
description: Last week the Board of Education announced that nine New York City high schools had programs that dispensed contraceptives either in school or at affiliated clinics. So do 53 other high schools throughout the United States. Those 62 schools include family planning among their health services because they are making an effort to lower the third highest level of early adolescent childbearing in the developed world.

title: L.I. BAYMEN FACE TOUGHEST WINTER
description: After several years of hardship and turmoil, the baymen of eastern Long Island are facing their toughest season in decades - a season that could signal the end of a 300-year-old fishing culture.

title: GOVERNMENT REPORT CITES LAXNESS IN INSPECTIONS BY CUSTOMS SERVICE
description: Inspections of incoming cargo at New York City ports by the United States Customs Service are ''superficial'' and fail to enforce trade laws adequately, according to a new General Accounting Office report.

title: A Loophole in U.S. Sanctions Against Pretoria
description: However irritated it may be by the new American sanctions legislation, the South African Government must be relieved that active American assistance in the gathering of intelligence on the black opposition is now specifically protected by law.

title: Labor Force Rates Differ
description: White, black and Hispanic men, aged 55 to 64, have different labor force participation rates. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, for white men in that age group, the rate dropped to 69 percent last year, from 79 percent in 1973.

title: Account
description: * Baltimore Metro Cadillac Dealer Marketing Association to Sawdon & Bess.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS BY SHULTZ AT THE NEWS CONFERENCE IN REYKJAVIK
description: Following is the opening statement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz at his news conference yesterday in Reykjavik, Iceland, and excerpts from the questions and answers, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: FOR KING, A TIME TO WATCH AND WAIT
description: Bernard King has had plenty of time recently to read. So he has devoured mysteries, and for good measure he added a book chronicling one family's rise and fall on Wall Street. This is not to say that the once-explosive forward is contemplating a future in the options market. ''Right now,'' King said, ''I'm looking to conserve and preserve.''

title: BANKAMERICA RECALLING CLAUSEN, GONE 5 YEARS, AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The board of directors of the troubled BankAmerica Corporation, in a special meeting today, named A. W. Clausen, former president of the World Bank, to resume the helm of the banking company he once led.

title: BRAZILIANS HIGH AND LOW MOURN A CULT PRIESTESS
description: They had kept going all night and, at dawn, women in white lace and cotton were still chanting and moving in a slow dance. The men, crouched on the temple floor, tapped a soft sad rhythm on hollow gourds. But the drums remained silent.

title: Viacom Investor Puzzles Wall St.
description: When Sumner M. Redstone bought his original stake in Viacom International, the diversified entertainment company, analysts who had long followed his dealings were not surprised. Mr. Redstone, who owns one of the largest private movie theater circuits in the country, has built a fortune not only through his theater chain but also by buying stakes in major media companies - often prior to their sale.

title: CONNECTICUT SENATE RACE HEATS UP IN FINAL DAYS
description: ''I have a big advantage in this campaign, believe it or not,'' Roger W. Eddy, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, was saying. ''Since I'm perceived to be an underdog, I can say what I believe.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HAPLESS K.G.B. MAN IS BRIEFLY STRANDED
description: Raisa Gorbachev's crack K.G.B. team misplaced one of its men today.

title: Truck Driver Shot in Theft
description: The state police are looking for suspects who in separate incidents on Interstate 95 robbed two truck drivers, one of whom was shot in the head.

title: STATUE IN NEW LONDON TO HONOR EUGENE O'NEILL
description: A bronze statue of Eugene O'Neill as a boy will be erected in the harbor of New London, Conn., as part of a celebration being planned for the 100th anniversary of the playwright's birth, city officials have announced.

title: SERIES TIED, 2-2
description: Mike Scott of the Houston Astros mastered, mystified and bamboozled the Mets one more time last night, firing his split-fingered fastball at them, overpowering them on three hits, beating them for the second time in four days and tying them at two games apiece in the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: ASHBY'S 2D CHANCE IS METS' UNDOING
description: As the foul pop fly drifted toward the seats behind third base, the capacity crowd at Shea Stadium sensed the end of the Houston half of the second inning and another opportunity for the Mets to try to solve Mike Scott.

title: H.H.C.C. Puts Stock Sale Off
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus of Boston, New England's largest agency, has deferred ''indefinitely'' its plans to go public.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Have any players hit home runs in the World Series for both National and American League teams?

title: THE EISENHOWERS: 2 WRITERS LOOK AHEAD
description: It was Sunday in the suburbs. David Eisenhower, back from a trip to the post office, was pulling up to his front door in a lumbering, wood-paneled station wagon with a toddler's seat in back. Inside the brick house surrounded by woods at the end of a long, secluded driveway, his wife, Julie Nixon Eisenhower, was bringing cookies and coffee into the living room.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page map caption in some copies on Thursday, with an article about Columbus's first voyage to the New World, incorrectly described the sequence in which an island in the Bahamas was named. It was originally San Salvador, later renamed Watling Island.

title: Boxer Is Winner
description: Ch. Turo's Cachet, a boxer owned by Leonard and Susan Magowitz of New York was named best of 1,545 dogs today at the 25th all-breed show of the Ramapo Kennel Club on the grounds of the Ramapo College of New Jersey.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the year-ago periods include a reserve of $2,516,000 for relocation costs.

title: SCIENTISTS DEVELOPING A NEW DRUG THAT BLOCKS AND HALTS PREGNANCY
description: Within a year, a drug should become available in France for use under physicians' supervision that both blocks and terminates pregnancy, according to a World Health Organization official.

title: COMEDY FINDS A NEW NICHE IN CABLE
description: As she paced back and forth before an expectant nightclub audience, Elayne Boosler measured the cadence of her one-liners about rites of passage with pauses between bursts of laughter.

title: JETS STOP PATRIOTS' LATE BID
description: The Jets, perfect in the first half, faltered in the third period but held on to defeat the New England Patriots, 31-24, today at Sullivan Stadium.

title: Dolphins End Slide
description: The much-maligned Miami Dolphin defense forced four turnovers today to spark a 27-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills that ended Miami's three-game losing streak.

title: Gramm-Rudman: A Sham
description: The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law has become a sham. Sooner or later, Americans will discover that the legislation that was supposed to halt the spiraling Federal budget deficit is merely covering it up. When they do, they are likely to be angry. They should be.

title: PROGRAM TEACHES BOSTON STUDENTS TO AVOID VIOLENT INCIDENTS
description: The question seemed to have surprised the teen-agers in the classroom at Jeremiah E. Burke High School: ''How many of you get really angry - angry enough to fight?'' Slowly the hands rose until every student, male and female, husky and frail, had answered in the affirmative.

title: Sarah Childress Wed To Stephen G. Ekern
description: Sarah Lee Childress, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Brooks Childress of South Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Godfrey Ekern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Ekern of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Edward Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: Floods Cut Railroad in Alaska
description: Rain-swollen rivers rose throughout south-central Alaska Saturday, isolating towns and settlements and cutting sections of the 500-mile Alaska Railroad, a major supply line to the interior.

title: CHARLES E. COOK
description: Charles E. Cook, chairman of the board and co-founder of the Community Bank in Los Angeles, died Thursday at Huntington Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Panel Completes Work On Philippine Charter
description: A commission today approved the final draft of a constitution that would give President Corazon C. Aquino a six-year term, set legislative elections for May 1987 and include safeguards against authoritarian rule.

title: COMPRESSION LABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $32,000 for the latest quarter and $65,000 for the year-ago period. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $800,000 and $65,000 for the latest 9 months and year-ago period, respectively.

title: A WILD VICTORY FOR BOSTON
description: Except for the muffled sounds of players talking among themselves, the clubhouse was relatively quiet. Don Baylor stood in the middle, still wearing an undershirt soaked with perspiration, and spoke of the emotion that had enveloped the long and twisting afternoon. He tried to put it into meaningful words, but the game defied simple explanation.

title: Pole Bars Solidarity Talks
description: Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner has declared that he will not talk with leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union because they oppose Communism, the official press agency PAP said today. ''There will not be any talks with the opponents of this system,'' Mr. Messner said in a speech to a Communist Party conference on Saturday.

title: INDIAN TEA REGION YIELDS BITTER HARVEST OF UNREST
description: For more than a century, plantation laborers have crowded the lush green mountainsides here to pluck some of the world's finest tea. But this year the harvest has also been one of bloodshed, hatred and fear.

title: Daniloff Affair Casualties: Candor and Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: JUILLIARD QUARTET'S 40TH BIRTHDAY
description: WAS this the Juilliard String Quartet celebrating its 40th birthday at Alice Tully Hall Saturday, or were we listening to four men marking the anniversary of a name?

title: Derailment at Reykjavik
description: If President Reagan's cool-handed purpose at the Geneva summit last year was to squeeze a better deal out of the Soviet Union, he succeeded. It appears that Mikhail Gorbachev was willing, at the Reykjavik summit, to pay a substantially higher price if the United States would back off its Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: FALCONS CONQUER RAMS, 26-14
description: Gerald Riggs ran for 141 yards and one touchdown today as the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 26-14, in a battle for first place in the National Conference West Division.

title: ISLANDERS AND RANGERS STUMBLE AT START
description: If the National Hockey League's Patrick Division standing looks a little unusual today, blame it on the Devils, the Islanders and the Rangers.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SECOND TO NONE: American Companies in Japan, by Robert C. Christopher. 258 pages. Crown. $16.95.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. HOUSTON ASTROS, at Shea Stadium, Fifth game of National League Championship Series, 3:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 2:20 P.M.; WCBS 880, 2:55 P.M.) FOOTBALL PITTSBURGH STEELERS VS. BENGALS, at Cincinatti, 9 P.M. (Television -Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660, 9 P.M.) HOCKEY WASHINGTON CAPITALS VS. RANGERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio -WPAT 930, 7:20 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS THOROUGHBRED RACING: Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: VIEW IN CONGRESS ON TALKS IS MIXED
description: Initial Congressional reaction tonight to the failure of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to reach agreement on nuclear arms control was mixed.

title: Green Shifts On Marijuana
description: Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New York, said yesterday he had changed his opinion on the dangers of marijuana and no longer believed that ''normal use'' of the drug is harmless.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are deeply disappointed by this outcome.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Iceland. [ A1:6. ]

title: A Flurry Of Account Switches
description: THE chemistry that causes major disconnections in nature in the autumn seems also to be affecting adland.

title: CLOSE AIDE TO BUSH LINKED TO FIGURE HELPING CONTRAS
description: Vice President Bush acknowledged today that his national security adviser had ties to a Central Intelligence Agency veteran identified as a leader of a secret effort to supply Nicaraguan rebels.

title: McEnroe Defeats Curren in Final
description: John McEnroe edged past Kevin Curren, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2 today to win the Championship of the $279,000 World Championship Tennis Scottsdale Open before a capacity crowd of 7,500 in the first year of this tennis tournament.

title: Derailment Is Linked To Lack of a Signal
description: An Amtrak train carrying 300 passengers was going over the recommended speed before it derailed last week because the engineer was not notified in time of a switching maneuver, a Federal investigator said today.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 13, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SCOTT IS ONE ASTRO WHO HAS THE RIGHT SCUFF
description: THE Mets kept hitting line drives and running the bases, slapping high-fives and taking curtain calls. But that was only on their Shea Stadium video scoreboard. In last night's fourth game of the National League Championship Series, their bats were almost as silent against Mike Scott's split-fingered fastball as they had been in the opener.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Lucky Stores Inc. misstated the amount of the company's stock held by Asher B. Edelman. Mr. Edelman, who has offered to buy the company, has not disclosed how much stock he owns.

title: Batten, Barton
description: The New York office of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, whose Detroit office handles Chrysler's Dodge division, has been assigned Chrysler First, a financial organization based in Allentown, Pa.

title: Videovisiting the Library
description: The video has penetrated the national fortress of the book. For the first time ever in its Christmas gift catalogue, the Library of Congress includes three videos: a tour of the Library of Congress, an introduction to its law library and a conversation with Gwendolyn Brooks, who was the library's consultant in poetry in 1985-86. All three are available in either Beta or VHS format, and each costs $25.

title: Common Virus Linked To Pregnancy Infection
description: Women exposed to a common, usually harmless virus for the first time during pregnancy have a 30 to 40 percent chance of infecting their unborn children, putting them at risk for hearing loss and mental retardation, researchers have reported.

title: ECONOMY CLOUDING OUTLOOK ON RATES
description: The uncertainty that has hung over the credit markets for the past few weeks is not likely to dissipate for at least another month, investment analysts say.

title: Allied's Move Is Opposed
description: The Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it would take all steps necessary to remove the ''poison pill'' adopted by the Allied Stores Corporation to thwart a $66-a-share tender offer for its stock by Campeau.

title: HAITIANS APPEAR INDIFFERENT AS A DEMOCRATIC VOTE NEARS
description: Later this month Haiti is scheduled to hold its first democratic national elections in nearly 30 years, but no one is campaigning and only a fraction of the eligible Haitians are expected to vote.

title: Police Detective Slain; His Girlfriend Arrested
description: A highly decorated police detective was shot several times and killed Saturday, and his girlfriend was arrested in the slaying.

title: GIANTS ROUT EAGLES
description: It isn't often that a linebacker catches a pass from his own quarterback in stride to score a touchdown.

title: May Chao Wed In White Plains To Jeffrey Hwang
description: The wedding of May M. Chao to Jeffrey Hwang took place yesterday at the Ridgeway Alliance Church, a Christian and Missionary Alliance Church in White Plains. The Rev. Thomas Fraser performed the ceremony.

title: IRAQ AND IRAN SPAR OVER OIL AND WAR
description: Iraqi officials attending an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries denied today that Iranian raids had crippled Iraqi oil facilities and said the Iranian claims would have no effect on Iraqi demands at the negotiations.

title: Arden Chamber Trio Plays at 92d Street Y
description: Some chamber ensembles seem like a single musical sensibility divided several ways, others seem marriages of compatible differences. The Arden Trio, which consists of the pianist Thomas Schmidt, the cellist Clay Ruede and the violinist Suzanne Ornstein, and played a concert of works by Beethoven, Saint-Saens and Paul Schwartz at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night, falls into the latter category.

title: Decision Near on Next I.M.F. Head
description: When the Finance Ministers of the European Community meet in Luxembourg on Monday to select the next managing director of the International Monetary Fund, they will be considering tradition and national interests as well as the candidates' qualifications.

title: CHRISTIANS TESTIFY IN ALABAMA TEXTBOOK SUIT
description: This next week and the following, a Federal courtroom here will once again be consumed with the issues spelled out Wednesday by Douglas T. Smith, an eighth grade science teacher who is a troubled Christian parent.

title: ROWE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Fallon McElligott
description: As the McKinney crowd is to the South, Fallon McElligott is to the vast area surrounding Minneapolis: a hot shop for its time. It got two bonanzas last week from existing clients.

title: COLUMN ONE: POLITICS
description: 'Not Satisfied'Mayor Koch is at odds with the religious leader he calls his ''spiritual father.''

title: About 600 People Battle Fires Near Mt. St. Helens
description: About 600 firefighters battled three forest fires near Mount St. Helens today, and as winds grew calmer, officials cut their estimate of acres burned from more than 1,000 to 620.

title: TEMPLE STAR ON THE RUN
description: For individual and team achievements among Eastern college football teams Saturday, there was nothing to surpass the 349 yards gained by Paul Palmer of Temple or Army's 25-21 upset of Tennessee at Knoville.

title: SIPPICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
TESTIMONY PORTRAYING DARKER SIDE OF MANES
description: The Federal corruption trial in New Haven is shedding a new and harsher light on the life and death of Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President who committed suicide by thrusting a knife into his heart last March.

title: BRAZIL IS SHOPPING FOR COFFEE
description: Brazil, the patriarch of coffee and long a mainstay of the world's drinkers of the brew, startled markets at home and abroad with the announcement last month that it would import up to 1.5 million bags of coffee this year.

title: Winning Friends, Pt. 1
description: Representative Marvin Leath, a Texas Democrat who has seen eye to eye with President Reagan on many issues over the last half-dozen years, has written the President an uncharacteristically critical letter. In it, the Congressman declared that some of Mr. Reagan's statements on House arms control proposals were ''simply not true'' and charged that the Administration had made ''no progress'' on arms control since it took office.

title: FOR HENDERSON, A CRAZY DAY
description: Demons of Fenway, move over. Anaheim Stadium had become the Bermuda Triangle for the Red Sox in this American League Championship Series. A place where Boston leads disappeared without a trace and Boston's hitters went to die.

title: LOUISE ERDRICH, PARTNER IN A CONSPIRACY TO WRITE
description: The interview appointment is for 9 A.M. with Louise Erdrich, the author of ''Love Medicine,'' winner of the National Book Critics Circle award for the best work of fiction published in 1984. A few minutes after 9, Ms. Erdrich shows up - and so does Michael Dorris, professor of anthropology and Native American studies at Dartmouth.

title: SURGE IN PREMATURELY JOBLESS
description: Benjamin Riddle, a laid-off steelworker in Chicago, sits around his apartment most days watching television and brooding, while Calvin Tuttle, a retired oil industry executive in Tulsa, Okla., keeps busy playing golf and fixing up his home. Their lives are quite different, but these two men have one thing in common: they are part of a fast-growing group of men, aged 55 to 64, who are out of the labor force.

title: Jamaican Leader Tells Of Plans to Retire in '87
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga said Sunday that he would retire next August, but party leaders said they would try this week to get him to change his mind.

title: AGENDA: OCT. 14, 1986
description: Human Rights Report Card Prisoners tortured in Chile and Cambodia, executed by the hundreds in Iraq and Iran, tortured and killed in police custody in South Africa -those are among the findings to be cited today by Amnesty International. The Nobel Prize-winning group will release its yearly report on human rights abuses. Yuri F. Orlov, the recently released Soviet dissident, will speak. Noon, ninth-floor conference room, 322 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street, Manhattan 'Secret' Witness in Court Identified as one of the secret prosecution witnesses in the municipal-corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman, Dr. Jerome Driesen goes back to court on new charges. He is expected to plead guilty to a misdemeanor stemming from the attempted extortion of shares in a hospital. Last week the psychiatrist pleaded guilty to other charges in connection with payoffs in the city's Parking Violations Bureau. 3:30 P.M. Criminal Court Building, 125-01 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens Proceedings Aftermath of ProtestTwelve protesters who occupied a Yale University office to demand that the school sell its holdings in companies doing business in South Africa are expected to plead not guilty to charges of criminal trespassing and disorderly conduct. A spokesman for the protesters, who were arrested Sept. 22, said they would ask for a jury trial rather than agree to plead no contest, which would clear the incident from their records after probation. 10 A.M., Superior Court, 121 Elm Street, New Haven Too Many InmatesWhile New York City is resorting to converted ferryboats to house its burgeoning jail population, Westchester County is trying to come up with its own solutions.

title: Letter: On New York Housing; Existing Buildings Are the Best Bet
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Japan Trade Surplus
description: Japan had a record monthly trade surplus in September, the Finance Ministry reported today, and even bigger surpluses may be coming.

title: DANCE: MARK DENDY AND TROUPE AT P.S. 122
description: MARK DENDY can certainly choreograph sassy dances. That was evident when Mark Dendy and Company appeared Saturday night at Performance Space 122.

title: FIRST WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $5,902,000, or 11 cents per share, from the sale of a subsidiary for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $9,252,000, or 18 cents per share, on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Suburban Housing Restrictions That Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: Reykjavik Riddles
description: It was good advice that President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, gave the world as they left Reykjavik empty-handed: Think it over and don't despair.

title: Careers; Software Engineers By G.E.
description: ON-THE-JOB training combined with a master's degree are advantages of a program offered by the General Electric Company. Each year, it selects a dozen or 15 college seniors for its software technology program.

title: Talks Expected On Egypt Debt
description: An International Monetary Fund delegation is expected in Cairo next week to resume talks on a $1.5 billion loan to Egypt, the Middle East News Agency reported today.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on sales of investments of $5.4 million and $12.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and equity in net of Argonaut Insurance and its subsidiaries of $2.2 million and $16.5 million for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes gains on sales of investments of $42.5 million and a charge of $9 million relating to Argonaut Insurance and its subsidiaries. d-Includes gains on sales of investments of $141.8 million, equity in net of Argonaut Insurance and its subsidiaries of $41.8 million, and a credit of $81.7 million relating to the distribution of Litton Industries stock to Teledyne holders. As previously announced, the company is distributing to its shareholders all of the outstanding common stock of Argonaut Group Inc.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Joseph Villa, Pianist, Performs Liszt Recital
description: Joseph Villa's Liszt recital at Alice Tully Hall Saturday touched all bases, as Liszt did. There were a couple of the Transcendental Etudes, one of the Hungarian Rhapsodies, some paraphrases of Italian opera and German song, the B minor Ballade to represent the ''big'' Liszt, a ''Consolation'' and a couple of waltzes to represent the charmer. The concert showed, if anyone needed showing, that a fully varied and never boring program can be assembled without ever leaving Lizst and his most natural medium, the unaccompanied pianoforte.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: There were 13 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year in the latest periods, compared to 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, for the year- earlier periods.

title: SEMINARY TEACHER CLEARED OF HERESY
description: In a dispute that has divided fundamentalist and moderate members of the Southern Baptist Convention, a seminary professor accused by fundamentalists of teaching heresy through his interpretation of the Bible was cleared today by a vote of the seminary's board of trustees.

title: Plea in Pan-Electric Case
description: Peter Tham, former director of the collapsed Singapore conglomerate Pan-Electric Industries pleaded guilty to 18 charges of forging share transfer forms, court sources said today. Mr. Tham, 38 years old, will appear in court again on Wednesday when he is expected to face 36 charges relating to Pan-Electric's collapse. Today's charges carry a maximum penalty of 14 years in prison and Mr. Tham was remanded in custody.

title: Details, Details
description: A major roadblock to dealing with America's homeless is that nobody seems to know how many there are. More than that, Mitch Snyder, the Washingtonian who has become a spokesman for the homeless, says the Government has an interest in minimizing the number.

title: ROWE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
James Allen, a Leader In Marxist Publishing
description: James S. Allen, former president of International Publishers Associates, which specialized in Marxist literature, died of cancer Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NATIONAL MICRONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes a loss provision on disposal of $95,000 for the quarter and a gain provision on disposal of $1,191,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,656,000 for the quarter and $7,522,000 for the year, and a loss provision on disposal totaling $19,544,000, for both the quarter and year.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Market Place; Hopes for Food Wholesalers
description: THE major food wholesalers have enjoyed steadily rising profits in recent years, but even this conservative, low-profile industry is not immune to bumps along the road. Last week, for example, shares of the Fleming Companies sold at a two-year low of 31 - down from their record high of 44 7/8 in the spring. Yesterday, the stock dipped 3/8, to 32 7/8, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: FOR YASTRZEMSKI, THE FIRES STILL BURN
description: For most New England fans over the age of 30, it will seem a little strange to watch the Red Sox in post-season play this year without Carl Yastrzemski. Though he retired three years ago, he was the linchpin on teams of three decades, two of which suffered seventh-game World Series defeats, another of which fell to the Yankees in a heart-breaking playoff game for the American League East title. Yastrzemski's career spanned 23 years, but never included a world championship.

title: REAGAN SAYS SOVIET BARRED ACCORD ON ARMS REDUCTION, BUT OFFERS TO RENEW TALKS: MOSCOW IS CRITICAL
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned from Iceland today to a rising chorus in the press echoing his assertion that President Reagan had let a historic chance at agreement on arms control slip by clinging to his ''Star Wars'' program.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary gains of $214,000 for the quarter and $482,000 for the 6 months.

title: NEW PATH IS URGED ON ROCKET DESIGNS
description: The panel charged with overseeing the redesign of space shuttle rockets has urged the space agency to explore wholly new designs and expressed ''serious concern'' about the adequacy of its current testing program.

title: Gordimer Is Honored
description: The South African writer Nadine Gordimer is the winner of this year's Bennett Award from the Hudson Review for ''her distinguished achievement in the short story and novel.''

title: GAME 5 RESET FOR TODAY
description: The Mets and Houston Astros were rained out of the fifth and tiebreaking game of their playoff for the National League pennant yesterday and will try to play it instead at 1 P.M. today in Shea Stadium, with Dwight Gooden pitching against Nolan Ryan.

title: ITALIAN TOWN AS A GLOBAL VILLAGE
description: IN the last 70 years, this idyllic village on the Adriatic, 18 miles west of Trieste, has been governed by the Austro-Hungarian crown, the Italian monarchy, Nazi Germany, the Allied military administration, and finally, today, the Italian Republic. But instead of settling down to a new provincialism, Duino four years ago accepted, reluctantly at first, an unlikely role as home of a global village, the United World College of the Adriatic.

title: Dallas
description: Changes in the dollar's value offer slim hope of increasing exports for the depressed agriculture and oil industries in Texas, but there are signs of reviving export activity in other sectors.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,617,000 from the repurchase of notes.

title: SHULTZ BRIEFS NATO ALLIES ON TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz briefed the NATO allies on the outcome of the Reykjavik summit meeting today and said later they had viewed it as, in some ways, ''a tremendous success.''

title: No Progress Seen In Pennzoil Case
description: The Pennzoil Company has not held talks recently with Texaco Inc. concerning a settlement of Pennzoil's $11.1 billion judgment against Texaco, according to Baine Kerr, a retired Pennzoil president who was appointed to represent the company in any negotiations.

title: Retailer Ties Name To City
description: TO ring down the curtain on its 100th anniversary celebration dear old Bloomingdale's will offer a non-commercial print advertising campaign that will link its venerable name with other names important in the city's life. And they will do it in a totally charming way.

title: ZONING FIGHT AGAIN IMPERILS GRAND CENTRAL
description: Eight years after the United States Supreme Court upheld the city's designation of Grand Central Terminal as a landmark, the future of the midtown blocks around it - and perhaps the character of the terminal itself - is again at stake.

title: Stocks Up as Volume Falls
description: With trading volume plunging to its lowest level in nearly two years, Wall Street yesterday sleepwalked its way through a session of slightly higher stock prices.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S BROADCAST ON TALKS WITH GORBACHEV IN ICELAND
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's broadcast address tonight on his meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in Iceland:

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
description: b-Reflects pre-tax charges of $2 million, including a $1.3 million writedown of surplus inventory and a $700,000 charge resulting from the company's decision to reduce excess leased floor space in the Spokane Industrial Park.

title: Norfolk Southern Acts to Trim Staff
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said its railroad units are seekng to speed normal attrition among train and engine-service employees by offering them a one-time separation allowance.

title: SWISS BANKING'S MILITARY WAYS
description: Tiny Switzerland bases its national defense on almost lifelong military service by Swiss men. It is a reliance that produces a curious blending of the nation's business and military leadership.

title: IMMUCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $102,189 for the latest first quarter and $3,800 for the year-ago period.

title: ELECTRONIC MOUSE: NEW BREED CAN ALMOST 'SEE'
description: THE mouse business is beginning to roar. Yet until recently cursor-pushing rodents were languishing in the background of the computing scene. What happened? If Apple Computers can't take the credit for inventing the electronic mouse, certainly the heroic marketing effort known as Macintosh is what made it a household name, at least among personal computer users. Yet except in the case of the virtually mouse-dependent Mac, the device has not scrabbled up onto most electronic desks. The main reason it has not is probably that its primary accomplishments are manipulative, whereas most people spend most of their time at the computer entering data.

title: Chrysler Prices Increasing 1.6%
description: The Chrysler Corporation's 1987 domestic cars will cost an average 1.6 percent more than the 1986 models, but its subcompact Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon America versions will cost 11.6 percent less, the company says. The base price for 1987 Omni and Horizon cars will be $5,799, Chrysler announced Friday.

title: Oil and Oil Products Dip On OPEC Uncertainty
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped on world markets yesterday. Analysts attributed the declines to news that Saudi Arabia had joined Kuwait in pressing the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to revise its temporary production accord.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income c-After a charge of $3 million from a provision for asset restructuring.

title: Marti Jones, Vocalist, At the Bottom Line
description: Like everything else in pop music, fashions in singing voices keep changing. In the 70's, mainstream pop stars like Linda Ronstadt, Bonnie Raitt, Joni Mitchell and Carole King helped to bring a new naturalness, maturity and stylistic flexibility to female pop singing.

title: Ryan and Hector Sparkle as Backups
description: Because Pat Ryan and Johnny Hector performed so well against the New England Patriots Sunday, the Jets have the luxury of waiting a bit longer on the recovery of Ken O'Brien and Freeman McNeil, the players the first two replaced.

title: Solving the Jail Space Puzzle
description: No one can argue with the desire of Mayor Koch of New York to be tough on crime and crack, or the police campaigns that now bring thousands more drug dealers into city courts. But there's an uncomfortable side effect: critical crowding of jails. Therein lies a challenge to the whole city. Ideally, jails ought to expand in the boroughs, near courts, the prisoners' families and lawyers. Though a well-run jail poses no threat to a community - one has functioned quietly near downtown Brooklyn for years - plans for new jails still ignite furious protest from potential neighbors. As a result, the Koch administration has chosen to cram more and more prisoners into the main city jail on Rikers Island, many of them in quickly constructed ''dormitories'' where inmates are held in open rooms instead of locked cells.

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS LOSE HEAVILY IN MUNICIPAL VOTING
description: The ruling Socialist Party of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou suffered serious losses to the Communists in voting Sunday for municipal offices. As a result, the party runs a risk of losing its hold over the three biggest cities - Athens, Piraeus and Salonika - in runoff races next Sunday.

title: KOLIUS PUTS END TO CONNER'S STREAK
description: America II, the 12-Meter that has been sent here to recapture the America's Cup for the New York Yacht Club, won its most important race of the early trial series today.

title: Connors Disqualified
description: Jimmy Connors failed to arrive for the opening of the $350,000 Australian Indoor Tennis Championship today and was disqualified from the tournament. The tennis star's wife, Patti, said Connors became ill at the Los Angeles airport shortly before he was to board his flight to Australia.

title: For Star Wars and Arms Control, Too
description: If reports are accurate, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed in principle in Iceland to abolish nuclear missiles. So why did President Reagan scrap this promising deal in order to preserve our right to research a ''Star Wars'' defense against nuclear missiles - missiles Moscow offered to tear up anyway? The answer is that, contrary to conventional wisdom, American deployment of Star Wars would not undermine efforts to reduce and abolish nuclear weapons.

title: European Ministers Fail To Choose I.M.F. Head
description: European finance ministers were in a deadlock today over rival French and Dutch candidates for the post of managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

title: POLICE DENY COERCION IN EL AL CASE
description: The British police today stood by the disputed confession of a Jordanian accused of trying to blow up an Israeli airliner, contending that he had admitted receiving aid from Syrian intelligence agents and meeting with the Syrian Ambassador in London shortly before his arrest.

title: Soviet Withdrawal Is a Trick, Afghan Guerrilla Chief Says
description: An Afghan guerrilla leader said today that the scheduled withdrawal of some Soviet soldiers from Afghanistan is a trick to manipulate world opinion and that Moscow has no intention of leaving Afghanistan.

title: AN ALBUM OF 'ME AND MY GIRL'
description: It took 99 takes and nearly 14 hours, but now MCA Records has on tape what will soon become the American cast album of the hit Broadway musical ''Me and My Girl.''

title: Missouri U. Arrests 17 In South Africa Protest
description: Campus police at the University of Missouri arrested 17 people for trespassing today and tore down a group of shanties built to protest the school's investments in businesses operating in South Africa.

title: OPERA: DEBUTS IN 'CENDRILLON'
description: THE New York City Opera's current production of Massenet's ''Cendrillon,'' a gently lyrical setting of the Cinderella tale, has been widely - and deservedly - praised for its grace, creativity and sheer visual beauty. On Saturday night, two new players joined the cast.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS LINKED TO AIRLIFT OF CONTRA SUPPLIES
description: American officials at least indirectly supported Nicaraguan rebel supply flights out of El Salvador, according to two sources here.

title: JAZZ: SEPTET AT MICHAEL'S PUB
description: THE New York Jazz Repertory Ensemble, a seven-piece group that is playing at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, through Oct. 25, is focused on a relatively small part of the jazz repertory that is rarely heard in New York clubs - music of the end of the ragtime era and the beginnings of jazz in the decade after World War I. The septet, led by the banjo virtuoso Eddy Davis, draws some of its material from such celebrated groups of the 1920's as King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band (''Snag It,'' ''Mabel's Dream''), the lesser-known Sam Morgan's Jazz Band (''Bogalusa Strut'') and such charming but obscure piano rags as May Aufderheide's ''Dusty Rag.''

title: E-SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,015,000 and $329,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the 1986 earnings include effect of FASB 87, accounting for pension expense of $2 million, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $6 million, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Eppler, Guerin, Turner Makes Plans for Its Sale
description: In 1951, William B. Eppler, Dean P. Guerin and John W. Turner formed an investment banking and brokerage firm in Dallas with $28,000 of capital. The three men were its only employees and collected about $300,000 in revenues their first year.

title: HIGH, BUT STABLE, U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT IS GAINING ACCEPTANCE
description: For more than two years the nation's unemployment rate has hovered around 7 percent, a level long considered intolerably high and far above the 4 percent target set by Federal law.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a one-time charge of $834,000 to discontinue the Magnawave line of products. c-Net income and after a $702,000 one-time special charge to settle a suit.

title: How to Select Students For Choice High Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: UNRAVELER OF MYSTERIES: RITA LEVI-MONTALCINI
description: When Mussolini's anti-Semitic laws forced her to leave the University of Turin in 1939, Rita Levi-Montalcini set up a small laboratory in the bedroom of her family home, and it was there that she first developed the expertise in cellular biology that today earned her a share of the 1986 Nobel Prize for medicine.

title: FALSE CITATIONS IRRITATE DRIVERS IN NEW JERSEY
description: New Jersey's motor vehicle agency, long hampered by an erratic computer, has recently been sending out suspension notices to motorists who have perfect driving records.

title: Vigor in the Court, Laughter in the Court
description: It may have been the brisk autumn air. It may have been the peculiar chemistry of the cases. But in the reconstituted Supreme Court's first week on the bench, the oral arguments seemed livelier than usual.

title: Moseley Cut
description: In the aftermath of their first loss, not including replays, the Redskins waived Mark Moseley, their veteran kicker.

title: City That Cannot Be Hid
description: To the Editor:

title: COLUMN ONE: POLICE AND LAW
description: Hiring Under ScrutinyA year and a half after it was formed - following several incidents of police misconduct - a mayoral panel is about to issue its preliminary report on how to better train, discipline and recruit police officers, and some of the ideas are certain to anger the police union.

title: URANIUM REMOVED FROM SNAKE RIVER
description: Divers today cut open the trailer of a truck that crashed into the Snake River Sunday and began unloading 16 tons of low-level radioactive uranium.

title: Boat Builder Filing
description: The Tacoma Boatbuilding Company, which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since September 1985, said it had filed a plan of reorganization in Federal bankruptcy court. The plan calls for 81 percent of the company's stock to be held by creditors, about 17 percent by curent shareholders and 2 percent by current management. The company said secured lenders, who have claims totaling $32 million, would receive about $5 million in cash, $6.5 million in secured notes and, under certain circumstances, an interest in the some of the company's incinerator ships.

title: Credit Market Activity Light
description: Activity in the credit markets was subdued yesterday, as securities firms operated with skeleton staffs and there was no New York trading in the cash market for Treasury securities.

title: Armstrong Tire Official Is Trying to Buy Plant
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company has announced plans to shut its truck tire plant in Natchez, Miss., but Dennis Terwilliger wants to keep it open.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am still optimistic that a way will be found. The door is open and the opportunity to begin eliminating the nuclear threat is within reach.''

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Californian Comes to Town
description: Beneficiaries of political fund-raising functions in the capital are usually candidates for the White House and the Senate or perhaps a House member of the rank of Speaker, whip or head of a major committee. Tonight, however, a coterie of 80 liberal luminaries will hold a reception for California's Chief Justice, Rose Elizabeth Bird.

title: In Varied Bill at Tully
description: Alec Chien's piano playing at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon showed an uncommonly strong musical personality and a very special ear for sound. Mr. Chien, who won the Utah Symphony Gina Bachauer competition this year, still feels restrained in the presence of Beethoven and Schubert, but he vividly re-creates the pictorial images of Liszt or Albeniz.

title: Abortion Trend
description: Forty million to 60 million induced abortions are performed in the world each year, about 33 million of them legally, according to a new study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute. By contrast, about 131 million babies will be born in the world this year, according to estimates by the United Nations.

title: 2 WOMEN ARE FOUND SLAIN IN CAR
description: Two women, one an Annapolis graduate and the other a College of William and Mary student from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., were found slain Sunday in a car near Yorktown, Va., an F.B.I. agent said yesterday.

title: POP: A-HA AT RADIO CITY
description: RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL reverberated on Saturday evening with the enthusiastic shrieks of hundreds of teen-age girls gathered to adore the young Norwegian pop group A-ha.

title: KLLM TRANSPORT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GREEN NOTES MAGAZINE ARTICLE THAT LAID A SLUR TO D'AMATO
description: Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New York, has raised as an issue a statement attributed by an anonymous source to his Republican opponent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, in which Mr. D'Amato was said to have referred to residents of New York City housing projects as ''animals.''

title: ROBIN WILLIAMS IN 'EVENING AT THE MET,' ON HBO
description: THE new Home Box Office special ''Robin Williams -An Evening at the Met'' provides the latest illustration of how maintaining status in show business can be hazardous to a performer's equilibrium. Forget little things like names going above or below a title. Today's stars are beyond mere billing squabbles. Outside of ''Dynasty,'' for instance, Joan Collins evidently won't tolerate anything less than a four-hour mini-series for her performance showcases. Or George C. Scott, returning recently as Gen. George Patton, insists on stretching to three hours a television movie that could have been done in 90 minutes.

title: ABA Journal Adds A Xerox Catalogue
description: Taking advantage of new postal regulations, The ABA Journal-The Lawyers Magazine has piggybacked a Xerox office supplies catalogue on its Oct. 1 issue in a test of 35,000 of its 344,000 subscribers.

title: Precisionist Wins
description: Precisionist won the $80,750 Yankee Valor Handicap at Santa Anita today as millionaire horses raced for a modest purse in preparation for the $2 million Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: Dana May Take Write-Downs
description: The Dana Corporation said it might write down assets of its businesses other than financial services, a move that could result in pretax fourth-quarter charges of $38 million to $40 million. Dana today reported third-quarter earnings of $12.2 million, after $12.3 million in charges, compared with net income of $41.1 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an estimated loss on disposal of $1,735,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $871,000. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $111,000 and $707,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also includes an after- tax gain of $570,000 from the sale of land not used in operations.

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a previously announced after-tax non-recurring charge of $18.6 million that resulted from the sale of most of the company's insurance operations, including the sale in the third quarter of its major life insurance company. This loss had no significant net impact on earnings because it was offset by increased gains from sales of loans and mortgage-backed securities in the third quarter. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split on May 16, 1986, distributed on June 10, 1986.

title: GIANTS ARE UNSURE OF BAVARO'S STATUS
description: The bad news is that the Giants don't know how serious Mark Bavaro's foot injury is. ''He's a wait-and- see guy,'' George Young, the general manager, said today. That was a somewhat gloomy assessment in that the Giants, now 5-1, are heading into a difficult stretch of games. They play the Seahawks in Seattle Sunday, followed by home games against the Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys.

title: IMPROVING SOVIET SCHOOLING
description: The Soviet Politburo is giving high priority to improving education in the hope that this will advance science and technology to raise living standards in the Soviet Union to those of the West, specialists have told a conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But there was a difference of opinion about the effort's chance for success.

title: CARTWRIGHT IS LOST FOR THREE WEEKS
description: Just as Bill Cartwright's comeback was progressing in impressive fashion, it has been interrupted by a freakish accident.

title: AMITY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Ships With 8,000 Sailors Make a 4-Day Call on Seattle
description: A group of Navy ships carrying 8,000 seamen, making a port call here, signal a growing Navy presence in the Pacific Northwest, according to their commander..

title: I.B.M. NET DECREASES ALMOST 27%
description: Reporting its worst quarterly profit decline in years, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter net income plunged almost 27 percent. The decrease was the result of a stubborn computer slump at home and recently slowed sales abroad.

title: CANADA'S BILINGUAL ADVENTURE: PARDON MY FRENCH
description: When Canada's House of Commons recently elected John Fraser as its new Speaker, the Member of Parliament from British Columbia regretted that ''I don't speak French that well'' and promised to work on his deficiency.

title: DAVID'S COOKIES TO ADD OTHER GOODIES
description: David Liederman, the founder and chairman of David's Cookies, who showed that chocolate chunk cookies could be big business, wants to keep growing.

title: FIRST COLONIAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * Philip Brady, a senior vice president, named director of client services at Rolf Werner Rosenthal.

title: Freight Cars Hit Building
description: Two Conrail freight cars crashed into a downtown building after a four-car derailment early yesterday that disrupted commuter train service.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
161 INMATES BLOCK 2 DORMITORIES TO PROTEST CONDITIONS AT RIKERS I.
description: More than 150 inmates at Rikers Island, complaining about a variety of conditions there, barricaded themselves in two prison dormitories for seven hours yesterday until prison officials agreed to meet some of their demands, officials said.

title: McGraw-Hill in Bid For Business Ad Stake
description: McGraw-Hill Inc., a major force in trade publishing, is about to challenge the leading business publications for its piece of the business advertising pie.

title: AMISTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Move Against Opposition Before Bangladesh Vote
description: The two main opposition leaders were put under house arrest today, the final campaign day for presidential elections.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 5
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1.8 million for the 16 weeks and $8.7 million for the 40 weeks. c-Includes tax credits of $900,000 and $4.7 million for the 16 weeks and 40 weeks, respectively, and the 40 weeks also includes a credit of $20.1 million representing cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting method.

title: TRANSLATED DOCUMENTS CAPTURE AMBIENCE AND AROMA OF THE NINA
description: FADED documents in archaic script, long overlooked in a Spanish archive, are giving scholars the first clear and authoritative picture of the ships that carried Columbus to the New World. These caravels, sturdy and highly maneuverable vessels, were the major advance in seafaring technology that launched the Age of Discovery.

title: THE IMPORTING OF 'CROCODILE DUNDEE'
description: ''Billabong'' and ''sticky beak'' are Australian slang for creek and sticking your nose into someone else's business. Both were snipped out of ''Crocodile Dundee'' by Paramount Pictures in an attempt to make the most successful picture in Australian history palatable to American audiences.

title: PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $3,543,000 for the quarter and $3,550,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1 million.

title: London Lauds 'Phantom of the Opera'
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber's new musical ''The Phantom of the Opera'' received a prolonged standing ovation at its London opening and good initial reviews.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the results for 1985 are restated to reflect the acquisition of Santiago Corp.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTFIELD SAID TO BUY MACY MALLS
description: The management group that took R. H. Macy & Company private has agreed to sell the bulk of the retailer's holdings in eight shopping centers to Westfield Holdings Ltd., an Australian real estate company, according to an industry source familiar with the deal.

title: CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLITICIANS SAY G.O.P. HAS LOST A CAMPAIGN PLUM
description: Politicians and political strategists expressed caution today about the effect of the deadlocked summit meeting in Iceland on the 1986 campaign, which has just three weeks to go, though many said the Democrats might make marginal gains.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: To Our Readers
description: The credit markets were subdued yesterday, Columbus Day, so a number of tables reflecting trading in bonds are not available.

title: INSIDE
description: Mitterrand Doubts He'll Run President Francois Mitterrand said that, at this time, he did not intend to be a candidate in the next presidential election in France.

title: REAGAN SAYS SOVIET BARRED ACCORD ON ARMS REDUCTION, BUT OFFERS TO RENEW TALKS: DEFENDS HIS STAND
description: President Reagan blamed Mikhail S. Gorbachev tonight for the failure to achieve agreement in Iceland on reducing nuclear weapons. But he said his invitation to the Soviet leader to come to the United States for a summit meeting was still in effect.

title: For Martina, A Milestone
description: Martina Navratilova will be aiming for the 1,000th victory of her professional career when she plays Natalie Tauziat of France tomorrow in the Porsche Classic at Stuttgart, West Germany.

title: THEORIES EXPAND CONCEPT OF LIABILITY
description: New legal theories that would significantly expand liability for negligence are reverberating in judicial decisions and law review articles from California to New Zealand.

title: Gangs Prompt 6 P.M. Curfew
description: The police declared an emergency 6 P.M. curfew in the Blackwood Terrace section of this southern New Jersey township today after increasing rowdiness resulted in the arrests of more than 30 youths.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago third quarter and 9 months results include an after-tax gain of $331,000 on the disposition of a heat-treating division and a $141,000 after-tax charge for relocation costs of another division. The 9 months results also included an after-tax charge of $431,000 related to alleged improper waste storage and disposal matters.

title: SARGENT-WELCH SCIENTIFIC COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GLATFELTER, P H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: Chairman to Retire At Lord & Taylor
description: Just days after the acquisition of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation by the May Department Stores Company, Joseph E. Brooks announced yesterday that he would retire on Jan. 3 as chairman and chief executive of Associated's Lord & Taylor division.

title: COST ACCOUNTING'S BLIND SPOT
description: When Boston Metal Products, a small manufacturer in Medford, Mass., was thinking about buying a robot, the company controller was asked to calculate whether the $200,000 investment made financial sense.

title: BALDWIN POLICYHOLDERS MAY FINALLY GET FUNDS
description: The 165,000 purchasers of high-yield annuities of the Baldwin-United Corporation, who have been blocked from touching their funds for more than three years, may soon be shown a way out of their financial limbo.

title: IN STAMFORD, AN UNEASY COEXISTENCE OF 2 WORLDS
description: Two starkly separate societies are emerging in this corporate mecca - one wealthy, one poor - with little social buffer between idyllic suburban lifestyle and seething pockets of poverty.

title: APPLE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $2,158,000 and $5,567,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $1,259,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company went public in July 1985 and didn't report share earnings for the year-ago 9-month period.

title: METROBANC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on sales of securities of $118,000 for the quarter and $588,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on sales of securities of $216,000 for the quarter and $437,000 for the 9 months.

title: TRANSLATING LOTUS 1-2-3 INTO ENGLISH
description: THE Lotus Development Corporation's 1-2-3 was recognized as a work of genius when it came out in 1983. It was the first program to combine three powerful business applications - a spreadsheet, a database and graphics - and it has become an indispensable tool in thousands of offices.

title: Canada
description: Canada, America's biggest trading partner, has seen its large trade surplus with the United States gradually erode this year. The shrinkage, however, has occurred primarily because the Canadian economy is expanding faster than the American economy rather than because of a shift in currency values.

title: MUSIC: JOSE CARRERAS SINGS ZARZUELA ARIAS
description: JOSE CARRERAS continues to have some commanding sounds in his voice, especially when he can stay out of its upper portion, as his program of zarzuela arias at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon permitted him to do rather more consistently than his operatic roles have. Not that he didn't sing high notes (It seems to be the only way he can think of to end an aria in this repertory) - but he chose the keys and selections so as to fly at a relatively conservative altitude.

title: HOLDOUT ON BIG SCIENCE: STANLEY COHEN
description: AT first, all Stanley Cohen had to go on was that the eyelids were opening too soon.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANNIVERSARY

title: Berry Reluctant
description: Walter Berry, one of the Portland Trail Blazers' first-round draft picks, had been expected to sign his contract yesterday, but he had a meeting with Bucky Buckwalter, the team's vice president of basketball operations, and said he wants to talk over some of the terms with his advisers back East. The 6-foot-8-inch former St. John's all-American underwent a physical and is expected to be ready for practice immediately.

title: LAW FIRMS INVESTIGATED FOR FRAUD IN SUING CITY
description: Law-enforcement authorities in New York City are investigating several law firms that they say may have won millions of dollars in negligence suits by using bogus witnesses.

title: THE GEOLOGY OF A QUAKE-PRONE REGION
description: The earthquake in San Salvador last Friday was the latest in a series of quakes that have severely shaken cities in a trough extending from Guatemala through El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua to the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica.

title: HELD TOP COMMANDS IN ARMY
description: Gen. Fred K. Mahaffey, considered by many of his fellow officers to be one of the fastest-rising stars in the Army, died of cancer today at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center here. He was 52 years old.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes tax benefits of $1,988,000 for the quarter and $1,696,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago figures have been restated.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., said it had completed the transfer of its Brewster Phosphates unit's phosphate rock processing plants in central Florida to the International Minerals and Chemical Corp.

title: GENERAL AIDING CONTRAS HINTS AT A BROADER ROLE
description: Over the last couple of years, an organization operating out of a cramped three-room suite in Phoenix with only three regular employees says it has supplied 8,000 ''freedom fighter kits'' to the contra rebels in Nicaragua. The camouflage-covered kits contain such items as shaving cream, non-melting candy and Spanish-language Bibles.

title: Woman Slain as She Calls To Report 2 Killings
description: Three men handcuffed a 54-year-old man and his son and shot them to death, shot and wounded another son, then fatally stabbed a woman and slashed her throat as she summoned the police by telephone, officers said.

title: CAREMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
West Germany
description: Although the weak dollar has made no statistical dent in West Germany's huge trade surplus with the United States, the effects of the lower dollar are creeping into the way German companies do business.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Konica Plant In the South
description: The Konishiroku Photo Industry Company of Japan, which makes Konica cameras and film, said that it plans to build an 87-acre manufacturing plant near Greensboro, N.C.

title: DISCORD IS VOICED ON REDFISH LIMITS
description: A debate is raging over proposed new rules to regulate the harvest of redfish in federally controlled waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The F.B.I.'s Misguided Focus on News Leaks
description: To the Editor:

title: Alligator Injures 8-Year-Old
description: An alligator was destroyed after injuring an 8-year-old boy at a Walt Disney World campground. A doctor said the alligator inflicted ''four or five superficial lacerations'' on the boy, Paul Santamaria, on Sunday.

title: STRIKE AT G.M. OVER OUTSIDE CONTRACTORS EXPANDS
description: A strike by workers at the General Motors research and development headquarters over the issue of outside contractors widened today as 450 additional members of Local 160 of the United Automobile Workers walked off their jobs, bringing the total number of strikers to about 700.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss from debt retirement costs of $1,361,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,466,000 and $4,594,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary in some editions on Monday about Kate Warmack McKay, a copyright reference librarian at New York University Law School, gave the day of her death incorrectly. It was Saturday, not Sunday.

title: Ahmanson Net Increases 31.3%
description: H.F. Ahmanson & Company today reported earnings of $78.9 million, or 80 cents a share, for the third quarter, an increase of 31.3 percent from $60.1 million, or 72 cents a share, for the quarter last year. Revenues were $769 million, up 2.7 percent from $748.9 million for the period last year.

title: U.S. TRADE SCENE SLOWLY IMPROVES AFTER 20-MONTH DECLINE OF DOLLAR
description: Finally, 20 months after the overvalued dollar began its long slide, there are scattered but unmistakable signs that America's trade picture is beginning to improve.

title: GUILD MORTGAGE INVESTENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public June 24.

title: KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. OFFICIALS LOOK TO GENEVA TALKS, BUT CRITICS ARE SKEPTICAL ON PROSPECTS
description: American officials expressed hope today that important progress could be made in the Geneva arms talks as a result of the Iceland meetings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1986
description: THE WORLD The President blamed the Kremlin for the failure to achieve an arms control agreement in Iceland, but he renewed his invitation to Mikhail S. Gorbachev for a summit meeting in the United States, Mr. Reagan said in a televised address. In a conciliatory tone, Mr. Reagan said Washington and Moscow were closer than ever before to agreements that could lead to a safer world. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Limited Recall Of Pepsi
description: Health officials in Westchester urged consumers yesterday to return certain cans of Pepsi to area stores as the investigation into how three of the cans became tainted continued.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAUDIS ASK TO INCREASE THEIR OPEC OIL QUOTA
description: Saudi Arabia threw its weight on the side of Kuwait today in demanding a larger share of OPEC oil production.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $142.2 million and an after-tax charge of $30 million from a writedown related to a restructuring. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $140,800,000 and a charge of $30 million from a writedown related to a restructuring.

title: INTERVOICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Airbus Denies Bonn Pressure
description: The European Airbus Industrie consortium denied today, despite reports to the contrary, that it had come under pressure from the West German Government to resume talks with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation on building a long-range passenger jet for the 1990's.

title:
THE OUTLOOK FOR AMERICAN PRODUCERS;
Chicago
description: Some major export manufacturers in the Middle West say they see no increase in the actual volume of goods they export even though the lower dollar has resulted in increased earnings on their products sold abroad. The reason is that, for now, they are taking the more favorable currency translation rather than lowering the foreign-currency price of their goods to undercut foreign competitors.

title: THEATER: 'POPS,' BY ROMULUS LINNEY
description: Romulus Linney's ''Pops'' is an evening of curtain raisers, six very short plays dealing with the subject of romantic love. The effect is like a buffet of tempting appetizers; taken together, the appetizers substitute for a main course. The title of the anthology, which opens the season at the Whole Theater company, refers to familiar classical music as played by the Boston Pops Orchestra. In each play we know the tune, but Mr. Linney, as an imaginative dramatist, adds his special variations.

title: Chicago Title Deal
description: The Chicago Title and Trust Company, a subsidiary of the Alleghany Corporation, said it had reached an agreement to purchase the Safeco Title Insurance Company, a unit of the Safeco Corporation.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: Accion International, 1385 Cambridge Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02139. Mark checks ''Accion International Relief.'' American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102. Mark checks ''El Salvador Relief.'' American Jewish World Service, 29

title: Xiamen International
description: China has lifted its stake in the country's first joint venture bank, the Xiamen International Bank to 51 percent, from 40 percent, leaving Panin Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong with a 49 percent interest instead of 60 percent, the People's Daily overseas edition said today.

title: SOMERSET BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People Express Sees Big Loss
description: People Express Inc. has warned debt holders that it faces a substantial third-quarter loss and may default if it does not get a new injection of cash from the Texas Air Corporation, whose acquisition of People awaits approval by Federal regulators.

title: Students Walk Out At 40 Soweto Schools
description: Thousands of students walked out at about 40 high schools in the black township of Soweto today in a coordinated school boycott, but there were no reports of incidents.

title: HALE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $92,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the loss from discontinued operations in the year-ago quarter and 6 months reflects the results of operations of the company's previously wholly owned subsidiary, Bankline Inc., which was sold by the company at the end of fiscal year March 31, 1986.

title: France
description: New statistics show that the dollar's fall is starting to affect trade between France and the United States.

title: What's Good for Belgrade
description: John Douglas Scanlan, the United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia for the past year or so, appears to have made a huge hit with his hosts by leasing a Yugoslav automobile and using it as as an occasional alternative to his stretch limousine.

title: Technology Concerns in Black
description: Two of the nation's leading technology concerns, the United Technologies Corporation and TRW Inc., posted profits in the third quarter in contrast to losses in the corresponding 1985 period. But both companies continued to be hurt by problems at various operations, including their military contracting units.

title: Chess: Some Backwater Openings Get Their Day in Limelight
description: In a strange turnabout, openings that formerly were considered untheoretical backwaters are currently in the front line of outre positional play.

title: Where Smokers Can Breathe Free
description: I understand there's a bill pending before the City Council in New York that would further restrict smoking in public places. I would like to express my strong opposition to it.

title: WORKERS FOR ALL GOVERNMENTS FOUND UP BY 254,000 IN 1985
description: The number of employees in all types of government increased by more than a quarter-million last year, with the Federal Government showing the largest gain, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: Fire Kills 6 in Chicago House With a Failed Smoke Detector
description: Six people, including two children and their great-grandparents, died in a house fire early today, fire officials said. The house was equipped with a smoke detector, but officials said its battery apparently did not work properly.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $49,000 for the quarter and $130,000 for the 6 months. The share earnings reflect 5 percent stock dividend in July.

title: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Product Pace
description: Although new product introductions in September continued to be up over not only September 1985, but also August this year, the pace of introductions has slowed, according to the DFS-Dorland New Product News.

title: LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accounts
description: * Kearney & Trecker Corporation, Milwaukee, to Hood, Hope & Associates, Tulsa, Okla., for its modular automation systems and stand-alone machine tools.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THEODORE DREISER: At the Gates of the City, 1871-1907. By Richard Lingeman. Illustrated. 478 pages. Putnam. $22.95. READING Theodore Dreiser's own story is a little like reading a Dreiser novel. It looms up, a heavy and forbidding prospect; but as soon as you get into it, you are carried along by its stubborn power. Or you are if it is told as well as it is by Richard Lingeman in the first volume of his new biography.

title: Jackson Assails F.B.I. Inquiry Into Death of Arab-American
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has criticized an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the killing of an Arab-American leader, saying that not enough has been done to solve the crime.

title: EXPERTS DISAGREE ON SPACE TEST BAN
description: Scientists inside and outside the Government sharply disagreed yesterday over what effect a 10-year ban on space testing would have on President Reagan's missile defense program, known popularly as ''Star Wars.''

title: Budget Deadline? What Deadline?
description: The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to balance the Federal budget was supposed to make Congress discipline itself. As it ignored the law's final deadline for fiscal 1987 last Friday, Congress made clear that it is complying about as well as a teen-ager told to enforce his own curfew.

title: PRATT U. JOINS EXPANSION TO SUBURBS
description: Pratt Institute, based in Brooklyn, will start an extension of its city and regional planning progam here at Sarah Lawrence College in the spring, school officials say.

title: FEDERATED GUARANTY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net realized investment gains of $475,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $938,000, or 11 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After a realized investment loss of $57,000 for the quarter and a net realized investment gain of $400,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: RANGERS, UP BY 3, LOSE IN OVERTIME
description: The Rangers are having their early season Broadway blues again.

title: BAYLOR HELPS RED SOX SURVIVE
description: It was a chance meeting, really. Don Baylor was getting off an elevator and heading toward an interview room just as Gene Autry was getting on. For a few moments, they spoke.

title: Some U.S. Relief Teams To Return to the Sudan
description: The United States will allow some Americans working on United States aid programs to return to the Sudan, the official Sudanese press agency said today.

title: SIMON OFFERS TO ASSIST FEDERAL CABLE INQUIRY
description: The Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon, said yesterday that he would ''offer my immediate help and full cooperation'' to a new Federal investigation into possible corruption in the awarding of cable television franchises outside the borough of Manhattan.

title: DISAPPOINTMENT IS EXPRESSED IN WORLD CAPITALS OVER ICELAND TALKS, BUT ALSO HOPE
description: Politicians throughout the world expressed disappointment today that the Reykjavik summit meeting had ended in stalemate. But most expressed hope that the Iceland talks could pave the way for far-reaching arms-control agreements.

title: Bridge: Wily Declarer Is Thwarted As He Tries to Steal a Trick
description: The right plan for the defense may be obvious to one defender but not to the other.

title: Bengals Win, 24-22
description: Jeff Hayes, the Cincinnati Bengals' punter, made up for a blocked kick and a safety by sprinting 61 yards with a fourth-quarter fake tonight to give the Bengals a 24-22 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Cold Slows Red Tide Along Texas Coast
description: A cold front that moved across the south Texas coast overnight will slow further blossoming of a fish-killing red tide but probably will not stop it, state officials said today.

title: Siemens-BASF Venture Seen
description: Siemens A.G. and BASF A.G. will link their I.B.M.-compatible mainframe computer business in a joint venture to be formed by November, industry sources said today.

title: Japan
description: Since May, Japanese imports of American manufactured goods have shown a substantial increase from 1985 levels. But the raw numbers, provided by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, are deceptive. Much of the leap came from a one-shot surge in imports of gold ingots and from an unusually heavy purchase in July of American-made planes by Japanese airlines.

title: Envelopes, Please
