description: A year after major league baseball decided to cash in on its renown by instituting its own most valuable player award for the World Series, Sport magazine, which created the award three decades ago, still plans to present its version this year. So although a single player is likely to win both, as Bret Saberhagen did in 1985, the possibility remains that the Series beginning this Saturday will have two most valuable players.

title: SEATTLE TRUST & SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

THE OUTLOOK FOR AMERICAN PRODUCERS;
San Francisco
description: In the San Francisco and Silicon Valley region, manufacturers give mixed reports on the condition of their foreign markets. Although semiconductor makers are struggling amid a prolonged industrywide slump, companies that manufacture microcomputers, mainframes and related products report healthy growth and strong sales of products tailored for overseas markets.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BankAmerica Stock Off a Bit
description: The stock of the troubled BankAmerica Corporation, which replaced its chief executive over the weekend, fell slightly today, closing down 37.5 cents at $14.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Imasco Ltd., the Montreal-based tobacco, retailing, and fast-food group, said yesterday that it would sell its Genstar Gypsum Products Company to Domtar Inc., also of Montreal, for $241 million in cash.

title: DR. HYMAN B. COPLEMAN
description: Dr. Hyman B. Copleman, who for 50 years was the physician for Rutgers University athletic teams until his retirement last year, died Sunday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Cranbury, N.J.

title: FRIZETTE TO PERSONAL ENSIGN
description: Personal Ensign and Collins dueled head to head for half a mile before Personal Ensign finally stuck her head out at the wire to score a surprisingly narrow victory in a three-horse running of the $224,000 Frizette Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: EACH SIDE BLAMES OTHER FOR FAILURE, BUT MEETING MAY STILL YIELD SUCCESS
description: The inability of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to attain tangible results at the Reykjavik meeting has left Soviet-American relations in a quandary, in the view of foreign policy experts within and outside the Government.

description: To the Editor:

title: Temple Gets Bomb Threat
description: Temple Emanu-el was briefly evacuated during Yom Kippur services yesterday after an anonymous caller told a temple official that there was a bomb inside the building.

title: Hal Mason, Animator, Dies; Created Famous Characters
description: Hal Mason, the creator of the Pillsbury Dough Boy, Mr. Clean and other animated commercial and entertainment characters, died of a heart ailment Friday.

title: Jobs Can Help Wean Young People From Crack
description: To the Editor:

title: Thrift Unit Is Closed
description: The Homestead Savings and Loan Association of Woodward, Okla., was put into receivership of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today. Insured deposits of Homestead were transferred to Midfirst Savings and Loan of Oklahoma City, the board said. Homestead had assets of $134.5 million.

title: LOUISIANA GOVERNOR ORDERS 10% SPENDING CUT
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards ordered most state agencies today to reduce their annual spending immediately by 10 percent, a move that would reduce Louisiana's deficit by about $232 million.

title: 'SCUFFED IN THE SAME SPOT'
description: In the manager's office in the Mets' clubhouse, Davey Johnson opened the lower right-hand drawer of his desk. ''Here they are,'' he said. As the drawer moved, eight National League baseballs rolled around. Some were cleaner than others. Some were slightly smudged with dirt or grass stains. But on each ball, the white cowhide was scuffed, as if sandpapered, in the area where the red stitches widen.

title: TALKATIVE RUSSIAN OFFICIALS SENSE DIPLOMATIC WINDFALL
description: As Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew home to Moscow, senior Soviet officials said today that it seemed clear to them that the Soviet leader stood to gain more, and lose less, from the outcome of the Iceland summit meeting than President Reagan.

title: UNION BANK IN GLOBAL THRUST
description: From its beginning in 1912 following the merger of two farm country banks, the Union Bank of Switzerland has prided itself on the conservative nature of its banking style. The disciplined ways of its top executives relate in part to their reserve corps status as senior Swiss Army officers and to their stewardship of billions of dollars of their countrymen's investment funds.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: LOSS OF DRUG RELEGATES MANY TO BLINDNESS AGAIN
description: Thousands of patients with rare neuromuscular disorders are suffering renewed contortions of the eyes, face, neck and other parts of the body because their supply of experimental medicine was cut off when its only manufacturer was unable to obtain liability insurance.

title: They Truly Beat The Other Guys
description: On most college football sidelines, the drum is just another instrument in the band. At Gallaudet College, it's a 12th man.

title: TRACING MARTIAN METEORITES
description: AT LEAST eight meteorites that have fallen to earth are suspected of being fragments from the planet Mars. Their chemistry strongly resembles that of Martian soil sampled by the two Viking spacecraft that landed there in 1976. But scientists have been reluctant to accept the Martian association because they could not conceive of how the rocks could be lifted rocks off Mars and accelerated to the speed necessary to reach Earth.

title: Instant No-Play
description: President Reagan was indirectly involved in a disputed touchdown awarded to the Dallas Cowboys Sunday in their 30-6 victory over the Washington Redskins. Again, the use of instant replay to check a ruling sparked the controversy.

description: Amtrak plans to expand its passenger train service in the Northeast and Middle West starting Oct. 26 to accommodate an increase in both passengers and mail carried by the system.

title: Unkind Cut
description: A 9-year-old Upper West Side girl who's not much of a baseball fan rose early yesterday morning, listened to the radio news while she dressed, then strode into the living room and, before even bidding her father good morning, posed a question. ''Daddy,'' she asked, ''does Mike Scott cheat?''

title: 2 Are Killed In House Fire
description: A retired firefighter and his wife died early yesterday when fire swept their two-story wood frame home, the police said.

title: CONTRAS TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE SUPPLY FLIGHT
description: Nicaraguan rebels took full responsibility today for the flight of a military cargo plane that was downed over Nicaragua last week.

title: BONNEVILLE PACIFIC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CORRECTIONS

description: Striking teachers in a Pennsylvania school district wore black arm bands in protest as they reluctantly obeyed a court order to return to work yesterday without a contract.

description: William C. Powell, a longtime staff member at the United Nations and its former press spokesman, died of cancer Saturday at his home in White Plains. He was 69 years old.

title: Ernestine Anderson Sings at Carlos 1

Accompanied by Harry Arnold's excellent big band, Miss Anderson, who had been with several bands by then, including Lionel Hampton's, sang with such sensitivity, warmth and subtlety on this disk that she was widely perceived to be in a tradition that encompassed both Ella Fitzgerald and Mabel Mercer.

title: Meat Cutters Will Try For New Pact Again
description: Working against a midnight strike deadline, negotiators are scheduled to resume bargaining this morning on a proposed contract for meat cutters from five supermarket chains in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island and on Long Island.

title: Whither the Budget-Balancing Law?
description: At the end of a Congress, many bills are forgotten in the rush to go home.

Block That Oil Shock
description: The OPEC oil ministers are edging toward an accord in Geneva, most likely one that keeps production and prices at current levels for a few more months. The more interesting oil news is the long-term deal that Sheik Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, has informally offered to the consuming nations: If you accept modest increases in what you pay for energy, we'll make sure that prices never again go through the roof.

description: * Continental Corp., a holding company, announced that Robert A. Newman, senior vice president and director of corporate communications, was leaving the company to form his own consulting concern.

description: A tall and striking woman, with dark glasses and a swinging mane of hair, steps for the first time into the quiet gray elegance of a new beauty salon on Madison Avenue and is whisked into a private room in back.

title: Stamford, Conn.

description: b-Net loss

title: OPERA: BELLINI'S 'NORMA'
description: BELLINI'S ''Norma'' is a notoriously difficult opera to mount, and the title role is next to impossible. The great Normas can be counted on the fingers of one hand, the good ones on two.

title: The Last Details
description: The Center for Defense Information, reporting on the Defense Department budget for 1986, maintains that, whatever else the military might do, it pays attention to detail.

description: The big skirt, sharply jutting out from a snug waistband or forming a frothy, rounded shape made up of bouncy, ruffled tiers, is the major contribution of fashion designers here to the spring and summer fashion scene.

title: IF YOU SHOW IT TO HIM, HE'LL TELL WHAT IT IS
description: Everyone wants to find a dinosaur, David Parris knows this. Day in and day out, citizens bring mysterious objects to Mr. Parris's office in the science museum here to be identified, and more often than not he has bad news for them.

title: BRYN MAWR TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
24 Hours of Surgery Gives Man New Face
description: A victim of a disfiguring bone disease who underwent 24 hours of surgery to give him a new face was alert today and recovering well.

description: Michael Kavanagh, the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, is already looking beyond the Nov. 4 election - and the view is not necessarily of the ornate office of the Lieutenant Governor in the State Capitol at Albany.

title: 2 PIONEERS IN GROWTH OF CELLS WIN NOBEL PRIZE
description: Two scientists who have made major contributions to the understanding of substances that influence cell growth and the orderly development of tissues, including the nervous system, were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday.

HIGHLY SENSITIVE TEST CAN DETECT DIOXIN YEARS AFTER EXPOSURE
description: USING tools of breathtaking sensitivity, scientists have learned that they can discern traces of dioxin that have persisted in a person for years, even decades after exposure. The advance should help resolve the painfully inconclusive debate over the dangers of the notorious chemical.

description: China, responding to complaints that its poor investment climate is driving away foreign business, has announced it will lower taxes, guarantee operating autonomy and reduce red tape for foreign enterprises.

description: To the Editor:

title: Business and the Law; Court to Hear Brokerage Suit
description: WHEN Eugene And Julia McMahon opened accounts with a brokerage firm several years ago, they signed the standard agreements providing that any dispute relating to the accounts would be settled by arbitration.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do bats hang upside down? A. Bats hang upside down because it's the most convenient position for them to roost, said Dr. Merlin D. Tuttle, a biologist of Bat Conservation International. They lock their feet around the perch and their bodies pull them downward. Dr. Tuttle said a bat hanging upside down can easily drop into the air and fly away if it is disturbed. Dr. Tuttle said that, by hanging head-down, bats can use roosting places without competition from other flying animals. It's much more difficult for an animal to take shelter in the roof of a cave or building if it must roost head-up, he said. Q. Do all honeybees have stingers and if not, why aren't such ''stingless'' bees cultivated by the honey industry? A. Several species of honeybee in South America and in tropical areas do not have stingers, according to Dr. James Gould, a biologist at Princeton University. These bees have jaws they use to bite honey raiders. Some stingless bees spit an acid mixture into wounds of honey raiders, causing a painful burning sensation. Dr. Gould said some stingless bees, which can bite their victims more than once, are more aggressive than bees with stingers, which can sting only once. Stingless bees are not cultivated by honey producers because they produce far less honey than bees with stingers, Dr. Gould said. Honeybees in colder climates store great amounts of honey for use during the winter.

title: HOW GRIM ENDING IN ICELAND FOLLOWED HARD-WON GAINS
description: As a chilly rain fell Sunday evening on the white stucco building overlooking Reykjavik Bay in Iceland, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev stepped outdoors, solemnly shook hands and ended their weekend meeting.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
MOTHER AND DAUGHTER SHARE A FULBRIGHT YEAR
description: The first mother-daughter research team ever to receive grants as Fulbright scholars has arrived in Britain to study how humans learn to imagine.

title: TENTATIVE HOSPITAL PACT FOR 40 SITES IS REACHED
description: Members of the city's largest hospital workers union are to hear details today of a tentative contract agreement reached over the weekend with 40 voluntary hospitals and private nursing homes.

title: GOODEN'S BURDENSOME MONTH
description: At the corner of 126th Street and Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing, in what would have been the shadow of the elevated subway tracks had the sun been shining early yesterday afternoon, the squad of unsolicited windshield cleaners had a different function to perform.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Street style has always been this city's strong suit and ''Street Cred,'' or credibility, the yardstick by which all fashion intentions were judged. But after years in which London seemed to be held prisoner by its rule, the Street seemed to have lost its sway.

title: Sneaky Catfish
description: Fishes in East Africa have provided a rare example of brood parasitism, in which the offspring of one species rely totally on parents of another for their survival. While some birds lay their eggs in the nests of a second species, the phenomenon had been unknown among other types of vertebrate animals.

title: Cinema Verite, Federal Style
description: The Justice Department has produced a public-awareness film that graphically focuses on the dangers of drug abuse as described by recovering addicts.

title: CAMDEN POLICE CHIEF SUSPENDED PENDING HEARING
description: The police chief here has been suspended without pay amid accusations by the city administration of perjury and insubordination.

title: 7 SHIPS SEIZED WITH STOLEN BIKES
description: The police have seized seven freighters and arrested three ship captains after a police officer found up to 1,000 stolen bicycles aboard the vessels, officials said today.

title: A Moral Mission for Colleges
description: Until about 50 years ago, it was commonly accepted that the university was responsible for offering its students moral guidance. Professors regarded themselves as not only the teachers of knowledge and skills, but also as educational stewards of a special kind of wisdom: the nature of the good life; truth and goodness and beauty; and the value of thought and reflection.

title: AIDED THE HOMELESS AS SHELTER DIRECTOR
description: Msgr. Charles B. Brennan, who from 195l until 1965 directed the Holy Name Center, a Catholic Charities shelter for homeless men on the Lower East Side, died yesterday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 75 years old and until six weeks ago had lived in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., where he was pastor emeritus of St. Mary's Church.

title: Detroit
description: Although the average price of Japanese-made cars sold in the United States has increased 15 percent since the dollar began its decline, the higher prices appear to have done little to curb America's appetite for vehicles from Japan.

title: BIG AFTERSHOCK HITS SAN SALVADOR
description: A strong aftershock shook El Salvador today, sending frightened people into the streets of the capital three days after a major earthquake that left hundreds dead.

title: STAGE: PATRICIA ELLIOTT IN 'LILLIAN WALD'
description: LILLIAN D. WALD was a great woman, and Patricia Elliott is a charming actress. Their coming together, however, in ''Lillian Wald: At Home on Henry Street,'' is about as exciting as a proper tea party. Humdrumness may be built into the nature of the play now showing, appropriately, at the Harry De Jur Playhouse of the Henry Street Settlement, which Miss Wald founded.

title: 'NOVA' LOOKS AT SEARCH FOR ARGENTINA'S MISSING
description: ''NOVA,'' public television's weekly science series, begins its 14th season tonight at 9 on Channel 13 with ''The Search for the Disappeared.'' The program, however, is not so much about natural science as it is about recent history, or, perhaps, political science. Watch it on those terms. It is a worthwhile piece of work.

description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer n.a. - Not available due to Columbus Day holiday Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Suspension Reinstated
description: Greg Townsend, a Los Angeles Raider defensive end, will be suspended without pay for the game Sunday against the Miami Dolphins, National Football League Commissioner Pete Rozelle said yesteday. The suspension was reinstated for three flagrant fouls Townsend committed during a game against the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: DEPENDENT ON BUSES, MUDWESTERN TOWNS FIGHT CUTS IN SERVICE
description: Goldie Pickle offered a simple reason as to why she believed that the Trailways Lines bus service should not be allowed to abandon this city and its 8,900 residents.

title: OIL STOCKS WEAKEN
description: With most oil issues weak, Wall Street closed mixed yesterday. Blue-chip stocks slightly outperformed the broader market.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
FOOD NOTES
description: Deluxe Pasta Sauces Premium pasta sauces may be edging basic red off supermarket shelves. In September, Classico - a preservative-free collection with award-winning designer labels -made its debut at A.&P., Waldbaum, King Kullen, Pathmark and Grand Union stores. The sauces are made by the new Gourmet Specialties division of the Prince Company. The three flavors are Classico di Napoli, a lusty marinara sauce with basil; Classico d'Abruzzi, with meat, and Classico di Sicilia, a spicy putanesca-style recipe. They sell for about $1.69 for 14 ounces, $2.60 for 26 ounces. They are among the best of the jarred pasta sauces.

title: THE C.I.A. ROLE IN SALVADOR: AIR BASE DESCRIBED AS THE KEY
description: Behind the high concrete-block walls that keep the Ilopango air base here from the public's view is a drab two-story building. Over the last three years, the building has served as the waiting room for agents working for the Central Intelligence Agency, leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels, mercenaries and American military advisers, according to American officials and Nicaraguan rebel sources.

title: Freedom of Speech, Not Selectively
description: Almost everybody in the university community will swear that freedom of speech is a fine thing, and many will declare their willingness to fight to defend it. But when it comes down to particular cases, unless it is a case of their own or one they champion, few reliable defenders of free speech are to be found.

title: E.G. MARSHALL STARS AS EISENHOWER IN 'IKE'

The earthquake, registering 4.7 on the Richter scale, hit about 7:30 P.M., according to the California Institute of Technology. The area has been shaken by hundreds of aftershocks following an earthquake measuring 5.6 on the Richter scale that injured 40 people and caused damage estimated at $8 million on July 8.

title: SALMON AND DUCKS SWIM IN STREETS AS TROOPS AID IN ALASKAN FLOODS
description: Salmon and ducks swam in the streets of Seward, valuable sled dogs were lost in flooding and the National Guard flew food to people trapped by raging waters unleashed by a freak Alaska typhoon.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY JEWELRY MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TECHNOLOGY MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $6,810 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: IN THE OTHER NICARAGUA: REGGAE AND RESENTMENT
description: Eastern Nicaragua has always been a land unto itself, and today its biggest town is astir with resentment against the Managua Government.

title: Not Just Whistling Dixie
description: At Confederate Memorial Hall, officials refer to the Civil War as the War Between the States, the books on the shelves have titles like ''I Rode With Stonewall,'' and visitors gather to hear old Southern tunes and to eat cornbread and black-eyed peas.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment tax credits of $2.3 million and $8.1 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Inlcudes investment tax credits of $2 million for quarter and $6 million for the 9 months. The company said in the 1986 second quarter it adopted a change in accounting for pensions effective Jan. 1, 1986. This accounting change will increase 1986 pretax income by $17.9 million, or 35 cents a share, of which $4.5 million, or 9 cents a share, is included in the third quarter and $13.5 million, or 27 cents a share, in the 9 months.

title: PARIS SECURITY IS TIGHT FOR SHOWS
description: A radio announcer here this morning told of calling a friend, a young accessories designer, and finding her asleep at 10 o'clock last night. Why, he asked, was she in bed so early? Because of the bombs, she replied. Because the Americans are not coming and there is nothing to do.

title: PROPER JUDGMENT: THE RIGHT PRICE
description: For once, praise a jury for a sensible damage award. Arthur Seitz, a photographer from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was awarded $50 in a lawsuit against Martina Navratilova, the tennis star.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 11 about the career of Laurence A. Tisch, acting chief executive of CBS Inc., misstated the location of the resort hotel that was the first investment of Mr. Tisch and his brother Preston. It was in Lakewood, N.J.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures for both years reflect the Aug. 29, 1986 acquisition of CommerceAmerica Corp., and a 10 percent stock dividend distributed on Aug. 15, 1986.

title: FILM: 'EMPTY QUARTER,' VIEW OF LOVE AND AFRICA
description: THE French photojournalist Raymond Depardon's keen sense of loneliness and dislocation sets the tone for his hauntingly bleak ''Empty Quarter,'' which opens at the Public Theater today. Mr. Depardon's camera wanders across Africa, from Djibouti to Alexandria, and seems to find barren, melancholy images wherever it goes. The cinematography is moody and evocative, and it gives the film a lingering impact, which is very nearly undone by the voice-over narration. Mr. Depardon accompanies his glimpses of these still, deserted places with a silly, exalted romanticism that has far less gravity than the images themselves.

title: EXCERPTS FROM LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR FOES' DEBATE
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between the three candidates in the Nov. 4 election for New York State Lieutenant Governor, Stan Lundine, Democrat-Liberal; Michael Kavanagh, Republican-Conservative, and Thomas A. Droleskey, Right to Life. Their Role in Office

title: One Arrested, 2 Sought In Georgia Slayings of 3
description: One man was arrested and two other suspects were being sought today in the slayings of two men who were shot while handcuffed and a woman whose throat was slashed as she was telephoning the police, the authorities said.

title: ANGELS' CHANCES SLIPPING AWAY AGAIN
description: Even now, four years later, Don Baylor can recall the smallest details about the collapse of 1982. He played for the California Angels back then; he knows how the Angels are feeling now.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the latest year includes a writedown of inventory, principally of equipment returned from rental and a recalculation resulting in an assessment for additional state corporate taxes and interest, all of which amounted to approximately $700,000. The company also said the latest year includes net depreciation of a large scale IBM computer amounting to about $350,000.

title: VLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTRACT SIGNED TO SAVE PERFORMING-ARTS CENTER
description: The Manhattan real-estate developer and philanthropist Lawrence A. Wien signed a $15 million contract yesterday to buy 890 Broadway, the performing-arts center owned by the producer and director Michael Bennett, in a move to save the building from commercial development.

title: Knicks Win by 23 In an Exhibition
description: The Knicks, after two lopsided defeats, routed the Golden State Warriors, 117-94, at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum for their first preseason victory tonight.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the previously reported 1986 segment results have been reclassified to reflect the July 1 reorganization as if it had occurred on Jan. 1. The 1985 data have not been reclassified because the company's divestiture program was not completed and the new organization is not applicable to the former operations.

title: Cabbage Packets
description: CABBAGE has always had a somewhat frumpy image, evoking hearty and soothing but rarely elegant dishes.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net income represents net investment income

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
For 14-Year, Nonrenewable Federal Judgeships
description: >To the Editor:

title: ONE STEP AHEAD OF US; TREND EXPERT'S VIEWS
description: IT was a frightening moment in marketing. Suddenly and without warning, millions of Americans just disappeared from trend monitors and fad-scans. The marketing people called Faith Popcorn, pronto.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Showtime's Chairman Announces Resignation
description: Neil R. Austrian said yesterday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive of Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc. to pursue his other interests.

title: LUNDINE AND KAVANAGH CLASH IN DEBATE
description: The two major party candidates for lieutenant governor of New York differed yesterday on the need for a special prosecutor to investigate corruption in New York City, the death penalty and the necessity for special anti-crack legislation.

title: Group Sells Part Of Viacom Stake
description: An investment group, led by the senior management of Viacom International Inc. and four brokerage houses, has lowered its stake in the communications concern to 6.9 percent, from 7.9 percent.

title: Head of Munitions Plant Killed in Workshop Blast
description: The head of a munitions plant and an employee were killed in an explosion in a workshop today as the executive worked on a ''pet project'' involving black powder, a company official said.

title: THEATER: 'THE DREAMER EXAMINES HIS PILLOW'
description: IN previous plays such as ''Danny and the Deep Blue Sea,'' John Patrick Shanley has revealed a talent for placing characters in violent confrontation. At the same time, he has had a tendency toward verbosity. His new work, ''The Dreamer Examines His Pillow,'' is deluged by words. The play, at the Double Image Theater, deals, at least in its subtext, with questions of art, but it is decidedly lacking in visual and visceral imagery.

title: U.S. IN NEW APPEAL; PRESIDENT HOPEFUL
description: President Reagan appealed to the Soviet Union today ''not to miss the opportunity'' for a major breakthrough on reducing nuclear weapons, saying such an agreement was ''within our grasp.''

title: Federal Judge Blocks Execution in Texas
description: A Federal district judge today blocked the execution of convicted murderer less than 12 hours before he was to be put to death by injection for murdering a gas station cashier.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. said Morris A. Perlis had been named executive vice president and general manager of the Personal Card division, U.S.A.

title: Cuomo Presses Lilco on Study
description: Governor Cuomo has asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to order the Long Island Lighting Company to disclose results of an audit of the qualifications of workers at the Shoreham nuclear plant, the state's consumer advocate said yesterday.

title: LEADERSHIP TRADE DELAYED IN ISRAEL
description: The job switch between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, which was scheduled for today, was postponed at least until Wednesday because of quarreling between the Labor Party and Likud bloc over Cabinet appointments.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said sales to IBM Corp. accounted for about 30 percent of revenue in the latest quarter compared to 49 percent in the year-ago period and that no other customer accounted for 10 percent or more of the revenues during the quarter.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the fiscal 1986 year is after a $22.5 million pre-tax charge for restructuring the company's operations.

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100-percent stock distribution paid in July.

title: New View
description: When Dr. Manuel Gilman began work in the stewards' stand at Belmont Park three weeks ago, he brought with him the experience of having seen more than 75,000 thoroughbred races. Some horseplayers, though, had a reservation: Hadn't he seen most of those races from an unusual vantage point, at ground level from behind the starting gate? True enough, says Gilman. ''But,'' he adds, ''you see a lot from down there.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MOHAWK. By Richard Russo. 418 pages. Vintage Contemporaries. Paper, $6.95. ''IT occurs to him that he had allowed himself to get more keyed up over the operation than he should've,'' writes Richard Russo of his hero, Dan Wood. ''The resulting disappointment was as slow and subtle in coming as the realization that, yes, once again he'd somehow gotten his hopes up. His grip on reality had always been a point of pride with him, and he felt a little like a backsliding AA member for losing that grip. Hope was a luxury he could not afford - a cruelty, really.''

title: MAYOR KOCH GETS PREVIEW OF DUKE ELLINGTON STATUE
description: Mayor Koch got an exclusive peek yesterday at the model for a huge bronze statue of Duke Ellington by the sculptor Robert Graham. The 20-foot high statue, depicting the late pianist, composer and band leader standing at his piano, is planned for the Milbank Frawley Traffic Circle at 110th Street and Fifth Avenue, near the northeast corner of Central Park.

title: LONG ISLAND STRUGGLES FOR AN IDENTITY
description: Having heard the opinions of 1,000 people about Long Island, Prof. Elaine Sherman has arrived at this conclusion: ''We have an identity problem.''

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUSTICES TO HEAR APPEAL ON ABORTIONS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may require girls under 18 years old who seek abortions either to wait 24 hours after the doctor has notified their parents of their plans or to obtain a judicial exemption from the notification requirement.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Sept 27
description: b-Includes a $8,862,000a pension settlement pre-tax gain.

title: PHILADELPHIA INDICTS 9 FROM THE POLICE, 18 OTHERS ON GRAFT CHARGES
description: Nine current and former police officers and 18 people accused of operating illegal lotteries have been indicted here on a variety of charges, the authorities announced today.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
CANNED VS. DRIED BEANS
description: ALTHOUGH dried beans can take a long time to cook, beans and their nutritional benefits - low fat, high protein and high carbohydrates - should not be overlooked. Nearly all types of beans are available canned, and a few frozen. A look at the differences between canned and dried beans may convince you to use the dried.

title: New El Paso Issue Of Housing Bonds
description: The El Paso Housing Finance Corporation is offering $200 million of 8.88 percent multifamily housing revenue bonds due in 1996 at par through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Woman Sues Fertility Center
description: Lawyers for a woman hired to bear the child of an infertile couple sued today to end surrogate motherhoods through the Infertility Center of New York. The suit charges the center and its executive director, Noel P. Keane, with negligence, fraud and breach of faith.

title: INTRAWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIX PREPARE EXPANSION PLEAS
description: There is $600,000 on deposit in an interest-bearing account in the name of the National Basketball Association at the Bank of New England. The money belongs to the expansion hopefuls - $100,000 from each - seeking to put teams in Minneapolis; Miami; Orlando, Fla.; Toronto; Charlotte, N.C., and Orange County, Calif.

title: TRUCK REMOVED FROM RIVER
description: A truck that careened off a bridge into the Snake River with a cargo of uranium was pulled from the river today as a team from the Department of Energy conducted final tests to make sure no radiation was released. The truck, destined for Richland, Wash., had been carrying 20 wooden boxes filled with low-level radiation uranium billets. No measurable traces of radiation was detected.

title: LATIN REPORTER, HERE TO ATTEND AWARDS, IS HELD
description: A journalist from Colombia, invited to the United States by Columbia University to attend ceremonies honoring Latin American journalists, was being detained yesterday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service after her name appeared in the service's ''Lookout Book.''

title: COURT TEST IS LIKELY AS DIAL-A-PORN SERVICES GROW
description: Scores of dial-a-porn telephone services continue to attract millions of calls each month despite Federal regulations that attempt to curtail the business to protect children from the explicit sex messages.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,829,000 for the latest quarter and $1,157,000 for the year-ago period.

title: NORTH SIDE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $995,000 for the quarter and $2,928,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $394,000 for the quarter and $1,008,000 for the year. North Side converted to stock form on April 15.

title: AGENDA: Oct. 15, 1986
description: Sex and School Clinics The Board of Education will consider the distribution of contraceptives at school health clinics. Robert F. Wagner Jr., the board's president, is expected to ask the board members to endorse such a program. He will also urge sex education throughout the system. At a public meeting afterward, look for family planning groups and religious organizations to vent their differences. Public session after 6 P.M. meeting, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn Interstate Homeless Newark Mayor Sharpe James, who last month set a time limit for New York City to remove its homeless from a New Jersey motel, will announce whether he intends to enforce today's deadline. Mayor Koch said yesterday that it would be ''cruel'' to evict the 44 families but that he would not contest the order if it came. 11 A.M., City Hall, 920 Broad Street, Newark

title: COKE BOTTLING UNIT SETS RICHEST STOCK OFFERING
description: The Coca-Cola Company's newly formed bottling concern yesterday announced the terms of an initial public stock offering that would be the richest ever made in the United States.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
J.R. POPPELE, 88, A RADIO-TELEVISION PIONEER
description: Jacob R. Poppele, a pioneer in the development of radio and television whose career began in the early 1920's when he started one of the nation's first radio stations, WOR, died Oct. 7 at the Memorial Hospital Center in Orange, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: Bozell's Omaha Office Wins a Pork Account
description: The Omaha office of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt got the long-awaited word yesterday that it had won the competition for the National Pork Product Council. The Des Moines-based client had talked to a number of agencies before deciding on a home for its $7 million account.

title: To Ways New York City Could Enforce Its Lead-Paint Law
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: >CONCERT FOR GUITAR AND ENIGMA AS concerts go, it was to be a once-in-a-lifetime performance - of the kind, really, that could only happen in New York. The sky was clear, the humidity low and the sun was setting gloriously over the Hudson. ''And there, on the northwest corner of 72d Street and Broadway, a guitarist was playing an exquisite arrangement of the pop tune 'Never Gonna Let You Go,' '' said Christine Lavin of Manhattan, an observer of the scene.

title: Bridge: District Event in New York Set for Grand National Pairs
description: Until the introduction of the Epson World Simultaneous Pairs this year, the biggest such event held anywhere was American Contract Bridge League's Grand National Pairs. Thousands take part each year, and two winners are crowned at the Spring Nationals.

title: BID FOR LUCKY IS RAISED
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, yesterday raised his offer to acquire Lucky Stores Inc. to $37 a share, or $1.88 billion, saying he was ''extremely disappointed'' with a restructuring announced by the company last week.

title: Lloyd Out of Wightman
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the world's second-ranked tennis player and winner of more Wightman Cup matches than any American player, withdrew yesterday from this year's competition because of a knee injury. The United States Tennis Association said Mrs. Lloyd would be replaced on the American team by Stephanie Rehe of Highland, Calif. Miss Rehe, ranked 13th in the world, joins Bonnie Gadusek, Kathy Rinaldi, Anne White and Elise Burgin on the American team that will face Britain in the Wightman Cup matches Oct. 30-Nov. 1 at Royal Albert Hall in London.

title: 'BETTER DAYS,' A NEW SITCOM ON CBS
description: IF the elaborate New York City street set for ''Better Days,'' the new series on CBS Wednesdays at 8:30 P.M., seems remarkably similar to the one used on last season's ''Redd Foxx Show,'' it could be because both sitcoms are Lorimar-Telepictures products and both list Stuart Sheslow as an executive producer. Waste not, want not, evidently, as television tightens its budgets nowadays.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: 5 RUSSIANS GIVEN NEW DAY TO LEAVE
description: The State Department announced today that the remaining Soviet diplomats ordered expelled by the Reagan Administration must leave the United States by Sunday.

title: Sally Ride Is Willing to Fly
description: The astronaut Sally Ride, who is working at NASA's headquarters while the space shuttle is being redesigned, said today that the agency had done a good job and that she had changed her mind about going into orbit again.

title: REAGAN MILITARY BUDGET GETS BIG CUT
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed on a military budget of about $290 billion for 1987 today, giving President Reagan the smallest increase of his Administration.

title: OROSCO IS PERFECT, GETS 2D VICTORY
description: Jesse Orosco is old enough to be linked to the last time the Mets passed this way: He is the relief pitcher acquired from the Minnesota Twins in the 1979 trade for Jerry Koosman. He is also old enough -and the fortunes that accompany his role as a short reliever are so unpredictable - that he has watched someone younger come along to do what he once did.

title: Stardust at the Summit
description: The Reagan-Gorbachev meeting in Iceland should be judged by the immensity of the task. Seldom have two leaders of divided nations tried to do so much in so short a time. Maybe this effort to negotiate the dangerous intricacies of the nuclear balance of power was a blunder. But it was not, as so many are now saying, a disaster. Everything was attempted without success, but nothing was irretrievably lost.

title: In-Flight Rights
description: Whatever was achieved or not achieved in the formal proceedings of the Iceland meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, some accidental progress seems to have occurred in its aftermath. Representatives of three Soviet dissidents who went to Reykjavik to lobby for their release were able to present their case to Yuri V. Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, on an airplane returning to New York, and they came away encouraged.

title: Topics; Proper Judgment: Keep Justice Lazer
description: Normally, Justice Leon Lazer would not have to fight to keep his seat on New York's Supreme Court, where he sits as one of the most respected members of the Appellate Division. Political leaders, who effectively select judges by determining whose names will appear on the ballot, have for generations exempted the ablest sitting judges from partisan re-election battles. A good judge whose term is expiring usually wins the cross-endorsement of the other political party.

title: Ted Bates Worldwide Says Jacoby Has Left
description: Robert E. Jacoby left his office Friday at Ted Bates Worldwide, and it is the agency's understanding that he is not coming back, according to Gina Greer-Whitley, its public relations director.

title: 'STAR WARS' BATTLE LOOMS IN CONGRESS
description: Congressional leaders from both parties agreed today that the outcome of the Reykjavik talks would lead to greater pressure from Capitol Hill next year for progress in arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union.

title: UMPIRE DEFENDS CLOSE CALL AT FIRST
description: The short man with mussed hair stood in black-stockinged feet in front of the umpires' room in the corridor under the Shea Stadium stands yesterday. He was explaining how he made the most controversial call of the day in the fifth game of the National League Championship Series.

title: MARY LUND, HEART RECIPIENT
description: Mary Lund, the first woman to receive an artificial heart, died tonight at Abbott Northwestern Hospital, nine months after her Jarvik-7 pump was replaced with a human heart. She was 40 years old.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

COLUMN ONE;
TRANSPORT
description: Back UpAre Americans losing their terrorist-induced fear of flying?

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
On People at Work
description: For the hundreds of thousands of Federal workers who labor in drab monastic cells all over Washington, there is good news from the Government's landlord and housekeeper, the General Services Administration. Terence C. Golden, Administrator of the agency, has developed a program to provide civil servants by the 1990's with ''intelligently designed, attractive, efficient, people-oriented workspaces.''

title: DEBT EXECUTIVE TESTIFIES HE SET UP LAZAR FUNDS
description: An executive of a company that collected debts for the New York City Parking Violations Bureau testified today that he was the go-between in arranging payments of $2,500 a month to Michael J. Lazar.

title: The Rev. Dr. Roscoe Foust, Former West Point Chaplain
description: The Rev. Dr. Roscoe T. Foust, a onetime West Point chaplain and former director of pastoral and social services of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey, died Oct. 8 at the Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital.

title: Experts Say Soviet Has Conducted Space Tests on Anti-Missle Weapons
description: Experts on Soviet technology said yesterday that the Soviet Union had apparently conducted weapon tests in space of the type that would be restricted by the 10-year ban on ''Star Wars'' testing proposed by the Russians in Iceland.

title: SHEPARD J. CRUMPACKER
description: Former Representative Shepard J. Crumpacker died today at St. Joseph Medical Center after an illness.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE RED, WHITE AND GREEN Between 1820 and 1981, the second largest group of immigrants to the United States, calculated by country of previous residence, came from Italy. Germany sent the largest group. In New York, ''the single largest ancestral group in the state, the city and at CUNY,'' the City University of New York, is Italian-American, according to the Italian-American Institute of the City University of New York (382-0629 or 473-3215).

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIME INC. WILL BUY TEXTBOOK PUBLISHER
description: Time Inc,. the nation's largest magazine publisher, said yesterday that it would acquire the company that helped teach millions of Americans how to read. In a $520 million deal, Time plans to acquire Scott, Foresman & Company, the elementary and high school textbook publisher that for years produced the Dick and Jane readers.

title: MORGAN, J P & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSFER QUARTERBACK KEY TO SUCCESS
description: Undefeated William & Mary is off to the best start in its football team's 94-year history, largely because a substitute University of Virginia basketball forward decided in December 1983 to become a William & Mary football quarterback.

title: GRAND DINING RETURNS TO AMERICAN HOTELS: A SELECT SAMPLER
description: DISCRIMINATING diners, as recently as five years ago, considered hotel restaurants to be little more than gastronomic purgatories, the purlieu of hapless travelers who lacked the time or knowledge to escape to a ''real'' restaurant. Today, all that has changed. In major cities across the country - from Boston, New York and Washington to Houston, Dallas, Los Angeles and Seattle - some of the most outstanding food and service is found in hotels.

title: A Spokesman Departs
description: Charles E. Redman, who has been serving as spokesman for the State Department since the resignation of Bernard Kalb last week, is leaving Washington to join the staff of the Secretary General of NATO, further intensifying Secretary of State George P. Shultz's search for a new Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs.

title: ALICE LUCILLE EMERICK
description: Alice Lucille Emerick, a former actress who was known professionally as Alice Scudder and who co-founded the American Theater Company, an Off Broadway group, died of cancer on Oct. 1 at the New Haven home of her daughter. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OFFICIAL BUILDINGS ARE FIRED ON IN TOKYO
description: Attackers believed by the police to be left-wing radicals fired six home-made rockets this evening in the direction of the Prime Minister's official residence and other Government installations.

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes charges, from provisions for income taxes, of $400,000 and $282,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. c-Includes a charge from a cumulative effect on prior years of accounting change for estimated costs to service memberships amounting to $467,000, less an income-tax effect of $432,000. Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in July 1986.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax securities gains of $2.5 million for the latest quarter and $5.4 million for the year-ago period. The latest quarter also includes a $2.8 million gain on the sale of equity securities, compared with a similar gain of $4.5 million in the year-ago period. The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid in November.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Walter Berry, the former St. John's all-American, signed a multi-year contract with the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday and took part in his first practice. Terms were not disclosed. The Blazers also signed Caldwell Jones, a free-agent center. . . The Washington Bullets signed John Williams, a swingman and the club's top draft choice from Louisiana State, and Frank Johnson, a veteran guard. . . . Bob Quinn, an assistant coach at Fordham for the past six years, will serve as interim basketball coach for the 1986-87 season while a search for a new head coach continues, the school said yesterday. . . . The Devils sent a rookie right wing, Doug Brown, to Maine of the American Hockey League . . . The Toronto Blue Jays released Mickey Mahler, a left-handed pitcher who had been obtained from the Texas Rangers on Sept. 1.

title: USX Stock Falls on Rumor
description: The stock of the USX Corporation, the most heavily traded issue yesterday, fell as speculators began to worry about whether the investor Carl C. Icahn would go forward with his offer to buy the steel and oil company.

title: Power Left
description: Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears, when asked whether William Perry had by now reduced to 320 pounds: ''Yeah. On his left side.''

title: U.S. Sees 'Subsidy War'
description: The Reagan Administration now sees Japan as its main opponent in an approaching ''subsidy war'' over the use of development aid funds to win export orders in foreign markets, a senior Treasury official said today.

title: Wary Fans Return to Shea
description: From Nolan Ryan's perfect start to the final delirious chants of ''GA-RY!'' yesterday's game was one for baseball purists.

title: An Outspoken Mayor
description: Jose Happart is the mayor, or ''bourgemeester,'' as some say here in Voeren, the Dutch name for this tiny commune of six villages and 4,000 people in Dutch-speaking Flanders.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on Nov. 30, 1985.

title: SIPPICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
U.S. INDICTS 3 FOR FRAUD IN BEVILL, BRESLER TRADING
description: Federal prosecutors announced a 26-count indictment today against three principals in Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., the failed firm that traded in government securities and was put into receivership in April 1985, owing its customers about $144 million more than it had in assets.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $75,000 and $235,000 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $87,000 and $216,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings are restated to reflect the 5-percent stock dividend paid in August 1986.

title: SIGNET BANKING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOINT PROJECT TO PROMOTE TV PROGRAMS ON JAPAN
description: WNET and the Japan Society will announce a joint project today aimed at creating programs about Japan that will be available to all public television stations in the United States. Japanese corporations will be asked to help finance the project, WNET officials said.

title: HEXCEL'S HONEYCOMB SUCCESS
description: If the Voyager, an experimental airplane, succeeds in its attempt to fly around the world on a single tank of fuel, it will be an accomplishment not only for the plane's designer and crew, but also for a little-known San Francisco company, the Hexcel Corporation.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter's net was reduced by $10.6 million in costs related to the acquisition of Thrifty Corp. The year-ago quarter's net reflects a charge of $60 million for the writeoff of Pacific's 10 percent interest in the Great Plains Coal Gasification Project. Year-ago figures were also restated to include Pacific's acquisition of Thrifty in August. The latest 9 months' figures reflect a $118 million after-tax writedown of oil and gas properties in the first quarter.

title: METS WIN ON CARTER'S HIT IN 12TH FOR 3-2 EDGE
description: The Mets marched to the brink of the National League pennant yesterday when they edged the Houston Astros, 2-1, in a titanic struggle that ended when Gary Carter singled home the winning run in the 12th inning.

title: KEY RATES
PACIFIC FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $3,114,000 for the quarter.

title: Burroughs Wellcome Places Anti-AIDS Drug
description: The Burroughs Wellcome Company has assigned its new anti-AIDS drug to Rolf Werner Rosenthal Inc., already one of its agencies, and it will produce an informational advertising campaign for primary care physicians.

title: No Reason to Flip-Flop on Lumber
description: The Commerce Department was emphatically clear, three years ago: No, American lumber companies should not have a say in the fees that Canada charges Canadian companies to harvest Canadian Government forests. That disposed of a petition from the American companies, asking for penalties on wood imports.

title: HOW TO FEED 1,200 FIGHTING A FOREST FIRE
description: THE Keeners cater at forest fires. Last year they did about $2.5 million in business, serving something in the range of a quarter million meals to firefighters in Nevada, Idaho, Montana, Oregon and Washington - an area known to the Forest Service as Region 6.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: OVER the course of a year, a third of all runners -whether dedicated marathoners or occasional joggers - can expect to suffer at least one running-related injury, ranging in seriousness from minor sprains to rare but debilitating fractures. And with tens of thousands training for marathons (the New York Marathon will be run Nov. 2), the risk of injury has risen as runners of all sizes, shapes and ages strive to achieve their personal best.

title: Asbestos in Play Sand
description: The Department of Health said today it had found traces of asbestos in samples of play sand, but that there was no imminent health hazard. Health officials studied samples of Kiddie Fun Sand, which had been voluntarily recalled in New Jersey.

title: REPUBLIC BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BAGS TO GO AND GROW
description: 1. Bagging It For the avid skier, shopping early makes the snowflakes seem that much closer. This sleek leather version of the fashionable European ski bag can be buckled around the waist or hung from a long strap worn across the chest. The bag shown here is bright pink, trimmed with pink iridescent cotton and black and turquoise leather. It also comes in white, green, black or blue. For $65 at the Bogner boutique, 655 Madison Avenue at 60th Street. 2. Packing It In If you are a traveler who always needs an extra suitcase at the end of a trip, here is the solution - the Expand-a-Bag, a little black nylon suitcase that grows and grows. Unzip the two compartments on the bottom and the bag expands from 16 inches to 28 inches tall. The bag has handles, a long, adjustable strap and sturdy wheels. It is available by mail from D. H. Doelker Inc., 20 West 20th Street, New York, N.Y., 10011. The cost is $29.95, plus $6 for shipping and handling. New York State residents must add $2.47 for sales tax. Telephone orders are also accepted at 212-242-5565. 3. Lighting the Way Flashlights can be fun when they are as bright and cheery as this plastic one from Leadworks. It is yellow, with a purple handle and turquoise trim. The price is $15 at Dapy, 431 West Broadway, between Prince and Spring Streets, and 232 Columbus Avenue, between 71st and 72d Streets. 4.

title: PRESIDENT APPOINTED AT RESEARCH VENTURE
description: Steven Lazarus, group vice president of health care services at Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., has been named president and chief executive of the new Argonne National Laboratory/University of Chicago Development Corporation.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fishing Method Barred To Avert Porpoise Kills
description: The Federal Government ordered a temporary halt today to the tuna industry's practice of setting its fishing nets around schools of porpoises, a technique that has killed nearly 20,000 porpoises this year.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The prior year figures reflect merger with Commonwealth Trust Bancorp. Share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid July 31.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company said results for the fiscal 1985 year are after a pre-tax provision of $36,966,000 for consolidation of operations.

title: Northrop Loss Is $30.5 Million
description: The Northrop Corporation today reported a third-quarter net loss of $30.5 million despite increases in sales and a business backlog, in contrast to net income of $47.8 million, or $1.03 a share, for the comparable 1985 quarter. The company attributed the loss to a $90 million adjustment stemming from the lower operating margin it expects to earn on a research and development contract.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After Reykjavik, it is clear to everyone that S.D.I. is a symbol of obstruction to the cause of peace, the epitome of militarist schemes and the unwillingness to remove the nuclear menace to mankind. There can be no other interpretation of it and this is the most important lesson from the meeting in Reykjavik.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: NO MORE SELLING OF VOTES? COUNTY IS A LITTLE WARY
description: It was four years ago when they held the last sheriff's election in Clay County, and both the candidate who won and the one who did not were later sent away to Federal prison for buying votes.

title: SEX: AT CITY SCHOOL CLINICS, IT'S A HEALTH ISSUE
description: A 16-year-old student visited the health clinic at Martin Luther King Jr. High School yesterday morning for a pregnancy test. She waited 15 minutes and had her suspicions confirmed: she was pregnant.

title: Stop Financing Deficit With Foreign Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Man From Upstate New York Gets Jarvik 7 Artificial Heart
description: A 43-year-old man from upstate New York became the second patient in less than a week and the eighth in a year to receive a Jarvik-7 mechanical heart at Presbyterian-University Hospital here.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $90 million representing a margin adjustment reflecting the lower operating margin the company expects ultimately to earn on a long-term customer-sponsored research and development contract. c-Net income

title: Racial Stereotypes Are Common in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE stated before that I am a bargain hunter at heart when it comes to grocery shopping. It gives me pleasure to know that I have purchased a bit of quality merchandise on sale, whether ground meat or a piece of well-trimmed fillet.

title: SENATE NOMINEE PUSHES 'STAR WARS' IN COLORADO
description: For months, Representative Ken Kramer, the Republican candidate in the race to succeed Senator Gary Hart, has been promoting President Reagan's space-based missile defense program.

title: FOOTBALL PLAYERS SUSPENDED FOR ATTACKING GIRL ON TEAM
description: A girl on the football team at North Hunterdon Regional High was knocked to the ground, struck and spat upon by three male teammates before practice last month in what school officials described as an attempt to get her to quit the squad.

title: Doug Flutie Rights Traded to the Bears
description: Doug Flutie's long-awaited chance to play in the National Football League came a step closer today, moments before the trading deadline passed.

title: CABLE COMPANY DISCUSSED HIRING FRIEDMAN FOR $10,000 A MONTH
description: The company selected to provide cable television service in the Bronx said yesterday that it had discussed hiring Stanley M. Friedman and other Bronx politicians under contracts totaling hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.

title: Emigres Plead Cases In a Plane Encounter
description: Two Soviet emigres flying home from Iceland found themselves seated near the Soviet Ambassador to the United States and used the encounter to press for the granting of exit visas to relatives.

title: PRICES OF U.S. SECURITIES FALL
description: Facing stiff competition from a $4 billion offering of corporate notes and lackluster investor demand before new Treasury offerings expected during the next month, prices of outstanding Treasury issues fell modestly yesterday.

title: Rates on Oregon Notes Up Because of Tax Law
description: Interest rates on a $185 million issue of Oregon notes due in one year were increased by about one-fourth percentage point or more because interest on the notes will be subject to the alternative minimum personal income tax, according to the tax bill recently approved by Congress. President Reagan is expected to sign it.

title: Warsaw Cuts Terms of 3 Jailed in Death of Priest
description: Prosecutors today reduced the sentences of three security police officers convicted in the death of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a Solidarity supporter.

title: Japan Air Sets Boeing Deal
description: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it had agreed to buy 11 airplanes from the Boeing Company for $870 million.

title: British Interest Rates Rise
description: Britain's interest rates went up by a full percentage point today as the Government tried to stem the pound's recent weakness on currency markets.

title: Hutton Case Is Criticized in House
description: A House subcommittee today strongly criticized the check overdrafting case brought by the Justice Department last year against E. F. Hutton & Company, charging that the investigation and lawsuit were flawed and that criminal prosecutions of individuals at Hutton should have been brought.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the results include negative tax provisions of $2 million and $13.3 million for the quarter and year-ago period, respectively, and the year-ago period also includes a $3.5 million loss on the sale of Kaiser Aluminum's International trading business.

title: New Olympic Cycle Approved
description: The International Olympic Committee voted today to alternate the summer and winter Games every two years, beginning in 1994.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $11,319,000, or 23 cents per share.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STUDY SAYS SOME BABIES STAY IN HOSPITAL TOO LONG
description: Many premature babies are kept in the hospital several days longer than necessary while their parents, with a little training from a nurse, could be caring for them at home and saving thousands of dollars in medical costs, a new study concludes.

title: VAC-TEC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings equal less than one cent a share.

title: Executive May Get Lord & Taylor Post
description: Marshall Hilsberg, the 41-year-old president and chief executive of G. Fox & Company of Hartford, is expected to be appointed chairman and chief executive of Lord & Taylor.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON VAST REVISIONS IN LAWS ON ALIENS
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on the terms of a landmark immigration bill that would prohibit the hiring of illegal aliens and offer legal status to several million illegal aliens already in the United States.

title: WITNESS FOR U.S. IN BRIBERY TRIAL FILES GUILTY PLEA
description: A Manhattan psychiatrist who is to testify for the Government in the corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to offering a ''reward'' to Donald R. Manes for efforts to get a Queens psychiatric hospital an operating license.

title: Excerpts From Reagan's Talk to Executive Branch Employees
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address today to executive branch employees at the Old Executive Office Building:

title: CHERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The company said year-ago loss is after a special pre-tax charge of $3.5 million to cover anticipated losses associated with the planned phaseout of domestic keyboard production

title: Medicine Must Not Be Exclusive to the Affluent
description: To the Editor:

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GLAXO HOLDINGS PLC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depository Receipt (ADR) and each ADR represents one share of Glaxo ordinary stock. All results are in U.S. dollars. The company said sales for both periods have been adjusted for comparison to exclude sales of companies which are not now part of Glaxo Group.

title: Surgery for McGee
description: Willie McGee, the St. Louis Cardinals' center fielder, and Andre Thornton, the Cleveland Indians' designated hitter, have undergone surgery on their left knees. The 27-year-old McGee had arthroscopic surgery on Monday to repair torn cartilage and is expected to be ready for next season, the team said.

title: Police Car Is Stolen By Handcuffed Man
description: A handcuffed man left alone in the back seat of a police car jumped into the driver's seat and sped away yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: OFFICIAL DESCRIBES PARLEY IN ICELAND
description: A Pentagon official, offering new details of the Iceland meeting, said today that the talks ended after Mikhail S. Gorbachev had toughened his bargaining position in response to an American demand.

title: Joffrey Ballet Marks 30th Anniversary
description: The Joffrey Ballet will celebrate its 30th anniversary in a five-week season that opens tomorrow at the newly renovated City Center Theater and features new ballets by Mark Morris and Mark Haim and a new production of ''La Fille Mal Gardee,'' by Sir Frederick Ashton.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net income of $588,000, or 1 cent a share, and $3,396,000, or 7 cents a share, for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, as a result of the change in accounting principle, effective Jan. 1, when the company adopted FASB 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results include costs associated with an 11-week strike at the company's pulp and paper mill totaling approximately $30 million before tax, or 55 cents a share, after tax.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Winn Bankruptcy
description: Winn Enterprises, the parent of Knudsen Foods Inc., filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws. Knudsen, the West's largest dairy company, filed for Chapter 11 protection on Sept. 17. Winn said the filing would not affect the operations or financial condition of its Mountainwest Savings and Loan Association of Salt Lake City, which has $340 million of assets.

title: TELXON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes utilization of foreign tax credits of $95,000 and $184,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $45,000 for both the year- ago quarter and 6 months. Share earnings are restated to give effect to the 3-for-2 stock split effective May 12, 1986.

title: U.S. IN NEW APPEAL; RUSSIAN IS CRITICAL
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that President Reagan had proved lacking in courage and political will to take a historic step forward at their Iceland meeting.

title: JWP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $23 million charge from the settlement of litigation, the writedown of inventory and the sale of a subsidiary. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid on June 12, 1986.

title: MUSIC: ANOTHER VIENNA
description: ACROSS the street from the Museum of Modern Art, which is offering the classiest concert series currently running in New York as a pendant to its ''Vienna 1900'' exhibit, the Donnell Library has presented a pair of interestingly chosen spinoff concerts. The second, called ''Vienna 1910: The Other Musical Avant-Garde,'' was given Sunday afternoon by members of the New Haven Chamber Ensemble.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MASSBANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures for the year- ago quarter and both 9-month periods are not available. The company went public in May.

title: Soviet General in Kabul Says Troops Are Going
description: A Soviet general said today that about 8,000 Soviet troops would leave beginning Wednesday under a plan announced earlier this year.

title: Valid Referendums
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M.'s Stance On Japanese
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that unless Japanese auto makers reduced the number of cars they ship to the United States, stiffer anti-import legislation or import quotas were likely.

title: INSIDE
description: Time Buys Text Publisher Time agreed to buy the textbook publisher Scott, Foresman, which once supplied Dick and Jane readers, for a price of $520 million.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 15, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SALVADOR QUAKE AID RISING, BUT SHORTAGES REMAIN
description: Aid appeared to be increasing today for the estimated 100,000 Salvadorans affected by the earthquake last Friday.

title: FRANCES C. CHOATE
description: Frances C. Choate, who as a youth made news by walking from Rochester to San Francisco, died of cancer Oct. 3 at her home in Southbury, Conn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1986
description: Companies

title: STAGE: 'ATKINSON AT THE ATKINSON'
description: GREAT comedy, it's said, has a grain of truth in it. Truth-seekers who visit Rowan Atkinson, the English comic who's traveled to Broadway's Brooks Atkinson Theater, may sit up and take notice when the star appears in devil's costume late in Act I. ''As the most perceptive of you have realized by now, this is hell,'' says Mr. Atkinson - then adding, ''You're here for eternity.'' The line gets a laugh because, for once, the man is speaking the truth.

title: REAGAN DESTROYS A TABOO
description: The Reykjavik summit meeting has shown Americans that President Reagan is a man of greater vision than many of us expected, bolder and more foresighted than most of those who oppose his nuclear policy.

title: The Politics of End-of-Session Nominations
description: The end of a Congressional session resembles a frantic marketplace. Legislation is the main commodity, with bills being traded, killed and resurrected at a dizzying pace.

title: WINE TALK
description: Richard Olney, an American who lives in France and who during three decades has turned out some of America's best-known cookbooks, has written his first volume on wine. It is a large-format, luxury volume on Chateau d'Yquem, the world's best-known producer of sweet white wine.

title: STRONG GAIN POSTED BY APPLE
description: Buoyed by increased acceptance among business users and continued strength in educational sales, Apple Computer Inc. today reported a 46.9 percent increase in earnings for its fourth quarter ended Sept. 26.

title: Firefighter to Be Moved In Right-to-Die Case
description: The wife of a former firefighter who has been kept alive for three and a half years says her husband will be moved this week from the hospital that touched off a long legal battle by refusing to disconnnect his feeding tube.

title: RIPLEY COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ARE BRITISH BANDS BETTER OR IN BUSINESS BIASED?
description: THE Beatles asked to hold our hands, and we haven't been the same since. That first British invasion of American pop music has had many consequences, the most tenacious of which has been that curious subgroup within rock fandom, the Anglophiles. Ever since the Beatles landed, no matter what the state of British rock, there has been a loyal core of American Anglophiles insisting that if it's rock-and-roll you want, the British do it better.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES INCREASE 22.6%
description: Customers rushed to new-car showrooms in early October, hoping to take advantage of expiring record low-interest-rate incentives, and pushed auto sales 22.6 percent above last year for the first 10 days of the month, the car makers said today.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PEOPLE SALE TENTATIVELY APPROVED
description: The Transportation Department today gave tentative approval to the Texas Air Corporation's proposed acquisition of the financially weak People Express Inc.

title: Making a Mold of General Jackson
description: People in Jacksonville, Fla., may recognize the tall statue of Andrew Jackson astride a rearing horse that stands in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House. Its silhouette has been on their city seal for years.

title: CHASE OFF
description: Four major bank holding companies reported third-quarter gains yesterday, while a fifth reported a slight decline. But even some of the banks whose profits rose said continuing problems with loans and a strong dollar, which has raised costs overseas, tended to crimp performance.

title: New Zealand Yacht Remains Unbeaten
description: Undefeated New Zealand dominated White Crusader of Britain today, setting up a showdown with Stars & Stripes of the United States on Thursday that will likely decide the winner of the first round in the America's Cup challenger selection trials.

title: ABC SAYS IT FORESEES LOSSES FOR 1986 AND 1987
description: The top executives of Capital Cities/ABC said yesterday that the broadcasting network, struggling with low ratings and a slow advertising marketplace, would probably lose money this year and in 1987 as well.

title: THIRD-GENERATION PERFORMER
description: Keenan Wynn - who played a clowning thug in ''Kiss Me Kate,'' blasted a vending machine in ''Dr. Strangelove'' and was one of Hollywood's most versatile supporting actors - died of cancer yesterday at his home in Brentwood, Calif. He was 70 years old.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 15.

title: Meritor Marketing Conduit Securities
description: The Meritor Financial Group is offering $200 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Collateralized Mortgage Obligation Trust II, a unit established by Salomon Brothers Inc. The securities are backed by 9 1/2 percent Federal National Mortgage Association pass-through certificates and are divided into four issues with yields ranging from 7.81 percent for an issue with an estimated average life of 3.4 years to 10.15 percent for 18.8 years.

title: Car Bomb in Barcelona Kills Spanish Policeman
description: A car bomb exploded in front of a police barracks here today, and a hospital spokesman said at least one policeman had been killed.

title: RED SOX VICTORY TIES SERIES AT 3-3
description: Two days earlier, the California Angels stood only one strike from winning the first pennant in their 26-year existence and the first pennant in Gene Mauch's 25 years of star-crossed managing. Now the team and their manager teeter on the brink of another failure.

title: Orange Julius Plan By Reuters
description: Orange Julius International Inc. said its board had approved a plan to restructure the company by disposing of all operations except its Orange Julius drink and fast-food franchise businesses.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Shultz to Meet Soviet Counterpart For Talks in Vienna in November
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he planned to meet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze early next month in Vienna to press ahead toward accords that were nearly achieved at the meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Gorbachev About Iceland Meeting
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the Soviet television yesterday, as translated by Cable News Network and recorded by The New York Times:

title: Gelco Plans Sales Of 5 of Its Units
description: The Gelco Corporation said it expected to receive more than $427 million for the sale of five of its business units. Gelco, a leasing and management services company, said it would sell Gelco TIP Trailer Leasing, Gelco Express Ltd., the British operations of Gelco Fleet Management Services, Gelco Space and its Puerto Rico vehicle leasing unit.

title: PEACE CORPS DAYS A PLUS FOR TEACHERS
description: LIKE all schools, New York City schools begin each year with administrative snafus and breakdowns - undelivered books, cracked petrie dishes, no chalk. These problems irk many teachers, but Ellen Blanker, a teacher at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn, is fairly unfazed.

title: King Requests Equal Time ALBANY (AP)-
description: Peter King, the Republican candidate for attorney general, says radio and television stations that have carried public service announcements by his incumbent opponent, Robert Abrams, should give him equal air time.

title: THE BEST, FROM NEW YORK TO NEWPORT BEACH
description: HERE is a selective roundup of leading hotel restaurants in major cities around the United States. All but 5 of the 35 listed have been visited by Bryan Miller or Pierre Franey; the others are included on the basis of their exceptionally strong reputations. New York Drake Hotel: Restaurant Lafayette, 440 Park Avenue; 2l2-832-1565. Jean-Georges Vongerichten, chef. The Drake, owned by Swissotel, opened the stunning $1.5 million Lafayette in July under the supervision of Louis Outhier, the renowned French chef of the famed Michelin three-star l'Oasis at La Napoule on the French Riviera.
