The bright Mediterranean-style food, turned out by Mr. Outhier's day-to-day chef, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, has been the talk of the Manhattan food world in recent months. Lexington Hotel: Menage a Trois, 134 East 48th Street; 212-593-8242. Antony Worrall-Thompson, chef.

title: HOME BREW IS BACK, IT'S LEGAL AND MAKERS PRAISE THE TASTE
description: STICKY sweet, seemingly thick enough to peel off the walls, the smell of boiling malt is the immediate and enveloping evidence that beer-making is going on. Home brewers adore it. And today the taste of home-made beer is not only prompting more people to make their own, it is also encouraging small entrepreneurs to reproduce the taste commercially.

title: Article 042186 -- No Title
description: IC Industries reported a third-quarter net loss of $259.6 million, reflecting a one-time charge of $530.2 million from discontinued operations at its rail and military businesses.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPEC SHAPING QUOTA GUIDLINES
description: Oil prices continued to decline today as OPEC ministers struggled through a weary ninth day of talks, trying to devise a price-support plan.

title: B.&O. to Be Ended As Separate Entity
description: The historic Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, the nation's oldest, is being eliminated as a separate business and consolidated into its parent company's transportation division, the company announced. The CSX Corporation said Monday it also would consolidate the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway into the division, CSX Transportation, as part of an overall restructuring.

title: NOW IN THE BEST OF COMPANY, GRITS CHANGES ITS IMAGE
description: FOR a foodstuff whose essential trait is blandness, grits are - or is (that will be sorted out later) - the source of remarkably peppery controversy. The humble cereal, consisting of coarsely ground dried, hulled corn kernels, has a long history of inspiring both testimony and invective.

title: SMOKELESS TOBACCO AT ISSUE
description: Although Congress approved legislation early this year requiring health warning labels on snuff and chewing tobacco, the controversy over them has resumed as the Federal Trade Commission struggles to devise rules implementing the law.

title: Butchers Gain Tentative Pact
description: Tentative agreement on a new contract was reached shortly before a midnight strike deadline last night by negotiators for meat cutters who work for five supermarket chains in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and on Long Island.

title: White House Official Linked To Arms Deliveries to Contras
description: A report by the staff of Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, charges that a member of the White House staff helped set up a private network that delivers arms to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: ISLANDER COACH NOT IMPRESSED
description: Two games into the season, the Islanders have not impressed their new coach, Terry Simpson, with their work ethic, concentration or winning attitude.

title: Man Charged In Bilking Plan
description: An 18-year-old North Brunswick man has been arrested and charged with using newspaper advertisements to bilk potential borrowers of more than $50,000, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Californian To Join Mellon
description: Richard H. Daniel, a West Coast banker with extensive credit experience, has been named a vice chairman of the Mellon Bank Corporation and its Mellon bank, it was announced yesterday.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $60 million after taxes from the sale of Computer Power Inc.

title: CITY ORDER TO DEMAND 12-STORY CUT FROM TOWER
description: The city will order that the top 12 stories be removed from a 31-story apartment building under construction on East 96th Street, after a ruling yesterday by a city appeals panel that the building is taller than zoning allows, the City Buildings Commissioner said.

title: DEFENDANT TAKES STAND IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: A defendant accused of heading the Mafia in Sicily testified in his own defense yesterday, telling the jury in the ''pizza connection'' trial that he had never dealt in drugs.

title: Preschool Enrollment Climbs To a Record High for Nation
description: Enrollment in kindergarten and nursery schools is at record levels as births edge upward, a trend that Census Bureau officials say will soon reverse the long-term decline in elementary school enrollment.

title: Advertising; Putting Cognac in Subways
description: IF you are lucky enough to be a New York subway rider, then you must have noticed the advertisements for Mumm V.S.O.P. Cognac. They are hard to miss really, since Seagram has contracted for what in effect are arches of advertising in 4,500 of the city's 6,000 cars.

title: Alimentary, Old Chap
description: Ordinarily I would have ignored news that an Albany restaurant much favored by New York State legislators had been closed by the Government, allegedly for tax-law violations. The context of the seizure, however, was anything but ordinary.

title: Runner Challenged
description: Videotapes have been submitted to The Athletics Congress for a ruling on whether Nancy Ditz, the second-place finisher in the Twin Cities Marathon in Minnesota Sunday, was unfairly assisted. Cathie Twomey, who was the fourth-place finisher in the women's elite division, said Ms. Ditz's husband, Bruce Mohrbacker, and Rod Dixon, a friend and former world-record distance runner, ran onto the course several times to offer encouragement.

title: NEW ENGLAND SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form in August.

title: MAGNET BANK A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $2.2 million increase in the reserve for possible losses on loans in real estate owned. c-Net income

title: ELIE WIESEL GETS NOBEL FOR PEACE AS 'MESSENGER'
description: Elie Wiesel, who survived Nazi death camps to become a witness against forgetfulness and violence, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today.

title: Market Place; How Humana Lost Glamour
description: IN February, Humana Inc. was the favorite of many Wall Street analysts who follow the hospital management industry. Its stock was trading then above $33 a share - not far below its record price of $36.75 set in mid-1985. Here was an issue with steadily rising profits that, adjusted for numerous splits, sold as low as $1 a share in 1977.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 stock split Oct. 1.

title: SOVIET ANTARCTIC RESEARCH STATION IS LOST IN THE ICE
description: One of the Soviet Union's Antarctic research stations, which was about to be occupied again for the annual summer season, has vanished.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HERMANN VON SIEMENS, DIRECTOR OF GERMAN CONCERN FOR 27 YEARS
description: Hermann von Siemens, an industrialist who for 27 years headed the Siemens Company, West Germany's largest producer of electronic and computer goods, died Monday in Munich. He was 101 years old. His death was announced yesterday by Siemens headquarters in Munich. It did not disclose the cause of death.

title: America's Foundling Teams
description: High school football stars who find their route to major-college fields blocked by freshman eligibility standards may soon have a new alternative: the pros.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MY children are upstairs in the house next door, having dinner with the Ecuadorean family that lives on the top floor. The father speaks some English, the mother less than that. The two daughters are fluent in both their native and their adopted languages, but the youngest child, a son, a close friend of my two boys, speaks almost no Spanish. His parents thought it would be better that way. This doesn't surprise me; it was the way my mother was raised, American among the Italians.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Economic Scene; Soviet Arms Vs. Growth
description: THE stalemate reached in the arms talks in Iceland between President Reagan and General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev is likely to interfere with the Soviet leader's ambitious plans for reinvigorating his country's economy.

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WITNESS TO EVIL: ELIEZER WEISEL
description: Elie Wiesel went home Monday afternoon to rest from a wearying day of fasting and prayer at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan and was confronted by a Norwegian reporter who said his newspaper was planning a front-page article declaring him the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: 'I'm Not an .050 Hitter'
description: In the eighth inning of last Saturday's third game, Gary Carter drilled a low line drive toward Charlie Kerfeld, the Astros' husky right-hander. While falling toward first base, Kerfeld swung his glove behind his back and Carter's drive hopped into it. Kerfeld stared at Carter, pointed to the Mets' catcher with his right hand that held the ball, then threw to first for the out.

title: The Leg of the League
description: * Active players. finis

title: Journalists Honored By Cabot Prize Panel
description: Correspondents of The Miami Herald and of Time magazine, along with newspapers and editors in Argentina and Colombia, will be awarded the 1986 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes tomorrow at Columbia University. The award is given to Western Hemisphere journalists for distinguished contributions to the advancement of inter-American understanding and freedom of information.

title: VALLEY UTAH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The share earnings for both year- ago periods have been restated to reflect the 15 percent stock dividend declared May 8, 1986.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring gains of $11,464,000, or 20 cents a share and $29,188,000, or 51 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of the company's Water Management Chemical business in the latest third quarter. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $8,139,000 from the sale of certain businesses. Results reflect the adoption of new FASB pension accounting standards.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: The company said the latest quarter results include $6.4 million in charges related to the reduction of jobs in the company's computer and controls operations in Phoenix.

title: RAI RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $72,059.

title: Swiss Tourism Down
description: The declining dollar and the fear of terrorism in Europe had a sharp impact on the Swiss tourist industry this summer, the Government said today. Tourists from the United States in June, July and August spent a total of 742,100 nights in Swiss hotels, a sharp 48 percent drop from the comparable period last year. The total of overnight stays in Swiss hotels during the quarter was listed at 10,970,000, down 5 percent from the period a year ago and a six-year-low.

title: F.B.I. SAYS REPORTED CRIMES ROSE 8% IN FIRST HALF OF YEAR
description: The number of serious crimes that were reported to the police rose 8 percent in the first half of 1986, the largest increase in six years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $61.4 million for the quarter and $72.1 million for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $600,000 for the quarter and the 9 months is after a loss from discontinued operations of $8.3 million. The company said the latest results reflect a special pre-tax charge of $449.4 million, recorded in September, mainly related to the company's ICG Railroad and Pneumo Abex Corp. units.

title: INDEPENDENT BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $179,000 for the quarter and $338,000 for the 9 months.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEDIATOR ENTERS TALKS IN MUSICIANS' STRIKE
description: A Federal mediator has entered the deadlocked negotiations between the striking Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and 12 New York-area orchestras that hire freelance musicians.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,350,000 from the settlement of a patent infringement suit.

title: Sterling Optical Joins Bloom
description: The Bloom Agency is topping a year of positive new-business performance by welcoming Sterling Optical of Woodbury, L.I., to the client list of the New York office. The agency said the budget would be $6 million.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
Campeau Reports Response to Offer
description: The Campeau Corporation said shareholders had tendered about 34.5 million shares of Allied Stores Corporation stock, or about two-thirds of the total outstanding, under its tender offer that was to expire at midnight last night.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' results include those of Provident Institution for Savings, acquired in April, and First Bank of Massachusetts, acquired in August. The year-ago periods' include results on a pooling of interests basis of Arltru Bancorp, acquired in August 1985, and Seymour Trust Co., acquired in October 1985. Per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Oct. 20.

title: Dock Workers' Local Reaches Tentative Pact
description: Negotiators reached a tentative agreement today between the largest of four striking dock workers' locals and dock companies here, a union leader said, but workers will not return to their jobs pending a ratification vote.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,473,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Real Estate; El Barrio Market's Renewal
description: FIFTY years ago Mayor La Guardia put a marketplace underneath the Park Avenue elevated train tracks between 111th and 116th streets. The purpose was to clear congested streets of pushcart vendors and to provide clean spaces for small neighborhood businesses.

title: The War Over Star Wars
description: Star Wars was not, as the White House is now working to remind the world, the only thing discussed at the Iceland summit meeting. The President and Mikhail Gorbachev broke some enormous pieces off the rock of arms control. The gains were conditional on the Soviet side, but they might yet become elements in a spectacular breakthrough.

title: UNION'S ACCORD WITH HOSPITALS COVERS 5 YEARS
description: A tentative agreement was announced yesterday on a three-year contract for union workers at 40 nonprofit hospitals and nine nonprofit nursing homes in the city.

title: 60 GUARDS STAY OFF JOB IN RIKERS ISLAND PROTEST
description: Sixty guards last night refused to take their assigned posts at the largest unit of New York City's jail system on Rikers Island, city officials said this morning.

title: SIGNS OF TRANSFORMATION IN NEIGHBORLY GREENPOINT
description: When housing prices explode in Manhattan, the tremors shake neighborhoods like Greenpoint in Brooklyn. One of the city's best-preserved working-class areas, Greenpoint is now feeling the exponential rent increases, housing turnover and influx of young professionals that have characterized gentrification in New York City.

title: BELGIUM'S LEADER OFFERS RESIGNATION
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens offered his resignation to King Baudouin today after failing to resolve a dispute over language that has split his coalition of Dutch and French speakers, a Government spokesman said.

title: Weiss Leaves Hospital
description: Representative Ted Weiss of Manhattan, who underwent quadruple coronary bypass surgery after a heart attack two weeks ago, was released yesterday from the Washington Hospital Center. A spokesman said the veteran Democrat expected to be back on the job within ''three or four weeks.'' He is seeking re-election to a sixth term in November.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VIRATEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: U.S. Acts to Enhance Image After Talks
description: White House officials, expressing unhappiness over news accounts of President Reagan's stance in his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have begun one of the most extensive public relations efforts of the Reagan Presidency.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $11.5 million or 13 cents a share from sales of investments and the settlement of expenses in connection with a terminated merger agreement for the quarter, and $26 million, or 29 cents a share from the exchange of stock for debentures for the 9 months. The company said latest year's results included pre-tax startup losses in HCA health plans of about $9.3 million in the quarter and $20.5 million in the nine months.

title: HERS
description: I DON'T remember summer that year. And what happened to winter and spring? Was it cold? Did it snow? Did the apple trees blossom and fill our senses with heady perfume and nostalgia? I don't recall.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FRANCE LIFTS BAN ON POLICE LEAVES
description: The French Government let an emergency ban on police leave expire tonight as Paris marked four weeks without a resumption of the terrorist bombings of September, in which 10 people died.

title: Budget Crunch Hits Caucuses
description: The Congressional Rural Caucus, which once produced regular briefing papers and reports for its 100 or so members, no longer has an office.

title: PERES AND SHAMIR AGAIN DELAY TRADE
description: The rotation between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir was postponed for a second day today as the two party leaders again failed to resolve a dispute over patronage appointments.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Man Awarded $1.5 Million
description: QUEENS

title: AMONG TOYS AND WORDS OF WORLDS NOW GONE
description: ''This,'' said Erle Leichty, ''is the oldest medical text in the world.'' He held up a 4-by-6-inch rectangle of brown clay, covered with wedge-shaped cuneiform characters inscribed by a writer in the Sumerian city of Nippur about 2500 B.C. ''It contains prescriptions,'' said Dr. Leichty, mostly ''plants and things we don't understand. One of them is beer, though.''

title: Four-Year Stroll
description: If Kevin Sweeney wants to know just how far he has gone in pursuit of Doug Flutie's Division I-A pass-yardage record, all he has to do is take a little stroll through Fresno, Calif.

title: AMERICANS HOPEFUL AS GENEVA TALKS RESUME
description: The Geneva arms talks resumed today, and the Americans characterized the Iceland meeting last weekend as an unexpectedly successful ''serious and positive step.

title: UNION CAMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes 9 cents a share and 27 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from investment tax credits.

title: Herbert J. Strong, 82, Attorney in War Case
description: Herbert J. Strong, who was associate defense counsel for 12 Germans tried after World War II for war crimes, died Sunday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SHOPPING: TRY IT OUT FIRST
description: A CONSUMER cannot judge a telephone by its weight. Some manufacturers pad their products with fishermen's lead sinkers to make them seem more solid. A.T.&T. now makes its phones lighter because, it says, people want them lighter.

title: AFTER FEUD, DYSON PLANS TO ENDORSE MARK GREEN
description: After months of bitter feuding, John S. Dyson, the Liberal Party candidate for the United States Senate, will endorse his Democratic opponent, Mark Green, today, according to aides to both candidates and the Liberal Party.

title: Grey Establishes Unit For Pan-European Ads
description: Answering the need of a select few advertisers who want to run pan-European advertising, Grey Advertising has established in its London office a media-buying operation called Greysat, whose services will be available to Grey clients only.

title: Campeau Extends Its Offer for Allied
description: The Campeau Corporation has extended its tender offer for shares of the Allied Stores Corporation until Oct. 24, including withdrawal rights and proration.

title: 2 Texas Banks Report Losses
description: Two of Texas's bank holding companies today announced sizable third-quarter losses, primarily because of additions to their reserves for possible loan losses.

title: Try 'Georgia on My Mind'
description: An evening with ''Peter, Wyche and Mary,'' as the event is being billed, may prove to be good entertainment, but some Georgia Democrats are worried that it could be risky politics for Wyche Fowler, the Atlanta Congressman trying to unseat Senator Mack Mattingly, a conservative Republican.

title: OPPOSITION BOYCOTTS BANGLADESH VOTE
description: Bangladesh held a presidential election today that was boycotted by the opposition to President H. M. Ershad but was still seen as strengthening his grip on the country after he lifts martial law, as he said he intends to do next month.

title: CONCERT: KAY SWIFT'S COMPOSITIONS
description: WHEN Kay Swift took the stage of the Merkin Concert Hall near the end of a program celebrating her music on Tuesday evening, the 89-year-old composer and close friend of George Gershwin was greeted with a standing ovation.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 21
GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago figures are restated to include the results of Product Coatings Inc., which was aquired in a pooling of interests during the latest second quarter.

title: 64-Inning Classic
description: Yes, the box scores will show that the Mets won the 1986 National League pennant in a six-game series. But what the Mets accomplished shouldn't be demeaned by being described simply as a six-game series. It deserves to be remembered as one composite box score, one 64-inning game. Especially the last 28 innings. Particularly the last 16 innings.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $23,763,000 for the quarter and $24,289,000 for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month results include coal-asset writedown of $46,725,000.

title: Technology; Plastic Blends Growing Fast
description: GREAT leaps forward are rare events in the world of plastics.

title: US HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been adjusted for a 50-percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 22, 1985. The company said that in July 1986 it contributed its Chicago and Florida HMOs and other assets for a total investment of approximately $15 million to a 50-percent owned joint venture named HealthWin; earlier this month, the company announced the sale of its 50-percent interest in HealthWin to its joint venture partner for $100 million and said that the closing on the sale of HealthWin is anticipated by Dec. 31, 1986, and is subject to board and regulatory approvals.

title: OPEC Toils On Quotas
description: OPEC oil ministers, emerging from their 10th day of talks, appeared today to be edging toward a tentative agreement on reapportioning their nations' production quotas to support oil prices.

title: Bomb Scare on Canadian Jet
description: A domestic Nordair flight from Montreal to Toronto was forced to make an emergency landing in Ottawa on Tuesday night after the airline received a bomb threat, airline officials said.

title: Walesa and Others Ask U.S. to End Sanctions
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union movement, joined nine well-known critics of the Government today in calling on President Reagan to lift remaining American economic restrictions and help Poland toward economic recovery.

title: Antipollution Bill Passes House
description: The House approved an $18 billion antipollution bill tonight and sent the measure to the Senate.

title: AUCTION HELD TO AID ARTISTS' LOFT BATTLE
description: In a crowded downtown ballroom Tuesday night, many of New York's leading artists, dealers, critics and collectors gathered at a benefit auction to raise money for a group of Brooklyn artists who face eviction from their lofts.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $318 million from the sale of 20 percent of the common stock of the company's cable television subsidiary, American Television & Communications; and a $34 million pre-tax gain from the sale of the company's holdings in Temple- Inland Inc.; and a special charge of $50 million covering the anticipated costs of relocating the company's Chicago-based subscription fulfillment operations. The company also said that as part of a long-term program, it purchased 1.1 million shares of its common during the quarter and that the program was interrupted during September because of the pending acquisition of Scott, Foresman & Co. which was announced Oct. 14.

title: LINES ARE TOO BUSY FOR 4 DESIGNERS
description: ''OH dear.'' Thus spoke the New York decorator Keith Irvine, gazing at a plastic yellow banana phone.

title: Bridge: Course for Children Starts On Saturday in New York
description: The chance that a child of school age will be able to learn bridge is much greater in Europe than it is on this side of the Atlantic.

title: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $1,367,000 or 45 cents.

title: DIGITAL TECHNOLOGY CHANGING MUSIC
description: Digital sampling, a new technology that allows any sound to be recorded, re-created and manipulated by computer, has begun to change the way music is made. It also challenges the ethical, legal and economic basis of copyright protection - and may demand new definitions of originality in music.

title: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Slasher Ruled Unfit For Trial
description: A homeless man accused of slashing 11 people on a Staten Island ferryboat with a sword, killing two, was declared mentally unfit to stand trial and was placed yesterday in the custody of the State Mental Hygiene Department.

title: Reagan Alumni Get Ready
description: Officials appointed by President Reagan are forming a continuing organization, two years before his retirement, to make their collective expertise available to the next Congress and the next Administration, even if both turn out to be controlled by Democrats.

title: Hexcel Profits Up 11.1%
description: The Hexcel Corporation, a San Francisco-based manufacturer of honeycomb and composite materials used primarily in aircraft, today reported third-quarter earnings of $2 million, or 46 cents a share, up 11.1 percent from $1.8 million, or 44 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Floating Point Chief Resigns
description: Floating Point Systems Inc., the troubled manufacturer of high-powered computers for scientific users, said today that its president and chief executive officer, Lloyd D. Turner, who is 54 years old, has resigned, but would continue to serve the company as a consultant.

title: Misspent Youth
description: So far as is known, no candidate this year has taken and failed a drug test. But a number of them have disclosed that they used illegal drugs in the past.

title: US BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in the form of a stock dividend in September.

title: BEEBA CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HUTTON SAID TO GET AND REJECT OFFER
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. offered to acquire E.F. Hutton Group for at least $1.5 billion in a friendly transaction but was turned down by the brokerage firm's management, according to Wall Street sources. Rumors, however, continued to circulate on Wall Street that other offers have been made to Hutton, including one from another investment banking firm, and that Shearson may at some point return to the bidding.

title: Shifts on N and R Lines Are Planned in Queens
description: Transit Authority officials yesterday proposed changing two subway routes in Queens, the N and the R, in a move, they said, to improve service between Queens and Manhattan.

description: Replacing Chief Guido The Police Department will get a new corruption watchdog today. Daniel F. Sullivan, an assistant police chief, is expected to succeed John Guido, retiring as head of Inspectional Services. Chief Sullivan worked under Chief Guido since 1972 and was his choice for the job. 10 A.M. news conference, 1 Police Plaza, Manhattan Accusing Waldheim Officials of the World Jewish Congress will release what they say is more evidence connecting Kurt Waldheim to the murder of civilians during World War II. The group, which has been collecting evidence against the former United Nations Secretary General, says it has part of a 1947 Yugoslav criminal file that implicates Mr. Waldheim. The file, they say, includes a transcript of testimony by a fellow officer in the German Army. 10 A.M., 1 Park Avenue, Manhattan Where Dyson Stands Will John S. Dyson actively campaign for Mark Green in his uphill Senate campaign against the Republican, Alfonse M. D'Amato? Mr. Dyson, the Liberal candidate, will face questioning at a news conference when he is expected to announce his endorsement of Mr. Green, ending a divisive episode for the Democratic Party. 11:30 A.M., New York Hilton, 1335 Avenue of the Americas, at 54th Street, Manhattan Politics Cuomo and the CardinalAfter weeks of being at odds with John Cardinal O'Connor, Governor Cuomo and the church leader come face to face. Mr. Cuomo will be a guest at the annual Alfred E. Smith Dinner, a church-sponsored event that is one of the year's prime political gatherings.

title: Wendy's Shifts To Coca-Cola
description: Wendy's International Inc., the fast-food restaurant chain, said yesterday that it would switch from serving Pepsi-Cola to Coca-Cola at its company-owned outlets and would urge its franchise operations to follow suit.

title: CBS Action By F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would take action Thursday on deciding whether control of CBS Inc. had changed hands.

title: STATE U. CHIEF TO RESIGN TO BECOME HEAD OF $50 BILLION PENSION FUND
description: Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr. is planning to resign as the Chancellor of the State University of New York to become chairman and chief executive officer of the country's largest private pension system.

title: Eastern Push In Philadelphia
description: Citing increased consumer interest in domestic travel and a desire to strengthen its position on the East Coast, Eastern Airlines said it would nearly double the number of flights from Philadelphia, making that city a hub between the Northeast and Florida, the Caribbean and the Bahamas. Beginning Dec. 10, the

title: ISELIN OF CHANNEL 13 QUITS AFTER 15 YEARS AT THE PUBLIC STATION
description: John Jay Iselin, who presided for 15 years over bounding successes and recurring financial crises at WNET, Channel 13, resigned as president of the New York public-television station yesterday, saying, ''It's a good thing for the organization, and for the individual.''

title: Mutual Shares Has 6.7% Stake in Gelco
description: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York investment firm, and its affiliates said they had acquired a 6.7 percent stake in the embattled Gelco Corporation for investment purposes. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mutual said it believed Gelco ''should actively pursue the sale of all the corporate assets and encourage competitive offers by third parties.''

description: b-Net income

CONTRACTS FOR COLLEGE ROOMMATES
description: Personal quirks and sloppy living habits have caused more than a few fights between college roommates, but students at Wilson College have found a way to avoid many ''Odd Couple'' problems.

McCarran-Walter Lives
description: Is Patricia Lara an anarchist, terrorist or Communist bent on overthrowing the U.S. Government? Or is she what she claims to be, a Colombian journalist who has written articles critical of the Reagan Administration policy in Central America? Federal officials have detained her and threaten to deport her but won't say why. If they have good reason, the burden is on them to show it today.

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 6.

title: Raising the Ante
description: President Reagan watched Mikhail Gorbachev's arrival in Iceland on television, and according to one of the aides in the room, said cheerfully to the figure on the screen: ''Gorby, if you're ready to give up your dream of world domination, we can make a deal.''

title: WILMA PORTER SOSS, 86, A GADFLY AT STOCK MEETINGS OF COMPANIES
description: Wilma Porter Soss, one of the country's best known and most colorful corporate gadflies, died of a heart attack Friday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 86 years old. At one time she worked in public relations, representing department stores, motion picture studios and the silk industry.

title: U.S. REVOKES THE VISA OF A DETAINED REPORTER FROM COLOMBIA
description: The State Department yesterday revoked the visa of a reporter from Colombia who has been detained since arriving in the United States Sunday to attend an awards ceremony for distinguished Latin American journalists.

title: A BRITISH ADAPTATION OF SHELLEY'S 'ZASTROZZI'
description: RETURNING for a second season tonight at 11, WNET's ''Channel Crossings,'' a collection of international television films, continues to be admirably adventurous and provocative with ''Zastrozzi, a Romance.'' Consisting of four 52-minute episodes - two will be broadcast this evening, the rest next Thursday -the work is described by its producers, Lindsey C. Vickers and David Lascelles, as a ''totally irreverent translation'' of Shelley's ''bad but inspired'' 1810 novel into the modern idiom of a television mini-series. Actually, the result, made for Britain's Channel 4, bears a remarkable resemblance to those Gothically overheated television commercials for a perfume called Obsession.

title: Man Left With 2 Hearts After a Transplant
description: A complex heart transplant operation performed by surgeons at the University Hospital at St. Louis University Medical Center has left a 44-year-old man with two functioning human hearts.

title: CHESEBROUGH-POND'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,568,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months includes income from discontinued operations of $3,987,000 and a credit of $8,233,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $10,604,000 for the quarter and $21,052,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago figures include results of Stauffer Chemical Co. since it was acquired March 15, 1985.

title: 3 Moscow Dissidents Are Reunited in U.S.
description: Yuri F. Orlov and two other founding members of a self-styled Soviet Helsinki Monitoring Group were reunited here today raising glasses of vodka to what they had called from the outset their ''hopeless cause.''

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Earnings for the first 9 months of 1985 included a $3.8 million, or 35 cents per share, adjustment for the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.

title: LEADER OF BONANNO CRIME FAMILY CONVICTED OF LABOR RACKETEERING
description: Philip Rastelli, who the authorities say heads the Bonanno crime family, and seven co-defendants were found guilty last night of taking part in a massive labor racketeering conspiracy from 1964 to 1985.

title: Berlin Escape Disclosed
description: Two young East Berlin men escaped to the West by climbing over the Berlin wall with a ladder, the West Berlin authorities said today. The escape by Jan Peter Mueller, 24 years old, a bricklayer, and Bernd Hansen, 26, a locksmith, took place in September and was reported for the first time today in the newspaper Bild.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Q. Last year I had a concrete floor poured in the basement of my country home. A layer of heavy plastic was laid on the ground before the floor was poured. Shortly after the concrete set, the surface became very dusty, and walking on the floor seems to make the problem worse. The mason who built the floor told me that this was caused by high humidity and that the problem could be helped by treating the concrete with nitric acid. Can you tell me how to go about doing this? A. Washing a new concrete floor with acid is sometimes advisable to neutralize excess alkalis before painting or treating it with a sealer, but the acid used is muriatic acid (a mild form of hydrochloric acid), not nitric acid. Dusting such as you describe is sometimes a problem for a little while on new concrete, but if it continues, it usually means the mix was not right, or it was troweled too much when it was finished.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST AMERICAN BANK FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

The bank did not give share earnings because it converted from mutual to stock ownership in July.

title: A $254 Million Offering Of Bonds From Hawaii
description: A $254 million issue of Hawaii bonds was offered yesterday. The Bankers Trust Company, winner of the bonds in competitive bidding, leads the underwriters.

title: Books; Big Shoulders
description: CHICAGO. By Studs Terkel. Illustrated. 148 pages. Pantheon. $15.95. NOBODY seems to be writing prose poems to the city of New York these days. With the sometime exception of Allen Ginsberg, there's no Walt Whitman around to sing the praises of (as he called the island) Mannahatta. Even one of the city's juiciest scandals has to get out of town in a hurry and be tried before a New Haven jury.

title: RANGERS FINALLY MAKE A POINT
description: Everything about the Rangers' performance was crisp tonight. Pierre Larouche was right where he was supposed to be, near a goalpost, sweeping in pucks. Nothing except the numbers suggested another Rangers' breakdown.

description: b-Net loss and after a $4.0 million LIFO inventory liquidation profit. The company went public in April. The company said it does not expect a LIFO liquidation gain in 1986.

title: Hanoi Says Chinese Assaulted a Village
description: The Vietnamese press agency said today that Chinese forces, backed by the heaviest shelling in months, had repeatedly attacked a Vietnamese village.

title: 'MAGNIFICENT TRIO' WHO SHED NEW LIGHT ON CHEMICAL REACTIONS
description: YUAN T. LEE ''The Mozart of physical chemistry'' is how a fellow Nobel Prize winner, Dudley R. Herschbach, described Yuan T. Lee yesterday. The description is apt, said another chemist, not only because Dr. Lee was a prodigy but also because in the laboratory he has ''a precise touch.''

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Utah Utility Bonds Get Yield of 9.47%
description: A $170 million competitive issue of Utah Power and Light Company first mortgage bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: DETAINED PALM-BRANCH SHIPMENT THREATENS SUCCOTH RITUALS
description: Observant Jews around the nation are struggling this year to fulfill a key commandment of the impending Succoth holiday - the ritual use of a palm branch and citron - because of a shortage of the plants created by a troubled shipment from Tunisia into Kennedy International Airport.

title: GRENADE ATTACK KILLS 1, WOUNDS 65 IN JERUSALEM
description: One person was killed and 65 others were wounded tonight when three hand grenades were thrown at a group of Israeli soldiers and their relatives as they were boarding buses near the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem.

title: Breland Stops Twining in First
description: Mark Breland, fighting tonight in front of his family and friends, scored a first-round knockout over Ralph Twining.

title: A Major Ruling, Or Nothing at All?
description: It has been two years now since Leon Wood sued the National Basketball Association in Federal court, and it's been four months since lawyers representing Wood, who lost at the district level, argued their appeal before a three-judge panel in Manhattan. Other cases heard at the time have since been decided, but so far there's been no ruling in Wood's suit. To his lawyers, at least, the delay indicates that the panel could be giving more than cursory consideration to his claims: that the N.B.A.'s draft and salary cap violate the antitrust laws.

title: Lift All Restrictions
description: To the Editor:

title: '87 SPENDING BILL WITH SMALLER RISE IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved a $576 billion comprehensive appropriation bill for 1987 that would restrain the growth of Federal spending.

title: New Godiva Product Set for Introduction
description: Godiva Chocolatier, at whose very name mouths have been known to water, is introducing a new brand through its Gourmet Collection named Barringer's.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
TV AT ISSUE ON PREGNANCY
description: An executive of Planned Parenthood has called on the television industry to portray accurately the use of contraceptive devices and help teen-agers avoid unwanted pregnancies.

title: World Paper to Appear In China, Its 23d Nation
description: World Paper, a monthly founded in 1978 in Boston to give an international perspective to global news, will soon be published in its 23d country, China.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and includes a non- recurring net gain of $2.8 million, or 53 cents a share on the sale of the company's plasma centers. The company said the latest quarter loss is after a net loss of $1.7 million on the sale of the company's dental laboratory business. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect operations on a comparative basis.

title: PAKISTAN SAYS IT MAY REQUEST AIR PATROLS BY U.S.
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq raised the possibility today of asking the United States to mount occasional patrols in Pakistani airspace with early warning aircraft that could detect attacks coming from Afghanistan.

BRIEFS

title: U.S. PROVIDING TESTS ON CHECKING FOR RADON
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has released a standardized test for radon contamination in homes and issued policies for approving companies to measure it.

title: INSIDE
description: Defeat for Birth Curbs A plan to allow distribution of contraceptives at nine New York high school clinics failed to win Board of Education approval.

title: Maryland Agency In Refunding Step
description: The Washington Suburban Sanitary District of Maryland is offering $73.3 million of sewage disposal, water supply and general construction refunding bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation.

CHICAGO SCHOOL CLINIC IS SUED OVER BIRTH CONTROL MATERIELS
description: A clinic that dispenses birth control materials at an all-black high school is aimed at reducing the black population, a group of ministers, parents and students charged in a lawsuit filed today.

title: ANTIQUES, CRAFTS, TOURS, BONSAI
description: Fall Antiques Show at the Pier, Pier 92, Berths 5 and 6, 52nd Street and Hudson River, 212-777-5218.

title: Carnegie Hall Concerts Set
description: Carnegie Hall, which has been closed since May for renovations, will reopen on Dec. 16 with appearances by the pianist Daniel Barenboim at 3 P.M. and the singer Marilyn Horne at 8 P.M. During the final stages of renovation, the box office will be set up temporarily in an area adjacent to the West 57th Street entrance.

title: U.S. AGAIN DENIES A NICARAGUA ROLE
description: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, repeated his assertion today that the United States Government had nothing to do with the supply flight shot down over Nicaragua on Oct. 5.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANES SET UP MEETING ON CITY TOWING PACTS
description: In an effort to block open bidding on highway towing contracts, Donald R. Manes arranged a meeting at City Hall in 1981 between a deputy mayor and towing companies that had long held the monopoly, according to investigators and participants.

FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago periods restated to include the results of the Portland National Bank.

title: Youth, 15, Held In Girl's Death
description: A 15-year-old boy was charged yesterday with murdering an 11-year-old girl missing since Oct. 8.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Taiwan Lifts Gold Curb
description: Taiwan will end controls on the import and trading of gold, effective Nov. 1, the Finance Ministry said today. Parliament had agreed in May to remove controls on gold and to regard it as a commodity rather than a medium of foreign exchange.

The 1986 results reflect Graniteville's operations as a 49-percent owned affiliate accounted for on the equity method, whereas the 1985 results include Graniteville as a 100-percent owned consolidated subsidiary. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect aggregate stock dividends paid through Oct. 14, 1986, the last stock dividend being paid by the company on July 1, 1985.

title: WALTER FLORELL, 75, MILLINERY DESIGNER FOR FAMOUS WOMEN
description: Walter Florell, a custom millinery designer who flourished in the 1940's and 1950's, when a fashionable woman's hats were as important as her clothes, died of a stroke Oct. 6 in Wilton, Conn., where he had made his home since he closed his New York salon in 1963. He was 75 years old.

title: 4 Peace Activists Held On Nuclear Test Range
description: The authorities today stopped four of six peace activists whose peace group said the failure of United States-Soviet arms talks Sunday gave members a ''heightened sense of urgency'' to halt a nuclear weapons test set for Thursday.

title: Louisiana Dockworkers Vote Pact But Stay Out
description: The city's largest dockworkers' union ratified a contract today, but many members said they would not return to work while three smaller locals remained off the job in the five-day strike that has idled about 2,000 workers.

title: Help for 911
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $16.3 million for the quarter and for the 9 months a tax credit of $49 million. c-After a reversal of a tax credit of $23.4 million for the quarter and a tax credit of $4.4 million for the 9 months.

description: b-Includes extraordinary items of $79,000 and $122,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, from the reduction of income taxes arising from the carryforward of prior years operating loss; and also includes extraordinary income of $182,095 and $383,344 for the same periods. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $122,605. The revenue figures for 1985 have been restated.

description: b-Net loss

title: HANOVER, 2 OTHER BANKS POST GAINS
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, whose erratic earnings record has been the source of rising concern among analysts and ratings agencies, reported yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 5.3 percent.

description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,866,000 and $4,288,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: GIANTS IMPROVISE AFTER BAVARO INJURY
description: With Mark Bavaro on crutches with a sprained right foot, the Giants broke in a new tight end today. His name is Jeff Hostetler-Tony Galbreath-Damian Johnson.

title: JESSE FINDS THE WAY
description: Opening a bottle of Great Western champagne was even harder than closing out the Houston Astros. You couldn't say Jesse Orosco was clawing at the wrapping around the cork, because he had no claws to speak of.

title: MICROSCOPE DESIGNS BRING THE NOBEL PRIZE TO THREE EUROPEANS
description: Three pioneers in microscope design won the 1986 Nobel Prize in physics yesterday for greatly expanding humans' ability to peer deep into the smallest facets of nature.

title: O'BRIEN, MCNEIL SEEM READY TO RETURN
description: Ken O'Brien not only recovers quickly from sacks, but today he also demonstrated a remarkable ability to bounce back from an injury.

title: PESTICIDE SHIPPING BLOCKED IN KANSAS
description: The police stood guard today outside an Environmental Protection Agency laboratory after the city passed an ordinance and got a court order barring the Federal agency from shipping in more hazardous pesticide.

title: SAMUEL OSTROVE
description: Samuel Ostrove, a former New York restaurateur, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 73 years old.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IN the last couple of years manufacturers of staple guns and other fastening tools have developed a new generation of tools that are more versatile and easier to use than ever before. Although the new staple guns look much like their older cousins in basic design, they are greatly improved in various ways and many can do jobs that formerly could not be done by any staple gun.

title: Micropro Adds NewWord Line
description: The Micropro International Corporation, best known for the Wordstar word processing program for personal computers, said it had acquired the NewWord product base from Newstar Software Inc. for about $3.1 million. Micropro acquired exclusive ownership of and distribution rights to NewWord 2 and NewWord 3, which are Wordstar lookalikes.

title: STRAUS FAMILY TO SELL WMCA
description: WMCA, which claims to be the first New York radio station to play rock-and-roll music and is now one of the city's top three talk stations, will be sold for $10 million in cash to Federal Enterprises Inc. of Detroit, its owners said yesterday.

title: REACTION TO IMMIGRATION BILL IS SHARPLY SPLIT
description: As Congress prepared today to vote on a landmark immigration bill in Washington, Judge Pat O'Rourke, the county executive of El Paso more than 2,000 miles away on the Mexican border, was unimpressed and cynical.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Omar Moreno, the outfielder signed last spring to a one-year contract by the Atlanta Braves, has been released after hitting .239 with a .289 on-base percentage and stealing 17 bases in 33 attempts. . . . Gerry Feehery, the Philadelphia Eagles' center, has undergone surgery on his right knee and will be out for the season. Feehery, injured in last Sunday's loss to the Giants, was replaced by Nick Haden. . . . Pat Tilley, the St. Louis Cardinals' 33-year-old wide receiver, will also be lost for the season.

title: ELIE WIESEL, NOBEL LAUREATE, IS OFF TO MOSCOW
description: Elie Wiesel, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, will be traveling to Moscow next week to meet with officials about a conference on non-Jewish victims of Nazism and to celebrate two Jewish holidays at a Moscow synagogue.

title: Prices of U.S. Issues Increase
description: Prices of Treasury securities posted moderate gains yesterday after a late burst of short covering in the futures and cash markets.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND GENE THAT BLOCKS THE GROWTH OF A FORM OF CANCER
description: Scientists for the first time have identified a gene that they believe acts to prevent the formation of a cancer in humans.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AN ANTIQUES DEALER'S LEGENDARY STYLE
description: THE exterior of the black-fronted shop at the Rue Jacob and the Rue Bonaparte in the Sixth Arrondissement of Paris is austere, so that most people walk by with only a casual glance inside. The small lamps, cachepots and candlesticks look as if they had been in the windows for decades and probably have.

TAIPEI IS READY TO LIFT MARTIAL LAW ORDERED IN '49
description: The Government said today that it was ready to lift martial law for the first time since Chiang Kai-shek's forces retreated to Taiwan from mainland China in 1949. The state of martial law would be replaced with less-restrictive security rules.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said Donald F. McHenry, a former U.S. representative at the United Nations, had been elected a director.

title: Shipbuilding Area Gets Aid
description: The West German Government today announced a multimillion-dollar plan to help coastal states deal with the collapse of the shipbuilding industry.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CRITICS SAY REAGAN MISSED CHANCE FOR ARMS PROGRESS
description: Former United States arms negotiators said today that President Reagan had missed an opportunity for a breakthrough in Iceland by declining to negotiate with the Soviet Union on the issue of how strictly to interpret the antiballistic missile treaty.

title: America II Wins by 0:33
description: The New York Yacht Club's America II (8-1) earned a 33-second victory over French Kiss (4-5), and unbeaten New Zealand earned its ninth straight triumph with an easy 4-minute-41-second decision over Eagle (4-5) today in America's Cup challenger competition.

title: OKLAHOMA URANIUM PLANT FINED IN FATAL BLAST
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today announced fines of $310,000 against a fuel company for what the commission said were serious safety violations that led to an explosion and the death of a worker in January at an Oklahoma uranium-processing plant.

title: 70'S MODE FOR PENNSYLVANIA UNDERDOG
description: Whatever the results of the summit meeting in Iceland, Representative Bob Edgar was going to have the activists of the peace movement rallying for him in the streets of Pennsylvania.

title: CAN OPPORTUNITY RETURN?
description: By any objective measure, the United States and Soviet Union missed a golden opportunity for arms control at the summit meeting. The coming weeks will tell whether that opportunity has been lost for the foreseeable future or whether it will knock a second time.

title: CONSTITUTION POSES AQUINO CHALLENGE
description: A new Philippine constitution approved by a presidential panel this week may produce the first electoral challenge to the eight-month-old Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Honda Profits Plunge 52.4%
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that its profits for the latest quarter plunged 52.4 percent from the comparable 1985 quarter. chiefly because of the sharp appreciation of the yen.

title: BRAGGING IS CITED ON LINKS TO BUSH
description: Sandinista officials said today that an American jailed here has said that both of the American agents running Nicaraguan rebel supply operations in El Salvador ''bragged'' that they personally knew Vice President Bush.

title: SCIENTISTS TRACE A GENE CAUSING MUSCLE DISEASE
description: The gene that causes a common form of muscular dystrophy has been found, giving scientists a major key to understanding and possibly treating the disease, it was announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption of a picture from Agence France-Press yesterday about President Reagan's report on his talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave the location incorrectly. It was the Old Executive Office Building.

title: THE END OF AN ERA
description: FOR thousands of American women growing up in the 1960's, the embodiment of teen-age girlhood was found in sweet-16 parties, crushes on the Beatles and in a pretty pink telephone aptly named the Princess.

NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: CHEMISTRY NOBEL IS AWARDED TO 3
description: Two Americans and a Canadian won the Nobel Prize in chemistry yesterday for helping to create the first detailed understanding of chemical reactions, replacing a traditional frozen picture with a way of seeing the intimate interplay of energy that transforms one kind of matter into another.

description: FOR a while, it seemed as if the plain old telephone was doomed.

title: 'CALL WAITING' AND OTHER CONUNDRUMS OF MODERN ETIQUETTE
description: THE telephone was an ornery object even when it was simple and ugly.

title: DATATRAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Blame in Connecticut Blast
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that a sewer contractor and Northeast Utilities shared responsibility for a natural-gas explosion that killed six people in a Derby, Conn., restaurant in 1985.

title: People
description: * Bruce Guidotti has joined Jordan, Manning, Case, Taylor & McGrath as senior vice president/management supervisor.

title: Driesell Deal Reported
description: The University of Maryland Chancellor, John B. Slaughter, is working on a deal to buy out the remaining nine years of Lefty Driesell's contract as basketball coach, The Baltimore Sun reported yesterday.

title: Market Place; Losing Out On CPC's Rise
description: MANY a person has sold a stock, only to watch in dismay as it soon jumped in price. A similar phenomenon can occur to decisions made by Wall Street's market strategists, showing that savvy professionals - just like the average investor - are far from infallible.

title: COSMETICS GIVEAWAYS BACKFIRE
description: The idea was simple: Lure cosmetics customers by offering free sample lipsticks, perfumes and powders. Publicize the gifts so that shoppers seek them out. Then give away so many that every medicine chest holds at least a handful.

title: KEAN OFFERS PLAN FOR 'DRUG-FREE' JERSEY
description: Governor Kean outlined a campaign today for a ''drug-free'' New Jersey, including proposals for drug education beginning in kindergarten and stiffer jail terms and fines for drug dealers.

title: SENATE VOTES DRUG BILL MINUS DEATH PENALTY
description: The Senate tonight passed the latest version of an anti-drug bill, stripping the death penalty from the version that passed the House of Representatives last week.

title: ARTIST'S WIFE AND MUSE
description: Jacqueline Picasso, second wife of Pablo Picasso, the prime inspiration of his later work and a generous benefactor of the Museum of Modern Art in New York since his death in 1973, died yesterday at her house in Mougins, France. Police officers who were called to the house reported that she had shot herself in the head with an automatic pistol. She was 60 years old.

title: CLAUSEN SEES ONLY SLIGHT CHANGES
description: A. W. Clausen, in his first public remarks since returning to head the BankAmerica Corporation, expressed confidence that the bank would be able to fend off the takeover bid from First Interstate Bancorp.

title: Keep U.S. Highways 55 M.P.H. Paradises
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATE ON SHOREHAM: WHO OPPOSED IT FIRST
description: Politicians seeking Long Island votes are busily staking out positions on everything from drugs to taxes to environmental protection. Yet the topic that arouses the strongest emotions for many residents - the Shoreham nuclear power plant - is scarcely being debated.

title: FIRST REACTION: POLL SHOWS ARMS-CONTROL OPTIMISM AND SUPPORT FOR REAGAN How the Poll Was Taken
description: The American public's initial reaction to the Reykjavik summit meeting is quite supportive of President Reagan and very optimistic about the future of arms control, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: DEATH CASE BIAS ARGUED IN COURT
description: Killers of white victims, especially blacks who kill whites, are sentenced to die in such disproportionate numbers in Georgia as to recall the explicit racial discrimination of the slavery era, a defense lawyer argued before the Supreme Court today.

title: SUFFIELD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Testing New Money
description: The new United States currency that will be introduced next year in an effort to thwart counterfeiters has passed a major test.

title: Topics; Historic Facts: Witness
description: What Elie Wiesel saw, and survived, eclipses nightmare. ''Never shall I forget that first night, the first night in camp, which has turned my life into one long night,'' he wrote in the first of the 26 books with which he has memorialized the Holocaust.

title: KOCH SAYS HE WILL SUE HOTELS THAT REFUSE TO TAKE HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would begin suing hotels in New York that have empty rooms but refuse to rent them to homeless families.

title: Vernitron Offer
description: An investment group, led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said it had reached an agreement to acquire control of the Vernitron Corporation, the electromechanical concern based in Lake Success, L.I. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investment group said it would purchase 2.4 million Vernitron shares for $12.50 a share. The purchase, combined with a 16.6 percent stake that the investment group bought for $5.78 million, would give the group about 57.6 percent of Vernitron. Vernitron stock closed today at $11.125, down 37.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: ASTROS SO CLOSE, YET SO FATIGUED
description: The mood of the Houston clubhouse after the Astros had lost the National League Championship Series to the Mets seemed one of fatigue - mixed, certainly, with disappointment.

F.D.I.C. MAY SELL STAKE IN CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, banking sources said today, will soon announce plans to sell to the private sector many of the shares it owns in the Continental Illinois Corporation.

title: Now See the Twin Towers of Debt
description: When President Reagan took office in 1981, the budget deficit of $80 billion seemed huge. In five years, Mr. Reagan and a complaisant Congress have run up deficits two and three times as big. They have doubled the national debt. Interest now costs $150 billion a year.

description: The man convicted of killing an elderly St. Albans, Queens, couple while burglarizing their home was sentenced yesterday to 66Z years to life in prison by a judge at State Supreme Court in Queens who said the death penalty would have been more appropriate.

title: PEOPLE GETS TEXAS AIR FUNDS
description: The Texas Air Corporation reacted cautiously yesterday to the Transportation Department's tentative approval of its proposed $301 million acquisition of People Express Inc. But Texas Air was heartened enough to provide People with $10 million, enabling the troubled airline to make a $13.4 million interest payment that had come due yesterday.

title: Reagan's Dream
description: Something deep and strange has happened since the Reykjavik summit meeting ended without agreement. The sense of what might have been - of what still might be in ordering the nuclear world - has begun to play a fundamental part in international politics.

title: L.S.U. Football Put on Probation

title: METS AND RED SOX WIN THEIR PENNANTS
description: The Mets won their first National League pennant in 13 years today when they rallied three times to defeat the Houston Astros, 7-6, in a 16-inning game that lasted more than four and a half hours and set records for drama and duration.

title: BALLET: FELD'S 'BENT PLANES'
description: TIMES - or at least our ways of suffering for our art - do change. Lining up on some barren SoHo street for at least a half-hour was once de rigueur for the proper savoring of a Spartan loft performance. On Tuesday, the audience joked about ice cubes as it shivered through an evening of dance by Eliot Feld at the well-appointed little Joyce Theater. The theater was unusually cold, according to a program insert, because of the ''technical requirements'' of ''Bent Planes.'' And when the curtain rose on that new work by Mr. Feld, the chill seemed entirely appropriate.

title: BALDI'S ELIGIBILITY IS RESTORED
description: Just as St. John's was trying to figure out how it would get along without Walter Berry, who opted for the pros, and Marco Baldi, the 6-foot-11-inch center who was ruled ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association last March, the Redmen received some good news.
