description: The empirical evidence is as clear and strident as an infant's howl at midnight. Poles are having more children than Government demographers thought they would, and more children in relation to population than any country in Europe.

title: BADILLO CALLS FOR RETRACTION OF STATEMENTS BY GOVERNOR
description: Herman Badillo, the candidate for comptroller on Governor Cuomo's ticket, has asked Mr. Cuomo to retract statements in which he said Puerto Ricans preferred welfare to low-paying jobs and came here unskilled and unprepared to contribute to the state's economy.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Credit Suisse Unit Picks Key Officerr
description: After seven years as a senior executive in the capital markets area for First Boston Inc., David C. Batten is moving over to Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., the leading underwriter in the Eurobond market. Mr. Batten, 42 years old, will work in the same field for Credit Suisse First Boston and head the London-based firm's efforts to attract and generate new business, starting Jan. 1, with the title executive director.

title: DEVILS RALLY TO BEAT CANUCKS
description: The game between the Devils and the Vancouver Canucks was so ordinary during the first two periods tonight that the loudest cheers came when the Mets beat the Astros.

title: Rumors Spur Hess's Stock
description: Pushed by widespread rumors that the company is the target of a takeover attempt, stock of the Amerada Hess Corporation rose strongly on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The stock gained $1.125 to close at $26.875, and with four million shares changing hands, Hess was the Big Board's most active issue.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter loss includes a tax credit of $393,000.

title: EL AL SUSPECT DENIES BOMB PLOT
description: A Jordanian accused of trying to blow up an El Al airliner testified today that he thought he was smuggling drugs aboard the plane, not explosives. He also said the Syrian Ambassador here had offered him extensive help after the bomb plot had been uncovered.

title: THREE WINNERS OF NOBEL: PIONEERS IN MICROSCOPES
description: Heinrich Rohrer Heinrich Rohrer was in his office at the International Business Machines Research Laboratory in Zurich when the telephone call came from Stockholm. He had heard beforehand that his and Gerd Binnig's research had been nominated for the Nobel Prize in physics, and so he was perhaps a little less surprised than his wife was.

title: S. BRUCE SMART
description: S. Bruce Smart, former president and chairman of Fruit of the Loom Inc. and the father of the Under Secretary of Commerce S. Bruce Smart Jr., died Sunday. He was 97 years old.

title: THE MERITS OF PLAYING FROM MEMORY
description: IT is always a disappointment for this listener to attend a recital and find that the recitalist is going to perform while looking at the music, rather than from memory. Naturally, it is also a disappointment for those recitalists to read about this. Indeed it is a sore subject with some, who feel their careers may be handicapped by their need to perform ''on book,'' as actors say. And it's a topic on which many musicians and observers disagree.

title: GLOBAL RIGHTS GROUP CALLS FOR MORE PRESSURE
description: Amnesty International, in its annual report Tuesday, said that although governments were responding to increasing pressure to respect human rights, there ''is a gulf between commitments and reality.''

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENROLLMENT LAG HURTS FOOTBALL IN HIGH SCHOOLS
description: Some suburban school districts in the New York metropolitan area this fall are dropping varsity and junior varsity teams, from football to soccer, because of declining enrollments.

title: Her 1,000th Victory
description: For the 1,000th time in her professional career, Martina Navratilova heard the words ''Match, Miss Navratilova,'' after she won her first-round meeting with Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in a Porsche Grand Prix tournament in Fliderstadt, West Germany.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net chargeoffs of $81,930,000. Energy related net chargeoffs included in the total were $22,570,000. c-Net income

title: Bias on Tickets Is Asserted
description: Members of a synagogue in lower Manhattan complained yesterday that their cars were ticketed on Yom Kippur, the holiest day in the Jewish calendar, when on Christian holidays ticketing is suspended.

title: REPORT LINKS EX-SENATE AIDE TO CONTRAS
description: A Congressional investigation into links between the Nicaraguan rebels and the White House has centered on the role played by Robert Owen, a former Senate aide whose business card was found in the wreckage of a downed cargo plane in Nicaragua.

title: Iran Reports Iraqis Attacked an Airliner
description: An Iranian airliner was attacked by Iraqi warplanes today as its passengers were disembarking at Shiraz airport, the Iranian press agency said.

title: Education Act Would Curb Foreign Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: KAYDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hesburgh's Last Address
description: About 800 University of Notre Dame faculty members gave two standing ovations Monday to the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh as he delivered his last address as president of the university. Father Hesburgh, now in his 35th year at Notre Dame, will retire in May after delivering the commencement address for the Class of 1987.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2.5 million and $17.3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the year- ago 9 months includes a similar $1.3 million tax credit. c-Includes a $2.4 million charge for a LIFO inventory adjustment. d-Net loss and includes a $387 million pretax charge for writedown of certain assets.

title: Home Loan Banks Marketing 3 Issues
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday began offering $1.74 billion of bonds with maturities of two, four and seven years at par through various securities dealers.

title: UPJOHN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1.7 million, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of its diagnostics business, a pension credit of 5 cents a share from the adoption earlier in the year of FASB 87 and a charge of 3 cents a share from an increase in product liability reserves in response to increased hazards of litigation that are affecting U.S. business in general. c-Includes a gain of $1,209,000 from the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 9 months, and a loss of $1,549,000 from discontinued operations for the 9 months.

title: Subway Crime Is Up 25%
description: Fueled by a rash of handbag and jewelry snatchings in Brooklyn, serious crime in the subways rose 25 percent in August compared with the same month last year, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: MURDER SUSPECT IS ALSO INDICTED IN 3 BURGLARIES
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., charged last month with murder in the strangulation of a young woman in Central Park, was indicted yesterday on burglary charges in a string of daytime break-ins last year on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: PORNOGRAPHIC MATERIAL: SHOULD IT BE OUTLAWED?
description: In 1970, a Presidential commission found that pornography did not contribute to crime, delinquency or sexual deviancy. This year, the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, established at the request of President Reagan, found a ''causal relationship'' between certain kinds of pornography and acts of sexual violence.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $6,164,000 from the sale of the company's Atlanta radio properties.

title: New Man at the Fed Thinks of Judge Wapner: H. Robert Heller
description: There are bright, ambitious people who turn down offers to become one of the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board, but there are many more who consider an appointment to what is probably the world's mightiest financial institution as a crowning achievement.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ASTROS, at Houston. Seventh game of National League Championship Series, 8:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M. WCBS 880, 8:07 P.M.) BASKETBALL KNICKS VS.

title: SPLINTERING OF ONCE-SOLID SOUTH POSES NEW PROBLEMS FOR DEMOCRATIC PARTY
description: The shifting allegiance of Southern whites, once solidly Democratic but now increasingly independent or Republican, has dramatically altered the political landscape throughout this region, according to political analysts.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Released Omar Moreno, outfielder.

title: Europe Loan to Portugal
description: The European Community's executive commission today announced loans of $1.05 billion to Portugal to help modernize its economy and bring it up to the same standards as those of its community partners. The commission said in a statement that the cash would come from the community's structural funds over a seven-year period. The announcement followed an investigation by community economic experts into a Portuguese industrial development plan, which disclosed that the economy was too reliant on external factors and that its domestic industry was backward.

title: COLUMN ONE: CHANGES
description: Starting OverGrace is the plaza's name. But it is graceless - harsh and barren, favored by drug dealers, shunned by passers-by. After years of failure, the Grace Building's owners have a plan for the southeast corner of 43d Street and the Avenue of the Americas. ''We are wiping the slate clean,'' said Ruth H. Stahl, vice president of the Swig, Weiler and Arnow Management Company.

title: Red Tide in Gulf Spreads Toward Mexican Border
description: A cold front that was expected to stall a red tide that has killed hundreds of thousands of fish along the Texas coast has, instead, spread the toxic organisms almost to the Mexican border, a biologist said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Does Dole Need His Job?
description: Perhaps no Presidential hopeful has a greater stake in the outcome of the battle for the Senate than Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader.

title: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $250,000 and $387,000 for the latest and year-ago 9 months, respectively, and $278,000 for the year- ago quarter. c-Includes a gain of $544,000, or 18 cents a share, to reflect the settlement of excess assets in the company's non-union pension plan. Results for 1985 have been restated to reflect the change in the method of accounting for the cost of pension plans.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its latest quarter results reflect the reversal of $300,000 of investment tax credits recorded in the previous two quarters, in accordance with the elimination of the investment tax credit under the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1986
description: The World 3 microscope design pioneers won the 1986 Nobel Prize in physics for greatly expanding humans' ability to peer deep into the smallest facts of nature. The honor went to three Europeans - Dr. Ernst Ruska, Dr. Gerd Binnin and Dr. Heinrich Rohrer. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] The 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry was awarded to two Americans and a Canadian. The recipients are Dudley R. Herschbach of Harvard, Yuan T. Lee of the University of California at Berkeley and John C. Polanyi of the University of Toronto. [ B19:1. ]

title: Lord & Taylor Chief
description: The May Department Stores Company, as expected, yesterday named Marshall Hilsberg chairman and chief of its Lord & Taylor division. Succeeding him as chief of the G. Fox & Company, Hartford department store unit will be Jerald S. Politzer, an officer of Hecht's of Washington.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
USX to Shift Division's Assets
description: The USX Corporation, the old United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it was transferring most of the assets of its chemical division into a new company, the Aristech Chemical Corporation, and expected to raise between $500 million and $570 million from selling stock in the new company.

title: RETAIL SALES ROSE 4.6% LAST MONTH
description: Retail sales, led by a stampede to auto showrooms, increased 4.6 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MICROPOLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Rise of 31.49 Best Since Sept. 4
description: A flurry of buying in the last hour of trading yesterday gave Wall Street its best gain in a month and a half.

title: ADINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted to stock form in June.

title: New Foundation to Aid Deutsche Oper in U.S.
description: Gotz Friedrich, artistic director of the Deutsche Oper in West Berlin, announced yesterday the establishment of the American Berlin Opera Foundation, designed to help support American activities of his opera company. Mr. Friedrich spoke at a news conference yesterday morning at the Hotel Pierre.

title: Outlay Review By Bell Canada
description: Bell Canada said today that it would review its proposed capital expenditures after a Government agency ordered it to refund more than $200 million (Canadian), or about $144 million (United States), to its customers. Bell said it did not agree with Tuesday's decision by the Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission that a 12.25 percent rate of return is adequate for the telephone utility.

title: U.S. ENVOY IN SALVADOR SAID TO MEET WITH AGENT
description: The United States Ambassador, who two days ago denied that he knew a Central Intelligence Agency agent linked to supply operations for Nicaraguan rebels, in fact had lunch with him, an official said today.

title: CAPITAL REMEMBERS PRINCESS GRACE
description: Princess Grace of Monaco, who died in an automobile accident in 1982, was memorialized here tonight at the unveiling of a bronze bust that will stand in the National Portrait Gallery among 1,000 paintings, prints and statues of Presidents, poets and politicians.

title: DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the year. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $1.5 million for the year.

title: Now, for Post-Summit Repairs
description: At the summit meeting in Iceland, the United States and Soviet Union were within reach of an across-the-board agreement to make drastic reductions in theater nuclear forces and offensive strategic weapons, and for the eventual elimination of the weapons testing that fuels the nuclear arms race. Yet despite the failure there is still room to negotiate an agreement without either side having to surrender its basic position.

title: RUSSIAN, IN BONN, DENIES ARMS LINK
description: A Soviet arms negotiator said here today that medium-range nuclear missiles could be removed from Europe without linkage to the United States' missile defense program.

title: DEVRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Warsaw Pact Countries Back Soviet Stand on Iceland Talks
description: The Warsaw Pact foreign ministers, after being briefed by the Soviet Union on the Iceland meeting, called here today for a ''responsible'' Western approach to the Soviet arms proposals.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Unison Loses Software Suit
description: A Federal District Court has ruled that Unison World Inc., a software company based in Berkeley, Calif., violated the copyright held by Broderbund Software Inc. for Print Shop, a program that lets users create greeting cards, calendars and printed stationery on personal computers.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that the 1985 results have been restated to reflect the company's June merger with Key Pharmaceuticals and that the merger has been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: MAUCH CAN'T HIDE ANGUISH OF DEFEAT
description: Gene Mauch was still wearing his uniform shirt a half-hour later. His eyes were red, but he stood behind his desk with his feet apart, his shoulders squared and his hands on his hips. When he spoke, it was in clipped sentences. When he was finished, he shook some hands and angrily waved off a photographer.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $9,428,000 for the latest 6 months and $1,015,000 for the year-ago period.

title: BASIC QUESTIONS ABOUT WHAT TOOK PLACE AT REYKJAVIK TALKS ARE STILL UNANSWERED
description: Days after President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev parted company in Iceland after appearing to be on the verge of making an arms pact of historic proportions, Administration officials and critics alike are still looking for answers to key questions about that meeting.

title: Trade Ads Aid Sales, Study Says
description: WHEN the packaged goods industry in 1965 got the first study proving that advertising does indeed sell products, there were no expressions of surprise. These people were already believers. Where proof has not existed and was needed was in the industrial arena, which is now called business-to-business advertising. This part of the business world is populated by many unbelievers who would prefer to rely on the abilities of a sales force and run just enough trade advertising to make them feel warm inside.

title: Utah Planner Cited by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a Salt Lake City-based financial planner, Larry B. Groover, five companies he controlled and three of his associates with defrauding their customers out of more than $2.5 million from 1982 to 1984. The S.E.C. civil suit, filed in Federal District Court here, charged, among other things, that Mr. Groover had diverted $165,000 from his client's accounts to put a down payment on a new house and to purchase a new van.

title: PRESIDENT STUMPS FOR A FORMER AIDE
description: Returning a favor to a former aide with a campaign stop in Maryland, President Reagan said today that ''the safety of our neighborhoods and the security of our country'' would be risked if Democrats win control of the Senate.

title: UNITED BANKS OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects an after-tax gain of $5.3 million, or 55 cents per share, from the sale of real estate and a potential loss of $3.3 million in United Bank of Denver's investment in Allied Internationa Bancorp Inc. The company that in the latest quarter the $4.6 million, after-tax loss, incurred by United Bank of Fort Collins (Colo.) had the single largest impact in the earnings decline.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $169,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $60,000 and a tax credit of $293,000.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KAISER CEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,098,000 for the year-ago quarter; $1,375,000 for the latest 9 months and $3,763,000 the for the year-ago period. The company said this latest quarter and 9-month earnings include $2.3 million, or 31 cents a share, resulting from a third quarter settlement with the Internal Revenue Service audit of the company's federal income taxes through 1983.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $22,000 and $1,480,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $933,000 for the quarter and $2,178,000 for the year. Share earnings reflects a 1-for-14 reverse split of common on Feb. 14.

title: HARVEY V. HIGLEY
description: Harvey V. Higley, who served as head of the Veterans Administration under President Eisenhower, died today at the age of 94.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of about $1.1 million from sale of land for the quarter and 9 months.

title: THE CESCA CANE CHAIR: REPAIRING AND WEAVING
description: Marcel Breuer's classic cantilevered chair - the Cesca - has been much imitated since it appeared in the 1920's. Originally manufactured by Thonet, it was made of chrome-plated tubular steel with caned wooden framed seats and backs.

title: STRAWBERRY HANDLES PRESSURE
description: The changing of the guard at Shea Stadium officially took place in late January 1980. The long trip to yesterday actually began six months later, in the visiting team's clubhouse at Dodger Stadium, when a tall, skinny 18-year-old from nearby Crenshaw High School walked through the door to meet players who would never be his teammates.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and full-year results are pro forma to reflect the company's change in its fiscal year-end to July 31, from Aug. 31.

title: SAILORS AT SEA IN DONE-UP SEATTLE PORT
description: In the fog at the Seattle waterfront's main ferry dock this morning, a sailor from the aircraft carrier Constellation was a bit confused, out of place among the commuters hurrying off the ferry on their way to work.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about earnings at major banking companies characterized the performance of the dollar incorrectly. Its value has declined in relation to those of some other major currencies, increasing some overseas costs of multinational banks.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WRITING FILM Writing for the movies is its own particular art, not like writing for books or theater, although some of the best film scriptwriters have started in television. Wherever they come from, the people who write screenplays are more often than not an articulate bunch, as the onlooker may judge personally in the new series ''From Script to Screen'' that starts today at the 92nd Street Y, on Lexington Avenue.

title: A Feud
description: A consumer group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, has been feuding for some time with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, criticizing the Federal agency for, among other things, not requiring that the ingredients be printed on the labels of alcoholic beverages.

title: SOVRAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 6 months figures restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: The Hidden Price Everyone Pays for Credit Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: P.& G. Makes Changes At Richardson-Vicks
description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday announced the first changes at the top of Richardson-Vicks Inc. which it acquired last year.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Retirement Offer For 4,000 at Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation, hurt by declining sales of office equipment and seeking to cut costs, offered enhanced early retirement benefits to 4,000 of its senior employees yesterday.

title: Suharto, With Party Backing, Will Probably Seek 5th Term
description: President Suharto is expected to announce Monday that he will run for a fifth term of office after Indonesia's ruling party said today it would name him as its candidate.

title: New Pact for Morrow
description: Ken Morrow, one of the remaining links to the Islander championship years, has been re-signed to a two-year contract. The defenseman, who was playing in his option year, had knee surgery in 1984 that limited his playing time to 15 games in the 1984-85 regular season.

title: 80 NAMED AS RECIPIENTS OF ELLIS ISLAND AWARDS
description: Eighty Americans from 42 ethnic groups were named yesterday as recipients of the Ellis Island Medal of Honor by the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation.

title: Zzzzzzz
description: Hugh Durham, basketball coach at Georgia, on the purpose of the midnight session that customarily opens the practice season: ''Basically, you just kind of get the attention of the players. How much you get is debatable.''

title: Reynolds Metals' Profit
description: The Reynolds Metals Company yesterday reported a third-quarter profit of $25.5 million, or $1.02 a share, in contrast to a loss of $303.8 million a year earlier, which included a $322 million after-tax charge for the write-down of certain assets, mainly in the company's raw materials and primary aluminum operations.

title: DOCTOR AND 4 OTHERS ACCUSED OF STEALING HUMAN BODY PARTS
description: A doctor who shipped human heads to a Colorado research center was charged today with abuse of a corpse, theft of body parts and conspiracy.

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Simmons Co. Goes to AC&R
description: AC&R Advertising has become the agency for the Simmons Company, Atlanta, which has been doing its advertising in-house since the closing last year of its previous agency, McDonald & Little, also in Atlanta.

title: BOARD BARS CONTRACEPTIVES AT CLINICS IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: The Board of Education voted yesterday to prohibit the distribution of contraceptives at health clinics in high schools, but to allow the clinics, at nine schools, to continue to operate for six months.

title: EPSCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BY POPULAR DEMAND, MORE PHONES THAT DO MORE
description: JULIE FLANDERS is tired of her phone. It works fine, she says. It gets her calls through. But she wants more.

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company said the 1985 quarter and year results include gains from business interruption insurance of $102,000 and $895,000, respectively.

title: A Resignation
description: Jerry Woodruff, who was press secretary to Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, from 1981 until the legislator's death earlier this year, did his bit the other day to keep down the number of people on the Federal payroll. He quit after just one day on a new job.

title: Drop the Smokescreen; Start the Debates
description: Governor Cuomo's reluctance to debate his underdog Republican opponent, Andrew O'Rourke, continues to shortchange New York voters and democracy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Washington Set for 2d Lesson
description: The education of Dwayne Washington continues tonight when the Nets oppose the Knicks in an exhibition game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: XYVISION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss The company said that in conjunction with its initial public offering on July 1, 1986, it issued 1,702,315 shares of common stock and common stock equivalents, and that the share earnings for the 3 months and 6 months ended Sept. 27 reflect the appropriate weighting of these shares.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grumman Jobs Cut
description: The Grumman Corporation said its technical services division had notified 180 employees at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California that their employment would be terminated Oct. 31. The Air Force had announced earlier this month that 1,000 contractor jobs at Vandenberg would be eliminated because the space shuttle complex at the base would not be operational until 1992.

title: CLEMENS SHUTS OFF ANGELS IN 7TH GAME
description: In the clubhouse before the game, the Boston Red Sox watched television. ''We watched the Mets' celebration,'' Don Baylor related. ''We said that's exactly what we want to do.''

title: JAMES BURKE RECOUNTS EFFECTS OF PIVOTAL IDEAS
description: WORDS, words, words; James Burke isn't still for a minute. Don't dismiss him, however, even when he seems to be skittering in, around and over his topic. Get past tonight's first episode, on Channel 13 at 10, and ''The Day the Universe Changed'' turns out to be an entertaining, intelligent series.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes loan loss provisions of $91.1 million for the quarter and $136 million for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: GOLDMAN NAMES 37 PARTNERS
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company named 37 new partners yesterday, the most ever in the firm's history. The group included the first black and the first female partner at Goldman and its size reflected, the firm said, Goldman's fast growth in recent years.

title: JAZZ: LARRY ADLER RETURNS
description: LARRY ADLER, making his third appearance since January at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, has brought with him a variety of new ways to present his virtuosic mouth-organ performances.

title: 18 ARE CONFIRMED ENVOYS BY SENATE
description: The Senate confirmed today the nominations of 18 ambassadors under a leadership agreement designed to placate Senator Jesse Helms.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TEARS OF THE WHITE MAN:

title: HISTORIC FACTS: THE WRONG BOX
description: With 1992, the 500th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America, in sight, it's none too soon to make sure the memorial wreaths are laid at the right tomb. That isn't easy: the admiral's remains appear to have traveled more than the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria.

title: MUSIC: PITTSBURGH OPERA'S 'MACBETH'
description: The true operatic stature of Ghena Dimitrova, who appeared here Tuesday night in a Pittsburgh Opera production of Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' must remain a question mark for Metropolitan Opera audiences until next season when she is scheduled to sing the title role in Puccini's ''Turandot.'' Although the Bulgarian soprano has been a familiar figure in the major European houses for many years, New York knows her only from concert versions of ''Nabucco'' and ''La Gioconda,'' where the rare power and thrust of her voice aroused great enthusiasm. These same performances also aroused doubts as to her importance as a singing actress.

title: SUN MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Parents Suing Alabama Over Books Rest Case
description: The lawyers for parents who are charging that Alabama pupils are threatened with brainwashing by humanist textbooks rested their case today. An attorney for the state then asked a Federal district judge to quash the lawsuit.

title: Baxter Travenol
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories said that it had begun a restructuring that results from its acquisition of the American Hospital Supply Corporation last year. The company said it had reduced its operations to five groups from 10 to reduce overhead and management levels. A spokesman said that it was too early to assess the impact of the steps, which affect mostly the company's hospital and medical specialty businesses, both of which will be streamlined into one group from three.

title: CABARET: JULIE KURNITZ
description: AS a comedienne Julie Kurnitz has the physical attributes - tall, thin and toothy - to caricature Eleanor Roosevelt, although Mrs. Roosevelt is not one of the people she portrays in her mix of monologues, songs and sketches at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, where she is appearing Thursdays through Saturdays this month.

title: PRESIDENT IS CRITICAL OF 'LIBERALS' WHO MAY 'CHOP UP' 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan today accused what he called ''liberals'' in Congress of trying to ''chop up'' the space-based missile defense program and playing into the hands of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of land of $8.8 million for the latest quarter and about $17.2 million for the year- ago period. Shares outstanding represent average partnership units.

title: No Cherry Bowl
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Council decertified the Cherry Bowl, citing the failure by officials of the postseason game to meet a $1 million minimum requirement for corporate sponsorships.

title: PEOPLE CAN TALK BACK TO NEW ALARM CLOCKS
description: WHEN the alarm goes off in the morning, why not roll over and just tell it to ''shut up!'' Because most people have learned that alarm clocks do not respond well to that. They need to be touched.

title: Lincoln Brigade
description: To the Editor:

title: Digital's Profits Up Sharply
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, accelerating its rebound while other computer makers are suffering, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings more than doubled to $182.6 million, or $1.37 cents a share, from $72.3 million, or 60 cents a share, a year ago.

title: NEWORLD BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Work Resumes at Plant Where 2 Died in Blast
description: Workers resumed production of oilfield explosives at the GOEX plant today, hours after a blast at the plant killed two men, one of them the president of the concern.

title: CONCERT: RED SNEAKERS

Since then, the Sneakers, as they call themselves, have composed, performed, conducted and produced more than 125 world premieres.

description: The reductions in long-range, strategic nuclear weapons tentatively agreed to in Iceland would be only 20 to 30 percent over a five-year period, according to arms-control experts.

title: ISRAELI JET IS LOST DURING BIG RAID AGAINST P.L.O.
description: The Israeli Air Force and Navy launched large-scale attacks today against suspected Palestinian guerrilla bases in southern Lebanon and the police said an Israeli fighter jet had been shot down by ground fire. [ An Israeli Army spokesman in Jerusalem confirmed that a fighter jet had been shot down while attacking Palestinian bases near Sidon. The spokesman said one of the fighter's two pilots was rescued in a ''quick and daring'' mission by Israeli attack helicopters. The other pilot was still missing, the spokesman said. ] Earlier the Lebanese police said the two pilots had been taken prisoner by Lebanese Shiite militiamen. Other reports said they had been captured by Palestinians in the area. Jets, Helicopters and Boats

title: CONNECTICUT DISTRICT ADMITS AIDS CHILD AMID CONCERNS
description: A decision by the Board of Education to allow a child with AIDS to remain in school has prompted great concern, even outrage, and in some cases proud support among people in this close-knit rural community.

What was left of the 11,000 tickets made available to subscribers last March sold out after only four days of public sale this week.

title: HOUSTON: A CITY OF AGONIZING LOSSES
description: Amid anguish and soulsearching over what might have been, this city did its best to resume normal life a day after the end of its baseball season. The playoff series became part baseball, part sociology and a full-time civic obsession in a city that is quietly developing one of the nation's greatest records of sporting frustration.

title: Panel Approves Restart Of Uranium Fuel Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted unanimously today to approve the restart of a uranium fuel processing plant where one worker died and 25 were injured in an explosion last January.

title: Westinghouse, NBC in Talks
description: Westinghouse Broadcasting and Cable Inc. and the National Broadcasting Company, two of the oldest names in radio, are discussing merging 20 of their 21 radio stations and the NBC Radio Networks, executives at the two companies said Thursday.

title: Two Are Killed In Plane Crash
description: Two people were killed and two others were injured yesterday when a plane taking off from a small airport here collided with a plane landing on another runway, the authorities said.

title: FIRST BOSTON IS HIGHER; AMERICAN EXPRESS RISES
description: Despite volatile conditions in the securities markets in the third quarter, two major financial services concerns, the American Express Company and First Boston Inc., reported yesterday that their earnings rose in the period.

title: A DILEMMA FOR PAKISTAN
description: The Soviet Union's decision to withdraw a tiny fraction of its troops (8,000 out of 115,000) from Afghanistan will do nothing to halt the exodus of Afghan refugees or alleviate the sufferings of those who have fled - a group that now accounts for more than one-third of Afghanistan's prewar population.

title: NETS MAKE OFFER FOR VALENTINE
description: The Nets, seeking a backup playmaker for Dwayne Washington, their top draft choice, presented Darnell Valentine, the free agent from the Los Angeles Clippers, with an offer sheet several hours before last night's 100-92 victory in an exhibition game against the Knicks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: A School's Five Is Worth 700
description: Last spring, unheralded Cleveland State captivated the basketball world by upsetting Indiana in the N.C.A.A. tournament and advancing to the round of 16 before losing to Navy by just 1 point.

title: Kathleen Carroll Reasoner, Lawyer and Wife of Newsman
description: Kathleen Carroll Reasoner, a lawyer and the wife of Harry Reasoner, a CBS News correspondent, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 60 years old.

title: IN THE LAUREATE'S WORDS
description: From ''Ake: The Years of Childhood,'' (1981):

title: Jersey Man Held in Slaying
description: An 18-year-old New Jersey man has been charged in the murder of a former state prosecutor who was found strangled in Central Park Oct. 1, the police said yesterday.

title: STRONG FIELD FOR CHAMPAGNE
description: When Gulch finished a dull second in the Norfolk Stakes at Santa Anita last Saturday, he not only bankrupted a lot of Californians who bet him at 4 to 5, but he also turned the 2-year-old division from the least to the most competitive in racing this year.

title: Woody Allen v. the I.R.S.
description: No one likes a good laugh more than Woody Allen. But he was apparently far from amused when the Internal Revenue Service sent him a bill last June for $310,729 in ''deficiencies'' in his 1977 and 1978 income tax filings.

title: 'South Pacific' Planned
description: The musical ''South Pacific,'' by Oscar Hammerstein, Richard Rodgers and Joshua Logan, will be presented by the New York City Opera next February as part of the company's annual musical comedy season. The production will be directed by Gerald Freedman, with set and costume design by Desmond Heeley. Performances will begin Feb. 27, with an opening scheduled for Feb. 28; it will then run for nine weeks.

title: McDonnell Charge
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said that its third-quarter net earnings would be reduced by $42.5 million, or $1.05 a share, because of write-offs in two aerospace programs. The company said that total earnings for the quarter would be about $1 a share, down from $1.81 a share during the correspondingperiod a year ago. The company said it would issue its final results for the third quarter on Oct. 24.

title: ARTISTS PUTTING STUDIOS ON DISPLAY
description: FOR anyone puzzled by painters and sculptors - by their creative minds and by the gritty question of how they live and survive and sometimes thrive in New York today - an ''open studio'' is just the thing. And this month, with several large open studios being held around the city, is just the time.

title: AQUINO TAKES CAMPAIGN FOR CONSTITUTION TO SOUTH
description: President Corazon C. Aquino met with the people of this southern city today for talks about their economic and security concerns, but a hoped-for meeting with local Communist leaders did not materialize.

title: BEARS, WITH McMAHON OUT, FACE TRUBLE WITH VIKINGS

A party financier involved in the selection has told friends that the odds are now ''7 out of 10'' that the Republican National Committee will pick the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans for its convention site when it meets in January.

title: Shell Group Letter

title: The Editorial Notebook; The William Walker Brigade
description: An unexpected bell tolled last week for the 1,600 Americans who died fighting for the Spanish Republic in the 1930's. President Reagan recalled the memory of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade to defend the right of private citizens to join rebels in Nicaragua. As a matter of principle, he has a point. After all, Lafayette and other foreigners were among the heroes of our own Revolution.

It turned out to be generated by smoke arising from a large black Sherlock Holmes-type pipe being puffed by a guest.

While the school was forced to drop its junior varsity team this year, it still has enough players for a varsity squad.

description: The two University of Maryland basketball players who were with Len Bias in the hours before he died of cocaine-intoxication testified before a grand jury yesterday for the first time since the investigation of the death began in July. Terry Long and David Gregg, who have been indicted on charges of obstruction of justice and possession of cocaine, testified in a closed hearing for nearly four hours. Neither would comment on what they said or what prompted them to testify after months of staying silent.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday TIBETAN SINGING BOWL ENSEMBLE The newer music gets, it often appears, the older it becomes. The case in point is a concert tonight featuring a new composition performed by the Tibetan Singing Bowl Ensemble, with a soloist playing the shofar, the ram's horn employed in Jewish High Holiday rites, and the Tibetan human thighbone trumpet. The contemporary piece, ''Music for an October Moon,'' was written by Raphael Mostel and was inspired to celebrate a time when visible and invisible worlds are in closest conjunction. The Tibetan Singing Bowl Ensemble consists of a half-dozen players who make their music with bowls, which are bell-like instruments made of certain alloys that produce a singular sound and trace their ancestry to mythical Himalayan times. The soloist is Dan Erkkila. The performance is at 8 o'clock tonight at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street (219-2527). Admission: $9; students and over-65's, $8.

title: Recliner-Chair Maker Picks Bozell, Jacobs
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has landed an account of a rather restful nature, even though the client's name is Action Industries.

title: GIANTS' JOHNSON HAS TROUBLE ON PATTERNS
description: For the Giants, who have won five straight games, this should be a time for happiness. For Bobby Johnson, the most experienced wide receiver on their roster, a sprained left ankle has made this a time of uncertainty and frustration.

title: Mayflower Gets Inside Buyout Bid
description: Mayflower Group said a group led by Mayflower executives has offered to acquire the moving company for $235 million, or $30.50 a share.

title: New York, of the National League
description: Cheer the New York Mets for the greatest baseball season since, well, it doesn't make any difference. Not for years has all New York been so united in its appreciation for a team. Whatever happens in the World Series that starts tomorrow, the Mets have already delivered a spectacular season. Their 108-win summer was a wonder and the playoff series against the Houston Astros was every bit as extraordinary - adding up, as Dave Anderson of The Times suggests, to one marvelous 64-inning game, which the Mets won, 21-17.

title: COGNITIVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges of $3 million and $8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for early extinguishment of debt. The company said a pretax gain of $54 million for the previously reported sale of Rorer Group Inc. stock held in the company's investment portfolio was included in the latest third quarter results.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Rosco Gordon, Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Rosco Gordon was present for the birth of rock-and-roll in the early 1950's, working around Memphis with the likes of Bobby Bland and Johnny Ace and singing his own rhythm-and-blues songs, accompanied by two-fisted piano chords with a distinctive kind of syncopation. While the beat of Mr. Gordon's ''No More Doggin' '' became popular in Jamaica and turned into a major influence on ska and reggae, Mr. Gordon went into obscurity. But in the 1980's, he has re-emerged with a gruffer voice, slightly more New Orleans-flavored piano, and plenty of renewed vigor. He will perform today and tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SAYS STATE RECORD-KEEPING OF AUTO POLLUTION TESTS IS SLIPSHOD
description: Federal environmental officals say there are probably thousands of cars in and around New York City that do not meet pollution-control rules, but sloppy record-keeping by New York State makes it impossible to identify them.

title: UNITED MISSOURI BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
E.P.A. to Help Detect Radon
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today it would help 10 states conduct surveys of household radon gas, an indoor pollutant scientists say could cause up to 20,000 lung cancer deaths a year.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: DYSON, DESPITE DIFFERENCES, ENDORSES GREEN FOR SENATE
description: John S. Dyson endorsed his former rival, Mark Green, for the United States Senate yesterday, declaring that they had reached agreement on a number of issues after meeting for several hours on Tuesday.

title: Lee Remick in Thriller, 'Of Pure Blood,' on CBS
description: Lee Remick can usually be counted on to bring a dogged integrity to every role she is handed. With her small, crisp speaking voice and delicate features that project a puzzled, searching intelligence, Miss Remick is a television icon of American decency under siege. In ''Of Pure Blood,'' a two-hour thriller that airs this Sunday at 9 P.M. on CBS, the actress's trustworthy persona and her gift for understatement go a long way toward redeeming a made-for-television film that clanks with stereotypical ex-Nazi fiends and assorted other stick figures.

title: Officer at Chemical Plans to Join Weill
description: In a move that surprised banking analysts, Robert I. Lipp, one of three presidents at the Chemical New York Corporation, said yesterday that he was leaving the bank holding company to join Sanford I. Weill at the Commercial Credit Company, the large but troubled consumer credit company that is about to be spun off from the Control Data Corporation.

title: MCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * F. Kent Mitchel has been named president of the Marketing Science Institute, Cambridge, Mass.

RADA ELECTRONIC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an operational loss of $225,000 resulting from the opening and activities of its sales and marketing organization in the United States, increased research and development expenses, and modification of a contract in which the company is still negotiating compensation, inflationary and economic conditions in Israel.

title: Dockworkers Return To Jobs in New Orleans
description: Dockworkers returned to their jobs today after negotiators for three union locals reached tentative agreements with cargo-handling companies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Sept. 20 described Hyman Bookbinder incorrectly. He is the special representative of the American Jewish Committee.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $30,000. The company converted to stock form in November 1985.

title: LANDMARK BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Changes at Mass Mutual
description: The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that its president, William J. Clark, 63 years old, had been elected chairman. He remains chief executive officer. Mr. Clark succeeds James R. Martin, 67, who will continue as a director. The company also named Thomas B. Wheeler, who is 50, president and chief operating officer and Seymour Sternberg, 43, senior executive vice president.

title: Hudson Valley Group Appearing in 2 Concerts
description: The Hudson Valley Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Imre Pallo, will open its 27th season with concerts at 8 tonight in Kingston, N.Y., and tomorrow night at 8 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Hermann Baumann, a French horn player, will be the soloist at both concerts in a program that includes works by Brahms, Bizet and Gliere.

title: 5 Die in Tobago Hospital Fire
description: Five people died and nine were seriously injured when fire swept through the geriatric ward of the Tobago General Hospital last night, fire officials said. Firefighters said they managed to evacuate 25 patients, but that 3 burned to death in their beds. Two more died on the way to emergency treatment.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS STOCK SALE
description: Looking to recoup some of the $4.5 billion it took to rescue the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it planned to sell 50 million shares of the bank to the public by the end of the year.

title: ART: 1960'S SCULPTURES OF RICHARD ARTSCHWAGER
description: THE dryly satirical sculptural representations of furniture made by Richard Artsch wager in the 1960's are offshoots of his income-producing work. He ran a furniture factory, then, in which the basic items were fabricated without frills. This was the era in which the brashness of Pop Art was giving way to the cool formalism of minimal art, and Artschwager's sculptures seemed to flip-flop between the two modes. They could be commonplace and friendly pieces but then turn severe and austere.

title: Pacific Soloists
description: The Pacific Soloists will play a concert of works by Haydn, Shostakovich and Brahms at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8, with all proceeds to benefit the New York City Chapter for Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association Inc. Tickets are $15 to $75. Information: 719-4744 or 362-1911. Those holding $75 tickets are invited to a champagne reception immediately after the program.

title: Reagan Triumphs From Failure in Iceland
description: Moments after President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded their meeting in Reykjavik Sunday night, its outcome seemed clear. Mr. Reagan was grim-faced, even angry, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz showed up at a news conference looking haggard and drained.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 2.

title: MEDALIST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
He Gets No Kick
description: The Rick Carey Unhappy Winner Award: To Frank Cashen, the Mets' general manager, who, while being interviewed on TV after the pennant-clinching victory Wednesday night, was drenched in the clubhouse by an unidentified player and then grumbled, ''Why is it always the guys who do the least that spray the most champagne?''

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Excludes the gain on the sale of substantially all of the company's industrial operations on July 1, 1985, which increased 1985 net income and share net by $38 million and 16 cents a share, respectively. c-Includes $9 million, or 4 cents a share, and $29 million, or 12 cents a share, respectively, resulting from the company's 1986 change in its method of determining pension expense to conform to requirements of FAS No. 87. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 common stock split-up distributed on April 10, 1986, to stockholders of record on March 14, 1986. Results for 1986 include General Foods Corp., a wholly-owned subsidiary since Nov. 1, 1985, and exclude Seven-Up Co. The company said it sold the international operations of Seven-Up to Pepsico Inc. on July 11 and announced on Oct. 3 a definitive agreement to sell the U.S. franchise business of Seven-Up to a group of investors.

title: Liszt Program
description: The pianist Francois Rene Duchable will make his New York recital debut tomorrow night at 8 with an all-Liszt program at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $10 to $14. Information: 362-1911.

title: THE MAYOR DISCOVERS BASEBALL
description: BASEBALL, hot dogs and apple pie are three things every American is supposed to love - and certainly every politician.

title: PLAIN SHEA: THE MAGIC COMES AT THE GATE
description: There is a stadium in Boston with a Green Monster.

title: PERES AND SHAMIR REACH AN ACCORD
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir today resolved all of the issues holding up their job-exchange, but members of Mr. Shamir's Likud bloc rejected part of the agreement and further negotiations were expected.

title: Protester Delays Test Of Nuclear Weapon
description: A large nuclear weapon was exploded today 2,000 feet beneath the Nevada desert after an antinuclear protester was arrested for trespassing and removed from the site by helicopter.

title: THE SCREEN: 'COMBAT SHOCK'
description: ''COMBAT SHOCK,'' which opens today at the U.A.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $797,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,422,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $597,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,093,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months. The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 12, 1986, as well as public stock offering in August 1985 and April 1986.

title: '87 SPENDING BILL PASSES INITIAL TEST IN VOTE IN SENATE
description: The Senate gave initial approval Thursday to a $576 billion comprehensive appropriation bill for 1987, and worked into the early morning today as Congress pushed to finish for the year.

title: OPEC DEBATES A DEBT QUOTA LINK
description: A meeting of OPEC ministers appeared stalled today over the issue of whether to include national debt among criteria for devising a crucial production-sharing program to prop up oil prices.

title: I.B.M. Contract At Social Security
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's Federal Systems division in Houston said that it has been awarded a seven-year contract from the Social Security Administration to supply computer terminals, controllers and printers for 1,300 offices.

title: PRECEDENT SEEN IN BALDI CASE
description: Practice for the 1986-87 basketball season has just started, but St. John's has already recorded a major victory. The eligibility of Marco Baldi, the Redmen's 6-foot-11-inch sophomore center, has been restored.

title: BARCELONA, A 4-TIME LOSE, WANTS THE '92 GAMES
description: If you listen closely, you might hear the gulps as this city's three million people wait nervously.

title: REAGAN SAID TO FAVOR SIGNING NEW ALIENS BILL
description: A leading Republican Senator said that President Reagan indicated today that he would probably sign a comprehensive immigration bill on which House and Senate negotiators agreed this week.

title: New U.S.F.L. Move
description: ''We're not giving up,'' said Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, as he announced the league's latest legal maneuver.

title: France's Tragic Lesson
description: The French capital has a breathing spell from the series of terrorist attacks that sowed panic last month. But the revelations and questions they brought out have not been swept away with the debris.

title: Piano Program
description: The pianist Krystian Zimerman will play music by Beethoven, Schubert and Schumann Sunday afternoon at 3 at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $9 to $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: CUOMO AND RIVAL CLASH ON THE AIR
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke unexpectedly telephoned a radio call-in program featuring Governor Cuomo yesterday, setting off a bitter five-minute broadcast exchange - in effect, their first debate of the gubernatorial campaign.

title: LONGER LIFE FOR ORBITING SATELLITES AT HAND, EASING LAUNCHING NEEDS
description: The nation's largest operator of communications satellites said today that it had developed a surprisingly simple technique for greatly prolonging the life of satellites now in orbit, a move that should lessen the acute need for launching vehicles since the space shuttle disaster.

title: Nevada Stunt Victim Said to Be an Inventor
description: A man who mysteriously jumped out of a plane to his death on Oct. 6 before videotape cameras was a West German inventor trying to get publicity for a parachute he had invented, the police said today.

title: On Arms, Democrats Feel Shellshocked
description: As things now stand, the Democrats are in a familiar posture. Most of them privately are critical of President Reagan in the aftermath of his arms control meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev last weekend in Iceland. But they are wary of making it an issue in the Congressional elections next month, especially when the President is trying to revive the old charge of Democrats being soft on defense.

title: SOYINKA, NIGERIAN DRAMATIST, WINS NOBEL LITERATURE PRIZE
description: Wole Soyinka, a Nigerian playwright and poet who has been a fierce champion of political freedom in black Africa, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature today.

description: b-Net loss

Hutton Denies Buyout Bids
description: The E. F. Hutton Group denied yesterday that it had received and rejected any offers to acquire the company and added that it was not in discussions with any party about an acquisition.

title: A Bonn View On Rate Cut
description: Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg today dampened hopes of a cut in the country's key interest rates, citing excessive growth in the West German money supply.

title: Herbalife to Pay $850,000 Penalty
description: Herbalife International Inc., a health and diet products concern, agreed Wednesday to pay $850,000 to settle a suit filed by the California Attorney General's office that charged the company with making false medical claims and running an illegal pyramid-style marketing scheme.

title: ROTHSCHILD L F UNTERBERG TOWBIN HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28

title: OPERA: APRILE MILLO IN TITLE ROLE OF 'AIDA'
description: THE world is not producing many important young Verdi voices nowadays, a lamentable fact that makes every performance of Aprile Millo of more than passing interest. A New Yorker by birth who was reared in California, she has developed in the two years since her Metropolitan Opera debut into a Verdi soprano of real quality. Last night, in the seventh ''Aida'' of the season, Miss Millo took on her greatest challenge yet, the famously taxing title role of the Ethiopian princess forced into Egyptian slavery.

title: 2d Horizontal Stand to Test Rockets Is Planned by NASA
description: Bowing to recommendations by outside experts, the space agency announced today that it would build a second horizontal test stand for the redesigned booster rockets for the space shuttle.

title: Newman on Saxophone
description: The saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman will lead his quartet Sunday at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M.; there is a $10 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

description: A crucial race between Stars & Stripes and New Zealand in the America's Cup challengers' series was postponed today because of 30-knot winds and storm warnings.

title: A MECCA OF ECLECTIC FOOD AND UNDERWATER FANTASY
description: In a city where rambunctiousness is the name of the game, one of the most rambunctious new places in town is a restaurant called Rebecca's in the Venice section. Even the tacos, filled with ingredients such as lamb's tongue and sea bass, are cunningly designed.

title: Vintage Cars to Make Run Through the City
description: The Stutz Bearcats will be rolling through lower Manhattan on Sunday, but don't try to hail one for a ride. They will be part of the seventh Brighton Run - American Style, a procession of vintage cars that begins at 11:15 A.M. at Herald Square.

title: California Businessman Gets Right To Seize Soviet Assets
description: A businessman who won a $450,000 libel judgment against the Soviet Union received permission Wednesday from a Federal magistrate to begin seizing Soviet assets in the United States.

title: Chief-Raider Fine
description: As a result of two brawls in an Oct. 5 game, Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the N.F.L., has fined Coach John Mackovic of the Kansas City Chiefs, eight of his players and 10 members of the Los Angeles Raiders, after having reinstituted the one-game suspension for the Raiders' defensive end, Greg Townsend, earlier this week. A total of $4,200 in fines was assessed the Chiefs players, with the biggest, $1,000, going to Brad Budde.

title: 61-YEAR-OLD MATHEMATICIAN TO HEAD SOVIET ACADEMY OF SCIENCES
description: Guri I. Marchuk, a Soviet mathematician and a leading science administrator, was elected president of the Academy of Sciences today.

description: ''THE MACHINE AGE IN AMERICA, 1918-1941,'' at the Brooklyn Museum, is an esthetic experience of a high order, in which artists, inventors and designers - many of them already forgotten - combine to heighten and tweak our responses to a period not often studied in such depth.

title: ...AND IN BOSTON, NO.1 FEVER IS EPIDEMIC
description: It has been a good year for sports in Boston. First the New England Patriots emerged from obscurity to win the American Football Conference crown, before bowing in the Super Bowl. Then the Celtics took the National Basketball Association championship.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dining Out Guide: Chinese
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AUNTIE YUAN, #1191A First Avenue, near 65th Street (744-4040) - **(June 13, 1986) A more tranquil alternative to an evening in Chinatown is dinner at this Upper East Side restaurant with its dramatic all-black dining room and pinpoint overhead lighting. To start, you might try cold noodles in a peppery sesame sauce with scallions; a cold salad of shredded duck meat and crackly skin, scallions, Chinese cabbage and coriander, or barbecued quails glazed with a zippy garlic paste.

description: The World Jewish Congress today made public Yugoslav documents that include testimony by a German officer who accused Kurt Waldheim of planning reprisal measures taken by the German Army in World War II.

title: The Pro Circuit in '88?
description: The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has been given a sentimental chorus of bipartisan praise in his closing days as a House member, but not every aspect of his long public career has been endorsed by everyone.

title: Zimmer Leaving Yanks
description: Don Zimmer, who was the third-base coach for the Yankees for most of this season, has been hired as the San Francisco Giants' third-base coach for next year, team officials announced yesterday. ''I got the guy I wanted,'' Manager Roger Craig said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about arguments before the Supreme Court, on a contention that racial discrimination occurred in administering the death penalty, misstated the position of a defense lawyer. The claim was that statistical evidence showed killers of white victims were far more likely to be sentenced to death than killers of blacks.

title: HARLAND JOHN H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nun Mugged on L.I.
description: A nun in a religious habit was knocked down and robbed by a purse snatcher, the state police said today. The nun, whose name was withheld, was walking near here Wednesday morning when a man came up on a bicycle and mugged her, the police said. Passers-by flagged down a state police car and gave a description, and Carl Roberson, 21 years old, of Riverhead, was arrested and charged with robbery.

title: IN BROOKLYN, OLD AND NEW MUSIC
description: WHEN Jon Hassell, the visionary electronic composer and trumpet player, talks about his music, the discussion goes far beyond technique and style. The Memphis-born explorer of African and Eastern music is an esthetician, cultural anthropologist and something of a mystic as well as a composer-performer.

description: Revenue was reported as gross earning.

description: Against all the odds, Donald Trump is getting his way - sort of - at the corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Central Park South.

description: Stock prices moved slightly higher on Wall Street yesterday and trading volume remained brisk in a session dominated by corporate earnings reports and, especially, takeover speculation.

description: A parachutist leaped from the Statue of Liberty's torch yesterday morning, landing uninjured 305 feet below as about 300 sightseers from a cruise watched. The parachutist was arrested for trespassing by Federal park rangers.

DARLING TO FACE HURST IN OPENER
description: The Mets brought their pennant home to New York yesterday, along with memories of the six tingling games against the Houston Astros that won it. And, after taking one day off from their travels and adventures, they will return to Shea Stadium today to prepare for the final test of 1986: the World Series against the Boston Red Sox.

description: Mike Sullivan and Payne Stewart, each without a victory in the last three years, took the first-round lead today in the Walt Disney World Oldsmobile Classic with rounds of 65, seven strokes under par.

title: BANGLADESH CHIEF CLAIMS VOTE VICTORY
description: President H. M. Ershad, proclaiming himself the victor in Wednesday's disputed presidential election, dismissed the widespread charges today that the voting was rigged and said he would soon move to lift martial law.

description: The stock of the Public Service Company of Indiana rose sharply following a report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that an Indiana-based investor group offered to buy the utility for $17 a share, or about $1 billion, last week.

title: PHYSICISTS CHALLENGE THEORY OF A 'FIFTH FORCE' BEYOND GRAVITY
description: Theoretical physicists have proposed an alternative and more conventional explanation for experimental data suggesting that some ''fifth force'' beyond gravity affects the motion of falling bodies, apparently causing them to accelerate at slightly different rates.

L.I. Freshman Dies
description: Troy Norton of Uniondale, L.I., a 6-foot-4-inch, 180-pound freshman at Clark College in Atlanta, collapsed and died early Wednesday, the first day of basketball practice allowed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. LIABILITY POLICY ASSAILED BY TWO IN CONGRESS
description: Two Democratic Congressmen today criticized a new policy the Justice Department was using to settle a case involving agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who were found to have illegally spied on and disrupted antiwar groups more than a decade ago.

title: 2 YOUNG FELD DANCERS COMING INTO THEIR OWN
description: Each dance season has its distinctions. Sometimes it is a new work. Often it is a new dancer. The Feld Ballet's current engagement at the Joyce Theater may be remembered most as a season of outstanding performances from James Sewell and Darren Gibson, two of the company's most gifted young dancers. And this weekend is a good time to see them in a variety of ballets by Eliot Feld.

title: SCREEN: 'RATBOY'
description: THE title character in ''Ratboy'' has an awful overbite, not to mention claws, twitchy whiskers and a vestigial tail. In sociological terms, he exists somewhere between E. T. and the Elephant Man, as an innocent alien adrift in an unsympathetic world. But ''Ratboy'' isn't exactly serious about this, nor is it really funny, or fanciful, or even very far out of the ordinary. As directed by Sondra Locke, who also stars in it, the curiously conventional film ''Ratboy'' is energetic but skittish, almost as much so as the character.

title: State and Agencies Set $1.5 Billion Bond Sales
description: New York State and major agencies in the state are expected to sell nearly $1.5 billion of bonds in the fourth quarter, according to a tentative schedule announced this week by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: PIANO: MIKHAIL RUDY RECITAL
description: Even the piano pieces Brahms wrote at the close of his career evoke the struggles of his earlier, grander works -namely their tense confrontation between formal disciplinarian and effusive Romantic. In his piano recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night, Mikhail Rudy played Opus 116 and Opus 118 complete, and in all 13 pieces he made his partisanship in this confrontation quite clear.

title: COLOMBIAN REPORTER BARRED FROM STAYING IN U.S.
description: The Government yesterday refused to let a reporter for Colombia's leading newspaper stay in the United States because it believed she might ''engage in subversive activities'' here.

title: For the Dyslexic Child, Appropriate Remedial Help Is Available
description: To the Editor:

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for both periods include accounting changes for pension costs that added $139,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $417,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 9 months. The share earnings for both year- ago periods were restated to reflect 50 percent stock dividend in February 1986.

title: FIRST BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sun Belt, Hot Stove
description: It is winter now in Houston, or what passes for winter near the Gulf of Mexico. People are still mowing their lawns and putting chemicals in their pools, but in their hearts it is winter.

title: Audi of America Inc. Will Replace Its Head
description: Peter Fischer, head of Audi of America Inc. since 1982, will be reassigned to another position in the Volkswagen organization.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McCarron Hurt in Spill
description: Chris McCarron, the nation's leading jockey, suffered a broken left leg yesterday when he was thrown from his mount during a five-horse spill in $45,000 feature race for older horses at Santa Anita. McCarron, 31 years old, whose mounts have earned more than $9 million in purses, was taken to the Arcadia Methodist Hospital.

description: b-After extraordinary credits of $525,000 for the quarter and $3,357,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $350,000 for the quarter and after an extraordinary credit of $251,000 for the 9 months.

Change at IBM Germany
description: Lothar S. W. Sparberg announced yesterday in Stuttgart that he would retire at the end of the year as president of IBM Germany. He will become chairman of IBM Germany's supervisory board.

title: Fireman's Fund Debentures
description: The Fireman's Fund Corporation, a property and casualty insurance underwriter, is offering $150 million of 9 5/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2016 at a price of 99.07, to yield 9.72 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: THEATER: 'RAGGEDY ANN,' A MUSICAL
description: THE bad news is broken early in Broadway's newest musical, ''Raggedy Ann.'' No sooner does the curtain rise at the Nederlander Theater than the audience is solemnly informed that the heroine's pet canary, Yellow Yum Yum, is dead. One might think that ''Raggedy Ann'' had nowhere to go but up after that, but never underestimate the self-destructive persistence of theater people who just can't bear to part with a terrible idea. Late in Act I, for a production number's sake, they go and bring Yellow Yum Yum back to life.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,650,013

title: COMEBACK SPURS BOSTON
description: Whether or not the Mets were right in their suspicion that Mike Scott does funny things to the baseballs he pitches, they don't have to worry about the Boston pitchers scuffing the balls. The Red Sox have a good starting staff, anchored by Roger Clemens, but we've never seen them throw any pitches that are unusual.

title: Huge Cutbacks Set At Owens-Corning
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, detailing a major restructuring plan, yesterday announced slashing cutbacks in its hourly employees and in its salaried middle-management employees.

title: ISRAELIS PROTEST TO EGYPT ON P.L.O.
description: The Israeli Foreign Ministry called in the Egyptian Ambassador to deliver a protest today after the Palestine Liberation Organization claimed resonsibility, in a message issued in Cairo, for the grenade attack Wednesday night in Jerusalem.

The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding for the 9-month period includes a one-time charge relating to the relocation of Raleigh operations to Seattle, of 4 cents per share, and a one-time charge associated with the sale of the Ponca City plant amounting to an additional 4 cents per share.

title: Bridge: New Reason Joins the List For Starting Matches Late
description: To the long list of possible reasons for a late-starting duplicate game a new one was added Wednesday evening - delay by baseball.

title: Microscopic Oversight
description: Prize committees and historians of science heap kudos on those who uncover important new facts about the world or who synthesize facts into new theory. A third kind of scientist receives less attention - the inventor of a new technique.

description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January.

title: SHULTZ TOURS SALVADORAN RUBBLE AND PROMISES MORE AMERICAN AID
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz took a tour through the twisted rubble of this city today and declared that El Salvador had suffered economic ''catastrophe'' of monumental proportions.

The company said the latest third quarter loss is after a $13 million after-tax charge to writedown oil and gas assets.

title: FOUR VETERANS ENDING FAST ON POLICY IN NICARAGUA
description: As they would sit on the steps in the chill shadow of the Capitol dome, shrunken bodies wrapped in blankets, four fasting veterans let anti-war aphorisms roll easily off their tongues. But today, 46 days after the protest against the United States' involvement in Nicaragua began, they called off the fast.

title: Senate Polishes Tax Legislation
description: The Senate today approved $58 million worth of tax breaks in making technical changes in the tax bill that cleared Congress last month.

title: EDUCATOR ON BOARD OF TIMES CO.
description: Donald M. Stewart, president of Spelman College in Atlanta and president-elect of the College Entrance Examination Board, was named a director of The New York Times Company yesterday.
