Gannett Profits Increase 7.9%
description: The Gannett Company, the newspaper publisher, yesterday reported a rise of 7.9 percent in third-quarter earnings.

title: Chambers Still Free on Bail
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., who was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on Wednesday on burglary charges, remained free on bail yesterday after the court agreed that the collateral posted as bail in Mr. Chambers's first indictment - charging him with murder - was sufficient for bail in the burglary indictment as well.

title: IT'S A SERIOUS BUSINESS, CARTOONISTS SAY, REALLY
description: Cartoons should be taken seriously. The writer Calvin Trillin says so. The cartoonists Jules Feiffer, Ed Koren and Gahan Wilson say so.

title: 'PARADISE POSTPONED,' A NEW SERIES ON 'MASTERPIECE THEATER'
description: PUBLIC television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' gets a new tenant this Sunday - on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. - bearing the most promising of credentials. ''Paradise Postponed'' was written by John Mortimer, adaptor of ''Brideshead Revisited'' and creator of ''Rumpole of the Bailey.'' It was directed by Alvin Rakoff, who did the same for Mr. Mortimer's autobiographical ''A Voyage Round My Father,'' which starred Sir Laurence Olivier. And the 11 parts of ''Paradise Postponed,'' produced by Jacqueline Davis, are dotted with the kind of splendid acting turns that are a peculiar specialty of the British.

title: ISLANDERS TOP CAPITALS, 7-4
description: For the first time this season, the Islanders received blanket congratulations from their new coach. And he, in return, received the game puck from them as a souvenir.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've loved them ever since they were losers.'' - Michael Creamer of Greenwich, Mets fan. [ B4:3. ]

title: Killers of Whites, Killers of Blacks
description: By refusing to strike down capital punishment as unconstitutional, the current Supreme Court majority opens itself to some difficult questions about the death penalty. Foremost is the claim that, in many states, the decision to execute is corrupted by racism.

title: JURY IS TOLD OF FAVORS TO DATACOM
description: The former comptroller of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau testified today that the bureau director, Lester N. Shafran, repeatedly showed favoritism to the Datacom Systems Corporation and its affiliates despite objections over conflicts of interest.

title: Greek Communists Defy Socialists
description: The Communist Party called on its members Wednesday night to withhold support from Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialists in the runoff for the Athens mayoralty on Sunday. It urged them instead to use their votes to strike at the policies of the Government.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: TEN major directors - including Jean-Luc Godard, Bruce Beresford and Robert Altman - will direct 7- to 12-minute segments for an innovative film that will combine classical music and cinematic imagery.

title: DEVILS (3-0) DISPLAY LOTS OF CONFIDENCE
description: An aura of confidence is evident around the Devils in the young National Hockey League season.

title: WOMEN PLAN TWO-YEAR GOALS
description: Participants in an international conference on women said today that traditional beliefs pose one of the greatest challenges to progress for women throughout the world.

title: Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the retailer that operates 1,254 stores in 48 states, announced plans to invest $5 billion in expansion of its operations over the next five years. Plans for the period from 1987 through 1991 would result in an annual compound growth rate of 13 percent in square footage, said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Minneapolis-based company.

title: G.O.P. ANXIOUS ON DAKOTA SENATORS
description: Of all the Republican Senate candidates expected to be hurt by the depression in American agriculture, none are considered by leaders in both parties to be more vulnerable than two incumbents, James Abdnor of South Dakota and Mark Andrews of North Dakota.

title: 'STAR WARS' FIGHT GIVES REPUBLICANS WAY TO ATTACK IN 'ISSUELESS' ELECTION
description: The 1986 midterm campaign has repeatedly been declared ''themeless'' and ''issueless'' by political organizers, but some issues, involving economics, the environment and military spending, are popping up with remarkable frequency in both Democratic and Republican camps.

Little girls in tutus pranced down the aisles and a cake was presented to Robert Joffrey, the company's founder and artistic director.

description: Never noted as a center of serenity, New York was even more manic yesterday as Mets fans - still reeling from the remarkable turn of events in Houston - clamored in anticipation of a World Series and savored the days when team loyalty was truly a test.

description: Of the 72 teams that have played in the league championship series, the 1986 Mets are only the second to have won the series despite batting below .200. And they are the first sub-.200 club to have won while being out-hit by the competition (.189 to Houston's .218).

title: NEW YORK MARATHON TO USE DRUG TESTS
description: Prompted by what he called a growing concern about the possible use of stimulants to enhance performance, Fred Lebow, the director of the New York Marathon, said yesterday that the race would implement drug testing for the first time when it is run on Nov. 2.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The New York Jazz Repertory Ensemble, Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). This newly formed septet, led by the banjo player Eddy Davis, plays a repertory of traditional jazz that is a stimulating change from the Dixieland warhorses that are often the staples of such groups. Its focus is late ragtime and such early jazz groups as King Oliver's and Sam Morgan's. With one exception, it is a band of young but already seasoned and versatile experts in the period styles and includes Peter Ecklund's crisp cornet, Joel Helleny's colorful trombone, Orange Kellin's New Orleans clarinet and Keith Ingham's rollicking piano. They are joined by 86-year-old Freddie Moore, who played drums in the 1920's with King Oliver and Jelly Roll Morton and can still give the band a strong, steady foundation. He also sings and plays washboard on such well-worn specialties as ''Bill Bailey'' and ''Sweet Georgia Brown.'' Greg Cohen is on bass. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11 o'clock, with a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK F S B reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: No year-ago per share figure is available; the company went public in December 1985.

STAGE: 'SOCIAL AMNESIA' AT NEXT WAVE
description: ''SOCIAL AMNESIA,'' the first theatrical event in this year's Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is experimental theater with a social conscience. As such, it is a reminder that the avant-garde is not necessarily hermetic when it comes to public issues. The production says things that bear repeating - about passivity, compromise and complicity, and about the obligation of citizens to stand up for moral principles. If anything, ''Social Amnesia'' tries to be too inclusive, or rather, its aggregate approach vitiates individual political points.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I'M here to make sure no one walks away with the art,'' said Michael L. Ainslie, the president and chief executive officer of Sotheby's Holdings Inc. Alexandra Daly, a student at Barnard College, wasn't sure why she was there. ''Someone told me this party was raising money for face lifts,'' she said. ''That's not true, is it?''

title: The 'Overlooked' War in Afghanistan
description: Several weeks ago, an Afghan student visited me. I gave him a tour of Yale, where 15 years ago as a student I protested against the Vietnam War and where I now teach. When I showed him the ''shantytown'' that some students have built to protest the university's financial involvement in South Africa, he asked, ''Do they say anything about Afghanistan?'' I wish I could have given him a better answer.

title: LOWELL INSTITUTION FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to stock form in May.

title: 'Machine Age' Movies Accompany Exhibition
description: A 12-part film series called ''Movies of the Machine Age,'' that highlights films dealing with the growth of the film industry and the effects of machines on life, begins Sunday at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, in the Crown Heights section. Sunday's films, which will be shown at 3 P.M., will be ''Take Next Car,'' a 1922 feature by Hal Roach, and ''The Iron Horse'' (1924), by John Ford.

title: MEXICO IN DEBT ACCORD
description: Mexico and an advisory group of commercial banks reached agreement last night on a debt package that could enable Mexico to receive $3.5 billion of a new $6 billion loan by Dec. 1.

description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest bank holding company, reported a 15.9 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: New Drive on Gun Smugglers
description: Treasury agents have begun their second crackdown in two months on gun smuggling along the Rio Grande, saying most of the weapons involved were destined for narcotics traffickers in Mexico.

Bard Awards for excellence in architecture and urban design were given this week by the City Club of New York to seven recent New York City projects - for the most part restorations and renovations of small and medium scale that respected the city's traditional structures and urban fabric.

title: U.S. SEEKING AWACS FOR PAKISTAN
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States would seek to provide early warning radar planes to Pakistan ''as quickly as possible'' to help defend against incursions from Afghanistan.

SCREEN: PAUL NEWMAN IN 'THE COLOR OF MONEY'
description: MARTIN SCORSESE'S ''Color of Money'' picks up the character of Fast Eddie Felson 25 years after he walked out of Chalkie's pool hall into the exhausted dawn at the end of Robert Rossen's fine 1961 melodrama, ''The Hustler.'' In the person of Paul Newman, who received an Oscar nomination for his performance in the Rossen film, the former pool-hall hustler has aged with remarkable grace, his physical vitality intact and his view of the world less cynical than barroom-pragmatic.

The menu created by Len Allison, the chef and co-owner, revolves around a series of moderately sized portions - somewhere between appetizer and entree - that allows lunchers to assemble a meal with two to four plates, depending on one's mood. Most of the selections sampled recently were astoundingly good and beautifully presented.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AFTER several dispiriting attempts to find an unheralded Japanese restaurant worth recommending, I have developed a theory that seems to show promise, at least at this early stage of empirical field-testing. It uses what I call the thoroughbred rule. Before deciding whether to dine at a particular establishment, I walk in, mutter something to the host about meeting a friend and walk over to the sushi bar. If the chefs are feverishly thrashing away filling a mountain of orders, the odds of getting good food are in my favor. If, however, the chefs are chatting among themselves and desultorily carving little rabbits out of daikon for mutual amusement, I head for the door. Sushi chefs, I have come to believe, are like thoroughbred horses -they need regular workouts and constant challenges to produce their best. Moreover, high-volume restaurants are less likely to serve old fish.

title: Ex-Cult Leader Is Sentenced
description: A former cult leader, Michael Ryan, was sentenced today to die in Nebraska's electric chair for the April 1985 slaying of James Thimm, a member of the cult. Mr. Ryan, 38 years old, was convicted April 10 of first-degree murder in the death of Mr. Thimm, 26, who had fallen out of favor with Mr. Ryan and was tortured before he was shot and buried on the group's farm. Mr. Ryan's son, Dennis, was convicted of second-degree murder in the death.

title: AUCTIONS
description: IN early July, jewelry dealers, investors and collectors - from London, Paris, Geneva, Antwerp, Tokyo, Singapore, Hong Kong and throughout the United States - began filing past the guards and television cameras that monitor Christie's and Sotheby's private viewing rooms in their jewelry departments. By Labor Day, the parade of potential bidders was relentlessly steady. And until the auctions Monday through Wednesday, the gem offerings at these galleries are expected to attract crowds that may outdo Tiffany's at Christmas.

The second of two shows was inspirational; the first was derailed by a Hollywood film crew and its director, Taylor Hackford.

title: Why I Won't Perform in South Africa
description: The recent violence in the streets of South Africa compel me to recall a concert tour I undertook there nearly 30 years ago. The first apartheid laws had just been introduced, and the evil they promoted was just beginning to be known to the world. I was filled with foreboding before I arrived, because I was as sure then as I am now that the music I was about to play spoke in universal terms to rich and poor alike, to black and white, to simple and sophisticated. So how could I play in good conscience only to the white, rich and sophisticated? What of the others, far more desperately in need of my music, cut off from it by unjust laws?

Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin as financial adviser to evaluate its ownership of the Source Telecomputing Corporation, an electronic information service. Jay Keller, president of the McLean, Va., company, which is known as The Source, said that one possibility was the sale of the unit. Mr. Keller said that Source - which has an estimated 61,000 subscribers and $13 million in annual sales - was profitable and that the Digest had ''tremendous presence'' in the home market.

title: Allan Gerdau Is Dead; Took Ads for Opinions

He was 87 years old and lived in West Redding, Conn.

description: The House gave a heartfelt and emotional farewell tonight to its Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who is retiring. There were praises from political friends and foes alike for the 10 years the Massachusetts Democrat presided over the chamber.

title: SOVIET CLEARS WAY FOR FAMILY'S EXIT
description: A day after releasing one prominent dissident, the Soviet authorities cleared the way today for the emigration of a Jewish couple seeking to go to Israel so that the wife can donate bone marrow to her brother, who has leukemia.

title: This Sweet Series
description: She was in a hardware store on Third Avenue Wednesday afternoon when she heard the screams, and with several others, ran outside. Others on the street had stopped, and all were staring up at a man in an apartment window. ''The Mets tied the game!'' he yelled. ''The Mets tied the game!''

title: Joe Louis Memorial
description: A 24-foot bronze monument in the form of a massive black fist and forearm, held in balanced suspension from a pyramid support of bronze poles, has been unveiled in Detroit as a memorial to Joe Louis, the heavyweight boxing champion from 1937 to 1950, who grew up on the city's East Side. Present at the unveiling were five boxers, including two, Jersey Joe Walcott and Billy Conn, who lost title fights to Louis in the 1940's.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Drift Lower
description: Prices of Government coupon issues drifted lower yesterday, while discount rates on Treasury bills moved moderately higher.

title: QUAKE INSURERES GET MORE CAUTIOUS Special to The New York Times
description: Many business executives and homeowners here can no longer obtain or afford insurance policies to fully protect their property from what Angelenos call ''the big one,'' the powerful earthquake that seismologists say will probably strike the region sometime in the next few decades.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary yesterday of Kathleen Carroll Reasoner misstated her marital status. She was divorced from the CBS news correspondent Harry Reasoner.

title: Proper Federal Funding for Youth Exchanges
description: Congress's determination to pare back the funding for international exchange programs for youth would provide only scant savings for our swollen Federal budget. Yet it would severely cripple one of the most promising and cost-effective programs available to foster understanding abroad for the people, ideas and ideals of the United States. Exchanges are also effective in helping our youth learn about and understand foreign societies.

description: An air mixer patented this week by John A. Paoluccio, a consulting mechanical engineer in Salida, Calif., is said to prevent insects from finding humans.

description: Legislation to create a new national park, the first in Nevada, and to prohibit development along stretches of rivers in four states has been passed by Congress and sent to the White House.

title: METS AND RED SOX: THE RIVALRY STARTS
description: One team believed it would be here all along; the other confounded experts who never gave it a chance. But now, after almost seven months and two harrowing playoff victories, the Mets and the Boston Red Sox are in the World Series, facing each other tonight in the first game of a rivalry between two cities as much as two teams.

title: DEBATE ON SOLVENT CONTINUES
description: THE Food and Drug Administration announced in December that it would not ban the use of methylene chloride to decaffeinate coffee, but it proposed banning the sprays and cosmetics. The chemical solvent is also used in paint strippers.

description: Because New York City has already opened its schools, municipal hospitals and other services to illegal aliens, the United States Senate's immigration bill will not have a major impact on the city, municipal officials said yesterday.

description: Construction of new homes and apartments fell 7.6 percent in September, the Government said yesterday. It was the sharpest decline since April and, more significantly, the fourth decline in the last five months.

description: The largest cache of crack ever seized in New York was discovered by the police and Federal agents in a raid on three apartments in the Bronx Thursday night, officials said. The find was seen as evidence of the growing sophistication of crack producers in the metropolitan region.

Mr. Petrie, chairman of the Petrie Stores Corporation, which includes several women's specialty retailers, said he had bought the shares for $5.9 million solely for investment purposes. He said he might buy more stock or sell all or part of his current stake.

title: DANCE: THE FELD BALLET
description: Eliot Feld's ''Over the Pavement,'' performed by the Feld Ballet on Thursday at the Joyce Theater, is both graphic and elusive. A haunting glimpse of people that society seems to have left behind, it refers explicitly at times to sexual renegades. But these are also merely hulking husks of mortals made almost human by their aimless rage, persistent motion and groping sensuality.

title: MUSIC: KLAUS TENNSTEDT
description: The German conductor Klaus Tennstedt's two weeks with the New York Philharmonic this month bring us symphonies by Bruckner and Mahler. Both are of considerable duration, and hearing Bruckner's mighty Seventh Symphony on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall - at the same time anticipating the Mahler Sixth a week from now - was to ask ourselves what ''length'' really means.

title: FORMER PRESIDENT OF A.T.&T.
description: Robert D. Lilley, former president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and chairman of a New Jersey commission that investigated the 1967 Newark riots, died Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan after a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: OPERA: APRILE MILLO IN ROLE OF AIDA
description: The world is not producing many important young Verdi voices nowadays, a lamentable fact that makes every performance of Aprile Millo of more than passing interest. A New Yorker by birth who was reared in California, she has developed in the two years since her Metropolitan Opera debut into a Verdi soprano of real quality. Thursday night, in the seventh ''Aida'' of the season, Miss Millo took on her greatest challenge yet, the famously taxing title role of the Ethiopian princess forced into Egyptian slavery.

title: Keep the Nationwide Speed Limit at 55 M.P.H.
description: In 1972, the Congress, responding to the oil crisis, enacted a nationwide 55 miles per hour speed limit. In his first Presidential campaign, Ronald Reagan promised to lift it and to return the power to set speed limits to the states. At the time, Congress asked the National Academy of Science to study the problem, and in 1984 the Academy delivered its report, recommending that the speed limit be retained. Efforts are now under way in Congress to raise the limit. They should be resisted.

description: Half a million Federal employees were sent home today as the Government, lacking money, was forced to shut down some operations.

title: 3 Teen-agers Held in Death
description: Three Manhattan teen-agers were being held for arraignment yesterday on a charge of second-degree murder in the Oct. 14 stabbing of a homeless man who lived in a West Side park, the police said. A fourth youth is still being sought in connection with the incident, the police said.

title: Latin American Nations Unite on Debt Question
description: Twenty-five Latin American nations stated tonight that they could not repay the region's $370 billion foreign debt under present conditions and recommended indexing their debt payments to export earnings or other economic variables.

description: b-Net income

title: DOWNED PLANE'S PILOT USED U.S. BASES, DOCUMENTS HINT
description: Documents captured from a downed rebel plane here appear to show that the plane's American co-pilot flew cargo planes to American military bases in the United States, Central America and the Caribbean until February of this year.

title: Series Gains Mets Owner Lots of New 'Old Friends'
description: His friends always said they were busy washing the dog, rotating the tires or sharpening the scissors when Nelson Doubleday Jr., owner of the Mets, used to call.

title: Jersey Suing On Waste Spill
description: New Jersey officials filed suit against New York City yesterday, claiming that solid waste spilling from a Staten Island landfill into a waterway and traveling to New Jersey is posing a serious health risk to state residents.

title: A Threat to New York State's Economic Growth
description: Federal tax reform is forcing New York State to rethink the fundamentals of its own tax policies. Governor Cuomo has already promised to make sure that state residents are not unfairly penalized by the loss of familiar deductions that have now been eliminated by the new tax law. Just as important, but little discussed so far, are the implications of tax reform for New York's economic development strategy.

title: NEW ZEALAND LOSES TO STARS & STRIPES
description: Dennis Conner proved today what he has been saying all along: When it comes to the America's Cup, he is still the man to beat.

title: LORENZO IS NAMED EASTERN'S CHAIRMAN
description: Frank Lorenzo, the head of the Texas Air Corporation, was named chairman of Eastern Air Lines Inc. today in a management shake-up that strengthens his hold over the carrier.

title: A TRANSFER TO SHAMIR IS PREPARED
description: President Chaim Herzog of Israel formally asked Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir to form a new government today.

title: TV: 'HOTEL DU LAC' BEING OFFERED ON CABLE
description: At one point in ''Hotel du Lac,'' Edith, a writer of romantic novels, confides to her agent that her stories are really variations of the old tortoise-and-hare theme. The unassuming, mousy heroine always gets her man, triumphing over more aggressive beauties. In certain unexpected respects, Edith herself becomes that kind of heroine in ''Hotel du Lac,'' the Anita Brookner novel that has been adapted for the BBC by Christopher Hampton. The 90-minute production can be seen, with commercial breaks added, at noon today on cable television's Arts and Entertainment Network.

title: GALLAGHER, ARTHUR J. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in July and certain acquisitions accounted for as pooling-of-interests.

title: Seaver Facing Knee Surgery
description: Tom Seaver, who is not on the Red Sox roster for the World Series, will undergo arthrosopic surgery to repair the torn cartilage in his right knee that kept him out of the American League Championship Series. ''I'll have the surgery sometime after the World Series ends,'' Seaver said yesterday.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $37,000. c-Net loss

title: TRANSWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSCON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Rush to Adjourn
description: These are the bills figuring in the 99th Congress's work to finish its session. IMMIGRATION

title: Conrail Bill Is Passed
description: Congress approved legislation today authorizing a $2 billion public stock sale of Conrail, ending two years of debate over how to return the federally owned freight railroad to the private sector.

title: CONSOLIDATED ENERGY PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 9 months includes $618,000 and $1,593,000, respectively, non-cash equity losses from the partnership's interest in the Princeville Hotel Associates Partnership and non-cash provisions for a loss on marketable securities of $337,000 for the quarter and $1,012,000 for the 9 months. The company said its year-ago 9 months results aren't available because the partnership was created on June 1, 1985.

title: JETS ABLE TO SURVIVE ABSENCE OF MCNEIL
description: There has been little hand-wringing over a Freeman McNeil injury this season, no sad, eyes-on-the-ground expressions from McNeil, no sense on the Jets that the team is wiped out without its star runner.

title: CONTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1985 third quarter results included a one-time benefit of $25 million, or 34 cents a share, which was due principally to a gain from the sale of its directory publishing division, less certain write-offs in non-regulated businesses. The 1985 share earnings for the quarter have been restated to reflect companies acquired by Contel on a pooling-of-interests basis. The company said its 1985 third quarter did not include revenue from American Satellite Co. and Contel Spacecom, which were not wholly owned by Contel until October 1985. Therefore, Contel said $750 million would be an appropriate comparable revenue figure for the 1985 third quarter.

title: Surgery for McCarron
description: Chris McCarron, who suffered a broken left femur, or thighbone, in a spill at Santa Anita Thursday, underwent surgery this morning and will be sidelined for at least four months, according to doctors at Rancho Los Amigos Hospital in Downey, Calif. McCarron will have to forgo mounts on two Breeders' Cup favorites Nov. 1 - Turkoman in the $3 million Classic and Sacahuista in the $1 million Juvenile Fillies.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: NEWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONGRESS APPROVES ANTI-DRUG BILL AS SENATE BARS A DEATH PROVISION
description: Congress passed an anti-drug bill today after an unusual parliamentary compromise broke a month-long impasse between the two houses over the death penalty.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $160,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $82,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $128,000 and $203,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain from the sale of a radio station of $2,118,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Trumpet on Seventh
description: The trumpeter Jack Walrath will lead a trio with Anthony Cox on bass and Ronnie Burrage on drums tonight at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, above 22d Street (242-9066). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: COLUMN ONE: STORIES OF THE CITY
description: Unscheduled Stop

title: Lindenauer Loses Job In Wake of Disclosure
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer lost his $3-an-hour job in a dry-cleaning store last week, the day after he revealed it during testimony in the Federal corruption trial here.

title: G.&W. Acquisition
description: Gulf and Western Inc. formally announced its $220 million acquisition of the Mann Theaters Corporation.

title: Shift to a Service Job Means Mostly a Pay Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEYSTONE HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ONE CLEAR DECISION: DARLING WILL START
description: Despite the belief of Mets enthusiasts - and perhaps the Mets themselves - that no one can beat the National League pennant winner, nothing is certain about tonight's first game of the World Series. If, on the other hand, anything is close to certain, perhaps it is the likelihood that Ron Darling will not be the winning or losing pitcher in the game.

title: BARCELONA GETS 1992 SUMMER OLYMPICS
description: After a week of suspense and months of political cajoling and arm-twisting, Barcelona, Spain, won the right to be host to the 1992 Summer Olympic Games and Albertville, France, was designated the site of the Winter Games in the same year.

title: Series Schedule
description: TODAY: At Mets - Hurst (13-8) vs. Darling (15-6), 8:30 P.M. TOMORROW: At Mets, 8:25 P.M. TUESDAY: At Boston, 8:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY: At Boston, 8:25 P.M. THURSDAY: *At Boston, 8:35 P.M. OCT. 25: *At Mets, 8:25 P.M. OCT. 26: *At Mets, 8:25 P.M. *-If necessary.

title: GRIFFIN BELL TO DEFEND CAPTIVE AMERICAN FLIER
description: The family of Eugene Hasenfus, the American flier captured in Nicaragua, announced today that they had retained former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell as his chief defense lawyer.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIAS SAID TO SUFFER SEIZURES
description: Two University of Maryland basketball players charged in connection with the cocaine-induced death of Len Bias told a grand jury that Bias suffered three seizures before paramedics were called, according to a television report.

title: FIRST AMER SAVINGS F.A.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: No year-ago per share earnings are available. The company went public in May.

title: INTEGRATED DEVICE TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After tax credits of $173,000 for the quarter and $325,000 for the 6 months.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $4,115,000 and $10,846,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain of $2,595,000 from the negotiation of an executory contract for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $1,343,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and a $16,191,000 charge reflecting a change in revenue recognition policy for the 9 months.

title: TRYING OUT THE BLOND LOOK
description: Last July Becky Aaronson became a blonde. It was something she'd been considering for a while, but with some trepidation, ''I was afraid of making a big mistake,'' she said. Then, as she was walking through a shopping mall in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., she came upon a machine that would enable her to try various hair colors without actually changing her hair.

title: KEAN SAYS BICKERING DISRUPTS SCHOOLS
description: Schoolchildren are suffering, Governor Kean told school officials today, because of constant conflicts over politics, power and money.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $802,611 for the latest year and $627,842 for the year-ago period.

title: REAGAN TERMS 'STAR WARS' PEACEFUL PROJECT LIKE RADAR
description: President Reagan today described the planned ''Star Wars'' space-based missile shield, which was the central source of contention at the Iceland summit meeting, as ''purely peaceful technology'' comparable to the development of radar.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $14,000. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $42,000.

title: HYGEIA SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: FOR STAID HERMES, A YOUNGER BEAT
description: In America, we call them preppies. In Paris, they have several names. One is B.C.B.G.'s, ''bon chic, bon genre,'' meaning stylish and well to do. In the 1960's, B.C.B.G.'s were women in their 30's, dressed in dull conservative clothes. But by the end of the 70's, a freshened-up B.C.B.G. style was assumed by the young.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOLDING THE FORT

title:
PATENTS;
Electrocardiogram Data Filtered and Analyzed
description: A system to determine a patient's heart rate from electrocardiogram signals by using speech-processing techniques was patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.

title: OSMONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Oct. 7 about the production of separate mini-series by CBS and NBC, based on different books dealing with the same murder case, incorrectly characterized reviews received by one book, ''At Mother's Request,'' by Jonathan Coleman. Although the book received a poor review in The Times, notices in other major publications were mixed.

title: Icelanders Are Not Slaughtering Whales
description: To the Editor:

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses of $367,000 and $491,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes losses of $20,000 and $59,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in March.

title: Arafat Says His Forces Have All Left Tunisia
description: All Palestinian military forces have been withdrawn from Tunisia, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, was quoted today as saying.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CAPTAIN KIDD AND THE WAR AGAINST THE PIRATES. By Robert C. Ritchie. (Harvard University, $20.) For much of his career Capt. William Kidd (1645?-1701) was not even a real pirate, and when he embarked on his most famous and ill-fated voyage, he was sponsored by some of the most powerful men in England.

title: Setting a New Course for the Shuttle's Rockets
description: Sally K. Ride, the astronaut who was on the Presidential commission that investigated the Challenger disaster, said last week that the redesign of the shuttle's rockets is going so well that she is willing to fly again. Although the panel charged with overseeing the changes agreed that they had ''progressed greatly,'' it indicated that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration still had a long way to go.

title: Adjustables
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama Textbook Trial Hears Auburn Professor
description: An expert in education psychology has testified in Alabama's textbook trial that teachers, not books, are the most important learning tools for students.

title: OPEC SALVAGES PRODUCTION PACT
description: In an unexpected shift, Saudi Arabia today dropped its demand for a major overhaul of OPEC's production-sharing system.

title: AFTER THE FOX IN IRELAND
description: As a young postal clerk sent by Britain's General Post Office to the remote Irish town of Banagher, Anthony Trollope found himself working for a superior who kept a pack of foxhounds. So the man who was to become one of Britain's most famous novelists bought a horse, and was introduced to the fox-hunting scenes that were to occupy a central place in many of his books. ''I have since been constant to the sport,'' he wrote in his autobiography, ''having learned to love it with an affection which I myself cannot fathom or understand.''

title: Robin Elise Schreier Wed To Steven L. Scari on L.I.
description: Robin Elise Schreier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schreier of Whitestone, Queens, was married yesterday to Steven Louis Scari, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Scari of Vineland, N.J. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony at the Sands of Atlantic Beach (L.I.) Club.

title: ICELAND'S BLEAK BEAUTY
description: Should you announce that you plan to spend a week in France or Italy, you will immediately be bombarded with questions from envious friends. Which mellow old towns will you visit? Which cathedrals and museums and as-yet-undiscovered little restaurants? Should you tell those same people you will be spending a week in Iceland, you will be asked only one question: Why?

title: For Yankee Fans, A Painful Series
description: NOT given to equivocation, Larry Fazio despises the Mets, ''just 'cause they're the Mets.''

title: Madison Edges John Jay by 8-6
description: A goal-line stand late in the third quarter yesterday preserved a 2-point lead for Madison (4-2) and allowed the Golden Knights to hang on for an 8-6 victory over John Jay (0-4-1). Ray Hosner, a linebacker, and Antonio Jorge, a cornerback, combined for 22 tackles to lead Madison's defense.

title: Jodi Kase to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Kase of Woodbury, L.I., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Jodi Lynne Kase, to Jeffrey Lawrence Pliskin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Pliskin of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. A December wedding is planned. Miss Kase, a Brown University graduate, was until recently the creative administrator for JanklowBender Advertising. Mr. Pliskin, a real-estate associate in the New York law firm Robinson, Silverman, Pearce, Aronsohn & Berman, graduated magna cum laude from Yale College and received a J.D. degree from the Columbia Law School.

title: MERGER SPURS UNION BATTLE OVER FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
description: The merger of two airlines here has an A.F.L.-C.I.O. affiliate fighting hard against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to represent the flight attendants.

title: Seaver's Twist of Fate
description: ALL along, the plot had been too good to be true: Tom Seaver returning to Shea Stadium with the Boston Red Sox to pitch against the Mets in the World Series that opened last night. And on the day last June when the 41-year-old right-hander was traded to the Red Sox, he understood the odds against that possibility.

title: Emilie Murphy Becomes Bride Of A.B. Nimocks
description: Emilie Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Murphy of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to A. Bryon Nimocks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Nimocks Jr., of Forrest City, Ark. The Rev. Edmund J. Whalen performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Resurrection Church in Rye.

title: European Community Has Environment Plan
description: The European Community has unveiled a six-year program to incorporate environmental protection into the 12-nation bloc's economic and social policies.

title: Pacesetters: Dark Colors, Bold Shapes
description: WHAT'S being worn these days by dues-paying members of the avant-garde are somber colors, adventurous shapes and - hold onto your headwraps, Lower East Siders - an occasional ear-to-ear smile.

title: DO TEXTBOOKS FOSTER 'SECULAR HUMANISM'?
description: A FEDERAL courtroom in Mobile, Ala., was the setting last week for what one lawyer called ''a clash of cultures.'' At issue are 50 of the 4,000 textbooks used in the city's schools. The plaintiffs, a group of Christian teachers and parents supported by lawyers from a conservative foundation set up by the evangelist Pat Robertson, argue that the books, used in history and home economics classes, unconstitutionally suppress the role of religion in America and unconstitutionally advance the teachings of ''secular humanism.'' That doctrine, they say, puts man and his values, rather than God, at the center of things. They are arguing, for example, that textbook passages on the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. do not pay enough attention to his religious beliefs. The State Board of Education is defending the books with the help of the American Civil Liberties Union and People for the American Way, a group set up by the television producer Norman Lear. They argue that the plaintiffs are attacking differing beliefs and have failed to count many passages on religion. The trial will continue this week. Following are excerpts from disputed passages in some of the books. VALUE JUDGMENTS AND DIVORCE

title: TO PROLIFIC HISTORIAN, A CHURCHILL BIOGRAPHY IS BUT A CHAPTER IN HIS WORK
description: If Martin Gilbert had written nothing but the authorized biography of Winston Churchill on which he has been toiling since 1968, he would have to be regarded as one of the most prolific of British historians.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MY DADDY WAS A PISTOL AND I'M A SON OF A GUN. By Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $14.95.) Lewis Grizzard, a columnist for The Atlanta Constitution, writes humor books with mock country-western titles like ''Elvis Is Dead and I Don't Feel So Good Myself.''

title: Freedom Day
description: They'll start lining up at dawn next July 1, outside a church basement here, a courthouse there. Hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens, most of them Hispanic, will wait patiently to accept America's offer of amnesty. That's the reform part.

title: T.V.A. TROUBLES WORSEN AS RESCUE EFFORT FALTERS
description: Trouble is following trouble at the Tennessee Valley Authority, the last major landmark of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.

title: Reporting From Moscow
description: After reading Philip Taubman's article ''The Perils of Reporting From Moscow'' (Sept. 21), there is an uneasy question in my mind. Why are these correspondents still there? They have access to no firsthand information, only to what the Soviet propaganda feeds them, thus giving free channels to the Russians. At the same time, they are hostages and can be easily framed, easy targets for blackmail.

title: SOUTHERN CITIES GAINING AS OTHER SEAPORTS DECLINE
description: For the first 250 years, the port of Savannah, like its rival at Charleston, 100 miles up the coast, was a small but busy regional operation, its docks piled with stocks of naval supplies, cotton and Georgia pine bound for export.

title: Nightmare Ends Teufel's Day of Promise
description: The day had held a promise that invites young baseball players to dream. For Tim Teufel, the platooned Met second baseman, the night held a very different feeling.

title: REYKJAVIK TALKS HOLD OUT HOPE ON EMIGRATION OF SOVIET JEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: OPPENHEIMER, STEPHENS PRESS ELECTION BIDS
description: THE race for State Senate in the 36th District centers on the question of whether the incumbent, Suzi Oppenheimer, a Democrat, ''gets the job done,'' as she says, or whether, as her Republican opponent, Willis H. Stephens Jr., asserts, the salary paid her is a ''waste of taxpayers' money.''

title: The Importance of The Loudspeaker Box
description: At a casual glance, a loudspeaker enclosure seems just a container - simply a box. But this appearance is deceiving. In fact, the speaker enclosure is an active partner in the enterprise of sound reproduction, and its design and construction strongly influence the character of the sound. An understanding of the basic principles involved is helpful in evaluating loudspeakers.

title: Scaling Down VHS Camcorders
description: If trade statistics are to be trusted, making your own video tape recordings is the fastest-growing hobby. It is estimated that this year more than a million camera-recorder combinations - commonly known as camcorders - will be sold in the United States alone, a 100 percent increase over the preceding year.

title: 2 COUNTY JUDGES VIE FOR SEAT
description: IN the only area judicial contest scheduled this November, voters in five counties will decide between two Westchester Family Court justices seeking a spot on the State Supreme Court bench.

title: Elvis Costello on Betrayal and the Many Troubles of Love
description: When Elvis Costello comes to the Broadway Theater this Tuesday through Saturday, he'll play five different shows. In shifting combinations, he will lead two bands (the Attractions and the Confederates), perform solo, sing duets and even take requests for his own songs and those of other writers. The point is clear: Mr. Costello would rather have variety than a formula, and any style in popular music is fair game.

title: 72 STATE INMATES AT RIKERS I. SENT FROM CITY JAILS TO UPSTATE PRISONS
description: Seeking to relieve overcrowding and tensions in New York City jails on Rikers Island, correction officials sent 72 state inmates to upstate prisons yesterday and said that scores more would be transferred into state custody in the next few days.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Though accurate, this book's primly efficient title barely hints at the pleasures inside. PAINTINGS OF THE BRITISH SOCIAL SCENE: From Hogarth to Sickert (Rizzoli, $35), by E. D. H. Johnson, is a work of unusual scope, confidence and vigor.

title: STATE U. READIES A GRADUATE STUDIES PROPOSAL
description: The Chancellor of the State University of New York, seeking to remedy what has been called the university's ''chief academic weakness,'' is ready to unveil an $84.5 million plan to strengthen graduate education and research.

title: MILITARY MAN HELPING GIVE NEW MARCHING ORDERS AT ADELPHI
description: THE reason I'm here,'' said Milton Frank, ''is because I'm convinced that what the president is trying to do in higher education today is important.''

title: Clemens, Vital to Red Sox Success, Is a Model of Determined Excellence
description: The questions were sounding the same, and so were the answers. Simple, forthright, unimaginative. But Roger Clemens had never clamored for the attention. He would not clamor for it now, even as it has continued to pursue him through a dreamlike season.

title: MANY CANDIDATES RUN STRONG
description: Thirty years ago, in the bayous of Louisiana and the cotton fields of Mississippi and other Southern states, it was unthinkable that a black would run for a seat in Congress - never mind stand a chance of winning.

title: Exhibit Illuminates Sargent, Fortune's Favorite
description: At no time since his death in 1925 has the reputation of John Singer Sargent stood as high as it does today. To confirm this, we have only to go to the Whitney Museum of American Art, where a retrospective exhibition of paintings and watercolors by Sargent can be seen through Jan. 4, 1987. (It can also be seen from Feb. 7 through April 19, 1987, at the Art Institute of Chicago). Thanks in part to a hefty subvention from Merrill Lynch, the museum has been able to assemble a remarkably large proportion of the paintings by which Sargent is most likely to be remembered.

title: MUSIC: GROTH ON TRUMPET
description: THE Berlin Philharmonic is in town and, on Friday night, that august ensemble's first trumpeter, Konradin Groth, joined forces with the organist Hayko Siemens for a free concert at St. Bartholemew's Church, including works for trumpet and organ by Telemann, Handel, Johann Melchior Molter and Jan Koetsier and pieces for solo organ by J. S. Bach and Franz Liszt.

title: ORTEGA, FAULTING REAGAN, WARNS OF COMING WAR
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra condemned President Reagan as an ''international outlaw'' today for signing a law allowing $100 million of American military assistance to go to Nicaraguan guerrillas.

title: CONCERT: LIBERACE AND THE ROCKETTES
description: LIBERACE, the reigning monarch of American glitz, outdid himself in campy showmanship Thursday at the opening-night performance of his Radio City Music Hall engagement, which runs through Nov. 2. Instead of gliding onto the stage in a chauffeur-driven Rolls Royce limousine, as in past years, the pianist arrived in midair, attached to a wire like a puffed-up Peter Pan, in a hundred pounds of purple and white feathers.

title: The Dollar Sags, but Bargains Remain
description: Everybody in Europe knows why the Americans stayed home this summer. There was Chernobyl and fear of contamination, and of course terrorism and fear of bombs. But mainly, everyone agreed, it was the dollar, the poor, drooping dollar.

title: BARBUTO CHALLENGES GOODHUE IN 37th DISTRICT
description: BEING an underdog is nothing new to Richard L. Barbuto of Croton-on-Hudson and he is certainly that now as he challenges Mary B. Goodhue, a popular Republican incumbent, for the state Senate in the 37th District, composed mainly of northern Westchester and Putnam.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ALL OF IT. By Jeannette Haien. (Godine, $14.95.) The fictional landscape of ''The All of It'' is the west of Ireland, an area known for its lush, fertile farmland, its excellent salmon fishing and its small, country villages - such as Jeannette Haien's Roonatellin - where Roman Catholicism is a strong and sobering force.

title: 'KING AND I' WORKS IN FESTIVE SETTING
description: THE Coachlight Dinner Theater, now in its 15th season, is a success story nonpareil.

title: Film Presents the Humorous Side of Skiing
description: EVERY seasoned skier knows that when Warren Miller comes to town, skiing is about to begin. After showing 37 films in 37 years, Miller has become a legend among several generations of skiers.

title: WHAT THIS COUNTRY NEEDS
description: IT happened in two restaurants in the last six months.

title: 'DOWN BY LAW' STAR: A PINOCCHIO, BY WAY OF CHICO MARX
description: Roberto Benigni, whose comic performance as an Italian tourist is one of the highlights of Jim Jarmusch's ''Down By Law,'' spoke only one word of English before he arrived in New Orleans for the filming. Since the word was ''goodbye,'' it didn't help much until he was ready to leave. He never read the full script of the movie, he could hardly communicate with the other actors and he barely understood his own lines. Why? ''They were in English,'' he said with a heavy Italian accent, crammed with vowels, ''I no spoke-a the Engaleesh.''

title: Penn State Crushes Syracuse
description: Undefeated Penn State completed the expected sweep of its first six opponents today with the help of a record 92-yard run from scrimmage by Blair Thomas, two touchdowns by Tim Manoa and a total of 434 yards rushing by 10 running backs. That all made it easy to whip Syracuse, 42-3.

title: Rye Neck Halts Dobbs Ferry's Streak
description: Dobbs Ferry's winning streak- longest in the county, longest in the state - has ended at 42 games.

title: Reactions Vary on Bangladeshi Vote
description: President H. M. Ershad of Bangladesh hailed last week's national election as ''the last bridge toward a democratic government.'' But to the main opposition leaders, it was another step toward stronger rule.

title: PSYCHIATRIC UNIT SAID TO MISUSE FUNDS
description: State investigators say a private mental-health program in Brooklyn has misused as much as $4 million in public funds, mainly through the payment of ''exorbitant'' rents to a real-estate corporation owned by the family of the program's founder and medical director.

title: Washington Puts A Large Tariff on Canadian Lumber
description: Reversing itself, the Reagan Administration decided last week to impose a substantial tariff on construction lumber from Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner.

title: UNIFORMITY ON PARADE
description: IF band uniforms are a reflection of the times, then the Scarsdale High School marching band has a message for the '80's. Gone are another generation's objections to a military-style unit parading smartly down the field. Gone also the aversion to formality in dress, to the very notion of a uniform.

title: Dr. Kutai, a Chemist, To Wed Martin Weiss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ithamar T. Kutai of Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Orna I. Kutai, to Martin A. Weiss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Weiss of Pembroke Pines, Fla. A Nov. 23 wedding is planned.

title: 'MAY MY 6-YEAR-OLD FIND THE SPIRIT OF AMERICA'
description: PARENTS with children going to school for the first time have many pleasures and fears in common. But recent immigrants have perhaps a particular poignancy in watching their kindergarteners and first graders enter the world of American public education.

title: PROMISING TO CUT DEFICIT, CONGRESS SETTLES FOR SCRATCHING IT
description: CONGRESS is heading home to campaign, having demonstrated yet again that politics is stronger than good intentions. This was to have been the season when the budget-balancing law would force the White House and Congress to make serious cuts in colossal Federal deficits, and the stock market boomed at the prospect.

title: LAND-SWAP PLAN ANGERS COOK COLLEGE
description: A PROPOSAL to exchange 1,800 acres of farmland in Cranbury Township for part of 350 acres owned or used by Rutgers University here faces a storm of opposition. The Rutgers property is on the east side of U.S. 1 adjacent to the Cook College campus.

title: WEARY LAWMAKERS PUT FINAL TOUCHES ON HECTIC SESSION
description: An exhausted 99th Congress completed its business and adjourned tonight, and the lawmakers eagerly headed home for a final stretch of campaigning before the November elections.

title: MASSACHUSETTS COLLEGE IS PLAGUED BY SCANDAL
description: Anger and tension continue at Westfield State College four months after it was disclosed that trustees approved a secret $10,000 settlement for a student who said he had been sexually assaulted by the man who was then the college's president.

title: AUDOBON THE WRITER: CELEBRITY IN BUCKSKIN
description: WE are all familiar with Audubon the painter. Reproductions of his vivid birds and beasts hang in our courthouses, lie in slick books on our coffee tables, decorate our bedrooms and greeting cards. Say his name, and in the minds of most listeners a colored print will arise. But Audubon was also a writer, and a remarkable one. During the years when he was feverishly painting the illustrations that made him famous, he was equally busy writing journals, letters, autobiographical essays and volumes of natural history. Taken together, these pages summon up for us the retreating wilderness and the boisterous frontier, and they display the appealing figure of Audubon himself, out in the fields and woods, observing it all with passion.

title: Army Rejects Tie, Loses
description: Army went for a victory rather than a tie today against Holy Cross, passing up a 35-yard field-goal opportunity on its last play of the game. But on a pass play on fourth down with 14 yards to go, the Crusader rush swarmed over Tory Crawford, the Cadet quarterback, who was downed on the 20-yard line with 21 seconds left.

title: THE BATTLE GROWS OVER ISLAND'S GARBAGE CRISIS
description: AS Election Day approaches, the continuing problem of Long Island's garbage - how best to dispose of it and who should pay the millions of dollars in costs - is becoming an even more highly charged political and environmental issue.

title: Merchant Marine Rallies Past St. John's
description: Tom Tiefenthaler scored three touchdowns and gained 162 yards in 31 carries as the defending Liberty Conference champion, Merchant Marine Academy, overcame St. John's, 24-21, yesterday in a conference game at Redman Stadium in Jamaica, Queens.

title: REPORT CHALLENGES DIALYSIS DATA
description: A Senate staff report charged today that Federal officials had withheld information about health problems associated with re-using kidney dialysis filters.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DARK VICTORY: Ronald Reagan, MCA, and the Mob. By Dan E. Moldea. (Viking, $18.95.) ''Dark Victory'' is an ambitious book that sheds some light on past events but falls short in showing that old ties make for current scandal.

title: The Transition on Fordham Road
description: FROM its highest floor, the new Fordham Plaza office building on Fordham Road in the Bronx offers a singular 360-degree panoramic view of the borough. To the north and east lie the Botanical Garden and the Bronx Zoo. Directly north is the verdant 85-acre campus of Fordham University. To the west and south, the land is a carpet of apartment houses.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Interesting Arrivals At Scarsdale Station The Store at the Coffee Shop at Scarsdale's train station displays some country and decorative handwork all week, serving commuters from 5 to 10 A.M. and open for events and sales Friday through Sunday from 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Where to Go After the Show: Madrid
description: The first thing to know about late-night glamour in Madrid is that it is very late indeed. Concerts at the Teatro Real normally begin at 10:30 P.M., when they are ending in New York. Recitals at small halls and museums are often a little earlier. Theaters usually have two performances a night, around 8 P.M. and, for the more fashionable, around 10:30.

title: Pigeon Problem At Jersey Capitol
description: PIGEONS perching on the State House and nearby buildings were once viewed as a serene touch in the New Jersey legislative scene. But by last year, their acidic droppings were so desecrating landmark tile roofs and stonework that maintenance officials hired a Pennsylvania company to ''help in solving the problem.''

title: ATLANTIC CITY: WHAT HAS GONE WRONG WITH THE PLAN?
description: THE violence, property damage, intimidation of innocent bystanders and the obvious inability of Atlantic City officials to cope effectively with the recent strike by hotel-casino employees should cause every legislator to reflect again upon the original promise of urban revitalization when casinos were first authorized for that city.

title: AGREEMENT TO EXPAND CONTACTS
description: The Reykjavik meeting between President Reagan and General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev was an extraordinary event. Far more was achieved than anyone had considered possible. If the Soviets are as prepared as we to follow through on the work done last week, Reykjavik could set the stage for a major advance in United States-Soviet relations, one that could potentially transform the international security landscape. In Reykjavik, we drew within sight of a major goal of this Administration - achieving the reduction and eventual elimination of the danger posed by nuclear weapons.

title: FRANCE NEARS THE END OF A SOCIALIST CHAPTER
description: TWO foreign diplomats responsible for following French politics were talking the other day about President Francois Mitterrand's opaque statement last week that he might not seek a second seven-year term in 1988.

title: Miss White Married To Martin Moynihan
description: Maryjane Willard White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Webster White of Ridgewood, N.J., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Martin Stephen Moynihan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Moynihan of Blauvelt, N.Y. The Rev. Vernon L. Dethmers performed the ceremony at the Community Church in Glen Rock, N.J.

title: FIDEL CASTRO'S YEARS AS A SECRET COMMUNIST
description: IT HAS LONG BEEN BELIEVED IN CERTAIN circles that the Castro revolution might have developed along more liberal, democratic and pro-American lines if only the United States had been more tolerant, understanding and supportive of the Cuban experiment. But a careful reconstruction of the sequence of events in the weeks and months after Fidel Castro took over in 1959 - almost all of which have been kept secret until now - makes it clear how, from the outset, Castro went about turning Cuba into a Marxist-Leninist state, with the collaboration of old-line Communists and the new Communist cadres he was creating within his rebel army.

title: DEPENDABLE ESCAROLE ALSO PLAYS IMAGINATIVE ROLES
description: ESCAROLE is as ubiquitous as lettuce or spinach, and available in just about every supermarket and grocery store. Yet this vegetable has not inspired many creations or made its way into the sort of eclectic recipes young chefs around the country are devising these days. Escarole has remained resolutely itself: old-fashioned and dependable.

title: Maria Mosca Is a Bride
description: Maria Elvira Mosca, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew M. Mosca of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary Richard Booth, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Conrad Booth of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. John Kauta performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y. Mrs. Booth is an analyst and programmer in the administrative data processing department of Columbia University. Mr. Booth is a sales associate for Weichert Company Realtors in Katonah.

title: Jo Imeson Is the Bride Of Howard D. Tarplin
description: Jo Imeson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Imeson of Tonbridge, Kent, England, was married yesterday to Howard D. Tarplin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ely A. Tarplin of Brightwaters, L.I., and Bucerias, Mexico. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at Table of Contents, a caterer in Manhattan.

title: Katherine Kirk Is Married To John Meyers, a Banker
description: Katherine Marie Kirk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kirk of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Henry Meyers, the son of Mrs. Bernhardt Henry Meyers of East Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Meyers. The Rev. Richard M. Fagley, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Christian Herald Chapel in Chappaqua.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sept. 21 about a confrence on international violence misidentified William J. Wholean. He is the executive director of the Connecticut Catholic Conference.

title: OUT OF SEMOLINA AND GRIEF- A PORTRAIT OF MY VOCATION
description: WRITING is my vocation and I have known this for a long time. If I do something else, if I study a foreign language or try to learn history or geography or shorthand or if I try and speak in public or take up knitting or go on a journey, I suffer and constantly ask myself how others do these things. And it seems to me that I am deaf and blind and I feel a sort of sickness in the pit of my stomach. But when I write I feel extraordinarily at ease. I had better make it plain that I can only write stories -invented things or things I can remember from my own life, but in any case stories. This is my vocation and I shall work at it till I die. I have known since I was 10, and I worked as hard as I could at poems and novels. I still have those poems. The first are clumsy but they are quite pleasant; and then they became less and less clumsy but more and more boring and silly. However I didn't know this and I was ashamed of the clumsy poems, while those that were silly and not so clumsy seemed to me to be very beautiful, and I used to think that one day some famous poet would discover them and have them published and write long articles about me.

title: Miss Lucado Wed To A.P. Pickman
description: Corneille Rylander Lucado, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Webster Lucado of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Paul Pickman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Pickman of Wethersfield, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence McColl Horton performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: QUEEN COMPLETES CHINA VISIT
description: Queen Elizabeth sailed from China today, ending a weeklong visit that the Peking Government called a success despite controversy over the Duke of Edinburgh's description of the capital as ''ugly'' and the Chinese people as having ''slitty'' eyes.

title: JUDGE BRIEANT, 63, TAKES OVER AS CHIEF OF U.S. DISTRICT COURT
description: The busy Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York has a new chief judge, Charles L. Brieant.

title: DEFENSE CHIEF SAYS HE MAY QUIT MANILA CABINET
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, who has been in increasingly open conflict with his Cabinet colleagues, said today that he was considering the possibility of resigning in response to their criticism.

title: The Folkloric Look of Bavaria
description: Nestled between delicately frescoed patrician townhouses on the quiet little street called Burgstrasse, 50 paces from Marienplatz in the heart of Munich's old city, stands the shop called Heimatwerk, an enclave of Bavarian tradition and folklore.

title: IMAGINE LOLITA AS A NERD
description: THE ENCHANTER By Vladimir Nabokov. Translated by Dmitri Nabokov. 127 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95.

title: Norman Leading By 5 Shots at 211
description: Greg Norman of Australia strengthened his bid for a fifth straight tournament victory today by carding a 67 to take a five-stroke lead after the third round of the $80,000 New South Wales Open.

title: TOPICS
description: NEVER talk about money where your appliances can hear you. This is one important piece of information that my parents never taught me.

title: BROAD BRUSH ROMPS TO VICTORY
description: Broad Brush, the temperamental 3-year-old who almost jumped into the grandstand in his last start, ran straight as a string and 3 3/4 lengths faster than Skip Trial, Little Missouri and Creme Fraiche tonight to win the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: Nancy Nammack Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Anne Nammack, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome W. Nammack Jr. of Garden City and Remsenburg, L.I., was married yesterday to Kevin Thomas Curran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Curran Jr. of Baldwin, L.I. Msgr. Thomas S. Forker performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Joseph in Garden City.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It hasn't been easy.'' - Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader.

title: Francine I. Chase To Become Bride Of N.B. Weisman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Chase of Edison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Francine Iris Chase to Norman B. Weisman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weisman of Annapolis, Md. A November wedding is planned.

title: OLD ENMITY SIMMERS BETWEEN INDIA, PAKISTAN
description: A DAY before a gunman shot at Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi this month, a rumor raced through Karachi, the largest city in Pakistan, that the Indian leader had been killed. Citing that evidence, Indian newspapers have been avidly speculating since then about a ''foreign hand'' in the attempt on Mr. Gandhi's life. Despite heated denials from Pakistan, the Prime Minister himself suggested that such a plot might have existed.

title: IN BUREAUCRACY, ALIENS FIND ANOTHER UNPROTECTED BORDER
description: THE conventional photograph of an illegal alien shows a person wading across the Rio Grande. To be sure, tens of thousands do so, but there are more sophisticated ways to short-circuit the immigration process.

title: THE AGONY OF GAMBLING
description: STARTING life again at 53 is no sure bet, and Vince (not his real name) cannot help but feel cheated when he notices others his age.

title: ORIGINS OF A COLLAPSE
description: The Reagan Administration may have precipitated the collapse of the Iceland summit a year ago, when in October 1985 it became known that Pentagon and State Department legal advisers had ''reinterpreted'' the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. This facilitated the amazing discovery that the treaty permitted testing and development of space-based missile defenses.

title: Riverside Rebirth
description: At the turn of the century, sunshine and salubrious breezes aided in the recovery of patients at Gouverneur Hospital, a U-shaped Renaissance Revival structure with verandas facing the East River. The hospital, at 162 Water Street on the Lower East Side, was closed in 1961, and a new one with the same name opened a few blocks to the northwest on Madison Street.

title: MUSIC: KOREVAAR AT PIANO
description: THE pianist David Korevaar's recital Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall was, in the main, highly successful. Mr. Korevaar plays with expanse, accuracy and cultivation. His pianism is carefully controlled throughout a wide dynamic range, his tone is usually full and lustrous.

title: WHAT THE GOOD LIFE REALLY MEANS
description: BETWEEN my first business suit and assertiveness training, I realized the awful truth - I'm in the slow lane. I have been there the whole time. And no amount of pushing or maneuvering will get me out. I am not cut out for the world of fast-track, fast-rising corporate stars.

title: Ellen S. Munt Is Married to Richard Jay Lieb
description: Ellen Susan Munt and Richard Jay Lieb were married yesterday at the Regency Hotel in New York. Rabbi Barry H. Greene officiated.

title: Seymour Defeats Shelton, 20-6
description: Joe Stochmal threw two touchdown passes for 219 yards to lead Seymour past Shelton, 20-6, in Seymour yesterday. The Wildcats handed Shelton its first loss of the season.

title: SERIES PLUMBS THE INTIMATE STATEMENT OF THE INDEPENDENT FILM
description: LIKE a commercial film, an independently made avant-garde film can be, at any given time, funny, provocative, annoying, beautiful, self-indulgent, inspirational, boring or captivating. But unlike its rich cousin, the independent film is often an intimate statement written, directed and filmed by one person - the film maker - who often stars in it as well. A collection of such films will be shown during the Cineprobe series, which begins tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Matthew J. Rosenblum Weds Tracey Epstein
description: At Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I., yesterday evening, Tracey Janet Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Epstein of Woodmere, L.I., was married to Matthew Jay Rosenblum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rosenblum of West Hempstead, L.I. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony.

title: PROFESSIONALS WHO LEAVE JOBS FOR REALTY
description: AFTER 16 years as a flight attendant with American Airlines, Carol Doherty of Briarcliff was earning $40,000 a year, with overtime plus substantial fringe benefits. Yet Mrs. Doherty, 46 years old, had no qualms about leaving her good job to work for a commission in real estate. Nor did Peter Chelimski. At 46, Mr. Chelimski was earning more than $50,000 a year as a management consultant in the textile apparel industry, commuting into Manhattan every day from his home in Somers. Now Mr. Chelimski has broken out of his 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. schedule but is working almost every weekend trying to sell houses.

title: PIANO: HODGKINSON PERFORMS AT TULLY HALL
description: RANDALL HODGKINSON, winner of the International American Music Competition at Carnegie Hall in 1981, did not abandon the works of American composers once the concerts that were part of his prize had been played. At Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the Boston-based pianist performed works by Ives, Sessions, Martino and Cage in a recital that also included sonatas by Beethoven and Bartok, and shorter works by Schumann and Liszt.

title: A City Board Trims a Building
description: The wreckers are not at work yet and may never be, but the ruling was enough to raise goose pimples on concrete: The New York City Board of Standards and Appeals held last week that the top 12 floors of the 31-story building under construction at 108 East 96th Street exceed the zoning ceiling. The city said those 12 stories must go.

title: Victorianism, Redefined, at the Met
description: Victorianism - a style of excess in carving, ornament and pattern - was banished from parlors across the land a half-century ago. Now, an exhibition, ''In Pursuit of Beauty: Americans and the Esthetic Movement,'' opening Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, makes it clear that the late 19th-century style is returning to favor - redefined, reorganized and radically simplified. The show, which remains through Jan. 11, is the most comprehensive museum presentation to date dealing with late 19th-century taste in this country.

title: Dr. J.C. Chunn 2d And Miss Barley Exchange Vows
description: Brenda Jean Barley, the dean of adult and continuing education at Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York, and Dr. Jay Carrington Chunn 2d, president of the college, were married yesterday at Grace Methodist Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Ivan Roberts performed the ceremony.

title: Recent Sales
description: Recent Sales Guilford, Conn. $135,000 125 Prospect Hill Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath 19-year-old home; brook on property, spiral staircase in entry, 1.2 acres; taxes $1,897.

title: UPDATING DIXIE'S OLD CONSTITUTIONS
description: SINCE it was adopted in 1890, the Mississippi Constitution has aged poorly, swelling over the years from 57 pages to more than 360, counting annotations, indices and all 85 of its amendments.

title: An Old Dispute Divides Belgium
description: There was a Government crisis last week in Brussels or, if you prefer, Bruxelles.

title: Anais Nin Unexpurgated
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Cedarhurst $254,000 29 Locust Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; den, eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $4,000. Hauppauge $194,000 390 Ridgefield Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; deck, 2-car garage; taxes $2,700.

title: PERCEPTION VS. REALITY
description: IT HAS now been more than eight years - and more than $900 million in resulting funds provided to the elderly and disabled in New Jersey - since the croupiers at Resorts International in Atlantic City spun the first roulette wheel and dealt the first cards to the hordes of blackjack players who waited to enter the casino floor.

title: Recent Sales
description: Recent Sales Bridgewater $243,000 1010 Rector Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, 2-car attached garage; taxes $2,816. Denville $124,900 58-B Indian Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 6-month-old town house; central air-conditioning, 2 decks, skylight; taxes $1,800.

title: A BASIS FOR PROGRESS ON ARMS
description: The Iceland summit meeting offers an opportunity for progress in the reduction of nuclear dangers more promising than any since the imperfect effort for international control of atomic energy broke down under Stalin's rejection 40 years ago. It also suggests that the aims of the two leaders are not in such conflict as to be a solid block to agreement.

title: Papal Economics
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
DRUG AWARENESS
description: As part of a Drug Awareness Teach-In Day on Thursday, students at the Westlake Middle School in Thornwood will sing an original copyrighted antidrug-abuse song, written by their music teacher, Claudia Morelli, and release dozens of red, white and blue balloons carrying antidrug messages.

title: McCarthy and the Universities
description: To the Editor:

title: BELGIUM'S CRISIS DEEPENS AS MINISTER RESIGNS
description: A week-old political crisis in Belgium suddenly deepened today with the resignation of Interior Minister Charles-Ferdinand Nothomb. Mr. Nothomb had been trying to solve the latest Belgian language conflict and failed.

title: Policeman Admits Addiction
description: A Bridgeport patrolman who admitted he is addicted to cocaine has been granted a six-month unpaid leave of absence to undergo rehabilitation. Police Superintendent Joseph A. Walsh said this week that the officer admitted using cocaine on his days off and requested time for treatment. Mr. Walsh declined to name the officer, who joined the force in May 1985.

title: SHIITES HINT AT WILLINGNESS TO TRADE ISRAELI AIRMAN
description: The Shiite Moslem militia Amal raised the possibility today that it might be prepared to exchange a captured Israeli airman for Lebanese prisoners held by Israel.

title:
ART;
CONFRONTATION ON THE DARKER SIDE OF THE PSYCHE
description: THE current exhibition at the Dowling College Gallery in Oakdale features paintings and sculpture by two artists who deal with the theme of human emotion in terms of personal conflict, always under control but nevertheless present even in the most benign of settings.

title: In New York, Met Charm Stirs Hearts
description: NEW YORK has always been a city of divided loyalties, a place too vast and too raucous to agree on anything - the best lox, the best bookstore, the best pesto, the best way crosstown. This city rather thrives on argument, discord, confusion and babble. It conspires to create a knot of sensory stimulus so Gordian that only a native could possibly unravel it.

title: Karen L. Powell Weds Marine Corps Officer
description: Karen L. Powell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Allen Powell of Havelock, N.C., was married yesterday to Lieut. Matthew Thomas Ashe Jr., U.S.M.C., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashe of Stamford, Conn.

title: House of Horrors to Home of Champions
description: HE shoveled fresh topsoil in the area around first base as if pouring batter into a baking dish. Pete Flynn, the head groundskeeper at Shea Stadium, meticulously spread the dirt with a grading rake, removing a pebble that appeared on the surface, a potential hazard for an unsuspecting first baseman.

title: Where to Go After the Show: London
description: To come to London and not go to the theater is unthinkable for most visitors. But finding a good post-theater dinner can be almost as hard as getting opening-night tickets. London tends to keep Cinderella hours. Pubs close at 11 P.M. Restaurants usually take their last order by 10:30. And finding a cruising taxi after midnight is a true challenge.

title: Susan Hill Weds Charles Wetmore
description: Susan Hill, a daughter of Roberta Wingerson of Nelson, N.H., and Ossining, N.Y., and Robert Germeroth of Austin, Tex., was married yesterday to Charles Delevan Wetmore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomson Wetmore of Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Rhebergen performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Smithfield Church in Amenia.

title: VARIED FARE IN A PLEASANT SETTING
description: FINDING memorable food is a challenge.

title: Jean Carol Stephan Weds Public Relations Executive
description: Jean Carol Stephan and Wayne S. Charness were married yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria by Justice Martin B. Stecher of the State Supreme Court. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Albert Stephan of Palm Beach, Fla., and Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Charness of Montreal.

title: Restoring Morgan To Its Original Role
description: THE blitz of ''Mendoza-grams'' is a key to his forceful style. Intense and impatient, Roberto G. Mendoza is constantly ripping sheets off a yellow legal pad and dashing off terse notes to his fellow officers at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: Curbing an Executive's Travel Rights
description: THE Stroh Brewery Company has always told its employees to ''travel efficiently.'' But, even though better than 1,000 of Stroh's 5,000 or so employees travel regularly on business, until recently Stroh's never spelled out for them what ''efficient travel'' meant.
