The result was that ''most pick the carrier and hotels that accommodate their frequent flyer packages,'' said Ronald K. Cupp, manager of corporate personnel.

title: LIBERALS STARTING ADVERTISING DRIVE
description: Liberal Party leaders, worried about the dissension-wracked party's survival, have started a radio and mail advertising campaign to turn out a Liberal vote in the Nov. 4 election.

title: FOCUS: Denver; Stylish Inner-City Shopping
description: LIKE a stage set rising amid boarded-up warehouses and weed-covered lots, the $450 million Broadway Plaza development appears, at first glance, too good to be true. But in the land of ''Dynasty,'' even the most outrageous dreams can come true.

title: Article 049186 -- No Title
description: The Rockefeller Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trusts together will give $10 million to up to six health institutions in the United States and Canada in an effort to encourage a new emphasis on public health.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ART AND BEAUTY IN THE MIDDLE AGES. By Umberto Eco. Translated by Hugh Bredin. (Yale University, $12.95.) In this short, interdisciplinary survey of medieval esthetics, written in 1958 but translated here for the first time into English, Umberto Eco (the semiotician and author of the novel, ''The Name of the Rose'') sets out to prove that medieval Latin civilization produced its own esthetic theories, not simply Christianized classical ideas but ''a new and systematic philosophical world'' that affected the ''actual artistic products'' of the 6th to 15th centuries.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SALVADORANS TELL OF TEARS AND TURMOIL AFTER THE QUAKE
description: Michele Hidalgo, a 25-year-old Salvadoran, seemed to symbolize all the anxiety and sorrow this country has withstood since the earthquake last week as she stood in front of the Ruben Dario building with tears streaming down her face.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are people around with so much gall that they would not have hesitated to explain the theory of relativity to Albert Einstein. Very often, they are perfectly pleasant types who mean well. Their only problem, which can be a major one, is that they are completely insensitive.

title: ON CAPTURING THE PRIZES OF THE SEASON
description: Leaves are to be seen everywhere now. Blazes of them cover the trees and filter down to the lawn and woods. Leaves even turn up in library books and jeans pockets. Intrigued by the idea that a pressed leaf, unlike a plucked flower, will last forever, children hoard them.

title: Art
description: A real challenge to artists, who are often invited to make work specifically for its gloomy, cavernous space, is the Mall of the City University Graduate Center at 33 West 42d Street. The Mall is now celebrating its 15th year as an alternative showcase for contemporary art, and the events are being commemorated by a series of shows, mounted by Ray Ring, who has run the art program since its beginning.

title: Washington Finds Better Fit
description: While watching his team play Riverdale on Friday, Coach Jim Walsh of George Washington High School paced the sideline and shouted instructions to his players.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Music listing today in The Guide, section 2A, for a concert by the Indian sarod player Amjad Ali Khan, and a related entry in the Critic's Choices column, have become outdated. He has suffered a hand injury and has canceled the engagement.

title:
ART;
WHAT THE STATE MUSEUM BOUGHT WITH A SPECIAL APPROPRIATION
description: THE State Museum here began life in 1832 as a cabinet displaying minerals collected in a survey for a canal from the Delaware to the Passaic River. Other milestones followed, of course, and in 1964 the fine-arts division began operating and collecting.

title: Footnote
description: To the Editor Your Aug. 31 article [ ''If You're Thinking of Living in Irvington'' ] presented an excellent overview.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on Oct. 5 with the photo of Dean Witter's chairman misidentified him. He is Philip J. Purcell.

title: Michigan Victor on Last Play
description: Mike Gillette booted a 34-yard field goal on the last play of the game today to give undefeated Michigan a 20-17 victory over Iowa in a showdown of Big Ten powers.

title: WHERE A CIGAR BECOMES MORE THAN A SMOKE
description: Marc Meneau rolled the cigar lightly between his fingers, pointing its glowing tip toward the ceiling of the bar and lounge at L'Esperance, his three-star gastronomic mecca in St.-Pere-sous-Vezelay. Smiling shyly, the chef offered an opinion about a cigar's place in the world of French haute cuisine. ''Smoking a fine cigar after a meal is a pleasure, not a vice. There's something sensual, almost sexual, about it. It says something about a man,'' Mr. Meneau said. Then he laughed. ''Or a woman, although not many women smoke cigars.''

title: In the Reagan World, With No Missiles
description: President Reagan has a vision. He believes in a world with no ballistic missiles and with the insurance of defenses against them. So far, few people have taken that vision seriously. The chaos of Reykjavik forces attention toward the radically different world to which the President seems determined to lead. What's the best case that can be made for it? How might we get from here to there? In Mr. Reagan's vision, each side would retain nuclear weapons, but they would be carried only on bombers and slow air-breathing cruise missiles. Presumably each side would have air defenses against these weapons, and a strategic defense system as insurance against the other side's having concealed a cache of ballistic missiles.

title: Constance Wallace Wed To Prof. Cyrus Gordon
description: Constance Victoria Wallace, a doctoral candidate in Hebrew, and Prof. Cyrus H. Gordon, director of the Center for Ebla Research, both at New York University, were married yesterday at the Brookline, Mass., home of the bride's mother, Dorothy Colman Wallace. David Neiman, an associate professor of theology at Boston College, officiated.

title: THE PROBLEM BEGINS AT HOME
description: CHILDREN AT RISK My Fight Against Child Abuse -A Personal Story and a Public Plea. By Paula Hawkins. 191 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. $16.95.

title: Scott L. Kuensell And Ms. Gowen Exchange Vows
description: Elizabeth Cabell Gowen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis I. Gowen of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Scott Lee Kuensell, a son of Mrs. Dean Carter Burtch of Devon, Pa., and Dr. S. Lee Kuensell of Marlton, N.J. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A QUEST TO FINISH MARATHON SEEMS TO RUN IN THE FAMILY
description: FRANK and Liz Bovich have become a customary sight, jogging through their Westport neighborhood, as recognizable as the country store. Each day at dusk, commuters returning from their daily journey are greeted by the father-and-daughter team, churning through the streets at an agreeable pace.

title: PUTTING A SPARK BACK IN THE ELDERLY
description: MINNIE WEBER of Commack had forgotten how to kiss.

title: HAZARDOUS WASTE: A HOST OF QUESTIONS
description: VOTERS will decide next month the fate of two proposed bond questions that together would commit $300 million of state funds to cleaning up hazardous-waste sites.

title: Politics and Obsolescence
description: A new national poll taken for a political scientist at the University of Virginia illustrates one of the most serious problems the Democratic Party faces in 1988: perceived obsolescence. It shows Americans associate the Democrats with leaders who served more than 20 years ago but the Republicans with contemporary figures.

title: 'Peggy Sue' Visits A Changeless Past
description: One of the funnier of the random jokes -which surface like debris from a sunken lifeboat during ''Peggy Sue Got Married'' - recalls the Ford Motor Company's disastrous attempt to create a market for what turned out to be the automobile industry's most colossal dud.

title: Workers Who Trim Their Own Costs
description: IN the past, cutting production costs was often a process of management telling workers to spend less and produce more - or else. Not any longer, experts say. Today, companies are asking employees at all levels to suggest ways to trim down.

title: INSPIRED BY RANDINESS
description: H. G. WELLS Desperately Mortal. A Biography. By David C. Smith. Illustrated. 634 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: Q AND A
description: Prepayment Penalties Question: When I bought a one-family home in Brooklyn in May 1985, I took out a 20-year fixed-rate mortgage at 13 percent from a local Federal savings and loan. I would now like to lock in a lower mortgage interest rate by refinancing, but my loan agreement has a prepayment penalty clause of six months' interest, or about $5,500. A recent ruling by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates savings and loans, supposedly no longer permits prepayment penalties. What are my chances of avoiding that prepayment fee if I refinance with another bank? . . . S. B., Brooklyn

title: IN MIAMI, A MYSTERY OF DISAPPEARING BICYCLES
description: For several years, bicycles have been disappearing from lawns, garages and school grounds here almost as fast as some people could buy them.

title: BEST SELLERS: OCTOBER 19, 1986
description: Fiction This Last Weeks on Week Week List

title: MUSIC: HASSELL TRIO PLAYS IN NEXT WAVE
description: JON HASSELL'S music dreams of a global crossroads, where digital electronics, ancient rhythms and improvised melodies can all be heard at once, intact yet together. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Carey Playhouse on Friday night, the trumpeter-keyboardist-composer and his Concert Ensemble - Richard Horowitz on synthesizers and J. A. Deane on percussion and keyboards -played a meditative two hours of music drawn from a world of influences, from Zimbabwean mbira (thumb piano) music to Cuban rhumbas to American minimalism to Arab and Indian songs.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY RIDE AIDS THE HOMELESS
description: TWO Connecticut men mounted horses at the State Capitol on May 5 and arrived at the shoreline of the Pacific Ocean in Washington State four months later, in a 3,300-mile trip to raise money for the homeless and hungry.

title: Christina Reiling Is Planning to Wed Hans Charles Breiter in May Ceremony
description: A May wedding is planned by Christina Lucille Reiling and Hans Charles Breiter, the parents of the bride-to-be, Prof. and Mrs. Henry B. Reiling of Lexington, Mass., have announced. The future bridegroom is a son of Prof. and Mrs. Manfred W. Breiter of Schenectady, N.Y., and Vienna.

title: UNEASY ACCORD ON GARBAGE PLANT
description: LONGSTANDING opposition by civic groups to the reopening of the Hempstead Resource Recovery Plant appears to have been eased by a recent agreement reached after the town made certain environmental concessions.

title: Cornell Wins, 27-9; Ties Penn for Lead
description: Stuart Mitchell, a senior tight end, caught a 22-yard touchdown pass and set up two other scores by Jeff Johnson as Cornell tied for the Ivy League lead with a 27-9 rout of Brown today.

title: New Jersey First In Two Events
description: New Jersey schools won the boys' and girls' championship races yesterday at the Fordham University Eastern States cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Evelyn Owen Has Wedding
description: Evelyn Turull Owen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Cooke Owen of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Jon Tomasson, a son of Heba Jonsdottir and her husband, Ambassador Tomas A. Tomasson, of Reykjavik, Iceland. The Rev. Robert R. Spears Jr. performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: GALAPAGOS, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Dell, $4.50.) Kurt Vonnegut populates a nature cruise with celebrities and turns it into a modern-day Noah's ark, bound for the Galapagos Islands, where its passengers will perpetuate the species after a global catastrophe. The novel is ''a madcap genealogical adventure,'' Lorrie Moore said in The Book Review last year. ''Mr. Vonnegut's grumbly and idiomatic voice has always been his own, unfakable and childlike, and his humanity, persisting as it does through his pessimism, is astonishing.'' TELLING LIES: Clues to Deceit in the Marketplace, Politics, and Marriage, by Paul Ekman. (Berkley, $3.95.) In a study of deception and lie catching, a psychology professor at the University of California draws upon scientific studies as well as material from politics, literature and everyday life to describe how and why people lie, and why some are good liars and others aren't. In these pages last year, Carol Z. Malatesta called the work a ''fascinating account . . . accurate, intelligent, informative and thoughtful.'' A SIMPLE STORY, by S. Y. Agnon. Translated by Hillel Halkin. (Schocken, $8.95.) Originally published in Hebrew in 1935 and in English 50 years later, ''A Simple Story'' takes place at the turn of the century, as Hirshl Hurvitz, the son of wealthy Galician shopkeepers, sinks into depression and madness after he is forced to renounce his love for his impoverished cousin and accept an arranged marriage. Our reviewer, Robert Alter, last year called the work an ''understated masterpiece'' rendered with ''extraordinary subtlety and conviction.''

title: Time Out
description: PHILLIP'S MOTHER HAS had her fourth baby by a third man. The child, my patient, is a boy. I wonder if she'll try again for the girl I know she wants. Twinkies, potato chips and Kool-Aid are still her kids' standard fare. Questions of child abuse haven't been raised in over two years, and the scars on Phillip's neck from the boiling water his mother spilled are not too deforming. All through this pregnancy she smoked a pack a day. She makes me mad.

title: Barry E. Schklair to Wed Diane Boas in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Boas of New York and Newtown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Diane Doris Boas to Barry Evan Schklair, the son of Rose Schklair of New York and the late Jack Schklair.

title:
GARDENING;
SUMACS ARE COLORFUL OPTIONS IN THE FALL
description: WHETHER one considers the sumacs useful in the garden or, for that matter, finds them attractive at all, will depend upon one's concept of gardening.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes
description: The Lily Tomlin Special: Vol. I. Co-starring Alan Alda and Richard Pryor; Produced by Herb Sargent. Directed by Bill Davis. Karl Lorimar Home Video. 60 minutes.

title: NEW LONDON VOTES REPRIEVE TO KEEP MORAN ZOO OPEN
description: A CITIZENS' group in New London has won its six-month battle with the City Council to keep the 26-year-old Herbert Moran Zoo open.

title: Town Caught in the Middle
description: This is baseball's Mason-Dixon line.

title: A Tune Up for the PC's Keyboard
description: OTHER than browsing through a bookstore, I've never been much of a shopper. I bought the same awful, slightly orange kangaroo hide Hanover shoes, size 9 1/2, throughout high school, college and beyond, because they were comfortable and I could be in and out of the store in about 5 minutes. One year this particular model was discontinued, not only casting my life into chaos, but inexplicably stepping me up to a size 10.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AFRICA ON CANVAS The paintings of African wildlife by Simon Combes go on exhibition today at the Greenwich Workshop Gallery, 2600 Post Road, Southport, until Nov. 7. It is the first American solo show for the 46-year-old British artist. Twenty paintings, some of them up to four feet in length and priced from $6,000 to $20,000, will be on view along with about 40 sketches and studies priced at $400 to $700.

title: STAGE: 'THE GILDED AGE,' IN HARTFORD
description: ''The Gilded Age,'' a first novel for each of its collaborators - Mark Twain and Charles Dudley Warner -was a sprawling satire about life, business and politics as usual in America after the Civil War. In a book that gave its name to an age, the authors paralleled western expansionism with what they saw as the decline of democracy. Perhaps with an eye toward the work's continuing applicability, they subtitled it ''a tale of today.''

title: SPEAKES AND PRESS DIFFER ON REMARKS
description: The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, continued today to dispute an account by a group of reporters of his description of a Presidential briefing for legislators on American arms control proposals.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Stone in the Avalanche

title: DO DRUG TESTS CAUSE MORE PROBLEMS THAN THEY FIND?
description: AS the capabilities of computers and laboratories grow, so, it seems, does a stern mood about drug use. While public employers try to work around constitutional difficulties, the private sector has adopted drug testing programs quickly; about a third of the Fortune 500 companies screen applicants or test some employees. As they are learning, urinalysis can identify drug users easily, but it can also be intrusive, expensive and sometimes mistaken. At a forum in New York last week, experts discussed privacy issues in employment and, as to drug testing, debated what is fair, what is legal and what makes sense. The discussion was led by Arthur R. Miller, a professor at Harvard Law School and a television commentator. Among the panelists were Dr. John J. Mahoney, a medical consultant and former corporate medical director for GTE; Allan Adler, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union in Washington; Jane P. Metzroth, a vice president and director of human resources for Salomon Brothers Inc.; Robert J. Freeman, executive director of the Committee on Open Government for New York State; Timothy R. Graham, a partner at a New York law firm, Alexander & Green; David Flaherty, a professor of history and law at the University of Western Ontario, and Robert B. Peters, manager of compensation and benefits for the Mobil Oil Corporation. The forum was sponsored by the Alexander & Alexander Consulting Group. Excerpts follow.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE PROPER MIX
description: IF someone at the American Bartenders School says, ''Name your poison,'' he might almost mean it literally: in lieu of alcohol, students use paint and food dye when stirring up their mock concoctions.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
A Clampdown on Coastal-Zone Cabanas
description: ALL along the coast, cabanas dot the landscape, sitting atop patches of sandy beach where the ocean brushes against the shore. Traditionally, they have been small, plain structures - mere changing rooms for bathers.

title: Salvadoran Chief Says Quake Toll Now 1,500
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that 1,500 people were killed by the earthquakes that struck El Salvador eight days ago. Previous estimates of the death toll were below 1,000.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AMERICAN ANTIQUE FURNITURE ON DISPLAY AT THE KATONAH GALLERY
description: FINE examples of American antique furniture, chosen from collections in the county and arranged chronologically, document the story of American history in the exhibition at the Katonah Gallery.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Atlanta last Sunday about division over the city's ordinance guaranteeing rights of homosexuals misstated the position of two members of the City Council. Richard Guthman and Buddy Fowlkes introduced a measure to repeal the ordinance.

title: Pamela McA. Brecker Plans to Marry Douglas Hendrickson, Fellow Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Brecker of New York and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela McAlpine Brecker to Douglas Tadd Hendrickson, the son of William Tadd Hendrickson and the late Jane Leber Hendrickson of Ridgewood, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: A FINAL, FRANTIC RUSH TO ADJOURN
description: AT times the 99th Congress seemed to be going down for the third time, with its life passing before its eyes.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A ROOM AT THE PALACE, POR FAVOR
description: Who would have thought that Spain, that most traditionalist European country, would dream up paradors? Surely the chain of state-run hotels is one of the tourism breakthroughs of recent decades. True, Spain started with great raw material - 9,000 crumbling monasteries, castles and palaces scattered throughout the country - but it took imagination and bureaucratic genius to eye the remains of her ancient glory and visualize them as wayside inns for the burgeoning tourist industry.

title: CALIFORNIAN WHO WON LIBEL SUIT CALLS SOVIET CHARGE PUZZLING
description: Two years ago, an article in the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia accused a California medical equipment exporter of intelligence activities and dishonest business practices.

title: THE LATEST THING IN EMPERORS
description: THE GREAT CHINESE REVOLUTION: 1800-1985 By John King Fairbank. Maps. 396 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $20.95.

title: Jill Wawro Wed To Bank Officer
description: Gillian Aileen Nugent Wawro, an institutional equity sales representative for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, an investment concern in New York, and Dwight Spurr Weatherhead, an assistant vice president of the Arab Banking Corporation, also in New York, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Allen O'Neil at St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Classical Music
description: Eighteenth-century string playing differs from more recent ''improvements'' in that it is quieter, more delicate, less throbbing and emotional. Classical Indian string instruments - the sitar, the sarod, the Western violin adapted for Indian usage - deal in very similar techniques and emotions, albeit in a very different style. Both 18th-century instrumental music and traditional Indian ragas were meant to be heard by the few, not the many, in small chambers for educated tastes.

title: DIRECTOR'S CHOICE' AT HUNTERDON CENTER CONTRASTS WORK OF 3 CERAMIC SCULPTORS
description: ONCE A year at the Hunterdon Art Center here, the term ''director's choice'' is applied to a show that has been conceived and organized by Linda Buki, the center's director. The intention is to focus on significant trends in the arts.

title: THE DANCE: CODANCECO AT SCHONBERG THEATER
description: MOST modern-dance companies feature the works of a single choreographer. One exception is Codanceco, which, since it was founded by Nancy Duncan in 1982, has commissioned 21 dances by 20 choreographers. The troupe delighted in diversity on Friday night when it offered two premieres at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: THERE'S MORE THAN NOURISHMENT IN A LUNCH PAIL
description: I SHOULD have been concentrating on the pretty girl and the perfect summer's day, but I was distracted by a gnawing sense of crisis.

title: Gooden Vs. Clemens: The Stars at Center Stage
description: In starting 33 times during the regular season, Roger Clemens never came back on less than four days of rest. Now, in being Boston's scheduled starter for tonight's second game of the World Series, Clemens will be pitching for the third consecutive time with only three days of rest.

title: Robin Salvadore Weds Edward H. Perkins 3d
description: The wedding of Robin Anne Salvadore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Salvadore of Lawrenceville, N.J., to Edward Howard Perkins 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Perkins Jr. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., took place yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Hughes performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: AMID MUD AND LOST ROADS, ALASKANS REAWAKEN FROM DELUGE
description: As Alaskans began to recover from flooding that forced hundreds of people from their homes, even the dogs were not forgotten.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Libraries are not just for reading, but also for listening. With the free autumn concert circuit in full swing, today's a day to please most musical tastes. For example, the Hofstra String Quartet will play at 3 P.M. at the Freeport Library, on South Ocean Avenue; the Metropolitan String Quartet will appear at 2:30 P.M. at the Great Neck Library, on Bayview Avenue, and the Roslyn Artists String Quartet will be at the Oceanside Library on Davison Avenue at 2 P.M.

title: Sudan Relief Total Put at 232 Tons So Far
description: The international relief effort known as Operation Rainbow has airlifted 232 tons of food and medicine for starving people in the southern Sudan, a Government official said today.

title: Real World Impinges on 'Miami Vice'
description: Occasionally, as in the case of a recent episode of ''Miami Vice,'' life seems to end up imitating entertainment. It has been argued that television is the Great Reflector, showing society at large where it is and where it might be going. If the country begins taking closer looks at the problems of, say, drug abuse or battered wives, those subjects are bound to begin popping up in TV movies, the normal instance of art, or at least entertainment, imitating life.

title: In A New York Minute
description: THE ATTORNEY General of Alabama, denied the Democratic nomination for Governor, was furious. He denounced the people around his opponent as ''a bunch of sleazebags - you can see that in a New York minute.''

title: Question Of the Week; How Can Football Improve Replays?
description: Football can improve TV replays by totally and completely ignoring them. The game has been tampered with enough. Football is now played on carpets, indoors in a climate-controlled environment, on Monday and Thursday nights, and with commercial timeouts and a myriad of other gimmicks designed to spoil the sport. ENOUGH!

title: A CASE STUDY: ICHAN vs. RODERICK; Heavyweight Fight Over USX
description: The case study method of teaching business requires students to study a company and suggest ways to solve its problems. This article takes the same approach, but in this case the subject is Carl C. Icahn's bid for USX, and the ''students'' are chief executives and corporate takeover specialists.

title: How Many Billionaires Are Enough?
description: ACCORDING to Forbes magazine, 1986 ''has been a splendid year for billionaires.'' Indeed. Their number almost doubled, to 26 from 14, reflecting what recent studies have demonstrated overwhelmingly: that America's economic elite is claiming an increasing share of the nation's income and wealth. The recently published Forbes 400 list of the richest Americans also shows that the net worth of these fortunate few rose $22 billion last year, to $156 billion. And, while many on the list made the bulk of their fortune in their lifetimes, it should surprise no one that 10 percent of them are descendants of Rockefellers, Mellons or Du Ponts.

title: Applause For Largent
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mets a Mirror Of Their City
description: IN the first year of my first term as Mayor, a World Series championship came to New York City.

title: Patrick O'Donnell Wed in California To Barbara Gates
description: Barbara Gates, the daughter of Mrs. Dillard P. Spriggs of New York and the late William B. Gates Jr. of Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to Patrick O'Donnell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. O'Donnell of Evanston, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Leatherwood, a United Church of Christ minister, at the Gault House in Inverness, Calif.

title: Fieldston Falls To Brunswick
description: Brunswick won its 29th consecutive game and tarnished a Fieldston homecoming, beating the hosts, 16-7, in the Bronx yesterday. The victory was the fifth this season and it made Brunswick champion of the Southern Division of the Fairchester League.

title: NORWALK WEIGHS BARRING SMOKERS FROM POLICE JOBS
description: The Norwak Police Commission is considering making the city the first in the state to require that new officers be nonsmokers.

title: New York City's Assets
description: When I retired in 1980, I made the mistake of giving up my small apartment on 10th Street and Fourth Avenue to move to Florida. Little did I realize that within six years rents in New York City would skyrocket to such heights.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: QUIET RAGE: Bernie Goetz in a Time of Madness. By Lillian B. Rubin. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) No one, says Lillian B. Rubin, is quite sure who Bernhard Goetz really is.

title: The Designated Hitter Rule Is Unfair to Don Baylor
description: He has been a leader wherever he has played, except in New York, when the owner of the Yankees and his favorite rotating manager were foolish enough to cut him down.

title: HACKLEY TIES AT 3 CONCERTS
description: NINA BEILINA may be a world-renowned violinist, and Ken Noda one of America's most promising young conductor-pianists, but they also have strong Hackley connections and thus are appearing in a lustrous three-concert series that begins this afternoon at the school in Tarrytown. Music has always been an important ingredient at the Hackley School: the much-admired composer Charles Tomlinson Griffes taught there for more than 12 years, and since 1974, a conservatory program has flourished as a separate division at the school. Membership in various performing groups carries academic credit, and the present cycle has been designed to raise funds for a Performing Arts Center to be built on campus.

title: Koch's Offer To Mother Teresa
description: AFTER winning the release of three New York prisoners with AIDS to a hospice in Greenwich Village last Christmas Eve, Mother Teresa called on Mayor Koch on Jan. 2 with a further request. Would he ask Governor Cuomo to free all state prisoners with the usually fatal immunity disorder, so they could be near their families when they died?

title: TRACKING DOWN SYRIA'S TERRORIST CONNECTIONS
description: IN THE discreet world of Western counterintelligence, the name of Syria's Brig.

title: CHILE ARMS CACHES ARE LAID TO CUBA
description: United States weapons experts have accused Cuba of providing the arms found hidden in several caches in Chile recently. The experts say the amount of weapons was too large for Chilean guerrillas to have acquired on their own.

title: BETTER WAYS TO ADJUST NEW YORK STATE TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: A Choice of Two
description: The United States Postal Service has announced that the 1986 Christmas stamps will go on sale Saturday. In keeping with standard practice, separate ''traditional'' and ''contemporary'' themes will be offered. The traditional stamp offers a religious scene, the ninth consecutive variation on a Madonna and Child. In this instance, the stamp reproduces the major portion of a 15th century oil painting by ''Il Perugino.'' The contemporary stamp depicts a winter village scene by Dolli Tingle of Westport, Conn.

title: A New Approach to Radio Jamming Abroad
description: For as long as there have been international rules on radio broadcasting, there have been prohibitions against interfering with radio transmissions. And for nearly as long, some countries have jammed those signals anyway, in defiance of the rules.

title: Soviet Player Wins An Award
description: Awards for outstanding performance on a single bridge deal usually go to world-famous players from countries that are prominent on the international scene. For an award to go to a player in the Soviet Union, where enthusiasts struggle in the face of official disapproval, is hardly conceivable. But it happened last month after a complex chain of events.

title: A COMPASSIONATE CAMERA
description: PHOTOGRAPHY'S ROLE in effecting social change has a distinguished record in the United States. In the late 19th century, the muckraking journalist Jacob A. Riis railed against slums and poverty. To prove the truth of what he wrote in The New York Tribune, he took photographs. Lewis W. Hine's photographs exposed the exploitation of children in the nation's textile mills; his images became weapons in the hands of the National Child Labor Committee, and the result was a Federal law enacted in 1938. In the 30's, Dorothea Lange's photographs of dispossessed migrant farm workers pricked the nation's conscience. In 1944, Ansel Adams exhibited his powerful photographs of interned Japanese-Americans in New York's Museum of Modern Art; his book on the subject was titled ''Born Free and Equal.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Minneapolis;
Resurrection Of a Flagship
description: FOR much of its 72 years, the elegant Radisson Hotel represented the last word in downtown accommodations here. It closed in 1981, a victim of travelers' changing tastes, but the Minnesota-based Radisson Hotel Corporation promised that a replacement would rise on the same site.

title: FROST AND HAWTHORNE JOIN U.S. POETS' CORNER
description: IN a surprising election and beating out stiff competition from such 19th-century contenders as Mark Twain, Henry James and Ralph Waldo Emerson, Robert Frost (1874-1963) today will become the first 20th-century poet to be inducted into the American Poets' Corner at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: KIDNAPPED BY EVERYONE
description: IN THE HOLLOW OF HIS HAND By James Purdy. 254 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $16.95.

title: Margaret D. Wise Weds D. S. Hartz
description: Margaret Douglas Wise and Douglas Smallwood Hartz were married yesterday at Leeds Parish in Hume, Va., by the Rev. Llewellyn Fairchild assisted by the Rev. Donald Hannan, Episcopal priests.

title: ZOROASTER IN THE NEW WORLD
description: AT THE ROYAL GAYLORD RESTAU-rant in suburban northwest Houston, a 9-year-old boy sits barefoot on a white blanket in front of a bowl of fire, while several priests in white robes and turbans chant beside him. The boy is undergoing a navjote -new worshiper - ceremony, a religious initiation rather like a bar mitzvah or a confirmation. Around him in a semicircle sits a good part of the Houston Zoroastrian community, which numbers some 300 families. Since the flock doesn't have its own temple yet, the ceremony is being held in the Indian restaurant.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: VILLAGE ACTIVISTS
description: HOPE IN HARD TIMES America's Peace Movement and the Reagan Era. By Paul Rogat Loeb. 322 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books/D. C. Heath & Company. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: FOR VARIETY OF TASTES, A VARIETY OF CHOICES
description: WHETHER your musical tastes run to operas, symphonies or chamber music, there will be ample opportunities to satisfy them in the next couple of weeks. In fact, this next fortnight could well be the busiest of the fall season.

title: LAST 'BAY OF PIGS' SOLDIER FREED BY CUBA
description: The last imprisoned member of a United States-sponsored force that launched the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in April 1961 was released from jail in Havana and arrived here today.

title: AIR-INDIA INQUIRY URGES TIGHTER SECURITY MEASURES
description: An Indian investigation into the crash last year of an Air-India jetliner off Ireland has recommended more detailed examination of baggage and tighter security measures at airports and airlines to help prevent terrorist attacks and hijackings.

title: FROM OXFORD FIELD, A 30's BARNSTORMER
description: EDMUND R. STRAUCHEN of Weston, a pilot for American Airlines, often can be found on his days off barnstorming around Connecticut in his open cockpit Stearman biplane.

title: A LAST STAND IN POLAND
description: REMNANTS The Last Jews of Poland. By Malgorzata Niezabitowska. Photographs by Tomasz Tomaszewski. Translated by William Brand and Hanna Dobosiewicz. 272 pp. New York: Friendly Press. $35. SHIELDING THE FLAME An Intimate Conversation With Dr. Marek Edelman, the Last Surviving Leader of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. By Hanna Krall. Translated by Joanna Stasinska and Lawrence Weschler. 124 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $13.95.

title: German Doctors and the Nazi Mentality
description: Professor Lifton's article, without directly raising the issue, provides a powerful brief for today's Right to Life movement. It clarifies the statement made by a German official explaining why the Federal Republic has no abortion-on-demand law: ''We have been down that road before.''

title: Kush Stays in Touch
description: Although no longer coaching professional players, Frank Kush is staying in touch with football. The former coach of the Indianapolis Colts of the National Football league and the Arizona Outlaws of the United States Football league has been offering assistance to beginning youngsters in the Pop Warner program in the phoenix area.

title: Where to Go After the Show: Rome and Milan
description: The pleasures of sipping a glass of Chianti or Barolo and enjoying a fine meal in a trattoria are complemented by the delights of people watching. Dining out in Rome or Milan is a bit like reading an intricate novel or watching a movie with a great cast of characters, if you let your eye and your imagination wander freely.

title: A Home For Hertz In Bergen
description: A new office complex that will spread across a 14-acre, wooded site in Park Ridge, N.J., will provide the final pieces in the puzzles of both sponsor and host.

title: Necessity Lies Behind Style
description: American players cannot correctly be said to show off for the grandstand, because there are never enough spectators on hand to organize a lusty cheer.

title: Mets Fans, Prepare for Rain
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'FLAMENCO PURO,' STRAIGHT FROM SEVILLE
description: In a small, steamy dance studio over a nightclub on a narrow side street in old Seville, the smoke was thick and the whisky flowed.

title: German Doctors And the Nazi Mentality
description: The enigma of why so many healers became murderers cannot be resolved through a rational analysis of Nazi philosophy (''German Doctors and the Final Solution,'' by Robert Jay Lifton, Sept. 21). Rather, to understand how this particular perversion of the Hippocratic Oath occurred, one must examine the preoccupation with death that was so much a part of the Nazi mentality.

title: Kathleen Fell Has Wedding
description: Kathleen Howell Fell, the daughter of Mrs. Robert L. Stott Jr. of New York and John R. Fell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I., to Thomas Charles Connor. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Robert Connor 3d of Essex, Conn.

title: HALF-NAKED FAKIR MEETS OVERDRESSED KING
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; Quake Safety For Landmarks
description: BRINGING landmark buildings that predate earthquake safety codes up to the standards can be both expensive and troublesome. But the owners of two disparate properties here - a fading, grand hotel and the oldest building at Los Angeles International Airport - have found the effort worth while.

title: CRATES OF AMUNITION WASH ASHORE ALONG FLORIDA BEACHES
description: Dozens of wooden ammunition crates containing fuses for explosives washed ashore here today and the authorities evacuated some beaches along highly populated coastal communities.

title: CONFEREES UNABLE TO RESOLVE DIFFERENCES ON HIGHWAY BILL
description: Legislation that would have authorized the Federal Government to spend billions of dollars on transportation programs and would have allowed states to raise the speed limit died today when House and Senate conferees announced they were unable to resolve their differences.

title: Rangers Beat Islanders for First Victory
description: The game ended with a flourish with six attackers descending on John Vanbiesbrouck and trying to repair the Islanders' 3-2 deficit with less than a minute remaining.

title: Elizabeth Tilt Wentworth Is the Bride Of Christopher Ferrone in Washington
description: Elizabeth Tilt Wentworth, a daughter of Mrs. Henry Brandon and Eric Wentworth, both of Washington, was married yesterday to Christopher David Ferrone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Ferrone of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. James Maier, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Washington, assisted by the Rev. John Harper, an Episcopalian priest. The bride, who will keep her maiden name professionally, is a staff assistant in New York for N.W. Ayer Inc., the advertising agency.

title: Pushing on Doors For the Homeless
description: With winter on its way and homeless families already overflowing New York City's welfare hotels, Mayor Koch last week reversed an earlier stand and said the city would sue hotels that refuse to accept the homeless.

title: CALL ME MRS., PLEASE
description: FORTY years ago, I became a ''Mrs.'' at the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas. Or so I thought. The church on Fifth

title: Meals in Tokyo
description: To the Editor: I read the article about Tokyo (Travel, Sept. 14) and would like to add one easy suggestion for good, inexpensive meals there: The major department stores each have several restaurants, and they are open at lunch and dinner. And the food halls in the basements of department stores are fantastic, and often give free samples! ALICE EPSTEIN Wilmington, Del.

description: In percent

description: The Princeton Forrestal Center, a corporate research complex owned by Princeton University, will soon have shops, restaurants and a 300-room Marriott Hotel.

title: What is Repetition Doing to Choreography?
description: ''There's something strange going on,'' the singer sings in Alvin Ailey's ''Blues Suite.'' Something strange is certainly going on in American dance today, and it warrants consideration. In short, what is the effect of the increased use of repetition as an artistic signature? Are choreographers deliberately reducing their vocabulary or actually expanding it under the pressure of self-imposed limits?

description: Gary Moy, a Chinese-American teen-ager, was stabbed while in Brooklyn last June by a youth who told him that Chinese ''don't belong in this neighborhood.''

description: With nearly deserted chambers, the House and Senate, having finished the real work of the 99th Congress before today, appeared to be sleepwalking through their final hours before adjourning tonight.

title:
DINING OUT;
EAST RUTHERFORD: THE NEW BREED
description: A few years ago, when nouvelle cuisine, (whether French or American) was in full swing, plate presentation was everything. The food was arranged so beautifully that it sometimes seemed a shame to spoil the arrangement by eating it.

title: VENUS PERSUED
description: MASTERPIECE By Thomas Hoving. 321 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

description: For 60 years, daydreaming has occupied beach-goers and artists who have visited the 16 grey-brown shacks of scrap wood and shingles among the tranquil dunes about two miles from the center of this Cape Cod town.

description: Many of the people who paid $100 to have their pictures taken with Bill Lucas, the Republican candidate for governor of Michigan, did not know the man from out of state who flanked them and smiled as the shutters clicked.

description: THE cleanup of hazardous wastes in Connecticut would get an infusion of Federal money from the $9 billion Superfund bill.

title: AS CALL COMES, MORE WOMEN ANSWER
description: THIRTY-TWO years ago, there were no women in degree programs at Harvard Divinity School. But when students signed up for classes at the school last month, more than half the degree candidates were women. ''Had it been an option, I would have done this 25 or 30 years ago,'' said one of them, Dillman Baker Sorrells. ''But at that time, the ministry seemed so inaccessible.''

title: SPOILED PARADISES
description: ECOLOGICAL IMPERIALISM The Biological Expansion of Europe, 900-1900. By Alfred W. Crosby. Illustrated. 368 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $22.95.

title: In Nicaragua, A Doomed Plane, A Tangled Tale
description: Like a Graham Greene novel of intrigue, the story of the American cargo plane shot down over Nicaragua continued to unfold last week.

title: PINCH-HIT FOR MICKEY
description: HEART OF THE ORDER By Tony Ardizzone. 314 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NICCOLO RISING. By Dorothy Dunnett. (Knopf, $18.95.) A historical novel set in 15th-century Europe would seem to be mostly an adventure story, but this book is about the rise of international commerce.

title: Shorter Has Regrets
description: SHEEPISHLY, Frank Shorter concedes now that he helped create a well-heeled American running monster whose specialty is burnout. After he gained international prominence by winning the marathat he thon at the 1972 Olympic Games, Shorter became an outspoken advocate of allowing runners to receive money without losing their eligibility for international competition.

title: Ellen Walsh Is a Bride
description: Ellen M. Walsh and Vincent S. Taschetti were married yesterday by the Rev. John J. Lynch at the Queen of the Most Holy Rosary in Bridgehampton, L.I. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James T. Walsh of Scranton, Pa., and Mr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Taschetti of Brooklyn. The bride, a graduate of Chestnut Hill College, is a freelance marketing consultant. Mr. Taschetti, a graduate of the School of Visual Arts, is a senior vice president and associate creative director at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: UPSTATE CANDIDATE IS LINKED TO POSSIBLE INTEREST CONFLICT
description: An upstate Congressional candidate may have violated state conflict-of-interest laws by accepting campaign contributions and advice from a director of a state utility while still a member of the Public Service Commission, an inquiry by the commission has concluded.

title: SPACE RUNNING OUT AT TOWN LANDFILLS
description: As Long Island mumicipalities approach the state's 1990 deadline to close landfills and dispose of garbage by other methods, some areas are discovering that their landfills may not last until 1990.

title: TRIBUTE TO GONSALVES IN LIVE JAZZ BROADCAST
description: A MAJOR jazz work will have its world premiere next Saturday in a concert to be broadcast live from Boston on National Public Radio stations. David Murray's ''Paul Gonsalves,'' a tribute to the tenor saxophonist who was a member of the Duke Ellington band in the 1950's and 1960's, will be performed by a 40-piece jazz orchestra. The group, made up of Mr. Murray's 18-piece big band and a 22-member string section of Boston musicians, will be conducted by Lawrence (Butch) Morris.

title: THE SIGN OF LIFE IS MAYHEM
description: TO SKIN A CAT By Thomas McGuane. 212 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 61 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 61 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Verbatim; Endangered Lofts
description: 'If you clear Brooklyn of its artists, the quality of art in New York is going to decline dramatically.

title: Business Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Recycling Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DANCING MEN. By Duncan Kyle. (Henry Holt, $16.95.) There's something faintly preposterous and too familiar about the characters in Duncan Kyle's new political thriller. Mr. Kyle, a British writer, seems to have learned about American politics from movies and television.

title: HUCK FINN IN MALAWI
description: MAKING A DIFFERENCE The Peace Corps at Twenty-Five. Edited by Milton Viorst. Foreword by President Ronald Reagan. 218 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $16.95.

title: An Israeli Flier Is Held in Lebanon
description: Terrorists struck with grenades as a group of Israeli soldiers from the elite Givati Brigade left the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem after a swearing-in ceremony last week. One person, a civilian, was killed, and 65 were injured in the attack, the most serious in Jerusalem since Palestinian gunmen killed 1 person and wounded 47 on a street in April 1984.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SERIOUS TROUBLE. By Paul Friedman (University of Illinois, $11.95.) Paul Friedman is a professor and writer in the Middle West who has surrendered the majority of this story collection to the unfocused angst of Alan Ware, a professor and writer in the Middle West. This premise could have made for a postmodern metaphysical comedy, but Mr. Friedman plays it straight. ''A Period of Grace'' shows Ware coping with the slow, painful death of his aged father, and with his suspicion that he is exploiting this death for material. ''It was abundantly clear that I couldn't write my father's story with any kind of authority, not now,'' he tells us candidly. ''It was abundantly clear I didn't even know what his story was.'' After 75 pages, despite his conscientiousness - or maybe because of it - the reader is inclined to agree. Ware's self-consciousness becomes stultifying, trivializing the very thing he tells and tells us he is trying so gamely not to trivialize. For all his earnest effort, Ware offers us a great deal more attitude than insight. The same holds true for ''The Family.'' Set in an artists' colony, it never really probes any subject but the writer's own vagaries of mood. Other stories, however, suggest that, with some distance on his material, the author can write powerfully and with deft control about people laboring to accommodate themselves to an inhospitable world. In ''An Unexpected Death'' we follow the pendulum swings of dread and hope in a man facing his own mortality.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Water-Use Curbs Restrict Construction
description: TO curb excessive water consumption in Nassau County, the State Department of Environmental Conservation began notifying the county's 41 water suppliers in June that limits would be placed on the amount of water they can pump out of the ground each year.

title: VETERAN FLEW NEAR PRESIDENT
description: The fighter pilot who intruded in Air Force One's airspace is a combat veteran who said he took evasive action after a bad radio transmission caused him to miss a first warning, a New York National Guard official said today.

title: U.S. SAYS MOSCOW MAY BE FLEXIBLE OVER 'STAR WARS'
description: The Soviet Union has told the United States since the Iceland summit meeting that it is prepared to allow some research and testing of the American missile-defense system outside the laboratory, Administration officials said today.

title: BROOKLYN WOMAN SLAIN IN DISPUTE OVER SMASHED WINDSHIELD IN '85
description: A 72-year-old Brooklyn man shot and killed the owner of a dry-cleaning store in the Red Hook section yesterday, apparently in an argument over whether she broke his car windshield more than a year ago, the police said.

title: In the Real World, With the Bomb
description: It's either visionary or kooky for leaders to talk the way Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev talked in Iceland. How should the world react when all the rules of summitry and arms control are broken: With delight at the amazing agreements almost achieved? With despair that the glass remains half empty? Or with unnerved uncertainty about the unknown world that the two leaders dared contemplate?

title: College Student Dies After Canoe Capsizes
description: The body of a 19-year-old college student was found by the police early yesterday, 10 1/2 hours after the canoe he and three other students were riding in was overturned by choppy waves of the East River near the Throgs Neck Bridge.

title: CONCERT: I SOLISTI ITALIANI
description: WHEN Renato Fasano died in 1979, the group he had created and led for three decades, I Virtuosi di Roma, split into two factions - I Nuovi Virtuosi di Roma and I Solisti Italiani. On Thursday night, the latter group made its New York debut at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: U.S.C. Is Beaten By Arizona State
description: Jeff Van Raaphorst passed for two touchdowns and Kent Bostrom made three field goals today as Arizona State (5-0-1, 3-0-1) remained atop the Pacific-10 Conference with a 29-20 triumph over Southern Cal. U.S.C. (4-2, 2-2) lost its second straight conference game.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Old Shipyard Into New Town
description: THE Navy once made all its chain and rope, as well as thousands of ships, at the Charlestown Shipyard in Boston Harbor. Now 18 developers and 15 architects, working on 17 commercial and residential projects, both new construction and rehabilitations, are turning it into a new community in one of the largest such undertakings in the country.

title: GRANDMOTHER'S HATS INSPIRES A NEW HAVEN DESIGNER
description: WHILE most people choose to go hatless these days, one New Haven hat designer is thriving nonetheless.

title: RECORD SALES
description: Westchester experienced a surge in residential real-estate activity during the third quarter of this year, with a total of 1,563 residential sales representing $505 million, according to a report by the Westchester Multiple Listing Service, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Westchester County Board of Realtors Inc. This represents a record report of activity by participating realtor firms.

title: 122 IN EAST EUROPE PROCLAIM PRAISE OF HUNGARIAN UPRISING
description: A proclamation extolling the 1956 Hungarian uprising as ''our common heritage and inspiration'' was issued today in Budapest, East Berlin, Prague and Warsaw, along with the names of its 122 prominent Eastern European signers.

title: SEARCHING FOR GOD IN THE NEXT APARTMENT
description: PORTRAIT OF DELMORE Journals and Notes of Delmore Schwartz 1939-1959. Edited, and with an introduction, by Elizabeth Pollet. 663 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35.

title: Old Story for the Bears: Unbeaten and Growling
description: IT was just about a year ago that the Chicago Bears unveiled the latest in appliances, thereby adding another episode to a strange story that would later include an acupuncturist, linebackers that go ''woof, woof,'' a rock video, and, of course, the event that justified everything: a victory in Super Bowl XX.

title: BOSTON WINS SERIES OPENER 1-0, OVER METS
description: The Boston Red Sox shut out the New York Mets in the first game of the World Series last night, 1-0, behind strong pitching by Bruce Hurst.

title: SIX-YEAR WAR POISED AT DEAD CENTER
description: BACK in the fall of 1980, it must have seemed like a good idea to the Iraqi strongman, Saddam Hussein. Revolutionary Iran appeared to be on the ropes, its once-mighty army battered and demoralized from the Islamic upheaval that overthrew the Shah. In command of increasing oil wealth, and what was believed to be the strongest military force in the region, President Hussein had just strengthened himself politically in a bloody purge of his associates. The time seemed perfect to prove that Iraq was tougher than its perennial enemy, Iran.

title: Bolivian Says Americans Will Start Leaving Soon
description: Foreign Minister Guillermo Bedregal of Bolivia said Friday that about 170 American troops involved in an anti-cocaine drive would begin leaving Bolivia next week.

title: Marjorie Merwin Harvey Weds Donald Scott Swift
description: The wedding of Marjorie Merwin Harvey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curran Whitthorne Harvey Jr. of Baltimore, to Donald Scott Swift, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Barr Swift of Basking Ridge, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. David M. Malone performed the ceremony at the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church of Bolton Hill in Baltimore.

title: Richard D. Gibbons Wed To Patricia Allison Weiss
description: Patricia Allison Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry H. Weiss of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Douglas Gibbons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Gibbons of Geneva, N.Y. The Rev. William W. Rogers performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Old First Church in Huntington.

title: A New Chief
description: Daniel F. Sullivan stepped into a big job last week when he was appointed the new Chief of Inspectional Services for the New York City Police Department. That puts him in charge of an office that, among other things, investigates police corruption, of which New York is suffering a periodic rash.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
SEASIDE GOLDENROD
description: Solidago sempervirens Size: One to eight feet. Color: Clusters of bright yellow flowers atop smooth, stout stem with thick, succulent, lance-shaped green leaves.

title: Hurst: Boston's New Ace
description: When the subject turned to hitting, Bruce Hurst forced a weak smile and shrugged innocently. This would not be an appealing post-game topic.

title: Robbery Suspect Is Wounded By Officer on Brooklyn Street
description: A probationary police officer shot a robber in an exchange of gunfire on a Brooklyn street yesterday after the officer, who was off duty, came to the assistance of a friend, authorities said.

title: Big-Time Blues At Big Blue
description: I.B.M.'s earnings dropped 26.5 percent in the third quarter, to $1.08 billion, on a tiny increase in revenues. The big computer manufacturer, which had been sending signals of gloom for months, blamed the drop on slumping sales abroad and at home. The company's stock price, already depressed in anticipation of the earnings report, hit a low of $119.75 after the earnings report. Although the chairman, John F. Akers, tried to play down the dismal performance, most analysts said they do not expect Big Blue to recover before the end of the year, especially because after-tax margins are dropped.

title: BUILDING DRAWERS: 5 PIECES OF WOOD WITH A GRAND DESIGN
description: EVERY homeowner occasionally wishes for some drawers, or more drawers than he or she already has, in a basement, attic, workshop or utility room.

title: THROUGH THE FLAMES ON THIN SOLES
description: DANCING ON MY GRAVE An Autobiography. By Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: Destiny Guides The Red Sox
description: THE Boston Red Sox as a team enjoy a genuine baseball tradition and a longstanding love affair with their fans.

title: Data Update
description: (Source: HSH Associates)*Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: MEDIEVAL ARMOR SHINES IN A WORCESTER MUSEUM
description: At the fringe of this aging industrial city, nestled between a Salvation Army thrift shop and a dilapidated tire company, sits $30 million worth of mostly medieval armor and weapons, housed in an Art Deco building of glass and steel.

title: Gene That Curbs A Form of Cancer
description: Why do some people inherit a tendency to develop cancer while others do not? The answer is one of the many mysteries of genetics, but scientists recently isolated an exciting clue: a gene that blocks the development of one form of cancer.

title: Centralia Deadline Passes
description: The deadline has passed for Centralia residents to participate in a Federal buyout of homes threatened by the toxic gases emitted by a 24-year-old mine fire. Residents had until Wednesday to decide whether to accept the offer or remain in the tiny borough. More than 400 families have agreed to sell their homes to the Government.

title: AGENCIES READY TO HELP ALIENS GET LEGAL STATUS
description: With amnesty to be a key part of the nation's new immigration laws, social service agencies are preparing to help an expected steady stream of illegal aliens who will want to prove their right to remain in the United States.

title: Listening to Berio, THinking of Bartok
description: There is nothing quite like a tiresome piece of music to cut a listener's thoughts free of their moorings. Try to concentrate on the work at hand though it may, the mind insists on furtively slipping away into obscure alleys, like a cat put out at night. My own thoughts took off, willy-nilly, on one of these unplanned excursions the other evening during the New York premiere of Luciano Berio's ''Voci,'' a half-hour piece in one movement that drew on Sicilian folk songs, cunningly disguised or distorted, for its basic construction material. When, after a few desultory minutes, it became evident that Mr. Berio's piece was going nowhere interesting, the uninvited words ''Bela Bartok'' insinuated themselves into my head and would not leave. I understood clearly what drove Poe to write about that nagging raven.

title: Restoring Order to Federal Lending
description: LAST February, in its budget for the fiscal year 1987, the Administration proposed a pilot program to sell to the private sector a selection of loans from the Federal portfolio. Although only $4.4 billion of a total of $257 billion in Federal loans would be sold, the initiative has generated considerable controversy, and not just a little confusion.

title: Polish Navy Wins the Champagne by a Nose
description: Polish Navy dug in through the stretch to regain the lead and outduel Demon's Begone by a nose to win the $337,500 Champagne Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Carr Suffers Burns
description: ANTOINE CARR of the Atlanta Hawks was discharged from Memorial Hospital in Lake Placid, N.Y., yesterday afternoon after receiving treatment for second-degree burns that he suffered on Thursday night in an accident in the bathroom of his hotel room. The 6-foot-9-inch forward from Wichita State, who is beginning his third pro season, stepped unknowingly stepped into a bath tub full of scalding water and suffered severe burns to his right foot and lower leg, acording to Joe O'Toole, the Hawks' trainer.

title: Comings and Goings
description: JOAN BENOIT SAMUELSON, who won the 1984 Olympic Marathon, has been named the winner of the 1986 Abebe Bikila Award for outstanding contributions to long distance running. . . . Wayne Rini, a jockey who is the leading rider at Thistledown race track with 134 victories this year, has been suspended indefinitely for testing positive for cocaine, according to Ohio state racing officials. . . . Oval Jaynes, assistant athletic director at Auburn since 1984, has agreed to terms as the athletic director at Colorado State University. He will receive an annual salary of $78,000 over four years. . . . Carlos Diaz, who was obtained by Los Angeles in a 1983 trade that sent Sid Fernandez to New York, has been released by the Dodgers. This season Diaz, 28, pitched in 19 games without a decision for Los Angeles and had a 1-4 record with Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. ...Chuck Bednarik, the Hall of Fame linebacker and center for the Philadelphia Eagles, has been charged with simple assault stemming from a dispute with a bulldozer operator at a housing development near Bedmarik's home in Allentown, Pa. A hearing is scheduled Nov. 3

title: 239 for Palmer; Temple Wins
description: Paul Palmer, the leader in Division I-A rushing and all-purpose yards, carried 44 times for 239 yards and a touchdown today, and Lee Saltz passed for two more touchdowns as Temple (5-2) routed Virginia Tech (4-2-1), 29-13.

title: ODYSSEUS OF THE GREEK LEFT FEELS BACK 'IN MY ELEMENT'
description: He is as wiry as he appeared in photographs nearly half a century ago, erect and shoulders squared - the man they called a kapetanios, the legendary guerrilla captain Markos Vafiadis.

title: Taylor In Pursuit of His Past Excellence
description: For his first three and a half seasons as a pro, Lawrence Taylor was the best linebacker many football people had ever seen. For the next year and a half - part of 1984 and all of 1985 - he did not seem as sharp, as alert, as dominant, as involved.

title: DON BALL JR.
description: Don Ball Jr., a railway consultant, author and photographer, died Wednesday of a heart attack at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: LEFTISTS' DISPUTE ROILS GREEK VOTE
description: A surprise appeal by the Communist Party to its members not to vote for the governing Socialist Party's candidate for Mayor of Athens in a runoff election on Sunday has turned what was a placid nationwide municipal campaign into a heated race.

title: STUDENT 'AMBASSADORS' RETURN AND REPORT ON MISSIONS ABROAD
description: CHRISTINE AMBROSE and Suzanne Valetutti, who saw Europe last summer in a way few American tourists have, have been reporting back to fellow students and neighbors recently. The two Irvington high school seniors were not on vacation -they were good-will ambassadors representing the people of Irvington, who made their five-week trip possible.

title: 'WHAT ARE WE GOING TO DO ABOUT MOTHER?' IS THE REFRAIN
description: ''I'VE died a thousand deaths this week,'' she says now.

title: 'The Color of Money': Three Men and a Sequel
description: For the novelist Richard Price, the first conference with Paul Newman could have been a scene in a Jim Jarmusch film. ''We were in Malibu - me and Marty Scorsese -the two New York guys on the beach. Marty's sitting there with his jacket and his nasal spray and I was smoking a cigarette, hunched over coughing. And then Newman comes out, all tanned up, Mr. Sea & Ski, eating a grapefruit. It was the two New York clowns with the Hollywood platinum. It was like something out of 'Stranger Than Paradise.' ''

title: MEXICANS LOOK AHEAD: A NEW ORDER, BUT NO REVOLUTION
description: ''When a spoon is dropped in the United States, the bang here is a bombshell,'' said Lorenzo Meyer, professor of history at the College of Mexico in Mexico City. ''We must learn not to magnify what is happening in the United States.''

title: TROOPERS ADD A CLASS TO ACADEMY TO INCREASE FORCE BY 50%
description: THE State Police Academy here has begun a crash program to increase the number of new troopers next year by 50 percent. The program calls for adding one 20-week class, from the present two a year to three overlapping ones.

title: Cynthia Page Cobbs Wed To James Ernest Ludwig
description: Cynthia Page Cobbs, an associate in the public finance division of E. F. Hutton, and James Ernest Ludwig, an associate in municipal finance at Salomon Brothers, both in New York, were married yesterday in Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. John H. Jordan Jr. performed the ceremony at the Galilee Episcopal Church.

title: A CLOUD WITH A ROCK IN IT
description: A MISSING PLANE By Susan Sheehan. Illustrated. 201 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Mets Bats Fail in 1-0 Loss
description: The Mets opened the 83d World Series last night in high style with a crowd of 55,076 jamming Shea Stadium and with the Boston Red Sox fanning a new rivalry between two old cities. But they opened it with one fatal error and no runs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with a Travel article last Sunday on the Auberge de l'Ill in Illhaeusern, France, incorrectly identified a waiter as Jean-Pierre Haeberlin, one of the owners. Mr. Haeberlin was not pictured.

title:
INVESTING;
The Market Whispers 'Recession'
description: WALL STREET - like any marketplace -is simply a group of individuals with different forecasts of the future, which acts on those expectations to establish prices. These days investors seem even more divided than usual about the prospects for the economy. It is on the brink of a rebound, some say. Others contend that it will continue to ''muddle along'' with slow but steady growth.

title: Geneva
description: The lushness of the parks on either side of Lake Geneva is gone, and the jet d'eau, which in summer soars from the water, is mostly dormant. An icy north wind, the bracing bise, makes the Genevois and their guests shiver on some days. Yet the city that hugs the southwestern end of the largest Alpine lake still offers its French atmosphere and cosmopolitan attractions in the colder months.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A BETTER CHANCE In 1963 a nationwide organization was formed by the headmasters of 23 elite preparatory schools to offer minority students from seventh to 10th grade a way out of their limited educational opportunities. A Better Chance Inc. arranges for such students to attend exclusive prep schools on the basis of academic merit, personal motivation and promise.

title: EUROPEAN INFLUENCE EXPLORED
description: BRIDGEPORT'S Museum of Art, Science and Industry marks the city's 150th anniversary with its most ambitious undertaking to date.

title: Robert S. Bryan Weds Miss Doll
description: Lauren T. Doll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Doll of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Scott Bryan, a son of Marion Weed and Justin Bryan, both of Dallas. The Rev. Dr. David Randolph performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in New York.

title: GIDEON AND TALMA AT 80- COMPOSERS AND NEIGHBORS
description: ''That's New York for you,''

title: Yale Overwhelms Columbia by 47-0
description: Columbia returned today to the site of its last victory three years ago, hopeful that perhaps the hallowed Yale Bowl could turn out to be a good-luck charm.

title: Dual-Use Properties Affected
description: While the new federal tax coed retains the benefits of owning primary and secondary property, it has complex effects on such properties when owners combine personal use with renting.

title: Joan N. Scerbo Wed To Richard A. Conti
description: Joan N. Scerbo, the daughter of Frances Scerbo of New York and the late Tullio Scerbo, was married yesterday to Richard A. Conti, the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Edward Conti of Mahwah, N.J. Msgr. Andrew Cusack performed the ceremony at the St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SMALL CLAIMS. By Jill Ciment. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $14.95.) Fresh Youth storms the Big City to make it as Artist: recently, short stories have teemed with gullible waifs transported to the metropolis.

title: THE LOST AGE OF INNOCENCE
description: ''MOMMY, what does gay mean?''

title: SOVIET ENDS SECRECY ON GRAIN
description: The Soviet Union has published figures on the size of the grain harvest for 1985, after five years of withholding information on the annual grain crop.

title: DROUGHT IN INDIA DISRUPTS MIGRATION OF BIRDS
description: A drought at India's best-known bird sanctuary will disrupt the annual migration of tens of thousands of Siberian cranes and other birds that travel vast distances to their winter abodes, according to a wildlife official.

title: Alabama Trounces Tennessee
description: Bobby Humphrey had 3 touchdowns and ran for 217 yards, third best in Alabama history, as the second-ranked Crimson Tide crushed Tennessee, 56-28, in a Southeastern Conference game today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE FISHER KING. By Anthony Powell. (Norton, $15.95.) Having completed his masterwork, ''A Dance to the Music of Time,'' and his memoirs, ''To Keep the Ball Rolling,'' Anthony Powell returns in his new novel to the pattern of his earliest fiction.

title: FILM DEATHS WITNESS SAYS HE WARNED OF DANGER
description: A fire safety officer who was on the set of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' has testified that he told his supervisor before a helicopter crashed and killed three people that he ''felt certain'' that disaster was imminent.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
A & E Is Trying to Broaden Its Image
description: In a sense, Arts & Entertainment is suffering from half an identity crisis. For its regular screenings of opera, ballet, classical music and drama, A&E; has become well established as a purveyor of cultural fare. But nowadays the cable service is after something different - for viewers to be more mindful of the second half of its name.

title: ROAD CREWS TAKE A HILL APART, SLIVER BY SLIVER
description: ''WHAT we did was take a hill and slice half of it away.''

title: Robert MacNeil's English
description: To the Editor:

title: A Doubly Effective Birth-Control Pill
description: The search for a ''morning-after'' birth-control pill has yielded a variation - it might be called a ''few-weeks-after'' pill - that should be marketed in France within a year, the World Health Organization says.

title: Debra Livingston Wed to S. J. Massey
description: Debra Ann Livingston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston of Flemington, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen J. Massey, a son of Gertrude Massey of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late W. Franklin Massey. The Rev. Dr. Thomas DeVenny, the bride's uncle and a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: OF 'PARADISE' AND JOHN MORTIMER
description: A sense of theater makes life's trials and obscenities bearable, and no one demonstrated this more literally than John Mortimer the writer when he was John Mortimer the barrister, burdened with defending alleged pornographers not too long ago in serving as one of England's senior public service lawyers, roughly akin to the American public defender. For the man who gave the television viewer the pleasure of Rumpole of the Bailey and ''Brideshead Revisited'' also gave the real-life voyeur the comfort of the Aversion Theory.

title: Kindness in Ghent
description: To the Editor: Inspired by the $99 fare on People Express, my wife and I flew to Belgium for eight days in February. Half of our stay was in ''Two Flemish Cities Prized by Kings'' (Travel, Sept. 7).

title: Using 'Conservation Triage' to Save Open Space
description: FROM the narrow footpath of the Appalachian Trail, the meadow is a golden bowl of wildflowers and grass stretching to the hills, a scene that is becoming increasingly rare in Garrison, N.Y., 50 miles from Times Square.

title: TOWN RALLIES TO HELP KIN OF JAILED FLIER
description: While the family of Eugene Hasenfus, the American flier captured in Nicaragua, struggles to rebuild its peaceful rural life, much of this quiet northeast Wisconsin community has plunged in to help.

title: SUMMIT PHOTOS DELAY TIME AND NEWSWEEK
description: Though editors at both Time and Newsweek magazines approved costly publication delays last week to include final developments in the Iceland summit meeting, Time came out dramatically ahead in the picture department.

title: AT 50, TYING UP THOSE LOOSE ENDS
description: A FEW days ago a balloon-bouquet arrived. The delivery man smiled when I said, ''Oh, it's for me.''

title: THE VISION OF MONETA SLEET IN SHOW
description: FOR 35 years Moneta J. Sleet Jr. has been working all over the world as a photojournalist, taking pictures of places and people - ordinary people and superstars, leaders and followers - and the universal reaction from his living subjects is that ''Sleet'' is a gentle man.

title: LINCOLN BRIGADE IS BACK ON BATTLEFIELD
description: It was, for many of them, the last crusade, the last time a volunteer army of civilians went to war for a cause, and as they stood on the sweeping plains of this battle site here today eyes welled with tears.

title:
DINING OUT;
REGIONAL CUISINE IN CROTON
description: IT seems that every other restaurant that opens these days flies the banner of regional American cuisine. Even some unabashedly international places have succumbed to temptation and have loaded their menus with catchwords such as blackened red fish, Cajun and mesquite. Certainly, with food as with most things, if it's good enough, one can have it every day without risk of surfeit; however, as with other dishes, sometimes these trendy American regionals turn out to be intriguingly delicious, sometimes little more than unworthy imitations.

title: Mical Z. Atz Wed To James Brenzel
description: Mical Z. Atz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Atz of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to James R. Brenzel, a son of Norma Brenzel of Kaukauna. Wis., and the late Russel Brenzel. The ceremony was performed by Leonard Cherlin, an American Humanist minister, at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Town Settles a Dispute With >a >Police >Couple
description: Two police officers who moved into an apartment together while one was still married can continue working, under an agreement with the Board of Selectmen, the couple's attorney said.

title: 'American Made'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Statement Of Elegant Simplicity
description: EVEN THOSE smug people who claim they can guess the designer of a home just by walking through the front door would be baffled. In the entrance, for example, the grandest decoration is an assemblage of 18th- and 19th-century walking sticks that are topped with a variety of handles - swans and skulls, dogs and monkeys -meticulously carved from wood or ivory. Their presence is particularly noticeable against the bare wood floors and cream-colored walls, on which only a few well-placed engravings and drawings hang. The setting is highly personal - far more a journal of the couple who live in this Manhattan apartment than a showcase for David Easton, the designer who helped pull together a lifetime of lovingly collected objects.

title: New York City's Assets
description: Hooray for Robert Price's article ''The Good News About New York City'' (Sept. 28). There is too little praising and too much decrying of our city nowadays.

title:
GARDENING;
SUMACS ARE COLORFUL OPTIONS IN THE FALL
description: WHETHER one considers the sumacs useful in the garden or, for that matter, finds them attractive at all, will depend upon one's concept of gardening.

title: Where to Go After the Show: Vienna
description: Vienna is a city of music lovers and theatergoers, and it shows: Posters pasted to the cylindrical billboards at street corners advertise nightly performances by the Vienna Staatsoper, the Volksoper, the Burgtheater, the Vienna Philharmonic. Soberly dressed musicians scurry through the streets on their way to rehearsals, unwieldy instrument cases under their arms; singers with scarves carefully folded around their throats sip lemon tea in the coffeehouses, and pallid actors pore over their scripts in the Cafe Landtmann next to the Burgtheater. At the coffeehouse in the newly restored Secession Building, symbol of the Wiener Werkstatte and such artists as Kokoschka and Klimt, performances as well as paintings will be earnestly discussed over late-morning coffee. In early evening people in formal dress can be seen disentangling themselves from taxis, the women with their long skirts sweeping the streets as they make their way to the opera.

title: Fueling Approved At Seabrook Plant
description: Citing its ruling on the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island, the Federal Goverment gave permission last week for New Hampshire's Seabrook plant to load radioactive fuel and begin low-power tests.

title: ABZUG VS. DIOGUARDI: A BATTLE FOR THE CENTER
description: With two weeks to go before Election Day, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, a freshman Republican from Westchester, and his challenger, former Representative Bella S. Abzug, are locked in a spirited battle for the political middle ground.

title: THE STAGE: 'LAS DAMAS MODERNAS'
description: SEEING the Cuban 1920's take the stage in Spanish, under the sympathetic ministrations of the Repertorio Espanol, it is hard to believe that Eduardo Machado wrote ''Las Damas Modernas de Guanabacoa'' in English, the language in which it made its debut as ''The Modern Ladies of Guanabacoa'' at the Ensemble Studio Theater in 1983.

title: Celebrating the Signing, Exhibiting Past Grandeur
description: Constitutional Rejoicing In Philadelphia

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption with the Travel Advisory column on Oct. 5 incorrectly identified a prehistoric cave painting. It was from the caves near Niaux in France.
