title: FIVE POETS TO GIVE READINGS IN A SERIES
description: THE Poet's Voice will begin its 10th season today with Stephen Dunn, an award-winning poet and a professor of creative writing, reading from his works at the Darien Library.

title: Discount Air Fares on Short Notice
description: Now you see it, now you don't. Such has been the case recently with a number of brief air-fare reductions offered in efforts to fill seats that otherwise would probably remain unsold. The reductions have appeared and disappeared abruptly, without advance notice to the public and often with little notice to travel agents. They have given impulse travelers an advantage over those who do what most airlines normally encourage: reserve and pay for their tickets as far in advance as possible and avoid any changes.

title: Raiders File Suit
description: THE Los Angeles Raiders have filed a $26 million suit in Superior Court in Salinas against the city of Oakland, Calif., alleging the team lost that amount in a six-year wrangle after electing to move from Oakland to southern California.

title: R. A. O'Brien Marries Miss Monaghan
description: Stephanie Catherine Maria Monaghan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis G. Monaghan of Centerville, Mass., was married yesterday to Richard Andrew O'Brien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. O'Brien of Corning, N.Y. The Rev. Raymond Rafferty, the Roman Catholic chaplain at New York University, from which the bride received a law degree, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Church in Centerville.

title: New Milford
description: ALTHOUGH the growing Bergen County Borough of New Milford is only 15 minutes from the George Washington Bridge, it is so little-known that residents still place it for outsiders by saying it is just north or Teaneck or a bit west of Paramus.

title: THE ENVIRONEMNT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection has raised the stakes in its effort to force a cleanup of ground-water contamination at the site of International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. in Union Beach, Monmouth County.

title: TRACING MARCOS'S MILLIONS
description: THE race by the Philippine Government's New Jersey lawyers to untangle the financial web spun throughout the state by Ferdinand E. Marcos, the country's deposed leader, almost faltered on its first day in court for want of a gold seal with red ribbons.

title: Meeting of Minds on Boston Arms
description: IT was 3 o'clock in the afternoon, some five and one-half hours before the start of the first game of the 1986 World Series, and Davey Johnson still hadn't changed into his baseball uniform. No rush. Sitting behind his desk, wearing a white short-sleeve shirt with a Mets' insignia on the pocket, he was conducting a meeting of his cabinet.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes
description: The Thing Produced by Howard Hawks. Starring Kenneth Tobey and James Arness. 1951. RKO Home Video. 80 minutes. $29.95

title: P.J. Ingrassia Wed To Lynn Del Duca
description: Lynn Del Duca, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Del Duca of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul J. Ingrassia, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Ingrassia of Garden City, L.I. Msgr. John Nolan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: 100 Volunteer to Take 9-Year-Old AIDS Victim
description: State officials said they were reluctant to make a televised appeal for a foster home for a 9-year-old AIDS victim, but were flooded with calls and now think the effort will pay off.

title: R.G. McCollum Jr. Weds Tibby Allen
description: Lainey Tibbetts Allen, a daughter of Lainey Patterson Allen of Darien, Conn., and John Carlin Allen of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Green McCollum Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. McCollum of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Alice Farquhar-Mayes performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Luke's Parish in Darien.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE 1. Nicaraguan Report: Vote on a resolution calling for President Reagan to report to Congress on the downing of the Nicaraguan rebel supply plane. Rejected 50 to 47, Oct. 16.

title: Susan Strandberg Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Salant Strandberg, the daughter of the late Robert S. Salant and the late Margaret Brownell Salant, was married yesterday to John R. Wierdsma, the son of Frederick R. Wierdsma of Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Nathan Allen. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Johns of Lattingtown Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: TOPICS
description: MY favorite possessions are useless and frivolous. One is a Chinese lamp of intricately carved green alabaster, although I like to think of it as jade.

title: THE OFFICIAL VIEW ON ICELAND IS STILL CHILLY, BUT THAWING
description: ''MANY people have asked why I seemed and looked so tired and disappointed immediately after the meeting ended in Reykjavik,'' a smiling and relaxed Secretary of State George P. Shultz told a National Press Club audience Friday. ''The answer is simple. I was tired and disappointed.''

title: A CLOSE CONTEST FOR ASSEMBLY
description: A CLOSELY contested race among two political newcomers - the Republican Joseph A. Rauso, a county engineer, and the Democrat Terence M. Zaleski, a lawyer - is shaping up in Yonkers for the State Assembly seat held by the Republican Nicholas A. Spano.

title: THE CENTURY OF THE STREET
description: THE CITY AS A WORK OF ART London, Paris, Vienna. By Donald J. Olsen. Illustrated. 341 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: Condo For Crafts
description: It is no longer unusual for cultural institutions to turn up in large office towers. But most of the time they are the poor stepchildren of rich corporations, given some leftover space in new skyscrapers. It is not pure philanthropy that puts them there, but city zoning laws that allow real-estate developers to make their new towers all the bigger if they give over some space to a worthy cultural institution.

title: In Boston, Red Sox Inspire Fanaticism
description: Like their Calvinist ancestors who believed they were predestined for failure, fatalistic Red Sox fans worried all summer that their team would collapse once again. After all, the last time the Red Sox won the World Series, the United States was fighting Kaiser Wilhelm in World War I. The Patriots might have improbably emerged from years of obscurity to go to the Super Bowl last winter, and the Celtics might have won the National Basketball Association championship another time. But the Sox, Boston's oldest and most cherished sports team, were haunted by the specter of disaster.

title:
A MUSEUM WITH NEW ANSWERS, AND OLD QUESTIONS;
...But Is It Art?
description: The opening next Sunday of the American Craft Museum's new building begs the resurrection of an old issue - the always tenuous relationship of craft to art. This is a thorny question, one which has obsessed craftsmen for decades. Painfully aware of their sub-artist status, relegated to the pages of craft journals, and generally shunned by galleries and museums, they have often assumed a militant stance in seeking to force their way into the charmed circle of the ''fine arts.'' While this can be a tiresome debate, an effective distinction can be made between the essentially intellectual approach that many 20th-century artists have applied to objects, and the more sensual handling of materials that has preoccupied craftsmen.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS TO CONVERSE HERE
description: ''THE same action we take for crack,'' said Theresa Murphy, a social worker and White Plains resident, ''we need to take for the homeless. I truly believe that when we talk about the increases in drug use, illiteracy and crime, we're talking about the demise of the family and the demoralizing effects of being homeless.''

title: THE LOST ART OF TRUE RELAXATION
description: RELAXATION is a lost art these days. And I've come to the conclusion that it truly is an art. With the proper diligence, time and necessary will, it can be acquired and even perfected.

title: Cable TV
description: For fans of science fiction, the week ahead could have been concocted by an alchemist: four significant science-fiction movies - one of them a successful venture into the genre, two respectable tries that fall on either side of the dividing line between worthwhile and disappointing, and a fourth that seems to have gone completely haywire.

title: Q AND A
description: Texas Air Question:Will Texas Air honor vouchers issued by People Express to passengers bumped from flights if the merger of the two companies is approved? Will the vouchers be honored if People Express is liquidated? - E. P., Westport, Conn. Answer:The Texas Air Corporation, which hopes to take over People Express this fall, says that so long as People Express exists, its vouchers will be honored on its routes. An official of Texas Air, a holding company that owns Continental Airlines and New York Air - and is in the process of acquiring Eastern Airlines - said that if the takeover is approved, it intends to retain People's identity for a year. During that time People will honor its vouchers. No decision, the spokesman said, has been made on what the status of those vouchers will be when Texas Air carries out its eventual intention of merging People with one of its own airlines.

title: HARD TIMES IN MEXICO CAUSE CONCERN IN U.S.
description: Economic troubles and other problems in Mexico appear to be severe enough that the United States must worry about the possibility of social unrest and political instability there, according to American experts in and out of Government and Mexican officials and scholars.

title: TOWNSHIP GAINS 2 COUNTRY DOCTORS
description: It took a while, but the result was doubly sweet. After looking for a country doctor for 20 years, Maurice River Township got two.

title: THREE FAVORITES STAND UP WELL
description: LETTERS to this column criticizing restaurants generally focus on one major complaint - disappointing service. Anyone who dines out recognizes how important flawless service is to the enjoyment of a meal. Superb food can be overshadowed by slipshod or rude service. Conversely, average food is often salvaged by superior service, turning an ordinary meal into a memorable dining experience.

title: TROUBLING LEGACY IN MOUNT KISCO: A PARK OR PARKING
description: WHEN Laura Flewellyn, an elementary-school teacher for 62 years, wrote her will at the age of 89, she thought she was making it iron-clad.

title: Jazz
description: New York jazz fans would do well to discover Mario Rivera, the virtuoso saxophonist from the Dominican Republic who is leading his band, the Salsa Refugees, Wednesday at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street. On baritone, tenor and alto saxophone, not to mention flute, Mr. Rivera is a marvel; his playing is articulate, passionate and full of surprises, in Latin-jazz performances that are never routine. Mr. Rivera is fluent in be-bop, and his ballads have an unabashed romanticism; with the Salsa Refugees behind him, Mr. Rivera can also spin full-toned, propulsive solos over the galloping rhythms of the Dominican merengue.

title: Acoustics And Burnout
description: Will Crutchfield's well-reasoned lament for the early demise of great operatic voices accurately portrays the urge toward self-destruction that afflicts many of today's potential operatic superstars (''Vocal Burnout at the Opera,'' Sept. 21). One point, however, seems to have eluded him: the fact that American opera houses tend, for the most part, to be built just about twice too large for the entertainment they are supposed to hold; compare the 3,800-seat Met, for example, with the 1,700-or-so-seat major European houses, and you'll see the problem.

title: A First-Hand Tale Of Second-Hand Municipal Bribery
description: The Parking Violations Bureau corruption trial in Federal District Court in New Haven moved through its third week with tales of payoffs, including a used television set and money exchanged in bathrooms, favoritism shown to a company accused of making payoffs and, for the first time, testimony directly connecting a bribe-giver with an alleged bribe-taker.

title:
GARDENING;
SUMACS ARE COLORFUL OPTIONS IN THE FALL
description: WHETHER one considers the sumacs useful in the garden or, for that matter, finds them attractive at all, will depend upon one's concept of gardening.

title: FEAR OF DRUGS PROMPTS PARK RENEWAL
description: Addressing an anti-crack rally in Washington Square Park yesterday, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern told about 150 Greenwich Village residents that the park would close this week for renovations as part of an effort to rid it of drug dealers.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Grand Opening In Philadelphia

title: Mailbox; A Red Sox Fan Feels Vindicated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A ROSE IS A ROSE: EXCEPT, OF COURSE, IN ACADEMIA
description: THESE are lean times in English departments. Teaching loads are heavy, and grant monies are unavailable. To fatten things up, though, would be easy. There is gold in mortars and pestles, and all that has to be done is change English Department to Literary Sciences.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes
description: Emmet Kelly Jr.'s Circus Directed by Thomas V. Grasso Best Film & Video. 60 minutes. 9.95

title: Miss Lenox Wed To Thomas Craig
description: Jennifer Christine Lenox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Lenox of Akron, Ohio, was married yesterday to Thomas Craig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Craig of Washington. The Rev. Joanne Swenson performed the Congregational ceremony at the Old South Church in Boston.

title: Putting the World in a Brush and the Self in Ink and Paper
description: Calligraphy is an art form and an example. It is a discipline in which painting, poetry and philosophy work together. Its success depends upon trust and control, patience and performance, spontaneity and theory. If calligraphy is regarded in China and Japan as the supreme artistic achievement, it is in part because of the conviction that the whole world can be channeled into a brush and the whole self can be cast in ink on paper.

title: WAS COMMUNISM AN AFTERTHOUGHT?
description: FIDEL A Biography of Fidel Castro. By Peter G. Bourne. Illustrated. 332 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $18.95.

title: Namecalling
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME KINGS OF THE HILL BOW TO TIME, AMBITION
description: THE end of every Congress closes another chapter in American political history. Old members leave, new members arrive, the page turns. But this fall the lawmakers who are concluding their careers on Capitol Hill are an extraordinary group, including some of the major figures of their generation: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who holds the record for the longest consecutive tenure as Speaker; Senator Barry Goldwater, the Republican presidential candidate in 1964, and Senator Russell B. Long, for many years the nation's most influential voice on tax policy.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE COST-CUTTING
description: AMERICAN companies are casting as sharp an eye on their costs as on their markets these days. Not only are they trying to squeeze the last ounce of concessions out of their suppliers on prices and payment terms, but they are even attacking such once-sacrosanct items as executive expense accounts.

title: Turning Your Home Into a Credit Card
description: THE home equity loan, a low-cost line of credit with growing appeal for borrowers, was given a big lift by the new tax bill.

title: A FORMER CONVENT TO HOUSE PREGNANT TEEN-AGERS
description: MELISSA DOLPH is 18 years old, nine months pregnant and homeless.

title: CONDUCTING PRIVATE WARS IS A CRIMINAL ACTIVITY
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPEDIENT GAME PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandburg
description: To the Editor: As a biographer of Carl Sandburg who got her start at Connemara, his Flat Rock, N. C. home, I am pleased that George McMillan's article (Travel, Sept. 21) introduces many of your readers to that lovely place.

title: WALL STREET'S TOMORROW MACHINE
description: ONLY 18 years ago, a sudden swamp of orders -upwards of 16 million shares a day - forced the nation's major stock exchanges to close every Wednesday, for weeks, to catch up on paperwork. Today, with computers ubiquitous on Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange alone handles 10 times that trading volume with ease.

title: Tempers Rise On Rikers Island
description: Outbreaks among prisoners and guards in the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island last week underscored tensions that have risen as overcrowding in city jails reached its worst level in 13 years.

title: COHALAN RACE HEADS KEY COURT CONTESTS
description: THE future of Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and one of the ranking judges on Long Island, Justice Leon Lazer of State Supreme Court, will be decided in unusually significant judicial elections Nov. 4.

title: Stevens Remains Undefeated
description: J. P. Stevens (4-0), ignited by Joe Rigg's 90-yard punt return for a touchdown in the first quarter, cruised to a 34-13 victory over Perth Amboy in Perth Amboy. Stevens, winner of 16 in a row, was also led by Joe Catena, who scored on runs of 1 and 37 yards, and Ray Patricco, who hit Tony Mayers with scoring passes of 3 and 38 yards.

title: Robin Schreiner Becomes Bride of David Selig Kroll
description: Robin Beth Schreiner, an account executive for Palmetto Enterprises, a clothing manufacturer, and David Selig Kroll, a buyer for Lord & Taylor, both in New York, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers. Rabbi Brooks Susman performed the ceremony.

title: SEOUL SAID TO PLEDGE CRACKDOWN ON DISSIDENTS
description: The Government was reported today to have pledged a crackdown on leftist dissidents.

title: FILM EDITING GOES ELECTRONIC
description: A NEW generation of electronic editing is edging its way into movie-making. A combination of video recorders and computers, the new systems do not change what audiences see. But behind the screens, they are altering how a handful of movies and an armload of television shows are made.

title: A Sneak Attack on Social Policy
description: WHEN Congress passed the mindless Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law, many of its supporters proclaimed that it was ''a bad idea whose time has come.'' Now one bad idea has spawned another: the huge sale of Federal loan assets as the primary way to meet the requirements of Gramm-Rudman.

title: TENSIONS AT RIKERS: COMPLEX CAUSES
description: Prisoner uprisings on Rikers Island, a sprawling and formidable complex in the East River, have erupted periodically over the years, then receded, only to surge again.

title: WHAT THE PRESS DOES WHEN THE GOVERNMENT LIES
description: To the Editor:

title: German Doctors and the Nazi Mentality
description: Professor Lifton cites the extermination camps of Chelmno, Belzec, Sobibor and Treblinka as closely resembling ''euthanasia killing centers in their use of stationary gas chambers.''

title: SHOULD PENN SOUTH CO-OPS GO PRIVATE?
description: JUDITH WEISS lives in a sun-filled, fifth-floor apartment overlooking Chelsea, a neighborhood that seems to gain in chic by the day. In addition to a sprawling bedroom, eat-in kitchen and living room large enough to double as office space, the apartment has a terrace just above the treetops, where Ms. Weiss sometimes takes her meals.

title: Reagan Ask Citizens to Vote
description: President Reagan, saying that he and his wife had already cast absentee ballots for the election Nov. 4, urged citizens today to ''show that you care about America's future and get out and vote.''

title: TO WASHINGTON, PASSING CLEVELAND
description: WHILE Governor Cuomo's re-election strategy seems to be to pretend there is no campaign, his well-financed political organization knows better. There is indeed a campaign, a feverish one, and it is against the late Grover Cleveland, the 22d and 24th President of the United States.

title: Laura Valentine, a Model, Marries Robert Ammirati
description: At the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday, Laura Valentine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Valentine of Leavenworth, Wash., was married to Robert Ammirati, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ammirati of New York and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Gregory performed the ceremony.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TEAPOTS IN NORTHAMPTON Teapots are the object of an exhibit opening Saturday at 4 P.M. with a reception at the Clay Gallery of Pinch Pottery, in Northampton, Mass., and continuing through Dec. 20.

title: Frederick Arnold Weds Janine Ducoin in Paris
description: Janine Ducoin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Emmanuel Ducoin of Paris, was married yesterday to Frederick Arnold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Arnold of White Plains. The Rev. Jean Paul Cazes performed a Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Maurice de Becon in Courbevoie-Becon in Paris immediately after a civil ceremony at the Courbevoie City Hall in Paris.

title: DON'T BLAME THE JAPANESE
description: LATE LAST MONTH, WHILE THE Finance Committee of the United States Senate was hammering out a bill intended to reduce America's huge trade deficit, that American folk hero Lee Iacocca endeavored to enlighten a Texas audience on the annoying complexities of international trade. The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, who in 1981 loudly supported ''voluntary'' quotas on Japanese cars that altogether cost American car buyers an estimated $11 billion last year, observed: ''It's not Japan's fault if we want to be a doormat. They're going to take advantage of us -and why not?''

title: BETTING BELIEVED ON RISE
description: COMPULSIVE gambling has been called a social illness that strikes the rich and poor, men and women, with no regard for age or background, and psychiatric and social experts involved in controlling it say that if educational programs and funds to combat it are not increased, it may soon become epidemic in New Jersey.

title: PENSION-FUND DIVESTITURE PLAN DEEPENS RIFT BETWEEN KOCH AND COMPTROLLER
description: A proposal that the city's largest public-employee pension fund divest its holdings in American banks that lend money to South African banks has divided Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, longtime political adversaries.

title: SELF-SERVE GAS STIRRING A DISPUTE
description: Citing a lack of employees and a wide discrepancy in gasoline prices, a number of service station owners in the Town of East Hampton are urging the Town Board to repeal a law banning self-serve gas stations.

title: MCKINNEY FACES A VIGOROUS CHALLENGE
description: THE Connecticut Congressional race drawing the most outside visitors these days is in Fairfield County, where an eight-term Republican veteran, Representative Stewart B. McKinney, is being challenged by State Representative Christine M. Niedermeier, a Fairfield Democrat.

title: Partisan Wrangles Delay Power Swap In Israeli Cabinet
description: Given the rumbustious nature of Israeli politics, the delay in transferring the Prime Minister's office from one faction to another was not surprising.

title: A JAZZMAN OUT TO SAVE BIG-BAND SOUND
description: KEN MACDONALD came of age in the mid-1950's, but he refused to rock-and-roll.

title: Defenses Star in Florida's Victory Over Rutgers
description: From the last play of last year's game in Gainesville, Fla., to the opening kickoff of today's game at Giants Stadium, Florida had awaited its rematch with Rutgers with a sense of revenge.

title: A Nobel Mix
description: The winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, James M. Buchanan, has combined economics and politics in unorthodox ways. In developing his public choice theory, an attempt to explain the economic reasons behind political decisions, Mr. Buchanan risked the wrath of both disciplines. Described by colleagues and former students at George Mason University as a serious, dedicated but intimidating scholar, Mr. Buchanan will, with the prize, likely gain loyalty and legitimacy in skeptics' eyes.

title: Of Smoking And Pregnancy
description: CITING medical evidence that babies born to mothers who smoke are usually smaller than normal, two obstetricians in Pennsylvania offered $100 discounts in January to patients who quit smoking during pregnancy.

title: SUNDAY SHOPPING: A WAY OF LIFE FOR MILLIONS
description: Ten years ago, the big New York department stores began a hotly debated policy of opening on Sundays. Within weeks, they were joined by thousands of smaller retailers in the city and region, many of them reluctant but swept up by competitive pressures. Since then, weekend life in New York and its suburbs has never been quite the same.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A television listing today in The Guide, section 2A, refers to ''The Africans,'' a co-production of WETA in Washington and the BBC.

title: A New Attack On Death Penalty
description: In the decade's broadest challenge to the death penalty, the evidence is statistical but the allegation profound: that Georgia punishes killers of whites more harshly than killers of blacks.

title: Eagleton's Farewell
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, a Missouri Democrat who is retiring this month after 18 years in the Senate and 30 in public office, has decided to trade politics for the academic life.

title: CALCULUS OR POTATO SALAD? CHOICES FOR THE JOB
description: WHEN my 9-year-old returned last month from his first day of school as a fourth grader, he announced that his first homework assignment was to write a short story entitled ''What I Did on My Summer Vacation.''

title: REGAN CHALLENGES BADILLO'S DEALINGS WITH PUERTO RICAN HOTEL
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has demanded that his Democratic opponent, Herman Badillo, disclose details of his involvement, while a state official, with a hotel corporation that bought a formerly bankrupt hotel-casino in Puerto Rico.

title:
ANTIQUES;
3 TALKS ON AMERICAN STAINED GLASS
description: FOR the last 51 years, without subsidies or financial patronage beyond the support of its membership, the Antique Club of New Jersey has been fulfilling a commitment to the furtherance of education in antiques.

title: Ken McFeeley Is Dead; Led City Police Union
description: Ken McFeeley, former president of the Patrolmen's Benvolent Association in New York City, died of lung cancer yesterday in Mid-Island Hospital in Bethpage, L.I. He was 47 years old and lived in Bethpage.

title: Martha Schreiber Is Wed To Duncan Kimber Smith
description: The First Congregational Church in Essex, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Martha Ann Schreiber, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Schreiber of Old Saybrook, Conn., and Duncan Kimber Smith, a son of Gabrielle Smith of East Hampton, L.I., and the late Kimber Smith.

title:
GARDENING;
SUMACS ARE COLORFUL OPTIONS IN THE FALL
description: WHETHER one considers the sumacs useful in the garden or, for that matter, finds them attractive at all, will depend upon one's concept of gardening.

title: Hitting Slump Is Puzzling
description: A bad omen for the Mets: The St. Louis Cardinals led the National League in hitting last year with a .264 average, then batted .185 in the World Series and lost to the Kansas City Royals.

title: Alicia de Larrocha: Beethoven With Poetry and Power
description: However insistently artists may try to avoid being typecast, it is almost inevitable that their particular repertory specialties emerge as the labels by which we most readily identify them, often to the exclusion of music they play equally well. We think of the Spanish pianist Alicia de Larrocha, for instance, primarily as the most eloquent advocate of the music of her countrymen, and secondarily as a graceful Mozartean with respectable sidelines in Scarlatti and Bach. Yet her concert repertory has always included a broad selection of the standard Romantic solo works and concertos, and among those, the Beethoven concertos have long been close to her heart. In New York alone, she has performed these works with the New York Philharmonic, the Y Chamber Symphony, the Brooklyn Philharmonic and at Mostly Mozart; and in 1979, she played all five here as a soloist with the visiting Pittsburgh Symphony. Strangely, the only evidence of her Beethoven on disk, until now, was an ''Emperor'' Concerto with Zubin Mehta and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, released the same year as her Pittsburgh series.

title: 2 LAROUCHE ACCOUNTS ARE SEIZED IN FRAUD CASE
description: An elderly widow who says she was defrauded of $60,000 by followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has won a Federal District Court order seizing the money of two groups tied to the political conspiracy theorist.

title: BERGEN KEEPS A SHARP EYE ON SCALES
description: THE design on the belt buckle that James A. Pollock wears - it shows the scales of justice - is doubly significant: Not only has Mr. Pollock been involved with law enforcement all his adult life, but he is, as the Bergen County Superintendent of Weights and Measures, much concerned about scales as well.

title: A RETURN TO THE OLD REPERTORY
description: WHEN Igor Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps'' received its premiere in Paris in 1913, the audience reacted by rioting. Nowadays, the wild rhythms and harsh sounds are ''willingly accepted and admired,'' according to the Harvard Dictionary of Music.

title: Australia Sees Rough Sailing
description: It has taken two weeks of intense competition for the 13 challengers in the America's Cup trial races to sort out the best and worst among them.

title: The Ghosts of Many Lands
description: CLOWNS, BALLERINAS and spacemen dart feverishly from one house to the next, gleefully amassing their booty. Grimacing jack-o'-lanterns stand sentry, guarding against evil spirits. It is, obviously, Halloween, a night of revelry and costume for American youths that is woven from the pagan, Christian and seasonal traditions of many lands.

title: NOMINEES FOR OREGON GOVERNOR IN CLOSE RACE
description: Norma Paulus and Neil Goldschmidt appear to be locked in one of Oregon's closest races for governor in modern times.

title: MUSIC: CONCERTS EXPLORE PIANO TRANSCRIPTION
description: PIANO transcriptions of orchestral works were common in the 19th century: before the age of recordings, they were the best way one could hear such music in the home. Today, such reductions might seem anachronistic, but curiously there was been a revival of them in recent years - especially Liszt's versions of Beethoven's symphonies, which have received numerous recordings.

title: Why Successful Exposures Are Often Elusive
description: IN this era of automatic-exposure cameras, you would think that exposure problems would have gone the way of the adding machine. But photographers continue to open their envelopes and boxes of processed film with trepidation, fearful that somehow the results will be off the mark.

title: DATA BANK: OCTOBER 19, 1986
People Express Sale Moves Ahead
description: When it agreed last month to be acquired by Texas Air Corporation, People Express Inc., the prototypical ''no-frills'' airline, was flying planes half-full, and losses were rapidly mounting. Having led the way to lower fares, leaner costs and aggressive competition, People fell victim, at least in part, to its own success.

title: Another Tragedy In San Salvador
description: ''We have lived through two conflicts: the war and now this,'' Trinidad Diaz said last week as she watched neighbors search the rubble for relatives buried in the earthquake that struck San Salvador nine days ago.

title: Running Back Lifts Long Beach
description: The Long Beach Marines, new to Nassau County Conference I, surprised Massapequa with a 29-6 rout yesterday. In the process, the Long Beach running back, Scott Graham, gained more than 200 yards for the third time this season.

title: Prescription, Yes; Contraceptive, No
description: The New York City Board of Education tried to hammer out a policy on birth control in the schools last week, but ended up tacking together a stopgap compromise instead. The state-financed health clinics operating in nine city high schools may continue to issue prescriptions for contraceptive pills and devices for six months, while the issue undergoes further review, but may not distribute the contraceptives themselves.

title: THE TERROR: WHY FRANCE? WHY NOW?
description: A suspicion, insidious and disturbing, began to spread among the French not long after the bomb attacks had begun to produce nearly daily scenes of carnage on Parisian streets. It was clear for all to see that France was convulsed by a new kind of war, waged by a mysterious and skillful band of Middle Eastern terrorists, and aimed at sowing panic. More puzzling was a simple question: Why France? Why had France, long the most friendly of all the major Western countries to the Arab cause, suddenly become the chief target of Middle Eastern terrorism?

title: Next Week; What Do The Knicks And Nets Need?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: THE BATTLE OVER DRUG TESTING
description: ALL OVER AMERICA, THE scenario is being acted out with increasing frequency.

title: Reporting From Moscow
description: The picture of the ''uniformed Russian'' vexed by the American who took his picture ill served an excellent article.

title: CALIFORNIA SENATE RACE REFLECTS ELECTRONIC ERA
description: California has a tendency to go to extremes, and this year it has pushed almost to the limit the accelerating trend toward the domination of American politics by the electronic press.

title: Greenwich Weighs Bank for Open Space
description: MOST people who chose to settle in the small residential towns of Connecticut do so because they enjoy living ''the good green life'' as John B. Margenot Jr., First Selectman of Greenwich, likes to put it.

title: 4 FROM INDIA MAKE CHARITABLE MARK
description: In philanthropy as in business, the four Hinduja brothers like to say they think as one.

title: THE STORY OF GENGHI: FANTASY VS. REALITY
description: GENGHI was in the attic for years. It was wrong, but one thing led to another, and before I knew it four years had flown by. Some people thought it was strange to keep his ashes at all, but when you have had a cat for 14 years, you don't just throw him on the -well, on the ash heap.

title: A Festive Dessert of Southwest France
description: The range of gastronomic riches of Southwest France - foie gras, confit and cassoulet - extends all the way to dessert. The tourtiere, which is a specialty of the region, just as, say, a cold Calvados mousse with poached apples belongs to Normandy, dates to the Middle Ages. The pastry is a volcanic eruption of thin petals, as crackly in texture and toasty in color as parchment paper. The tourtiere must be served warm, when its insides become tenderized, its aroma of eau de vie or rum wafts to the nostrils and its vanilla sugar dusting practically sizzles. The extremely delicate dish is a fitting conclusion to the robust fare of the region.

title: Miss Rosenman Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Lee Rosenman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rosenman of New York, was married yesterday to John Evangelakos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Evangelakos of Brookline, Mass. Judge Edward Weinfeld of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club of New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SAILING WITH THE WIND Written and illustrated by Thomas Locker. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books. $15. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: ELIE WIESEL AND WOLE SOYINKA WIN NOBELS
description: ELIE Wiesel, who was freed from Buchenwald in 1945 and 40 years later appealed to President Reagan not to visit a cemetery where Nazi SS members are buried, won the Nobel Peace Prize last week. The announcement in Oslo cited ''his belief that the forces fighting evil in the world can be victorious.'' For Mr. Wiesel, who received the news at home in Manhattan just after Yom Kippur, it meant that ''some of my friends and myself have prayed well.''

title: Sarah Jane Long Wed To George R. Gagliardi
description: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Watertown, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sarah Jane Long, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Long of Green Brook, N.J., to George Robert Gagliardi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gagliardi of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Whelan performed the ceremony.

title: London Wedding For Miss Mellon
description: Patricia Margaret Vibeke Mellon, a daughter of James Mellon of New York and the late Frances Mellon, was married yesterday to Dr. Piers Timothy John Wilson, a son of Lyn Wilson of Stevenage, Hertfordshire, England, and the late Jeanetta Wilson. The Rev. Charles McGowan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady in London.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ONE MORE TIME. By Carol Burnett. (Random House, $18.95.) Like all great clowns Carol Burnett has a profound respect for both the sentimental and the grotesque. She begins this affecting memoir of her childhood as an extended letter to her three daughters to explain ''just how your mom turned out to be the kind of hairpin she is.'' Raised only a block or so away from where Nathanael West placed ''The Day of the Locust,'' her family life was the very model of instability. Mother was an alcoholic. Her big dream was to write for the fan magazines but she spent most of her time in bed with a bottle and the shades pulled down. Father also drank; he sold things door-to-door when he could and died in a charity ward. This left Carol's upbringing to her maternal grandmother and it is the bond between the gawky, insecure little girl and the eccentric old woman that makes this book special. Nanny (Mabel Eudora Creighton) comes vividly to life: we see her in the one-room apartment the two of them shared, taking out her teeth to amuse the 3-year-old Carol or checking under the bed each night to make sure a man wasn't lurking. Nanny was subject to strange ailments, most particularly her ''hissy fits'' during which she clutched Mary Baker Eddy's ''Science and Health'' with one hand and downed phenobarbitals with the other. This woman is clearly just beneath the surface of all those wonderfully neurotic characters Miss Burnett created during the heyday of her television show.

title: THE WORLD SERIES '86: Baseball Notebook; A Dream Comes True for Baylor and Fades for Grich
description: THEY cried in 1976 when the Baltimore Orioles traded Don Baylor to the Oakland A's. It would be the first year of their 10-year professional career that Baylor and Bobby Grich would not be teammates, and they were upset at the upheaval. Now, 10 years later, Baylor is in the World Series for the first time and Grich is retiring without having made it.

title: 'In the Hollow of His Hand'
description: IT'S as if Cormac McCarthy with his dark genius and Edward Bulwer-Lytton with his overblown prose style had joined hands to rewrite ''Joseph Andrews,'' sending their young protagonist forth across a landscape provided by Louis L'Amour. In this grimly antic antipicaresque, the passive young half-Indian Chad - instead of setting out on a traditional quest to find his own father - is kidnapped repeatedly by potential fathers eager to adopt him. And yet, many of the conventions of the picaresque are observed: the importance of coincidence; the totally episodic nature of the journey itself; its consequent lack of cause and effect; the stock characters who never develop; the bawdy encounters; the use of talismans.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Honors From Iceland
description: Iceland is making news these days not only in the field of international diplomacy, but also in the realm of coins. Its government has authorized a new 500-krona silver coin to commemorate the 100th anniverary of the National Bank of Iceland.

title: AT SLEEPY HOLLOW, HOW CHILDREN WERE
description: PAINTINGS and playthings, nursery rhymes and tombstones are among the historical resources that will be discussed in ''Childhood in Early America,'' an all-day conference sponsored by Sleepy Hollow Restorations on Friday.

title: Air Shuttles Duel for Fans
description: METS and Red Sox, get out of the way of a real fight: the battle in the skies between the rival shuttle carriers for the loyalties of World Series fans shuttling between the Big Apple and Beantown.

title: Headliners; A Visiting Queen
description: After 200 years of mostly tense relations, Britain and China celebrated a new closeness last week with a visit to China by Queen Elizabeth II, who became the first British sovereign to enter that country. The Queen was greeted warmly by millions of Chinese and a host of their leaders, including the paramount one, Deng Xiaoping.

title: LAND-USE BOARDS: VOTERS DECIDE WHO MAY SIT ON THEM
description: BACKERS of a proposal to bar lawyers and real-estate agents from sitting on Bridgeport's planning and zoning commissions think it would eliminate an inherent conflict of interest.

title: NORTH CAROLINA TO ENFORCE RULE ON SPANKING
description: At the Vandalia Baptist Church Day Care Center, naughty children are ushered into the director's office, paddled, and promptly told that Jesus still loves them.

title: LOSERS IN A ZERO-SUM GAME
description: WHY ERA FAILED Politics, Women's Rights, and the Amending Process of the Constitution. By Mary Frances Berry. 147 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $17.95. WHY WE LOST THE ERA By Jane J. Mansbridge. 327 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $9.95.

title: SUFFOLK SYSTEM FAULTED IN PSYCHIATRIC EMERGENCIES
description: SEVEN years ago, David Myers's son began to develop psychiatric problems. Periodically, Mr. Myers said, his son would ''act out,'' a term used for an episode that can often include violent behavior.

title: PLAN TO PUT WASTE IN PINELANDS OPPOSED
description: IT'S rail-hunting season on the Maurice and Manumuskin Rivers in South Jersey, where, for three weeks every fall, the gentry hunt the marsh bird from flat-bottomed boats paddled by a guide-gondolier.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SCOTTISH PIPERS Ossian, a Scots traditional band, will appear Saturday evening in Madison, its only stop in New Jersey on its tour of the United States.

title: THE UNIVERSITY AS A METAPHOR FOR BRITISH LIFE
description: The old image of Cambridge was of golden boys, fresh from their Homer or Virgil, spending mellow afternoons indolently punting past ocher cloisters to serene picnics somewhere far up river. ''Stands the church clock at 10 to 3?'' the poet Rupert Brooke famously rhapsodized in an ecstasy of nostalgia for the university and its rural trimmings, ''and is there honey still for tea?'' But in recent years, novels, stage plays and television dramas have combined to present a harsher picture. Cambridge, in this revisionist view, is a blend of dream factory and success mill, filling the heads of its undergraduates with standards that they then proceed to compromise and expectations that they inevitably fail to fulfill. As a more jaundiced Brooke might put it today: stands the clock at 10 to 4, and is their liquor still to pour?

title: Stewart Is Leader In Disney Classic
description: Payne Stewart overcame a bogey on his first hole and treacherous winds today to shoot a 71 for a two-stroke advantage through three rounds of the $500,000 Walt Disney Classic.

title: Cashen, Gorman: 2 Builders Meet on the Top Floor
description: THE telephone rang in Lou Gorman's house in Boston at 8 o'clock last Thursday morning, not many hours after the Red Sox had won the American League pennant. It was Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, who had just won the National League pennant.

title: Penn Upsets Navy, 30-26
description: Jim Crocicchia passed for three touchdowns to Brent Novoselsky and for another to Jim Bruni to rally Penn to a 30-26 victory over Navy today.

title: Airspace Policing Plan Called Off Over Publicity
description: A Federal operation involving police helicopters following errant pilots flying in controlled airspace has been postponed because of advance publicity.

title:
MUSIC;
WILD TO PLAY WITH WESTFIELD
description: THE pianist Earl Wild will be the soloist next Saturday when the Westfield Symphony Orchestra, under Brad Keimach, its music director, opens its fourth season.

title: 18th-Century Ship Is Moved
description: Salvage crews used powerful cranes to move the remains of the H.M.S. deBraak, an 18th-century British brig, off a docked barge Wednesday, then slowly hauled it through this town to a holding tank where chemically treated water would protect it. Attempts to move the hull of the deBraak, which sank in 1798 and was raised from the floor of the Delaware Bay in August, failed Tuesday because the cranes were not large enough.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Required Reading; Presidential Libraries
description: Excerpts from an essay, ''Taking the Presidency to the People,'' by Frank G. Burke, Acting Archivist of the United States, in Prologue, the journal of the archives, summer 1986:

title: Cutting to Smithereens
description: MY NAME'S SMITH-ers. People in the business call me Smithereens. ''Get Smithereens,'' is the cry you'll hear ringing through every TV station in America when they've got a three-hour movie, plus 45 commercials to fit into two hours of TV time.

title: 100-Yard Return Helps Ohio State, 39-11
description: David Brown set a modern-day conference record with a 100-yard touchdown return of an intercepted pass, and Cris Carter caught 7 passes for 118 yards as Ohio State (5-2, 3-0) remained in a tie for first place in the Big Ten tonight with a 39-11 trouncing of Purdue.

title: Judge Feinberg Notes 25th Year on Bench
description: Wilfred Feinberg, the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, observed his 25th anniversary last week as a judge.

title: CLAIMING THE ANIMALS
description: THE EAGLE'S NEST Natural History and American Ideas, 1812-1842. By Charlotte M. Porter. Illustrated. 251 pp. University: The University of Alabama Press. $24.95.

title: Restoring 90's Look
description: Muraled ceilings, stained-glass skylights and tiled fireplaces are a few of the features that prompted an independent developer to buy an old Brooklyn town house this month for $725,000. But the location did not hurt.

title: Julienne Schaer and Irving J. Gotbaum Are Wed
description: Julienne Schaer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert R. Schaer of Lisle, Ill., and Irving J. Gotbaum, a son of Victor Gotbaum of Brooklyn and Sarah C. Gotbaum of Chevy Chase, Md., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Greenberg in Earl Hall at Columbia University.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A MEMORIAL LOSES A HOME WANT to buy a Vietnam veterans memorial? One is for sale in Holbrook.

title: New Zealand
description: To the Editor: I share Judith Heath's enthusiasm for the Routeburn Track in New Zealand (Travel, Sept. 14). It is only a few miles from the more popular and renowned Milford Track yet is less expensive, more accessible and, as the author notes, more varied in terrain.

title: INSIDE IMAGES OF THE DEAF AND BLIND
description: LIKE many people, Mathieu Roberts was ill at ease when he first made contact with the deaf and blind residents of the Helen Keller National Center in Sands Point.

title: 'JEWLER'S EYE': 200 PIECES FROM 1785 to MID 1880's
description: ON the banks of the Hudson River, Trevor Mansion, a part of the Hudson River Museum, offers a glimpse into the elegance of the 19th century. Built in 1876 as a summer residence by John B. Trevor, a well-to-do New York City stockbroker, the mansion contains intricate stenciling, carved woodwork and other rich details that reflect the wealth and status of its former occupants.

title: Social Events; SEASON IN FULL SWING
description: Manhattan Open House Oct. 21 - From 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. six imposing Manhattan apartments, four on the Upper East Side and two on Central Park West, will be open for house tours to benefit United Cerebral Palsy of New York City. The homes, which may be visited in any order, provide examples of different styles of life in the big city involving a bachelor, a widow, a mother and daughter and three apartments of designers. Wine and cheese will be served throughout the four hours of the tour at the Claremont House, 52 East 72d Street. Tickets, $50 or two for $90, from 212-683-6700. China-American Party Oct. 22 - Founded by American and Chinese educators in 1926, the China Institute in America sponsors programs fostering knowledge of Chinese culture among Americans and provides services to visitng Chinese students. A 60th anniversary benefit will be held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets for black-tie evening, $250, from 212-744-8181. Egyptian Celebration Oct. 22 - 18 - Mayor Koch's counterpart from Cairo, Youssef Sabri Abou Taleb, will be in town to promote the New York-Cairo Sister City Program of business, cultural and educational exchanges. A highlight of many planned activities will be a black-tie dinner benefit with an Egyptian flavor at the St. Regis-Sheraton, starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets, $175, from 212-319-9300. Aiding the Executives Oct. 22 - Along with business acumen, business executives who deal on the international scene are sometimes in need of a cultural appreciation of the nation's trading partners.

title: The Rise of the 'No Frills' Convention
description: COMPARED to the annual extravaganzas it used to throw, the Philip Morris Companies' corporate affairs conference last month was positively austere. The refrigerators in attendees' rooms were devoid of beverages. There was no open bar at lunch, and the pre-dinner cocktail hour was only 45 minutes.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Youth and Taxes

title: New York City's Assets
description: Robert Price's article neglected to mention one of the city's major assets in retaining and attracting business: its telecommunications infrastructure.

title: Europe's Fall-Winter Calendar
description: Addresses and phone numbers for ordering tickets before you go are given where appropriate; a way to avoid problems with fluctuating exchange rates is to provide the number of a major credit card when ordering. Methods of getting tickets on the spot vary. Many major hotels offer ticket services or can direct you to an agency, or your concierge can obtain tickets. ENGLAND

title: OBSTACLES FORCE NARROWER FOCUS ON 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan's missile-defense program has made advances in the last two years but has run up against technical and financial barriers that are forcing changes in emphasis and direction.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL '86: HOLY CROSS;
Playing in Memory of a Coach
description: ON a wall behind the desk of Gregg Burke, the sports information director of Holy Cross College, there are two photographs. One is of Bo Schembechler, the football coach at Michigan, where Burke attended school. The other is of Rick Carter, the football coach at Holy Cross from 1981 until last Feb. 2. That was the day when the 42-year-old Carter, one of the nation's most promising young coaches, committed suicide.

title:
INVESTING;
A Well-Dressed I.P.O.
description: Having assembled one of the country's largest privately held industrial companies, William F. Farley is about sell part of it to the public. The 43-year-old chairman of Farley Industries is spinning off Farley Apparel Inc., whose brands include Fruit of the Loom and BVD underwear and Acme and Dingo boots, in an initial public offering valued at more than $450 million.

title: 2 Superb Actors Elevate A Shaw 'Play Pleasant'
description: On opening night of ''You Never Can Tell,'' Uta Hagen, the putative star of the evening, was greeted with a round of applause. In the second scene, the waiter entered and, before he had spoken a word, he, too, was applauded. That fact was an acknowledgment of the audience's recognition of, and indebtedness to, Philip Bosco, who for several decades has been brightening classics - and less than classics - with his salutary stage presence. His specialty has been Shaw at Circle in the Square. If you want to do Shaw in America, the first step is to contact Mr. Bosco and ask him which part he wants to play.

title: Trodding to Military School
description: To the Editor:

title: Papal Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss McNeil Wed To A.L. Lewis 4th
description: Joanna Phelps McNeil and Andrew Lindsay Lewis 4th were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. The Rev. Charles A. Carter performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Jack R. Rothenberger of the Central Schwenkfelder Church in Worcester, Pa.

title: BUSH PILOTS' NEW PERILS
description: OLDTIMERS here still reminisce about the good old years of the 1920's when Wilfred May serviced the North in a wood-and-fabric Bellanca Pacemaker until the Government discovered that he had only one good eye and made him quit.

title: CRISIS ROILS GOVERNMENT IN UGANDA
description: WHEN President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda seized power nearly nine months ago, his takeover of this impoverished country raised hopes of security, political stability and strict concern for human rights in a nation that has suffered wave upon wave of brutish atrocities of ethnic and religious origin.

title: HOW TO MISS THE BOAT
description: The closer the United States and the Soviet Union get to a nuclear arms compromise, the more they tend to tear it apart. The loudest critics of the Reagan-Gorbachev Iceland proposals are pulling up these new plants before they've had time to take root.

title: Susan Hagopian Weds in Darien
description: Susan Kelly Hagopian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Hagopian of Darien, Conn., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Bronson Goddard 2d, a son of Helen K. Goddard of Nonquitt, Mass., and Richard M. Goddard Jr., of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Henry Albeke performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: A Detained Reporter
description: The United States was lectured from within and without last week on, of all things, freedom of the press. The issue involved Patricia Lara, a Colombian journalist who, for rather vague reasons, was barred from entering the country, detained for five days, then deported.

title: DRUGS MOVE UP ON TRENTON'S AGENDA
description: NEW JERSEY has discovered the drug-abuse problem, and it is clear that drugs will become a dominant issue in the 1987 legislative elections the way environmental cleanup and car insurance were in every campaign speech in prior years.

title: RED SOX WIN, 9-3, OVER METS TO LEAD BY 2
description: The Boston Red Sox took a two-game lead in the World Series last night, defeating the New York Mets, 9 to 3.

title: Advertising; Cadillac Group To Biederman
description: Having weighed with care the credentials, the track record, the client list and the people chemistry at seven advertising agencies, the agency selection committee of the Tri-State Cadillac Dealers Association decided to go with Biederman & Company.

title: SOVIET ORDERS OUT 5 U.S. DIPLOMATS ON SPYING CHARGES
description: The Soviet Union ordered five American diplomats out of the country today for engaging in ''impermissible activities,'' the diplomatic formula for spying, the press agency Tass reported.

title: STUDENT BODY PRESIDENT DIES IN HIT-RUN
description: A 17-year-old girl who was president of the student body at the Spence School was struck and killed on the Upper East Side of Manhattan early yesterday by a speeding white car that dragged her 200 feet and then sped away, the police reported.

title: KEN McFEELEY, UNION LEADER
description: J. Kenneth McFeeley, a former president of the Patrolmen's Benvolent Association in New York City, died of lung cancer Saturday in Mid-Island Hospital in Bethpage, L.I. He was 47 years old and lived in Bethpage.

title: 10-YEAR STUDY SAYS NUMBER OF SMOKERS FELL BY ALMOST 20%
description: The number of adult smokers in America has declined by nearly a fifth in the last decade, leaving what the American Cancer Society calls a ''hard core'' 30 percent who refuse to quit.

title: DANCE: 'FILLE MAL GARDEE'
description: THE Joffrey Ballet has made a wise choice in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Fille Mal Gardee,'' which it acquired this season. The story is a charming one of a willful young farm girl, the peasant boy she loves, and her widowed mother, whose schemes to make a good marriage for her daughter go happily awry. Sir Frederick's telling of the story - with typical humanity, humor and radiant romantic interludes - makes this one of his loveliest and most characteristic ballets. Those touches clearly delighted the audience in the company's performances of ''La Fille Mal Gardee'' at City Center on Friday and Saturday nights. And the ballet, with its bouncy, tuneful score by Ferdinand Herold, adapted and arranged by John Lanchbery, has a sunniness very like the youthful spirit that distinguishes the Joffrey.

title: POLITICS
description: Back BurnerHow much does Governor Cuomo think you should pay in state taxes over the next four years? How much in rent? The answer is that he hasn't taken a stand. Those issues - a restructuring of the state tax code, revision of the rent-stabilization laws - are among several politically sensitive decisions that the administration has put off until after the election. And some groups are beginning to complain: after all, they ask, isn't one purpose of an election campaign to elicit from candidates a commitment on the issues?

title: REPORT SAYS TIGHTER POLICIES REDUCE KILLINGS BY THE POLICE
description: The number of people killed by police officers in the nation's largest cities has been cut almost in half in 13 years, primarily because of more stringent police policies on firing weapons, according to a study made public today.

title: EXPERTS DISCERN A BLOC: 'NEW COLLAR' VOTERS
description: Gary and Janice Bloedorn will tell you that the high-tech revolution, like most revolutions, does not always deliver on its extravagant promises.

title: Sound Settlement on Foster Care
description: To care for most of its 17,000 foster children, New York City relies on private voluntary agencies with Protestant, Catholic or Jewish affiliation. Their insistence on caring for children according to sectarian belief has brought repeated turmoil about asserted discrimination. The turmoil may now be over, brought to a welcome end by the apparent settlement of a 13-year-old lawsuit that may finally inhibit the sectarian dominance.

title: U.S. AIDES SEE PUSH FOR 2 PACTS WITH RUSSIANS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they expected the United States and the Soviet Union in coming weeks to try to conclude two of the tentative agreements they achieved at last weekend's meeting in Iceland.

title: Advertising; New Agency Starting In Bank Advertising
description: There are beneficiaries from the account fallout generated by agency mergers, as Craig Campbell and Michael Wagman of Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, will attest.

title: LEGISLATORS HEAD HOME AFTER FINAL FLURRY OF BILLS
description: The 99th Congress adjourned Saturday night, and by this morning most of its members were headed home to present themselves for re-election on the basis of a legislative record that includes major revisions in the tax, budget and immigration laws.

title: Bridge: Australian Makes His Mark In a Visit to Cavendish Club
description: For every bridge player who could name the capital city of Australia there are probably 10 who could name the capital bridge club of America. The first is certainly Canberra, and the second, in terms of influence rather than size, is the Cavendish in Manhattan.

title: The Second Season
description: No later than one week from today, if the weather cooperates, the World Series will be history, and a new baseball season, the free-agent season, will have begun. The day after the final pitch, more than 100 major league players are eligible to file for the right to weigh contract offers from all comers, and the list this year includes six Series participants: Ray Knight and Danny Heep of the Mets and, from Boston, Rich Gedman, Dave Stapleton, Joe Sambito and Sammy Stewart.

title: 3 Children Killed in Fire
description: Three children were killed yesterday when a fire engulfed their 2 1/2-story duplex in a public-housing project in the South Meriden section of the city, authorities said.

title: Lucky Stores To Study Offer
description: Lucky Stores said Friday that its board would consider a sweetened offer from Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, at a special meeting to be scheduled this week.

title: Gold Is Back At U.S. Mint
description: The first investment-grade gold bullion coins offered by the United States Mint in more than 50 years will be made available to 25 authorized purchasers around the world today. The coins, called American eagles, will be issued in four sizes, with face values from $5 to $50.

title: WHY IS IRELAND SMILING? IT'S A FINE BOG HARVEST
description: A sudden splurge of autumn sunshine has eased the chill of two dismal harvests of cut turf - the primal fuel by which the morbid but merciful boglands of Ireland, sliced, dried and fed into the hearth, have warmed its hardiest souls into modern times.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many innings did Carl Erskine of the Brooklyn Dodgers pitch in an extra-inning victory over the Yankees years ago, and is that the longest complete-game victory for a World Series pitcher?

title: INSIDE
description: Courts Defied on Contract A former city commissioner defied court rulings and refused to award a towing franchise to a winning bidder, records show.

title: SOVIET ENVOYS: A 320 LIMIT
description: After the Soviet Union entered the civil war in Afghanistan in 1979, part of the Carter Administration's response was to limit to 320 the number of Soviet employees allowed at the Soviet Embassy in Washington and the Soviet Consulate in San Francisco.

title: The University Connection
description: Many corporations, professional associations and nonprofit groups lobby Congress more or less openly on legislation in which they have an interest. Some colleges and universities feel they should use their political influence only for broad higher education causes, avoiding attempts to promote specific Federal research projects at specific institutions.

title: CANADA SETS MARK IN CHARLES REGATTA
description: Canada's 1984 Olympic gold medal-winning eight-oared crew set a new course record as it won the featured championship eight's event in the Head of the Charles Regatta today.

title: Market Place; G.P.U. Payout Termed Likely
description: ELECTRIC utility stocks are typically prized by investors for their cash dividend payments. But shares of the General Public Utilities Corporation, which pays no dividend, have climbed more than fivefold in the last four years.

title: THE BOSTON TEE PARTY
description: THE only consolation for the Mets now is that no team has ever won the World Series after losing the first two games in its own ball park since last year. The Kansas City Royals bounced off a trampoline after having lost the first two games in Kansas City to the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: THE POLISH PRISONER: A NEW PROFILE
description: When new prisoners are led into the 12-man cells at Czarne Prison, they are eyed carefully by the older inmates, and then, according to one man who was recently released from there, someone usually asks the newcomer whether he intends to ''gryps'' or not.

title: 10 Seamen Said to Die In an Iranian Attack
description: Ten seamen were killed when an Iranian gunboat fired a missile into a Panamanian oil tanker, shipping sources said today.

title: HIGHER HOLIDAY SALES EXPECTED BY RETAILERS
description: The 1986 Christmas selling season - the 27 shopping days starting the day after Thanksgiving - has a generally good look to both retailers and analysts at this point. But most agree that this season probably will not match the outburst of consumer buying that marked both the 1985 and 1984 periods.

title: OUTDOORS: FALLEN LEAVES AID STREAMS, FISHERMEN
description: LIKE most people, I loathe raking leaves, but as a fisherman I take cheer from the leaf drop at this time of year. If it were not for the leaves that fall or get blown into streams, trout and other fish would be hard put to find a number of aquatic insects on which to dine.

title: FRUSTRATED METS LOOKING FOR INTENSITY
description: Their race was over before springtime was. Over six months, in the 162-game season, they did more things right than any team in baseball. Suddenly, in the space of one weekend, everything is going wrong.

title: 8 Die Digging Canal in Nepal
description: Eight workers digging a canal died Thursday in a landslide in Thaksip village, about 125 miles east of Katmandu, the Nepalese news agency reported.

title: Ball From Stands Nearly Hits Rice
description: A spectator threw a ball from the stands at Jim Rice as the Boston Red Sox left fielder was attempting to catch a fly ball in the sixth inning of Game 2 of the World Series last night at Shea Stadium.

title: School Censors Book And Then Removes It
description: School officials have confiscated copies of Stephen King's vampire novel ''Salem's Lot'' from a class of ninth graders even though teachers had inked out objectionable words with a felt-tip marker.

title: First Chicago Officer Resigns
description: The First Chicago Corporation said Friday that George L. Davis, a 52-year-old executive vice president, had resigned. Mr. Davis had long been considered a potential successor to the bank's chairman, Barry F. Sullivan.

title: Faith in Floating Point Cited by Interim Leader
description: Milton R. Smith has seen the good times come and go at Floating Point Systems Inc.

title: CABARET: RICHARD RODNEY BENNETT AT PIANO
description: TO call Richard Rodney Bennett ''a singing pianist's singing pianist'' is not merely a random cliche. The evidence was apparent at his weekly performance on Friday at J's, on Broadway near 97th Street, where Stan Freeman, Warren Vaughn and Franklin Underwood - all polished veterans of the trade - were on hand to relish Mr. Bennett's choice of material, his easy, rough-edged singing and his occasional, simply-stated, brief but swinging piano solos.

title: Vikings Surprise Bears, 23-7
description: Tommy Kramer threw two touchdown passes in the first quarter and the Minnesota defense sacked Steve Fuller seven times today as the Vikings upset the Chicago Bears, 23-7.

title: Fire Damages Bronx School
description: Vandals set fire to Public School 125, at 1111 Pugsley Avenue in this section of the Bronx, early yesterday, damaging the building, according to a police spokesman, Sgt. Diane Kubler.

title: Amy Finkelstein Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Finkelstein, an arms-control analyst for the State Department, and Jeffrey M. Winton, an associate at the Washington law firm Arnold & Porter, were married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi H. Phillip Berkowitz officiated. Ms. Winton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Finkelstein of Ossining, N.Y., graduated from Vassar College and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1986
description: The World

title: Eisenhower Highway Marker
description: The first commemorative sign bearing the name of the Dwight D. Eisenhower Highway has been unveiled at a tourist information center off Interstate 70.

title: Despina Koules Is Married To A.C. Anton Jr. in Boston
description: Despina Louise Koules, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven A. Koules of Fitchburg, Mass., was married yesterday to Arthur Charles Anton Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton of Chelmsford, Mass. Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of New England in Boston.

title: I.B.M. Realignment Shifts Officer Roles
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has given responsibility for two of its four product groups and its Rolm Corporation subsidiary to Allen J. Krowe, a senior vice president who is also the company's chief financial officer.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS SECRET DATA EASED CARGO PLANE ISSUE
description: A senior Reagan Administration official asserted today that classified information provided to Congress had allayed most suspicions among members of Congress about Government involvement in the flight of a plane downed over Nicaragua.

title: I'm A Banker, 19-1, Triumphs
description: I'm A Banker and Duluth ran first and second all the way around the Belmont Park inner turf course yesterday to lead an improbable order of finish in the $91,200 Kelso Handicap.

title: Susan Shapiro Is Wed To Robert B. Williams
description: Susan Joan Shapiro and Robert Bruce Williams were married yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me., by Justice of the Peace Janet Winters at the Shawmut Inn. The bride is a daughter of Sherman George Shapiro of Auburn and Pine Point, Scarborough, Me., and the late Mrs. Shapiro. Mr. Williams is a son of Jayne Thompson Williams and Bruce Williams of Bay Head, N.J.

title: What Claiborne Did
description: Three cheers for Harry E. Claiborne, the former Federal District Court judge. He may do more to develop an efficient system for disciplining Federal judges than any other judge in history. As he sat in prison for income tax evasion, drawing his Federal salary, he mocked the Federal judicial disciplinary system, the public and Congress for its failure to provide for the removal of Federal judges by means other than impeachment.

title: An Army of Lobbyists
description: Excerpt from the preface to ''1986 - Washington Representatives,'' a list of lobbyists and others in Washington, published by Columbia Books.

title: RAIDERS BEAT DOLPHINS, 30-28
description: Marcus Allen ran for 96 yards and scored three touchdowns today to lead the Los Angeles Raiders to their fourth straight victory, a 30-28 decision over the Miami Dolphins.

title: RED SOX' BUCKNER PLAYS WITH PAIN AND ENTHUSIASM
description: Bill Buckner of the Red Sox runs the bases as if one foot is on a curb and the other on the street. He runs from side to side, lopsided, part hobble, part stumble, part desperation.

title: Washington Watch; New Study of World Bank
description: Some big operational changes could be coming at the World Bank. Barber Conable Jr., the bank's new president, has sent a notice to all employees alerting them to a sweeping internal review to be done with the help of an outside management consultant, Cresap, McCormick & Paget.

title: New York Can Have School Excellence and Excellent Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Storage Technology Gain
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, the manufacturer of disk and tape storage devices for mainframe computers that filed for Chapter 11 protection nearly two years ago, reported net income Friday for the third quarter of $9.1 million, or 26 cents a share. That is in contrast to a loss of $14 million in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues for the period, which ended Sept. 26, rose 4.9 percent, to $178.5 million, from $170.2 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: RANGERS, ISLANDERS END IN TIE
description: They entered the weekend filled with doubts and uneasiness. The Rangers had squandered lead after lead and had shown none of the new look that a summer of change had promised. They left the weekend bolstered and reassured.

title: Big Press, Small Press and Staying Impartial
description: To the Editor:

title: Files Link Ex-Official And Contra Suppliers
description: Clandestine suppliers of Nicaraguan rebels maintained an extensive support network run by Americans in San Salvador with possible links to a retired senior Pentagon official, according to Salvadoran Government documents and sources.

title: DANCE: GYPSY ARTISTS IN 'FLAMENCO PURO'
description: THE heart of Spanish flamenco is the ''cante jondo,'' the ''deep song,'' whose mix of the sacred and the profane vibrates so visibly from every singer and dancer in the new show ''Flamenco Puro.''

title: NO BIG RISE IN OIL PRICES SEEN
description: A decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to basically extend its current production agreement is unlikely to cause oil prices to stray out of the $13-to-$16-a-barrel range they have been in since Sept. 1, according to oil analysts in the United States.

title: 'MY SISTER SAM,' SERIES STARRING PAM DAWBER
description: TOP-HEAVY with parent-child generation differences, television sitcoms are now exploring the demographic potential of sibling gaps. CBS's ''My Sister Sam,'' Mondays at 8:30 P.M., offers preppy-ish Samantha Russell, whose comfortable life as a photographer in San Francisco is disrupted -charmingly, of course - when her kid sister, Patti, suddenly arrives from Oregon wanting to become a rock star. Irrepressible, pretty Patti is 16. Finicky, pretty Sam (the juices in her refrigerator are arranged alphabetically) is 29. The difference of 13 years is enough, the producers hope, for a world of laugh-provoking age collisions.

title: 'SILK STOCKING' DISTRICT SEES TOUGH CONGRESSIONAL RACE
description: The hardest-fought Congressional contest in New York City this fall is the campaign being waged in the famed ''Silk Stocking'' district on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: THE OPERA: WATANABE AS BUTTERFLY
description: YOKO WATANABE, a Japanese soprano who has been singing Puccini's Madama Butterfly in Munich, Berlin, Milan and Naples, made her Metropolitan Opera debut Saturday afternoon in the role. It is a pity she is here only as a ''cover'' for Renata Scotto, because her assumption of the role is distinguished in its own right, and Metropolitan audiences would doubtless enjoy seeing more of it.

title: A Prediction and Solace
description: Sometimes it can be discouraging as well as lonely up there at the top. When President Reagan boarded Air Force One after the Iceland conference a week ago, he retired to his cabin, and aides were concerned that the normally upbeat chief executive might be dispirited by the impasse on arms control with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: STAGE: SIMON GRAY PLAY, 'THE COMMON PURSUIT'
description: THE fun to be found in ''The Common Pursuit,'' Simon Gray's first play since ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' is the voyeurism and laughter of juicy gossip. In his opening scene, Mr. Gray introduces a half-dozen high-minded Cambridge University litterateurs of 20 years ago. From then on, the characters (five men, one woman) switch beds, careers, ethics and aspirations while hurtling headlong from cheeky late youth to chastened, even sordid early middle age. The on- and offstage personages of ''The Common Pursuit'' are entirely fictional, of course - and never mind if they passingly resemble such real-life English literary figures as Ian Hamilton, Kenneth Tynan, Clive James or James Fenton. Mr. Gray and the excellent cast at the Promenade make these Cambridge alumni so vivid in their own right that we follow their various slouchings toward Bethlehem as avidly as we might the misbehavior of the brand-name celebrities who dominate our own tonier slick magazines.

title: PROPOSALS ON CONRAIL SEEN SOON
description: The Department of Transportation is expected this week to begin soliciting proposals from investment houses to participate as one of four to six ''co-lead managers'' in the public sale of the Government's stock holdings in the Consolidated Rail Corporation, commonly known as Conrail.

title: THE STATES, THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AND THE ATOM
description: Once the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission decides that a power plant has been properly designed, built and staffed, should a state or local government be able to block its operation?

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS DEFEATED IN 3 BIG CITIES
description: The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou suffered a painful defeat Sunday as conservative challengers ousted the Socialist mayors of three of Greece's four largest cities in runoff municipal elections.

title: SEXUAL ABUSE: SPEAKING OUT
description: Parents, therapists, even police officers still whisper in her ear when they want to discuss child abuse, molestation or exploitation. That furtiveness annoys Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, who is used to discussing the mistreatment of children in a loud and clear voice and who has written a new book on the subject.

title: AGGRESSIVE TACTICS RAISE $7.7 MILLION FOR D'AMATO
description: Alfonse M. D'Amato, the freshman Senator from New York, has raised more money than any candidate for Federal office in the state's history -$7.75 million as of Sept. 30.

title: ISRAEL CONFIRMS DOWNED PILOT IS HELD BY MILITIAMEN
description: The commander of the Israeli Air Force confirmed for the first time today that the pilot who disappeared in Lebanon Thursday, after bailing out of his stricken aircraft, was alive and in the hands of militiamen.

title: M.T.A. Is Said To Overcharge
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has overcharged the city $10.5 million over the last five years for maintenance of Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road stations, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin asserted yesterday.

title: James F. Waterhouse, Leader in Chattanooga
description: James Franklin Waterhouse, a prominent attorney and civic leader in Chattanooga, Tenn., died of cancer at his home early yesterday.

title: Tax Law Causes Chief Of SFN to 'Move Fast'
description: About six weeks ago, Jack Purcell, chairman and president of SFN Companies Inc., saw tax news that startled him.

title: CONCERT: BERLIN ORCHESTRA
description: ILLNESS forced Herbert von Karajan out of the Berlin Philharmonic tour, but the sound he has nurtured and husbanded in three decades of leadership - three decades that have seen the steep erosion of identifiable, distinctive sounds in other orchestras - came to the Metropolitan Opera House without him yesterday afternoon. A striking moment, for this listener, came at the beginning of ''Im Abendrot,'' the last of Strauss's ''Vier Letzte Lieder,'' where James Levine threw the same haul-off-and-hit fortissimo gesture that he had thrown at the Chicago Symphony about a year ago for the same piece. In Chicago, the sound he got was tense, brilliant and hard. Here, it was rich, mellow and deep. Mr. Levine is far more than a stopgap substitute for Mr. von Karajan, but we hear him a lot; the feature of the afternoon was the Berlin orchestra. From the first notes of Wagner's ''Siegfried Idyll'' - tender, affectionate, superbly balanced string playing - the tone was set. This is an orchestra that has collectively remembered to care about fineness of tone, about blend, about the beauty of a very soft sound floating through a large, acoustically receptive space.
