It was wonderful to hear the Vivace of Beethoven's Seventh Symphony begun with such fluent grace, and extraordinary to hear the fortissimo arrive without horns and trumpets glaring forth as though all else were background.

title: PARCEL BOMB KILLS NIGERIAN JOURNALIST ACCUSED OF PLOTTING
description: A Nigerian journalist was killed today when a parcel bomb delivered to his home exploded.

title: Full U.S. Financing Schedule Is Set
description: The Treasury has a full financing schedule this week, and government securities dealers expect that the supply of new issues will grow now that Congress has increased the Federal debt limit.

title: SOVIET POET LOOKS HARD AT SUFFERING OF THE JEWS
description: The poet Andrei Voznesky has published a major new article commemorating the suffering of Soviet Jews during World War II, a subject long suppressed by the authorities.

title: SURVIVING IN THE THEATER: SUGGESTIONS AND SYMPATHY
description: As far as the Foundation of the Dramatists Guild was concerned, the purpose of its weekend conference was to assess a four-year program for new plays and to announce an additional boon.

title: Carolyn A. White Wed to a Lawyer
description: Carolyn A. White, an account executive at N. W. Ayer, the advertising company, and Martin J. Yudkowitz, the senior counsel to the Olympics unit of the National Broadcasting Company, were married yesterday at the Esterwood Mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., by Town Judge Herbert Rosenberg of Dobbs Ferry.

title: QUESTIONS ARISE ABOUT LAW FIRM OF BIAGGI'S SON
description: In the winter of 1984, Henry Thomas, a businessman and would-be military contractor, was facing a crisis.

title: Ford Recalls 1987 Lincolns
description: The Ford Motor Company has recalled about 6,200 1987-model Lincoln Town Cars to repair an engine wiring harness that the automaker said could cause a short circuit and fire.

title: RON DARLING IN THE FOURTH
description: THE BRUTAL events of the past two nights have more or less dictated that Ron Darling will pitch the fourth game of the World Series Wednesday night as the Mets see if they can struggle back to Shea next weekend.

title: 800 FEMINISTS LOOK TO FUTURE OF THE DECADE OF WOMEN
description: Eight hundred women from 60 organizations and more than a dozen countries met here for a three-day meeting ending Saturday, in a ''national summit'' to follow up the 1985 United Nations Decade for Women conference. In July of that year, 1,400 delegates in Nairobi, Kenya, capped 10 years of work with the unanimous passage of a comprehensive feminist manifesto that plotted strategies for women until the year 2000.

title: Wometco Sale Is Expected
description: The sale of the Wometco Broadcasting Company for a price slightly more than $600 million is expected to be announced as early as today, according to a source familiar with the negotiations.

title: Echo of Civil War Marks Prisoner's Disinterment
description: Men wearing Confederate gray discharged volleys of musket fire and a high school band played a funeral march Saturday while the remains of a Confederate prisoner once held by the Union were disinterred, the first step in taking him back to his native Tennessee.

title: CALMNESS NOT PART OF ELWAY PLAYBOOK
description: Calm down, John Elway. It's only a game.

title: U.S. Oil Tax Denounced
description: The Government on Saturday denounced as unacceptable the United States tax on imported oil that President Reagan signed into law as part of the $9 billion Superfund program to clean up toxic waste. It called on other nations to join Venezuela in asking the United States for ''a correction that would benefit the international community and its own strategic interests.'' In Mexico, the Foreign Ministry said its ambassador to the United States would file a formal protest Monday with the State Department over the tax.

title: Washington Watch; Outlook for Economic Panel
description: Representative David R. Obey's two-year tenure as chairman of the Joint Economic Committee is just about up, with the current session of Congress ended and a new one beginning in January. That means the strong Democratic tone the Wisconsin Congressman has set for the committee would shift markedly to the right if Republicans keep control of the Senate.

title: Australia IV Loses In Defender Trials
description: Kookaburra III showed Alan Bond today that winning the 1986 defenders' trials may be more difficult for him than winning the America's Cup itself.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: The Reckoning. By David Halberstam. 752 pages. William Morrow. $19.95.

title: Foreign Competitions: Import Surge
description: It's no news when Japan's automobile exports soar, but now imports are soaring, too. Sales of foreign cars in Japan this year are up 25 percent.

title: His Favorite Year
description: When the 35th anniversary of Bobby Thomson's famed homer was celebrated with a party at a Manhattan restaurant two weeks ago, Sal Yvars was the only other member of the 1951 Giant team who attended. He wouldn't have missed it, and for good reason: In lining Ralph Branca's pitch over the left-field wall of the Polo Grounds, sending the Dodgers back to Flatbush and the Giants into the World Series, Thomson had left a lasting mark on Yvars's life.

title: DANCE: CHOREO SHOWCASE
description: ON Saturday night, the Theater of the Riverside Church presented Choreo Showcase III, its third workshop program of the season. It was something of a hodgepodge.

title: 2,800 Illegal Aliens Arrested In a Weeklong Border Sweep
description: More than 2,800 undocumented aliens were arrested by Border Patrol agents last week in a five-day roundup of people who had crossed the border illegally.

title: Barbara Whitman Is Wed To David James Carlyon
description: Barbara Elizabeth Whitman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Whitman of New York, and David James Carlyon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Carlyon of Bay City, Mich., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The bride's aunt, Judge Phyllis W. Beck of the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony.

title: Sikh Militants Reported To Kill 4 in Punjab
description: Four people were shot dead in Punjab state over the weekend, apparently by Sikh militants, as India's main Hindu opposition group charged Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had failed to restore peace to the northern state.

title: FLOYD IS WINNER IN 3-WAY PLAYOFF
description: Ray Floyd sank a 6-foot put for par on the first playoff hole today to beat out Mike Sullivan and Lon Hinkle for the championship of the $500,000 Walt Disney Classic.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CORRECTION
description: The Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Wednesday misattributed a description of autumn as a season of ''mists and mellow fruitfulness.'' The quotation, from the poem ''To Autumn,'' was by Keats, not Coleridge.

title: A THRIVING PORTFOLIO BACKS NOBEL PRIZES
description: For this year's Nobel laureates, the prize was certainly worth the wait. Besides the prestige, the 1986 prizes announced in recent days come with 2 million Swedish kronor apiece. That is roughly $294,000, or 11 percent more than last year.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 20, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Yale Reaffirms 9 Suspensions
description: A Yale University disciplinary board has reaffirmed its suspension of nine anti-apartheid protesters who conducted a sit-in at the investments office in September.

title: Unanimous Decision
description: It was actually only half the civilized world that was transfixed by the telecast of the Mets' extra-inning pennant-clincher at Houston last Wednesday. For the other half, it was business, and pleasure, as usual.

title: HAITIANS VOTE, BUT IN SMALL NUMBERS
description: Haiti held its first democratic national elections in nearly 30 years today, but most Haitians appeared to have stayed away from the voting places.

title: MEXICO AND THE NARCOTICS TRAFFIC: GROWING STRAIN IN U.S. RELATIONS
description: The scene was familiar, both to John Gavin, then the United States Ambassador to Mexico, and to the Mexican officials he was meeting, including President Miguel de la Madrid.

title: FINANCE OFFICERS' WIDE ROLE
description: When Fred Zuckerman, treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation, decided to spread Chrysler's name in the financial world, he turned to Japan. Chrysler cars are not sold in Japan, but as of last month its stock has been. With its shares now listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the name of Chrysler is shouted by traders in Tokyo as loudly as it is on Wall Street.

title: Two Skydivers Killed in Jump
description: A skydiver whose parachute failed to open plunged into one of four fellow parachutists, and both men died, an official said today.

title: SERIES STARS MOONLIGHT IN TV FILMS
description: On their summer vacations this year, most stars of successful television series chose to take a busman's holiday.

title: Karen Weinstein Wed To Jeffrey Michael Katz
description: Karen Kurkhill Weinstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Simon H. Weinstein of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Michael Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Katz of Silver Lake, S.I. Rabbi Bernard H. Bloom performed the ceremony at the Glen Sanders Mansion in Scotia, N.Y.

title: SURGE IN BOGUS PAPERS PREDICTED IN WAKE OF CHANGE IN ALIEN LAW
description: Immigration officials say they expect a huge market in bogus documents to emerge soon to help those living illegally in the United States take advantage of or circumvent the immigration measure that Congress passed Friday.

title: For Tip
description: Along with oratorical tributes, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will take into retirement a portrait of himself, painted by Anne Jerome, deputy superintendent of the House periodical press gallery and given to him last week by the House press corps. The artist has attended the Speaker's daily news conferences for the last decade and painted from her ''mental image'' of him.

title: HOLY CROSS HANDLES WISHBONE ATTACK
description: On the field, the distinctions between the National Collegiate Athletic Association's divisions, I-A or I-AA - such things as stadium capacities and overall enrollment - make little difference.

title: KNICKS' WALKER ADDS SPARK
description: He certainly doesn't look like very much in a uniform, with his baggy shorts - he likes them that way - his slightly bow-shaped legs and knobby knees. He looks as if he was the last guy to make the team, the one they couldn't find a proper-sized uniform for. If clothes made the player, Kenny Walker would be cut.

title: King Comeback Is Slowed
description: Just when it looked as if Bernard King's long and arduous rehabilitation was beginning to show results, the Knick forward suffered another setback. While jogging near his home yesterday in Franklin Lakes, N.J., King inadvertently stepped in a hole and sprained his right ankle and knee.

title: BECKER TOPPLES LENDL IN FINAL
description: Boris Becker lost the first set but fought back with a devastating service attack today that produced 17 aces to defeat Ivan Lendl in the final of the Australian indoor championships.

title: TEXANS FEAR RED TIDE COULD KEEP TOURISTS AWAY
description: More than a month after it began along the northern end of Texas' Gulf Coast, a toxic tide is spreading consternation along much of this state's coast and into Mexico.

title: O'NEILL-BELAGA CONTEST OFFERS CONTRAST IN STYLES
description: In the final weeks of Connecticut's gubernatorial campaign, Gov. William A. O'Neill and Julie D. Belaga, his Republican opponent, are dwelling on two recurring themes - leadership and each other's records.

title: More Taxi Service With No More Taxis
description: If the City Council adopts Mayor Koch's plan, New York will add 1,800 badly needed taxis to the fleet of 11,800 now licensed to respond to street hails. But no conceivable increase in the fleet could eliminate the shortage of taxis at rush hour. A partial fix, serving both the public and the taxi owners, would be group riding.

title: GREEN LINKS D'AMATO TO CONVICT
description: Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, said yesterday that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato accepted a $500 campaign contribution from a Long Island nightclub owner who had been convicted on conspiracy charges and had ties to organized crime. Mr. Green said the Senator should return the contribution.

title: FAST FOOD, MIGRATION, HOMELESS
description: A pair of California entrepreneurs in the beach city of Santa Cruz, 65 miles south of San Francisco, have got on the wrong side of the giant McDonald's Corporation with the name they chose for their vegetarian fast-food restaurant, McDharma's Natural Fast Foods.

title: TASS REPORT ON DIPLOMATS
description: Following is the text of the Tass report today on the expulsion of five American diplomats, as transmitted by the press agency's English-language service:

title: CONGRESS SENDS A MESSAGE WITH AIR SAFETY MONEY
description: The appropriations bill passed by Congress Friday gave the Federal Aviation Administration the money needed to press ahead with tests of a system to avert collisions.

title: AMERICANS DO IT MAZDA'S WAY
description: The work day begins with shouting. Wearing their tan company uniforms and hard hats, the trainees from the United States stand facing each other outside the Mazda Motor Corporation factory in this small city in western Japan. First, the Americans bow to each other. Then they touch their hats and point at their partners' hats. ''Hat O.K.!'' one shouts, and the other replies. One by one, they check their partners' safety glasses, uniforms, name tags and shoes, shouting approval.

title: ARIZONA STATE SETS SIGHTS ON ROSE BOWL
description: Since Arizona State and Arizona defected from the Western Athletic Conference to take up with the Pacific-10 Conference in 1978, neither has come as close to reaching the Rose Bowl as the Arizona State Sun Devils are today. Historically, however, something almost always goes wrong for the team smelling the roses.

title: PLANNING BEGINS AT SITE OF MAN-MADE DRY FOREST
description: Just south of the Nicaraguan border in northwestern Costa Rica, in an area of savannas, farmlands, pastures and devastated forest land, a scientific project is getting under way: the creation by man of a diverse and complex tropical forest.

title: Gorbachev's Global Respite
description: One of the world's most far-seeing diplomats, asked for the reason behind the Soviet Union's current moves, responded with a question of his own: Had I read Mikhail Gorbachev's July 28 speech at Vladivostok?

title: Robertson's New Aides
description: Two Reagan Administration officials have left to join the political organization of the Rev. Pat Robertson, the all-but declared 1988 Republican Presidential candidate. Carolyn B. Sundseth, an associate director of the Office of Public Liaison in the White House, has joined the political operation of the television evangelist.

title: 55 Are Indicted in 27 States In Mailing of Explicit Photos
description: A complaint by an elderly woman who inadvertently received mail intended for a woman who posed for sexually explicit photographs upon request has led to the indictment of 55 people in 27 states, according to Federal prosecutors.

title: Boston and the Separatists
description: Boston's referendum next month on whether to create a separate municipality out of its black central-city neighborhoods already constitutes a civic tragedy, no matter how the vote turns out. It invites more of the racism that has periodically inflamed the city. It also bespeaks a disaffection so deep among some blacks in Boston that they are willing to embark on so self-destructive an experiment in racial separation.

title: JERSEY COURT WRESTLES AGAIN WITH DEATH AND CIVIL RIGHTS
description: New Jersey, long a leader in establishing the rights of patients to refuse invasive medical treatment in the face of growing medical technology, is preparing to further define those rights.

title: Washington Watch; Capital Budget Idea Is Revived
description: THE Reagan Administration is reviving an old idea for reporting Federal finances. In a little-noticed speech to the American Enterprise Institute last week, James C. Miller 3d, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said, ''Why not institute a capital budget?''

title: Sociologist Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: PRETORIA PUZZLE: 'HOMELANDS' AT ODDS
description: The South African authorities are seeking to intervene in a bizarre and potentially violent dispute between two of their own apartheid creations, the so-called homelands of Ciskei and Transkei, whose rivalries seem to have slipped beyond their creator's control.

title: HIGH PRESSURE OF WORLD SERIES HAS DOUBLE EDGE
description: When baseball players, even capable players, perform poorly at critical points in post-season games, it is not necessarily surprising: Few, if any, are immune to the pressure or tension of the World Series or the playoffs, when one bad pitch or one errant play can determine the World Series champion.

title: IN TV DEBATE, IT'S BOLOGNA VS. PARSLEY
description: Some picnic. Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi brought parsley; his Democratic challenger, Bella S. Abzug, bologna. Gabe Pressman, who was moderating a noontime debate yesterday between the two on the NBC-TV program ''News Forum,'' looked as if he were developing a bit of a bellyache.

title: PARTNERS POSE A THREAT
description: Michael Fay doesn't ride horses, but he owns and breeds more than 100 thoroughbreds. He doesn't like to sail, but he has three 12-Meters and better-than-average chances of winning the America's Cup. But that's not really why he's here.

title: Michael Andretti Narrows Title Gap
description: Michael Andretti tightened the Indy Car point race today with a runaway victory in the Circle K-Fiesta Bowl 200 at Phoenix International Raceway.

title: PENNSYLVANIA GOVERNOR'S RACE UPENDS THE WAR OF GENERATIONS
description: At first glance, the Pennsylvania Governor's race looks like a classic conflict between political generations.

title: FOR HASIDIC VILLAGE, UNEASY TIMES
description: Conceived in conflict 10 years ago, this insular Hasidic community in Orange County has once again become the focus of controversy - an enclave of ultraorthodox Jews intent on preserving their traditions, often over the objections of their more mainstream suburban neighbors.

title: IT SEEMS LIKE '75 AS EVANS EXCELS
description: The American League playoff was relatively quiet for Dwight Evans. He batted .214, hit a home run, played some helpful defense in right field. Solid. Typical of his career. Last night, Evans offered a similar performance. Perhaps it will be lost in Boston's 9-3 victory over the Mets, a victory that gave them a 2-0 lead in the World Series. But it will not take away from Evans's joy now, an elation he last felt in 1975 - his only other appearance in a World Series.

title: OPEC PLAN SNAGGED AS KUWAIT DEMANDS BIG RISE IN ITS QUOTA
description: A tentative OPEC production-sharing accord hit a snag tonight, after several member countries staked last-minute claims to higher quotas.

title: FOR 5TH AVE.: OFFICES OR STORES?
description: Fifth Avenue, America's premier shopping boulevard for most of this century, is entering a period of development that may determine whether it remains the country's pre-eminent retail address or becomes simply another midtown avenue of office towers with stores along the street.

title: To Remain Firmly Opposed to Apartheid's Madness
description: To The Editor:

title: FUSES ON FLORIDA BEACHES SAID TO BE SOVIET-MADE
description: Forty-seven explosive devices that washed ashore on beaches near here this weekend are Soviet-made rocket fuses, according to officials at Patrick Air Force Base.

title: AGENDA: Oct. 20, 1986
description: 'Pizza' Trial: Key Defendant on Stand The main defendant in the year-old ''pizza connection'' trial, Gaetano Badalamenti, could face pointed questions about wire-tapped telephone conversations that the Government says include coded references to drug dealing. The conversations, with some of the 20 other defendants, deal with shipments of ''shirts'' made of ''good cotton'' or ''10 percent acrylic'' - phrases the prosecution says signfy the purity and price of cocaine and heroin. 9:45 A.M., Federal District Court, Foley Square, Manhattan Hearing in Officer's Shooting Shavod Jones, the 15-year-old charged with attempted murder in last summer's shooting of a police officer, will appear in court for a hearing that could include the setting of a trial date. The teen-ager's lawyer is expected to argue that the case should be tried in Family Court, but his motion is unlikely to succeed since Mr. Jones has already been treated as an adult offender in a separate robbery case. 9:30 A.M., State Supreme Court, 100 Centre Street, Manhattan PROCEEDINGS Bane of LandlordsLawyers, musicians and people who work at night are sometimes discriminated against when they seek housing. Lawyers, some landlords say, are too quick to sue; musicians make too much noise, and night-shift workers clatter up and down the stairs at odd hours. Two similar bills about such occupational discrimination, one backed by Mayor Koch, are to be considered and perhaps voted out of the City Council's General Welfare Committee. 10 A.M., Committee Room, City Hall Long List LengthensThe list of lawyers who have represented Claus von Bulow grows ever longer, with each replacement slowing the continuing litigation of the man who was last year acquitted of trying to murder his wife.

title: ANALYSTS DIVIDED OVER RATES
description: Short- and long-term interest rates have been rising this month, and credit market participants are citing everything from prospects for improved economic growth and a strong gross national product report next Wednesday to a heavy supply of Treasury offerings.

title: 6 Institutions Get $240 Million
description: A reclusive widow from Beverly Hills has willed $240 million to four schools and two hospitals, although officials at some of the institutions said they had never heard of her.

title: What's Ahead For Conrail
description: Following are key steps in taking Conrail public:

title: PLASTIC-CAR PLAN DEAD, G.M.'S CHIEF CONFIRMS
description: Confirming industry reports, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said today that his company had scrapped plans to produce a new generation of plastic-body sports cars.

title: STUDENTS' BOOK CASHES IN ON A NEW RUBIK PUZZLE
description: Dr. Erno Rubik, the Hungarian inventor who bedeviled millions when his beguiling Mondrian-colored cube became a phenomenal best seller in the early 1980's, is himself bedeviled by two University of Pennsylvania computer-science graduate students who are cashing in on the spiraling popularity of his newest brain twister, which has been on the market for only two weeks.

title: Political or Serious?
description: Ronald Reagan has never been more breathtaking as a politician than in the weeks since Reykjavik. He has pictured failure as success, black as white, incompetence as standing up to the Russians. And according to the polls, Americans love the performance.

title: RIVALS SAID TO GET PAC CONTRIBUTIONS
description: Political action committees hedged their bets by contributing to both Republican and Democratic candidates in some of this year's Senate races, according to a study by Common Cause, the public affairs lobby.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN TOWN VOWS TO RESIST ORDER TO MOVE
description: The black residents of this rundown township north of Pretoria vowed today to resist an official edict to move them to a new site 15 miles away.

title: JETS' TOON HAS IMPOSING SKILLS
description: AROUND him, people are going crazy. But Al Toon glides in and out. He's there.

title: QUARRELS OF ELDERLY PARENTS
description: ''I HATED visiting my parents because all they did was argue,'' complained Josephine Mazzola, a 46-year-old Boston speech therapist. ''I used to come home exhausted because they expected me to settle their differences.''

title: PRAISE AND CRITICISM FROM MOSCOW CONDUCTOR
description: Yevgeny Svetlanov, smartly done up in windbreaker and ascot, paused on his way to Arlington National Cemetery this morning to answer some questions about the State Symphony Orchestra of the U.S.S.R. From Moscow. The orchestra - being advertised here as the Moscow State Symphony - plays in New York Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Dr. Wiggs Is the Bride Of Dr. Eric Schreiber
description: Dr. Janey Lee Wiggs, a daughter of Dolores Ray of Washington and Russell L. Wiggs Jr. of Spokane, Wash., was married yesterday to Dr. Eric Stephen Schreiber, a son of Lois Conway of San Diego and Dr. Herbert G. Schreiber of Windsor Locks, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass. Rabbi Neil Kominsky performed the ceremony at the Parker House in Boston.

title: COWBOYS EDGE EAGLES AT :002
description: Rafael Septien's 38-yard field goal with two seconds remaining lifted the Dallas Cowboys to a 17-14 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today.

title: CONDUCTED BROADWAY SHOWS
description: Stanley Lebowsky, who conducted nearly two dozen Broadway musicals, including the current productions ''Cats'' and ''Me and My Girl,'' died yesterday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center after a heart attack at his home on the Upper West Side. He was 59 years old.

title: Satellite Launching Reset
description: The twice-delayed launching of a scientific satellite has been rescheduled for Nov. 7 after technical defects were repaired, the Air Force said Friday. The satellite contains experiments aimed at improving communications between ground stations and weather and surveillance satellites that orbit the earth's poles.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashton-Tate, a software company based in Torrance, Calif., said Ronald S. Posner, executive vice president and general manager of the systems, service and information division, had resigned. Richard DeGiovanni was named acting general manager of the division.

title: ALSO AT STAKE NOV. 4: OVERSIGHT OF JUDICIARY
description: If the Democrats take control of the Senate after the elections next month, nowhere will the change be more obvious than in the darkly paneled hearing room of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: APPEAL FOR 2 DISSIDENTS TO BE MADE TO RUSSIAN
description: In an unusual move, representatives of two leading Soviet dissidents are to meet with a Russian diplomat in Washington today to appeal for the release of the dissidents.

title: Miss Bush, a Designer, Wed to Charles Leeds
description: Cynthia Katherine Grace Bush, the director of design for the Best Manufacturing Company, a maker of uniforms in New York, was married yesterday to Charles R. Leeds, a senior vice president and chief financial officer of the BAII Banking Corporation in New York. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin of Temple Emanu-El in New York performed the ceremony at the Jordan Pond House in the Acadia National Park, Bar Harbor, Me.

title: IN UTAH, CLEAN-CUT POLITICS SETS IN TONE IN TWO CHALLENGES TO REPUBLICANS
description: The snow-capped Wasatch Mountains bear silent witness to an anomaly: In perhaps the most Republican state in the nation, two Democratic candidates are waging strong campaigns for seats held by Republicans in the House of Representatives.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: IF GORBACHEV CLOSED SIBERIA
description: Dear Mikhail S. Gorbachev:

title: Utility to Start Phone Refunds
description: New York Telephone Company begins refunding nearly $1.3 million to more than 260,000 customers this week for excess charges stemming from bounced checks, the State Consumer Protection Board said yesterday.

title: Bridge to Offer Lane For Use by Car Pools
description: A new eastbound bus and car-pool approach lane to the George Washington Bridge is to open this morning in what officials call a new effort to encourage use of higher-occupancy vehicles during the rush hour.

title: N.A.A.C.P. OPENS NEW HEADQUARTERS
description: Rosa Parks was there. So was the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, Myrlie Evers and Daisy Bates.

title: BILL PASSED TO HELP FARM BANKS SPREAD LOSSES
description: In a flurry of last-minute activity before adjourning, Congress has passed legislation to give the Farm Credit System, a network of borrower-owned cooperative banks, a way to spread its losses over the next 20 years.

title: Soviet Report on Sub Adhered to Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: KUERTI PIANO RECITAL
description: ANTON KUERTI'S Saturday afternoon piano recital at Alice Tully Hall was deeply satisfying. He chose a program devoted entirely to Beethoven - the Sonatas in G (Op. 31, No. 1) and F (Op. 10, No. 2), the Fantasy in G minor (Op. 77), Two Rondos (Op. 51), the Six Bagatelles (Op. 126) and the Andante Favori in F (WoO 57) -works that are neither war horses nor particularly obscure.

title: Bucking the Odds
description: The loudest roars at Belmont Park the last two weeks came not at the finish of races but instead, at least when there was an afternoon game going on, from the crowds milling around television monitors, watching the Mets. Yes, New York's horseplayers, just like New York's butchers, bakers and barbers, have been gripped by World Series fever.

title: 8 Hurt, 20 Held in Shootout Between 2 Motorcycle Gangs
description: A shootout between rival motorcycle gangs at a charity benefit left at least eight people hospitalized, one in critical condition, and 20 others under arrest, the police said today.

title: METS FACE TOUGH ODDS
description: The Mets, Keith Hernandez said, ''have to take our off-day tomorrow, retreat, dig in and come out fighting.'' But have they already, in only two games of the World Series, dug themselves such a hole that they won't be able to fight their way out of it?

title: WITH VISIONS OF OIL FORTUNES, 4,000 HEIR-HOPEFULS CONVENE
description: British genealogists came to the hills of northeast Tennessee today and told scores of Americans in search of black gold that they may be heirs to an oil fortune.

title: Advertising; Afrin Goes After Users Of Nasal Decongestants
description: Dristan, Sinex and Neo-synephrine are all fighting for their piece of the $210 million nasal decongestant spray market. And their major weapon is television advertising.

title: Advertising; Audi Ads Are Team Effort
description: THE two 30-second TV commercials for the Audi motorcar that ran a total of five times on network television yesterday marked the first example of the creative outpouring of the merged talents of Doyle Dane Bernbach and Needham Harper Worldwide.

title: Topics; Foreign Competitions: Homage to Catalonia
description: Barcelona is an admirable choice to host the Olympic Games in 1992 -the 500th anniversary, as it happens, of Spain's discovery of the New World. Not only is the timing right, but Barcelona has a moral and symbolic claim to this international festival.

title: SEAHAWKS BEAT GIANTS BY 17-12
description: Before today's game, the Giants thought they should beat the Seahawks, and after the game they thought they should have beaten them. But the Seahawks turned two interceptions into touchdowns, then held off the Giants' furious finish and won, 17-12.

title: 'BANQUET' OF MIDEAST VIEWS IS ENDING
description: For the last six years, through a series of lectures and discussions on the Middle East, the American Enterprise Institute here has provided one of the few forums in the world where an official of the American Jewish Committee can ask questions of an Iraqi foreign minister, or where a relative of King Hussein can converse with an Israeli rabbi on the subject of Israel's moral crisis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We were down 3-0, then we came back to 3-2. We were in the game.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ASIAN ROOTS The arts and rhythms of Asia and America will move this week into the Universal Jazz Coalition's Jazz Center, 380 Lafayette Street, near East Fourth Street. This Asian/Asian-American Jazz and Cultural Festival gives every indication - this being its third time around - of becoming a hardy New York perennial.

title: HASENFUS SAYS HE DOES NOT KNOW WHO RAN NICARAGUA OPERATION
description: The American captured when a rebel plane was shot down over Nicaragua said in a television interview broadcast tonight that while he believed he was working for the Central Intelligence Agency he was uncertain who actually ran the rebel supply operation based in El Salvador.

title: GET 18 HITS FOR 2-0 LEAD
description: The wonderful world of the Mets, a happy and heady place in baseball all year, crumbled a bit more last night before 55,063 wondering fans in Shea Stadium.

title: Environment Proposal Is Too Costly a Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Faults Inquiry Into Fatal Mine Fire
description: Officials of the United Mine Workers have criticized a Federal agency's investigation of the 1984 Wilberg mine fire, saying its narrow focus did not explain why 27 miners died.

title: Eve Smith Is the Bride Of Jonathan L. Rounds
description: Eve Karen Smith, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David I. Smith of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonathan Lincoln Rounds, a son of Austin L. Rounds of Wilmington, Mass., and the late Anne M. Jones of Honolulu. Judge Amy Herz Juviler of the Criminal Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: In Defense of the Portuguese Language
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-SOVIET TRAFFIC CONTINUES APACE
description: The Kremlin's expulsion of five American diplomats today added to an unusual flurry of traffic between the Soviet Union and the United States in recent weeks.

title: 2 LOTUS PROGRAMS DUE FOR TECHNICAL USERS
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, whose 1-2-3 spreadsheet program for personal computers dominates the business software market, is expected to announce today two new products aimed at scientific and technical users, including the company's first word processing program.

title: Walesa Joins 5,000 to Mark Anniversary of Priest's Killing
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, joined 5,000 worshipers at a mass today marking the second anniversary of the death of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, who was tortured and beaten to death by the secret police.

title: MANILA RESUMES PEACE TALKS WITH THE COMMUNISTS
description: Government and Communist negotiators this weekend resumed peace talks that had been threatened by the arrest of a rebel leader, an official said today.

title: DESIGNER SCULPTURES MOUNTAINS TO ATTRACT SKIERS
description: To an unusual degree, Paul Mathews has combined his life's passion with his life's work.

title: TAX BILL MAY SPUR RUSH TO FORM PARTNERSHIPS
description: Tax experts say there could be a rush by small and medium-sized companies to transform themselves from public corporations to limited partnerships in the coming months.

title: Afghan Leader Backs Reconciliation
description: The Afghan leader, Najibullah, has told a group of Western reporters that reconciliation with Moslem guerrillas is his main goal and that he envisions political parties in the future.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, FIERCE CHALLENGE TO JUDGES
description: The face of a smiling 12-year-old girl has looked out repeatedly from television screens across California in the last week, followed by an appeal to voters that they remove three Justices from the California Supreme Court in the Nov. 4 election.

title: Tests Indicate Patient Given Kidney Has AIDS Antibodies
description: A man who received a donor kidney found to contain AIDS antibodies also tests positive for antibodies to the deadly virus itself, hospital officials reported.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL JETS VS. DENVER BRONCOS, at Giants Stadium, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 9 P.M.) BASKETBALL NETS VS. INDIANAPOLIS PACERS, at Fort Worth, 7:30 P.M., preseason game.

title: Big Press, Small Press and Staying Impartial
description: To the Editor:

title: COURTS DEFIED IN CITY'S AWARD OF TOW PERMITS
description: In defiance of court rulings, a New York City transportation commissioner repeatedly refused to award a franchise for highway towing to a winning bidder who had challenged a longtime industry cartel, court records show.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1986
description: International

title: TWO PASSAGES FROM VOZNESENSKY
description: These passages from Andrei Voznesensky's work, ''The Ditch: A Spiritual Trial,'' were translated for The New York Times in Moscow by Victor Klimenko and Stephanie Sandler: Afterword On April 7, 1986, my friends and I were driving along the Feodosiya highway from Sevastopol. The clock on the taxi's dashboard showed 10 in the morning. The taxi driver was Vassili Fyodorovich Lesnykh, a man of about 60, reddened by the wind, heavy-set, his blue eyes faded by all he had seen. Over and over he kept repeating his painful story. Here, just outside the city, at the 10-kilometer mark, 12,000 peaceful citizens were shot during the war.

title: Barbara Reville Weds Dr. Morris J. Birnbaum
description: Barbara Anne Reville, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Reville of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Morris J. Birnbaum, the son of Grace Birnbaum of Great Neck, L.I., and Longboat Key, Fla., and the late Dr. Harry A. Birnbaum. Rabbi Alvin Roth and the Rev. David Miller, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Hampden (Mass.)

title: CITY CHECKS ON REPORTS OF BEATINGS AT RIKERS
description: The city's Correction Commissioner said yesterday that he was investigating reports that handcuffed inmates at Rikers Island were beaten by correction officers over the weekend after they were moved from one jail to another on the island.

title: SEAHAWKS WIN IN TRENCHES
description: It was a classic matchup in the trenches, the offensive tackle against the defensive end. The offensive tackle was the 6-foot-6-inch, 285-pound Karl Nelson of the Giants, and the defensive end was the 6-foot-3-inch, 252-pound Jacob Green of the Seahawks.

title: Racists Gather to Declare White Republic in Idaho
description: About 20 white supremacists burned an 18-foot-high cross Saturday to signal establishment of what they say will be a white republic in the Northwest.

title: YANKS ADD COACH, DISMISS 2
description: In a shakeup of Lou Piniella's coaching staff, the Yankees have added Mike Ferraro and released Roy White and Joe Altobelli, a club source said yesterday. Mark Connor, the pitching coach, and Jeff Torborg, the bullpen coach, also will return, and Stump Merrill will join the staff, the source said, adding that one coach remains to be hired.

title: RODMAN & RENSHAW CAPITAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TOXIC WASTE LAW: A PRAGMATIC VICTORY
description: Until virtually the 11th hour last week, it appeared that President Reagan was going to shoot down an arduously achieved bill to extend the national hazardous waste cleanup program.

title: On the Trade Wars
description: Efforts to assure American companies a level playing field in trade dealings with the Japanese have had many ups and downs, and Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, has just entered a complaint of another down.

title: NOW FOR THE REAL ISSUES
description: The torrent of self-serving argument about who won and lost what at Reykjavik is beside the central point. The breathtaking new fact resulting from the freestyle encounter of President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev is that two basic questions have been posed seriously for the first time.

title: U.S. AUDIT ACCUSES CATHOLIC CHARITY
description: A United States Government audit asserts that Catholic Relief Services, the largest voluntary organization distributing free United States surplus food overseas, improperly refused food to African mothers and children who were unable to pay fees to the group amounting to pennies a month.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STANDARD PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. RED SOX, at Boston, third game of World Series, 8:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:35 P.M., WCBS 880, 8:10 P.M.) BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS.

title: USG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $26,668,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and a loss from discontinued operations of $1,456,000 and $3,026,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $281,000 and $26,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Court to Decide Rail Tax Case
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a lower Federal court had made it too hard for railroads to prove that states have charged discriminatorily high taxes on their property.

title: UNION FEDERAL S&L ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company noted that its net interest income increased in the latest quarter, attributing the improvement mainly to improvement in its interest rate spread.

title: A Lonely President At Insurance Concern
description: Brian M. O'Hara is the new president and chief operating officer of the X. L. Insurance Company, the new offshore insurance company with $600 million in assets. He is also its first full-time employee.

title: SPENDTHRIFT FARM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: MELVIN H. PURVIS 3D
description: Melvin Horace Purvis 3d, a nondenominational minister who lost to Strom Thurmond in the 1984 race for the United States Senate in South Carolina, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack.

title: MICROSOFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Auto Maker's Statement
description: Following is the text of the statement today by Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, on the decision to sell a subsidiary, General Motors South African Ltd.: There were several factors behind the decision, but our main objective was to create a financially sound organization which will have a greater chance for long-term viability and will continue to be a positive force in the ending of apartheid.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOUSING WOES PERPLEX ELDERLY IN SUBURBS
description: Elderly residents of the New York suburbs, caught in a simmering dispute between the generations, are being forced by the thousands into substandard housing, homelessness and despair.

title: PARENTS, FOOD AND FAT
description: THE popular notion that overindulgent parents are the cause of childhood obesity has been dealt another blow. Earlier this year, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania, who studied adopted children and their adoptive and natural parents, showed that genetics had a far greater influence over children's body weight than did environmental factors.

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: A report in the Agenda column yesterday about a civil suit against Claus von Bulow, who was acquitted in Rhode Island last year of attempting to kill his wife,described his legal representation incorrectly. Mr. von Bulow is represented by Harold R. Tyler Jr.; Michael F. Armstrong represents Mr. von Bulow's stepchildren.

title: OPERA: MARTON AND DOMINGO IN 'TOSCA' AT THE MET
description: UNDER any circumstances, ''Tosca'' is one of the most violent of operas, but last night's performance at the Metropolitan, the first of the season, turned out to be a particularly bruising affair. Shortly before Eva Marton was to sing Tosca's celebrated second-act aria, ''Vissi d'arte,'' the Hungarian soprano caught an elbow in the jaw during her simulated struggle with the villainous Scarpia, her would-be rapist. Some simulation: during the intermission word came from backstage that Miss Marton had suffered a dislocated jaw.

title: MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains of 81 cents a share from recognition of pension income and pension settlement gains, as well as a non-recurring gain from the sale of certain oil property rights.

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a net gain of $43 million, or 24 cents a share, related to a reversion of surplus pension funds. c-Includes a net gain of $19 million, or 22 cents a share, related to the sale of 50-percent of Union Texas Petroleum Co., after a charge related to the shutdown as well as the writedown of certain assets in connection with the anticipated disposition of certain businesses. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month results include the operations of Signal Cos., which was consolidated as of Oct. 1, 1985. The company said the 1985 results were restated for comparative purposes to reflect the deconsolidation of Henley Group, Inc.

title: AGENDA: Oct. 21, 1986
description: Turning Point for Town House A brick and stone mansion could be topped by a steel and glass addition if its owner gets his way and the Landmarks Preservation Commission declines to protect the building. At a hearing today, proponents are likely to argue that the 1892 town house, on West End Avenue at 85th Street, is an unusual design that draws on several European architectural forms. But others disagree, including the owner, Ivan Stux, who says age does not ''make a landmark.'' 9:30 A.M., Landmarks and Preservation Commission, 20 Vesey Street, Manhattan

MOSES ASCH, WHO FOUNDED FOLKWAYS RECORDS, DIES AT 81
description: Moses Asch, who founded and operated Folkways Records, died Sunday of a heart attack at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and a resident of New York City.

title: H. FREEMAN MATTHEWS, DIPLOMAT SINCE 1920'S
description: H. Freeman Matthews, a former Deputy Under Secretary of State and a 38-year Foreign Service veteran who had been Ambassador to Sweden, to the Netherlands and to Austria, died Sunday at his home in Washington after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: LEON HENDERSON, A LEADING NEW DEAL ECONOMIST
description: Leon Henderson, a leading New Deal economist who became the first director of the Office of Price Administration, which was established to curb inflation in World War II, died Sunday at the Tri-City Medical Center in Oceanside, Calif. He was 91 years old and lived in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Results include tax credits of $346,000 in the latest quarter and $145,800 in the year-ago period.

title: HEAVY-DUTY SOFTWARE FOR SERIOUS WRITERS
description: THE Lotus Development Corporation is now putting the final touches on Manuscript, the company's first major word processing program. If the final product is anything like the test version demonstrated the other day, it will set new standards for speed and power.

description: The share earnings were restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock distribution issued on May 14, 1986.

description: To the Editor:

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHERE BANK RIVALRY IS HOT
description: Not long ago one of the last frontiers of banking opportunity was the vast realm of medium-sized corporations that kept so many local bankers in clover. Over recent years, just about every type of bank imaginable - from large regional banks to money-center institutions to the great lenders of Europe and Asia - has pursued the field with abandon.

title: NICARAGUA FORMALLY CHARGES HASENFUS
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American captured when a rebel supply plane was downed over Nicaragua two weeks ago, was charged here today with several political crimes carrying a maximum sentence of 30 years.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARARA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $900,000 and a cummulative effect of a charge of $1,328,000 in method of providing loss reserves on debt securities. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $622,000 for the quarter and $854,000 for the 9 months. Revenue represents gross revenue.

title: Toll Workers Give Stickers ALBANY (AP) -
description: Toll booth attendants at several major entrances to the New York State Thruway handed out bumper stickers on Sunday that prominently featured Governor Cuomo's name, officials said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1986
description: The World Mozambique's leader was killed in a plane crash in South Africa, Pretoria announced. The cause of the crash, which also killed 25 other people, was not immediately known. The leader, Samora Moises Machel, had been President since 1975.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This was a reluctant decision, but the right decision when you consider the pressure the U.S. company has been under and the pressure we've been under.'' - Robert A. White, the American managing director of General Motors South African Ltd. [ D30:5. ]

title: SENATE REJECTS NO. 2 JERSEY JOB
description: The New Jersey Senate yesterday voted down two bills calling for the creation of the post of lieutenant governor, a position requested by Governor Kean in his State of the State Message last January.

title: THEATER: 'ALL MY SONS' REVIVED AT LONG WHARF
description: As a play with a social conscience and an unswerving moral commitment, ''All My Sons'' is as relevant today as it was when it was first produced in 1947. Though in this early work, his first Broadway success, Arthur Miller was unable to conceal the mechanics of his dramaturgy, the play has a cumulative emotional power.

title: PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 12
description: b-Net loss

title: CAMPEAU ADDS TWIST TO ALLIED BID
description: In another wrinkle in its six-week-old fight to acquire the Allied Stores Corporation, the Campeau Corporation yesterday raised its offer for the portion of Allied stock it would lack after its $66-a-share tender offer expires Friday.

title: Israel Holds 3 Jews in Attack On Arab Sanitation Workers
description: Three Jews were arrested today after assaulting two Arab sanitation men in Bat Yam, south of Tel Aviv, in apparent retaliation for the recent fatal stabbings of Jews in Gaza, police spokesmen said.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: The weather turned wet and chill in Paris this past weekend. The French fashion business, too, has been feeling a chill. Stores here are mostly empty and quiet. Tourists have given France a cold shoulder this season, deterred as much by the strong franc as by fear of terrorism. The fashion collections have been affected too, evidenced by the absence of most top American models at the shows now going on in three tents in a courtyard of the Louvre.

title: WOLVERINE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50-percent stock distribution in June.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax provision for carpet operation restructuring costs of $4.3 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Reflects legal, investment banking and other expenses relating to Mohasco's stock buyback program of $486,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September.

title: U.S. WEIGHS REPLY ON SOVIET OUSTER
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was considering the expulsion of five Soviet diplomats in retaliation for Moscow's order for five American diplomats to leave.

title: ENRON BUYS BACK ITS STOCK
description: The Enron Corporation yesterday ended a double threat to its independence by repurchasing stock held by both Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, and the Leucadia National Corporation at a price well above the going rate.

title: SEVENTH HEAVEN?
description: Don't worry. The historical record shows that in the 10 previous World Series involving the Mets or the Red Sox, neither franchise has ever won fewer than three games, which suggests at least the drama of a seventh-game showdown at Shea Stadium next Sunday.

description: Revenues represent total investment revenues.

title: RAZOR-EDGED RACE FOR MARYLAND SEAT
description: Barbara A. Mikulski grabbed Calvin Guy's arm and looked up, many feet, to read the legend on his Harley-Davidson sunglasses - ''Ride to Live, Live to Ride.''

title: INTERNATIONAL HOLDING CAPIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 MET LOSSES, NOW THE WALL
description: Now their backs were literally to The Wall. And there, in the shadow of Fenway Park's left-field wall, the most inviting and most dangerous home run target in baseball, the Mets will resume the World Series on Tuesday night, two games down to the Boston Red Sox and thinking about the unthinkable.

title: EXTRA GUARDS FOR SOVIET GROUP
description: Under rigid security, the Moscow State Symphony gave its scheduled performance at Avery Fisher Hall last night, despite a small fire outside the hall earlier.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes charges of $130.6 million related to anticipated loss on long- term insurance contracts in effect Aug. 31, 1986 in the quarter and latest year. c-Includes an $8 million, or 8 cents a share, gain from favorable adjustments of prior year reimbursement issues and the gain on the sale of an investment in a health care-related venture in the second quarter. d-Net income e-Includes non-operating charges and credits, primarily a gain on the sale of three hospitals, of $3 million, or 3 cent a share in the first quarter. The company said included in the latest quarter was a write-off of certain intangible assets, provisions for the estimated costs associated with the planned disposition of certain Medfirst facilities, and a writedown for a hospital in Mexico City.

title: PARIS: CHANEL KICKS UP ITS HEELS
description: Karl Lagerfeld electrified the Chanel audience this morning with an engaging show that spoofed fashion and boosted Chanel. Neither will be the same again.

The share earnings for the 9 months in 1985 included 20 cents a share in net gains from discontinued operations and other dispositions, and 25 cents a share in earnings from settlements of outstanding issues involving certain telecommunications contracts in Africa. Sales and revenue in the latest quarter included insurance and finance revenue of $2.5 billion, compared with $2 billion in year-ago period. Sales and revenue for the latest 9 months included insurance and finance revenue of $7.3 billion, compared with $5.8 billion for the year- earlier period. The year-ago quarter's revenue figures is restated.

title: POLLUTED MEDITERRANEAN ON THE WAY TO RECOVERY
description: THE Mediterranean, a sea whose death from pollution was fashionable to predict not so long ago, is on its way to gradual recovery, according to the United Nations official who directs a 17-nation campaign to clean it up.

title: BOGGS ADAPTS TO DEFENSE WITH EASE
description: The general presumption about Wade Boggs was that a glove on his left hand was some kind of foreign and unlikely object. But he stood in the clubhouse this afternoon looking comfortable, a ball in one hand, a fielder's mitt in the other and a bat nowhere in sight.

description: It is a ball park, not a stadium.

title: A DEFINITE FINISH FOR BRONCO STREAK
description: The Denver Broncos had run into several good teams on their way to winning their first six games. But they hadn't encountered anything like they saw tonight.

description: A car bomb exploded in an eastern suburb early today, killing the driver, the police said.

title: MOZAMBICAN CHIEF DIES IN AIR CRASH IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: President Samora M. Machel, leader of Mozambique since it won independence from Portugal in 1975, was killed Sunday night in a plane crash in South Africa, the Pretoria Government announced today.

title: FRANKFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARA Services To Buy Servisco
description: ARA Services Inc. - a company that provides food services, rents work uniforms and manages child-care and health-care operations -agreed to buy Servisco, another garment rental company, for $30 a share in cash, or about $63.9 million.

title: GIANTS ARE SEEKING TO MEND OFFENSE
description: The Giants and the Washington Redskins have played the same seven teams this year. The only difference in their records is that the Redskins beat the Seattle Seahawks, 19-14, three weeks ago and the Giants lost to the Seahawks, 17-12, Sunday.

title: SEASON OF DISASTERS ENDS FOR ALPINISTS
description: The high country is now closed by cold and snow until next May, and alpinists in the Pacific Northwest Cascade range are looking back on a disastrous 1986 climbing season in which 11 lives were lost.

SOME SAY MEESE REPORT RATES AN 'X'
description: After New York publishers declined to reprint the ''Final Report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography,'' which the Government Printing Office issued last summer in two volumes, Rutledge Hill Press of Nashville scored something of a publishing coup by rushing it out last month in an inexpensive one-volume edition.

title: U.S. BONDS CONTINUE TO SLUMP
description: Pessimism was pervasive in the credit markets yesterday as Treasury bond prices fell to their lowest levels since early this year and short-term interest rates continued to rise.

title: KEYSTONE HERITAGE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: SOVIET ORCHESTRA PLAYS SHOSTAKOVICH 5TH
description: ONE thing can be said for threats of violence: they certainly put an electric charge in the air. As it happened, the performance last night by the Moscow State Symphony - or the State Symphony Orchestra of the U.S.S.R., as it is formally known - at Avery Fisher Hall passed without political incident. But the half-hour delay caused by the stringent security set up a nervous anticipation unrelated to the musical occasion.

title: AQUINO MEETS WITH HER ANGRY DEFENSE MINISTER
description: Despite worries about a Government crisis, President Corazon C. Aquino met publicly today with her Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, and smiled and patted his hand. Mr. Enrile, for his part, wore an angry expression.

title: More Words
description: There must be some protocol issue involved here.

description: Government officials, as is widely known, like to use words, lots of them. Sometimes they use so many words that the pages are measured in bulk rather than counted.

FIRST TWO GAMES FALL SHORT IN DRAMA
description: You don't have to be a Mets fan to be disappointed in the World Series. Even viewers with bipartisan spirits are likely to feel blue over the first two contests.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Barris Industries, Beverly Hills, Calif., said its chairman, Chuck Barris, would sell two million shares of the company, or 23 percent of the outstanding stock, for $13 each to Giant Group Ltd. The sale is subject to approval by the Barris board and compliance with the Federal Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust amendments.

title: Chrysler to Spend $1 Billion for Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would spend more than $1 billion to build a truck assembly facility at a site in a crumbling section of Detroit where its Aries and Reliant cars are currently produced.

title: Continental Illinois Declares Dividend
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, which was kept afloat two years ago by a $4.5 billion Federal rescue plan, declared its first dividend on common stock since February 1984, another important symbolic move to show it is on the road to recovery.

title: ADVANCES-AND PROBLEMS-ON TWO FRONTS
description: AMONG the trends in personal computing, two - the proliferation of graphics and the coming of compact disks for read-only memory - seem to be garnering the greatest attention at the moment. Both pose significant potential problems.

description: b-Net loss

title: Politics by the Numbers
description: The confusion that has marked Democratic politics in Illinois since two supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political conspiracy theorist, won the nominations for Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of State last March will be reflected on the November ballot.

title: Bridge: There Is Benefit in Counting Cards Held in the Rival's Suit
description: In a competitive auction it pays to keep an eye on the number of cards held in the opponent's suit. A singleton or a void is obviously a plus, but length can also be desirable: it may be possible to infer shortness in partner's hand.

title: Illinois Offering Highway Issue
description: The Illinois State Toll Highway Authority tentatively priced $400 million of highway revenue bonds through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Inc.

title: CITICORP PROFITS UP 8.8% IN 3D PERIOD
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, said yesterday that it earned $247 million in the third quarter, up 8.8 percent from net income of $227 million in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: HART, INVOKING A SENATE CUSTOM, STUMPS FOR GREEN
description: Campaigning for Mark Green, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado arrived in New York yesterday to criticize Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato - but not too much.

description: b-Includes income of $344,000 and $267,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the results reflect the planned divestitures of the Hilton-Davis chemical business.

title: SHAMIR CABINET SWORN IN, ACCORDING TO ROTATION
description: Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud bloc's leader, was sworn in today as Israel's new Prime Minister. He replaced Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
'Raggedy Ann' Closes
description: ''Raggedy Ann,'' a musical fantasy with book by William Gibson and music by Joe Raposo, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Nederlander Theater. The play, directed by Patricia Birch, ran for 15 previews and 5 regular performances.

title: DANCE: ROOTS OF A MODERN AMERICAN ART FORM
description: THE selective survey of early American modern dance on view Sunday afternoon in a program billed as ''Roots: Foundations of American Modern Dance'' had several unexpected virtues.

title: New Gold Coins Sell Briskly
description: The first general-circulation gold coin to be minted in the United States in more than 50 years went on sale today, and Treasury Department officials reported brisk demand.

title: THE STAGE: 'CHINA FISH' AT LAMB'S
description: DAVID MCFADZEAN'S drama ''The China Fish,'' set in 1975 in a southern Indiana town threatened by flood, depicts a family coming to terms with the death of an alcoholic father. Estranged from her daughter Val, Jenise (Mary Armstrong) is considering marrying Bud (Paul Collins), a local barber who dreams of converting her late husband's fishing tackle shop into a video arcade. Distraught and secretive, Val (Sally Prager) has retreated into a childhood fantasy world. Periodically she repairs to the tackle shop for impassioned colloquies with an enigmatic observer known simply as the Man (Leon Russom), who represents her dead father's memory.

title: THE DANCE: MARIA LA BAJA'
description: STYLE and content often vie for attention on the dance stage these days. But ''Return to Maria La Baja,'' performed by the Feld Ballet on Sunday afternoon at the Joyce Theater, is all about atmosphere.

BECOR WESTERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BAUSCH & LOMB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OUT OF HIS ERA: DENNIS BOYD
description: This is Dennis Boyd's world, and everyone is merely a face in the grandstand. It is 1930, not 1986; the Negro Leagues, not necessarily the World Series. The uniforms are loose-fitting cotton, the shoes are black and devoid of any manufacturer's markings, the red stirrups are cut low. Boyd is a younger Satchel Paige, standing tall and lean as a solitary figure on the pitcher's mound. The moment is his alone.

title: COURT WILL REVIEW ACCESS TO BEACHES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether California can require owners of private beachfront property to give the public access to their beaches as a condition of allowing the owners to build on adjoining land.

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring, after- tax gain from the sale of assets of $4,678 for the latest quarter, compared with a $165,661 gain in year-ago quarter; for the latest 9 months, the gain was $933,565 compared with $499,599 a year earlier.

title: MEXICO'S NEW TYPE OF EMIGRANT: WELL-TO-DO, SKILLED, DISILLUSIONED
description: Acting quietly, the father-and-son team that runs one of Mexico's leading industrial groups recently liquidated most of the men's assets here. Then they boarded their personal planes and flew north to new homes and headquarters in Aspen, Colo., and La Jolla, Calif.

description: Companies

title: A Shiver in Southern Africa
description: If there is anything southern Africa doesn't need, it's more instability. Now a new shiver reverberates from the plane crash yesterday that killed Mozambique's President, Samora Machel. He was a Marxist-Leninist presiding over a poor, war-torn country. He was also a political realist who more than once advanced the cause of stability in this troubled region.

title: From Oil Industry To Teaching Science
description: Laid-off engineers and geologists are being invited to try their hand at teaching math and science under a program developed by the Chevron Corporation and universities in three cities.

title: On a Vital Mission
description: Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, skipped the final week of this Congressional session to return home on a critical political mission. Mr. Laxalt is campaigning full time for Jim Santini, who is Mr. Laxalt's choice to succeed him in the Senate, but is trailing. Beyond trying to salvage Mr. Santini's chances, Mr. Laxalt, who has expressed an interest in seeking the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, was also campaigning for himself.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
They May Not Play Dice With Their Patients' Lives
description: To the Editor:

DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Defense, and Defensive, in Congress; Shoving a Plane Down the Pentagon's Throat
description: New Yorkers will find no reason for excessive pride in the victory their Congressional delegation has won on the T-46A trainer plane. It's a prime example of how by fighting for pork in the defense budget, Congress loses the battle to shape national defense.

title: IN 'PACIFIC CENTURY,' SARIS AMID THE PALM TREES?
description: Late at night, as passengers stumble into the nearly deserted arrival hall of a Fijian airport, Indian music is drifting from a radio in the corner, and the tellers who scramble to cash travelers' checks seem to be speaking Hindi.

title: ITT Profit Up 63.6% In Quarter
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings climbed 63.6 percent on a 20 increase in sales, helped by strong gains in its insurance and financial operations.

title: 'JOHNNIE MAE GIBSON: F.B.I.' ON CBS
description: IF you must watch the World Series on NBC tonight, be assured that you won't be missing much on CBS. Perhaps bowing to industry wisdom that there is not much point to competing seriously with baseball's championship games, CBS is offering at 9 P.M. one of those television movies that claims to be a ''dramatization based on true events.'' In fact, the basic story of ''Johnnie Mae Gibson: F.B.I.'' is reasonably promising. Here is a woman, a black woman who is married and has a young daughter, who becomes an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: LAG IN HIGH-TECH TRADE SEEN IN CONGRESS STUDY
description: The United States is losing its ability to compete in high-technology manufacturing, considered a growth sector of the economy, and faces a deficit in high-technology trade of more than $2 billion this year, according to a study released today by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

title: Market Place; How Digital Bested a Rival
description: BOTH the Data General Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation, once regarded as perennial rivals in the minicomputer business, were outstanding stock market performers in 1984. Data General's shares climbed 57.7 percent, while Digital's stock rose 53.8 percent.

title: Ex-Seabrook Workers Cite Possible Defects
description: Six state legislators who oppose the opening of the Seabrook nuclear plant appeared at a news conference today with two former workers who said the plant might have a variety of defects.

title: COMP-U-CHECK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

description: Seven players tied for first in the seventh Memorial Day Classic Tournament in Los Angeles - the grandmasters Nick DeFirmian of San Francisco; Larry Christiansen of Pasadena, Calif.; Dmitry Gurevich of Brooklyn, and Sergey Kudrin of Stamford, Conn.; the international masters Igor Ivanov of Montreal and Kamran Shirazi of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Larry Remlinger of Pasadena.

title: TRAVELERS REAL ESTATE INV TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Limited's Credit Lines
description: The Limited Inc. said yesterday that it had doubled its committed bank credit lines under revolving-credit and term-loan agreements to $1.4 billion.

title: Tosco Arranging Debt-Equity Sale
description: The Tosco Corporation, Santa Monica, Calif., one of the nation's largest independent oil refiners, announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $325 million of debt and equity through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. Tosco experienced heavy losses in 1983 and 1984 before showing a profit in 1985.

title: BANKVERMONT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Throwing Money at the Drug Problem
description: The anti-drug program Congress approved before adjourning was conceived in fear and developed in cynicism. Legislators who traditionally decry throwing money at a problem outbid each other in a panicky appeal to voters who appear aroused about narcotics as never before.

title:
Careers;
Recruiting Business Is Booming
description: BUSINESS is booming at management recruiting firms, despite the fact that corporate staffing is becoming leaner. Perhaps one reason is that mobility among managers is rising. Also, many recruiters say, the top managers that they find for companies tend to be flexible about moving where compensation packages are better.

title: Cougar Attack on Boy Prompts Park's Closing
description: A county wilderness park has been closed indefinitely as a result of the mauling of a 6-year-old boy by a cougar on Sunday. It was the second incident of its kind this year at the Ronald W. Caspers Wilderness Regional Park.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the effect of the tax bill on corporations misstated the revenues of Community Psychiatric Centers for the nine months ended Aug. 31. They were $184.1 million.

title: Clearing Inc. Deal
description: Hanson Industries North America, a subsidiary of Hanson Trust P.L.C. of Britain, said that it had agreed to sell Clearing Inc. to the Hitachi Zosen Corporation for $64 million in cash and notes. Clearing, which makes hydraulic and mechanical action presses, had sales last year of about $39 million and pretax profits of $3.9 million. Its net asset value is about $64 million.

description: The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in August 1986.

title: Microsoft Net Up 2 1/2 Times
description: The Microsoft Corporation, a leading producer of personal computer software based in Redmond, Wash., today reported sharply higher net income for its first quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: UNDER OATH, CLAUS VON BULOW DENIES INJECTING WIFE IN 1979

title: Advertising; Shotgun And Rifle Approach
description: OF the book ''MaxiMarketing'' it has been said, ''This book may well be the book that tells how advertising will be in the 1990's.'' That could be a biased opinion, however, because it comes from Stan Rapp, who wrote the book with Tom Collins.

title: Underdog Role

title: Q&A
description: Q. What caused the great plagues to wane? A.Most of the great plagues such as bubonic plague and tuberculosis waned when they saturated the susceptible population, leaving everyone either dead of the disease or immune to it, according to Dr. James Cassedy, a medical historian at the National Library of Medicine in Bethesda, Md. But he said such diseases may recur later in the same or other areas.

title: Ascent Continues At McDonald's
description: Michael R. Quinlan, one of the three ''barbers'' who runs the McDonald's Corporation, will soon be wearing an additional hat. Continuing his rapid ascent, the 41-year-old Mr. Quinlan, the president and chief operating officer, will become its chief executive on March 1.

title: DART & KRAFT INC reports earnings for 13wks to Sept 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $37,600,000 and $2.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss of $12,700,000 for the quarter and a gain of $24 million for the 9 months related to the separation of Dart & Kraft into two public companies. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $11,600,000 for the quarter and $45,700,000 for the 9 months, and losses from the separation of the company of $2,600,000 and $3,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said included in the results for discontinued operations for the latest quarter are charges of about $55 million after-tax, for facility and business rationalizations and other adjustments, of which $44 million related to Premark International and $6 million are net costs associated with the separation of those businesses from Dart & Kraft. The company said the discontinued operations for the latest quarter primarily include Tupperware, The Food and Equipment Group (Hobart and Vulcan-Hart), Wilsonart Brand Laminates and West Bend Co. These businesses, which are being separated from Dart & Kraft, will constitute a new company, Premark International, through a pending distribution of its common stock to Dart & Kraft shareholders.

title: Evidence on Extinction
description: Analysis of a blob of glass formed when lightning struck the ground has led geologists at the University of Michigan to question an important premise to the theory than the impact of an asteroid or comet caused mass extinctions 65 million years ago.

title: KEY RATES

description: The USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers said today that they would resume contract bargaining Tuesday for the first time since 22,000 union members stopped work at the nation's largest steelmaker 11 weeks ago.

title: 3 Killed in Peru Shootout
description: Two policemen and a leftist guerrilla were killed Sunday in a shootout on a Lima street, the police said today. They said about eight Shining Path guerrillas opened fire with pistols and machine guns on the two policemen as they were patrolling the streets around dawn. One of the officers managed to shoot back despite his wounds and killed one of his attackers, the police said.

30 Years After the Hungarian Revolt;
ELBOW ROOM IN THE BLOC
description: A painful dilemma has plagued most of the Communist leaders of Eastern Europe in the 30 years since the Hungarian Revolution. Operating under the shadow of Soviet power, they have had to satisfy Moscow in order to rule; yet, operating in countries where anti-Sovietism runs deep, they have also had to put distance between themselves and Moscow in order to govern.

title: CRAFT MUSEUM CELEBRATES
description: It was a ribbon cutting with a difference. Not just one big red ribbon, but a rainbow of ribbons was stretched across the central curving staircase in the new home of the American Craft Museum. Gripping scissors decorated with a bright blue bow, Matilda Cuomo joined six other scissors-wielding dignitaries last night to officially open the museum's multilevel space at 40 West 53d Street. The Governor's wife had earlier in the evening toured the inaugural exhibition, ''Craft Today: Poetry of the Physical,'' with Kitty Carlisle Hart, Joan Mondale and Paul J. Smith, director of the museum.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE

It is one of midtown's most popular hanging-around spots, with its brightly lighted interior and its double-decked table areas where one may sit, drink coffee and watch the world surge by. Hanging around not only applies to people but, these days until Halloween, also to the 30 or more marionettes that will be suspended there.

''Summit meetings,'' he observed, ''tend to be like panda matings. The expectations are always high, and the results usually disappointing.''

title: KANSAS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY MAKES IT OFFICIAL: THEY'RE ARTISTS
description: FIFTEEN years after the Museum of Modern Art acquired its first work by Benny Andrews, and four years after the National Endowment for the Arts named him director of its visual arts program, an advisory committee to the city's Department of Cultural Affairs sat in a conference room the other night pondering whether he was a professional artist. They concluded he was. The 55-year-old painter was relieved. Last month the panel, the Artist's Certification Committee, had postponed action on Mr. Andrews's application for official status as an artist because of a technicality. ''I forgot to sign my name,'' he said, rolling his eyes. ''We artists don't always think about dotting 'i's' and crossing 't's.' '' Breaking New Ground

title: Half a Miracle in Israel
description: After a few final days of bickering, Israel's National Unity coalition did the miraculous yesterday: it transferred power from one side to the other. That the coalition has held together at all is an achievement; so was Shimon Peres's productive 25-month term as Prime Minister.

And during Bob Ojeda's four seasons with the Red Sox, the left-hander who will start for the Mets in tonight's third World Series game often stretched out on that couch.
