title: No Reimbursement
description: When he decided to seek the Democratic Senate nomination in Georgia this year, Hamilton Jordan asked his friends in Congress to hold off from pushing a private relief bill in his behalf. The legislation would have allowed him to seek Federal reimbursement for $67,000 in legal fees for his defense against charges, which were to be found groundless, that he used cocaine while he was President Carter's chief aide.

title: AUSTRALIAN FILMS FACE QUANDARY
description: Equally afraid of being seduced by flashy Americans and of remaining a wallflower on the world movie scene, the Australian film industry is facing the future with a mixture of self-assertion and longing.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD NUCLEAR LICENSE
description: The United States Supreme Court today rejected an appeal that sought to shut down the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant on the ground that it posed a hazard in the event of an earthquake.

title: BOULEVARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bank Board Clears Aid for Talman
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it cleared the way for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to contribute $150 million to Talman Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago and to forgive $71 million of income capital certificates, in the event Talman converts from a mutual thrift to a stock institution. Talman said earlier today that it was seeking Federal approval to convert to stock form, but the bank board said no application for conversion had yet been filed.

title: COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CIRCADIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $109,000.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary loss on extinguishment of debt of $1,482,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: ENERGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the net for the year was reduced by $3.2 million due largely to the reduction in the carrying value of Energen's oil and gas assets during the second quarter.

title: 3 WARDENS AT RIKERS OUSTED IN RESPONSE TO BRUTALITY REPORTS
description: Three ranking wardens at the Rikers Island jail complex were replaced yesterday in response to reports that correction officers had beaten inmates last week, including inmates in handcuffs.

title: Wall at P.S. 16 Comes Down
description: A partition at a Brooklyn public school separating Hasidic girls taking remedial classes from other students was removed over the weekend by the Board of Education, the board's president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday.

title: The Immigration Bill: Step by Step
description: In passing a comprehensive bill to curtail illegal immigration, the 99th Congress overcame obstacles that had blocked its predecessors for more than a decade. Now, in a final step down this long legislative road, President Reagan has indicated he intends to sign the landmark measure.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FORTUNES OF MITCHELL KENNERLEY, BOOKMAN. By Matthew J. Bruccoli. Illustrated. 337 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95. MITCHELL KENNER=

title: HOMECOMING: BOB OJEDA
description: Maybe it was the sight of the Charles River on a New England autumn afternoon that made Bob Ojeda smile yesterday. Perhaps it was the friendly faces in and around Fenway Park, where he spent the first five seasons of his major-league career, or the opportunity to get reacquainted with that large green business associate in left field that will again appear over his right shoulder tonight, the one that demands improvement and consistency in his line of work.

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Charges Dropped
description: Prosecutors in Maryland yesterday dropped charges against David Gregg and Terry Long, two of the men who were with Len Bias the night of June 19, when the University of Maryland basketball star died of cocaine intoxication.

title: Ryan Homes Move
description: Ryan Homes Inc., in a continued effort to thwart a hostile takeover bid from NVHomes L.P., said that its directors had told management to pursue preliminary discussions with other companies that might be interested in buying the Pittsburgh home builder. The company did not name any potential suitors.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: MUSIC: 'VIENNA 1900'
description: SUNDAY night's music at the Museum of Modern Art appeared under a single rubric, ''Vienna 1900: A Festival of Music.'' But in fact it employed two very different singers for some very different kinds of music.

title: Take Me Out to the Day Game
description: There is something all wrong about this year's World Series and it isn't only the Mets' performance in the first two games. It's simply that all the games are being played at night.

title: G.M. PLANS TO SELL SOUTH AFRICA UNIT TO A LOCAL GROUP
description: The General Motors Corporation, the largest American company doing business in South Africa, said today that it would withdraw from South Africa by selling its operations there to a group of investors led by local G.M. managers.

title: INSTINET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Haven Newspaper To Cease Publication
description: The New Haven Journal-Courier will cease publication next year while The New Haven Register will switch from an afternoon to a primarily morning newspaper, the Jackson Newspapers announced today.

description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $18,003,000 and $27,935,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,120,000 and $10,396,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: IC Industries Deal For Ogden Food
description: In another move designed to strengthen its position in branded foods, IC Industries, the industrial and consumer products company, said that it plans to acquire the Ogden Food Corporation for $320 million.

description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, a maker of electrical appliances and personal care products, has named Edward B. Harmon senior staff vice president and associate general counsel.

Allegheny Rumors
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. is trying to put together a new investor group to bid for Allegheny International Inc., maker of Sunbeam and Oster electrical appliances, Wall Street sources said. The new move developed after Willard F. Rockwell, 72-year-old former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation, and John R. Green Jr., former president of Magic Chef, dropped out of an earlier group when it failed to raise the money, according to the sources.

title: Court Rules On Sex Abuse
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a charge of sexual molestation need not include the exact date of the incident if the victim is under 13 years of age.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Option Is Held On Magazine
description: Sports Illustrated has taken a one-year option to buy the 12-year-old Women's Sports and Fitness magazine. During that year, it will put money and people into it to see if it is a viable property.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of about $26,300,000 and $8,200,000 for the latest and year- ago 9 months, respectively, on the sale of 2.4 million common shares in each year of Hasbro Inc. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 22, 1986.

title: COMMITTEE VOTES A BAN ON JOB BIAS IN HOUSING
description: A bill barring New York City landlords and cooperative-apartment boards from turning away people because of their occupations was approved yesterday by a City Council committee.

GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a pre-tax restructuring charge of $4,450,000 covering product line eliminations, inventory liquidations and severance payments.

title: THIS TIME, DIOGUARDI HAS A RECORD TO RUN OUT
description: Two years ago, when Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican, was running for the House of Representatives in his first bid for public office, he associated himself closely with President Reagan's policies and campaigned fiercely against the soaring Federal debt.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DEFINING VALUES
description: WHENEVER Americans sense a crisis of values and ethical behavior, they ask the schools to do something about it.

title: Fight Doctor II
description: He is 27 years old and, in Ireland, a fully certified physician, holder of a medical degree from Trinity College in Dublin. So what in the name of Hippocrates is Dr. Terry Christle doing training six days a week at the Petronelli Brothers Athletic Club, a fight gym in Brockton, Mass.?

title: UNGERMANN-BASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special pre-tax charge of $6,263,000. c-Net income

title: KEY NBC OFFICIALS RESIST 5% BUDGET-CUT REQUEST
description: Robert C. Wright, the new president of NBC, has asked each division of the network to plan budget reductions of 5 percent - a process that has met firm resistance from key NBC executives, including the president of NBC News.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $948,012 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $871,648. c-Includes a loss of $739,552 from discontinued operations. Results includes figures for Ashley Outlet stores acquired last February.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of 23 cents a share, after taxes, related to a special early retirement program. Share earnings for 1986 include the operations of M. Lowenstein Corp. acquired in late 1985.

title: SUNFLOWER FARMERS SAY U.S. POLICIES RUIN THEM
description: Only two years ago sunflower seed fetched 22 cents a pound at the Buffalo Farm Supply elevator, one of two in this wind-whipped prairie town of 200 people. Almost every farm from the railroad tracks to the horizon raised sunflower seed, and when the flowers bloomed in late July, Cass County's stout grain bins and skinny silos looked like candles set in gaudy yellow frosting.

title: WELLS FARGO MORTGAGE & EQITY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $495,000.

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIVESTMENT ENDS A 5-YEAR STRUGGLE
description: The announcement by the General Motors Corporation that it would sell its South African operations ends a five-year struggle marked by increased losses and political pressures.

title: O'Neill Leads Belaga in Poll
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has increased his lead over Julie D. Belaga, his Republican opponent, although a large number of voters remains undecided, according to a poll taken by the University of Connecticut for The Hartford Courant.

title: NEW YORK HAS A NEW NATIONAL CHAMPION
description: WHATEVER the fate of the Mets, New York State has a new national champion in another arena. A black willow tree along the banks of the Great Valley Creek, near Salamanca in the western part of the state, has been reported as the nation's biggest of its kind.

title: AFTER 4 TROUBLED YEARS, HOUSTON IS EXPECTED TO BEGIN SLOW REVIVAL
description: A conference of Houston's business leaders was told today that the city would finally end its four-year economic slump this year and begin a slow recovery.

title: Marketcorp Buys Right To Publish Master Chef
description: Just as it promised when it was formed last January, Marketcorp Publishing has acquired a magazine, or at least the rights to publish one in North America.

title: OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Matter of Definition
description: Kent Conrad, a Democrat who is seeking to unseat Senator Mark Andrews, Republican of North Dakota, could, if he wins, become a one-term Senator.

description: b-Net loss The company said for 1985 it posted a net loss of $41,911,000, including non- recurring charges of $17,500,000 related to a restructuring and $5,300,000 for inventory writedowns.

description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $100 million on the sale of Master Builders unit.

title: Delay in Withholding-Tax Change Will Be Costly to New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center chose a diverse program for the opening concert of its 18th season Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall -a joyful Handelian noise, a charming Serenade by Mozart, a rarely heard late work by Aaron Copland and, finally, Beethoven's Trio in B flat (Op. 97, ''Archduke'').

title: HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: TRADITIONAL JAZZ: A FLICKER OF LIFE
description: TRADITIONAL jazz has always had a precarious position in New York jazz clubs, which, understandably, lean toward whatever is contemporary. In fact, jazz that is now viewed as ''traditional'' - anything from the ragtime of pre-World War I to the swing bands of pre-World War II -has been steadily disappearing from clubs in the last few years along with the clubs that specialized in this kind of music. But suddenly there are rays of hope.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1986
description: The World

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Wells Fargo said its 1986 results include earnings from the operations of the former Crocker National Corp. beginning June 1.

title: SENATE CONTEST IN WASHINGTON STATE IS HEATING UP
description: Six weeks ago Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, a Republican, considered himself a sure bet for re-election. One of his aides said at the time that he saw no real need for President Reagan to come to the state to give his campaign a lift.

title: BUS AND TRUCK DRIVERS TO FACE NATIONAL STANDARDS
description: Congress, in a little-noticed provision of the anti-drug legislation it passed before adjournment last week, has approved a requirement that the Federal Government set national standards for licensing commercial bus and truck drivers.

title: CASE AGAINST NAZI JUDGES ENDED
description: West Berlin officials said today that they would not prosecute aging members of the Nazi People's Court that sentenced more than 5,000 people to death. They criticized West German prosecutors for not pressing charges earlier.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: NEW YORK
description: WITH the leaves adrift, the weather cooler and the price of gasoline more bearable, the countryside beckons. Within the most resolute urbanite there is often a yen to watch the swift descent from summer to autumn, and New Yorkers are well placed to observe the fall spectacle. Motorists can head toward the hills and waterways of New York, New Jersey and Conneticut.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $150 million on the sale of Container Corp. for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss d-After a $508 million provision for the restructuring of Montgomery Ward for the quarter and 9 months.

title: For the Record
description: The Government Printing Office is proud that one day's Congressional Record is normally on the members' desks before the next day's session begins, but the rush to adjourn and the volume of last-minute work sometimes slows such efficiency. The 99th Congress closed down last Saturday evening, but the transcript of that day's long proceedings will not reach those few lawmakers still in the capital until today at the earliest.

title: Elizabeth McGrew Bennett, Feminist Activist and Writer
description: Elizabeth McGrew Bennett, a feminist activist and a founder of the Center for Women and Religion at Graduate Theological Union in Berkeley, Calif., died Sunday at the Pilgrim Place Retirement Community in Claremont, Calif. She was 82 years old.

title: Montedison Talks With Fermenta Off
description: Long takeover talks between Montedison, the Italian chemicals group, and the Swedish biotechnology concern Fermenta A.B. broke down today. A Montedison official said the company believed Rafaat el-Sayed, Fermenta's owner, had violated a preliminary accord last July under which he agreed to sell 76.5 percent of his voting shares to Montedison.

title: Bill Is Signed to Permit Suit Over Thalidomide
description: Stephen McKenna, born without legs 26 years ago in a United States Army hospital, will get a long-sought day in court thanks to legislation signed today by President Reagan.

title: The Crack Crackdown's Jail Backlash
description: The crisis all summer concerned crack, the cheap cocaine derivative, and Mayor Koch of New York made clear his determination to combat it with aggressive police action. Now, suddenly, the crisis is jail crowding. Rikers Island is so stuffed that both inmates and guards are rebelling against its administrators. City officials profess surprise, but the emergency is the wholly predictable result of the crackdown. Therein lies a sobering lesson.

title: INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $9 million for the quarter and $387,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary loss of $4,967,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $4,944,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $800,000. d-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $17,522,000.

title: Retail Sales Up 12.6% in City
description: Several of the city's largest retailers recorded an average sales increase of 12.6 percent in September over the month a year earlier, a spot-check found yesterday.

title: Headless Men Found in Home
description: Two unidentified men were found slain last night in an apartment in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

title: A Tax Law to Hail. Yes, a Tax Law.
description: Shortly before noon today President Reagan will sign H.R. 3838, and thus enact the biggest and best tax reform in decades. At last. It's a day to stop and take unashamed satisfaction in a triumph of the whole over the parts.

title: The Girls Who Had Everything
description: Fairy godmothers are not distributed equally, but the same witch appears at every birth. Her gift is vulnerability: once delivered into the world no child is ever safe again.

title: NICARAGUAN, AT U.N., SAYS HASENFUS WILL BE TREATED WITH MERCY
description: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister said here today that Eugene Hasenfus, the American captured when a rebel supply plane was downed over Nicaragua two weeks ago, could expect mercy from the Sandinista court that is trying him there.

title: COMDATA NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $756,000 relating to a contested proxy solicitation in the second quarter.

Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: How to Tame the Big Bad Wolf
description: How is it now with the old Russian bear? How many years have we shivered and said, ''Something tremendous is coming from there,'' While Europe's old ladies look under the bed? Was she a fury? Or was she a fake? A figure of fun? Or a figure of dread? How many years has she kept us awake, Wondering, ''What is it under the bed?'' - A.P. Herbert

description: b-After a $45 million special charge for the quarter and 9 months. c-After $155 million in charges from debenture retirement, staff reductions and corporate reorganization.

description: b-Net loss

title: Firestone Plans to Take A Charge of $79 Million
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it plans to take a charge of about $79 million against earnings for the quarter that ends Oct. 31 to cover costs of a continuing restructuring of its tire operations in North America. As a result, Firestone said, it expects to report a loss for the quarter, its final one of the fiscal year.

title: Yanks Confirm Moves
description: Mike Ferraro as expected yesterday was named the Yankee third-base coach for next season. Ferraro replaced Don Zimmer, who has joined the San Francisco Giants. The Yankees, as expected, also announced that Mark Connor (pitching coach) and Jeff Torborg (bullpen coach) would be back, that Stump Merrill would be the first-base coach and that Joe Altobelli and Roy White would not be back.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BANKERS FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Flutie Signs With Bears
description: Doug Flutie signed a contract with the Chicago Bears yesterday and will be activated by the Super Bowl champions within two weeks. Flutie, who won the Heisman Trophy at Boston College and played with the Generals of the United States Football League, signed a contract for the rest of this season plus the 1987 and 1988 seasons.

title: Athens Car-Bomb Blast Kills High-Ranking P.L.O. Official
description: A car bomb today killed a man identified by the Palestine Liberation Organization as a high ranking P.L.O. official.

title: KOHL IN WASHINGTON, MEETS WITH REAGAN TO DISCUSS ICELAND TALKS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany met for an hour with President Reagan today to discuss the strategic arms negotiations that were conducted this month at the Iceland meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
PRESIDENT SIGNS DEFICIT CUTS DESPITE DOUBTS OVER CONRAIL
description: President Reagan today signed a law designed to reduce the deficit by $11.7 billion despite misgivings over what he said were ''burdensome'' tax provisions in a section of the bill that calls for the sale of Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad.

title: BILL WOULD OPEN UP POLICE REVIEW
description: A bill to open the Police Department Civilian Complaint Review Board to members from outside the department - an issue that prompted a citywide referendum two decades ago - was approved yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: MOBIL OPERATING INCOME DOWN 15.3% IN QUARTER
description: The Mobil Corporation, hurt by the depressed price of crude oil, reported yesterday that its third-quarter operating profits dropped 15.3 percent, to $332 million, or 82 cents a share, from $392 million, or 96 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

description: The company said year-ago 9-month figures are not available because its initial public offering was completed in May 1985.

title: Hafts Plan to Sell Safeway Warrant
description: The Haft family of Washington agreed to sell its negotiating rights for parts of the Safeway Stores Holding Corporation for $59 million to the investor group that acquired the giant food retailer in July.

description: b-Includes an after tax provision of $90 million for restructuring for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes a pretax gain of $24 million from the sale of the company's Store Equipment Group.

description: b-After tax credits of $483,000 for the quarter and $1,952,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $550,000 for the quarter and $890,000 for the 9 months.

description: The company went public June 27 and share earnings were not calculated for preceding periods. The company attributed the increase in the latest third quarter to expanded loan volume a decline in the interest rate paid on deposits, and earnings on the proceeds of the conversion from mutual ownership to a stock company, which the net proceeds of the conversion were $161 million.

title: ALBANY SPEAKER'S AIDE INDICTED ON MAIL FRAUD AND TAX CHARGES
description: Richard L. Rubin, a special counsel to the New York State Assembly Speaker and the former executive secretary of the Queens Democratic Party, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on 14 counts of mail fraud and tax evasion.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago second quarter includes expenses related to the litigation between the company and EAC Industries Inc. arising from an unfriendly takeover attempt launched by EAC in April 1985. The company said these expenses reduced its net for the year-age second quarter and 6 months by $452,000 and $622,000, respectively.

title: Refunding Bonds Set By Triborough Bridge
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is offering about $245.7 million of refunding revenue bonds through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

description: 1. Deco Frame-Up

title: CORRECTION
description: A Managua dispatch on Oct. 10, about statements by an American captured by Nicaragua after his rebel supply plane was shot down, incorrectly characterized a document found in the wreckage.

title: World Bank Sets Yield on Notes
description: The World Bank is offering in the United States bond market $150 million (Canadian currency) of 9.35 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.80, to yield 9.40 percent, or 1/4 of a percentage point more than Canadian Government securities with a similar maturity, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: May Wilson, 81, Artist Noted For Her 'Junk' Assemblages
description: May Wilson, an artist known for her ''junk'' assemblages, died Sunday of pneumonia at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IT was during the 13th inning, with it all tied up at 3-3, that I found myself hanging over the partition inside a Checker cab, my back end in the back seat, my front end in the front, twisting the dials of the radio to find the playoff game between the Mets and the Astros. My driver, who had been tuned to so-called easy-listening music, was a Thai immigrant who seemed to think that what he was witnessing was exactly what you could expect of indigenous Americans. His English was spotty, but moments before I finally picked up the game amid a ribbon of relentless static, he did manage to say feelingly, ''You big fan.''

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEEP COVERED, TOP COURT TELLS NUDE SUNBATHER
description: A three-year-old state law that prohibits nude sunbathing was unanimously upheld yesterday by New York's highest court.

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Medicare Is Denied For the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Charge Is Considered
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they were considering whether to seek a murder indictment against a Queens man who was arrested Sunday in the hit-and-run death of a 17-year-old honor student on the Upper East Side.

title: DEFINING FASHION'S CHANGING SHAPE: RUFFLES, PETTICOATS
description: Valentino provided the most thoughtful collection and Emanuel Ungaro the most extravagant in the spring and summer fashion openings this week. Hubert de Givenchy's clothes were quietly reassuring.

title: USX Confirms Icahn Talks
description: Confirming Wall Street reports circulating for more than a week, David M. Roderick, chairman of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that the company had held discussions with Carl C. Icahn, the Manhattan investor who owns 11.4 percent of the oil and steel producer, and that such discussions were ''continuing.''

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the shares outstanding reflect the repurchase of about 12 million shares previously owned by Brascan Ltd.

title: Reagan to Stump for G.O.P.
description: President Reagan plans to spend most of the remaining days before the Nov. 4 elections campaigning for Republican candidates.

title: IN PRETORIA, STIFFER RESOLVE
description: After the United States Congress imposed sanctions on South Africa, overriding a Presidential veto, something here seemed to change, as if the measures, far from frightening an embattled white regime, stiffened its resistance.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1986 net income and share earnings for the quarter and 9 months is after previously announced writeoffs of $106.8 million, or 97 cents a share, primarily in connection with plant closings in the Tobacco Group and a reduction of goodwill in the Office Products Sector. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 10, 1986. The company said the latest net income and share earnings for the quarter and 9 months were increased by $4.4 million, or 4 cents a share and $13.2 million, or 12 cents a share, respectively, from the company's early adoption of FASB 87 in June, 1986.

title: Books; Executive Life
description: STAYING AT THE TOP: The Life of a CEO. By Sonny Kleinfield. 298 pages. New American Library. $17.95. About a year ago, N. R. (Sonny) Kleinfield profiled Hicks Waldron, the chief executive of Avon Products, at length - great length - in The New York Times Magazine. In one of the most memorable anecdotes of the piece, Mr. Waldron spots several ''not overly offensive scraps of litter'' on the carpet in a reception area where a photographer is taking his picture. Mr. Waldron ''seems flustered and alarmed, as if there were several dead rats supine on the floor.''

title: Jacoby Steps Down As Four-A's Chairman
description: Robert E. Jacoby, former chairman of Ted Bates Worldwide, has resigned as chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the organization said yesterday.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 12.7%, TO A RECORD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was up 49.1 million shares, or 12.7 percent, in the month ended Oct. 15, to a record 436.3 million shares. The previous high of 387.1 million shares was set Sept. 15. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 222 million shares.

title: First Chicago Unit Gets A Coordinating Partner
description: When George L. Davis resigned his position last Friday as one of the top four people at the First Chicago Corporation, Stephen C. Diamond, an executive vice president, was called on to fill his shoes - at least in part.

title: Bell Atlantic Hires Direct Marketing Group
description: Bell Atlantic, which is based in Philadelphia, has hired the Direct Marketing Group in New York for its direct marketing needs.

title: INFORMIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. RED SOX, at Boston, fourth game of World Series, 8:25 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:45 P.M., WCBS 880, 8:07 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. LOS ANGELES KINGS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M.

title: Downed C-123: Actors in Drama
description: Since an American-made C-123 cargo plane carrying supplies for the contras was shot down over Nicaragua on Oct. 5, several names have been mentioned in connection with the case. These are some of the people mentioned: GEORGE BUSH Vice President of the United States. He has acknowledged meeting Max Gomez, whom he called a patriot, twice this year, most recently in May. It is believed that they became friends when Mr. Bush was Director of Central Intelligence.

title: JOHN B. SULLIVAN
description: John B. Sullivan, retired deputy chief fire marshal of the New York City Fire Department, died Saturday at his home in the Bronx. He was 75 years old.

title: Getting Personal With the Poor
description: Troubled by the segregation of the city poor in vast, dismal slums a century ago, social reformers decided to offer a helping hand by moving into those same slums and settling amid the victims of industrial urbanization.

title: WOMETCO CABLE SALE ACCORD SET
description: Wometco Cable TV Inc. signed a definitive agreement yesterday to sell its cable operations for $625 million in cash to a group that includes the Taft Broadcasting Company, the Robert Bass Group and executives of Wometco's cable operation.

title: RULES EASED FOR MEAT INSPECTION
description: In a victory for meat processors, the Secretary of Agriculture will have the authority to vary the frequency of Federal inspection of their products under a measure approved by Congress late last week.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today: Oct. 22, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Brodhead Resigns
description: Bob Brodhead, Louisiana State University's athletic director, resigned yesterday, a day before he was to have gone before the university's athletic council to answer charges of violating the State Ethics Code.

title: Bridge: David and Lisa Berkowitz Achieve a 'Double Double'
description: Redoubles are certainly rare, but ''double doubles'' are virtually unknown, particularly in New York City. They can happen however, in the context of a tournament rather than a single deal, and did during the past weekend in Grand National Pairs play at the Halloran House in Manhattan.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Chips and Vitamin C Under the heading ''Good Source of Vitamin C,'' the copy on the back of an 11-ounce bag of Lay's potato chips tells consumers that an ounce of the product provides 10 percent of the recommended dietary allowance of that vitamin. But let's put that in perspective. Consider that a single 4-ounce glass of orange juice contains the entire 60 milligrams of vitamin C recommended daily for adults and that an ounce of potato chips also contain 150 calories, 10 grams of fat and 200 milligrams of sodium. A New West-Side Butcher

title: LA PETITE ACADEMY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $236,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: PEARS FROM BOSC TO BARTLETT
description: BETWEEN the king of summer - sweet corn - and the prince of autumn - the apple - stands the neglected, misunderstood pear. Long live the pear.

title: Body of Pilot Is Found After Fighter Crashes
description: The body of an Air Force pilot was found today, a day after he ejected from his jet fighter before it crashed into a swamp near here.

title: 3 CONTENDERS VIE TO FOLLOW DE LA MADRID
description: In a country where one party has won every presidential election since its foundation 57 years ago, the real struggle for power takes place not at the polls but in the fierce competition to determine who should become the party's candidate.

title: AGENDA: OCT. 22, 1986
description: Input on Education

title: AGAINST ALL ODDS, FAITH HANGS IN AT BAKER FIELD
description: The Columbia Lions football team faces hapless Colgate, 0-6 on the season, Saturday at Columbia's Baker Field. Odds-makers have made Colgate a 30-point favorite.

title: FORMER CHINESE HEAD OF STATE
description: Marshal Ye Jianying, a veteran army officer who became one of China's top leaders in the late 1970's and its titular head of state from 1978 to 1983, died today, the New China News Agency reported in Peking.

title: DeLorean Defense Statement
description: The financial transactions that John Z. DeLorean is accused of using to steal $8.5 million from his car company were legitimate deals arranged by European banks and a British executive, his attorney said today.

title: BROCKWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Edwin Robson Dead; Senior Federal Judge
description: Senior Federal District Judge Edwin A. Robson, who was appointed to the bench by President Eisenhower, died today after surgery for injuries suffered in a fall. He was 81 years old.

title: IN SHANGHAI, CHEF FACING CULINARY ODDS
description: THIS was once a sophisticated city where both native and foreign-born chefs catered to the adventurous palates of residents. Chinese regional delicacies like stir-fried eels were as much in demand as flaky French pastries. During the revolution in late 1940's many master chefs fled and by the late 1960's, at the height of the Cultural Revolution, most remnants of so-called Western imperialism were banished from the city, including foreign food.

title: SALES OF U.S. GOLD COIN EMBARRASSINGLY LARGE
description: After two days of sales, the American Eagle, America's new gold coin, has proved a success of embarrassing proportions. The supply has run out.

title: CALIFORNIA BOARD REJECTS MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOKS
description: One year after refusing to accept more than 20 science textbooks, the California Board of Education has voted to reject every mathematics textbook submitted for use in kindergarten through eighth-grade in the public schools.

title: Now, a Boasting Blitz
description: The White House has gone beyond explaining with pride that Reagan aides successfully orchestrated American public opinion after the President's meeting with Michail S. Gorbachev in Iceland. The President's men are now documenting this operation with the number of ''media events'' they scheduled so the voters would not regard the Reykjavik conference as a failure.

title: IOWANS GIVE POLL TAKER A PIECE OF THEIR MIND
description: They were hired to talk about politics. And they spoke their minds.

title: SEARS PROFITS UP 25.1%; BIG ALLSTATE GAIN CITED
description: Buoyed by a strong performance at its Allstate Insurance subsidiary, Sears, Roebuck & Company today reported a 25.1 percent increase in third-quarter net income.

title: FISCHER & PORTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect 5-percent stock dividends paid in April and June.

title: IN INTIAL DEBATE, D'AMATO IGNORES GREEN AND CRITICISM
description: In their first debate, Mark Green repeatedly criticized Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato here tonight but the Senator did not respond in kind.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLUMN ONE: TRANSPORT
description: Seats for Sitting

title: SLOOP PLIES HUDSON SELLING PUMPKINS
description: A RICH slice of the fall harvest is floating down the Hudson River, and young and old alike are being drawn to the river in hope of getting some of the bounty.

title: THE DANCE: THE JOFFREY IN 4 WORKS
description: THE Joffrey Ballet presented four works from its repertory on Sunday afternoon at the City Center.

title: INSIDE
description: OPEC Agreement

title: REBOUNDING, METS DEFEAT RED SOX, 7-1
description: The New York Mets defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7-1, last night, winning their first game of the World Series and narrowing Boston's lead to two games to one in the four-of-seven-game series.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MOLESTATION CHARGES IN DIVORCE
description: Fathers seeking custody of their children in divorce battles are increasingly subject to false accusations that they sexually molested their children, according to psychotherapists.

title: Study by U.N. of Trade, Jobs
description: Trade with developing countries in manufactured goods has created more jobs in industrial countries than it has cost, according to a study by the United Nations Industrial Development Organization. For Japan, the employment gains were equivalent to as much as 15 percent of its total manufacturing employment in 1983.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago 9-month comparisons include the period from Feb. 25, the inception of the trust, to Sept. 30, 1985. The company said the 1985 share earnings are restated for the prospective dilution of shares due to potential conversion of unexercised warrants into one-fifth of one share of common stock.

title: Fairchild Posts a Profit
description: Higher profits in some aerospace divisions helped Fairchild Industries to report a third-quarter profit today of $7.7 million, in contrast to a $77.6 million loss last year, the company said. The 1986 period included an after-tax extraordinary gain of $2.9 million. Quarterly sales increased to $236.3 million, from $220.1 million a year earlier.

title: Altman Chief Sentenced
description: Anthony R. Conti, chairman and chief executive of the B. Altman stores, was sentenced yesterday to serve 22 days of community service in a drug treatment center and received two years' probation for failing to file his 1982 Federal income tax on time. Appearing before United States Magistrate Serena Peretti in Newark, he was also ordered to pay a $2,000 fine.

title: Market Place; Institutional Index Options
description: JUST when investors in stock index options thought they had enough products to choose from, the American Stock Exchange has introduced another innovative index option. How innovative? The Amex's new Institutional Index option is based on 75 stocks most widely held by large institutions and is exercisable only at the expiration date. Most other options in this country can be exercised at any time during the contract life.

title: Prime's Net Slips 20.4%
description: Prime Computer Inc. said today that weak demand in United States markets and a softening in some international markets contributed to lower earnings in the third quarter. Prime announced a 20.4 percent decrease in net income to $12.1 million, from $15.2 million last year, despite a 12.8 percent increase in revenue, to $221.9 million, from $196.7 million.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reserve for loan losses of $288.6 million. c-Net income The year-earlier results were restated to reflect adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 87 covering pension expense.

title: WALTHAM SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There are no comparable per share earnings for the latest 9 months and year-earlier periods since the company converted from mutual to stock form on May 22. Results for the year-ago third quarter included a $736,000 restructuring loss attributed to the sale of certain long-term low-yielding fixed rate mortgages.

title: METS' FAST START RUNS DOWN RED SOX
description: The Mets who won 108 games during the regular season showed up at Fenway Park tonight and made their initial impact on the World Series. Refreshed from their controversial day off, the Mets unleashed their largest hit production in nine postseason games and thrashed the Boston Red Sox, 7-1, behind the nifty pitching of Bob Ojeda.

title: N.B.A. OFFICIALS PLAN EXPANSION BY 1990
description: The National Basketball Association Board of Governors today voted, 23-0, to expand the league by one to three teams by the 1990-91 season.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL MANAGEENT & RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHESAPEAKE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERLEAF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANCTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After a reversal of tax-loss carryforward of $42,000 for the quarter, and a tax credit of $346,000 and a gain of $513,000 from a change in accounting methods for the 6 months.

title: NEWS MEDIA GAIN IN TWO COURT DECISIONS IN JERSEY
description: In two opinions issued today, the New Jersey Supreme Court expanded the ability of news organizations to defend themselves against defamation suits.

title: Relatively Easy
description: When a front-office executive of a club that's just clinched a World Series berth is awakened by a telephone call from a distant relative, the smart betting is that the relative is very distant indeed and that the conversation will evolve into a request for some choice seats at the ball park. So Frank Cashen can be forgiven if he was on his guard when jarred from slumber in his Westchester County home at 7:15 last Thursday morning, less than four hours after his team's return from an evening of high drama in Houston.

title: Boning A Leg of Lamb
description: WHEN I was growing up in Burgundy, the heady aroma of a leg of lamb roasting in the oven with garlic and fresh rosemary usually signalled a celebration - a birthday, Christmas, Easter. Gigot farci, or stuffed roasted leg of lamb, is still one of my all-time favorite meals.

title: BENCH CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.N., by Record Vote, Urges Vietnam to Leave Cambodia
description: By a record margin, the General Assembly called again today for the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia and for Cambodian self-determination.

title: TV Ratings Up for Series
description: The television audience for the first two games of the World Series was up 10 percent this year, according to figures released yesterday by the A. .C. Nielsen Company.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of 11 cents a share from the sale of the company's Titanium Dioxide business. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5.9 million and a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $3 million.

title: FILM: 'MATTER OF HEART'
description: ''MATTER OF HEART,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinema, is a loving consideration of the life and career of Carl Gustav Jung (1875-1961), the Swiss doctor whose psychoanalytic theories and work at first paralleled - then departed from - those of his onetime mentor and associate, Sigmund Freud.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SIGNS OF DANCE The calligraphy of dance is called notation, symbols preserving the choreographer's grand design that, in performance, is as fleeting and fragile as the tick of a second. ''Four Hundred Years of Notation,'' an exhibition that not only demonstrates how dance is recorded but presents the beauty of the markings in themselves, opens today at the Grolier Society, 47 East 60th Street (838-6690).

title: MINERS' UNION FACING DECLINE, WEIGHS MERGER
description: The leaders of the United Mine Workers, in an effort to strengthen their proud but diminished union, are considering merging with another union after nearly 50 years of independence.

title: Connecticut
description: TO New Yorkers, Connecticut is made for getaways -close, often secluded and relaxed enough to make an afternoon or evening away from the city easy and worthwhile. There are dozens of delightful havens here, but this trio of restaurants is especially agreeable: good food, appealing ambiance and scenic locations. The Inn at Chester SOUTH of Hartford, near the Connecticut River, is the handcraft- and antiques-rich village of Chester. Just outside, in beautiful woods bordering the Cockaponset State Forest is The Inn at Chester, where the dining room is in the John B. Parmelee House, a 1776 clapboard farmhouse. The high-ceilinged dining room, with a large walk-in fireplace and a greenhouse area looking out on pond, features a seasonal menu. The dishes, prepared in the light New American style, with a nod toward New England specialties, include a mushroom strudel and Cornish game hen stuffed with a homemade ground sausage and spinach dressing.

title: Exile Andrew Cuomo?
description: To the Editor:

title: UAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pretax gain of $79.8 million on Westin Hotels L.P. for the quarter, and the 9 months is after a gain from an accounting change of $28,524,000, as well as a deduction for foreign exchange losses , substantially unrealized, of $94,219,000. c-After a pre-tax gain of $27.3 million on the sale of GAB Business Services Inc. and a pre-tax gain of $23 million on the sale of certain leasehold investments for the quarter, and the 9 months is after a pre-tax gain of $36,591,000 on the sales of certain leasehold investments and a deduction for foreign exchange losses, substantially unrealized, of $17,751,000. d-Net loss The company said the year-ago quarter results includes one month of Hertz Corp., which UAL acquired Aug. 30, 1985.

title: A Rare Ruby Auctioned For Record $1.5 Million
description: A rare, 15-carat Burmese ruby was auctioned at Sotheby's yesterday for $1.54 million, a world record for a colored stone sold at public sale.

title: HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $849,000 and $1,286,000 of the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: DARLING ON MOUND GIVES METS EDGE
description: Pat Gillick, the man who runs the Toronto Blue Jays, put it bluntly: ''Game 4 may be the Mets' best shot, Ron Darling pitching against Al Nipper. The Mets can beat Nipper.''

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings on a fully diluted basis for the latest periods are $1.63 for the quarter and $5.10 for the 9 months, compared with $1.60 and $5.43 for the year-ago quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Budget Chief Is Staying On
description: James C. Miller 3d, President Reagan's budget director, in response to rumors that he would be taking over the presidency of the University of Georgia, said today that he did not plan to leave the Administration for at least another year.

title: PRETORIA TO INVESTIGATE MOZAMBICAN LEADER'S CRASH
description: South Africa appointed a Supreme Court judge today to head an inquiry into the plane crash that killed President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEAD OF PARKING BUREAU IS HEARD ON TAPE AT TRIAL
description: As the corruption scandals in New York and Chicago began to unravel, the director of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau was secretly tape-recorded telling a debt-collection executive that he had got his business ''on the merits.''

title: A Step Toward Nuclear Sanity
description: Reykjavik formally ended as a diplomatic failure, but it has begun an overdue revolution in perceptions. At long last, both superpowers have said in concrete terms that vastly smaller nuclear arsenals would make them safer. Implicitly, they are saying that nuclear weapons are not useful weapons. Those insights are a prerequisite to nuclear sanity.

title: BOYD IS RATTLED IN SERIES DEBUT
description: A path had been cleared from one end of the clubhouse to the other, and Dennis Boyd walked quickly until he reached his dressing stall near the front door. He slumped into a chair and seemed to be alone with his thoughts, even as bodies pressed closer. For several minutes, he did not speak.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss includes a charge of $506,000 for the writeoff of development equipment and staff separations costs related to the reduction of the company's Corvet Application Generator project.

title: British Airways To Go Public
description: The British Government announced today that it would sell the state-owned British Airways to the public early next year in the latest stage of its denationalization program. Transport Secretary John

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations.

title: People
description: * Garry Gassel has been named a partner in Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about A. W. Clausen's first news conference since his return to head the BankAmerica Corporation misstated the number of company employees at the start of the year. There were about 80,000.

title: AMERICAN IS SEIZED, BEIRUT GROUP SAYS
description: A Lebanese underground group said today that it had kidnapped another American, and asserted that he is an intelligence agent working for the United States and Israel.

title: Real Estate; Suburban Office Area Expanding
description: FOR decades the town of Mount Pleasant in Westchester County was content to serve as a bedroom community for the metropolitan area.

title: FRENCH CIVIL SERVANTS STRIKE FOR DAY
description: Millions of civil service employees staged a 24-hour strike today.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TREASURY PRICES IN REBOUND
description: After three consecutive sessions of falling prices, the Treasury note and bond market rebounded yesterday.

title: A Letter From Rangel
description: Over the many years that the House majority whip was appointed by the majority leader, his assignment was clear: to serve the leadership by organizing a rapid and accurate system for counting votes on forthcoming legislation.

title: Billy and Other Kids
description: We have a letter from Stump Quigley 4th, the ''unabashed reactionary,'' as he proudly styles himself. He is in testy spirits after seeing several press references to Secretary of Education William Bennett that refer to the Secretary as ''Bill Bennett.''

title: BANTA, GEORGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Coors for Japan
description: The Adolph Coors Company, which is based in Golden, Colo., said it had signed a licensing agreement for Asahi Breweries Ltd. to brew and distribute Coors beer in Japan. Coors signed a similar agreement with Molson Breweries Ltd. of Canada in 1985. In Japan, Coors will join Anheuser-Busch Inc., which first signed a licensing agreement with Suntory Ltd. in 1983.

title: MARTON'S TOSCA DOWN BUT NOT OUT AT THE MET
description: ''Now,'' said Eva Marton, ''I know how a boxer feels when he is knocked out.''

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 15.

title: MUSICIANS PLAN TO PICKET CONCERTS AS STRIKE TALKS FAIL
description: Negotiations have broken down in the 12-day-old strike of freelance orchestral musicians against 12 major New York-area orchestras.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shultz Names Redman As Policy Spokesman
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz named Charles E. Redman today as the chief State Department spokesman.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme Electric Corp., Olean, N.Y., said G. Wayne Hawk, president, would assume the additional post of chief executive on Jan 1.

title: TRANSWORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6,060,000 and $11,797,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: A-ARMS CUTS STIR CONCERN AT NATO PARLEY
description: Defense ministers of the Atlantic alliance told American delegates to a meeting here today that European support for sharp reductions in strategic nuclear forces hinged on further steps to insure a balance in conventional arms between NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: UNIVERSITY PAID JIHAN SADAT $50,000 TO TEACH FOR A TERM
description: Jihan el-Sadat, widow of Anwar el-Sadat, who was President of Egypt, was paid $50,000 to teach a course for one semester at the University of South Carolina, the university has confirmed.

title: MICHAEL NEWTON, AN ARTS OFFICIAL
description: Michael Newton, a leading figure in the presentation of performing arts in Los Angeles, died today of cancer at his home here. He was 53 years old and had resigned in March because of his illness from his position as president of the Los Angeles Music Center's performing arts council.

title: IN BOSTON, NOT MANY FRIENDS FOR METS
description: This old, steepled, autumn-dappled town is decidedly and expectedly pro Red Sox in the World Series between the local nine and the New York Mets, but there are dissenters.

title: APACHE PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATS SEE CHANCE FOR CONTROL OF SENATE
description: With polls predicting that Governor Cuomo might win as much as 70 percent of the vote on Nov. 4, Democrats are facing their best prospects in two decades for retaking control of the State Senate.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN the past, I have noted that the normal manner of menu planning is to first determine the main entree and then plot suitable accompaniments as an afterthought. However, at times I am inclined to reverse this technique.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: MACHEL'S DEATH SETS OFF A RIOT IN ZIMBABWE
description: Hundreds of youths rioted here today in response to charges that South Africa was behind the death of President Samora Machel of Mozambique.

title: CHILE VICTIM LINKED TO FIREBOMBS
description: A youth who was fatally burned during an anti-Government demonstration was apparently carrying a firebomb when he was stopped and doused with gasoline by troops, a lawyer for his family said today.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes results for C.H. Masland & Sons, acquired June 28, 1986. c-Net loss The company said the fiscal 1986 results include a gain of 30 cents a share from the sale of a division. The company said the results for 1985 include gains of 6 cents a share from settlement of litigation and 9 cents a share from sale of a division. The company said the year-ago quarter includes a restructuring charge of 60 cents a share related to the restructuring of the blended fabrics area and a gain of 8 cents a share from retirement system expense reduction.

title: CONVERTIBLES GET AIR BAG EXEMPTION
description: The Department of Transportation has granted automobile makers an indefinite exemption from the rule that requires eventual installation of air bags, self-fastening seat belts and other automatic restraint systems in convertible autos.

title: NIPPER SHAKES OFF PLAYOFF DEJECTION
description: Al Nipper got the word from a reporter before he got it from John McNamara. The news was bad enough - that he would not start in the playoffs, but Nipper was even more angered by the fact there had been a lack of communication with the manager. So he moped. For two days, he refused to discuss the matter with anyone. His unhappiness was consuming him.

title: TULANE'S PASSING DUO MAKING WAVES
description: Tulane is having another of its ''rebuilding'' years under Mack Brown, its second-year coach. And despite the team's 1-5 record, Brown has lots of hope for the future.

title: Death Warrants Signed For 2 Killers in Florida
description: Gov. Bob Graham today signed a new death warrant for Theodore Bundy, ordering his execution at 7 A.M. on Nov. 18. Mr. Bundy was convicted of killing a schoolgirl and two college sorority sisters in Florida in 1978 and is believed to have slain 36 other women around the country.

title: 'WINGS OVER WATER,' NAVAL HISTORY
description: ''WINGS OVER WATER,'' a 90-minute documentary on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, is an intelligent, provocative look at the history of naval aviation. How has naval aviation affected foreign policy? When did it become an instrument of foreign policy? The documentary is more than a standard military history of battles won and lost.

title: Harnischfeger
description: A group of investors, led by the Miami-based Columbia Ventures Inc., said it had purchased a 7.7 percent stake in the Harnischfeger Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it ''may seek to influence management or may even seek control'' of the Milwaukee-based concern.

title: PENNSYLVANIA CANDIDATE PULLS NEGATIVE COMMERCIALS OFF TV
description: Maybe it was bound to happen in a year when the low road of political campaigning seems more crowded than usual.

title: PRIVATE PIPELINE TO THE CONTRAS: A VAST NETWORK
description: The downing by Nicaragua of a plane with an American crew carrying military equipment for rebel forces has revealed a largely clandestine United States-based supply operation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM D'AMATO-GREEN DEBATE IN ALBANY
description: Following are excerpts from a debate last night between the two candidates in the Nov. 4 election for United States Senator from New York - the incumbent Alfonse M. D'Amato, and Mark Green. Opening Statements

title: SCORE THE PLAY MOE TO LARRY TO CURLY
description: After all the talk about The Wall and the long ball and the Wall Ball, the pattern for the third game of the World Series was set in the very first inning tonight by a leadoff home run and a simple, fundamental rundown play. And neither involved the left-field wall of Fenway Park.

title: Let the Russians Pay for Half of 'Star Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADOFF HOME RUN SPURS DYKSTRA
description: His job is to create mischief. That is what the Mets have in mind when they pay Lenny Dykstra - to create doubts, to introduce the element of surprise, to start something.

title: Knicks Defeat Lakers
description: Any uncertainty about how much the Knicks missed Bill Cartwright was settled last night.

title: Pacific Nations Sign Tuna Deal
description: The United States and 16 Pacific nations are reported to have reached an agreement that will channel $60 million in fees and developmental aid to the region over the next five years in return for fishing rights.

title: An Auction Plan for Lower East Side Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmers Take Protest To Palace in Manila
description: More than 23,000 farmers marched on the presidential palace today in the largest leftist protest against President Corazon C. Aquino's Government.

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2.8 million for the quarter and $16.6 million for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $2.1 million for the quarter and $7.8 million for the 9 months. The latest third quarter results reflect a $7 million sale to Metallgesellschaft AG of half the company's 49 percent interest in the Cayeli Bakir Isletmeleri AS copper-zinc deposit in Turkey, and a $6.5 million writeoff of the company's Douglas, Ariz., copper smelter, which will close permanently by Jan. 15, 1987.

title: MISMATCH IN JOBS AND SKILLS IS FOUND IN SURVEY OF CITIES
description: Economic recovery in Northern cities is creating new jobs, but growing numbers of poor minority residents lack the skills to perform them, according to an analysis of new census data.

title: Another Pall on U.S.-Soviet Relations?
description: The meeting in Iceland between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev may have ended in a stalemate and the United States and the Soviet Union may be expelling each other's diplomats, but the exchange of artists and musicians has remained a bright exception to the state of relations between the superpowers. Until now, perhaps.

title: ARAB LANDS SHRUG AT ISRAEL'S CHANGE OF GUARD
description: To the divided and frustrated leaders of the Arab world, the rotation of power in Israel, with Yitzhak Shamir and his hard-line Likud bloc replacing Labor's Shimon Peres as Prime Minister, is of less moment than their own increasingly pressing problems.

title: 2 Squibb Products
description: DFS Dorland Worldwide has been named by E. R. Squibb & Sons to do the advertising for the products of its Squibb Mark division.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company noted that under a May 1986 order by the Cook County Circuit Court, revenue for the latest third quarter are subject to refunds of $172,507,000.

title: Sullivan Principles' Author Hopes for Change
description: For the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, the announcements that two of the biggest American companies, the General Motors Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation, would sell off their South African operations came as neither a victory nor a defeat - but it did mark the end of an era.

title: Marietta's Net Up 2.6%
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter had increased to $51 million, or 92 cents a share, up 2.6 percent from $49.7 million, or 84 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The aerospace company, which is based in Bethesda, Md., said that sales rose to $1.17 billion, up 7.3 percent from $1.09 billion.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Buy U.S. Realty Specialist
description: PACE ADVERTISING, a New York real estate specialty agency, has been acquired by the WPP Group P.L.C., a publicly held British company that until a year ago was primarily a manufacturer of wire and plastic products. Then two men who had worked with Saatchi & Saatchi bought a big block of stock and moved the corporation in the direction of communications.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI OPPOSES BIG '87 TAX CHANGES
description: On the eve of President Reagan's signing of the historic tax revision legislation, Representative Dan Rostenkowski said he would strongly resist pressures to make major changes in the new tax system in the next Congress.

title: OPEC SETS EXTENSION OF ACCORD
description: Oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a frustrating 17-day conference early this morning by agreeing to extend production controls aimed at strengthening prices.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PARADISE. By Donald Barthelme. 208 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95. SIMON, the hero of Donald Barthelme's third novel, is a 53-year-old architect, prominent enough to be featured in ''Progressive Architecture'' and vain enough to think that his work could drive Louis Kahn's ghost mad with jealousy. As a student he once submitted a plan to redo Rockefeller Center in pickled pine, and he's apparently still partial to vaguely eccentric, avant-garde structures -transforming armories into schools and designing churches out of steel and glass blocks. Although he's always wanted ''to be a hearty, optimistic American, like the President,'' he's long since settled ''for being a competent, sometimes inventive architect with a tragic sense of brick.''

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss

title: More Continental Shares for Sale
description: In filing a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today, the Continental Illinois Corporation said that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had granted the underwriters of a public offering of 50 million Continental common shares the option to purchase up to 7.5 million additional shares to cover over-allotments.

title: One Swing Of the Bat
description: His name was on the Mets' lineup card taped to the wall in their dugout last night. Ray Knight was playing third base in the World Series again after having been benched for Sunday night's second game. Benched after having driven in two of the Mets' most important runs in their 16-inning victory in Houston that won the National League pennant. Benched after having batted .295 as the Mets' everyday third baseman in a theatrical comeback from .218 the year before. Benched, the most embarrassing feeling in baseball, especially during his first World Series.

title: Bush Aides Assess the Contra Speculation
description: Marlin Fitzwater, Vice President Bush's press secretary, still chuckles about the reporter who recently telephoned the Vice President's office, mentioned a man's name, then asked if the man worked for George Bush in Central America.

description: William P. Benton, 62 years old, is joining Wells, Rich, Greene as its third vice chairman.

title: WINE TALK
description: It was just an innocent little notice in one of the local papers. It probably didn't attract the eye of one reader in 20. But anyone in the wine business in America would have noticed it immediately - and chuckled. It said that the consumption of white wine was on the rise in France.

description: This Henderson, this on-a-roll, out-of-his-mind, great-big-gap-toothed-smile Henderson, doesn't want much out of life.

title: North Americans Leading Seniors
description: Winning six of eight golf matches today, a team representing North America defeated a team from Europe, 8-4, after two days of competition in the first annual Senior Women's Invitation Match at the New Orleans Country Club. Monday, in foursomes play, the teams were tied, 2-2. The competition for women over 50 is scheduled to be played next year at the St. Cloud course near Paris.

title: Economic Scene; Nobel Laureate Pierces Veil
description: THE awarding of this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to Prof. James M. Buchanan of George Mason University will help break down the intellectual walls between economics and political science, and quite possibly the other social sciences as well. The result is likely to be greater institutional and psychological realism for economics and a more useful, logical structure for political and social science. And, beyond the realm of academia, the ultimate outcome could be better public policy.

title: Stocks End Mixed in a Quiet Day
description: Trading was dull and stock prices closed mixed on Wall Street yesterday as investors, already puzzled about the economy's direction, heard a number of conflicting forecasts for the third-quarter gross national product. The Government will release preliminary G.N.P. figures today.

title: DANCE: MICHAEL CLARK OFFERS A U.S. PREMIERE
description: TAKE away the black lipstick, shaven head and platform shoes, and Michael Clark, the British choreographer performing this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, looks like a rather sweet fellow.

title: WESTERN ALLIES GRUMBLE ABOUT REYKJAVIK PLANS
description: Western European Governments and strategic arms experts are warning that some of the sweeping proposals aired at the Iceland meeting might be harmful to their military interests and undercut the NATO deterrence doctrine.

title: A Big Jump for Dime
description: The Dime Savings Bank of New York reported yesterday that it earned $28.6 million for the three months ended Sept. 30, more than four times the $6.7 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: RETURN TO WESTCHESTER: ABZUG TRIES COMEBACK
description: The political stage has not been the same since the mid-1970's when ''Bella,'' a one-woman show, ran in Manhattan, but received nationwide attention. Today the show - still rousing, still impassioned, but scaled back a bit -has moved to White Plains. And the critics are asking: Will it play in Westchester?

title: THE THEATER: 'TIGERS WILD'
description: ''CRYING is when feelings drown you and you can't fight back,'' explains Shell, the unofficial leader of the Angels, the quartet of morose El Paso teen-agers who roam through John Rechy's play ''Tigers Wild.''

title: FILM: 'RATE IT X,' ON MALE ATTITUDES
description: ''THERE is one thing that is infinitely more absurd and unpractical than burning a man for his philosophy,'' wrote G. K. Chesterton. ''This is the habit of saying that his philosophy does not matter.'' The documentary ''Rate It X,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is an intriguing and often hair-raising look at male attitudes toward women, filled with interviewees who have never quite considered the implications of what they do. By asking these men the simplest of questions, the film makers, Lucy Winer and Paula de Koenigsberg, sometimes elicit startling results.

title: ISLANDERS OUTWIT ROOKIE IN SCORING BLITZ
description: The Islanders took advantage of Chris Terreri, an uneasy rookie goaltender, and were motivated by their own discomfort about being last in the Patrick Division to score a 6-3 victory over the New Jersey Devils tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Co-founder Takes Helm at Equatorial
description: Edwin B. Parker was a communications professor at Stanford University when he conceived the technology for a small earth station that could receive satellite signals, a lower-cost method for data reception than private telephone lines.

title: U.S. IS EXPELLING 55 IN LATEST REPRISAL ON SOVIET ENVOYS
description: The United States, in a surprise move, today ordered the expulsion of 55 Soviet diplomats by Nov. 1. The action was in retaliation for Moscow's ouster on Sunday of five American diplomats.

title: MEXICO'S EMBATTLED RULING PARTY: THE CALLS FOR CHANGE GROW LOUD
description: Having brought steady growth and enviable stability to Mexico for more than half a century, this country's special form of one-party rule is now being tested by a crisis marked by a slump in public confidence and new electoral challenges to its political monopoly.

title: 100 JAIL GUARDS REPORTEDLY QUIT EMERGENCY UNIT
description: More than 100 city correction officers in an emergency unit gave up those voluntary assignments yesterday to protest actions by the Correction Department after reports that Rikers Island guards beat inmates, their union president said.

title: Tax Bill, Lights, Action!
description: Speaking of media events, the White House may set a record for both attendance and political promotion when Mr. Reagan signs the comprehensive tax legislation this morning. Reagan-watchers say it will be the largest such ceremony in the six years of the Administration, and old White House hands cannot recall a more ambitious legislative approval by any of the President's predecessors.

description: The All Nippon Airways Company will buy eleven 747 jumbo jets from the Boeing Company for $1.56 billion as part of the Japanese carrier's plan to expand its new international routes, the two companies said today.

title: LABELS DON'T STICK: BBC SETTLES WITH TWO TORIES
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation agreed today to pay out-of-court damages and make on-the-air apologies to two Conservative politicians who charged they had been libeled as right-wing extremists.

description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas, citing further deterioration in its loan portfolio because of the slumping energy industry, said yesterday that it lost $47.9 million in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $10.8 million, or 20 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

title: PRESSURE IS CITED
description: Citing deteriorating business and political conditions, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would join the ranks of multinational companies withdrawing from South Africa.

description: A New York City police officer has been charged with sexually abusing a 10-year-old boy who lives in a children's shelter in Dobbs Ferry, authorities here said yesterday.

Lindgren Surfaces
description: Gerry Lindgren, who won 11 national collegiate track titles and shared the world record at six miles, has been located after dropping out of sight nearly seven years ago. The former Washington State University runner is 40 years old and lives in Honolulu under the name Gale Young.

title: Letterman vs. Letter of Law
description: As Iowa Supreme Court cases go, it may seem like a cyclone in a teapot -but not to one Cyclone, and not to the Cyclones either. Jeff Braswell, an Iowa State linebacker who ranked third among Big Eight tacklers last year but was declared ineligible by the school for his senior season this fall, says that if he's not reinstated, his chances of winning a lucrative pro contract will be severely diminished. Iowa State says that if it's forced to reinstate him, it risks N.C.A.A. sanctions that could cost the school $1.25 million in television revenues and possible bowl appearance fees.

title: ST. LAWRENCE RIVER TAKES FIRST PLACE IN WATER FLOW
description: The St. Lawrence surged past the Mississippi last month to take first place among American rivers for amount of water, the United States Geological Survey reports.

title: OPERA: MARTON SINGS 'TOSCA' WITH DOMINGO
description: UNDER any circumstances, ''Tosca'' is one of the most violent of operas, but Monday night's performance at the Metropolitan, the first of the season, turned out to be a particularly bruising affair. Shortly before Eva Marton was to sing Tosca's celebrated second-act aria, ''Vissi d'arte,'' the Hungarian soprano caught an elbow in the jaw during her simulated struggle with the villainous Scarpia, her would-be rapist. Some simulation. During the intermission word came from backstage that Miss Marton had suffered a dislocated jaw.

title: Beware '86 Election Post-mortems
description: The Congressional, state and local elections are nearly upon us. Thus, so are post-mortems that will attempt to detect deep national meaning in the elections and to extrapolate accordingly for the 1988 Presidential campaign. Pay little attention to the morning-after dopesters. These midterm elections will have less significance than most previous ones, which themselves did not mean much.

description: It'S getting to be that time of year when voices become unpredictable. A cold or sore throat or draining sinuses can temporarily impart a Tallulah Bankhead quality to the most mellow of laryngeal tones.

description: Two weeks before Election Day, Governor Cuomo flew to Syracuse and Buffalo today, emphasizing his role as Governor, not candidate, in what has become a typical day in a campaign of little campaigning.

Stout, a former New Jersey State Senator from Monmouth County, died of cardiac arrest Thursday in Newark while addressing a memorial service for Joseph DeVito, a former Federal bankruptcy court judge there, who died in April. Mr. Stout was 74 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

FRESH APPLE CIDER, A SEASONAL SIP
description: PERHAPS it is only the imagination that perfumes the first sip of fresh apple cider with the smoky tang of burning leaves. Maybe you don't automatically see jack-o'-lanterns flickering with candlelight or footballs spiraling through the air, but a taste of what surely is liquid autumn encourages a belief in the power of food to trigger all the senses.
