title: IT HAS OPERATING LOSS
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that it sustained an operating loss of $338.5 million in the third quarter. But income tax credits and the earnings of its financing subsidiary gave the automotive giant a net income of $264 million, or 56 cents a common share.

title: SETON HALL SOCCER HAS A RESURGENCE
description: Nick Berardinelli's soccer life was empty when he was the starting goalkeeper for Seton Hall's soccer team two years ago. Although he is now the backup, his dream as has been fulfilled.

title: Minnesota Group Seeks Reprimand of Prosecutor
description: A state lawyers' panel has recommended that the Minnesota Supreme Court take disciplinary action against a county prosecutor, R. Kathleen Morris, for her handling of a case in which she charged 24 adults with sexually abusing children, then dropped charges against 21 of them.

title: EX-NASA AIDE SAYS ROGERS PANEL FAILED TO DO THOROUGH JOB
description: Richard Cook, a former budget analyst at the space agency, charged today that the Presidential commission that investigated the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger had failed to carry out its job thoroughly.

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: GETTING CITY HELP ON BULKY CASTOFFS
description: OUT with the old and in with the new is not as easy as it sounds - especially not in New York. What to do with unwanted refrigerators, discarded couches or oversize dining room sets are some of the trials of city dwelling.

title: Kroger Drugstores
description: The Kroger Company said that it was negotiating to sell its drugstore operations to an investor group led by Philip E. Beekman, former president of the Seagram Company, and several executives of the drugstore division. Mr. Beekman has been a Kroger director since 1978.

title: First Israeli Liver Transplant Is Done Over Rabbis' Protest
description: Haifa doctors performed Israel's first liver transplant today in spite of objections voiced by the Chief Rabbis, who say the operation could be a violation of Jewish law.

title: SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the quarter results include a charge of $3 million from the repurchase of an additional $10 million of the company's 11 3-4 PC debentures due in 2005 and $11 million of its 11 5-8 PC debentures due in 2015. The company said the profits in the year-ago 9 months include a pre-tax gain of $11 million on disposal of a marketable security.

title: CO-WORKERS WALK OFF JOBS AS AN AIDS VICTIM RETURNS
description: An AIDS victim's return to work for the first time in 17 months, part of a settlement of a lawsuit against The New England Telephone Company, led to a walkout today by most technicians at a garage in suburban Needham.

title: HAD BEEN CHINA'S HEAD OF STATE
description: Marshal Ye Jianying, a veteran Communist army officer who became one of China's leaders in the late 1970's and the head of state from 1978 to 1983, died yesterday, the New China News Agency reported in Peking. He was 90 years old.

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $41 million for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income The company said the charge is the result of exiting several unprofitable businesses that had combined sales of $77 million and pre-tax losses of $21 million in the first nine months of 1986.

title: EL TORITO RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Air Rights and Wrongs
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsche Bank In U.S. Offering
description: The Deutsche Bank made its public debut in the American bond market yesterday with a $200 million offering of 7 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.577, to yield 7.603 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Queen Tours Hong Kong
description: Queen Elizabeth II wound up a whirlwind tour of Hong Kong today with a day at the races and a fireworks display that attracted more than 600,000. The Queen, who came to Hong Kong after a six-day tour of China, spent much of the afternoon at the Shatin horse-racing track.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $14.8 million from restructuring the company's retirement plan. Other extraordinary items, primarily gains from the sale of assets and the retirement of debt, added $51 million. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4 million for the quarter and $7 million for the 9 months. The company in the latest quarter took a $63 million after-tax charge to reflect a reduction in value of crude oil and natural gas reserves. The 1985 earnings were restated to reflect a gain of $57 million, or 26 cents a share, and $71 million, or 24 cents a share, for changes in accounting.

title: Mr. Wonderful
description: Given what happened at Shea Stadium last weekend, the Mets would have been embarrassingly short of their own Series m.v.p. nominees had they been asked to name a few right then and there. Or maybe not.

title: STRESS ON THE JOB CITED
description: Stress and boredom in the workplace are causing substantial health problems in the United States, and the situation may get worse, according to Federal health researchers.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $648,000 and $108,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago quarter, respectively.

title: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A LOOK AT BASEBALL IN JAPAN
description: ''FACES OF JAPAN,'' a 13-part series with Dick Cavett as host, continues briskly and amiably on Channel 13 at 7 tonight with ''Young Baseball Heroes.'' A high-school team marches toward, and nearly reaches, national glory. Baseball in Japan, apparently, is serious stuff.

title: 3 East Germans Flee
description: Three East German men fled over the heavily guarded border to West Germany early today, bringing to at least 26 the number of East Germans who have escaped to the West in the last 32 days, officials said. The border police in Munich said two men, aged 20 and 27, climbed over East Germany's metal border fences to reach the state of Bavaria. In the north, a 29-year-old factory worker slipped across the border to Lower Saxony, the border police in Hanover said.

title: ROBINSON AND HIS GIFTED STUDENT
description: It was Theodore S. Williams, considered the greatest living authority on hitting a baseball, who declared that his field of expertise was the most difficult feat in all of sport. These days, Teddy Ballgame may no longer be exactly correct.

title: BLUES LIVES AT KING BISCUIT FESTIVAL
description: When this Mississippi River town decided that a free blues festival might stimulate tourism and downtown business, no one seems even to have considered calling it anything but the King Biscuit Blues Festival. Live blues, played by artists as extravagantly and demonstrably gifted as Sonny Boy Williamson and Robert Lockwood, had become a part of the Helena environment, reaching and influencing whites as well as blacks when ''King Biscuit Time'' went on the radio here in December 1941.

title: When Russia, Slyly, Expels Russians
description: In the tit-for-tat world of diplomacy, reciprocity is predictable, but yesterday Mikhail Gorbachev jumped out of the rut. The Soviet Union kicked not only Americans but Russians out of the U.S. Embassy in Moscow. That promises more nuisance than trouble for the United States - but it's enough nuisance to dramatize how little each side wins in games of mutual escalation.

title: Viacom Stake
description: A unit of the New York-based financial services firm, Oppenheimer Group Inc., said it had increased its stake in Viacom International Inc. to the equivalent of 6.3 percent, from its previous stake of 5.3 percent, paying prices ranging from $43.75 to $44.25 a share.

title: Yields Are Still Weak
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds remain weak for the third consecutive week.

title: Dynamics Net Drops Slightly
description: The General Dynamics Corporation yesterday reported a slight drop in third-quarter earnings, reflecting interest payments resulting from the $680 million acquisition of the Cessna Aircraft Company.

title: KENT ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Budget Head to Quit Congressional Post
description: Rudolph G. Penner, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said yesterday that he would resign in early January, when his term expires. The disclosure came as a surprise to his staff, which had assumed that he would seek and be named to another term.

title: RED SOX SQUANDER CHANCES
description: The feeling was one of aggravation more than humiliation. The Boston Red Sox looked back tonight and saw one opportunity after another, each wasted. A two-game lead in the World Series is gone; now, it is the Red Sox who have begun to skid.

title: COMMERCE UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BATTERY-POWERED METS EVEN SERIES
description: The Mets and the Boston Red Sox will play at least one game in New York this weekend. The Mets insured that development tonight as Ron Darling's shutout pitching and a flurry of three home runs, two by Gary Carter, carried them to a 6-2 victory over the Red Sox. But the way this World Series has developed, do the Mets really want to play at home?

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share figures adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in November 1985.

title: OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAINT LAURENT: WITH RUFFLES AND WITHOUT
description: Dozens of models in vivid multicolored summer dresses streamed down the runway carrying multicolored bouquets while ''Happy Birthday to You'' was sung on the sound track. It was a rousing finale to Yves Saint Laurent's show, on the last day of the spring and summer openings.

title: JOHN A. MULCAHY
description: John A. Mulcahy, a former official of the New York City Parks Department, died Monday at Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J., after suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: NBC Censors Comedian On 'Saturday Night'
description: A West Coast broadcast of ''Saturday Night Live'' was censored by NBC, because a routine by a comedian violated a network policy that references to drugs must be negative, a producer said.

title: State Attorney General Rules Against Drug Tests
description: Maryland's Attorney General, Stephen Sachs, ruled today that mandatory drug testing of state employees was unconstitutional and said that civil liberties could not be sacrificed in the war against drugs.

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months include securities gains of 4 cents per share, compared to 7 cents per share in the year- earlier period. The year-ago third quarter results include securities gains of 4 cents per share. The 1985 data has been restated to reflect the acquisition of General Bancshares Corp. on March 29, 1986, on a pooling of interests basis as if that corporation had always been combined with Boatmen's.

title: POP: PIERCE TURNER
description: PIERCE TURNER, an engaging pop composer and singer from Wexford, Ireland, has been performing his original folk songs in the United States since the mid-70's, usually in the company of his longtime musical partner, Larry Kirwan. Recently Mr. Turner recorded a solo album produced by Philip Glass and Kurt Munkacski.

title: GOODEN IS NEXT AFTER A SHORT REST
description: Can Dwight Gooden pitch and win on short rest? The Mets will get the answer Thursday night when their 21-year-old ace pitches on three days of rest for only the second time in his career.

title: GEORGIANS VIE FOR THEME PARK
description: So far, Georgia's ''war between the counties'' - fought over the right to build a ''Gone With the Wind'' theme park - has been little more than talk. But now the dispute is heating up. Clayton County, where the plantation Tara is set in the Pulitzer Prize-winning book and the Oscar-winning movie, has long planned an attraction to honor the author Margaret Mitchell and her epic tale of the Old South.

title: Cleaner Streets Are Up to All New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: LAW FIRMS CALLED ANTI-UNION
description: More than 200 students at Harvard Law School have pledged not to seek jobs with five law firms that they say encourage companies to engage in ''union-busting'' activities, according to organizers of the boycott.

title: NEW OPEC TEST IN DECEMBER
description: The OPEC oil ministers, after surviving the longest and one of the most intractable gatherings in memory, now face the prospect of reconvening in December to devise output and pricing plans.

title: ST. JOSEPH BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arts Endowment Plans To Continue Grant Programs
description: The National Endowment for the Arts is scheduled to announce the names today of 35 grant recipients in its Advancement Program and that the program - now in its third and final year - is to be continued.

title: Improving Truck Safety, if Slowly
description: Deregulation of trucking has helped consumers, but with a catch. Since 1980 truck safety has declined. Now, however, Congress has taken a worthy if halting remedial step.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After one-time charges of $335 million.

title: ZION UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTINENTAL AIRLINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes about $10 million in Chapter 11 reorganization costs and a $12 million gain on the sale of an airplane. c-Includes tax credits of $19 million and $42,322,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes a $1.5 million gain on the sale of assets and $6 million in reorganization-related expenses. d-Net income

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS NEW TAX BILL
description: President Reagan today signed into law the most thorough revision of the Federal income tax code in more than 40 years, calling the new tax system ''less a reform than a revolution.''

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special after-tax restructuring charge of $945 million. c-Net income

title: Shift by Chavez
description: Linda Chavez, the former White House aide who is running for the Senate in Maryland, has changed honorifics in mid-campaign. One day this week, her press secretary said she preferred to be called ''Ms. Chavez,'' but a few hours later he called back to say that the approved designation was now ''Mrs. Chavez.'' This was not politically surprising because the Republican, who is married to Christopher Gersten, has been stressing her background as a wife and mother in her campaign against Representative Barbara Mikulski, a Democrat, who is single.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOYS AND HISTORY Toys go in and out of fashion, but there is something about them that makes a former generation's toys no less attractive to youngsters than those of the current generation. This will be verified by a visit to the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West (873-3400), where the large ground-floor gallery has been converted into the most unusual toy room in town.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 9 months include pretax income of about $25 million resulting from a settlement agreement in August with the Department of Energy. The year-ago quarter and 9 months are restated to reflect a change in accounting for pensions and to adjust prior estimates of proceeds from an insurance settlement related to a refinery.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW TAX CODE'S PRINCIPAL ELEMENTS
description: Here are the main elements of the tax bill President Reagan signed into law today: Revenues: The new law is projected to generate the same total revenue over the next five years as the old tax system, although in some years it will raise slightly more and in some years slightly less. Over a five-year period, corporate taxes will be increased by $120 billion, and taxes on individuals will be reduced by that amount. Tax liability: About 6 million poor people will be removed from the tax rolls altogether. When fully effective, about 15 percent of taxpayers will have a tax increase, and the rest will pay approximately what they would have paid under the old system or less.

title: BROOKLYN MAN IS HELD IN KILLINGS
description: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing two men who were found decapitated on Tuesday in a Queens apartment, the police said.

title: JOSLYN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
King Is Topic Of Salary Cap
description: If Bernard King were certified as unable to play for the entire 1986-87 season by doctors for both the team and the National Basketball Association, the Knicks would have available half of his $874,000 salary with which to obtain a replacement player under salary cap provisions. But Scotty Stirling, the team's vice president and general manager, says ''it's too early'' to consider that option.

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it is a 50-50 joint venture of Dow Chemcial Co. and Corning Glass Works.

title: Kookaburra III Goes 5-0
description: Kookaburra III, skippered by Iain Murray, remained undefeated today after the completion of the first round of the America's Cup round-robin defender trials. Kookaburra III raised its record to 5-0 for 5 points, defeating South Australia, skippered by John Savage, by 6 minutes 43 seconds.

title: A SCULPTURE GIVES WAY TO PETUNIAS
description: Last July 5, the sculptor Charles Ginnever took a morning walk to Battery Park. He wanted to see how his monumental outdoor sculpture, a one-ton steel piece that had stood on a grassy mall in the park for 16 years, had withstood the crowds of the Liberty Weekend celebrations.

title: ACCEPTANCE INSURANCE HOLDNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $20,510 and $36,475 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $190,000 for the quarter and $720,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes realized investment gains of $13,921.

title: A TV STATION IS CUT FROM LORIMAR DEAL
description: In yet another restructuring of the deal, Lorimar-Telecommunications said it would not buy the Miami television station that was one of seven stations it had originally agreed to purchase from Storer Communications and Wometco Broadcasting.

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARD-HIT MEXICO TRIES TO COPE
description: For several recent weeks, the people of Mexico City coped with a scarcity of eggs.

title: U.S. Takes Lead In Amateur Golf
description: Jay Sigel of the United States shot a four-under-par 66 in the opening round of the world amateur golf team championships today, leading his team to a 204 score and a four-stroke lead over Canada.

title: DESPITE U.S. ACTIONS, CANADA SEEKS FREER TRADE
description: Canada's leaders are pushing ahead on trade liberalization negotiations with the United States, despite being stung by recent American actions against imports from Canada.

title: REPUBLIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IFR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Worm and the Apple: Paved/Scrubbed; Gaining on Graffiti
description: Subway cars without graffiti? For years, New York transit officials said the problem couldn't be controlled: the pool of potential artists is too numerous, spray paint too accessible, the transit cops too busy with serious crime.

title: MUSIC: BIRTHDAY TRIBUTE TO MIRIAM GIDEON
description: TODAY is Miriam Gideon's 80th birthday, and Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall there was a birthday tribute to her, with four of her own compositions and two others she particularly loves. The hall was filled with a knowledgeable, admiring audience, and the occasion was in every way a touching success.

title: LEBANESE PROFESSOR, 5 MONTHS A CAPTIVE, IS RELEASED IN BEIRUT
description: A Lebanese Christian professor at the American University of Beirut, abducted by gunmen five months ago, was freed by his captors overnight.

title: Hughes Tool: Its Background
description: The Hughes Tool Company was the foundation of the fortune of Howard R. Hughes Jr. It was founded by his father, Howard R. Hughes Sr., to manufacture and lease the rotary bit used for drilling oil wells through rock that the senior Hughes had invented and patented in 1909.

title: Peruvian Rebels Kill 6
description: Six peasants from Peru's leading coca-growing region were killed by Maoist guerrillas who painted red hammer-and-sickle emblems on their victims' backs, the police said today.

title: Anheuser-Busch Gains
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies today reported record sales and earnings for the third quarter, aided by surging beer sales.

title: WHEN HEAT'S OFF IN NEW HOME, CAN YOU GET HELP?
description: PHYLLIS FUNARI, a 42-year-old Westchester psychologist, remembers none too fondly the move nine years ago with her husband, David, from a two-bedroom apartment in Stuyvesant Town to their first house, in Pelham, a 29-minute train ride away.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sensitive Issues
description: Elie Wiesel, who recently won the Nobel Peace Prize, says he supports the re-election of Senator Paula Hawkins, a Republican, but objects to the way her campaign is using his name in a fund-raising drive aimed at the Jewish voters in south Florida.

title: PIANO: KRYSTIAN ZIMERMAN
description: THE pianist Krystian Zimerman played a disappointing recital of works by Beethoven, Schubert and Schumann at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Zimerman is a polished artist: his technique is immaculate and he calls a bright, glittering sound from his instrument. But there seemed little rectitude beneath the glittering surface.

title: NETWORK SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOME GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on sales of securities of $12.6 million and $99,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month period also includes a tax credit of $23,100,000. c-Includes a gain on sales of securities of $6.8 million and a loss from discontinued operations of $23.1 million for the quarter, and the 9 months includes a loss from discontinued operations of $17,200,000. d-Net loss The company said the year-ago quarter is after income tax benefit of $97.4 million, principally attributable to the termination of the company's tax sharing agreement with City Investment Co. and the discontinued Life and Accident and Health insurance business. The company said the year-ago 9 months is after income tax benefit of $141,600,000, of which $97,400,000 is principally attributable to the termination of the company's tax sharing agreement with City Investment Co. and the discontinued Life and Accident and Health insurance business.

title: NARCOTICS OUTPUT SOARS IN MEXICO, U.S. REPORT SAYS
description: A State Department report made public today says production of marijuana and opium poppy in Mexico has increased dramatically in the last year.

title: NEXT ON AGENDA: A BOOK
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. may be retiring from Congress, but he is not retiring from public life.

title: American Book Awards
description: Judges of the American Book Awards yesterday announced their nominations for the best books of 1986. They are: FICTION: ''World's Fair'' by E. L. Doctorow (Random House); ''Whites'' by Norman Rush (Alfred A. Knopf), and ''Summons to Memphis'' by Peter Taylor (Knopf). NONFICTION: ''War Without Mercy: Race and Power in the Pacific War'' by John Dower (Pantheon); ''The Paper:

title: CENTRAL BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings are not meaningful as company converted to stock form July 1986.

title: JEFFERSON BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE U.N. TODAY: OCT. 23, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A TASTE FOR DEATH. By P. D. James. 459 pages. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Steinberg Plans to Raise Stake in British Firm
description: A long-smoldering battle broke out yesterday between the parent of S. G. Warburg & Company, one of Britain's biggest merchant banking houses, and Saul P. Steinberg, the Manhattan businessman.

title: Is the C.I.A. Involved?
description: Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams conceded last week that the Central Intelligence Agency reports to the Administration on clandestine mercenary activity carried out by United States citizens in support of the contras. Yet he maintains that the C.I.A. does ''not direct it, directly or indirectly, wink or nod, or steer people.'' I would like to believe the Administration, but I remain concerned that it may turn out to be connected with soldiers of fortune sent to Central America with a wink and a nod and a shrug - sent to get around both our foreign policy and the law.

title: CITY'S WATER IS SALTIER, STUDY SHOWS
description: New York City's drinking water is becoming slightly but steadily saltier, a new study has found. If the upward trend continues, the report said, in about a decade doctors might have to advise some patients on low-sodium diets to drink and cook with distilled water.

title: CHIPS & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: FINANCIAL CORPORATION SHOWS $11.6 MILLION PROFIT
description: The Financial Corporation of America, the giant California thrift company that was once near collapse, said today that its third-quarter net income fell 5.7 percent, to $11.6 million, or 24 cents a share, from $12.3 million in the 1985 period, when it earned 22 cents a share.

title: HURST IS CHOOSING A RETICENT ROLE
description: The pre-game ritual was the same: stretching, running, gathering stray balls and returning them to the mound for batting practice. But this time, Bruce Hurst did not stop to talk when he was finished. He held his glove in one hand, sprinted toward the dugout and disappeared up the runway.

title: 'Baby on Board' Signs
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: HASENFUS LAWYER IN A CHALLENGE
description: The lawyer defending the American captured from a rebel plane challenged the legality of court documents today and showed a statement signed by the American prisoner that contends his human rights have been violated.

title: Cuomo Orders Lilco Deadline
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that the Long Island Lighting Company must agree to abandon its $4.6 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station by Jan. 15 if it wants to avoid a takeover by a new power authority.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: 2 MORE COMPANIES SEEN QUITTING SOUTH AFRICA
description: Following the lead that the General Motors Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation took earlier this week, two more companies - Honeywell Inc. and Warner Communications Group -have apparently decided to sell their South African operations.

title: Sharing Responsibilities
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: THEATER: 'INTO THE LIGHT,' A MUSICAL
description: ''I'VE waited four years to get my hands on that rag,'' says James Prescott (Dean Jones), the hero of Broadway's latest musical, ''Into the Light.'' The rag in question is not the secular cloth found in the season's previous ''Rags'' and ''Raggedy Ann,'' but none other than the Shroud of Turin, the linen relic revered by true believers as Jesus' burial cloth. James, a skeptical physicist from Los Alamos, belongs to an American scientific expedition attempting to determine whether the shroud is miracle or hoax. While he eventually does get his hands on the rag, the audience at the Neil Simon Theater must first survive an onslaught of boogeying nuns and more than a few songs with lyrics like ''science without data will not get you from alpha to beta.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (AL) - Renewed the contract of Jim Morrison, third baseman, for 1987. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Released Jim Thomas, guard, and Yvon Joseph, center.

title: LINCOLN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago revenue restated to include interest and miscellaneous income.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Salant Proposal
description: The Salant Corporation, an apparel producer based in New York, said it had agreed on a reorganization plan with committees of unsecured creditors and stockholders. Salant and its major subsidiaries, the Thomson Company and Obion Company, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1985. The plan, subject to approval by the bankruptcy court, provides that for each $1,000 of unsecured claims, creditors would get $450 in cash, $500 principal amount of senior subordinated debentures and four common shares.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
ST. JUDE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings reflect 100 percent stock dividend paid Sept. 30.

title: BLAME FOR 6 SACKS IS SPREAD BY GIANTS
description: When the Giants lost by 17-12 to the Seattle Seahawks last Sunday, their quarterback, Phil Simms, was sacked six times. Today, Ron Erhardt, the Giants' offensive coordinator, disclosed who was at fault. Everyone. ''Two sacks were breakdowns by our line,'' said Erhardt. ''Two came because the receivers were covered. Two were the quarterback's fault. And when you throw interceptions and you have six sacks, you're going to put the defense in trouble.''

title: 2 Prosecutors Removed From F.B.I. Agent's Case
description: A Federal judge today disqualified two Government lawyers from the prosecution of a former agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is charged with lying under oath to prevent the indictment of a former union president.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results include other income of $4.7 million, or 12 cents a share, due principally from an insurance settlement and a state tax refund. The company said year-ago quarter results include other income of $7.7 million, or 19 cents a share, generated primarily from a gain on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: CALENDAR: BUYING AND TOURING HOUSES
description: Home Buyers' Class, White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Avenue, at Grove Street, White Plains, 914-428-4507.

title: Magazine Publishers Change Their Thrust
description: The Magazine Publishers Association has apparently realized the ineffectiveness of promoting its medium through the anti-TV advertising that has been used in recent years. So now the publishers will promote the medium to the people who run agencies, and those that work for them and make the ads.

title: Agenda Item Postponed
description: Attorney General Edwin L. Meese 3d had been scheduled to deliver his recommendations on how to respond to the pornography commission's findings at a press conference on Monday.

title: PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Desktop Alliance
description: Three companies in computer hardware and software said they had formed an alliance to market their products as a complete desktop publishing system. The companies involved are the Aldus Corporation of Seattle, which makes the Pagemaker software for desktop publishing; the Hewlett-Packard Company, which will supply its Vectra personal computer and LaserJet printer; and the Microsoft Corporation, which will supply its Word word processing software and Windows operating environment. The companies plan to spend more than $2 million on promotion.

title: Big Jail Terms Are Criticized
description: Attorney General W. Cary Edwards said yesterday that it would be a ''colossal mistake'' to impose stiff mandatory sentences on drug sellers without increasing the capacity to prosecute and imprison the offenders.

title: PREFERRED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alpha Microsystems, Irvine, Calif., said it had been informed by Televideo Systems Inc. that Televideo's new board had voted to cancel a proposed acquisition of Alpha.

title: Player Loses in Court
description: Despite arguments by his attorney that Iowa State is sacrificing the career of the linebacker, Jeff Braswell, in the hope of securing leniency from the National Collegiate Athletic Association in its inquiry of improper recruiting at the school, the Iowa Supreme Court has ruled that Braswell must remain ineligible. The higher court's decision annulled last Friday's district court ruling that had granted Braswell a temporary injunction ordering the school to allow him to play until a Nov. 7 hearing on a permanent injunction.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
PRUDENTIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORTHEN BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $52 million charge incurred in April 1985 through the failure of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., and its affiliates to honor repurchase agreements. The company posted a gain of $4.3 million on the sale of securities for the latest quarter and the loss for the latest 9 months was primarily attributable to the $9 million loss recorded in the second quarter.

title: STAGE: 'NEON PSALMS,' ABOUT A DESERT FAMILY
description: AS husband and wife in Thomas Strelich's ''Neon Psalms,'' Tom Aldredge and Scotty Bloch are encamped in a trailer in the Mojave Desert -Sam Shepard country, with a shaggy Strelich twist. Mr. Aldredge is playing a desert rat, retired, a wry old philosopher who idles away his days watching ''Bonanza'' on re-reruns and rounding up turtles as if they are wild horses. Miss Bloch, a born-again Psalm reader, surveys the desert, actual and metaphorical, and says, ''Our lives are so full.''

title: A DESERT HOME FOR NUCLEAR ARMS FUEL AND RADIOACTIVE WASTE
description: A few weeks after Enrico Fermi operated the first nuclear reactor at the University of Chicago in December 1942, the Manhattan Engineering District came here to the arid, sparsely inhabited desert to make the plutonium for the first nuclear bomb test.

title: Talks Today in Swift Strike
description: The Swift Independent Packing Company and the union for striking workers agreed Tuesday to reopen contract talks. The walkout started Oct. 1. The announcement by the National Brotherhood of Packinghouse and Industrial Workers that new talks wouldstart Thursday came as four days of violence at the plant ended.

title: DODD AND EDDY ARGUE ROLE OF U.S. IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, and Roger W. Eddy, his Republican challenger, clashed sharply yesterday over the role of the United States in Central America and in providing aid to the rebel forces in Nicaragua.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS LET DIPLOMAT VISIT THE INJURED SOVIET FLIER
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 22 (AP) -

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared in September.

Subsequent to the split, and as part of the recapitalization, 101.6 million shares held by public shareholders and 3.4 million shares held by employees in the company's thrift and stock purchase plans were redeemed at $17.14 a share.

AQUINO, PRESSED BY DEFENSE CHIEF, WARNS REBELS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she would soon set a deadline for Communist rebels to accept a cease-fire or face a ''declaration of war.''

description: b-Net income. Latest quarter results include revenue of $12.6 million and a net loss of $300,000 of Intecom Inc. from its date of acquisition on Sept. 3.

title: Bridge: Night at Woollcott's Mixed Sharp Play and Sharp Wit
description: In the early days of contract bridge there was much disagreement about terminology. In a social evening one would hear ''jump takeout'' for ''jump shift''; ''business double'' for ''penalty double''; and ''informative (or informatory) double'' for ''takeout double.''

title: Citicorp Vice Chairman Gets Added Job Duties
description: In his 36 years at Citicorp, James D. Farley has usually found himself in the thick of the bank's fastest-growing businesses.

description: Revenue represents net revenue.

title: CHANGES
description: Disappearing Act The Corn Exchange Bank disappeared from the financial scene in the 1950's. It seems that its handsome architectural vestige - two adjoining neo-Romanesque towers from the turn of the century - is about to disappear as well.

title: AT HIGH POINT, IT HAS TO LOOK OLD TO BE NEW
description: IN the movie ''Peggy Sue Got Married'' the actress Kathleen Turner attends a high school reunion, blacks out and travels back in time.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The concrete patio in back of my house has cracked in several places. I'm trying to decide whether to remove and replace it with new concrete or a wood deck. If I replace the concrete, how can I prevent it from cracking again? A.First, make certain the subsoil under the new slab is properly prepared. There should be a base of at least three inches of gravel under the concrete in normal soil to insure adequate drainage and minimize settling. In soil with a heavy clay content, there should also be a couple of inches of sand on top of this.

title: Dayton Hudson's Issue Yields 9.60%
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation is offering $200 million of 9 1/2 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2016 at a price of 99, to yield 9.60 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: VIEW-MASTER IDEAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ratings by a Caucus
description: The National Women's Political Caucus today will make public today the results of a survey that sought to determine which governors had the best records in appointing women to Cabinet-level positions, and some surprises are likely to result.

title: LEAVES: HELPFUL EQUIPMENT
description: ALL sorts of innovative equipment is available to help make fall cleanup in the garden less of a chore.

title: ROBERT SIEGEL
description: Robert Siegel, managing director in Manhattan of the stock brokerage and investment banking concern of L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Inc., died of leukemia Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months net sales exclude sales of Weyerhaeuser Real Estate Co., an unconsolidated subsidiary accounted for under the equity method.

title: NORTHEAST PLANT IS LOADING FUEL
description: The builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant began loading fuel into the reactor today, five days after receiving the go-ahead from the Federal authorities.

title: The Civil Liberties of the Unborn
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW LAW REQUIRES SCHOOLS TO ELIMINATE HAZARDS OF ASBESTOS
description: President Reagan today signed into law a bill requiring schools to protect children and school employees from health hazards posed by asbestos.

title: U.S. Offers Conrail Plan
description: The Department of Transportation today outlined its process for selection of brokerage houses to handle the sale of the Government's 85 precent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AMONG the many new products on the market are interesting storage accessories and other items that can help to make life easier for do-it-yourselfers. Some of them follow. Wall-Mounted Shelf

description: The per share earnings are restated to reflect the 15 percent stock dividend declared in 1985, and the 2-for-1 stock split declared in 1986.

title: Audit Criticizes State U. on L.I.
description: The State University of New York at Old Westbury, L.I., is ''a badly managed college'' that has violated university policies, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan charged yesterday.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ICELAND ARMS OFFER NOT YET ON THE GENEVA TABLE
description: The Reagan Administration has not yet presented the arms control proposals it made at the Iceland summit meeting in the arms talks in Geneva because senior military leaders say they first need to review them, officials said today.

title: EXPERTS SAY SOME CHILDREN ARE READY TO HEAR OF AIDS
description: Broaching the topic of AIDS to young children and telling them of the sexual practices that contribute to its spread is appropriate if parents are sensitive to how much information a given child can absorb, child psychologists and psychiatrists said in interviews yesterday.

title: Gandhi Shuffles Cabinet For 8th Time in 2 Years
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today dropped a politically powerful cousin from a key post and moved to stop dissent in his Congress Party in a sweeping Cabinet shuffle.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income The company said income tax benefits and charges have not been recorded on 1986 results.

title: Detectives Kill An Attacker
description: Two detectives shot and killed a disturbed man who repeatedly swung at them with a baseball bat after he broke a window of their unmarked car on an Upper West Side street early yesterday, the police said.

title: INDONESIAN FURNITURE AT A NEW BOUTIQUE
description: IN Indonesia the government owns a chain of department stores that gather the local products - hand-carved furniture, hand-painted screens and textiles, and clothing made of batik - under one roof. This week Sarinah, the first Government-owned store outside Indonesia, opened to the public in the Indonesian Pavilion, a five-story Italian Renaissance town house designed in 1900 by the architects McKim, Mead & White.

title: THE OPEC SCHISM: PRICE WAR HINTED
description: The contentious meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that ended early yesterday morning has underscored the deep fissures within OPEC and raised the possibility that in late December or early next year a new price war could again drive oil prices down, perhaps to single digits, according to American oil specialists.

title: PHILIP SMIT
description: Philip Smit, a retired printing and lithography executive, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: EXCHANGE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arms Labors Lost
description: American negotiators are saying that they came away from the Iceland summit meeting with a great deal of admiration for a Soviet official, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the Chief of General Staff, whom most of the United States participants met for the first time.

title: NATIONAL SANITARY SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' earnings include the acquisition of Paul Koss Supply Co., a contingent payment of $10 million to the former owners of National Sanitary's predecessor companies and the additional costs of operating as a separate, publicly held entity, the company said.

title: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter results include a pre-tax gain of about $300,000 from the sale of a foreign subsidiary's laser printing product line.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said in the latest quarter it made an additional provision of $76.2 million to its previously established reserve for losses on loans and real estate, which now brings the reserve total to $580.4 million as of Sept. 30, 1986.

title: ROHATYN CALLS REAGAN ADMINISTRATION 'FISCALY IRRESPONSIBLE'
description: The 100th anniversary of the establishment of settlement houses in New York was celebrated yesterday, and the featured speaker, Felix G. Rohatyn, used the occasion for a wide-ranging attack on the Reagan Administration.

title: West Coast Bank Plans Sale of Unit
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its New York securities clearing operations to its rival, the Security Pacific Corporation.

title: D'AMATO-GREEN CLASH STICKS TO SCRIPT
description: The second and final debate yesterday between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his Democratic challenger, Mark Green, demonstrated strategies they had used in their first debate Tuesday night and in the preceeding weeks of campaigning.

title: FOOD STAMPS TO AID HOMELESS ARE HALVED AT FEDERAL BEHEST
description: Food-stamp benefits have been slashed by more than half for homeless families living in hotels because of a change in Federal procedures.

title: Comebacks And Comedowns
description: After the Mets dropped two to Boston last weekend, much ado was made of the fact that only nine teams in history had ever come from 0-2 down to win the World Series. Largely overlooked was that all but one of those comebacks have occurred since 1955 (the other was in 1921, a season of the five-of-nine-game Series) and that there have been a total of only 14 Series since '55 that were marked by a sweep of the first two games.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures include the results of the sale of Desiccant and industrial business units.

title: NL Says It Spurned Bid For Its Chemicals Unit
description: NL Industries, a company with interests in both chemicals and oil services, said late yesterday that a ''large financial institution'' it did not identify was prepared to buy its chemical operations, which it is contemplating spinning off.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After unusual items reduced the net income by $11 million, or 32 cents a share. These items include $3 million from write-downs by Ashland Exploration reflecting reductions in property values due to world crude oil price declines and also $10 million from reserves associated with a joint venture ethanol operation. The company said the effect of these items was mitigated somewhat by the favorable impact of the early adoption of a required change in accounting for pension costs. This added $2 million to the quarter's net income and $9 million in the year. The company said the fiscal 1986 is after the fourth quarter charge of $9,873,000 and a credit of $8,831,000 for an accounting change.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV SPEECH ON THE REYKJAVIK TALKS AND 'STAR WARS'
description: Following are excerpts from a broadcast address yesterday in Moscow by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as distributed in translation by the official press agency Tass:

title: Inquiry on Wright Relatives
description: Tarrant County prosecutors said Tuesday that they planned further investigation of drug and weapons possession charges against the daughter and son-in-law of the House majority leader, Jim Wright. The couple, Alicia Carnes, 27 years old , and John Carnes, 33, were arrested Sunday night in a park near the shores of Lake Worth in Fort Worth on charges of posession of a controlled substance and illegally carrying a weapon, said Capt. Jerry Blaisdell of the police.

title: 4 Sons Get $2.8 Million In Death of Their Mother
description: The sons of a woman who was killed by her husband have won a $2.8 million settlement from a counseling center and one of its marriage counselors for failure to warn the woman that her husband wanted to kill her.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in June. The company also reported fully diluted share earnings of $1.38 for the latest 9 months and $1.10 for the year- ago period, ending Sept. 30, 1986 and 1985, respectively.

title: Continental Air Income Up 58%
description: Low fares helped Continental Airlines, which is controlled by Texas Air, to report today a record third-quarter net profit of $65.1 million, or $2.12 a share, its highest quarterly profit ever.

title: NET FALLS AT AMOCO, ASHLAND
description: The Amoco Corporation, one of the nation's largest energy companies, said yesterday that its earnings dropped 97.3 percent in the third quarter because of a $162 million special charge for various offshore properties that have been drilled without success.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MEESE SAYS RULINGS BY U.S. HIGH COURT DON'T ESTABLISH LAW
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said in a speech Tuesday evening that Supreme Court interpretations of the Constitution were not ''the supreme law of the land.'' He added that officials should be guided by their own views of that document rather than always deferring to the Court's.

title: Hyundai Offers An I.B.M. 'Clone'
description: Blue Chip Electronics Inc., a computer marketer in Chandler, Ariz., introduced a $699 personal computer made by the Hyundai Electronics Industrial Company of South Korea.

title: CONSULTANT NAMED H.R.A. CHIEF
description: Calling it ''the toughest job that one could imagine,'' Mayor Koch yesterday appointed a management consultant and former Ford Foundation official, William J. Grinker, to be Human Resources Administrator.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
WHITE CHURCH ASSAILS APARTHEID
description: In a break from its support of racial separation, South Africa's main white Dutch Reformed Church denounced apartheid today.

title: Imasco Unit Sold
description: Imasco Ltd. said it had sold Genstar Rental Electronics Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., for about $63 million to a company formed by the president of Genstar Rental, William D. Rollnick. Genstar Rental rents electronic test and measurement equipment to a variety of industries, Imasco said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BETWEEN CONNECTICUT'S SENATE RIVALS
description: Following are excerpts from a debate at The New York Times yesterday between the two candidates in the Nov. 4 election for United States Senator from Connecticut - the incumbent, Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, and his Republican challenger, Roger W. Eddy:

title: TRAFFIC COPTER CRASH IN HUDSON KILLS REPORTER
description: A traffic news reporter died after her helicopter crashed in the Hudson River just off 45th Street yesterday while she was broadcasting.

description: b-Net loss

title: PEPITONE SENTENCED TO SIX MONTHS IN JAIL
description: Asserting that Joe Pepitone had gone from being a ''first-rate baseball player'' to a ''second-rate drug operator,'' a Brooklyn judge sentenced the former New York Yankee first baseman yesterday to six months in jail for two misdemeanor drug convictions. He would have to serve four months on Rikers Island before he can be paroled.

title: OHIO RACE FOR GOVERNOR IS MARKED BY VOTER APATHY
description: In the race that sets Gov. Richard F. Celeste against former Gov. James A. Rhodes, it has been difficult at times to tell who is the challenger and who is the incumbent.

title: 6 CIVILIANS KILLED BY MINE IN NICARAGUA
description: At least 6 civilians were killed and 30 seriously wounded Monday when their crowded civilian transport truck ran over a powerful land mine north of here, according to several wounded passengers and doctors at the scene.

title: UNION AND COMPANIES AGREE ON DOCKWORKER WAGE PLAN
description: Union officials and managers from five East Coast ports agreed today to a single wage system for all dockworkers, clearing the way for approval of a three-year master contract affecting 30,000 workers, officials said.

description: b-Net loss

title: PIANO: DUCHABLE PLAYS LISZT
description: FRANCOIS-RENE DUCHABLE'S all-Liszt piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night was so filled with handsome attributes that the critic wrestles uneasily to balance fairly this evening's virtues and its disappointments.

title: Advertising; Dr. Ruth Helps Sell Mousse
description: THE beauty of using Dr. Ruth in testimonial advertising is that when she says something is ''the next best thing'' nobody has to ask ''To what?'' And most people would consider second place a pretty good ranking.

description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. SAYS ALL MAJOR SOVIET SPIES WILL BE GONE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the 55 Soviet diplomats ordered to leave by Nov. 1 included all the senior spies in the United States.

title: China Will Broadcast Disney Cartoon Series
description: The Walt Disney Company has completed a deal with the China Central Television Network that will provide a weekly Disney cartoon series to Chinese television beginning this Sunday - marking the first time that Disney productions have been seen in that country in nearly 40 years, according to studio officials.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income of $10.8 million from discontinued operations.

description: The commanding officer of the 42d Infantry Division of the New York Army National Guard was abruptly relieved of duty yesterday amid an investigation into his conduct in office, state officials said.

description: When Congress barred the Administration from providing military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the system adjusted, as Administration officials put it, so that aid continued to reach the contras.

Market Place; Stocks Slowed By Bond Yields
description: ONCE again, stocks are bumping against the roadblock of rising bond yields. ''The action of the long Treasury bond has had a dampening effect on stocks in general,'' said Steven Kroll, who heads Hutton Asset Management.

title: INSIDE
description: Talk of AIDS Is Urged The Surgeon General urged parents and schools to talk frankly with children about the dangers of AIDS, and psychologists suggested how to approach the issue.

title: Carrier Commissioning
description: The Navy will commission the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt in Newport News, Va., on Saturday, bringing to five the number of nuclear-powered carriers in the fleet, the Navy announced today. The 96,000-ton carrier will join a fleet of 13 in all; she is the fourth of the Nimitz class. The fifth nuclear carrier, the Enterprise, is in a class of her own.

title: Biederman Is Named For Watney Red Barrel
description: Biederman & Company has been named to do advertising and public relations for Watney Red Barrel, a well-known British beer, at least in Britain.

description: A political action committee has announced a $300,000 television advertising campaign to make President Reagan's plan for a defense against missiles a conservative political issue in key states two weeks before Election Day.

RANGERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: The Rangers went again last night to where they have been many times before: into overtime.

title: THE JAUNTY LILT OF PARIS HATS
description: Hats are hot on the runways of the Paris spring shows. But hats are not what they used to be, and neither are the women wearing them. They don't think of hats as old hat; indeed they hardly remember the days when they were de rigueur.

description: The new chief spokesman for the State Department said today that he was confident the Reagan Administration had no intention of deliberately misleading American news organizations.

description: Behold the mini-firestorm in support of the show trial being produced by the Communist regime in Nicaragua. Vice President Bush, the C.I.A. and American credibility are getting a bum rap.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused the United States today of deliberately misrepresenting the results of the Iceland meeting.

FORD CHARITIES GETTING FEES FROM HIS POLITICAL SPEECHES
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford has stumped for 41 Republican candidates this fall and received $250,000 for two nonprofit organizations in exchange, according to Bob Barrett, a sppkesman for Mr. Ford.

description: b-Includes a credit of $2.9 million, or 22 cents a share, from adoption of statement of financial accounting standard number 87, which is employers accounting for pensions. c-Includes gains of $12.3 million, 0r 92 cents a share, from the sales of certain cellular telephone and Sportschannel interests. The year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change for the company's investment in Cowles Media Co.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the capital and exploration expenditures for the latest quarter and 9 months were $21.6 million and $163.4 million, respectively, including the recent acquisition of North Sea Properties, compared with $68.4 million and $233.7 million for the respective periods in 1985. The company said net income and cash flow from operations in the latest third quarter were augmented by realized gains from hedging oil prices on the crude oil futures market and insurance proceeds of $9.3 million received following settlement business interruption insurance claims arising from the fires that occurred in 1984 at the company's Syncrude plant.

title: Drugs as an Issue
description: Concern about illegal drugs is not a partisan issue in the 1986 elections, but unless Democrats are careful it could help the Republicans in the long run. That is the conclusion emerging from a series of voter discussion groups conducted by The Analysis Group Inc. of New Haven.

title: 'Murph the Surf' Paroled
description: The notorious jewel thief Jack Murphy, whose theft of the 535-carat Star of India sapphire inspired a movie, will be paroled Nov. 11, the Florida Parole and Probation Commission said today. Mr. Murphy, also known as ''Murph the Surf,'' was serving a life sentence for the murders of two secretaries.

title: SECURITY RULE DIED BUT LIVED ON
description: Nearly three years ago, after a storm of criticism, the Reagan Administration announced it was suspending a Presidential directive requiring hundreds of thousands of officials to submit to lifelong censorship.

title: CLAIMING THE CREDIT IN 1988
description: In affixing his signature to the tax bill today, President Reagan established one of the legislative landmarks by which he hopes his Presidency will be remembered.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1986
description: The World

title: EDWIN D. WITTER
description: Edwin D. Witter, an original partner of Dean Whitter & Company, the investment firm, died Tuesday.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. RED SOX, at Boston, fifth game of World Series, 8:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:45 P.M., WCBS 880, 8:20 P.M.) BASKETBALL NETS VS.

title: Dwight Wants the Ball
description: Bill Robinson does not speak only to the hitters he coaches for the Mets. He also speaks to pitchers, and particularly to Dwight Gooden, who will be pitching the fifth game of the World Series on only three days' rest tonight.

description: b-Net loss

title: JETS' MCELROY ON INJURED LIST
description: Even with their 6-1 season, the Jets are still making desperate post-midnight phone calls. Perhaps that is a major reason why no one in the National Football League has a better record.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., citing sagging sales in its most expensive lines of computer systems, yesterday reported a loss of $30 million in its most recent quarter, in contrast to a profit of $7 million, or 5 cents a share, in the comparable 1985 period.

title: METS' VICTORY IN GAME FOUR EVENS SERIES
description: There was once talk of a Red Sox sweep. But the Mets put that to rest Tuesday and now their 6-2 victory at Fenway Park in tonight's fourth game has squared the series at two games each and reduced it to a three-game playoff, with the last two games back home at Shea Stadium.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIA
description: FOR the Philharmonia Virtuosi concert at Town Hall on Tuesday night, Richard Kapp, the music director, put together a program that featured a number of the ensemble's players in solo assignments. The idea was nice enough, but the resultant concert had its longeurs.

title: LAROUCHE ASSOCIATE ARRESTED
description: An associate of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, was held under $80,000 bond today on charges of bilking an elderly woman in Missouri out of her life savings, the police said.

title: STATE DEPT. SUED ON BIAS CHARGES
description: Six black Foreign Service officers have filed a lawsuit against the State Department, charging it with ''continuous classwide discrimination.''

title: 'Our Pitching Is Set Up'

title: EXECUTIVE CITES CITY CONTRACTS BEFORE PAYOFFS

description: The Hughes Tool Company and the Baker International Corporation, two of the nation's largest oilfield-services concerns, said today that they would merge in a stock transaction valued at roughly $460 million.

title: Girl Will Have Abortion Despite Parents' Protest
description: A State Appeals Court panel today gave a 15-year-old who is 11 weeks pregnant the right to obtain an abortion despite objections by her adoptive parents.

description: Stock prices improved a bit yesterday, thanks largely to a rally in the bond market, but even the release of the gross national product figures did not prod Wall Street to quicken the trading pace.

''Why would I do a thing like that?'' McGuire, a basketball commentator for NBC, said he had spoken on the telephone with the Fordham athletic director, Frank McLaughlin, who has named Bob Quinn to replace Tom Penders as the Rams' coach on an interim basis.

The Worm and the Apple: Paved / Scrubbed; Night Shift
description: New York City's Department of Transportation warrants no special praise for finally doing its job and resurfacing the northernmost section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, but it deserves a big shiny apple for the way the work has been done: under floodlights, at night.

title:
LET'S GET THE FACTS ON NICARAGUA;
Lincoln Brigade?
description: President Reagan has expressed approval of private mercenaries aiding the Nicaraguan contras and has compared their efforts to those of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War. Drawing an analogy between two such dissimilar causes is an affront to the decidedly unmercenary American volunteers in Spain. It also shows a disregard for history and for our Federal Code, which our chief executive is expected to uphold.

title: Technology; Ion Beams And Metals
description: EVER since ancient man alloyed copper with tin to produce bronze, the search for harder, longer-wearing, less corrosion-prone tools has gone on. Alloys have been improved and surface treatments developed that make cutting edges harder and smoother than the base material, prolonging their useful life.

title: DARLING DISPLAYS SOME TRUE GRIT
description: If the Mets indeed left their game in Houston last week, they found it in Boston this week. And they flaunted it tonight in Fenway Park with several winning performances that tied the Boston Red Sox at two games apiece in the World Series.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA SINGS BACH
description: IT'S been bad news and, if not good, then not-so-bad news for Musica Sacra over the past 10 days, as a result of the strike by freelance orchestral musicians against those organizations that hire them.

FILM STUDIOS BUYING UP THEATERS IN MAJOR CITIES
description: Almost overnight, the stable business of owning movie theaters has been shaken by the challenge of movie studios eager to control the destinies of their films. And the owners of most of America's 22,000 theaters are facing the future with varying degrees of resignation and concern.

title: Standing Up on Abortion
description: While most candidates around the country seem to be treading lightly on social issues, Harriett Woods has taken an unusually bold stand on abortion in her Senate race against Christopher S. Bond, the former Governor of Missouri.

title: 49er Collapses
description: Larry Roberts, a defensive end who was the first draft pick of the San Francisco 49ers last spring, became dizzy and collapsed while leaving a team meeting yesterday and was rushed by ambulance to Stanford Medical Center.

title: F.B.I. INQUIRY IN BOSTON POLICE DISCLOSED
description: Federal and city law-enforcement officials disclosed today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been conducting a major investigation of police corruption here for at least two years.

title: AGENDA: OCT. 23, 1986
description: Attention Turns to Rikers The Legal Aid Society will offer what it says is a chronicle of violence at Rikers Island - including accusations of clashes between guards and inmates - at the start of a Constitutional-rights case. The group seeks a cap on the jail population, a system to separate inmates by age and severity of offense and better investigations of confrontations. 9:30 A.M., Federal District Court, Foley Square, Manhattan Key Witness in Friedman Case A former president of Citisource Inc., Robert R. Richards, will take the stand in New York City's corruption trial. He is expected to be a key witness because a city contract with Citisource for hand-held computers is at the heart of Government charges against the Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley M. Friedman. 9:30 A.M. Federal Court House, Church Street, New Haven S.I. Homeless Shelter Plan A municipal shelter for the homeless on Staten Island - the borough's first - will be considered by the city's Board of Estimate, and approval is expected. A local coalition has opposed the shelter, saying it would hurt neighborhood's revitalization. 10 A.M., Board of Estimate Chambers, City Hall

title: DANCE: JENNIFER MONSON IN IMPROVISATORY WORK
description: THE possibilities of musical and choreographic improvisation were explored in ''Dive In,'' a series of four programs that Jennifer Monson arranged for the Danspace Project of St. Mark's Church. At Sunday night's performance, improvisation resulted in at least one fascinating piece.

description: A New Jersey foundation has donated $17.2 million for the care of AIDS patients in northern New Jersey and major metropolitan areas around the country, it was announced today.

description: Roy M. Cohn, the combative and influential lawyer, was remembered yesterday by his friends as a complicated man whose dedication to fighting Communism inspired liberals to a ''lust for revenge'' that persisted throughout his turbulent career.

title: SURGEON GENERAL URGES FRANK TALK TO YOUNG ON AIDS
description: In an unusually explicit report to the nation, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop today urged parents and schools to shed their inhibitions and start engaging in ''frank, open discussions'' with very young children and teen-agers about the dangers of AIDS.

title: Scholastic Inc. May Go Private
description: Major stockholders of Scholastic Inc. have moved to take the company private. Under their proposal, holders of common shares of the publishing and television programming company would receive $34 a share and owners of class A stock would receive $36.

title: Ellard Returning
description: After 88 days and after missing seven regular-season games, Henry Ellard, the wide receiver-punt returner of the Los Angeles Rams, decided yesterday to end his holdout. He was expected to sign a contract this morning.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Wine Talk column in some copies of The Living Section yesterday misattributed the comment that people who do not study history are condemned to relive it. The thought was expressed by Santayana; it does not appear outside the National Archives building in Washington.

title: Energy Prices Decline On News of OPEC Deal
description: Prices of crude oil and refined petroleum products slumped in heavy volume on the futures markets yesterday as traders who had bid up prices in advance of the breakup of yesterday's OPEC meeting reacted to news of the agreement by liquidating positions.

MASTER'S PROGRAM IN COMPUTER ARTS
description: COMPUTERS are changing the way art is conceived and produced. Recognizing the increasing numbers of marriages between computers and art, the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan is now offering what its officals believe is the nation's first master's degree in computer arts.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Chicago is offering $203.9 million of bonds through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.

description: John Dell Isola, a center at Fordham and later a guard and assistant coach with the Giants, died Tuesday at Symmes Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: STUDY LINKS HEAVY DRINKING TO INCREASED RISK OF STROKE
description: Men who drink heavily are four times more likely than nondrinkers to suffer stroke, but light drinking appears to reduce the risk, British researchers said today.

title: NEW INDICTMENT IN TV INQUIRY IS HANDED UP BY QUEENS JURY
description: The Queens grand jury that has been investigating cable-television franchises in the borough handed up a sealed indictment yesterday, shortly after a lawyer who is representing Judge Francis X. Smith of Queens Administrative Court failed to block further action by the grand jury.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1986
description: The Economy

title: NORWESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. WEIGHS TRUCE ON THE EXPULSIONS
description: The White House embraced Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today, pointedly ignoring his sharp criticism of Washington's actions since the Iceland meeting. Instead it tried to depict the Soviet leader and President Reagan in agremeent on moving ahead in pursuit of arms control accords.

title: Presidential Airways
description: Presidential Airways, which serves 14 markets from Dulles Airport, is switching its $4 million to $6 million ad account to Tromson Monroe Advertising, specialists in travel advertising in New York. The former agency was Rosenthal, Greene & Campbell in Bethesda, Md.

title: Buyout Offer For Big Bakery
description: The American Bakeries Company said that a group headed by its chairman and chief executive had proposed acquiring the company for $43 a share. The announcement sent the company's stock up $10.125 a share, to $44.75, as investors speculated that a higher offer would emerge.

STANFORD TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

RITES OF FALL CLEANUP
description: IN my suburban neighborhood the neighbors are at no time more in evidence than on autumn weekends, when the weather is clear and cool, the oaks and maples are a blaze of gold and crimson and the leaves have started to fall. There are a few holdouts, people who wait until mid-November to do their raking just once and for all, but they are exceptions to the general rule that 50 leaves on the ground are reason enough to lure most homeowners outside to tend to the prime chore of the season - leaf harvesting.

title: Open Item on Agenda
description: At a brief news conference on Sept. 30 that was called to announce the Reykjavik meeting, President Reagan commented on the release by the Soviet Union's release of the American correspondent Nicholas K. Daniloff, whom he had described as a hostage. He was asked about American hostages held in Lebanon.

title: Chalkspeak
description: Favored quotations of the week, heard echoing along the halls of academe:

SALOMON'S EARNINGS DOWN 7.9%
description: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings declined 7.9 percent, largely because of lackluster results from its Philipp Brothers commodity operations. This was somewhat offset, however, by an improved performance in Salomon's brokerage operations.

title: For Edward Regan and Robert Abrams
description: After the Governor, New York's Comptroller is the state's most important and influential elected official. He serves as independent auditor of state agencies and finances and sole trustee of its $30 billion in pension funds.

title: IN THE HILLS OF BANGLADESH, A CONFLICT GATHERS FURY
description: The hilly jungles of this southeastern pocket of Bangladesh have for years been a haven for settlers escaping the densely populated plains nearby.

title: BALLOT ISSUES IN CALIFORNIA PROMPT POLITICAL WARFARE
description: Opinion surveys indicate that Californians favor approval of a sweeping measure on the Nov. 4 ballot that would impose some of the nation's strictest controls on toxic chemicals, a proposal that is drawing mounting fire from business and agricultural leaders.

title: NEWMONT GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Anti-Drug Forces In Bolivia Pulling Back
description: American troops who were sent to Bolivia to help fight the drug trade have begun moves to prepare to leave the country this week, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Ex-Adviser Recalls Dokes Bouts With Temptation
description: The news that Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, had been indicted in Nevada this week on charges that included drug trafficking and possession of marijuana did not surprise Marty Cohen.

title: LESLIE FAY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The net income figures respresent pro forma net income. The pro forma share earnings reflects the after-tax effect of non-recurring charges of 5 cents a share in the 39 weeks and 13-week periods ended Sept. 27, 1986.

title: China and Portugal In Accord on Macao
description: China and Portugal have reached an agreement on returning the Portuguese settlement of Macao to China, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: SAFETY LAPSES PARALYZE NUCLEAR BOMB COMPLEX
description: The potentially lethal mistake that prompted the Department of Energy to indefinitely shut key links in the nation's production line for nuclear bombs started with a flexible plastic tube a little smaller than a garden hose. Workers on the graveyard shift at a chemical plant here were using the tube to transfer some liquid waste laced with plutonium from one 50-gallon tank to another.

title: CHARLES HAINES
description: Charles Haines, a partner in the architectural firm of Haines Lundberg Waehler from 1957 until 1973, died on Oct. 10 after suffering a heart attack in Green Valley, Ariz., where he lived. He was 80 years old and for many years had been a resident of Tarrytown, N.Y., serving as its Mayor from 1949 to 1951.

title: NOVAMETRIX MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Penalties for Hasenfus In U.S. Could Be Harsh

title: PIANO: JEROME ROSE IN LISZT RECITAL
description: THIS season celebrates Franz Liszt doubly in that it marks the 175th anniversary of his birth and the 100th of his death. Naturally, his music has been more than usually in evidence, especially under the hands of pianists, since Liszt is the patron saint of their instrument. Jerome Rose, who has made a specialty of Liszt and is engaged in recording his entire piano repertory, last night gave what his program billed as a Liszt Birthday Gala Concert at Alice Tully Hall.

title: TOYS PLUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSCRIPT OF RADIO REPORT
description: Following is a transcript, made from a tape provided by WNBC radio, of the report being broadcast when a traffic news helicopter crashed in the Hudson River:

title: NETWORKS RAISE RATINGS BY SHOWING MORE FILMS
description: The announcement this week by CBS officials that the network would add a third night of movies to its weekly prime-time schedule illustrates an important and reliable network strategy - when the regular series start to fail, it's time to go to the movies.

title: 11 INDICTED IN A DRUG SCHEME FOILED BY AGENTS OF U.S. AND BRITAIN
description: Eleven people, including a Miami lawyer and a professional race car driver, were indicted today in Federal District Court here in what officials called a ''classical drug operation.''

title: GLENMORE DISTILLERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $25 million from sale of the marketing rights for Amaretto Di Saronno.

title: SAN ANTONIO OFFICER INDICTED IN SLAYING OF PARTNER
description: A city police officer was indicted today by a state grand jury on charges of murdering his former partner, in a case clouded by allegations that the slain officer had committed violent vigilante acts and was planning to assassinate three city officials.

title: FOR MUSEUM'S VIENNA, A GALA FAREWELL
description: IN Gustav Klimt's painting ''Auditorium of the Altes Burgtheater, Vienna,'' hundreds of people are gathered in what looks to be their finest clothes. A similar scene unfolded at the Vienna Ball at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night to mark the end of the exhibition ''Vienna 1900: Art, Architecture and Design.''

title: THERE'S NO STOPPING CARTER
description: After waiting 12 years to get into a World Series, Gary Carter is not about to allow a couple of sore knees, a single sore thumb, a ''beat-up'' left palm, a dollop of frustration, a soupcon of fatigue, and assorted other maladies and inconveniences - like the Boston Red Sox - to interfere with his good time.

title: Johnson Profits Rise by 13.7%
description: Johnson & Johnson, the manufacturer of health-care products, said today that gains by its consumer and pharmaceutical divisions contributed to its higher third-quarter profits and sales.

title: RESTRICTIONS ADDED
description: Striking in another round of the diplomatic expulsions, the Soviet Union said today that five more staff members of the United States Embassy would have to leave and that all 260 Soviet employees of the embassy would be withdrawn.

title: Article 123186 -- No Title
description: A Federal district judge today ordered four former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to pay more than $50,000 in damages to four 1960's political activists and a peace organization whose constitutional rights were violated.

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT 2.4% RATE IN QUARTER, PUSHED BY AUTO SALES
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the third quarter, a marked pickup from the six-tenths of 1 percent expansion rate in the spring, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Chief Justice Bird: Calm at the Center
description: The most significant political event in the country today may be the campaign to remove Chief Justice Rose Bird and two other Justices from the California Supreme Court. The attack on the judges challenges the whole American tradition of reliance on an independent judiciary to protect the system from abuse of power.

description: b-Net loss

title: COMMERCIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
