title: EPISCOPAL RESOLUTION ASSAILS VATICAN 'COERCION'
description: By a unanimous vote, the 518-member Convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New York has passed a resolution deploring what it says is ''coercive discipline'' or other action ''that narrows the realm of free debate'' among theologians and biblical scholars.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gene Banks, whom the Chicago Bulls were projecting as a starting guard this season, suffered a fractured right foot in practice and will be sidelined six or seven weeks. He averaged 10.9 points a game last season. . . . George (The Iceman) Gervin, who averaged 26.2 points in 10 National Basketball Association seasons and won four league scoring titles, has signed a one-year contract with Banco di Roma of the Italian League for $250,000, the average salary for foreign players in the league. Gervin, 34 years old, was with the Bulls last season after being traded from San Antonio. . . . Jorgen Petterson, a left wing who had 174 goals and 192 assists during his six and a half seasons in the National Hockey League, has decided to return to his native Sweden because he is unhappy with his lack of playing time with the Washington Capitals.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
USX to Hold Union Talks
description: After meeting for three hours late Tuesday, negotiators for the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America agreed to resume talks on Thursday toward ending a labor dispute that has idled about 22,000 workers since Aug. 1.

title: CRAFT'S INCREASING DOMAIN
description: IT has been 30 years since the Museum of Contemporary Crafts first opened in modest quarters on West 53rd Street, a small institution heavy with mission: to restore to public consciousness a sense of the ''handmade'' object in a world of factory products. The museum's founder was Aileen Osborn Webb (1892-1979), a woman of impeccable social credentials whose interest in crafts dated from the Depression, when she organized a co-op in Putnam County to sell the handmade goods of her neighbors.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings represent subshares.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Q & A: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.; WATCHING THE PENDULUM OF POWERS OF CONGRESS
description: Until he officially retires in January, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will keep his office here on the 22d floor of the Federal buildingnamed for John F. Kennedy, the man whom Mr. O'Neill succeeded in 1952 as the Representative of the Eighth Massachusetts District. The Speaker will be succeeded by President Kennedy's nephew, Joseph P. Kennedy.

title: Imperial Gas
description: Imperial Continental Gas Association P.L.C. said that it does not believe that a $1.07 billion bid for the company by the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, fairly reflects its value. The British energy company advised its shareholders not to sell their shares. Gulf Resources announced the offer on Tuesday.

title: Father Watches as Sons Are Killed in Plane Crash
description: A father watching one of his sons giving another son an airplane ride saw the single-engine craft crash, killing both the men.

description: b-After writedowns of $402.4 million. c-Net income

title: HERS
description: ''ALL is forgiven, please come home.'' This was no anonymous beseeching set in the newsprint of a ''personals'' column.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,161,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $166,000 and $600,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: The Senior Soph Of Salem State
description: College tennis players don't ordinarily seek advice from a sophomore teammate who's never won a varsity singles match, but Joe Sweeney of the Salem (Mass.) State Vikings is no ordinary sophomore. For one thing, he's a former coach of the Viking women's team, which he led to a state championship in 1983. For another, he's 71 years old.

title: U.S.-SOVIET SPARRING: A YEAR OF OUSTERS
description: March 7: The United States tells the Soviet Union that it must reduce the size of the Soviet, Ukrainian and Byelorussian Missions to the United Nations from 275 to 170 over two years, with the first cut of 25 by Oct. 1. The American announcement asserts that the Soviet Union is using the mission for spying. Aug. 23: Gennadi F. Zakharov, a physicist who is a Soviet employee of the United Nations, is arrested in New York on espionage charges.

title: Elly Ameling Recital
description: The soprano Elly Ameling will sing Hugo Wolf's ''Spanisches Liederbuch'' cycle with the baritone Ruud van der Meer at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon at 3. Admission is $17.50. Information: 362-1911.

title: 15 U.S.-Soviet Deals Proposed
description: Fifteen American companies, including such giants as Monsanto and Occidental Petroleum, have proposed creating joint ventures in the Soviet Union under new regulations aimed at liberalizing and strengthening the Soviet economy, according to the top Soviet trade official in the United States.

title: TELEVISION CITY PROJECT: TEMPERED, BUT STILL BIG
description: When plans were announced nearly a year ago for Television City, the vast project the developer Donald J. Trump hopes to build on the site of the former Penn Central rail yards between 59th and 72d Streets on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the proposal to make a 150-story tower the centerpiece gave the project instant national attention. At home, however, the reaction was less than enthusiastic. Community Board 7 of the Upper West Side held stormy hearings, and though the plans were never formally submitted to the City Planning Commission for approval, the commission was known to have expressed doubts about its chances.

title: REAGAN PUTTING CONTRA AID LAWS INTO EFFECT
description: President Reagan today began putting legislation into effect to funnel $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and allow the Central Intelligence Agency to resume direct support of the insurgent forces.

title: Americans Aren't Buying Beyond Their Means
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDFORD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings not available; the company went public in March.

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after tax depletion charge of $13.8 million related to the extraordinary decline in energy prices earlier in the year.

title: AMERICAN CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions yesterday about a helicopter crash in the Hudson River that killed a traffic news reporter misidentified a rescuer. He was Paul Hashagen.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FORT MYERS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $297,040. The extraordinary credit was a federal dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board paid in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dempsey a Free Agent
description: The Baltimore Orioles have notified Rick Dempsey, their regular catcher for the last nine years, that they will not pick up the option year of his contract, which would make the 37-year-old Dempsey a free agent. The 14-year veteran hit a career-low .208 this season after batting .254 in 1985. Dempsey batted .385 and was voted the World Series most valuable player in 1983, when the Orioles beat the Philadelphia Phillies, four games to one.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings restated for the 3-for-2 common stock split in June, 1986.

title: Times Co. Up 18.1%
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that net income for the third quarter rose to a record $26.7 million, or 33 cents a share, up 18.1 percent from $22.6 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. The per-share amounts have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in September.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $24.8 million on the sale of gates and ground facilities. c-Includes tax credits of $1,653,000 and $5,090,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes $52.5 million from an employee profit-sharing reserve. d-Net income

title: Battle Re-enactment
description: Hundreds of Revolutionary War aficionados will take part this weekend in a re-enactment of the battle of White Plains at Lake Minnewaska Day Park, Route U.S. 44/N.Y. 55, New Paltz, N.Y. Tomorrow, visitors will witness the daily doings of a Colonial encampment; on Sunday at noon, the actual clash between the Revolutionary and British forces is planned.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect a May 1986 pooling of interests acquisition and a change to the equity method of accounting for three facilities which began operating under a partnership agreement in October.

title: TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its second quarter results were hurt by the acquisitions of Gulf Broadcast Properties and the sale of Taft's Canadian amusement-theme park, and also said another negative factor was softness in independent television revenue combined with high programming costs.

title: OLD WAVE, NEW WAVE AND NEXT WAVE IN DANCE
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago this weekend, the New York dancegoer had a choice of four programs to attend. Tonight, 13 companies are performing at theaters around New York City, among them the Joffrey Ballet, which is celebrating 25 years of dance making by its resident choreographer, Gerald Arpino. Things have changed since Mr. Arpino created his first ballet. Jerome Robbins's Ballets: U.S.A. company was on Broadway that weekend in 1961, and Charles Weidman was performing in a downtown loft. But other than that, the pickings were limited to a folk dance and music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall and folk-dancing lessons complete with free tea.

title: ART: 4 YOUNG EAST VILLAGERS AT SONNABEND GALLERY
description: THE widely anticipated group exhibition at Sonnabend Gallery, 420 West Broadway, near Spring Street, brings some of the best and brightest young talent of the East Village art scene to prominent light in the SoHo emporium of Ileana Sonnabend. The artists are Ashley Bickerton, Jeff Koons, Peter Halley and Meyer Vaisman, all under 34 years old. Their work is seen by some to herald the return of an art that is certifiably American and firmly rooted in the Pop-Minimal-Conceptual tradition. It clearly replaces Neo-Expressionist excess with cool calculation, and its emergence is definitely one of the more hyped events in this hype-prone decade.

title: INCOMES EXPAND 0.3% AS BUYING SURGES 1.6%
description: Americans' personal incomes crept up three-tenths of 1 percent in September while consumer spending, powered by brisk automobile sales, surged 1.6 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FRUSTRATING RECORD FOR GOODEN IN SERIES
description: Vintage Gooden it wasn't.

title: NBD to Acquire USAmeribancs
description: NBD Bancorp, a bank holding company in Detroit, said that it had agreed to acquire USAmeribancs Inc., which operates six banks in the Chicago area, for $250 million.

title: REAGAN BEGINS 13-STATE CAMPAIGN TOUR
description: President Reagan, opening the first stage of a 13-state campaign tour, said today that the 1986 election marked a fundamental choice for the nation's voters on tax increases, law and order, and his program to defend against attacking missiles.

title: Convergent Has Deficit
description: Stung by reduced sales to its major customers, Convergent Technologies Inc. today reported its largest quarterly loss ever. The computer maker, based in San Jose, Calif., also announced that Cyril Yansouni, former vice president and general manager of the Hewlett-Packard Company's personal computer group, was joining the company as president.

title: No Passport for Now, Poland Tells Walesa
description: The authorities refused today to give Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, a passport for a trip to the United States, where he was to receive a humanitarian award, a Walesa associate said.

title: DU PONT NET UP 24.7%
description: Hurt by losses in their exploration and production divisions, three oil companies - the Standard Oil Company, the Shell Oil Company and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation -said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell subtantially below those of a year ago.

title: Topmost Teams
description: Miami's top spot in the polls marks the fourth straight week that the Hurricanes are No. 1.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 9 months earnings include a gain of $972,000, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of the company's home health-care operation and the sale of property.

title: JETS' TODD MOVES INTO ROLE AS BACKUP
description: In semi-retirement at $15,000 a week, Richard Todd finally seems to be enjoying life in New York.

title: D&N SAVINGS BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $444,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the 9 months. There were no per share earnings in the year-ago 9 months because the company converted to stock ownership in February 1985.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $135,000.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN WESTERN SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in May.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company attributed its net losses primarily to a loss on the sale of marketable securities of $494,000 and an unrealized loss on valuation of marketable securities of $622,000 in the latest third quarter, and a loss on the sale of marketable securities of $622,000 and unrealized losses of $1,413,000 in the 9 months.

title: ACROSS STATE, SCHOOLS TEACH ABOUT DRUG ABUSE
description: At John F. Kennedy High School here, students in a creative-writing class talked today about crack instead of Ray Bradbury.

title: CAPITOL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF DENVER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOSELEY HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $174,000 for the quarter and $327,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after a non-recurring charge of $9,750,000 for the quarter and $12,024,000 for the 6 months representing final liquidation of inventories and other costs associated with certain ceased U.S. government securities trading activities.

title: QUANTUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
COCHRANE FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
DEBBI BILOWIT
description: Debbi Wasserman Bilowit, senior manager of Telelearning for Channel 13, died of cancer yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ARPINO MARKS HIS 25TH
description: The Joffrey Ballet will honor Gerald Arpino, the company's resident choreographer, tonight at City Center with an all-Arpino program celebrating his 25th year of making dances. Mr. Arpino remembers vividly his first ballet. Called ''Ropes,'' it was inspired by Charles Ives's ''Unanswered Question,'' which served as the score for the ballet.

title: Flying to Pretoria
description: When Congress acted Oct. 2 to pass legislation imposing economic sanctions on South Africa, overriding a veto by President Reagan, the bill gave the President 10 days to direct the Department of Transportation to order an end to all direct air travel between the United States and South Africa. Since there are no direct flights by American carriers to that country, the principal impact would be on South African Airways, the goverment-owned carrier there.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $5.4 million and $14.2 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $10.1 million and $6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter results include a charge of 22 cents a share for inventory adjustments and facilities restructuring in its medical systems business and that the latest 9 months also included the charge of 22 cents.

title: Fannie Mae Securities
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, offered $700 million of stripped mortgage-backed securities yesterday through a syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. It is the sixth issue of stripped mortgage-backed securities sold and the first public offering through a syndicate.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $296 million and $323 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $58 million from the early extinguishment of interest rate hedge contracts for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6 million for the quarter and $14 million for the 9 months. The company said the results for 1986 reflect the acquisition of American Hospital Supply Corp. in late 1985. In addition, results for the first half of 1986 have been restated for the sale of the company's Flint and American Critical Care units in September 1986. The company said the 1985 results have been restated to reflect only the sale of Flint, since Critical Care was a unit of American.

title: DONNELLEY, R R & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROLE OF OUSTED GENERAL IN PURCHASES IS EXAMINED
description: The Manhattan District Attorney is investigating allegations that the former commander of the largest National Guard organization in the country improperly intervened on behalf of a private company that sold equipment to the unit, according to officials familiar with the investigation.

title: DESPITE WOMEN'S GAINS IN STATES, STUDIES FIND FEW IN THE TOP POSTS
description: Women are making steady progress in obtaining high-level posts in state government, and in some states they occupy more than one-third of the cabinet positions, according to two newly published studies of women in state cabinets.

title: Diner's Journal
description: MY frustrated quest for homey Spanish cooking has made me feel like Don Quixote in pursuit of evil knights.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LEGG MASON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid last month.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net gains of $137,000 and $7,053,000 from the sale of assets for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
13 Reported Dead In Pakistan Air Crash
description: A Pakistan International Airways plane on a domestic flight crashed today near Peshawar in northwest Pakistan, killing at least 13 people and injuring 26, an airline spokesman said.

title: Advertising; Burnett Sets Its Own Pace
description: THE Leo Burnett Company, Chicago's gift to the advertising world, does not do things impulsively. It was one of the last of the major agencies to move internationally. But it did move - acquiring 22 agency offices from one company and six from another in 1969.

title: Toots Thielemans
description: The harmonica player-guitarist Toots Thielemans, the pianist Roger Kellaway, the bassist Michael Moore and the guitarist Gene Bertoncini will perform together Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (369-8040). Tickets are $8, or $6 for students and the elderly.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A '34 CAR, GOOD AS NEW For $3,500 this weekend you can buy a 1934 Duesenberg four-door convertible. Made of wood. Three feet long. It is one of the items for sale at Crafts Park Avenue, a bazaar-exhibition at the Armory on Park Avenue between 66th and 67th Streets that opens today. The model car, built to scale, sports spoked wheels and a detailed chassis. Those interested in more functional crafts may choose from surrealistic sculpture clocks, sushi dishes and chopsticks made from exotic hardwoods, handblown glass lampshades, and belts and bags made from leather and snakeskin. These and other creations represent the work of the more than 200 artisans participating in the exhibition. The show is open today from 5 to 9 P.M.; tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M., and Sunday from noon to 7 P.M. Admission is $4 today, ($5 for both Saturday and Sunday.) Information: (914) 679-7277.

title: Black Sox Of a Red Hue
description: It may be a while before free agency takes hold in the Soviet Union, but, among the nation's top soccer players, the quest for a bigger piece of the national pie seems to have produced a lucrative alternative: chicanery.

title: Maj. Gen. Lucas Beau Dies; Commanded Civil Air Patrol
description: Lucas V. Beau, a retired Air Force major general whose career included service as a World War I pilot and as commander of the Civil Air Patrol, died Wednesday at Sibley Memorial Hospital here after suffering a heart attack. He was 91 years old.

title: Africa's Locust Picture Is Reported to Improve
description: A threatened plague of grasshoppers and locusts has been brought under control in much of western and eastern Africa, the director general of the Food and Agriculture Organization, said today.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SOME HUNGARIANS REMEMBER 1956, SOME FORGET
description: As dusk settled today, not a single bloom had been placed at the statue of Sandor Petofi to mark the spot where the Hungarian uprising - the fiercest popular revolt against Communist rule in Eastern Europe - began exactly 30 years ago.

title: BANKVERMONT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains of $58,000 for the quarter and $157,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $7,524,000 for the quarter and $9,058,000 for the 9 months.

title: WEBB, DEL E CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $251,000 for the latest 9 months, a net of $87,000 for the year- ago quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $1,026,000 for the year-ago 9 months.

title: Dining Out Guide; Low-Calorie
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMSTERDAM'S BAR AND ROTISSERIE, #428 Amsterdam Avenue, between 80th and 81st Streets (874-1377) - **(Aug. 24, 1984) The core of the appealing menu at this smart and functional restaurant is the gas-fired rotisserie in an open kitchen. Rotisserie cooking, an excellent method for sealing in juices and natural flavors, while remaining greaseless, demands an attentive chef.

title: MOZAMBIQUE FUTURE: DOUBTS RAISED
description: Not long after he took power in 1975, President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique was invited to Zambia for a ceremony in which he was given the keys to a northern copper-mining town. The black aldermen of

title: John J. (Don) McNamara Jr., Banker and Olympic Sailor
description: John J. (Don) McNamara Jr. an investment banker and sailor who earned a bronze medal in the 1964 Olympic Games, died in his sleep at his home in Boston last Saturday, apparently because of blood pressure problems. He was 54 years old.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Who Is Julia?' TV Movie on CBS
description: Can the head of a glamorous model find happiness on the torso of an average-looking wife and mother? If that question interests you, an answer of sorts is available Sunday on CBS at 9 P.M.

title: RECITAL: LANI MISENAS-PADUA
description: LANI MISENAS-PADUA, the Philippine coloratura soprano who gave a recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night, clearly has her sights set on a music-theater career. After making her way respectably through groups of songs by Faure and Wolf, she went full tilt at ''O luce di quest'anima,'' from Donizetti's ''Linda di Chamounix,'' and everything thereafter had a theatrical touch about it.

title: Economic Scene; To Correct Moral Erosion
description: PROF. JAMES M. BUCHANAN of George Mason University, this year's winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, argues that politics can be subjected to the same analysis that economists apply to markets, since individuals in both realms essentially seek to serve their own interests, rather than those of society.

title: AUCTIONS
description: BEATRIZ PATINO may never miss the $7 million worth of European and English silver, the 18th-century French furnishings and the Old Masters that will be auctioned by Sotheby's and Christie's - the furnishings and silver in sales during the next nine days, with the paintings going under the hammer in January. Mrs. Patino said this week that the palace-quality furnishings and art - which her husband, Antenor Patino, the Bolivian tin magnate, collected over 60 years until his death at the age of 85 in 1982 - are not all that remains of the Patino holdings.

title: KEY CENTURION BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago results are restated. The per share earnings are net of preferred dividends. All earnings periods are restated to include the results of Boone National Bank of Madison, Madison, W.Va., a merger accounted for on a pooling basis, and also reflect the Centurion Bancorp Inc. merger, accounted for as a purchase, completed Nov. 30, 1985, and accordingly included in Key Centurion results from that date.

title: Books; The Sakharovs
description: ALONE TOGETHER. By Elena Bonner.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1986
description: THE WORLD The Iceland meeting included talk about eliminating all nuclear weapons, but President Reagan did not offer the idea in a formal proposal to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to the White House.

title: EASTERN POSTS DROP OF 25.1%
description: Eastern Air Lines, the troubled carrier that is being acquired by the Texas Air Corporation, said yesterday that its net income dropped 25.1 percent in the third quarter.

title: Red Tide on Texas Coast May Be Weakening
description: The red tide that has plagued Texas's Gulf Coast for two months may be weakening and killing fewer fish, state officials say.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''SOUL MAN,'' which opens today (review on page C5), is about a wealthy college senior whose parents refuse to pay for his law school education. Desperate to go to Harvard, he decides to apply for a minority scholarship by disguising himself as a black student.

title: Berlin: Still the Front
description: The old U.S. Mission building here is being refurbished, bright, modern, very up to date. At the entrance to the headquarters building where the big issues of war and peace, the chance for freedom versus Soviet domination, were once focused, black American women soldiers in camouflage fatigues stand chatting. The snappy honor guard is gone and so is the tension, the excitement of history being made by the minute.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Jo Anne Lala has joined Scali, McCabe, Sloves as a senior vice president, management supervisor.

title: GOLDEN POULTRY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INSIDE
description: Hasenfus Cites Secret Field Eugene Hasenfus said a plane carrying supplies for Nicaraguan rebels used a clandestine airstrip in Costa Rica this year.

title: Around the World With Weinberger
description: On Oct. 11, as senior Administration officials gathered in the chill of Reykjavik, Iceland, for a superpower conference, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger sat in semitropical Kunming, China, 200 miles from the tense border with Vietnam, being briefed on a running artillery duel that most of the world has long ignored.

title: THEIR LEAKY DEFENSE IS COSTLY
description: Tommy Lasorda, the manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, watched the Mets play some untypically gross baseball and lose the fifth game of the World Series tonight, and brought them into sharp focus.

title: STAGE: CHONG'S ''ANGELS,' BASED ON BORGES TALE
description: IN ''The Book of Imaginary Beings,'' Jorge Luis Borges writes about the 18th-century Swedish visionary Emanuel Swedenborg, who thought of angels as ''those souls who have chosen Heaven.'' Borges continues, ''Earthly things are but emblems of heavenly things.'' These and other cosmological statements serve as the inspiration for Ping Chong's new play, ''The Angels of Swedenborg,'' an interpretation of life in seraphic spheres. The performance piece opened Wednesday in the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Equal Time Is Requested
description: Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi said Thursday he had asked for equal time on the Fox Broadcasting system because his Democratic opponent, Bella S. Abzug, appeared on the Joan Rivers television show.

title: Market Place; Dart & Kraft, After the Split
description: SOME Wall Street analysts believe that Dart & Kraft Inc., the giant food and consumer products company that soon will be divided into two separate entities, is undervalued.

title: HERITAGE-NIS BANK FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form on Oct. 9, 1986 and because the bank had no stock outstanding prior to its conversion, per share earnings are not applicable.

title: Four Crewmen Arrested
description: Four crewmen from the Courageous challenge were arrested by the West Australian police Wednesday and charged with damaging a $25,000 mainsail belonging to the syndicate.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Webster Industries, a Boston plastic bag manufacturer, to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.

title: PEACE MARCHERS WALK FROM SEA TO SHINING SEA
description: A disheveled band of visionaries passed beneath the arches of the George Washington Bridge at midday yesterday, eight months and hundreds of pairs of hiking boots since their dreams of awakening Americans to the possibility of a world blowing up seemed dashed in the dust of the Mojave Desert.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES RISE A SHARP 4.9%
description: Orders to American factories for durable goods such as heavy machinery, aircraft and transportation equipment as well as for large household appliances jumped 4.9 percent in September, the largest rise in nearly two years.

title: FINESSE MIGHTIER THAN POWER
description: The crowd lingered near the railing when the game was over, cheering madly but also knowing that Fenway Park would soon shut down for the winter. They knew, too, that the Boston Red Sox were one game from a World Series title and that Bruce Hurst had taken them there.

title: Kingsley Amis Receives British Fiction Prize
description: The Booker Prize, Britain's top honor for fiction, has been awarded to Kingsley Amis for ''The Old Devils,'' a novel about elderly, alcoholic couples in south Wales.

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $200,000.

title: Cuomo Meets On Judges
description: Governor Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature met privately for more than an hour in Mr. Cuomo's Manhattan office on Wednesday but failed to reach final agreement on a plan to add judges in New York City.

title: TEXT OF U.S. DOCUMENT ON REAGAN AT SUMMIT
description: Following is a document prepared by Administration officials setting forth the Administration's view of the sequence of events in the talks between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Reykjavik, Iceland, this month. The document, dated Oct. 23, was prepared as a guidance sheet for Administration spokesmen. The headings such as Contingency Only and If Pressed are intended for the guidance of the spokesmen using this document to answer questions from journalists. These documents, commonly called ''talking points,'' are not customarily made public, but they usually are not classified. Contingency Only

title: ENSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-Includes tax credits of $306,000 for the quarter and $833,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes $2,333,000 of non-recurring costs related to the company's mergers with California Analytical Laboratories Inc. and Rocky Mountain Analytical Laboratory Inc. in June 1986.

title: Wright's Daughter Charged
description: The daughter of Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, was charged with unlawful possession of a firearm today, but prosecutors said they had not decided whether she would be be charged with a narcotics offense. Mr. Wright's daughter Alicia and her husband, John T. Carnes, were arrested Sunday in Lake Worth after a park officer stopped them for driving erratically and noticed a gun barrel protuding from Mrs. Carnes's purse, an assistant district attorney in Tarrant County said.

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter results include those of Richardson Foods Corp and Golden Grain Macaroni Co. from the dates of their acquisitions in August 1986.

title: Company Tax Disclosures
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a directive for companies to quantify certain effects of the tax revision law in 1986 annual reports to shareholders.

title: BROADCAST NOMINATION DIES
description: When Congress adjourned over the weekend, among the unfinished business was President Reagan's nomination of Sonia Landau to return to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, of which she had been chairman until her term expired on March 26.

title: On Bottles of Rum
description: Americans who think price control is a 20-century achievement should examine one of the documents going on exhibit today at the National Archives in conjunction with the 200th anniversary of the Constitution.

title: DEVILS END THREE-GAME SLIDE
description: The Devils got excellent goaltending for the first time in four games and ended a three-game losing streak tonight with a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: WESTERN UNION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes charges of $18.2 million reflecting expenditures incurred during 1986 in connection with a proposed financial restructuring program, which was terminated in September, and a $6.3 million writedown of an investment. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $7,173,000, a gain of $6 million on the disposal of discontinued operations and extraordinary charges of $1,940,000. d-Includes a gain of $4,020,000. e-Includes net from discontinued operations of $17,524,000 and extraordinary gains of $4,020,000. Results for 1985 included income of $11.0 million from a division that has since been sold and the termination of an inactive retirement plan.

title: Music Improvisations
description: The Festival of Improvised Music: Women in Improv will continue this weekend. Tomorrow at 9 P.M. at Roulette, 228 West Broadway at White Street in TriBeCa, the performers will be Ladonna Smith, Anne LeBaron, Judy Dunaway and Christian Marclay, and Cinnie Cole and Davey Williams. Sunday at 4 P.M. at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, near 10th Street, there will be music by Charlotte Moorman, Hizohi, Lesli Dalaba and Ushio Torikai and Carol Emmanuel with Jana Grace, Jason Hwang and Polly Styron. Tickets for each concert are $5; information, 206-1680.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company said results for 1985 are restated to give effect to the adoption of new pension standards in the fourth quarter of last year retroactive to the beginning of the year. This increased last year's previously reported first quarter net income and share earnings by $800,000 and 2 cents a share, respectively.

title: EXPULSION ROUNDS NOW APPEAR OVER
description: The State Department criticized the Soviet Government today for withdrawing all of its 260 employees from the United States diplomatic missions in the Soviet Union. But American officials indicated that they hoped the cycle of diplomatic expulsions had ended.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Armco's Loss at $59 Million
description: Armco Inc., the financially troubled steelmaker, yesterday reported a $59 million loss in the third quarter, in contrast to net income of $78.2 million, or $1.12 a share, in the comparable period last year. The company said the loss primarily reflected the impact of a strike and a $21 million charge from increases in loss reserves in its insurance units.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Woolridge Leads Victory by Nets
description: Orlando Woolridge scored 21 points and Dwayne Washington added 18 as the Nets used a big third quarter to defeat the Golden State Warriors, 114-102, tonight in a preseason game.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Agenda column yesterday about the pending trial of David Fillyaw, accused in an attack on a Columbia University student, incorrectly described the charges against him. Mr. Fillyaw is charged with attempted murder, attempted rape, assault, burglary and criminal possession of a weapon.

title: KMW SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago first quarter restated to reflect a change in accounting for pensions.

title: BOKASSA MAKES SURPRISE RETURN HOME
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the former self-proclaimed emperor of this country, returned here today from exile in France and was promptly arrested and jailed.

title: HAWKEYE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $20.5 million writedown related to continuing asset sales.

title: Songwriter Performs
description: The songwriter J. J. Cale will perform tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows, with the blues singer John Hammond opening, begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: 5 Suspects Are Held in Chile In Attempt to Kill President
description: The police have arrested five men they suspect fired rifles at the motorcade of the President, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, in an assassination attempt last month, the military Government said today.

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $17,429,000 pre-tax gain on the sale of assets for the quarter and $192,526,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a $31,942,000 pre-tax gain on the sale of assets for the quarter and $46,950,000 for the 9 months.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TO THE LAND OF THE CATTAILS. By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 148 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $14.95. IT is the summer of 1938. A mother and her son have made their way eastward from Austria to Bukovina, traveling first by train, then by horse and carriage. The mother, Toni, is a woman of 34. Seventeen years ago she ran away from a traditional Jewish home in the region together with a non-Jew; once they reached Vienna, they married and had a child, Rudi, but by the time she was 20 she was divorced. Now, after coming into a legacy from one of her many lovers, she has been seized by an urge to revisit her native village and see the parents with whom she has lost touch, taking Rudi with her.

title: White House Staff Shift Linked to Leak Inquiry
description: A staff member of the National Security Council has been shifted to the State Department following questions that emerged in the leak of classified information about the reported Reagan Administration campaign to confuse the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a White House official said tonight.

title: COAST MUSEUM MAY SELL ART
description: Concerned about finances, the new Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles has been discussing the possibility of selling some works from the major group of contemporary paintings and sculptures it acquired for $11 million in 1984 from the Italian industrialist Count Giuseppe Panza di Buomo. The discussions have occurred even as the museum moves toward the gala Dec. 10 opening of its glamorous new building in downtown Los Angeles..

title: Doc Cheatham Sextet
description: The trumpeter Doc Cheatham will lead a sextet - with Britt Woodman on trombone, Joey Cavaseno on saxophone, Dick Katz on piano, Victor Gaskin on bass and Al Harewood on drums - tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Vons and Allied Call Off Merger
description: The Vons Companies and Allied Supermarkets Inc. said they had called off their proposed $660 million merger.

title: CHUBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $11,300,000 and $45,900,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $500,000 for the quarter and $37,000,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings for 1985 have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split.

title: UNC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,831,000 for the quarter and includes for the 9 months net from discontinued operations of $1,081,000, a tax benefit of $6,228,000 and a loss on debt retirement of $1,112,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $356,000 and a tax credit of $1,014,000. d-Includes a gain of $1,186,000 on the sale of a building, a loss from discontinued operations of $203,000 and a tax benefit of $5,414,000.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALD DUCK LEARNS CHINESE
description: A large animated mouse and an orange-billed duck in a red bow tie waddled into Peking today to sell Disney's magic kingdom to one billion Chinese.

title: THE SCREEN: 'LOOPHOLE'
description: ''LOOPHOLE,'' a 1983 English movie about a bank robbery, is of such ineptitude that you are allowed to suspect there's a far more interesting (and possibly more cautionary) story behind the screen than anything that's on it. The cast includes Albert Finney, Martin Sheen, Susannah York, Jonathan Pryce, Colin Blakely and, in an ill-fitting miniature, Robert Morley - all of whom must have seen something more than money when they began the project.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLUMN ONE: THE PRESS
description: At CBSThe cutbacks at CBS have hit all corners of the company. Now, the United Way finds itself caught in the bind.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BOXING GENE HATCHER VS. DARYL ANTHONY, 12 rounds for W.B.C. Continental Americas welterweight title, at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City.

title: Strauss to Speak
description: Democratic leaders in Congress, who rarely go outside the Senate and House for a spokesman to respond to President Reagan, have chosen a former party chairman, Robert S. Strauss, to answer the President's radio broadcast tomorrow. Mr. Strauss served as Special Trade Representative in the Carter Administration, and he is expected to be particularly critical of Mr. Reagan on the economic and trade issues with which the Democrats hope to score in next month's elections.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROADWAY
description: THE pens are poised, and the signing and sealing apparently will be within days, but delivery isn't scheduled for another year. At that time, ''Cabaret,'' the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical with book by Joe Masteroff, should be back on Broadway starring -well, who else but Joel Grey? It probably needn't be said, but Mr. Grey originated the role of the master of ceremonies two decades ago, won a Tony for it the following year, and later went on to star in the movie version.

title: RIBI IMMUNOCHEM RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Penguin Streak Ends at 7
description: Mark Howe scored a goal and assisted on two others to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-3 victory over Pittsburgh tonight, ending the Penguins' seven-game winning streak from the start of the season. The Flyers are now 6-0 this season.

title: WITNESS AT TRIAL DESCRIBES FRIEDMAN STOCK-BRIBE ROLE
description: The former president of a company chosen to make hand-held computers for the New York City Parking Violations Bureau testified today that he had been told that Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, was to hold hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stock for the deputy director of the bureau and the Queens Borough President.

title: Goodyear Net Climbs by 18%
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today its third-quarter profit rose 18 percent to $182.3 million, or $1.68 a share, from $154.5 million, or $1.44 a share, a year earlier.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9 months results include a net gain of $102 million, or 38 cents a share, from the sale of Ford's North American paint operation and the sale of Ford's interest in Starnet Corp.

title: The Road Not Taken
description: William W. Scranton 3d has announced cancellation of all his ''negative'' radio and television commercials - a welcome move whether it represents a slick campaign tactic or real repugnance for the ''back alley brawl'' he said the Pennsylvania gubernatorial race had become.

title: CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Don't Turn Your Back on the Veteran, Uncle Sam; Home-Loan Phase-Out
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-GENERAL CALLED KEY TO CONTRA ARMS
description: Retired Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord is a West Point graduate, a much-decorated combat pilot and a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense who was instrumental in persuading the Senate to sell top-secret Awacs radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia in 1981.

title: BELEAGUERED MEXICO CEDES ROLE AS CENTRAL AMERICA POWER BROKER
description: Even though an independent foreign policy remains essential to its nationalist self-image, Mexico has quietly ceded its place in Central American diplomacy as its economic and political problems have grown.

title: Contraceptives for Students: A Copout or a Check on Dropouts?
description: To the Editor:

title: Delta-Western Deal Advances
description: The Transportation Department gave tentative approval today to the acquisition of Western Airlines by Delta Air Lines, concluding that the merger poses no significant competitive problems.

title: SCREEN: A COMEDY 'SOUL MAN'
description: THERE'S nothing automatically funny about the story of a rich white college boy who masquerades as black in order to collect a scholarship to Harvard Law School. That's putting it mildly. But ''Soul Man,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, has a breezy, unapologetic manner. And it also happens to be funny, which goes a long way toward making up for any underlying obtuseness or insensitivity.

title: Bonds Rise in Active Trading
description: Bond prices rose smartly in brisk trading yesterday, as traders tended to shrug off several reports that, on the surface at least, suggest the nation's economy may be firming.

title: CYPRUS MINERALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The company said the latest third quarter loss includes a reserve of $13 million established on receivables of about $17 million due from LTV Corp.'s LTV Steel Co. unit as a result of LTV Corp.'s filing for Chapter 11 reorganization.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a company that designs mountains for skiing misidentified the owner of Vail Associates Inc., the Colorado ski resort. It is owned by Gillette Group Inc. of Nashville, which is primarily a communications company, not the Gillette Company, which produces personal care products.

title: Quaker Oats, Sara Lee Gain
description: The Quaker Oats Company and the Sara Lee Corporation today reported profit gains. Both companies cited strong performances in their food operations.

title: Edelman's Offer Rejected by Lucky
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said its board had rejected a $37-a-share takeover proposal from the New York investor Asher B. Edelman as inadequate. The company, based in Dublin, Calif., said that its directors plan to meet next week to consider additional steps to restructure the company to improve the value of its stock and permit the company to remain independent.

title: NORTHWEST SEEMS COOL TO TARIFF ON CANADA LUMBER
description: Big producers, small mill operators and labor in the Pacific Northwest's lumber industry all seem cool to an announcement last week that the United States plans to levy a 15 percent tariff on Canadian lumber entering the country.

title: PUROLATOR COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIANTS VS. REDSKINS: A RUGGED RIVALRY
description: Anyone who saw the last game between the Giants and the Redskins will never forget it.

title: Pumpkin Festival
description: Several tons of pumpkins will be up for grabs this weekend during the annual Pumpkin Festival sponsored by the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater. Tomorrow from 11:45 A.M. to 5 P.M., the sloop will be at Liberty State Park, South Dock, Jersey City.

title: NEVADA NATIONAL BANCORPORAION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COAST GUARD WORRIED OVER HAWAII PROJECT NEAR TRANSMITTER
description: The Coast Guard has become a reluctant ally of critics of a 15-mile freeway that would link Oahu's leeward shore near Pearl Harbor and the island's windward side near Kaneohe Marine Air Corps Station.

title: Ex-Coach to Sue
description: Dave Schellhase, a former college player at Purdue and a member of the Chicago Bulls from 1966-68, said he would sue Indiana State University next week, claiming that the school failed to honor his contract as basketball coach and failed to help him deal with alcoholism. Schellhase, 42 years old, said he would file suit next Monday in United States District Court in Terre Haute, Ind., charging that ''Indiana State University kept me sick by ignoring my problem.''

title: KNOLL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net income

title: Spencer Phenix, 95, Is Dead; Helped Draft Anti-War Pact
description: Spencer Phenix, a retired Foreign Service officer who helped draft the 1928 Kellogg-Briand pact renouncing war, died Oct. 15 at the Peabody Home in Franklin, N.H. He was 95 years old and lived in Chocorua, N.H.

title: FAMILIAR PATTERN AS METS STUMBLE
description: ''If you would have told me we would come in here and take two out of three, I'd be pleased with that,'' Keith Hernandez said. The Mets had won two of three games at Fenway Park. After creating a two-game deficit at Shea Stadium, they now trail the four-of-seven-game Series by one game.

title: RIKERS I. GUARDS GIVEN CONDITIONS FOR RESIGNATION
description: New York City's Correction Commissioner said yesterday that scores of jail guards would be allowed to quit an elite emergency response team to protest allegations of brutality against inmates on Rikers Island last weekend, but not until replacements could be found.

title: JURY IN EL AL BOMB CASE BEGINS DELIBERATIONS
description: With a parting glance at Nezar Hindawi as he sat staring from the Old Bailey dock, the 12 members of the jury began verdict deliberations today on the charge that the 32-year-old Jordanian tried to blow up an Israeli airliner.

title: MERRY LAND & INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a pooling of interests with Urethane Technology Inc.

title: Baxter Shows Profit Rise
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories reported third-quarter net income of $287 million, reflecting a $285 million gain from the sale of its Flint pharmaceutical unit.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE baseball diamonds of Shea Stadium and Fenway Park were not on the minds of the partygoers who trooped into Tiffany & Company and Christie's on Monday evening. Jewels and silver were.

title: WEBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,947,000 on sale of insurance.

title: LEAR SIEGLER SEEKS RESTRUCTURING PLANS
description: Lear Siegler Inc., an aerospace, automotive, industrial and agricultural company based in Santa Monica, Calif., said today that it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to advise it on a possible restructuring to maximize shareholder value.

title: WILLIAM HIRSCHER
description: William Hirscher, an honorary deputy Sanitation Department commissioner, died Tuesday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 98 years old and lived in the Concourse Village West apartment cooperative in the Bronx.

title: INQUIRY LOOKING FOR MALFUNCTION AS POSSIBLE CAUSE OF COPTER CRASH
description: A possible mechanical malfunction is being investigated as a cause of the traffic helicopter crash that killed a radio reporter on Wednesday, the top Federal official investigating the accident said yesterday.

title: VALID LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: MURRAY SPALDING
description: LIKE many dancers and choreographers today, Murray Spalding travels a lot, and during her journeys she often eats in restaurants. The conversations she has heard about her while dining became the inspiration for ''Tables, Titterings and Travels,'' which the Murray Spalding Dance Theater of Washington brought to the Jose Limon Dance Foundation Center on Thursday night.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (KALAMAZOO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN MOSCOW, A DO-IT-YOURSELF EMBASSY COPES
description: The Ambassador drove his own car to work and maintenance workers dispensed pizzas at the snack bar today as the United States Embassy coped with its first day without Soviet employees.

title: TRAFFIC REPORTERS, SHAKEN BY CRASH, ASK IF IT'S WORTH IT
description: The men and women who are paid to fly over New York City and report on its traffic often think of themselves as airborne comrades, and when one of their number crashed and died in the Hudson River Wednesday, some of them, especially Roz Frank, began to think anew of the danger in their job and whether that risk was worth taking.

title: Ranger Maneuvers
description: The Rangers completed their side of the trade that brought them a defenseman, Don Jackson, from Edmonton last month for future considerations.

title: RED SOX WIN FOR 3-2 EDGE IN THE SERIES
description: The Mets, who had every reason to believe they had escaped a horrendous postseason scoring slump, drifted back to their hapless ways tonight: Their 4-2 loss to the Boston Red Sox left them one defeat away from losing the 83d World Series.

title: His Number's Up
description: He grew up in Baltimore watching Alan Ameche play for the Colts and dreaming of the day when he would follow in his idol's footsteps, wearing Ameche's number, 35. He never played for the Colts, but Calvin Hill made his numerical dream come true.

title: 2 JUDGES AND 17 UNION OFFICIALS INDICTED IN PHILADELPHIA INQUIRY
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted two judges and 17 union officials on charges ranging from racketeering to extortion and bribery.

title: Advertising; Burrell Is Top Winner At Awards Presentation
description: Burrell Advertising, Chicago, the country's largest black-owned agency, last night was the big winner at the annual CEBA Awards presentations at the New York Hilton.

title: ELIE WIESEL, IN MOSCOW, MEETS GOOD FRIENDS
description: Elie Wiesel, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, met today with ''old friends'' among Jewish would-be emigrants, but there was no word on a meeting he had hoped for with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Group to Study Brooklyn Piers
description: The Brooklyn Heights Association yesterday announced the formation of a committee to formulate plans to develop six, largely unused piers below the Brooklyn Heights Promenade.

title: NEW ENGLAND CRITICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $361,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $921,000, or 27 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss Year-earlier quarter and 9 months nets include a pre-tax charge $305,000 from the closing of a facility.

title: Advertising; More Warnaco Work For Wells, Rich Unit
description: Last August, Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, established a special unit called the Image Group, whose mission was to create wonderful print advertising in a television age.

title: SERBS BEWAIL THEIR LOT IN THE YUGOSLAV FEDERATION
description: To listen to Serbs these days in this, their capital, which is also the capital of the multinational federated state of Yugoslavia, is to hear a rising chorus of rancor about their lot.

title: Albany Can Untangle the Cable Knot
description: Manhattan has had cable television for two decades, but wiring in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island is only just starting. Why? An odor of corruption arises from state and Federal grand jury investigations; those will deal only with criminal charges like those just brought against John Zaccaro and Justice Francis X. Smith, administrative judge of the state Supreme Court in Queens. The public needs more - a fully rounded explanation for all the frustrating delay, the kind of explanation that requires a state investigating commission.

title: DEFICIT PUT AT $220.7 BILLION, LESS THAN FORECAST
description: James C. Miller 3d, President Reagan's budget director, disclosed today that the Federal budget deficit for the fiscal year 1986, ended Sept. 30, amounted to $220.7 billion.

title: Response From Rose
description: The Cincinnati Reds' player-manager, Pete Rose, responding to a request by Bill Bergesch, the general manager, that he remove himself from the protected roster this winter so a younger player could take the spot, said any such move would be premature. ''I can understand Bill's feelings,'' Rose said in Tampa, Fla.

EMBATTLED ALAIA UNVEILS A SOFT NEW LOOK
description: The world of fashion loves a good fight. And last Saturday, the press and buyers covering the fashion collections here had ringside seats for a championship bout. Azzedine Alaia was in one corner and Women's Wear Daily in the other.

description: The per share earnings are not available because the bank went public July 17.

title: RICE SETTING AN UPBEAT TONE
description: The music in the locker room was rock 'n' roll and the mood was definitely upbeat as the Boston Red Sox finished their World Series duties at Fenway Park tonight with a 4-2 victory. Now the World Series goes back to New York, and the Red Sox need one victory to end it.

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest 9-month period resulted primarily from the previously reported rescission of the sale of Zeta Laboratories Inc., and the discontinuation of the company's Thin Film Media operation earlier in the year. The rescission agreement resulted in a loss before taxes of $5,737,000 and the writeoff related to the Thin Film Media operations was $14,191,000 before taxes.

title: Meeting at USX
description: Negotiators for the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers met again, raising hopes that their renewed contract talks might continue on a daily basis.

Advertising; Frye Becomes a First For Messner, Vetere
description: Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey, previously known as Tuesday Team II, has got its first consumer account, the Frye Company of Marlborough, Mass., maker of boots and shoes.

title: FUJITSU IN DEAL ON CHIP MAKER
description: Fujitsu Ltd., the giant Japanese electronics company, will buy a majority interest in the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, a pioneering Silicon Valley computer chip manufacturer now owned by Schlumberger Ltd.

title: MAYOR BALKS AT SIGNING REVISED CABLE CONTRACTS
description: Mayor Koch, citing investigations into the awarding of cable television franchises, announced yesterday that he was refusing to sign revised contracts for cable service to the Bronx and most of Brooklyn.

title:
How to Preserve National Defense;
Deploy S.D.I. Now
description: President Reagan has made it clear to the Russians that he does not plan to abandon his Strategic Defense Initiative. He should now instruct the Pentagon to move ahead without delay to develop and deploy a missile defense. The technology is already available, and there is no reason to hesitate.

description: Government officers have resumed their questioning of John A. Walker Jr. about his family's Soviet spy ring, Reagan Administration officials and his lawyer said today.

Advertising; A Shift by Air France
description: Air France, forced to find a new home because of conflicts arising from a mega-merger, announced yesterday that it had selected Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson from a field of five to handle its estimated $3 million in billings. Its previous hangar was Kenyon & Eckhardt, which merged with Bozell & Jacobs, which is in the American Airlines flight pattern.

title: TANDY CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that costs associated with the assimulation of the recently acquired Joshua's Christian stores and the September sale of its Tandy Tools division lowered net income.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AGENDA: OCT. 24, 1986
description: Hit and Run Case in Court

title: VOLUME REBOUNDS
description: A surprisingly strong increase in orders for durable goods in September gave Wall Street a lift yesterday, sending stock prices to their biggest gain in a week and helping trading volume get back to more normal levels.

title: Colts Sign Hicks
description: Dwight Hicks, a four-time Pro Bowl safety with the San Francisco 49ers, signed with the Indianapolis Colts yesterday after getting a tryout with the team Tuesday. Hicks was released by the 49ers last summer after revealing he had used cocaine over the last five years.

title: ART: LARRY RIVERS USING RELIEF IN HIS NEW WORK
description: MONTAGES of historical events can be found in murals in post offices and high schools throughout the country. Larry Rivers appropriates this popular form in ''Public and Private,'' the showpiece of his exhibition at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street. Always a history buff, Rivers here blends memories of his own life during the 1940's and 50's with figures from the headlines.

title: U.S. SAYS 2 LEADERS SPOKE OF GIVING UP ALL NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The White House said today that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev had talked in Iceland of ultimately forgoing all nuclear weapons, but without setting a time limit.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Larry Adler, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). The consummate lyricist of the mouth organ is back at the Ballroom with an evening of music and reminiscences. Mr. Adler's new show includes film clips from his movies ''Music for Millions,'' ''Three Daring Daughters'' and ''The Singing Marine,'' embellished with witty anecdotes of Hollywood in the 30's and 40's. Mr. Adler also offers music from his celebrated film score ''Genevieve.'' And with the pianist Ellis Larkins and the guitarist Celia Linde, he plays a program that runs from ''My Funny Valentine'' to Villa-Lobos's ''Bachianas Brasileiras.'' Nobody makes the harmonica croon more sweetly. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 9 P.M. There is a $15 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: Indicted Albany Aide Quits
description: Richard L. Rubin, who was indicted this week on charges that he defrauded the state to pay the salaries of two secretaries at his Queens law office, has resigned as special counsel to the Assembly Speaker. David Langdon, a spokesman for the Speaker, Stanley Fink, said yesterday that Mr. Rubin resigned his $44,553-a-year post Wednesday.

title: Recall of Toys Planned By Johnson & Johnson
description: The Johnson & Johnson Baby Products Company will recall three crib toys that could pose a threat to infants, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW LINE CINEMA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Clive Lythgoe, Pianist
description: The pianist Clive Lythgoe will play works by Edward MacDowell and Johannes Brahms at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Sunday afternoon at 3:30. Admission is free. Information: 662-2133.

title: CONCERT: TENNSTEDT AND MAHLER'S 6TH
description: IT is unlikely that his Sixth Symphony is the most beloved work of many devotees of Mahler. It is one long descent into the pit of despair, and despite the fact that the composer later removed the original subtitle, ''Tragic,'' that word accurately summons up the mood that must have been on him when he wrote this desperate bit of psychological autobiography. Most conductors avoid this symphony simply because it is difficult to please an audience with. So it is not often that we are asked to take this harrowing trip to the ragged edge of an artist's sanity.

title: Koch Pushing For Divestment
description: The city's largest public-employee pension fund would accelerate by more than two years its divestment of stock in companies that operate in South Africa, under a proposal made yesterday by Mayor Koch and City Council President Andrew J. Stein.

title: FRENCH EARLY-MUSIC GROUP TO BOW
description: The early-music movement has revolutionized our ideas of the performance of Baroque music, but its attentions have been oddly selective. For a long time, the Austrians and Germans and Dutch and English took the lead, with a natural emphasis on their native music - plus a requisite dollop of Italian music, so central to the entire Baroque era.

title: PRICES UP BY 0.3%, BRINGING INCREASE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Commerce Department today reported a modest rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in inflation for September. The latest figures, in turn, will mean a 1.3 percent increase in Social Security and related benefits for more than 37 million Americans.

title: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEITH HARING PAINTS MURAL ON BERLIN WALL
description: East German border guards peered over the top of the Berlin Wall to photograph the event. West German citizens, police officers and a crowd of reporters gathered on the other side. A United States Army helicopter hovered in the sky. Everyone had come to see Keith Haring paint.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; A SCENIC CALIFORNIA SETTING FOR THE BREEDERS' CUP
description: If nothing else, the third Breeders' Cup will be the prettiest.

title: PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Pioneer converted to a stock savings bank in early 1985, therefore per share earnings for the full year are not presented.

title: A Big Bang Heard Round the World
description: London's international financial community quivers with anticipation - and dread. On Monday, at a single stroke, most government controls on who can sell securities, and at what fees, will be swept away. That's fine news for investors and corporations, who are certain to pay less for financial services. And it's good news for the British economy, which is likely to benefit by breaking up the unproductive, unimaginative old-boy network of securities dealers and investment bankers.

description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's statements this week that officials need not defer to Supreme Court interpretations of the Constitution were denounced as an ''invitation to lawlessness'' today by the American Civil Liberties Union. description: John (Blue Moon) Odom, who pitched in three World Series with the Oakland A's in the 1970's, reported to the Orange County Jail in Santa Ana, Calif., to begin serving a 90-day sentence. He was convicted of selling cocaine to a co-worker 17 months ago. . . . John Drew, the former National Basketball Association player who has been jailed in Atlanta since Oct. 2 on charges of sale and possession of cocaine, has been denied release on bond. . . . Winston Bennett, the senior forward expected to replace Kenny Walker as the University of Kentucky's basketball standout this season, will require surgery on the right knee he injured in practice Wednesday. . . Gordie Howe, the National Hockey League Hall of Famer, has joined the International Hockey League as an ambassador-at-large who will help the league with clinics and promotional work.

title: HURST A HIT, GOODEN A FLOP, SOX AHEAD
description: Bruce Hurst is a left-hander with no particularly special pitching pedigree. Dwight Gooden is a fireballing right-hander who at the age of 21 has been reputed at times to be only a step or so away from the Hall of Fame. Hurst, however, outpitched Gooden tonight and that's why the World Series will return to New York with the Boston Red Sox one victory from extinguishing the Mets' blazing season.

description: Attorney General W. Cary Edwards recommended today that all law-enforcement officers in the state who carry firearms undergo drug-testing and that those who fail the tests be dismissed.

description: A Federal Judge last night rejected a motion by the Campeau Corporation seeking a temporary restraining order against the Allied Stores Corporation's shareholder rights plan. The decision by District Court Judge Pierre N. Leval of the Southern District of New York means the rights plan would be exercised when any individual or group acquires 50 percent or more.

title: MIDMONTH AUTO SALES ROSE 2.3%
description: Sales of new American-made autos in mid-October edged up 2.3 percent from the corresponding period last year, the nation's seven major manufacturers reported today. The increase was slightly above analysts' expectations for the post-incentive selling period.

title: New York City Sets Auction-Business Rules
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has proposed a set of new regulations of the auction business after more than two years of studying the auction-house trade. The proposed regulations, published in full in today's edition of the City Record, would require auction houses to change several of their practices.

Fahrenkopf Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that he planned to seek the support of the League of Women Voters and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in a new campaign against voter registration fraud before the 1988 Presidential election.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN TRIAL ON RELIGION AND TEXTBOOKS
description: A woman who proudly called herself ''a Christian grandmother'' stood on the courthouse steps here Wednesday morning clutching a copy of ''Contemporary Living.'' The home economics textbook is under legal attack as advancing what some Alabama Christians see as an enemy religion they call secular humanism.

title: Meese Shuns Nudity
description: When Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d made public his commission's report on pornography last July, the news conference was held in the Great Hall of the Department of Justice, and pictures of Mr. Meese in front of a nude statue of justice received almost as much attention as the recommendations in the report. So his news conference this week on putting the report into effect was moved across Pennsylvania Avenue to the auditorium of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which contains no comparable art works. When reporters asked the Attorney General about the change of scene, he replied, to laughter: ''There wasn't the opportunity to get that lovely statue moved in time.''

description: An Afghan warplane landed at a Pakistani air base this morning and the pilot requested political asylum, the Pakistani Government said this evening.

title: OTHER EXHIBITIONS OF DECORATIVE ARTS

This year more shows than ever have been organized by museums and galleries to satisfy this boom in interest in the decorative arts. These are some of the exhibitions open this weekend that may be of interest to collectors:

title: RICHARD BURTON STARS IN 'WAGNER' ON 13
description: EVEN the more ardent admirers of his musical genius will concede that Richard Wagner, the man, was obnoxious - fascinating, perhaps, but almost relentlessly obnoxious. He was egomaniacal, treacherous with the wives and fortunes of others, thoroughly convinced that, as a superman striving to unify Germany, the world owed more to him than to ordinary mortals. He is not, therefore, the easiest subject for a biography. When not being monumentally repulsive, his behavior tends to look merely ridiculous. Separating the silly man from the gifted artist requires delicacy of the highest order. ''Wagner,'' a four-part ''Great Performances'' series beginning tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, is about as delicate as a 300-pound Brunnhilde.

title: FAN IS MARRIED TO THE RED SOX
description: He's older than Fenway Park, older than the Red Sox franchise. He's seen Cy Young and Babe Ruth pitch. He's seen Tris Speaker play center field. He's seen Ted Williams and Yaz and Wade Boggs hit. And in 1918 he attended the fifth game of the last World Series the Red Sox won.

title: Crane Tips Over at a Casino
description: A crane hoisting concrete slabs at the construction site for a 10-story casino parking garage tipped over yesterday, knocked over the boom of another crane and dropped its load of concrete, the police said. No one was injured in the mishap at the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, but traffic was jammed in the area of Mississippi and Pacific Avenues throughout the day.

title: SOUND QUALITY EQUAL TO CD'S
description: While digital audio tape has not been officially shown in this country, this reporter attended a demonstration of a prototype at Sony's laboratories in Tokyo two years ago. Impressions gained on that occasion were vivid enough to be recalled even after so long a span. To sum it up, the sound emanating from a tiny cassette -notably smaller than those currently used in audio equipment -seemed as good as what can otherwise be heard only from laser-scanned compact disks.

title: HERPESLIKE VIRUS IS FOUND IN IMMUNE DEFENSE SYSTEM
description: Scientists at the National Cancer Institute have discovered a previously unknown herpeslike virus in patients who had cancers and other abnormalities in cells of their immune defense systems.

title: Father Is Held in Drug Case
description: A suspect in a narcotics case who briefly left his 3-year-old daughter with a drug dealer as collateral until he returned with $40 to buy a quarter ounce of marijuana will face charges for using the girl, in addition to the narcotics charges, the police said today. The suspect, Floyd W. Cook, told undercover agents after he was arrested Wednesday night that the swap was simply a business decision. Mr. Cook, 35 years old, had been granted a $2,500 bond on the marijuana charge but that will be superseded with new charges, the police said.

title: A FANTASY-FILLED FAIR OF AMERICANA AT THE PIER
description: FANTASY - laced with wit and romance - dominates this year's Fall Antiques Show, where a 20th-century sphinx kicks up her heels, an alligator crowns a motorized whirligig, and Pancho Villa, the Mexican bandit, surfaces in the form of a scarecrow.

title: Slum in Mississippi Makes Way for Housing

description: Justice Francis X. Smith, the administrative judge of the State Supreme Court in Queens, has been indicted by a grand jury investigating the awarding of cable television franchises and will be arraigned today, his lawyers said yesterday.

title: GAUGING THE REAL IMPACT OF LEAVING SOUTH AFRICA
description: The announcements this week that General Motors and International Business Machines will be pulling out of South Africa have had an unquestioned symbolic importance, since both corporations have been publicly committed to using their business presence in South Africa as a force against apartheid.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Afro-Cuban Meets Afro-Brazilian Jazz, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (307-7420). ''Meeting'' is the operative concept here, but not the meeting that the billing implies. Given the hypothesis that meetings of musical and cultural strains, or ''crossovers,'' are the most significant process taking place in modern music, Mario Bauza is a towering figure. He introduced modern jazz musicians to Afro-Cuban rhythm and form, and, as director of Machito's Afro-Cubans, he introduced the best Cuban-rooted dance-band musicians to the fine points of modern jazz. If he can work a remotely comparable alchemy with some of the leading Afro-Cuban musicians of the post-Mariel generation, this concert will be a landmark. Tania Maria and her group are opening the show and along for the ride. The concert takes place tomorrow night at 8 at Town Hall. Tickets are $18 and $15 in advance, $20 and $17 the day of the concert, and are available at the Town Hall box office or at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street.

title: ART: BURKE TREASURES FROM JAPAN ON DISPLAY
description: HOW can we be surrounded every day by household objects that touch an absolute perfection? The best idea I have had so far is to apply for some lifetime loans from the Mary and Jackson Burke Collection. It is well known among those who care for Japanese art that in a remarkably short time - beginning in the year 1956 - Mr. and Mrs. Burke put together a collection of Japanese art that stands very high indeed in its class. It is big on painting, big on sculpture, big on calligraphy and big on both ceramics and lacquer objects. As for the tea ceremony, which bulks so large in the esthetic of Japanese life, it can only be said that caddy, bowl, pitcher and dish reach apotheosis in the Burke Collection.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Redefining Poverty
description: Who's poor? By the last official count, in 1985, there were 33.1 million poor people in America - depending on what is meant by poor. Now, the Census Bureau says that if you count non-cash benefits like food stamps, housing subsidies and medical assistance, the number may be more like 20 million. But wait. By another Census measure, even when those same non-cash benefits are included, there are still 30.4 million poor people.
