title: French overseer at a new kitchen.
description: JUST when I was becoming cynical about all these famous jet-set chefs who lend their names to restaurants and swoop into town periodically to help out the presumably inadequate kitchen staff, along comes Louis Outhier. Swissotel, owners of the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue at 56th Street, hired Mr. Outhier, creator of the acclaimed l'Oasis on the French Riviera, to oversee the kitchen of its graceful new $1.5 million restaurant, Lafayette. And what a job he has done.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Peru Rebels Seize Candy
description: Left-wing guerrillas seized a confectionary truck at gunpoint today and distributed candy to children in a poor neighborhood of the Peruvian capital, the police said.

title: Two Sentenced In Shooting
description: Two teen-age boys found guilty of involvement in the shooting of a 29-year-old police officer in Central Park last July were sentenced yesterday to 18 months in a limited security youth center.

title: Now if Only Columbus Had a Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: MAX ERNST GRAPHICS AT THE PUBLIC LIBRARY
description: ''MAX ERNST: Beyond Surrealism'' is the first major retrospective of the artist's graphic work to be held in this country. It has arrived at the New York Public Library, on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, with the minimum of fuss -and just as well, for this is not art that lends itself to saturation publicity. Ernst the printmaker is a more profound, more inventive and much more subtle personality than Ernst the painter and sculptor. Paper is his element and the book-sized format his scale, so the show is at the right place - and at the right time too, for Surrealism has turned out to be one of the most influential movements of the century.

title: LODGE & SHIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lawyer Reports Finding 'Twilight Zone' Memo
description: The prosecutor in the trial involving ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' said today that a crucial memorandum written by a firefighter, thought to be missing last week, had been found.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1986
description: The Economy

title: I.R.S. BEGINS NEW TAX GUIDELINES
description: In its first official step in enforcing the new tax law, the Internal Revenue Service issued guidelines today on how taxpayers can pay up interest penalties before year-end on taxes owed under the old law.

title: TV Dinner
description: Gary Thorne, a radio broadcaster for the Mets, on the array of television trailers in the streets adjoining Fenway Park: ''There are more dishes out there than mother's got in the cabinet.''

title: Net Up 11.1% at McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation today reported record net income of $142.3 million in the third quarter, up 11.1 percent from $128.1 in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: PALESTINIANS RAID SHIITE AMAL CAMP
description: Palestinian guerrillas in rubber dinghies attacked a Shiite militia camp in southern Lebanon today, killing five people and wounding four others.

description: Recognizing that aerospace may play a less pivotal role in the company's future, Morton Thiokol Inc. announced that S. Jay Stewart, its group vice president for chemicals, would become president and chief operating officer.

title: G.O.P. FUNDS LEAD DEMOCRATS' 5 TO 1
description: The three national Republican committees, continuing their lopsided dominance in fund raising, have collected more than five times as much as their Democratic counterparts in the 1985-86 election season.

title: REAGAN CAMPAIGNS IN WISCONSIN RACE
description: The nip-and-tuck struggle for control of the United States Senate focused on Wisconsin today. President Reagan praised the incumbent Republican, Bob Kasten, and warned members of a partisan suburban Milwaukee audience that their votes could determine who controlled the Senate for his last two years in office.

title: Bridge: Dutch Women May Have Chance for the World Title
description: Recent bridge history suggests that the next world women's team championship, in Jamaica in a year's time, will see Britain and the United States battling for the title. But it will not greatly surprise the cognoscenti if both are upset by the Netherlands.

title: MUELLER, PAUL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FOLK SINGING WITH A TOUCH OF COMEDY
description: ONE afternoon last summer, the New York folk singer Christine Lavin was invited to play softball in Riverside Park. Ms. Lavin, who is short and not very athletic but is still what she calls ''a team player,'' agreed. But when it came time to choose, she experienced the acute discomfort of being selected last out of a field of 20. And once chosen, she was delegated to patrol deep right field. When it came her turn at bat, she succeeded in hitting the ball - a dribbling little grounder to the pitcher, who tossed it to first base. With magnanimous condescension, the opposition volunteered not to count her outs because she didn't know how to play.

title: BEST-DRESSED, PAST AND PRESENT
description: Some people scoff at the very idea of a Best-Dressed List, yet the idea has endured for more than 50 years. It started with Paris couturiers who used it as a way to flatter their favorite clients. When World War II closed off Europe, Eleanor Lambert, a fashion publicist, initiated an annual Best-Dressed List in this country as a way of promoting American fashion. As years went by, the list became international in scope, just as fashion did.

title: VOLUNTEERS AROUND U.S. SUBMITTED TO RADIATION
description: Hundreds of human volunteers around the nation were exposed to radiation to determine its effect on fertility and other biological functions, and how the human body absorbed and retained radioactive contaminants, according to documents released earlier this year by the Department of Energy.

description: In 1904 the Gramophone and Typewriter Company was telling people that equipment for the reproduction of sound had reached the ultimate state of perfection. It wasn't true then and it isn't true yet.

The State Public Service Commission gave permission Wednesday for Consumers to resume spending on the plant as long as the money does not come from ratepayers.

title: The Wharton Legacy at SUNY
description: ''There is a state university campus within 50 miles of every New York State resident and I don't know of a subject that you can't study at some SUNY institution,'' observes Dr. Clifton Wharton, who will step down in January as chancellor of the State University of New York. He has earned the right to speak proudly of SUNY's strengths for he has dealt honestly with its weaknesses. He will leave a legacy of sound management and a blueprint for improvement.

title: C. C. Ryan Is Wed To R. D. Shay Jr.
description: At St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Long Branch, N.J., yesterday Corita Curry Ryan and Rodger D. Shay Jr. were married by the Rev. Regis Ryan, the bride's uncle. Mrs. Shay, who is known as C. C., is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter M. Ryan Jr. of West Long Branch, N.J. The bride, who is on leave, will resume her position as a registered nurse at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in pediatric oncology on Nov. 8. She graduated from Skidmore College.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. These marchers have been on the road since March. Who are they and what have they done? 2. An African leader died suddenly last week. Who was he, and what were the circumstances? 3. The new immigration law is expected to create a huge new market to help those living illegally in the United States take advantage of the measure. What is involved? 4. In Washington, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is known as the ''vacuum cleaner,'' according to an aide. Why? 5. The final players' pool for the World Series totals $8,646,928.30. How much is each winning and losing player expected to get? 6. Three major American companies announced that they would sell their South African operations, and one other is expected to follow suit. What are the companies? 7. With the discovery of the largest black willow in the country, New York now boasts 13 of the nation's champion trees. Which state has the most? 8. The United States ordered the expulsion of the largest number of Soviet diplomats ever ousted at one time. How many are involved? 9. A study has found that New York City's drinking water is becoming slightly but steadily saltier. What is the apparent cause of the salinity? 10.''Now I know how a boxer feels when he is knocked out,'' said the soprano Eva Marton after her performance as Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: No Way To Teach
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett's call for an overhaul of the elementary curriculum is long overdue - particularly so when he criticizes the teaching of writing as being too frequently confused with ''filling in little blanks.'' Those little blanks are the perfect symbol of what is wrong not only with elementary education but with much education at all levels in America. And it all goes back to Sputnik.

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
description: b-After gains of $210,000 for the quarter and $248,000 for the 9 months related to prepayment of long term debt. c-Net income

title: SMOKELESS TOBACCO WARNINGS
description: The Federal Trade Commission today issued regulations requiring specific health warnings on packages of snuff and chewing tobacco starting early next year.

title: Dollar, Renewing Rally, Is at July Level vs. Yen
description: The dollar rose strongly again yesterday, sustaining a rally and taking the currency to its best level since July against the yen.

title: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $41.4 million gain from the sale of a stake in Fording Coal Ltd. c-After a $9.4 million gain.

title: Joy Blackett, Mezzo
description: The mezzo-soprano Joy Blackett will sing the world premiere of Lee Hoiby's ''Bermudas: A Song of Praise,'' as well as works by Ariosti, Brahms and Ravel, tomorrow night at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $10 and $12. Information: 362-1911.

title: Official Abandons Plan To Indict Governor
description: A prosecutor said today that he would not pursue indictments against Gov. Edwin W. Edwards in connection with an reported bribery scheme.

description: The U.S. dollar amounts have been translated at the rate of U.S. $1 equals 153 yen. Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represents 10 shares of common stock.

title: Long-Distance Rate Drop Seen
description: Mark. S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, predicted today that most long-distance telephone rates would fall by about 5 percent, or $900 million, in January, reflecting reduced costs for the use of local exchange-carrier equipment for call completion.

title: UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McCarran-Walter Strikes Again
description: Margaret Randall, who teaches women's studies and American studies at the University of New Mexico, has been ordered to be deported under the McCarran-Walter Act. The decision was based solely on the ''ideology'' of her writings, which were scrutinized by a lone immigration judge. The Center for Constitutional Rights, in New York City, has appealed the order, thus staying execution until the appeal is decided. Ms. Randall, who is considered a visitor who has overstayed her welcome, should be permitted to remain in this country.

title: Greg Ginn and Gone
description: Gone, the trio led by the guitarist Greg Ginn, will perform tonight and tomorrow night at Tin Pan Alley, 220 West 49th Street (582-9376), on a bill with the duo of Zeena Parkins and Chris Cochane. The music begins at 10 P.M. tonight and at 9 P.M. tomorrow; admission is free.

title: Kaiser to Sell A Unit to Kemper
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed to sell a subsidiary that owns a big portion of its real estate holdings to Kemper/Bedford Properties Inc., a venture of the Kemper Corporation and Bedford Properties Inc. The company said that Kemper/Bedford would pay about $130 million in cash and that more than $325 million in liabilities of its Kaiser Development Company unit would be terminated as part of the sale.

title: Still Quiet on the Western Front
description: Is it time to forget about West Germany again? Chancellor Helmut Kohl has finished his Washington visit. He's a shoo-in for re-election in January. His economy is looking healthy. And the ruckus over whether all the Euromissiles might really be removed will pass. Except for the occasional storm over the likes of Bitburg or missile deployments, West Germany hasn't held America's attention since the Berlin crisis. It's something Germans in the United States lament: how might it be changed?

title: Dr. Ivor D. Fenton, 97, Dies; Was Congressman 24 Years
description: Dr. Ivor D. Fenton, a physician who represented Pennsylvania's hard-coal country in Congress for 24 years, has died. He was 97 years old.

title: REAGAN MILITARY STAND UNITING CONSERVATIVES
description: President Reagan's handling of the arms talks in Iceland and his strong support for a defense against missiles have cooled a feud among conservatives over the direction of their movement and the strategy that Republicans are pursuing in this year's elections.

title: SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
At Harcourt Brace, An About-Face
description: For 67-year-old Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., its planned $500 million purchase of CBS Inc.'s educational and professional publishing business marks an about-face return to its traditional business: book publishing.

title: Car Loans: Read the Fine Print
description: LAST year, John Fitzgerald, a New York City police officer, decided that his wife, Eileen, needed a new car. In July, he drove her to the B. F. Curry Chevrolet dealership in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., picked out a used 1983 Mercury Marquis, and said, ''Honey, this car's for you.''

title: CONSENT GIVEN FOR CONVERTING OLD FERRYBOAT INTO NEW JAIL
description: The New York State Commission of Correction yesterday approved a New York City plan to convert a retired Staten Island ferryboat into a floating jail for 162 inmates to help ease overcrowding at the city's prison complex on Rikers Island.

title: JUDGE BARS CAMPEAU'S ALLIED STEP
description: The Campeau Corporation, which has been locked in a bitter battle to take over the Allied Stores Corporation, tried to overcome one hurdle yesterday by buying a majority of Allied's stock on the open market. But late in the day, a Federal judge delayed completion of the transaction for a week to consider Allied's accusation that the purchase constituted an illegal tender offer.

title: Salvador Rebels Kill 6 In First Raid Since Truce
description: Guerrillas killed five militiamen and a civilian in their first attack since they called off a truce this week, military officials said today.

title: Student Boycott at Wellesley
description: Students at Wellesley College boycotted classes today to support 49 classmates who were arrested while protesting the trustees' decision to retain stock in companies doing business in South Africa. Organizers said about 1,100 of the college's 2,230 students stayed away from classes.

description: A preparation patented this week for the University of Texas system in Austin is regarded as primarily useful in the diagnosis of cervical cancer, and may result in the development of an effective vaccine. The invention was made under a grant from the National Institutes of Health.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch last Saturday from Managua, Nicaragua, about documents found in a downed rebel supply plane, referred incorrectly to the location of Langley Air Force Base. It is near Norfolk, Va., not Richmond. Neither city is close to Langley, Va., site of the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters.

description: The first time Patrick Reynolds remembers seeing his father, R. J. Reynolds Jr. was lying down with sandbags on his chest to exercise his diaphragm. ''He could hardly breathe,'' recalls Patrick, who was then 9 years old. ''My memories of my father are all of a man always short of breath, and counting the time he had left to live.''

description: Following are segments from stories and articles in two textbooks published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston that were cited by plaintiffs in a lawsuit on which a Federal judge ruled yesterday in Greeneville, Tenn. description: Neither Tom Watson nor Lee Trevino, who have won 14 Grand Slam events between them, will win this weekend's $1 million Vantage Championship at San Antonio. For the first time in his 16-year pro career, Watson was disqualified from a Tour event.

Eugenio Gudin Dies in Brazil; Ex-Finance Minister Was 100
description: Eugenio Gudin, a prominent economist and former Finance Minister, died today of pneumonia, hospital sources said. He was 100 years old.

title: Leonard Satisfied
description: Although Sugar Ray Leonard has signed a proposed agreement for a fight against Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the world middleweight champion, Leonard's attorney insists the fight has not yet been officially scheduled. ''To say we have a contract for the fight is inaccurate,'' the attorney, Mike Trainer, told The Associated Press yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch yesterday from Peshawar, Pakistan, about the defection of an Afghan pilot, described the landing site incorrectly in some editions. The pilot landed his MIG-21 at a military airstrip in Kohat, Pakistan, after taking off from an Afghan air base in Bagram.

description: Dr. Edward Adelbert Doisy Sr., the 1943 Nobel Prize winner in physiology and medicine who isolated vitamin K and two female hormones, died Thursday. He was 92 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1986
description: The World Britain severed ties with Syria after a Jordanian was convicted of attempting to place a bomb on an Israeli jet last April. London charged that Syrian diplomats and agents were involved. #1 Syria ended relations with Britain and closed its ports to British aircraft and ships. The announcement, which came after London's action, gave British diplomats one week to leave the country. #4 A Jordanian journalist was convicted and sentenced to 45 years in prison for trying to blow up the Israeli airliner. A jury found that Nezar Hindawi, 32, had hidden a bomb in his lover's luggage. #4 The U.S. will also withdraw its Ambassador to Syria, William L. Eagleton Jr., as a show of support for Britain's decision to break relations with Damascus, the White House announced. #4 Syria called effective with terror 1 Tales of corruption in Mexico are legion among Mexican citizens, virtually all of whom say they have paid bribes for such things as avoiding a traffic ticket or speeding service in a government matter.#3 A Nicaraguan rebel group diverted $15,000 in U.S. funds to buy ammunition earlier this year, Congressional and Administration officials said. The money was intended for nonlethal aid. #3 Western newspapers are critical of the back-and-forth expulsions of diplomats by the U.S. and the Kremlin. Many commentators have voiced concern that the withdrawals may derail disarmament efforts, but European leaders remain silent. 5 News analysis: Summit issues 1 U.S. takes steps at embassy 1 Focus of disinformation inquiry 3 The Nation The largest paid acreage reduction program in history was announced.

Vallone, the Council majority leader. The purpose of the commission, they said, would be to ''halt raids on the city's professional sports teams'' and to ''provide a positive and profitable base for professional teams wishing to relocate here.''

title: The Soviet and U.S. Missions
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have been engaged in a round of reciprocal diplomatic expulsions recently. Here are partial listings of embassy and consulate workers before the latest expulsions. The numbers of American workers in the Soviet Union are based on an unofficial diplomatic directory in Moscow, and the numbers of Soviet workers in the United States are based on reports from State Department sources, who say it is difficult to get a firm count of the Soviet diplomats in the United States because those numbers constantly fluctuate. The numbers for Soviet diplomatic workers in the United States date to August, and do not include the 55 expelled from the United States on Tuesday. The numbers of American diplomatic workers in the Soviet Union date to late last week, and do not include the 10 expelled on Sunday and Wednesday. It is not known from what category, diplomatic or staff, the Soviet reductions must come.

Lanier was in his rookie season as a manager when he took the Astros to the Western Division championship this year. . . . Bill Russell, who in 18 seasons with the Los Angeles Dodgers played in four World Series and three All-Star Games, will retire as an active player and become the team's infield coach.

description: New York City's police chief, confident that tomorrow will bring a seventh World Series game and a Mets victory, said yesterday that 700 officers, 80 of them ringing the field on horseback at the final out, would be assigned to protect the players, fans and Shea Stadium.

GUGGENHEIM WOULD ALTER NEW DESIGN
description: The Guggenheim Museum has proposed that it change the design of its expansion plan to reduce the addition's visual impact on the museum's distinctive spiral rotunda.

title: Long Island Is Where It's At
description: Long Island is the paradigm of the American Dream. Yet somehow the people of Long Island lack pride in their place, the largest, most populous piece of island real estate in the continental United States.

title: FILM: 'TRICK OR TREAT' ABOUT MUSICIAN'S GHOST
description: Haunted houses, demonic pumpkins, spirits from the great beyond -so what else is new this Halloween? Haunted rock stars, that's what. ''Trick or Treat,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO Warner Twin and other theaters, is about a deceased heavy-metal star who returns to wreak havoc at a small-town high school. The rock star is played most energetically by Tony Fields, who stomps through the film in studs and low-cut black leather, scaring everyone he sees. Ozzy Osbourne, who does this kind of thing in real life, appears in the film briefly (and none too convincingly) as a minister.

title: Reuters Holdings Makes Instinet Bid
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the large British financial news and information service company, said yesterday that it had offered $92 million, or $7.25 a share, to acquire the Instinet Corporation, a small New York-based company that provides professional investors with a computer-based market access network.

title: PERELMAN HAS 15% TRANSWORLD STAKE
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the New York investor who took control of Revlon Inc. last year, has been secretly amassing Transworld Corporation stock in recent weeks and now owns about 15 percent of its outstanding shares, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: Ms. Greenbaum Bride Of Mark A. Armstrong
description: Judith Ellen Greenbaum and Mark Avery Armstrong were married yesterday at the Quinnipiack Club in New Haven by Justice of the Peace Frederick Moss, assisted by Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg.

title: No Headline
description: A report yesterday in Column One, The Press, said the November issue of Vanity Fair ''is a family affair,'' and ''the family belongs to Morton L. and Linda LeRoy Janklow.''

description: Tisch Reshaping CBS

description: Four Russian emigres announced today that they were returning home because their hopes for a better life were not fulfilled in America.

description: Federal prosecutors are investigating the role of the city's former transportation commissioner, Anthony R. Ameruso, in the selection of a company to repair city parking meters, according to officials close to the investigation.

description: After more than 40 years, Tiffany & Company has returned to London's Old Bond Street. A champagne breakfast celebrated the occasion last week.

description: The back-and-forth expulsions of diplomats by the United States and the Soviet Union have evoked considerable hostile commentary in the Western European press.

However, the company said it expects its tax rate to decline significantly in 1987 as a result of changes in the tax code.

description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday named an experienced police commander - who is also a lawyer - to be the special prosecutor in the department's trials of officers accused of corruption in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn.

description: The Strategic Air Command has ordered its bomber crews to prepare for making attacks with conventional explosives as well as with nuclear bombs, according to Gen. John T. Chain Jr., SAC's new commander.

description: TAX-EXEMPT zero-coupon bonds, a backwater of the municipal bond market for many years, suddenly became a hot product this week after President Reagan signed the sweeping tax revision bill.

description: In an undertaking described as a ''significant symbolic statement'' of its ''vitality and renewal,'' Barnard College next spring will begin construction of an 18-story dormitory tower that will transform its campus and the Morningside Heights skyline, college officials said yesterday.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times; Daughters and Lovers
description: THE MOTHER'S RECOMPENSE. By Edith Wharton. Introduction by Louis Auchincloss. 272 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. Cloth, $15.95; paper, $8.95. ''The Mother's Recompense,'' first published in 1925 and out of print for more than 30 years, recapitulates many of the themes mapped out in Edith Wharton's better-known works: the tension between domestic entrapment and rootless freedom; the dues exacted by family and society, and the costs of illicit passion in the highly stratified, manner-conscious world of the American upper class. Though one might dispute Louis Auchincloss's contention that the novel ''is really the last of her major fictions'' - it marks a precipitous falling off from ''The Age of Innocence,'' published five years earlier - it does stand as a sort of transitional piece between her masterly early work and the trite, blowsy effusions that were to follow.

title: Bridge; Countries Differ in Picking Teams for World Title Play
description: Whether selection of teams for international play should be objective or subjective has long been debated. For nearly 20 years North America has favored totally objective methods: national championships leading to playoffs.

title: FILTERTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago third quarter.

title: Red Sox Confront Skeptics
description: By winning Game Six of the World Series tonight, the Boston Red Sox could do unto the Mets what the Mets' 1969 team did to the Baltimore Orioles - snatch the World Series from the team that was heavily favored to win. But will the Red Sox instead do unto themselves what they are infamous for - self-destruct in sight of their ultimate goal.

title: TEXACO NAMES TWO TO ITS TOP POSTS
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, said yesterday that James W. Kinnear would succeed John K. McKinley as chief executive at the end of the year.

DANCE: TAYLOR VIA JOFFREY
description: Nobody can possibly forget how good a choreographer Paul Taylor is. But a reminder can occur in different ways - namely, the Joffrey Ballet's own production of Mr. Taylor's ''Cloven Kingdom.''

title: Kennedy Joins Green at Rally
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy told an audience of senior citizens yesterday that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was ''assaulting and attacking basic Social Security programs,'' and urged them to elect Mark Green to the seat once held by Mr. Kennedy's brother Robert F. Kennedy.

title: QUEENS JUDGE INDICTED, DENIES CABLE CHARGES
description: Justice Francis X. Smith, the Administrative Judge of State Supreme Court in Queens, was charged by a Queens grand jury in an indictment unsealed yesterday with perjury and criminal contempt during an investigation of a cable television company's efforts to obtain a franchise.

title: Pitching Matchup Is Fitting
description: Ojeda or Clemens?

title: MUSICIANS END ON STRIKE
description: The White Plains Symphony has agreed to a new three-year contract with its players, breaking ranks with a consortium of orchestras being struck by freelance musicians. It remained unclear what effect this settlement would have on the strike against the 11 other orchestras.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We regret that these actions have been forced on us by the unacceptable behavior of the Syrian authorities.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 17 about an architectural competition to expand the Brooklyn Museum misstated the working relationship between the winners - the Japanese architect Arata Isozaki and the New York architectural firm of James Stewart Polshek & Partners. Mr. Isozaki is not a member of Mr. Polshek's firm.

title: Accused of Bias, PBS Plans a Policy Review
description: The Public Broadcasting Service, criticized by conservative groups and members of Congress as broadcasting politically biased programs, has announced it will review its programming policies and practices.

title: Report Details 30 Years Of U.S. Radiation Tests
description: A House subcommittee made public today a report showing that Federal agencies conducted radiation exposure experiments on people for 30 years.

title: Nippon Telegraph Bids
description: After weeks of suspense, the results of the first round of bidding on Japan's most-wanted stock were announced today. The winners got the right to purchase, at prices ranging from $7,000 to $15,000, shares of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's former telecommunications monopoly.

title: Polyglot Protest Planned Today
description: Not for at least 18 months has Washington experienced a truly large demonstration.

title: DESIGNER PACKAGES THAT SELL
description: Decades of advertising taught America to spell cheese K-R-A-F-T. But consumers walking into supermarkets in recent years have had difficulty spotting the famous brand name amid a wall of lookalike competitors.

title: Dr. Koop's Decent AIDS Dissent
description: Even after 26,566 reported cases and 14,977 deaths, Americans tend to whisper when they talk about AIDS. Welcome, therefore, the loud voice of Surgeon General C. Everett Koop. His is a message Americans need to hear, and it rings with added credibility from someone of such rigorous stature in this Administration. No one needs to hear it more than this Administration's Justice Department.

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Inludes a gain of $14,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month results include a pre-tax gain of $1,689,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Delta Sets Tokyo Flights
description: Delta Air Lines said today that it will begin nonstop flights between Portland, Ore., and Tokyo on March 2, 1987, and one-stop flights between Atlanta and Tokyo on March 4. The carrier was awarded the Pacific routes by the Department of Transportation last month. Delta said it would initially operate five round-trip flights every week.

description: A grand jury investigating a fire that destroyed a 20-acre industrial complex in Passaic criticized the companies today for inadequately securing dangerous materials and found poor communication among the firefighters at the scene of the 1985 Labor Day fire.

title: Price of Bellwether Bond Falls
description: A late burst of selling sent the price of the bellwether long Treasury bond tumbling a half-point yesterday, while all other Government coupon issues closed the day with small losses. Meanwhile, discount rates on Treasury bills were narrowly mixed.

title: The Time to Bring Down Consumer Interest Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan, Up Close
description: The other day President Reagan demonstrated again how he can shift quickly from a large ceremony to a smaller, more personal setting and enjoy success at both.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $617,000 and $2,930,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $962,000 for the quarter and $2,646,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter and 9 months figures include results of Stoppenbach Inc., which was acquired Dec. 1, 1985.

title: Henry Berg, 47, Ex-Official Of the Guggenheim Museum
description: Henry Berg, a museum administrator who was deputy director of the Guggenheim Museum and held posts at art museums at Harvard and Yale, died on Oct. 12 in Lucca, Italy, from a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 47 years old and lived in Lucca.

title: 7 JETS AND 28 BILLS FINED A TOTAL OF $16,000 FOR FIGHTING IN GAME
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle handed down one of his most sweeping penalties for on-the-field fighting today when he fined 35 players - 7 Jets and 28 Buffalo Bills - a total of $16,000 for their skirmish on Oct. 5 at Giants Stadium.

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,274,000 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $4,523,000.

title: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on early extinguishment of debt of $10,021,000, or $5.06 a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: RECITAL: BYLSMA, CELLO
description: The cellist Anner Bylsma and the fortepianist Malcolm Bilson presented one of the season's most continuously engaging programs Monday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, as part of the Hebrew Arts School's ''On Original Instruments'' series.

title: Tax Bill Is Signed, And Its Revision Gets Under Way
description: The Tax Reform Act of 1986, declared President Reagan as he signed the most sweeping overhaul of the Federal income tax in 40 years, is ''less a reform than a revolution.'' The celebratory signing ceremony, before an audience of more than 1,000 on the White House South Lawn, marked less an end than a beginning.

title: Detroit Sets Curfew To Prevent Arson
description: A 6 o'clock curfew will be in effect for children under 18 years old for three nights next week in an effort to eliminate a seasonal surge in arson.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: VIEW OF THE ARTIST At the age of 74, Hananiah Harari is still going strong as an artist, working in his Croton studio, and as a teacher at the Art Students League and the School of Visual Arts in New York. A retrospective of the many styles he has adapted, adopted, created and re-created in his long career may be seen until Nov. 8 at Nardin Fine Arts, Yellow Monkey Village in Cross River.

title: NOVELIST BECOMES SCRIPT WRITER IN ONE HECTIC LESSON
description: Barbara Taylor Bradford is a small woman with a young girl's, almost a little girl's, voice. This is deceptive. She has the powerhouse energy of her famous fictional creation, Emma Harte, the Woman of Substance herself.

title: Drug Suspension
description: The Athletics Congress has suspended Rick Meyer, a 25-year-old discus thrower who failed a drug test after placing first during the United States Olympic Festival in Houston last August.

title: A Chutist Drops In On Game
description: He landed on the grass between first base and the pitcher's mound without a ticket, an airborne party-crasher at the World Series. The skydiver who chose Shea Stadium as a landing strip in the first inning last night had read that the Mets were disappointed in the fan support they were receiving, and he decided to do his part for the team.

title: Two Share Lead In Vantage Golf
description: Payne Stewart shot a five-under-par 65 today that left him tied for the lead with Ben Crenshaw at eight-under 132 midway through the Vantage Championship.

title: Even Mets Are Amazed
description: Keith Hernandez had just made what seemed so certain to be the next-to-last out of the game, the World Series and the Met season. The Mets were trailing the Red Sox by two runs in the bottom of the 10th inning, and after Hernandez flied out to center field with no one on base, he took a long, slow walk to the dugout and kept going.

title: Sampling Trains
description: To the Editor: Hugh O'Haire's article ''Sampling Trains Around Europe'' (Travel, Sept. 28) was most interesting.

title: Benazir Bhutto's Return
description: In his article on Benazir Bhutto, Steven Weisman quoted what appeared to be an English version of a prayer issued by the leadership of the Pakistan Army.

title: Letters From Asselstine
description: The most conspicuous dissenter on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is a little less audible in Congress these days. Commissioner James K. Asselstine, a Republican appointed by President Reagan in 1982, has lost the right he enjoyed in the past to include his separate views in letters the agency sent to members of Congress when he disagreed with those letters' presentation of commission policy.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: I TOOK the old way - east on Route 94 - the only way I knew before I learned the short cuts.

title: Rewound Mets Back in the Chase
description: Charlie Samuels, the Mets' clubhouse man, walked through the hectic room early this morning, yelling to the players, ''Fellas, don't forget to turn your clock back.''

title: Suzanne Gavin Is Wed To John F. Mahoney
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan yesterday, Suzanne Gavin, the daughter of Donald F. Gavin of White Plains and the late Rosemary Benton Gavin, was married to John F. Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Mahoney of Milwaukee. The Rev. Thomas Joyce performed the ceremony.

title: Gauguin and Boudin Works Stolen From Australia Estate
description: Thieves stole four paintings today, including three by Paul Gauguin, worth more than $1.2 million, the police said.

title: KATHLEEN RIORDAN TO WED KENETH M. EPSTEIN NOV. 8
description: Kathleen Riordan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Riordan of New York, Quogue, L.I. and Miami Beach, and Keneth M. Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Epstein of Fair Lawn, N.J. plan to be married Nov. 8.

title: IS AQUINO FALLING BEHIND IN POLITICAL POSTURING?
description: ''JOHNNY, won't you come join us?'' President Corazon C. Aquino asked her truculent Defense Minister as she posed with newly promoted generals at a ceremony in her office last week. ''No, Ma'am, only you, only you,'' Juan Ponce Enrile replied, raising his hands and bowing slightly.

title: JERSEY TO VOTE ON $200 MILLION FOR TOXIC CLEANUP
description: Voters in New Jersey, the state with the most hazardous-waste sites on the Federal priority list, are being asked to approve a $200 million bond issue on Nov. 4 that would allow the state to begin a $1.6 billion cleanup program.

title: Imperial C.E.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE PANEL FINDS HUNGER WIDESPREAD
description: THE New Jersey Commission on Hunger, created by legislation two and a half years ago, has completed its study of how well or poorly people are eating and has found that the state's apparent affluence masks a serious problem.

title: A Ticket to Jail
description: It seems that Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the exiled former leader of the Central African Republic, could have saved everybody concerned some trouble last week by telephoning ahead. Instead, Mr. Bokassa slipped out of France and returned to the country from which he had been ousted as ruler in 1979, apparently with visions of lending a hand in its leadership.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COLLECTIBLES
description: ''COLLECTING is like eating peanuts -you have one and can't stop,'' says Malcolm S. Forbes, the 67-year-old chairman of Forbes Magazine Inc. He should know. Since he purchased his first set of miniature World War I doughboys at auction more than 20 years ago, he has acquired 12,000 toy soldiers, 1,200 miniature motorcycles, 40 shipbuilders' models, and 500 toy boats, including a 1905 battleship for which he paid $21,000. And then there is always the key to the White House from the Lincoln era, and, of course, his famous collection of Faberge eggs.

title: Disinformation Prep School
description: THE WHITE HOUSE Family Theater is the room in which the Usual Suspects - a motley assortment of pundits, itinerant authors and editorialists - are assembled on the eve of major occasions to hear The Word from The Man.

title: Mary Michelle Fahey Weds William Ganon
description: Mary Michelle Fahey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fahey of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Eliot Ganon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ganon of Pompton Plains, N.J. The Rev. Richard Clifford, a Roman Catholic priest and cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection assisted by the Rev. Dr. Paul Freed, a Presbyterian minister.

title: CRIME
description: Margaret Millar, the widow of Ross Macdonald, has herself been a prolific writer of mystery stories, and recently she won the Grand Master Award from the Mystery Writers of America. Her latest product is SPIDER WEBS (Morrow, $16.95).

title: Hiking in a Volcano, on Camelback in Kenya
description: Backpacking In Hawaii

title: Back to Basics
description: PEANUT farming didn't prove profitable for Gaylord Perry, the two-league Cy Young Award winner, who filed for bankruptcy in August after his North Carolina farm ran up debts of more than $1 million. So now the 48-year-old Perry, who retired from the majors in 1983 after winning 310 games with seven teams over 22 years, has put farming behind him and set his sights on a new career: baseball.

title: THE AMERICAN WIFE
description: IN A LARGE, EXPEN-sive house in one of those sprawled-out suburbs of Los Angeles, the family of Oma Minyard had gathered to commemorate the birth of her first grandchild and the possible death of her marriage. As they talked, their tears got all mixed up. The house was darkened against the summer heat. The television was on in the den. Oma's mother and her second husband and Oma's son and his pretty young wife, the baby's mother, were handing the baby around and picking at last night's leftover fried chicken.

title: A Fonda Connection
description: Red meat, it turns out, can be a tender political issue in some parts of the country, particularly true in South Dakota, a major beef-producing state. Senator James Abdnor, a Republican, has produced television commercials criticizing his Democratic challenger, Representative Thomas A. Daschle, for accepting a campaign contribution from Jane Fonda.

title: Cable TV
description: Though 20th-century Halloweens may pay obeisance to tradition with jack-o-lanterns, costumed goblins and witches and trick or treating, the modern observance also calls for a horror movie to intensify the ghostly atmosphere.

title: Final Touches
description: In some ways food presentation is akin to clothing fashions. Distinctive styles in both fields are embraced by those on the cutting edge, adapted and modified by others, then gradually tampered gether different evolves. In the food world, of course, the seasons are much longer - measured in years rather than months - the the dynamics are much the same.

title: Turning In to These Conservative Times
description: NOBEL prize winners in the physical and biological sciences seldom if ever are described as partisans of big or small science, public or private financing. Politicians do not pause to praise them unless a winner happens to be a constituent. Matters arrange themselves differently in economics.

title: Grand Style
description: Dining rooms have always been elusive places, appearing and disappearing from house plans depending on fashions in design and entertaining for more than three centuries now. Perhaps more than any other room in the house, the dining room has suffered something of an identity crisis. Give a modern architect his way and the dining room can lose its status as a room altogether, becoming instead an ''area'' either married to the ''living area'' or kitchen, or used for everything from a combination guestroom and library to a temporary nursery.

title: Very Nice. Lovely, What's the Next Meeting?
description: STAYING AT THE TOP The Life of a CEO. By Sonny Kleinfield. 298 pp. New York: New American Library. $17.95.

title: WHERE DID THEIR LOVE GO?
description: DREAMGIRL My Life as a Supreme. By Mary Wilson with Patricia Romanowski and Ahrgus Juilliard. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: CRISIS IN BETHLEHEM: Big Steel's Struggle to Survive. By John Strohmeyer. (Adler & Adler, $17.95.) John Strohmeyer, who for 28 years was the editor of The Globe-Times of Bethlehem, Pa., witnessed the rise and fall of the nation's steelmakers, and ''Crisis in Bethlehem'' is a highly readable account of the triumphs and trials of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, once one of the nation's most profitable companies but now near bankruptcy.

title: VATICAN ASKS HELP TO MEET INCREASING DEFICIT
description: The Vatican is running up steadily increasing financial deficits and urgently needs greater contributions from Roman Catholics, according to a commission of cardinals who met here this week.

title: A DAY IN THE SNOW PEAKS
description: ''Good morning. Lemon tea. How many sugar?''

title: Journalist Was Victim Of U.S. Border Law
description: To the Editor:

title: A Limit to the Fifth
description: As far-reaching as Fifth Amendment protections may be, they don't stretch quite far enough for Irene Marcos Araneta and her husband, Gregorio, the daughter and son-in-law of Ferdinand E. Marcos. The Aranetas recently cited the Fifth Amendment in arguing that they should not be compelled to testify before a grand jury investigating possible corruption in Pentagon-financed arms deals with the Philippines, even though they were immune from prosecution.

title: CHILD-CARE AID FOR EMPLOYEES RISING
description: DEBBIE APPIO of Yaphank recently dropped off her 5-year-old daughter, Anne Marie, at the Just Kids Early Childhood Learning Center in Middle Island, as she has every almost every weekday morning for several years.

title: WHEN TEACHERS AND STUDENTS CLASH ON TV QUIZ BATTLEFIELD
description: FOUR award-winning New Jersey teachers were huddled here earlier this month, desperately trying to identify the four assassinated American Presidents.

title: CLEAN AIR DEADLINE NEARS, AND CITY PONDERS ITS CHOICES
description: IN the 17 years since Congress passed the Federal Clean Air Act, officials in New York City and other congested metropolitan areas have learned that clean air does not come easily. Now, with a major deadline for reducing pollutants little more than a year away, the big cities are facing tough decisions about the movement of cars and trucks. Tomorrow and Tuesday, Mayor Koch will preside over City Hall hearings that are expected to underscore the conflict between some city officials and environmentalists, on the one hand, and motorists and businessmen on the other.

title: RICHARD DARMAN'S INVISIBLE HAND
description: RICHARD G. DARMAN, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, was not among those posing for photographers last week at the White House ceremonies commemorating the passage of the tax bill. He was the anonymous man of the tax law until the end.

title: Wines With History
description: When Peter Bienstock, Michael Aaron and Kevin Zraly agreed to host a dinner party to benefit the New York Public Library, it was understood that the meal would focus on extraordinary wines. Aaron is the president of Sherry-Lehmann Wines & Spirits Merchants, one of New York City's leading wine dealers; Zraly is the wine director of Windows on the World, which has one of the largest restaurant wine cellars in New York, and Bienstock, in whose comfortable Fifth Avenue apartment the dinner was held, is well known for his interest in good food and drink. Moreover, Bienstock had recently purchased the contents of a remarkable wine collection in Wilmington, Del., that had been kept in a walk-in safe early this century by S. Hallock duPont, a distant relative of Bienstock's wife, Anne Bienstock, and a direct descendant of Eleuthere Irenee duPont, the founder of the Du Pont Company.

title: Elizabeth M. Murray Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Meyer Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Rahul Kalahastri Naidu, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kalahastri J. Naidu of Evanston, Ill. Msgr. John F. Corr and the Rev. William J. Galvin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: SMALL BUSINESS USA: The Role of Small Companies in Sparking America's Economic Transformation. By Steven Solomon. (Crown, $22.50.) Big business employs fewer people than it did a decade ago, even though America's work force is larger than it was then.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER GROUP AT Y
description: THE 92d Street Y has plans to scrap its old chamber-music format and replace it with the kind of single-theme, innovative-repertory, top-performer format that has worked so well in this fall's ''Vienna 1900: A Festival of Music'' produced by the Y at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Music Notes column in the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect date for the Juilliard Orchestra's memorial to the cellist Leonard Rose at the Juilliard Theater. It will take place next Saturday at 8 P.M., not Dec. 1.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 41 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 41 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Leslie DeRose Is Married
description: Leslie Ann DeRose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James DeRose of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Alan Welhoelter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Welhoelter of Fremont, Calif. The Rev. Edmund Whalen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection. Mrs. Welhoelter, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, graduated from Colgate University, as did her husband, an independent computer consultant in New York.

title: PASTOR FINDS G.O.P. SUPPORT LUKEWARM
description: The Rev. Donald Lynch is a 31-year-old assistant pastor who decided to run for Congress this year.

title: Peggy Fox, a Lawyer, Married to Dennis R. Hartin
description: Margaret Smallwood Fox, a daughter of Mrs. S. Smallwood Fox of Jacksonville, Fla., and the late Mr. Fox, was married yesterday to Dennis Robinson Hartin, a son of Mrs. William J. Hartin of Wading River, L.I., and the late Mr. Hartin. The Rev. William D. Dearnaley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in New York at the home of Paula J. Mueller, the bride's cousin, and her husband, Thomas C. O'Keefe.

title: Stick to the Clean Water Deal
description: Any bill that passes both House and Senate without a single contrary vote must be bursting with either motherhood or money. The clean water bill is stuffed with $18 billion of sewage treatment grants, some for every state of the Union, and the Budget Office is warning of a veto.

title: Montclair State Suffers First Loss, 13-6
description: Kevin White, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns to lead undefeated Salisbury State to a 13-6 victory yesterday over previously unbeaten Montclair State in Salisbury, Md.

title: THE FEMALE EXPERIENCE- UNCENSORED
description: THE WOMEN'S DECAMERON By Julia Voznesenskaya. Translated by W. B. Linton. 302 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: RESENTMENT AGAINST NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: A FORMER President demands the deportation of any immigrant who fails to learn English after five years. Twenty states impose ''Americanization'' programs to promote what the California Commission on Housing and Immigration calls ''the language of America.'' And the Governor of Iowa forbids the use of any language but English in gatherings of three or more people or even over the telephone.

title: O'Neill Theater Head Is Recipient of Medal
description: George C. White, the president and founder of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., has been awarded this year's Eugene O'Neill Birthday Medal. The award is given annually by the Theater Committee for Eugene O'Neill to someone who has furthered the playwright's works.

title: Recent Sales

title: Julia L. Russin to Be Bride Of Jeffrey Bercow, Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. David J. Russin of Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Lowell Russin, to Jeffrey Bercow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Bercow of Scotch Plains, N.J. The wedding is planned for Feb. 15. The future bride, an assistant area director of the American Jewish Committee of Miami, is an alumna of Simmons College.

title: The Family Silver
description: If a new wave of formality is a signal for everyone to bring the antique Limoges and Minton out of storage, to unwrap the crystal goblets, packed up since the thank-you note was written, and to begin using the ancestral silver daily, I am in trouble.

title: EARLY MORNING FIRE KILLS 8, INJURES 7 IN MINNESOTA
description: Eight people, including five children, were killed and seven were injured, one critically, in a fire early this morning in a two-story duplex here, the authorities said.

title: Redskins Have Respect For Giants
description: Once one team in a division achieves parity with another and they are both legitimate playoff contenders, a rivalry develops, The Washington Redskins and Dallas Cowboys have had one for years, beginning in earnest and intensifying during George Allen's regime as the Redskin coach in the 1970's.

description: RESETTING BRISTOL CLOCKS

Thomas McClennan performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Mary's-at-the-Cathedral church in Philadelphia.

title: TE KANAWA TAKES TO ISLAND STAGE
description: ''I'VE always loved Long Island, since I first began singing in New York,'' Dame Kiri Te Kanawa said last week. ''I live in London - that is where I keep my permanent home. I like to travel around when I'm in the United States. But I am happiest in the country, among the trees and flowers, working in a garden, away from the hassles of the city.

title: ON DRACULA'S TRAIL IN TRANSYLVANIA
description: OUR GROUP clustered closer to the warmth of a bonfire, anxiously waiting and watching the western horizon. As the sun vanished behind the Carpathian peaks - leaving brilliant red-orange streaks across the darkening sky - we raised our glasses, silently saluting the Count who had met his death here on the Borgo Pass, in the heart of Transylvania.

title: TRICK OR TREAT: THE REAL SCARINESS
description: WHEN the sticky heat of summer leaves Long Island and the cool, crisp air of autumn arrives, certain things are inevitable. Red trees, fresh apple cider, football season, and something that has meant a lot to us all - Halloween.

title: 'The Mission' Carries a Message From Past to Present
description: The Iguassu waterfalls, which define the borders of Brazil, Paraguay and Argentina, are a breathtakingly ethereal, almost mystical spot, a place where earthly concepts like time and money are drowned out by the deafening roar of millions of drops of water exploding on rock hundreds of feet below.

title: Let This Be a Lesson
description: TRADING SECRETSBy R. Foster Winans. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $17.95.

title: Q AND A
description: Charter Flights Question:Do you know of any charter flights going from New York to Rome? - E. H., Yonkers Answer:Weekly charter flights to Rome can be booked through Fantasy Holidays (366 North Broadway, Jericho, N.Y. 11753; 516-935-2970) or, out of state, 800-645-2555). The flights, departing Friday evenings from Kennedy Airport and going via Paris, are on Boeing 707's of Skystar International, the New Jersey-based charter service. Return flights are on Saturdays. Round-trip fares are $398 on some dates and $498 on others and rise to $598 for the Christmas period. The lower rates generally apply to November and January, when demand for seats is lower. (On Alitalia, the Italian airline, a 21-day, advance-purchase fare from New York to Rome costs, from Nov. 1, $729 on weekdays and $779, weekends, round trip, nonstop.) Fantasy operates a year-round program to Rome; in spring the service is expected to continue with nonstop flights on another charter airline, Tower Air. The company also offers packages of air fare and seven nights' accommodations in the city, starting at $499 a person. This is generally a slow time of year for charter flights to Europe, and this past season has not been busy. It is expected that other operators will be offering charters to Rome from next April.

title: HOSPITALS UNVEIL NEW EFFORT
description: IN its latest effort to adapt to a changing market for medical services, the county's first formal hospital alliance has accepted the results of a four-month consultants' study and chosen three health fields to emphasize in a cooperative venture.

title: DEVELOPER PLANS TO LINK 39-STORY TOWER TO A WEST SIDE LANDMARK
description: After a noble and notorious century, a brooding chateau on Central Park West that was once the Towers Nursing Home would be restored and joined to one of the tallest skyscrapers in upper Manhattan, under plans filed with the city.

title: Search for Fugitive Moves Toward Chicago
description: A search for a convicted felon who used a hidden pistol to escape from two prison guards Friday spread west toward Chicago today, the authorities said.

title: THE CENTURY OF MY FATHER
description: AS my father's 100th birthday approached, I paid a visit to the United States Military Cemetery in Farmingdale, where we left him in 1957. In 1983, my mother joined him there. It took a while to find them in that vast city of the dead, but finally there they were: Thomas McMorrow and Hedwig Evers McMorrow.

title: A LAG IN DEMAND SEEN BY EMPLOYERS
description: MANY employers who sponsor child-care programs say demand has fallen far short of their expectations, leaving some to question whether a real need exists.

title: OCTOBER! A MONTH OF MAGIC
description: ALL right, all you closet October freaks, it has been your time to shine. I say closet because lovers of October as a group are quiet, tasteful folk who wish to keep their numbers small and not draw attention to themselves. That is why opinion polls state that most people name one of the summer months as their favorite. But I know better. The plain truth is that, deep down, people revel in the return of October.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Builders Turning South for Cheaper Land
description: OVER the last two decades, Ocean County, with its 50 milies of Atlantic Beaches, has become synonymous with age-restricted communities.

description: TRICK or treat, trick or treat!

description: ''I'M too big to go out on Halloween and he's much too big,'' my 15-year-old son informed me. ''You mean too old,'' I replied. ''You said it, Mom, not me,'' Christopher answered.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
Bringing 'Em Home Alive
description: If ever there was an event as large as all outdoors, ''World Safari'' is probably it. Produced by the BBC in association with 11 other international broadcasting agencies, this 90-minute live presentation will travel to 16 photogenic wilderness areas around the globe and, via satellite hookups, visit with the varieties of wildlife in residence there. ''World Safari'' will be shown at 3 P.M. today on WTBS, without commercials, as a special entry in the National Geographic ''Explorer'' series; it will also be repeated this evening at 8 in a two-hour slot, with commercials.

title: POSTINGS: Workshop; Saving Facades
description: The repercussions of Local Law 10, enacted by New York City in 1980, are bittersweet. Pedestrians no longer fear being killed by falling masonry, but the facades of many buildings are being denuded of ornament.

title: A Home Away From Home
description: Bob asked me not to publish his surname because if I did, he might be forced out of business. He and his wife welcome paying guests for bed and breakfast in their three-story home in Kansas City, Mo. They are highly recommended by Diane C. Kuhn, who runs the Kansas City Bed and Breakfast referral service, but they have never made their business known to city authorities. ''I don't want to be taxed for it and told how to run it,'' Bob said. ''That's why I don't put up a sign outside. The day they try to control me is the day I close up.''

title: 'The Africans': An Attack On Western Values
description: Attention must be paid to ''The Africans.'' The nine-part series makes a statement: The West is responsible for all of Africa's afflictions. The operative word here is ''all.'' Political corruption, moral decay, telephones that do not work in Lagos - it is hard to think of a single African problem the series does not trace to the West. In itself this is not important; television series come and go, and although ''The Africans'' has created a controversy, the controversy will be forgotten by next season. Dismiss ''The Africans'' as a random shot, however, or a piece of television programming gone astray, and you miss the reasons it is significant. ''The Africans'' is laden with academic credentials; it is supposed to be the centerpiece of the public-television season; it is being offered as a course for college credit. In the battlefield of ideas, it occupies a prominent place.

title: STAKES ARE HIGH IN SUFFOLK HOUSE RACE
description: GREGORY J. BLASS and George J. Hochbrueckner, the Republican and Democratic candidates for the House seat from the First Congressional District in Suffolk County, have had at last 25 joint appearances and debates. But there has been little heat and few major differences between them.

title: 'GROWN UPS'' GIVEN NEW LIFE AT EMELIN
description: WITH Jules Feiffer's best-known play, ''Little Murders,'' the theater suffered a case of delayed readiness. The original version ran less than one week in 1967. A couple of years later, an Off Broadway revival - and revision - was a moderate success. The play has since become a recognized classic of contemporary urban violence and paranoia, often revived in regional theaters.

title: ADJUSTING THE SPEED LIMIT TO MATCH REALITY
description: IN January 1974, with blocks-long lines at filling stations, the Federal Government imposed a top speed of 55 miles an hour nationwide. Not three months later, when shortages eased, surveys found that many people were driving somewhat faster than that.

title: Fredrica Pitkin Welles Is Married to Leslie S. Ash

title: IRAQI RAIDS REPORTED TO CUT IRAN OILS EXPORTS
description: Heavy raids by Iraqi bombers on Iranian oil refineries and shipping installations have reduced Iran's petroleum exports from 1.6 million barrels a day at this time last year to 600,000 to 700,000 barrels at present, according to American and British intelligence sources and experts on Middle East oil production and exports.

title: A Japanese Master Debuts On Two Coasts
description: It is clearly Arata Isozaki's season. The Japanese architect's Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, among the most eagerly awaited buildings in the United States, opens Dec. 10. And earlier this month, , as if to add to the mounting excitement, the Brooklyn Museum announced that it had hired the team of Mr. Isozaki and James Stewart Polshek & Partners to design a renovation and major expansion of its landmark Beaux-Arts building.

title: THE SINGLES LIFE: ANOTHER VIEW
description: Concerning the article on the author Bruce Feirstein [ '' 'Real Man' Limns Singles Life,'' Oct. 5 ] : Dear ''Real Man,''

title: For Malone, New Exit on N.B.A. Beltway
description: ONE section of the Capital Beltway, which encircles the nation's capital and much of the surrounding area, looks very much like another. Most outsiders try to avoid it. On a recent morning, one of the area's newest residents accepted the challenge, but soon he was completely lost. ''Usually,'' said Moses Malone, sitting cautiously at the wheel of a Bronco truck, the most conservative of his nine vehicles, ''I just go to the practices and the games. Nowhere else.'' He pauses and searches for a familiar landmark. ''I think I missed my exit.''

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;
The Disease Is Past, but the Cure Lingers On
description: THE GREAT DEPRESSION An Inquiry Into the Causes, Course, and Consequences of the Worldwide Depression of the Nineteen-Thirties, as Seen by Contemporaries and in the Light of History. By John A. Garraty. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Meese Dissents On the High Court
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d extended his constitutional critique in a new direction, aiming at what he called an ''astonishing'' arrogation of power by the Supreme Court and at those who place its rulings ''on a par with the Constitution itself.'' A High Court decision, he said in a speech at Tulane University in New Orleans, ''does not establish a 'supreme law of the land' that is binding on all persons and parts of Government, henceforth and forevermore.''

title: OPTIONS ON HOUSING ARE EXPLORED
description: WESTCHESTER'S housing shortage could be alleviated by local governments, according to several speakers at a housing conference last weekend. But while some suggested that the localities could do it if they had enough public support, others said it would be accomplished only with court orders.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IS IT FAIR TO REGULATE DOCTORS?
description: OUR SOCIETY is facing a rapidly worsening problem with health care, a problem that, if untreated, will result in a crisis of major proportions.

title: Popular Music Finds Itself in a Caribbean Groove
description: This decade, pop music has discovered the groove - a continually expanding palette of smooth, supple, steady rhythms. At the top of the Billboard charts, albums as diverse as Run-D.M.C.'S ''Raising Hell,'' Madonna's ''True Blue,'' the ''Top Gun'' soundtrack and Janet Jackson's ''Control'' think in grooves ranging from the rowdy to the lithe to the industrial-strength, and they pass the two million mark in sales. For fans of jazz, rhythm and blues or Latin music - whose innovations the mainstream continually borrows - a rhythmic foundation is nothing new. For rock and especially pop, however, it has amounted to a revolution.

title: Putting On A Renewed Face
description: HIS FACE WAS AS creased as his chaps, and he wore a look of assurance. But the leathery Marlboro-man image, once ubiquitous, is no longer the one that American men seem to esteem. In place of ruggedness, skin-care experts say, men want a face that is both polished and apparently ageless.

description: To the Editor: I am amused by the many letters to the editor these days in which the writers express delight at being in Europe when so few Americans were there.

title: Truffaut's 'Woman' and Rockabilly From Perkins
description: Never on Sunday Starring Melina Mercouri and Jules Dassin; directed by Mr. Dassin, 1960 MGM/UA Home Video 94 minutes. $59.95

title: Red Sox: 68 Years and Counting
description: THE special agony of the Boston Red Sox continues for at least another day - or maybe another 68 years.

title: TOWNS SCRAMBLING FOR DISPOSAL PLANS
description: A REQUIREMENT that all towns have in place by the end of the year long-range plans for solid-waste disposal is causing many municipalities to scramble as the deadline draws nearer.

title: New York's Spunky Style
description: INSPIRATION CAN BE ILLUSIVE. Perhaps it is the works of a great designer. Or maybe in the current work of a talented colleague from across the sea. Fabrics and their colors are often important, as are observations of the social and artistic scenes, personal conviction, instinct, the desire for something to wear oneself, even a cognizance of what is selling best at the moment. It can even be discovered in an egg.

title: NATO NERVOUSLY CONTEMPLATES A CONVENTIONAL FORCES GAP
description: FOR years, West European politicians have ritually urged the superpowers to strive for a world freed from the terror of nuclear weapons. Yet when Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev boldly explored that prospect in Iceland, a number of the United States's allies became very nervous. However terrifying, American nuclear weapons have become symbols of a commitment to the defense of Western Europe - and a cheap way of compensating for the superiority in ground forces that the Warsaw Pact holds over NATO.

title: Dance
description: Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker is celebrated in Europe. But the 26-year-old Belgian modern-dance choreographer has never presented her minimalist and formalist works here.

title: O'ROURKE, IN NEW DISPUTE, MAY QUIT TV DEBATE
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would withdraw from a televised debate with Governor Cuomo if the candidate of the New Alliance Party, which he accused of extremist views, participates.

title: Article 912486 -- No Title
description: Big Brothers Inc. of New York City has received a $75,000 Federal grant for a pilot program to match homeless families with volunteer families that will act as their friends and advocates.

title: ...But 'Star Wars' Seems a Defense Against Improved Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Paul Newman
description: In the middle of a critical telephone conversation with my sister, she said,''Oh, look who is on the cover of The New York Times Magazine'' (''Paul Newman: Testing Himself, by Maureen Dowd, Sept. 28).

title:
DINING OUT;
DOWN BY THE RIVER IN RED BANK
description: BASED upon our first visit to La Rive, the elegant restaurant in Red Bank's new Oyster Point Hotel, the best rating it could eke out would have been ''Satisfactory.''

title: Four Corners
description: To the Editor: From experience on a recent trip to the Southwest, I have a suggestion and a request to make travel there more interesting and possibly safer.

title: Faure, 'Dolly' And Gaby Casadesus
description: Concertgoers will have an opportunity to come into contact with some living musical history this Wednesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, when Grant Johannesen and Gaby Casadesus join forces to play Gabriel Faure's ''Dolly'' Suite for piano, four hands. ''Dolly'' has long been one of Faure's most beloved compositions.

title: INSIDE
description: Jet Engine Alert Issued Prompted by four in-flight engine failures, Pratt & Whitney, the manufacturer, issued an ''alert bulletin'' urging design changes.

title: 'Prizzi's Family'
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN LINKED TO SERIES OF DEATHS
description: The authorities investigating a man who was killed in an attack on a young couple have found evidence linking him to a series of killings in western Montana as far back as 1974.

title: DEATH TRIAL RAISING QUESTIONS
description: WHEN Robert G. Rogoski goes on trial in Riverhead this week charged with second-degree murder in the death of his 22-month-old son, he will have spent more than 17 months in jail maintaining his innocence.

title: 4 ENGINE FAILURES SPUR ALERT FOR AIRLINES TO OVERHAUL 99 PLANES
description: Reacting to a baffling run of four in-flight engine failures over the past 16 months, Pratt & Whitney, the engine maker, yesterday sent an ''alert bulletin'' to airlines urging prompt design changes to prevent such breakdowns.

title: DID THE SUMMIT CHANGE ANYTHING?
description: The spirit of Reykjavik - if it ever existed - did not last long. The United States' expulsion of 55 Soviet diplomats and the Kremlin's retaliation, have delivered a powerful blow to the optimism. One reason for the renewed hostility is that the meeting was not handled well, either by the General Secretary or by the President.

title: Reagan And the Senate
description: By all the political trends and statistics of the past, the Republicans should lose control of the Senate on Election Day, but the guess here is that the President will pull them through.

title: NEUTRONS IN PARADISE
description: PENTAGON By Allen Drury. 593 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: Southern Feast
description: ''Corn fritters,'' Emily Coxe Winburn was saying as she moved about in her kitchen, ''are an essential part of our Thanksgiving dinners because they go well with turkey, goose and all game birds. Once, I recall, we ate five hundred of them. The cook stopped counting.''

title: Rutgers Rolls Up 527 Yards and Overwhelms Army
description: Rutgers ran and passed at will against Army today, scoring early and late and often in between. Everything the Scarlet Knights tried against the Black Knights offensively and defensively worked so effectively that it led to an inevitable rout, 35-7, at Giants Stadium.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY COMPANY IN ALL-ARPINO PROGRAM
description: THE Joffrey Ballet celebrated Gerald Arpino, its resident choreographer and associate director, in an all-Arpino program on Friday at City Center that honored his 25th year of making dances. The evening did not offer the sense of a retrospective that one might have wished for, but it did suggest several facets of this controversial creator's work.

title: Differing Styles in Game 7
description: The starting pitchers in tonight's seventh game of the World Series provide a unique matchup: the product of Yale University against the disciple of Satchel Paige.

title:
GARDENING;
TULIP: OLD WORLD NATIVE STILL A FAVORITE
description: THE tulip is just about everyone's favorite spring flower.

title: VIOLENT REACTION TO A SOUTH AFRICAN CRASH
description: PRESIDENT Samora M. Machel of Mozambique, one of the self-described ''front-line'' countries that coexist precariously alongside South Africa, was killed last week in a plane crash that generated immediate political confusion.

title: Tigers and Lion Found On Massachusetts Farm
description: Two tigers, a lion, an elephant and other wild animals were found without adequate food, some of them in cramped and filthy cages, in a circus tent hidden on a farm, the authorities said today.

title:
THE NEW FORMALITY;
A Modern Tea
description: Stopping to savor a hot cup of tea is a calming respite at the end of the day. In these tranquil moments, welcome refreshments can be served, much like those found at teatime in the finest English hotels. Indeed, a growing number of hotels and restaurants in this country are offering late afternoon fare reminiscent of proper English teas.

title: U.S. AIDES SPLIT ON HOW TO USE NEW CONTRA AID
description: The Reagan Administration is divided over how to spend $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and is debating what goals can be reasonably achieved with the money, according to Administration officials.

title: Ex-College Head Is Charged
description: The former president of Westfield State College was booked Friday on charges of sexually assaulting two male students.

title: WHITE HOUSE AGAIN SAYS REAGAN DIDN'T AGREE TO DROP ALL A-ARMS
description: The White House today repeated its position that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev had discussed the elimination of all nuclear weapons, but that the talks had never reached a tentative understanding on this issue.

title: A Bullish View From the Midwest
description: ALTHOUGH doubts about the economy and the deficits, both budget and trade, have cooled the ardor of many stock investors, two veteran money managers in the Middle West remain strongly bullish on the large capitalization growth companies that have led the market averages. Citing historic price-earnings ratios, Ralph Kosmicke and David White, who manage about $2.7 billion in pension and insurance assets, believe that investors are justified in buying the stocks of premier growth companies at much higher P/E's than in the past.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: THE FRONTIERS OF MANAGEMENT: Where Tomorrow's Decisions Are Being Shaped Today. By Peter F. Drucker (Truman Talley/Dutton, $19.95.) Whether he is lavishing praise on Germany's economic miracle compared to Japan's or proposing a way to defuse worker resentment of executives' high pay, Peter F. Drucker seems to tell managers what they've overlooked while they've been running their companies.

title: STARVING THE HANDS THAT FED THEM
description: THE HARVEST OF SORROW Soviet Collectivization and the Terror-Famine. By Robert Conquest. Illustrated. 412 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Clash of Opinions on Westchester Hotels
description: JACK PARKER, of Parker Meridien Hotels, announced recently that he would not build a 350-room luxury hotel near the White Plains railroad station, as planned, because the county had too many hotel rooms.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: AS Arthur Owens sees it, he is the founder and president of Sports and Health Club Inc., Marc Crevier and Forest Larson are the ''secular stockholders'' and God owns the business.

title: Best Seller: October 26, 1986
description: FICTION

title: MAN WHOM CHURCH DECLARED RECIPIENT OF '63 MIRACLE DIES
description: Michael Flanigan, whose recovery from cancer in 1963 was considered a miracle and led to the canonization of St. John Neumann, the first American male saint, died after a heart attack Monday at his home here. He was 29 years old.

title: OUSTER OF JUDGES FOR RULINGS DENIED
description: The House Judiciary Committee has refused to start impeachment proceedings against three Federal judges, ruling explicitly for the first time that a judge cannot be subjected to impeachment for a judicial decision, even an erroneous one.

title: THEATER: 'THE MAIDS,' BY JEAN GENET
description: WITHIN the mirror of ''The Maids,'' there is another mirror, as images reflect and distort one another, as artifice is amassed atop artifice. In the Genet play, the two maids alternate roles - theirs and that of their mistress - and both finally carry pretense into visceral reality. As Sartre said about Claire and Solange, ''Their minds are inside out, and they are always other than themselves.'' At any single moment, one is not sure who is representing whom. When one maid strikes the other, it is not clear in which of several persona each is operating.

title: NEW PARTY CHIEF OFFERS GLOOMY PICTURE OF VIETNAM
description: Hanoi's new Communist Party leader, in a series of tough speeches over the last week setting the agenda for a party congress, is portraying Vietnam as a troubled country that has squandered its material and human potential through its own mistakes.

title: BRITISH ASK SOVIET TO DECLARE ITSELF AGAINST TERRORISM
description: Britain called on the Soviet Union today to declare publicly its rejection of state-supported terrorism in the wake of allegations that Syria, a Russian ally, was involved in a plot to blow up an Israeli airliner.

title: TV MINISERIES GETS A CHORUS OF OBJECTIONS
description: ''Preposterous,'' said a top United Nations official. ''Offensive,'' said another. A third said, ''It has the intellectual weight of 'Dynasty' meets 'Red Dawn.' ''
