title: CALIFORNIA CHIC IN EAST NORWICH
description: CANCEL that trip to Los Angeles and travel instead to the Black Walnut in East Norwich, the most authentic example of California-style dining on Long Island. Even the elegant new shopping complex in which the restaurant is situated has a look more Beverly Hills than East Hills or Dix Hills.

title: 'The Nazi Doctors'
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENCY CHIEF TO RUN HEARING ON PIPELINE
description: IN a break with tradition, the new head of the Federal agency that must review the proposed Iroquois natural gas pipeline will take testimony Tuesday in Torrington.

title: Photography
description: Andreas Feininger, now 80, was once a commanding figure in photography. Son of the Bauhaus painter Lyonel Feininger, he trained at the German design school in the 20's and established himself in Europe as a photojournalist until the war forced him to come to the United States. Here he parlayed his experiments with an extra-long telephoto lens into a successful career as a staff member of Life magazine. In addition, he wrote innumerable columns and books on photographic subjects over the years, and in 1976 the International Center of Photography organized a retrospective exhibition of his work.

title: L.I. POLICE DEPT. ENTERS COMPUTER AGE
description: When two police officers recently arrested a man for burglary, grand larceny and criminal mischief, they were back on patrol in less than an hour, their paperwork neatly completed and checked for spelling.

title: TO LYONS FOR LUNCH
description: Gastronomically, Lyons is a city of contrasts. Moving from well-worn back-alley bistros to sparkling three-star temples, from smoke-filled train station eateries to sleek modern cafes, a visitor can ramble through France's second city sampling old France one moment, new France the next, spanning a handful of decades in a single day. In some strange ways, Lyons of the 1980's looks the way many of us imagine Paris of the 1930's, inspiring one recent visitor to announce, ''The last time I saw Paris it was in Lyons.''

title: Theatergoers Take Note: All the Audience's a Stage
description: AUDIENCE BEHAVIORAL TECHNIQUES. An intensive course, with lecture demonstrations, designed to instruct theatergoers in methods of response to requests from actors during performance. There will be special seminars in Flinching, Wincing and Avoiding Eye Contact. Guest speakers will include Penn, Teller, the Flying Karamazov Brothers and members of the Royal Shakespeare Company.

title: Ashley M. Lickle To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Lickle of Montchanin, Del., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ashley Morgan Lickle to J. Pierce O'Neil, the son of Mrs. Peter E. Kernan of Kennebunkport, Me., and James H. O'Neil of Kiawah Island, S.C. The wedding is planned for March.

title: BROOKHAVEN: 'LAST FRONTIER' GRAPPLES WITH CHANGE
description: MANY developers, environmentalists and civic leaders refer to the Town of Brookhaven as Long Island's last frontier. But Vincent Donnelly, the town's Commissioner of Development, Environment and Planning, has some problems with that term.

title: HAVEN FOR RETIRED GREYHOUNDS
description: ''THERE'S no such thing as a gray greyhound,'' said Eileen McCaughern as her three dogs - blue brindle, fawn and solid black - romped around her East Haven yard. ''Solid blue is the closest to gray that they come.''

title:
THE NEW FORMALITY;
Weekend Lunch
description: When two young British women of aristocratic background and artistic bent who live in Manhattan entertain their friends on a Sunday afternoon, they do not prepare a typical New York brunch. True to British tradition, Eliza Smith-Ryland and Debbie Morris-Adams opt for something civilized, simple to prepare and evocative of home. Smith-Ryland is a costume designer, and has worked in theater and film productions, including the movies ''Heartburn,'' and ''The Mosquito Coast,'' due out in December. Morris-Adams, who is Smith-Ryland's roommate, is a graphic designer. The two women give a party in the same inventive but nonchalant style that marks Smith-Ryland's apartment, a felicitous mix of modern and traditional, elegant and eclectic.

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: SINCE becoming the state's Commissioner of Health last August, Dr. Molly Joel Coye has been reorganizing the Department of Health and reshuffling some top officials.

title: Peking Asks Seoul to Return An Air Force Pilot and Plane
description: China asked South Korea today to return a Chinese Air Force pilot and the MIG-19 jet fighter he flew to a South Korean air base.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Clothing and Things At Scarsdale Fair For 40 years the Women's Guild of the Scarsdale Congregational Church had scheduled its fair on Election Day. This year it is earlier - Saturday from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. The location is the same, Dyckman Hall near the church, and the fair will feature the traditional lunch with Rachel Mead's corn chowder, a favorite for 25 years. It will also introduce examples of Don Herner's culinary skill -25 homemade apple pies.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOWCASE OF PRESERVATION
description: ''UNION COUNTY: Preservation in Our Towns,'' a two-day showcase of accomplishments highlighted by talks and tours, will take place Saturday and next Sunday at historic sites in 12 communities. It is free and open to the public. Included in the self-directed itineraries will be access to historic houses, inns, churches, cemeteries, theaters, old farmsteads and historic districts spanning more than 300 years of county and state history, according to Linda McTeague, the county's Preservation Planner.

title: Donna Babbitt Marries
description: At St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Marion, Mass., yesterday Donna Lynn Babbitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin V. Babbitt Jr. of Marion, was married to John Norman Reinman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Reinman of DeWitt, N.Y. The Rev. Charles P. Scott, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Robert Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Reinman is an advertising sales representative for Gourmet magazine in New York. Her husband is a vice president of Willcox Inc., a reinsurance brokerage in New York.

title: Phyllis Sah Weds Dr. John P. McHenry
description: Phyllis Fay Lee Sah, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kung-Fu Sah of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. John Persons McHenry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Keers McHenry Jr. of Birmingham, Ala. The Rev. Robert T. Baggott 3d performed the ceremony at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Coconut Grove, Fla.

title: STATE SEEKS REGIONAL PLANNING ON TRANSPORTATION
description: WITH a view toward heading off another crowded and cluttered development corridor such as the one along U.S. 1 in Mercer County, state transportation officials are trying to bring, for the first time, a regional approach to planning.

title: OUR PETS, OUR PORK CHOPS
description: IN THE COMPANY OF ANIMALS A Study of Human-Animal Relationships. By James Serpell. Illustrated. 215 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $19.95.

title: DON'T THROW IT OUT -- REPAIR THAT WOBBLY OLD FURNITURE
description: PROMPT attention to minor problems can often mean the difference between having to throw out an old, treasured piece of furniture that has become wobbly or shaky, or being able to extend its life almost indefinitely.

title: School Soccer Team Penalized for Girl Player
description: A school soccer team has been removed from a Catholic Youth Organization league for the rest of the season because one of its top players is a 7-year-old girl.

title: FINANCING RESOLVED
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN and Governor Kean have finally settled the question of where the $1.6 billion for New Jersey's hazardous-waste cleanup program will come from.

title: THE KING LEAR OF OCHTERMOCHTY
description: MEMOIRS OF MANY IN ONE By Alex Xenophon Demirjian Gray. Edited by Patrick White. 192 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: OUT OF THE BLUE, SIX BEQUESTS FOR $240 MILLION
description: When Liliore Green Rains died last November at the age of 76, representatives of four California colleges, a Los Angeles hospital and a psychiatric clinic in Topeka, Kan., gained $40 million each. To this day they are not sure why.

title: WORK RULES OVERTAKING PAY AS KEY IN LABOR DISPUTES
description: While pay scales continue to attract the most public notice in labor disputes, more and more of the contention between management and labor now is over contract rules that establish the way work is organized and performed.

title: Olivier on Acting: How to Create The Universe in the Palm of Your Hand
description: Where do we start when we talk about the history of acting? Surely we have always acted; it is an instinct inherent in all of us. Some of us are better at it than others, but we all do it. The child plays games. The child cries when tears are the order of the day, endears himself to avoid criticism, smiles when necessary; he predicts what reactions we require. Look behind those eyes which are giving the beholder the laughter he expects, and you will see the veil of the actor. We have all, at one time or another, been performers, and many of us still are - politicians, playboys, cardinals and kings. We wear the robes that we have designed for ourselves, and then act out other people's fantasies. This is singular; this is the monologue; this is the one-man show.

title: Luring the Big-Spending 'Sixties Types'
description: FROM plastic goodies that came in cereal boxes to expensive works of art, things reminiscent of America's past are fast becoming best sellers with collectors. ''Popular culture items are hot,'' says Dana Hawkes, director of collectibles at Sotheby's.

title: Man Talk
description: A number of things disturbed me about Christopher Hallowell's article ''Man Talk'' (About Men, Sept. 28), and not the least of them was the sense that the article was probably well-intentioned. I honestly don't think he realizes how offensive it is to use the circumstances of one man's death as a way to focus on other men's embarrassment or their failure to rise to an occasion.

title: Headliners; An Elbow to the Jaw
description: The little-known violent side of big-time opera claimed its latest victim last week as Eva Marton, the dramatic soprano, caught an elbow to the jaw during a performance of ''Tosca'' at the Met. Though she suffered a dislocated jaw, Miss Marton was able to finish the performance and even joke about it later.

title: DID 2 AMERICAN COMPANIES MEET DIVESTMENT TEST?
description: The decisions by the General Motors Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation to sell their South African subsidiaries have created a quandary.

title: Best Sellers: October 26, 1986
description: Fiction

title: THEATER SEASON WILL OFFER A PLETHORA OF PREMIERES
description: THE state's theaters are presenting a profusion of premieres this season: world, American and New Jersey ones.

title: SHORTAGE OF SCHOOL BUS DRIVERS CAUSES GROWING CONCERN
description: THE shortage of school-bus drivers in the county has grown worse this year, forcing at least one school district to warn parents of the possible cancellation of bus service and other districts to cancel athletic events and field trips, creating delays in service that have prompted calls from irate parents and causing tension between school officials and bus companies.

title: Murder On Long Island
description: Cheryl Pierson is right when she says she didn't ask for help because no one would have believed her. Back in the 1960's, no one believed me when I told my relatives.

title: PARTIES POUR RESOURCES INTO 2 RACES
description: Early on in the Congressional campaign season, national political scouts from both major parties checked out central and upstate New York and found that two Republican representatives there were in popularity slumps while their Democratic challengers were gaining momentum.

title: FOR TWO SCHOLARS, HISTORY IS WHERE THEY FIND IT
description: FOR two historians, Bruce Clouette and Matthew Roth, work is more than researching old documents in dusty archives. They do plenty of that, of course, but they have also leaped from the gunwale of a rocking United States Coast Guard boat onto a ladder dangling from a lighthouse, scrambled up a muddy Vermont hillside to examine the underpinnings of a bridge and canoed along the waters of the Naugatuck River.

title:
GARDENING;
TULIP: OLD WORLD NATIVE STILL A FAVORITE
description: THE tulip is just about everyone's favorite spring flower.

title: EX-GOBLIN REMEMBERS THE WAY IT WAS
description: THEY come with eager masks and outstretched hands, each acting a part, some fulfilling a dream. Beautiful princess, red devil, wicked witch, scruffy tramp, eerie ghost, engaging gorilla, fearsome tiger and a walking television set. Caught up in the ultimate world of make-believe, our Halloween visitors, some barely out of the cradle, remain one of the constants in the scheme of things.

title:
GARDENING;
TULIP: OLD WORLD NATIVE STILL A FAVORITE
description: THE tulip is just about everyone's favorite spring flower.

title: Catherine Ridenour, a Media Planner, Marries T. E. Fancher in Connecticut
description: The marriage of Catherine Bowman Ridenour, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus Edward Ridenour 3d, to Terrence E. Fancher, a son of Catherine L. Fancher of Lethbridge, Alberta, Canada, and Samuel W. Fancher of Gig Harbor, Wash., took place yesterday in Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: eanne Ellen Hoenicke Is Wed to Thomas Melia
description: Jeanne Ellen Hoenicke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Hoenicke of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to Thomas O. Melia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Melia of Centerport, L.I. The Rev. Sidney D. Skirvin, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of the Pilgrims in Washington. The Rev. Michael Kerper, a Roman Catholic priest, read the 100th Psalm, The bride, who will keep her name, is an associate in the Washington law firm of Steptoe & Johnson.

title: Debbie Scott Simmons Wed to Robert M. Jaffe
description: Debbie Scott Simmons and Robert Michael Jaffe were married yesterday at the Springfield, N.J., home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Scott. The Rev. John D. Martin, an Assemblies of God minister who is chaplain of the Peddie School, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: An article in the Business section on Sept. 14 about the management shakeup at CBS discussed the contrasting backgrounds of William S. Paley and Laurence A. Tisch, the company's key figures.

title: It's in Our Power to Ease East-West Tensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Riverdale Honors Hill
description: A former star was back at his original line of scrimmage in the Bronx yesterday. Calvin Hill, a former running back with the Dallas Cowboys, Washington Redskins and Cleveland Browns from 1969 to 1981, was honored by the Riverdale Country Day School yesterday, where he was a quarterback from 1961-65.

title: Lockouts
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ANGRY TIT-FOR-TAT MAY BE DELAYING MORE URGENT BUSINESS
description: IN Soviet-American relations, opportunity is transitory and elusive. It comes fleetingly, at the rare moments when the two superpowers find a common ground of interests and aspirations. And often it is quickly lost in the thicket of mutual annoyance. That seems to be the situation now.

title: 7 Killed in Oregon As Auto Hits Van
description: A speeding car crashed head on into a van, killing all seven people involved in the crash, the police said today.

title: The Joffrey Has Become An Ashton Showcase
description: With this season's production of Frederick Ashton's ''Fille Mal Gardee,'' the Joffrey Ballet presumably reaches a peak if not the capstone of its continuing policy of producing ballets by one of the dance geniuses of our time. The choreographer himself, it is rumored, may arrive to see the company's all-Ashton programs this week at the City Center.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;
Wall Street Speak: Triple Witches and Poison Pills
description: IF you want to get serious about investing, you need to know a lot of business jargon. In today's fast-paced, ever-changing economy, a sound knowledge of that jargon is far more important than actual money. Let's say, for example, that you're at a party, and you find yourself in a conversation with a savvy investor. If you don't understand what he's saying, you could wind up looking very foolish:

title: Florida Spa Fined $600,000
description: The Ocean Reef Club, a Key Largo resort that is a favorite retreat for former President Richard M. Nixon, faces $600,000 in fines for dumping untreated sewage into the John Pennekamp State Park, an ecologically sensitive part of the Atlantic Ocean that contains a living coral reef. Federal District Judge Sidney Aronovitz ordered the fine Wednesday and put two directors of the club on probation for a year.

title: Labor's Pains
description: UNIONS IN TRANSITION Entering the Second Century. Edited by Seymour Martin Lipset. 506 pp. San Francisco: ICS Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95. THE TRANSFORMATION OF AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS By Thomas A. Kochan, Harry C. Katz and Robert B. McKersie. 287 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: THE GENERAL: David Sarnoff and the Rise of the Communications Industry. By Kenneth Bilby. (Harper & Row, $20.95.) Kenneth Bilby, a former vice president for corporate affairs at RCA Corporation, wrote ''The General'' to remind readers that some business heroes once willingly sacrificed short-term profits to achieve far-reaching visions.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: AN EXCHANGE of branches by Midlantic Banks Inc. of Edison and the Security Savings and Loan Association of Vineland is expected to be completed during the first quarter of next year.

title: Less Food Aid For the Homeless
description: The food-stamp benefits of homeless families living in hotels have been reduced by more than half because of Federal insistence that the money paid to hotel owners be counted as income to the families, city officials said last week.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: THE DEMING MANAGEMENT METHOD. By Mary Walton. (Dodd, Mead, Cloth, $19.95. Gamut, Paper, $9.95.) W. Edwards Deming, who was born in 1900, could never convince American business to adopt his management philosophy, which appears to consist of a statistical analysis of quality coupled with democratization of the workplace.

title: Blow for Kentucky
description: WINSTON BENNETT, a University of Kentucky forward and the leading returning scorer for the Wildcats, underwent reconstructive surgery on his right knee yesterday and will miss the 1986-87 season. ''We're all disappointed,'' Coach Eddie Sutton told reporters.''

title: 9 Are Reported Killed In Clashes in Lebanon
description: At least 9 people were killed and 25 wounded today in an escalation of fighting between Shiite Moslem and Palestinian fighters in refugee districts in the south, the police said.

title: Cornelia S. Guest Becomes a Bride
description: Cornelia Schermerhorn Guest, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Spencer-Churchill Guest of New Canaan, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Allan Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian E. Mitchell of Bridgeport, Conn. The Rev. John Wade Payne, a Disciples of Christ minister, and Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church in New York.

title: Miss Schmeelk Weds Joseph Nerich Jr.
description: Virginia Schmeelk, a daughter of Richard Joseph Schmeelk of New York and Lawrence, L.I., and the late Mrs. Schmeelk, was married yesterday to Joseph Thomas Nerich Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nerich of New York. The Rev. Bruce Ritter performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Ignatius Loyola Church in New York.

title: THREATS AND WHIMPERS: THE NEW BUSINESS HEROES
description: ''IACOCCA'' . . . ''A Passion for Excellence'' . . .

title: Now Women Are Buttoning Up in Men's Cardigans
description: LOTS of styles make comebacks, even repeated comebacks. And when they show up again some are more welcome than others. That is certainly the case with one that is now enjoying a warm revival: the man's cardigan sweater.

title: Arms Talks: A Glossary
description: There are many specialized terms in the language of the nuclear arms talks. These are a few of those terms. Ballistic missile. This missile, powered by a rocket engine, travels outside of the atmosphere for part of its flight. Conventional forces. Forces capable of carrying out warfare without the use of nuclear weapons. Also distinguished from insurgency forces. Cruise missile. A low-flying missile that looks like a flying torpedo, it is powered by an air-breathing engine and is armed with either nuclear or nonnuclear warheads. The current generation of cruise missiles, which are subsonic, can be launched from the ground (GLCM's), sea (SLCM's) or air (ALCM's). Re-entry vehicle (RV). The part of a ballistic missile that re-enters the earth's atmosphere carrying the nuclear warhead. Intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). A land-based missile that has a range of more than about 3,400 miles, including the Soviet SS-18 or the American Minuteman. Intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF). Sometimes called theater nuclear forces (TNF). Missiles and aircraft with a range of less than 3,400 miles, including the Soviet SS-20 and the American Pershing 2 and ground-launched cruise missile. Intermediate-range bombers include the Soviet Backfire bomber - which is included in the American Geneva proposal as a strategic bomber - and the American B-111 bomber. Multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicle (MIRV). One of several re-entry vehicles carried by a single ballistic missile that can be directed at separate targets. Missiles with MIRV's employ a dispensing mechanism, called a post-boost vehicle, with devices that direct the re-entry vehicles and their warheads to the various target points.

title: FACT, FICTION AND SMITHTOWN'S CLASS OF 1957
description: WHEN Vic Holyfield heard that Smithtown High School, his alma mater, was going to be auctioned, he decided to buy it and hold a yearlong 30th reunion there for his class in 1987.

title: Holy Cross Reaches 7-0 Mark
description: Gordon Lochbaum rushed for 77 yards, caught nine passes for 114 yards and had two touchdowns to pace unbeaten Holy Cross to its seventh victory, 22-7 over Brown today.

title: Elis Prove to Be No Match for Quakers
description: Two touchdowns in the third period broke open the game for unbeaten Penn today as the Quakers defeated Yale, 24-6, and continued their dominant role in the Ivy League.

title: Systems for organizing a Personal Photo Archive
description: AS gratifying as it is to take pictures, there's one heavy price to be paid: you have to put them somewhere. And after you put them somewhere, you have to be able to find them again. For those of us with an aversion to sorting, filing, cataloguing and other tasks best left to a librarian, organizing an archive of our photographs is as much fun as a trip to the dentist.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LOVE FOR 3 ORANGES'
description: MAURICE SENDAK'S illustrative vision is bountiful and childlike, yet rarely without an element of primal discomfort. The innocent and the cruel, the simple and the convoluted, the pastoral and the nightmare are inextricably intertwined, and the results are something akin to what Henri Rousseau might have produced under the influence of LSD.

title:
ART;
AN ARTIST'S EYE BEHIND THE LENS
description: A SURE, confident eye and a sense of perfection are unmistakably present in ''Leslie Gill: A Classical Approach to Photography, 1935-1958.''

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;
Not As Easy as It Sounds
description: THE ECONOMIC EMERGENCE OF WOMEN By Barbara R. Bergmann. 372 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95. MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS Women and Men in Dual-Career Marriages. By Rosanna Hertz. 245 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $18.95. SUCCESS AND BETRAYAL The Crisis of Women in Corporate America. By Sarah Hardesty and Nehama Jacobs. 464 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $18.95.

title: Tolkien's Tale of Hobbits Set for Shubert
description: In J. R. R. Tolkien's 500,000-word trilogy, ''The Lord of the Rings,'' the struggle between good and evil winds up with the War of the Ring. On the outcome hangs the fate of the world.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: HOW TO BE A MOGUL: For Those Who Know the Best Things in Life Are Things. By Diane Hartford, Lynn Phillips, Milo Steale and Rusty Unger.

title: TOLKIEN'S TALE OF HOBBITS SET FOR SHUBERT
description: IN J. R. R. Tolkien's 500,000-word trilogy, ''The Lord of the Rings,'' the struggle between good and evil winds up with the War of the Ring. On the outcome hangs the fate of the world.

title: MARION'S SECRET FUDGE WAS A TRADITION
description: EVERY Halloween for the last 15 years of her life, my friend Marion made old-fashioned chocolate fudge, and children and their parents came from all over our town to knock at her door.

title: IMMIGRATION IS DISCUSSED AT A SEMINAR
description: In the marble and tapestried grandeur of the Trustees Room at the New York Public Library, a group of academics clapped to the beat of ''Fifty-Fifty,'' Joseph Rumshinsky's 1916 Yiddish tune about a workers' plan to share their toil with management.

title: Music
description: This is a good week for concerts. In fact it's an unusually good day for concerts: A decent week's worth of events, for programming, personnel or both, are scheduled Sunday alone. Alicia de Larrocha's 8 P.M. recital at Avery Fisher Hall will probably not be up for grabs at the box office, but it might be worth hanging around Lincoln Center to see whether returned tickets or stage seats are available, since she's scheduled to play one of her most special specialties: Albeniz' ''Iberia.'' If anyone on the planet does it better, a major light is being hid under a bushel somewhere.

title: LETTER TO GORBACHEV
description: And where do you fly to, Russia? Answer me! . . . She doesn't answer. The carriage bells break into an enchanted tinkling, the air is torn to shreds and turns into wind; everything on earth flashes past, and, casting worried, sidelong glances, other nations and countries step out of her way. - NIKOLAI GOGOL, ''DEAD SOULS,'' 1842, TRANSLATED BY ANDREW R. MACANDREW.

title: 'The Nazi Doctors'
description: To the Editor:

title: Buy a Lamp, Get a 'Society' for Free
description: FOR about a year, Arnold Jaffe has been showing up each week at the outdoor flea market at 76th Street and Columbus Avenue with a collection of old books, farm tools, glass trinkets and other items he gleaned from his attic or from country garage sales. ''I can make anywhere from $100 to $3,000 in a day,'' he says.

title: Winning A Few
description: SECOND TO NONE American Companies in Japan. By Robert C. Christopher. 258 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $16.95.

title: The Folly of a Domed Stadium in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: Palmer Gains 187 But Syracuse Wins
description: Paul Palmer, the nation's leading rusher in Division I-A, carried the ball 39 more times today and ran for 187 more yards, giving the Temple running back 775 yards in his last three games, something no other runner has accomplished over such a span.

title: SUDDENLY, IT'S OPEN SEASON ON PUBLIC SERVANTS
description: WHILE New York City is being staggered almost daily, it seems, by new allegations of bribes or shakedowns by prominent political figures, such cities as Philadelphia, Boston and Chicago are also watching scandals unfold.

title: Environmentalists Turn Over New Leaf, Sort Of
description: The environmental lobby has emerged from the 99th Congress with what many say is an enhanced reputation for accommodation and professionalism.

title: Knicks Win; Nets Lose
description: The Knicks gave a preview last night of what it would be like if Bill Cartwright can stay healthy and play alongside a healthy Patrick Ewing. The two 7-footers completely dominated the Warrior big-man tandem of Joe Barry Carroll and Chris Washburn as the Knicks defeated Golden State, 114-108, in the second game of an exhibition doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Wendy Millman Becomes a Bride
description: Wendy Beth Millman, the daughter of Muriel L. Laverson of Haddonfield, N.J., and Dr. Julian D. Millman of Penn Valley, Pa., was married yesterday to Jason Matthew Franklin, the son of William B. Franklin of New York and the late Lillian Franklin. Rabbi Max Hausen performed the ceremony at the College of Physicians of Philadephia, a professional organization.

title: STRETCHING BOUNDARIES: THE MERLIN OF LA MAMA
description: For those who know La Mama and its guardian spirit, Ellen Stewart, the theater represents a haven for experimentation, wild triumphs and terrifying mistakes. For those who've never heard of the place, I like to explain La Mama as the Marx Brothers version of the United Nations, where Tibetan monks are encouraged to learn to belly dance and American playwrights are bullied to abandon their fraught obsessions with Western narcissism. At La Mama we learn to move our rib cages in five different directions, chant three pitches at the same time, and make masks out of wet mud. La Mama is, and has been for a quarter century, passionately dedicated to global exchange.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Knicks And Nets Need?
description: Under the Hubie Brown regime, the Knicks have always had a superb defense. Hubie's teams are invariably well-conditioned and driven to exert full-court pressure against their opponents. Offensively however, Hubie's teams exhibit a lack of imagination and are not oriented towards total team play. The Knicks need help in two areas as follows: 1. Redesign the offense so that all players are in a position to get a high percentage shot. 2. Acquire one or two guards with complete offensive games so as to reduce the double- and triple-teaming that hampers the play of all Knick big men with the exception of a healthy Bernard King. RALPH SCHEFFLAN New York

title: Shawn Sparks Marries Bruce William Bolger
description: Laura Shawn Sparks, the daughter of Mrs. Frank Holloway of Redding, Conn., and Herschel Sparks of Miami, was married yesterday to Bruce William Bolger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bolger of New York. Bishop Alexander Doig Stewart and the Rev. Frederick Bender performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Dr. Judith Smith, David E. Fairbank To Marry in May
description: Dr. Judith Wilson Smith and David Ezekiel Fairbank plan to be married in May, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James W. Smith of Greenwich, Conn., have announced. Mr. Fairbank is a son of the late Kellogg Fairbank and the late June W. Taylor and a stepson of Dr. John W. Taylor of Chicago.

title: TRIAL TO OPEN IN '81 SLAYING OF JERSEY TROOPER
description: Two self-styled revolutionaries, who became the target of the most intense state police manhunt in New Jersey since the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son in 1932, are going on trial here in the 1981 slaying of a state trooper.

title: Planning Waterside Town Houses
description: JUST off the Raritan Bay waterfront in the Princes Bay section of Staten Island, a town-house development called Captain's Quarters is beginning, as construction people say, to ''come out of the ground.''

title: HOLMES FANS GROW MORE DEVOTED
description: IN the 60 stories he wrote about Sherlock Holmes, Arthur Conan Doyle never mentioned a cape, a deerstalker hat or a curved pipe, Harold Niver told an audience recently at the Waterford Public Library.

title: MEET DOCTR SPIN
description: ''Spin doctors'' are the hot new item in 1986 politics, though they have long been with us under other pseudonyms. However called, they ''put the right spin on the ball'' in 1968, when they saw light at the end of the tunnel in Vietnam; and in whatever guise, they were setting up the hitters in 1981 with the message that taxes could be cut, military expenditures raised and the budget balanced nevertheless.

title: NOTHING'S MORE FUN THAN BUYING BOOKS
description: NOTHING makes me happier than buying books. Being able to, without stopping to ask myself: ''Can you afford this luxury?'' I recall the Chinese proverb that advised the possessor of one loaf of bread to sell half and buy himself a hyacinth. And I know what I must do.

title: Taking It Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: MINNIE THINKS THE WORLD OF MANNY
description: THE GRANDMOTHERS' CLUB by Alan Cheuse. 326 pp. Salt Lake City, Utah: Gibbs M. Smith/ Peregrine Smith Books. $18.95.

title: G.M. and I.B.M. Exit from South Africa
description: G.M. and I.B.M. will pull out of South Africa. And there were hints that Honeywell and Warner Communications would sell off their South African holdings as well. The companies, which acknowledge that they are bowing to pressure from apartheid foes, say the operations contribute only a fraction of their earnings. And in some instances, they are trying to negotiate terms that would let them return to South Africa if the political and economic atmosphere improves.

title: AUTUMN'S APPEAL: MORE THAN LEAVES
description: IN late October, the Connecticut landscape takes on a somber hue and the frenetic pace of early autumn slackens.

title:
THE REGION;
Judge Indicted, Former City Aide Investigated
description: The ripples of New York City corruption investigations lapped at some new doorsteps last week.

title: Triumph of Arches
description: McDONALD'S Behind the Arches. By John F. Love. Illustrated. 470 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: NASTY STING LIVES ON IN MEMORY
description: AS I bent over to stake up a late-blooming gladiolus, I was startled by yellow jackets rushing past my side. I stepped back and followed their flight to an abandoned mouse hole directly in front of the porch.

title: NEW EXHIBITION ILLUMINATES THE GREATNESS THAT WAS MATISSE
description: It was in March 1913 that the understanding of Henri Matisse in the United States was furthered by a long interview that ran in these pages. Though the object at that time of considerable derision - his ''Blue Nude'' was about to be burned in effigy by the students of the Art Institute of Chicago -Matisse had had the patience, and was given the space, to present himself not as a wild animal in human shape but as a professorial paterfamilias whose ''unaffected cordiality'' put the interviewer at her ease.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Disinvestment II?

title: POETS PUT THEIR VERSE ON VIDEO
description: ''IF you say poetry is coming up, people will leave the room and go make a sandwich,'' said Morgan Baylog Finn of Newtown.

title: A Singer Whose Personal Life Comes First
description: It is not an unfamiliar story: American singer goes to Europe, makes good, comes home to debut in a meaty role at the Metropolitan Opera. In the case of Barbara Hendricks, however, there are a few unusual twists. Miss Hendricks, who will sing Sophie in ''Der Rosenkavalier'' at the Met on Thursday, did not forsake America for the sake of her career. Indeed, her career had started out nicely in the United States when she decided, in 1977, to move to Paris for love. Her friends, she says, tried to discourage her, warning that her career would collapse. ''They have orchestras over there, don't they?'' she says she replied.

title: WESTPORT FOR TRUCK CHECKS, BUT NOT THERE
description: TROOPERS at a weigh station that had been temporarily set up last month in Westbrook on the John Davis Lodge Turnpike checked a tank truck loaded with acid, and found they had a potentially explosive situation on their hands, State Police Sgt. Daniel Lewis recalled.

title: TERESA CERRUTTI CAN TAKE IT
description: CELEBRATION By Mary Lee Settle. 356 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: MUSIC: FROM INDIA, NORTH AND SOUTH
description: FRIDAY evening's concert of Indian music at Town Hall had promised to be a remarkable event. It didn't turn out to be quite that, but it had its moments, and the possible reasons for disappointment were interesting in themselves.

title: Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek Returns to Taiwan
description: Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, widow of the late Nationalist Chinese president, returned to Taiwan on today for her first visit since she left for the United States in 1975 after her husband's death.

title: SOME ANNOTATED IDEAS FOR PRESERVING
description: ARIS BOOKS, a Berkeley, Calif., publisher that has produced a number of elegant cookbooks recently, has just released ''Fine Preserving,'' M. F. K. Fisher's annotated edition of Catherine Plagemann's cookbook ($9.95 paper, $17.95 cloth). The timing could not have been better.

title: Cost of Convention Center For Philadelphia Increases
description: The estimated cost of building Philadelphia's proposed convention center here has risen to $466 million, city development officials say.

title: Parkchester
description: METROPOLITAN OVAL is the communal, esthetic and geographic center of Parkchester in the Bronx, one of the country's largest planned neighborhoods. It is where elderly residents gather to chat, admire the plantings or gaze at water gushing out of bronze fountains in a cement pond.

title: LEAVING SOUTH AFRICA INCREASINGLY ALONE WITH ITS TROUBLES
description: THE advertisements on the state radio seem designed to reassure and register, perhaps, a little defiance. Sanctions or no sanctions, one says, South African Airways will get you to the United States. Along Johannesburg streets, newspaper billboards reflect the same news of economic punishment. ''Disinvestment: more to follow?'' was a headline in Business Day, a financial newspaper.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is taking a second look at alternatives to its proposal to dilute and dump radium-contaminated soil, now in Montclair, at a quarry in Vernon Township, Sussex County.

title: Mexico Said to Grow More Drugs
description: How to contain the torrent of drugs flowing into the United States from Mexico has become the most divisive issue between the two countries. Last week, more bitterness was in prospect.

title: Linda Susan Pelehach Is Wed to Glenn Notice
description: At Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I., yesterday, Linda Susan Pelehach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Pelehach of Centerport and Weston, Vt., was married to Glenn Scott Notice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Notice of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The ceremony was performed by Msgr.

title: Truffaut's 'Woman' and Rockabilly From Perkins
description: La Cenerentola By Gioachino Rossini. Glyndebourne Festival Opera. Conducted by Donato Renzetti. 1983. HBO/Cannon Video. 152 minutes. $39.95.

title: Shedding Some (TV) Light on Officiating
description: THE trouble with sports officials is that they just don't care who wins. What they do care about is competence and integrity in uniformly applying the rules with complete objectivity. This is especially true with professional arbiters.

title: Peruvian Army Kills 39 Rebels in Skirmishes
description: Army patrols killed 39 Shining Path guerrillas last week, including an insurgent considered a top leader of the Maoist group, the state-run Andina news agency reported today.

title: What Can Break Apartheid?
description: Racial segregation in South Africa has long rested on two assumptions: that apartheid is consistent with divine purposes and that it makes good business sense. Events of the last week undermine both beliefs. The Dutch Reformed Church, the largest Afrikaner denomination, has reversed itself after years and now says that apartheid is un-Christian. Four big American corporations now are pulling out because their presence in South Africa is bad for business. The cracks are visible from the outside. Does Pretoria see them?

title: Why Governments 'Got Out of Hand'
description: Earlier this month, James M. Buchanan was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, primarily for his work in developing ''public choice theory,'' which has provided the intellectual underpinnings of the property tax revolt and the balanced-budget movement. In the following, excerpted from a 1979 article, Mr. Buchanan explains the public choice analysis of how representative democracy and government bureaucracy have distorted economic policy and, in the process, created a constitutional crisis in the industrialized democracies.

title: Authentic Verdi Sopranos Are In Short Supply
description: In the space of three evenings not long ago I had the strange experience of hearing two authentic Verdi sopranos. I say strange because, next to the virtually extinct species known as the Wagnerian soprano, the Verdian variety is the most elusive of operatic creatures. Not that Verdi sopranos ever roamed the earth in enormous numbers, like the bison, but within the memory of living hunters fairly sizable herds of these formidable females could be encountered. Fortunately, the thrilling cries of some of the most impressive specimens were captured on recordings and can be studied by students of vocal fauna.

title: NAVY DECLINES TO RECOVER BODIES IN '48 CRASH
description: Thirty-eight years after his brother and eight others died in the crash of a Navy bomber, Raymond H. Swentek has experienced another setback in his efforts to have the crew's remains returned to the United States for a military burial.

title: Apres Opera
description: Americans love their desserts. Too much to give them up, despite story after story about dramatic changes in this country's eating habits. Beef has been replaced by chicken and fish; cream and butter-rich sauces by vegetable purees. But careful examination of all these stories reveals not a single serious word about the demise of decadent fudge tortes, creamy fruit mousses or rich cheesecakes.

title: TREASURES OF SANDBOX ARCHEOLOGY
description: ''HERE'S an arrowhead!''

title: Rangers Finish Tied in Overtime
description: When they last convened here, it was at the height of drama, with everything at stake. When the Rangers and Canadiens met tonight, they were still toying with new line formations, still working out the clinks that a new season brings, and yet they managed to create tension anyway.

title: From Curmudgeon to Scholarly Giant
description: LAST week's announcement that James M. Buchanan had won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science came as no great surprise to most North American economists. It was just a matter of time. Evidently, it caught the winner a little off-guard, since he remarked at a news conference that he had been passed over in years gone by and he had figured that was that. And it seems to have struck a sour chord with a few economists, who think the Nobel Committee's past decisions were sounder than that of Oct. 17.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: RISK, RUIN & RICHES: Inside the World of Big Time Real Estate. By Jim Powell. (Macmillan, $22.50.) ''Risk, Ruin & Riches: Inside the World of Big Time Real Estate'' lets us experience the roller-coaster life of the men (this industry has almost no women) who have turned our cities into towers of granite and glass and converted our suburbs into climate-controlled shopping experiences.

title: Last Call to Plant Hardy Bulbs for Spring Bloom
description: Scurry, that's the word for gardeners now. There is still time to plant bulbs, but your days are numbered.

title: Cheers Float After Parachute
description: For some, it was too much to believe that the Mets could be amazing again. As jubilant cheering erupted all around her last night, Nancy Cross sat in the stands at Shea Stadium, savored the Mets' 6-5 victory over the Red Sox, and cried. ''Because I'm happy,'' said the 26-year-old computer manager.

title: Ohio State Routs Minnesota By 33-0
description: A freshman tailback, Jim Bryant, had two touchdowns as Ohio State stretched its winning streak to six with a 33-0 victory over Minnesota in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: TRIAL IN NICARAGUA IS SET TO PROCEED
description: After four days of pretrial maneuvering, a Sandinista political tribunal is now expected to spend the next 8 to 12 days judging the case against the American captured from a downed rebel plane.

title: TOCCI, PERONE CONTRAST RECORDS
description: THE race for Assembly in the 85th District centers on the question of who is more effective on the job: John M. Perone, a Republican who served for six years until last year, or Ronald C. Tocci, the Democrat who succeeded him.

title: Libya Bars British Planes
description: Libya announced tonight that it was closing its airspace to British aircraft in support of Syria's breaking of relations with London.

title: Mixed Reviews
description: The last major economic reports before Election Day produced, not surprisingly, sharply partisan assessments. The President in his weekly radio address yesterday and spokesmen for the Administration, which has been predicting a growth rate of 4 percent this year, hailed the third quarter's annualized 2.4 percent growth rate as a sign of expansion ahead under Republican policies; Democrats called the July-to-September report anemic.

title: National Postage Show Will Open In New York
description: The National Postage Stamp Show moves to a new location this week when it opens Thursday and continues through Sunday in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street in New York City. The show will have 160 dealers, government agencies and societies. Its sponsor, the American Stamp Dealers' Association (ASDA) selected a site that meets the needs of these varied interest groups, while still operating within its own budgetary constraints.

title: BRITAIN BREAKS ITS TIES TO SYRIA, CITING TERRORISM
description: LARGELY out of concern for the safety of hostages thought to be in Syrian-controlled eastern Lebanon, most Western countries have been reluctant to accuse Syria of sponsoring terrorists. That judgment shifted last week after a jury in London convicted a Jordanian of hiding a bomb in the hand luggage of his pregnant Irish lover as she prepared to board an Israeli airliner at Heathrow.

title: Tentative Accord Is Reached In Temple University Strike
description: Temple University and striking professors agreed on a tentative contract Friday, negotiators said, ending a 19-day walkout that had canceled most classes for 22,000 students.

title: Imperial C.E.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder On Long Island
description: The incest situation described in Dena Kleiman's article ''Murder On Long Island'' (Sept. 14) is classic -the invalid mother who later dies (leaving the husband sexually frustrated), the daughter taking over the household duties, the resentment of the father, taking care of the children alone (leading to a feeling of entitlement), the fear for the younger sister, the daughter's anguish (conflicting feelings for the father, trying to hold the family together) and suspicions not followed up on by others. Clearly, the girl is the victim - the betrayal by her father, the loss of her mother, no one to protect her, disbelief all around her, and, in this case, complicity in murder.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Pierre Boulez Shows A Flair For the Second Viennese School
description: ''Boulez is Back,'' screamed the posters in New York this past March, when Pierre Boulez returned for a mini-festival that included concerts with the New York Philharmonic, performances by his Ensemble InterContemporain, and the premiere of his ''Repons.'' Yet, far removed from the glare of public scrutiny, an equally important project has been progressing almost entirely unnoticed by the media. For a number of years, Mr. Boulez has been recording the music of Schoenberg, Berg, and Webern for CBS Masterworks, a project that has proved significant in several respects. Not only have Mr. Boulez's recent recordings amounted to a welcome reinterpretation of the works of the Second Viennese School, but they indicate a maturation of his own musical vision.

title: IN PURSUIT OF THE PERFECT PUMPKIN
description: FOR many of us, our first encounter with the Cucurbitaceae cucurbita was in a nursery rhyme. Of course, the author was insightful enough to make Peter a pumpkin-eater, rather than an eater of something dreadfully hard to remember.

title: Iberian Leaders Meet
description: The Prime Ministers of Portugal and Spain today discussed ways of improving commercial and political ties to put relations between their countries on a new footing within the European Community. The talks in Guimarais, in northern Portugal, were the first formal meeting between Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal and Felipe Gonzalez of Spain since their nations joined the Community in January.

title: WHAT ALIEN LAW WILL MEAN: SOME QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: The passage of the landmark immigration bill has created confusion and apprehension among illegal aliens and among employers, who for the first time will have to check the citizenship status of all new workers.

title: 'The Jeweler's Eye' Reflects a Passion for Collection
description: In 1968, Gilbert and Nancy Levine purchased a Victorian gold bracelet, awash with scenes of an Assyrian lion hunt. That acquisition sparked a passion for collecting that soon encompassed the entire 19th century, as can be seen in ''The Jeweler's Eye,'' an exhibition of their holdings on view at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers through Jan. 4.

title: FOR SALE: STERLING FOREST'S 19,990 ACRES
description: IN its current atlas of Orange County, N.Y., the Hagstrom Map Company has colored the 19,990 acres of Sterling Forest a parkland green, the same shade used for nearby Palisades Interstate Park and Abraham S. Hewitt State Forest.

title: BLACK HORSEWOMEN FIND FUN IN CLUB
description: AS a child growing up in the North End of Hartford, Pat Lawson would spend hours watching movies starring the cowboy actor Roy Rogers. ''I was fascinated by Roy Rogers and I loved his horse, Trigger,'' Ms. Lawson said.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
An In-Depth Look at America's Coinage
description: The third annual Coinage of the Americas Conference will take place next weekend at the American Numismatic Society, Broadway and 155th Street. The theme will be ''America's Silver Coinage, 1794-1891.'' This year's conference will provide an in-depth look at a single major segment of American numismatics.

title: DANCERS RESIST PAPP PLAN
description: Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, offered Friday to join the campaign to convert a building at 890 Broadway to a nonprofit arts center in order to preserve theater rehearsal facilities and an Off Broadway theater there, but his proposal garnered a cool response from three dance companies with their own plans for the property.

title: Gedman's Hallmark: A Diligent Confidence
description: The scene had been played out before - 11 times, to be precise, since the regular season ended - and Rich Gedman, the Boston Red Sox catcher, was almost getting comfortable at it, bracing himself for another news-media crush of lights, cameras and action.

title: Sarah Hovey Nutt Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Hovey Nutt, the director of market analysis for CBS-TV, was married yesterday to Thomas Melton Van Leeuwen, a vice president in the equity research department of E. F. Hutton & Company in New York. The Rev. John H. Walsted performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in West Brighton, S.I.

title: REAGAN IS QUOTED BY SOVIET ON END OF ALL ATOM ARMS
description: The Soviet Union took an unusual step today by quoting from statements attributed to President Reagan at the Iceland meeting to show that American versions did not correctly reflect his confidential talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: STAMFORD CENTER'S COLLECTION OFFERS MORE THAN JUST NATURE
description: THE Stamford Museum and Nature Center is well known for its temporary exhibitions of art and a collection of animals as permanent as nature will allow. That it also has a permanent collection of paintings and sculpture will take most of its habitues by surprise. But the proof is in ''Treasures From the Past . . . Promises for the Future,'' a sampling of the art acquired since 1955.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE Z PARTICLE
description: JUST AFTER DAWN, A MAN IN his mid-50's rides a wobbly moped through the Santa Clara Valley in California. The countryside is green and jagged, packed with tilted meadows on sharp little hills, a land of horse farms and lush pasture. Cutting straight as a rifle shot from west to east across the valley is a low, hangarlike structure 16 feet tall, 35 feet wide and some two miles long. The building is the above-ground portion of the Stanford Linear Accelerator; the man parking his moped nearby is its director, Burton Richter.

title: Williams Surveys Straw
description: FROM the time Darryl Strawberry signed with the Mets, he's been touted as ''the black Ted Williams,'' an unfair burden for any young player. The young Henry Aaron was never known as the black Babe Ruth, the younger Dwight Gooden was never known as the black Bob Feller. And as the World Series returned to Shea Stadium last night, Darryl Strawberry had been as perplexing as ever.

title: Imperial C.E.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston;
Hispanic Mall Fights Failure
description: WHEN El Mercado del Sol opened 17 months ago on the poor, Hispanic east side of town with the help of the city's first investment in a private development, it was billed as the centerpiece of what could be a major effort to revitalize a deteriorating neighborhood.

title: SOME MEASURE THE NATION'S PROGRESS BY WHAT IS NOT BUILT
description: DURING the Civil War, the Washington and Old Dominion Railroad carried Union and Confederate troops back and forth from the Shenandoah Valley to the Potomac River. The right of way now serves a distinctly different purpose. Running through the middle of one of the more rapidly growing areas of the country, it has become what is known as a ''linear'' park, used by more than a million people a year for biking, hiking, jogging and picnicking.

title: U.S. AID APPROVED TO RESTORE NEW YORK BEACHES
description: Shrinking beaches at Coney Island and other stretches of the nearby shoreline will nearly double in size as a result of legislation passed in the closing hours of the 99th Congress, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday.

title: Giants' Anderson Learning A Blocking Role
description: Ottis Anderson searched for the word.

title: Penn State Routs Alabama to Go 7-0
description: Often maligned for its easy schedule during the first half of the season, Penn State gained a large measure of new respect today when it upset previously undefeated Alabama, 23-3.

title: Pension Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: Marine Chief on Excess Costs
description: The Commandant of the Marine Corps has said that people who report excess costs or questionable payments for military equipment should be promoted, not censured, according to a spokesman for the corps.

title: Sarah Allan Married To Michael Rufkahr
description: Sarah Sledge Allan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Nance Allan of Chicago, was married yesterday to Michael Rufkahr, a son of Mary Rufkahr and Clifford N. Rufkahr, both of St. Louis. The Very Rev. Charles Greene, dean of the St. James Episcopal Cathedral in Chicago, performed the ceremony at the Fortnightly Club in Chicago.

title: Federal Licensing
description: A favored tactic of legislators who support marginal measures is to piggyback them on bills that are sure to pass. In the closing days of the 99th Congress, one such certainty was the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986.

title: HEATED CONTEST UNFOLDS TO REPLACE FLYNN IN ALBANY
description: IN a hard-fought campaign for the 35th State Senate District seat, Andrew Macdonald, a Democrat, and his opponent, the Republican Assemblyman Nicholas A. Spano, are focusing on each other's records and debating about their ability to deliver programs and state financial aid to the district.

title: DOUBLE-HOCKED COLLATERAL LATERALS
description: THE LEAGUE The Rise and Decline of the NFL. By David Harris. Illustrated. 710 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: Hugh Merrow
description: It was only for a moment that Merrow failed to place them, aware as he was, as soon as they were introduced, of having already seen them. That was all they at first showed, except that they were shy, agitated, almost frightened: they had been present to him, and within a few days, though unwittingly, in some connection that had made them interesting. He had recovered the connection even before the lady spoke - spoke, he could see, out of the depths of their diffidence, and making the effort, he could also see, that the woman, in the delicate case, is always left by the man to make. ''We admire so very much your portrait at the Academy - the one of the beautiful little boy. We've had no one to introduce us to you, but we thought you'd perhaps just let us call. We've - a -been wondering. We were so struck.''

title: HARVEST IS IN AT CENTURIES-OLD DISTILLERY
description: AS it has for more than 200 years, the autumn apple harvest is pouring into the storage bins and vats of a distillery here that has been owned and operated by the same family since Colonial days.

title: Rwanda Jails 300 in Sects
description: Rwanda's state security court has sentenced about 300 Jehovah's Witnesses and members of other unauthorized religious sects to prison terms ranging from 11 months to 12 years, judicial sources said today. The defendants, who include women and children, were found guilty on Friday of ''inciting the population to rebel against the established powers and disobey the laws, holding prohibited public meetings and dishonoring the Rwandan flag and other symbols of sovereignty'' in the former Belgian colony in central Africa.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GRIEF
description: TWO widows are talking. They sit face to face, but often, their conversations take place on the phone. The words they are saying now, in fact, are similar to the many words that have floated between them through the telephone wires:

title: SOUTH AFRICA CHURCH EASES STAND
description: South Africa's white Dutch Reformed Church, the body that formulated scriptural justification for apartheid, has edged away from its previous stance, saying theological rationales for enforced racial separation were an error that should now be rejected.

title: THE DANCE: CHUN TROUPE
description: MYUNG SOOK CHUN boldly tried to make her choreography express metaphysical concepts in the two works that the Myung Sook Chun Contemporary Dance Company presented Thursday night at the Triplex Theater of Manhattan Community College.

title: ELI WHITNEY MUSEUM IS MAKING STRIDES
description: Would you please correct some misleading statements in your article ''Whitney Museum the Target of Takeover Study'' [ Oct. 5 ] .

title: Knight's Impossible Dream
description: ''If you've got grit,'' Will Knight once told his grandson, Ray, ''anything is possible.''

title: WHERE ART AND NATURE MEET
description: At the Guggenheim Museum, the artist Richard Long placed chunks of chalk in a perfect circle on the floor, laid out slabs of slate in a path that followed the gentle curve of the museum's ramp, and, on a pristine wall, painted a circle of mud with his bare hands.

title: TEXTBOOK PUBLISHERS ARE UNDER ASSAULT ON SEVERAL FRONTS
description: WHILE Christian conservatives in Alabama led the assault on ''secular humanism'' in a Federal court case seeking to remove offending books from the public schools, a Federal district judge in Tennessee held last week that a group of fundamentalist parents could at least keep their children out of reading classes.

title: LACK OF UNDERSTANDING FOR GROUP HOMES
description: In her thoughtful article, ''The Truth About Group Homes for the Retarded'' [ Opinion Page, Sept. 28 ] , Mary Minturn put her finger on the difficulties facing those seeking to establish suitable accommodations for mentally handicapped people. Such citizens may not be capable of living on their own, but they are not abnormally disturbed.

title: IN FRANCE'S SECOND CITY
description: If you ask a resident of Lyons, a city of gentle colors and good food, for his comment on Paris, the slightly rueful, good-humored reply might well be, ''Oh, Paris, yes, that's a suburb of Lyons two hours away on the high-speed train.''

title: The Electronics of Revenge
description: LESSONS An Autobiography. By An Wang with Eugene Linden. Illustrated. 248 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing. $17.95. MADE IN JAPAN Akio Morita and Sony. By Akio Morita with Edwin M. Reingold and Mitsuko Shimomura. Illustrated. 309 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: IN SCARSDALE, BUSY BEEKEEPING OPERATION
description: HONEY is the world's oldest natural sweet. For centuries, bees have provided food for man and have fascinated him with their efficient social organization and artistry. Honey- gathering was known as early as the Stone Age, and Egyptian reliefs from about 2600 B.C. show beekeeping operations that appear to be little different than those practiced today.

title: INCREASES IN CASES OF WHOOPING COUGH REPORTED
description: CASES of whooping cough are increasing in Connecticut, and doctors and nurses are concerned the rise may show that some parents, unfamiliar with the disease or worried about the safety of the vaccine, are not be getting their children immunized promptly.

title:
MUSIC;
STATE OPERA TO OFFER SELDOM SEEN 'ZAZA'
description: LEONCAVALLO'S verismo opera ''Zaza,'' last seen on the East Coast at the Metropolitan Opera in 1922, when the soprano Geraldine Ferrar gave her farewell performance, will open the New Jersey State Opera's 21st season at Newark Symphony Hall next Sunday.

title: Sibling on Lease
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward P. McKenzie Wed To Laura Elizabeth Gamble
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Laura Elizabeth Gamble, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cotter Gamble of Saugatuck, Mich., to Edward Paul McKenzie, a son of Katherine C. McKenzie of Point Pleasant, N.J., and the late Edward J. McKenzie. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony.

title: DOCTORS ARE STUDYING ETHICS
description: IN February, second-year students at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine will find themselves in a new course called ''Communications Skills,'' which focuses on the relationship between doctor and patient. At the University of Miami, first-year medical students in the ''Health and Human Values'' course visit community service agencies and chronically ill patients. At the University of California at San Francisco, students serve as the jury while a judge and a lawyer recreate a malpractice trial in a course called ''Responsibilities of Medical Practice.''

title: Having Civilians Review the Police
description: On May 20, 1965, in the first major speech of his successful mayoral campaign, Representative John V. Lindsay proposed adding four civilian outsiders to the New York City Police Department's three-member board for reviewing complaints of police brutality and discourtesy. ''It is time for a change,'' he said.

title: Stephanie Anne Sava, Writer, Marries Michael Boeschenstein in Connecticut
description: Stephanie Anne Sava, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerard Anthony Sava of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Moll Boeschenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wade Boeschenstein of Perrysburg, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Amato, assisted by the Rev. Rufin Kuveikis, at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena in Riverside, Conn.

title: Scenes From Teams' Perplexing Path
description: Expectations were so high as the World Series began that it could hardly go anywhere but down. At least at first.

title: Sandra Salmans Wed to Peter Phillips
description: Sandra Salmans, a reporter for The New York Times, and Peter C. Phillips, an assistant professor of neurology at Johns Hopkins University, were married yesterday. The Rev. Scott Matheney, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, from which the bride received a master's degree in journalism.

title: Ms. Way Married to Frank T. Judge 3d
description: Carolyn Way, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kendall Sherman Way of Richmond, Mass., was married yesterday to Frank T. Judge 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Judge Jr. of Grosse Pointe Park, Mich. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Kyte, a United Church of Christ minister, and the Rev. William Cunningham, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church on the Hill in Lenox, Mass.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The non-recession team scored a touchdown.'' - Robert Barbera, chief economist at E.F. Hutton, on the series of economic indicators.

title: The Buck Starts Here
description: LEADERSHIP AT THE FED By Donald F. Kettl. Illustrated. 218 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.50.

title: KOREANS ADD TO FLAVOR OF SHOPPING IN EL PASO
description: From the ever-present Border Patrol cars to the the shops selling used clothes, the southern end of downtown El Paso is the ultimate Texas border strip: part Mexico, part Texas, part Texan-Mexican hybrid.

title: DANCE ARTISTS SEEK CITY HELP TO KEEP THEIR SPACE
description: IN August 1985, when the New York School of Ballet on Upper Broadway closed down rather than face escalating rental costs, West Side dance teachers became concerned that they, too, would have to go out of business or find space elsewhere in the not-too-distant future.

title: Lisa B. Friedman Married To Scott B. Schermerhorn
description: Lisa Beth Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Friedman of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Scott B. Schermerhorn, a son of Helen Schermerhorn and Robert Schermerhorn, both of Manchester, Mass. Rabbi Phillip E. Schechter performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club of New York.

title: QUAKER STARS IN A WALL STREET SOAP
description: IF the bizarre takeover battle for the Anderson Clayton Corporation had been a Broadway melodrama, the curtain for the final scene would have gone up on the comfortable, book-lined study at Charles Nathan's Brooklyn town house.

title: A MASTER'S MIND
description: Henry James (1843-1916) is the only American writer whom our well-ingrained democratic literary conventions have encouraged us to call Master. Not even Emerson, the philosopher of individualism who stands as a kind of Muse to all subsequent American culture and society, has been granted that title. It fell to James - this acknowledgment of magisterial illuminations - not simply because of his Balzacian amplitude, although that would have been reason enough. From the oceanic plenitude of James's imagination and genius there rode out, with the aristocratic majesty of great seagoing ships, a succession of novels (20 of these), short stories (112, some, by contemporary standards, the size of novels), biographies and autobiographies, critical and social essays (ranging from a book-length vision of Hawthorne to the 1905 Bryn Mawr College commencement speech), travel and museum impressions, a dozen plays, innumerable literary notebooks, and dazzling letters bearing both difficult truths and what James himself termed ''the mere twaddle of graciousness.''

title: The Spotlight's Harsh Glare
description: There always was a glare at the end of the baseball season. It just used to be the glare of sunlight. When summer gave way to autumn, and the weeks and months defined levels of performances, the sudden restriction of time would challenge those levels each year.

title: Against the Odds
description: John Litvinchuk, a 19-year-old Brooklyn master, defied the form chart in winning the United States Junior Invitational Championship held at Concordia College in Bronxville, N.Y. Litvinchuk, a Yale sophomore, scored 6 1/2-2 1/2 to outpace a field that had seven players with higher rankings on the International Chess Federation's computer.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: FAMILY PRIDE: Profiles of Five of America's Best-Run Family Businesses. By Thomas Goldwasser. (Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) In ''Family Pride'' Thomas Goldwasser, a business writer, discusses Hallmark Cards, Noxell Corporation (Noxema and Lestoil), Marriott Corporation, H & R Block and S. C. Johnson & Son (Johnson Wax).

title: Data Bank: October 26, 1986
Wedding Planned By Susan Estrich, A Law Professor
description: Susan Estrich, a professor of law at Harvard Law School, and Martin Kaplan, the vice president of motion picture production at Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, Calif., plan to be married Nov. 29. The announcement of their engagment was made by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Louis Kaplan of Swampscott, Mass.

title: Son Held in Mother's Death
description: A Naugatuck man was held on $100,000 bond today, charged in the shooting death of his mother on her 48th birthday, the police said. Police Chief Dennis Clisham said Kenneth Semasko, 27 years old, was to appear in Waterbury Superior Court Monday for arraignment in the death of Noreen Semasko. She was shot once in the chest about 6:30 P.M. Friday.

title: Uganda Kills 65 Rustlers
description: Ugandan troops have killed 65 cattle rustlers in the northeast of the country in the last few weeks, a Government statement said today. The troops battled with rustlers in two incidents near the towns of Soroti and Mbale, the statement added.

title: STUDY RECOMMENDS BRIEF REST FOR BACK PAIN
description: Most people suffering from backache should go back to work as soon as possible, even if they are still feeling some pain, new research suggests.

title: THE WEALTHIEST WOMAN IN AMERICA
description: THE tomatoes were ripening on one of the family farms, so Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf persuaded her sister, Margaret Hunt Hill, and her three brothers, Nelson Bunker, W. Herbert and Lamar, to come out last month for a day of picking. And there they were, five people with a total net worth of at least $3 billion and an age range from 71 (Margaret) to 54 (Lamar), sweating under the blazing Texas sun.

title: VOTES SET ON TOWN LAND PLAN
description: SOUTHAMPTON Town residents will vote Nov. 4 on a referendum that would authorize the town to spend $8 million to purchase land that could soon be developed.

title: REHABILITATION EXPERT WITH A MESSAGE
description: ''HANDICAPPED people have a lot of needs,'' said Jaime Sznajder of Lawrence. ''You can't just give them a prescription.''

title: Punish the Library Criminal
description: Russell Mokhiber, who led an ultimately effective protest against shortened visitors' hours at the Library of Congress earlier this year, has begun serving the sentence he received in District of Columbia Superior Court after a conviction for unlawful entry during a sit-in at the library. Mr. Mokhiber, a lawyer, is performing ''community service'' of 30 hours a month at a local shelter for the homeless. But he is also appealing both the conviction and the sentence, contending that his exercise of civil disobedience in the sit-in was protected by First Amendment guarantees of freedom of expression.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: MONEY: Myths and Realities. By Paul Beland and Isaac Cronin. (Carroll & Graf, $17.95.) In ''Money: Myths and Realities,'' Paul Beland, a historian and sound engineer, and Isaac Cronin, a writer and businessman, allude frequently to the significance of one's ''relationship to money,'' but they do not explain what they mean by it.

title: A Gold Mine in Labels and Cans
description: AS many veteran collectors have discovered, starting -or even maintaining - a potentially profitable collection need not cost a fortune.

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: Westchester; Irvington Routs Dover Plains
description: Irvington won its sixth straight game of the season, trouncing Dover Plains, 45-14.

title: THE WORLD SERIES '86: Baseball Notebook; Yanks Take Aim at Rhoden and Pena
description: AS a hunter, Syd Thrift sets the sights of his shotgun on quail and ducks. As the general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, Thrift has a couple of players, Rick Rhoden and Tony Pena, on whom many clubs have set their sights. Rhoden is a capable starting pitcher who could bring aid and comfort to the ailing pitching staffs of most teams. Pena is a talented, durable catcher who would instantly improve and stabilize the catching position on most teams.

title: Barbara Lawrence Is Wed
description: Barbara Ann Lawrence, the daughter of Mrs. Irving Lawrence of Sands Point, L.I., and the late Mr. Lawrence, was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Allan Bruce Kaiser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kaiser of Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph Potasnick performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel. The bride, who will keep her name, is an associate director of Dunham & Marcus Inc., a marketing consulting concern in New York. Dr. Kaiser is an internist in private practice in Brooklyn.

title: Mr. Meese's Contempt of Court
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese considers respect for the Supreme Court dangerous. Just because the high court interprets the Constitution, he told an audience at Tulane University the other night, that doesn't make its decision a supreme law of the land ''binding on all persons and parts of government, henceforth and forevermore.'' His speech managed to be both obvious and contemptuous of the Court.

title: 4 Lowe Filed Goals Lift Boston COllege
description: Brian Lowe kicked a school-record four field goals and Boston College's defense stopped West Virginia three times inside the 15-yard line today for a 19-10 victory that ended a six-game losing streak against the Mountaineers.

title: MARKING L.I. JEWISH HISTORY
description: SOME 300 major contributors are to gather at the Garden City Hotel on Saturday to mark the official merger of the United Jewish Appeal and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: E. Michael Ward And Miss Ballard Become Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Ballard of Chatham Township and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ann Ballard to E. Michael Ward Jr., the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin M. Ward of Alexandria, Va.

title: Q and A
description: Rents After 421a Expires Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a building whose property taxes are abated under the 421a program. What will be the status of our rent-stabilized apartments after the abatement expires next June? . . . M. S., Manhattan Answer: There are two categories of new residential structures built under the 421a program - those begun before July 3, 1984, and those begun after. Tenants of buildings in the first category are entitled to renewal leases with guideline increases as long as they are in residence; when apartments are vacated, the rent may be raised only by the amount of the vacancy allowance and the apartment remains under rent stabilization. When the tax benefits expire after 10 years, however, the apartments are deregulated upon vacancy and new tenants thereafter may be charged market rents upon arrival.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: LAND OF OPPORTUNITY: The Entrepreneurial Spirit in America. By Donald Lambro. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Donald Lambro, the author of ''Fat City: How Washington Wastes Your Taxes'' and ''Washington - City of Scandals,'' captures the business-loving spirit of the mid-1980's wonderfully, if somewhat inadvertently.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Norfolk, Va.;
Crowded Field Gets a Big Entry
description: WHEN Harvey L. Lindsay Jr. first envisioned an office building overlooking the revitalized harbor here, he was thinking big, not biggest - in the range of perhaps 20 stories. But after his two Dallas partners, Alan T. Gregory and Don V. Averitt, got involved, plans soon shot to 26 stories. ''You know those Texans,'' Mr. Lindsay remarked.

title: FOR NEW YORKERS, IS THERE LIFE AFTER RENT REGULATION?
description: Two-thirds of Americans own their own homes. Two-thirds of New Yorkers rent their living space. Although most of these tenants will never buy a home, they will probably agonize over the decision many, many times.

title: Imperial C.E.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Redemption for a Long-Suffering Region?
description: AS the Red Sox tried to close out the Mets in Shea Stadium last night, a recent visitor to Boston could not help but feel a great surge of sympathy for the Red Sox -not for the players themselves, who are young men without much history, but for the deeper cause, the town and its fans.

title: Norway
description: To the Editor: ''Norway's Civilized Mountain Trails'' (Travel, Sept. 9, 1984) by Mark C. Hansen was a fascinating illustrated report of a fall ''walk'' (Norwegian term) in the country's highest mountains.

title: 3 RUNS IN 10TH INNING COME WITH 2 OUTS FOR 6-5 VICTORY
description: The Mets marched to the brink of losing the World Series last night but saved themselves with a dramatic three-run rally with two outs in the 10th inning that defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-5, and tied the Series at three games apiece.

title: Ms. Licht Plans To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Licht of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alyssa D. Licht to Dr. Jonathan L. Held, a son of Justice and Mrs. Gerald S. Held of Oceanside, L.I.

title: Flip Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: After Dinner
description: The French, who are known to have a way with words, are not quite up to this reputation when it comes to after-dinner drinks. Just when diners are beginning to look forward to a mellow Cognac or a rich Armagnac, the waiter asks: ''Would monsieur and madame care for a digestif?''

title: Susan Kramer Weds William Flora Jr.
description: Susan Ambler Kramer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edmund Kramer of Wilmington, Del., and Long Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to William Blane Flora Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Flora of Naples, Fla. The Rev. J. Fletcher Lowe performed the ceremony at the Immanuel Episcopal Church in Wilmington.

title: GAMES BECOME BIG BUSINESS IN AN L.I. TAKEOVER
description: EIGHT familiar hardwood tiles, snuggled in a familiar wooden rack, sit atop the desk of the president of a Bay Shore company. The letters on the tiles read: R-S-E-L-C-H-O-W.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Inn in Amherst Reopens After Sale

title: Red Sox Lose Grip On Vision
description: There were two outs in the bottom of the 10th inning last night when the Shea Stadium message board in left field briefly flashed a message: ''Congratulations, Red Sox.''

title: TOURIST INDUSTRY LEADERS PLAN SELF-HELP DRIVE IN '87
description: Despite one of the most extensive and costliest promotions ever undertaken by the state, the tourism season in New Jersey this summer was disappointing. As a result, industry leaders already are regrouping, convinced that their 1987 effort must involve self-help.

title: Speaker Cabinets Adjust To the CD Challenge
