description: Like a roving spotlight, the focus of audio activity wanders from one area to another. Only a short time ago, all the creative attention of the industry was concentrated on CD players. Now engineering priorities seem to have shifted to the upgrading of loudspeakers. There's a logic to this. With laser sound emerging as the new norm, speakers must be fortified against its greater demands.

title: A SUPERVISOR SPEAKS OUT
description: HENRIETTA (HENNY) ACAMPORA, 64 years old, is one of the two women who are town supervisors on Long Island (Judith Hope of East Hampton is the other). Mrs. Acampora's strong Brooklyn accent, down-to-earth manner and reputation for ''telling it like it is'' have made her a favorite with constituents in the five years she has been in office.

title: O Ye Windows!
description: To the Editor:

title: IS ENGLISH THE ONLY LANGUAGE FOR GOVERNMENT?
description: ON NOV. 4, California voters will decide whether to make English the state's official language.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRANSIT SERVICE SAID TO FACE MAJOR CUTS IF STATE DOESN'T HELP
description: Some say it is a calculated ploy that smacks of brinksmanship; others say not.

title: G.O.P. GOING NATIONAL WITH REAGAN AS DEMOCRATS TAKE LOCAL APPROACH
description: The final days of the 1986 political campaign have come down to a contest between Republican efforts to focus the race on President Reagan and Democratic efforts to keep the elections local and personalized.

title: BRITISH SAY THEY HEARD SYRIAN ENVOY DISCUSS PLOT
description: British intelligence agents were able to eavesdrop directly on conversations verifying the complicity of the Syrian Ambassador in the plot to bomb an Israeli airliner, Government officials asserted today.

title: JESUITS' DISMANTLING OF 1861 SANCTUARY SPURS ANGER IN BOSTON
description: This month, a group of Jesuit priests had a contractor start tearing up the interior of a church they have owned and operated since it was built 125 years ago. Art historians, organists and local residents are furious.

title: Truffaut's 'Woman' and Rockabilly From Perkins
description: Blue Suede Shoes: A Rockabilly Session with Carl Perkins MCA Home Video 60 minutes. Stereo. $29.95

title: Jeanne K. Gromer Weds T. A. Smith
description: At St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday, Jeanne Katherine Gromer, a member of the class of '87 at New York Medical College, was married to Thomas Anthony Smith, who teaches law at the University of California at Davis. The Rev. Christopher Schiavone performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: FILLING A NICHE IN LITCHFIELD
description: AS one of Connecticut's prettiest towns, Litchfield has long been a tourist magnet.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: TOGETHER OUTDOORS Before the thermometer takes its final seasonal plunge and while the going outdoors is still good, now is the time for family togetherness al fresco. So how about a quick trip to Jones Beach State Park to catch the annual chrysanthemum show? More than 10,000 garden mums in every imaginable hue - and some beyond belief - are currently at their peak bloom and will stay that way, barring frost, through Thanksgiving. The park is open from 8 A.M. to sunset daily, and there's no admission charge these days.

title: STUDY FORECASTS GAINS IN BROOKLYN
description: After a decade of losing jobs and population, Brooklyn saw a slight rise in employment this year that is likely to continue through 1990, according to a study released yesterday.

title: SEASON ENTERS A BUSY TIME
description: WHETHER your musical tastes run to opera, symphony or chamber music, there will be ample opportunity for satisfaction over the next couple of weeks. The coming fortnight, in fact, might turn out to be the busiest of the fall season.

title: POSTINGS: Offices Plus for Riverhead; A Winged Hotel
description: Life in Riverhead, the Suffolk County seat, centers mostly around local politics, farming and fishing.

title: M. J. Kirk Is Wed To Miss Arledge
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Anne Arledge to Michael John Kirk took place yesterday at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Martha H. Hedgepeth performed the ceremony.

title: Bring Up the Big Pop Guns
description: THE REAL COKE, THE REAL STORY By Thomas Oliver. 195 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95. THE OTHER GUY BLINKED How Pepsi Won the Cola Wars. By Roger Enrico and Jesse Kornbluth. 280 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: FOUNDATION SETS $30,000 MANAGEMENT PRIZES
description: Thousands of private organizations that care for children, the elderly or the disadvantaged in New York City are being invited to compete for up to six $5,000 prizes for efficient management.

title:
THE NEW FORMALITY;
The Menus
description: Whether it is a snug winter dinner for four or a holiday extravaganza for 18, Carolyne Roehm throws herself into the spirit of the occasion with unbridled elan. Her inspired approach to orchestrating the menus matches her skill at creating a delightful setting.

title: THE WARP AND WOOF OF A TUSSLE WITH CUSTOMS
description: There is nothing, absolutely nothing, that conspires against one more than to be in the right setting, at the right time. There we were, in the China National Native Produce & Animal By-Products Import & Export Corporation Showroom, Shanghai Animal By-Products Branch, surrounded by stacks of hand-knotted woolen carpets, when my wife said, ''Let's buy a rug.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
IN SERVICE TO HISTORY
description: The Lower Hudson Conference, an umbrella organization of historical agencies and museums in five counties, will present six Historical Services Awards at its yearly meeting Thursday. ''It's the first time in the region that a whole group of awards will be given to museums and historical groups at one time,'' said Ann Kiewel, director of the Elmsford-based organization.

title:
MUSIC;
FESTIVAL TO CELEBRATE AMERICAN MUSIC
description: SEVERAL New Jersey programs will be among the events making up the second annual ''American Music Week,'' which takes place Nov. 3-8 throughout the country.

title:
FOCUS: LIABILITY;
Coast Case Raises Risk Of Directors
description: EXPERTS in the law covering condominium and other common-interest housing have reacted with alarm to a recent ruling by the California Supreme Court that a homeowners' association and its individual volunteer directors may be held liable for injuries sustained by a unit owner at the hands of a criminal who broke into her apartment.

title:
ART;
AT THE ROBERT MARTIN GALLERY, SKIN-DEEP BEAUTY THAT'S MORE
description: ONE admires the canniness of the owners of the Kroger Company headquarters in Cincinnati and the Reliable Corporation warehouse in Chicago. They hired Richard Haas to do their exterior refurbishing for them, and although Mr. Haas's ministrations are only skin deep - he does his magic solely with paint - the results are almost as classy as if the impossible architectural remodeling that Mr. Haas limns had been undertaken. Trompe l'oeil works magic. An insightful sampling of Mr. Haas's work is at the Robert Martin Gallery of the Westchester Financial Center in White Plains. Walking up the stairs to the mezzanine-level gallery, the visitor encounters a painting of the courtyard of the Frick Museum with its large fountain and small frog that spouts water, too. This painting is too small in scale to fool the eye, but does call attention to Mr. Haas's fidelity.

title: Victoria R. Asiaf Becomes a Bride
description: Victoria Ruth Asiaf, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Asiaf of Centerville, Mass., and Thomas James Goodrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Goodrick of Sharpsville, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. Michael Dufault, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. David George, a Maronite priest, at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE NEW FORMALITY
description: This season, it is apparent that the emphasis once again is on the fine points of hospitality, those special touches that convey to guests that they are indeed special, worthy of the best. The new formality is more an attitude than an entertaining blueprint; it can be conveyed in anything from a gilded gala replete with silver and crystal to a homespun weekend lunch.

title: The Real Paul Newman
description: Paul Newman was tending bar at an outdoor charity party in Westport a few years back. When the crowd was thinning, a friend said to me, ''I wonder what I should do with this,'' holding up an empty plastic glass. ''Throw it over your shoulder into the fireplace,'' came a voice from behind. That's the real Paul Newman - terrific! MARIE WASTCOAT Dallas

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
A Country Craft Reproduced
description: The furniture made during the 18th and early 19th centuries in New England villages and small towns is a vigorous and varied genre that is getting harder and harder to find. As the number of admirers and collectors of the furniture has grown, so has the acumen of its owners. Country folk - if there are still any left - no longer sell the family's comfortably worn heirlooms to the first person who comes along with a truck and a $5 bill. And the younger generation, more nostalgic, or appreciative of heritage, or delighted with handwork, is not as eager as less sophisticated generations were to part with their forebears' belongings.

title: PARENTS IN SCHOOLBOOK CASE WARY ON VICTORY
description: Fundamentalist Christian parents who won a Federal court suit for the right to challenge their children's use of certain books in public schools believe their struggle is far from over, one of the parents said today.

title: KNOW-HOW MILLS
description: TO ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE The Growth of American Research Universities, 1900-1940. By Roger L. Geiger. 325 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50.

title: RESERVATIONS IN PARADIES
description: The hotel is Haus Paradies, and for once reality merits the billing.

title: BIg Bucks at High Velocity
description: BEHIND CLOSED DOORS Wheeling and Dealing in the Banking World. By Hope Lampert. 386 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95. BAILOUT An Insider's Account of Bank Failures and Rescues. By Irvine H. Sprague. 299 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95. SELLING MONEY By S. C. Gwynne. 182 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $16.95.

title: PHILIPPINE DEFENSE CHIEF FAULTS AQUINO
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile today broke an announced agreement not to criticize President Corazon C. Aquino, telling a rally that he thought her Government was ineffective.

title: Risky Ground
description: JOHN HAS BEEN ON HIS FIRST job for a month now. He's 16 and went to work at Bill's Hardware, a neighborhood store in Arlington, Va., that's been there for years and sells everything. They're teaching him to make keys and fit pipe and sharpen lawn mowers.

title: GUID
description: BORGE AT WOOLSEY HALL Victor Borge will be the featured performer in the Connecticut Liberty Concert at 8 P.M. Wednesday in Woolsey Hall, College and Grove Streets, at Yale University. The concert, which takes place a day after the New York celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty dedication, was organized by the Connecticut Centennial Commission for the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island and Yale University. It is sponsored by the First Federal Bank of Connecticut.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Chester, N.Y. $239,500 89 Middle Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,100. Mohegan Lake, N.Y. $140,000 3262 Chelsey Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, family room, lake rights; taxes $2,835.

title: Marilyn Walsh Weds
description: Marilyn Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Walsh of Palm City, Fla., and Robert O'Bryant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Bryant of Charlotte, Mich., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Trainor performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx. Mrs. O'Bryant graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo. Mr. O'Bryant, a design engineer for the International Paper Company in Wallkill, N.Y., graduated from Western Michigan University. His first wife died.

title: TRIALS OF THE TRIB
description: THE PAPER The Life and Death of the New York Herald Tribune. By Richard Kluger With Phyllis Kluger. Illustrated. 801 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. WHAT did Karl Marx, Henry James, William Dean Howells, Bret Harte, Jacob Riis and John O'Hara have in common? Answer: all worked for The New York Herald Tribune or one of its precursors, The Herald or The Tribune.

title: Chemicals Linked To an Ozone 'Hole'
description: Scientists investigating a ''hole'' in the earth's ozone layer above Antarctica said last week that they were still puzzled about its cause but suspected a ''chemical process.''

title: FOREIGN CONCERNS FIND COUNTY A HAVEN
description: DESPITE the inroads foreign competitors have made in markets that were once the exclusive domain of American companies, some things remain particularly American - such as business opportunities. The United States continues to attract entrepreneurs from abroad who turn hard work into successful businesses, and Westchester has drawn its share of them. Recently two such businessmen, one Israeli and the other French, agreed to talk about why they chose to establish their businesses here.

title: THE LOONY HORROR OF IT ALL- 'CATCH-22' TURNS 25
description: Looking back today at ''Catch-22''- which was published 25 years ago this month- we are able to see that it has had a remarkable, if not altogether unclouded, literary history. It has passed from relatively modest initial success with readers and critics - many of whom liked the book for just the reasons that caused others to hate it - through massive best-sellerdom and early canonization as a youth-cult sacred text to its current status as a monumental artifact of contemporary American literature, almost as assured of longevity as the statues on Easter Island.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hamilton $105,900 2 Brown Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; partially finished basement, carport, modern eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,337. Livingston $595,000 34 Cornell Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old custom-built contemporary; den, greenhouse, deck, 3-car attached garage; taxes $7,471.

title: Topics: Pick a Number; Digit Widget
description: Some 22 states and the District of Columbia regularly conduct lotteries. To outwit mere chance, millions of Americans cudgel their brains each week and rake over their dreams in a search for clues to winning numbers.

title: Italy's Buttery Buffalo Cheese
description: Standing in a steamy mozzarella factory in Battipaglia, peering into a large wooden tub where white domes the size of grapefruits are bobbing in a milky bath, while beyond them two men work long white hoses of cheese into 15-inch braids, you begin to suspect that there is more to mozzarella than the chewy cheese on the top of a slice of pizza that you played with as a kid.

title: CORRECTION
description: A music listing today in The Guide, section 2A, and a related entry in the Critics' Choices column there, carry an incorrect time supplied by Lincoln Center for an appearance by the pianist Alicia de Larrocha at Avery Fisher Hall. (The error also appeared in the Events and Openings column of Weekend on Friday.) She will perform today at 3 P.M., not 8.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1986
description: The World A Soviet official quoted the President in Moscow to show that Mr. Reagan agreed in Iceland to eliminate all strategic offensive forces, not just ballistic missiles, as the White House has said. Page 1 The White House restated its position that Mr. Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev had discussed the elimination of all nuclear weapons, but that the talks had never reached even a tentative agreement. #12 Britain called on the Soviet Union to announce publicly its rejection of state-supported terrorism. The request came after London said it had evidence that Syria was involved in an El Al bomb plot. #1 British agents eavesdropped on conversations verifying the complicity of the Syrian Ambassador in the plot to bomb an Israeli airliner, according to Government officials. #6 A vote to oust the South African delegation from a Red Cross conference was made as a protest to apartheid, many countries said. It is the first delegation to be excluded since the Red Cross began. #1 G.M.-I.B.M. moves in Pretoria 14 Financial deficits grieve the Vatican, which urgently needs greater contributions from Roman Catholics, according to a commission of cardinals. The Holy See suffered a shortfall of $39 million in 1985. #9 A trial in Nicaragua is set to proceed in the case against the American captured from a downed rebel supply plane. A tribunal is expected to spend the next 8 to 12 days judging the case, political analysts say.

title: COVER-UP IS CHARGED AT RIAL ON MOVIE DEATHS
description: Defense attorneys in the manslaughter trial over three deaths in ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' have repeatedly charged that fire officials tried to cover up their department's role in a fatal helicopter crash.

title: 1717 WRECK OF GALLEON OFF CAPE YIELDS TREASURE AND HINTS AT PARIATES' LIVES
description: The Whydah, which archeologists say is the only pirate ship ever identified and salvaged, is providing a glimpse of the swashbuckling life of crime on the high seas in the 18th century.

title: Summit Snaps Union's Streak
description: Summit scored a major upset yesterday when it ended Union's 26-game winning streak, the longest in the state, with a 7-0 victory before 2,000 in Union.

title: McNamara Joy Slips Into Cruelest Defeat
description: The Red Sox were braced in the dugout, preparing for that traditional mad dash to the pitcher's mound in celebration of baseball's ultimate victory. Among them was John McNamara, only a strike from savoring his finest moment as a major-league manager. A strong, silent type, McNamara was credited for leading the Boston Red Sox to the American League pennant with a low key, even handed approach.

title: Nancy Mortensen Wed To Christopher Piper
description: The marriage of Nancy Elizabeth Mortensen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Mortensen of Stony Brook, L.I., to Christopher White Piper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Piper of Winnetka, Ill., took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Mark Anschutz performed the ceremony.

title: The Real Paul Newman
description: I had to laugh when I read one paragraph in Maureen Dowd's article. Ms. Dowd writes, ''They have worked hard at their marriage - she has gone to the races he loves and he has gone to the operas and ballets she loves.''

title: REAGAN SAYS NATION'S ECONOMY IS 'ACCELERATIN'
description: President Reagan, in an upbeat pre-election talk about the nation's economy, said today that America ''is solid and accelerating again.''

title: RYAN AND PATAKI VIE IN A REMATCH
description: IN Northern Westchester's 91st Assembly District, the so-called Bear Mountain Bridge district, the campaign is focused on the records of two freshman legislators. There is the 1985-86 record of George E. Pataki of Peekskill, the Republican-Conservative incumbent who won the Assembly seat in November 1984, and the earlier, two-year record of William J. Ryan, also of Peekskill, the Democratic candidate, who served as the district's Assemblyman in 1983-84 before his defeat by the incumbent.

title: Kansas City
description: Once a year, Kansas City sheds its urbanity and turns itself into a cow town again. The occasion: the American Royal, a combined stock show, horse show and rodeo now in its 88th year. The Royal - some Kansas Citians say that the name was appropriated from the British Agricultural Royal show, others will say that they don't know why it's called that -harks back to the days of the great cattle drives, when Kansas City was where Wyatt Earp, Wild Bill Hickok and Kit Carson hung their hats. (To say nothing of such less exemplary citizens as Jesse James and a throng of locally famous madams.) The show, which runs from Nov. 8 to 23 this year, kicks off with a parade - complete with marching bands and majorettes, floats and beauty queens, specifically the Future Farmers of America State Sweethearts, who will vie for the title of American Royal Queen. The parade is scheduled to begin at the corner of 14th and Baltimore Streets at 9:45 A.M. and end at Pershing and Main two and a half hours later. Some of the highlights of this year's Royal are the professional rodeo (one performance Nov. 5, then twice daily on Nov. 13 to 15), the Saddle Horse Show (Nov. 17 to 22) and a Willie Nelson concert (Nov. 16) in Kemper Arena. Livestock judging takes place in the American Royal Building and Arena; the Grand Champion Steer competition is scheduled for Nov. 15, and the winner and runners-up will be auctioned (don't ask what for) the following day.

title: Truffaut's 'Woman' and Rockabilly From Perkins
description: The Woman Next Door Starring Gerard Depardieu, Fanny Ardant; directed by Francois Truffaut. 1981. (R) Key Video. 106 minutes. $59.95.

title: People's Sale Approved
description: Applying a broader test than it had only two weeks ago, the Transportation Department gave final approval last week to the acquisition that will make the Texas Air Corporation the largest airline holding company in the country - the $301 million purchase of financially troubled People Express Inc. and its bankrupt subsidiary, Frontier Airlines. Rather than examining the impact on competition at airports in Washington, D.C., Denver and the New York City area, its recent concern, the agency said it had found that facilities and terminals in existence or under construction would ''insure'' the ability of other airlines to compete with Texas Air's carriers. They include Eastern Air Lines, Continental Air Lines and New York Airlines Inc. With People's and Frontier, the Houston-based corporation commands 20.1 percent of the market.

title: Carle Place Earns a Tie
description: Carle Place struggled to a 6-6 tie against undefeated Cold Spring Harbor in a Nassau County Conference 4 match.

title: WHEN NISSAN HAD A BETTER IDEA
description: THE RECKONING By David Halberstam. 752 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: IN LOVE AND IN BUSINESS: How Entrepreneurial Couples Are Changing the Rules of Business and Marriage. By Sharon Nelton. (John Wiley & Sons, $16.95.)

title: Benazir Bhutto's Return
description: Steven R. Weisman's balanced article ''The Return of Benazir Bhutto'' (Sept. 21) was a useful corrective to the uncritical promotion of Miss Bhutto as (in the words of her supporters) ''the new Cory Aquino.'' However, some of the circumstances that he found murky can easily be cleared up.

title: Decline in Bombing Deaths
description: Bombings declined 10 percent and killed fewer people in the first six months of 1986 than in the same period last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today. The bureau's report said 6 people died, 122 were injured and property damage totaled $1.4 million in 377 explosions across the United States and its territories, as against 10 deaths and injuries to 44 people in the first six months of 1985. The report said none of the 1986 bombings were attributed to terrorist groups.

title: TESTS ON ANIMALS SHOW OZONE MAY CAUSE CANCER
description: The gas ozone, which has been recognized as causing headaches and breathing difficulties, may also cause cancer, according to recent experiments conducted on animals.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Brooding on the Beach

title: Trial of American In Managua Stirs Allegations on Aid
description: A political court in Managua began last week the trial of Eugene Hasenfus, the American adventurer captured Oct. 6 when a cargo plane with supplies for the contras was shot down over southern Nicaragua.

title: Born in the U. X. A.
description: I SEE A NATION OF hamburger servers. It is called the U.X.A. In the days before everybody spoke in initials it would have been called the Uxited Xtates of Axerica. It is the land of the Exxon and the home of the USX.

title: PHOTO EXHIBIT SHOWS FARMING THE OLD-FASHIONED WAY
description: WHEN Georgia Sheron, a photographer, first met a neighboring farmer, John Ludorf, in Southbury back in 1970, he was still using the same methods his father used on the farm nearly 100 years earlier.

title: MOLIERE THE STAR OF NEW 'TARTUFFE'
description: THE Long Island Stage company has pampered its audiences with so many excellent shows that what would be merely a lackluster production at any other theater seems shockingly bad here.

title: Next Week; Should All Series Games Be At Night?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: MORRISTOWN WILL OFFER BALLOTS IN BRAILLE
description: ABSENTEE ballots in Braille will be available for the asking to blind and visually impaired Morris County voters for the Nov. 4 election.

title: Social Events; In and Out of the City
description: July 4, Continued Oct. 27 - Bob Hope will be the master of ceremonies and Andy Williams, Victor Borge and Anita Bryant are scheduled to entertain at a black-tie tribute to distinguished Americans who have contributed to the nation's heritage. Prompted by the Statue of Liberty centennial, the evening at the Waldorf-Astoria, which starts with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., will benefit the work of the New York Statue of Liberty Centennial Commission and programs for the needy. Tickets, $250, from Cathy Capri at 212-838-9867. Oct. 28 - Who will create the enduring grand statues of the future? Trying to assure that they will be built, the New York Statue of Liberty Celebration Foundation is creating the Bartholdi Studio, named for the Statute of Liberty sculptor. It will be a sculpture museum and study institute with spacious studios and a faculty of 15 artist-professors. The site: the New York Academy of Art, 419 Lafayette Street, next to the Public Theater. A black-tie benefit starts with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. at the academy followed by dinner, opera excerpts and an auction. Tickets, $150, from Diana Crane at 212-995-8440 or 212-995-8441. Ecumenical Evening Oct. 29 - ''Dori,'' a musical on the life of the Zionist leader Theodor Herzl (1860-1904), will have its premiere at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine with a 120-voice choir from synagogues and churches along with a 35-piece orchestra. The evening, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., will benefit Jewish and Christian groups.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THE question is, to speak or not to speak. Is it a kindness to sometimes mind someone else's business, or is silence the better part of valor? Anyone who thinks the answer is simple or clear-cut is absolutely wrong. Silence, in certain situations, can be unkind and even mean. And yet speaking out in these same situations, and with the best of intentions, can lead to a swat in the face, a kick in the shins or simple belligerence and a ''mind your own business'' snarl. What to do, what to do? Let's say you're a woman and your slip or bra strap is showing. Would you like to be told about it, even by a stranger, or would you prefer to remain unaware? Reversing the situation, would you tell someone you've never seen before about the peek-a-boo slip or strap? Or a run in a stocking, an undone snap, lipstick on teeth or a label that's showing. Would you, a woman, tell a male friend that his zipper is unzipped? Would you, male, be so embarrassed by said woman that you would rather carry on in blissful ignorance? Would one man tell another?

title: Reversing Loss Of a Rape Case
description: WHEN a Brooklyn man charged in 1981 with raping four women won dismissal of the charges two years later, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, was widely criticized. The State Supreme Court justice who threw out the case said the prosecutor had delayed too long to try it, thereby violating the defendant's right to speedy justice.

title:
OPINION;
ON STATE SCHOOL INTERVENTION
description: NEW JERSEY'S proposal to assume control of chronically deficient school districts has been criticized as drastic and unfair. But what is known as ''New Jersey's Plan to Intervene in Deficient School Districts'' is a logical and essential conclusion to the state's process of reviewing or ''monitoring'' local school districts.

title: BOMB KILLS MILITARY GOVERNOR IN BASQUE PROVINCE
description: The military governor of a Basque province was killed along with his wife and son today when a bomb exploded moments after it was planted on top of their car at a traffic light, the police said.

title: TOTING UP THE REGION'S RESOURCES
description: WHAT a draft report of the President's Commission on Americans Outdoors proposes for the national level, the Regional Plan Association has undertaken in the 31-county New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan area.

title: MEXICO VOTE: RULING PARTY BEING TESTED
description: Shortly before Christmas last year, two teen-agers on a motorcyle passed by a bar here in the capital of Sinaloa state.

title: PROFIT REPORT FUELS INSURANCE DEBATE
description: THE heated debate over the turmoil in New Jersey's commercial liability-insurance marketplace has been refueled by a consumer coalition's study of the industry's profits.

title: A Davis Connection
description: For a few days last week the Senate contest in Colorado was overshadowed by a furor over television commercials in the race for Governor that a group of Colorado religious leaders denounced as ''an act of political terrorism.''

title: Anne Macmillan Weds John M. Reid Jr.
description: The Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Elizabeth Macmillan, a daughter of Mrs. Alexander Sinclair Stuart Macmillan Jr. of Boston and the late Dr. Macmillan, to John Mayne Reid Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid of New Canaan, Conn., and Hawley, Pa. The Rev. Carl R. Scovel, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Comings and Goings
description: BILLY CONNORS has been dismissed as the Chicago Cubs' pitching coach after his staff compiled a 4.48 earned run average, the worst in the National League. The 44-year-old Connors, who had held the job for five years, was offered a similar post in the club's minor league operation. . . . Dr. Cary Middlecoff, the dentist who won more golf tournaments and money in the 1950's and 1960's than any of his contemporaries, yesterday became the 47th member of the Golf Hall of Fame in Pinehurst, N.C. Middlecoff, 66, won 40 tournament titles and $250,000 in career earnings on the professional tour before back surgery in 1963 forced an end to his career. . . . Eddie Johnson has signed a new contract with the Sacramento Kings after the Kings matched an offer from the Cleveland Cavaliers that would have reportedly brought the 6-foot-7-inch forward $2.6 million over four years. . . . The United States Tennis Association has appointed Elise Burgin of Baltimore, who is ranked 40th in the world, as captain of the United States Wightman Cup team, replacing Chris Evert Lloyd, who was forced to withdraw because of a knee injury.

title: ALASKA NATIVES TO RENEW EFFORTS ON LAND BILL
description: Eskimo, Aleut and Indian leaders in Alaska say they will try again next year to persuade Congress to help keep native lands in native hands after 1991.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a recent reference in the Long Island Weekly to penalties for stray shopping carts in the Town of Hempstead, the amount of the fine was given incorrectly. Violators of the town code can be fined $250, in addition to paying storage charges for impounded carts.

title: New American Envoy Takes Post in Mexico
description: The new United States Ambassador to Mexico, Charles J. Pilliod, has pledged to try to improve relations sorely strained over illegal immigration, oil sales and charges of Mexican complicity in drug trafficking.

title: Loosen Up, America
description: THE HIGH-FLEX SOCIETY Shaping America's Economic Future. By Pat Choate and J. K. Linger. 301 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: David I. Ashe, Lawyer For Unions, Dies at 75
description: David I. Ashe, a lawyer who represented several international and local unions and a former member of the city's Board of Higher Education, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Adams Passing Topples Bayside, 18-7
description: In a matchup between Adams (4-2-1), which has the league's best offense, and Bayside (5-1), with the league's stingiest defense, Adams came away with an 18-7 victory.

title: Classic French
description: The country road D-2, which runs north from the charmless suburbs of Bordeaux in southwest France, scattered with industrial parks, Renault dealerships and shopping centers, offers no hint of the glories that await just a short distance ahead. As the road approaches the wide, turbid Gironde River, then jogs north, following it to the Atlantic coast, 20th-century detritus gives way to timeless beauty: undulating fields of crimson and yellow that seem to go on forever, annual harbingers of the grape harvest in the Medoc region.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
EPILEPSY AND WORK
description: The Epilepsy Institute, an education and advocacy group, will sponsor its first Employers Conference on Epilepsy on Wednesday. Co-sponsored by the Ciba-Geigy Corporation and the New York State Epilepsy Association, it will be held at Ciba-Geigy headquarters in Ardsley. The institute is based in Manhattan and maintains regional offices, including one in White Plains.

title: DISSIDENTS ACCUSE SEOUL OF PRESS DISTORTIONS
description: Two dissident groups have made public what they say is evidence of an official campaign to distort press coverage of the Government's relations with the United States and to portray the opposition as pro-Communist.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kansas City, Mo.;
Digging In To Save Energy
description: OPENING for free public tours this month on a corner in the heart of Kansas City is a recently completed house that could represent the future of bulding low-cost, single-family housing in inner cities.

title: Susan M. Reinfeld Marries Jeffrey Zager, a Law Clerk
description: Susan Mann Reinfeld and Jeffrey Zager, members of the classes of '86 and '85, respectively, at the Vanderbilt Law School, were married last evening by Rabbi Barry H. Greene at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Albert I. Reinfeld of South Orange, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zager of Nashville.

title: A Very Tight Little Island
description: Stress signals from the overcrowded Rikers Island jail complex continued to erupt into the news last week as investigators looked into reports that guards had beaten handcuffed inmates as the prisoners were being moved from one building to another. The transfer last weekend followed a series of outbreaks that injured 13 guards and 11 inmates.

title: PETER KING AND THE I.R.A.
description: In two recent articles mentioning Peter King's campaign for State Attorney General, the reporter managed to miss the most important thing about the Republican-Conservative-Right to Life candidate. Peter King is (or was - is he toning it down for this, his first statewide race?) the only elected officeholder in this state who is an open endorser of the terrorist Irish Republican Army and supporter of its Noraid fund-raising arm in this country.

title: TOXIC SITE CLEANUP PLAN FACES TEST
description: As Election Day approaches, Governor Cuomo, other state officials and conservation organizations say they are worried that a lack of public awareness may threaten the passage of a proposed bond issue to clean up the state's worst toxic sites.

title: If You Think 1986 Is the Year for a Mink
description: IF you have been dreaming of a fur coat, there is an incentive to buy this year: The sales tax -which can easily amount to $500 or more in New York - will cease to be deductible in 1987.

title: Topics: Pick a Number; Worn Again
description: In the current movie ''Tough Guys,'' about two geriatric hoodlums, a marvelously fit Alexis Smith tells a somewhat less trim Burt Lancaster that ''You have to work at staying young.'' Clara Mari of Buffalo, N.Y., has found out how to stay young in order to work.

title: Bossy Adds Edge As Islanders Win
description: He did no diving, no rink-long sprints, and he didn't turn a hat trick, but he did score once and assist on the winning goal, and the added dimension Mike Bossy brings a team by his very presence once again belonged to the Islanders.

title: THE NEW SOCIAL REFORMERS
description: VISITS TO DE-crepit buildings in Pittsburgh have replaced stays at five-star hotels in London and Munich. His $200,000-plus annual salary has dropped 75 percent. And instead of hammering out multimillion-dollar deals on Wall Street at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., Bart Harvey is concentrating on improving housing for families with annual incomes at the $10,000 level.

title: A Clone Invades the Modem Market
description: PERSONAL computers are a modern marketing marvel. When they first made their appearance a decade ago, they did so as essentially high-status, expensive paperweights, gadgets that enthusiasts endeavored, often in vain, to figure out what to do with. In a few years, a smattering of applications software became available for the machines, but they still sold in far greater numbers than their usefulness at the time would seem to dictate. They sold on the promise of wonders to come, a promise that in some areas, such as business, but not in others, like the home, was to be eventually fulfilled.

title: SOUTH PACIFIC COMES OF AGE IN GLOBAL POLITICS
description: THROUGH most of history, the South Pacific, with its tens of thousands of islands and more than five million square miles of sea, was a singular world only in the minds of travelers, romantics and naval strategists. Now from Kiribati to Canberra, from Papua New Guinea to Polynesia, its leaders say that shared problems are bringing their 20 or so diverse countries and dependencies together into the beginnings a definable political and economic region.

title: Packing List
description: To the Editor: Among the items mentioned in the article ''One Traveler's Packing List'' (Travel, July 20) was a battery-operated hair dryer.

title: When A Seventh Game Is Necessary: High Drama
description: SPARKY ANDERSON, cool, glib, witty, seasoned, admits he was ''uptight.'' ''It's not that you're scared, but you're so uptight, you don't remember how you feel,'' Anderson said. ''Your whole thing is revolving around that game. I don't remember either game real well. I see films of the games now; that's the only way I can remember them.''

title: Colorado Tricks Nebraska Into Upset
description: Jeff Campbell dashed 39 yards on a reverse for a touchdown and a halfback, O. C. Oliver, threw a 52-yard pass to Lance Carl for another as Colorado used trick plays and an aroused defense to upset unbeaten Nebraska, 20-10, in a Big Eight Conference game today.

title: L.I. Man Fatally Shoots Two In Bars Then Wounds Himself
description: A Long Island man walked into two bars yesterday and fatally shot one person in each, then seriously wounded himself.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: THE ENTREPRENEURS: An American Adventure. By Robert Sobel and David B. Sicilia. (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) Robert Sobel, a professor of business history at Hofstra University who has made a second profession of turning out popular histories of business, had reason to take on an apprentice, David B. Sicilia, a research associate in a consulting firm, for an expansive repackaging of his book ''The Entrepreneurs: Explorations Within the American Business Tradition'' (1974).

title: Mule for a Bandwagon
description: Senator Mack Mattingly, Republican of Georgia, seems to have had many advantages in his campaign against Representative Wyche Fowler Jr., his Democratic challenger. President Reagan will visit the state Tuesday in behalf of Mr. Mattingly, who has outspent Mr. Fowler by a 4-to-1 margin.

title: A Religious Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: A WINNING TEAM CREDITS ITS 'SYSTEM'
description: THIS could be a milestone week in Ed Bengermino's coaching career. There is a good chance his volleyball team, the Fairfield Mustangs, as of last weekend undefeated in 11 games, will be participants in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference's championship game Thursday night at Norwalk High School. And, if it should emerge victorious, as five of Mr. Bengermino's previous teams have, it would mark his 200th lifetime win.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CRACKDOWN ON BUCKLING UP OFFICER Kenneth Hawkinson of the Nassau County Police Department highway patrol usally sights his targets from behind, he says. ''You're in traffic and you pull up behind a new car. With the cross-belts, you can usually tell whether or not they've got their seat belts buckled.''

title:
GARDENING;
TULIP: OLD WORLD NATIVE STILL A FAVORITE
description: THE tulip is just about everyone's favorite spring flower.

title: A SLEUTH'S NEWEST VENTURE
description: NANCY DREW, America's young blonde sleuth, has traded in her sporty blue roadster for a Mustang, exchanged her proper dresses for designer jeans and carries a credit card. She even kisses boys who are not Ned Nickerson.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NIGHT IN THE COUNTRY By Cynthia Rylant. Illustrated by Mary Szilagyi. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 6) HALF A MOON AND ONE WHOLE STAR By Crescent Dragonwagon. Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: A LIFE OF HER OWN
description: THE PEBBLED SHORE The Memoirs of Elizabeth Longford. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: A World Series Without Dad
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STATE PANEL IS DRAFTING RULES TO BAR POLITICAL CONTROL OF CABLE TV GROUPS
description: The chairman of a state commission examining cable television operations in New York City says the panel is drafting new regulations to combat political control of local cable groups.

title: END OF FORCED RETIREMENT MEANS A LOT - TO A FEW
description: WHEN Congress voted earlier this month to eliminate mandatory retirement for nearly all workers, supporters called it a legislative landmark that would bring striking changes to the workplace. And from the outpouring of Congressional sentiment in favor of the bill, one would guess that the existing law was forcing armies of Americans out of the workplace at 70 years of age.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LOVE WITH A FEW HAIRS, by Mohammed Mrabet. Translated from the Moghrebi and edited by Paul Bowles. (City Lights, $6.95.) This novel by the Moroccan writer Mohammed Mrabet is the story of a young Moroccan man, involved with a rich English homosexual, who becomes obsessed by a young woman and wins her love with a magic potion. ''This is a story well worth reading,'' J. M. Edelstein said here in 1968. ''It is a view of the world where love is a commodity and perfunctory, where the gulfs between humans are not only vast but are also taken for granted as permanent.'' WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) Born in England and raised in Kenya, the author and aviator Beryl Markham (1902-1986) was the first person to fly solo across the Atlantic from east to west and the first professional female bush pilot in Africa. This memoir of her Kenyan childhood and her historic flight ''is quite unlike anything that has been written by any other woman or about Africa, its natives, its hunting and its future by anybody,'' our reviewer, Jane Spence Southron, said in 1942. The work, she said, ''written with exceptional, simple beauty,'' is ''all the more thrilling for being true.'' Another African memoir, A TOURIST IN AFRICA by Evelyn Waugh (Little, Brown; paper, $7.95; cloth, $15.95), is the British novelist's diary of a two-month trip to Central Africa in 1959. Our reviewer, Elspeth Huxley, said in 1960 that ''a crumb from Mr. Waugh's table remains more appetizing and, in a curious way, more nourishing than a whole meal from the groaning platter of most earnest, informative newshawks and television teams.''

title: Not Since Thomson Homer
description: In the uproar after the Mets somehow won, 6-5, with three runs in the 10th inning last night, Chub Feeney, the retiring president of the National League, put both the World Series and the wonderful world of baseball in their proper perspective.

title:
N.B.A. 1986-87;
Much Movement and One Constant- the Celtics
description: Big names in new uniforms.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS: BUSINESS IN SHORT
description: WHAT THEY REALLY TEACH YOU AT THE HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL. By Francis J. Kelly and Heather Mayfield Kelly. (Warner, Paper, $9.95.)

title: DANCE: THE EROTIC SIDE
description: ''SEX AND DANCE,'' which opened on Thursday at Performance Space 122, is an ambitious festival that aims to explore the erotic in dance in just about every kind of movement known to man and woman. Sixteen groups and individuals are performing everything from classical Indian dance and ballet to a striptease and mud wrestling during the festival's two weeks at two theaters. There is also a photography exhibition and a critical seminar on sex and dance. But what was lacking in the opening program was a point of view about the topic.

title: FREE ACTIVIST STIRS DEBATE ON DEFENSE JOBS
description: IN Groton, where the largest employer is the producer of nuclear submarines, the addition of a nuclear-freeze activist to the City Council has caused some heated debates on how arms-dependent the area's industry is - and should be in the future.

title: SCHOMBURG CENTER MARKS 60 YEARS OF BLACK CULTURE RESEARCH
description: From his position as a supervisor of the foreign mail division of a New York City bank in the 1920's, Arthur A. Schomburg carried on a lively correspondence with book dealers in London, Paris, Havana and Madrid, seeking to build his collection of information about the ''global experience'' of blacks.

title: 'STARS OF MAGIC'
description: HOCUS-POCUS, dominocus. Now you see it. Now you. Such is the stuff of life in the world of magic. The fellows in tails and tophat (rabbit extra) are always pulling something from thin air or having things appear where they weren't before.

title:
IDES & TRENDS: IGNORING THE LAW;
BILINGUALISM IN FACT
description: IN 1980, Dade County voters approved a measure that prohibited spending county funds ''for the purpose of utilizing any language other than English or promoting culture other than that of the United States.''

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN FARE IN LARCHMONT
description: IT says a great deal when a restaurant celebrates a 10th anniversary. Only a happy clientele can be responsible for such staying power, and La Villetta, the happy celebrant in this case, does its best to please. True, some dishes could use more care in the timing and some a little imagination; however, considering the great number of items offered, the kitchen does a pretty good job of delivering the promised fare with skill that's dependable enough.

title:
N.B.A. 1986-87;
New Pieces To Fit In Place
description: THE Nets needed a small forward who could score. They got Orlando Woolridge. They needed a point guard to run Coach Dave Wohl's complicated offense. They gambled that Dwayne Washington, who left Syracuse University after his junior year, was the answer and made him their No. 1 selection in the college draft. They needed additional bulk up front. They signed the 6-foot-9-inch, 240-pound James Bailey, cut by the Knicks.

title: ROCK: ELVIS COSTELLO, TWICE
description: ELVIS COSTELLO knows how to turn concert appearances into events. In 1979, he played three New York clubs in one day. And his current, sold-out engagement, ''Costello Sings Again,'' calls for five nights at the Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway at 53d Street, with five different programs - three with his longtime British band, the Attractions, and two with an American band, the Confederates, plus guests and gimmicks.

title: IS ANY CHOICE RIGHT IN SEX SELECTIONS?
description: TO a dismayed Japanese public, the discovery had overtones of ''Brave New World'': Medical researchers said they had developed a technique allowing couples to choose the sex of their children.

title: Martin Scorsese: Showmanship and Mystery
description: There are only a few ways a film maker can photograph a game of nine-ball billiards, unless that film maker happens to be Martin Scorsese, in which case there may be a million. In ''The Color of Money,'' which marks Mr. Scorsese's return to the kind of pyrotechnics that put him on the map in the first place, his virtuosity seems to know no bounds. Nor does it know any rules, since his camera has so great a penchant for the unexpected. It may scan a room and then swerve back to study something it missed, or make a 90-degree turn in midmotion. It may zero in on someone who's speaking and then, just as quickly, pull away. It may turn the image of two dozen pool tables in an Atlantic City ballroom into a cathedral, a gladiatorial arena, a majestic crucible.

title: POSTINGS: New Image in White Plains; An 'Estate Feel' for Condos
description: The architectural assumption underlying Wyndham Close, a new condominium project in White Plains,is that people are tired of the ''stacked town-house'' look.

title: LOCAL COLOR, EXCEPT GREEN, IS GONE FROM THE HUSTINGS
description: The thing you hear most often in Boise about David Leroy, the Republican gubernatorial candidate in Idaho, is that he does not have a hunting or fishing license. Mr. Leroy denies it.

title: Deviant Socialization on a Sesame-Seed Bun
description: WHEN TEENAGERS WORK The Psychological and Social Costs of Adolescent Employment. By Ellen Greenberger and Laurence Steinberg. 275 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: Finish planting. . . . Rake leaves. . . . Keep mowing. . . . Apply anti-desiccants to broadleaved evergreens and young conifers. . . . Be sure new plantings of bulbs, perennials and shrubs are well watered. From Readers

title: Maginot Line in the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
OF HUMAN CONTACT: PORTRAITS THAT PASS IN THE NIGHT
description: LOOKING at ourselves in the mirror of art can be a pleasurable experience when what we see reflected is the positive side of human nature, but it can be discomfiting when art reflects our negative aspects.

title: SCHOOLCHIDREN TAKE A LOOK FROM INSIDE AT WORLD OF ART
description: THE painting shows a huge bouquet of roses with the sun and moon shining at once outside a window. Lovers kiss in a pale blue haze, and a couple meet under a parasol.

title: 'PIZZA' TRIAL DEFENDANT EVASIVE ABOUT TAPES
description: A defendant identified as the former chief of the Sicilian Mafia has resisted a prosecutor's persistent efforts to make him explain what he was discussing in wiretapped conversations that are crucial evidence in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial.

title: Chicago Rolls Show 34,538 Are Registered to Vote Twice
description: More than 34,000 people in Cook County are registered to vote twice, a computer search by a nonpartisan group has found.

title: Amy Inglesby Is a Bride
description: Amy Elizabeth Inglesby, a daughter of Betty Gilreath Huntington and Allen Jervey Inglesby, both of Greenville, S.C., was married there yesterday to Edward Floyd Hawke, a son of Barbara S. Feeney of Bricktown, N.J., and Edward C. Hawke of Shallotte, N.C. The Rev. Dennis Maynard performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church. Mrs. Hawke is a broker for Bellmarc Realty in New York, where her husband is a second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Turn-Of-The Century Boat Ride
description: BEAUTIFUL boat designs reach the water in two ways. Some are drawn by naval architects and others evolve from use, developing over many years into a perfect shape for the job they do.

title: Article 880486 -- No Title
description: New York has collected $401.3 million in delinquent taxes from the state's 90-day tax amnesty program that ended last Jan. 31, the State Department of Taxation and Finance reported yesterday.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BACHELOR BIDDING
description: Single? Tired of moaning, ''There are no men out there?'' Come to the Rye Town Hilton Friday night and buy one.

title: Carol L. Gruendel Becomes the Bride Of Michael Kaelin
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan yesterday, Carol Lisa Gruendel, an associate in the New York law firm Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, and Michael Peter Kaelin, an associate in the New York law firm Healy & Baillie, were married by the Rev. Justin Hennessey.

title: AMENTA IN UPHILL FIGHT AGAINST JOHNSON
description: TEN years ago, a relatively unknown Republican named Nancy L. Johnson upset State Senator Paul S. Amenta, the incumbent, by the slimmest of margins - 150 votes out of 3,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map last Sunday with a Washington dispatch on Mexico's economic problems incorrectly located the city of Matamoros. It is just over the border from Brownsville, Tex. The point shown on the map was a smaller community also called Matamoros.

title: Politics and Football
description: Joe Paterno, the head football coach at Penn State, was not known for playing semantic games until he got involved in politics this year. He has been campaigning for two Republicans, Senator Arlen Specter and Representative William F. Clinger.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CHILD PRODIGY AT 61 When Ruth Slenczynska made her debut at Town Hall in New York City, the headline on The New York Times review was:

title: PROST GAINS 2D DRIVING TITLE
description: Alain Prost of France drove his Marlboro McLaren to victory in the Australian Grand Prix today and captured the world drivers' championship for the second straight year.

title: U.S. to Assess Police Shooting
description: For the second time in three months, a Federal Justice Department official is to come to Norwalk in an effort to quell tensions in the aftermath of a fatal shooting by the police.

title: RED SOX HOPING PAST ISN'T PROLOGUE
description: The telephone calls came yesterday, one to Don Baylor and another to Bill Buckner. The voice at the other end said not to worry, that it was more important to remain eternally optimistic in these instances. He said he was speaking from experience, having been there himself not too long ago.

title: Bus Drivers Back Strike
description: Union drivers for a suburban Westchester County bus company voted yesterday to authorize a strike that could strand thousands of county and Bronx commuters.

title: Wellesley May Drop Charges
description: Wellesley College says it will seek to drop trespassing and disorderly conduct charges against students arrested in a demonstration against South Africa's racial segregation. Fifty students were arrested in the protest Thursday, prompting a rally and a boycott of classes Friday.

title: SKY DIVER LANDS IN THE RIGHT COURTROOM
description: For the sky diver who parachuted into Shea Stadium Saturday night, yesterday's date in Queens Criminal Court could be called the case of the lucky draw.

title: LOCKBAUM SPARKS HOLY CROSS TO NO. 7
description: The Gordon Lockbaum show played well for a seventh straight Saturday as the extraordinary Holy Cross player had another big game, this one against Brown.

title: GOVERNOR VOWS TO REDUCE TAXES IN HIS AGENDA FOR A SECOND TERM
description: Laying out his agenda for a second term, Governor Cuomo pledged over the weekend to cut personal income taxes, build more prisons, renew New York City's rent guidelines and increase state aid to local school districts.

title: J. PRESS CHAIN IS BOUGHT BY A JAPANESE CLOTHIER
description: J. Press Inc., the tweedy men's clothier that has been a favorite of Harvard and Yale graduates for more than 80 years, has been purchased by a Japanese marketing and licensing company for an undisclosed sum.

title: REPUBLICAN CANDIDATE STRESSES COMBATING DRUGS AS TOP PRIORITY
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, has established three priorities if he is elected - combating drugs, making the state economically competitive with its neighbors, and creating jobs.

title: Activists Protest Trident Submarine
description: Antinuclear activists today protested the deployment of the U.S.S. Alaska, the nation's seventh submarine with Trident nuclear missiles.

title: BRONX CONCERN IS TARGET OF U.S. INQUIRY
description: Federal investigators are examining payments made by a Bronx defense contractor to a law firm headed by relatives of a Baltimore Congressman shortly after the Congressman began an inquiry into the contractor.

title: Article 146686 -- No Title
description: Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi and his Democratic challenger, Bella S. Abzug, have raised $1.3 million between them in what is shaping up as the second most expensive Congressional race in the state.

title: PARADE OPENS SECOND SALUTE TO STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: True to the indomitable spirit of the American immigrant, hundreds of people ignored steady rain yesterday to parade down lower Broadway in a celebration of the country's ethnic diversity, and for a moment, green foam tiaras no longer seemed passe.

title: ANTI-DRUG LAW: WORDS, DEEDS, POLITICAL EXPEDIENCY
description: As President Reagan formally opened the White House's campaign against drug abuse in early August, he articulated a notion that has been growing among drug law-enforcement officials over the last few years.

title: Three Contests in New Jersey
description: With no statewide contests this year, Congressional races top the ballot. Even these seem cut-and-dried except in the 14th District in Hudson County and the 12th in the west central part of the state. The contest commanding the greatest interest is for Essex County executive.

title: STAGE: APRES CAESAR, IN SAM SEGAL'S 'CICERO'
description: GIVE credit to Sam Segal for audacity. In choosing as a subject for his new play the events following the assassination of Julius Caesar, he is inviting comparisons with Shakespeare, that tough competitor. As the title, ''Cicero,'' hints, Mr. Segal centers his work on the renowned Roman orator, lawyer, philosopher and politician who wound up on the hit list of the Triumvirate that took power after defeating Caesar's assassins. Cicero comes off better at the Samuel Beckett Theater than he does in Plutarch. With the evident approval of Prof. D. R. Shackleton Bailey, an eminent classicist who served as consultant, Cicero is portrayed as a selfless champion of republican virtues. No note here of the weakness, which Plutarch criticized, for filling his books with his own praises.

title: Kathleen M. Troy Is Wed To David Samuel Cohen
description: Kathleen Mary Troy and David Samuel Cohen, lawyers in the Brooklyn office of the National Labor Relations Board, were married yesterday.

title: RED CROSS PANEL SAYS IT FEARS THE EFFECTS OF PRETORIA ACTION
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said in a statement today that it ''fears strongly'' the ''serious consequences'' of South Africa's decision to expel the organization from its territory.

title: Let's Turn Smoking Into an Outdoor Activity
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Investment Expands
description: Every month lately, the Japanese embassy has been sending around lists of ''Milestones of Progress in U.S.-Japan Economic Relations.'' The lists summarize investments, joint ventures and licensing and distribution agreements by the two countries' industries.

title: Washington Watch; 'Last' Chance On Bank Bills
description: NEXT year is the Reagan Administration's ''last big chance'' to try to deregulate Government controls to give commercial banks a bigger crack at the increasingly diversified marketplace, according to George D. Gould, the Treasury's Under Secretary for Finance. Presumably the following year, such efforts are likely to get embroiled in election campaigning.

title: GERSHWIN TRIBUTE IN CAPITAL
description: The music of George Gershwin was performed this afternoon at a White House concert that began with praise for one of the nation's greatest composers and ended with Nancy Reagan's singing to the President a Gershwin refrain, ''Our love is here to stay.''

title: Topics: Cash Flows; Budget Counterfeiting
description: The Federal budget director, James Miller, finds reason to cheer the fact that the budget deficit was only $221 billion in the fiscal year 1986 just ended. He's pleased because the figure is $10 billion less than was predicted in August.

title: Margaret Ann Caspler Weds J. Jeffrey Cianci
description: At Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Margaret Ann Caspler, a daughter of Mr and Mrs. Roy S. Caspler of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married to J. Jeffrey Cianci, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Cianci of Smithtown, L.I. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman and the Rev. Walter Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Red Pekingese Is Best of Show
description: A Pekingese, Ch. Briarcourt's Coral Gable, owned by William MacKay of Bellmead, N.J., and handled by David Fitzpatrick, was named best at the 54th All-Toy Breed Show of the Progressive Dog Club yesterday at Loew's Summit Hotel.

title: Bridge: Estimating the Point Count Partner Holds Can Be Easy
description: A useful habit for a defender with a good hand is to estimate the number of points in his partner's hand. This is very easy if the declarer's bidding has limited his strength within a narrow range.

title: TAXPAYERS SEEK LAST BENEFITS BEFORE OLD RULES END DEC. 31
description: When President Reagan signed the Tax Reform Act of 1986 into law last Wednesday, he set into motion the most sweeping restructuring of the tax system in at least a generation. The signing also spurred what had already been an intense race against the clock by taxpayers looking to take maximum advantage of the transition from the old system to the new system.

title: Laughs
description: A new political action committee called Citizens for a Funnier Future has registered with the Federal Election Commission. Its goal, its founder, David Bolger of Philadelphia, reports, is ''to make quality humor more accessible to the average American.'' According to Mr. Bolger, the committee plans to lobby the new Congress ''for the addition of a laugh track to C-SPAN coverage of Senate debates.''

title: WIESEL ENDS HIS SOVIET VISIT WITH PLEA FOR RELEASE OF JEWS
description: Elie Wiesel, winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, concluded a five-day visit to the Soviet Union today with an appeal to the Soviet authorities to release Jews seeking to emigrate.

title: JETS HOLD ON AS SAINTS FALL SHORT
description: The Jets recorded their sixth straight victory today and reached the halfway mark of the season with a 7-1 record. But their coach and some key people looked as if they had lost.

title: Kuwaitis Fire Two Missiles At an Unidentified Aircraft
description: Kuwait said today that it had fired two antiaircraft missiles at an unidentified target on Saturday night, apparently downing it as it approached Kuwaiti airspace.

title: People
description: * Elyse Zorn promoted to senior vice president at DFS Direct division of DFS Dorland Worldwide.

title: God in the Clubhouse
description: If you think it was God's will that the Mariners lost 95 games this season, don't tell Dick Balderson. Too often, Seattle's general manager says, he's heard some of his own players explain a loss the same way, which, he concludes, may be the reason they lose so frequently.

title: YOUNGER RIDERS RIPE FOR BREEDERS'
description: THREE years ago, when the Breeders' Cup was still in planning stages, doctors were telling Randy Romero he would never ride again after suffering second-degree burns over 80 percent of his body. Jose Santos was looking for a way out of his native Chile, and Gary Stevens was riding horses at tiny Le Bois Downs in Idaho.

title: ATLANTA BANKER LED DESEGREGATION PANEL
description: John A. Sibley, an Atlanta banker and lawyer whose special committee on schools was credited with explaining the state's desegregation crisis to Georgia citizens, died Saturday in Atlanta. He was 98 years old.

title: OPERA: 'ORLANDO' AND 'PARSIFAL,' AT CHICAGO LYRIC
description: In Handel's ''Orlando,'' the hero struggles to abjure the softnesses of love and to turn instead to military glory in defense of Christendom. In Wagner's ''Parsifal,'' a naive youth turns away from fleshly pleasure to become, through compassion, a vessel of salvation, and to join an order of knights who do battle with the forces of evil. Both are long and demanding operas, and the Lyric Opera of Chicago tackled both for the first time this season.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: VIETNAMESE IN HONG KONG: THE BITTER LAST STOP
description: One of the inmates of Hong Kong's refugee detention camps hanged himself this month. After trying vainly for eight years to escape the camp by winning permanent sanctuary in some country other than Vietnam, he had finally given up.

title: NETS MARKET WASHINGTON
description: CHARTERED buses will leave from Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, Dwayne (Pearl) Washington's alma mater, for all Net games. At the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, fans will be seated in a special cheering section.

title: COMPUTERS A 'BIG BANG' WORRY
description: The ''Big Bang'' that will open up London's financial markets starting Monday has been looked upon as largely a regulatory watershed. But as securities firms have scrambled to install the computer systems needed to compete in the new era, it has become clear that a technological revolution is also being unleashed - for which few seem well prepared.

title: THEATER: IMAGINARY ENCOUNTER
description: MARILYN MONROE breathlessly analyzes the theory of relativity for Albert Einstein, and Einstein is in awe of her intuitive erudition. With that scene, Terry Johnson's ''Insignificance'' is off on a crazy-quilt, seemingly contradictory trajectory. Actually, neither character is identified by name - they are the Actress and the Professor - but there is no mistaking the real-life models, as is also the case with the Senator (Joseph R. McCarthy) and the Ballplayer (Joe DiMaggio).

title: Give Japan a Turn at the I.M.F.
description: When the Western powers created the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund 40 years ago, they cut a deal on the top jobs: Americans would head the bank and Europeans the fund. That made sense at the time, given their dominance of the global economy and their financial stake in the two institutions. But times have changed. Now Japan also qualifies for a leadership role. It should have one.

title: SPEAKES WEIGHS TAKING POST WITH MERRILL LYNCH OR OTHERS
description: Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, acknowledged today that he was exploring a number of job possibilities in private business, including one with Merrill Lynch & Company, but he said he had reached no decision on his plans.

title: WEST COAST BANK BID MAY RISE
description: Pressure is mounting on the First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles to increase the price it is offering for the troubled BankAmerica Corporation, and investment banking sources said this weekend that a sweetened offer was becoming increasingly likely.

title: PHILADELPHIA VOTERS START LOOKING TO MAYORAL RACE
description: Even though the campaigns for governor and United States senator are not yet over, Philadelphia's attention is already turning to another, possibly more riveting political race. This race will not only determine the future of W. Wilson Goode, the city's first black Mayor, but may also affect the city's racial climate.

title: NEITHER RIDERS NOR DRIVERS BENEFIT FROM MORE TAXI MEDALLIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTWRIGHT ADDS SPARK
description: IT'S nothing personal, said Sherry Cartwright, but perhaps the best thing about her husband's return to work this Friday after four stress fractures and two operations is that it gets him out of the house.

title: A New Poll Shows Cranston Leading Zschau by 11 Points
description: Senator Alan Cranston has an 11-point lead over his Republican challenger, Representative Ed Zschau, according to a poll published today.

title: Fairchild Chip Officer Defends Fujitsu Deal
description: The agreement by Japan's Fujitsu Ltd. to buy a majority interest in the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation is already starting to raise hackles in California's Silicon Valley. It is another sign, some people say, of how the Japanese are overrunning the American semiconductor industry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet contention is absurd, the President was not about to and did not agree to give up all nuclear weapons.'' - Richard N. Perle, Assistant Defense Secretary. [ A11:4. ]

title: Required Reading
description: The Reformers' Target Excerpts from ''The U.S. Senate'' by George E. Reedy, scheduled to be published by Crown this month:

title: MUSIC: FINLANDIA SINFONIETTA
description: THE Finlandia Sinfonietta was formed from members of the Helsinki Philharmonic almost 12 years ago but is just now paying its first visit to New York. The group, conducted by Ari Rasilainen, centered its program at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night on Finland's own Jean Sibelius.

title: Regan Predicts Critical Audit
description: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that his office would release an audit in mid-November that would be critical of various city and state agencies.

title: Winifred Markus Becomes a Bride
description: Winifred A. Markus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Markus of Wayne, Pa., was married there yesterday to Watt Wetmore Webb 3d, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Webb Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. Steven Jacobson performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church.

title: Roberta L. Turkell Is Wed To Peter Schwartz on L.I.
description: Roberta Leslie Turkell and Peter R. Schwartz, graduates of the State University of New York College at Oneonta, were married yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel by Rabbi Charles Agin.

title: London Markets Face Global Arena
description: Never before has the deregulation of one city's financial markets caused such a change in the tempo of its business and attracted so much attention from the leading banks and investment firms of the world.

title: MUSIC: AMELING SINGS WOLF
description: THE songs of Hugo Wolf are well suited to rainy autumn afternoons, and a near-capacity audience went to Alice Tully Hall yesterday to hear the soprano Elly Ameling and the baritone Ruud van der Meer sing selections from the Austrian master's ''Spanisches Liederbuch,'' accompanied by the pianist Rudolf Jansen.

title: Crucial Negotiations On Trade With Japan
description: United States trade policy toward Japan will soon face a crucial test. On Oct. 27 and 28, American and Japanese negotiators will convene in Washington for talks on automobile parts trade between the two countries. The talks will show whether the Reagan Administration has really pulled out of its ideological tailspin on trade policy.

title: 5 Gold Miners Killed In South Africa Accident
description: At least five gold miners were killed and six were seriously injured today when tons of mining equipment fell down a 2,600-foot ventilation shaft, mining officials said.

title: JURY DELIBERATES FATE OF PHYSICIAN WHO ADMITS KILLING WIFE IN FIGHT
description: Nobody in this case disputes that Dr. Russell F. Manfredi, a 33-year-old cardiologist, killed his wife.

title: Treasury Offerings Dominate Week
description: Treasury financings are in the forefront of credit market activity this week, with today's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills followed by the sale tomorrow of seven-year notes.

title: Details of Fiat's Bid for Alfa
description: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest private industrial concern, has offered to merge the ailing state-owned car maker, Alfa Romeo S.p.A., with its own executive car division, Lancia, to form one of Europe's largest makers of quality cars.

title: ALLIED CASE ISSUE: WHAT COMPRISES TENDER OFFER?
description: The legality of the $1.73 billion purchase of Allied Corporation stock last Friday by the Campeau Corporation will hinge on how similar it was to the takeover strategy that Hanson Trust used on the SCM Corporation, legal experts said yesterday.

title: 9 Hurt in Cable Car Mishap
description: A cable car bound for Fisherman's Wharf jumped its tracks on the Powell-Hude Line Friday night and nine people were injured, the authorities said. A spokesman for the Municipal Railway said a theory under consideration was a possible defect in the car's slot blade. The blade and a grip extend from the cable car through a slot in the pavement to grip the moving cable.

title: GRAF OVERPOWERS LINDQVIST IN FINAL
description: Steffi Graf defeated Catarina Lindqvist, 6-3, 6-3, today at the Brighton Center to win a $200,000 tennis tournament.

title: RANGERS TIED BY MAPLE LEAFS
description: Over a period of time, a goaltender comes to know the shooters, their quirks and their habits. So when John Vanbiesbrouck saw Tom Fergus approaching him, he expected the usual. ''No decoys. A quick shot. That's Fergus,'' Vanbiesbrouck said. ''At least that's the Fergus I knew.''

title: C.I.A. IS RECRUITING NEW YORK POLICE
description: Responding to requests from the Central Intelligence Agency, the New York City Police Department is making members of the city's force available as temporary agents for counterterrorism operations abroad.

title: INTERNATIONAL RED CROSS WORKERS ARE ORDERED OUT BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African Government has reacted to the expulsion of its delegation from a Red Cross conference in Geneva on Saturday by ordering 25 foreign Red Cross workers to leave the country.

title: Barnett Banks In Georgia Deal
description: Barnett Banks of Florida, in its first out-of-state acquisition, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy First City Bancorp of Marietta, Ga.

title: AIR FORCE COMMANDER WANTS TO PLACE MX MISSILES ON TRAINS
description: The commander of the Strategic Air Command wants the United States to build 50 more long-range MX missiles and deploy them on trains that would travel the nation in times of tension.

title: 2 Are Injured In Traffic Fight
description: An out-of-town college student was stabbed and another was hit over the head with a pipe in a traffic dispute in Chelsea early yesterday, the police said.

title: IN THE ELECTRONIC AGE, MAGAZINE MATCHES PEN PALS
description: Advertisement No. 2230 reads:

title: STRAW STIRS JOHNSON
description: OUTSIDE, steady rain was about to postpone the decisive seventh game of the World Series until tonight. Inside, behind his shiny maple desk in the Mets' clubhouse, Davey Johnson reacted calmly, but firmly to Darryl Strawberry's threat to break off diplomatic relations with the Mets' manager. Minutes after the Mets' theatrical 10th-inning 6-5 victory Saturday night over the Red Sox, their 24-year-old right fielder spoke harshly about having been removed in the ninth inning in a ''double swtich'' by the manager.

title: 62 INJURED AS THAI JETLINER LOSES PRESSURE OVER JAPAN
description: A Thai International Airways jetliner carrying 247 people suffered a sudden loss of cabin air pressure Sunday night and, after 20 minutes of wild bucking, made an emergency landing in the central Japanese city of Osaka. At least 62 people were reported injured, 14 of them seriously.

title: BRONCOS TOP SEAHAWKS, 20-13
description: John Elway passed for 321 yards today, including a 34-yard touchdown toss to Vance Johnson on a flea-flicker play, and a tough Denver defense yielded only a pair of field goals until the closing minutes as the Broncos defeated the Seattle Seahawks, 20-13.

title: PARK SALE, SQUIRRELS AND TRAPS
description: It's not exactly like buying the Brooklyn Bridge, but some people here have taken in $5,000, much of it from out-of-towners, by selling bricks, blades of grass and even pigeons in Copley Square.

title: 2 Killed in L.I. Car Collision
description: An Long Island couple were killed when their car was struck by another car as they tried to make a turn off the road they lived on, the police said today. Pronounced dead at Glen Head Hospital after the accident at 7:30 P.M. Saturday were the driver, Roy Tenhaagen, 69 years old, of 44 Orchard Street here, and his wife, Elizabeth, 68, according to a Nassau County police spokesman, Officer Frank O'Connor. The driver of the second car, Edward Puzo, 18, of 8 Elm Place here, was treated at the hospital for facial cuts and released, Officer O'Connor said.

title: LACK OF INCUMBENT ENLIVENS L.I. RACE
description: William Carney, the four-term representative to Congress from eastern Suffolk County, this year became one of the most prominent political victims of the Shoreham nuclear power plant when he decided not to run for re-election.

title: BROKERS GETTING READY FOR PROGRAM TRADING
description: Program trading, blamed for causing sharp price gyrations on American stock markets, is coming to London.

title: DAVID HAND
description: David Hand, an award-winning animator who directed such Walt Disney classics as ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' and ''Bambi,'' died Oct 11 in a hospital here of complications of a stroke.

title: PRESSURE BUILDS AS RAIN HALTS WORLD SERIES
description: The pressure period that builds throughout the World Series and peaks with the seventh game gained an extra 24 hours last night when the decisive game between the Mets and the Boston Red Sox was rained out and rescheduled for 8:10 P.M. today.

title: Birthday Flop
description: When Congress, in its adjournment rush, refused to establish a one-time national holiday on Sept. 17, 1987, the 200th anniversary of the Constitution, it was both an institutional and personal setback for Warren E. Burger, the retired Chief Justice of the United States. Mr. Burger is chairman of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution and thus chief promoter of the celebration. More than that, Sept. 17 marks his 80th birthday.

title: Fittest and Fastest Survive in the Deregulated Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLY REMBRANDT WORK TO BE SOLD BY SOTHBY'S
description: A major, early Rembrandt painting - ''Portrait of a Young Girl Wearing a Gold-Trimmed Cloak'' from 1632 -will be auctioned by Sotheby's in London on Dec. 10, the time and place determined in part because of the United States tax reform bill that takes effect Jan. 1.

title: Ads for Suzuki Samurai Expand to Northeast
