description: A week from today, on Nov. 3, the Suzuki of America Automotive Corporation will begin its first advertising in the Northeast for its four-wheel-drive Jeep-like Samurai, which has been selling like hotcakes in the Far West and Sun Belt.

title: U.S. SAYS RUSSIANS VIOLATE DIPLOMACY BY QUOTING TALKS
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that the disclosure by Soviet officials of purported quotations from President Reagan at the Iceland summit meeting was an ''unprecedented violation'' of diplomatic practice.

title: IN HISTORY OF EXCHANGES, U.S. OIL TECHNOLOGY IS OFF-LIMITS TO SOVIET
description: When the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, met in Iceland with President Reagan this month, he ridiculed the President's renewed suggestion that information gained through ''Star Wars'' research could be shared with the Soviet Union.

title: Giants' Warren Gets His Chance
description: There are few sights in sports as graceful as that of a fluid wide receiver sprinting downfield - someone like Lance Alworth or Lynn Swann in the past or Roy Green or Mark Duper now.

title: Weighty Issues
description: As a rule, delegates to boxing conventions are usually asked to deal with no more than the narrow concerns of the sport: rule changes, safety measures and sometimes the convoluted internal politics of their organizations.

title: STANDING OVATION AS LEAHY STREAK ENDS
description: The players mobbed him and the fans gave him a standing ovation.

title: Girl Is Killed In Car Crash
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed early yesterday when a car in which she and five companions were riding skidded out of control in lower Manhattan.

title: OLD FRIEND RETURNS, RICH IN MYSTIQUE
description: It was almost a quarter of a century ago, but John Scali remembers the moment vividly.

title: POLICY SHIFT RAISES HOPES OF FARMERS
description: A shift in farm policy by the Reagan Administration was welcomed this weekend by farmers from Kansas to Georgia as well as by many agricultural economists.

title: Polish Debt Talks End
description: Debt rescheduling talks between Poland and the Paris Club of Western creditor nations ended inconclusively Friday and there will probably be another meeting in the near future, sources close to the talks said today. The meeting was to examine Poland's request for postponement of payments due by the end of the year, put at between $500 million and $800 million. So far this year, Warsaw has renegotiated payments totaling $2.4 billion to Western governments and $1.6 billion to commercial banks.

title: RECITAL: NIGI SATO, SOPRANO
description: EAST and West meet uneasily in music, their systems of tuning opposed in two separate worlds of values. Thus, although Nigi Sato's recital offered songs both from and about Japan at the Asia Society Saturday night, none were truly Japanese, but more aptly ''Japanesque.''

title: Nadine Agree Marries
description: The marriage of Nadine Agree, a daughter of Judith Agree of Stamford, Conn., and the late Martin Agree, to Scott Brian Marcus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Robert Marcus of Great Neck, L.I., took place yesterday. Martin E. King, a justice of the peace in Mamaroneck, N.Y., officiated at the Manursing Island Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: PROTESTS RESUME AT JAPAN AIRPORT
description: Large sections of Tokyo and its eastern suburbs were under police siege today as farm families and radical supporters rallied here to protest plans to expand Japan's main international airport.

title: INSIDE
description: Issues of Governor's Race In interviews, the two major candidates for New York governor, Mario M. Cuomo and Andrew P. O'Rourke, outlined their goals.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS DOWN BY 12.7%
description: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 12.7 percent in September from August's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Neither Riders Nor Drivers Benefit From More Taxi Medallions
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousand Pay Homage To Mozambican Leader
description: Thousands of Mozambicans today filed past the coffin of President Samora M. Machel.

title: Report Finds Hospices Aid Alzheimer Patients
description: Patients in the advance stages of Alzheimer's disease suffered less when cared for in a hospice and lived about as long as those who received aggressive medical treatment to prolong their lives, a medical study says.

title: Arthur Pomerantz Wed To Katherine Ridgway
description: Katherine Diane Ridgway, a daughter of Dr. Walter Stevens Ridgway and Josephine Lardaro Ridgway, both of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Arthur Stephen Pomerantz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Pomerantz of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: COLUMN ONE: POLITICS
description: Political Arithmetic

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1986
description: The World A U.S. official charged the Russians with an ''unprecedented violation'' of diplomatic practice for their disclosure of purported quotes from President Reagan during the Iceland summit meeting.

title: Seko of Japan Surges to Win in Chicago
description: Japan's Toshihiko Seko outran Ahmed Saleh of Djibouti over the final three miles today to win the America's Marathon/Chicago in a personal best time of 2 hours 8 minutes 27 seconds for his second marathon victory of the year.

title: What Have Values to Do With the U.N.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Demand in Spotlight
description: While the American economy is not sending any signals dramatic enough to change interest rates greatly, traders and investors are again focusing on demand from foreign investors.

title: Law or Power?
description: In speech after speech Attorney General Meese has been calling for radical changes in our view of the Constitution. Last year he said its familiar guarantees, of free speech and the like, should not protect us against repression by state governments. Now he has told us that Supreme Court decisions should not be respected as ''the supreme law of the land.''

title: Market Place; Jefferies Role In Takeovers
description: THE increasingly important role that risk arbitragers play in hostile corporate takeovers was demonstrated last Friday morning, when Jefferies & Company, the stockbroker, sold a huge block of their holdings in the Allied Stores Corporation. The purchaser of the 25.8 million-share block, worth $1.73 billion, was the Campeau Corporation, Allied's takeover nemesis for the last two months.

title: Personal Ensign Injured
description: Personal Ensign, the 2-year-old who would have been a favorite in the $1 million Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies at Santa Anita here Saturday, suffered a broken bone in her left rear leg in a workout at Belmont Park this morning and will not race again this year.

title: 3 Sharing a Dream With Celtic Fans
description: The three owners of the Boston Celtics - Don F. Gaston, Alan N. Cohen and Paul R. Dupee Jr. - are canny businessmen, well-schooled in the world of professional sports.

title: Navy Seeking Competitive Bids
description: For the first time in memory, the Navy has spent more than half its annual procurement budget on contracts for which more than one supplier bid -an apparent sign that the disciplines of cost control are gaining ground in the Pentagon.

title: FURTHER RISE IN DOLLAR IS SEEN AS SHORT-TERM
description: The sharp upturn in the value of the dollar at the end of last week may continue for a few more weeks, but most traders and foreign exchange analysts said yesterday that the currency would decline by year-end.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1986
description: The Economy

title: La Guardia Service Cut
description: Presidential Airways, which serves 14 markets from Dulles Airport near Washington, said Friday that it would terminate its flights to La Guardia Airport, effective today, and that it had sold its landing and take-off slots at La Guardia to Eastern Airlines.

title: Ad Pages Off 3.3%
description: Magazine advertising pages were down 3.3 percent in September from a year earlier while ad revenues were up 3.3 percent. The totals, said the Publishers Information Bureau, were 14,635 pages and $476.7 million.

title: GRANDMA AT THE AGE OF 30 OR 40
description: ''I'M footloose and fancy-free. I love my grandbaby, but I don't have time for knitting bootees and baby-sitting.''

title: Empire Plate Special
description: To the Editor:

title: GREEN CALLS D'AMATO CONTRIBUTIONS TAINTED
description: Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for Senate, said yesterday that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York received campaign contributions from three people with ties to organized crime.

title: CHERNOBYL CAUSING BIG REVISIONS IN GLOBAL NUCLEAR POWER POLICIES
description: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster is leading to major reappraisals of reactor safety and emergency planning around the world, even for nuclear plants far different from the ruined Soviet unit, nuclear experts say.

title: CABARET: SONGS BY CELESTE
description: CELESTE, who is singing in the upstairs room of the Greene Street Cafe, 101 Greene Street, on Friday evenings, has been working for several years toward a balance between her talents as a comedienne and as a singer.

title: Jane E. Goldfarb Wed To Jeffrey A. Himmel
description: Jane Ellen Goldfarb, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerry Goldfarb of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Himmel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Himmel of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Emily Korzenick performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Kathleen Frick Is Wed to John Biggins
description: Kathleen Elizabeth Frick, an account executive for Ogilvy & Mather Advertising in New York, was married yesterday to John Coleman Biggins, executive director for finance and economic development in Mayor Koch's office. The Rev. Kevin McGrath performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York.

title: Retirement Rights and Real Life
description: Mandatory retirement is out. Just before adjourning, Congress extended protection against age discrimination in employment to most workers over 70. Ronald Reagan, at 75 the nation's oldest President, is sure to sign it.

title: TOP AQUINO RIVAL AT MARCOS RALLY
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, in increasingly open defiance of his own Government, addressed a rally of loyalists to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos today amid chants of ''Down with Cory!''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did Greg Harris, the ambidextrous relief pitcher for the Texas Rangers, ever pitch both left-handed and right-handed in a game this season?

title: DYSLEXIC STUDENT FILES A SUIT AGAINST HER OLD HIGH SCHOOL
description: A woman who suffers from dyslexia has filed a lawsuit against her former high school in an effort to force it to pay for special classes she took to catch up on her work.

title: TORTURE BY FORMER DUVALIER AIDE IS RECOUNTED AS TRAIL NEARS
description: A few years after Jean-Claude Duvalier came to power as President of Haiti, Hector Estime was picked up at his home by men in civilian clothes and taken to an office in the national palace.

title: McMAHON BACK, BEARS WIN
description: Wilber Marshall sacked Eric Hipple, stripped him of the football and ran 12 yards for a touchdown today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 13-7 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: Gas Prices Off Slightly
description: The average retail price for a gallon of gasoline dropped nearly one cent in the last two weeks, the Lundberg Survey showed today. The biweekly survey of about 16,000 gasoline stations nationwide showed the average price for a gallon on Oct. 24 was 84.73 cents, down .86 of a cent since Oct. 10, survey publisher Trilby Lundberg said.

title: Digging for Dollars
description: There's nothing new about putting prizes inside cereal boxes, but now General Mills offers a new twist. In the coming months, it will add a dollar bill to every 20th box of Cheerios, for a total of $1 million.

title: JEFFREY ARCHER QUITS HIS TORY PARTY POST AMID VICE SCANDAL
description: Caught in the coils of a plot he might well have devised for one of his best-selling novels, Jeffrey Archer resigned today as deputy chairman of the Conservative Party after a Sunday tabloid disclosed he had made a payoff to a prostitute.

title: Boston's Mayor Urges Rejection of Secession
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn urged hundreds of black churchgoers today to reject a ballot initiative that calls for the city's minority neighborhoods to secede from Boston.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Dominion Resources, Richmond, elected Thomas E. Capps president, succeeding William W. Berry, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: PLANS FOR TV DEBATE ARE UNCERTAIN
description: Plans for the only live televised debate of the New York gubernatorial campaign remained clouded yesterday after the withdrawal of the Republican and Right to Life nominees to protest the inclusion of the candidate of a minor party, which they accused of extremist views.

title: Debt-Service Figure Is $57 Billion Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBTERRANEAN ENGINEERS
description: Daniel W. Greenbaum, a mild-mannered civil engineer who runs one of New York's largest engineering firms, thinks of himself as a diplomat, helping clients find their way through the regulatory and political maze that controls construction in Manhattan. But Mr. Greenbaum and the firm he heads are most respected as spaghetti chefs, not as diplomats.

title: Crash Hurts 12 On East Side
description: A patrol wagon carrying prisoners struck a divider on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive yesterday morning, slightly injuring at least nine prisoners and three police officers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL METS VS. BOSTON RED SOX, at Shea Stadium, seventh game of World Series, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:35 P.M., WCBS 880, 8 P.M.) FOOTBALL GIANTS VS. WASHINGTON REDSKINS, at Giants Stadium, 9 P.M. (Television -Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 9 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS BASKETBALL: Dallas Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics, at Springfield, Mass., 7:35 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 7:30 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: The Series From Afar
description: The expatriate pain of searching by shortwave radio through the London night for drifting snatches of the World Series was eased considerably this year by an amiable man named Martin Tyler, a television announcer who has become to American baseball in England what Alistair Cooke is to ''Masterpiece Theater'' in America. This fall, Tyler, a soccer expert, sat back in his cardigan sweater and presided over British television's most elaborate attempt thus far to interest the English sports viewer in the colonial game.

title: PENN STATE IS STILL CLIMBING
description: Penn State went through five undefeated regular seasons in its first 21 years under Coach Joe Paterno without winning a national championship. The Lions' only final No. 1 ranking came in 1982, after they lost one game - to Alabama.

title: Kookaburra III Captures Lead
description: Peter Gilmour switched boats today and sailed Kookaburra III to its seventh straight victory in the America's Cup defender trials.

title: 1818 JEFFERSON LETTER TO BE AUCTIONED
description: A letter that Thomas Jefferson wrote in 1818 to a Jewish diplomat and journalist in New York, in which the former President condemned prejudice toward Jews and reiterated his distaste for religious intolerance, will be auctioned by Sotheby's on Wednesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table of short interest in Business Day on Wednesday carried incorrect data supplied by the New York Stock Exchange for the Manville Corporation and Wells Fargo Mortgage and Equity Trust.

title: Robertson's Endorsers
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson's prospective campaign for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination and his endorsement by such colleagues as the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart and the Rev. Oral Roberts should not lead politicians to conclude that all evangelicals will unite behind Mr. Robertson, a national spokesman for an evangelical group has concluded.

title: Honorary Degrees Granted
description: The actress Irene Worth and the writer Eudora Welty will receive honorary degrees on Nov. 6 at Queens College during the inauguration of Shirley Strum Kenny as the school's president. Dr. Kenny, formerly a provost of the University of Maryland, is a scholar of 18th-century British theater. Irene Worth is appearing in repertory at the National Theater in London, in works by David Hare. Miss Welty, who lives in Mississippi, won a Pulitzer Prize for her novel ''The Optimist's Daughter.''

title: ISRAEL SAID TO ABDUCT SELLER OF A-BOMB SECRETS
description: An Israeli nuclear technician who reportedly sold the secrets of Israel's nuclear bomb industry to The Sunday Times of London was secretly brought back to Israel against his will and is now being held incommunicado, a friend of the technician's said at a news conference today.

title: HURST GETS A LATE CALL TO START: RAINOUT KEY TO DECISION
description: The seventh and deciding game of the World Series was rained out last night at Shea Stadium. So the Mets and Boston Red Sox, still emotionally spent from their 10-inning thriller of the night before, will be forced to wait until tonight at 8:10 to hold their final shootout of the 1986 season.

title: Airline Expert Becomes Oppenheimer Executive
description: One recent day, Robert McAdoo was listening to an airline executive explain how a merger problem was going to be worked out.

title: FILM: TV AND STAGE VETERAN
description: Forrest Tucker, a veteran actor of film, stage and television, died of cancer Saturday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital and Country Home in Woodland Hills, Calif. A resident of Los Angeles, he was 67 years old.

title: Bobby Short in Benefit
description: A benefit for the N.A.A.C.P. will feature the pianist Bobby Short on Nov. 3 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 65th Street.

title: FRANCE RELUCTANT TO CRITICIZE SYRIA
description: A disagreement between France and Britain seemed to be emerging today as foreign ministers of the European Community prepared to discuss their response to Britain's break in diplomatic relations with Syria.

title: REAGAN EMPHASIZES 'STAR WARS' PLAN ON STUMP
description: Neil Drucker, a registered nurse, backs President Reagan's decision not to bargain with the Soviet Union over his space-based antimissile program. ''If he gives 'Star Wars' away, that would tie our hands very badly,'' Mr. Drucker said as he conducted free blood pressure tests on shoppers at a large mall here.

title: G.M. May Scale Back Its Saturn Corp. Plans
description: The General Motors Corporation is scaling back plans for its highly touted Saturn Corporation, according to a report today in the Detroit News.

title: MUSIC: GROSSMAN ORCHESTRA
description: ENSEMBLES like the Julius Grossman Orchestra not only offer a valuable training service to young musicians, but can also provide some diverting moments in the concert hall. On Saturday night, the orchestra, in tandem with the pianist Abbey Simon, played a program of Bartok, Beethoven and Chopin at Alice Tully Hall under Mr. Grossman's direction.

title: NEW JERSEY SISTERS LEAD HOT MERENGUE GROUP
description: Two working mothers who live in New Jersey lead one of Latin America's hottest bands.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOLDEN RINK The ice-skating rink in Rockefeller Center's sunken plaza opens a new season today, a very special one, its 50th. During this half-century, the rink's plaza, over which the Christmas tree towers during the holiday season, has become one of New York's most popular town squares. Today at 2 P.M., the golden anniversary begins with a flourish of activity, including a free champion skating exhibition and an appearance by Liberace, not at piano but at birthday cake, which he will slice.

title: Bernie & Walter Team: Some Self-Promotion
description: Bernie Most and Walter Cohen have been advertising creative partners for 18 years, first at Benton & Bowles and then at MCA Advertising. Since July 1 it has been as Bernie & Walter, which is based at whichever of their homes they happen to be in. Mr. Most resides in Scarsdale and Mr. Cohen in White Plains.

title: RAINOUT DOESN'T DAMPEN INTEREST
description: People dawdled in the aisles at Shea Stadium, reluctant to leave. Empty champagne bottles were scattered in the parking lot. In Manhattan, residents heard firecrackers exploding and car horns tooting as diners and bar patrons hugged and drank a toast to victory. On a night when the Mets gained a reprieve, forcing a seventh game of the World Series, many of their fans celebrated as if the championship had already been won.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 27, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEW TEACHERS AIDED IN GREAT NECK
description: Starting a career in the school district that serves this affluent and influential community can be an unsettling experience.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE USES OF LITERATURE: Essays.

title: Advertising; 'Ideas' Help Appliance Campaign
description: TODAY Black & Decker will start the television wave of its $11 million fourth-quarter assault on consumer consciousness and next month the $6 million in print.

title: Crampton Takes Seniors Event by 1
description: Bruce Crampton became the senior golf tour's first five-time winner this year, firing a final round of one-under-par 71 today to capture the rain-plagued $250,000 Pepsi Senior Challenge by a stroke over Gary Player.

title: AGENDA: OCT. 27, 1986
description: Cutting Traffic, Cleaning Air

title: Speculation About A.E.I. Post
description: The American Enterprise Institute has been looking for a new president since the resignation last June of William J. Baroody Jr. and the appointment of Paul W. McCracken, once President Nixon's chief economic adviser, as interim president.

title: Quiet in the Recess
description: A number of President Reagan's nominees for significant Federal jobs had not been confirmed by the Senate when Congress adjourned a week ago, and a year-old agreement between the White House and Senate Democratic leaders makes it unlikely that any of them will get interim appointments before the legislators return in January.

title: GAME 6 REMOVAL ANGERS STRAWBERRY
description: Darryl Strawberry left the Met clubhouse, went down the walkway toward the field at Shea Stadium, entered the first-base dugout and stood on the top step. He looked out into the mist and heard a worker sitting in the dugout say that the field was in good enough condition to play a seventh game of the World Series last night.

title: STAGE: PUPPET SHOW 'A LITTLE LIKE MAGIC'
description: THE ectoplasm that bounces about the Stygian-black stage of the Lyceum Theater is all man-made, although not until the very end of ''A Little Like Magic'' do you see a full, normal human being. This puppet show, which opened yesterday, is something the like of which you may never have seen. It comes to us from Canada, the home of the puppet troupe Famous People Players.

title: Use of VCR's Growing, Wary Advertisers Hear
description: Almost 40 percent of all the country's television homes are also equipped with VCR's, according to a survey by Nielsen Station Index that goes up to July.

title: Accounts
description: * Homequity, a subsidiary of the PHH Group, to Warwick Advertising.

title: Crenshaw Wins Shortened Event
description: Ben Crenshaw, the beneficiary of a thunderstorm and an executive decision, scored a one-shot victory over Payne Stewart today in the shortened Vantage golf championship.

title: Outdoors; FALL'S SIREN SONG
description: EVERY year since I first lifted a trout from a stream bedecked with fallen leaves, I have not (except when World War II intruded) let October go by without setting forth with flyrod in hand.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS UP SLIGHTLY
description: Hindered by slow economic growth and intense foreign competition, third-quarter corporate profits have improved only slightly over last year's results, based on earnings reported by most of the nation's largest companies.

title: Pretoria Must Deal With Black Leaders
description: Although President Samora Machel of Mozambique, who died last week in an airplane crash, at first appeared to be a devilish Marxist, he later cooperated with the West as a sensible pragmatist. It is likewise a dangerous mistake to characterize the African National Congress of South Africa as stridently Leninist, terrorist, oppressive and dictatorial.

title: Red Cross to Check Supply Of Blood for AIDS-like Virus
description: The American Red Cross says immediate steps will be taken to keep out of its blood supply a virus that is believed to cause a form of leukemia.

title: White Castle in Japan
description: The White Castle fast-food chain is entering the Japanese market, its first venture outside the United States.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CURFEWS AN ISSUE FOR PARENTS OF TEEN-AGERS
description: Parents in New York City and the region are becoming increasingly strict about setting standards for teen-age social life. After a long period of general permissiveness, new rules and curfews are being set amid heightened fears over drug and alcohol abuse.

title: Ranger Cheering Section
description: It was quite a sight, the entire Ranger team crowded around a one-inch television screen at Dorval Airport in Montreal watching the wild finish to the sixth game of the World Series.

title: WHY THE METS ARE STILL ALIVE
description: IN New England, it will always be The Schiraldi/Stanley/ Buckner Game, just as the fourth game of the 1941 World Series will always be the Casey/ Owen Game for Brooklyn Dodger fans. But the epic sixth game of this World Series could also be labeled The McNamara Game, after the Red Sox manager, who declined to replace a hobbling first baseman with a two-run lead.

title: LACK OF DAY CARE WORRIES SUBURBS
description: Like inexpensive homes and uncluttered highways, child care has become one of the great shortages of the New York suburban region.

title: 42% of Ex-U.S. Aides Admit Disclosing News
description: A survey of former Federal officials reports that 42 percent said they made selective disclosures of Government information to news organizations, mainly to influence public debate on governmental policy.

title: AT A CHURCH IN FAIRFIELD, OLD VS. NEW
description: Inside Trinity-St. Michaels, an old, stone Episcopal church here, the words and ways of prayer have remained unchanged for generations.

title: REAGAN DUE TO HELP IDAHO REPUBLICAN
description: The Republican heavy artillery will come to Idaho next week to try to shove Senator Steven D. Symms's re-election campaign out of a deadlock and into the winners' column.

title: Jet Overshoots Runway; 34 Are Slightly Hurt
description: A Piedmont Airlines jetliner overshot a rain-slick runway in a Saturday night landing and smashed through a fence into an embankment, slightly injuring 34 people, officials said today.

title: DARLING'S BIG DAY DELAYED
description: It was a dark and leaky afternoon, and Ron Darling turned on the lights and windshield wipers of his 250SL silver-blue Mercedes Benz, on this, what his wife, Toni, said was ''the most important day of his life.''

title: Big Gain For Tribune
description: Net earnings at the Tribune Company increased more than fourfold in the third quarter over the comparable period in 1985, largely because of gains from sales of units, the company said Friday.

title: Addenda
description: * Sports Illustrated will increase its circulation rate base 2.68 percent, to 2,875,000, and its advertising rates 6.7 percent with the Jan. 5 issue.

title: AUSTRALIANS STAKING OUT TV MINISERIES TERRITORY
description: Australian television discovered the mini-series a few years ago. The results of that discovery vary from steamy soap opera to minute inspections of painful moments in the country's history to first-rate children's programs. In general, the soap operas travel best.

title: SECOND SALE DUE TODAY FOR EAGLE GOLD COINS
description: The second sale of the wildly popular American Eagle gold coins is scheduled to take place today, when the United States Mint will offer 152,000 ounces of the coins to 24 authorized purchasers around the world.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY'S 'TAMING OF THE SHREW'
description: ''THE Taming of the Shrew'' is certainly not Shakespeare's most subtle comedy. Yet in a good production, it can be fun.

title: Oris V. Wells, 82, Ex-Deputy Of U.N.'s Agriculture Office
description: Oris V. Wells, a former Deputy Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, died Thursday at Mount Vernon Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 82 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: GIBBS KEEPING REDSKINS TOUGH
description: AT the time, all Joe Gibbs wondered about was that first pass. Little did he know, little could he know, that right along with the football, a baton would also be passed, marking the end of one era for the Washington Redskins and the start of another.

title: CUTTHROAT COMPETITION EXPECTED IN BRITISH GOVERNMENT BONDS
description: In the new order of London finance that begins with the so-called Big Bang on Monday, the arena of greatest change and most intense rivalry is likely to be the market for British government bonds.

title: SEQUEL TO 'A WOMAN OF SUBSTANCE'
description: WELL into ''Hold the Dream,'' the two-part, four-hour television movie that begins at 8 o'clock tonight on Channel 11, Paula, spirited granddaughter of the fabulously successful Emma Harte, whimpers that ''Grandy had her dream, I'm just a caretaker.'' That is the first serious problem faced by this sequel to ''A Woman of Substance,'' a six-hour mini-series that, adapted from Barbara Taylor Bradford's best-selling novel and also directed by Don Sharp, grandly provided the television equivalent of a good read.

title: 'Reckless Disregard'
description: Beware daring to criticize a media giant.

title: SOVIET OFFICIAL SUGGESTS MINUTES OF SUMMIT TALKS MAY BE ISSUED
description: A Soviet expert on United States affairs suggested today that his Government might have to make public minutes of the Reykjavik summit meeting to rebut what he termed ''a massive disinformation campaign by the American Administration about what really happened in Iceland.''

title: MEESE AND THE STORM OVER THE COURT
description: Jefferson said it. Jackson said it. So did Lincoln and Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: OLD BASEBALL HABIT SAYS A MOUTHFUL
description: It is almost as much of a personal trademark as a pitcher's windup or a batter's stance. A player crams something into his mouth - a wad of tobacco, a pinch of snuff, a couple of sticks of gum or a handful of sunflower seeds. And later he spits it out.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS A U.S. SITE FOR TRAINING NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: American military officials are searching for a site within the United States for training Nicaraguan rebels because countries in Central America have refused to allow such activities on their soil, according to an Administration official.

title: Palestinians and Shiites Declare Partial Truce
description: A truce between Palestinian and Shiite Moslem militiamen was declared today at two refugee districts in southern Lebanon after three days of fighting, but clashes continued in a third refugee area.

title: Article 077186 -- No Title
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported a third-quarter net income of $290 million, or $2.94 a share, reflecting a $252 million gain from the sale of several businesses, particularly the home and automotive products division.

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $378,000. c-Net loss and is after a loss from discontinued operations of $335,000. The latest quarter results include a pre-tax gain of $1,318,000 from the sale of 300,000 common shares of Careercom Corp.

title: MINNETONKA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAWMAKERS SAY CRISIS HURTS MANILA
description: Key members of Congress warned today that even if the Philippine Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, was not actively seeking to overthrow President Corazon C. Aquino, his open defiance was already hurting the young democracy by undermining the image of stability that the Philippines needs to attract foreign investment.

title: Debatable Matters
description: Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, recently agreed to debate his Democratic challenger, Endicott Peabody. Mr. Peabody's campaign aides say they like to think Mr. Rudman changed his mind about debating because of the attention given to Mr. Peabody going around the state debating a chicken. Actually, it was a Peabody campaign aide dressed in a chicken suit and pretending to be Mr. Rudman.

title: DRAIN OF THE LONG SEASON
description: DENISE GRIESER was shopping on Lexington Avenue yesterday for a portable radio with an earplug so she could listen to the Mets last night at the opera. Don Blaisdell was buying one as a Christmas present for his son.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $871,000.

title: Boeing Income Rises by 19%
description: Buoyed by strong aircraft sales, the Boeing Company reported today third-quarter earnings of $157 million, or $1.01 a share, up 19 percent from $132 million, or 85 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: PRE-KINDERGARTEN ENROLLMENT IS UNEXPECTEDLY LOW
description: New York City's first public pre-kindergarten classes - started by the Board of Education as part of a plan to make classes available to all 4-year-olds by 1989 - open tomorrow with fewer children enrolled than expected.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HUNT, J B TRANSPORT SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on trade-in of equipment of $861,615 for the quarter and $1,496,934 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on trade-in of equipment of $183,029 for the quarter and $1,482,991 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 7.

description: b-Net loss

SANFORD SHIFT TIGHTENS RACE IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The key question of the 1986 Senate campaign in this state is boiling down to: How much difference can President Reagan make?

title: Suspect in U.S. Gaming Case Pleads Guilty to 68 Charges
description: Anthony Grosso, long reputed to be the chief of western Pennsylvania's numbers racket, pleaded guilty to a 68-count indictment on the opening day of his trial today, a week after his former top aide admitted guilt.

title: AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: ELVIS COSTELLO
description: THERE is a side of the austere English post-punk rocker Elvis Costello that has always covertly aspired toward a Las Vegas style of pop glitz. And on Friday evening, at the fourth of his five performances at the Broadway Theater, Mr. Costello indulged that longing in a typically backhanded way, In the show, titled ''The Spinning Songbook,'' the singer-songwriter emceed an audience participation extravaganza that suggested a satirical hybrid of ''Wheel of Fortune'' and mid-60's rock variety shows.

title: USX SEEN HAVING HARD TIME IN RESTRUCTURING
description: The USX Corporation may have an exceptionally difficult time finding a way to reshape itself and outmaneuver Carl C. Icahn, analysts said yesterday.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $500,000 from the reduction in reserve for closing a plant in Dublin, Ireland for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Careers; Scanners Changing Marketing
description: SCANNERS, those computerized devices that record product details in supermarkets and retail stores, are causing an upheaval in merchandising and a rapid change in marketing careers.

title: Rating Bush
description: Vice President Bush does not seem to be overly popular among leading political scientists, but they have a healthy respect for his prospects, according to American Politics magazine. It said interviews with 50 heads of college and university political science departments found that only 5 percent of them would like to see Mr. Bush elected President in 1988, as against 25 percent for the first choice, Governor Cuomo of New York.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: HOCKEY PHILADELPHIA FLYERS VS. ISLANDERS, at Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel 8 P.M. Radio -WOR, 710; 8 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 1 P.M. and 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight)

title: Comings and Goings
description: Danny White, the Dallas quarterback hampered by a groin injury, and the Dallas running back, Tony Dorsett, who sat out last week with an injured left knee, are listed as probable starters for the Cowboys Sunday against the Giants. . . . The New Orleans Saints cut Guido Merkens, who in seven years with the club had started at defensive back, wide receiver and even quarterback. He had been injured this season. . . . Jimmy Piersall, the former major-league player and broadcaster, has joined the front office of the Chicago Cubs in a public relations capacity.

title: Glass Houses
description: After Senator Paula Hawkins said in a recent radio interview in Miami that immigrants from Mexico were not as patriotic as those who come here from Cuba, her Democratic challenger, Gov. Bob Graham, castigated the Republican incumbent, saying she displayed ''a mentality of prejudice.'' But then Mr. Graham slipped into a similiar controversy when he suggested that Japanese could grow larger by drinking more Florida orange juice.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This legislation is not intended as a means of filling our jails with drug users.

title: THEATER: 'WHEN THE COOKIE CRUMBLES,' A MUSICAL
description: ''WHEN the Cookie Crumbles, You Can Still Pick Up the Pieces,'' a musical revue that looks at divorce through the eyes of children, approaches a touchy subject from a perspective that is at once realistic and scrupulously upbeat.

title: D'Amato Asserts Green Shifts Jerusalem Stand
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday accused his Democratic challenger, Mark Green, of changing his position on the status of Jerusalem.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $5.2 million, or 22 cents a share, from the company's participation in an agreement for handling asbestos-related personal injury claims.

title: DODD'S RECORD UNDER CRITICISM IN SENATE RACE
description: As he seeks re-election to the United States Senate, with what most analysts say is a comfortable advantage, Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, is encountering dogged criticism over his legislative record from his Republican challenger, Roger W. Eddy.

title: UNIONS LEAD DONORS AIDING CUOMO FUND OVER 4 YEARS
description: Unions, real-estate developers and financial houses made up nearly half of the major contributors to Governor Cuomo's campaign treasury, according to an analysis of his financial reports over the last four years.

title: LIST OF CONTRIBUTORS TO CUOMO'S CAMPAIGNS
description: Following is a list of leading contributors - those whose gifts totaled $25,000 or more - to Friends of Mario Cuomo from Sept. 13, 1982, to Oct. 24, 1986. Names listed have New York addresses unless otherwise noted. Bear, Stearns, $169,000. New York State United Teachers, $104,835.

description: b-After a tax benefit of $640,000. c-Net loss

NEGRO ENSEMBLE COMPANY CELEBRATES 20 YEARS
description: ''It's meant everything to me,'' says Samm-Art Williams, who has seen six of his plays produced by the Negro Ensemble Company.

title: 'BIG BANG' OPENS ERA IN LONDON
description: Amid champagne toasts and computer breakdowns, the London securities markets today stumbled into a new, more competitive era with a burst of deregulation called the ''Big Bang.''

title: SURGICAL CARE AFFILIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: DANCE: 'LAST OF BEST!,' BY ANN MARIE DE ANGELO
description: IF anything, Ann Marie De Angelo has spirit and spunk - courage even to put her soul on display. A leading dancer in the Joffrey Ballet in the 1970's, this brilliant technician and fiery spirit took off several years ago on the freelance route and to dance the 19th-century classics.

title: MANY TONGUES, 1 MESSAGE
description: Representatives of 12 major faiths took part here today in the ''World Day of Prayer for Peace.'' Here are excerpts from some of their prayers, as supplied by the Vatican. Buddhist

title: EISENHOWER AIDE LEFT UNDER FIRE
description: Sherman Adams, who resigned under fire as President Eisenhower's chief White House assistant after a House subcommittee disclosed that he had accepted gifts from a favor-seeker, died yesterday of respiratory arrest and renal failure at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in New Hampshire. He was 87 years old. Mr. Adams, a stern, crusty former Governor of New Hampshire who was an early and influential supporter of Eisenhower's Presidential candidacy, directed the day-to-day operations of the Eisenhower White House from 1953 to September 1958.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $31.6 million, a tax credit of $18 million and a charge of $27.2 million in connection with an accounting change. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2.2 million for the quarter and a net from discontinued operations of $18.3 million for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter results benefited by $5.2 million from the new pension accounting standard which it adopted at the beginning of the year.

title: LAWRENCE FERTIG
description: Lawrence Fertig, who for many years was an economics columnist for The New York World-Telegram and The Sun, died Sunday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RED SOX STUNNED BY LOST CHANCES
description: Their silence filled the room, from Calvin Schiraldi at one end to Bill Buckner at the other. They did not want to look back to Saturday night, but it stared at them coldly, reminding the Boston Red Sox that they had been one out from a championship. Now they were trying to sort out a World Series loss to the Mets.

title: U.S. TO PAY U.N. $100 MILLION
description: The United States told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today that it would contribute $100 million to the United Nations' 1986 budget, less than half of what it is obligated to pay under the Charter, the chief United Nations spokesman said.

title: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Counting Your Tips?
description: A greater Government effort is in the works to collect income taxes on tips, especially those received by people who work in restaurants and bars.

description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the August 1986 acquisition of Pacific Instruments, accounted for by the pooling-of-interests method.

description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE best fun at the semiannual European ready-to-wear fashion collections isn't always on the runway. Sometimes it's in the audience.

title: Citadel Board to Review Hazing Incident
description: The Citadel's president announced today that a college board of review would consider the case of five white cadets wearing sheets who, he said, had confessed to hazing a black student, and that he would impose a punishment by the end of the week.

title: THEATER: JOHN JESURUN'S 'WHITE WATER,' AT KITCHEN
description: TALKING heads talk back in John Jesurun's ''White Water,'' the latest in a cycle of high-technology theatrical expeditions conducted by the author-director. Drawing upon his own experience in television production, Mr. Jesurun freely mixes electronic action and live performance - last season with ''Deep Sleep,'' a movie on stage, currently with ''White Water,'' a videodrome drama at the Kitchen.

title: PHARMAKINETICS LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said both periods included extraordinary gains.

title: ELIMINATING ALL A-ARMS: GOAL IS BEING QUESTIONED
description: Although American and Soviet civilian officials have suggested that arms control could lead to eventual elimination of nuclear weapons, the abolition of nuclear arms is not an idea with much attraction to the military establishments of either superpower, arms analysts say.

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: GERMANIA FA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a charge of $442,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: 7-Year High In Home Sales
description: Sales of existing homes, bolstered by falling home prices and low mortgage rates, climbed 4.4 percent in September to the highest rate in seven years, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: ICE AGE COMES ALIVE ON BANKS OF SEINE
description: APART from a few distant high rises and power line towers, this picturesque section of the Seine Valley, 40 miles southeast of Paris, looks much as it did a century ago when painted by Alfred Sisley and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. The scene 12,000 years ago, however, was very different.

title: 'ISSUES HIT HOME,' ON SENATE RACES
description: EARLY in ''The Issues Hit Home,'' Judy Woodruff mentions the problem with 30-second political commercials: they're too brief and superficial to discuss substantive issues. Then the one-hour program presents what seems like an endless series of experts pondering this year's campaign issues. The effect, unfortunately, is like the 30-second commercials: too brief and superficial. The program, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is a disappointment.

title: RED CROSS MOVEMENT CHANGES ITS NAME
description: The International Red Cross movement agreed by consensus today to change its name to the International Movement of the Red Cross and Red Crescent. The move was protested by the World Jewish Congress and Israel, which said the move added religious significance to the organization's symbols.

title: Wheeling Net $19.2 Million
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which has operated under bankruptcy-law protection since April 1985, today reported a third-quarter profit of $19.2 million, or $3.33 a share, in contrast to a loss of $133.1 million a year earlier.

title: Glitches Snarl London Trades
description: Electronic glitches were the first order of the day as the London Stock Exchange began electronic share trading today.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $354,000 for the quarter, and for both the quarter and 9 months includes a one-time expense of 12 cents a share for relocation of the company's HIAC-ROYCO instrument division to Silver Spring, Md., from Menlo Park, Cal. The company said that savings from a reduced labor force as well as other operating efficiencies will offset the $1.2 million relocation expense in less than one year.

title: Cats in the Wild
description: When he recruited his baseball players to Brigham Young University, Gary Pullins, like other coaches, talked about the nice trips the team would take together. He didn't mention the one to the Little Sahara Sand Dunes.

title: Colombian Allowed Into U.S.
description: A Colombian journalist who was detained at Miami International Airport Sunday as a possible security risk was admitted into the United States today after further investigation by Federal officials.

title: FIRST ALBANY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Baker Head Cites Savings in Merger
description: The proposed merger of Baker International Corporation and Hughes Tool Company, creating a $1.2 billion giant in the troubled oilfield-services industry, could save the companies up to $80 million a year in redundant costs, Baker's president, James D. Woods, said. Mr. Woods estimated the savings could allow the combined company ''to break even and perhaps go into the black'' within a year to 15 months even if oil prices and drilling activity remain depressed.

title: FIESTA ANGLING FOR TWO TOP TEAMS
description: The Sunkist Fiesta Bowl will come up with more than $2 million per team if it can get a game for the national championship of college football, according to Bruce Skinner, executive director of that New Year's Day game in Tempe, Ariz.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The 1985 figures are restated to reflect consolidation of previously unconsolidated international subsidiaries.

title: ADMINISTRATION AND DEMOCRATS AT ODDS ON PANEL TO MONITOR CONTRAS
description: The Reagan Administration and Congressional Democrats are at odds over the membership of a new bipartisan commission set up to monitor human-rights abuses by the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Varian Associates Loss
description: Stung by the continuing slump in the semiconductor industry and charges resulting from plant shutdowns, Varian Associates Inc. today reported a loss of $11.4 million for its fourth quarter ended Oct. 3, in contrast to earnings of $11.1 million, or 55 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales rose 1.9 percent, to $236.3 million, from $231.9 million in the 1985 period. ''Conditions in our major markets were worse than we had anticipated,'' Thomas D. Sege, Varian's chairman, said in a statement.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS SANCTIONS AGAINST SYRIA
description: The United States is considering imposing punitive economic sanctions on Syria in an effort to persuade the Damascus Government to stop supporting terrorism, a ranking Administration official said today.

title: Medical School Group for Human Body Donations
description: To the Editor The issues raised in your news article on unauthorized ''trafficking'' in human body parts (Sept. 25) are of serious concern to the many educational institutions of the health professions in the New York City area. These illegal practices must be dealt with firmly and promptly.

title: Transworld Weighs Restructuring, Sale
description: The Transworld Corporation said yesterday that it was considering a restructuring after it was reported that Ronald O. Perelman, the New York investor, had bought 15 percent of Transworld's outstanding shares.

title: ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F.A.A. PROPOSES NEW RESTRAINTS ON SMALL PLANES
description: Spurred by the midair collision that killed 82 people near Los Angeles Aug. 31, the Federal Aviation Administration today announced a crackdown on private pilots who violate restricted areas over the nation's 23 busiest airports.

title: Status on Smith
description: Bill Smith, the Islander goalie, is suffering from lower-back strain, the team orthopedist, Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff, said after an examination yesterday. Team officials said the problem is not a serious one, although Smith is out indefinitely. Smith was injured working out at a private gym Friday

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 30.

title: BULKHEAD SUSPECT IN THAI JET MISHAP
description: A Thai Airways International jetliner that lurched wildly before making an emergency landing Sunday in Osaka, Japan, had suffered severe damage to its rear pressure bulkhead before the landing, a Transport Ministry official said today.

title: 'MANHUNT FOR CLAUDE DALLAS,' A MOVIE ON CBS
description: TONIGHT'S ''Manhunt for Claude Dallas,'' the TV movie on CBS at 9, is another one of those ''based on a true story'' exercises that try mightily to horrify everyone and offend nobody.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kookaburra III Holds Trial Lead
description: Iain Murray and Kookaburra III put themselves in a strong position to clinch first place in the opening round of the America's Cup defender trials' series by cruising to an easy victory today.

title: ROZELLE'S PLAN FOR UNSCHEDULED DRUG TESTING IS OVERTURNED
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, cannot implement a league-wide drug program that includes unscheduled testing of players, an arbitrator has ruled.

title: MINE WORKERS AUTHORIZE LEADERS TO SEEK MERGER OR ALLIANCE
description: In a vote that could end nearly 40 years of independence, members of the United Mine Workers of America today authorized their leaders to seek a merger or affiliation with another union.

title: Smith College to End South Africa Investments
description: The trustees of Smith College have voted to divest the school of its $39 million in stocks of companies doing business in South Africa, the school's president announced today.

title: 12 FAITHS JOIN POPE TO PRAY FOR PEACE
description: Spiritual leaders from 12 different religions gathered here today to offer individual prayers alongside Pope John Paul II, who had asked them to join him in a ''World Day of Prayer for Peace.''

title: Interest Rates Drop Modestly
description: The Treasury securities market benefited from expectations of good foreign demand and lower oil prices yesterday as interest rates fell modestly for short-term and long-term issues.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results include pre-tax gains on securities transactions of $$33 million and $48.5 million for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectivley, and $600,000 and $4.1 million for the year-ago quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: BancTexas Posts a Loss
description: BancTexas Group Inc., a troubled bank holding company with headquarters in Dallas, said today that it lost $27 million for the third quarter, in contrast to earnings of $537,000 a year ago.

title: F.B.I. CHARGES FORMER AIRMAN PASSED SECRET DATA
description: A former Air Force staff sergeant was arrested today and charged with trying to pass classified information on Air Force reconnaissance to Soviet agents.

title: Advertising; Big Topic At A.N.A.: Change
description: After one of the most eventful years in the memory of advertising people, the Association of National Advertisers began its 77th annual meeting here today with the changing scene very much in mind.

title: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-operating expenses related to the recent tender offer and debt restructuring of $1 million and a capital loss of $2.9 million for the anticipated loss on the sale-leaseback of one MD-82 aircraft. c-Net income

title: Bridge: Giving Declarer a Problem Can Console the Defender
description: One of the higher arts of defensive play is the creation of problems for the declarer. If he seems to be rolling home in his contract, a defender who can give him something to think about often deserves applause.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wedtech to Buy White Engines
description: The Wedtech Corporation - a manufacturer of farm, contruction and mining machinery based in the Bronx - said it had agreed to acquire White Engines Inc., a Canton, Ohio-based maker of heavy engines for jeeps and trucks, for $51 million.

title: FOUND: A BOOKSTORE WHERE BOOKS COUNT
description: Vic Goldie has been to the malls, he has seen the chain bookstores, he has stood before their powerful inventory computers. On his way to literature, he has fought the crowds, six deep at the self-help shelves and he has gone face to face with 16-year-old clerks who think Lillian Hellman is the remarkable real-life story of the mayonnaise heiress.

title: Concert Version of 'Dori' To Have Its Premiere
description: A concert version of the musical ''Dori,'' which is based on the life of the Jewish leader Theodor Herzl, will have its world premiere tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. The musical has a book and lyrics by Eric Blau and music by Elliot Weiss; Douglas Fairbanks Jr. will narrate the work, which is set in Vienna at the turn of the century.

title: Players Support Driesell
description: Charles G. (Lefty) Driesell, the Maryland basketball coach who has been under fire since the cocaine-related death of Len Bias, has been getting support from players and other coaches.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A NEW DIMENSION

title: What Makes Plastic Better Than Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHEKHOV. By Henri Troyat. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 364 pages. Illustrated. Dutton. $22.50. ANTON CHEKHOV'S father was an unsuccessful grocer in Taganrog, a somnolent seaport in southern Russia that by the mid 19th century had lost whatever prosperity it had once enjoyed. He was also a domestic tyrant who beat his children virtually every day, in the conviction that he was carrying out the will of God, and who forced them to spend long hours toiling in his grimy little shop under dismal conditions - on one occasion, when a rat drowned in a barrel of oil, he sent for a priest to recite a purification ritual so he could continue offering the oil for sale.

title: Response to a Beef
description: For the record: Jane Fonda has not made a campaign contribution to Representative Thomas A. Daschle, the Democratic Senate candidate in South Dakota. And, contrary to what some may say, the actress and physical fitness promoter does eat red meat, too.

title: Group Bans Richardson
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, banned by the National Basketball Association earlier this year after testing positive for drugs for a third time, has been barred from playing in Israel by the International Basketball Association.

title: LAWYER FOR HASENFUS SUGGESTS AN EXCHANGE
description: Former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, who is helping in the legal defense of an American captured while flying supplies to insurgent forces, suggested to Nicaragua today that some form of prisoner exchange with the United States could lead to his client's release.

title: Report on Fire Angers Mayor
description: The Mayor of Passaic yesterday assailed a grand jury report on a 1985 multimillion-dollar industrial fire here, saying that the panel's criticism of the firefighters' performance was unwarranted.

title: RADIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Includes a pre-tax gain of $137,000 on the sale of land.

title: READING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes a gain of $222,000 due to an accounting change.

description: b-Includes a gain of $106 million on the sale of Occidental's 20 percent holding of Southland Corp. common. c-Includes a $424 million gain, of which $180.9 million was recorded as an extraordinary item. d-After extraordinary gains of $9 million for the latest 9 months and $222 million for the year-ago period. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: PIONEER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BALLET: 'SLEEPING BEAUTY' BY INDIANAPOLIS TROUPE
description: INGENUITY can accomplish a lot. Yet it cannot necessarily work miracles. That was evident Sunday night when the Indianapolis Ballet Theater offered a complete production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' at Queensborough Community College.

title: CHIEF AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: English Channel Tunnel
description: The British partners building a rail tunnel between Britain and France said today that their first bid to raise money from outside investors had been met with a lukewarm response. Eurotunnel P.L.C. said it had failed to meet its target portion of a $:206 million ($288 million) international share placing by last Friday - the date set for institutions to return placing letters.

title: CHEMISTS VISITING CHINA FIND INFORMATION FLOWS ONE WAY
description: Since establishing diplomatic relations 14 years ago, China and the United States have developed a scientific partnership that has become an important conduit of advanced Western technology to the most populous land on earth. But although many fields of Chinese research are now progressing rapidly on their own, growing numbers of American scientists say the flow of scientific information from China to the United States remains a mere trickle.

title: Advertising; AIDS Center TV Spots Are Set for This Week
description: Public service announcements for the AIDS center at St. Clare's Hospital in New York will begin showing this week as 30- and 10-second TV spots in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with Helen Hayes as the spokesman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1986
description: The World

title: CNW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,409,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter includes a pretax gain of $12,891,000 from the previously announced sale by CNW's principal subsidiary, Chicago & North Western Transportation Co., of an 826-mile portion of that unit's system. Also included is an $11,744,000 charge to operating expense to cover severence payments for employees of the Chicago & North Western.

title: Ferryboat Jail To Open in '87
description: A retired Staten Island ferryboat, which the city plans to use to ease crowding in its jails, will be ready to house 162 male prisoners by Jan. 1, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Canada Duty On Corn Seen
description: Canada is expected to impose duties this week on corn imports from the United States, a move that is likely to exacerbate trade tensions between the two countries, Government and industry sources said today.

title: TRUCE ISN'T WORKING IN LEBANON
description: Fighting continued today between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen near the southern port of Sidon despite a cease-fire agreed to on Sunday night.

title: CITY PLANS INCENTIVE ON HOUSING
description: Developers of high-rise luxury apartment buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn would be allowed to put up larger buildings than zoning permitted if they agreed to build low- and moderate-income housing on the site or nearby under a proposal from the Planning Department.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $5,424,000 The company said it is applying to be relieved of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy status; the company had filed for Chapter 11 protection in August 1985.

title: U.S. Gold Coins Again Sell Fast
description: The popular American Eagle gold coin went on sale again today, with eager dealers snapping up 134,000 ounces of the one-ounce coins.

title: WHAT MAKES PLASTIC BETTER THAN PAPER
description: To the Editor:

title: SHUTTLE TEST SUCCESSFUL
description: Early tests show that a new rocket engine design will eliminate the flaws that caused the January disaster of the space shuttle Challenger, a space agency official said today.

title: MCI Gets Cable Rights
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said that it had obtained the rights of way for a new fiber optics cable route between Chicago and Los Angeles. The route would connect with MCI's existing East Coast and San Francisco-to-San Diego links to give the long-distance carrier a coast-to-coast fiber optics network. MCI acquired the rights of way from National Exchange Inc.

title: FERNANDEZ KEY TO COMEBACK
description: Sid Fernandez, the obligatory champagne bottle in hand, walked around the Mets' frenzied clubhouse last night, looking for fellow World Series champions but winding up stuck in a massive roadblock of people. ''Let me join the party,'' he pleaded at one point.

title: PLAINS PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOUID BANCEL WARREN, LAWYER AWARDED VATICAN DECORATION
description: Louis Bancel Warren, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren who was decorated by the Vatican for his work for Roman Catholic education, died yesterday at his home in Bernardsville, N.J. He was 81 years old. Mr. Warren, over the years, was a member of the Cardinal's Committee for Education in the Archdiocese of New York and a planner for and initiator of programs at Roman Catholic institutions in New York City, elsewhere in the United States and in England.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income of $16,002,000 for the quarter and $57,644,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income of $18,408,000 for the quarter and $39,228,000 for the 9 months.

title: Civil Rights Commission Needs a Good Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO: CLIVE LYTHGOE RECITAL
description: LISTENING to Clive Lythgoe play Edward MacDowell's piano music at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Sunday afternoon was to ponder once again the identity of American music. Mr. MacDowell is celebrated among us as one of this country's first important composers, but the two pieces on the first half of Mr. Lythgoe's program - ''A.D. MDCXX-Sea Piece No. 3'' and the Second Sonata - seemed wholly absorbed by Europe in general and the Germans in particular, this in spite of their references to folk tune and pounding Indian drums.

title: For the New York Legislature
description: New York voters will choose a new Legislature next Tuesday. Here are judgments on some close Senate and Assembly races. We also take note of some legislators who, while not pressed, warrant recognition as well as re-election. MANHATTAN

title: Flying, Fighting
description: The heads of two Federal agencies concerned about aviation safety, the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board, met yesterday to try to smooth over differences that have developed between their offices.

title: AT GARDEN CONCERT, AT GIANTS STADIUM: ALL EYES ON THE METS
description: There was an oddly timed ovation last night during the Lionel Richie concert at Madison Square Garden -right in the middle of a soulful ballad called ''Lady.''

title: COLUMN ONE: POLICE AND LAW
description: Our Crowded Courts

title: MERRILL'S NET SURGES IN QUARTER
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings more than doubled, as it posted a generally strong performance across the board and avoided some of the trading problems that afflicted other brokerages.

title: HELP WITH THE S.A.T.'S
description: TENS of thousands of high school students will invade cafeterias and lecture halls on Saturday to take the first Scholastic Aptitude Test (S.A.T.) of the academic year, and their scores will be viewed by many college admissions officers as a measure of potential to profit from four years of higher education.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT REDSKINS AND TIE FOR LEAD
description: If you thought the Mets' victory was exciting, you should have seen the one the Giants executed tonight.

title: PRESIDENT'S AIDES DIVIDE ON SIGNING OF A HEALTH BILL
description: Advisers to President Reagan are deeply divided over whether he should sign a comprehensive health bill designed to promote exports of prescription drugs and to compensate children injured by vaccines.

title: VATICAN, REPLYING TO CRITICS, EXPLAINS CURB OF U.S. BISHOP
description: In an unusual move, the Vatican yesterday replied to critics of the disciplining of Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle by issuing a four-page chronology disclosing the findings against him and explaining why much of his authority was superseded.

title: Subsidiaries' Gains Lift Texas Air's Net by 82%
description: The Texas Air Corporation, which will become the nation's largest air carrier when recent acquisitions are completed, said today that its third-quarter net income rose 82 percent, to $125 million.

description: b-Includes a gain of $1,324,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Leader of Recovery To Retire at Mattel
description: Arthur S. Spear, the chairman of Mattel Inc., said yesterday that he would retire from the toy company he rescued and restored during two decades in which expansion and financial crises alternated.

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a loss of $20,000 and income of $629,000, both from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $530,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Knight-Ridder
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. has reached an agreement to buy the State-Record Company, a Columbia, S.C.-based media firm that publishes six daily newspapers and two weeklies, officials for both companies announced Monday. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed by Knight-Ridder's chairman, Alvah H. Chapman Jr., or by Ben R. Morris, president of State-Record. The transaction is subject to approval by shareholders and directors of State-Record and by Knight-Ridder's directors.

title: Business and the Law; Pension Unit Seeks Changes

title: A Protest in Punjab Forces Shops to Close
description: A work stoppage to protest the recent killing of eight Hindus and Sikhs by Sikh terrorists led to sporadic violence in the Punjab today and forced businesses, offices and markets to close in the state.

title: Revision in Bankruptcy Law For Farms Signed by Reagan
description: President Reagan signed a major change in the nation's bankruptcy law today that backers said would give new hope to thousands of farmers being forced into foreclosure.

title: Large Volume For Goodyear
description: Almost 12.8 million shares of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's stock were traded yesterday, and its price climbed to a new high as speculation intensified that the world's largest tire manufacturer was the target of a takeover effort.

description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, once one of the fastest-growing companies in the computer industry, today reported its third consecutive quarter of losses. Daisy, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., makes computer systems used in designing electronic components.

title: Shifts Seen in Supply Of Taxable Municipals
description: The supply of new taxable municipal bonds, which has been dominated recently by special financings that take advantage of investment profits, is likely to change with more emphasis on financings needed for government spending projects, according to a research report published yesterday by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: SOVIET TEST MONITORS TO GET VISAS
description: Soviet scientific experts are scheduled to visit the United States early next month to discuss potential sites for monitoring American tests of nuclear weapons.

title: NBC'S COVERAGE OF THE WORLD SERIES
description: SAY this about the World Series: It has been intimate.

title: ADVISERS URGE AQUINO TO RESPOND TO DEFENSE CHIEF
description: Advisers to President Corazon C. Aquino urged her today to take action against her Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile. But despite an increase in his criticism of her Government, she declined, palace sources said.

description: b-Includes a gain of $11,745,000 on the sale of property. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: A 'POSH' SALE TO HELP THE BLIND
description: Vera Drake and Theresa Barber were getting tense. They had been standing in the drizzle on East 60th Street for an hour and a half yesterday and were itching to get their hands on some evening dresses. ''We're smaller than the people in front of us,'' Ms. Drake said, waving at the other women in line. ''So we should be okay.''

description: The share earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 1, 1986.

description: The company said during the second quarter it adopted FASB No. 87, Employers Accounting for Pensions, which resulted in net periodic pension credits of $662,000 and $1,545,000, respectively, for the 12 week and 28- week periods for 1986 as compared to pension expense of $1,690,000 and $3,944,000 for the comparable periods of 1985.

title: CUOMO PRESSED FOR A DECISION ON TV DEBATE
description: Governor Cuomo, pressed repeatedly yesterday for a decision, declined to commit himself to participating -or not participating - in the only television debate of the gubernatorial campaign, scheduled for Saturday.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,435,000. c-Includes a losses from discontinued operations of $1,741,000 for the quarter and $5,603,000 for the 9 months.

title: SHARP DROPS AT 3 OIL CONCERNS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, and the Unocal Corporation, reflecting the continued depression of crude oil prices, reported steep declines in third-quarter earnings yesterday. The Pennzoil Company, which also cited a debenture buyback program, posted a small loss.

title: AMID BOOM, BLACK ENCLAVE SHRINKS
description: For nearly 200 years, blacks have occupied the tidy blocks of housing between John and Witherspoon Streets here, but now the pressure of rising real-estate prices may end that legacy.

title: Court Backs Schwab
description: A Federal District Court in Washington dismissed a complaint today filed by the Securities Industry Association against Charles Schwab & Company and the Federal Reserve Board. It sought to block Schwab's participation in an offering of Schafer Value Trust, a closed-end mutual fund.

title: ORTHODOX ISRAELI STIRS A DISPUTE BY DISRUPTING A REFORM SERVICE
description: A major dispute has erupted in Jerusalem between Reform and Orthodox Jews growing out of an incident last weekend in which an Orthodox rabbi burst into a Reform synagogue, denounced it as a house of prostitution and tried to run off with its Torah scrolls.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $135.5 million. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter and $8.4 million for the 9 months. The company said the loss from discontinued operations in the latest 9-month period includes a provision of $130 million for future estimated losses associated with higher-than-expected costs on several defense systems. The company said the year-ago 9-month results include a special charge of $159.2 million related to the company's decision to downsize its semiconductor and other operations. Year-ago results reflect the discontinuance of Gould's defense systems business.

title: HOPES FOR 'DRUG-GREE GENERATION'
description: President Reagan today proclaimed a goal of a ''drug-free generation'' as he signed a comprehensive $1.7 billion anti-drug bill into law.

title: Thrown Object Injures Driver
description: An object, possibly a large rock, crashed through the windshield of a car on the Long Island Expressway in Elmhurst, Queens, early yesterday, critically injuring the driver, an off-duty New York City fire lieutenant.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,222,000, or 8 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Mozambican Says Storm Wasn't a Factor in Crash
description: The head of Mozambique's weather service, appearing to reject South African accounts, said weather conditions had not been bad enough to have been a factor in the plane crash in South Africa that killed President Samora M. Machel.

title: 55,032 AT SHEA AND MILLIONS IN OTHER SPOTS CELEBRATE AS RED SOX FINALLY FALL, 8-5
description: The Mets brought their season of splendor to a stunning finish last night when they rallied twice to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 8-5, and win their first World Series in 17 years.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago quarter includes a $91 million after-tax gain from the public offerings of units in Union Exploration Partners Ltd., its oil and gas limited partnership.

title: Mistrial Denied In Murder Case
description: A Superior Court judge denied a defense motion yesterday for a mistrial in the murder case of two self-styled revolutionaries, Richard C. Williams and Thomas W. Manning, who are accused of killing a state police trooper in 1981.

title: METS WIN IT, CITY LOVES IT
description: Mookie Wilson stood in a corner of the Mets' clubhouse, just enjoying the view. He has seen World Series celebrations before, the champagne being sprayed like a tugboat fire hose on the Fourth of July, joyous teammates hugging in a moment all baseball players dream about but few ever experience.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rights Group Backs Homosexual Marriages
description: In a new formal policy statement, the American Civil Liberties Union said today that it was seeking elimination of legal barriers to homosexual and lesbian marriages.

title: Two Issues for New Yorkers; Stamping Out Corruption
description: If 1929 brings to mind the Depression and 1963 the assassination, then 1986 will be remembered as the Year of Corruption. From the Donald Manes tragedy to Wall Street inside trading to the organized crime trials to the Michael Deaver influence-peddling scandal, corruption dominates the news. The city's newspapers read like criminal law bulletins.

title: HUGE CROP IN THE FIELD, BUT SOME OF IT IS SODDEN
description: Les Rockers has survived all sorts of disasters: droughts, floods and glutted markets that wiped out all hope of profit from his crops.

title: HARD DISKS ON A CARD
description: LESS than two years ago, the Plus Development Corporation introduced a novel twist in hard disks in the form of a plug-in, add-on card for the IBM PC and its compatibles that permitted the easy upgrading of computers with only floppy disks. Today, not only are a number of manufacturers cranking out these hard disks on a card, making them almost commodity objects, but several have outpaced Plus Development, releasing, for instance, 30-megabyte versions affording three times the storage capacity of the original Plus Development Hardcard.

title: COMPUGRAPHIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $2,329,000 pre-tax, or $1,132,000 after tax, related to a patent litigation settlement. c-Includes a credit of $1,919,000, or 23 cents a share related to the sale of two subsidiaries.

Mexico? Did Someone Mention Mexico?
description: Customs Commissioner William von Raab is slowly, carefully, working his way back toward prime time. Although he has toned down his act considerably, on the subject of Mexico and law enforcement he is still more vocal than most others in Government.
