MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: New Study Released About Self-Regulation
description: The International Advertising Association, a self-proclaimed advocate for self-regulation, has released a new 98-page study on just that topic, ''Advertising Self Regulation: 16 Advanced Systems.''

title: Dr. Raul Trillo Is Dead at 62; Former Physician to Castro
description: Dr. Raul A. Trillo, former physician to Fidel Castro of Cuba, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Queens. He was 65 years old. Dr. Trillo was director of surgery at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn from 1980 to 1982, when it closed.

title: HARTFORD STEAM BOILER INPECTION & INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment gains of $2,733,000 for the quarter and $6,868,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $339,000 for the quarter and $1,822,000 for the 9 months.

title: Accounts
description: * The American Academy of Family Physicians, Kansas City, Mo., to Trunk, Shea & McCaffrey, Clifton, N.J., for its official academy journal, the American Family Physician.

title: Insider Case At Tymshare
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged two relatives of a director of Tymshare Inc. with illegally trading in stock and options of the California-based computer information concern while in possession of inside information regarding a pending $25-a-share merger agreement with McDonnell Douglas Corporation in February 1984.

title: IN BOSTON, LOVE FOR SOX DEFEATS ANGER
description: Some Red Sox fans were embittered today, remembering all the other years the Sox had found some painful way to lose the World Series with victory in sight.

title: SIMON RELUCTANT TO SAY HOW HE MADE FORTUNE
description: Barely six years ago, people guessed that William E. Simon might be worth as much as $20 million. Today, according to Forbes magazine, he is worth 10 times that much.

title: Newfoundland Oil Refinery Acquired
description: A Newfoundland oil refinery mothballed since 1976 has been acquired by a United States gasoline retailer for the token sum of $1 and will be processing 100,000 barrels of oil per day by late next year. Newfoundland Premier Brian Peckford announced that Newfoundland Energy, owned by Boston engineer, Ken Brown, has agreed to spend $20 million Canadian, about $14.4 million in United States currency, to upgrade the facility immediately.

title: WILLCOX & GIBBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,093,000 and $3,567,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Two Choices: Suicide Or Taking 'the Heat'
description: Dr. Jerome Driesen testified today that Geoffrey G. Lindenauer had told him that he had been given ''two choices'' by Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, after their corrupt scheme in the New York City Parking Violations Bureau was uncovered: ''He could stand up and take the heat or he could kill himself.''

title: SUBURBAN BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in June.

title: USX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the favorable impact of $141 million and $172 million in LIFO inventory liquidations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and for both periods includes a $30-million loss to reflect the complete withdrawal of the company from a 50-percent equity interest in Navios Shipholding Inc., and the 9 months also include an $8 million extraordinary gain from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and includes $27 million and $96 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from LIFO inventory liquidations, and for both periods includes the favorable effect of a $24 million unusual item for the reduction of a provision for occupational disease claims as a result of a triennial valuation, and extraordinary gains of $15 million and $53 million, net of income tax, from the extinguishment of debt for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bomb Rips Offices Of Lufthansa in Cologne
description: A bomb exploded in the main offices of Lufthansa German Airlines here today, and hours later a West Berlin official was shot and wounded. A prosecutor's spokesman said both attacks might be linked to the refugee problem.

title: Help in New York
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MORRIS FILES AS FREE AGENT
description: Within 15 hours after the Mets and the Boston Red Sox ended baseball's summer game, Jack Morris, Tim Raines and Andre Dawson were among seven players who yesterday initiated baseball's winter game. They filed for free agency on the first day eligible players could file.

title: James River Offers Preferred Stock
description: The James River Corporation, a maker of paper and paper-related products, is offering two million shares of $50 convertible exchangeable preferred stock with an annual dividend of $3.375, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,826,721 for the quarter and $4,275,298 for the 9 months, and includes a special charge of $164,024,952 and an income tax credit of $81,725,257, both for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $3,098,678 for the quarter and $10,522,969 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split Sept. 30.

title: Odor Reported in Midtown
description: A sulfurous odor was detected over much of Midtown Manhattan yesterday evening, resulting in scores of telephone calls to the police and the city's environmental authorities.

title: Viacom Request Cleared
description: The chairman of National Amusements Inc., Sumner M. Redstone, said today that the Government had lodged no opposition to his request for permission to buy up to 24.99 percent of Viacom International Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Redstone, who controls National Amusements, said the waiting period for his application with the Federal Trade Commission ended last Wednesday.

title: Fun For Grown-Ups
description: 1.Keeping Time The watch pin is a timeless fashion accessory. This 40's pin, decorated with rhinestones and a large pearl, is filled with 14-karat gold. The watch is new and has a quartz movement. It costs $155 in the jewelry shop on the first floor at Henri Bendel, 10 West 57th Street.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that its 1985 third quarter results include $2.1 million of expenses associated with stock appreciation rights, while the 1986 quarter includes income of $1.1 million from the reversal of such expenses recorded in prior periods. The company attributed the decline in net income for the latest 9-month to the inclusion in last year's results of 100-percent of BHC Inc.'s net income and a limitation on the amount of income tax benefits recorded in 1986, which factors were only partially offset by a reduction in expense associated with the stock appreciation rights. BHC is Chris-Craft's majority- owned television broadcasting subsidiary.

title: Colonel and Vehicle
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Train Derailments Investigated by F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was investigating two train derailments in Michigan that were apparently a result of sabotage.

title: CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Army Ponders Lottery Fund To Finance Morale Program
description: The Army, seeking a new source of money to finance its morale and recreation programs, has been thinking of starting a lottery for service people stationed overseas.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of Business Day on Monday about the sale of J. Press Inc. to a Japanese company gave conflicting accounts of the clothier's three store locations. They are in Manhattan, New Haven and Cambridge, Mass.

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $562,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $300,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $5,290,000 and $7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a provision for disposal of discontinued operations of $25,600,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. d-Net loss The company said the results include gains of $360,000 in 1986 on the sale of certain plant facilities and $514,000 in 1985 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: EG&G INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EUROPE BLOC AND TERROR
description: The Italian writer Luigi Barzini once likened the countries of Western Europe to a bunch of ''irritable hens'' more likely to peck at one another - or to quarrel with the United States - than to get on with a unity that would enhance the continent's strength and influence.

title: PRODUCTS RESEARCH & CHEMIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Filipinos Don't Need Rambo
description: Juan Ponce Enrile, Defense Minister of the Philippines, grows impatient with his boss, President Corazon Aquino, to the point that he now openly asks for the support of people who still chant ''Marcos forever!'' If February's peaceful revolution is to survive, his challenge requires a far sterner rebuke than Washington has yet mustered.

title: WILAND SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PARTIES FINDING WAYS TO EVADE SPENDING LAWS
description: Political strategists have found so many ways to evade Federal statutes that the laws on campaign financing have been seriously undermined in the election cycle that ends next Tuesday, according to experts in the field.

title: Goldman Leads 2 Utility Issues
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company led the winning group of underwriters for two issues of electric utility bonds sold at competitive bidding yesterday. The Virginia Electric and Power

title: QUIET CEREMONY MARKS MISS LIBERTY'S BIRTHDAY
description: About 1,500 people gathered on Liberty Island yesterday for the official birthday of the Statue of Liberty in a ceremony that was as subdued and small town in its way as last July's was joyous and extravagant.

title: Could Be Worse
description: Our Congressman is doing false advertising. Every few minutes our television entertainment stops for one of his commercials, each of which lasts 30 seconds and states that he will provide leadership if re-elected.

title: ABRAMS FILES LAROUCHE LAWSUIT
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and four officials of a pro-nuclear energy group affiliated with the political extremist were named yesterday in a suit that seeks to permanently bar the group from raising funds in New York State.

title: Thoughts on Wrinkles
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: On Succeeding Speakes
description: With Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, listening to job offers from private business, people in and near the Reagan Administration are speculating on a possible successor. Among names that have arisen are those of Ann Dore McLaughlin, an Under Secretary of the Interior who is married to John McLaughlin, the television host and interviewer; Marlin Fitzwater, press secretary to Vice President Bush; Gary F. Schuster, former Washington reporter for The Detroit News and former White House corespondent for CBS News; and Sheila B. Tate, former press secretary to Nancy Reagan, now with a Washington public relations concern.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LIKE most serious cooks, I take a certain pride in rarely duplicating a dish served at home in exact detail, other than by special request. Almost invariably, I will alter ingredients or cooking techniques according to mood or inspiration. I do this with moussaka, perhaps my favorite Greek dish.

title: Lawrence Klingman, Author And Public-Relations Official
description: Lawrence L. Klingman, an author, journalist and public-relations executive, died of emphysema Oct. 20 in Carlsbad, Calif., where he lived in retirement. He was 68 years old.

title: QUEBEC CHIEF COURTS BUSINESS
description: When Robert Bourassa was first elected Premier of Quebec in 1970, his foremost priority was the separatist strife that was tearing his province apart. One of his ministers was kidnapped and murdered, and federal troops took to the streets, arresting 450 suspected separatists.

title: GREAT WESTERN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $583,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary charge of $704,000.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Pie Crust: Easy as 3-2-1
description: CHILDHOOD food memories are often found curled up in the fluted crusts of the fresh-baked pies whose warming, golden presence has cheered many a child. Such a simple recipe for all that happiness: Flour, fat and water in set proportions combined in set ways. Each element contributes much to the final product.

title: NBC SCORED IN GAME 7, TOO
description: Michael Weisman is not one to waste an opportunity. And so yesterday, Weisman, the executive producer of NBC Sports, accepted an invitation to say, ''I told you so.''

title: RUNNING TOGETHER, FAMILIES ENTER THE MARATHON
description: A FEW months ago John Jay Schieffelin Jr. was less than enthusiastic about running in the New York City Marathon this Sunday. Then his mother said she would be participating. ''I never had any desire to run a marathon,'' said Mr. Schieffelin, 50 years old, ''but when your 75-year-old mother says, 'let's do it,' you do it.''

title: Iran to Let Red Cross Again Visit P.O.W.'s
description: Iran has agreed to allow the International Committee of the Red Cross to resume visits to Iraqi prisoners of war, a senior Iranian Foreign Ministry official said today. Such visits had been barred by Iran for two years.

title: Yuri N. Babayev Dies; Noted Soviet Physicist
description: Yuri N. Babayev, a Soviet physicist who is believed to have been one of the youngest participants in the nuclear weapons program in the 1950's, died this month in Moscow, according to Soviet newspapers received in the United States. He was 58 years old.

title: BALLET: JACKSON IN 'SHREW'
description: THERE are times when performances seem to be influenced by some external magic. Such a performance occurred on Sunday afternoon at City Center, where Denise Jackson and Philip Jerry starred in the Joffrey Ballet production of ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' choreographed by John Cranko to a score composed by Kurt-Heinz Stolze, after music by Domenico Scarlatti.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $730,000 for the quarter and $6,670,000 for the 9 months.

title: MURPHY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: JERSEY RARITY: CONGRESSIONAL RACES LEAD THE BALLOT
description: An election phenomenon that occurs once every 12 years in New Jersey is at work this year, as the 14 members of Congress from the state run for re-election at the top of the ballot, out of the shadow of national and statewide campaigns.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1986
description: The World

title: In Re Pro Bono
description: The Washington Legal Foundation is undertaking what it says is the first study of the public service activities of Washington law firms.

title: OWLS CLEVER, BUT PIGEONS GET WISE
description: Rooftop sightings in the Clinton section of Manhattan on a recent morning: one plastic great horned owl at 402 West 46th Street, no pigeons; one plastic great horned owl at 503 West 47th Street, no pigeons; two plastic great horned owls, not courting, at 461 West 47th Street, no pigeons.

title: 'Shadowlands,' a C.S. Lewis Episode
description: IN a television world of glitter, screeching car chases and eagerly bared chests, there are few things more heartening than the small, modest production that intelligently remains true to its source material and quietly leaves the viewer with an insight or two. Just such a rare bird has been found by the Public Broadcasting Service and can be seen this evening, at 9 on Channel 21 and at 10 on Channel 13.

title: BELO, A H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KARACHI HIJACKING LINKED TO LEBANON
description: Pakistani investigators have concluded that the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet in Karachi last month was probably directed from Lebanon rather than Libya, Government officials said today.

title: MATTINGLY IS TOP-RATED PLAYER
description: Following are the top five players at each position in each league, according to the ranking statistics compiled by the Elias Sports Bureau under terms of baseball's collective bargaining agreement. Players are ranked at their respective positions based on various statistical categories for the past two years. They are ranked in each category and their standings totaled and then averaged, resulting in the number that appears after each name. Yankees and Mets not in the top five are included. AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: A-ARMS CAPACITY OF ISRAELIS: A TOPIC RICH IN SPECULATION
description: Ever since 200 pounds of highly enriched uranium was discovered missing from a Pennsylvania plant more than 20 years ago, the mystery of Israel's nuclear-weapons capability has been the subject of intelligence analysis and speculation.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $488,000 for the quarter and $904,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $205,000 for the quarter and $996,000 for the 9 months. Revenue represents gross income. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $126,000 and $722,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $416,000 and $536,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: FROM PROTOTYPE NERD TO INCREDIBLE HULK
description: FOR those of you thinking about getting into shape -think again. For those of you anxious to emulate the Stallone body - drop that barbell before it's too late. Being fit is not all it's cracked up to be.

title: Quake Near San Diego Shakes a Large Area
description: A sharp earthquake centered five miles southeast of downtown San Diego shook a wide area tonight from Tijuana, Mexico, to the Los Angeles suburbs but apparently caused no injuries or major damage.

title: Emhart Expands
description: The Emhart Corporation, which makes hardware, chemical products and electric motors, said that it agreed to acquire the Planning Research Corporation for $31.50 a share, or $210 million. Planning Research, a professional services company based in McLean, Va., provides information processing, engineering and technical services to government and industrial customers. One its largest projects recently has been the $300 million automation of the Patent and Trademark Office in Washington.

title: NICARAGUA SAID TO GET MORE GUNSHIPS
description: Nicaragua's armed forces recently received new helicopter gunships that doubled their inventory of the aircraft, the Pentagon said today.

title: RELIEVERS RIGHT FOR METS, FLOP FOR SOX
description: Marty Barrett, the Boston second baseman, who tied a World Series record by collecting 13 hits, was asked a direct question: Did the Mets win the 1986 World Series or did the Red Sox lose it?

title: GOAL FROM ROOKIE TOPS ROOKIE GOALIE
description: The Islanders, who just met Monday with their coach to discuss the secret of combining hard work and a good time, found their answer tonight in a 2-1 victory against the Flyers.

title: CHEMICAL WASTE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grand Jury Clears Merchant Whose Trap Killed a Burglar
description: A grand jury refused today to indict a merchant in Liberty City who, after repeated burglaries, set a booby trap that electrocuted a habitual criminal who broke into his store.

title: SENATE HOPEFULS USE TV TO POLISH THEIR IMAGES
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato released a new television commercial yesterday, a montage of him, set to music, appearing in different parts of the state, talking with people, playing football with his sons.

title: Bowa to Manage Padres
description: Larry Bowa, the former all-star shortstop whose team won a minor-league title in his first managing job, was named manager of the San Diego Padres yesterday, replacing Steve Boros. Boros was dismissed as manager but will work in an unspecified job in the Padres organization, General Manager Jack McKeon announced.

title: ON BORDER, DOUBTS ABOUT CURBING ALIEN FLOW
description: Here on the Rio Grande, where thousands of illegal aliens from Mexico play a cat and mouse game daily with Border Patrol agents, there is widespread skepticism that the immigration legislation passed by Congress will dramatically alter the porous nature of the border.

title: NICARAGUA'S ATLANTIC COAST: BOATS, BATHING, BULLETS
description: In the nearly trackless expanse of jungle and rain forest that is southeastern Nicaragua, all life centers around the water.

title: Effort to Keep Death Penalty
description: Republican legislators said yesterday that they planned to push for an amendment to the State Constitution to prevent the State Supreme Court from declaring the death penalty unconstitutional.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income

The company said the year-ago results include a loss for adjustment to facilities and operations of $92,070,000.

title: TRANSPORT
description: Bumper to BumperPort Authority officials, not totally in jest, are saying these days that Kennedy and La Guardia Airports may soon be accessible only by air. Hoping to reduce traffic from Long Island, they will take the first step this week to persuade travelers to leave their cars at home.

title: ITALIAN COUNTRYSIDE BRINGS FEAST TO CITY
description: YOU can take the chef out of the country, but you can't take the country out of the chef - even in one of New York's most sophisticated restaurants.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT OPENS CONTRA STUDY
description: The Justice Department has begun examining whether a special prosecutor should investigate possible violations of the law by Administration officials in aiding the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Robert Gallaway, 52, New York Air Official
description: Robert D. Gallaway, an executive vice president of New York Air, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 years old.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $224,000 for the quarter and $333,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split paid June 4, 1986.

title: Mondale Panel Found Owing U.S. $260,000
description: The Federal Election Commission, winding up its audits of primary candidates in the 1984 Presidential election, has ordered Walter F. Mondale's campaign to repay the Government $260,000, the commission said today.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Soda Wars Are Heating Up

Hardly pleasure jaunts, these brief trips typically include stops in Lisbon, Madeira, Paris and London, days crammed with appointments, darting from place to place in search of the antique rugs, linens, fabrics, furniture and the like that he cannot find in America. ''Engish and European dealers tend to have the larger, more unusual pieces,'' he says. ''American dealers hesitate to bring in such things.''

title: PIZZOLATO ENJOYS MARATHON SCENERY
description: Sometimes, a marathon is a race, but it is always a matter of survival. That, in part, might help explain the success Orlando Pizzolato of Italy has had in the New York City Marathon the last two years. In warm, humid conditions - the worst kind of weather for a long-distance runner - Pizzolato was the tortoise who caught the hares in the front of the pack, entering the picture in the second 13 miles, passing wilting runners as if they were stalled cars on the expressway.

title: Q & A
description: Q.We have a shallow water well at our country home and the pump is in the basement. Although the house is winterized and heated, the water line comes pretty close to the surface as it approaches the well house. The water line at this point is surrounded by the remnants of foam insulation, and since this was once a year-round farm I assume this was enough to protect the line against freezing. Still, I'm worried. Will this insulation be enough, or must we take other precautions? A.Normally, insulation alone is not enough to protect an exposed water line against freezing. Eventually the cold will get through unless the water line is in frequent use. Such lines should normally be buried below the frost line to prevent this. An alternative is to wrap the pipe with electrical heating tape that is turned on only when the thermometer goes below freezing. Insulation is then wrapped around the outside. Q.I live in a co-op apartment where walls, floors and ceilings are made of poured concrete. There are spaces in the corners where the walls and the ceiling meet, apparently due to expansion and contraction of the structure. I would like to cover these openings, and saw an ad for plastic mouldings that looked like they would be easy to install. Do you know how these are attached or installed, and would they cover up the cracks or open seams? A.The type of moulding you are referring to is made of moulded polystyrene and is usually attached to walls, ceilings and other surfaces with a special cement that the manufacturer sells.

description: Joe Morris of the Giants and Ronnie Lott of the San Francisco 49ers were named the National Conference's offensive and defensive players of the week. Morris rushed 31 times for 181 yards and 2 touchdowns and caught 5 passes for 59 yards as the Giants beat the Washington Redskins, 27-20, Monday night.

title: Coryell Quits Chargers
description: Saying that the change would be beneficial to the team, Don Coryell resigned as head coach of the San Diego Chargers yesterday after a meeting with the team owner, Alex Spanos, who said he was surprised by the move. Coryell, 62 years old, was in his ninth season with the Chargers, who have a 1-7 won-lost record this season after winning their opener.

title: DELCHAMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
STORYTELLING ART MIXES FANTASY AND WIT
description: LINDA GOSS grew up 500 miles from here, in Alcoa, Tenn., an area where tall tales and legends are born in the shadow of the Smoky Mountains. Now Mrs. Goss is Philadelphia's official storyteller, one of the best-known artists of her kind in the country.

title: TIMKEN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest-quarter results were adversely affected by a recent 30-day work stoppage at three Ohio plants.

title: Boston Celtics Filing
description: The Boston Celtics today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to become the first publicly traded professional basketball team.

title: IMPROVING SCHOOLS: NEW ROLE FOR BOARD
description: The nerve center of New York City's public school system, its central administration, is at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn, a 12-story former Elks Club widely known inside and out as ''the Leaning Tower of Jell-O.''

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,641,000 and $5,918,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,433,000 for the quarter and $15,400,000 for the 9 months. The company said in the year-ago quarter and 9 months, it did not report revenue because it was in the process of selling off railroad properties. The company also said it did not have a unit with sales until it purchased Hoover Co. in November 1985. The company said sales and earnings for the latest third quarter and 9 months include those from Hoover Co.; the Rowenta Group, acquired in July 1986; and Furniture Group America Inc., acquired in August 1986. The company said revenue and earnings for the first 9 months of 1985 came from the liquidation of railroad assets and interest income on invested funds.

title: Cash Autopsy Finding
description: An autopsy has found that Norm Cash, the former Detroit Tiger first baseman, accidentally drowned in northern Lake Michigan after falling off a boat dock while drunk, according to the Charlevoix County Sheriff, George Lasater.

title: RESTORING HANDIWORK ON WOODEN BOXES
description: REMARKABLE as it may seem, the number of different woods that have gone into the construction of small decorative wooden boxes is probably exceeded only by the number of purposes they were designed for.

title: CONSENT TO RESEARCH ON THE AGED QUESTIONED
description: A new study reported today that a third of family members who thought their elderly relatives would not want to be used for research had allowed physicians to experiment on them anyway.

title: Bidding for the Black Vote
description: The Republican Party has been running a series of commercials on black-oriented radio stations in the South that feature fictitious black families whose names vary from state to state. In Georgia it is Sam and Betty Dawson complaining that they are tired of being taken for granted by the Democratic Party and making up their minds to vote Republican for a change.

title: 79 ARE ENTERED IN 7-RACE BREEDERS' CUP
description: Seventy-nine thoroughbreds, including most of the best horses in this country and several European stars, were entered today to run for $10 million in the seven Breeders' Cup races at Santa Anita Park Saturday.

title: PARIS SAID TO SEEK DEAL WITH SYRIANS TO CURB TERRORISM
description: There were signs today that France was moving toward closer cooperation with Syria in an effort to curb terrorism in Paris, less than a week after Britain severed diplomatic ties with Damascus, also over terrorism.

title: A MONUMENTAL FLIGHT STIRS REAGAN TO RECITE
description: President Reagan was moved to recite poetry today as Air Force One passed over the Black Hills of South Dakota, flew over Mount Rushmore, then doubled back for a second look at the monument.

GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THROUGH OTHERS' EYES The series that starts at 5 P.M. today under the aegis of New York University's Poetics Institute in Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, consists of more than mere reading. It is an advanced how-to course - how to read not only poetry but also movies, plays and, yes, even architecture.

title: PLUGGED IN! AN APARTMENT FOR THE ELECTRONIC FAMILY
description: WHILE many people are still debating whether to plug in their new color television set in the bedroom or the living room, others are embracing the home electronics age with gusto. In some homes, it is not unusual to find elaborate sound installations, multiline telephone and intercom systems and sophisticated lighting. But instead of the family gathering together in the media room, each member is going a separate electronic way. Today, television watching seems to be a pluralistic activity and represents just one aspect of the electronic home.

title: Shamir on the Phone
description: Now it's Yitzhak Shamir's turn to be Prime Minister of Israel.

title: Man Convicted Of 2 Murders
description: A 25-year-old man was convicted yesterday of murder and burglary in the stabbing and beating deaths of a Southampton couple just weeks before they were to be married.

title: SYSTEM INTEGRATORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATS TIGHTEN BELT BEFORE LAST-MINUTE TV DRIVE
description: As Election Day nears, Democratic Senate candidates around the country have cut their campaigns to the bone, and even gone into debt, to come up with funds needed to saturate television in the final week.

title: IN SECRET TRIAL, INDIA SENTENCES 6 FOR SPYING FOR U.S.
description: A judge here today sentenced six men, including five former Government officials, to three-year jail terms for spying for the United States and passing on secret information about India's military projects.

description: b-Net income

title: BANKAMERICA APPEARS WARY OF SWEETENED BID
description: The First Interstate Bancorp's new offer to buy the troubled BankAmerica Corporation will be much harder for BankAmerica directors to resist, industry analysts said today. But the feeling within the banking concern, they added, is that the new offer is still too low.

title: Disputed Commercial
description: Despite protests from Jewish organizations, officials of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee said there were no plans to withdraw or revise a radio commercial that mentions the importance to young people of ''a close relationship with Christ.''

title: U.S. Attorney Plans to Resign
description: Thomas W. Greelish, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, announced yesterday that he would resign because ''I just cannot afford financially'' to keep the post.

title: HOT LINE ON COCAINE SET UP
description: A statewide ''Cocaine Baby Help Line'' opened its telephone lines Tuesday to help pregnant women overcome addiction to cocaine, a drug that seriously damages or kills one out of every 10 addicted mothers' babies. The toll-free confidential line (800-327-BABE) will be run by Northwestern Memorial Hospital from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekdays.

title: STOKELY USA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; For Hutton, Few Options
description: THE E. F. Hutton Group appears to be doing more listening than talking these days.

Why G.M. Decided To Quit South Africa
description: Of all the troubled places in the world, South Africa is probably the saddest because of missed opportunities. Chief among these has been the opportunity to bring all of the South African people into the economic and political mainstream of one of the richest and most promising countries on the continent.

title: METS ARE LOOKING TO MAKE CHANGES
description: Ray Knight, Lenny Dykstra, Wally Backman, Tim Teufel, Lee Mazzilli and absolutely Darryl Strawberry will be back. Mookie Wilson, Kevin Mitchell, Howard Johnson, Randy Niemann and Danny Heep probably will not.

title: Screening Visitors at the Door
description: IN the middle of ''Miami Vice,'' glass of wine in hand, slumped deep into the sofa, you hear the doorbell ring. There is no answering machine to take this call. It is live. For most people, the only choice is to get up and risk missing whether Don Johnson, driving at more than 100 miles per hour in his new Ferrari Testerosa along Biscayne Boulevard, will make the next turn.

title: LOCAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: NWA Inc., corporate parent of Northwest Airlines, said today that its net income surged 53.1 percent, to a record $59.7 million, or $2.32 a share, compared with $39 million, or $1.55 a share, in the 1985 period.

description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, which had clung tenaciously to life despite years of financial problems, ceased publication last night after its owners said they could no longer afford to keep it in operation.

COACH'S LEGACY: VICTORIES, PROBLEMS
description: When Lefty Driesell arrived from Davidson to take over as the University of Maryland basketball coach 17 years ago, he inherited a program that could barely sell a ticket, much less win a game. Driesell changed all that with his outspoken, flamboyant approach to coaching.

In the first half of 1986 two subsidiaries were sold, Kusan and Tull Industries, and its investment in Met- Mex Penoldes for a net gain of $74.8 million. title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, an outdated version of the main sports page, D29, appeared in some late-edition copies on Tuesday, causing omission or duplication of phrases in article continuations. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: WALHEIM ADMITS ROLE IN NAZI UNIT
description: A spokesman for Kurt Waldheim said tonight that the Austrian President was connected with a Nazi unit that participated in a massacre of Yugoslav civilians in 1942. Mr. Waldheim had previously denied any involvement in the operation.

title: 2 Everest Expeditions Off
description: Two United States climbing teams have abandoned attempts to scale Mount Everest after the onset of winter weather. A publicist for one group, Grant Benson of Tacoma, said Tuesday that climbers in ''Everest '86: Americans to China'' had called off the climb. Snow and high winds forced that group and the other, led by Andrew Harvard, to abandon their efforts after reaching the 25,000-foot level.

title: Success Is Reported In New Missile Test
description: An bypassed electronic jammers aboard a target drone aircraft and successfully intercepted it in the first test of the weapon's ability to overcome attempts to foil its guidance system, the Pentagon said today.

title: MEDICAL IMAGING CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Illiteracy Statistics: A Numbers Game
description: Education writers do not have an enviable job these days. Every month, a new statistical report appears that purports to present the ''latest truth'' about illiteracy in the United States.

title: Topics: Blasts; Pro-Death
description: Whoever planted a bomb in a flower pot at the Eastern Women's Center, an abortion clinic on the East side of Manhattan, thereby renounced any respect for life.

title: TREASURY SECURITIES REBOUND
description: Treasury note and bond prices rebounded yesterday in response to falling oil prices and Japanese press reports that the Bank of Japan is considering a cut in the discount rate.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the United States visit of Francois Leotard, France's Minister of Culture and Communications, omitted the time and place of his comments. Mr. Leotard was interviewed on Tuesday at The New York Times.

title: ECOLOGISTS PRESS LENDING GROUPS
description: The World Bank and other international development institutions are being pressed to stop financing what critics, including the Reagan Administration, complain are environmentally destructive projects.

title: BLUES ROUT RANGERS AND VANBIESBROUCK
description: The St. Louis Blues entered tonight's game against the Rangers as the lowest-scoring team in the National Hockey League with 17 goals in seven games. By game's end, though, the Blues no longer had that dubious distinction, thanks to a 7-2 victory over the Rangers that evened St. Louis's record at 3-3-2. The Rangers slipped to 2-4-4 as their six-game unbeaten streak came to an end.

title: I.R.A.'S TO LOSE SOME PUNCH
description: Individual Retirement Accounts, which became an American institution in a few short years, lose a lot of their allure under the new tax law. Millions of middle- and upper-income workers covered by a company pension plan will no longer be allowed to claim deductions for I.R.A. contributions.

MEHL'S CAREER IS IN JEOPARDY
description: A four-man surgical team operated today on the right knee of Lance Mehl, the Jets' Pro Bowl linebacker, in an attempt to save his career.

title: Brightening Winter's Gray by Planting Evergreens in the Fall
description: CITY gardeners have a choice now: continue staring at a bare balcony, terrace or yard until spring - or add species of needle evergreens for a brighter winter outlook instead. Some may be fearful about autumn planting, but nurserymen have found that for both plant, and planter, there are advantages to using the time between now and Thanksgiving.

title: INSIDE
description: Rikers Jail Inquiry Widens Federal and city investigators say the recent violence on Rikers Island was far more serious than was first reported.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AMONG the seasonal changeovers that most homeowners have to tackle at this time of year are two closely related chores: Laying up the power mower for the winter so it will be ready to go next spring, and getting the snow thrower out of winter storage.

title: Skadden, Arps Disqualified From Robins Case
description: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, a New York law firm, was disqualified yesterday from representing the A.H. Robins Company in its bankruptcy proceedings.

title: BOSTON ENFOLDS ITS HEROES, WAIVING NOTE OF A DEPLORABLE FACT
description: What do you say in a great sports town after the other team won? That it is a great sports town. Boston today basked in penultimate glory, with a parade and rally at City Hall for the Red Sox, who were pointedly referred to as the American League champions, and not as the World Series almost-made-its. The activities included a marching band, twirlers, speeches, airplanes towing banners and a lot of all-round good feeling, with an understandable lack of specificity.

title: TBC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amazin' Seibu
description: It was as dramatic a postseason comeback as professional baseball has ever seen, and when it was over Monday the police didn't have to ride onto the field to keep celebrating hometown fans at bay. That's partly because the home fans didn't have anything to celebrate, and partly because this was not the Mets beating the Red Sox in raucous New York but the Seibu Lions beating the Hiroshima Toyo Carp in decorous Hiroshima.

title: ARREST IN WESTCHESTER SLAYING
description: A self-employed contractor was ordered held without bail yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a Somers woman.

title: Zambian Blames Pretoria For Mozambican Crash
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, repeating earlier charges, said today that there was ''sufficient, circumstantial evidence'' to hold South Africa responsible for the death of President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PAPER: The Life and Death of the New York Herald Tribune. By Richard Kluger with the assistance of Phyllis Kluger. Illustrated. 801 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. IT has always seemed to this observer a dubious notion that an institution can possess a life of its own. Any organization is the sum of its people, and to ascribe independent life to it is at best fuzzy-minded and at worst totalitarian. And yet, upon finishing ''The Paper'' by Richard Kluger and witnessing in its closing pages the demise of The New York Herald Tribune, one feels as if one is mourning the death of a close friend. Perhaps the greatest compliment that one can pay Mr. Kluger's monumental new book is that it forces one to get his categories mixed up and to be all the happier for that confusion.

title: Judge's Leave To Be Weighed
description: The State Court of Appeals said yesterday that it would consider suspending Justice Francis X. Smith, the state's administrative judge in Queens, with or without pay because of his indictment on perjury charges.

description: The United Farm Workers Union, backed by New York City's major trade unions, began a nationwide boycott Tuesday of A.&P. stores after the supermarket chain refused to take California grapes from its shelves.

title: HORNER BECOMES FREE AGENT
description: Bob Horner, who is virtually certain to join baseball's select circle of $2 million-a-year players, was one of six players who filed for free agency yesterday. Thirteen players, five of whom earned $1 million or more this year, have placed their names on the free-agent list in the first two days of the 15-day filing period.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $616,000 and a gain on disposal of $10,558,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the spread of the virus is not checked, the present epidemic could become a catastrophe.

title: AIR-CONDITIONING DOES WONDERS FOR 'GREEN HELL'
description: When the rains and the heat coincide and late-afternoon swarms of mosquitoes recall morning headlines about malaria raging in the jungle, it is still just possible to evoke this city's old image as the inhospitable capital of the ''green hell'' of the Amazon.

title: 'No Fishing' Zone Imposed Off Falklands
description: Britain moved today to halt overfishing around the Falkland Islands and to head off Argentine encroachment by declaring a 150-mile protected zone.

title: Technology; New Challenge In Automation
description: AMERICAN manufacturers have long comforted themselves with the knowledge than the United States leads the world in the development of new manufacturing technology. Many of them believe they can use that lead to gain a competitive edge on foreign rivals.

title: Genoa Court Explains Achille Lauro Sentence
description: A panel of Italian judges said Tuesday that a hijacker of the cruise ship Achille Lauro received a 30-year sentence for murder, rather than life imprisonment, because he had been raised in a climate of violence in Palestinian refugee centers.

title: PRIVATE LIBRARIES SEEM PART CLUB, PART MUSEUM AND ALL CHARM
description: OFTEN when New Yorkers stumble upon one of Manhattan's three private libraries for the first time, they are uncertain about exactly what they have found.

title: RIKERS ISLAND VIOLENCE WAS WORSE THAN REPORTED, INVESTIGATORS SAY
description: Federal and city officials investigating the violence that rocked Rikers Island on Oct. 17 say it was far worse than first reported and are focusing on whether the two worst incidents that night were planned by guards in retaliation for earlier disturbances by inmates.

title: RIGHT AND WRONG KINDS OF LOVE IN THE THEATER
description: WILL you love me? Sorry to be so forward. But if you're startled to be asked that question by a total stranger in print in a newspaper, imagine the feeling when asked it by a total stranger in the flesh in a theater. That's the disconcerting ambush that awaits trusting visitors to ''The Concept,'' the earnest documentary play about drug addicts and their rehabilitation. As the performance ends, the cast members, real-life recovered addicts all, venture into the auditorium, ask individual patrons, ''Will you love me?'' and then demand a hug to prove that the answer is ''yes.''

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BERGEN, AFTER 271 YEARS, TO ELECT FIRST EXECUTIVE
description: Bergen County's 271-year-old form of government - which critics have called fragmented, weak and obscure - vanishes with the election of the county's first Executive next Tuesday.

title: U.S. to Offer $1 Silver Coin
description: The United States Mint today struck a $1 American Eagle silver bullion coin, the first investment-grade silver bullion coin ever issued by the Government.

title: JOHN BRAINE, BRITISH NOVELIST AND PLAYWRIGHT, DEAD AT 64
description: John Braine, the novelist and playwright, who was a leading figure in the British generation of ''Angry Young Men'' in the 1950's, died Tuesday in a London hospital after a burst stomach ulcer, his family reported yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: A NIGHT FOR GHOSTS, REAL AND UNREAL

title: Bell Assails Sandinistas Over Case of U.S. Flier
description: Griffin Bell, the former Attorney General who is seeking to defend a captured American flier before a Nicaraguan tribunal, arrived here today from Managua and said he could not see his client.

title: CAPITOL CHRISTMAS TREE TO GET A GRAND SEND-OFF

description: From giant public corporations to small family enterprises, companies are frantically trying to buy and sell businesses - or even liquidate themselves - before the sweeping new tax law goes into effect on Jan. 1, increasing their tax bills.

title: MUSIC: LIBERTY GALA AT AVERY FISHER
description: ''EVERY party has to come to an end, and tonight we tip our hats to Lady Liberty and sing to her one last time,'' announced Lee Iacocca from the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening. The occasion was the all-star finale of the series of events celebrating the Statue of Liberty's 100th anniversary.

title: Delay Denied For Manville
description: Judge Burton R. Lifland of Federal Bankruptcy Court yesterday ruled, for the second time, that disgruntled shareholders of the Manville Corporation, which has been in bankruptcy proceedings for four years, should not be allowed to delay the reorganization by forcing the company to hold a shareholders meeting.

description: A bomb exploded in a midtown Manhattan abortion clinic early yesterday morning, but the center opened later in the day.

title: Memorial Will Honor Black Patriots in U.S.
description: The newest memorial in the nation's capital will honor a group of people whose contributions to the American Revolution are largely unrecognized: the 5,000 blacks who fought in the Continental Army and Navy against the British.

title: AQUINO'S MORAL TONE: IS ANYBODY LISTENING?

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Tuesday, about a Federal crackdown against private pilots who violate airspace rules, incorrectly reported recent enforcement actions in the Los Angeles area. Twenty-five pilots have been accused of violations that could result in license suspensions of 60 days, double the penalty previously authorized.

title: Commercial Credit Stock Active
description: The stock of the Commercial Credit Company was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange following the company's initial public offering of 38 million shares at $20.50 a share. About 8.75 million shares traded hands.

title: Port Everglades
description: A $105.4 million issue of Port Everglades Authority, Fla., port facilities revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.572 percent for a 7 percent issue due in 2016 at a price of 93 1/4, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert. Yields on serial bonds ranged from 4 1/4 percent in 1987 to 5 3/4 percent in 1991, 6 3/4 percent in 1996 and 7.2 percent in 2001. Term bonds due in 2006 were offered at par to yield 7 1/2 percent. All the bonds are rated A by S.&P.

title: German Jailed In Fraud Case
description: A West German builder was jailed today for six and a half years and fined the equivalent of $45,000 for defrauding a Saudi Arabian of about $50 million.

LaRouche Jr. Judge Leonard Sokolove of Bucks County issued the order Tuesday after the daughters of Elizabeth Rose testified that LaRouche followers befriended their mother, then persuaded her to give them 62,000 shares in Dwight & Church.

title: YAMANI OUSTED AS OIL MINISTER OF SAUDI ARABIA
description: In a move that stunned oil specialists, the King of Saudi Arabia yesterday abruptly removed Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the chief architect of the Arabs' campaign to control their oil resources, as the Saudi oil minister.

title: For the House From New York
description: We usually adhere to an Incumbency Principle, that officials who perform creditably deserve re-election, but the principle doesn't help much this year. In two contested House races in metropolitan New York, in Queens and in Suffolk County, there are no incumbents. In a third, in Westchester County, both candidates can be described as incumbents. Only in the fourth race, in Manhattan, is the principle useful. 15th District (Manhattan East Side): This is the sole Democratic district in the country represented by a Republican, and with good reason. The Republican is Bill Green, a sober lawyer and a smart, diligent legislator. By giving him a sixth term, voters will give him added seniority where it counts, on the Appropriations Committee. Mr. Green has repeatedly won housing funds for the district and city. He has been a searching overseer of NASA. That he is a Republican helps the city during a Republican Administration. That he is a moderate Republican brings welcome balance to his party.

title: RELUCTANT DRIESELL QUITS AS COACH
description: After months of saying he would not quit, a subdued Charles G. (Lefty) Driesell reluctantly resigned today as head basketball coach at the University of Maryland. Driesell said he would accept a position as assistant athletic director under an eight year-contract with Maryland that would pay him about $900,000.

title: Hats On
description: At the suggestion of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Senate has quietly amended its rules to permit spectators in the gallery of the chamber to wear hats. The New York Democrat, at the behest of a constituent, wrote the Senate Sergeant-at-Arms, Ernest E. Garcia, last July that a rule against men wearing hats ''could lead a Jewish or a Sikh guest to forgo visiting our chamber.''

title: THE DANCE: ROSAS TROUPE AT NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL
description: TO put it simply, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker is a minimalist. But even though that's not an inaccurate description of her, it may also be a somewhat misleading way to classify the Belgian choreographer who offered a work lasting about an hour and 40 minutes, without intermission, last night as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: G.M. WORKERS IN SOUTH AFRICA GO OUT ON STRIKE
description: Employees of the General Motors Corporation in South Africa went on strike today, seeking a greater say in company affairs once the unit is sold to South African interests.

title: OPERA: 'TSAR'S BRIDE'
description: ''The Tsar's Bride'' would seem an unpromising candidate for revival. Even when it first appeared in 1899, Rimsky-Korsakov's opera must have struck a Wagner-infatuated world as a retrograde, primitive work. And, in fact, with its old-fashioned structure of arias, duets and other set pieces, it does belong to an earlier, more innocent time in opera's history. Nevertheless, as the Washington Opera's performance demonstrated Tuesday evening, ''The Tsar's Bride'' can be both dramatically workable and lyrically enchanting when produced by people who understand and honor its tradition.

title: HOW TO FIGURE A CROWD SIZE: TAKE A GUESS
description: Like medicine, Kremlinology and dead-reckoning navigation, determining crowd size is an inexact science.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $970,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit for both the quarter and 6 months, and net of $1,156,000, or 15 cents a share and $2,336,000, or 31 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, related to the Youngs Drug Products Business acquired Sept. 13, 1985. c-Includes net of $200,000 related to Youngs Drug Products Business for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the latest quarter includes sales from Youngs of $11,547,000 and $21,467,000 for the 6 months; and $1,650,000 for both the year-ago quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S.I.A. TO APPEAL RULING ON FILM-APPROVAL SYSTEM
description: The United States Information Agency said today that it would appeal a decision by a Federal judge here who has held unconstitutional the regulations the agency uses to approve distribution of documentary films abroad.

title: Peoples Jewellers Adds to Bid for Zale
description: Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto resumed its bid for the Zale Corporation yesterday, joining with Swarovski International Holding of Zurich to offer $50 a share in cash, or about $550 million, for the largest jewelry retailer in the United States.

title: Advertising; McCaffrey & McCall Loses ABC Sports
description: ABC Sports is leaving McCaffrey & McCall, its agency of 23 years, for Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK.

title: JAZZ: SHIRLEY HORN RETURNS
description: SHIRLEY HORN, a pianist and singer from Washington, has been a will-o'-the-wisp to New York audiences during the last four and a half years. Since early 1982, when she came back to the city for the first time since her debut here 20 years earlier with Miles Davis at the Village Vanguard, she has made only a few brief visits with relatively little fanfare.

title: PANDICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Las Vegas Resort
description: Golden Nugget Inc., a leading casino-hotel operator, said it had assembled more than 80 acres on the Las Vegas Strip for development of a self-contained resort.

title: PACESETTER OF OPEC: SHEIK AHMED ZAKI YAMANI
description: He was dismissed the way he had ministered: by royal decree.

title: A.C.L.U. CRITICIZES PENTAGON 'HATE' GROUP POLICY
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, which defended the right of American Nazis to march in a Jewish suburb of Chicago 10 years ago, is now challenging the Pentagon over its efforts to curtail participation by military personnel in white supremacist or other ''hate'' groups.

title: A.T.& T. REVISES COMPUTER STRATEGY
description: Seeking to strengthen its weak computer division, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian office equipment maker, would be given full responsibility for developing and manufacturing its line of I.B.M.-compatible personal computers.

title: BITTER DIOGUARDI-ABZUG RACE: SPICE FOR A BLAND BALLOT
description: As Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi and his Democratic challenger, Bella S. Abzug, settled themselves around the microphones at WFAS Radio in Hartsdale for their second debate of the day, the station's sound technician, with a look of fear on his face, asked them please not to shout, he had a headache.

title: Hey, Coach, What's a Sideline?
description: Well, one thing you can't say is that Krieg and Lomax never got a chance. Among all N.F.L. quarterbacks, these have compiled the longest current streaks of regular-season starts:

title: CULTURAL BOOM STIRRING IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA
description: Easy-going as they are, to deal in a gross generality, southern Californians are truly rankled when this region is dismissed in matters of the arts and culture as a black hole in space.

title: Nader Says Reagan Is Telling 'Big Lie' About the Economy
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, asserted Wednesday that President Reagan was selling ''the big lie'' about the economy as he campaigns across the nation for Republican candidates.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JAMES MADISON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $130,000 on the sale of leaseholds for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $40,000 on sale of leaseholds.

title: GUGGENHEIM HEARINGS TO REOPEN
description: The New York City Board of Standards and Appeals has voted to reopen public hearings on the proposed expansion of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, in order to consider a revised plan to enlarge the museum building. The new plan, to be done by the New York architectural firm Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, will replace the original scheme presented by the same firm.

title: NWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $17,231,000 from non-recurring costs associated with integrating Northwest Airlines and Republic Airlines, and a charge of $13.3 million related to the method of handling investment tax credits on leased aircraft. The latest third quarter results included the acquisition of Republic Airlines, effective Aug. 12.

title: DOFASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Ecuador to Get Loan
description: Officials from the New York branch of Banque Paribas have announced a loan for up to $220 million to Ecuador, backed by that country's oil exports.

title: In the Name of Love
description: To mark the recent installation of Bonita Granville Wrather as chairman of its board, the American Film Institute has begun a retrospective of the actress's films. The other night at its Kennedy Center theater, for example, it showed ''These Three,'' a 1936 adaptation of Lillian Hellman's play ''The Children's Hour.''

title: Instinet Talks
description: The Instinet Corporation said it had authorized members of its board to meet with officials from Reuters Holdings P.L.C. to discuss Reuters' proposal to acquire Instinet for $92 million.

title: GHOSTLY DISPUTE SETTLED IN EARTHLY MANNER
description: In a litigious society anything can come to court, and so it was no surprise during Halloween week to find ghosts before the bar.

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ferraro's Car Recovered
description: The police found a car belonging to Geraldine A. Ferraro yesterday morning, about 24 hours after it was reported stolen from outside the former United States Representative's house in Forest Hills, Queens, the authorities said. The 1982 gray Oldsmobile sedan, its front bumper missing, was found at 88th Street and Sutter Avenue in Ozone Park, Queens, about 9:45 A.M., said a police spokesman, Officer Joseph McConville.

title: DANCE: SENTA DRIVER AND HARRY OFFER 2 PREMIERS
description: SENTA DRIVER'S choreography is both analytical and intensely physical - one wonders how two such disparate aspects can be fused so creatively and brilliantly.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $255,000 and $350,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $200,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: MEI DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: RIVAL MILITIAS PUSH FIGHTING INTO BEIRUT
description: Fighting between Palestinians and Shiites spread to the capital today as artillery and rocket duels broke out around Burj al Brajneh, the largest of three Palestinian centers in the area.

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Japanese Link Grenade To Thai Airliner Plunge
description: The accidental explosion of a Japanese gangster's grenade may have caused a Thai jetliner to make a violent 21,000-foot dive in which 62 people were injured, according to press reports here today.

title: 2 MAJOR ACQUISITIONS FOR NATIONAL GALLERY
description: Two major acquisitions - a famous series of 15 canvases by the Abstract Expressionist painter Barnett Newman, and a large group of pictures and sketchbooks by the early 20th-century American watercolorist John Marin - have been announced by the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Pulitzer Plans Share Offering
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company said it plans to offer 1.4 million shares, or about 10 percent of its stock, to the public. The price has not yet been determined.

title: A SCHOOL GETS UNLIKELY VISIT BY A RUSSIAN
description: An unlikely visitor toured a Hebrew day school on Manhattan's East Side last week.

title: JEFFERSON LETTER BRINGS RECORD PRICE
description: A letter Thomas Jefferson wrote in 1818 to a Jewish diplomat and journalist in which the former President condemned prejudice towards Jews and all religious intolerance was sold yesterday at Sotheby's for the highest price ever paid at auction for any letter or any Presidential document.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings are based on earnings after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Pro-Consumer Voters In Congress Are Rated
description: A consumer advocacy group said Tuesday that 14 members of the 99th Congress were perfect ''consumer watchdogs'' and said 31 others led the list of ''special interest lapdogs.''

title: Factories' Efficiency Up Briskly
description: With American industry continuing to hold down labor costs to compete against foreign imports, manufacturing productivity increased at a healthy annual rate of 4.2 percent over the summer, the Government reported today.

title: Oops! A 690-Page Bill, But Reagan Got 688
description: A not-so-funny thing happened to the big Government spending bill on its way from Congressional passage to Presidential signature. An unthinkable thing, in fact.

title: Two Wordy
description: Rod Dowhower, coach of the 0-8 Indianapolis Colts, after declaring that he could sum up the first half of the season in one word: ''Not good.''

title: FEDERAL JUDGE BARS WITNESS IN BRIBE TRIAL
description: A Federal judge, questioning whether he wanted to ''unleash this sewer on this court,'' today blocked New York City's former director of leasing from testifying to a jury about bribes he said he had received from Michael J. Lazar, a real-estate developer.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reduced by $434,000 for the writeoff of good will in connection with the closing of a subsidiary. c-After income from discontinued operations of $109,000 and a loss on disposal of $1,979,000. The company said the latest third quarter results are restated for a change in accounting for pensions, effective Jan. 1. This effect of the change was to increase net income for each of the first three quarters by $202,000, or 1 cent a share. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May. Year-ago results restated to reflect poolings of interests.

title: INSURERS TO PUT UP $50 MILLION TO FINANCE HOUSING FOR POOR
description: Seven New York-based insurance corporations announced yesterday that they would provide $50 million worth of mortgages for low- and middle-income housing projects in the city.

title: IN THEATER, ONE ROLE BELONGS TO MONEY
description: Artists with unbalanced checkbooks are the enduring mainstay of New York's cultural landscape, and even the most driven among them knows the advantage of having a Ford or a Rockefeller in the background. Supporting the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, housed in a grotto on Sheridan Square, has a different kind of glamour from being a no-less-valued trustee of the Lincoln Center Theater.

Revenue represents gross income. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in June. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviet Union Protests Cut in the U.N. Mission
description: The Soviet Union has asked the United Nations to block an American order reducing the size of the Soviet missions to the world organization.

title: Advertising; Explosive Speech by RJR Chief
description: The 77th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers ended on an almost explosive note with a far-ranging speech by J. Tylee Wilson, chairman and chief executive of RJR Nabisco, which will be spending about $1 billion on advertising worldwide next year.

title: FEDERAL EFFORTS ON AIDS CRITICIZED AS GRAVELY WEAK
description: The National Academy of Sciences charged yesterday that the Federal Government's response to the AIDS epidemic had been dangerously inadequate and called for a $2 billion-a-year educational and research effort to avert a medical catastrophe.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * American Learning Corporation to J. Walter Thompson West/Los Angeles for its learning centers unit.

title: CUOMO AND RIVALS IN LOW-KEY DEBATE
description: After months of long-distance campaigning in which they impugned each other's character and ethics, Governor Cuomo and Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke took it all back yesterday.

title: SHIFTS AT PRECINCT IN BROOKLYN SEEN
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward is planning a large-scale transfer of supervisors, and possibly patrol officers, from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, where 13 officers have been suspended amid accusations of corruption and misconduct, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: On Theater Row and a Water View.
description: IN an era when many restaurants carry on with a seriousness of purpose bordering on the reverential, Chez Josephine is noteworthy for its dedication to unpremeditated fun. And the food is good, too. An exuberant bistro in the Theater Row district, Chez Josephine is the production of Jean-Claude Baker, a buoyant and engaging Frenchman who runs on a megavolt Duracell. He rushes to greet arriving customers with open-armed warmth, and at the drop of a fork he will regale them with tales of the restaurant's namesake, Josephine Baker, the glamorous chanteuse who was the rage of Paris in the 1920's. Mr. Baker happens to be one of Josephine Baker's celebrated ''rainbow tribe,'' 13 officially and unofficially adopted children.

title: DUTCH ARE QUIETLY TAKING THE LEAD IN EUTHANASIA
description: Quietly, with barely a public debate, this nation has become the leader in voluntary euthanasia.

title: WARMING OF ALASKAN ARTIC SEEN AS EVIDENCE OF GREENHOUSE EFFECT
description: Frozen ground beneath the Arctic region in Alaska has warmed four to seven degrees in the last century, providing more circumstantial evidence that the ''greenhouse effect'' is heating the earth's climate, a Government study says.

description: b-Includes $84.2 million from the sale of 50 percent of CITGO Petroleum Corp. to Petroleos de Venezuela. Share earnings for the latest 9 months include the impact of preferred dividend first paid in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: U.S. SET TO OFFER NEWER JET FIGHTER TO THE HONDURANS
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to offer Honduras a more advanced jet fighter and to upgrade its aging squadron of warplanes, State Department officials said today.

Baby Sitter, 13, Found Guilty In Death of Infant in Illinois
description: A 13-year-old boy charged in the slaying of a 16-month-old girl he was baby-sitting has been found guilty of felony murder and involuntary manslaughter.

description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BATONS, #62 West 11th Street (254-2288) -

title: On Succeeding Volcker
description: Who will succeed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve System when his term expires in August? The Fed Fortnightly, a new magazine devoted exclusively to that formidable agency, reports that ''more and more financial policy people'' are mentioning Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff and former chief executive officer of Merrill Lynch & Company. Others listed as ''possible picks'' are Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Secretary of State George P. Shultz; Beryl W. Sprinkel, current chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Manuel Johnson, vice chairman of the Fed.

title: RETHINKING NECESSARY FOR MANY INVESTMENTS
description: For investors, the rules of the game are radically changed. In sweeping fashion, the new tax law has dramatically diminished the returns of some investments and enhanced the yields of others.

title: Sri Lanka Not Cooperating, Amnesty International Says
description: Officials of Amnesty International, the human-rights monitoring organization based in London, accused the Government of Sri Lanka this week of ignoring repeated calls for cooperation in the investigation of more than 300 disappearances there.

title: Wedding Celebration Blamed For Airliner Crash in Pakistan
description: Revelers at a wedding firing rifles into the air may have caused a Pakistani plane crash, a newspaper said today. It said seven bridegrooms had been arrested for ''lethal celebrations during marriage ceremonies.''

title: Pretoria Denies Role In Machel Plane Crash
description: South Africa today denied accusations by black African countries that it was involved in the plane crash that killed President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique 11 days ago.

title: Nellie Mae Offering
description: The trend for local governments and authorities to sell taxable, rather than tax-exempt, securities is evident in the short-term market, as well as the long-term bond market.

title: Money and Gasoline Vapor
description: Many automobile drivers may not know it, but the Environmental Protection Agency is about to decide whether to require an additional anti-pollution device on all new cars or to require gasoline stations to install a vapor-control system at all their pumps.

title: Meese Urges Drug-Use Watch
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d urged employers today to control drug use by workers by keeping watch on parking lots, locker rooms and on nearby bars if necessary.

title: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results reported in pounds sterling have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.44 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Sept. 30, 1986. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt (ADR) and four units of ICI ordinary stock are represented by each ADR.

title: AS ELECTION DAY NEARS, D'AMATO GROWS QUIET
description: He has often been seen on the evening news, filibustering the Senate to save a defense contract on Long Island, buying crack on the streets of Washington Heights to demonstrate the extent of New York's drug problem, extolling the virtues of the new tax revision bill.

title: ORGANIZING TO BLOCK THE HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration's proposal to build 20 shelters for the homeless throughout the city comes while its homeless policies in midtown Manhattan are facing organized, well-financed and politically savvy opposition.

title: ACCOUNTING CHANGE FOR OIL LOSSES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today rejected a heavily lobbied staff proposal that could have led to abolition of an accounting method used by 60 percent of the nation's oil and gas companies.

title: 4 SHOT TO DEATH IN SOUTH BRONX
description: Four men were found shot to death yesterday afternoon on the bedroom floor of an apartment in the South Bronx.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $228 million gain from discontinued operations and $72 million extraordinary charge on the redemption of debenture. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $65 million for the quarter and $4 million for the 9 months.

title: CITY'S ECONOMY IS STILL BOOMING, STUDY SAYS
description: New York City's economy is having another robust year despite an uncertain national outlook, according to a report yesterday from the office of State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a write-off of $9,370,000. The results for 1985 have been restated to reflect an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: STANLEY LEBOWSKY HONORED BY 1,000 AT MEMORIAL TRIBUTE
description: More than 1,000 people connected with Broadway paid memorial tribute to one of their own, the conductor and composer Stanley Lebowsky, at the Marriot Marquis Theater yesterday. Mr. Lebowsky, who died of a heart attack on Oct. 19 at age 59, was remembered as a demanding but warm musical-theater perfectionist by speakers who ranged from the longtime American director and choreographer Bob Fosse to the English director Trevor Nunn.

title: ART: SONIA DELAUNAY, STUDIES IN COLOR
description: EXHIBITIONS of the work of Sonia Delaunay are true rarities. In her lifetime, she went from 1916 to 1953 without a one-person show, and it wasn't until 1980, the year after her death, that a full-fledged exhibition of her work was mounted in New York. The current, compact one at La Boetie, 9 East 82d Street, is well chosen and tells her story in a sparkling way. One comes away with a myriad of impressions and insights.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for all periods have been restated to account for the acquisition of Clark-O'Neill Inc. on June 12 as a pooling of interests.
