description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Plenary - 10 A.M.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1986
description: The World

title: No. 7 Subway Service To Face Interruption
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that service on the No. 7 line of the IRT subway will be disrupted over the next two weekends because of work on the tracks.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the year-ago quarter includes an $18.3 million pre- tax gain on the sale of producing properties in California and a $4.8 million writeoff related to abandoned exploration leases and two refinery projects that were cancelled.

title: OPERA: 'TROVATORE'
description: If opera lovers were polled, ''Il Trovatore'' would probably rank high among their favorite works. Its tunes and its plot, which centers around a gypsy who absentmindedly throws the wrong baby into a fire, are known to everyone. Not for nothing did the Marx Brothers make Verdi's work the target of their fun in ''A Night at the Opera.'' However, for all its familiarity, ''Il Trovatore'' does not turn up in major houses as regularly as it once did, simply because there are now so few dramatic sopranos capable of singing a creditable Leonora.

title: Petitions for U.S.F.L.
description: Three weeks ago, the United States Football League, which had been awarded $3 in its antitrust suit against the National Football League, filed a motion before United States District Judge Peter K. Leisure asking that the N.F.L. be divided into two independent leagues - the American Football Conference and the National Football Conference. Yesterday, the players' associations of five sports filed briefs on behalf of the U.S.F.L. motion. The unions participating in the petition represented both the National Football League and the U.S.F.L. as well as major league baseball, the National Hockey League, the National Basketball Association and the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: PROCEDURE MAY GIVE SPINAL CORD VICTIMS HOPES FOR FATHERING
description: The wife of a paraplegic is the first in the nation to become pregnant through a technique offering new hope of fatherhood to neurologically impaired men, the University of Michigan Medical Center announced today.

title: Paper Lions
description: As it is, the job's a cinch.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $550,000 for the quarter and $7,875,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $675,000 for the quarter and $2.7 million for the 9 months.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $7.3 million and $20.7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $12.3 million for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $1.9 million for the quarter and $4.1 million for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a loss of $28.5 million from discontinued operations. The company said that concluding the restructuring of Life Reinsurance operations started earlier in 1986, and following an evaluation of Life Reinsurance reserves, the net benefit reserves of Life operations were increased in the third quarter by $60 million. This resulted in an after-tax charge to operating earnings of the Life Reinsurance segment of $36.7 million.

title: Saudi Change Brings A Surge in Oil Prices
description: Oil prices surged on record volume in world petroleum markets yesterday, as participants chose to overlook the industry's dismal economics and bought on the hope that Saudi Arabia's acting oil minister would take steps to firm up prices.

title: VATICAN REPROACHES HOMOSEXUALS WITH A POINTED ALLUSION TO AIDS
description: In what appeared to be a clear allusion to the AIDS epidemic, the Vatican said today that ''advocates'' of homosexual rights seem undeterred by the realization that ''homosexuality may seriously threaten the lives and well-being of a large number of people.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Denver Nugget coach, Doug Moe, currently in the second year of a three-year contract, has signed a two-year extension. Terms were not announced, but Moe earned $275,000 last season, and the Nuggets' president and general manager, Vince Boryla, said the extension would make Moe ''one of the highest-paid coaches in pro basketball.'' . . . The Pittsburgh Penguins, off to the best start in the 20-year history of the franchise, have extended the contracts of Coach Bob Berry and his assistant, Jim Roberts, through the 1987-88 season.

title: 27 Years in Poison Case
description: Edward Arlen Marks, an unemployed stockbroker, was sentenced in Federal District Court today to 27 years in prison for trying to manipulate stock prices by lacing drug capsules with rat poison. Mr. Marks, 25 years old, pleaded not guilty to 27 counts of product tampering, wire fraud and giving false information. He had told news agencies various nonprescription capsules had cyanide in them.

title: MEXICO AIDE'S BROTHER IN DRUG ARREST
description: The Mexican federal police have arrested the brother of a former Governor of the northern state of Sonora and charged him with drug trafficking in connection with marijuana fields discovered on ranches he owned, Mexican officials said today.

title: OFFER MADE OF IMMUNITY TO TESTIFY ABOUT GRAFT
description: Federal prosecutors said today they would offer complete immunity to the Datacom Systems Corporation and its top executives in return for testimony that they said would directly implicate Stanley M. Friedman and three of his co-defendants in the New York City corruption scandal.

title: SCRREN: 'SKY BANDITS'
description: ''S KY BANDITS,'' which opens today at the U. A. Twin and other theaters, is not a space adventure, as you might think from the title, but a charmless comedy about a couple of young bank robbers who become World War I flying aces. The screenplay, the direction and the performances are terrible.

title: YAMANI CAUGHT IN A CROSSFIRE
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, who was replaced Wednesday as Saudi Arabia's oil minister, was cut down in the crossfire of increasingly strained Middle Eastern oil politics, diplomats and oil industry sources in the Persian Gulf and Western Europe said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WOMEN AS EXPLORERS An exhibition focusing on the contributions made by female explorers opens today at the American Museum of Natural History, where it will be on view through April. ''Ladies in the Field: The Museum's Unsung Explorers'' includes photographs, diaries, published monographs and mementos of women who went on American Museum expeditions, collecting and cataloguing specimens and artifacts in locales that range from Siberia to Kenya. The museum is open today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. and on Sunday from noon to 5:45 P.M. Suggested admission is $3.50. The number for more information is 873-4225.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profits and Feuds
description: In politics as well as the entertainment world, well-publicized feuds sometimes turn out to be profitable for both combatants. In its Sept. 13 issue, The Nation printed ''The Rise and Decline of Accuracy in Media,'' a 12-page critical examination of the conservative press-watchdog group headed by Reed Irvine.

title: CECO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MICROTONAL MUSIC
description: The American Festival of Microtonal Music will present a program of works by La Monte Young, Harry Partch, Andrew Bolotowsky and others at St. Peter's Church Sunday evening at 7. Admission is $6. St. Peter's Church is in the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53rd Street. Information: 864-2951.

title: Global Finance: Tale of 3 Cities
description: THIS week, J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, 75.1 percent of which is owned by the Industrial Bank of Japan, agreed to buy Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a privately held American dealer in United States government securities. Is this one more step marking the de-Americanization, or the Japanization, of the American economy? Is Tokyo, as a financial center, overtaking New York and London?

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BY CANDIDATES FOR NEW YORK GOVERNOR
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times among candidates in Tuesday's election for Governor of New York, Governor Cuomo, Democrat-Liberal; Andrew P. O'Rourke, Republican-Conservative, and Denis E. Dillon, Right to Life. Ethics Charges

title: FIRST UNION RE EQUITY & MORTAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $664,000 and $3,409,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $587,000 for the quarter and $1,708,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March. The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9-month include a gain of $3,300,000 related to the settlement of litigation.

title: RENEWAL BACK ON TRACK FOR ARCHIVES LANDMARK
description: People who regularly pass the Federal Archives, a landmark building in the West Village, can see evidence that the rehabilitation of the Romanesque Revival structure is finally back in business. Thanks to a recent scrubbing, the exterior of the 10-story smooth brick building has gone from a grayish brown to a lustrous red.

title: THE STAGE: 'ALTERATIONS,' WITH GRETCHEN CRYER
description: WATCHING Leigh Curran's ''Alterations'' at the WPA Theater, one can only wonder: How many made-for-television domestic problems can be packed into a single two-hour, one-set play? Ms. Curran seems determined that the answer roughly approximate the number of angels who can dance on the head of a pin.

title: ART: JOSEPH BEUYS AT THE FELDMAN GALLERY
description: THE current show at the Ronald Feldman Gallery, 31 Mercer Street, is in effect a memorial exhibition, though not announced as such. When Joseph Beuys died, earlier this year, the question arose as to what would happen to his reputation now that he himself was no longer around. With his unforgettable appearance, his status as the ultimate antiestablishment man in an ever more conformist age and the beautiful open courtesy with which he would treat those who sought to make mock of him, he was the indispensable leaven in a world that, without him, seems to have all too much unrisen dough.

title: OTTER TAIL POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Account
description: * Baxter-Travenol, Du Pont Pharmaceutical and Biotechnica Diagnostics have all given assignments to Barnum Communications.

title: AQUINO, UNRUFFLED BY ENRILE, IS CONFIDENT OF ARMY BACKING
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she did not feel threatened by the posturings of her Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, and that she was confident she had the backing of the military.

title: BROADWAY
description: THIS week, the big name taking to the stage or, in this case, returning to it, is Sigourney Weaver. She's been signed to play Portia in Shakespeare's ''Merchant of Venice'' for a four-week run at the Classic Stage Company, and she'll be directed by her husband, James Simpson. It will be Miss Weaver's first New York stage appearance since ''Hurlyburly'' in 1984. Before her opening, on Dec. 14, the company, celebrating its 20th season, will present Thornton Wilder's ''Skin of Our Teeth'' with a cast that includes Novella Nelson and Steven Coats, an engagement that will begin Nov. 14 and also continue for four weeks. The theater is at 136 East 13th Street; telephone: 677-4210. Single tickets go on sale a week before performances begin, but subscribers get guaranteed seats.

title: MONTANA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amax Acquisition
description: Amax Inc., a minerals and metals company in Greenwich, Conn., said it had agreed to acquire the 50 percent stake it did not already own in Alumax Inc., the nation's fourth-largest aluminum company, for $435 million. Mitsui & Company U.S.A. owns 45 percent of Alumax, and Nippon Steel U.S.A. owns 5 percent. Amax also reported net income of $2.6 million, or 2 cents a share, for the third quarter, compared with a loss of $88.2 million in the period last year.

title: WYNN'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,000 and $296,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $82,000 and $49,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Burnstyn and Weld in 'Something in Common'
description: ''I haven't got a fatal disease, I've got a relationship,'' explains 22-year-old Nick Hollander (Patrick Cassidy) to his widowed mother, Lynn (Ellen Burstyn), about his affair with Shelly (Tuesday Weld), a Scarsdale divorcee nearly twice his age. Nick, a handsome, soft-spoken mama's boy, and Shelly, the blond, somewhat aimless mother of two, have met in gourmet cooking school. They begin their affair while Lynn, a high-powered New York editor, is in Los Angeles working with Theo Fontana (Don Murray), the best-selling author of books that advocate his ''touchy-feely'' philosophy. His latest title, ''Fondle With Care,'' is Lynn's idea, and it pretty much sums up her prudish sexual attitudes.

title: DANCE: KOREAN TROUPE
description: THERE were three living national treasures on hand for ''Korean Traditional Music and Dance'' to insure the solemnity of the program, performed on Wednesday at Asia Society. But this touring company of nine musicians, singers and dancers proved that ancient folk culture can also be delightfully low fun.

title: 'Justice' in Nicaragua
description: Eugene Hasenfus is not likely to receive a fair trial in Nicaragua. He is appearing before a special Sandinista court in a system called the Popular Anti-Somocista Tribunals, whose conviction rate is 99 percent. Like 2,000 Nicaraguans who have been tried or are awaiting trial by these courts, he enjoys no presumption of innocence, has limited access to defense counsel and faces judges whose ''impartiality, fairness and independence of judgment are seriously compromised,'' according to the Organization of American States' human rights office.

title: Borden to Buy Unit of Beatrice
description: Borden Inc., the dairy and chemical products company, said today that it had agreed to acquire the dairy division of Beatrice Companies for $315 million. The acquisition would almost double the revenues of Borden's dairy division and add 14 states to the 24 it serves.

title: 3 Openings At the Top Are Filled
description: IN New York yesterday Conde Nast Publications named a new president to replace Robert J. Lapham, 64 years old, who decided to retire from the job he has held for 12 years. And in Chicago, at the Leo Burnett Company, the country's 10th-largest agency, a similar decision was reached by the topmost two in its worldwide organization - John J. Kinsella, 53, and Norman Muse, 52. All go with the year on Dec. 31. The new man at Conde Nast is Bernard H. Leser, 61, who has 27 years with the company. He will be coming to New York from London, where he led the British subsidiary.

title: A Way Out of the Vaccine Morass
description: The vaccines that protect millions of American children have injurious side effects on about 70 children a year. The courts provide uneven relief, awarding nothing to some victims and windfall settlements to others. As a result, insurers have increased premiums, forcing some manufacturers to raise prices and others to quit making vaccines altogether.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $16.1 million on the sale of securities and a pre-tax writeoff of $17.8 million related to the company's electronic warfare operations. c-Includes $2.3 million gain on sale of plastic packaging subsidiary and a $1 million writedown of a minority interest investment.

title: SOLDIER STRING QUARTET
description: The composer Nicolas Collins and the Soldier String Quartet will perform new music tomorrow and Sunday at Tin Pan Alley, 220 West 49th Street (582-9376). Music begins at 10 P.M. tomorrow, 9 P.M. Sunday; admission is free.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE Museum of Modern Art will auction 17 duplicate prints from its photography holdings - the first public sale of such works from the museum's collection - at Christie's on Nov. 11. John Szarkowski, director of the Modern's department of photography, said each of the prints is ''of excellent quality and represents an important work in the history of photography.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The credits on Wednesday with a review of Alan Ayckbourn's play ''Taking Steps'' gave an incorrect address for the York Theater. It is at 2 East 90th Street.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A RECENT craving for unembellished broiled fish prompted a lunch revisit to the Dolphin, an inconspicuous seafood restaurant on Lexington Avenue near 33d Street that received two stars in April 1985 for its exceptionally fresh and well-prepared catch. I am pleased to report that quality is as impressive as before. Lunch started with oversized but tender baked clams topped with buttery breadcrumbs, followed by an enormous whole broiled flounder that was golden, firm and moist. A drizzle of lemon was all it needed. The Dolphin is not cheap - flounder is $16.50, red snapper $19.50 and Dover sole $23 - but neither is good seafood these days.

title: STOCKS SOAR: DOW ADDS 26.57
description: Stock prices soared on Wall Street yesterday, propelled by the possibility of a discount rate cut by Japan, strength among blue-chip issues and rising takeover speculation.

title: Discount-Store Momentum
description: RETAILING analysts and the media have been enthralled for some time by the dramatic growth of the K Mart Corporation and Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's two largest discount chains. So it is easy to overlook the fact that other large discount chains are being heavily financed and are expanding to major proportions.

title: Unions and the Federal Worker: Hard Times
description: It is a footnote for the history books, perhaps, but consider this: Within minutes after President Reagan signed the Tax Reform Act of 1986 into law last week, the American Federation of Government Employees became the first group to file suit in Federal court challenging its constitutionality.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in September.

title: Elisabeth Schwarzhaupt, 85; First Woman in Bonn Cabinet
description: Elisabeth Schwarzhaupt, who in 1961 became West Germany's first woman to be named a Cabinet member, has died at the age of 85, her political party announced today.

title: Hutton Trading Inquiry
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would investigate the trading of E.F. Hutton Group stock because of unusual price swings in recent days. Hutton's shares soared $4.875, to $52, on Wednesday on rumors that it had received a takeover offer from the American Express Company, and then fell $1.75, to $50.25 yesterday.

title: Milk-Licensing Change Will Serve Consumers and New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
3 Colombos Are Sentenced
description: Anthony Colombo, eldest son of Joseph A. Colombo, the late boss of the crime family, was sentenced yesterday to 14 years in Federal prison and to pay $500,000 in fines and restitution.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
WASHINGTON TALK: REQUIRED READING
description: A Time to . . .

title: Raiders and Broncos Closest of Rivals
description: In the last few years, the Denver Broncos playing the Los Angeles Raiders has been one of the best shows in the National Football League. The scores of their last six games, including the one played the first week of this season, show why: Raiders, 22-20. Broncos, 16-13. Broncos, 22-19, in overtime. Raiders, 31-28, in overtime. Raiders, 17-14, in overtime. Broncos, 38-36.

title: Garment Area Focus of Study
description: The workshops and showrooms of New York City's garment center should be shielded from conversion to offices by the creation of a ''Garment Center manfacturing preservation district,'' a city report released yesterday recommended.

title: SCHOLASTIC COACH REPLACES DRIESELL
description: Citing the need to restore stability to a program that has been riddled by controversy, Chancellor John B. Slaughter of the University of Maryland today named Bob Wade, head basketball coach at Dunbar High School in Baltimore, to replace Charles G. (Lefty) Driesell.

title: Polluter to Pay Up to $5 Million
description: International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. agreed yesterday to pay the largest fine ever levied by the state for water pollution and to pay to clean up contaminated ground water at its Raritan Bay plant.

title: Miller-Reid Will Sell 7 Offices to Interpublic
description: The Miller-Reid agency of Chattanooga, Tenn., which serves a number of Coca-Cola bottlers in its network of eight offices, mostly in the Sun Belt, is selling all of them, except its headquarters, to the Interpublic Group of Companies, the Coca-Cola Company's major advertising resource.

title: Celtics' Injury Woes
description: The Boston Celtics, trying to become the first team to win consecutive National Basketball Association championships since they did it in 1969, open their season tonight at the Boston Garden against the Washington Bullets with 10 healthy players. To get down to the 12-player roster, the Celtics placed Scott Wedman, one of their key reserves, on the injured list, retaining David Thirdkill for the time being.

title: MOSCOW, IN A THAW, AWAITS A LITERARY BOMBSHELL
description: As literature and the arts become less confined under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet writer Anatoly Rybakov has promised a literary bombshell for next spring.

title: Some Trick-or-Treaters Are Unicef Ambassadors
description: To the Editor:

title: IN CONNECTICUT, BELAGA STEPS UP ATTACKS ON FOE
description: With a cheery, ''Hi, guys!,'' Julie D. Belaga, the Republican candidate for governor, worked her way through the lunch tables at the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's employee cafeteria here, shaking every hand in sight and urging people to vote next Tuesday.

title: Study Indicates Waste In Disability Program
description: The Social Security Administration wasted millions of dollars on unnecessary medical examinations in an effort to remove a half a million people from the disability rolls from 1981 to 1984, a Congressional panel has reported.

title: Ellis Island Honoree Heads Lanston Deal
description: Peter Rona, president and chief executive of the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, says he is astonished by critics who say the Japanese should not be allowed to own a firm that is a primary dealer in United States Government securities.

title: CONVEX COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CYBERTEK COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THE PRESS
description: Book PartyPrentice Hall Press gave a party for Gael Greene's new novel ''Delicious Sex,'' and restaurateurs and chefs supplied food for it without charge.

title: CONCERT: SOLOS BY 6 CATS IN TULLY HALL 'MEOW OFF'
description: ALICE TULLY HALL has seen soloists of every stripe, from the piccolo to the tuba, the mighty organ to the delicate celesta. But last night - along with an orchestra, a conductor, two singers and a narrator - the soloists were six cats. That's right, felines, who, like the battling troubadours in Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' were engaged in a contest of song.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRANCE DENIES DEAL SYRIANS
description: Government officials repeated denials today that Syria had helped France to obtain a ''truce'' with the extremist group believed responsible for a series of terrorist bombings in Paris last month.

title: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SAID TO HAVE DECIDED TO KEEP SENTENCING BARGAIN WITH WALKERS
description: The Justice Department has decided to keep a plea bargain with John A. Walker Jr. and his son, Michael Walker, despite some lingering suspicions that John Walker has not told the full truth about his family's Soviet espionage ring, two Government sources said today.

title: Ueberroth's PAC: Behind His Back
description: Ever since the Senators moved to Texas in 1972 and became the Rangers, the quest to return baseball to the nation's capital has been nothing less than an obsession with some Washingtonians. One latter-day result is something called Puppac. That stands for the Peter Ueberroth Political Action Committee (the extra ''p'' being inspired by the founders' desire to soften the ''u'' from the commissioner's name and give their PAC a warm and cuddly sound, as in ''puppy'').

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: TONIGHT may be Halloween, but this week has been fiesta time in Manhattan. Spanish guitars set the mood for Casita Maria's annual fiesta on Wednesday, and Tito Puente's Latin jazz ensemble set the beat for Ballet Hispanico's Noche de Gala on Monday. Even Lenox Hill Hospital went Latin last night with a tribute to Chita Rivera, who had also been honored - along with Priscilla Lopez of the ''Kay O'Brien'' TV series - by Ballet Hispanico.

title: G.O.P. FIELDS STAR IN COLORADO, SEEKING ANY EDGE
description: For several weeks, White House political operatives have been arguing that in the final days of this year's campaign, President Reagan would be able to add two or three percentage points to the vote for Republican candidates in close races, pulling them through and keeping control of the Senate in Republican hands.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $700,000 and $4,900,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $71,700,000 from the sale of discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $4,700,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5,900,000 for the quarter and $18,200,000 for the 9 months.

title: T.W.A. Back In the Black
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. yesterday reported third-quarter earnings of $65.2 million, or $1.64 a share, in contrast to a loss of $13.5 million in the period a year ago.

title: TRIO AT WEST END
description: The bassist Mickey Bass, the saxophonist Carter Jefferson and the drummer Michael Carvin will perform tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Boradway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow,a $5 cover and a $7.50 minimum on Sunday.

title: Gelco Rejects Deal
description: The Gelco Corporation said that its board had rejected a hostile tender offer of $338.1 million, or $26 a share, from a group led by Coniston Partners, a New York-based investment partnership. Gelco, a Minneapolis-based leasing and management services concern, said its own offer - to exchange up to six million shares of common stock for $26 to $30 a share in cash and preferred shares - was still in effect.

title: California's Hostile Race for Governor
description: In its closing days, California's gubernatorial campaign has evolved into an increasingly hostile personal war between Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, and his Democratic challenger, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1986
description: International

title: EFFINGHAM S. DEANS
description: Effingham S. Deans, chairman of E. S. Deans & Company, of Danbury, Conn., and Manhattan, manufacturer and importer of sportswear, died Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn.

title: ROBYN HITCHCOCK
description: The British songwriter Robyn Hitchcock will perform tomorrow night at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), about 1 A.M. Sunday; Beat Rodeo will open at midnight. Tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 tomorrow.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $159,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $799,000. d-Includes a $2,628,000 gain from the termination of a pension plan. The year-ago periods were reclassified for discontinued operations.

title: Quality Diluted by High Fees
description: As strong as the fields may be for the seven Breeders' Cup races at Santa Anita Saturday, they would be much stronger if not for the punitive rules regarding suppplemental nominations. Super Diamond, Creme Fraiche and Broad Brush should be running in the $3 million Classic, but they are staying home because their owners balked at paying exorbitant penalty fees to start them.

title: NICARAGUA ASSAILS U.S. PLAN ON JETS
description: A senior official of the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry today assailed a plan by the United States to offer Honduras a new fighter aircraft, calling it ''a direct slap in the face to the Contadora peace process, which has as one of its basic principles a prohibition on new offensive weapons systems.''

title: AGENDA: Oct. 31, 1986
description: Financial State of City City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin will release his annual report on New York City's finances. Word is the city, for the sixth consecutive year, collected more revenue than it expected. The report is expected to say the city had a $423 million surplus but has already spent all but $7 million of it. More Books for Children

title: Gannett Purchase
description: The Gannett Company announced an agreement to purchase the 125,000-circulation Arkansas Gazette for $51 million from the family of Judge Carrick White Heiskell. The Little Rock daily would be Gannett's fourth major newspaper acquisition in slightly more than a year, and it would bring Gannett's number of daily newspapers to 93, with total circulation of more than six million.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $46,700,000 and $128,200,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $19,200,000 for the quarter and $42,600,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $19,400,000 for the quarter and $51,500,000 for the 9 months. The company said the 1985 quarter included a $79 million gain from the sale of Cigna's interest in the Howard Research and Development Corp., the developer of Columbia, Md.

title: Lucky Stores Offer Halted by Edelman
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said he has dropped his $37- a-share offer to acquire Lucky Stores Inc. because the company refused to negotiate with him.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Afterrealized investment gains of $420,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,395,000, or $1.01 a share, for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $1,578,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,270,000, or 30 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KISS ME ONCE. By Thomas Maxwell. 317 pages. Mysterious Press. $16.95.

title: Jaclyn Smith in 'Rage of Angels' Sequel on NBC
description: FIRST things first. The budget for ''Rage of Angels: The Story Continues,'' which begins this Sunday at 9 P.M. on NBC, was somewhere around $8 million. Nearly half of the $125,000 spent on costumes went for some 45 outfits worn by the star, Jaclyn Smith. Michael Nouri, who plays the mobster villain of the piece, is draped in a Giorgio Armani wardrobe. Extensive on-location shooting was done at assorted chic locales in New York and Rome. In short, this is one of those lavish exercises in which the look is everything. Trying to follow, much less believe, the story can only bring on one of those dreaded headaches so treasured by television commercials.

title: JOFFREY BALLET: 'ESTEEMED GUESTS'
description: TALENT will out, we have been assured, but sometimes it ventures forth prematurely. Was it Groundhog Day Wednesday at the City Center? The occasion was the Joffrey Ballet's local premiere of ''Esteemed Guests'' by Mark Morris - a young modern-dance choreographer who has received considerable attention with his own troupe.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS 'STAR WARS' PLAN WILL CREATE JOBS AND BETTER LIFE
description: President Reagan, pressing in the West for continued Republican control of the Senate, today described his space-oriented missile defense proposal as a vehicle for creating thousands of new jobs and for improving the quality of life.

title: LONDON FINDS NO SIGN OF ABDUCTION OF ISRAELI
description: Scotland Yard said today that an extensive investigation into the whereabouts of a former Israeli nuclear technician had revealed no evidence that he was kidnapped in London.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $682,000.

title: Concerts With a Cause: Fight Against Crack
description: CHURCH bells across the city will ring today at noon, beginning a weekend of music aimed at stopping the spread of crack, the cheap, addictive cocaine derivative that has spurred community concern. There will be two all-star ''Crackdown'' benefit concerts this weekend at Madison Square Garden Center.

title: People
description: * Susan Read has joined SSC&B/Lintas Worldwide as an executive vice president, executive creative director and Alan Colello, a senior vice president, has been named a creative director.

title: SURVEY FINDS NO BIG COLLEGE SWING TO RIGHT
description: The results of a new survey rebut the idea that college students have become politically more conservative. The study shows a move to the center and a continuation of liberal views on specific issues such as abortion, the environment and taxing the wealthy.

title: 4 IN CHICAGO GANG INDICTED IN LIBYAN TERROR PLOT
description: A Federal grand jury here today indicted four street gang members on charges of conspiring to commit terrorist acts in the United States for the Libyan Government.

title: GUARDS HELD IN 2 SHELTER KILLINGS
description: Two security guards hired to patrol shelters for the homeless in the Bronx and Brooklyn stabbed two homeless men to death in separate incidents this week and have been charged with murder, the police said yesterday.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MASCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend in June.

title: Joseph Bell Dies at 64; Ex-Bronx Zoo Official
description: Joseph L. Bell, retired deputy director of zoology at the Bronx Zoo, died of a heart attack Monday while vacationing in Kenya. He was 64 years old and lived in Rocky Point, L.I.

title: CAPITAL WIRE & CABLE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADVO-SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time pre-tax goodwill writeoff of $75,181,000.

title: The Mets and the Moon
description: We knew the baseball game last Monday was important, but we didn't realize just how big it was until Mayor Koch himself was discovered in the Mets' dugout near the end of Game 7, trying desperately to avoid the glare of television cameras.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, sold $300 million of 8 percent mortgage-backed securities yesterday at an average price of 96 8/32 to yield 8.62 percent. The securities are backed by a pool of mortgages guaranteed or insured by the Government.

title: Shareholder Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $30.9 million and $34.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from the settlement of a lawsuit. c-Net income The company said the charge in the latest quarter reflects the previously announced settlement of an anti-trust suit between Data General and Fairchild Semiconductor Corp.

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
description: Shares outstanding restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split in June 1986.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Victory for Terrorists
description: Despite an endless series of mutual pledges against terrorism, Europe has now openly displayed its split.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $934.5 million, to $237.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: The Election in Connecticut
description: When Connecticut voters go to the polls Tuesday, they will have a hard choice between two capable candidates for governor. In the races for senator and all six House seats, incumbents outshine challengers, most of whom are distressingly weak.

title: U.S. SUBPEONAS DATA ON IMPACT OF BIG PROJECTS
description: Federal investigators have subpoenaed city records concerning environmental impact statements on several major development projects, city officials said yesterday.

title: FARMERS LINK 2 PROGRAMS FOR A BONUS
description: Beleaguered farmers across the Corn Belt have found a new way to take advantage of the farm law to help bolster sagging incomes in the face of plunging prices.

title: SEOUL RIOT POLICE STORM UNIVERSITY
description: The police stormed five buildings held by protesting university students today, arresting more than 1,000 students after a two-hour battle in which the protesters hurled gasoline bombs and set the buildings ablaze.

title: W.B.A. Issues Ban
description: By a 30-18 vote, the World Boxing Association voted yesterday to suspend South Africa from its organization until the country abandons its policy of racial apartheid. Gilberto Mendoza, president of the W.B.A., said that under the suspension, South African boxers would continue to be ranked by the association and would be able to have options to W.B.A. title fights outside of South Africa.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: IT'S an old question, but Paul Smith has been hearing it a lot in the last few days: What is the difference between art and craft?

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES SPURT BY 10.6%
description: Sales of new homes, bolstered by low mortgage rates and strong demand in the Northeast, rose 10.6 percent in September to break a string of five consecutive monthly declines, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Even when the practice of homosexuality may seriously threaten the lives and well-being of a large number of people, its advocates remain undeterred and refuse to consider the magnitude of the risks involved.'' - Vatican letter to Roman Catholic bishops. [ A17:1. ]

title: Stellar Cast For Wining and Dining
description: ONE of the longest-running dramas on Broadway - one suffused with suspense, mystery, discovery and occasional flashes of humor - might be called the Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Theatrical Universe. Theatergoers looking for appealing restaurants before or after a show this season have a diverse cast from which to choose. New members of the lineup range from the buoyant French bistro Chez Josephine on West 42d Street to such full-blown productions as Palio and Le Bernardin on West 51st.

title: Wendy's Shifts Back to Rich
description: Wendy's International is returning its advertising account to Dick Rich Inc., which it split with in 1980 because of ''differences in marketing direction.''

title: DOUBT CAST ON MISSILE SHIELD
description: Members of the National Academy of Science think President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' program cannot produce an effective defense against Soviet nuclear attack, and they believe spending for the program should be cut, according to a survey released today.

title: INQUIRY CITES FAILURE OF CLUTCH IN COPTER CRASH
description: A Federal safety official investigating the crash last week of a traffic news helicopter said yesterday that the craft plunged into the Hudson River after a clutch not matched to the helicopter failed, cutting off power to its rotor blades.

title: KNICKS OBTAIN OLDHAM
description: At a time when National Basketball Association teams are reluctant to play without two legitimate centers, the Knicks will soon have three.

title: WESTCOAST TRANSMISSION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $5 million writedown of investments.

title: SCREEN: 'THE MISSION,' WITH DeNIRO AND IRONS
description: IN the mid-18th century, the Jesuit priests in what is today northeastern Argentina and western Paraguay found themselves caught in a not unusual struggle between the Pope in Rome and two of Europe's most aggressive temporal powers.

title: DROPS OUT OF GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: Attorney General Charlie Graddick of Alabama announcing his withdrawal as a write-in candidate for Governor yesterday in Montgomery. With him were his wife, Corinne, son, Herndon, daughter, Corinne, and father-in-law, Wythe Whiting. Mr. Graddick said he wanted to prevent a split in the state's conservative vote. His withdrawal was aimed at preventing Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley, the Democratic nominee, from winning in a splintered field over Mr. Graddick and Guy Hunt, the Republican candidate. (AP)

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $24,974,000 for the quarter and $42,587,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $23,599,000 for the quarter and $39,593,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months also included net from discontinued operations of $12,136,000.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC (TWA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-operating expense of $34,680,000 and $108,500,000 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, and $64,700,000 and $118,971,000 for the year-ago comparable periods, respectively. c-Net losses and for the 9 months includes an extraordinary gain of $14,815,000.

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Papandreou Replaces 4 And Drops 11 in Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou replaced four Cabinet ministers and abolished 11 deputy Cabinet jobs today in a Government reorganization ordered after losses by his Socialist Party in local elections.

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest 9-month period includes credit losses of $3,030,000 recorded in the first half that are related to certain loans and leases of its German leasing subsidiary that are in default. These losses include unauthorized real estate loans, guarantees and other financings that were initiated several years ago. Share earnings reflect provision for the dividend on the convertible exchangeable preferred stock issued May 13, 1986.

title: MIXED ISRAELI FEELINGS OVER LEBANON
description: Israeli military officials have been watching the latest fighting in Lebanon between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen with a mixed reactions.

title: SUN RA, KEYBOARDIST
description: The keyboardist Sun Ra will lead his Omniverse Arkestra big band tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleeker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum tonight and tomorros, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: WITHOUT FEATHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Cuts Estimates for Saturn Output and Jobs
description: The General Motors Corporation conceded today that its Saturn plant in Tennessee would fall well below predicted production and employment levels when it goes into operation in the summer of 1990.

title: U.S. General Criticizes Soviet on Afghanistan
description: The Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, Lieut. Gen. Leonard H. Perroots, today accused the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, of ''sham and deception'' over his claim to have pulled out six regiments from Afghanistan.

title: MARATHON IS LAST BARRIER FOR A DISABLED RUNNER
description: Aaron Shor wobbled into Central Park, shaky on the limbs that have been diseased for most of his life. An ambulance roared past. ''Oh good,'' he said, turning to his friend, Joy Werner. ''They know I'm here.''

title: Ex-Colonel Denied Bail In Posse Comitatus Case
description: A former Army colonel who says he is a founder of the extremist group Posse Comitatus is being held without bail on charges of threatening to kill tax agents and a judge, officials said today.

title: How Sanctions Look From Inside South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Group Withdraws Ad That Drew Jews' Objections
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee today withdrew a radio commercial following objections from some Jewish groups.

title: 5 CENTERS IN CITY TO OFFER ANONYMOUS AIDS TEST
description: In a new effort to contain the AIDS epidemic, health officials in New York City are opening five new blood-testing centers and beginning an aggressive campaign to warn heroin addicts of the danger.

title: Move Against Lanston Deal
description: House Banking committee members say they intend to introduce legislation in the new Congress delaying a Japanese bank's purchase of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a United States Government bond dealer, until Japan takes more steps to open its financial markets to Americans.

title: O'Neill Responds to Reagan, Saying Truth Is a 'Casualty'
description: The retiring House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., today sharply responded to President Reagan's attacks on him by saying, ''The truth is a frequent casualty in the heat of an election campaign.''

title: SOME ANALYSTS STILL CAUTIOUS
description: The nation's trade deficit, one of the most politically sensitive economic indicators, narrowed in September for the second straight month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Zale Studies Bid
description: The Zale Corporation said in a terse statement that it was reviewing an unsolicited $50-a-share cash offer from Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto and Swarovski International Holding of Zurich.

title: FILM: 'DUST,' COETZEE'S AFRICA
description: J. M. COETZEE'S ''In the Heart of the Country'' (published here as ''From the Heart of the Country'') is written as a diary, in the fierce, scathing, half-mad voice of a woman living in near-isolation on a South African sheep farm. With its startling clarity and its paradoxically hallucinatory style, this brief 1977 novel would seem to be well out of any film maker's reach.

title: MINIATURE PUMPKINS FOR SHOW
description: The miniature pumpkins now at florist shops and produce markets are actually gourds, grown strictly for ornament. ''They're very popular,'' said Alan Boehmer, a partner at Madderlake, a Manhattan florist.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The American Jazz Orchestra, Cooper Union, Third Avenue at Eighth Street (254-6374). This newly organized jazz repertory ensemble, which made its debut last May, will start its first full season of four concerts tonight with a program of arrangements written for Benny Goodman's orchestra by Fletcher Henderson, Edgar Sampson, Eddie Sauter, Mel Powell and others. The clarinetist Walt Levinsky will be featured in such classic Goodman arrangements as ''King Porter Stomp,'' ''Don't Be That Way,'' ''Benny Rides Again,'' ''The Earl,'' ''Clarinet a la King'' and ''Down South Camp Meeting.'' John Hammond, who helped Mr. Goodman organize his orchestra, will offer some recollections of the days in the mid-1930's when Mr. Goodman's band launched the Swing Era. The program will also include the first work written specifically for the American Jazz Orchestra - a clarinet concerto composed by Bob Brookmeyer and commissioned by Broadcast Music Inc. Tickets for tonight's concert at 8 are $12 at the box office.

title: Infant Is Fatally Raped
description: A two-month Brooklyn girl was pronounced dead on arrival yesterday at Kings County Hospital, the victim of a rapist, the police said. The infant, Chanell Hurley of 195 East 51st Street in the East Flatbush section, was brought to the hospital by her father, Edward Hurley, 20, who was arrested last night and charged with her murder, the police said. At 11 A.M., the infant was left in the care of her father, who is unemployed, by her mother, Karen Hurley, 20, and when the mother returned to their apartment at 4:24 P.M., she learned that the father had taken the baby to the hospital, the police said.

title: RATES FALL ON JAPAN SPECULATION
description: Expectations of lower interest rates in Japan spurred the Treasury securities market to higher prices and lower interest rates in active trading yesterday.

title: BARD COLLEGE TO EXHIBIT PHILIP EVERGOOD WORKS
description: An exhibition of more than 100 paintings by Philip Evergood will open at Bard College Art Gallery tomorrow at 3 P.M. with a reception and symposium on his work. Mr. Evergood, who died in 1973, was a Social Realist painter.

title: Tokyo Stocks in Record Rise
description: Share prices closed in Tokyo today with a record one-day gain amid expectations that the Bank of Japan will soon cut its discount lending rate by a half point, to 3 percent, brokers said.

title: Huron and Michigan Rise To Peak for the Century
description: Lakes Michigan and Huron continued their unseasonal climb this month, reaching their highest level on record and increasing fears that autumn winds could cause grave damage.

title: If This Is Friday, It Must Be A Musicale Day
description: No one knows why a group of Georgetown women in 1886 decided to hold their musicales on Friday mornings.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Doctor Says Emigre Has Cancer of the Lung
description: David Goldfarb, a Soviet emigre who was flown to the United States in a private jet this month, has been diagnosed as having lung cancer.

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company said the latest quarter and first half results include Addressograph Farrington Inc. which was acquired Aug. 25, 1986. The year-ago results are adjusted to reflect the acquisition of Credit Card Sentinel Inc. which was accounted for as a pooling-of-interests.

title: A Sheik Departs; the Noose Remains
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, OPEC's most influential voice and the mastermind of the oil embargo of 1973, has been dumped by Saudi Arabia's ruling family. It's not known whether the suave, Harvard-trained lawyer was canned for policy differences, or simply lost a power contest. But it's likely that the impact on world oil will be transitory. A change of oil ministers will not alter the forces that drive the market or the policy dilemmas they create for both producers and consumers.

title: BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $676,000 and a loss of $5 million on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Pacific Emergency Lifted
description: France lifted an emergency decree today on the tiny South Pacific islands of Wallis and Futuna, a day after it was ordered to head off opposition by tribal leaders to a transfer of Government officials. The senior administrator of the French territory, Jacques Le Henaff, called the state of emergency Wednesday and dispatched the police when tribal leaders complained about the transfer of eight government bureaucrats from the islands.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $1,406,000 from the sale of leases.

title: IN BROOKLYN AND QUEENS, EXAMPLES OF EXCELLENCE
description: One school has 260 pupils and is on a curving street of quaint shops in Queens. The other school has 1,282 pupils and is next to a burned-out shell on a street in Brooklyn where a discarded hypodermic needle lay yesterday amid the curbside rubble.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADULTS MOVE IN ON HALLOWEEN
description: Being frightened and being frightening has become big business.

title: FOSTER, L B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest quarter it posted a $2.5 million charge for amortization expense of certain intangible assets acquired from Kidde Inc.

title: Of Original Copies and Original Originals
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Chief of Celeron To Join Entex Inc.
description: When Gale L. Galloway left as head of the Celeron Corporation earlier this month, he said he was retiring early to pursue personal business interests. But yesterday he signed on as president of Entex Inc., a Houston natural gas distributor that is having its problems.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $395,000 and $2,032,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month results includes a $73.1 million charge from a writedown of assets and restructuring costs.

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $350,000 and $936,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $1,711,000 for the quarter and $4,300,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $231,000 for the quarter and $1,003,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dollar Up After Surprise On Trade Deficit Figure
description: The dollar rebounded yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that the nation's merchandise trade deficit for September was $12.5 billion, well below most estimates.

title: PARENTS' PICTURE IN MANES'S BOX
description: A safe-deposit box used by the late Donald R. Manes was opened yesterday in the presence of F.B.I. agents and state tax officials, who found old insurance policies and a picture of Mr. Manes's parents.

title: Rules Altered On Specialists
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved rules to allow large brokerage firms to operate as specialists on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange.

title: DETROIT 'QUIETER' AS CURFEW GOES ON
description: The police, seeking to hold down what has become a surge of arson surrounding Halloween, arrested more than 250 juveniles Thursday night and early today as they enforced a second dusk-to-dawn curfew. There were 246 arrests on the first night of the curfew.

title: Battle for the Senate
description: No wonder President Reagan is racing around the country, doing his formidable best for endangered Republican senators. As the 1986 campaign takes its last gasps, the struggle for the United States Senate appears to be almost a dead heat, with Democrats within reach of the four additional seats they need for control.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $4,231,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $1,112,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes income from discontinued operations of $3,699,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $35,274,000 and $34,980,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net loss The 1985 results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: 2 RESISTING EVICTION BY RELIGIOUS SECT ARE SHOT TO DEATH IN FLORIDA
description: Two men who resisted eviction by a militant religious sect were shot to death today outside an apartment complex the sect had just bought and a sect member was charged in one of the slayings, the authorities said.

title: BIRTH ADVICE IN SCHOOLS CONDEMNED BY BENNETT
description: The United States Secretary of Education charged yesterday that the New York City Board of Education had made a ''bad decision'' in offering birth-control counseling in nine high school health clinics.

title: Angry Vow by Clemens
description: The Boston Red Sox pitcher Roger Clemens, angry about the behavior of fans and security guards at Shea Stadium, said he would not return there for an exhibition game with the Mets scheduled next April or May. The Red Sox ''can dock me one day's pay,'' Clemens said.

title: Southern Bell
description: The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company is offering $300 million of 8 3/4 percent debentures due in 2024 at price of 96.875 to yield 9.042 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The 38-year debentures are not refundable for five years and are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.

title: Yale to Divest Some Holdings
description: The Yale University Corporation, the school's governing body, has voted to divest itself of stock in companies operating in South Africa that do not subscribe to the Sullivan Principles, the president of Yale, Benno C. Schmidt, said yesterday.

title: WALDHEIM DENYING BLACKMAIL BY SOVIET IN THE POSTWAR DAYS
description: President Kurt Waldheim denied a published report today that he had ever been blackmailed by the Soviet Union or any other nation to become a Communist agent.

title: 3 YANKS JOINS FREE-AGENT LIST
description: Three Yankees, including one who didn't play this year, opted for free agency yesterday, and Ray Knight, the most valuable player in the World Series, said he would join them today.

title: WAY IS CLEARED FOR DE CASTELLA TO RUN
description: The negotiations, said Fred Lebow, were long and arduous, lasting well into the night. At least he did not call it a marathon session. In any event, the issue of sponsorship conflict involving the New York City Marathon and its star attraction, Rob de Castella, was resolved. Thus, de Castella will make his first run across the Verrazano Narrows Bridge on Sunday morning as scheduled. Was there really any doubt? Lebow, the race director, does have a flair for the dramatic. He insinuated on Wednesday that he might not permit the 29-year-old Australian to run if the sponsorship issue involving de Castella's contract with Mazda and the New York City Marathon's promotional ties with Mercedes-Benz was not resolved. It was an embarrassing situation for Lebow, as well as a revealing look into how far long-distance running has come in the sports business world.

title: MINSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,684,000 for the quarter and $13,762,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge of $7,986,000 from the extinguishment of certain notes. c-After income from discontinued operations of $655,000 for the quarter and $615,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $7,375,000 from the termination of a pension plan, for the quarter and 9 months. Results for 1985 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 20 about a company that designs mountains for skiing misidentified key legislation that contributed to the rise of master plans for large ski areas. The law was the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969.

title: INSIDE
description: City Contractors to Testify Prosecutors said executives of New York's top debt-collection agency would testify under immunity in the municipal corruption trial.

title: Campeau Can Buy Allied Shares
description: Federal Judge Pierre N. Leval allowed the Campeau Corporation to buy 48 percent of the common stock of the Allied Stores Corporation but ruled that the Canadian developer cannot vote the shares until litigation is resolved.

title: MDC HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUERTO RICO NOT CONSULTED ON CONTRA BASES
description: The Governor of Puerto Rico said yesterday that the Federal Government had not consulted him about a proposal to train Nicaraguan rebels in the Caribbean commonwealth, and he warned that any such program would create significant political problems on the island.

title: Polling the Aides
description: Proximity breeds respect. A survey by mail of senior Congressional staff aides this month showed them rating both Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Democratic Ways and Means chairman, and Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, above President Reagan as effective leaders.

title: ABEL MEEROPOL, 83, A SONGWRITER, DIES
description: Abel Meeropol, a songwriter and composer who adopted the sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, died of pnuemonia yesterday at the Jewish Nursing Home in Longmeadow, Mass. He was 83 years old and had lived in South Miami, Fla., before entering the nursing home.

title: Between Deals, Two Experts Found Time for a Wedding
description: Many bridge experts find it hard to combine energetic playing careers with full-time occupations, not to mention other significant activities.

title: BATTLE MOUNTAIN GOLD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ST PAUL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $6,749,000 and $10,408,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $30,041,000 and $41,137,000 for the same periods. c-Net loss d-Includes realized capital gains of $12,187,000 and $36,059,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
10 WRITERS WIN AWARD OF $25,000
description: Hayden Carruth, the poet, and August Wilson, who wrote the award-winning play ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' were among 10 people named winners of the Whiting Writers' Awards yesterday. The 10 Whiting winners will all receive tax-free checks for $25,000.

title: ARGENTINA ANGERED BY FALKLANDS MOVE
description: Argentina announced today that in response to a British move to expand its Falkland Island fishing zone by nearly 200 miles it was canceling plans to discharge military conscripts.

title: WEYENBERG SHOE MANUFACURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLITICS GETS PERSONAL IN LOUISIANA'S 8th CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT
description: In the battered studio of radio station KCLF, a tiny AM channel in this little town on an old coil of the Mississippi River, Clyde Holloway, a conservative white nurseryman who is the Republican candidate for Louisiana's Eighth Congressional District, was taping an interview this afternoon to be broadcast to the 25,000 people who live within the reach of the station's signal. He was talking about sex, race, murder and patriotism or the lack of it.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said an accounting adjustment increased the latest third quarter net by $1.5 million and year net by $5.7 million.

title: Iraq Reports 14 Dead In Iranian Raid on Basra
description: Iraq said 14 people were killed and 66 wounded today when Iran bombed the port of Basra in retaliation for two days of Iraqi attacks on an Iranian refinery city that left 32 people dead.

title: Article 285986 -- No Title
description: Capping weeks of speculation that fueled a sharp rise in stock prices, a partnership formed by AFG Industries and Wagner & Brown said last night that it had offered to buy Lear Siegler Inc. for $85 a share in cash, or $1.51 billion.

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Texas Catholic Shelter For Refugees Is Closed
description: A Roman Catholic shelter that has housed 10,000 Central American refugees over four years was closed today.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JET AND DRUG AGENCY HELICOPTER HAVE A CLOSE CALL AT LOS ANGELES
description: The crew of a United Airlines Boeing 727 jet reported a near-collision with a Government helicopter Wednesday as the jet turned to land at Los Angeles International Airport, officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. UNVEILS PLAN TO CURB MARIJUANA BOOM IN NATION'S FORESTS
description: The Forest Service today made public a plan to crack down on the widespread and rapidly expanding practice of growing marijuana in the National Forests.

title: Nets Send O'Koren to Bullets for Wood
description: The Nets, who go into tonight's season opener lacking backcourt and scoring experience because three free agents are still unsigned, obtained both a streak shooter and backup point guard yesterday when they acquired Leon Wood from the Washington Bullets in a trade for Michael O'Koren.

title: A Way to Break The Welfare Cycle
description: The White House commission that is developing recommendations for welfare reform for submission by early next year ought to depart from previous approaches. The reason is simple: today's causes of poverty are different from what the nation has known and successfully dealt with in the past.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $600,000 and $1,200,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and also includes a gain of $12,563,000 related to the termination of a pension plan, as well as a $3 million charge, also related to the pension plan. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,360,000 for both the quarter and 9 months and also includes a gain of $4,845,000 from the sale of real estate for both periods.

title: DEVILS WINNERS IN OVERTIME, 7-6
description: Standing ovations have been a rarity for the Devils in their four seasons in New Jersey, but they drew one tonight from their fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CLASHES ON HONDURAN BORDER
description: Continuing clashes between United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels and Sandinista soldiers inside Honduras cut off public transportation to a sealed-off border area, a senior Honduran military commander said today.

title: MERITOR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $9,603,000 for the quarter and $23,436,000 for the 9 months. The quarter also included a gain of $9.3 million from settlement of pension plan obligations. c-After tax credits of $7,992,000 for the quarter and $34,883,000 for the 9 months.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN Roland Joffe embarked on his latest film, ''The Mission,'' which opens today (review on page C13), he needed about 300 extras to play the trusting South American Indians who become pawns in a European battle for power and influence. The director found what he was looking for in the Choco department of Colombia, and the result ''was like the coming together of two tribes - the film tribe and the Indian tribe,'' Mr. Joffe said. ''We both needed each other.''

title: College Network Signs Agreement With Pepsi
description: The College Satellite Network and Pepsi-Cola USA have signed a long-term agreement under which Pepsi will be the sole sponsor of CSN's live satellite concert series and participating sponsor of its educational programs.

title: POLITICS OF POLITE DEBATE: O'ROURKE'S SHY CRITICISM AIDS CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo, in the only debate of the gubernatorial campaign, avoided making a commitment yesterday on several politically sensitive issues, among them taxes and a revision of rent-stabilization laws. At the same time, his

title: To Catch a Few Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the University of Rochester's decision to rename its graduate business school for William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, misidentified a donor to the endowment fund. It was the John M. Olin Foundation of New York, which is not related to the Olin Foundation, also of New York.

title: RECORDER PROGRAM
description: Marion Verbruggen will play a program of recorder works from the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries at Corpus Christi Church Sunday afternoon at 4, as part of the church's Music Before 1800 series. Admission is $8; $5 for students and the elderly. Corpus Christi Church is at 529 West 121st Street; information 666-0675.

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Attractions All Around Times Square
description: TUCKED away in the large tract that is Times Square and its surrounding theater district are little pleasures awaiting visitors drawn to it by the stage, by its legendary and flamboyant spectacle of lights, and by the worldwide reputation its effusive partisans have accorded it as crossroads of the world.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. NETS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.; WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) WASHINGTON BULLETS VS.

title: RAMADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $2,491,000 and $3,414,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: TDK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The amounts shown in U.S. dollars have been converted from yen at the rate of U.S. to 156 yen.

title: POLL FINDS ANGER ON OFFICIAL LIES
description: Americans think their Government often lies and they do not like it, a New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: ART: DRAWINGS BY ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG, 1958-68
description: THE 61 drawings by Robert Rauschenberg in the large and important exhibition at Acquavella Contemporary Art, 18 East 79th Street, cover 1958 to 1968, the years when the artist, who had already changed the look of painting and sculpture, made his indelible mark on drawing.

title: CONSOLIDATED BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $3 million charge related to the closing of a U.S. glass container plant for the quarter and special charges of $50.5 million for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $7.1 million on the sale of an investment for both the quarter and 9 months. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Imperial Chemical Up
description: Imperial Chemical Industries said today its third-quarter profit jumped 48 percent, to $223 million, or $1.37 per American Depositary Receipt, up from $151 million, or 93 cents per A.D.R., a year earlier.

title: OIL MARKETS RESPOND WITH RALLY
description: Saudi Arabia's acting oil minister, Hisham Nazer, called today for an urgent meeting of OPEC's three-member price committee only hours after he had succeeded Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani.

title: PUMPKINS, PAGEANTS AND OTHER TREATS
description: HALLOWEEN, in the words of one aficionado, is the last chance to ''express your wildest imagination before shutting in for winter.''

title: STAGE: CAROLINE KAVA'S 'EARLY GIRL,' AT CIRCLE REP
description: IN her pungent new play, ''The Early Girl,'' Caroline Kava probes beneath the decadent surface of prostitution and, with admirable candor and a lack of sentimentality, offers pertinent commentary on the pursuit of the profit motive. ''The Early Girl'' opened last night at the Circle Repertory Company.

title: POLL FINDS VOTERS DISCOUNT VIEW ELECTION IS REEFERENDUM ON REAGAN
description: Despite President Reagan's intense schedule of campaigning and his near-record level of popularity, voters still see next Tuesday's elections as contests among individuals and not as a referendum on the President, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: UPSTATE COMMUNITY MOURNS YOUNG CRASH VICTIMS
description: Hillside Lake, a close-knit, working- class neighborhood in this Dutchess County town, had hardly recovered from the automobile death last August of Bea Parisella's 16-year-old son when three more of its young people - and a fourth from a nearby community - were killed in a car accident on the same dark winding road.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,874,000 for the quarter and $4,694,000 for the 9 months. Corrected from Saturday, Oct. 25, editions.

title: WAYS OF REDUCING TOXIC WASTE CITED
description: A study released by the Environmental Protection Agency today indicates that American industries could reduce by at least a third the amount of hazardous wastes they produce.

title: Indian Group Seizes Tribal Headquarters
description: An armed faction of Kiowa Indians, led by a man who believes he should be tribal chairman, seized control of tribal headquarters today, officials said.

title: Mets Won't Change Plea
description: Dick DeGuerin, a lawyer defending Ron Darling and Tim Teufel against felony charges that the two Mets players assaulted two off-duty police officers during a scuffle in a Houston nightclub July 19, denied again today that he had sought to have the players plead guilty to a lesser charge. ''We have never, never offered to plead guilty; it will not happen,'' said DeGuerin after a court hearing in which the defense sought to discover state evidence in the case, which was set to be heard before a jury Jan. 26 or Feb 2.

title: TRANSWORLD CONTROL IS SOUGHT
description: A group headed by Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Group Inc., has acquired a substantial stake in the Transworld Corporation ''as a step in attempting to obtain control'' of the company.

title: RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for fiscal 1985 first quarter are restated for accounting change and for operations of Elographics Inc., acquired in January 1986 on pooling of interests basis.

title: GAULTIER: FASHION DESIGNED TO PROVOKE
description: When Jean-Paul Gaultier, the self-described ''enfant terrible'' of French fashion, was a small boy in a middle-income suburb of Paris he would sketch the patrons of his grandmother's faith healing and Tarot card salon, not as they were, but as he imagined they should be.

title: CASTLE, A M & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: CHARLES McPHERSON
description: The saxophonist Charles McPherson and his quartet are performing tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Solid as a Rock
description: When it seems that would-be tacklers bounce off Herschel Walker as if they were running into concrete, the reason is that they are, virtually.

title: 'WOMEN ARTISTS' SHOW
description: The National Museum of Women in the Arts has announced that it will open next April 10 with a show entitled ''American Women Artists, 1890-1930.'' It will consist of 110 pieces of art, including paintings by Mary Cassatt and Georgia O'Keefe. The inaugural show will continue until June 14 and then be taken on tour to the Minneapolis Institute of Arts in Hartford, the San Diego Museum of Art and the Meadows Museum and Sculpture Court in Dallas.

title: ANDREW LOPEZ
description: Andrew Lopez, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for United Press International and a Medal of Freedom recipient, died early today of cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: Borg-Warner Stake to Jacobs
description: Irwin L. Jacobs and a holding company that he controls said they had acquired a 6.1 percent stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation.

title: WYSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1985 are restated to reflect the acquisition of Amdek Corp., which was completed on Feb. 26, 1986.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Steve Earle and Jason and the Scorchers, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Two songwriters who promise to revitalize country music - or country-rock, or rock-and-roll - are appearing in successive shows tonight in association with the College Media Journal convention of alternative rock. The early show, at 8:30, presents Steve Earle, who draws on the three-chord basics and populist sentiments of Bruce Springsteen and John Fogerty, but sings with a solid twang. The late show, at 11:30, brings Jason and the Scorchers - honky-tonk's answer to the Sex Pistols - a band that takes traditionalist country storytelling and the songwriter Jason Ringenberg's fondness for Southern myths, then backs it up with full-tilt rock. Opening for each band is Steve Skrovane; tickets are $10.

title: Executive Is Promoted At Wells Rich Greene
description: James G. Aaby, 42, a gift of Auburn, Wash., to Madison Avenue, has been named executive president and creative director of Wells Rich Greene.

ENGLISH CONCERT
description: The English Concert, under the direction of Trevor Pinnock, will open ''Music on Original Instruments'' segment of the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series with a program of Purcell, Corelli Handel and Bach at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8. Tickets are $20; information: 362-1911.
